headline: Oregon Man Convicted in Holiday Bombing Plot
abstract: Mohamed Osman Mohamud was found guilty of pushing a button that turned out to be an F.B.I. decoy device at a Christmas tree lighting ceremony in 2010 in Portland.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A 21-year-old Somali-American arrested here in late 2010 after pushing a cellphone button to trigger what he believed was a huge car bomb — in fact an elaborate and inert F.B.I. decoy device — was convicted on Thursday in Federal District Court of attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction. He faces up to life in prison.

lead_paragraph: Roomy Khan, a central figure in the investigation that led to the conviction of the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam, was sentenced to one year in prison on Thursday for illegally passing inside information and obstructing justice.

headline: Alan Cumming’s ‘Macbeth’ Will Join a Crowd of Solo Stars on Broadway
abstract: With the addition of Alan Cumming in “Macbeth,” there are now four plays opening on Broadway this spring that are essentially solo performances.
lead_paragraph: Broadway producers have always relied on star actors to generate ticket sales for shows, but this spring some stars are the shows, with four plays now on tap that are essentially solo performances. The latest is an avant-garde production of “Macbeth,” with the Tony Award winner Alan Cumming (“Cabaret”) performing most of the characters in the Shakespeare classic; it will begin preview performances on April 7 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater and open on April 21, the producer Ken Davenport announced on Thursday.

headline: Philosopher Kings and Fiscal Cliffs
abstract: Exploiting the public’s confusion about fiscal policy for political advantage is a danger not just to the economy, but to democracy.
lead_paragraph: Plato had a famously dim view of democracy. He regarded politics as a craft, and thought that understanding the essence of a craft is to have expertise. Plato argues that we cannot hope the multitude to achieve expertise in the craft of governing. They are too easily misled by sophists. It followed, for Plato, that democracy must be rejected as a just system of governance. It is “probable that the origins of tyranny are found nowhere else than in the democratic regime.” (“The Republic”). A just system of government must have a philosopher king, who understands the essences of things. Translated into the modern context, Plato’s view is that the only just system of government is one that is run by one or several experts in economics and public policy. The multitude is too easily swayed by propaganda.

headline: Chicago Teen Gun Victim Starred in Antigang Video

lead_paragraph: Four years before Hadiya Pendleton, a 15-year-old honors student, was shot and killed in a Chicago park after school on Tuesday, she had starred in a YouTube video urging fellow students to avoid gangs.

headline: Critics Assail Syrian Opposition Leader’s Offer on Talks
abstract: Battle-hardened fighters and others said Sheik Khatib’s offer to open a dialogue with the government would only embolden President Bashar al-Assad to intensify the civil war.
lead_paragraph: The top opposition leader’s softened position on possible talks with President Bashar al-Assad’s government caused an uproar within the fractious rebel coalition on Thursday as battle-hardened fighters and others said the offer would only embolden Mr. Assad to intensify the civil war. The opposition leader, Sheik Ahmad Moaz al-Khatib, said many critics had not fully read the explanations he had posted Wednesday on his Facebook page. Sheik Khatib’s offer to open a dialogue with the government, which contained several conditions, received a measure of support from Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, and Lakhdar Brahimi, the peace envoy for the Arab League and the United Nations. But the offer to start talks broke a longstanding opposition demand: no talks until Mr. Assad steps down. Sheik Khatib said in his Facebook posting that he would be willing to talk with Mr. Assad’s representatives in Egypt, Tunisia or Turkey, all of which support the Syrian opposition. He also demanded other preconditions, including the release of 160,000 prisoners in Syria. “Nobody has said it is going to be easy,” Mr. Brahimi said. “But perhaps negotiating is better than killing each other.”

headline: Looking for Mister Goodpain
abstract: Where are the austerity successes? Britain? Ireland? Keep looking.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, a terrible thing happened to economic policy, both here and in Europe. Although the worst of the financial crisis was over, economies on both sides of the Atlantic remained deeply depressed, with very high unemployment. Yet the Western world’s policy elite somehow decided en masse that unemployment was no longer a crucial concern, and that reducing budget deficits should be the overriding priority.

headline: Teachers and Policy Makers: Troubling Disconnect

lead_paragraph: Can the school reform movement accept constructive criticism? Gary Rubinstein hopes so. Mr. Rubinstein joined Teach for America in 1991, the program’s second year, and has now been teaching math for 15 years, five of them in some of the nation’s neediest public schools and 10 more at the prestigious Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. He has a bachelor’s degree in math and a master’s in computer science, has written two books on classroom practice and at one point helped train new corps members for Teach for America. For years, he was a proponent of the program, albeit one with the occasional quibble.

headline: Timbuktu Endured Terror Under Harsh Shariah Law
abstract: Shops owned by Arabs have been looted in the city and some residents have fled, a foretaste of ethnic strife that many fear will roil Mali for years.
lead_paragraph: TIMBUKTU, Mali — When the Islamist militants came to town, Dr. Ibrahim Maiga made a reluctant deal. He would do whatever they asked — treat their wounded, heal their fevers, bandage up without complaint the women they thrashed in the street for failing to cover their heads and faces. In return, they would allow him to keep the hospital running as he wished.

headline: Myths About Gun Regulation
abstract: The gun lobby propaganda is convincing lawmakers that the 10-year ban on assault weapons was ineffective.
lead_paragraph: As busy as the gun lobby is in promoting macho myths about self-defense — stand your ground and outshoot the bad guys — it is no less dedicated to spinning myths for lawmakers to use as excuses to avoid enacting laws to deal with the shooting sprees that regularly afflict the nation. This was clear at the opening Senate hearing on gun controls this week, where Judiciary Committee members seemed to have largely swallowed gun lobby propaganda that the evidence shows the original 10-year ban on assault weapons was ineffective.

headline: Treatment, Not Jail, for the Mentally Ill
abstract: In an ideal system, the mentally ill who commit minor offenses and pose no real danger to the public would never see the inside of a jail.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg has started an important new corrections initiative focused on mentally ill offenders, who make up about a third of the city’s jail population and are more likely than other prisoners to resume criminal behavior once they are freed. The aim is to give the courts up-to-date information about a defendant’s record and mental health status so that a judge can decide whether the defendant should be sent to a treatment program instead of jail.

lead_paragraph: LaTroy Hawkins, a 40-year-old right-hander, joined the Mets on a minor league contract, the team said Thursday. The Mets have a number of concerns with their bullpen, particularly after their closer, Frank Francisco, finished a rocky season battling arm problems. They have begun to stockpile arms, giving the left-hander Pedro Feliciano, 36, and the right-hander Scott Atchison, 36, minor league deals. Hawkins pitched for the Angels last season, compiling a 3.64 earned run average.

headline: Louisiana: New Orleans Wants Out of Police Plan
abstract: The City of New Orleans filed a motion in federal court on Thursday night arguing that it should be allowed to withdraw from a federal consent decree to overhaul the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: The City of New Orleans filed a motion in federal court on Thursday night arguing that it should be allowed to withdraw from a federal consent decree to overhaul the Police Department. In the filing, which included more than 1,700 pages of exhibits, lawyers for the city argue that the reform agreement was tainted by ulterior motives and arrived at under misleading circumstances. Mayor Mitch Landrieu had invited in Department of Justice officials to investigate the department in 2010, and celebrated the signing of the consent decree last July. But on Jan. 11, when a federal judge formally approved the document, the mayor made known publicly that the city wanted out, insisting that the costs of police reform combined with the costs of a separate consent decree pertaining to the city jail would do “catastrophic damage” to the city budget.

headline: The Boy With a Thorn in His Joints
keywords: ['Rheumatoid Arthritis, Juvenile', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Intestinal Tract', 'Immune System', 'Gluten', 'ANTIBIOTICS']
abstract: When 3-year-old Shepherd Strauss got sick, his parents turned to doctors and drugs. But they couldn’t anticipate that what would help him feel better didn’t come with a prescription.
lead_paragraph: When my son, Shepherd, was 3 years old, he and his twin brother, Beau, took soccer lessons for the first time. They were so excited that they slept in their uniforms — a purple T-shirt with a yellow star kicking the ball with one of its points — the night before their first practice. But when we got to the field the next day, Shepherd’s enthusiasm evaporated. While Beau and the other kids ran zigzags around the cones, Shepherd stood still and looked bewildered. When it was his turn to kick the ball, he seemed lost. After 15 minutes, he walked off the field and sat down in my lap, saying he was too tired to play. We watched the other kids, and I pointed out to him the drills I thought he might enjoy, the ones that Beau was charging through. But he refused to go back to the field. His passivity didn’t concern me much — he was 3, after all, and I already thought of him, in the way that parents tend to categorize their children even as we tell ourselves we shouldn’t, as a little clingy and not especially athletic. My husband, Darin, and I had recently noticed that Shepherd occasionally walked with a limp, but it was faint enough that sometimes when you looked for it, it was gone. Faint enough — though it seems incredible now — that we didn’t connect it to his reluctance on the field.

abstract: In a phenomenon that could contribute to climate change, the hole in the Antarctic ozone layer has changed the way that waters in the southern oceans mix, scientists report.
lead_paragraph: One of the most sobering realities of climate change is that even if all greenhouse gas emissions  came to an abrupt halt tomorrow, climbing temperatures, rising seas and extreme weather would still be in the global forecast for perhaps hundreds of years because of the carbon dioxide already released into the atmosphere.

headline: Suicide Attack at Market in Northwest Pakistan Kills at Least 21
abstract: The explosion came as Sunni and Shiite villagers in northwestern Pakistan were leaving nearby mosques. The police said it killed at least 21 people and wounded 33.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — An explosion in a market in northwestern Pakistan on Friday killed at least 21 people and wounded 33 in what the police described as a suicide bombing.

lead_paragraph: Political gridlock over fiscal policy didn’t push the economy off a cliff. But it certainly isn’t helping anything, either.

headline: Suicide Blast Kills U.S. Embassy Guard in Turkey
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives']

headline: The Gun Report: February 1, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old student was shot in the head at Price Middle School in Atlanta on Thursday. The student was taken to Grady Memorial Hospital and was said to be alert and conscious. A suspect taken into custody has tentatively been identified as a student, according to police.

headline: The Origins of ‘Big Data': An Etymological Detective Story
abstract: Tracing the origins of the term “Big Data” shows how digital technology is changing the way words and ideas develop and spread, and how they are studied.
lead_paragraph: Words and phrases are fundamental building blocks of language and culture, much as genes and cells are to the biology of life. And words are how we express ideas, so tracing their origin, development and spread is not merely an academic pursuit but a window into a society’s intellectual evolution.

headline: Art in Odd Places, Plus Some Evens, Equals a Numbers-Themed Festival
abstract: Circle Oct. 11 on your calendar.
lead_paragraph: Art in Odd Places, which presents visual and performance art in unexpected public spaces in New York, is inviting proposals for its coming annual festival.

keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']

lead_paragraph: A future stepparent writes in with a quandary — or at least, a request for been-there-done-that advice. I’ve paraphrased the e-mail somewhat to protect anonymity (no details have been changed; only removed):

headline: Bolshoi Ballet Postpones ‘Rite of Spring’ Premiere
abstract: It was not the Bolshoi Theater that announced the cancellation of Wayne McGregor’s new ballet, but Emerging Pictures, the United States distributor for the films of the Bolshoi Ballet and Opera.
lead_paragraph: The Bolshoi Ballet has postponed the late-March premiere of the choreographer Wayne McGregor’s new “Rite of Spring” because of the health of its artistic director, Sergei Filin. Mr. Filin has been in the hospital since Jan. 17 after he was attacked with acid by a masked assailant. Curiously, it was not the Bolshoi Theater that announced the cancellation, but Emerging Pictures, the United States distributor for the films of the Bolshoi Ballet and Opera, which was scheduled to present a screening of Mr. McGregor’s “Rite” on April 21.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Feb. 1
abstract: Times critics on “Warm Bodies,” “John Dies at the End” and “Koch.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics look at the zombie comedy “Warm Bodies,” Don Coscarelli’s “John Dies at the End” and “Koch,” a documentary about the former New York mayor. See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: NPR: To lovers of steak tartare and beef carpaccio: salmonella may be coming for you. — Julia Moskin

headline: British Antiterrorism Official Sentenced in Hacking Scandal
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Newspapers', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: April Casburn, a senior police officer, was sentenced for seeking cash payments from Rupert Murdoch’s News of the World tabloid.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A senior police officer in Scotland Yard’s counterterrorism command was sentenced to a 15-month prison term on Friday for seeking cash payments from Rupert Murdoch’s News of the World tabloid in return for information about a Scotland Yard investigation into phone hacking at the paper.

headline: Viewing the Oscar-Nominated Shorts
abstract: Images from the “Oscar Nominated Shorts 2013″ program.
lead_paragraph: As the Bagger noted this week, this year’s nominees includes the very shortest film ever to be in the running for an Oscar, the animated “Fresh Guacamole,” which clocks in at under two minutes. The Bagger’s colleague, the critic Stephen Holden, took a look at all the nominated shorts (live action, animated and documentary) and reports: “In the movies, at least, the balance between hope and suffering usually tilts decisively toward hope. That is the predominant mood of ‘The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013,’” being released in theaters on Friday. Take a look at the slide show of images from the anthology, above, and read his review here.

headline: Finding Drama in Musicians’ Discord
abstract: The mechanics of classical music get attention in two recent movies, “Quartet” and “A Late Quartet,” about the interaction and work of musicians and singers — with interesting challenges for the actors.
lead_paragraph: THAT A STRING QUARTET has one cello and one viola but two violins complicates things. What makes a particular performer more suited to the first violin part? Or the second? Must a first violinist, of necessity, be the more assertive and flashy player?

headline: Tales of Innocence, and Now Experience
abstract: It’s a homecoming of sorts: Carla Körbes, a Brazilian ballerina who spent seasons with New York City Ballet, is coming to City Center with her current company, Pacific Northwest Ballet.
lead_paragraph: Carla Körbes was just 14 the first time she danced Terpsichore in George Balanchine’s “Apollo.” The performance, at her ballet school in Porto Alegre, Brazil, changed her life. Her partner, flying in from New York City Ballet, happened to be the refined principal dancer Peter Boal.

headline: Masters of Subservience
abstract: In China, “bureaucracy lit” cuts the red tape for the civil-service-minded.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese author Wang Xiaofang learned to write corruption exposés the hard way. His decade as a pen-pushing civil servant culminated in a three-year investigation for corruption while his boss, the deputy mayor of the rust-belt city of Shenyang, was executed for gambling away $3.6 million of public money in Macau’s casinos.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Ian Buruma’s forthcoming book is about the months following the end of World War II.
lead_paragraph: “When I studied Chinese in the early 1970s,” Ian Buruma recalled in a recent e-mail, “there was nothing of literary interest coming from the People’s Republic of China. The language had been strangled into a kind of rigor mortis by the official jargon of propaganda. Then Mao died. And it took some time for Chinese writers to bring their language fully to life again.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE LAST HOLIDAY: A Memoir,  by Gil Scott-Heron. (Grove, $16.) Scott-Heron, the uncompromising poet, novelist and spoken-word recording artist (“The Revolution Will Not Be Televised”), died in May 2011, at 62. His posthumously published memoir, which ends before drug use and a prison sentence sent his life off the rails, is an elegiac culmination to his career and offers deeply personal insights into the civil rights movement.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE INSURGENTS: David Petraeus and the Plot to Change the American Way of War,  by Fred Kaplan. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) An authoritative, gripping and somewhat terrifying account of the United States’ approach to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Selling ‘Midnight’s Children’ in India
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Books and Literature', 'Hinduism', 'Movies', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: The careful, deliberate marketing of the movie, based on the book by Salman Rushdie.
lead_paragraph: “Am I allowed to mention the Rushdie word?” quipped the historian and author Tom Holland at the recently concluded Jaipur Literature Festival. Mr. Holland was speaking of Salman Rushdie’s 1981 novel, “Midnight’s Children,” a book he called a contemporary classic.

headline: Rays of Hope
abstract: George Saunders’s stories offer a close look at life’s dark aspects, but don’t succumb to them.
lead_paragraph: “Writing short stories is very hard work.” That, at any rate, is what George Saunders had to say on the subject some years ago, in an essay about the postmodern master Donald Barthelme, and lest anyone raise a skeptical eyebrow — since by then Saunders had already proved himself to be one of the most gifted, wickedly entertaining story writers around — he continued to wring his hands, revealingly, a few pages later: “The land of the short story,” he fretted, “is a brutal land, a land very similar, in its strictness, to the land of the joke.”

headline: Mexico’s Toll Rises in Blast as Hunt Ends for Survivors
abstract: The explosion at the headquarters of Mexico’s state-owned oil company on Thursday injured at least 121 people, officials said, but they gave no information about the cause.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Hundreds of rescue workers ended their search for survivors on Friday at the site of an explosion that tore through an office building of Mexico’s state-owned oil company a day earlier, as the death toll rose to 33. The head of the company said early indications about the cause suggested that it was an accident.

headline: Scenes From the Arizona Sandbox
abstract: Sheriff Joe Arpaio wants to arm his deputies with military-style assault rifles.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of good people in Arizona who have thoughtful, moderate views about guns and government. This is not about them.

headline: A Rake’s Progress
abstract: Michael Dean’s novel imagines the bawdy, philanthropic life of the painter William Hogarth.
lead_paragraph: Born in 1697, William Hogarth was one of the most influential and fascinating British artists of the 18th century. A painter and satirist, he was known for depicting, as he himself puts it in Michael Dean’s new historical novel, “modern moral subjects.”

headline: Where a Poet’s Vision Lives on in India
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A trip to Shantiniketan, three hours north of Kolkata, is a cultural pilgrimage for Indians thanks to what the Nobel Prize winner Rabindranath Tagore started there in 1901.
lead_paragraph: Great writers often shape our impressions of a place. Steinbeck and Dust Bowl Oklahoma, for instance. Sometimes a writer might even define a place, as Hemingway did for 1920s Paris. Rarely, though, does a writer create a place. Yet that is what the Indian poet and Nobel Prize winner Rabindranath Tagore did with a town called Shantiniketan, or “Abode of Peace.” Without Tagore’s tireless efforts, the place, home to a renowned experimental school, would not exist.

headline: Feb. 3 — 9
abstract: A selection of events this  week.
lead_paragraph: Riffs Inspired By an Aesthetic

headline: In Travel, We’re All Boomers Now
abstract: From backpacking to glamping, the postwar generation has long influenced travel choices. This year it’s truer than ever.
lead_paragraph: Big font. Easy-to-print pages. Luxury hotels that can be sorted by amenities like cooking lessons and connecting suites. If you find yourself enjoying the carefully planned features on Preferredfamily.com, you have the baby boomer generation to thank.

headline: Cleary Gottlieb Partner to Join Prosecutor’s Office as Chief Counsel
abstract: Joon Kim, a partner at Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, is leaving the law firm to join the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan as chief counsel.
lead_paragraph: Joon Kim, a partner at Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, is leaving the law firm to join the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan as chief counsel.

headline: Ed Koch: A Mayor’s Journey
abstract: TimesCast: A look back at the life and legacy of Ed Koch, who ruled New York City for 12 years.
lead_paragraph: TimesCast: A look back at the life and legacy of Ed Koch, who ruled New York City for 12 years.

headline: Starry, Starry, Starry Night
abstract: What city dwellers might see in the absence of light pollution.
lead_paragraph: What city dwellers might see in the absence of light pollution.

headline: The 1.20.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WHICH WAY DID THE TALIBAN GO?

headline: How to Write Yourself Into Existence
abstract: On the next Shakespeare, self-karaoke and art with a visible string to the world
lead_paragraph: There appear to be three distinct phases that most new technologies undergo. At first, the computer was so big and expensive that only national governments had the resources to build and operate one. Only the military and a handful of universities had multiroom-size computers. A little later, large corporations with substantial research budgets, like I.B.M., developed computers. The computer made its way into midsize businesses and schools. Not until the late ’70s and early ’80s did the computer shrink enough in size and price to be widely available to individuals. (Roughly the same pattern has played out with access to mass communication, access to high-quality printing, Humvees, G.P.S., the Web, hand-held wireless communications, etc. )

headline: Should I Become a Woman and Risk Causing Pain to My Wife and Children?
abstract: A father wonders whether to reveal his sexual identity, and the Ethicist has second thoughts on bees.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been living the life of a married man for 20 years. I have a successful career and three children. All this time, however, I have battled gender dysphoria and the deep sadness that comes from living a lie. From the earliest age, I’ve been unhappy being male. I believed I would find happiness only once I was true to myself. I recently had my self-diagnosis confirmed, and I’m initiating a transition to living as the real me. There is a cost involved: pain to my family and stress on my career. Ethically, is it right to be “true to myself” even if that authenticity ends my otherwise happy marriage and damages the emotional stability of my three children? If I had to maintain the lie, the emotional cost would be tremendous; a transition would share the pain with all who love me but might result in happiness. What’s the ethically correct thing to do? NAME WITHHELD, MASSACHUSETTS

headline: A War Zone I Can’t Escape
abstract: My stepson’s battle was virtual. But the one I experienced was real.
lead_paragraph: As soon as “Call of Duty: Black Ops 2” came out last year, my stepson, like virtually every male teenager on the planet, rushed out to buy his copy. Mercifully, he uses headphones when playing that game, sparing us — well, me — from the prickly memories that its sound produces. But that wasn’t the case five years ago when he became the proud owner of “Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare.” For days our apartment reverberated with the deafening sound of gunfire. One Sunday, I looked at the screen and saw a destroyed streetscape with Arabic writing everywhere. The mangled city that his character was roaming through looked eerily similar to the war-ravaged Beirut of my childhood.

headline: Michelle Rhee Gets an Education
abstract: The ex-chancellor of Washington schools on what she has learned and why her kids don’t have to get A’s.
lead_paragraph: In your new book, “Radical,” you recount that while growing up in a Korean-American household in Toledo, if your brother brought home a bad grade, your mother would ground you, not him. Can you explain her thinking?  My mother is a very traditional Korean mom. I grew up with clear roles as the girl of the family, and one of them was being responsible for my brothers and specifically to make sure my younger brother was doing well in school. Korean culture is very lenient on boys.

headline: Son’s Suicide Leads to Aid for Students
abstract: Tyler Clementi’s parents and Rutgers officials will work together through a new center that will focus on students making the transition to college.
lead_paragraph: Jane and Joe Clementi once considered suing Rutgers University. Their son Tyler, a freshman, had discovered that his roommate used a webcam to spy on him having sex with another man and had jumped off the George Washington Bridge a few days later, setting off wide debate about cyberbullying and the struggles of gays and lesbians coming of age.

headline: Shares of Zoetis Surge on Debut
abstract: Shares of the Pfizer animal health spinoff — the biggest initial public offering in the United States since Facebook’s last spring — make an impressive market entrance.
lead_paragraph: 4:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: Long Before the Brooklyn Nets, There Were the Black Fives
abstract: With a new book, Claude Johnson, a former director of international licensing for the N.B.A., is determined to lift all-black club basketball teams out of obscurity.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, the National Basketball Association published an encyclopedic history — 800 pages about the players and the teams. Claude Johnson, who was the league’s director of international licensing at the time, leafed through it and found only two and a half pages devoted to the all-black teams that had predated the N.B.A.

headline: Culture Thrives in a Former Madrid Slaughterhouse
abstract: Matadero Madrid has transformed a space built for butchery a century ago into a center for music, design and film.
lead_paragraph: The center of life in Madrid has long focused on the grand boulevards of Salamanca, the winding historic streets around Plaza Mayor and the cool alleyways of Malasaña, Chueca and La Latína. But city planners have in recent years nudged Madrileños and tourists toward the outer barrios of the city through Madrid Rio, an ambitious project that moved the unsightly highway that rings the city underground and replaced it with a ribbon of parkland alongside the all but forgotten city river.

headline: G.M. Recalling 12,800 Vehicles for Suspension and Air Bag Problems
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The suspension problem, which could make the vehicles difficult to control, covers about 8,500 2013 Chevrolet Malibus.
lead_paragraph: In two actions General Motors is recalling about 12,800 vehicles because of a rear suspension problem or a possible air bag malfunction, according to reports the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: A New Web Site Warns Small-Business Owners of Coming Regulations
abstract: A spokesman for the House Small Business Committee, which created Small Business Reg Watch, said the panel had no political purpose in mind for the Web site.
lead_paragraph: Long concerned that small businesses are over-regulated by the federal government, Republicans in Congress have enlisted business owners to make that case directly to the rule makers.

headline: Game Day Coverage at a Glance
abstract: The Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers will end two weeks of hype when they meet on the Superdome field on Sunday to decide the winner of Super Bowl XLVII, and The Times will offer comprehensive coverage.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers will end two weeks of hype when they meet in the Superdome on Sunday to decide the winner of Super Bowl XLVII. Visit nytimes.com for comprehensive coverage, including:

headline: Common Core Practice | Deadly Showers, Killer Cats and Children’s Lit
abstract: This week: narrative writing about a children’s book award; informative writing about daily routines and their potential risks; and argumentative writing about cats and their surprisingly deadly habits.
lead_paragraph: The teachers we collaborate with for this feature might have made some macabre choices this week, but, as always, only in the service of learning.

headline: Leading Off: Breaking From the Super Bowl Script
abstract: Players are usually fairly dull during the week before the Super Bowl. But Chris Culliver? Joe Flacco? Randy Moss? Their remarks started a lot of animated conversations.
lead_paragraph: Normally by this point in Super Bowl week, the players have succeeded in turning their big media stage into a big nap. They employ the time-tested strategy of saying absolutely nothing interesting, and doing so repeatedly. This is why fringe reporters have to show up at media day in funny hats, just to keep everyone from dozing off.

headline: A Cry of Frustration at Delhi’s Sustainable Summit
abstract: Another international conference underscores the lack of concerted policy action on climate change.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – Once more, frustration with stymied efforts on climate change has emerged as a major theme at an international conference on the planet’s health. Opening the 13th annual Delhi Sustainable Development Summit conference this week, India’s prime minister noted that similar sentiments surfaced last year at the United Nations Rio+20 meeting, which marked the two-decade anniversary of a landmark Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Architectural League Names Winners of Emerging Voices Competition
abstract: The awards honor individuals and firms who have distinguished themselves in architecture, landscape design and urbanism.
lead_paragraph: Eight designers have been selected by the Architectural League of New York as the winners of its annual juried Emerging Voices competition. The awards highlight individuals and firms who have distinguished themselves in architecture, landscape design and urbanism.

headline: The Operatic Walt Disney, Delivered by Philip Glass
abstract: Philip Glass’s opera “The Perfect American,” based on the novel of that title, is an account of Walt Disney’s life, as told from a Disney animator’s point of view.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Peter Stephan Jungk’s novel “The Perfect American” is a surreal, meditative, episodic account of the last days of Walt Disney.

headline: Remembering Ed Koch
abstract: From all around, remembrances of the man, his deeds and his words.
lead_paragraph: With the death on Friday of Edward I. Koch , the “little Jewish kid from the Bronx” who grew up to govern New York City through 12 of its most memorably turbulent years, remembrances of the man, his deeds, his words and his 88 years flowed in from all over the world in every possible form.

headline: Alec Soth’s Great Plains Dispatch
abstract: Alec Soth discusses his method behind his photographs documenting the oil boom in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s cover story about the oil boom in North Dakota, we asked Alec Soth, known for his photographic road trips, to drive from his home in Minnesota to northwestern North Dakota last fall and document life there. Recently he answered a few questions about the project via e-mail.

headline: Video Shows Aftermath of U.S. Embassy Bombing in Turkey
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Video broadcast on Turkish television showed the aftermath of a suicide bombing at the American Embassy in Ankara on Friday that killed a Turkish security guard.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:46 p.m. As my colleagues Sebnem Arsu and Rick Gladstone report, a suicide bomber attacked the American Embassy in the Turkish capital Ankara on Friday, in a blast that officials said killed at least one Turkish citizen and wounded another at a side entrance to the compound.

headline: A Light to Read By
abstract: Ali Smith weaves fact and fiction in these interconnected essays, whose narrator is haunted — literally — by a former lover.
lead_paragraph: “Clever” and “inventive.” Are these the two readiest adjectives that spring to mind when describing the fiction of Ali Smith? Certainly they are common responses to her work. But as understandable as this may be, I hope to convince you that neither word is quite right. One damns her with faint praise, while the other misapprehends what she actually does.

headline: Capital One Picks Banker as Its Chief of Finance
abstract: Capital One Financial has hired Stephen S. Crawford, a top executive of the boutique investment bank Centerview Partners, as its chief financial officer.
lead_paragraph: Capital One Financial said on Friday that it had hired Stephen S. Crawford, a co-founder of the boutique investment bank Centerview Partners, as its chief financial officer.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Christoph Irmscher discusses the life of the scientist Louis Agassiz; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Timothy Naftali talks about Richard Nixon; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Christoph Irmscher discusses the life of the scientist Louis Agassiz; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Timothy Naftali talks about Richard Nixon; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Living Reefs, Under Fire
abstract: Our expedition’s goal for the day was to visit the best and the worst coral reefs near Biak, Papua.
lead_paragraph: Drew Harvell is associate director for environment at the Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future at Cornell University. She is studying the health of coral reefs and marine ecosystems in Indonesia.

headline: A Simple Way to Invest Grows More Complicated
abstract: Twenty years after the first exchange-traded fund was created, new variations are adding complexity to an investment vehicle that has been promoted as being simple.
lead_paragraph: THIS week was the 20th anniversary of the creation of the first exchange-traded fund, the Standard & Poor’s Depositary Receipts E.T.F., which tracks the performance of the S.& P. 500 index and is bought and sold like a single stock. Even now, what is known as the SPDR S.& P. 500 remains the largest, with nearly $130 billion in assets.

headline: Full Text of the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking on Women’s Preventive Services Coverage
abstract: The following is the full text of the notice of proposed rulemaking allowing some religious institutions to opt out of the contraceptive coverage regulations.
lead_paragraph: The following is the full text of the notice of proposed rulemaking allowing some religious institutions to opt out of the contraceptive coverage regulations.

headline: Like a Country Song You Keep Humming
abstract: The couple dated in high school but had not forgotten each other.
lead_paragraph: Country music has evolved, said the songwriter and singer Buffy Lawson, from “lost my dog, lost my truck, lost my woman.” Still, once love is lost it usually stays that way.

headline: New Yorkers Remember a Mayor
abstract: New Yorkers react to the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers react to the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch.

headline: ‘30 Rock’ Gets a Ratings Bounce for Series Finale
abstract: The hourlong finale drew an audience of 4.8 million viewers, its best performance in two years.
lead_paragraph: The finale of NBC’s much-honored comedy “30 Rock” showed a bit of a bounce against extremely tough competition Thursday night, rising 26 percent from its previous week to a level it had not reached in two years.

headline: Finding Transcendence in the Living and Dead
abstract: Jim James, My Morning Jacket’s frontman, draws inspiration from meditation and musicians like Gil Scott-Heron, Roy Ayers and Lula Collins.
lead_paragraph: THE MUSICIAN JIM JAMES lives in Louisville, Ky., a city that he says defies expectations.

headline: Conceived by Students, a Portfolio That Pays
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Many investors are trying to figure out how to generate income in a time of low interest rates. Some Duke undergraduates think they have the answer.
lead_paragraph: Squeezed by historically low interest rates, a wide range of investors — from retirees living on fixed incomes to huge endowments and pension funds trying to meet budgets — are trying to figure out how to generate income.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The former Red Sox manager Terry Francona is at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list with a scorched-earth memoir taking aim at the team owners who showed him the door.
lead_paragraph: HARDBALL: Terry Francona, who coached the Red Sox to two World Series titles before his departure in 2011, has made news lately thanks to the scorched-earth memoir he’s written with the Boston Globe columnist Dan Shaughnessy, “Francona: The Red Sox Years.” The book — it’s new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 2 — touches fleetingly on steroid use, sabermetrics and Michael Jordan’s stint in the minor leagues (where Francona was his manager), but it saves its heaviest artillery for the owners who elected not to renew Francona’s contract, leaving him to figure out for himself that they were done with him: “When people ask me if I left the Red Sox on my own or if I was fired, I don’t even know how to answer that,” he says.

headline: Basketball Machine
abstract: A once-beloved Kentucky high school team fights to regain glory.
lead_paragraph: The marvel of Keith O’Brien’s first book — a chronicle of a high school basketball season in Kentucky — is that the basketball scenes are not especially strong, occasionally sinking into clunkiness, and it doesn’t matter one bit. Like a jump shooter with shaky form who still finds a way to dominate, O’Brien weaves such rich detail into his narrative that one feels petty for even bringing this up.

headline: Next Stop
abstract: A fresh look at the story of America’s industrial development.
lead_paragraph: In 1886, according to Charles R. Morris in “The Dawn of Innovation: The First American Industrial Revolution,” “Bloomingdale’s catalog — 160 pages, stuffed with some 1,700 products, from ladies’ corsets to pistols — advised its clients to send a follow-up inquiry if they had not received an order confirmation within 10 days after they had posted it, but to allow 15 days if they lived on the Pacific Coast.” The variety of goods offered by Bloomingdale’s and also the ease of ordering and transporting them were results of a century of rapid development of the country’s factories, canals, railroads and telegraph lines.

headline: Conceiving ‘Frankenstein’
abstract: Grave robbers, ghoulish experiments and the Romantic age: Roseanne Montillo traces the origins of Mary Shelley’s masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: The laboratory was dark that November evening. The young scientist watched the still body on the table, peering through shadows thrown by flickering candlelight. And then, through the gloom, he “saw the dull yellow eye of the creature open” and its limbs begin to twitch.

headline: Breaking New Ground
abstract: An idiosyncratic English church is the starting point for Jenny Uglow’s biography of the Victorian architect and heiress Sarah Losh.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1982, when Jennifer S. Uglow issued her ambitious “International Dictionary of Women’s Biography,” aiming to satisfy “a desire to look at women’s strength in action, rather than (as is so often done) to lament their oppression as passive victims,” the 19th-­century Cumbrian architect Sarah Losh, with little more than a country church, a schoolhouse and a sexton’s cottage to her credit, didn’t make the cut. Nor did Losh answer Uglow’s “request for heroines” by the time a third edition of the dictionary appeared, published in the United States in 1999 as “The Northeastern Dictionary of Women’s Biography.” There, if she’d qualified, Losh would have shared a page with the “American feminist poet” Audre Lorde, the “Italian actress” Sophia Loren, the “Spanish soprano” Victoria de los Angeles and the “English trade unionist” Dame Anne Loughlin. In 1999, not even the California architect Julia Morgan, with numerous commissions for public buildings and her splendid Hearst Castle at San Simeon, qualified.

headline: He Was a Camera
abstract: The final volume of Christopher Isherwood’s diaries.
lead_paragraph: There is a deliriously weird moment, close to the start of this new and final volume of Christopher Isherwood’s diaries, when Isherwood is in London in April 1970 and is visited by a young admirer. “Have just seen Christopher Isherwood off,” Isherwood writes. “He’s a disc jockey from Bristol who wrote me several times.” The diarist Isherwood notes this other Isherwood’s “Beatle haircut” and “sort of egocentricity which seems quite attractive and wholesome,” and also that he’s been driven there that day by another youth: “Christopher Isherwood said of him, ‘I’m his idol.’ ”

headline: Gulf War
abstract: Describing a life caught between Seattle and Qatar.
lead_paragraph: The neon skyline of the Gulf Arab states encroaching on the Arabian Desert forms the preternatural backdrop to Sophia Al-Maria’s memoir, “The Girl Who Fell to Earth.” Born to an American mother from Puyallup, near Seattle, and to a Bedouin Qatari father, Al-Maria spent her childhood shuttling between the “soggy blades of grass” of the Pacific Northwest and “the pockmarked moonscape of construction pits and cranes” in the Qatari capital of Doha.

headline: Send Word
abstract: Joan Wickersham explores relationships in her collection.
lead_paragraph: “A love story,” one of Joan Wickersham’s narrators insists, “can never be accurately reported, only imagined. It is all dreams and invention.”

headline: Mother Galaxy
abstract: In her poetry, Brenda Shaughnessy imagines a world without a child’s pain.
lead_paragraph: When Brenda Shaughnessy’s first collection of poems, “Interior With Sudden Joy,” was published in 1999, I was among the many readers dazzled by Shaughnessy’s snazzy syntax and inaugurating mind. Here was a book that was funny, smart, playful, the feminine present and unapologetically intellectual and erotic. But, finally, impressive as it was, that first collection didn’t do for me what Dickinson claimed great poetry should — make me feel that the top of my head was taken off. In bold and moving contrast, Shaughnessy’s emotionally charged and gorgeously composed third volume of poems, “Our Andromeda,” moves me line by line and poem by poem so that by the book’s final, monumental title poem, I am top-of-the-head-blown-off undone. In “Our Andromeda” Shaughnessy has brought to bear her inevitable syntactic and sonic hula-hooping, her playful and ironic uses of form, her vivid mind on poems that absolutely matter.

headline: Landlord and Tenant: Natural Enemies?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Living in the same building as your landlord can be too close for comfort. But wait! Some tenants find close kind of cozy.
lead_paragraph: A young woman spent the night with Rob Curtin at his apartment in Astoria, Queens, some while back, and a good time was had by all.

headline: Wayne Shorter: Jazz Standard-Bearer and Cosmic Philosopher
abstract: Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss Wayne Shorter; his new album with his quartet (“Without A Net,” on Blue Note); his obsessions with eternity and the falsity of endings; and the link between Buddhism and Louis Armstrong.
lead_paragraph: Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss Wayne Shorter; his new album with his quartet (“Without A Net,” on Blue Note); his obsessions with eternity and the falsity of endings; and the link between Buddhism and Louis Armstrong.

headline: Vandalized California Petroglyphs Recovered
abstract: Investigators recovered five stone panels that were chiseled and sawed away last year from a volcanic escarpment in a remote area of the Eastern Sierra region of California.
lead_paragraph: The United States Bureau of Land Management announced that investigators had recovered five petroglyph panels that were chiseled and sawed away last year from a volcanic escarpment in a remote area of the Eastern Sierra region of California, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: In Wake of Restructuring, NBC News President Quits
abstract: Steve Capus, president of NBC News for the last eight years, said he was leaving.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

headline: Off the Charts: As January Goes, So Goes the Year?
abstract: January was a good month for the stock market in the United States, which could be a sign this will be a good year.
lead_paragraph: January was a good month for the stock market in the United States, which could be a sign this will be a good year.

headline: The Brothers Harbaugh, Live on Stage
abstract: John and Jim Harbaugh will face off in the Super Bowl on Sunday. On Friday, they shared a news conference, and laughs were provided.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Anyone looking for insight into Sunday’s Super Bowl was in the wrong place Friday morning when the Brothers Harbaugh took the stage for a joint news conference. Trading vague compliments and assuring everyone that they intend to win seemed to be the flavor of the event more than any discussion of strategy.

headline: A Bad Jobs Report Turns Out to Have Been Wrong
keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The jobs report for last March was a big disappointment, one that spurred talk of a new recession. Now we learn that report was simply wrong, that March was actually a very good month and that jobs rose much more rapidly in 2012 than we had previously been told.
lead_paragraph: The jobs report for last March was a big disappointment, one that spurred talk of a new recession. Now we learn that report was simply wrong, that March was actually a very good month and that jobs rose much more rapidly in 2012 than we had previously been told.

headline: Birth Control Rule Altered to Allay Religious Objections
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The Obama administration proposed a compromise that it said would guarantee free coverage of birth control while allowing churches and religious organizations not to pay for it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday proposed yet another compromise to address strenuous objections from religious organizations about a policy requiring health insurance plans to provide free contraceptives, but the change did not end the political furor or legal fight over the issue.

headline: How the Vanity Fair Party Found Its Groove
abstract: The history of the well-known Oscar party.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The Bagger is lucky enough to have witnessed the surreal cross-section of celebritydom known as the Vanity Fair Oscar party, which is having its 20th anniversary this year. From its humbler start at Morton’s restaurant here, to its current incarnation as a must-stop on the valedictory circuit, Graydon Carter’s bash has been an object of fascination, as much for those with an invite as without. In the magazine, Frank DiGiacomo looks back on two decades of star-studded mingling, brazen crashing attempts, and love affairs started and broken, all in formalwear and sometimes with a little golden man in hand.

headline: Hedgehog Bacteria, a New Solar Sail and More
abstract: A look at science headlines from around the Web.
lead_paragraph: Friday in science, clues to owls’ backwardness, fresh dangers to the seas and the launch of a giant kite. Check out these and other headlines from around the Web.

headline: Car Sales Climb Sharply in Strong Start to 2013
abstract: New vehicle sales in the United States rose sharply in January, raising expectations that the industry’s steady recovery would accelerate in 2013.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Automakers said new vehicle sales in the United States rose sharply in January, indicating that the industry’s steady recovery is not slowing despite weak job growth and an uncertain economy.

headline: After a Nudge, Chandler Awakens on Offense
abstract: The Knicks’ center scored a team-high 21 points on 10-of-11 shooting Wednesday after taking just nine shots in his previous four games.
lead_paragraph: In contrast with most games this season, the Knicks’ main objective in the first quarter of their victory over the Orlando Magic on Wednesday was not to get Carmelo Anthony into an offensive rhythm.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Legacy of Louis Agassiz
abstract: Christoph Irmscher discusses his new biography of the 19th-century scientist.
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Rebecca Stott reviews “Louis Agassiz: Creator of American Science” by Christoph Irmscher. Agassiz was a prolific and influential scientist and teacher, but his racist beliefs and his opposition to evolutionary theory tarnished his image. Mr. Irmscher calls his subject “distinctly undelightful.” Ms. Stott writes:

headline: Anti-Hagel Groups Emboldened After Confirmation Hearing
abstract: The sense that Chuck Hagel performed poorly in his confirmation hearing has buoyed the outside groups that have been working to defeat his nomination, many of them financed by donors who refuse to identify themselves (and are not legally compelled to do so).
lead_paragraph: The sense that Chuck Hagel performed poorly in his confirmation hearing has buoyed the outside groups that have been working to defeat his nomination, many of them financed by donors who refuse to identify themselves (and are not legally compelled to do so).

headline: Energy Secretary Is Resigning After 4 Years Focused on Clean Technologies
abstract: Energy Secretary Steven Chu, a winner of the Nobel Prize, will leave office soon, possibly by the end of this month.
lead_paragraph: Energy Secretary Steven Chu will step down soon, possibly by the end of the month, he said in a statement on Friday, ending a four-year tenure in which he concentrated on fostering research and development of clean energy technologies, and opponents pilloried him over stimulus loans that went bad.

headline: DJ Steve Porter Takes on the Harbaughs
abstract: The Harbaugh brothers may be good coaches, but neither of them has much to say in news conferences. DJ Steve Porter took their lack of things to say and turned it into his latest remix.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Coach Jim Harbaugh of the San Francisco 49ers has mastered the art of not answering questions. He often stares at the questioner with a confused (like a fox) look on his face and provides a reply that says very little. If asked the same question again, he replies with a nearly verbatim response.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Munich, Amsterdam, France, Virginia Beach
abstract: A weekly calendar of events across the globe.
lead_paragraph: Hoffentlich Öffentlich, Munich The city of Munich has handed some of its public spaces to the Scandinavian artists Elmgreen and Dragset, above, who will curate several works through September. First up: Fourth Plinth Munich by Stephen Hall and Li Li Ren, a replica of the Trafalgar Square’s Fourth Plinth that will sit in the Wittelsbacherplatz square in Munich. If you’re lucky enough to be in the area March 12, you can take in a performance of “It’s Never Too Late To Say Sorry,” a work created by the curators that involves a vocalist shouting the title of the piece over a megaphone at noon. Don’t worry, the engineers on lunch break from the nearby Siemens headquarters will be scratching their heads, too. (muenchen.de)

headline: Comparing Jobs in Recessions and Recoveries
abstract: Employment still has a long way to go before returning to its pre-recession level.
lead_paragraph: For the 28th straight month, the country added jobs: 157,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in January, to be more precise.

headline: On Iran, Hagel Muddles the Message
abstract: In his confirmation hearing on Thursday, Chuck Hagel became the latest official to send what many inside the administration fear has been an inconsistent and confusing message to Iran’s supreme leader about the possibility of using military measures to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.
lead_paragraph: Dealing with Iran is complicated, but President Obama’s policy on the question of whether a nuclear-armed Iran could be successfully “contained’’ – the way the Soviet Union was during the cold war – is simple.

headline: Diocese Papers in Los Angeles Detail Decades of Abuse
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Cardinals (Roman Catholic Prelates)', 'Priests', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The church files are filled with outrage, pain and confusion. There are handwritten notes from distraught mothers, accounts of furious phone calls from brothers and perplexed inquiries from the police following up on allegations of priests sexually abusing children.

headline: Brown Decides Against Massachusetts Senate Bid
abstract: The decision leaves the Republicans without a candidate yet for the special election set for June 25, and it could leave the seat in Democratic hands.
lead_paragraph: Scott P. Brown on Friday opted out of the Senate race in Massachusetts to fill the seat being vacated by John Kerry, leaving Republicans without a candidate for the special election set for June 25.

headline: For Markets, a Strong January Is a Good Sign

headline: The First Fighting Irish
abstract: The war comes to Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 10, 1862, Lt. Orville Chamberlain of the 74th Indiana Infantry wrote home to his family in Elkhart from his camp, 50 miles northeast of Nashville, Tenn. A few days earlier, the regiment had marched eight miles from its camp after hearing the sound of cannon to the east. “Our advance was cautious,” he wrote, “as we expected to meet the enemy.”

headline: A Peek into the Start of a Ticket Business
abstract: A ticket broker explains how he got into the business.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — On Thursday, I wrote an article for The Times that provided a peek into the life of a ticket broker during Super Bowl week. As often happens in the newspaper biz, it had to be cut for space. One aspect I found interesting was how Steve Sigel got into the business in the first place. Figuring that some of you out there might be curious about how The Ticket Guys came to be, I’m passing along a portion of the story pertaining to that. Enjoy.

headline: A Friend, in Need and Deed
abstract: A family-oriented community that has shown its true colors in aiding Newtown, Conn., its neighbor to the north.
lead_paragraph: The town of Monroe has for a long time been intertwined with Newtown, its Fairfield County neighbor to the north — the way towns that share a border often are. Residents of each have regularly crossed town lines without giving it much thought, heading to church, dropping off children at day care, or rushing to make tee time.

headline: Advice for the Wandering Boomer
abstract: Kurt Kutay, an expert on adventure travel, takes questions about blending wanderlust with the preferences and health concerns of baby boomers.
lead_paragraph: This Ask the Expert features Kurt Kutay, who will answer questions about adventure travel for the older traveler. Mr. Kutay is the founding president and chief executive of Wildland Adventures and is the director of the nonprofit Travelers Conservation Trust. He has traveled and guided throughout the world since 1975 and served on the boards of the Adventure Travel Trade Association and the International Ecotourism Society. He is currently the president of the International Galapagos Tour Operators Association. With its outsized demographics and yearnings for adventure, the baby boom has been reshaping the travel industry for decades, from shoestring student trips in the ‘60s to singles resorts in the ‘70s and the luxury hotel boom of the ‘90s. Now, as the economy slowly recovers, the travel industry is hoping that boomers will indulge their wanderlust.

lead_paragraph: Billy Hunter’s long, sometimes-controversial tenure as the head of the N.B.A. players union could be nearing an ignominious end.

headline: In Praise of Turnips, Year Round
abstract: Try them braised in stews or simmered in soups, slivered into salads or simply sliced, buttered, salted and nibbled raw.
lead_paragraph: MOST COOKS think of turnips only in winter, but I reach for them all year long. Whether braised in stews or simmered in soups, slivered into salads or simply sliced, buttered, salted and nibbled raw as a snack (a favorite with my 4-year-old), turnips are quietly making a bid for your attention.
