headline: The Many Faces of Harbaugh
abstract: 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh can convey boredom, surprise, happiness and contempt with his facial contortions.
lead_paragraph: 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh can convey boredom, surprise, happiness and contempt with his facial contortions.

headline: At the Table With Ed Koch
abstract: Ed Koch loved many things about New York, but especially its food.
lead_paragraph: “Mentally, I’m always noshing,” Ed Koch told Mimi Sheraton, then the restaurant critic for The Times, when they dined together at Lutece in 1982. He told her he kept jars of pickles at Gracie Mansion and at his Greenwich Village home. The former mayor, who died Friday morning, was known as a good eater, but he preferred “cheap, homey and informal restaurants,” Ms. Sheraton wrote. She asked him if he felt uncomfortable in an expensive restaurant, and he told her: “Only if I’m paying for it. Not when I’m a guest.”

headline: Prince, Last Jettisoned Piece of Pistons’ Glory Days, Could Lift Grizzlies
abstract: Much was said about Memphis trading away its talented star Rudy Gay, but getting Tayshaun Prince from Detroit may pay more dividends than people expect.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday’s trade involving the Memphis Grizzlies, Toronto Raptors and Detroit Pistons did not lack compelling headlines: about a small-market team managing costs by cutting a bloated contract, about another team’s approach to roster construction, and about a much-criticized general manager reeling in the deal’s most underrated chip.

headline: Ang Lee and the Solution to the Unsolvable
abstract: The director of “Life of Pi” said he finally realized he could make the seemingly unfilmable novel work if it was in 3D. Still, the studio dropped the movie twice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – “Making this film was a nightmare.”

headline: Saying It All Without a Word
abstract: 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh can convey boredom, surprise, happiness and contempt with his facial contortions.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Jim Harbaugh can scream when he is silent and pose questions without words. He can say anything without saying anything. His facial expressions are part of his charm, a window into his personality and coaching style, a way for Harbaugh to express the full spectrum of human emotion.

headline: Merck Delays Osteoporosis Drug
abstract: The drug maker said it would delay seeking approval for an experimental osteoporosis drug, an announcement that helped send the company’s shares down 3 percent.
lead_paragraph: Merck said on Friday that it would delay seeking approval for an experimental osteoporosis drug, an announcement that helped send the company’s shares down 3 percent on the same day it announced its fourth-quarter earnings for 2012.

headline: On Our Radar: A Reprieve for the Wolverine?
abstract: The federal Fish and Wildlife Service is now said to favor a threatened species designation.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials propose listing the wolverine as threatened under the Endangered Species Act after repeatedly deferring its consideration. The animal’s western habitat has been eroded by declines in mountain snows related to climate change. [Fish and Wildlife Service]

headline: Philadelphia Papers Reach Tentative Deal With Union
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: The agreement stipulates that no guild members would be laid off in the first year of the contract, in exchange for pay cuts this year and next.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Media Network, which publishes of The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Daily News and Philly.com, reached a tentative two-year contract with its union that guarantees that both papers will continue to be run as daily print publications.

headline: College Is (Still) Worth It
abstract: The unemployment rate for college graduates is just 3.7 percent. That is less than half the rate for those with no more than a high school diploma.
lead_paragraph: Every week I hear from recent college graduates who question the value of their higher educations. They are indebted, un- or underemployed, and horribly discouraged.

headline: Brothers Develop New Device to Halt Allergy Attacks
abstract: A quest that two brothers with severe food allergies began 15 years ago has culminated in a new device to inject epinephrine in the event of a severe allergic reaction.
lead_paragraph: Twin brothers Eric and Evan Edwards grew up with serious food allergies and were under doctor’s orders to carry their medicine everywhere they went.

headline: Griner’s Season for the Record Book
abstract: Brittney Griner set the Big 12 scoring record on Wednesday, after setting the N.C.A.A. block record on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Scoring 40 points for the fourth time in her career at Baylor, senior forward Brittney Griner made breaking the Big 12 scoring record look easy in a 90-60 win over Texas Tech on Wednesday.

headline: Crow Indians’ Lawsuit Against F.B.I. Agent to Proceed
abstract: The suit contends that the agent discriminated by taking crime on an Indian reservation less seriously than crime elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Two families from the Crow Indian Reservation in Montana can proceed with a lawsuit against an F.B.I. agent that accuses him of failing to properly investigate crimes against American Indians on and around the reservation, the United States Supreme Court has ruled.

headline: Refining Helps Profit at Exxon Mobil
abstract: The No. 1 American oil company reported strong earnings on its refining and chemical businesses, compensating for disappointing results in oil and gas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil reported strong earnings on its refining and chemical businesses for the fourth quarter on Friday, compensating for disappointing results in its oil and gas businesses.

headline: The Muffin Man Goes Gluten-Free
abstract: For people who need to eliminate gluten from their diet, baking becomes a challenge. Martha Rose Shulman provides five new ways to make gluten-free muffins — and even your children won’t know the difference.
lead_paragraph: For people who need to eliminate gluten from their diet, baking becomes a challenge. Beginners often find gluten-free baked goods too dense. Even the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman didn’t like the flavor of a commercial gluten-free flour mix, which left her gluten-free cookies and tart-shells with a strong taste of bean flour. As a result, she created her own gluten-free mix for baking muffins. She writes:

headline: Teenagers in The Times | January 2013
abstract: Our latest collection includes the Manti Te’o saga, as well as pieces on dating, LGBT youth, college internships and more.
lead_paragraph: Each month we round up all the latest articles and multimedia published on NYTimes.com about young people, so that teachers and students can find this rich collection of nonfiction writing all in one place.

headline: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Television Critic
abstract: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Hall of Fame basketball player, has turned to television criticism, reviewing the HBO series “Girls” for The Huffington Post.
lead_paragraph: “The characters talk boldly about sex, but their actions are often shy and unsatisfying. The contrast of the generation that’s been taught that pretty much anything goes sexually trying to act cool while struggling with their vulnerabilities is generally fresh and original and insightful about this generation.”

headline: Pop Quiz Answers
abstract: Answers to the pop quiz.
lead_paragraph: Data Interpretation: 1. e., 2. c.

headline: Big Ticket | Full-Floor Luxury for $12.9 million
abstract: A nine-room apartment, with 4,200 square feet of space, including a mahogany-paneled library and fireplaces with marble mantels, was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor condominium with ample Park Avenue frontage and white-glove amenities in a prewar building that underwent a luxurious and luminous two-year makeover under the direction of the architect Barry Rice in 2004, sold for $12.9 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The original listing price was $15 million.

headline: A Million Strong: Helping Them Through
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: With more than $10 billion being spent this year educating troops and veterans, the order has been given: help them graduate. But how?
lead_paragraph: THE class was humanities, the book under discussion Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein.” Suddenly an alarm blared and 20 students, some calm and some not, filed out of the makeshift classroom. Kandahar Airfield in southern Afghanistan was under rocket attack, again.

headline: Collector Says He Will Donate Johns Works to MoMA as promised
abstract: Collector accused of reconsidering his gift of Jasper Johns’ paintings to the Museum of Modern Art says that he has not changed his mind.
lead_paragraph: The art collector Donald L. Bryant Jr. is dismissing recent accusations that he is trying to go back on a pledge he made to the Museum of Modern Art and the artist Jasper Johns that he would donate three important paintings by Mr. Johns to the museum.

headline: To Peel, or Not to Peel
abstract: Purple turnips need to be peeled, in general, before cooking, but others may not. How to tell the difference.
lead_paragraph: This week’s column and video are a love letter to turnips, which are easy to adore if you take the time to get to know them.

headline: His Honor, Mr. Koch
abstract: Edward Koch made an uber-career of distilling and billboarding New York City’s essence as he saw it, usually with himself at the center of things.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine New York City without Edward Koch impressing himself on its every facet, demanding, in his trademark imperiousness, to be saluted by one and all. His death Friday at the age of 88 is a moment of unalloyed sadness in the city’s history. For while Mr. Koch had a decidedly mixed record of City Hall management through some of the best and worst of times, he made an über-career of distilling and billboarding the city’s essence as he saw it, usually with himself at the center of things.

headline: Tales From the Pressroom About a Man Who Relished Publicity
abstract: Three reporters for The New York Times recount their experiences covering Edward I. Koch.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who died on Friday at age 88, loved to be in the spotlight and to spar with the press. Here are the recollections of the man from three reporters at The New York Times who covered him:

headline: At the Movie Theater, Paying Tribute to a Mayor
abstract: For many who attended screenings of “Koch” on Friday, watching the film was a way to remember both the former mayor and the city he led.
lead_paragraph: “He loved New York like no other mayor I can remember before or after. And people felt it.”

headline: Feeling For | A Brief Note
abstract: Oversized logos, begone! A slew of brands are offering more minimal designs for undergarments in nicer fabrics and slim fits.
lead_paragraph: For the amount of consideration men are giving to tailored suits and good jeans these days, it’s astonishing that when it comes to what to wear underneath, they’re much less discerning. Exposed waistbands often reveal oversize logos and patterns that would not otherwise be acceptable in any other kind of garment — which is to say nothing of the entire genre of action-hero-inspired underwear. Thankfully, a slew of undergarment-centric brands are offering cleaner, more minimal options in nicer fabrics, slim fits and rid of any obnoxious branding. Special Delivery is a New York-based company that uses incredibly soft and durable supima cotton from North Carolina to cut its range of comfortable briefs ($36) and these slightly shorter, trimmer boxers ($48; specialdeliverynyc.com). Sunspel, under the consultation of the young British designer-of-the-moment J. W. Anderson, and the Swedish-based Bread & Boxers (packaged appropriately in white bread bags) are also making uncomplicated undies.

headline: Who Should Be Obama’s Next Energy Secretary?
abstract: Who has the mix of skills necessary to propel a sustainable energy quest?
lead_paragraph: As Matthew L. Wald and others reported this morning, Energy Secretary Steven Chu is poised to head back to California, leaving President Obama with a new opportunity to signal his approach to energy and climate policy in his final term.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 1
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including Davis Cup action in Charleroi, Belgium and a skeleton world championship in St. Moritz, Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including Davis Cup action in Charleroi, Belgium and a skeleton world championship in St. Moritz, Switzerland.

headline: How Your Broker Repelled (or Attracted) You
abstract: Bucks readers share stories of telltale signs that led them to believe that the financial professionals they work with are honest and decent (or corrupt and to be avoided).
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I point to four signs that you may want to use in finding a new stockbroker or financial adviser. They’re drawn from the case of Philip Horn, a Wells Fargo broker who may soon go to jail for his fraudulent activity.

headline: Week in Review: Wall Street’s Friend Atop the S.E.C.
abstract: Federal authorities are investigating firms hired to help banks clean up misdeeds like foreclosure abuses. | Battling big beer. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that Mary Jo White’s work for Wall Street is a problem. | A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are investigating firms hired to help banks clean up misdeeds like foreclosure abuses. | Battling big beer. | The renewable energy industries are pushing for more financing options. | MF Global’s bankruptcy is near a happy conclusion. | Under fire, Chesapeake Energy’s co-founder is to depart. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that Mary Jo White’s work for Wall Street is a problem. | Beneath the calm, SAC Capital worked to contain the fallout from an inquiry.

headline: Know Your Investment
abstract: Bucks readers discuss their own experiences in investing in exchange-traded funds.
lead_paragraph: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan takes note of the 20th anniversary of the creation of the first exchange-traded fund, the Standard & Poor’s Depositary Receipts E.T.F., which tracks the performance of the S.& P. 500 index and is bought and sold like a single stock.

headline: Vows: Lisa and David
abstract: David Jacobsen likes to write snarky songs that “pour battery acid” on the traditional love ballad. His fiancée, Lisa Schwartz, thinks he’s hilarious.
lead_paragraph: David Jacobsen likes to write snarky songs that “pour battery acid” on the traditional love ballad. His fiancée, Lisa Schwartz, thinks he’s hilarious.

headline: What About Penn?
abstract: A photo essay about New York’s other train station.
lead_paragraph: Everyone’s been making a huge deal this week about the 100th anniversary of Grand Central Terminal, throwing around words like “Beaux-Arts” and “landmark.”

headline: The Role of the Military and Veterans in Politics
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Veterans']
abstract: The interplay between politics, the military and veterans is a complicated subject matter, writes Tim Hsia who is in the Army Reserves as an R.O.T.C. instructor at Santa Clara University.
lead_paragraph: The recent death of Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a celebrated World War II veteran, coincided in many ways with the waning influence of veterans in American politics. There are now only three World War II veterans in Congress: Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, Representative Ralph Hall of Texas and Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan. Over all, the number of veterans joining Congress has perpetuated a four-decade-long slide.

headline: Movie Review | ‘Warm Bodies’
abstract: A Times critic reviews “Warm Bodies.”
lead_paragraph: A Times critic reviews “Warm Bodies.”

headline: How You Know the Super Bowl Is Near: Just Look Up
abstract: The view from New Orleans: Airplanes dragging banners have joined the blimps in signaling to New Orleans that the Super Bowl is only two days away.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — It has been a long week of festivities, but the Super Bowl is now two days away and I can see the finish line. Personally, I want it to hurry up and get here because as it gets closer, I’m becoming more and more excited about the game itself. I really think it has the makings of a classic.

headline: The French Debate Gay Marriage, in Their Fashion
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Marriages', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Polls show wide support for legalizing gay marriage in France, but there is plenty of ambivalence, too.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The invitation-only soiree at the Rond-Point Theater on the Champs-Élysées last Sunday gathered 1,000 of this city’s glitterati, among them government ministers, intellectuals, politicians, artists and even union leaders, to support the legalization of same-sex marriage in France.

headline: Privacy Flaw in Path’s iPhone App Shares Location Data
abstract: Path, a social media start-up company, has to pay $800,000 in damages for privacy violations, the Federal Trade Commission said on Friday. But this may not be the end of Path’s troubles with privacy. A security researcher has pointed out a loophole that allows Path to share location data even when a user has turned off location sharing.
lead_paragraph: 4:59 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from a Path employee.

headline: French President to Visit Troops in Mali
abstract: François Hollande will thank his soldiers and indicate to both Mali and his own country his expectations for resolution of the military crisis.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — President François Hollande of France was on his way to Mali on Friday evening to thank French soldiers, to underline the need for a political solution to Mali’s divisions and to emphasize to French voters his resolute and so-far successful intervention in the former French colony.

headline: Movie Review | ‘John Dies’
abstract: A Times critic reviews “John Dies at the End.”
lead_paragraph: A Times critic reviews “John Dies at the End.”

headline: Edward I. Koch in His Own Words
abstract: A selection of Op-Ed articles and Letters to the Editor by the former mayor.
lead_paragraph: A selection of Op-Ed articles and Letters to the Editor by the former mayor.

headline: The Mouse That Roars
abstract: The Nissan Versa is America’s cheapest new car and every bit an entry-level vehicle. Its 4-cylinder engine musters a mere 109 horsepower, and its transmission is confounding.
lead_paragraph: TESTED Nissan Versa SL

headline: Not So Quiet or Quick, but It Scoots Over Snow
abstract: The 2013 Subaru XV Crosstrek is basically a modified Impreza hatchback operating at a higher level. While the Impreza has 5.7 inches of ground clearance, the Crosstrek has 8.7.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2013 Subaru XV Crosstrek

headline: How Do You Get to Carnegie Hall? Start in Kabul
abstract: Unimaginable not so long ago, students from the Afghanistan National Institute of Music are coming to the United States for a 13-day tour, including a Carnegie Hall performance.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Every night, Mohsen, a slight, awkward 13-year-old boy, goes home from school to an orphanage here and does something that would probably have been impossible a dozen years ago: he practices his violin before going to bed.

headline: A Mercedes With Tenure
abstract: A diesel Mercedes-Benz is still a Hoboken, N.J., professor’s loyal companion after 37 years.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — Though Naomi Harley’s 1976 Mercedes-Benz 240D is not exactly the same shade of yellow as the taxis waiting for fares at the train terminal here, it blends in well enough that she can sneak into the line along Hudson Place and pick up a visitor. It’s a useful perk of owning the squared-shouldered sedan, but the ruse has occasionally backfired — when cab-seeking patrons have opened a door to get in.

headline: What Happened to All Those Eggs?
abstract: Women start with millions of eggs, which disappear with increasing frequency as menopause approaches.
lead_paragraph: Baby girls enter the world with enough of them to populate perhaps 40 small cities. A dozen or so years later, the first will make a debut of its own. And in the months and years to come, others will appear regularly, sometimes greeted with relief, other times with disappointment, perhaps most often with a touch of annoyance.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Mali and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Mali, Kashmir, Pakistan and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Mali, Kashmir, Pakistan and China.

headline: Documentaries Thrive in Sandy’s Ruins
abstract: The documentaries “Shored Up,” “The Rider and the Storm” and “Beach 119” were born amid the ravages of Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: For three and a half years Ben Kalina struggled to find just the right elements and imagery that would make his documentary “Shored Up,” a convincing statement about rising seas, beach erosion, the fragility of barrier islands and the wisdom of replenishing oceanfront property.

headline: Father Guilty of Manslaughter in Shaken-Baby Case
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The jury in Queens voted to acquit the defendant, Li Hangbin, on a more serious murder charge.
lead_paragraph: After spending five years in jail awaiting trial, a Chinese immigrant was convicted of manslaughter on Friday for the death of his 2-month-old daughter.

headline: Gifts for Keeping Warm and Connected While on the Go
abstract: Gadgets and equipment that enable communication, music on the run, good old-fashioned sledding and other items.
lead_paragraph: Gadgets and equipment that enable communication, music on the run, good old-fashioned sledding and other items.

headline: An Eye for the Radical Perspective
abstract: As a tribute at Anthology Film Archives attests, Amos Vogel, the film scholar and New York Film Festival founder, regarded cinema as a revolutionary force.
lead_paragraph: Part movie guide, part manifesto, Amos Vogel’s 1974 book “Film as a Subversive Art” has loomed large in many a film buff’s coming of age. A mind-expanding compendium of cinematic radicalism — from silent-era comedy to antiwar agitprop, avant-garde experiments to hard-core provocations — it is an idiosyncratic bid to create an anticanonical canon. The book has introduced generations of cinephiles to a wide array of seditious and often challenging work, but at its core is a simple, even utopian premise: Subversive cinema shows its viewers new worlds and new ways of seeing the world.

headline: Graduates Going for Broke
abstract: For an increasing number of prospective grad students, the math no longer works out. Here’s the latest on loans.
lead_paragraph: IT wasn’t too long ago that a graduate degree was a ticket to the good life, or at least to a nice bump in salary. But the lingering impact of the financial crisis, coupled with the continuing escalation of college costs and new barriers to borrowing, have changed the calculus.

headline: Few Thrills With a Diesel Continental
abstract: The Lincoln Continental Mark VII, a luxury coupe introduced for 1984, was intended to compete with prestigious German imports, but the underpowered car found few takers.
lead_paragraph: WHAT WAS IT? Lincoln Continental Mark VII with the turbodiesel engine option.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 1
abstract: Subjects include the Bolshoi Ballet, the Pacific Northwest Ballet and Christine Andreas.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the Bolshoi Ballet, the Pacific Northwest Ballet and Christine Andreas.

headline: Learning From Failure
abstract: Researchers need to openly discuss their failures, because in a learning process, you get things right by first analyzing why you’ve been getting them wrong.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS love success stories. Go to the Web sites of the United States Agency for International Development, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation or a plethora of global health and development organizations, and you’ll find articles, charts and videos documenting their triumphs and innovations, with the promise of more on the way.

headline: Mates in Peril, Actress in Clover
abstract: Criterion releases a Blu-ray reissue of Hitchcock’s British “Man Who Knew Too Much” and TCM offers a three-disc Carole Lombard set.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Man Who Knew Too Much’

headline: Kerrey, in Reversal, Decides to Quit Job at New School
abstract: Former Senator Bob Kerrey, now part of an education venture based in California, has decided to leave his post as president emeritus of the New School.
lead_paragraph: Bob Kerrey has resigned as president emeritus of the New School, two weeks after joining an experimental higher education venture based in San Francisco, the university said Friday.

headline: Video and Images of New Clashes in Cairo
abstract: As clashes between protesters and the security forces escalated in Cairo on Friday night, bloggers and journalists uploaded video, images and text updates from the scene.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 7:16 p.m. As our colleagues Kareem Fahim and David Kirkpatrick report, Egyptian protesters clashed with riot police officers outside the presidential palace in Cairo on Friday night.

headline: Off the Field, on the Screen
abstract: Dozens of former football players have found a welcoming home on sports programming, but the list of those who have branched out into show business is not quite as long.
lead_paragraph: Michael Strahan, with his weekly gig on “Fox NFL Sunday,” is one of dozens of football players who have found a welcoming home on sports programming — either as commentators or game analysts — once their gridiron careers have come to an end. These days, stars like Dan Marino, Phil Simms and Boomer Esiason, and even journeymen like Tim Hasselbeck and Rich Gannon, can be found on the air talking about the sport they once played. (Though perhaps none made the transition from player to commentator more memorably, or did it better, than Frank Gifford and “Dandy” Don Meredith when they were on “Monday Night Football” in the 1970s and ‘80s.)

headline: The Fifth Quarter
abstract: The former football star Michael Strahan has had an unlikely post-football career, one that has made him one of the few celebrities as recognizable to housewives as to their teenage sons.
lead_paragraph: On the Friday before the presidential inauguration, Michael Strahan paid impromptu homage to Michelle Obama’s new bangs during a taping of “Live With Kelly and Michael,” the morning show he co-hosts with Kelly Ripa. Seated next to Ms. Ripa at the desk they share five mornings a week, Mr. Strahan entertained the crowd in the show’s studio by donning a wig, batting his lashes and staring longingly into the camera — a ridiculous gesture for any man, let alone one who stands 6 feet 5 inches, weighs 240 pounds and helped the New York Giants win the Super Bowl in 2008 with his talent for driving quarterbacks into the turf.

headline: Warrior Voices
abstract: In workshops on campus and at military hospitals, veterans learn to write about their, and try to heal.
lead_paragraph: RON CAPPS sat alone in a truck in a Darfur desert preparing to shoot himself in the head. He had been in the military for 22 years, serving in the Army and working for the Foreign Service in the world’s hot spots, including Afghanistan, Iraq, Kosovo, Sudan and Rwanda. He’d debriefed Iranian terrorists held in Iraq, observed rebel forces and assessed the carnage they’d left behind in Sudan, counted the mass graves of the hundred thousand killed in the civil war in Zaire — and reported all back to Washington. After five wars in 10 years, Mr. Capps had developed post-traumatic stress disorder, and it was killing him.

headline: For Super Bowl Ticket Prices, the Sky May Not Be the Limit
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said it is pointless to try to cap prices of Super Bowl tickets because the secondary market will always prevail.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect ticket prices for Super Bowl to stop rising. That’s effectively what Roger Goodell said on Friday at his annual state of the league address in New Orleans.

headline: Feeling For | Jen Kao for Anthropologie Bracelet
abstract: Anthropologie is introducing some Eastern flair through Jen Kao’s Bali-influenced line starting this Monday.
lead_paragraph: Adding to its revolving repertory of guest designers, Anthropologie is introducing some Eastern flair through Jen Kao’s Bali-influenced line starting this Monday. Taking cues from the designer’s trip to Bali in 2009, “all the pieces were inspired by something I felt that I needed while traveling,” says Kao. “Whether it was a dress to wear to the Rock Bar at night or shorts to the beach,” she says, “I designed each piece to be easy and work together to tell the same story.” The collection includes tailored separates and jewelry priced from $98 to $1,298 — ideal for those left pondering what to pack while still being cost conscious. “The multicolored rubberized rope can be customized for multiple purposes,” says Kao about the piece shown above. “A woman can wear it as a longer necklace or wrap it around her wrist as a bracelet.”

headline: A Truce in the Bragging Wars
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Guidelines for when it’s acceptable, or not, to brag about your children.
lead_paragraph: MOMMY BLOGGERS (and their daddy counterparts, too) agree about almost nothing. Some favor co-sleeping; others do not. Some favor banning video games; others do not. Similar disputes surround breast-feeding, vaccines, cursing and whether it’s O.K. to force-feed your child broccoli.

headline: Shame Serves as a Muse
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: Ann Leary, the novelist, writes about secrets and explores some of her own. In “The Good House,” a woman has a secret drinking problem, an affliction Ms. Leary knows all too well.
lead_paragraph: I am covered in dog. Four, to be precise: little, big, bigger, mutant (Gomer, a 125-pound Leonberger). “Daphne is a little needy,” the novelist Ann Leary says as the Labradoodle wedges her head between my knees and refuses to budge. “We don’t get too many visitors out here.”

headline: Afghan Youth to Perform at Carnegie Hall
abstract: A group from the National Institute of Music will perform in New York on Feb. 12.
lead_paragraph: A group from the National Institute of Music will perform in New York on Feb. 12.

headline: Ed Koch’s Unconventional Portrait
abstract: Koch liked the photograph that Gregory Heisler took of him for the magazine in 1989 so much that he made it his official portrait hanging in City Hall — instead of the traditional oil painting.

headline: Timing Tips for the ACT and SAT
keywords: ['ACT (Examination)', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Watches and Clocks']
abstract: Fill in those bubbles fast, or slow down. What you need to know when the proctor says, “Go!”
lead_paragraph: HOW do you pace yourself during standardized tests? Jordan Liss, a sophomore at the University of Michigan, faced this question each time he took the ACT, which was five times. “The last thing a student wants to do is a math problem trying to figure out how much time they have,” Mr. Liss said. He thought a timer would help, but “every time I brought a watch on the test day it was declined for its own reason,” like being capable of beeping or browsing the Web.

headline: Expressly for Execs
keywords: ['Graduate Management Admission Test (GMAT)', 'Business Schools', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Graduate Schools and Students']
abstract: An E.M.B.A. entrance exam for the unprepped professional.
lead_paragraph: HOW many 45-year-old upper-level managers want to bone up on high school geometry and grammar? Not too many. So perhaps it’s not surprising that in the global competition for executives willing to invest weekends in an E.M.B.A. program, a growing number of top business schools no longer require an entrance exam.

headline: Just Don’t Call It a Drone
abstract: Dozens of colleges now offer courses, and universities are beginning to add majors, in unmanned aircraft systems — the new frontier of aviation.
lead_paragraph: CHARLES A. TAYLOR loves radio-controlled model airplanes — a hobby, he decided, that could give him a leg up in a potentially lucrative new industry: drones. Mary A. Wallace expected to end up in management at an airport or airline but switched majors to remotely piloted planes because, incongruously, there would be less travel. Thomas Boutain wanted to start a company serving farmers around the Minnesota town where he grew up, mapping moisture, growth, pests and other conditions in their fields, from the air.

headline: You, Too, Can Make It Work
abstract: Tim Gunn, the “Project Runway” style guru, has seen more than his share of classrooms. He answers a few questions about mentoring in and out of them.
lead_paragraph: ON “Project Runway,” which just started its 11th season, Tim Gunn famously advises the competing designers to “Make it work.” Gentle and invariably honest, he nudges them toward realizing their own voice and potential while staying on deadline.

headline: Prometheus, Raw and Fiery
abstract: The towering conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi, looking fit and distinguished at 83, is leading the Philharmonic in a Beethoven program.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a conductor can make.

headline: Big Names on Campus
abstract: What are the perks of being student body president? Meet Michelle Obama, see a game, park your car, or nothing.
lead_paragraph: ELECTION season is approaching, and aspiring student body presidents are drafting platforms, posting fliers and plotting ways to capture votes. For last February’s election, with the $1,000 cap on campaign spending lifted at the University of South Carolina, Kenny Tracy unleashed “Kenny for Carolina” T-shirts, sunglasses, koozies and “mood cups” that turn his campaign color, blue, when liquid is added. Mr. Tracy won after spending about $2,200.

headline: Clip: ‘Caesar Must Die’
abstract: A scene from “Caesar Must Die,” directed by the Taviani brothers.
lead_paragraph: A scene from “Caesar Must Die,” directed by the Taviani brothers.

headline: Class Assignments
abstract: Love them or loathe them, but you can’t ignore them. We invited students to share a photo of their favorite class project.
lead_paragraph: Love them or loathe them, but you can’t ignore them. We invited students to share a photo of their favorite class project.

headline: A Formula for Owner Loyalty
abstract: Naomi Harley’s 1976 Mercedes-Benz 240D has rolled up more than 250,000 miles and is still reliable nearly four decades later.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Harley’s 1976 Mercedes-Benz 240D has rolled up more than 250,000 miles and is still reliable nearly four decades later.

headline: Little Time to Prepare; Now a Legacy to Keep
abstract: Pretty Yende, a young soprano from South Africa, is drawing attention after her recent Metropolitan Opera debut in Rossini’s “Comte Ory.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent cold and rainy afternoon, Pretty Yende sat on a couch in the press room of the Metropolitan Opera House, retracing the path that took her from a childhood in South Africa to her acclaimed Met debut last month. On Jan. 17 she received a raucous standing ovation from the audience after singing Adèle in Rossini’s “Comte Ory” opposite the star tenor Juan Diego Flórez. Now, dressed in leggings and boots and wearing rimless, flexible glasses that resisted her frequent attempts to fix them in place, Ms. Yende, a 27-year-old soprano, looked more like a graduate student than like a diva.

headline: A Humble Chair Speaks Volumes
abstract: Jack Pierson, an artist and photographer, does not know who transformed orange crates into a chair he prizes, but he loves the possible stories that surround it.
lead_paragraph: WHEN IT COMES to describing the magnetic power that California has held on the American imagination, where do you start? In 1848, when gold was discovered in Sutter’s Mill? Or 70-odd years later, in Hollywood, when they discovered glitter?

headline: Brothers, Romans, Filmmakers
abstract: The brothers Paolo and Vittorio Taviani, who have written or directed 22 films together over nearly 60 years, have set their latest movie, “Caesar Must Die,” in an Italian prison.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 40 years ago the brothers Paolo and Vittorio Taviani wrote and directed “Allonsanfan,” starring Marcello Mastroianni as a revolutionary in the Napoleonic era. After its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival Mr. Mastroianni met with reporters, and when they asked him about the unusual experience of working with two directors on the same film, he feigned surprise. “Were they two?” he asked.

headline: Black Cabs of London Get a Bailout From China
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: The Zhejiang Geely Holding Group said that it had agreed to pay $17 million for the assets of Manganese Bronze, whose London Taxi Company unit produces black taxis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For more than six decades, black cabs have been as much a part of London’s street scene as gray rainy days.

headline: Playful Superheroes, Walking on Walls. Will They Fly Next?
abstract: “Set and Reset” is enchanting in its use of peripheral space, with dancers bounding out of the wings, hovering halfway out of them, even walking along the side scenery.
lead_paragraph: Trisha Brown’s “Set and Reset” — surely the most beloved and irresistible work of postmodern dance — will be 30 years old this year. On Thursday evening it returned to the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Howard Gilman Opera House for a single performance during the Trisha Brown Dance Company’s current season there.

headline: The Difference Between Koch’s City and Today
abstract: A look back at the tenure of Edward I. Koch.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the tenure of Edward I. Koch.

headline: Now Showing | Andy Kaufman
abstract: The West Village gallery Maccarone pays tribute to the reluctant comic and high-concept prankster.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Improvising With Cornel West, After a Trip to Hell
abstract: Sean Curran’s “Fireweather,” a visit to hell, and “Left Exit,” an examination of faith, are playing at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: How do they dance in hell? According to Sean Curran’s new “Fireweather,” the first half of his company’s program at the Joyce Theater, the damned gravitate to the floor. Stretch and spring up as they might, something keeps pulling them down.

headline: An Editor’s Third Act
abstract: Jesse Pearson, former editor in chief of Vice magazine, now has a new venture, Apology, a magazine that takes him away from the Williamsburg culture of the 2000s he helped popularize.
lead_paragraph: In late 2010, Jesse Pearson was putting the finishing touches on his final issue as editor in chief of Vice magazine. The cover featured a photo of a car crash; the back page an image of James Joyce’s death mask hovering above the author’s supposed last words: “Does nobody understand?”

headline: Do Parents Really Brag Too Much?
abstract: Are we really a nation of parents bragging about our children, or do we need to take more “victory laps”?
lead_paragraph: Do you brag about your children?

headline: The Week in Pictures for the New York Region, Feb. 1
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Transit Systems', 'Canals']
abstract: Subjects include a dolphin in the Gowanus Canal, the retirement of a Manhattan mailman after 45 years on the job and the reopening of a historic church in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include a dolphin in the Gowanus Canal, the retirement of a Manhattan mailman after 45 years on the job and the reopening of a historic church in the East Village.

headline: A Melting Pot of Sounds, With Latin Spices
abstract: David Virelles, his band Continuum and a couple of guest performers are filling the Village Vanguard with sounds that roam far and wide.
lead_paragraph: You might have to contain your need for immediate comprehension when you hear David Virelles’s music at the Village Vanguard this week. It won’t slot easily into what you know.

headline: More Antlers on the Wall
abstract: In 1983 it opened and closed on the same night. Now “Moose Murders,” the most famous flop in Broadway history, has returned in a revised version.
lead_paragraph: “I’m sorry, I don’t understand the question.”

headline: Bank of America Suffers Widespread Outages; Hacking Is Not Suspected
abstract: Bank of America customers were unable to access their online banking accounts, mobile payment systems or the company’s telephone call centers on Friday. But it does not appear to be the result of hacking.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America customers were unable to access their online banking accounts, mobile payment systems or the company’s telephone call centers on Friday.

headline: Wheelies: The Hail-a-Cab Edition
abstract: Manganese Bronze, the parent company of LTI, which makes the iconic black London taxis, has been bought by Geely for £11.4 million, or about $18 million.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Contraception Compromise
abstract: The Obama administration has tried everything it can think of to accommodate religious groups that don’t want to pay for their employees’ birth control.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has tried everything it can think of to accommodate religious groups that don’t want to pay for their employees’ birth control.

headline: Subaru Gives Its Hatchback a Lift
abstract: The XV Crosstrek, a thoroughly likable crossover based on the Impreza, is impressive not for its speed but for its ability to adapt to driving conditions.
lead_paragraph: The XV Crosstrek, a thoroughly likable crossover based on the Impreza, is impressive not for its speed but for its ability to adapt to driving conditions.

headline: Hunter’s Lawyer Responds to Union’s Move
abstract: Thomas R. Ashley, Billy Hunter’s lawyer, issued a statement after Hunter was placed on indefinite leave as executive director of the National Basketball Players Association.
lead_paragraph: After Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, was placed on indefinite leave Friday, Thomas R. Ashley, his lawyer, issued this statement:

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 1
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: I Paid for a Piston, So Toss Me Your Keys
abstract: The Dodge Dart Registry allows your friends and family, through crowd-funding, to buy you a Dart, part by part.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever bought a gift on your friend’s wedding registry and wondered, “Why can’t I do this for me, for nonwedding things?” If you’re in the market for a 2013 Dodge Dart, you can, with the Dodge Dart Registry. If that sounds like a crowd-funding exercise, it is, but one for new cars instead of start-ups and hipster rock bands.

headline: Winter’s Balm: A Bubbling Pot of Polenta
abstract: Grilled with a spicy tomato sauce or baked with a rich stuffing of spinach and cheese, made-from-scratch polenta is a meal worth the cooking time.
lead_paragraph: I’M ALWAYS IN THE MOOD for polenta. Furthermore, I always make it from scratch, stirring a pot of good cornmeal slowly over a low flame. Yes, there is instant polenta, and the packaged type in plastic tubes — shun them. You wouldn’t buy instant coffee, would you?

headline: Making Mozzarella, a Hands-on Affair
abstract: With several places in New Jersey regularly offering cheesemaking classes, mozzarella may be the favorite.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Dave Briegel, 54, knows that this is not the seasonally correct time to sit down to a plate of fresh mozzarella with tomatoes and basil. Still, he was happy that he and his partner, Ted Manzke, 67, were attending a recent mozzarella-making class at Olsson’s Fine Foods, a tiny gourmet shop here that specializes in cheese.

headline: Police Video of Shootings at South African Mine Raises Questions
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: Video recorded by South African police officers during the mass shooting at the Marikana mine has raised new questions about the official account.
lead_paragraph: Last year the South African police shot and killed 34 miners after a strike and unrest at a platinum mine in the town of Marikana. The police have long argued that they were acting in self-defense. But footage shown by Britain’s Channel 4 News this week seems to show a more complex series of events.

headline: Novella’s Sympathetic Portrayal of Armenians Causes Uproar in Azerbaijan
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Azeri lawmakers condemned the work, by an Azeri writer, and protesters burned his portrait outside his house, illustrating the depth of hostility between the two nations.
lead_paragraph: BAKU, Azerbaijan —  A novella by an Azeri author that portrays ethnic Armenians sympathetically has provoked an uproar in Azerbaijan, with Azeri lawmakers denouncing the work and protesters burning the author’s portrait outside his house.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Old Hat
abstract: Annie Hall and her felt hat have returned for a new generation.
lead_paragraph: Annie Hall and her felt hat have returned for a new generation.

headline: Schizophrenia and the Art of the Possible
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, “Successful and Schizophrenic.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Moveable Feast Macroeconomics
abstract: What can bond vigilantes do if you borrow in your own currency?
lead_paragraph: Ah, Paris in the 1920s. It was the era of Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald, Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas, sovereign debt and stabilization. Wait, what?

headline: The Library and the Architect Respond to a Critic
abstract: Tony Marx, president of the New York Public Library, and Norman Foster fire back.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A reader responds to an About New York column, “Weighing Political Risk Against Mercy for Prisoners.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: The founder of the Opportunity Network responds to a front-page article, “In Hiring, a Friend in Need Is a Prospect, Indeed.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: German Legislators Vote to Outlaw Bestiality
abstract: An amendment criminalizes “using an animal for personal sexual activities” and punishes offenders with fines of as much as $34,000.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s upper house of Parliament, the Bundesrat, voted Friday to criminalize for the first time “using an animal for personal sexual activities” and to punish offenders with fines of as much as $34,000. It was the final legislative hurdle for a bill the lower house passed in December.

headline: A Robot at My Side, to Help and Advise?
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, “Talking, Walking Objects.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: No Suspects Are Identified in Texas Prosecutor’s Death
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Legal Profession', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: A day after a lead prosecutor was fatally shot in an employee parking lot near his office, the police said they had no motive or suspects.
lead_paragraph: KAUFMAN, Tex. — The county courthouse here reopened Friday, the day after it was locked down and closed after the fatal shooting of a lead prosecutor by an unknown killer or killers.

headline: Postal Service Considers Sale of Bronx General Post Office
keywords: ['Art', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Murals', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: A money-saving move by the Postal Service would put under new ownership a building that houses a gallery of the work of a leading Social Realist artist.
lead_paragraph: The money-starved United States Postal Service is considering selling the Bronx General Post Office on the Grand Concourse — an official city landmark, a centerpiece of life in the borough for more than 75 years and a monumental gallery of the work of Ben Shahn, one of America’s leading Social Realist artists. Postal operations would move to a much smaller leased space.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow
abstract: All I ever do is wrong.
lead_paragraph: So many great new bands:

headline: The King of New York
abstract: Even when wrong, Edward Koch was brave and earnest in ways I didn’t at first comprehend.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN

headline: Kids Draw the News: Special 3-D Assignment
abstract: This Sunday, Feb. 3, at the Museum of the City of New York, you can make a super-small apartment in a shoebox and it might wind up in Kids Draw the News.
lead_paragraph: This assignment is about Very Small Apartments.

headline: Seeing Darwin Through Christian Eyes? It All Depends on the Christian
abstract: For the religious, evolution continues to divide more than 150 years after “On the Origin of Species.”
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 22, Rush D. Holt, a Democrat who represents central New Jersey’s 12th Congressional District, introduced a resolution designating Feb. 12, 2013 — Charles Darwin’s 204th birthday — as Darwin Day, “recognizing the importance of science in the betterment of humanity.”

headline: Twitter Hacked: Data for 250,000 Users May Be Stolen
abstract: Twitter announced late Friday that it had been hit by a “sophisticated attack” in which hackers may have accessed usernames, e-mail addresses and encrypted passwords for 250,000 Twitter users. The attackers appear to have broken in using a well-known vulnerability in Oracle’s Java software.
lead_paragraph: Twitter announced late Friday that it had been breached and that data for 250,000 Twitter users was vulnerable.

headline: A Worldwide Race Has a Winner, but Is Not Over
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Vendee Globe Challenge', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: At 29, François Gabart became the youngest sailor to win the grueling Vendée Globe. He also set a record by finishing the race in under 80 days.
lead_paragraph: During the frigid early hours Sunday, François Gabart was on the verge of becoming the youngest winner of the Vendée Globe, the solo, nonstop, around-the-world sailing race.

headline: To Thwart a Powerful Intruder, He Let Him Open the Door
abstract: A young man in SoHo recalls how he lost a tug of war with a robber over a doorknob, and therein won the battle.
lead_paragraph: The young man was strong, but the intruder was stronger. The man was inside his apartment, pulling at the doorknob, trying to close the door, but the intruder in the hall had gripped it with both hands and jammed a leg against the wall for leverage. The door was opening, inch by inch.

headline: District 3 Winter Regional
abstract: Jay Borker and Doug Doub of Connecticut won the Open Pairs event on Jan. 21.
lead_paragraph: The District 3 Winter Regional ended on Jan. 21, Martin Luther King’s Birthday. Jay Borker of Greenwich, Conn., and Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn., won the concluding Open Pairs. They finished just under half a board ahead of Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J., and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City. Helen Raleigh and Robert Heitzman Jr. of Suffern, N.Y., were third.

headline: Another Reset With Russia in Obama’s Second Term
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Four years after Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. proposed a “reset” of relations with Russia, the United States is quietly adopting a new approach: the cold shoulder.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Four years ago, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. used an audience of world leaders at an annual security conference in Munich to propose a “reset” with Russia, the Obama administration’s first big foreign policy statement. But as Mr. Biden arrives in Germany for the same conference this weekend, the United States is quietly adopting a new approach to its old cold war rival: the cold shoulder.

headline: In Burrows Across the City, It’s Groundhog Day Year Round
abstract: While New York’s prognosticating groundhog, Staten Island Chuck, primps for his annual turn in the spotlight on Saturday, the Real Groundhogs of New York City are slumbering hard in their boroughs.
lead_paragraph: Staten Island Chuck lives the pampered life one would expect of a celebrity groundhog, lounging in a heated nursery at the Staten Island Zoo and noshing on sweet potatoes as the world outside shivers.

headline: Mets’ Bullpen Continues to Be a Concern
abstract: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson has added veterans on minor league contracts in recent days.Yet he remains less than confident about the state of the bullpen.
lead_paragraph: General Manager Sandy Alderson has continued to make it clear, through both actions and words, that he is less than confident about the state of the Mets’ bullpen.

headline: Earl Williams, Baseball Slugger, Dies at 64
abstract: Williams won the National League’s rookie of the year award in 1971, but was out of major league baseball by the end of the decade.
lead_paragraph: Earl Williams, a slugging if ambivalent catcher and infielder — “My favorite position is batter,” he once said — who won the National League rookie of the year award in 1971 but whose promise went unfulfilled amid a welter of minor controversies, died early Tuesday at his home in Somerset, N.J. He was 64.

headline: In New York, Echoes of a Talkative Mayor
abstract: Readers were invited to share their reflections about the mayor. Here are some excerpts.
lead_paragraph: A chance encounter at a Citarella. An impromptu performance in a tourism commercial. A tough job interview. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who died on Friday, left a lasting impression on those who met him. Readers were invited to share their reflections about the mayor. Following are excerpts:

headline: On the Beach, With Jetés
abstract: In its premiere on Thursday night at the David H. Koch Theater, Justin Peck’s “Paz de La Jolla” set New York City Ballet down at the edge of the Pacific Ocean.
lead_paragraph: In San Diego the weather is almost always right for a trip to the beach. Not so in New York, yet on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater, members of New York City Ballet were dressed for a dip. Young love was in the air, and if you couldn’t smell the ocean, you could see it. The corps de ballet danced the Pacific.

headline: Funeral Arrangements
abstract: Edward I. Koch’s funeral will be held at 11 a.m. on Monday and will be televised by NY1.
lead_paragraph: Edward I. Koch’s funeral will be held at 11 a.m. on Monday at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street in Manhattan. The funeral will be televised by NY1.

headline: In Senate, Traditional Decorum Gives Way to New Discord
abstract: Chuck Hagel’s grilling as nominee for defense secretary was striking in a place where respect for fellow and retired senators of the same party has been more or less a given.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Senator John McCain had an inkling of curiosity how his old buddy Chuck Hagel felt as the senator raked him over the confirmation coals on Thursday, Mr. McCain would get a slight taste an hour later during his own rendezvous with rudeness.

headline: A Day for Isolation and Creative Design
abstract: Zac Posen, a new judge on “Project Runway,” uses the time to experiment with fabric and get inspired by his playlist.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, fresh out of college, Zac Posen was a wunderkind of the fashion industry, starting his own label and making his name among the established brands. Now, at 32, after some setbacks, he is reintroducing himself to the public as a judge on “Project Runway,” which began its 11th season last month. He will also show his fall collection at the Plaza on Feb. 10. Mr. Posen lives in SoHo with his partner, Christopher Niquet, 34, a stylist and fashion editor, and “three lovely ladies”: Tina Turner, a poodle; Betty Blue, a dapple miniature dachshund; and Candy Darling, an English cream miniature dachshund.

headline: Health Care’s Trick Coin
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: If I toss a coin, but hide the result every time it comes up tails, it looks as if I always throw heads.
lead_paragraph: LONDON

headline: Where Las Vegas Stardust Rests in Peace
abstract: The “boneyard” that has been the Neon Museum of Las Vegas has grown a bit more sophisticated, with a visitors’ center made of the lobby of the 1961 La Concha motel.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — We may be made of star stuff, as the astronomer Carl Sagan once said, but our imaginations contain a strong dose of “Stardust” — at least as the word appears here. The capital S, its 17-foot-tall body peppered with bulbs, is shaped like a coy lightning bolt. Its jagged strokes change thickness and meet at unexpected angles, like the stylized clothes of “The Jetsons.” The T’s are like toon sketches of rays shooting from stars.

headline: The New, Weird World of Atlanta Rap
abstract: A city that has become the headquarters of hip-hop is home to both the progressive sounds of Future and the sartorially flamboyant but musically conservative Trinidad James.
lead_paragraph: Years ago Atlanta took control of hip-hop’s center, both geographically and sonically. But as the hub of the genre, it’s been a steadily moving target, far more volatile than New York or Los Angeles ever were in their heyday. Trap music, snap music, strip club anthems: Atlanta can be almost anything it sets its mind to.

headline: F.T.C. Suggests Privacy Guidelines for Mobile Apps
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', "Children's Online Privacy Protection Act", 'Smartphones', 'Tablet Computers', 'Computer Security']
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said the mobile industry should include a do-not-track feature in software and apps and take other steps to safeguard personal information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a strong move to protect the privacy of Americans as they use the Internet on their smartphones and tablets, the Federal Trade Commission on Friday said the mobile industry should include a do-not-track feature in software and apps and take other steps to safeguard personal information.

headline: Making Room for Southern Cuisine
abstract: An 11-month-old restaurant in a 1940s railway-car diner serves smoked barbecue ribs, fried chicken and pulled pork po’boys.
lead_paragraph: Biscuits and Barbeque opened in Mineola last March in a 1940s railway-car diner. When Joan Gallo, who has lived in Mineola for 17 years, noticed that the space was available, she decided it would be perfect for her style of hearty, down-home Southern food. She and her business partner, Thomas Sullivan, also own the 15-year-old Delta Grill in Manhattan; Bobby Bouyer is their chef in Mineola.

headline: Washington Post Joins List of News Media Hacked by the Chinese
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Washington Post has joined The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and Bloomberg as news organizations hacked after writing articles about China’s leaders.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The question is no longer who has been hacked. It’s who hasn’t?

headline: The Ed Koch Show
abstract: A new documentary about Hizzoner says a lot about what makes a great mayor.
lead_paragraph: “I never doubted that I would be a good mayor,” said Ed Koch, with a self-satisfied smile. “I never did.”

headline: Investigators Begin to Test Other Electrical Parts on the 787
abstract: Regulators in Washington and Tokyo said they had no answers to explain why two batteries on Boeing’s troubled Dreamliner emitted fire or smoke.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have not found enough evidence in the charred remains of two Boeing 787 batteries to determine why they overheated, and they are expanding their examination of other electrical components, regulators in Washington and Tokyo said on Friday.

headline: Tribal Battles Displace Thousands in Darfur
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Relations', 'Gold']
abstract: Fighting that broke out last month between two Arab tribes in the Jebel Amir gold mining area has displaced around 100,000 people, United Nations officials said.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Intense clashes between two Arab tribes fighting over a gold mine in a remote corner of Darfur, Sudan, have displaced around 100,000 people, becoming one of the biggest crises in Darfur in years, United Nations officials said Friday.

headline: Big, Bold Italian Food, No Skimping on Cheese
abstract: At Carbone’s Kitchen in Bloomfield, flavors are rich and crowd pleasing, servers are friendly, and no one begrudges the glutton his due.
lead_paragraph: Anchoring the back corner of a Bloomfield strip mall, Carbone’s Kitchen presents a warren of rooms accented everywhere in black. Black leather booths, black window casings, a big, black wrought-iron wine rack, black cocktail napkins, even black ceilings all strike a raffish contrast with the vermilion walls of the main dining room.

headline: A Soccer Star Who Rarely Stands Still
abstract: With Tottenham Hotspur vying for a top finish in the English Premier League and the United States about to begin the final stage of its bid for the World Cup, Clint Dempsey has not slowed down.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For club and country, Clint Dempsey will do what has to be done.

headline: Washington Post Says It Will Seek New Home
abstract: The Washington Post, another newspaper struggling to trim costs, is planning to move out of the District of Columbia headquarters where its staff has worked for nearly four decades.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post, another newspaper struggling to trim costs, is planning to move out of the District of Columbia headquarters where its news staff has worked for nearly four decades.

headline: Suicide Data Report, 2012
abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs has released a report showing the latest statistics on suicides by soldiers.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs has released a report showing the latest statistics on suicides by soldiers.

headline: As Suicides Rise in U.S., Veterans Are Less of Total
abstract: The convergence reflects the fact that suicide numbers are rising slightly among both veterans and everyone else, but has increased more in the general population.
lead_paragraph: Suicides among military veterans, though up slightly in recent years, account for a shrinking percentage of the nation’s total number of suicides — a result of steadily rising numbers of suicides in the general population, according to a report released on Friday by the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: As U.S. Growth Lags, Some Press the Fed to Do Still More
abstract: Federal Reserve officials believe the bank could do more to increase the pace of inflation and aid growth. They simply are not persuaded that the benefits outweigh potential costs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the five months since the Federal Reserve started a campaign to increase growth and reduce unemployment, the economy has slowed and unemployment has increased.

headline: More Lessons About Charter Schools
abstract: States will only replicate mediocrity if they expand charters too quickly.
lead_paragraph: The charter school movement gained a foothold in American education two decades ago partly by asserting that independently run, publicly financed schools would outperform traditional public schools if they were exempted from onerous regulations. The charter advocates also promised that unlike traditional schools, which were allowed to fail without consequence, charter schools would be rigorously reviewed and shut down when they failed to perform.

headline: Authentic Thai Fare, With Heat Held in Check
abstract: Despite a pungent eponym, there is nothing off-putting about a new Thai restaurant in Larchmont.
lead_paragraph: My first visit to a Thai restaurant, some 30 years ago, is hard to forget: the opening gambit, a soup made with coconut milk and insanely hot peppers, had the 10 of us begging for pitchers of water, our tongues numb to everything that followed. I’ve risked authentic Thai food only a few times since, despite the meteoric rise in its popularity, but after dining at the estimable Durian, in Larchmont, where the heat is held in check and dishes can dazzle, I could see myself getting on something of a Thai kick.

headline: A Good Compromise on Contraception
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', "Women's Rights", 'Freedom of Religion', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Obama administration’s latest proposal again protects both religious liberties and women’s right to affordable birth control.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has proposed a sensible way to provide women who work for religiously affiliated institutions with free coverage of contraceptives while exempting the organizations they work for from financial or administrative obligations to provide the coverage.

headline: Police and Protesters Clash Near Egypt’s Presidential Palace
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Police']
abstract: Opposition to President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt led to violent clashes Friday outside the presidential palace in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: Opposition to President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt led to violent clashes Friday outside the presidential palace in Cairo.

headline: In a Suburban Home, Some Unwelcome Guests
abstract: In Edward Albee’s Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece, the suburban characters illustrate the paralyzing fear of existence and the fragility of connections.
lead_paragraph: The cat story gets me every time. A mature, well-to-do husband and father sits in his manorlike suburban living room, drink in hand, and recalls a pet cat he had in his youth who inexplicably turned against him. Nothing violent. The cat just stopped liking him and wanting to be in the same room with him. Not long after that, he had the animal euthanized; now he is haunted by the experience.

headline: Critics Say Proposed Guidelines for Japan’s Nuclear Industry Will Hinder Business
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Many in a nation still recovering from a nuclear disaster said that the guidelines — in line with standards in the United States — were too strict.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Proposed new safety guidelines for Japan’s nuclear industry — strict enough that they could keep reactors shuttered for years for emergency upgrades — have set off intense political maneuvering by those who say the regulations will cripple business just as hopes were rising for economic relief.

headline: Rosa Parks, Revisited
abstract: A new book seeks to restore a heroine’s wholeness, even at the risk of stirring unease.
lead_paragraph: Most of what you think you know about Rosa Parks may well be wrong.

headline: A Classic That Still Delivers a Good Scare
abstract: In a new production of “Wait Until Dark,” audiences are asked to overlook unlikely situations for the sake of suspense and a scary payoff.
lead_paragraph: A good scare is the point of most thrillers, and the production of “Wait Until Dark” now being staged at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport delivers a spellbinding final scene that fulfills the promise of the play’s, and the subsequent movie’s, reputation as a classic.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
keywords: ['BlackBerry (Handheld Device)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Beef', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Japan eases its decade-long restrictions on American beef imports, the new BlackBerry 10 operating system is released, and economic growth in the United States turns narrowly negative.
lead_paragraph: Japan eases its decade-long restrictions on American beef imports, the new BlackBerry 10 operating system is released, and economic growth in the United States turns narrowly negative.

headline: A Man of Certitude and Joy
abstract: I was expected to hate this atypical liberal mayor, Edward Koch. It didn’t turn out that way.
lead_paragraph: I WAS a late arrival to the Ed Koch fan club. I grew up in a liberal, Jewish, Bella Abzug-loving household, and my parents spoke of him with a level of contempt they usually reserved for Republicans. Centrist Democrats are a dime a dozen these days, but back in the 1970s the prospect of a union-bashing, death penalty-backing Democrat winning City Hall was driving Manhattan Jewish liberals crazy. I was expected to hate him.

headline: High Points, and Other Stops, in a Painter’s Career
abstract: Two exhibitions about the painter Colleen Browning, a British-born artist who immigrated to America, are on view at Fairfield University.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — In a painting hanging in the Bellarmine Museum of Art, a little girl in a crimson dress stands alone on a city sidewalk littered with crumpled paper. Entwining her hands behind her back, she looks down, her expression a mix of defiance and disappointment.

headline: First Pull-Ups, Then Combat, Marines Say
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: The announcement last week ending the ban on women in combat only accelerated a sweeping re-examination of fitness standards in the American military.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — How many pull-ups does it take to make a female Marine?

headline:
Algeria Sowed Seeds
of Hostage Crisis as
It Nurtured Warlord
abstract: Algeria’s antiterrorism policy of playing favorites among armed groups like Ansar Dine, founded by Iyad Ag Ghali, backfired last month when extremists seized a gas field.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — To the Algerians, the desert warlord in the swirling blue robes was a man of his word — the key to managing the crisis next door in northern Mali — and for months they lodged his representative here in the Algerian capital in high style in one of the city’s finest hotels.

headline: Baseball Officials Navigate Puzzle of Anti-Aging Clinics
abstract: Baseball officials and law enforcement officers are investigating anti-aging clinics in Florida and the work of Anthony Bosch. The clinics might be linked to players and the possible use of banned substances.

headline: From Abstract Expressionism to Nude Self-Portraits
abstract: The few dozen paintings in Joan Semmel’s show create a coherent conceptual project that is also highly engaged with the tactility of paint and the possibilities of color.
lead_paragraph: Like most painters of her generation, Joan Semmel, who was born in the Bronx in 1932, started off painting abstractly. In the 1970s, however, she returned to the figure — and a new set of problems. Not only was she working in a supposedly moribund medium — the radical ’60s were filled with calls for the “death of painting” — but she was returning to a fraught traditional form. As a feminist, how could Ms. Semmel paint the female figure — particularly the female nude — without returning it to its old role as a passive object presented to a historically male viewer?

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Feb. 2, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Feb. 2, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "I wasn’t lying, I wasn’t embellishing, I wasn’t making it up. It shows the pattern of complicity. It shows the cover-up.”

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Syria’s Rebel Fighters
abstract: Antigovernment leadership is emerging inside Syria – a phenomenon unfolding on battlefields only intermittently visited by outsiders.

headline: Quizzical Cries

lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Have you ever gotten the feeling while solving that you are not so much cracking the code as successfully guessing?

headline: Why So Many New York Street Names Include ‘Park’
keywords: ['Buses', 'Names, Geographical', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Transit Systems', 'Global Positioning System']
abstract: Some avenues and places and the like are not near a recreational area even if they sound as if they are.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why are there so many city streets named “Park,” many of which aren’t near parks? Are they named for specific parks?

headline: A 49ers Lineman Really Does Feel All the Weight of His Position
abstract: The 49ers’ Joe Staley was a slim and lanky tight end when he entered college. But then his coaches wanted him to play on the offensive line.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Joe Staley has a dream. It is not about football, really, and certainly not about winning a Super Bowl title, though Staley, a San Francisco offensive lineman, would very much enjoy that. It is about his pants.

headline: Students Disciplined in Harvard Scandal
abstract: The university would not say how many students had been disciplined for cheating, but its statements indicated that the number forced out was around 70.
lead_paragraph: Harvard has forced dozens of students to leave in its largest cheating scandal in memory, the university made clear in summing up the affair on Friday, but it would not address assertions that the blame rested partly with a professor and his teaching assistants.

headline: A Rebel Commander in Syria Holds the Reins of War
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
