lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria

headline: A City Where Underground Gambling Plays by Its Own Rules
abstract: While New Orleans is known for its food, booze and jazz, there is a deep history of underground bookies and bettors in this city’s underbelly.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — There is a man living here named Michael. He is in his 30s, went to high school in the Uptown area and enjoys watching his two children run around and play. He is, in his own words, “a regular, boring family guy.” He has also had a bookmaker since he was 14.

headline: Wounded Candidate in Armenia Likely to Postpone Vote
abstract: An opposition presidential candidate who was shot and wounded Thursday outside his home in the capital said Friday that he would probably seek to postpone the Feb. 18 election.
lead_paragraph: An opposition presidential candidate who was shot and wounded Thursday outside his home in the capital said Friday that he would probably seek to postpone the Feb. 18 election. The candidate, Paruir A. Airikyan, 63, is one of eight opponents challenging President Serzh Sargsyan, who is widely expected to win re-election by an wide margin. Mr. Airikyan was shot in the shoulder by an unknown assailant but is expected to make a full recovery. Investigators offered no immediate motive for the attack. He spent years in Soviet prisons for promoting Armenian independence and was stripped of his citizenship and expelled to Ethiopia in 1988. He lived in Los Angeles before returning to Armenia after the fall of the Soviet Union. He has run for president several times but never won more than a small share of the vote. A provision in the Constitution allows for the postponement of elections by two weeks if a candidate faces an “insurmountable obstacle” and potentially for another 40 days if the obstacle cannot be removed.

headline: Smartphone as Wingman
abstract: Some apps are trying to reinvent online dating by replacing the process of browsing profiles and initiating lengthy exchanges with gamelike interactions that move things along quickly.
lead_paragraph: With Valentine’s Day looming, Adele Ernsberger decided to go on a blind date. But instead of having a friend set her up, she turned to a smartphone app.

headline: Nets Get Just About All They Can Handle From a Bulls Team Missing 3 Starters
abstract: A win over Chicago was devoid of the fluidity and ease that was a staple of the Nets’ winning ways early last month.
lead_paragraph: The hardest Nets player to please, Gerald Wallace, had 13 rebounds in 41 minutes in Brooklyn’s 93-89 win over the Chicago Bulls on Friday, a scratching, clawing, wrestling match of a basketball game that would seem right up his alley.

headline: Felton Fights Off Pain as Knicks Hold Off Bucks
abstract: Raymond Felton aggravated his right pinkie and left the game late in the third quarter. But he returned in the fourth to score 5 of his 14 points in a victory at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Felton grimaced. He then shook his head in anger. A few minutes later, he was crouched on the court at Madison Square Garden, the pinkie finger on his right hand throbbing. Felton did not want to drink from the water bottle that was given to him when he was forced to go to the Knicks’ bench. He threw it to the court with his left hand.

headline: Koch: Recalling the 105th Mayor
abstract: In Edward I. Koch’s early political base, Greenwich Village, and around the city, New Yorkers share feelings and recall encounters with the former mayor.
lead_paragraph: In Edward I. Koch’s early political base, Greenwich Village, and around the city, New Yorkers share feelings and recall encounters with the former mayor.

headline: Alabama: Hostage Standoff Continues
abstract: A hostage standoff in Midland City continued for a fourth day on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A hostage standoff in Midland City continued for a fourth day on Friday. Law enforcement officials released a photograph of Jimmy Lee Dykes, left, who they say raided a school bus, shot the driver and is holding a 5-year-old boy in an underground bunker. Mr. Dykes, 65, has a record of run-ins with the law as well as with his neighbors. While officials gave little indication of what was happening on the hill where the bunker is situated, activity continued throughout the day, and the school bus on which the initial confrontation took place was towed away.

headline: Basketball Prospector
abstract: Tom Konchalski has, over several decades, built a career as a basketball scout that he calls his “revenge” for not performing well on the court.
lead_paragraph: From the moment he shakes your hand and looks you square in the eye — part military dad, part concerned priest — Tom Konchalski is assessing: Are you Division I material, or simply junior college?

headline: New Images of Syria’s First Lady and Iran’s Space Monkey Cast Doubt on Two Reports
abstract: New images appear to cast doubt on the accuracy of two of the week’s most widely-reported stories: the rumored pregnancy of Syria’s first lady, and the pioneering space flight of an Iranian monkey.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Saturday, 12:37 p.m. Bad news, readers. New images appear to cast doubt on the accuracy of two of the week’s most widely reported stories: the rumored pregnancy of Syria’s first lady, and the pioneering spaceflight of an Iranian monkey.

headline: The Model for a Tribute to Model Players
abstract: Steve Wright, a 12-year N.F.L. tackle whose teams included the Giants, was the inspiration for the hulking figure depicted on the league’s Walter Payton Man of the Year award.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. will present its Walter Payton Man of the Year award on Saturday, an honor that goes to a player who excels on the field and is known for his charitable activities off it.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared in January
abstract: How the automobile industry fared in January.
lead_paragraph: How the automobile industry fared in January.

headline: The Waiting Is Finally Over for a 30-Year-Old Rookie
abstract: The Devils’ Matt Anderson endured long stints in the minors, and two concussions, before finally making his N.H.L. debut.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Matt Anderson had to wait until he was 30 for word that he had been promoted to the N.H.L. When the Devils finally reached out, a balky cellphone nearly caused him to wait even longer.

headline: U.S. Proposes to Protect Wolverines
keywords: ['Wolverines', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'ANIMALS', 'Land Use Policies', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The federal Fish and Wildlife Service proposed Friday to give Endangered Species Act protections to the animal, largely because climate change is whittling away its habitat in the northern Rockies.
lead_paragraph: The federal Fish and Wildlife Service proposed Friday to give Endangered Species Act protections to the wolverine, one of the largest and hardiest members of the weasel family, largely because climate change is whittling away its wintry habitat in the northern Rockies.

headline: A Pregame Reunion in Brooklyn
abstract: Beer and oysters started the night at Woodland for a group split between Brooklynites and Aussies, who saved room for food at the Barclays Center later.
lead_paragraph: A free throw’s distance from the Barclays Center in Brooklyn — all right, maybe a three-point shot — Woodland, a dark, earthy American bistro, gets a crowd as diverse as the events at the new arena. When the Rolling Stones played, wrinkled rock fans turned up for the charred Cornish hen ($21) and the crispy pork shank ($24). When the Brooklyn Nets are in town, there are office parties and tieless finance guys and pregame groups, like the one that showed up Wednesday night to celebrate the reunion of two old friends with a meal and some basketball (the Miami Heat, led by LeBron James, later trounced the home team).

headline: Mariachi in New York
abstract: Mariachi originated as a folk style in Mexico, of course, but mariachi bands have long been part of the fabric of New York as well.
lead_paragraph: Mariachi originated as a folk style in Mexico, of course, but mariachi bands have long been part of the fabric of New York as well.

headline: Leading the Rebel Fight for Aleppo
abstract: C.J. Chivers, a correspondent for The New York Times, profiles Abdulkader al-Saleh, a k a Hajji Marea, who leads the largest Syrian antigovernment fighting group operating in and around Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: C.J. Chivers, a correspondent for The New York Times, profiles Abdulkader al-Saleh, a k a Hajji Marea, who leads the largest Syrian antigovernment fighting group operating in and around Aleppo.

headline: Mexican Music for Life’s Milestones
abstract: In Mexico, where Mariachi originated as a folk style, bands traditionally play baby showers, communions, weddings and funerals.
lead_paragraph: Rock stars play in clubs, orchestras play in concert halls, and mariachis play anywhere, everywhere, from morning till night. On your average Saturday, Mariachi Real de Mexico, an 8-to-12-man band founded in 1991, plays five gigs across New York — zooming around town in a GMC Yukon that sports the license plate “MARIACHI.” They have booked up to 10 shows on a single day; graced Chinese weddings, traditional quinceañeras and Carnegie Hall; and performed for the pleasure of Henry A. Kissinger, Bruce Springsteen and one particularly lucky pup. “We asked, ‘Where’s the birthday person?’ ” remembered Ramon Ponce Jr., 37, the bandleader, chuckling. “And it was a birthday party for a dog.”

headline: Ran City, but Didn’t Own a Piece of It
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Edward I. Koch spent his entire adult life as a renter, opting not to buy a home in New York City.
lead_paragraph: In a city where residents are both doomed and blessed to live crammed on top of one another, one New York City politician shared an apartment building with two of his great nemeses. As mayor, he earned the keys to Gracie Mansion but would not relinquish his rent-controlled apartment downtown. And rather than buy a home, as the American dream decrees, he preferred to spend his entire adult life as a renter, right until the very end.

headline: Goodell Says Suspensions May Rise for Hits to Head
abstract: Commissioner Roger Goodell said that forcing players to miss games was a compelling deterrent for helmet-to-helmet hits.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell suggested Friday that the league could use suspensions more often to enforce its crackdown on hits to the head. During the season, the league suspended Ravens safety Ed Reed for his third violation of rules prohibiting helmet-to-helmet hits on defenseless players. The suspension was overturned on appeal by Ted Cottrell, an N.F.L. hearing officer.

headline: Ferrol Sams, Doctor Turned Novelist, Dies at 90
abstract: Dr. Sams, a country doctor in Georgia, was in his 50s before he began a career as a novelist, drawing on his practice and rural upbringing for material.
lead_paragraph: Ferrol Sams, a country doctor who started writing fiction in his late 50s and went on to win critical praise and a devoted readership for his humorous and perceptive novels and stories that drew on his medical practice and his rural Southern roots, died on Tuesday at his home in Fayetteville, Ga. He was 90.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 2
abstract: American reset with Russia; power broker in Syria; perilous road in Algeria; and a prescient espionage novelist.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Four years after Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. proposed a “reset” with Russia, the United States is quietly adopting a new approach to its old Cold War rival: the cold shoulder. David Herszenhorn and Andrew E. Kramer report from Moscow.

headline: Mayor Turned Movie Critic
abstract: “I say exactly what I think,” Ed Koch told reporters as mayor. He never stopped saying it, even as his subjects shifted from union leaders to romantic comedies.
lead_paragraph: Ed Koch was never one to keep quiet. “I say exactly what I think,” he told reporters on his first day as mayor.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: As pilgrims flock to the Maha Kumbh, a mass gathering in which Hindus travel to bathe in the confluence of the Ganga and Yamuna rivers, Soma Basu and Bharat Lal Seth examine the impact on the rivers and the surrounding areas. In their article in Down To Earth magazine, Ms. Basu points out that the large number of people drawn to the event help cause water pollution and demand a large number of resources such as waste disposal, sanitation facilities and basic amenities like food, water and electricity. She writes that despite the authorities’ claim that they are prepared for the pilgrimage, the region remains ill equipped to deal with such crowds.

headline: In a Memphis Cheating Ring, the Teachers Are the Accused
abstract: Federal prosecutors said a Memphis educator paid teachers to take qualifying exams for others in three states who were afraid they would not pass.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — In the end, it was a pink baseball cap that revealed an audacious test-cheating scheme in three Southern states that spanned at least 15 years.

headline: So, How’d He Do?
abstract: Ed Koch often asked straphangers at subway stops to assess his record with a “How’m I doin’?” While opinions about the former mayor may vary, there is no doubt he left a notable mark in several areas.
lead_paragraph: Ed Koch, the blunt-spoken and theatrical three-term mayor of New York City, who became a national emblem for the way New Yorkers talk and behave, often asked straphangers at subway stops to assess his record with a “How’m I doin’?”

headline: Veterans in College: Share Your Stories
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: It is unclear how the thousands of veterans who are in college are faring; only last month, the Department of Veterans Affairs announced a partnership with the National Student Clearinghouse and the Student Veterans of America to analyze data with an eye to determining if the veterans are succeeding — or failing — and why.
lead_paragraph: “Graduate, graduate, graduate,” the secretary of veterans affairs, Eric K. Shinseki, recently implored the audience at a conference of the Student Veterans of America. But what, exactly, will it take to ensure that veterans succeed in college?

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) BETTY & CORETTA (2013) Angela Bassett (above left, with Mary J. Blige) portrays Coretta Scott King, the wife of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (Malik Yoba), and Ms. Blige is Betty Shabazz, the wife of Malcolm X (Lindsay Owen Pierre). Together, these women inherited the mantle of the civil rights movement when their husbands were assassinated — resulting in a relationship that spanned more than three decades. Ruby Dee narrates this fictionalized account of their friendship.

headline: When the Law Says a Parent Isn’t a Parent
keywords: ['Child Custody and Support', 'Law and Legislation', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Fighting for custody of his son, Jonathan Sporn has fallen prey to a legal system that excessively privileges the conventional family models.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to interpret the popularity of a network television series like “Modern Family” as proof that we have mainstreamed the various and sweeping ways domestic life has reshaped itself over the past two decades. A nation of squares would not embrace a comedy about a badly dressed, middle-aged gay couple raising an adopted Vietnamese baby, we tell ourselves, no matter what they might say in Copenhagen or Berlin.

headline: Taliban Militants Attack Pakistani Base
abstract: At least nine soldiers and four paramilitary soldiers died in an attack on a Pakistani Army base in northwestern Pakistan early Saturday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Taliban militants killed at least nine soldiers and four paramilitary soldiers in an attack on a Pakistani Army base in northwestern Pakistan early Saturday, officials said. Ten civilians, including three women and three children who were living in a nearby compound, were also killed.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah has appointed two of his close aides to take charge of the National Conference party in the Jammu region and the Kashmir region of the state, India Today reported. The move is considered a step toward preparing the young brigade in the party to take over the reins from the old leadership.

headline: Timbuktu Gives France’s President an Ecstatic Welcome
abstract: After French troops helped drive militants from cities in northern Mali, thousands gathered to greet François Hollande, but little was known of the fighters’ fate.
lead_paragraph: TIMBUKTU, Mali — France’s president, François Hollande, paid a triumphant visit to this ancient city on Saturday, receiving a rapturous welcome from thousands of people who gathered next to a 14th-century mosque to dance, play drums and chant “Vive la France!” The muezzin, whose singing calls residents to pray five times a day, wore a scarf in the colors of the French flag as he shouted, “Vive Hollande!”

headline: The Early Word: Push and Tug
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, the president’s weekly address, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times

headline: Strahan’s Journey to Hall: Never a Sure Thing
abstract: The former Giant Michael Strahan stands a good chance of being elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Michael Strahan stands a good chance of being elected to the Hall of Fame later today.

headline: India Moves to Strengthen Sexual Assault Laws
abstract: Critics say measure, which does not address marital rape or offenses by armed forces, is incomplete.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, a special meeting of the Union Cabinet approved an ordinance to strengthen laws to deal with sexual violence against women. While the ordinance approved some suggestions made by the Justice Verma Committee making stalking, voyeurism and acid attacks punishable under criminal law, it diverged on issues such as marital rape, capital punishment and the prosecution of armed forces personnel who commit sexual assaults. The ordinance has received a mixed response from lawyers and women’s groups, who were agitating for more holistic legislation.

headline: Five Accused in New Delhi Gang Rape Case Plead Not Guilty
abstract: Charges include gang rape, murder, kidnapping and conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: The five men accused in a brutal  gang rape that led to nationwide protests entered not guilty pleas on Saturday to the 13 charges filed against them.

headline: Keeping Score: What Stats and Simulations Say About the Super Bowl
abstract: The 49ers have the edge in several key statistical categories that can help predict the winner of the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Carlton Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method.” They have previously written about the B.C.S. national title game, the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, and last year’s Super Bowl.

headline: The Gun Report: February 2, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The second victim in Wednesday’s shooting in an office complex in north-central Phoenix has died. Mark Hummels, a partner at Phoenix law firm Osborn Maledon, was shot in the neck and back when Arthur Douglas Harmon, 70, opened fire on Hummels and Steven D. Singer after an arbitration meeting. Singer died Wednesday.

headline: Cockroach Ideas
abstract: They keep coming back.
lead_paragraph: Three decades ago, when I went off for my year in the U.S. government, an old hand explained to me the nature of the job: it was mostly about fighting bad ideas. And these bad ideas, he went on to explain, were like cockroaches: no matter how many times you flush them down the toilet, they keep coming back.

headline: Doctors to Prescribe Self-Help Books, Poetry for Mental Health Ills
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Can curling up with a good book be an answer to some mental illness? That’s the thinking behind a new initiative that will encourage doctors to prescribe a visit to the local library.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Doctors in England will soon be prescribing books as well as pills to patients suffering from anxiety and depression.

headline: Government Spending in the Crisis
abstract: The bulge goes away.
lead_paragraph: Mostly a note to myself. Not long ago, the usual suspects were going on and on about how government spending had soared under Obama, pointing to spending as a share of GDP. Some of us tried to point out that this bump represented two temporary factors: 1. GDP was depressed thanks to the crisis, so the spending share was correspondingly elevated 2. Emergency aid programs, notably unemployment benefits, were up because of the crisis. The implication of this argument was that the government spending share would decline as the economy recovered.

headline: President Claims Shooting as a Hobby, and the White House Offers Evidence
abstract: Comments by the president’s that he shoots clay pigeons “all the time” at Camp David draw surprise — and skepticism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama mentioned last week that he had picked up a new hobby — skeet shooting at Camp David — it was a surprising disclosure by a president whose main identification with guns these days is his effort to ban assault rifles and high-capacity magazines.

headline: WWS 543, Class 1: A Brief History of Trade Policy
abstract: PowerPoint attacks.
lead_paragraph: Slides (pdf).

headline: Charlotte Longs for Its Blue Period
abstract: The N.B.A. team in New Orleans, which moved from Charlotte in 2002, will drop its Hornets nickname for next season, and some fans in North Carolina want it back.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Michael Jordan has added a hint of his beloved North Carolina Tar Heels blue to the uniforms of the Charlotte Bobcats, perhaps hoping that will endear the N.B.A. franchise to the city it has called home since 2004.

headline: Love and Lessons From the Niners
abstract: Football and a devotion to the 49ers offered a sense of security and identity.
lead_paragraph: The night the San Francisco 49ers advanced to Super Bowl XLVII, I got a text from my old friend Brian, whom I hadn’t spoken to in years.

headline: Dangerous From Any Angle
abstract: The Ravens have spent the last two weeks honing instincts and concocting strategy, but they face a challenge trying to stop the 49ers’ inventive offense, the Pistol, in the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — At bottom, football is math. A brutal, ruthless form of it, but math. The offense schemes to gain an advantage — more blockers than defenders — while the defense plots to foil those plans.

headline: In Short Time, 49ers’ G.M. Quietly Made a Lot of Noise
abstract: General Manager Trent Baalke, with his meticulous scouting for the 2011 N.F.L. draft, helped to assemble the 49ers team that will play in the Super Bowl on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — On the eve of the 2011 N.F.L. draft, Trent Baalke struck confidants as calm. This surprised them, because Baalke is not exactly the calm type. They describe him as intense and meticulous and opinionated, which is how he went from a South Dakota State assistant coach to an obscure Jets scout to general manager of the San Francisco 49ers.

headline: A ‘Real’ Kick in the Head
abstract: In his first game against his old team, Demba Ba took a foot in the face and was forced to leave the match on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Demba Ba’s first game back at St. James’ Park against Newcastle United was a real kick in the face. Literally.

headline: N.F.L. Joins With G.E. in Effort to Detect Concussions
abstract: The league is looking to jump start the development of imaging technology and encourage the creation of materials to better protect the brain.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The N.F.L., faced with increasing concern about the toll of concussions and confronted with litigation involving thousands of former players, is planning to form a partnership with General Electric to jump-start development of imaging technology that would detect concussions and encourage the creation of materials to better protect the brain.

headline: Southern Louisiana Is a Pipeline to the N.F.L.
abstract: At the start of the 2012 football season, there were 61 players from Louisiana in the N.F.L., many of them from the river towns between New Orleans and Baton Rouge.
lead_paragraph: At the start of the 2012 football season, there were 61 players from Louisiana in the N.F.L., many of them from the river towns between New Orleans and Baton Rouge.

headline: As Self-Immolations Near 100, Tibetans Question the Effect
abstract: A quiet debate is under way among Tibetans anguished over the deaths of their young men in gruesome acts of protest against Chinese rule.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A crowd of Tibetans came here to India’s capital last week, bearing flags and political banners and a bittersweet admixture of hope and despair. A grim countdown was under way: The number of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibet had reached 99, one short of an anguished milestone.

headline: In Louisiana’s River Towns, a Flow of Talent
abstract: The presence of the Ravens’ Ed Reed and Jacoby Jones provide a 16th consecutive Super Bowl with players from Louisiana, where more N.F.L. players hail from than any other state.
lead_paragraph: HAHNVILLE, La. — Hahnville High School was surely one of the few teams in the country to hold full-contact spring football practice in January, only two months after the previous season ended. That is not its only distinction.

headline: Variety: A Shorter Diagramless
abstract: A short diagramless by Paula Gamache.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Starting Square Alert! This diagramless is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep and has regular crossword symmetry. 1 Across begins in the first square of the first row.

headline: Kidnappings Imperil Talks With Rebels in Colombia
abstract: Peace talks between the government and rebels are imperiled by the development, bad news for a nation weary of a civil conflict that has gone on for decades.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The recent kidnappings of two police officers in Colombia by the country’s largest rebel group have cast a shadow over peace talks between the rebels and the government, disheartening a nation weary of the decades-old conflict.

headline: Spanish Leader Pledges Transparency Amid Corruption Inquiry
abstract: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy pledged to provide “complete transparency” about his own financial assets to refute documents showing that he and others had received regular payouts.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain pledged on Saturday to provide “complete transparency” about his own financial assets and those of other politicians in his party to refute what he described as “apocryphal” documents showing that he and others had received regular payouts from a secret parallel account maintained by the party.

headline: What It All Means, From Squib Kicks to Salsa Stains
abstract: Some experts say it takes about 10,000 hours of intense study to learn a language, but for fans looking to become fluent in football before the Super Bowl, here is a primer.
lead_paragraph: Some experts have posited that it takes about 10,000 hours of intense study to learn a language. Although the CBS pregame show for Sunday’s Super Bowl may seem that long, the reality is that fans hoping to be fluent in football by the kickoff do not have nearly that much time. As a reference, then, The New York Times offers this primer.

headline: Syrian Opposition Leader Confers With U.S. and Russia
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: There was no sign of progress in separate talks between Sheik Ahmad Moaz al-Khatib and American and Russian officials at a conference in Munich.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The leader of the Syrian opposition council, Sheik Ahmad Moaz al-Khatib, met here on Saturday with representatives of the United States and Russia — who fundamentally disagree on how to resolve Syria’s civil war — but the meetings were separate and there was no indication, officials said, that any progress had been made toward a workable plan to bring the violence to an end.

headline: Marxists Claim Bombing of U.S. Embassy in Turkey
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: A group with a history of political violence denounced American foreign policy and condemned Turkey’s support for Syrian rebels.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Marxist group with a history of political violence in Turkey claimed responsibility on Saturday for a suicide bombing at the American Embassy in Ankara the day before, releasing a statement calling the United States “the murderer of the peoples of the world.”

headline: We Can Be Healthy and Rich
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Controlling health care costs will help, not hurt, the economy.
lead_paragraph: Just about everyone agrees that health care in America is too expensive, and that something must be done to control the rising costs. Except for one group: hospitals and the unions representing hospital workers.

headline: Egypt’s Government Apologizes After a Beating Is Televised
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The rare apology came a day after officers stripped and beat a man two blocks from the palace of President Mohamed Morsi during clashes between protesters and riot police officers.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s interior minister offered a rare apology on Saturday after officers under his command were seen on television beating a naked man two blocks from the presidential palace. But under what his family said was police coercion, the victim, Hamada Saber, said in an interview later that the officers had been helping rather than attacking him.

headline: Delaware, Cradle of Super Bowl Quarterbacks
abstract: While powerhouse programs Ohio State, Texas and Southern California have never had a quarterback start the Super Bowl, Joe Flacco will become the Blue Hens’ second to do so.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — For all the Heisman Trophy winners and national championships that Ohio State, Texas and Southern California have combined to produce, those marquee football programs have never had one of their quarterbacks start a Super Bowl. The same is true for Oregon, Auburn and a host of other traditional powerhouses.

headline: Backstage Glimpses of Clinton as Dogged Diplomat, Win or Lose
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The instincts of Hillary Rodham Clinton, the departing secretary of state, were often more activist than those of a White House that has kept a tight grip on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last summer, as the fighting in Syria raged and questions about the United States’ inaction grew, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton conferred privately with David H. Petraeus, the director of the C.I.A. The two officials were joining forces on a plan to arm the Syrian resistance.

headline: Breeding Grounds for Super Bowl Quarterbacks

lead_paragraph: A look at where the starting Super Bowl quarterbacks played in college.

headline: Bronx Youth Is Accused of Throwing Boy, 9, From Roof
abstract: Casmine Aska, 17, was arrested and charged on Saturday with attempted murder after being identified by the victim, police officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old Bronx boy who had been thrown from the roof of his apartment building was able to identify his attacker to a police officer, and that led to the arrest of a neighbor, the police said on Saturday.

headline: The Great Gerrymander of 2012
abstract: Congress doesn’t reflect the people’s vote.
lead_paragraph: HAVING the first modern democracy comes with bugs. Normally we would expect more seats in Congress to go to the political party that receives more votes, but the last election confounded expectations. Democrats received 1.4 million more votes for the House of Representatives, yet Republicans won control of the House by a 234 to 201 margin. This is only the second such reversal since World War II.

headline: Imbalance of Power
abstract: The party that gets the most votes usually wins the most seats in Congress, but that did not happen in the November election in states with gerrymandered districts.
lead_paragraph: The party that gets the most votes usually wins the most seats in Congress, but that did not happen in the November election in states with gerrymandered districts.

headline: The Horses of War
abstract: The Civil War was in many ways an equine war.
lead_paragraph: The Civil War is not normally called a horse’s war, but it most certainly was: cavalry and artillery horses, draft and pack horses and mules, approximately one million on the Union side alone. The seat of war was also the lap of America’s horse culture – or, rather, cultures, north and south.

headline: On Loss and Regret
abstract: Remorse now hangs like an albatross: you should have tried harder to make special occasions for her.
lead_paragraph: YOU’RE in Florence and you want to buy something, say, a rare perfume, for your mother in the States. You know which store she would like and that she will both wear this scent and treasure it, the way older people know how to be frugal and extravagant at the same time. But as you’re about to buy it, you already poison the gift with this thought: the day will come, perhaps sooner than you know, when you will have to clean out her house before giving her things away and you will find the selfsame bottle there, at once oblivious or indifferent to the tragedy that has occurred, the scent still summoning up the smile you imagined on her face as you roamed that dark, large store by Santa Maria Novella on that sunny day when you said, “Why not, it’ll make her happy.”

headline: Dangerous Gun Myths
abstract: The idea that weapons make women and homes safer is wrong. The opposite is true.
lead_paragraph: The debate over what to do to reduce gun violence in America hit an absurd low point on Wednesday when a Senate witness tried to portray a proposed new ban on assault rifles and high-capacity magazines as some sort of sexist plot that would disproportionately hurt vulnerable women and their children.

headline: The Way Out
abstract: Five players in the Super Bowl come from a conflicted region of Florida known as Muck City, where football can open a window for escape.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers take the field during the Super Bowl today, the teams will have five players who come from a small, conflicted region in the northern Everglades known as Muck City. The dark, silty soil surrounding the Florida towns of Belle Glade and Pahokee, some 45 miles west of Palm Beach, creates a fertile region for agriculture.

headline: Nagging Concerns Before the Big Game
abstract: As President Obama pointed out, football must change because of the long-term damage from concussions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama injected some reality into the endless Super Bowl rituals glorifying the game with his candid remarks about the long-term damage from concussions suffered on the playing field. Mr. Obama said the sport will most likely have to change in order to reduce the traumatic hits that can leave players suffering dementia years after their careers have ended.

headline: A Cruel Blow to American Families
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', "State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Editorials']
abstract: Millions of dependents may suffer because of the I.R.S.’s needlessly strict reading of the health care law.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service has issued a hugely disappointing ruling on how to calculate the affordability of health insurance offered by employers. Its needlessly strict interpretation of the Affordable Care Act could leave millions of Americans with modest incomes unable to afford family coverage under their employers’ health insurance but ineligible for subsidies to buy coverage elsewhere.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Immigration and Emigration']

lead_paragraph: Justice Anthony Kennedy regards himself as a teacher. The main role of the Supreme Court, he has said, is to instruct Americans about the Constitution’s fundamental values so they know what it takes to preserve American democracy.

headline: A Fan Who Knows How It Feels to Win
abstract: Michael Phelps, 27, who retired after last summer’s London Games with 22 Olympic medals for his career, will be at Super Bowl XLVII, cheering on his hometown Ravens.
lead_paragraph: At the 2008 Beijing Olympics, the swimmer Michael Phelps took time out from his pursuit of Mark Spitz’s gold medal record to talk about his N.F.L. fantasy draft. Born and bred in Baltimore, Phelps counts as one of his most cherished mementos from Beijing a Ravens jersey, signed by all the players, which he received early in his race to eight gold medals.

headline: My Grandfather the Outlaw
abstract: Chapters in the immigration saga change. The risks and hopes stay the same.
lead_paragraph: MY father’s father embodied the American dream. His is the kind of story trumpeted from the stages of our political conventions, the kind of life held up as an affirmation of the rewards this country holds for people willing to take chances, work like crazy and insist on something better for their children than they themselves ever knew.

headline: Why Police Lie Under Oath
abstract: Perversely, the criminal justice system gives officers an incentive to perjure themselves.
lead_paragraph: THOUSANDS of people plead guilty to crimes every year in the United States because they know that the odds of a jury’s believing their word over a police officer’s are slim to none. As a juror, whom are you likely to believe: the alleged criminal in an orange jumpsuit or two well-groomed police officers in uniforms who just swore to God they’re telling the truth, the whole truth and nothing but? As one of my colleagues recently put it, “Everyone knows you have to be crazy to accuse the police of lying.”

headline: Genomic Analysis, the Office Edition
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Computers and the Internet', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment']
abstract: A new computer, made by a company called Knome, is the size of a file cabinet and can filter a person’s genetic information, possibly yielding insights into cancer or other diseases.
lead_paragraph: THE price of sequencing a person’s genome — putting in order all three billion base pairs of DNA in a set of human chromosomes — keeps dropping. But interpreting the billions of letters in a person’s DNA blueprint for use in medicine, and keeping that highly personal information secure and anonymous, is still a complex task.

headline: The Boys at the Back
abstract: Boys are being left behind in educational advancement. We need to address the reasons.
lead_paragraph: Boys score as well as or better than girls on most standardized tests, yet they are far less likely to get good grades, take advanced classes or attend college. Why? A study coming out this week in The Journal of Human Resources gives an important answer. Teachers of classes as early as kindergarten factor good behavior into grades — and girls, as a rule, comport themselves far better than boys.

headline: On Ice at Soldier Field, ‘It’s Like You’re a Kid Again’

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The weather was picturesque for hockey at Soldier Field on Friday. Snow fell on a clear and cold winter night on the shore of Lake Michigan. The rest of the scene was less conventional. Two teams made up of adult recreational league players, some who only recently learned the sport, skated before more than 60,000 empty seats.

lead_paragraph: UNLESS lawmakers act by March 1, the budget sequestration process will start cutting government spending automatically — reductions that would amount to $1.2 trillion by 2021. Studies have shown that poor managers can cause good employees to leave and, ultimately, can seriously reduce productivity in a workplace.

headline: Stormy Weather: Blues in Winter
abstract: Like many New Yorkers, I am having a delayed response to Hurricane Sandy. It continues to return, flooding my psyche, whenever events show up as severe and unyielding.
lead_paragraph: I have been trying to get a grip on my winter blues. Philosophy has a long history of handling the experience of distressed states. The ancients were concerned with stand-out types of psychic debilitation; Descartes, Kant, and Nietzsche probed, each in his own way, into the dark side of mood and temperament; Kierkegaard passed the mic to fear and trembling; Heidegger based his existential analyses on anxiety; and Sartre drilled down on sheer nothingness. Philosophers wondered whether it was possible to feel at-home in the world, given our basic homelessness — a predicament that many of them saw as the uprooted nature of our dwelling on this earth. I count on these abyss-gazers to land me safely, without much illusion, and somehow to keep me going, even if the trek is bound to be mournful.

headline: A ‘Macbeth’ Mash-Up
abstract: Hearing the Scottish play through middle school ears — and mouths.
lead_paragraph: TEACHERS and education experts often ask what a particular reform or innovation looks like in the classroom. We say the classroom, as if an ideal classroom exists that somehow resembles every other classroom in America. In reality, every classroom has its own dynamic, and every class I’ve ever taught looks different from every other class. Perhaps more important, they also sound different.

headline: To Do the Expected, the U.S. Is Bracing for the Unexpected
abstract: The United States men’s soccer team has played in six consecutive World Cups, but there are no guarantees in the Concacaf region as the final round of qualifying for 2014 is about to begin.
lead_paragraph: The taut drama of the World Cup can be enjoyed only by teams that emerge from the more rugged slog of regional qualifying, and though the United States is a tournament regular now, having participated in the previous six editions, regarding qualification as a formality still feels like a taboo.

headline: Upside of Distraction
abstract: How my monomaniacal devotion to writing poisoned my work.
lead_paragraph: Writing a book consists largely of avoiding distractions. If you can forget your real circumstances and submerge yourself in your subject for hours every day, characters become more human, sentences become clearer and prettier. But utter devotion to the principle that distraction is Satan and writing is paramount can be just as poisonous as an excess of diversion. I tried to make writing my only god, and it sickened my work, for a while. The condition endemic to my generation, attention deficit disorder, gave way to its insidious Victorian foil: monomania.

headline: Self-Reliance, Learned Early
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Amber Alert', 'Global Positioning System']
abstract: A chief executive learned as a girl that no job was beneath her — and that no job was above her, either.
lead_paragraph: I’M the oldest of six. My dad was an engineer at Xerox and started his own medical technology company on the side, which was ahead of its time and did well. When I was an adolescent, we moved from Rochester to Arizona, where he started a second company, which sold an oil-based product used in items like sinks and bathtubs.   That company failed as a result of the 1970s oil embargo.
