headline: In Hard Economy for All Ages, Older Isn’t Better ... It’s Brutal
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Baby Boomers', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Discrimination', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Recent data present a strong case for baby boomers as the greatest victims of the recession and its grim aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Young graduates are in debt, out of work and on their parents’ couches. People in their 30s and 40s can’t afford to buy homes or have children. Retirees are earning near-zero interest on their savings.

headline: Gun Control Group Buys Ad Time for Super Bowl
abstract: The 30-second spot by Mayors Against Illegal Guns will run on CBS stations in the Washington D.C. market in an effort to push Congress to pass universal background checks on all gun purchases.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s leading gun control groups has bought television time during Sunday’s Super Bowl in an effort to push Congress to pass universal background checks on all firearm purchases.

headline: For the Niners’ Punter, Remaining on the Sidelines Is a Good Thing
abstract: Andy Lee, the All-Pro punter for the 49ers, finds he has more time on his hands, thanks the team’s explosive offense.
lead_paragraph: In Andy Lee’s first seven seasons, the San Francisco 49ers went 39-73. As the team’s punter he was called on to bail out the struggling offense time and again, a skill he mastered. The 2004 sixth-round draft pick led the N.F.L. in punts three times and punting yards twice. He became a perennial All-Pro and Pro Bowler, and one of the league’s top directional punters.

headline: Letter From Consumer and Civil Liberties Groups on Privacy Laws
abstract: A coalition of American advocacy groups composed a letter to senior Obama administration officials seeking to bridge a divide in the way the United States and Europe handle the protection of people’s personal information.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of American advocacy groups composed a letter to senior Obama administration officials seeking to bridge a divide in the way the United States and Europe handle the protection of people’s personal information.

headline: Woman Found Dead After Vanishing on Vacation in Istanbul
abstract: The body of Sarai Sierra, 33, of Staten Island, was discovered near a major road along the ancient walls of a city she was visiting alone, a news agency said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Staten Island woman who failed to return home from a vacation alone in Turkey last month, setting off a frantic search by American and Turkish authorities, was found dead on Saturday, according to her family and the Turkish authorities.

headline: Louisiana’s N.F.L. Success
abstract: For years the Bayou State has sent more players to the N.F.L. than any other state per capita. Local football coaches explain the reasons why.
lead_paragraph: For years the Bayou State has sent more players to the N.F.L. than any other state per capita. Local football coaches explain the reasons why.

headline: Iran’s Space Agency Confirms Reports on Launch Used Images of Two Different Monkeys
abstract: A senior official at Iran’s space agency confirmed on Saturday that state media reports on the launching of a monkey into the thermosphere had used images of two different monkeys.
lead_paragraph: A senior official at Iran’s space agency confirmed on Saturday that state media reports on the launching of a monkey into the thermosphere had used images of two different monkeys. The official insisted, however, that the monkey had survived the journey and that Iran was not trying to cover up a failed flight.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 3
abstract: The Sunday political shows feature conversations about gun control, Chuck Hagel’s nomination hearings and immigration reform — including President Obama’s interviews with two Hispanic media organizations.
lead_paragraph: Gun control, the military and immigration take center stage on the Sunday shows this week.

headline: A Whiff of Cologne
abstract: Sunday with Dan Schoenholz.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Wilkommen to the German version of The New York Times. Just kidding, but we do have an interesting puzzle by Dan Schoenholz that gives us a whiff of some words of German origin that have been adapted (some more than others) into the English language. Some people don’t mind when foreign words are used in an American crossword puzzle, and I fall into that group. However, I can think of at least one person I know who will do this puzzle and get ticked off by the fact that the entire theme is made up of words in another language. Whatever floats your boat, I say. There’s always a new puzzle tomorrow.

headline: Hey, Beyoncé, It’s Your Look, but Maybe His Moment
abstract: For Rubin Singer, the designer of Beyoncé Knowles’s Super Bowl outfit, the gig could have legs for his business.
lead_paragraph: FOR THE LAST MONTH Rubin Singer has savored the thought that he was asked by Beyoncé Knowles to design her outfit for her Super Bowl performance on Sunday. Mr. Singer is a little known designer in New York — “I don’t feel new, but I am,” he said — and he has stayed tight-lipped on the design, while wondering what the mega-exposure could mean to his career.

headline: Interview With Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Excerpts from the interview with Hillary Rodham Clinton as she left the post of secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton was interviewed by Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler on Thursday, her second-to-last day as secretary of state. Below are excerpts from the interview, which was conducted in her State Department office. Some of the questions have been edited for brevity.

headline: With Modern Facility, England Must Update Mind-Set
abstract: The England Football Association now has a modern complex at St George’s Park, but that does not cure an ingrained national soccer malaise.
lead_paragraph: An evocative mosaic depicting legendary England players and iconic moments of past glories greets visitors to the English Football Association’s new St George’s Park facility.

headline: Militants’ Goal in Algeria Gas Plant Siege: Giant Fireball
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Hostages', 'Explosions', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Natural Gas', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Heavily armed fighters who seized a desert complex on Jan. 16 sought to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a bomb. What none of them knew was how, in the vast maze of metal, to do it.
lead_paragraph: TIGUENTOURINE, Algeria — The goal of the heavily armed militants who seized the desert gas plant here is becoming increasingly clear: to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a giant bomb, and to blow up everything and anyone around. What none of them knew was exactly how, in the endless maze of metal, to do it.

headline: Twitter End to Love Story Born in Russia’s Protests
abstract: Russia’s glamorous political-opposition couple, Kseniya Sobchak and Ilya Yashin, are no more. Ms. Sobchak has surprised Moscow by marrying another man.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Into the swirl of riot police officers they marched side by side as the Romeo and Juliet of the revolution — inspiring, fearless and beautiful on the streets of Moscow.

headline: Koch’s Lunch Mates Convene Without Him, and He’s Still the Center of Attention
abstract: Edward I. Koch’s friends carried on a tradition that began in the mid-1960s, meeting for a weekly gathering that this time included anecdotes of the former mayor.
lead_paragraph: Edward I. Koch’s weekly luncheon club convened as usual on Saturday, but with a few differences.

headline: Iceland, Fervent Prosecutor of Bankers, Sees Meager Returns
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: In a country that has gone after financiers with far more vigor than others hit by the financial crisis, obtaining convictions has proved devilishly difficult.
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — As chief of police in a tiny fishing town for 11 years, Olafur Hauksson developed what he thought was a basic understanding of the criminal mind. The typical lawbreaker, he said, recalling his many encounters with small-time criminals, “clearly knows that he crossed the line” and generally sees “the difference between right and wrong.”

headline: Morton’s Murder Conviction Comes to Define Anderson
abstract: As Ken Anderson faces a court of inquiry about the murder case that wrongly convicted Michael Morton, Mr. Anderson’s longtime associates say they have difficulty believing he behaved unethically.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the 1960s, Ken Anderson admired the great trial lawyers in movies: Gregory Peck in “To Kill a Mockingbird” and Spencer Tracy in “Inherit the Wind.” The good guys who broke down lying thugs on the stand.

headline: Lawmakers Aim to Limit Drones and Safeguard Privacy
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Privacy', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A bill would make it a misdemeanor to use the miniature aircraft used by hobbyists and law enforcement authorities to take video or photographs of private property.
lead_paragraph: A drone, no bigger than a toy airplane, hovered north of the Texas Capitol, floating over the heads of lawmakers who were momentarily distracted from their morning meetings. Several of them gathered beneath it, faces tilted skyward, marveling over a pair of goggles that allowed them to watch live video of the craft’s panoramic bird’s-eye view.

headline: Plenty of Money in State Coffers, but Not to Spend
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The state has an unexpected $8.8 billion two years after it cut programs and services to meet a shortfall. But it is being held back by self-imposed caps.
lead_paragraph: ​​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: The World’s No. 1 Player Breaks His Own Record
abstract: In winning the Tata Steel tournament, Magnus Carlsen increased his rating to 2,872 points, the highest in history and better than his previous record-setting number.
lead_paragraph: Magnus Carlsen produced another dominating performance last month at the Tata Steel tournament in the Netherlands.

headline: Disgraced Owner, but What About Cadillac Ranch?
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: With the oil heir Stanley Marsh 3 facing trial for sexual abuse, some Texans believe Cadillac Ranch, his art installation and roadside attraction near Amarillo, should be dismantled.
lead_paragraph: Cadillac Ranch, located just off Interstate 40 a few miles west of Amarillo, is one of the most famous roadside attractions in America. The art installation, consisting of 10 tail-finned, brightly painted Cadillacs planted nose down in a pasture, was financed in 1974 by Stanley Marsh 3, the eccentric Panhandle oil heir and arts patron.

headline: Parcells Is Chosen for Pro Football Hall; Strahan Falls Short
abstract: Bill Parcells highlighted a class of seven inductees while another prominent Giant, Michael Strahan, failed to make the cut in his first year of eligibility.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Bill Parcells, the only coach to lead four teams to the playoffs and the winner of two Super Bowls with the Giants, highlighted a class of seven inductees to the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday.

headline: Battered California Republicans Find Hope in a Long Shot
abstract: Kevin L. James, a gay Republican, is a candidate for mayor of Los Angeles, and members of his party see an outside chance to grab what could be a spirit-lifting victory.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Kevin L. James, a conservative talk show host running for mayor of Los Angeles, was sitting in his campaign office recently pondering which was his bigger obstacle to victory: being openly Republican, or being openly gay.

headline: A Career With Many Stops but Only One True Home
abstract: Bill Parcells, who contributed to the success of five N.F.L. franchises, was defined by his two Super Bowl titles when he coached the Giants.
lead_paragraph: Most members of the Pro Football Hall of Fame have two or three team logos in their past, but Bill Parcells was elected Saturday with five on his résumé: coach of the Giants, the Patriots, the Jets and the Cowboys before joining the Dolphins as director of football operations.

headline: Drowned in a Stream of Prescriptions
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'ADDERALL (DRUG)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: A young man’s suicide highlights issues in the treatment of A.D.H.D., as youths fake symptoms to feed their addictions to potentially dangerous stimulants.
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH — Every morning on her way to work, Kathy Fee holds her breath as she drives past the squat brick building that houses Dominion Psychiatric Associates.

headline: Japanese Premier Won’t Take Step in Relocating U.S. Base Before Meeting Obama
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is caught between trying to improve relations with the United States and opposition on Okinawa to an American military presence.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said Saturday that he would not immediately ask the Okinawan authorities for approval to begin constructing a long-stalled American air base, casting doubt on his government’s hopes to show progress in a troubled base-relocation plan ahead of his planned trip to Washington later this month.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning numbers for Feb. 2, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Stephen Simon, Conductor Who Led a Handel Revival, Dies at 75
abstract: The founder of the resident chamber orchestra of the Kennedy Center, Mr. Simon showed audiences that there was more to a composer than the “Messiah.”
lead_paragraph: Stephen Simon, a conductor who in the 1970s and afterward helped spirit the Handel revival into being in the United States, died on Jan. 20 in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Egyptian League and Fans Try to Heal With Help From an American Coach
abstract: Bob Bradley, the American coach of the Egyptian national soccer team, has immersed himself in Egyptian society since 74 people were killed during a league match last February.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — It took only 12 minutes for Al Ahly to score the Egyptian soccer league’s first goal in 366 long and bloody days.

headline: Many High Schools Still Allow Full-Contact Practices in Off-Season
abstract: At a time when concern is mounting about football-related injuries, at least 29 high school athletic associations permit full-contact practices in the off-season.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has been working to address the issue of concussions and brain trauma by pouring millions of dollars into research, changing on-field rules and adding medical staff during games. Notably, the league has also limited the number of full-contact practices during the season.

headline: Caltech Ends Losing Streak at 228
abstract: The California Institute of Technology hadn’t won a game in nearly 10 years.
lead_paragraph: The baseball team at California Institute of Technology broke a 228-game losing streak Saturday with a 9-7 nonconference victory over Pacifica. The team last won on Feb. 15, 2003.

headline: Charlotte Smallwood-Cook, a Pioneering District Attorney, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Smallwood-Cook, who won her office in a landslide victory, had to defy Republican Party political bosses in Wyoming County, N.Y., to run in a 1949 primary.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Smallwood-Cook, who is believed to have been the first woman elected a district attorney in New York State, died on Jan. 26 in Batavia, N.Y. She was 90.

headline: Lady Malcolm Douglas-Hamilton, American Who Aided Britain in War, Dies at 103
abstract: A Manhattan socialite, she started Bundles for Britain, which became an enormous World War II relief operation.
lead_paragraph: In 1939, Lady Malcolm Douglas-Hamilton, who died on Jan. 14 at 103, had neither that title nor that name. She was Natalie Latham, a fixture of Manhattan society whose beauty drew notice in Vogue magazine. She had achieved a dollop of fame when she and her two young daughters, nicknamed Mimi and Bubbles, appeared together in matching swimwear in a Life magazine photo spread, having captivated a photographer at a beach club one day.

headline: Stoudemire Gives Knicks Jolt in Their Blowout of Kings
abstract: After missing 12 of their first 13 shots, the Knicks’ offense kicked into gear behind Amar’e Stoudemire’s 10-of-10 shooting and ended up with a 39-point margin of victory.
lead_paragraph: In the Knicks’ lexicon this season, few terms are as forbidding as “back to back” — as in games played on consecutive nights. This was the test they had before them this weekend, and for the Knicks, it has not always been easy to limber up two days in a row.

headline: Top Donors to Republicans Seek More Say in Senate Races
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Campaign Finance', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: The Republican Party’s biggest donors are financing a new group to recruit seasoned candidates and protect Senate incumbents from challenges by far-right conservatives and Tea Party enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — The biggest donors in the Republican Party are financing a new group to recruit seasoned candidates and protect Senate incumbents from challenges by far-right conservatives and Tea Party enthusiasts who Republican leaders worry could complicate the party’s efforts to win control of the Senate.

headline: Lunch for Hizzoner
abstract: At their weekly lunch, friends and colleagues of Edward I. Koch now have one seat missing around the table. However, they decided not to let the former mayor's death break a tradition.
lead_paragraph: At their weekly lunch, friends and colleagues of Edward I. Koch now have one seat missing around the table. However, they decided not to let the former mayor's death break a tradition.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Feb. 3
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Feb. 3.
lead_paragraph: "When you’re older, they just see gray hair and they write you off.”

headline: Carolyn Aishton, Gerald Ouderkirk Jr.
abstract: The couple is married in New York.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Euretta Aishton and Gerald Baker Ouderkirk Jr. were married Saturday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber, an associate pastor at the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Nicole Fitlow and Haran Rashes
abstract: The couple have timed the start of their reception to the Super Bowl kickoff.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Elizabeth Fitlow and Haran Craig Rashes are to be married Sunday in Livonia, Mich. Rabbi Kim Blumenthal is to officiate at the Detroit Marriott Livonia.

headline: Lisa Schwartz and David Jacobsen
abstract: The bride and groom share a birth date.
lead_paragraph: Finding a Bohemian (With a Day Job)

headline: Elizabeth Ambrose and Steven Johnson
abstract: The couple was married in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Jane Ambrose, a daughter of Jeannie V. Ambrose and Edward F. Ambrose Jr. of Oakmont, Pa., was married Friday evening to Steven Paul Johnson, the son of Diane L. Johnson and Ashton J. Johnson of Youngsville, La., at St. Peter’s on Capitol Hill, a Roman Catholic church in Washington. The Rev. William Byrne, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Adriana Salazar and Ben Lopez
abstract: The couple are married on the Duke University campus, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Ignoring the Invitation’s Fine Print

headline: Gitika Ahuja and Rajeev Kaul
abstract: The couple is married in Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: Serenade on a Secluded Beach

headline: Carrie Drazan and Howard Hersch
abstract: The couple were married on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Erin Drazan, the daughter of Cheryl A. Drazan and Andrew M. Drazan of Old Brookville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Howard Scott Hersch, the son of Harriet K. Hersch and Ronald M. Hersch of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Cantor Richard Berman officiated at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

headline: Corrections: February 3, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 3, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: In Villages, Praying for the Souls of Tibetan Self-Immolators
abstract: With the number of self-immolations by Tibetans hovering at around 100, an eyewitness describes the large prayer meetings for the souls of the dead taking place in villages in Tibetan regions of China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Since November, when winter began in the high Tibetan Plateau, thousands of Tibetan villagers have been gathering daily to pray for the souls of the nearly 100 Tibetans who have burned themselves to death in protest over Chinese rule, in a show of widespread support for the self-immolators among ordinary people, according to witness testimony from a person recently returned from the region.

headline: ‘Wreck-It Ralph’ Scores Big at Annie Awards
abstract: Annie Awards voters gave “Wreck-It Ralph” five trophies on Saturday night, including one for best feature.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Wreck-It Ralph” is headed to the Oscar podium, at least if the animation industry’s biggest awards gala is any indicator. Annie Awards voters gave it five trophies on Saturday night, including one for best feature.

headline: Dozens Die in Attack on Police in Iraqi City
abstract: An assault on a provincial police headquarters in Kirkuk by a suicide car bomber and other attackers left at least 35 people dead and dozens wounded, the police said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A suicide car bomber attacked a provincial police headquarters in the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk on Sunday morning, the police and the city’s civil defense director said, killing at least 36 people and wounding 105. Three other suicide attackers who tried to enter the police headquarters after the blast were killed by the police.

headline: Affleck Rides On at Directors Guild Awards
abstract: The Directors Guild of America gave Ben Affleck its top feature film award for “Argo,” his third movie.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Directors Guild of America anointed Ben Affleck as its filmmaker of the year for “Argo,” his third film.

headline: Pollution in China
abstract: Fresh air is a casualty of China’s economic expansion.
lead_paragraph: Fresh air is a casualty of China’s economic expansion.

headline: Super Bowl: Do You Speak Football?
abstract: The Super Bowl speaks to all of us in different ways, but first, you have to at least be fluent in the jargon of the game.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl speaks to all of us in different ways, but first, you have to at least be fluent in football.

headline: Untouchable in Iraq, Ex-Sniper Dies in a Shooting Back Home
abstract: Chris Kyle, a former Navy SEAL, had taken a troubled fellow veteran to a gun range for a kind of therapy session, but the police said the man turned his gun on Mr. Kyle.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — From his perch in hide-outs above battle-scarred Iraq, Chris Kyle earned a reputation as one of America’s deadliest military snipers. The Pentagon said his skills with a rifle so terrorized Iraqi insurgents during his four tours of duty that they nicknamed him the “Devil of Ramadi” and put a bounty on his head.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Leave the Building
abstract: G.D.P. slips. Optimism rises. And the intrigue continues at Downton Arby’s. Will immigration reform help your business?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Despicable Me
abstract: I welcome your hatred!
lead_paragraph: Funny: Angry Bear finds some of the usual suspects explaining How to Debate Paul Krugman, and the answer appears to be this: invent a straw man who bears no resemblance at all to the economist/columnist of the same name, and ridicule that imaginary person.

headline: How Does Job Loss Affect Life Expectancy?
abstract: Phillip Levine, an economist at Wellesley College, is taking readers’ questions about the link between losing a job and living a shorter life.
lead_paragraph: Phillip B. Levine is an economics professor at Wellesley College and an associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research, an affiliate of the National Poverty Center. Last fall he was one of the authors of a study that adds a health dimension to the idea that baby boomers are the greatest victims of the Great Recession. Dr. Levine and his co-authors, Courtney C. Coile and Robin McKnight, concluded that the life expectancy of boomers ages 57 to 61 who lose their jobs — and health insurance — may be decreased by as much as three years. However, the life expectancy of those 62 and older who lose jobs is unaffected — in part because Social Security and Medicare provide a safety net to cushion the blow.

headline: Pepsi’s Next Coke Parody Involves Pepsi Next
abstract: On Sunday, about nine and a half hours before kickoff, PepsiCo Beverages plans to unleash a comical video clip for Pepsi Next that tweaks the commercial planned during the game for Coca-Cola.
lead_paragraph: 5:00 p.m. | Updated One of the two combatants in the cola-wars battle to be waged Sunday night during Super Bowl XLVII is trying to get an early jump on the other.

headline: When ‘Help’ With Homework Is Too Much
abstract: I’ve always been “on call” for homework help. I never thought of it as “cheating” in any way – but one of my daughter’s schoolteachers did.
lead_paragraph: I’d always thought that being a parent is, in part, a teaching job.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY BOWL IX Sixty-three of the cutest bruisers around, rescued from shelters across the country, go in for tackles, fumbles and “Fido first downs,” above (and vie for the title of M.V.P., as in Most Valuable Puppy), at Geico Stadium. Dan Schachner calls plays and penalties as the Ref; stars from the series “Finding Bigfoot,” “Tanked” and “Call of the Wildman” provide analysis and commentary. A hedgehog pep squad cheers from the sidelines; Meep the Bird tweets the action online. Aerial coverage is provided by the Ice Breakers blimp and its hamster crew. Sloppier ground-level angles are offered by the ever-popular water-bowl camera; an upgraded puppy cam, to watch the action from the players’ perspective; and the kiss cam. Not to be missed: the Kitty Halftime Show. The action is repeated at two-hour intervals throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: ‘Warm Bodies’ Leads on a Cold Weekend for Movies
abstract: The Super Bowl often hurts business at movie box offices, and this year has been no exception.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl usually takes a bite out of moviegoing, but yikes: Despite one successful counterprogramming effort — “Warm Bodies,” aimed at teenage girls, opened to solid results — total ticket sales for the weekend fell 24 percent compared with last year, which was also a very slow box-office period. The biggest casualty was Sylvester Stallone, whose unfortunately titled “Bullet to the Head” (Warner Brothers) took in an anemic $4.5 million, for sixth place, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

headline: United States and Mexico Reach Tomato Deal, Averting a Trade War
abstract: An agreement raises the minimum price at which Mexican tomatoes can be sold in the United States, narrowly averting a trade war that threatened to engulf a broad swath of American businesses.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Mexico have reached a tentative agreement on cross-border trade in tomatoes, narrowly averting a trade war that threatened to engulf a swath of American businesses.

headline: Study Discovers Internal Trigger for Panic Attack in the Previously Fearless
abstract: An experiment involving a woman incapable of experiencing fear because of brain damage suggests a different path for signals generated by internal bodily stress like heart attacks.
lead_paragraph: In the past few years, scientists have learned a lot about fear from a woman who could not experience it. A rare illness had damaged a part of her brain known as the amygdala and left her eerily unafraid.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Snow White’s Children Top the List
abstract: “Cubs in Toyland,” the latest volume of “Fables,” is No. 1 on the paperback list.
lead_paragraph: At No. 1 on the graphic books paperback best-seller list this week is Volume 18 of “Fables,” by Bill Willingham and Mark Buckingham. “Fables,” published by DC Comics, is about storybook characters (from Cinderella to Pinocchio) making their way in the modern world. The ongoing series reaches issue No. 125 this month with an adventure about the Big Bad Wolf, who is learning to drive, and Snow White. In the world of “Fables,” the Wolf and Snow are married and have had children, two of whom take center stage in this volume, titled “Cubs in Toyland.” It’s difficult to say too much without spoiling the story, but their daughter Therese goes off on an adventure that has some dire consequences. It starts out as a trip to an island of misfit toys, but the playthings have a very sad secret.

headline: Which G.O.P. House Members Might Support Immigration Reform?
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Most House Republicans come from districts that are both very conservative and overwhelmingly white. The ones who don’t could be pivotal to the passage of any immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: Last Monday, a bipartisan group of eight senators agreed to a set of overarching principles for immigration reform. On Tuesday, President Obama traveled to Las Vegas to outline his own proposals. Mr. Obama’s speech was followed by reports that a bipartisan group of representatives in the House were hashing out a set of measures.

headline: Candidate for President of Paraguay Dies in Crash
abstract: The death on Saturday of Lino Oviedo, 69, one of Paraguay’s most polarizing political figures, opens a new phase of uncertainty in one of Latin America’s most politically unstable countries.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Lino Oviedo, a candidate in Paraguay’s presidential election and one of the country’s most polarizing political figures, was killed in a helicopter crash on Saturday night while returning from a rally in northern Paraguay, government officials said Sunday.

headline: Live Analysis of Super Bowl XLVII: Ravens 34, 49ers 31
abstract: Ben Hoffman, Andrew Das and a host of Times reporters, photographers and editors offer live coverage and analysis of the N.F.L. championship game, the commercials and the halftime show.
lead_paragraph: Ben Hoffman, Andrew Das and a host of Times reporters, photographers and editors provided live coverage and analysis of the N.F.L. championship game, the commercials and the halftime show. Readers also got to rate the ads and saw how their predictions fared in the Crystal Bowl prediction game.

headline: Reina Gives City a Point, but Not Much Hope
abstract: Manchester City’s Sergio Aguero rescued a point on Sunday against Liverpool in England’s Premier League.
lead_paragraph: Manchester City’s Sergio Agüero rescued a point on Sunday against Liverpool in England’s Premier League, but little else.

headline: Tabasco’s Ties to Football Burn Deep
abstract: The family behind Tabasco sauce, which is made about 150 miles west of New Orleans, has deep ties to sports.
lead_paragraph: AVERY ISLAND, La. — Walter Stauffer McIlhenny, the fourth chief executive of the McIlhenny Co., the makers of Tabasco sauce, was a farsighted risk taker. The son of one of Theodore Roosevelt’s Rough Riders, he was an expert marksman who was wounded at Guadalcanal in 1942. He did not have the bullet in his leg removed until the next year so he could keep fighting.

headline: Raising Voices and Awareness for Overlooked Works
abstract: The Da Capo Chamber Players performed works by five black composers, anticipating the traditional observance of Black History Month by a few days.
lead_paragraph: In the program notes provided for the latest concert by the Da Capo Chamber Players at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday, Patricia Spencer, a flutist and the sole remaining member of the group’s original 1970 personnel, offered an unusually candid and personal essay to explain the evening’s offering.

headline: From State to State, Varied Responses to the Issue of Gun Violence
abstract: More than a dozen governors invoked the Newtown, Conn.,  shooting as they opened their legislative sessions. But the debate has not always followed party lines.
lead_paragraph: Although the debate over curbing gun violence after the massacre in Newtown, Conn., is breaking down mostly along partisan lines in the nation’s statehouses — with several Democratic governors calling for stricter gun laws and most Republicans urging tighter security or revamped mental health policies — the handful of exceptions show the political and geographical complexities of the issue.

headline: 2 Top Officers at Barclays to Step Down
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: Barclays says its chief financial officer and its general counsel are leaving, the latest in a wave of departures at the British banking giant.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Barclays said on Sunday that its chief financial officer and its general counsel would resign, the latest departures after the British bank’s involvement in a series of scandals, including an investigation into the manipulation of global interest rates.

headline: Israeli Strike Into Syria Said to Damage Research Site
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The weapons research center has been the target of sanctions because of intelligence suggesting that it was the training site for engineers who worked on chemical and biological weaponry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Israeli attack last week on a Syrian convoy of antiaircraft weapons appears to have damaged the country’s main research center for work on biological and chemical weapons, according to American officials who are sorting through intelligence reports.

headline: More Literary Remixes From a Mash-Up Artist
abstract: In his new book, David Shields gets down to what has become his usual business, dismissing the conventional novel and memoir and championing art that blurs the idea of genre.
lead_paragraph: The most generous reaction to David Shields’s recent books would be to assume they are straight-faced parodies in the vein of those performed by Joaquin Phoenix or Andy Kaufman, sly commentaries on the culture’s already rampant solipsism. But all signs are that he’s serious.

headline: Official Says Iran Is Open to New Round of Nuclear Talks
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Ali Akbar Salehi, Iran’s foreign minister, restated a call for direct talks with Washington, but his comments were viewed as more atmospheric than definitive.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Iran’s foreign minister said Sunday that his country was open to a renewed offer of direct talks with the United States on its nuclear program and that it looked favorably on a proposal for a new round of multilateral nuclear negotiations on Feb. 25 in Kazakhstan.

headline: Lawyers Fight to Keep Auction Sellers Anonymous
abstract: The common auction-house practice of granting anonymity to sellers could change, depending on the outcome of an appeal to be heard by a New York State court.
lead_paragraph: New York’s highest court has decided to review a recent ruling that could force the state’s auction industry to end its longstanding practice of keeping sellers’ names anonymous.

headline: Pentagon Expects U.S. to Retain Presence in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Defense Secretary and chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said the United States would sustain a strategic partnership with Afghanistan after the NATO mission ends in 2014.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon’s top civilian and military officials on Sunday expressed an expectation, even a desire, that American troops would remain in Afghanistan after the NATO mission ends in December 2014, although they emphasized that no decision had been made.

headline: Before the Big Game, Indulging in All Things New Orleans
abstract: A crawfish feast fairly summarized a week of Super Bowl gluttony in the Big Easy.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS – You knew it had to start with the crawfish.

headline: Paganini’s Melody, Borrowed for Keyboard
abstract: The composer-pianist Marc-André Hamelin performed his arrangement of Paganini’s Caprice No. 24 in its New York premiere at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: The theme of Paganini’s jaunty Caprice No. 24 has proved irresistible to many classical composers, most famously Rachmaninoff. Like Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations the Caprice has inspired myriad arrangements for instruments as eclectic as marimba, brass ensemble and balalaika.

headline: On Decimated Shore, a Second Life for Christmas Trees
abstract: Thousands of naked Christmas trees have been arranged along the beach in Long Beach, N.Y., as part of an unusual plan to restore the protective dunes washed away by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — It is February, but the smell of Christmas wafts up from the shores of Long Beach these days.

headline: The Author Himself Was a Cat in the Hat
abstract: A tour featuring hats from the collection of Theodor Geisel, also known as Dr. Seuss, will begin Monday at the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue building.
lead_paragraph: The Cat wore a hat. Everyone knows that.

headline: A Moment With the Mayor
abstract: Mitch Landrieu, the mayor of New Orleans, says the Super Bowl has helped New Orleans rebuild. And he picks the 49ers.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In a previous post I noted how there were many spots available at the bar at Sylvain, one of the more popular eating and drinking establishments in the French Quarter these days. Shortly after filing that dispatch, the beaming, triumphant New Orleans mayor, Mitch Landrieu, and his wife, Cheryl, came in, sat next to me and ordered a couple of drinks. He graciously agreed to a quick interview to discuss what this day has been like for him, as well as what he thinks will happen on the field tonight.

headline: Sinewy Sparks and Creative Combustion
abstract: “Mechanics of the Dance Machine,” Karole Armitage’s new work for Armitage Gone! Dance at New York Live Arts, features voyeuristic themes and extreme physical juxtapositions.
lead_paragraph: While working on the choreography for a play about Marie Antoinette, Karole Armitage became turned on by the idea of voyeurism. In Marie’s time the court got to watch the queen dress, eat and sleep; in Ms. Armitage’s premiere of “Mechanics of the Dance Machine,” performed by Armitage Gone! Dance on Thursday at New York Live Arts, the body is on display in no uncertain terms. But even though the dancers wear next to nothing — nude bikinis for the women and short trunks for the men — this dance, with its mix of duets and group sections, remains as distant as a painting.

headline: A Singer Figuring It Out as She Goes Along
abstract: Allison Weiss brought her songs of angst, wit and punch to the Public Assembly in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In 2008 Allison Weiss released an EP called “The Only Girl at an All-Boys Pool Party,” the last song of which was “I Was an Island.” It’s a jagged little number, with scratchy guitars and sweet, yelping vocals, part pop-punk, part confident ’80s rock. The lyrics are imaginative, wounded and direct, and they begin like this:

headline: The Face of America’s Illegal Immigration
abstract: The population of illegal immigrants to the United States is changing. After Mexico, where illegal immigration is slowing, comes Central America and Asia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In my latest Letter From Washington, I write about the “Kumbaya” moment that immigration reform seems to be enjoying — and the certainty that it will not last as the hard work of writing laws gets underway. But who are the illegal immigrants?

headline: Adding Pages to a Songbook
abstract: Cécile McLorin Salvant, Valerie Simpson, Karen Akers and Lea Salonga have appeared at the Lincoln Center American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: Can one astoundingly gifted singer revive a beloved but dormant jazz vocal tradition? They say it takes only one to start a movement. As Cécile McLorin Salvant spun songs into a brilliant silk tapestry at the Allen Room on Saturday evening, I thought, “Here she is.” If anyone can extend the lineage of the Big Three — Billie Holiday, Sarah Vaughan, and Ella Fitzgerald — it is this 23-year-old virtuoso born in Miami to a French mother and a Haitian father and trained in France.

headline: A Test Before the Vows
abstract: The opera “Lalla Roukh” is about a princess who thinks she must choose between a poet and a king.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening Opera Lafayette presented a graceful and witty production of Félicien David’s “Lalla Roukh” at the Rose Theater. This opéra-comique set in Mughal India had fallen into oblivion since its wildly successful premiere in 1862, well ahead of the wave of other French operas like Bizet’s “Pêcheurs de Perles,” Delibes’s “Lakmé” or Meyerbeer’s “Africaine.”

headline: Hit With a Ray Gun
abstract: A lofty puzzle from Randall J. Hartman.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Cox & Rathvon Alert! You love their Acrostics that run here in The New York Times, but the Hex team of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are now also offering their fabulous “Boston Globe” crossword puzzle to puzzleheads for the low, low price of $10.00 annually. If the Acrostics are just not enough Hexing for you, click here to join.

headline: Finding Comfort in Moving Between Old and New
abstract: Melissa Aldana, a 24-year-old tenor saxophonist, wants to show you how much she knows of the jazz tradition and how authoritatively she can play it.
lead_paragraph: There was a time not long ago, before major-record labels almost completely cut their losses with jazz, when young bandleaders were busy covering bases and making cases. They wanted to show you how much they knew of the jazz tradition and how authoritatively they could play it. These were defensive actions, and also perhaps the last manifestations of hope that jazz could have a general listenership.

headline: Shakespeare’s Mighty Sorority
abstract: The topic at hand in “Women of Will” is the burning issue of pants versus dresses, which assumes genuine urgency.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is hardly the first thing on Tina Packer’s mind in “Women of Will,” her impassioned exploration of Shakespeare’s heroines, which opened Sunday night at the Gym at Judson. Yet even in this month, when designers are strutting their wares on runways all over New York, there’s unlikely to be a more compelling demonstration of how clothes make the woman than the one provided by Ms. Packer, a longtime, multifarious interpreter of Shakespeare.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Feb. 4
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Data to be released includes factory orders for December 0n Monday and fourth-quarter productivity on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include factory orders for December (Monday); the Institute for Supply Management nonmanufacturing index for January (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims, fourth-quarter productivity and consumer credit for December (Thursday); the trade deficit for December and wholesale trade inventories for December (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'States (US)']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Saturday Open Pairs at District 3 Winter Regional
abstract: The winners of the Saturday Open Pairs at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., last month were William Ehlers of Madison, N.J., and Corey Krantz of Drexel Hill, Pa.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the Saturday Open Pairs at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., last month were William Ehlers of Madison, N.J., and Corey Krantz of Drexel Hill, Pa.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Intrigue’s Shadow in a Church
abstract: Minnesota Opera recently finished its premiere run of “Doubt,” the operatic version of John Patrick Shanley’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The playwright John Patrick Shanley had good reason to hesitate when the composer Douglas J. Cuomo proposed that they collaborate on an operatic version of “Doubt,” Mr. Shanley’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play, which had already been reborn as an Oscar-nominated film. The story, claustrophobically set in the parish grounds of a Roman Catholic church in the Bronx and inner-directed in its drama, lacks classic qualities of opera, typically the most extroverted of forms.

headline: 3 Guys Bound by Only a Name
abstract: “David,” a Hindi film directed by Bejoy Nambiar, has three separate protagonists and story lines, set in 1975, 1999 and 2010.
lead_paragraph: Opened on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Unemployed Adman Makes a Deal With His Body
abstract: Álex de la Iglesia’s “As Luck Would Have It” examines marketing and morality through a dejected, unemployed adman.
lead_paragraph: A toothless examination of marketing and morality, Álex de la Iglesia’s “As Luck Would Have It” combines lecture, farce and soapy sentiment in a single misshapen package.

headline: Reformers Aim to Get China to Live Up to Own Constitution
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Constitution guarantees full powers for a representative legislature, the right to ownership of private property, and freedoms of speech, press and assembly.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After the chaos of the Cultural Revolution, the surviving Communist Party leaders pursued a project that might sound familiar to those in the West: Write a constitution that enshrines individual rights and ensures rulers are subject to law, so that China would never again suffer from the whims of a tyrant.

headline: Medical Pay Model: Hospitals and Doctors Weigh In
abstract: Spokesmen for hospital groups and the American Medical Association respond to a column by Bill Keller and an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shunning the Safe, FX Indulges Its Dark Side
abstract: Behind FX’s recent success is its willingness to give its shows creative freedom.
lead_paragraph: The FX channel can be a rugged place, full of prostitutes, charlatans, spies, bikers and thugs. But it’s a nice place if you are trying to make a show.

headline: California’s Hydraulic Fracturing Hotbed
abstract: The Monterey formation in Southern California is partially composed of oil and gas-rich shale plays, areas considered promising for production. As hydraulic fracturing operations expand in the region, the number of wells dotting the landscape may grow from a few hundred to a few thousand.
lead_paragraph: The Monterey formation in Southern California is partially composed of oil and gas-rich shale plays, areas considered promising for production. As hydraulic fracturing operations expand in the region, the number of wells dotting the landscape may grow from a few hundred to a few thousand.

headline: Irish Tycoon Found, Hazy on Abduction
abstract: Kevin McGeever, who made a fortune selling luxury homes in Dubai, disappeared from his mansion in County Galway last May and said he was kidnapped and tortured.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The story of an emaciated, ragged man found wandering barefoot in the middle of a quiet country road last week in County Leitrim, near the border with Northern Ireland, continues to confound the police, even after he was identified as a missing Irish property tycoon who said he was abducted eight months ago and tortured during his captivity.

headline: Diane Wolkstein, Children’s Author Who Spurred a Storytelling Revival, Dies at 70
abstract: During her years a New York City’s lone full-time storyteller, Ms. Wolkstein set off a national wave of interest in the ancient art of the yarn.
lead_paragraph: Diane Wolkstein, a children’s author and folklorist who once upon a time served as New York City’s official storyteller, deputized to revive the dying art in this city of eight million stories, died Thursday in Kaohsiung, Taiwan. She was 70.

headline: Citizen Zhu
abstract: Zhu Ruifeng is a citizen reporter on a mission to expose corruption in China. But his passion for truth has cost him his marriage, and possibly more.
lead_paragraph: Zhu Ruifeng is a citizen reporter on a mission to expose corruption in China. But his passion for truth has cost him his marriage, and possibly more.

headline: Service Is Held for School Bus Driver Who Tried to Prevent Kidnapping in Alabama
abstract: The funeral for Charles Albert Poland Jr., who saved as many children as he could when a kidnapper boarded his bus last week, drew hundreds.
lead_paragraph: OZARK, Ala. — The service for the school bus driver had the feel of a state funeral.

headline: Once BlackBerry Focused, a Campus Widens Its View
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'BlackBerry (Handheld Device)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The University of Waterloo, a world-class engineering school in Canada, is a feeder campus for big-name global tech companies like BlackBerry, a neighbor and Waterloo offshoot.
lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Ontario — The University of Waterloo, in a city that people outside Canada would struggle to find on a map, is one of the world’s best technology schools.

headline: Teen Vogue, a Survivor at 10 Years
abstract: The magazine has outlasted a string of rivals in a sector notable for its audience outgrowing it every few years.
lead_paragraph: After a long day of classes, homework and college preparation, Susannah Davies, a 17-year-old high school junior, takes a break by flipping through her print copy of Teen Vogue, the fashion magazine she has subscribed to since the sixth grade.

headline: The Verge Hires  Writer Who Quit CNET in Protest
abstract: Greg Sandoval said The Verge had given him a “written guarantee from management that nobody from the business side of the company will ever have any authority over my stories.”
lead_paragraph: Greg Sandoval, the CNET senior writer who resigned in protest when the site’s parent company, CBS, interfered with its editorial coverage last month, has been hired by The Verge, the Web site that first revealed the full extent of CBS’s involvement.

headline: André Cassagnes, Etch A Sketch Inventor, Is Dead at 86
abstract: A chance inspiration involving metal particles and the tip of a pencil led Mr. Cassagnes to develop Etch A Sketch in the late 1950s.
lead_paragraph: André Cassagnes, a French electrical technician who half a century ago invented Etch A Sketch, the mechanical drawing toy that has lately become an American political simile, died on Jan. 16 near Paris. He was 86.

headline: A Drug Maker Objects
abstract: Amgen disputes that it lobbied Congress for extension of a patent.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Airlines, Getting Greener
abstract: Airlines for America, a trade organization, responds to a Sunday Review news analysis, “Your Biggest Carbon Sin May Be Air Travel.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Beyoncé’s Super Bowl Outfit
abstract: The costume, by the New York-based designer Rubin Singer, was meant to evoke warrior women.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few details about Beyoncé Knowles’s costume for her Super Bowl halftime performance at the Super Dome in New Orleans. The outfit, by the New York-based designer Rubin Singer, included a cropped black leather motorcycle jacket and a leather bodysuit made with strips of python and iguana, with insets of lace. Mr. Singer, who has worked with Ms. Knowles before, had a Valkyrie in mind. More warrior women. He also designed the costumes for Michelle Williams and 120 backup singers

headline: Late Surge Turns Nail-Biter Into Easy Devils Win
abstract: Unable to solve Islanders goalie Evgeni Nabokov for nearly the entire game, the Devils erupted for three goals in the last few minutes.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Seven games into a lockout-shortened 48-game regular season, the Devils knew they would be tested Sunday. They responded with a stout defensive effort in front of the reserve goalie Johan Hedberg before erupting for three goals in the final 3 minutes 54 seconds in beating the Islanders, 3-0.

headline: Question of Aiding Cyprus Places Germany in a Bind
abstract: As a Russian loan runs out and Cyprus seeks aid, Germany finds itself in a fierce debate over whether to help bail out the island nation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When German officials said they would save the euro zone at all costs, the prospect of bailing out Russian oligarchs was not what they had in mind.

headline: Envisioning Tiny Apartments, No Bathroom Required
abstract: Kids visiting the Museum of the City of New York’s “Making Room” exhibition constructed their own small apartments from buttons, pipe cleaners, construction paper and stickers.
lead_paragraph: Gianluca Polenzani, 6, knows exactly what he wants out of an apartment. There has to be a bed big enough for sleepovers. Two bathrooms would be nice. And he requires at least one air-conditioning unit, preferably a brand he knows and trusts.

headline: After Assad, Chaos?
abstract: Syria’s opposition isn’t credible or prepared.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan

headline: Tax Loopholes May Be Next, Obama Says
abstract: President Obama said the focus of a budget deal in Congress should now be on targeted spending cuts and changes to the tax code.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said in a televised interview on Sunday that he could foresee a budget deal in Congress that did not include further increases in tax rates but instead focused on eliminating loopholes and deductions.

headline: A Chance at Justice in Guatemala
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The trial of Efraín Ríos Montt, the former dictator of Guatemala, for genocide is the beginning of a process, not its conclusion.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Tracking the Pack
keywords: ['Wolves', 'ANIMALS', 'Science and Technology', 'Satellites', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Global Positioning System']
abstract: Modern communications technologies are reshaping our relationships with other species.
lead_paragraph: IN December, wolf 832F ventured out of her territory in Yellowstone’s Lamar Valley. As soon as she left the park, she lost its protections, and the wolf, a 6-year-old alpha female, was shot and killed by a hunter.

headline: Friends of Fraud
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Republicans are fighting to make America safe for financial abuse.
lead_paragraph: Like many advocates of financial reform, I was a bit disappointed in the bill that finally emerged. Dodd-Frank gave regulators the power to rein in many financial excesses; but it was and is less clear that future regulators will use that power. As history shows, the financial industry’s wealth and influence can all too easily turn those who are supposed to serve as watchdogs into lap dogs instead.

headline: Basking in Home Crowd’s Warmth, Mickelson Never Gives Up Lead
abstract: With what amounted to a home-course advantage, Phil Mickelson secured his 41st PGA Tour title with a four-stroke victory at the Waste Management Phoenix Open.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The marshal at the first hole at T.P.C. Scottsdale introduced Phil Mickelson on Sunday by mentioning his three Masters victories and two Phoenix Open titles but not his city of residence.

headline: Broad Powers Seen for Obama in Cyberstrikes
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The administration is moving to approve the nation’s first rules for how the military can defend, or retaliate, against a major cyberattack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A secret legal review on the use of America’s growing arsenal of cyberweapons has concluded that President Obama has the broad power to order a pre-emptive strike if the United States detects credible evidence of a major digital attack looming from abroad, according to officials involved in the review.

headline: Vast Oil Reserve May Now Be Within Reach, and Battle Heats Up
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Environment', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Reserves (Natural Resources)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Monterey Shale deposits, which could turn California into the nation’s top oil-producing state, is stirring conflict between drillers and environmental interests.
lead_paragraph: FELLOWS, Calif. — Secure in this state’s history and mythology, the venerable Midway-Sunset oil field near here keeps producing crude more than a century after Southern California’s oil boom. Many of its bobbing pump jacks are relatively short, a telltale sign of the shallowness of the wells and the ease of extracting their prize.

headline: New Jersey’s Useful One-Gun-a-Month Law
abstract: The law does not, as an N.R.A. affiliate argued, infringe on Second Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey statute limits purchases of firearms in the state to one handgun a month, with some exceptions. The superintendent of state police, for instance, can exempt collectors or competitive shooters from the limit so they can buy a set of guns all at once.

headline: Film Financier Faces a Critical Juncture
abstract: Time will tell if Thomas Tull, one of the most successful walk-on players in movie history, really is the latest outsider to win an insider’s game through his company, Legendary Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — During the baseball strike of 1995, Thomas Tull, then a 24-year-old laundromat owner, was audacious enough to turn up at a training camp for the Atlanta Braves. They looked at his swing and sent him home.

headline: Europe Moves Ahead on Privacy
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Consumer Protection', 'Editorials']
abstract: The United States is far behind when it comes to protecting people’s data online.
lead_paragraph: The European Union is considering far-reaching privacy regulations that would give the citizens of its member countries significant control over how Web sites and marketing companies collect and use data about them. Years in the making, the effort stands in stark contrast to the much slower pace of discussions about online privacy laws in Washington.

headline: More in France Are Turning to Islam, Challenging a Nation’s Idea of Itself
abstract: A growing number of young people are now seen as converting to be better socially integrated in poor neighborhoods where Islam is dominant.
lead_paragraph: CRÉTEIL, France — The spacious and elegant modern building, in the heart of this middle-class suburb of Paris, is known as “the mosque of the converts.”

headline: A New Space Race, or Chances to Collaborate?
abstract: How should the U.S., Europe and Russia respond to developments in Iran, the Koreas and China?

abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article about museums giving in to pressures from foreign governments.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cuomo Seeking Home Buyouts in Flood Zones
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has a proposal to spend as much as $400 million to buy homes wrecked by Hurricane Sandy, demolish them and preserve the undeveloped land.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is proposing to spend as much as $400 million to purchase homes wrecked by Hurricane Sandy, have them demolished and then preserve the flood-prone land permanently, as undeveloped coastline.

headline: A Million Jobs at Stake
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Editorials']
abstract: The dire effects of the sequester are clear, but no one in Washington seems able to stop it.
lead_paragraph: With enormous struggle, the sluggish economy managed to create 2.2 million jobs last year. But beginning at the end of this month, at least half that amount — more than a million jobs — will start to disappear because of a mindless government austerity program that no one in Washington seems able to stop.

headline: Amid All the Contradictions, Another Championship for Lewis
abstract: Even in festive New Orleans, the mood for Ray Lewis’s retirement party had been subdued, but the celebration began anew after the Ravens’ victory, sending Lewis out in style.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Sexual Abuse Scandal Grips and Divides Hispanic Parishioners in Los Angeles
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Cardinals (Roman Catholic Prelates)', 'Priests', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Conversations with dozens of parishioners at three largely Spanish-speaking churches in Los Angeles illustrate how divided the faithful still are over the details of decades of abuse.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At Dolores Mission Church in Boyle Heights, there was no shrinking from the news reverberating through the pews. The Rev. Scott Santarosa spent time usually reserved for the homily talking instead about what he called “really painful stuff.”

headline: More Taxes and Less Heat
abstract: Suzanne Daley of The New York Times reports on how Greeks are turning to dirty and environmentally damaging solutions for heat after the government raised taxes on heating oil by 450 percent.
lead_paragraph: Suzanne Daley of The New York Times reports on how Greeks are turning to dirty and environmentally damaging solutions for heat after the government raised taxes on heating oil by 450 percent.

headline: On Book-Tour Circuit, Sotomayor Sees a New Niche for a Justice
abstract: The release of her memoir, “My Beloved World,” suggests Sonia Sotomayor wants to play a larger and more personal role on the public stage than her colleagues.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At her Wednesday night book talk here, Justice Sonia Sotomayor glided through her audience of 700, dispensing homespun wisdom through a cordless microphone, interrupted by impromptu applause.

headline: Rise in Oil Tax Forces Greeks to Face Cold as Ancients Did
keywords: ['Trees and Shrubs', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Heating', 'Sales and Excise Taxes']
abstract: After a 450 percent increase, many residents have switched to firewood but still cannot keep warm, as smoke and logging raise environmental worries.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Even in the leafy northern stretches of this city, home to luxury apartment buildings, mansions with swimming pools and tennis clubs, the smell of wood smoke lingers everywhere at night.

headline: Lawyers Say Surveillance of Muslims Flouts Accord
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Muslim-Americans', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Civil rights lawyers say the treatment of Muslims in New York violates federal court guidelines and they will ask for an independent monitor to review compliance with the Handschu agreement.
lead_paragraph: Civil rights lawyers have asked a federal judge to appoint an independent monitor to review the New York Police Department’s counterterrorism efforts. The lawyers said the police’s tactics have placed Muslim communities under surveillance in violation of longstanding federal court guidelines.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning numbers for Feb. 3, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Selling Amnesty
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How to get real immigration reform past a right-wing blockade.
lead_paragraph: Let’s assume that President Obama and the Democrats sincerely want an immigration bill, that this is not a trick to trap Republicans into an anti-immigrant vote that will alienate Hispanic voters and secure Democratic advantage for a generation.

headline: Services to Reflect Koch: Proudly Jewish on His Own Terms
abstract: The former mayor’s burial site is classic Edward I. Koch: he rejected a Jewish cemetery for Trinity Church Cemetery, an Episcopal site open to all.
lead_paragraph: The final resting place of Edward I. Koch, the former New York City mayor, is, in many ways, very Jewish. A Jewish star tops his monument’s headstone. Its inscription, which he wrote, includes an epitaph proclaiming he was “fiercely proud of his Jewish faith.”

headline: Notorious Attack Spurs India to Approve New Rape Laws
abstract: The government approved tough new laws to deter sexual violence against women, including the death penalty in certain rape cases.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s government on Sunday approved tough new laws to deter sexual violence against women, including the death penalty in certain rape cases, as leaders moved to respond to public outrage over a recent gang rape case in the national capital.

headline: Super Bowl Ads Speak to a Generation. But Which One?
abstract: The ads CBS broadcast nationally represented a missed opportunity for marketers to show that they understood how modern consumers think and behave.
lead_paragraph: ACCORDING to the calendar, it is 2013, but anyone who watched the commercials during Super Bowl XLVII on Sunday night might be excused for believing it was a year when “Modern Family” meant the Cleavers, the Bradys, the Huxtables or the Conners.

headline: New Details Suggest a Defense in SAC Case
abstract: Internal trading records also raise questions on whether the government will be able to build a case against Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: At the center of the government’s insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is a trade that directly involves Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the fund.

headline: Fresh Questions Over a Bank of America Settlement
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The bank continued dubious mortgage modification practices even after its acquisition of Countrywide, court documents show.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America has long rued its decision in 2008 to acquire Countrywide Financial, the subprime mortgage giant. To date, the bank has set aside some $40 billion to settle claims of mortgage misconduct that occurred before it acquired the freewheeling lender.

headline: As Extremists Invaded, Timbuktu Hid Artifacts of a Golden Age
keywords: ['Manuscripts', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Tombs and Tombstones', 'Tuareg (Ethnic Group)', 'ARCHAEOLOGY']
abstract: Residents found ways to hide delicate artifacts from the Islamists who reigned over the city until last weekend, when fighters set fire to dozens of ancient manuscripts.
lead_paragraph: TIMBUKTU, Mali — When the moment of danger came, Ali Imam Ben Essayouti knew just what to do. The delicate, unbound parchment manuscripts in the 14th-century mosque he leads had already survived hundreds of years in the storied city of Timbuktu. He was not about to allow its latest invaders, Tuareg nationalist rebels and Islamic extremists from across the region, to destroy them now.

headline: Saving Timbuktu’s Priceless Artifacts
abstract: Amid all the fighting in Mali, residents of Timbuktu managed to preserve many ancient manuscripts, until recently.
lead_paragraph: Amid all the fighting in Mali, residents of Timbuktu managed to preserve many ancient manuscripts, until recently.

headline: Before Game Is Decided, Superdome Goes Dark
abstract: The lights on one half of the Superdome’s roof suddenly went out, making for one of the oddest, most embarrassing moments in Super Bowl history.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — It was not New Orleans’s brightest moment. About 90 seconds into the second half of Sunday’s Super Bowl, the lights on one half of the Superdome’s roof suddenly went out. Internet connections in the press box were cut, and the scoreboards went dark.

headline: Distillery’s Small Batches Will Soon Be Less Small
abstract: Two copper stills, custom-made in Scotland, arrived last Monday at the Kings County Distillery in Brooklyn, which in 2010 became the first legal distillery in New York City since Prohibition.
lead_paragraph: In 1869, federal troops raided more than a dozen neighborhood whiskey-making operations in Brooklyn and dragged their equipment back to the Navy Yard. The seizure did not sit well with some in the troubled Fifth Ward neighborhood; the soldiers were greeted with curses and a hail of bricks tossed from the rooftops on Little Street.

headline: Suspect Is Arraigned in 9-Year-Old’s Fall From a Bronx Roof
abstract: A lawyer for Casmine Aska, 17, who was charged with attempted murder, said he did not intentionally push the boy from their apartment building on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for a Bronx teenager accused of throwing a 9-year-old boy from the roof of their apartment building told a judge at his arraignment on Sunday that what happened was “a tragic accident.”

headline: Turkish Authorities Seek Killer of Tourist From S.I.
abstract: Turkish authorities had questioned nearly two dozen people in connection with the death of Sarai Sierra, who was 33 and lived in the Stapleton neighborhood of Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — It was her first trip overseas, but in many ways Sarai Sierra was the epitome of a modern young tourist — alone yet constantly connected.

headline: An Evolving Country Begins to Accept Sara, Once David
abstract: A concert pianist writes of seeking luck in a baby elephant, before surgery to become a woman. Now she works to spread that luck.
lead_paragraph: Ten summers ago, on an early evening stroll in Bangkok, I met a baby elephant. The animal’s owner was walking him past the open-air food stalls of one of the city night markets where, for the price of five Thai baht, one could purchase a handful of bamboo stalks and feed it to the little fellow. Concentrating on the broken sidewalk under my feet, and wishing not to trip, I hadn’t noticed the elephant until I nearly walked smack into him, eyeball to eyeball. Needless to say, it was a startling encounter. In my beloved Bronx, I had bumped into plenty of interesting creatures but no elephants. Being in Bangkok for extraordinary reasons, and in need of good luck, I fished into my purse and found a coin. I patted the head of the elephant for good measure as he crunched up his vegetarian treat.

headline: For the Ravens’ Jones, a Trip Home and 2 Trips Into the End Zone
abstract: Jacoby Jones caught a touchdown pass and returned a kickoff an N.F.L. postseason-record 108 yards for another in his return to his native New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Jacoby Jones is not the most notable native Louisianian on the Baltimore Ravens; that would be safety Ed Reed. He is also not the Ravens player best known for on-field dancing; that honor goes to the retiring linebacker Ray Lewis.

headline: Academic Study Weakens Israeli Claim That Palestinian School Texts Teach Hate
abstract: The report is unlikely to resolve more than a decade of fierce wrangling about the textbooks — part of a broader debate about Palestinian incitement against Israelis.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An academic study of the contents of Israeli and Palestinian Authority textbooks, to be published Monday, finds that each side generally presents the other as the enemy, but it undermines recent assertions by the Israeli government that Palestinian children are educated “to hate.”

headline: Scarlet Fever Probably Didn’t Blind Mary Ingalls
abstract: Mary Ingalls’s blindness at age 14 was likely caused by viral meningoencephalitis. Why did the book name scarlet fever as the culprit, and why does it matter?
lead_paragraph: Those are among the first words of “By the Shores of Silver Lake,” by Laura Ingalls Wilder, and they are haunting ones. Generations of children who had grown to know Mary in the first books of the “Little House” series read them with the same sense of shock — Mary, the annoying, bossy, well-behaved sisterly nemesis to the wild “half pint” Laura, blind?

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) MEA MAXIMA CULPA: SILENCE IN THE HOUSE OF GOD (2012) Alex Gibney documents the case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, above, a Roman Catholic priest in Wisconsin who died in 1998 after having molested dozens if not hundreds of children in his care at a boarding school for the deaf, resulting in a trail of denial and cover-up from rural America to the Vatican. Mr. Gibney’s “methods are a blend of solid journalism and cinematic sensationalism,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The reliance on melodramatic music and lurid — though not explicit — re-enactments does not seem to me to make the movie more powerful, but rather the opposite. There is something to be said for a clear and unblinking recitation of facts, and thankfully Mr. Gibney does a lot of that.” But the heart of the film, “the real source of its emotional impact,” Mr. Scott said, “lies in a remarkable series of interviews with some of the men, most now in their 60s, who endured Father Murphy’s assaults when they were children and who have worked for almost 40 years to bring his crimes to light.” John Slattery, Jamey Sheridan, Chris Cooper and Ethan Hawke interpret their words.

headline: Word of the Day | chafe
abstract: This word has appeared in 134 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: chafe •\ˈchaf\• verb and noun

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Feb. 4
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Feb. 4.
lead_paragraph: "They belong to all of humanity. It is our duty to save them.”

headline: Power Fails and 49ers Surge, but Ravens Win
abstract: After a game delay because of a power failure, M.V.P. Joe Flacco and the Ravens, leading 28-6, withstood a determined comeback by the 49ers to win the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The lights went out at the Superdome during the Super Bowl. Only then did the game really begin.

headline: Beyoncé Silences Doubters With Intensity at Halftime
abstract: Beyoncé answered her critics during her halftime performance by singing live with fierceness and confidence. Late in her set, she was joined by her former sidekicks of Destiny’s Child.
lead_paragraph: A main requirement for a halftime performer at the Super Bowl is indestructibility. Too much is on the line for anything but. The halftime show is time-constrained, highly choreographed and responsible for keeping hundreds of millions of people around the world entertained between aggressive bursts of football and extremely expensive bursts of commercials. It is a show, but more important, it is the glue that holds the night together, the short money that keeps the long money flowing.

headline: Medicines Co. Buys Cholesterol Drug Rights
abstract: The drug inhibits the protein PCSK9 and might one day be used to treat millions of people whose cholesterol is not lowered enough by common statins, such as Lipitor.
lead_paragraph: The Medicines Company is licensing the rights to a powerful type of cholesterol-lowering drug from Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, entering one of the hottest races in the industry.

headline: Simms Is Short of Analysis, and CBS Is Out of Sync
abstract: Though Jim Nantz and Phil Simms did a decent job of calling the game, they did not provide much in the way of insight.
lead_paragraph: I was wondering if Sean McManus, the chairman of CBS Sports, slipped into the network’s booth at the Superdome on Sunday night to give Jim Nantz and Phil Simms a pep talk.

headline: Kaepernick, Showing Guts, Falls Slightly Short of Glory
abstract: After an erratic first half in the Super Bowl, the second-year quarterback Colin Kaepernick led San Francisco to a rally but not a title.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — San Francisco quarterback Colin Kaepernick slumped forward toward the microphone, his eyes aimed downward, his face blank. Reporters pressed in all around him. They wanted to know how it felt for his final drive to end 5 yards from the end zone, 5 yards from a lead in Super Bowl XLVII.

lead_paragraph: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction.
