headline: Flacco’s Precision Typical of Elite Quarterbacks
abstract: Joe Flacco, who was named the game’s most valuable player, completed 22 of 33 passes for 287 yards and 3 touchdowns and did not throw an interception.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Neither of Joe Flacco’s two brothers was on the field in the Super Bowl on Sunday night. Flacco, the Baltimore Ravens’ quarterback, was not part of any pregame controversies involving deer antler spray, and he did not turn this game into a much-publicized finale of his retirement tour. At this point, there is no such thing as Flacco-ing.

headline: Super Bowl Ads: Readers React
abstract: As advertisers tried to generate buzz by releasing commercials early online, Times readers voted Sunday night on which of the game’s ads stuck out, and which of the ads they could have done without.
lead_paragraph: As advertisers tried to generate buzz by releasing commercials early online, Times readers voted Sunday night on which of the game’s ads stuck out, and which of the ads they could have done without.

headline: Why Always Him? Balotelli Scores Twice in Milan Debut
abstract: Mario Balotelli made a dramatic return to Italy on Sunday by scoring two goals for Milan in its 2-1 victory over Udinese.
lead_paragraph: Mario Balotelli made a dramatic return to Italy on Sunday by scoring two goals for A.C. Milan in its 2-1 victory over Udinese.

headline: In China’s Most-Watched Divorce Case, 3 Victories, 1 Defeat
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Domestic Violence', 'Education (K-12)', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: After a difficult court battle, Kim Lee, an American, was divorced from Li Yang on grounds of domestic violence, in a victory for the rule of law that contained one major flaw, feminists said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For over a year, Chinese society has been riveted by the case of Kim Lee, an American woman who did something extremely unusual: go public with accusations of domestic violence against her wealthy and famous husband, Li Yang.

headline: After 17 Seasons, Lewis Retires
abstract: A look at Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis’s storied football career through pictures.
lead_paragraph: A look at Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis’s storied football career through pictures.

headline: Jim Harbaugh Criticizes Officiating in Super Bowl
abstract: The 49ers coach seemed most upset with a noncall on Colin Kaepernick’s final pass, to Michael Crabtree, which went incomplete.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco Coach Jim Harbaugh took issue with a few of the calls in the waning moments of the Super Bowl.

headline: With a Son on Each Sideline, the Harbaughs Remain Neutral to the End
abstract: Jack and Jackie Harbaugh stayed upbeat as they faced questions about their sons Jim (coach of the 49ers) and John (coach of the Ravens).
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Two days before Thanksgiving in 2011, Jack Harbaugh received an unsolicited phone call from Archie Manning. Harbaugh’s sons, Jim and John, were about to face each other as coaches of the San Francisco 49ers and the Baltimore Ravens. Over the years, Manning had watched two of his sons, Peyton and Eli, battle each other and he wanted to sympathize.

headline: News Quiz | February 4, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Super Bowl Replay: Ravens 34, 49ers 31
abstract: The Baltimore Ravens survived a second-half rally by San Francisco and a power outage to win in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Ravens survived a second-half rally by San Francisco and a power outage to win in New Orleans.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 4
abstract: A legal review of the United States’ arsenal of cyberweapons; Germany weighs bailing out Cyprus; starting a business in France; and the first weekend of the Six Nations rugby tournament has wrapped up.
lead_paragraph: NEWS A secret legal review on the use of the United States’ growing arsenal of cyberweapons has concluded that President Barack Obama has the broad power to order a pre-emptive strike if the United States detects credible evidence of a major digital attack looming from abroad, according to officials involved in the review. David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker report from Washington.

headline: Felling Trees to Save Kashmir’s Wullar Lake
abstract: Decades of planting willow trees has led to water shortages and shrinking marshes.
lead_paragraph: A vast shoreline forest of willow trees is being chopped down and dredged out in Kashmir Valley to help restore water levels, fish stocks and wildlife in one of Asia’s largest bodies of freshwater.

headline: Bones Under Parking Lot Belonged to Richard III
abstract: In one of Britain’s most dramatic modern archaeological finds, tests identified the remains of the reviled English monarch, a discovery that could lead to a reassessment of his reign.
lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — Until it was discovered beneath a city parking lot last fall, the skeleton had lain unmarked, and unmourned, for more than 500 years. Friars fearful of the men who slew him in battle buried the man in haste, naked and anonymous, without a winding sheet, rings or personal adornments of any kind, in a space so cramped his cloven skull was jammed upright and askew against the head of his shallow grave.

headline: Challenging the Laws of Physics in the Subway
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poet describes how the laws of physics are seemingly reversed in a New York City subway station.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Pirates Seize French-Owned Tanker and Hold 17 Aboard
abstract: The attack was the most serious in a series of recent raids by pirates in the Gulf of Guinea, where patrols are scarce.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A French-owned oil tanker that went missing off the Ivory Coast is believed to have been hijacked by pirates who are holding the 17 sailors on board, a maritime agency said Monday.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 4, 2013
abstract: Can you calculate a comparison between the average rent on a Manhattan apartment and the average sale price of a new home in the United States?
lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “What Is Middle Class in Manhattan?”

headline: A Conversation With: Former Solicitor General Gopal Subramanium
abstract: On amending sexual assault laws, the need to overhaul the police force and entrenched corruption in the political establishment.
lead_paragraph: A recently-issued report from the Justice J.S. Verma Committee, established to recommend reforms to India’s sexual violence laws after the gang rape of a 23-year-old woman in Delhi sparked nationwide protests, has been described as a game changer: it represents a scathing critique of  the Indian state and governing class, while suggesting ambitious reforms to the country’s legal, judicial and political system.

headline: A Hard Life on the ‘Roof of the World’
abstract: The Kyrgyz people of the Wakhan Corridor in Afghanistan live a traditional semi-nomadic life in an isolated, inhospitable land. There are no doctors, no trees and no roads, yet photographer Matthieu Paley keeps coming back.
lead_paragraph: It is a harsh, unforgiving existence for the 1,200 Kyrgyz people who live at the end of the remote and inhospitable Wakhan corridor in Afghanistan, a 140-mile-long strip of land surrounded by China, Tajikistan and Pakistan. Less than half of the children there live to see their fifth birthday. And it is commonplace for women to die during childbirth.

headline: Does Being a Fan Help Define Who You Are?
abstract: How does loving a team, sports figure, entertainer, book, movie or television show affect your identity?
lead_paragraph: Are you a fan of a particular sports team — or actor, television show, musician, band, movie, writer or anything else? Fanhood can bring you joy, and make feel like you’re part of a community with other like-minded people.

headline: New Archbishop of Canterbury Takes Office
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ANGLICAN CHURCHES']
abstract: Rt. Rev. Justin Welby is taking over an Anglican church that is divided on the issue of same-sex marriage, an issue that the British Parliament will consider this week.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the eve of a divisive vote in Parliament on the legalization of same-sex marriage, Justin Welby, the former bishop of Durham, on Monday took over formally as the 105th archbishop of Canterbury, the spiritual head of the world’s 77 million Anglicans, saying he shares the Church of England’s opposition to marriage among people of the same gender.

headline: Commonwealth Games Organizer in India Could Face Life in Prison
abstract: Will appear in a fast-track court for corruption.
lead_paragraph: Suresh Kalmadi, the former chief organizer of the 2010 scandal that marred the Commonwealth Games, was charged Monday with cheating, conspiracy and causing a loss of more than $16 million to taxpayers by a Delhi court.

headline: February College Checklist for Seniors
abstract: A college counselor reminds high school seniors to keep perspective about admission decisions, and to look for scholarships.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: Ravens Soar to Super Bowl Victory
abstract: What was the final score in the Super Bowl on Sunday night?
lead_paragraph: In the article “For the Ravens’ Jones, a Trip Home and 2 Trips Into the End Zone,” Sam Borden writes about the Baltimore Ravens’ Super Bowl victory.

headline: Citigroup Names Senior Banker in Europe
abstract: Luigi de Vecchi has been appointed chairman of corporate and investment banking for continental Europe at Citigroup, the bank announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Luigi de Vecchi has been appointed chairman of corporate and investment banking for continental Europe at Citigroup, the bank announced on Monday.

headline: A 49ers Defense That Simply Wore Down
abstract: San Francisco fell behind in each of its last five games, including the playoffs, a sign of a defense that was far from dominant.
lead_paragraph: Were you wondering where Aldon Smith (19 games started) was during the Super Bowl? He played (2 tackles, 1 QB hit), although he wasn’t very effective.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Chip Brown on Witnessing North Dakota’s Oil Boom
abstract: The author of this week’s cover article answers questions about North Dakota’s transformation, its unflamboyant beauty and whether the scarcity of women there is a shock.
lead_paragraph: Chip Brown, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover article about life in and around the Williston Basin in North Dakota, which is experiencing its biggest oil boom. He last wrote for the magazine about the filmmaker Whit Stillman.

headline: How Green Is My Hotel?
abstract: More people are traveling and more travelers are taking an interest in sustainability. But the cornucopia of certification programs for environmental friendliness can be confusing.
lead_paragraph: The Hague — seen from the outside, the Court Garden Hotel, with its 1970s utilitarian commercial exterior, doesn’t appear particularly green.

headline: Trial by Video
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: A member of Pussy Riot was left staring at a videoscreen in her Russian penal colony as her own trial for camp violations played out just 10 miles away.
lead_paragraph: BEREZNIKI, Russia — “I can barely see you,” the young woman on the videoscreen said, her high-pitched voice trembling. “You are just a dark silhouette. And I cannot see or hear the defense or the prosecution at all.”

headline: Five Questions for: Author Jamil Ahmad
abstract: An octogenarian and first-time author from Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Jamil Ahmad is the author of “The Wandering Falcon,” a novel that delves into the lives of the tribal population living in the border region of Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iran. This is the debut novel of the former Pakistani bureaucrat, now in his 80s. He has spent more than 20 years in the Balochistan and Frontier provinces in Pakistan during his service.

headline: Japan Airlines Says 787 Grounding Will Cost It $7.5 Million
abstract: In announcing the forecast loss, the Japanese carrier joins other Dreamliner operators, like All Nippon Airways and United Airlines, in raising possible compensation demands.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan Airlines said on Monday that the grounding of its Boeing 787 Dreamliner fleet would cost it 700 million yen, or $7.5 million, in earnings through March and that it would seek compensation from Boeing.

abstract: They were his sentences and he could do with them as he liked, couldn’t he? A short fiction by Jonathan Baumbach.

headline: Police Call Match-Fixing Widespread in Soccer
abstract: A 19-month investigation by a European intelligence agency found that nearly 700 games globally may have been fixed, with profits from the wide-ranging scandal totaling about $11 million.
lead_paragraph: Soccer is known throughout much of the world as the beautiful game. But the sport’s ugliest side — the scourge of match-fixing — will not soon go away.

headline: Ex-Official Pleads Guilty to Old Charge in Britain
abstract: Chris Huhne on Monday pleaded guilty to obstructing justice by persuading his former wife to take responsibility for a speeding offense he had committed in 2003.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A former British government minister announced his resignation from Parliament on Monday, after reversing his longstanding denials to accept responsibility for persuading his former wife to take the blame for a speeding offense he had committed a decade ago.

headline: Victory Declared for Beyoncé
abstract: The only controversy over Beyoncé’s performance was whether her set somehow overtaxed the Superdome and led to the blackout.
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl halftime shows can be polarizing, if only because so many recent acts have been past their prime, but the only controversy over Beyoncé’s performance Sunday was whether her set somehow overtaxed the Superdome and led to a blackout. Most reviews made note of Beyoncé’s controversial lip-syncing at the recent presidential inauguration. A sampling:

headline: On Our Radar: A Power Plant, Imploded
abstract: A plant powered by oil and later by natural gas is blown up in Chula Vista, Calif.
lead_paragraph: A 1950’s-era power plant on San Diego Bay that was long viewed as a polluting eyesore is blown up to make way for a park. {The Los Angeles Times]

headline: Peace Talks Start Between Myanmar and Rebels
abstract: China hosted peace talks on Monday between the Myanmar government and ethnic Kachin rebels amid tentative signs that recent clashes were easing.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — China hosted peace talks between the Myanmar government and ethnic Kachin rebels on Monday, as outside pressure grew on both sides to end the intense fighting of recent weeks.

headline: Bolshoi Director Accuses Rivals
abstract: Sergei Filin, who was severely burned by an acid attack, said he believes he may have been targeted by a group of people who hoped to replace the theater’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, who was severely burned by an acid attack on Jan. 17, says he was targeted by a group of people who hope to replace the theater’s current leadership and who had previously attacked another top executive at the ballet, prompting that man to leave his post in 2011.

headline: Therapy Plateau No Longer Ends Coverage
abstract: Thousands, and possibly millions, of Medicare beneficiaries with chronic health problems can now continue to be covered for physical therapy because of an action by Congress and a recent court settlement.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Gorman, 72, a New York psychotherapist, can’t walk very far and gets around the city mainly by taxi, “which is really expensive,” she said. Twice since 2008 her physical therapy was discontinued because she wasn’t progressing. But after a knee replacement last year, she is getting physical therapy again, exercising with her therapist and building up her endurance by walking in the hallway of her Manhattan apartment building.

headline: Signs of a Possible Defense in SAC Case
abstract: Details about a suspicious trade raise questions about whether a case can be built against Steven A. Cohen of SAC Capital Advisors. | President Obama seems ready to revive a debate over carried interest. | BlackBerry and Samsung looked to shine in Super Bowl ads. | New documents cast doubt on a Bank of America mortgage settlement.
lead_paragraph: The government’s insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors centers on a trade involving Steven A. Cohen, the hedge fund’s billionaire founder. But new details cast doubt on how authorities have portrayed the trade, “suggesting a possible line of defense for the portfolio manager and raising questions about whether the government will be able to build a case against Mr. Cohen,” DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman report.

headline: So Why Did the Power Go Out at the Super Bowl?
abstract: Electrical work was an urgent matter at the Superdome in the months leading to the Super Bowl, The Times-Picayune reported.
lead_paragraph: Richard Rainey of The Times-Picayune offered a possible explanation for the power failure at the Superdome on Sunday. Electrical work was an urgent matter at the stadium in the months leading to the Super Bowl. Rainey said “it’s not clear whether there’s a connection between the emergency work and Sunday’s blackout.” But what is clear is that a lot of work needed to be done.

headline: Money, Wealth, and Models
abstract: Printing presses to the rescue.
lead_paragraph: Some further thoughts inspired by the welcome hatred of the usual suspects toward yours truly. One quite common statement among the Austrianish horde is something along the lines of “It’s ridiculous to imagine, as Krugman does, that you can create real wealth by printing more pieces of paper.”

headline: Pereira Says Officials Made Right Call
abstract: The former N.F.L. supervisor of officials did not agree with Coach Jim Harbaugh that pass interference should have been called on the 49ers’ final offensive play.
lead_paragraph: Mike Pereira, the Fox Sports analyst and former N.F.L. supervisor of officials, gave the officials a passing grade in the Super Bowl.

headline: The Gun Report: February 4, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Weekends are always when most people get shot. This weekend, a famous sniper was killed by a troubled veteran he was trying to help, two kids were shot by accident (one wounded, one killed) and a shooting took place outside a church on Sunday.

headline: Rate Expectations (Wonkish)
abstract: Is there a Japan puzzle?
lead_paragraph: FT Alphaville links to a puzzling piece by Maasaki Kanno, who argues that the relative success of Abenomics in Japan, so far, reflects a divergence in expectations between the currency and bond markets:

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Disappointing Super Bowl Ads, and a Hollywood Outsider Makes His Move
abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.
lead_paragraph: For those viewers hoping for exciting, high-quality performances in the Super Bowl Sunday night, the Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers delivered in thrilling style. For those more interested in the advertisements than the football, the results were more disappointing, Stuart Elliott writes in The Times. The commercials, he says, “fell back on familiar strategies and themes’’ that would have been more appropriate for the Eisenhower administration, with a joke about a mother-in-law, a gag about the word panties and an ad set at a prom, among others. It was a missed opportunity for marketers, Mr. Elliott writes.

headline: Pressures Mount on European Media
abstract: What can be done to preserve the independence of the European media and ensure competition?
lead_paragraph: The euro crisis is damaging Europe’s media. In Germany, a leading newspaper closed and another newspaper has been placed in receivership. Many newspapers are cutting back on staff for lack of advertising. Reporting will suffer, say editors.

headline: In Words and Unmistakable Song, Koch’s Bond With City Is Celebrated
abstract: Politicians from across the political spectrum filled the sanctuary Monday morning at Edward I. Koch’s funeral at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: After the eulogies by a mayor and a former president, after the loving references to “Uncle Eddie” by a 17-year-old grandnephew, after the coffin had been lifted on the shoulders of the Police Department’s ceremonial unit, the 10,000-pipe organ in Temple Emanu-El played a piece that is not usually heard at a funeral, but that seemed singularly appropriate for the funeral of Edward I. Koch: “New York, New York.”

headline: Moscow Exchange Prices I.P.O.
abstract: Russia’s largest stock Exchange said it had priced its shares at 55 rubles to 63 rubles, in a listing that would value the company at up to $4.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Moscow Exchange, Russia’s largest bourse, said on Monday that it had priced its shares at 55 rubles ($1.83) to 63 rubles ($2.10), in a listing that would value the company at up to $4.6 billion.

headline: What Sacha Baron Cohen Refused to Do and Other Producers’ Secrets
abstract: The producers of Oscar hopefuls spilled some of their productions secrets (yes, that’s David O. Russell’s voice on the audio track for “Silver Linings Playbook”).
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Who knew that movie producers — alternately reviled and exalted, depending on their access to money — could be so chatty? A panel organized by the Producers Guild of America last week produced a slew of revelations, from the bet that a “Django Unchained” producer, Stacey Sher, made against her own Oscar chances to Ang Lee’s real feelings about Hollywood.

headline: A New Year, but Some Old Issues
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Those who say China has too many railroads and roads should travel in the country this week, when the annual Spring Festival migration by hundreds of millions of people gets under way.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s column concluded with the comment that a resolution to the Chinese-Japanese dispute over the Diaoyu/Senkaku Islands seemed far away despite hopeful talk about the possibility of a summit meeting between Xi Jinping of China and Shinzo Abe of Japan.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: National Geographic Traveler: Chicken potpie. Whoopie pie. Shoo-fly pie. A crusty guide to chowing your way through the Pennsylvania Dutch Country. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Shell Denies Tax Evasion in India
abstract: Energy giant accused of evading taxes by India’s income tax department.
lead_paragraph: The Indian unit of the Anglo-Dutch oil company Royal Dutch Shell said Monday that it would challenge a notice by the Indian tax authorities alleging tax evasion through the transfer of shares.

headline: Carlyle’s Investment Ideas, by Podcast
abstract: In its latest foray into new media, the private equity firm Carlyle Group releases a podcast in which William E. Conway Jr., the co-founder and co-chief executive, discusses the investment outlook for the coming year.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group is making its debut on iTunes.

headline: Blackout Is a Boon for Super Bowl Ratings
abstract: The interruption was not only a diversion, but also changed the momentum in the game, helping to retain an audience that otherwise might have tuned out.
lead_paragraph: 8:43 p.m. | Updated CBS came close to matching the audience levels of the two most-watched television events of all time Sunday night, turning an electrical failure in the New Orleans Superdome into a likely ratings advantage for its coverage of Super Bowl XLVII.

headline: Malala Yousafzai, Pakistani Girl Shot by Taliban Militants, Speaks in New Videos
abstract: Speaking on camera for the first time since she survived an assassination attempt by the Pakistani Taliban last year, the young activist Malala Yousafzai began with the words, “Today you can see that I’m alive.”
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 4:54 p.m. Speaking on camera for the first time since she survived an assassination attempt by the Pakistani Taliban last year, the young activist Malala Yousafzai began with the words, “Today you can see that I’m alive.” The 15-year-old, who was shot in the head as she left school in Pakistan’s Swat Valley four months ago, promised that she would continue to be an outspoken advocate of the right for “every girl, every child, to be educated.”

headline: ‘Bombshell’ Doesn’t Exist, but Its Songs Are Real Hits
abstract: “Bombshell,” a fictional musical based on Marilyn Monroe’s life, is a plot device in NBC’s “Smash,” but its tunes are hot in piano bars.
lead_paragraph: On any given night at Marie’s Crisis, a cozy singalong piano bar in Greenwich Village, the pianist can be reliably counted on to deliver a fistful of standards. Songs made famous by Broadway royalty — Barbra, Liza, Patti — come out to play.

headline: U.S. Roster vs. Honduras
abstract: The United States roster for Wednesday’s World Cup qualifying match at Honduras.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-four players will train Monday in Miami, two days before the start of the final round of regional qualifying for a berth in 2014 World Cup in Brazil. The United States opens play in the hexagonal against Honduras in San Pedro Sula (4 p.m. Eastern; TV, beIN Sport).

headline: Where Strange Is Normal
abstract: It seemed fitting that this year’s Super Bowl included its share of weirdness, including a power failure during the game and a story line about the restorative powers of deer antler velvet extract.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS

headline: BMW Recalls 1 Series ActiveE for Powertrain Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The 1 Series ActiveE models were part of what BMW described as a field test program in which it leased the vehicles to consumers in markets on the East Coast and in California.
lead_paragraph: BMW is recalling vehicles in its test fleet of 1 Series all-electric cars designed to “help define the future of mobility” because of a possible immobility problem, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Leading Off: The Weirdest, Wildest Super Bowl
abstract: It started out as a Ravens romp. Then the lights went out. And then the 49ers staged a comeback that fell short. No doubt about it, it was a strange night at the Superdome.
lead_paragraph: When Ray Lewis finally stops preening for the cameras, Jim Harbaugh stops bellowing for a holding call and people finally run out of lights-out jokes, this Super Bowl will find its rightful place in the pantheon of Super Bowls as the strangest one ever: It started out as a Ravens romp, featured a halftime show that could have been seen from space had the Superdome not been a dome, and then became a combination of social commentary on the failing state of our infrastructure and slapstick comedy drawn from the lessons of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Frank Ocean Suggests He Will Not Press Charges Against Chris Brown
abstract: A statement posted to Mr. Ocean’s Web site suggests that he will not pursue charges against Chris Brown after a fight over a parking space in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: 11:52 a.m. | Updated  Frank Ocean has published an online message suggesting that he will not press charges against Chris Brown in connection with a brawl the two singers had in a parking lot last week. In a paragraph on his Web site that did not mention Mr. Brown or the fight, Mr. Ocean wrote: “I’ll choose sanity. No criminal charges. No civil lawsuit. Forgiveness, albeit difficult, is wisdom.”

headline: Owner Gets Lesson in Managing Sales Reps
abstract: Promoting an experienced sales rep into a sales manager, Susan Parker says, was the best thing she’s ever done.
lead_paragraph: At the last meeting of the She Owns It business group, Beth Shaw, founder of YogaFit, wondered why her recently hired sales representative was not meeting expectations. As that conversation continued, Ms. Shaw came to see the importance of a good customer-relations management system. She also considered putting role-playing exercises in place for her sales representatives and setting clear goals for them — from Day 1.

headline: Italian Government Blocks Premiere of Film on Berlusconi
abstract: A showing in Rome is postponed until after the Feb. 24 national election.
lead_paragraph: A documentary film that offers a scathing portrait of Silvio Berlusconi’s tenure as Italy’s prime minister has had its premiere in Italy postponed at the request of the government there. “Girlfriend in a Coma” was to be shown in Rome on Feb. 13, but it is now scheduled to be shown only after Feb. 24, the date of a national election in which Mr. Berlusconi is a candidate.

headline: Clearing Homes From Flood Zones
abstract: TimesCast: A buyback proposal for New York homes damaged in Hurricane Sandy. | New cyberattack capabilities for President Obama. | Greeks struggle to pay for home heating.
lead_paragraph: TimesCast: A buyback proposal for New York homes damaged in Hurricane Sandy. | New cyberattack capabilities for President Obama. | Greeks struggle to pay for home heating.

headline: A Closer Look at Moderating Views of Climate Sensitivity
abstract: An experienced climate scientist joins those seeing less warming from the building greenhouse effect.
lead_paragraph: | Live Updates below |“Worse than we thought” has been one of the most durable phrases lately among those pushing for urgent action to stem the buildup of greenhouse gases linked to global warming.

headline: Quick One-Dish Meals, Some Cooking Required
abstract: Five healthy one-dish meals that can be cooked in less than an hour, start to finish.
lead_paragraph: This week, in response to readers’ requests on the Recipes for Health Facebook page, I focused on quick one-dish dinners. You may have a different opinion than I do about what constitutes a quick meal. There are quick meals that involve little or no cooking – paninis and sandwiches, uncomplicated omelets, scrambled eggs, and meals that combine prepared items with foods that you cook -- but I chose to focus on dishes that are made from scratch. I bought a cabbage and a generous bunch of kale at the farmers’ market, some sliced mushrooms and bagged baby spinach at Trader Joe’s, and used them in conjunction with items I had on hand in the pantry and refrigerator.

headline: The Question You Should Be Asking About the Stock Market
keywords: ['Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Most people worry about whether to buy more or sell out when the stock market gets hot. Carl Richards reframes the question.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Arizona Mining Project Wins Crucial Permit
keywords: ['Chemicals', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Federal Lands', 'Mines and Mining', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: State environmental regulators have decided that emissions from a proposed Rosemont Copper mine would meet federal air standards.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian mining company has come one step closer to building a mile-wide, half-mile-deep open-pit copper mine on public land 30 miles south of Tucson. On Thursday, Arizona’s Department of Environmental Quality granted Rosemont Copper, a subsidiary of Augusta Resource of Vancouver, a crucial air quality permit, saying emissions from the proposed mine would not violate federal standards for carbon monoxide, nitrogen and sulfur dioxide, or fine and large particles.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 4
abstract: A parrot nibbles on a seasonal flower in Guwahati, Assam.

headline: A Sung-Through Plea to the Academy (Just Kidding)
abstract: A video parody of Anne Hathaway’s big number in “Les Misérables” is making the rounds.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – You know you are an Oscar front-runner when you merit a parody. So Anne Hathaway must be sitting pretty, now that a spoof of her Academy Award-nominated turn as Fantine in “Les Misérables,” with its show-stopping “I Dreamed a Dream,” is racking up hundreds of thousands of views on YouTube.

headline: Next Stop: Ed Koch Station? M.T.A. Suggests Otherwise
abstract: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney wants to rename a subway station at 77th Street and Lexington Avenue for Edward I. Koch, though transit officials quickly squashed the idea.
lead_paragraph: He has a bridge. He has a movie. But it seems that a subway station may be one honor too many for Edward I. Koch.

headline: Feeling For | Aurélie Bidermann Miki Dora Necklace
abstract: Aurélie Bidermann is showcasing her latest jewels — including this gold, nautical-rope-inspired necklace — at Barneys New York starting Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A longtime favorite of the fashion flock for her whimsical take on a tribal aesthetic, Aurélie Bidermann is moving up — or rather down — to Barneys New York’s recently refreshed first floor on Madison Avenue to showcase her latest jewels starting tomorrow. Nestled among her spring collection is the Miki Dora necklace, a twist on her preppy nautical rope bracelets. The piece is exclusive to the store and is finished in a gold patina. Don’t let this one sail away.

headline: Kitty Kelley Writing Book on Women in the Senate
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Kelley has previously written unauthorized biographies on Oprah Winfrey and Nancy Reagan.
lead_paragraph: Kitty Kelley, the author of unauthorized best-selling biographies of Oprah Winfrey and Nancy Reagan, will turn her gossipy form of reporting to the women of the United States Senate, her publisher said Monday. The book is tentatively set for publication in the spring of 2016.

headline: Works Owned by Lucian Freud Head to British Museums
abstract: The British painter’s estate is donating works by two 19th-century French artists to arts institutions in order to limit the amount of inheritance tax Mr. Freud’s heirs will face.
lead_paragraph: When the British painter Lucian Freud died in 2011, at the age of 88, his heirs faced a considerable inheritance tax. But his estate, taking advantage of a provision in British law that envisions “acceptance in lieu” of taxes, has now blunted that burden by donating works by two influential 19th-century French artists, Corot and Degas, to British arts institutions.

headline: Responding to a Digital Attack
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Times’s David E. Sanger discusses a secret legal review concerning President Obama’s powers in the face of a major cyberattack on the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David E. Sanger discusses a secret legal review concerning President Obama’s powers in the face of a major cyberattack on the United States.

headline: Syrian Rebels Free 3 Hostages in Exchange for Captured Fighters
abstract: The hostages, two Russian steel plant workers and an Italian citizen, were kidnapped by rebels in December as they traveled from Homs to a Russian base at the port of Tartus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Two Russian steel plant workers and an Italian citizen kidnapped by rebels in Syria have been freed in exchange for captured rebel fighters, the Russian Foreign Ministry said on Monday.

headline: The Get-Barry-Off-Antarctica Origami Puzzle
abstract: Can you solve this origami puzzle and help Barry Hayes end his stay in Antarctica?
lead_paragraph: Barry Hayes currently lives and works at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station at the center of Antarctica — the coldest, windiest and driest continent on the planet. He’s been there for the past three months, but austral winter will soon be rolling in. It’s time to go home.

headline: Is it Flat-Foldable?
abstract: Can a given crease pattern be folded into a flat origami?
lead_paragraph: The Get-Barry-Off-Antarctica Origami Puzzle featured in Numberplay originally emerged from research into the fundamental mathematics of paper-folding: can a given crease pattern be folded into a flat origami?

headline: Despite Reorganizations, Scant Signs of Change in Airline Industry
abstract: Major airlines have followed one of two main paths in their reorganization cases. But they never seem to use Chapter 11 to consider a new business model.
lead_paragraph: Given the many airline Chapter 11 cases in this country, you might expect that there would be some room for innovation. You would be wrong.

headline: Street Style: Turtlenecks
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Jan. 28.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Jan. 28.

headline: Obama’s Shifts May Affect U.S. Legal Plan on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: After advocating a state-by-state approach to the issue, President Obama seems now be thinking nationally, complicating the strategy in a pivotal case in California.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The practice of law would be much more pleasant, many lawyers will tell you over a second Scotch, if it did not require clients. It is one thing to construct an airtight legal argument and quite another to deal with the demands of inconstant human beings.

headline: Walkabout — 2/4: Super Bowl Exodus, and Best and Worst of U.S. Airports
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Easy Come, Easy Go After yesterday’s Super Bowl, about 42,000 people are expected to board planes at Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport. With visitors arriving by Friday for festivities leading up to Fat Tuesday, Feb. 12, it’s a busy week for the Big Easy. (The Associated Press, via Huffington Post)

headline: Investigation Reveals Match-Fixing in Hundreds of Games
abstract: Criminal organizations have infiltrated the highest levels of European and international soccer, threatening the integrity of the sport, global law enforcement officials said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Criminal organizations have infiltrated the highest levels of European and international soccer, threatening the integrity of the sport, global law enforcement officials said Monday as they disclosed the results of a 19-month investigation that indicated that hundreds of people had been involved in match-fixing. The matches fixed included qualifying games for the World Cup and for the European Championship, and two Champions League matches, including one in England. David Jolly and Sam Borden have the story.

headline: Moody’s Warns Jefferies on ‘Excessive’ Pay
keywords: ['Bonuses', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: The credit rating agency said in a note on Monday that it regarded the large compensation packages awarded to top executives as a potentially ominous event for bondholders.
lead_paragraph: The $78 million compensation package that the Jefferies Group doled out to its top executives raised more than a few eyebrows — including those at Moody’s Investors Service.

headline: Back to the Future, in the Kitchen
abstract: In 1967, Walter Cronkite’s documentary program, “The 21st Century,” foresaw a kitchen of the future where dish-washing would not be necessary.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1967, and the legendary anchorman Walter Cronkite is touting the kitchen of 2001: meals are automatically programmed from “menus given to the automatic chef via typewriter or punch computer card,” and used dishes are melted down, leftovers and all, to be made into new dishes, so that there is no waste. Smithsonian recently featured him in a nostalgic blog post about his CBS documentary program, “The 21st Century.”

headline: Audio Excerpt
abstract: Jamaica Kincaid reads from “See Now Then.”
lead_paragraph: Jamaica Kincaid reads from “See Now Then.”

headline: Joseph Mitchell Back in The New Yorker
abstract: “Street Life,” in the new issue of the magazine, is a previously unpublished excerpt from an uncompleted memoir.
lead_paragraph: This week’s edition of The New Yorker’s annual anniversary issue includes a never-before-published piece by Joseph Mitchell, one of the magazine’s most celebrated contributors.

headline: Look of the Moment | Kerry Washington
abstract: The “Scandal” actress sported pleasing pastels to the NAACP Image Awards in Los Angeles last week.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The “Scandal” actress who took home the award for Best Actress in a Drama Series at the NAACP Image Awards in Los Angeles on Friday.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: The Q. and A. puts on its blue suede shoes to discuss 1950s recordings and current commercials.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Fill-In | Where Las Vegas Stardust Rests in Peace
abstract: Fill in the blanks in the first six paragraphs of the museum review “Where Las Vegas Stardust Rests in Peace” by Edward Rothstein.
lead_paragraph: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first six paragraphs of the museum review “Where Las Vegas Stardust Rests in Peace” by Edward Rothstein.

headline: Zinging Spielberg and Hooper, Praising Bigelow and Lee
abstract: Ang Lee and Cedric the Entertainer got in a few zingers amid the sincere remarks by Kathryn Bigelow and others at the Directors Guild awards ceremony.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The Directors Guild has a unique tradition on the awards circuit, allowing each of its feature film nominees to give a speech and accept a prize medallion before the actual winner (this year it was Ben Affleck) is announced. “They will get to keep the medallions,” said the ceremony’s host, Kelsey Grammer, “as a reminder of just how close they came.”

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Lia Armatas joined the New York office of Arnold Worldwide as director for creative services. Ms. Armatas had been creative resource manager at Grey New York, part of the Grey Group.
lead_paragraph: Lia Armatas joined the New York office of Arnold Worldwide as director for creative services. She succeeds Tara Maldonado, who left, the agency said, to focus on her floral design business. Ms. Armatas had been creative resource manager at Grey New York, part of the Grey division of the Grey Group, which is owned by WPP. Arnold Worldwide is part of the Havas Creative division of Havas.

headline: Out of Darkness, Springing Into Action
keywords: ['Super Bowl', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Football']
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said that the power failure at the Superdome was not caused by the halftime show and that it would it not affect New Orleans’s ability to host future Super Bowls.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — When half the Superdome went dark Sunday, so did the N.F.L.’s control center, up near the top of the stadium, above the last row of seats. Among the two dozen gathered there was Doug Thornton, the building’s manager since 1997.

headline: Fox News Monitors Geraldo as He Mulls Political Office
abstract: Mr. Rivera, a longtime commentator and reporter, has said that he’s interested in running for the Senate in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Geraldo Rivera’s stated interest in running for a Senate seat in New Jersey has been derided as a joke and a publicity stunt. But his employers are taking it seriously.

headline: Girls Lead in Science Exam, but Not in the United States
abstract: Girls outperformed boys in more countries in a science test given to 15-year-old students in 65 countries — but in the United States, the scores reverse.
lead_paragraph: Girls outperformed boys in more countries in a science test given to 15-year-old students in 65 countries — but in the United States, the scores reverse.

headline: Energy Department Is the Latest Victim of an Online Attack
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: The attack, which compromised the personal data of several hundred employees, is the latest in a string of major online attacks to surface in the last week.
lead_paragraph: The Energy Department was hit by an online attack last month that compromised the personal data of several hundred employees.

headline: Tactics for Getting the I.R.S. on the Phone
abstract: Wait times have been growing when seeking help from the I.R.S. by telephone, and Monday is probably the worst time to call.
lead_paragraph: If you need help with a federal tax question, the Internal Revenue Service offers free, live assistance by telephone. But you’ll probably need to be patient when you call.

headline: Campaign Just Wants to Say ‘Know’ to Kidney Disease
abstract: A public service advertising campaign on behalf of the National Kidney Foundation is using new technologies not only to lower production costs but also to gain attention.
lead_paragraph: A public service advertising campaign that seeks to help in the fight against kidney disease is using new technologies not only to lower production costs but also to gain attention.

headline: Besides the Gym and Great Views, Don’t Forget to Mention the Garbage Disposal
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Plumbing', 'Kitchens']
abstract: Garbage disposals have not been illegal in New York City homes since 1997, but they remain rare, and some buildings still do not allow them.
lead_paragraph: The online listing for a condominium in Brooklyn Heights advertises five bedrooms and wide-open views of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline for $4.995 million. A 19th-floor two-bedroom on East 59th Street offers floor-to-ceiling windows, a gas fireplace and two balconies; corporations and pieds-à-terre welcome, $2.495 million. And a penthouse on Greenwich Street offers a 500-square-foot terrace and a pet spa for $6.195 million.

headline: McCain’s Iran Humor Isn’t Fully Appreciated
abstract: Senator John McCain’s joke on Twitter about the Iranian president’s ambitions to be an astronaut drew some accusations of insensitivity.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain just can’t help himself, it seems. At least not when there’s a joke to be told about Iran.

headline: Motorsports Monday: Showing Off the 2013 Models
abstract: The defending champion Infiniti Red Bull Racing team introduced its new car, the RB9, on Sunday at the team’s headquarters in England.
lead_paragraph: Formula One teams have begun unveiling their 2013 models.

abstract: TimesCast Media+Tech: The successes and failures of this year’s Super Bowl ads. | Ang Lee on the technology behind “Life of Pi.” | An interactive project encourages action against human trafficking.
lead_paragraph: TimesCast Media+Tech: The successes and failures of this year’s Super Bowl ads. | Ang Lee on the technology behind “Life of Pi.” | An interactive project encourages action against human trafficking.
