lead_paragraph: The successes and failures of this year’s Super Bowl ads. The Oscar-nominated director Ang Lee on the technology behind “Life of Pi.” An interactive project empowers students to take action against human trafficking.

headline: Pigeons, in All Their Genetic Variety
abstract: They might be called the “rats of the sky,” but Charles Darwin certainly saw something in pigeons. It turns out the father of evolution saw in the birds an amazing variety of variation in color, shape and form.
lead_paragraph: They might be called the “rats of the sky,” but Charles Darwin certainly saw something in pigeons. It turns out the father of evolution saw in the birds an amazing variety of variation in color, shape and form.

headline: Pigeons Get a New Look
abstract: Genetic scientists are using pigeons to study the mutations that produce radically new kinds of anatomy.
lead_paragraph: In 1855, Charles Darwin took up a new hobby. He started raising pigeons.

headline: Despite Expectations, Corporations Could Face More Cases of Criminal Liability
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Mary Jo White, the nominee to be chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, expressed disdain for corporate criminal liability while she was in private practice. But that does not mean companies under investigation can expect an easy ride under her reign.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White, the nominee to be chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has stated that she is not a fan of pursuing cases of criminal liability against corporations. Such views are likely to draw scrutiny during her confirmation process, but it does not necessarily mean companies facing sanctions can expect an easy ride in Washington.

headline: Take the Over on Underwear
abstract: On Twitter, one of the most comment-worthy events of Sunday night came about an hour into the game: that you-had-to-see-it-to-believe-it commercial for Calvin Klein underwear.
lead_paragraph: Yes, the Ravens pulled off what turned out to be an exciting win over the 49ers. Yes, Beyoncé was amazing. And, yes, that 35-minute power failure in the second half made this one of the strangest Super Bowls ever. But on Twitter, one of the most comment-worthy events of Sunday night came about an hour into the game: that you-had-to-see-it-to-believe-it commercial for Calvin Klein underwear. Will Matthew Terry turn out to be the Marky Mark of 2013?

headline: Bruno Mars, Rihanna and Sting to Perform Together at Grammys
abstract: The trio will perform together during Sunday’s awards show, the Recording Academy announced Monday.
lead_paragraph: To the ever-growing list of artists already scheduled to perform at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, add this unlikely combination: Bruno Mars, Rihanna and Sting. The trio will perform together during the show, the Recording Academy announced Monday, as will Kelly Clarkson. All but Sting also are nominees for awards this year.

headline: A President and His Governor Catch Up
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and former President Bill Clinton seemed to be engaged in a friendly chat outside the funeral for Edward I. Koch, but their relationship may soon be tested.
lead_paragraph: They spoke intently and uninterrupted, eyes fixed on each other for about five minutes despite the swirling crowd around them.

headline: The Decoded Pigeon, Living Gluten-Free, and a Problem With ‘SimplyThick’
abstract: Carl Zimmer on sequencing the pigeon genome, one woman’s choice to dump gluten and Catherine Saint Louis on the complicated case of a food thickener that has raised safety concerns in premature babies.
lead_paragraph: Carl Zimmer on sequencing the pigeon genome, one woman’s choice to dump gluten and Catherine Saint Louis on the complicated case of a food thickener that has raised safety concerns in premature babies.

headline: Microsoft’s Reller Talks Windows 8 Sales
abstract: Tami Reller, the chief marketing officer and chief financial officer of Microsoft’s Windows division, said the company is pleased with the early progress of Windows 8 and predicted that a host of new touch screen devices featuring the operating system would soon be available, increasing sales.
lead_paragraph: The introduction of Windows 8 did not restore growth to the personal computer business over the holidays. Microsoft, though, says the product is just getting warmed up.

headline: Home With the Flu? 20 Years of the Family Medical Leave Act
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'Part-Time Employment']
abstract: Parents following those public service announcements to keep themselves and kids at home if they have the flu can find themselves without a job when they return.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday is the 20th anniversary of the Family and Medical Leave Act. During those 20 years, it has been used more than 100 million times by employees caring for new babies, tending sick parents and spouses, and coping with illness.

headline: Effective Addiction Treatment
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Many addiction treatment programs are rooted in outdated methods rather than new evidence-based approaches, dooming many addicts to failure.
lead_paragraph: Countless people addicted to drugs, alcohol or both have managed to get clean and stay clean with the help of organizations like Alcoholics Anonymous or the thousands of residential and outpatient clinics devoted to treating addiction.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: A selection of events for this week.
lead_paragraph: Treats

headline: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
abstract: The best N.B.A. games of the week feature the Lakers at Brooklyn, Golden State at Oklahoma City and Chicago at Denver.
lead_paragraph: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

headline: U.S. Accuses S. & P. of Fraud in Suit on Loan Bundles
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Collateralized Debt Obligations', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The Justice Department has filed civil fraud charges in federal court in Los Angeles against Standard & Poor’s over its ratings of mortgage-related securities.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed civil fraud charges late on Monday against the nation’s largest credit-ratings agency, Standard & Poor’s, accusing the firm of inflating the ratings of mortgage investments and setting them up for a crash when the financial crisis struck.

headline: Brain Shape Linked to Cocaine Addiction
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Brain', 'Research']
abstract: Sporadic cocaine users tend to have a larger frontal lobe, a region associated with self-control, while cocaine addicts are more likely to have small frontal lobes even before they start using drugs, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Why are some people able to use cocaine without becoming addicted? A new study suggests the answer may lie in the shape of their brains.

headline: A Contest of Caillettes
abstract: Sampling the fare at the First World Championship of Caillettes in the town of St.-Péray.
lead_paragraph: Sampling the fare at the First World Championship of Caillettes in the town of St.-Péray.

headline: Forget ‘Top Chef.’ Here, Meatballs Compete.
abstract: In France, there are a lot of cooking contests, including one for the slightly flattened meatballs that are a specialty of the Ardèche region.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Ardèche region in south-central France is famous for chestnuts, sheep farming, Stone Age cave paintings and a scenic river.

headline: Governor, a Casualty of Sandy
abstract: The young restaurant, already saddled with the high price of its initial construction, could not handle more debt to rebuild after the storm.
lead_paragraph: 5:57 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Play on Nature’s Patterns
abstract: The sculptor Haresh Lalvani, whose eight-foot-tall SEED54 is installed in Manhattan, plays with natural shapes and mathematical principles to create seemingly anomalous objects.
lead_paragraph: If ages from now, when New York City is covered in dust, archaeologists were to dig through its many layers and uncover the stainless-steel sculpture that currently stands at the southeast corner of 54th Street and Avenue of the Americas, what would they think?

headline: The Evolution of the Ed Koch Obituary
abstract: Several paragraphs were added after the former mayor’s obituary was published online Friday.
lead_paragraph: When former New York Mayor Edward I. Koch died early on Friday, The Times was prepared. At least, it looked that way.

headline: Top Iranian Politicians Exchange Accusations
abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad escalated a fight with Iran’s most influential political family by disclosing secret recordings of what he purported were fraudulent business deals.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad escalated a bitter political fight this week with Iran’s most influential political family by disclosing secret film recordings of what he purported were fraudulent business deals.

headline: Study Flags Duplicate Financing
abstract: Federal agencies may be paying out duplicate grants, according to an analysis, with almost $70 million possibly spent on projects that were already at least partly financed.
lead_paragraph: The government may be wasting millions of dollars by paying for the same research projects twice, according to a new analysis of grant and contract records.

headline: Remembering Chris Kyle, a Deadly American Sniper
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Chris Kyle, a former Navy SEAL, who was killed Saturday at a gun range in Texas, wasn’t just a legend. He was The Legend, with four tours in Iraq, two Purple Hearts and a hand in every major battle during the conflict.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2006, my infantry platoon gathered in a dusty patrol base in Baghdad to watch our own being killed in fuzzy, pixilated video clips. An insurgent sniper named Juba was terrorizing Baghdad with precise and methodical shots at allied troops, and it was all captured on film. A soldier in a turret falls in a puff of smoke. Another soldier standing along a road is shot in the head.

headline: The Sound and the Fury
abstract: Age-related hearing loss, called presbycusis, is characterized by loss of hair cells in the base of the cochlea, or inner ear.
lead_paragraph: Q. Nearing 70, I have increasing difficulty hearing conversations, yet music in restaurants is too loud. Why?

headline: Super Bowl Ads Recall Days Gone By
abstract: The ads CBS broadcast nationally represented a missed opportunity for marketers to show that they understood how modern consumers think and behave.
lead_paragraph: The ads CBS broadcast nationally represented a missed opportunity for marketers to show that they understood how modern consumers think and behave.

headline: Bet on U.S. Pays Off for Germany’s Carmakers
abstract: The American auto market’s recovery has also been a boon for Daimler, BMW and Volkswagen, which have invested heavily in the United States.
lead_paragraph: It was only a few years ago that some economists were arguing that Europe was “decoupling” from its long dependence on trade with the United States and predicting that the Continent’s future lay with the so-called tiger economies of Asia.

headline: Gallup Conducts Review of Tracking Poll Methodology
abstract: Gallup announced that Michael Traugott, a polling expert from the University of Michigan, is helping the company review its election polling methods.
lead_paragraph: After an election season in which it received significant criticism for the results of its Daily Tracking poll, Gallup announced last week that Michael Traugott, a polling expert from the University of Michigan, is helping the company review its election polling methods.

headline: Focus on Hospitals’ ‘July Effect’
abstract: Researchers found that patients admitted to teaching hospitals in July, when new medical residents arrive, fared as well as those admitted in other months.
lead_paragraph: Some people believe that being admitted to a teaching hospital in July, when the new medical residents have just arrived, is a guarantee of poor care, and some research supports that view. But a new study suggests that fear of the “July effect” may be exaggerated.

headline: Assad Can Avoid Trial by Leaving, Coalition Says
abstract: Syria’s opposition coalition gave qualified backing to its leader’s surprise offer last week for a dialogue with President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s opposition coalition gave qualified backing on Monday to its leader’s surprise offer last week for a dialogue with President Bashar al-Assad to end the civil war, pressing him to respond definitively and even offering the added inducement that he could avoid trial if he resigned and left the country.

headline: Warning Too Late for Some Babies
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Infant Formulas', 'Medicine and Health', 'Necrotizing Enterocolitis', 'Premature Babies']
abstract: An F.D.A. warning not to use a thickener with xanthan gum — a common food additive — for any infants comes after a number of deaths from intestinal damage.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks after Jack Mahoney was born prematurely on Feb. 3, 2011, the neonatal staff at WakeMed Hospital in Raleigh, N.C., noticed that his heart rate slowed slightly when he ate. They figured he was having difficulty feeding, and they added a thickener to help.

headline: Turks Turn to DNA in Search for Staten Island Woman’s Killer
abstract: The authorities in Turkey have obtained a court order to let them take genetic samples from 21 people questioned in the bludgeoning of Sarai Sierra.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Turkey have obtained a court order allowing them to take DNA samples from 21 people who have been questioned in the bludgeoning of a New York woman who was found dead in Istanbul over the weekend, according to Turkish news reports.

headline: Bureaucracy’s Salaries Defended in Europe
abstract: An article in Die Welt am Sonntag said many European Union functionaries make more than Chancellor Angela Merkel.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Days ahead of a summit meeting where leaders of the European Union’s 27 member states are to wrestle again with a proposed seven-year budget, a spokesman for the bloc’s executive body was forced to defend the salaries of some officials.

headline: Really? Timing of Meals Affects Weight Loss
abstract: Studies suggest that eating at later hours, especially main meals, can affect efforts to lose weight.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: Photo Replay: February 4
abstract: The day in sports includes a happy Super Bowl mom, high-flying performers at the world ski championships and a team time trial through the desert.
lead_paragraph: The day in sports includes a happy Super Bowl mom, high-flying performers at the world ski championships and a team time trial through the desert.

headline: NBC Universal Puts Cable Units Under One Executive
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'News and News Media', 'Relocation of Business', 'Television']
abstract: The company placed the new entity under Bonnie Hammer, head of the USA Network and other cable channels, making her one of the more powerful women in television.
lead_paragraph: NBCUniversal announced Monday that it was consolidating all of its cable entertainment properties under Bonnie Hammer, the longtime head of the USA network and other NBC cable channels. The move elevates Ms. Hammer to a position among the most prominent and powerful female executives in the television business.

headline: Viewing the Nazis Through Their Children’s Eyes
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Movies', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The Australian director of “Lore” talks about why she took on a WWII-era story focused on the children of Nazis and why she decided to make the film in German.
lead_paragraph: One of the curiosities of the current Academy Award season is that Australia was competing in the best foreign-language film category with a German-language film. Cate Shortland’s “Lore,” a drama about the waning days of World War II, did not pick up a nomination, but it has created a stir everywhere it’s been shown, winning audience awards at festivals on its way to opening in New York on Friday.

headline: Finding Poetry in Cancer
abstract: The rhythms of poetry can help make sense of what is happening for those facing a cancer diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: When Kyle Potvin learned she had breast cancer at the age of 41, she tracked the details of her illness and treatment in a journal. But when it came to grappling with issues of mortality, fear and hope, she found that her best outlet was poetry.

headline: Obama Presses for Gun Measures, Offering Up Minneapolis as a Model
abstract: President Obama cited the city’s successful gun violence prevention efforts, even as evidence mounted that expanded background checks on sales may emerge as a compromise.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — President Obama traveled to the nation’s heartland on Monday to press his case for tougher national gun laws, even as he appeared to acknowledge that expanded background checks on gun sales were far more likely to pass Congress than a ban on military-style assault weapons.

headline: Driving Precautions
abstract: Letters to the editor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Avoiding Everyday Hazards (2 Letters)
abstract: Letters to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A $100,000 Prize for Yo-Yo Ma
abstract: The cellist is awarded the Vilcek Prize for his contributions to contemporary music.
lead_paragraph: Yo-Yo Ma, the popular and successful cellist who has already received several major cash awards, has won another: the $100,000 Vilcek Prize, given by the Vilcek Foundation. The foundation, which this year is recognizing achievements in contemporary music, also gave three $35,000 awards to three other musicians: the British-born songwriter James Abrahart, known as JHart; Samuel Bazawule, a Ghanaian producer and composer known as Blitz the Ambassador; and Tigran Hamasyan, an Armenian-born vocalist and pianist.

headline: What I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of India Today
abstract: The most striking feature of a late December issue of India Today is its aspirational tone and near-relentless gloss and promotional fervor. I fear that a more consistently mainstream editor eventually will make this periodical much less interesting, so in the meantime I am glad that the editor is the daughter of the owner.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Cowen writes the One Sentence Book Review for The One Page Magazine, as well as a regular column for the Sunday business section.

headline: Men Who Took Silicon to Silicon Valley
abstract: “Silicon Valley,” on “American Experience,” traces the beginnings of the inventions that revolutionized the area now called Silicon Valley, and the world.
lead_paragraph: “Silicon Valley” is a deceptively grand title for the new “American Experience” documentary Tuesday night on PBS. “Fairchild Semiconductor” would be more accurate. It could even be called “Robert Noyce” or, with a musical score and some dance numbers, “Noyce!”

headline: Venture Capital’s Sluggish Performance
abstract: Investors need to strip the venture capital industry of its mystique and demand greater transparency and a better deal, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: American venture capital needs a reboot. A decade of insufficient shrinkage hasn’t fixed wimpy performance. At 6.1 percent annually over 10 years to September, according to Cambridge Associates and the National Venture Capital Association, V.C. fund returns undershoot boring stock indexes like the Nasdaq and the Russell 2000.

headline: Steps Taken to Fill In Gender Gap
abstract: “Working Women,” a program spotlighting dances by eight female choreographers, surveyed a range of talent at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Eight dances by eight different dance makers — even for a sampler, that’s a lot of dishes. In “Working Women,” which ended its run at the Joyce Theater on Sunday, what connects them is that the choreographers are all female. That’s hardly an uncommon distinction, but there’s still enough bias in favor of putting men in charge that women can use a little special attention.

headline: Ang Lee on Directing ‘Life of Pi’
abstract: The director explores how his roots in theater contributed to the making of “Life of Pi,” which received Oscar nominations for best picture and best director.
lead_paragraph: The director explores how his roots in theater contributed to the making of “Life of Pi,” which received Oscar nominations for best picture and best director.

headline: A Top-Tier Quarterback Set to Be Paid Like One
abstract: After turning down an earlier offer from the Ravens that he felt was too small, Joe Flacco has done more in one year to solidify his bargaining position than any other N.F.L. free agent.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS

headline: 4,500 Tons of Evidence of Strike in Seville
abstract: The strike by garbage collectors is entering its second week and threatening to turn into a health safety issue in one of Spain's most touristic cities.
lead_paragraph: SEVILLE, Spain — Along one of the windy streets of Seville’s historic Santa Cruz neighborhood, Alfonso José Carnerero Ávila, a hotel employee, was enjoying a drink with colleagues and friends on the doorstep of a wine cellar on a recent day, trying hard to ignore the overflowing pile of trash nearby.

headline: Rwanda’s Health Care Success Story
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A report in BMJ cites impressive gains in AIDS treatment and reducing child mortality, mostly through a network of village-based health workers.
lead_paragraph: In the less than two decades since the 1994 genocide that killed nearly a million Rwandans and displaced another two million, the country has become a spectacular public health success story and could provide a model for the rest of Africa, according to a new analysis by American health experts.

headline: Sri Lankan Leader Seems to Reject Greater Autonomy for Tamils
abstract: President Mahinda Rajapaksa promised for years to support greater political autonomy for the country’s Tamil ethnic minority in the wake of a bloody civil war.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The president of Sri Lanka appeared to rule out greater political autonomy for the country’s Tamil ethnic minority on Monday, despite promising for years to support the idea in the wake of a bloody civil war.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Eulogizes Ed Koch
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered the eulogy for Edward I. Koch, the three-term New York City mayor who died at 88.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered the eulogy for Edward I. Koch, the three-term New York City mayor who died at 88.

headline: Obama Talks Gun Control in Minneapolis
abstract: Will he put his muscle behind an assault weapons ban?
lead_paragraph: With members of Congress looking pretty squishy on some aspects of gun control &#8212 like banning civilian ownership of weapons that are designed to kill as many people as possible in as short a time as possible while in combat — President Obama delivered his first big speech on the subject since he unveiled his own regulatory priorities.

headline: Vain Glorious | Make Up For Ever Bus Tour
abstract: The brand is sending its makeup artists on the road.
lead_paragraph: Make Up For Ever is sending its makeup artists on the road. The mobile Make Up School kicked off its tour on Friday, in Los Angeles, and will make eight more stops across the United States through April. The goal: teaching cosmetics enthusiasts how to use what products they already have (regardless of the brand), what to ditch (like that foundation that doesn’t match your neck) and what to get. The price: a Like on Facebook. Each pupil will get 30 minutes with her own makeup artist, a professional photo of her “after” look and, for an additional $30, a limited-edition Remix Make Up Bag designed by Christina Ricci. To see the tour schedule and book a 30-minute appointment, go to makeupbagremix.com.

headline: Winning a Losing Battle
abstract: Jesse Schenker, the chef at Recette, has shown that even someone constantly surrounded by food can control his consumption enough to shed 55 pounds.
lead_paragraph: Before we get to the story of how Jesse Schenker, a young chef in the West Village, managed to shed 55 pounds, let us consider what he consumed during a recent Monday night on the town.

headline: Bill Clinton Speaks at Koch’s Funeral
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton speaks at former Mayor Edward I. Koch’s funeral.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton speaks at former Mayor Edward I. Koch’s funeral.

headline: Poll Finds Slight Decline in Cuomo’s Popularity After Gun Package
abstract: In a Siena poll conducted last week, 67 percent of voters said they had a favorable opinion of Mr. Cuomo; 58 percent rated his job performance as excellent or good.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY – Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo saw only a modest decline in his popularity among New York State voters after winning passage of strict new gun laws last month, and voters approve of the new laws more than two to one, according to a Siena College poll released Monday.

headline: For One Monopoly Token, the Days Are Numbered
abstract: Tuesday is the deadline to take part in online voting to determine which existing piece used in the board game will disappear forever, and which of five candidates will replace it.
lead_paragraph: Despite the onslaught of high-tech games played on smartphones, tablets and giant flat-screen televisions, some old-fashioned board games played at a more methodical pace endure. Of those, perhaps the most popular is Monopoly, which was born 78 years ago.

headline: ‘Bad Pharma’ and a Look at Oscillation
abstract: Events at the intersection of science and culture.
lead_paragraph: BOOK

headline: Seeking Offense and Depth, the Rangers Trade a Fighter
abstract: Mike Rupp, a third- and fourth-line wing, was traded for Darroll Powe, a 27-year-old center known primarily for penalty killing, and Nick Palmieri, a 23-year-old minor leaguer.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers traded Mike Rupp to the Minnesota Wild on Monday, exchanging one of their more frequent fighters for more depth at forward.

headline: A Clash in Pennsylvania Over Fracking and Water Tests
abstract: State officials cite an “unacceptable” remark by one environmentalist as their reason for canceling a Jan. 22 meeting on the water issue.
lead_paragraph: A war of words has broken out between environmentalists and the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection over the cancellation of a meeting on the state’s testing of water from water wells near natural-gas drilling sites.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Cambodia, New York and Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Cambodia, New York and Myanmar.

headline: Treating Constipation in the Old
abstract: Scientists found that some laxatives had significant effects but that there was little or no evidence that enemas or increased fluid intake had any benefit.
lead_paragraph: The incidence of chronic constipation increases with age, but its causes remain unknown, and recommendations for treatment vary widely. Now a review of 16 randomized controlled trials separates the treatments backed by scientific evidence from those that are not.

headline: Pneumonia Strain Has Spread
abstract: Strains of a pneumonia that is dangerous to hospitalized older patients and resistant to a class of antibiotics are appearing across the nation.
lead_paragraph: Infection with Klebsiella pneumoniae is a serious danger to older hospitalized patients, with an estimated mortality rate as high as 40 percent. It has generally been treated with broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotics. Another class of antibiotics, carbapenems, is used as an antibiotic of last resort for the most persistent infections.

headline: Staten Island Chuck: The Untold Story
abstract: No animals were hurt for this post-Groundhog Day report, but no representations are made about harm to the truth.
lead_paragraph: The following note from Joyce Wadler, a former Times reporter, appeared mysteriously in our mailbox today. Attempts to confirm its truthiness were foiled when City Room’s fact-checking staff went out for crullers and never returned, so we are publishing it as is. Caveat lector.

headline: Most Food Illnesses Come From Greens
abstract: Leafy vegetables like lettuce — not dreaded spoiled shellfish — cause the most food-borne illness, with contaminated poultry being responsible for the most deaths.
lead_paragraph: Spoiled shellfish and unrefrigerated mayonnaise are notorious for causing digestive troubles, but the most common cause of food-borne illness is leafy vegetables like lettuce, according to a new study, and the most common cause of death is contaminated poultry.

headline: A Tattoo to Help a Soldier Remember
abstract: In “Vampires in the Lemon Grove,” Karen Russell’s new collection of short stories, a soldier’s tattoo depicts the death of a comrade in arms, and a teenage girl dates a ghost.
lead_paragraph: A vampire couple who live in an Italian lemon grove, a pack of girls sent away by their werewolf parents to be educated by nuns, a minotaur and his human family joining the great westward American migration, a teenage girl who’s dating a ghost, a group of Japanese women turned into silkworm slaves by a greedy silk merchant — many of the characters and predicaments depicted in Karen Russell’s fiction belong to that wondrous world of fable that first captivated us as children and that still retains a magnetic hold over many of our imaginations.

headline: Tagg Romney Declines Senate Bid in Massachusetts
abstract: Mitt Romney’s oldest son announced that he would not pursue John Kerry’s now-vacant Senate seat in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The possibility of a new Romney campaign was dashed on Monday evening when Mitt Romney’s oldest son, Tagg, announced that he would not pursue John Kerry’s now-vacant Senate seat in Massachusetts.

headline: For the Oscar Nominees, Fake Fog and Air Kisses
abstract: The Academy Award candidates meet for their annual luncheon, held by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — If the Oscars are a horse race, then the annual nominee luncheon here is the paddock. With the qualifying rounds over and voting set to begin, the competitors are ritually assembled for a high-wattage gathering and a cordial glass of Champagne or two before the bell rings and the jockeying starts in earnest.

headline: Gluten-Free, Whether You Need It or Not
abstract: Avoiding gluten is a must for those with celiac disease, but many people are going gluten-free in a bid for a healthy diet.
lead_paragraph: Eat no wheat.

headline: Never Mind the Parallels, Don’t Read It as My Life
abstract: Jamaica Kincaid says she isn’t writing about her life in her new novel, “See Now Then,” even though it centers on a Caribbean writer with two children married to a composer, just as Ms. Kincaid was.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jamaica Kincaid, whose novel “See Now Then” is her first in 10 years and widely presumed to be autobiographical, wanted to set a few things straight. First, unlike the fictional Mr. Sweet of the novel, her former husband, Allen Shawn (also short and also a composer), never used an expression like “off the banana boat” to describe Ms. Kincaid, who is from Antigua. Nor did he compare her to Charles Laughton or create a nocturne called “This Marriage Is Dead.”

headline: U.S. Military Suspends Ban on Afghan Airline
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense Contracts', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The American military agreed to give the Afghan government details of its drug smuggling accusations against Kam Air, after days of Afghan criticism.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American military on Monday lifted at least for now a recent decision to blacklist one of Afghanistan’s main airlines, Kam Air, on suspicion of drug smuggling, and it agreed to share details of its accusations with the Afghan government.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Super Bowl Tech, and Listening With Google Glass
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include our fascination with apps and other things based on the phenomenon of the loop, a collection of looks at social media, the Internet and the Super Bowl and a collection of photographic creativity from the Web.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Sing Out to the Balcony? Oh, Wait, It’s Just TV
abstract: “Smash,” NBC’s musical-within-a-soap-opera, begins its second season but still looks like a cable mini-series rather than a Broadway spectacular.
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom about the first season of “Smash,” NBC’s musical within a soap opera, was that it started on a high note it couldn’t sustain. The pilot received overwhelmingly positive reviews, but by the last episode it was hard to find anyone who would say a kind word about the show. People were more likely to be tweeting about a misbegotten musical number or how much they hated Ellis, the personal assistant who filled the obligatory young Machiavellian schemer role in the style of “All About Eve.”

headline: Republicans Versus Consumers
abstract: Once again, the G.O.P. is trying to weaken the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell sent a letter to President Obama, cosigned by 42 other Senators, insisting on “structural changes” to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau – a government agency created after the Great Recession to stop private mortgage lenders, money transfer agencies, credit card companies and the like from ruining ordinary Americans in pursuit of ever-higher profits. Unless those changes are made, Mr. McConnell said, the Senate by golly is not going to approve the appointment of a director.

headline: The Players Are Many, the Effect Subdued
abstract: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra added strings and murk to Wayne Shorter’s music at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The title of the latest CD by the saxophonist Wayne Shorter, which will be released on Tuesday, is “Without a Net.” It’s also an apt description for the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which has been playing symphonic music without a conductor for 40 years. On Friday evening they joined forces at Carnegie Hall, where they performed works that Mr. Shorter wrote and arranged for jazz quartet and chamber orchestra. The result, though virtuosic in part and often riveting, somehow fell short of the sum of its parts.

headline: Avenue Capital Prepares New Fund for Europe
abstract: The hedge fund run by Marc Lasry is in the process of raising a $500 million fund to invest in distressed European assets, signaling the firm’s continued belief in a long-term recovery for the region.
lead_paragraph: The Avenue Capital Group, the hedge fund run by Marc Lasry, is increasing its bet on Europe.

headline: Into a Song’s Mysterious Heart
abstract: Amanda McBroom sang standards and original songs like “The Rose” and “Errol Flynn” in her cabaret show at the Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: Listening to Amanda McBroom perform her song “The Rose” at the Café Carlyle on Wednesday evening, I pondered the notion that one person’s art is another person’s kitsch. It would be easy to dismiss this beloved inspirational ballad as a greeting-card homily. To me, however, “The Rose” is art: a miraculous burst of empathy that transcends clichés with its concentrated intensity of feeling as it searches for a definition of love.

headline: An Asteroid, So to Speak, Lands Onstage
abstract: The Juilliard School’s Focus! 2013 ended its exploration of postwar British compositions with renditions of works like “Ceres” and “Ritual Dances.”
lead_paragraph: After conducting the Juilliard Orchestra in a vibrant performance of Mark-Anthony Turnage’s colorful “Ceres,” which received its New York premiere on Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, Mark Wigglesworth turned to the audience and said that it used to be common practice to repeat a new work during a concert. So the ensemble played “Ceres” twice, offering a welcome chance to hear it again.

headline: Familiar Hotel Signs Glow in Unfamiliar Places
abstract: American luxury hotel brands are a common sight overseas, but the major hotel companies are also expanding their midlevel brands to foreign cities.
lead_paragraph: I KNOW that travel is enriching and that locally managed hotels in exotic places can provide wonderful experiences.

headline: Kicking Yourself for Missing That Wigman Tour Back in ’30?
abstract: Fabián Barba reconstructed solos by the German expressionist choreographer Mary Wigman, then danced them as her at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: In 1930 Mary Wigman, one of the innovators of expressionist modern dance in Germany, toured the United States. In 1973 she died, and on Friday at the Museum of Modern Art she returned.

headline: Stirring Music for a Stormy World: A Symphonic Bridge to Understanding
abstract: The West-Eastern Divan Orchestra and the Westminster Symphonic Choir, led by Daniel Barenboim, performed Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony culminates with the ultimate call for understanding and joy among all people, the “just and unjust” alike, to translate a crucial phrase from Schiller’s “Ode to Joy,” the text for the final choral movement. Schiller describes joy as a gift of divinity to mankind. But only those who know the joy of forming an abiding friendship or winning the love of a spouse, only those who can call at least one soul theirs, are truly able to join in this song of praise.

headline: Untamed Instincts, but Traditional Roots
abstract: Lindi Ortega, the Canadian singer-songwriter, performed tracks from her new album, “Cigarettes & Truckstops,” at Joe’s Pub on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Last year, in the first season of the ABC drama “Nashville,” one of the main characters, Avery Barkley (Jonathan Jackson), wished intensely that his band might snag a slot opening for the acclaimed folk-pop dullards the Lumineers when they came to town. But on “Nashville,” even though the show was fiction, the details were real: his band didn’t get the gig, because Lindi Ortega did.

headline: Mental Tests Are Ordered for Cole Bombing Suspect
keywords: ['Cole (USS)', 'Terrorism', 'Military Tribunals', 'Torture', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Detainees']

lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The military tribunal case stemming from the 2000 bombing of the American destroyer Cole bogged down on Monday when prosecutors asked for a mental health evaluation of the defendant, citing defense lawyers’ repeated assertions that he is suffering from post-traumatic stress because of torture by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Egypt: Two Coptic Christians Sentenced for Stealing Weapons
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A criminal court on Monday sentenced two Coptic Christians to three years in prison for stealing weapons from soldiers during a 2011 clash that left more than two dozen Copts dead.
lead_paragraph: A criminal court on Monday sentenced two Coptic Christians to three years in prison for stealing weapons from soldiers during a 2011 clash that left more than two dozen Copts dead. The clash took place on Oct. 9, 2011, when a group of Coptic Christians marched to the state television building to protest discrimination under the generals then ruling Egypt. Video of the episode showed soldiers who were guarding the building driving over protesters with armored vehicles and firing into the crowd. Twenty-seven people died, mostly Coptic Christians. The military has maintained that weapons were stolen from its soldiers and then fired at them and the protesters, causing the soldiers in the vehicles to panic. Last year, the army charged three soldiers who were said to have lost control of their vehicles with the “wrongful killing” of some of the protesters. But a military court acquitted them. Lawyers for the two Coptic Christians convicted Monday said they would appeal.

headline: U.S. Defender Jumping In With Both Feet This Time
abstract: An appearance in Wednesday’s World Cup qualifier in Honduras would tie the German-born Timothy Chandler to the United States national team permanently.
lead_paragraph: The United States national team will open the final round of World Cup qualifying on Wednesday in Honduras, and Timothy Chandler will be a significant addition to the team’s backline. Once he enters the game, he will finally be an official American player.

headline: Party-Line Voting Makes Scott Brown Part of a Dying Breed in the Senate
abstract: Ten years ago there were eight Republicans serving as senators from blue states. Today there are four.
lead_paragraph: Scott P. Brown’s decision not to run in a special Senate race in Massachusetts is a blow to Republican hopes of reclaiming the Senate. Mr. Brown might have had a 50-50 chance of capturing the seat formerly held by Secretary of State John Kerry. But Republicans as popular as Mr. Brown are hard to come by in Massachusetts.

Our mission as filmmakers was to follow the “state builders” — those people in the South Sudanese government and in the United Nations who would be on the front line of implementing, step by step, a road map for the world’s newest state.

headline: Europeans Await Report on Bus Blast in Bulgaria
abstract: Expectations are rising that Bulgarian officials will confirm a link between Hezbollah and a bombing that killed five Israelis in Bulgaria last July.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — A meeting of top government officials and security personnel of this small Balkan country on Tuesday could have wide-reaching repercussions for Europe’s uneasy détente with the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah. Expectations are rising that Bulgarian officials will confirm a link between Hezbollah and the suicide bombing in July 2012 that killed five Israeli tourists and a Bulgarian bus driver and wounded dozens of others in Burgas on the Black Sea coast.

lead_paragraph: It is the peculiar fate of the New Jersey driver, as indelible as a shoreside weekend or a Bruce Springsteen composition, if less easily romanticized.

headline: A Convenient Morality
keywords: ['Priests', 'ABORTION', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Catholic officials all too often pick and choose when laws apply to the church.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Obama administration proposed a further tweak to its rules about insurance coverage of contraception, trying to quiet religious organizations’ complaints that the edict tramples on their beliefs. Roman Catholic officials have been especially vociferous. Their moral conviction, they insist, cannot be slave to secular convention.

headline: The Philosophy of Data
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Statistics', 'Political Advertising', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Our ability to gather and process huge amounts of data does many things, including correcting intuitive biases and illuminating patterns of behavior.
lead_paragraph: If you asked me to describe the rising philosophy of the day, I’d say it is data-ism. We now have the ability to gather huge amounts of data. This ability seems to carry with it certain cultural assumptions — that everything that can be measured should be measured; that data is a transparent and reliable lens that allows us to filter out emotionalism and ideology; that data will help us do remarkable things — like foretell the future.

headline: A Burden of Care Over Seized Exotic Wildlife in Thailand
abstract: With more than 46,000 exotic animals seized from traffickers, vendors and trappers, the country’s wildlife centers are overwhelmed.
lead_paragraph: KHAO PRATUBCHANG, Thailand — Thailand wants to shed its image as a place where many types of wildlife — turtles from Madagascar, marmoset monkeys from South America, baby sun bears, exotic birds — are for sale, an international trade driven by the global market in exotic meats and rare pets.

headline: Thailand Cracks Down on Animal Trafficking
abstract: The Thai government wants to shed its image as a place where many types of wildlife — turtles from Madagascar, marmoset monkeys from South America, baby sun bears, large exotic birds, to name a few — are for sale.
lead_paragraph: The Thai government wants to shed its image as a place where many types of wildlife — turtles from Madagascar, marmoset monkeys from South America, baby sun bears, large exotic birds, to name a few — are for sale.

headline: Academic Counseling Racket
abstract: The case of Michael McAdoo, now a Baltimore Raven, shines a light on the real scandal at the University of North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: On the day after the Super Bowl, I got a call from Michael McAdoo, a 22-year-old defensive lineman for the winning Baltimore Ravens. I had been expecting his call for several weeks, ever since the North Carolina Court of Appeals refused to revive his lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. and the University of North Carolina, where he had played for two years before being declared permanently ineligible. Though he didn’t dress for the big game — he’s been injured most of his short professional career — McAdoo had attended the team’s practices and meetings; he told me he’d been too busy to call earlier.

headline: Them Bones
abstract: More than 500 years later, Richard III will now lie in hallowed ground, but his reputation still wanders the earth.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the final ignominy in the troubled reign of Richard III is this: The monarch’s bones have been found buried under a parking lot in the city of Leicester, England. The skeleton was discovered in September, its spine deformed in a manner consistent with contemporary descriptions of Richard, who died in 1485. Now, thanks to DNA taken from the skeleton and compared with Richard’s modern descendants, there is no doubt that this is the man who, in Shakespeare’s words, wore fortune buckled on his back. He was 32 when he died, and his death in battle ended the struggle for succession called the Wars of the Roses.

headline: A Death Penalty Case in Puerto Rico
abstract: Seeking capital punishment for a federal crime with no clear proof underscores the arbitrariness of the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico abolished the death penalty in 1929 and, a generation later, made it unconstitutional. The island’s Bill of Rights expressly decrees that “the death penalty shall not exist” there. But as a commonwealth of the United States, the island is subject to federal law, including the death penalty for many federal crimes.

headline: Explaining, or Maybe Not, Failure in Talks With Teachers
abstract: The past few weeks have been consumed by competing accounts of how Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the United Federation of Teachers lost $240 million for city schools.
lead_paragraph: Our mayor being true to himself, Michael R. Bloomberg journeyed to Albany last week to lecture state legislators on his decision to blow up negotiations with our teachers union and so lose $240 million for New York City schools.

headline: Litmus Tests
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The sad truth is that criticism and honest discussion about Israeli policy is shrinking, when, in fact, it is essential.
lead_paragraph: One dispiriting lesson from Chuck Hagel’s nomination for defense secretary is the extent to which the political space for discussing Israel forthrightly is shrinking. Republicans focused on Israel more than anything during his confirmation hearing, but they weren’t seeking to understand his views. All they cared about was bullying him into a rigid position on Israel policy. Enforcing that kind of orthodoxy is not in either America’s or Israel’s interest.

headline: Goal to Go

lead_paragraph: After being down 22 points, San Francisco began a furious comeback. With 2:39 left in the game and trailing by 5, the 49ers found themselves with first-and-goal from the 7. Four plays later, their Super Bowl dreams were dashed.

headline: More Jobs, Higher Pay
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Organized Labor', 'Series', 'Editorials']
abstract: To have healthy economic growth, President Obama needs to elevate labor issues in his second term.
lead_paragraph: In President Obama’s first term, the fiscal stimulus and the auto-industry rescue of 2009 created and preserved millions of jobs. But the stimulus ended years ago, replaced with temporary measures that have been insufficient to propel the economy forward. Health care reform in 2010 was a major step in the effort to support the middle class, but its broad effects will be felt only in the years and decades to come.

headline: Known for Crime and Poverty, but Working on Its Image
abstract: Marseille, France’s second-largest city, is hoping that its designation as European Capital of Culture for 2013, and its makeover, will lift tourism and its economy.
lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — In a building here, down by the old port, immigrants from the colonies, most of them North African, were showered, deloused and examined before entry into France. A sort of French Ellis Island, the structure had been abandoned for 40 years and was nearly demolished in 2009. Now, it is being rehabilitated as a museum, for an exhibition opening on March 1 called “Regards de Provence, Mediterranean Reflections” — part of Marseille’s celebration of itself as a European Capital of Culture for 2013.

headline: For Lundqvist, Question Gets Old but Rivalry Doesn’t

Nevertheless, I will be here with you while the incredibly yummy chicken wings are being devoured, because that is the kind of deadline-busting service we provide here at Wordplay. Never let it be said that the copy editors and I don’t make sacrifices for this blog.

headline: New Idea for Penn Station Entails Relocating a College
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Pennsylvania Station (NYC)', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Related Companies is promoting a proposal to restart the redevelopment of Pennsylvania Station by making a community college the anchor tenant in the post office across Eighth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposed transforming the sprawling post office on Eighth Avenue, with its Corinthian columns, into a grand entryway to the busiest transit hub in North America, Pennsylvania Station. Since then, a succession of plans for what is to be known as Moynihan Station have surfaced with fanfare, only to sink later.

headline: Sinopec to Raise $3.1 Billion in Hong Kong
abstract: The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, the oil and refining giant better known as Sinopec, said proceeds from the private placement of new shares would be used to finance business development.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, the state-owned oil and refining giant better known as Sinopec, is selling new shares worth up to 24 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $3.1 billion.

headline: A Ritual Jewish Boundary Stirs Real Town Divisions
abstract: Three lawsuits have been filed in a divisive and emotional dispute over the erection of a ritual boundary for Orthodox Jews in the Westhampton Beach area.
lead_paragraph: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, N.Y. — Every Saturday, Eugene Milanaik, a nurse anesthetist, walks more than five miles back and forth between his Orthodox synagogue and his weekend house on Dune Road. When it rains, he gets soaked, because he cannot carry an umbrella. When his 3-year-old grandson is in town, as he was last weekend, his wife must stay home, because she cannot push his stroller.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Ex-Sniper Extended Hand to Troubled Marine Accused in His Death
abstract: Authorities try to piece together the scene of a shooting and the lives of an ex-Navy SEAL sniper who was killed by a former Marine.
lead_paragraph: LANCASTER, Tex. — On Saturday, when Chris Kyle, a retired Navy SEAL sniper, parked his truck outside Eddie Ray Routh’s house in this Dallas suburb, the two men were virtual strangers. Their plan was to spend the afternoon at a remote shooting range, one of Mr. Kyle’s techniques for helping struggling veterans adjust to civilian life.

headline: In Rebuilding, Alderson Puts the ‘M-E-T’ in Methodical
abstract: The Mets were the last team to sign a major league free agent this off-season, reflecting General Manager Sandy Alderson’s cautious philosophy.
lead_paragraph: The equipment van idled in the players’ parking lot at Citi Field on Monday, loaded with bats and balls and hopes and dreams, bound for Port St. Lucie, Fla. Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ general manager, will follow soon, with his golden retriever, Buddy, by his side. Alderson does not know precisely when he will leave because his daughter is due to deliver her third child this weekend. With the Mets these days, it is always about the kids.

headline: Port Deal Pushed by Menendez Could Benefit Former Aide, Not Just a Major Donor

lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — It turns out that the lucrative port security contract pushed by Senator Robert Menendez would enrich more than just a major benefactor.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several Republican senators — notably John McCain — said Monday they would oppose a filibuster of former Senator Chuck Hagel’s confirmation as secretary of defense, moving the nominee much closer toward approval.

headline: Report Says 54 Countries Helped C.I.A. After 9/11
abstract: The report from a rights advocacy group is the most detailed external account of other countries’ assistance in the agency’s secret detention, rendition and interrogation program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some 54 countries helped facilitate the Central Intelligence Agency’s secret detention, rendition and interrogation program in the years after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, according to a new human rights report that documents broad international involvement in the American campaign against Al Qaeda.

headline: Arlene C. Ackerman, Superintendent, Dies at 66
abstract: Dr. Ackerman improved students’ test scores, including those in the most severely underperforming schools, in each of the three cities in which she presided.
lead_paragraph: Arlene C. Ackerman, who won national accolades for improving student performance as a schools superintendent in all three cities that hired her — Washington, San Francisco and Philadelphia — even as her bulldozer management style rankled union leaders and politicians, died on Saturday in Albuquerque. She was 66.

headline: Bishop John D’Arcy, Who Sounded Alarm on Sex Abuse, Dies at 80
abstract: Bishop D’Arcy was ignored by his superiors in the 1980s when he warned about priests who later figured in the sex-abuse scandal that rocked the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston.
lead_paragraph: Bishop John D’Arcy, who was ignored by his superiors in the 1980s when he warned about priests who later figured in the sex-abuse scandal that rocked the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, died on Sunday at his home in Fort Wayne, Ind., where he had led the Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend for 24 years. He was 80.

headline: Ohio: Governor Will Seek to Cover More Under Medicaid
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Reform and Reorganization']
abstract: Gov. John R. Kasich, a Republican, said he would seek to expand the Medicaid program in Ohio to cover several hundred thousand more adults with incomes up to 138 percent of the poverty level.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John R. Kasich, a Republican, said he would seek to expand the Medicaid program in Ohio to cover several hundred thousand more adults with incomes up to 138 percent of the poverty level. Expanding the program is a central goal of President Obama’s health care law, but the Supreme Court ruled last year that it was an option for states, not a requirement. The federal government is supposed to pay the entire cost of Medicaid for newly eligible beneficiaries from 2014 to 2016, and 90 percent or more in later years. Mr. Kasich said he would reverse his decision if the federal government did not cover its promised share.

headline: 20 Rebounds for Chandler and Win for Knicks
abstract: Tyson Chandler became the first Knick since Willis Reed to grab 20 rebounds in three straight games as the Knicks rolled over the Pistons for their fifth consecutive victory.
lead_paragraph: Tyson Chandler and Steve Novak were unaware that Monday was the first anniversary of the start of Linsanity, which says quite a bit about the season the Knicks are having. This past summer, Chandler and Novak watched Jeremy Lin, their friend and teammate, leave the Knicks for the Houston Rockets.

headline: Gas Buildup and Spark Blamed in Blast
abstract: Mexico’s attorney general said that a buildup of gas ignited by a spark from a faulty electrical system caused the explosion at the Pemex headquarters last week.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s attorney general said Monday that a buildup of gas ignited by a spark from a faulty electrical system had caused the explosion at the headquarters of Mexico’s state-owned oil company, which killed at least 37 people last week.

headline: Memo Cites Legal Basis for Killing U.S. Citizens in Al Qaeda
abstract: Obama administration lawyers said it would be lawful to kill a United States citizen who is a ranking figure in Al Qaeda and who poses “an imminent threat” against the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Obama administration lawyers have asserted that it would be lawful to kill a United States citizen if “an informed, high-level official” of the government decided that the target was a ranking figure in Al Qaeda who posed “an imminent threat of violent attack against the United States” and if his capture was not feasible, according to a 16-page document made public on Monday.

headline: Five Questions for: Journalist and Author Mary Harper
abstract: The British writer on writing about Africa.
lead_paragraph: Mary Harper, the Africa editor at the BBC World Service, is the author of “Getting Somalia Wrong? Faith, War and Hope in a Shattered State,” which was released in February 2012. While she is particularly interested in Somalia, which she visits regularly, Ms. Harper has reported from several other African conflict zones, including Algeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Sudan. India Ink interviewed Ms. Harper at the Jaipur Literature Festival.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3 P.M. (TCM) CAMELOT (1967) Richard Harris stars as King Arthur; Vanessa Redgrave is Guenevere, his queen; and Franco Nero, above left with Harris and Ms. Redgrave, is Lancelot du Lac, her lover and her husband’s best knight, in this adaptation of the Lerner and Loewe musical, directed by Joshua Logan and written by Alan Jay Lerner. “It is hard to feel cozy with people you simply don’t understand,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. “If we’re supposed to regard theirs as a clandestine ménage-à-trois, which is likely to be suspected from the campy way Mr. Harris sometimes performs, it isn’t developed sufficiently to make it daring or interesting.” Nonetheless, the film won Oscars for best art direction, best costume design and best music.

headline: Worse Than Poisoned Water: Dwindling Water, in China’s North
keywords: ['Chemicals', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Rivers', 'Water', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: When members of China’s Greenpeace office inspected the site of a massive chemical spill in Shanxi province last month, they found an even more worrying environmental problem: disappearing water resources.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When 39 tons of the toxic chemical aniline spilled from a factory in Changzhi in China’s Shanxi province at the end of December, polluting drinking water for hundreds of thousands of people downstream along the Zhuozhang River and dangerously fouling the environment, it seemed a grave enough disaster. And it was.

headline: UBS Posts $2 Billion Loss Tied to Legal Settlements

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swiss bank UBS on Tuesday reported a large loss for the fourth quarter, driven by the costs of settling legal matters, including its role in a global rate-manipulation scandal.

headline: Will All Be Forgiven for Timothy Chandler?

lead_paragraph: Brian Sciaretta, a regular contributor to the Goal blog, spoke with the German-American defender Timothy Chandler for an article that appeared in Tuesday’s editions of The Times. Chandler, 22, has made only nine appearances for the United States national team, all in international friendlies, but by opting not to make more in the past two years he had become a source of frustration for American coaches and fans.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Even if North Korea follows through with its threat to conduct a third nuclear test, Washington and its allies will have difficulty determining whether the device detonated is made of plutonium or uranium, a prominent American nuclear scientist and South Korean officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Money Changes Everything
abstract: According to new research, money actually does buy happiness — with one notable exception.
lead_paragraph: Depending on when you’re reading this column, economists have a pretty good guess as to what kind of mood you’re in. If it’s Sunday, you’re almost certainly happier than if you’re catching it on a Monday. Either way, there’s a good chance you’re in a lousy mood if it’s 7 a.m. (Sorry!) You’ll be happier around lunchtime, sadder at 2 p.m. but should perk up by 8 in the evening.

headline: Is School Designed More for Girls Than Boys?
abstract: Have you noticed boys who are struggling in school because of poor behavior? Do you see boys who are “smart,” yet unengaged by school? More so than girls?
lead_paragraph: Girls tend to develop certain skills earlier than boys: for example, the ability to sit still and stay attentive. Our school day, more often than not, demands that students do just that — sit for long periods of time and listen attentively — or else suffer a lower grade or disciplinary action. Now, girls are outperforming boys at all levels of the educational ladder, from kindergarten to graduate school.

headline: An X-Ray of Russian Corruption
abstract: Has corruption become so ingrained in Russian society that it is almost part of the nation’s genetic code? Using a panoramic camera, Misha Friedman explored how people accept corruption and shortcuts in daily life.
lead_paragraph: Before James Watson, Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins won the Nobel Prize for their discovery of DNA’s double helix, “Photo 51″ — an X-ray photograph — helped them identify the molecule’s complex structure. And just as photography made visible what scientists suspected, Misha Friedman is training his camera on what seems like a common trait in his national genetic code.

headline: Ahmadinejad’s Ally Arrested as Fight With Political Family Grows

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian judicial authorities arrested a protégé of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Monday, the latest round in an escalating power struggle between Iran’s elected leader and the country’s most influential political family.

The Japanese Defense Ministry also said that a Chinese frigate directed the same kind of radar at one of Japan’s military helicopters in a previously undisclosed episode on Jan. 19.

lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley rose up en masse last year to trash the reality series “Start-Ups: Silicon Valley,” mostly for the sin of making it look as if just about anyone who was good-looking and self-confident could start an Internet company. If you were striving here to succeed or were covering those trying to succeed, wouldn’t you want to believe that skill if not genius was required too?

headline: Germany and Drones
abstract: One of the clearest signs of Germany’s new self-confidence is Chancellor Angela Merkel’s pursuit of armed drones.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When France launched a military intervention in Mali last month, Germany appeared to be in the familiar position of the bashful, gentle giant. No German combat troops would be sent to support their French comrades, Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle declared. Instead, the German government sent two cargo planes and promised the delivery of 50 flak jackets “in the very near future.”

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks to Resume This Month
abstract: Iran reached an agreement on Tuesday with world powers to resume the stuttering dialogue over its disputed nuclear program later this month in Kazakhstan, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Breaking a deadlock over the location and timing of new talks on its disputed nuclear program, Iran has agreed to resume its stuttering dialogue with world powers later this month in Kazakhstan, Iranian and Western officials said on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: A deal for Dell is almost here. In what would be the biggest buyout since the financial crisis, Dell was close to an agreement to sell itself to a consortium of its founder, Microsoft and the private equity firm Silver Lake for more than $23 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced.

headline: Irish Premier’s Apology Fails to Appease Workhouse Survivors
abstract: A 1,o00-page government report puts a spotlight on the detention of thousands of women in Catholic workhouses, which were found to have extensive state involvement.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Advocates for survivors of a Roman Catholic workhouse system that kept generations of young women and girls in virtual slavery expressed disappointment and anger on Tuesday at Prime Minister Enda Kenny’s failure to formally apologize after a report found extensive state involvement in the institutions.

headline: At Odds With the Government, Japan’s Central Bank Chief Offers an Early Exit
abstract: Masaaki Shirakawa, criticized for caution as the country endured years of deflation, said he would leave three weeks before his term ends.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The governor of the Japanese central bank, Masaaki Shirakawa, said on Tuesday that he had offered to step down on March 19, three weeks before the end of his term, under intense government pressure on the bank to take bolder steps to resuscitate the deflationary economy.

headline: ‘Walking Dead’ Man Walking: An Exit Interview With Glen Mazzara
abstract: Glen Mazzara, who is stepping down as the show runner of the hit AMC series “The Walking Dead,” discusses his departure from the series and his vision for his final episodes.
lead_paragraph: On  “The Walking Dead,” there are no guarantees which members of its still-living ensemble will stick around from one week to the next — and that goes for the creative team as well. Glen Mazzara, the show runner of this hit AMC survival-horror drama, is the latest to leave the show: after steering “The Walking Dead” through its  second and third seasons, Mr. Mazzara, a former producer of “The Shield,” announced in December that he was parting ways with AMC and with “The Walking Dead” — having taken over the show from Frank Darabont, who developed it from the comic-book series and was deposed after its first season.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting:  Super Bowl Ads Hewed to the Sentimental or Comical, and Muzak Faces the Music
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Super Bowl']
abstract: Most Super Bowl ads tried for either humor or sentimentality; the Muzak name is going away, but not necessarily the music; and an NBCUniversal executive moves up.
lead_paragraph: Most of the 46 commercials that ran during Super Bowl XLVII were either emotional or humorous, Stuart Elliott writes in The Times.  Comic actors like Tracy Morgan and Amy Poehler anchored irreverent spots for MiO Fit and Best Buy, and some of the memorable ads in a largely disappointing crop relied on sentimentality.  For example, The Chrysler Group ran two tributes to veterans and American farmers to sell Jeep Cherokees and Dodge Rams.  Other sponsors, like Anheuser-Busch InBev, used both approaches.  An ad for Budweiser showed one Clydesdale’s reunion with the man who raised it, echoing a popular YouTube clip of a lion named Christian; and an ad for Bud Light featured Stevie Wonder as a voodoo king casting good luck spells for ardent football fans.  Suzanne Vranica of The Wall Street Journal also covers the more successful Super Bowl ads.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Perfect Record
abstract: He’s the only one on the losing side of every Senate vote taken this term.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz of Texas has been in the Senate for all of a month, but has already compiled an impressive voting record, according to the Washington Times. He is the only senator who has been on the losing side of every vote he has taken this term, a zero-for-11 record.

headline: A Son ‘Cuts,’ and a Father Struggles
abstract: A text, from a tween: “Dad ummm there no easy way to tell you this but (my brother)’s been cutting himself don’t tell you know or he’ll do it again.”
lead_paragraph: To protect his family’s privacy, the author of this essay has asked that his name be withheld, and because of the sensitive, but important, nature of the subject, I’ve agreed. This is the first anonymous post since I’ve taken over here at Motherlode, and I expect such contributions to be rare. Even when an issue is delicate, a writer who wants to be heard on a topic should be willing to speak publicly.

headline: Football’s Over. Now What Do We Watch?
abstract: Eventually we have to emerge from the post-Super Bowl stupor and face the rest of the sports world.
lead_paragraph: While the Monday after the Super Bowl may be the day of the actual hangover — especially if you make a drinking game out of every time Phil Simms said something ludicrous on the CBS broadcast, and let’s hope you dropped that idea by the opening kickoff to avoid needing medical attention — Tuesday is the day of the sports hangover.

headline: Rendez-Vous With French Cinema Puts Focus on  Renoir
abstract: Films by and about Jean Renoir is among the focuses of the 18th annual Rendez-Vous With French Cinema.
lead_paragraph: A score of films ranging from drama to comedy by established and rising talents, as well as a selection of work by and about Jean Renoir will make up the 18th edition of Rendez-Vous With French Cinema, a series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and Unifrance Films, an entity sponsored by the French government, the society announced Tuesday. The showings, scheduled to take place not only at Lincoln Center, but also at the IFC Center, BAMcinematek and the Paris Theater, will begin Feb. 28 and run through March 10.

headline: About.me Buys Itself Back From AOL
abstract: On Monday, About.me’s co-founders announced that they had purchased their company back from AOL, which originally acquired the company two years ago for tens of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Here’s your next challenge as a founder of a start-up: Sell your company to a digital behemoth for tens of millions of dollars, then buy it back for a fraction of the cost. Oh, and keep the change.

headline: New Director Named for National Portrait Gallery
abstract: Kim Sajet, the current president and chief executive of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania, will be the new director of the National Portrait Gallery in Washington.
lead_paragraph: The National Portrait Gallery in Washington will have a new director on April 1: Kim Sajet (pronounced SAY-et), the current president and chief executive of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania. Ms. Sajet, who was born in Nigeria, raised in Australia and is a citizen of the Netherlands, will be responsible for a staff of 65, an annual budget of about $9 million, and 21,000 objects that include Gilbert Stuart’s famous unfinished portrait of George Washington, photographs of Abraham Lincoln and videos of more recent presidents.

headline: On Our Radar: A Research Station on Skis
abstract: To cope with shifting ice in the Antarctic, researchers devise a structure made of modules with legs that sit atop skis.
lead_paragraph: To deal with shifting ice in the Antarctic, a British research station has extendable legs on giant skis so they can move in unison. [RTTNews]

headline: What We’re Reading
