headline: The Japan Story
abstract: Not at all what people say.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baker is annoyed at Robert Samuelson, not for the first time, and with reason. The idea of invoking Japan, of all places, to justify fears that stimulus leads to inflation or asset bubbles is just bizarre. And while there is much shaking of heads about Japanese debt, the ill-effects if any of that debt are by no means obvious.

headline: Crash Injuries End Vonn’s Season, but Not Her Hopes
abstract: Lindsey Vonn, whose ski racing career has mixed stirring triumph with frightening spills, tore two knee ligaments and was airlifted from the Alpine world championships.
lead_paragraph: SCHLADMING, Austria — The Olympic champion Lindsey Vonn, whose record-breaking ski racing career has frequently mixed stirring triumph with frightening spills, tore two knee ligaments in a tumbling crash Tuesday and will need reconstructive surgery. Vonn fell in the super-G of the Alpine world championships, a race contested one year and two days before the scheduled start of the Sochi Olympics in Russia.

headline: Bulgaria Implicates Hezbollah in July Attack on Israelis
abstract: The finding could have repercussions for Europe’s détente with the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, which is an influential force in Middle East politics.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — The clues to a fatal bomb attack on Israeli vacationers in Bulgaria included a charred tour bus, a decapitated head and a fake driver’s license.

headline: The Army Behind Dell’s Big Deal
abstract: Gigantic leveraged buyouts don’t happen all by themselves. Roughly a dozen advisers were involved in the $24.4 billion takeover of Dell by its founder, Michael S. Dell, and the investment firm Silver Lake.
lead_paragraph: Huge leveraged buyouts don’t happen all by themselves.

headline: New Bridget Jones Novel Coming in November
abstract: Helen Fielding, the author of “Bridget Jones’s Diary” and “Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason,” said the new novel “represents a totally new phase in Bridget’s life.”
lead_paragraph: It has been some 14 years since Bridget Jones last put pen to paper (or fingertips to a keyboard) to record her weight, her caloric intake and her shags in her celebrated diary. Now that celebrated, self-deprecating literary protagonist (and sometime alter ego of the author Helen Fielding) will return in her first novel since the publication of “Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason.”

headline: Apple to Highlight Self-Published Books
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: The Apple iBookstore will feature a grouping of self-published books titled “Breakout Books.”
lead_paragraph: Yet another sign that self-publishing is making inroads into the traditional houses: On Tuesday Apple will include a feature that organizes a group of popular self-published e-books together and then gives them prominent display on iBookstore.

headline: Chinese Blogger Thrives as Muckraker
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'News and News Media', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Zhu Ruifeng, who became a celebrity of sorts after posting online a sex video involving a government official, says he will release more videos involving others.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With his five cellphones constantly ringing, it is not easy these days to get the undivided attention of Zhu Ruifeng, a professed citizen journalist whose freelance campaign against graft has earned him pop-star acclaim and sent a chill through Chinese officialdom.

headline: Ahmadinejad Visits Egypt, Signaling Realignment
abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Tuesday made the first visit by an Iranian leader to Egypt since the two countries broke off diplomatic relations three decades ago.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s historic three-day trip to Egypt, the first in three decades by an Iranian leader, started pleasantly enough on Tuesday.

headline: Companion of Delhi Gang Rape Victim Testifies in Court
abstract: Male friend of the victim, who was also attacked, appeared in court in a wheelchair.
lead_paragraph: The male friend who witnessed the fatal rape of a young woman by a group of attackers in New Delhi in December entered court in a wheelchair to testify on Tuesday.

headline: Surplus Paint From the Brooklyn Bridge Now Could Be Yours
abstract: Looking for 500 or so gallons of chocolate brown semi-gloss enamel and about 100 gallons of buff? Check out the city’s public surplus auction.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Bridge may not be for sale, but surplus paint from the span is.

headline: On Online Matchmaker for Tax Preparers and Clients
abstract: Prosado, a new Web site, aims to have tax preparers bid for your business.
lead_paragraph: The traditional way to find a tax preparer is to ask your friends and family for a recommendation. But what if you don’t want to go the word-of-mouth route — and risk ending up with your eccentric second cousin doing your taxes (or your ignorant but well-meaning friend’s idea of a good accountant)?

headline: Reasons to Be Suspicious of Buyouts Led by Management
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Dell shareholders take note. Many management-led buyouts have been successful enriching management at shareholder expense. A look at some of the worst ones shows why.
lead_paragraph: With the help of the private equity firm Silver Lake and Microsoft, Michael S. Dell, the founder and chief executive, is buying back his computer company.

headline: Elizabeth Meriwether Answers Your ‘New Girl’ Questions
abstract: Elizabeth Meriwether, the creator of “New Girl,” responds to questions from Times readers about the show.
lead_paragraph: Previously we heard from the creators of “Modern Family,” “Homeland” and “Justified.”

headline: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
abstract: President Obama pressed lawmakers on Tuesday to pass a package of limited spending cuts and tax changes to avoid the across-the-board reductions set to take effect on March 1.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday called on Congress to quickly pass a new package of limited spending cuts and tax increases to head off substantial across-the-board reductions to domestic and military spending set to begin on March 1, but his appeal for more revenue was dismissed by Republicans.

headline: ‘House Sister,’ Collector of Properties, Held in Chinese Graft Case
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Outrage is growing over revelations that officials and their confederates have accumulated dozens, if not scores, of homes in China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese police said on Tuesday that they had detained Gong Aiai, popularly known as House Sister, in a corruption case that has gripped China for weeks after it was revealed that Ms. Gong and her family had accumulated dozens of houses and other properties. She was caught on Sunday, the police said, and is being held on suspicion of forging official identity papers and other documents she used in an effort to escape detection.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 5
abstract: An air show in Bangalore, Karnataka, ahead of the Aero India 2013 aviation exhibition.

headline: A Rationale for Killing
abstract: A memo outlines the Obama administration’s views on killing American citizens linked to Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: A memo outlines the Obama administration’s views on killing American citizens linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: Celtics Find a Way Without Rondo
abstract: The Celtics, written off as playoff contenders when Rajon Rondo was lost for the season, are finding new ways to run their offense without him.
lead_paragraph: During Doc Rivers’s tenure, the Boston Celtics have made an amusing habit of heading into the All-Star break haggard and hobbled, only to work themselves back into playoff contention.

headline: Capturing Modernism’s Chic and Sheen
abstract: Ezra Stoller’s photographs of architecture helped fix modern design into America’s consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Stoller, the American architectural photographer, left behind a trove of modernist classics of modernist classics. Picture Eero Saarinen’s TWA Terminal, or Philip Johnson’s Glass House, or the Manufacturers Trust building by Gordon Bunshaft, with its bank vault by Henry Dreyfus. Chances are you’ve got one of Stoller’s images in mind. Immaculate, self-effacing and with a mix of light and shadow revealing every angle and surface, his photographs stressed geometry, transparency, timelessness — like the buildings.

headline: Architecture Photography by Ezra Stoller
abstract: Mr. Stoller’s pictures helped fix modern design in America’s consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Stoller’s pictures helped fix modern design in America’s consciousness.

headline: ‘Anna Karenina,’ ‘Pi’ and ‘Skyfall’ Win Art Director Awards
abstract: The Art Directors Guild names its choices for best production design of the year.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Art Directors Guild divide their choices for the year’s best production design over several categories. But even so, the winners, announced over the weekend, do overlap somewhat with the Oscar nominees.

headline: The Gun Report: February 5, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Need to call the National Rifle Association? You ought to try it just to hear the hold message. “Thanks for calling the National Rifle Association,” a soothing female voice intones. “Due to the attacks on our Second Amendment, we are experiencing higher than usual wait time.”  The number, by the way, is 1-800-672-3888; choose option 2.

headline: Exit Light, Enter Night
abstract: How Times Square and areas near New York looked without light pollution — if only for a few nights.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday the French government decreed that as of July, all shops and offices in France must shut off their lights at night. The action is intended to “reduce the print of artificial lighting on the nocturnal environment.” Thierry Cohen’s portfolio “Starry, Starry, Starry Night,” which appeared in this past weekend’s magazine, shows us what major cities might look like if there were no light pollution.

headline: S.&P. Calls Government’s Suit ‘Meritless’
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services defended its corporate practices on Tuesday, saying a civil lawsuit filed against it by the Justice Department was unjustified.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services defended its corporate practices on Tuesday, saying a civil lawsuit filed by the Justice Department that accuses the firm of inflating its ratings of mortgage investments was “meritless.”

headline: Mano de Estados Unidos frena promoción de general en México
abstract: Evitan que al general Moisés García Ochoa se convierta en Ministro de Defensa. Funcionarios americanos expresaron preocupación de que tuviera vínculos con narcotraficantes.
lead_paragraph: Por GINGER THOMPSON, RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD y ERIC SCHMITT

headline: Maysville
abstract: Inside the new restaurant that is a winning blend of the refined and the unpretentious.
lead_paragraph: Inside the new restaurant that is a winning blend of the refined and the unpretentious.

headline: Nuance Meets Its Kentucky Roots
abstract: A new restaurant on West 26th Street named after the birthplace of Kentucky bourbon is a confident restatement of the American tavern.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I HEARD that a new restaurant on West 26th Street had named itself after Maysville, the Kentucky town where Rosemary Clooney was born, I wondered why nobody had thought of this before. The singer had hopscotched her way across lyrics laden with enough food references to inspire a full menu.

headline: Preparing for the Iditarod
abstract: A view of some of the two- and four-legged competitors getting ready for the Iditarod sled dog race next month in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: A view of some of the two- and four-legged competitors getting ready for the Iditarod sled dog race next month in Alaska.

headline: Top Judge Says Bail in New York Isn’t Safe or Fair
abstract: Jonathan Lippman, the state’s chief judge, said the system unfairly detained many people and did not allow judges to consider public safety when determining bail.
lead_paragraph: Castigating the bail process in New York as unfair to the poor and susceptible to allowing dangerous suspects to be set free, the state’s top judge called on Tuesday for an overhaul of the bail system that would bring the state closer in line with the rest of the country.

headline: In Performance: Will Chase of ‘The Mystery of Edwin Drood’
abstract: The actor puts a country twist on a number from the Broadway revival at Studio 54.
lead_paragraph: “The Mystery of Edwin Drood,” now in a Roundabout Theater revival on Broadway, is set in a Victorian music hall where actors are putting on a performance of Charles Dickens’s last, unfinished novel. In this scene, Will Chase, who plays the actor Clive Paget (who portrays the villain John Jasper), puts a country twist on the number “Both Sides of the Coin.” The show continues through March 10 at Studio 54.

headline: Most Facebook Users Have Taken a Break From the Site, Survey Finds
abstract: A new survey from Pew Internet, a research center, found that a majority of Facebook users took voluntary breaks from the site, citing boredom or concerns about privacy.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is the most popular social network in America — roughly two-thirds of adults in the country use it on a regular basis.

headline: Study Slams Nuclear Waste Practices at Hanford
abstract: A former site for manufacturing weapons-grade uranium is poorly managed “by just about any definition,” a report from the Government Accountability Office says.
lead_paragraph: Management and disposal of radioactive waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State, marred by problems for more than two decades, is the focus of a harsh new assessment by the Government Accountability Office.

headline: U.S. Accuses S.&P. of Fraud
abstract: The Justice Department accused the credit ratings agency of inflating its assessment of mortgage investments that spurred the 2008 financial crisis
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department accused the credit ratings agency of inflating its assessment of mortgage investments that spurred the 2008 financial crisis

headline: Sax Inspiration in a Greek Epic
abstract: The saxophonist Chris Potter discusses his new album, “The Sirens,” and how it was influenced by “The Odyssey.”
lead_paragraph: Since recording his first album just over 20 years ago, Chris Potter has earned his stature as the most commandingly skilled saxophonist of his generation, an improviser of deft insight and athletic poise. His high profile as a sideman — in the studio with Steely Dan, and in bands led by the drummer Paul Motian, the bassist Dave Holland and, most recently, the guitarist Pat Metheny — has sometimes overshadowed his output as a bandleader.

headline: America’s Moral Volcano
abstract: American landscape painters engaged with the Civil War on a metaphorical level, none more so that Frederic Church’s “Cotopaxi.”
lead_paragraph: For all the wealth of visual material made to document the Civil War – photographs, battlefield sketches – America’s landscape painters seemingly paid little attention to the war’s events. Despite occupying a dominant position in the country’s culture at the time, they rarely depicted Civil War battlefields. But much lies beneath the literal surface: many of their paintings demonstrate a strong sense of the tension and turbulence of the times, conveyed by the skies and the terrain.

headline: Warm Mushing Season
abstract: It has been an unusually warm winter in Alaska, and that has caused trouble for mushers and their sled dogs.
lead_paragraph: It has been an unusually warm winter in Alaska, and that has caused trouble for mushers and their sled dogs.

keywords: ['Poverty', 'Income Tax', 'Welfare (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Food Stamps']
abstract: The president of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities says many safety-net programs are quite effective. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Warm Weather Forces Changes Ahead of Iditarod Race
keywords: ['Dog Sledding', 'Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race (Alaska)', 'Global Warming', 'Weather']
abstract: Temperatures in the 30s and 40s mean several dog-sledding events before the Iditarod have been rerouted, postponed or canceled.
lead_paragraph: WILLOW, Alaska — By 9:30 most mornings here in the world’s unofficial dog-sledding capital, Luan Marques has harnessed 10 Alaskan huskies to his sled and shot off into the awakening woods for a training ride, his sights set on the famous Iditarod competition next month.

headline: N.W.S.L. Keeps the Dream Alive
abstract: In women’s professional soccer, is the new N.W.S.L. finally going to get it right?
lead_paragraph: Many of us who were invested in Women’s Professional Soccer rejoiced when the National Women’s Soccer League was announced.

headline: Hockey Night in Queens
abstract: M. Wells Dinette turns into a sports bar for one night.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re a hockey fan or not, you can grab dinner Wednesday evening at M. Wells Dinette, a cafeteria inside MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, while cheering for either the Montreal Canadiens or the Boston Bruins as they face off on the big screen. The dinette normally does not serve dinner, so why now? Hugue Dufour, the chef and co-owner of the restaurant, happens to be French Canadian, and the Bruins are to the Canadiens what the Red Sox are to the Yankees. The dinner, starting at 7 p.m., costs $60, and includes fried chicken, Philly cheesesteaks, pizza, fondue, poutine and more. Reservations can be made at mwellsreservations@gmail.com. Be sure to include contact information and the size of your party. The restaurant, at 22-25 Jackson Avenue,  (718) 786-1800, has announced new hours: noon to 6 p.m. every day except Tuesdays and Wednesdays, when the museum is closed.

headline: Common Application Releases New Essay Prompts
abstract: The Common App will still be a stickler for word lengths, as we reported in October. However, the maximum word count has increased to 650 words.
lead_paragraph: The new Common Application — which received some criticism a few months ago for removing the “topic of your choice” essay prompt — has released five new essay prompts for the 2013-14 admissions season, Inside Higher Ed reports.

headline: Red Carpet: Academy Awards Luncheon
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had a luncheon on Monday to honor this year’s Oscars nominees, including Jennifer Lawrence and Denzel Washington.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had a luncheon on Monday to honor this year’s Oscars nominees, including Jennifer Lawrence and Denzel Washington.

headline: Rivals Don’t Mean to Rain on Dell’s Parade, but …
abstract: Dell may be promoting its $24.4 billion leveraged buyout as the next step in its turnaround plan. But some of the computer maker’s rivals, including Lenovo and H.P., couldn’t resist throwing a few jabs at the company all the same.
lead_paragraph: Dell may be promoting its $24.4 billion leveraged buyout as the next step in its turnaround plan. But some of the computer maker’s rivals couldn’t resist throwing a few jabs at the company all the same.

headline: North Korean Propaganda Video Imagines a Brighter World, Without Manhattan
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Propaganda']
abstract: When North Koreans dream of taking revenge on the United States, it appears that American video games and music figure heavily.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 3:52 p.m. When aliens strike, the climate goes berserk, the Russians invade, an asteroid threatens the Earth, New York City is often the first place to be destroyed. Hollywood has long used the city’s skyline to demonstrate what destruction looks like in action movies and video games. It seems as if North Korea, in seeking to show how an assault on America would play out, also has Manhattan squarely in its cross hairs.

headline: Spielberg and Affleck Get the Last Laughs
abstract: At the DGA Awards, Steven Spielberg and Ben Affleck were delivering the one-liners, though it was Mr. Affleck who walked away with the trophy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – What do you do as a follow-up to an introduction by Bill Clinton? At the Directors Guild Awards on Saturday, Steven Spielberg and the team from “Lincoln” called in a different kind of artillery in Martin Short.

headline: And Spotify’s Grammys Go To…
abstract: Spotify is betting that it can predict which artists will take home coveted gold gramophones at the Grammy Awards, based on how many times their tracks or albums have been streamed.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, hundreds of artists and musicians will gather in Los Angeles, hoping to take home one of the most prestigious awards in music at the Grammy Awards.

headline: Not Letting Anything Slide
abstract: Global cruise lines try to trump one another with bigger and better water slides on deck.
lead_paragraph: Anything you can do I can do better. The Irving Berlin line pretty much sums up the mind-set of global cruise lines, which are offering such a staggering number of itineraries that they are forced to stand out by trumping one another.

headline: Do Your Board Members Represent Your Interests?
abstract: Once you’re on the venture-capital treadmill, the investors always want the next round completed and the round after that.
lead_paragraph: Whenever small-business owners and entrepreneurs come to me looking for capital, I encourage them to think about the trade-offs involved in choosing debt or equity. Sometimes there is no choice, and they have to pick one or the other. But often there is a choice, and that’s when it’s especially important to think things through.

headline: China Issues Proposal to Narrow Income Gap
abstract: The government offered broad vows to lift the incomes of workers and farmers and choke off corrupt wealth but few specific goals to rein in the nation’s wide inequality.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government issued a long-awaited plan on Tuesday to narrow the gulf between rich and poor, offering broad vows to lift the incomes of workers and farmers and choke off corrupt wealth but few specific goals to rein in the nation’s wide inequality.

abstract: In the winter, Hasidim take special steps to protect themselves, and their clothing, from the elements while making sure not to violate the customs of the Sabbath.
lead_paragraph: Hasidim have hoodies too — though theirs are intended for winter Sabbaths.

headline: Woman Fatally Struck by a Truck in Midtown Manhattan
abstract: The truck fled the scene after hitting the 69-year-old victim, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A woman was hit by a truck in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday morning and died later from her injuries, according to the police.

headline: Talking About Pucci in the Present Tense
abstract: The house long synonymous with prints colorfully psychedelic enough to induce seizures in Japanese schoolchildren is now dabbling in Morticia Addams silhouettes for dignified state occasions.
lead_paragraph: For me, the real shocker wasn’t that Beyoncé lip-synced the national anthem at President Obama’s inauguration (you were expecting maybe Maria Callas?), complete with dramatic shedding of unnecessary earphone. It was that the long-sleeved, boatnecked black gown she was wearing bore the label of Emilio Pucci.

headline: Justice Department Faces Uphill Battle in Proving S.& P. Fraud
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The Justice Department in a civil complaint accused Standard & Poor’s of issuing faulty credit ratings on securities tied to mortgages. While the document is chock full of dubious actions, it may be hard to prove the behavior amounts to fraud.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department accused Standard & Poor’s of issuing faulty credit ratings on securities tied to mortgages. The 119-page civil complaint is chock-full of e-mails that paint a picture of shoddy practices and greed as S.& P. purportedly watered down its standards to generate more business.

headline: Don’t Let Iran Stall for Time
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Negotiations with Iran won’t be successful if Tehran believes it can wait out international pressure.
lead_paragraph: FEW of President Obama’s original foreign policy goals have eluded him so much as engagement with Iran. Over the weekend, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced during a speech in Munich that the United States was ready for direct talks with Iran. With the risk of war over Iran’s nuclear program looming, the offer is prudent, but it is also beside the point. As Iran continues to evade negotiations — literally in this case, since the Iranian foreign minister was in the same building as Mr. Biden — the real question is not whether America should talk to Iran, but how to get the Iranians to talk to us in earnest.

abstract: Price increases didn’t hamper subscriber growth at the satellite radio company, which is offering new services to compete with the likes of Pandora.
lead_paragraph: Sirius XM Radio reported strong subscriber and revenue growth for 2012 on Tuesday and described new features that the company hopes will put competitive pressure on Internet radio services like Pandora and Clear Channel’s iHeartRadio.

lead_paragraph: When the trio of conservative judges on the D.C. Circuit ruled last month that President Obama’s three recess appointments to the National Labor Relations Board were unconstitutional, the decision had immediate and wide repercussions for the administration.

headline: Obama Plans Visit to Israel This Spring
abstract: President Obama’s time in Israel could be tense as he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu try to move past years of friction. Mr. Obama will also go to Jordan and the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to travel to Israel this spring for the first time since taking office, as he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu try to move past the friction of the last four years now that both have won re-election.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Tuesday staked out what they cast as a middle-ground option in the debate over immigration, pushing an approach that could include legal residency but not a path to citizenship — as their Democratic counterparts favor — for the 11 million illegal immigrants already in the country.

headline: Many Relying on Home Equity for Retirement
abstract: A survey finds a big gap between what workers expect to need for retirement and what they’ve saved.
lead_paragraph: Even though the housing market has not recovered, nearly half of older working Americans expect to use equity in their homes to help finance their retirement, a new survey finds.

headline: Lost Votes, Problem Ballots, Long Waits? Flaws Are Widespread, Study Finds
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'States (US)']
abstract: Problems in the election system extend beyond isolated voting issues in a few locations, according to a study from the Pew Charitable Trusts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The flaws in the American election system are deep and widespread, extending beyond isolated voting issues in a few locations and flaring up in states rich and poor, according to a major new study from the Pew Charitable Trusts.

headline: 2 Pulled From Pond in Central Park After Falling Through Ice
abstract: The people fell through the ice around 2 p.m. but were quickly pulled to safety.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:56 p.m. | Two people were rescued from the frigid water of the pond in Central Park after falling through the ice around 2 p.m. Tuesday, the Fire Department said. A firefighter in a wet suit entered the pond, in the southeast corner of the park near 59th Street and Fifth Avenue, and helped pull them to safety.

headline: Cantor Speech Expands His Visibility and Party Vision
abstract: Eric Cantor laid out an expansive social agenda for the Republican Party on education, health care, job training and scientific research.
lead_paragraph: Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, seeking to soften the image of a Republican Party that has been focused almost exclusively on budget cutting, laid out an expansive social agenda on Tuesday for education, health care, job training and scientific research — what he called “creating the conditions for health, happiness and prosperity.”

headline: Cuomo Acted Like Hitler in Gun Push, Official Says
abstract: Assemblyman Steven F. McLaughlin compared Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s push for quick action on gun limits to Hitler’s and Mussolini’s dictatorships, but later apologized.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A Republican state assemblyman unhappy with the way Gov.Andrew M. Cuomo pushed the Legislature to approve strict new gun laws said Tuesday that Hitler and Mussolini would have been proud of the governor’s actions.

headline: Losing Baby Teeth in Concert
abstract: Daniil Trifonov, the 21-year-old Russian pianist, will make his Carnegie Hall recital debut in the main hall on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: At only 21 the charismatic Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov has already reached a

headline: Curiosity Ready to Drill, Dream Science and More
abstract: A sampling of some of the day’s science headlines.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday in science, sharks with an image problem, good teeth get more dates, dog geniuses and remembering your dreams. Check out these headlines and other science news from around the Web.

headline: Quirks of the Game: The Other Calls That Altered the Course of the Super Bowl
abstract: Plenty of people were discussing the Super Bowl officials’ non-call on the 49ers’ late fourth-and-goal play, but other officiating decisions played key roles, too.
lead_paragraph: In the final seconds of the Super Bowl, announcers, pundits and fans argued whether the lack of a pass interference call on San Francisco’s frantic fourth-and-goal play changed N.F.L. history, although it’s likely a minority of people outside the Bay Area believed that and fewer still believed it was wise of 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh to whine about it at his news conference afterward.

headline: France Arrests 4 It Says Planned to Aid or Join Militants
abstract: The interior minister and judicial officials said the men had links to a French citizen suspected of seeking to join jihadist fighters in Mali.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French police arrested four men on Tuesday who were suspected of seeking to aid or join Islamic militants in the African desert, while French air and ground forces continued operations against militants in northern Mali.

headline: A Death Penalty Fight Comes Home
abstract: Kirk Noble Bloodsworth, the nation’s first death row inmate exonerated by DNA, is pressing to end capital punishment in Maryland, the state that sought his execution.
lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Kirk Noble Bloodsworth, a beefy, crew-cut man whose blue T-shirt read “Witness to Innocence,” took the microphone in a church hall here and ran through his story of injustice and redemption one more time. Twenty years ago, he walked out of a Maryland prison, the first inmate in the nation to be sentenced to death and then exonerated by DNA.

headline: State Debt Guarantees That Are ‘Hidden’ Add to Worries in Europe
abstract: The hawks who watch government debt are starting to focus on what they consider the under-reported financial obligations of countries like Slovenia, Malta and others.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to euro zone hot spots, few international investors these days are likely to be losing sleep over Slovenia or Malta.

headline: So Jennifer Lawrence and Sally Field Start a Car Pool …
abstract: After the Oscar nominees luncheon, even the stars reported some out-of-body experiences.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. – The Oscar nominees luncheon is an annual occasion for surreal showbiz congratulations, and the far-reaching back-slapping doesn’t stop there. A few hours after the luncheon and its attendant media blitz – when nominees do a round-robin of interviews by the pool at the Beverly Hilton here – there was another celebration of their talents at nearby Spago.

headline: ‘Plug-In Ecosystem’ Available at Indiana Mall
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: The Carmel system has the potential to eliminate the need for a larger and costlier utility transformer, said Paul Mitchell, president and chief executive of Energy Systems Network.
lead_paragraph: Electric car owners who visit the Clay Terrace mall in the Indianapolis suburb of Carmel can connect to a charging station that taps into energy from the sun. On Jan. 30, the mall cut the ribbon on a “Plug-In Ecosystem” that combines solar power, a large storage battery and both Level II and Level III chargers. For the time being, the electricity is free.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Your School Bus Strike Drawings
abstract: Drawings of New York City’s school bus strike submitted by young readers.
lead_paragraph: The Last Assignment

headline: A Pocket Speaker System Hits a New Low
abstract: Soundmatters has introduced a worthy successor to its pocket size FoxL speaker, the Dash 7 and mini subwoofer the FoxLO.
lead_paragraph: For quite a while the FoxL from Soundmatters was the gold standard of pocket-size speakers for its unusual sound quality-to-size ratio. It pumped out mighty good sound for a speaker so small.

headline: Mean Streets to Grub Street? Scorsese Films New York Review’s 50th Anniversary
abstract: Neither the magazine nor the director will say whether the shoots are part of a formal documentary project.
lead_paragraph: Having captured the mean streets of Little Italy and the 19th-century gangs of New York, Martin Scorsese is currently aiming his cameras at a more high-brow Gotham subculture: The New York Review of Books.

headline: Jim O’Neill, Prominent Goldman Economist, to Retire
abstract: Jim O’Neill, the Goldman Sachs economist who a decade ago coined the term “BRICs,” plans to retire later this year, the firm announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Jim O’Neill, the economist who a decade ago coined the term “BRICs” — the acronym for the emerging growth economies in Brazil, Russia, India and China — plans to retire from Goldman Sachs Group later this year, the firm announced on Tuesday.

headline: Problems at the Polls in 2008
abstract: States’ effectiveness varied in how they administered the 2008 presidential election, according to an analysis of several indicators by the Pew Charitable Trusts.
lead_paragraph: States’ effectiveness varied in how they administered the 2008 presidential election, according to an analysis of several indicators by the Pew Charitable Trusts.

headline: Babbitt Exhorts Obama to Protect Public Lands
abstract: Bruce Babbitt faults the president for opening vast tracts of public land drilling and protecting less than some recent predecessors.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Babbitt, the interior secretary in the Clinton administration and a former governor of Arizona, made one of his periodic forays out of the political wilderness on Tuesday to criticize the Obama administration for favoring oil and gas development over conservation on public lands.

headline: New Problems in Syria: Hepatitis, Closed Hospitals, Ambulance Shortages
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Hepatitis', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness']
abstract: The World Health Organization is the latest United Nations agency seeking to add a new sense of urgency to the humanitarian crisis in Syria.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Outbreaks of hepatitis A and other diseases spread by poor hygiene are now becoming problems among Syrians displaced by the civil war, the World Health Organization said Tuesday. It is one of at least four United Nations agencies seeking to add a new sense of urgency to the humanitarian crisis afflicting the country.

headline: Pub Grub With ‘a Wink and a Smile’
abstract: Wylie Dufresne, the pioneering, science-friendly chef at WD-50, plans to open a restaurant specializing in what some might call a cubist spin on pub grub.
lead_paragraph: “The door’s going to be where the door is,” Wylie Dufresne said last Thursday afternoon, standing in a space in the East Village that will soon become his new restaurant, Alder. “We’re not moving the door.”

headline: Are Immigrants Taking Your Job? A Primer
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: There are a lot of competing studies (and pundits), but the general takeaway from conservative and liberal economists is that immigration is good for native workers’ living standards over the long run.
lead_paragraph: Immigration reform is back on the table, reviving debates about whether immigration is good or bad for American-born workers.

headline: U.S. Contends S.& P. Purposely Used Faulty Models
keywords: ['Collateralized Debt Obligations', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities']
abstract: The Justice Department’s suit against Standard & Poor’s over mortgage-related securities says computer programs assessing risk were manipulated to ensure high ratings and big profits.
lead_paragraph: 10:18 p.m. | Updated

headline: Alec Soth Hits the Road
abstract: The photographer loves wandering around with an open-ended assignment, capturing people in ordinary settings.
lead_paragraph: When it came time to assign a photographer to this past weekend’s cover story about the oil boom in North Dakota, Alec Soth was the obvious choice. He not only lives in the neighboring state of Minnesota, where he was born and raised, but he also has delivered strong covers for us in the past. He also is the type of photographer who loves wandering around with an open-ended assignment, capturing people in ordinary settings.

headline: Donor, Citing Fraud, Sues Imam Tied to Mosque Near Ground Zero
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Robert Leslie Deak is accusing the imam Feisal Abdul Rauf of using money given to his nonprofit organizations for personal real estate and lavish trips.
lead_paragraph: The imam and former spiritual leader of an Islamic community center and mosque near ground zero is accused in a new lawsuit of defrauding donors to his nonprofit organizations of millions of dollars, using the money for personal real estate, lavish trips and a luxury sports car.

headline: Dell’s Lonely Club Deal
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Michael Dell will account for about three-quarters of the deal’s equity. Few other companies have a structure that would allow for anything on Dell’s scale.
lead_paragraph: Dell’s $24 billion leveraged buyout involves essentially a club of one. And Silver Lake Partners, the sole private equity firm included, is not even really the charter member.

headline: His Twists and Turns, on Paper and in Life
abstract: “Miracles of Life” details the novelist J. G. Ballard’s real life and how it influenced his work.
lead_paragraph: J. G. Ballard’s extraordinary novel “Crash” (1973) is about a form of symphorophilia: car crash sexual fetishism. In The New York Times Book Review, D. Keith Mano didn’t just review it; he reacted as if someone had thrown a severed head into his lap.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 5
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including sadness on the slopes at the Alpine world championships in Austria and happiness in the streets of Baltimore for Ravens fans.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including sadness on the slopes at the Alpine world championships in Austria and happiness in the streets of Baltimore for Ravens fans.

headline: Hops and Spirits Renew an Old Friendship
abstract: The Dutch of yore flavored gin with hops, and now modern distillers are discovering they were onto something.
lead_paragraph: For years, the craft-beer and craft-distilling movements have toiled away at their parallel but separate efforts. Now the two have a shared enthusiasm to talk about.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, a scale that measures and folds away, take out from Taste of Ethiopia and pickles from Boulton & Watt.
lead_paragraph: In a weekly column, Florence Fabricant recommends things to read, taste, covet, order, cook, give and more.

headline: Face Time | Ivanka Trump
abstract: Ivanka Trump tells T about her inspirations, eco-friendly ways and beauty essentials.
lead_paragraph: Ivanka Trump’s fragrance and body lotion, scented in a floral Oriental blend, are the newest additions to her self-named empire. In addition to playing creative director of her own collection, Ivanka also divides her time working for the Trump Organization, judging “The Apprentice,” and playing mom to her 18-month-old daughter Arabella alongside husband Jared Kushner. Here, she tells T about her inspirations, eco-friendly ways and beauty essentials.

abstract: A preview of Harlow, reopened by Richard Notar; Just Bread by Bien Cuit and Clarke’s Standard open; Governor closes.
lead_paragraph: Preview Harlow

headline: Prosecutors Ask Judge to Revoke Chris Brown’s Probation
abstract: A Los Angeles prosecutor told a judge there is little evidence that the singer Chris Brown completed the community service he was ordered to do as part of his sentence for assaulting Rihanna four years ago.
lead_paragraph: A Los Angeles prosecutor told a judge on Tuesday there is no credible evidence that the singer Chris Brown completed the community service he was ordered to do as part of his sentence for assaulting Rihanna four years ago, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Guest Post | Who Are You Online? Considering Issues of Web Identity
abstract: In this post we celebrate Digital Learning Day by exploring issues around online identity and expression, with help from both Common Sense Media resources and materials from The New York Times and The Learning Network.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday (Feb. 6) is Digital Learning Day, an annual opportunity to contemplate the place of technology in the classroom and in our lives.

headline: Georgian Sees Closer Ties With Russia
abstract: The country’s new prime minister, Bidzina Ivanishvili, said Tuesday that he was making progress on a campaign promise: repairing badly frayed relations with Russia.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — As Russia took steps to resume imports of Georgian-produced wine and mineral water, Georgia’s new prime minister, the billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili, said Tuesday that he was making progress on one of his campaign promises — to repair the country’s badly frayed relationship with its huge neighbor.

headline: Gluten-Free for Children With Sensitivities, and Without
abstract: Gluten-free is safe for children, but a dietitian says, “It’s not just going out and buying a bunch of gluten-free cereals and cupcakes.”
lead_paragraph: “Eat no wheat.”

headline: Zynga at a Crossroads in Mobile Quest
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: As its revenue remains flat, the social-game creator faces the test of successfully putting its most popular Web games, starting with Farmville, on mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Zynga has been on a monumental losing streak. Hits have been rare, profits nonexistent and crucial employees are fleeing.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Yemen, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Yemen, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Egypt.

headline: If You Like Steppenwolf, Try the Black Keys
abstract: Steppenwolf’s “Magic Carpet Ride” was an unrivaled  rock song until the 20somethings’ band the Black Keys came along with  “Gold on the Ceiling.”
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Ahmadinejad Attacked With Shoe in Cairo
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Video from Turkey’s Anadolu Agency showed a man hurling a shoe at Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, in Cairo on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:44 p.m. Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s visit to Cairo, which started with an affectionate welcome on Tuesday from Egypt’s new Islamist president, turned less pleasant as the day wore on. First, Mr. Ahmadinejad, the Iranian president, was lectured by a senior Sunni Muslim cleric and then was nearly struck with a shoe by a man furious at Iran’s support for the Syrian government.

headline: The Spending Brownout
abstract: Congress seems determined to throw more than a million people out of work.
lead_paragraph: For misguided reasons of ideology and inertia, Congress seems determined to throw more than a million people out of work over the next two years. This is the price of the unnecessary spending brownout known as the sequester, and today the failure to stop it became even more inexcusable.

headline: Profit Slides 6% at Disney as Movie and TV Divisions Lag
abstract: Increases in costs for programming like basketball and football at ESPN provided a drag on the results from Disney’s media networks unit. Walt Disney Studios struggled compared with the same period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Higher costs at ESPN and lower DVD sales resulted in a 6 percent decline in quarterly profit at Disney, the company said late Tuesday. But Disney’s video game and Web unit finally swung to a profit and the conglomerate steered attention toward potential “Star Wars” growth.

headline: Jets Finalize Coaching Staff
abstract: The team announced a group that includes seven new coaches and five others who will assume new responsibilities in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The Jets completed their staff overhaul Tuesday, announcing a group that includes seven new coaches and five others who will assume different responsibilities in 2013. Mike Devlin, formerly the tight ends coach, is now in charge of the offensive line, replacing Dave DeGuglielmo. Steve Hagen, formerly the Cleveland Browns’ tight ends coach, takes over for Devlin.

headline: Hillary 2013 Gives Way to ‘Hillary 2016’
abstract: From her farewell tour to her “Global Townterview,” the U.S. secretary of state’s final week felt a lot like the first week of the next campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton woke up today with no place to go — at least in an official capacity.

headline: A Three-Way Game of Musical Teasing
abstract: Angelika Kirchschlager and Ian Bostridge performed a recital of selections from Hugo Wolf’s “Spanish Songbook” on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Ian Bostridge and Angelika Kirchschlager sang beautifully on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. So much for the obvious. Both singers are big names who rarely appear on opera stages this side of the Atlantic, and the reputations of their voices — Mr. Bostridge’s cleareyed tenor, Ms. Kirchschlager’s richly hued mezzo — would have been sufficient to draw a capacity crowd to their recital of Hugo Wolf songs, presented as part of Lincoln Center’s Great Performers series.

headline: Peeling Through Layers, With Drums and High Kicks
abstract: Claude Wampler, who specializes in both art and performance, offered the multimedia “N’a pas un gramme de charisme” (roughly, “Hasn’t an ounce of charisma”) at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: “N’a pas un gramme de charisme” is a worthy title for Claude Wampler’s new show: it translates, roughly, as “Hasn’t an ounce of charisma.” Ms. Wampler is not alone in this creation, which I saw at the Kitchen last weekend; it was made in collaboration with Amelia Saul (who performs), John Tremblay (who designed the set) and Antonius Wiriadjaja (the “wizard” behind its use of visual technology). During the course of more than 36 years of intensive theatergoing, I must have seen drearier shows, but they do not stay in the memory, and it is likely that this too will pass into the oblivion it so richly deserves.

headline: University Revokes German Official’s Doctorate
abstract: The plagiarism case against Annette Schavan, the education minister, is a blow to the government of Chancellor Angela Merkel.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A German university has moved to strip the country’s education minister of her academic title after ruling that she plagiarized parts of her doctoral dissertation some 30 years ago.

headline: Red Bulls Wheeling and (Still) Dealing
abstract: The Red Bulls on Monday sent Kenny Cooper to Dallas, then on Tuesday re-signed midfielder Dax McCarty in the club’s latest waves of transactions.
lead_paragraph: Kenny Cooper will never be mistaken for Lionel Messi (too tall) and Dax McCarty will never be mistaken for Frank Lampard (too short).

headline: My Head Talks At Business Insider
abstract: Mumbo-jumbo, I’m sure.
lead_paragraph: Not much blogging today or probably tomorrow – course prep! But I talked to Business Insider, last week, and you can watch my head discourse on the US economy, technology and inequality, Japan, and the deficit.

headline: Friends, Romans, Countrymen, All Brought to Life by Inmates
abstract: “Caesar Must Die” sets Shakespeare’s play in an Italian prison, using inmates to tell the tale of politics and power.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to imagine that the performers in “Caesar Must Die,” a riff on Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar,” are cut from coarser, more authentic material than that found in most productions. The movie, after all, is set in an Italian prison and cast almost entirely with real inmates. The prisoners’ rough faces and darting eyes, the crooked arc of one man’s nose and the unnervingly sly line of another’s smile, suggest so much (murder most foul, to borrow a line), as do the occasional shivery biographical asides, particularly about the mafia, that jostle alongside the play’s poetry. These men, surely, know about betrayal, vengeance and power, a knife in the gut and hands washed in blood.

headline: Trayvon Martin’s Birthday Remembered Online
abstract: People remember what would have been the 18th birthday for Mr. Martin, who was killed almost a year ago.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Lizette Alvarez reports, a Florida judge denied a request by George Zimmerman’s lawyer to delay his June 10 trial in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.

headline: Chocolate Caramels Worthy of Your Sweetheart
abstract: More and more of the country’s finest artisanal chocolate markers are producing caramels. So which ones should you give your Valentine?
lead_paragraph: More and more of the country’s finest artisanal chocolate markers are producing caramels. So which ones should you give your Valentine?

headline: The Best in the Box
abstract: The Dining section conducted a blind tasting of 27 candies to find the best American small-batch, handmade chocolate-covered salted caramels.
lead_paragraph: With Valentine’s Day nigh, the lure of the heart-shaped bonbons box pulls hard. Maybe you’re thinking of buying your sweetheart a box of retro buttercreams, or sophisticated (but, yawn, predictable) ganache truffles? Or perhaps a selection of artisanal, austerely bitter, single-origin chocolate bars?

headline: Playing With Passion for a Patron
abstract: Five ensembles honor Ralph Kaminsky, an advocate for contemporary classical music, in a concert of works by composers he championed.
lead_paragraph: Luminaries of the contemporary classical-music world, from New York and points beyond, gathered at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening to remember one of their own. Ralph Kaminsky, who died in January 2012 at 85, was not a performer, composer or arts executive but a music lover with a passion for discovery and a benefactor whose quiet generosity bolstered his community.

headline: Pentagon to Extend Certain Benefits to Same-Sex Partners
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Though a final benefits package has not been decided, it was unlikely to include the medical, dental and housing allowances desired by gay and lesbian couples.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is preparing to expand benefits to same-sex partners of military personnel, but it remained doubtful that the Pentagon could offer the medical, dental and housing allowances desired by gay and lesbian couples, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Social Creative Network, and a Bit of Hacking History
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include a look back at phone phreakers and how they influenced today’s hackers, an app inspired by a film about a town hurt when an auto plant closed and a study about possible racial bias in the generation of search ads.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: With Chocolate, Go for a Fortified Wine
abstract: What wine to drink with chocolates? Maybe skip the chocolates.
lead_paragraph: The Dining section sampled 27 candies to find the best American small-batch, handmade chocolate-covered salted caramels, just in time for Valentine’s Day. Here are some thoughts on what to drink with them; share your suggestions in the comments section below.

headline: In/Out: New Hope for Massachusetts G.O.P.
abstract: After days of prominent Republicans announcing they will not run for John Kerry’s seat, one is at least exploring the possibility.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With just over three weeks to go before candidates need to submit 10,000 signatures to the state, the special election for Senate in Massachusetts is still waiting for its first major Republican contender after several of the party’s prominent members declined to make a run. On Tuesday morning, one such candidate took a step toward getting in.

headline: Release of 13 Episodes Redefines Spoiler Alert
abstract: Netflix subscribers had to decide this weekend whether to watch “House of Cards” all at once, or dribbled out. This led to much discussion on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: This article about “House of Cards” contains no spoilers.

headline: At This Marathon, No Running Shoes Are Required
abstract: The Music of Now Marathon, the beginning of the Composers Now series, gave contemporary classical musicians a notable platform on Saturday at Symphony Space.
lead_paragraph: No concert, however epic in duration, could encompass the entirety of the contemporary classical world, which has grown too broad and variegated to sample in one sitting. But as a microcosm of the teeming activity that falls under the broad umbrella of the new-music rubric, the Music of Now Marathon, a recently instituted annual event at Symphony Space, does nicely. Programmed by Laura Kaminsky, a composer and Symphony Space’s artistic director, the marathon is the opening event in Composers Now, a monthlong series organized by Tania León, which includes dozens of concerts throughout the city.

headline: Wild, Wired, Remembered
abstract: Assessing Richard Pryor’s film legacy as the retrospective “A Pryor Engagement” comes to the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s BAM Rose Cinemas.
lead_paragraph: When a jittery Richard Pryor emerges from underneath a desk in “Uptown Saturday Night,” playing a black private eye who is not a sex machine to anybody, a jolt of adrenaline shoots into this sluggish comedy that keeps it wired long after he’s gone.

headline: Ouster Sharpens Debate on the Sage Grouse
abstract: The forced resignation of Nevada’s wildlife director reflects resistance to his efforts to protect the bird’s habitat.
lead_paragraph: The ouster of a Nevada wildlife official has fanned a debate over whether the sage grouse can best be kept off the Endangered Species List by protecting its habitat or by killing more of its predators.

headline: A Guide to Spying on Cisco Phone Calls
abstract: At a security conference in Puerto Rico this week, a security researcher demonstrated how to spy on calls made with Cisco’s VoIP phone. Yes, the same phone the president uses on Air Force One.
lead_paragraph: 7:35 p.m. | Updated to remove an erroneous reference to a Java security flaw.

headline: In Propaganda Video, Only North Korea Sleeps Easy
keywords: ['Propaganda', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'United States International Relations', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Animation of Manhattan in flames, taken from a video game, is part of a sleeping citizen’s dream of a glorious future of rocket launchings and the reunification of the Korean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea is not known for its subtlety, famous instead for its soaring patriotic rhetoric and threats to turn the capital of its rival, South Korea, into a “sea of fire.”

headline: Lackluster Start for BlackBerry’s New Phone in Canada
abstract: The new BlackBerry phone is out in Canada, but customers don’t seem to be flocking to buy it.

headline: Corporate Forces Endangered the Twinkie, but May Save It
abstract: While repeated changes in ownership and questionable management helped bring down Hostess Brands, bankruptcy may be the salvation of one of its most prominent brands, Twinkies.
lead_paragraph: Snack cake aficionados rejoice, the Twinkie will live.

headline: Restaurant Loses Effort to Have Ex-Delivery Workers’ Suit Dismissed
abstract: A federal judge allowed the continuation of the suit, in which eight former employees said their tips were reduced to pay service fees of food-delivery Web sites.
lead_paragraph: A lawsuit brought by former delivery workers against an Upper West Side restaurant that deducted money from their tips to pay the service fees of food-delivery Web sites can proceed, a federal judge has ruled.

lead_paragraph: Alzheimer’s and dementia patients at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale receive much-needed stimulation and a chance to socialize.

lead_paragraph: The artist Song Dong has turned the contents of his mother’s former home in Beijing into an installation at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: In New Orleans, Vivid Flavors of Vietnam
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', "Farmers' Markets", 'Restaurants', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: When you think about eating in New Orleans, does pho come to mind? Or banh mi? Perhaps they should, as the Frugal Traveler discovered during a tour of the city’s Vietnamese community.
lead_paragraph: Hawking her ya-ka-mein soup at a recent New Orleans concert, Linda Green went through her basic sales pitch: it’s beef and noodles. It’s a local secret, she told me. It’s an African-American tradition. But then came an odd clincher.

headline: Bryant Says Stars Must Take Active Role in Union Matters
abstract: Kobe Bryant said it was time for the N.B.A.’s stars to take a stronger role as players deliberate the fate of Billy Hunter, the union’s embattled executive director.
lead_paragraph: Creating a healthier, more functional N.B.A. players union will require deeper involvement from its members, but especially from its most famous members, according to perhaps the most famous member of all.

headline: Twitter Buys Company That Mines Chatter About TV
abstract: Twitter is buying Bluefin Labs, which analyzes online chatter about TV shows and sells its findings.
lead_paragraph: Twitter confirmed on Tuesday that it was acquiring Bluefin Labs, a company that analyzes online chatter about TV shows and companies and sells its findings.

headline: U.S. Soccer Gets Down and Digital
abstract: U.S. Soccer, the sport’s national governing body, on Tuesday released several new digital offerings for fans.
lead_paragraph: One day before the United States national team plays at Honduras in its opening match of the final round of regional World Cup qualifying, U.S. Soccer released some digital goodies for fans — apps for smartphones and tablets, and a Facebook app.

headline: Harlem’s 125th Street Attracts Big Retailers
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: Financing is still tight, but a four-story shopping center and a $14 million retail building are being built in the Manhattan neighborhood’s longtime shopping hub.
lead_paragraph: The recession slowed commercial real estate development everywhere, but it was particularly hard on Harlem, which had only recently begun to attract national retailers after decades of disinvestment. A number of projects had to be shelved when the financial markets dried up.

headline: People With Mental Illness More Likely to Be Smokers, Study Finds
abstract: People with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness, two federal health agencies reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: People with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness, two federal health agencies reported Tuesday.

headline: Security Pioneer Creates Service to Encrypt Phone Calls and Text Messages
abstract: Phil Zimmermann, the creator of the widely used Pretty Good Privacy e-mail encryption software, recently unveiled Silent Circle, which adds security features to phone, video and text messages sent by smartphones. The new service, which charges a monthly fee, could emerge as a more secure rival to Snapchat and Skype.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO– Attention, Snapchat: You have some very serious competition.

headline: California: Detectives Examining Church Documents
abstract: The Los Angeles Police Department is examining pages of newly released church files detailing decades of sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests to determine if any new criminal charges could be brought.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Department is examining thousands of pages of newly released church files detailing decades of sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests to determine if any new criminal charges could be brought, officials said Tuesday. Much of the focus will be looking for new information on priests who were previously investigated, the police said. But detectives will also try to determine if there is any evidence of criminal activity by top church officials, like failure to report abuse to law enforcement. It is unclear how many of the cases are within the statute of limitations, said Cmdr. Andrew Smith, a spokesman for the Police Department. Clergy members were not legally required to report child abuse until 1997. Last week, facing a court order, the Los Angeles Archdiocese released the files on 122 priests accused of sexually abusing children as part of a record $660 million settlement.

headline: Carnegie Mellon Chooses a New President
abstract: Subra Suresh, the director of the National Science Foundation, has been chosen as the next president of Carnegie Mellon University and will assume the post on July 1.
lead_paragraph: Subra Suresh, the director of the National Science Foundation, has been chosen as the next president of Carnegie Mellon University and will assume the post on July 1. At the foundation, Dr. Suresh, a materials engineer, was the host of a Global Summit on Scientific Merit Review. The meeting brought together, for the first time, the heads of leading science financing agencies from nearly 50 countries and led to the creation of the Global Research Council, a vehicle for multinational collaborations. Dr. Suresh, 56, who has been on leave from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology since joining the foundation in 2010, earned his bachelor’s degree in his native India at the Indian Institute of Technology Madras and his doctorate at M.I.T. He is the co-author of more than 240 journal articles, has registered 21 patents and has written three widely used materials science books.

headline: U.S. to Release First Installment of $51 Billion in Hurricane Sandy Aid
abstract: New York City will receive $1.77 billion of the $5.4 billion installment; New York State, $1.71 billion; and other states will split the rest, Senator Charles E. Schumer said.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials plan on Wednesday to release the first installment of a nearly $51 billion emergency aid package to help millions of victims of Hurricane Sandy in the Northeast.

headline: Liverpool Game Is Part of Match-Fixing Investigation
abstract: A European police agency revealed that its investigation into widespread fixing of soccer matches included a Champions League game played in England in 2009.
lead_paragraph: After a European police agency revealed that its investigation into widespread fixing of soccer matches included a Champions League game played in England in the past few years, fans and news media members paged through old results to try to guess which game was tainted. Did it involve Manchester United? Manchester City? Chelsea?

headline: NBC’s Broadcasts of 2014 Winter Games Will Begin a Day Early

headline: Mexico: Six Tourists Are Raped in Home Invasion Near Acapulco
abstract: Five armed and masked men broke into a beach house near the port of Acapulco and raped six Spanish tourists, Mexican authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Five armed and masked men broke into a beach house near the port of Acapulco and raped six Spanish tourists, the authorities said. Eight other people in the same group, which included a Mexican woman who was not attacked, were bound during the assault, which began at 2 a.m. Monday. The city’s mayor, Luis Walton Aburto, acknowledged that the episode would affect the image of Acapulco, which officials have been trying to rehabilitate after years of skyrocketing cartel-related violence. But Mr. Aburto also played down the attack, saying such things happen all over the world. Shortly after, he issued an apology for his comments and offered to increase security in the city.

headline: Remembering a Pioneer in Fields Far Beyond His Sport
abstract: Twenty years ago, Arthur Ashe died of complications from AIDS at age 49, but his legacy lives on, both on the tennis court and off.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, on Feb. 6, 1993, Arthur Ashe died of complications from AIDS at age 49. He was my best friend and client for 23 years, and his death continues to touch me, almost daily.

headline: Bipartisan House Plan Focuses on Gun Trafficking
abstract: Members of both parties in the House outlined a plan to stiffen penalties on the illegal purchase and transportation of guns, a rare show of agreement on a long-divisive issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of both parties in the House outlined a plan on Tuesday to stiffen penalties on the illegal purchase and transportation of guns, a rare show of agreement on an issue where bipartisanship has been scarce.

Geraghty arrived here a year and a half ago to lead the state’s largest health insurer, Florida Blue, he has expanded its operations in Medicare and Medicaid, entered arrangements with hospitals and doctors, bought a medical group, and dabbled with a new private sector marketplace that allows employees to choose plans from different insurance companies.

headline: India’s Speech Impediments
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: In the world’s biggest democracy, there is no true freedom to speak and write.
lead_paragraph: INDIA is in the throes of what Salman Rushdie rightly calls a “cultural emergency.” Writers and artists of all kinds are being harassed, sued and arrested for what they say or write or create. The government either stands by and does nothing to protect freedom of speech, or it actively abets its suppression.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s Sandy Plan
abstract: Buying damaged properties and returning them to their natural state to protect residents from future floods is one of the best ideas to come along.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York wants to spend as much as $400 million to buy and raze damaged homes in the floodplains of New York State. These properties, victims of Hurricane Sandy, would then be turned into parks, bird sanctuaries, dunes or simply stretches of open beach, serving as buffer zones to protect residents inland from future floods.

headline: U.S. Soccer Team Lets Others Keep Danger at Bay
abstract: The three-day visit to San Pedro Sula, Honduras, has been tailored so American players will not encounter any of the city, which was labeled the world’s most violent.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — Near the start of an afternoon news conference inside a hotel ballroom here on Tuesday, a member of the local news media prefaced his question to Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States soccer team, with a greeting.

headline: Essie Mae Washington-Williams, Child of Famous but Secret Father, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Washington-Williams lived for decades with a stunning secret — that she was the interracial daughter of Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, who never publicly acknowledged her as his child.
lead_paragraph: Essie Mae Washington-Williams, who lived for decades with a stunning secret — that she was the interracial daughter of Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, a former segregationist who never acknowledged her publicly as his child — died Monday in a nursing home near Columbia, S.C. She was 87.

headline: Colorado Gun Control Proposals Face Fight
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'School Shootings', 'Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: The measures proposed by Democrats would require background checks for private gun sales and limit some kinds of ammunition.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Democratic lawmakers in Colorado, a state haunted by two of the worst mass shootings in American history, unveiled a broad package of gun-control measures on Tuesday, but they stopped short of proposing a ban on assault rifles or any other types of firearms.

headline: Study Looks at Particles Used in Food
abstract: The group As You Sow said nanoparticles, the size of molecules, have been found in the blood stream after ingestion and inhalation.
lead_paragraph: Nanomaterials, substances broken down by technology into molecule-size particles, are starting to enter the food chain through well-known food products and their packaging, but there is little acknowledgment by the companies using them, according to a new report from a nonprofit group that works to enhance corporate accountability.

headline: One-Third the Man He Used to Be, and Proud of It
abstract: Since Paul Mason had gastric bypass surgery in 2010 after weighing about 980 pounds, he has lost nearly two-thirds of his body weight, but the road to a new life is uphill.
lead_paragraph: IPSWICH, England — Who knows what the worst moment was for Paul Mason — there were so many awful milestones, as he grew fatter and fatter — but a good bet might be when he became too vast to leave his room. To get him to the hospital for a hernia operation, the local fire department had to knock down a wall and extricate him with a forklift.

lead_paragraph: TUCSON — The spring semester started at the University of California the week before the Arizona Intercollegiate, which presented a problem for two of the top players on the Bears’ No. 1-ranked men’s golf team.

headline: When Can the U.S. Kill One of Its Own?
abstract: Are targeted killings depriving U.S. citizens of constitutionally protected due process rights?

headline: Debevoise & Plimpton Drops Trusts and Estates Practice
abstract: The law firm’s move to get out of the estate-planning business comes as the legal industry continues to emphasize more profitable practices.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the nation’s leading trusts and estates lawyers convened at a Florida resort to discuss the latest in estate planning.

headline: Standard & Poor’s Stands Accused
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Editorials', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: But will the Justice Department make the civil fraud charges against the credit-ratings agency stick?
lead_paragraph: The financial crisis could never have happened without the credit-ratings agencies issuing stellar ratings on toxic mortgage securities that inflated the bubble. Before the Justice Department filed civil fraud charges this week against Standard & Poor’s, the nation’s largest credit-ratings agency, it seemed as if the entire ratings industry — which reaped record profits in the boom years — was going to escape, unrepentant and unpunished. That may now change.

headline: To Kill an American
abstract: A new document underscores the Obama administration’s chilling analysis of executive power.
lead_paragraph: On one level, there were not too many surprises in the newly disclosed “white paper” offering a legal reasoning behind the claim that President Obama has the power to order the killing of American citizens who are believed to be part of Al Qaeda. We knew Mr. Obama and his lawyers believed he has that power under the Constitution and federal law. We also knew that he utterly rejects the idea that Congress or the courts have any right to review such a decision in advance, or even after the fact.

headline: Drone Strikes’ Risks to Get Rare Moment in the Public Eye
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism']

headline: The Star Who Dwells on Wherever He Isn’t

lead_paragraph: Had he stuck to his original plan, been resolute, Dwight Howard — and not Brook Lopez — would have been the tallest lord of Flatbush on Tuesday night. He would have spent the first half of this N.B.A. season rising with the Nets in the less competitive East instead of falling with the Lakers in the merciless West.

headline: With a Super Bowl Ad, Scientology Gets a Crowd
abstract: The Church of Scientology’s commercial, alongside pitches for Budweiser, Coca-Cola and Mercedes-Benz, came in the wake of criticism of treatment of church members.
lead_paragraph: After several months of mounting accusations over the treatment of its members, the Church of Scientology on Sunday tried to spread a softer, gentler message using the biggest advertising event in the country: the Super Bowl.

headline: School Plans Its 17th Move, but Its First Since 1892
abstract: Collegiate School, the oldest private school in New York, has purchased land to build new quarters a short distance south on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: After debating nearly seven years about where to move, the board of the Collegiate School, New York City’s oldest and one of its most prestigious private schools, announced Tuesday that it had purchased land for a new building between West 61st and 62nd Streets and between West End Avenue and Riverside Boulevard.

She wanted to play Tennessee Williams’s famed Maggie the Cat on Broadway. Her only worry about timing, she recalled, was a tight window between wrapping movies in 2012 and filming a “Captain America” sequel in 2013.

lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Devils-Rangers rivalry picked up where it left off last spring during the Stanley Cup playoffs, with fans at sold-out Prudential Center chanting the names of Martin Brodeur and Adam Henrique.

headline: Law Would Close Trailers for Sex Offenders in Suffolk
abstract: Some ex-convicts in Suffolk County found they had no legal residency options.

headline: Gliding Across New Stage, Bryant Slices Right Through the Nets
abstract: Without Dwight Howard or Metta World Peace at his side, Kobe Bryant attacked often and found his way to the rim frequently, scoring 21 points as the Lakers beat the Nets.
lead_paragraph: The court was foreign to these feet, but the stage seemed just about right: dark around the edges, brightly lit in the center, with enough wattage to illuminate every ounce of Kobe Bryant’s brilliance.

headline: Vote This Week May Close a North Brooklyn Hospital
abstract: Long Island College Hospital, in northern Brooklyn, was losing too much money, said Dr. John Williams, president of SUNY Downstate Medical Center, which runs it.

headline: Quake Leads to Tsunami, but Fears Ebb
abstract: Residents of islands from the South Pacific to Australia were alerted to the possibility of a tsunami after an 8.0-magnitude earthquake off the Solomon Islands, but warnings were called off.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — A powerful 8.0 magnitude earthquake caused a tsunami that sent strong waves crashing into several South Pacific islands, with officials in the Solomon Islands fearful that some residents had lost their lives.

lead_paragraph: In counties and cities across the country, the medical examiner is often a steady player in the rotating cast of public officials. Turn on the evening news, see that familiar face solemnly addressing a bank of cameras, and you know: Someone has died.

headline: Reg Presley, Lead Singer of Troggs, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Presley’s growl made the song “Wild Thing” a classic hit.
lead_paragraph: Reg Presley, a bricklayer-turned-singer whose ebulliently lusty vocal on the Troggs’ smash hit “Wild Thing” helped elevate the song to rock ’n’ roll legend, died on Monday at his home in Andover, England. He was 71.

headline: Is Music Un-Islamic?
abstract: The director of the Institute of Islamic Studies at Jamia Millia Islamia University weighs in.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI— A teenage girl band in Kashmir split up Monday after a senior cleric issued a fatwa, or Islamic edict, against them. The rock band, a trio of schoolgirls calling themselves Praagaash, meaning “darkness into light,” faced threats following a public performance in December.

headline: Getting Into Your Exercise Groove
abstract: A series of recent studies involving runners, walkers, metronomes and virtual reality curtains suggests that while the tug of physiological laziness is strong, it can be controlled, or at least tweaked, with some conscious effort — and perhaps your iPhone playlist.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t meant as an insult, but you are physiologically lazy. So am I. So are we all. Using treadmill testing, scientists have definitively established that, like other animals, humans naturally aim to use as little energy as possible during most movement. So when we walk or run, our bodies tend to choose a particular cadence, a combination of step length and step frequency, that allows us to move at any given speed with as little physiological effort as possible.
