headline: Can’t Watch U.S.-Honduras? Watch One of These Games Instead
abstract: The United States-Honduras World Cup qualifier on Wednesday afternoon on beIN Sport may be invisible to many American fans, but there are plenty of other attractive matchups on TV,

abstract: China’s economy wows the world, but at home, over-reporting of local G.D.P. figures has produced an entire “phantom province,” Chinese media say.

headline: Tsunami Causes Deaths and Damages Homes on Solomon Islands
abstract: The tsunami sent strong waves crashing into several South Pacific islands, with officials in the Solomon Islands saying that at least four people died.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — A powerful magnitude 8 earthquake caused a tsunami that sent strong waves crashing into several South Pacific islands on Wednesday, with officials in the Solomon Islands saying that at least four people died.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 6
abstract: Drone strikes in the spotlight in Congress; gay marriage in Britain; Dell goes private; role-switching in a Pinter play; Lindsey Vonn tears two ligaments; and two soccer players come of age.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Individual strikes by Predator and Reaper drones are almost never discussed publicly by U.S. officials. But the clandestine war will receive a rare moment of public scrutiny on Thursday, when its chief architect, John O. Brennan, the White House counterterrorism adviser, faces a Senate confirmation hearing as President Barack Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director. Robert F. Worth reports from Sana, Yemen, and Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane from Washington.

headline: Presidential Aide Freed, Reports Say, as Top Iranian Politicians Trade Accusations
abstract: The release of Saeed Mortazavi, the imprisoned aide to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, marked a new turn in a fight between the president and Iran’s most influential political family.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — As President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad escalated a bitter political fight this week with Iran’s most influential political family by disclosing secret film recordings of what he said were fraudulent business deals, Iran’s political maneuvering took a new turn on Wednesday when an imprisoned associate of Mr. Ahmadinejad was reported to have been freed.

They announced that they would restructure the Islamist-led government and form a national unity cabinet as thousands took to the streets in protests that security forces beat back with tear gas.

headline: Kids Who Worry, Kids Who Don’t

headline: Why Can Some Kids Handle Pressure While Others Fall Apart?
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Scientists think bouts of panic in stressful situations can be traced to genetics. But don’t freak out. Biology is not necessarily destiny.
lead_paragraph: Noah Muthler took his first state standardized test in third grade at the Spring Cove Elementary School in Roaring Spring, Pa. It was a miserable experience, said his mother, Kathleen Muthler. He was a good student in a program for gifted children. But, Muthler said, “he was crying in my arms the night before the test, saying: ‘I’m not ready, Mom. They didn’t teach us everything that will be on the test.’ ” In fourth grade, he was upset the whole week before the exam. “He manifests it physically,” his mother said. “He got headaches and stomachaches. He would ask not to go to school.” Not a good sleeper anyway, Noah would slip downstairs after an hour tossing in bed and ask his mom to lie down with him until he fell asleep. In fifth grade, the anxiety lasted a solid month before the test. “Even after the test, he couldn’t let it go. He would wonder about questions he feared he misunderstood,” Muthler said.

headline: Peeking Into the Sex Lives of Endangered Turtles
keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Reproduction (Biological)', 'Turtles and Tortoises']
abstract: Genetic research reveals a surprisingly high level of monogamy and paternal diversity in hawksbill sea turtles, hinting that populations may be on the rise.
lead_paragraph: Studying any animal in the wild is hard enough, let alone one that spends 30 years at a time out at sea. Because of its ocean-faring lifestyle, scientists know next to nothing about the life style of the critically endangered hawksbill sea turtle, save for the fleeting observations they make when female turtles come to beaches to lay their eggs.

headline: More Than a Land Grab
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Land Use Policies', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Jewish settlers aren’t just taking empty space, they’re destroying Palestinian property and threatening their lives.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Last week some inhabitants of the Palestinian village of Burin, near Nablus, set up a small and peaceful protest camp on private land in an attempt to protect the village from encroaching Jewish settlers. On Saturday, the Israeli Army evicted the Palestinians. According to one report, the settlers uprooted nearly 100 olive trees, a 16-year-old Palestinian was wounded, 20 people suffered tear gas inhalation, and a mosque was set on fire.

headline: A ‘Grown-Up Discussion’ About Sports Betting

headline: Go West, Young Band
abstract: Years of building a local following in Denver gave the Lumineers momentum that led to a Top 10 single, “Ho Hey,” and two nominations at Sunday’s Grammy Awards.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The Meadowlark isn’t exactly the big time. It’s a brick-and-stone-walled basement club, capacity 72, with a bar occupying half the room and a barely raised stage where three’s a crowd. Sipping a $2 Bud Light during a happy hour in January, Wesley Schultz, the singer and guitarist in the Lumineers, fondly looked the place over.

headline: Documents in S.& P. Case Show Alarm
abstract: Documents in a lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s provide a glimpse at the company’s inner working in the run-up to the financial crisis. | Royal Bank of Scotland poised to settle accusations that it manipulated Libor. | Debevoise & Plimpton is eliminating its trusts and estates practice. | The fate of Hostess Brands shows how corporate machinations can both doom and save a company.
lead_paragraph: Documents included in the Justice Department’s lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s provide a glimpse at the company’s inner working in the run-up to the financial crisis. “Tensions appeared to be escalating inside the firm’s headquarters in Lower Manhattan as it publicly professed that its ratings were valid, even as the home loans bundled into mortgage-backed securities, or M.B.S., were failing at accelerating rates,” Mary Williams Walsh and Ron Nixon write in DealBook. “Together, the documents show a portrait of some executives pushing to water down the firm’s rating models in the hope of preserving market share and profits, while others expressed deep concerns about the poor performance of the securities and what they saw as a lowering of standards.”

headline: Now Bidding | The ‘Watchmen’ Covers
abstract: Comic book fans with deep pockets will have a chance to own a piece of “Watchmen” when covers of the inaugural issues are sold at Heritage Auctions this month.
lead_paragraph: Comic book fans with deep pockets will have a chance to own a piece of “Watchmen” when the covers of the first three issues are sold at Heritage Auctions this month, in a sale that ends on Feb. 22; issue No. 1 alone is expected to bring in more than $100,000. (Three additional auctions will follow in May, August and November, each featuring three covers from the original 12-issue series published by DC Comics.) Written by Alan Moore and illustrated by Dave Gibbons, “Watchmen” ushered in a new level of mature storytelling with adult themes and flawed heroes. Gibbons sold the covers and original artwork to “Watchmen” — “pitifully cheap,” he noted — nearly as quickly  as he created it, fearing that there would be no takers. “It seemed like a good idea to me at the time,” he said. “In my experience, the sort of comic art that sold well were kind of money shots — big action shots of the heroes in costumes doing something interesting. I realized that ‘Watchmen’ was filled with a lot of meat and potatoes stuff, people standing around talking, which I didn’t think would be as popular.” The series went on to become a perennial best seller. It was adapted into a live action film that was released in 2009 and, last year, DC began publishing a series of prequels called “Before Watchmen,” which caused some consternation with fans and creators who felt that “Watchmen” should stand alone.

headline: The Non-Decisive Decade
abstract: The numbers keep refusing to justify panic.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the CBO came out with its updated budget outlook — and the release was met with a collective yawn. Why? Basically, because the projections over the next decade just didn’t show the kind of fiscal disaster everyone in DC wants to believe in. That’s not to say that the outlook is completely benign — CBO still thinks we’ll end the decade with high debt by historical standards, especially under the “alternative fiscal scenario” that assumes that some cuts that are supposed to happen under current law won’t. (I’m still waiting for the wonks at CBPP and elsewhere to do a full analysis; as best I can tell, a truly realistic scenario would lie in between the baseline and the alternative). But there’s nothing there lending comfort to the Greece, Greece I tell you crowd.

headline: On Our Radar: Mapping the Nation’s Emissions

lead_paragraph: Drawing on data from 8,000 power plants, refineries and factories, the Environmental Protection Agency releases an interactive map of greenhouse gas emissions in 2011 from the nation’s biggest industrial polluters. Emissions dipped from the previous year, largely because of a shift away from reliance on coal-fired power plants. [Environmental Protection Agency]

headline: A Look at the Role of Policy in America’s Shale Oil and Gas Era
abstract: An energy economist explores how American policies and open markets, not just technology and geology, lie behind the surprising shale oil and gas boom.
lead_paragraph: You probably already read about California being added to the list of states facing the economic opportunities and environmental issues that come with abundant shale oil or gas (oil in California’s case, because of the Monterey Shale). And if you’ve been reading here for awhile, you’re aware of the reality, for better and worse, of “oil’s long goodbye” and “the gas age.”

headline: Replaying Super Bowl Ads’ Effectiveness
abstract: Myriad analyses, polls and surveys of consumer responses to the Super Bowl commercials scrutinize the biggest day of the year in advertising.
lead_paragraph: Given that Super Bowl Sunday is the biggest day of the year for advertising as well as for football, Madison Avenue waits each year after the game with bated breath for the results of the myriad analyses, polls and surveys of consumer responses to the commercials.

headline: After Floating Idea of Lifting Ban on Gays, Scouts Delay Decision
abstract: The Boy Scouts of America, which earlier said it was reconsidering a ban on participation by openly gay people, will put off a decision until May.
lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts of America, which confirmed last summer its policy barring openly gay people from participation, then said last week that it was reconsidering the ban, announced Wednesday that it would postpone a decision once more, until May, as talk of gay men and lesbians in the ranks has roiled a storied organization that carries deep emotional connection and nostalgia for millions of Americans.

headline: To Egypt or Not to Egypt?
abstract: Sanctuary Retreats is offering new trips from Cairo to Aswan after Egypt decided to lift the 18-year ban on Nile River cruises north of Luxor.
lead_paragraph: Sanctuary Retreats is offering new 10-night trips from Cairo to Aswan in six departures April through September, capitalizing on a decision by Egypt last year to lift the 18-year ban on Nile River cruises north of Luxor. The lengthened itineraries, on three ships with 40 or fewer cabins, visit sites like the rock tombs of Beni Hassan and the Valley of the Kings. The new offering comes as the cruise-ship giant Norwegian said that it would drop Egypt from its Mediterranean route through 2015, citing security concerns.

headline: Lens: Photos at El Museo del Barrio
abstract: A new show at El Museo del Barrio is designed to address the short attention span of the viewer in the digital age. Read about it on the Lens blog.
lead_paragraph: Starting today, some 80 images will be on display in “superreal: alternative realities in photography and video,” a new show at El Museo del Barrio, in East Harlem. What’s on display is shot with a documentarian’s eye, but includes a dose of mystery and otherworldliness. A spare-looking installation is designed to address the short attention span of the viewer in the digital age, forcing one to stop and look a little longer at how the images were created.

headline: Vain Glorious | Sachajuan’s Body Care Collection
abstract: The European brand’s body products — in three subtle unisex scents — are finally coming stateside.
lead_paragraph: Stockholm-based beauty brand Sachajuan — already a cult favorite among hair industry pros and celebrities thanks to its popular algae-infused styling products — is finally bringing its range of body washes and lotions stateside. Instead of marine ingredients, this collection relies on beta-glucan, a soluble fiber made from oats, for its moisturizing and skin-soothing properties. “All the formulas are very light but still effective, and the lotion absorbs really quickly so there’s no dry-down time needed,” says Misha Anderson, co-founder of Woodley & Bunny apothecary and Sachajuan’s U.S. distributor. The body products come in three subtle unisex scents that won’t overwhelm the nose, and the simple packaging is firmly in keeping with the brand’s minimalist aesthetic. “In Swedish culture, they have a word called “lagom” — the idea that things should be chic yet understated and functional,” Anderson says. “This line embodies that in every way.”

headline: Getting Israel’s Security Chiefs on Camera
abstract: Dror Moreh, whose “Gatekeepers” is nominated for a documentary Oscar, says his film was inspired by “The Fog of War.”
lead_paragraph: The title characters of “The Gatekeepers,” nominated for the Academy Award for best feature-length documentary, are six former directors of the Shin Bet, Israel’s internal security service. They are operatives used to working in the shadows, so the first set of challenges the film’s director, Dror Moreh, faced was convincing them to sit in front of his camera, reflect on the role they and their agency have played in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and answer his questions about specific operations.

The new biography “Nelson Mandela,” written and illustrated by Kadir Nelson; “Fifty Cents and a Dream: Young Booker T. Washington,” by Jabari Asim with illustrations by Bryan Collier; and “Light in the Darkness,” a story about how slaves learned in secret, written by Lesa Cline-Ransome and illustrated by James E. headline: The Times Was Right to Report — at Last — on a Secret Drone Base
abstract: Editors were asked by the C.I.A. to withhold information and did so for months before publishing it online Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The media and national-security worlds, internationally, are abuzz over an important story on the front page of Wednesday’s New York Times that describes a drone strike in Yemen last August. The article reveals a great deal about the secret drone program, the architect of which is John O. Brennan, who has been nominated to head the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Wiped Out by Sandy, an Owner Sizes Up the Risk in Starting Over
abstract: Ralph Lucci, at 60, has to decide whether he can recoup the Automobile Film Club of America with the financing available to him, or if he would rather do something else.
lead_paragraph: The Automobile Film Club of America has played a supporting role in New York-based film and television productions since 1993. It owns a fleet of vehicles — including police cruisers, taxis and vintage automobiles — that have squired stars and models in advertising shoots, TV shows and action films, including two Spider-Man movies and two “Men in Black” films. Woody Allen rented a 1964 Porsche Cabriolet for one movie and bought an Aston Martin that was totaled in another. “When they crash something, they buy it,” said Ralph Lucci, the owner.

headline: Should a Victim of Hurricane Sandy Risk His House to Revive His Business?
abstract: The owner of a company that rents automobiles for film and television production faces a big decision after the storm.
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about the Automobile Film Club of America, a company that has played a supporting role in New York-based film and television productions since 1993. Based in Stapleton, on Staten Island, a half-block from the waterfront, the company was overwhelmed last October by Hurricane Sandy’s surge, when its 6,000-square-foot lot and 57 cars were submerged in saltwater. “I have mechanics, they all say they’re totally junk,’’ said Ralph Lucci, the company’s owner, of the cars. “It took five hours to destroy the business.’’

headline: Doing Some Math Before the U.S.-Honduras Game
abstract: Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, figured 18 points would be sufficient to advance in World Cup group qualifying and hoped for a good start on Wednesday against Honduras.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras – Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, was having some fun with numbers Wednesday morning before the men’s national team took the field to begin the final round of World Cup qualifying.

headline: Cranky Is Contagious. (So Is Everything Else.)
abstract: Teaching children that their emotions are contagious—so whatever they bring to a conversation is likely what they’ll get back.
lead_paragraph: This is a concept I’ve been trying to explain to my children (who are 11, 8, 7 and 6 years old) for some time. There I will be, innocently making a smoothie or something, when a child will appear, fuming, eyes blazing, loaded for bear.

headline: Girl Scouts Embrace Social Media
abstract: Cookie sales seek a lift from Twitter, food trucks and a new package design.
lead_paragraph: Modernity takes all comers, and the Girl Scouts are no exception. The do-gooding cookie sellers are celebrating their first National Girl Scout Cookie Day on Friday, embracing Twitter, food trucks and new package design. @GirlScouts will tweet the location of its Cookie Day Truck as it makes its way through New York City, staffed with Girl Scouts selling thin mints and other favorite treats. In the first package design update since 1999, cookie boxes sold by Girl Scouts, which was founded in 1912, will feature iconography of the skills troopers learn.

headline: Comparing Ballot Lengths Around the Country
abstract: The numbers of choices voters must make reflect regional differences in political cultures, but voting can sometime be more onerous in places that value participation most.
lead_paragraph: Long lines at the polls are part of a raft of barriers to voting, as documented by a recent Pew study (and broken down by The Times’s Adam Liptak on Wednesday). And one of the chief culprits, according to an article by Jeremy W. Peters on Tuesday: long ballots.

headline: The 0.03% Solution to Washington’s Budget Problems
abstract: A financial transactions tax would take a 3-cent nip out of every $100 traded, and raise billions. The burden of proof is on opponents to explain how so slender a tax could harm the capital markets.
lead_paragraph: The unwritten rule of Washington debates about taxing and spending is to never consider anything new. But wouldn’t it be wonderful if the pressure of the next few months’ debate changed that?

headline: Image of the Day: Feb.6
abstract: Student protests outside a Delhi college that hosted Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi.

headline: Truck Driver Arrested in Fatal Hit and Run in Midtown
abstract: A 47-year-old man from New Jersey was arrested after the death of a pedestrian Tuesday at the intersection of 41st Street and Ninth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: The police have arrested a 47-year-old New Jersey truck driver in Tuesday’s death of a pedestrian in a hit and run in a crowded intersection near Times Square.

headline: How to Cruise Solo
abstract: Whether you’re looking for romance, enrichment or rest and relaxation, here are tips for setting sail on your own.
lead_paragraph: Toying with the idea of setting sail on your own? Consider your age, your budget and — perhaps most important — your goal. Are you looking for romance? Enrichment? Rest and relaxation?

headline: Cable TV Revenue Helps Spur Time Warner Profit
abstract: The revenue from ads and subscription fees from its cable properties helped overcome a challenging quarter for the media conglomerate’s publishing and movie divisions.
lead_paragraph: 2:14 p.m. | Updated The cable television business helped propel Time Warner to a 51-percent increase in net income and offset weakness in magazine publishing and movies in the three months that ended Dec. 31.

headline: Timing Tips for the ACT and SAT
abstract: What’s the best way to ensure you have enough time on the SAT and ACT? Here are some tech-savvy and more tried-and-tested suggestions.
lead_paragraph: What’s the best way to ensure you have enough time on the SAT and ACT?

headline: City Plans to Allot First $1 Billion in Storm Aid to Housing and Businesses
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he would seek federal permission to use much of the money to make grants and loans.
lead_paragraph: New York City plans to spend its first $1 billion in federal money for Hurricane Sandy recovery on loans and grants to homeowners and businesses affected by the storm and efforts to protect public housing and critical infrastructure in the future, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Wednesday.

headline: Visualizing ‘Django Unchained’
abstract: Robert Richardson, the cinematographer of “Django Unchained,” discusses his work on the film.
lead_paragraph: The cinematographer Robert Richardson has partnered with some of America’s most high-profile and visually driven  directors. His accolades include Academy Awards for his work with Oliver Stone (“J. F. K.”) and Martin Scorsese (“The Aviator” and “Hugo”). Now “Django Unchained,” his fourth film with Quentin Tarantino, has garnered him another nomination, but Mr. Richardson says his job is always to put the director’s goals above his own.

headline: Your Lost Bags Sent a Text; Come Get Them
abstract: While services for tracking luggage with RFID tags, bar codes or GPS have been around for a while, a company called Trakdot is taking a slightly different approach, putting a radio transceiver on your bags that tells you where your luggage is.
lead_paragraph: While services for tracking luggage with RFID tags, bar codes or GPS have been around for a while, a company called Trakdot is taking a slightly different approach. It is putting a radio transceiver on your bags that tells you where your luggage is when it isn’t where it should be.

headline: Obama’s ‘Just Trust Me’ Argument
abstract: The administration doesn’t seem to think that the public deserves real information on its targeted killing policy.
lead_paragraph: During the 2012 campaign, President Obama and Vice President Biden and many other people, including our editorial page writers, pointed out that Mitt Romney’s campaign boiled down to one proposition: Just trust me.

headline: The Latest on Rasheed Wallace
abstract: Rasheed Wallace of the Knicks, who has not played since December, hopes to return to the court in late February.
lead_paragraph: Rasheed Wallace has a new goal. He wants to be able to participate in his first full practice in more than a month when the Knicks return from the All-Star break.

headline: Clashes Erupt in Damascus as Prospects for Syrian Talks Dim
abstract: Some antigovernment activists described the fighting in Syria as part of a renewed effort by rebels to seize control of central Damascus, but that claim appeared to be exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian insurgents attacked military checkpoints and other targets in parts of central Damascus on Wednesday, antigovernment activist groups reported, shattering a lull in the fighting as prospects for any talks between the antagonists appeared to dim.

headline: In the Wrong Record Book
abstract: Ryan Braun was back in the headlines as a report linked him to the records of a clinic being investigated by baseball for supplying banned drugs.
lead_paragraph: Wasn’t it less than a week ago that Alex Rodriguez was in the P.E.D. spotlight after a newspaper article in Miami New Times linked him to an anti-aging clinic in South Florida?

headline: Staying Private on the New Facebook
abstract: How to guard your information on Facebook in light of the new search tool that lets strangers discover who you are, what you like and where you go.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is a personal vault that can contain photos of your firstborn, plans to bring down your government and, occasionally, a record of your indiscretions.

headline: Cruises Get a Channel
abstract: Cruise Industry TV, a new YouTube channel, will host videos from member cruise lines that provide highlights and tips.
lead_paragraph: Cruise Industry TV, a YouTube channel that provides industry news, was recently started by Cruise Lines International Association, which represents major cruise lines. The channel will host videos from member lines that highlight destinations and ships, and provide tips and other consumer-friendly information.

headline: Malawi’s Leader Makes Safe Childbirth Her Mission
abstract: The drive to make childbirth safer in Malawi involves a delicate balance between respect for tradition and stressing the importance of medical science.
lead_paragraph: Malawi is a country of rolling hills and marshy flatlands, where 85 percent of the population live in the countryside, most subsisting on less than $2 per person per day, typically from corn and tobacco farming. It is also a country with extremely high maternal mortality. In the U.S., 1 in 2,400 women are at risk of dying while giving birth over the course of their lives; in Malawi, it is 1 out of 36. If the country’s new president, Joyce Banda, has her way, that will soon change.

headline: Old Friends Help New York Review Celebrate 50 Years
abstract: The literary journal celebrated its 50th anniversary at Town Hall with Joan Didion, Michael Chabon and others.
lead_paragraph: The eager crowd milling in the lobby of Town Hall on Tuesday night looked ready for the opening of an A-list movie. For one thing, Daniel Craig was present. “James Bond is standing over there,” a man said. A stranger next to him, a woman in a large furry hat, peered over. “Is he really? How exciting!”

headline: Russia and Stravinsky Are Themes for SummerScape Festival
abstract: The Bard College festival is scheduled for July 6 to Aug. 18.
lead_paragraph: The Bard SummerScape festival, which will run from July 6 to Aug. 18, will focus on Russia and explore the cultural impact of Igor Stravinsky, devoting its final two weekends to a broad survey of his music, organizers said in announcing the new season.

headline: Things Get Rough on Twitter Over Gun Debate
abstract: Things got ugly on Twitter after the editor of Mother Jones tweeted about the murder of a former sniper over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: 2:50 p.m. | Updated Twitter is often full of short-burst, back-and-forth argument, but Clara Jeffery, the co-editor of Mother Jones, found out that the debate can turn dark after tweeting last Saturday about the death of Chris Kyle, an ex-sniper who was killed at a gun range by a fellow veteran he was trying to help. (Hat tip to Peter Sterne for putting together a list of the tweets on Storify.)

headline: ‘Smash’ Premiere Falls Short, Loses Viewers
abstract: The show, which was extensively retooled by NBC after a disappointing season, fell a staggering 71 percent in viewership from its opening episode last season.
lead_paragraph: 3:25 p.m. | Updated It may be time for NBC to change the title of its Broadway drama, “Smash.” After its second-season premiere Tuesday night, the show might more appropriately be called, “Smithereens.”

headline: Things Serious People Believe
abstract: For no good reason.
lead_paragraph: Duncan Black is struck by a Meet the Press transcript in which Bob Woodward declares that

headline: Highlights From the International Watch Salon
abstract: In the face of smartphone time tellers, the ages-old watch business is very much alive and kicking.

headline: Political Intelligence
abstract: Brooks and Collins on a few suspicious signs that we might actually be headed in the right direction.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks: Gail, let me start out with a troubling issue before I get to a bunch of encouraging ones. How would you vote on the Chuck Hagel nomination for secretary of defense? I would probably still vote yes, but only because I think a president should be given enormous deference to fill out his team.

headline: Recruits Stay True to SEC as Teams Shift Loyalties
abstract: Robert Nkemdiche, the top football prospect in the country, chose Mississippi, kicking off another national signing day that showed the strength of the Southeastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: There is always talk about inroads and pipelines, coaching staffs that reshuffle and conferences that realign. But on national signing day, the Southeastern Conference, as it has for nearly a decade, ruled the national recruiting scene.

headline: Stone Links: Is Same-Sex Marriage Homophobic?
keywords: ['Education', 'Humanities', 'Philosophy', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In this week’s links: the problem with same-sex marriage; the wisdom of play; a passionate defense of philosophy, and more.
lead_paragraph: That question, answered in the affirmative, was the focus of a short post  by the philosopher Roger Scruton and the theologian Philip Blond at The Spectator on Monday. The authors think it’s a mistake for homosexual couples to “conform to heterosexual norms,” and that by doing so they are “absorbed into a structure that does not give due credit or recognition to [homosexuals’] distinction and difference.” Their position turns on an understanding of the concept of equality which sees the latter as valuable not because it erases differences, but preserves them. Stressing that gays deserve “not just acceptance but celebration and recognition,” they claim that what is most likely to achieve that is “equity that respects difference not equality that destroys it.” Scruton and Blond elaborate their position further in a “Green Paper” for the think tank ResPublica.

headline: For Women, Reduced Access to Long-Term Care Insurance
abstract: Gender-distinct pricing is a strategy that will raise long-term care insurance rates for single women by as much as 40 percent beginning in April.
lead_paragraph: “This was a very, very good business for a short time, with people buying long-term care insurance like it was candy in a candy store,’’ said Michael Perry, a vice president at the Opus Advisory Group, a strategic financial planning firm in Purchase, N.Y.

headline: From PETA, a Video of Animals Strutting Their Stuff
abstract: The advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather has created an animated video for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, just in time for Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather has created an animated video for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, just in time for Fashion Week. In a reversal of roles, animals in exotic outfits are seen preening on a catwalk, while backstage naked humans are confined to cages. Although the spot doesn’t directly target China or other Asian countries that supply fur and leather products, including India, the only caged human clearly visible is a Chinese girl. Ogilvy’s Beijing office produced the video.

headline: Picasso Fetches $44.8 Million at Auction
abstract: A canvas Picasso painted of his lover Marie-Thérèse Walter brought $44.8 million at Sotheby’s in London on Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: A canvas Picasso painted of his lover Marie-Thérèse Walter seated by a window that had sold for $7.5 million at a Christie’s auction in 1997 brought $44.8 million, including fees, at Sotheby’s in London on Tuesday evening.

headline: Liberty’s Bid for Virgin Media Pushes the Envelope on Debt
abstract: Liberty Global’s $23 billion offer for Virgin Media has most of the hallmarks of the precrisis boom, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Liberty Global’s $23 billion offer for Virgin Media is a turning point in postcrisis deal finance. This merger in cable television has most of the hallmarks of the precrisis boom.

headline: Darwin’s Pigeons: Learning About Evolution From Bird Traits
abstract: In this lesson, students read about a study that sheds new light on Charles Darwin’s hobby of breeding pigeons, which includes exploring how scientists unravel the connections between the birds’ genes and physical characteristics.
lead_paragraph: Overview | In this lesson, students read about a study that sheds new light on Charles Darwin’s hobby of breeding pigeons. They learn about the origins of genes responsible for certain traits in pigeons, explore how scientists unravel the connections between genes and physical characteristics, and create their own selective breeding program.

headline: Scientists Find Life in the Cold and Dark Under Antarctic Ice
abstract: The discovery reported by scientists of a subglacial ecosystem in a lake beneath a half-mile of ice may aid knowledge of how life could survive on other planets.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, scientists report, they have found bacteria living in the cold and dark deep under the Antarctic ice, a discovery that might advance knowledge of how life could survive on other planets or moons and that offers the first glimpse of a vast ecosystem of microscopic life in underground lakes in Antarctica.

headline: Sounds of the Road, in 17-Syllable Verse
abstract: Readers offered haiku to commemorate New York City’s decision to remove no-honking signs.
lead_paragraph: Well beeped, City Room readers. On the occasion of the city’s decision to take down those seemingly unavailing “No Honking” signs, we asked you to send us a Honku or two to mark the moment. You responded in droves, with extreme literary alacrity. Here is some of your work:

headline: Two-Tax Rise Tests Wealthy in California
abstract: California’s top earners are now facing a combined 51.9 percent federal and state income tax — the highest rate in the nation — a cause for grumbling and, maybe, an incentive to move.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — It is getting awfully expensive to be a millionaire in California.

headline: With R.B.S. Settlement, Legal Tab for Banks Grows and Grows
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In the wake of various financial scandals, European banks are expected to pay a total of about $25 billion for settlements and client compensation so far.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The sprawling investigations into interest-rate manipulation, money laundering and inappropriately sold products, while bad for many London-based banks, have turned into a goldmine for lawyers, accountants and other advisers.

headline: Symbol of a Struggle
abstract: Hoki Sport Club Csikszereda is in the vanguard of bringing greater autonomy for the Szekely Land, a Hungarian-dominated area of Romania.
lead_paragraph: MIERCUREA CIUC, Romania — A city of 38,000 on a plateau in eastern Transylvania, Miercurea Ciuc is famous for three things: its status as one of Romania’s coldest places; its brewery, where the country’s Ciuc beer is produced; and its ice hockey team, which has won the last six Romanian league championships.

headline: Selling Jewelry and a Lifestyle, a Snapshot at a Time
keywords: ['Social Networking (Internet)', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'E-Commerce', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Largely through social media, Dannijo went from a few homemade necklaces, strung together in an East Village apartment, to a top seller at Bergdorf Goodman and Shopbop.com.
lead_paragraph: For those who suffer from #fomo (fear of missing out), it’s a good idea to avoid the Instagram feed of Dannijo, a fashion jewelry line favored by downtown socialites and celebrities.

headline: Excerpt: 'Community'
abstract: The NBC sitcom returns Feb. 7 after a lengthy hiatus.
lead_paragraph: The NBC sitcom returns Feb. 7 after a lengthy hiatus.

headline: Video of Protests Across Tunisia After an Opposition Leader Is Gunned Down
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: Video and photographs shot by Tunisian activists and bloggers on Wednesday gave close-up views of protests across the country.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Monica Marks and Kareem Fahim report, there were protests across Tunisia on Wednesday following the assassination of Chokri Belaid, a leader of the secular opposition.

headline: Fame Tries to Keep Up With a Busy Stylist
abstract: Kate Young’s work on runways shows and the red carpet is the star, she says, not her.
lead_paragraph: Kate Young, 37, a stylist for red carpet supernovas like Natalie Portman, Rachel Weisz and Michelle Williams, can often be spotted in Manhattan’s garment district, darting into designers’ showrooms to inspect their latest dresses.

headline: Little Blog Post About Little Particles
abstract: Just because you can’t see them doesn’t mean they are not there.
lead_paragraph: Nanoparticles are really little; a nanometer is a billionth of a meter. A nanoparticle might be 10 nanometers, or 100; it doesn’t matter much. By comparison, a human hair is around 100,000 times thicker. Needless to say, you can’t see a nanoparticle.

headline: Think You Can Beat Them?  Readers Who Get the Top Categories Right
abstract: Talking with three players in the New York Times Oscar pool who’ve gotten the top six categories right for each of the last two years.
lead_paragraph: (Vote for, share and keep track of your Oscar favorites with The Times’s interactive awards ballot. Start Your Oscar Ballot)

headline: Honda Plans Big Product Push at Geneva
abstract: The Acura NSX hybrid, advancing toward production, will be shown in Europe for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Honda will be making a major product statement at the Geneva Motor Show on March 5, introducing three important models.

headline: Mayor Backs College’s Plan to Welcome Critics of Israel
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Brooklyn College should be free to sponsor a forum on any topic, “including ideas that people find repugnant.”
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a vocal supporter of Israel but also a frequent advocate of free speech, on Wednesday forcefully defended Brooklyn College’s decision to co-sponsor a panel discussion about a movement that calls for economic boycotts and sanctions against Israel.

headline: Desperate Dad: Amity Gaige Talks About ‘Schroder’
abstract: In Ms. Gaige’s third novel, a father takes his daughter on an unplanned road trip.
lead_paragraph: In “Schroder,” Amity Gaige’s third novel, an increasingly distressed father in the middle of a custody battle takes off on an unexpected road trip with his 6-year-old daughter, Meadow. The novel takes the form of a long letter written by the father, Eric, to his wife, Laura, trying to explain his actions. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Gaige discussed the slipperiness of identity, why this is her darkest novel yet, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Democrats Seek to Stave Off $1 Trillion in Cuts
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Government Employees', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: House Democrats were counting on the arrival of federal furloughs and layoffs to make Republicans more receptive to a solution that would combine cuts with closing tax loopholes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With at least one million jobs on the line, Senate Democrats on Wednesday said they were closing in on legislation to temporarily head off nearly $1 trillion in cuts that were already affecting Pentagon decision-making and could force significant reductions in staffing and services across the government.

lead_paragraph: The entrepreneur discusses the importance of teaching creativity and his drive for innovation.

headline: A Nice Clean Sport With No Reffing Controversies
abstract: George Vecsey is looking forward to watching the teams from the United States and Honduras play Wednesday–and the officiating too.
lead_paragraph: “Some friends are upset because the U.S. looked so miserable in that 0-0 draw with Canada in Houston last week. I can only say that match had nothing to do with World Cup qualifying. It was the equivalent of a baseball spring training game, when the regulars don’t quite make the bus ride,” George Vecsey writes on his Web site, in anticipation of today’s game between the United States and Honduras. Read more here.

headline: Highlights: The Westminster Dog Show
abstract: News, photos and behind-the-scenes accounts from the 137th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York City.
lead_paragraph: News, photos and behind-the-scenes accounts from the 137th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York City.

headline: What to Do if Your W-2 Is Missing
abstract: You can file a substitute W-2 form if the real one doesn’t show up.
lead_paragraph: Most workers have received their W-2 forms from their employers by now. Companies are required to provide the forms to employees, showing their annual income, tax payments and other deductions, by Jan. 31.

headline: Getting Models Into Fighting Shape
abstract: To help runway models squeeze into sample sizes for Fashion Week, the former boxer Michael Olajide Jr. has been training them to “sleekify” at his West Village gym.
lead_paragraph: For models, the former boxer Michael Olajide Jr. is the heavyweight of trainers — the go-to guy for girls who have to get runway-ready in a hurry.

lead_paragraph: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Late-Night Chills at South by Southwest
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The South by Southwest film festival announces its midnight movies lineup.
lead_paragraph: Vampires rise and so does Rob Zombie in this year’s Midnighters lineup at the South by Southwest film festival. The program will include nine after-dark films that either wallow in the creepy or bask in the crazy.

headline: Trade Group Lawsuit Challenges Olive Oil Labeling
keywords: ['Olive Oil', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Consumer Protection', 'Oils and Fats']
abstract: The North American Olive Oil Association contends that Kangadis Food falsely labeled its Capatriti brand as olive oil when the product is a fat from leftover olive skins and pits.
lead_paragraph: The North American Olive Oil Association, a trade group that represents the olive oil business in the United States and Canada, is suing Kangadis Food, saying it falsely labeled its Capatriti brand as olive oil when the product is a fat from leftover olive skins and pits.

headline: A How-To Guide for Banks Facing Libor Settlements
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Now that a third bank has settled a case involving manipulation of Libor, other firms ensnared have a guidebook on what to expect when negotiating their own agreements.
lead_paragraph: The settlement announced Wednesday by the Royal Bank of Scotland with United States and British authorities is the third deal by a global bank emerging from the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate, or Libor.

headline: FINAL: Honduras 2, U.S. 1
abstract: Commentary and analysis of the United States national team’s World Cup qualifying match against Honduras from San Pedro Sula on Feb. 6.
lead_paragraph: The United States men’s soccer team lost to Honduras, 2-1, on Wednesday in the first game of the final round of regional World Cup qualifying.

headline: Rap Duo Wins the Week With ‘Thrift Shop’
abstract: Beyoncé may have rocked the Super Bowl, but the biggest victory in music this week belongs to Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, an independent rap duo, and the hit song “Thrift Shop.”
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé sang for an estimated 104 million people at the Super Bowl on Sunday, and Justin Bieber has scored his fifth No. 1 album. But the biggest victory in the music industry is an independent rap duo from Seattle and its hit song about the pleasures of smelly secondhand clothes.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 6
abstract: A view of the day in sports, with cycling through the sands of Qatar.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, with cycling through the sands of Qatar.

headline: Panetta Warns of Dire Consequences to Military From Budget Cuts
abstract: The defense secretary, who has been cautioning about the impact of cuts for months, said in a speech that “this is not a game, this is reality.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the wake of President Obama’s appeal to Congress to stave off across-the-board military and domestic spending cuts, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned Wednesday that reductions from the automatic cuts would curtail American naval operations in the western Pacific by as much as a third and force one-month furloughs for as many as 800,000 Defense Department civilian employees starting this spring.

headline: Leader Signals G.O.P. Shift on Wages and College Aid
abstract: State Senator Dean G. Skelos of New York indicated a new willingness to back not only a higher minimum wage, but also college aid for illegal immigrants’ children.
lead_paragraph: The Republican leader of the New York Senate said Wednesday that his caucus was open to raising the state’s minimum wage and creating a private fund to help the children of illegal immigrants pay for college.

headline: Detain: No. Kill: Yes.
abstract: What would Senator Obama have made of the “targeted killing” memo that NBC News published on Monday?
lead_paragraph: What would Senator Obama have made of the “targeted killing” memo that NBC News published on Monday? In a December 2007 interview with Charlie Savage — then of The Boston Globe, now of The New York Times — Mr. Obama didn’t specifically address drone strikes. But he did say it was unlawful to detain U.S. citizens without charges, and argued that it’s always preferable for the commander in chief to obtain support from Congress prior to military actions.

headline: Good News and Bad for Pompeii
abstract: A restoration project starts — the day after an arrest connected to restoration work.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy on Wednesday inaugurated a project financed by the European Union to restore the ancient city of Pompeii, a day after the police arrested a former restorer on charges involving inflated contracts and placed several others under investigation. Two years after the announcement that the union would commit more than $140 million to the restoration of Pompeii, where exposure to the elements and ill-fated interventions have led to routine collapses, the union’s regional affairs commissioner, Johannes Hahn, visited the city on Wednesday with three Italian government ministers.

headline: Google Buys E-Commerce Company to Improve Shopping Search
abstract: Google is spending $125 million to buy Channel Intelligence in an attempt to create a better experience for retailers and consumers who are using Google’s shopping search tool.
lead_paragraph: Google is moving deeper into e-commerce. On Wednesday, it announced it has agreed to acquire Channel Intelligence, a company that provides services to online retailers, for $125 million.

headline: 5 From Queens Charged in Toy-Smuggling Scheme
abstract: The men imported counterfeit, and sometimes dangerous, toys in an elaborate operation that law enforcement officials said operated for eight years.
lead_paragraph: Winnie the Pooh was the first to come to the attention of law enforcement officials, when customs agents seized a shipment of bubble blowers from China that illegally used the portly bear’s image.

headline: Apple’s iPad Dominated PC Market During Holiday Season
abstract: If you count tablets as computers, iPads far outsold personal computers in the fourth quarter worldwide.
lead_paragraph: The iPad is defined as a tablet, but you might as well call it a personal computer. Over the holiday season, about one in six people buying computers around the world bought Apple’s tablet, according to research from Canalys.

headline: Calling All Anti-Models
abstract: Daisuke Obana, the designer of a niche men’s-wear label called N.Hoolywood, scouts his runway models on the street.
lead_paragraph: MAURICE MAULTZ WAS zooming along West Fourth Street on a skateboard, thinking about the 300 pieces of film he had to scan for a class project at New York University, when he noticed a photographer taking his picture. Also, the photographer was surrounded by what appeared to be a small group of Japanese tourists, all of them staring at him.

headline: Depression and the Limits of Psychiatry
abstract: The recent revisions to the DSM’s definition of depression are based on a questionable conception of what is “normal.” Why is that dangerous?
lead_paragraph: I’ve recently been following the controversies about revisions to the psychiatric definition of depression.  I’ve also been teaching a graduate seminar on Michel Foucault, beginning with a reading of his “History of Madness.”   This massive volume tries to discover the origins of modern psychiatric practice and raises questions about its meaning and validity.  The debate over depression is an excellent test case for Foucault’s critique.

headline: A Gastro Pub by the Palms in Miami
abstract: At Pubbelly, the menu flirts with global flavors while almost never committing to a single culinary tradition.
lead_paragraph: To many Miamians, Pubbelly is not just a great gastro pub. It’s not even just the flagship restaurant in what has fast become an exceedingly successful mini-empire. In Miami, the “Pubbelly guys,” as they’re almost universally referred to, are often spoken of as folk heroes and credited with having fundamentally transformed the city’s food landscape with six spots in just over two years, and another scheduled to open this year. If you ask Andreas Schreiner, who with Jose Mendin and Sergio Navarro opened Pubbelly in late 2010, that kind of recalibration of the Miami food scene was exactly their goal.

headline: The SLS Hotel South Beach: Good for Gawking. Sleeping, Not So Much
abstract: This new property is sprinkled with celebrity pixie dust, but the customer service isn’t quite as magical.
lead_paragraph: Stats

headline: Magazines React to Post Office Cutbacks: ‘The Friday Evening Post’?
abstract: The loss of Saturday delivery are another blow for the industry, particularly affecting the newsweeklies and celebrity magazines like People.
lead_paragraph: 4:22 p.m. | Updated The magazine industry, which has already been hurt by advertising declines and the loss of readers, spent Wednesday afternoon reeling from the latest news that they no longer would be able to get magazines delivered on Saturdays.

headline: Japan Subsidy for Whaling Is Challenged
abstract: The report challenges assertions by the Japanese government that whaling is a tradition with wide support among Japanese consumers.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A wildlife conservation group said in a report on Wednesday that Japan has been propping up its whaling industry with nearly $400 million in tax money in recent years, stepping up subsidies even as consumption of whale meat here has slumped.

headline: Scene City: Social Animals Come Out of Their Shells
abstract: A benefit for Eric Goode’s Turtle Conservancy draws the party people.
lead_paragraph: A benefit for Eric Goode’s Turtle Conservancy draws the party people.

headline: Guests With a Hard Shell
abstract: The Turtle Ball, which was held to benefit the Turtle Conservancy, attracted guests like Kate Spade, Gina Gershon and Parker Posey.
lead_paragraph: Here’s something you might not know about turtles: some of them can still have sex when they’re 200 years old.

headline: New Polls Show Rise in Support for Obama’s Handling of Immigration
abstract: Following the president’s campaign-style blitz last week to unveil his proposals to overhaul immigration, the public’s rating of his handling the issue appears to be improving.
lead_paragraph: Following President Obama’s campaign-style blitz last week to unveil his proposals for immigration overhaul, the public’s rating of his handling of the issue appears to be on the rise, with several of his proposals enjoying broad support.

headline: United States Announces New Iran Sanctions
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The United States blacklisted several organizations in Iran, widening the American effort to pressure the government over its nuclear program and human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: The United States blacklisted Iran’s state broadcasting authority, Internet-policing agencies and a major electronics producer on Wednesday, an action that widened the American sanctions effort to pressure the Iranian government over not only its disputed nuclear program but also over the stifling of domestic dissent and access to information.

headline: Runway Crescendo: Strut Over, Beethoven
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Models (Professional)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Music']
abstract: When the models at the Carolina Herrera show hit the runway, the music they’ll strut to will be a piece commissioned by the designer herself.
lead_paragraph: At Carolina Herrera’s fashion show on Monday at Lincoln Center, don’t expect to hear the Knife’s “Full of Fire,” Haim’s “Don’t Save Me” or Rihanna’s “Diamonds.”

headline: Rubio to Deliver State of the Union Rebuttal
abstract: As Republicans try to heighten their appeal to Hispanic voters, party leaders announced the Senator Marco Rubio will respond to the president — in English and Spanish.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio will give the Republicans’ response to the State of the Union address, party leaders announced on Wednesday.

headline: If the Shoe Fits
abstract: Leave it to Miuccia Prada to dream up this season’s most boundary-breaking shoes.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to Miuccia Prada to dream up this season’s most boundary-breaking shoes. For her futurist Japanese-inspired spring collection, the designer sent models down the runway in Harajuku girl-style platforms and metallic judo socks with ribbon thong detailing, which left one or two fashion editors wondering if these otherworldly concoctions would actually make it into the stores. Starting tomorrow, and continuing through the end of the month, the Prada Fifth Avenue store will let clients customize select styles, from floral-embroidered bow getas (Japanese wooden sandals) to high satin sandals in colors like classic black and white, pale pink and metallic silver. And if you dare to wear, you can add your own initials — in gold lettering — on the soles. (Delivery takes six to eight weeks.)

headline: Carnegie Mellon Selects New President
abstract: Subra Suresh, the director of the National Science Foundation, will become president of the Pittsburgh school on July 1.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Mellon University has selected Subra Suresh, the director of the National Science Foundation, as its new president, our colleague Tamar Lewin reports:

headline: A Capitalist Case for Emancipation
abstract: For one businessman, slavery had to end not because it was immoral — but because it was inefficient.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation was met with both roars of approval and curses of outrage. Many of the most vocal supporters spoke in moral and political terms, arguing that slavery was either a sin or an abuse of intrinsic human freedom. But a third case was made too, one often overlooked today: slavery had to end because it violated the laws of the free market.

headline: Tortorella, in a Mellower Mood
abstract: Rangers Coach John Tortorella softens his criticism of the team–and takes some responsibility for the 4-5 start.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It doesn’t happen often, but a kinder, gentler John Tortorella emerged after practice here Wednesday afternoon, as he tempered the paint-peeling criticism he leveled at his Rangers after a 3-1 loss to the Devils on Tuesday night.

headline: Judge Asked to Settle Twombly Foundation Dispute
abstract: A Delaware judge has been asked to settle a feud among the directors of a foundation established by Cy Twombly.
lead_paragraph: A Delaware judge has been asked to settle a feud among the directors of a foundation established by Cy Twombly, the American artist who died in 2011. The complaint, which was filed in the Chancery Court in Wilmington last week, asks the judge to appoint a custodian to “break an ongoing deadlock among the Foundation’s divided, four-person board of directors,’’ according to court papers.

headline: In Lisbon, a Sleek Three-Bedroom Aerie
abstract: A recently renovated apartment in Amoreiras Towers is on the market for $1.15 million. The complex was built about 30 years ago by the Portuguese architect Tomás Taveira.
lead_paragraph: A recently renovated apartment in Amoreiras Towers is on the market for $1.15 million. The complex was built about 30 years ago by the Portuguese architect Tomás Taveira.

headline: House Hunting in ... Portugal
abstract: Portugal’s property market is stable after several years of falling prices.
lead_paragraph: A THREE-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY APARTMENT OVERLOOKING LISBON

headline: Nigeria and Burkina Faso in Africa Final
abstract: Nigeria and Burkina Faso advanced to Sunday’s final of the Africa Cup of Nations in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Burkina Faso ousted Ghana in a penalty-kick shootout, 3-2, after playing to a 1-1 draw after 120 minutes, and Nigeria rolled over Mali, 4-1, in South Africa on Wednesday in the semifinals of the Africa Cup of Nations. On Sunday in Johannesburg, the two countries will play for the title and a berth in this year’s FIFA Confederation Cup in Brazil.

headline: Online Campaign Draws Attention to Case of Saudi Father Accused of Rape and Torture
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Domestic Violence', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Sex Crimes', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Reports that a man in Saudi Arabia, who had frequently appeared on television as a preacher, had raped and tortured to death his 5-year-old daughter have fueled outrage online.
lead_paragraph: Reports that a man in Saudi Arabia, who has appeared on television as a preacher, had raped and tortured to death his 5-year-old daughter have fueled outrage online about the way the legal system works in the conservative kingdom and about the lack of protections for domestic abuse victims.

headline: Where Chicken Nuggets Dip Themselves
abstract: An installation by Banksy, the pseudonymous, secretive British artist, was unveiled on Wednesday at 89 Seventh Avenue South in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: An installation by Banksy, the pseudonymous, secretive British artist, was unveiled on Wednesday at 89 Seventh Avenue South in Greenwich Village.

headline: Nannycam Video of Baby Being Slapped Leads to Arrest
abstract: Staten Island prosecutors have charged a 52-year-old nanny with endangering the welfare of a child after a hidden camera recorded her slapping the face of a 5-month-old.
lead_paragraph: Staten Island prosecutors have charged a 52-year-old nanny with endangering the welfare of a child after a hidden camera recorded her slapping the face of a 5-month-old girl.

headline: The Nuclear Power and Natural Gas Equation
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Natural Gas', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: Given the abundance of cheap natural gas, aging nuclear plants with expensive safety problems may find it harder to survive.
lead_paragraph: Duke Energy is weighing the issue of how to replace the power generated by its troubled Crystal River nuclear plant in Florida, which the company has announced that it will permanently shut down.

headline: App Smart: Video Editing
keywords: ['iPhone', 'Science and Technology', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: Kit Eaton reviews apps that turn smartphone video into fun short films.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton reviews apps that turn smartphone video into fun short films.

headline: Former Top Media Banker Sues Los Angeles and 2 Police Officers
abstract: A former top Deutsche Bank deal maker sued the city of Los Angeles and two of its police officers on Wednesday, accusing the men of beating him and smearing his reputation in a widely publicized arrest last year.
lead_paragraph: 5:48 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tools of the Trade for the Smartphone Cineaste
abstract: There are several apps to edit unnecessary parts, string clips together or add special effects to the video on your smartphone.
lead_paragraph: I’ll bet that your smartphone is full of lots of little video clips. You know, ones that you make when you see something cute, surprising or beautiful. They may be nice mementos, but I’ll also bet they are not great examples of cinematography. Instead of just leaving these clips in their raw state on your phone, you can use apps to trim off unneeded parts, string clips together or add special effects.

headline: No One Forgets a Name When It’s Strange
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Names, Organizational']
abstract: It has become bad form — not just uncompetitive and unoriginal — to do something as 20th century as naming your fashion line after yourself.
lead_paragraph: What’s in a name? Beats me.

headline: Matthew Perry Becomes a Dreamer
abstract: The actor Matthew Perry is an investor in the company that bought the “Field of Dreams” movie site in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: The Field of Dreams just got another dreamer.

headline: Same Classroom, New Curriculum on ‘Community’
abstract: The misfit group of study partners returns for a fourth season, without the show’s creator, Dan Harmon, and much of his distinctive quirky humor.
lead_paragraph: One of the many reasons to watch the first three seasons of “Community,” the fiercely quirky and unapologetically smart NBC sitcom, was that you actually had to watch it. Every offhand remark, every reaction shot, every bit of physical business communicated something (usually something funny). More than any other show in prime time it demanded that you pay attention.

headline: A Crack in the Ice Between Musicians and Management
abstract: As its lockout continues, the Minnesota Orchestra performs in concert to celebrate its Grammy nomination.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Sibelius’s music is thought by many to reflect the long, deep winters of his native Finland. So if you’re looking to Sibelius to shed a bit of warmth, it must be cold.

headline: Theater World Friends Bring Ailing Playwright Closer To Home
abstract: María Irene Fornés, who is suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, was welcomed by friends and fellow playwrights when relocated on Wednesday to a Manhattan nursing home.
lead_paragraph: About a dozen friends and colleagues of the adventurous Cuban-born playwright and director María Irene Fornés gathered Wednesday morning near the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to await her arrival at Amsterdam House, the nursing home to which she was transferred from another facility in upstate New York. Just before 1 p.m. the small throng waved and applauded as Ms. Fornés, 82 and gaunt but seeming to enjoy the attention, was wheeled into the home.

headline: Professor Pinault Pays a Visit
abstract: Last week, while visiting New York, François-Henri Pinault, the chief executive of PPR, stopped by the M.F.A. fashion design program at Parsons the New School for Design.
lead_paragraph: Going into the fall 2013 collections on Thursday, there is no question that the fashion landscape is getting younger. This season, we’re all looking forward to seeing the maturing work of a large group of designers who have entered the business over the last decade, many of them right out of college.

headline: Now Serving Spite and Dutch Malaise
abstract: Herman Koch confines his novel “The Dinner” to one fraught restaurant meal, where malice, cruelty, craziness and a deeply European malaise are very much on the menu.
lead_paragraph: “The Dinner,” Herman Koch’s internationally popular novel, is an extended stunt. Mr. Koch confines his story to one fraught restaurant meal, where malice, cruelty, craziness and a deeply European malaise are very much on the menu. The four diners can leave the table occasionally, headed to the restrooms or the garden or the handy room of flashback memories. But mostly they sit and seethe at one another as a miserable night unfolds.

headline: An Author Attracts Unlikely Allies
abstract: Thomas Nagel’s latest philosophy book questions the randomness of Neo-Darwinism.
lead_paragraph: In 1974 Thomas Nagel published “What Is It Like to Be a Bat?,” a short essay arguing that the subjective experience of consciousness — what philosophers call the “qualia” — could not be fully reduced to the physical aspects of the brain.

headline: About Last Night | The Marni Fragrance Party
abstract: Inspired by the evening, T asked partygoers to dish on their go-to scent.

headline: Egyptian Prime Minister Criticized for Soliloquy on ‘Ignorant’ Mothers
abstract: In the middle of political turmoil, Egypt’s prime minister, Hisham Qandil, took a moment to blame infant diarrhea on the unclean breasts of “ignorant” nursing mothers.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Thursday, 1:21 p.m. With angry protesters challenging the Egyptian government’s grip on strategic cities of the Suez Canal, the army chief warning of the potential “collapse of the state,” violent sexual assault plaguing demonstrations in Tahrir Square and more than 50 deaths in the latest round of street clashes, the nation’s prime minister spoke this week on state television about a social problem that few people saw coming: unclean breasts.

headline: Scouting Report
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Free macarons from Barbara Bui, more ways to get the feline look, and a fashion museum looks at shoes.
lead_paragraph: FASHION’S NIGHT OUT may come only once a year, but there are still plenty of ways to partake of macarons this Fashion Week. At the BARBARA BUI celebration at Intermix on Thursday, East Village-French confections like candied bacon with maple cream cheese meringue from Macaron Parlour will be on offer. At 1003 Madison Avenue from 6 to 8 p.m. R.S.V.P. at rsvp@intermixny.com.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Feb. 7
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Jeans (Apparel)']
abstract: Get noticed in playful jeans; lounge in style with Creatures of the Wind; and stay dry in a new line of mod raincoats.
lead_paragraph: Get noticed in playful jeans; lounge in style with Creatures of the Wind; and stay dry in a new line of mod raincoats.

headline: A Gathering of Songs and Friends
abstract: The Pulitzer-winning composer Kevin Puts (“Silent Night”) led the most recent edition of NYFOS Next, presented by the New York Festival of Song.
lead_paragraph: As he explained to the audience at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Tuesday night, the composer Kevin Puts did not know much about song when he was asked to serve as curator for a whole program of them. The invitation came last year from Michael Barrett, the associate artistic director of the popular New York Festival of Song, who was recruiting a composer to plan one of the organization’s NYFOS Next programs, a mini-series devoted to recent American songs.

headline: Fans Hooked, a Ballet Company Casts About for Converts
abstract: A four-ballet program by the New York City Ballet was part of Art Series, an effort to get more people to attend performances.
lead_paragraph: The terrific density of New York City Ballet’s repertory, without parallel anywhere in the world, is something its audience often takes for granted. We’re now less than halfway into the fourth week of the company’s six-week winter season. Already it has presented 21 ballets. These include 12 by George Balanchine, 2 each by Jerome Robbins, Peter Martins and the promising young choreographer Justin Peck, as well as one each by William Forsythe, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon.

headline: Celebrating 20 Years of Life After a Legend
abstract: Buglisi Dance Theater offered an opening-night program at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, as it celebrates its 20th year.
lead_paragraph: It hasn’t quite been two decades since Jacqulyn Buglisi and three of her colleagues in the Martha Graham Dance Company formed a troupe of their own. At the time Graham was declining, and Ms. Buglisi hoped to continue the Graham line from where Graham had left off. But the works on the opening-night program of Buglisi Dance Theater’s 20th season, which began at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, could have passed for much older than 20. And that’s including the two premieres.

headline: Eyes on Gun Violence, Lawmakers Propose Expanded Mental Health Access
abstract: The director of “Silver Linings Playbook” is expected to help promote a bipartisan measure to broaden access to mental health care, especially as veterans return from war.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to put their stamp on the Congressional debate over how to deal with gun violence, a bipartisan group of senators will introduce a bill Thursday that would seek to strengthen the nation’s mental health services and perhaps stave off violent acts by the mentally ill.

headline: Homes for $1.3 Million
abstract: Properties in Atlanta, Vermont and Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: Properties in Atlanta, Vermont and Minnesota.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.3 Million
abstract: A midcentury modern in Atlanta, a bowed-roof cape in Vermont and a Queen Anne in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA

headline: Music Seems Familiar, Even When It’s Not
abstract: Works by the Argentine composer Osvaldo Golijov, performed by the St. Lawrence String Quartet and other musicians at Carnegie Hall on Monday, abounded with allusions to folk tunes and prayer melodies.
lead_paragraph: The Book of Kohelet, or Ecclesiastes, contains one of the most frequently quoted phrases from the Bible: “There is nothing new beneath the sun.” The world-weary author of the text then continues, “Sometimes there is something of which one says: ‘Look, this is new!’ — it has already existed in the ages before us.” “Qohelet” is the title of an instrumental work by the Argentine composer Osvaldo Golijov, which the St. Lawrence String Quartet performed on Monday evening at Zankel Hall as part of an all-Golijov concert that attested to his profound interest in Middle Eastern and Mediterranean spiritual traditions. Mr. Golijov holds this season’s Richard and Barbara Debs Composer’s Chair at Carnegie Hall.

headline: It Took a Village to Film ‘Lincoln’
abstract: “Lincoln” leads the Oscars with a dozen nominations — spread among many veteran award-winning filmmakers — but it was a bear to make, even for professionals at the top of their field.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — If there were an oral history of the making of “Lincoln,” it might start with a 6-year-old Steven Spielberg visiting the Lincoln Memorial in Washington one winter. “I was freezing my little tush off, and my uncle brought me to meet this giant,” he recalled in an interview here on Monday. “I had no idea who he was except he was bigger than me and really intimidating.”

headline: Longtime Animosity at Bolshoi Described
abstract: Weeks after someone threw acid in the face of the Bolshoi Ballet artistic director, two figures tied to the company describe its acidic atmosphere in separate interviews with a Russian magazine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It remains a mystery who threw acid into the face of the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, three weeks ago. But new information about the Bolshoi did emerge this week: The theater’s director and its most prominent male dancer went public with a range of accusations, revealing dramas that were simmering long before the attack, though, in the end, they may have no connection to it.

headline: News Corp. Posts Gain on Strength of Cable Channels
abstract: On Wednesday, the company reported net income of $2.38 billion, or $1.01 a share, compared with $1.06 billion, or $0.42 a share in the same three-month period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: 8:54 p.m. | Updated Strong growth at News Corporation’s cable channels FX, Fox News and regional sports networks helped the company more than double its net income in the three-month period that ended Dec. 31, offsetting lingering costs related to a phone-hacking scandal and the cost of a planned split of the media conglomerate into two publicly traded companies.

headline: Young Man With a Lengthy To-Do List
abstract: The young Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov made his Carnegie Hall debut on Tuesday evening, playing a program of Scriabin, Liszt and Chopin.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a monumental few years for the 21-year-old Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov, who recently won the Tchaikovsky and Rubinstein competitions and made his debut with the New York Philharmonic. On Tuesday, just a day after signing a new partnership with Deutsche Grammophon, Mr. Trifonov gave his Carnegie Hall recital debut, which the label will release as a live recording.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Vine Restriction, and Amazon ‘Money’
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include professional athletes versus giant ducks, privacy advice to companies from the A.C.L.U. and an analysis of Amazon’s push to introduce another virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Zeke Jabbour’s Tournament in Boca Raton, Fla.
abstract: Zeke Jabbour hosts an annual pro-am bridge tournament at the St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla., that raises money for Parkinson’s research.
lead_paragraph: Zeke Jabbour hosts an annual pro-am bridge tournament at the St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla., that raises money for Parkinson’s research. The date, the Sunday before the Super Bowl, is carefully chosen because there are no playoff football games that day.

headline: The Fashion Week Diet
abstract: Eric Wilson, a fearless fashion reporter, lost five pounds covering the last round of nonstop runway shows in September, by eating whatever was available, which was sometimes a feast, sometimes not a lot.
lead_paragraph: I lost five pounds on the Fashion Week Diet, and I ate anything I wanted!

headline: In an Old Packard Plant, Life Goes On
abstract: A semi-retired autoworker calls 90,000 square feet of abandoned factory space home.
lead_paragraph: A semi-retired autoworker calls 90,000 square feet of abandoned factory space home.

abstract: Photos from Greece, Syria, Tunisia and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, Syria, Tunisia and Iraq.

headline: Life in the Ruins
abstract: Despite the lack of heat or reliable running water, an old Packard plant has become a home.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Allan Hill has an unwavering faith in Jesus and a slow startle response, traits that have served him well in his adopted home. For the last seven years, Mr. Hill, a 68-year-old semiretired auto-body worker, has lived in an old Packard plant, the concrete hulk that was once headquarters of the long-defunct automobile manufacturer and is now, in the words of the Motor City Muckraker blog, a “lawless wasteland.”

headline: Trees That Make the Best Neighbors
abstract: The experts praised bark and flowers, fruit and trunks, and suggested tricks for planting and pruning.
lead_paragraph: The feud with my neighbor has festered for a year or two now. He cusses at my children when they sled down the knoll near the property line. He grouses when I shovel snow near his garage. Come to think of it, the feud consists of my neighbor’s being a sorehead and my having the misfortune to live next door.

headline: For U.S. Leader in Afghan War, Much Time Making Peace

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After 19 months in Afghanistan, Gen. John R. Allen, the commander of American and coalition forces here, is leaving a war that has become as much about damage control and crisis diplomacy as fighting the Taliban.

headline: The Sky’s the Limit

lead_paragraph: Experts offer suggestions for buying trees, ranging from Southern magnolias to Tibetan cherries.

headline: Interview With Gen. John R. Allen on Leaving Afghanistan
