headline: BMW Confirms 3 Series Gran Turismos
abstract: The BMW 328i and 335i models will be sold in North America beginning this summer, the automaker says.
lead_paragraph: BMW officially confirmed Wednesday an expansion of its Gran Turismo line to its popular 3 Series, with the addition of 328i and 335i models.

headline: A Second Chance
abstract: When Jay Fielden rebuilt his house after it burned down in 2010, it was an opportunity to make the midcentury gem more livable.
lead_paragraph: When Jay Fielden rebuilt his house after it burned down in 2010, it was an opportunity to make the midcentury gem more livable.

headline: Restoration Drama
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: After Jay Fielden’s beloved house was lost in a fire, he reimagined it, just as he’s done with the magazine he edits.
lead_paragraph: WILTON, CONN. — In the annals of domestic horror stories, Jay Fielden’s is as gothic as they come. It begins with the collapse of Lehman Brothers and the attendant financial meltdown in the fall of 2008. He and his wife, Yvonne Orteig Fielden, now both 43, and their two young children had just moved into their new home, a sturdy example of Connecticut’s storied collection of modernist glass houses, which they had bought for $900,000 in 2007 and spent eight months renovating.

headline: Better Place, Proponent of E.V. Battery Swapping, Pulls Out of U.S. and Australia
abstract: Better Place, a company that provides charging infrastructure for electric vehicles, said it would concentrate on Denmark and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Better Place, a company that provides charging infrastructure for electric vehicles, said on Wednesday that it would wind down its operations in North America and Australia and concentrate solely on Denmark and Israel.

headline: Shopping for Serving Utensils
abstract: James Klein and David Reid, the married partners of the New York porcelain company KleinReid, believe that tableware and serving utensils are “the most intimate things at your dinner party.”
lead_paragraph: James Klein and David Reid, the married partners of the New York porcelain company KleinReid, believe that tableware and serving utensils are “the most intimate things at your dinner party.”

headline: Serving Utensils
abstract: To the partners of the New York porcelain company KleinReid, almost nothing comes under as much scrutiny when entertaining as table settings.
lead_paragraph: James Klein and David Reid believe in the power of table settings. Because when you entertain, almost nothing else comes under such close scrutiny.

headline: Summoning Nature for Healing
abstract: Mikyoung Kim, a Boston-based landscape architect, recently completed two therapeutic gardens for hospitals.
lead_paragraph: The Crown Sky Garden, on the 11th floor of the Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago, is a 5,000-square-foot area for play and contemplation and the second healing garden completed last year by Mikyoung Kim. Ms. Kim, a 44-year-old landscape architect, is regarded as an artful weaver of nature and sculpture. The Sky Garden features a bamboo grove and interactive furniture that emits sounds when an embedded brass hand is touched with a live one.

headline: Reflections by the Thousands
abstract: Lighting inspired by pirate’s loot.
lead_paragraph: With its shimmering metal clusters, the Argent suspension light by Terzani looks like something from the glam ’70s, but it was inspired by old pirate films. “When you open the chest — the one you used to see in child’s movies — it looked like an explosion of coins,” said Dodo Arslan, the designer.

headline: A New Home for Homer
abstract: Richard Mishaan’s design shop reopens in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer Richard Mishaan is reintroducing Homer, the stylish shop he owned from 1997 to 2008. (It would still exist, he said, had the Whitney Museum not reclaimed the Madison Avenue space.) Homer is now in Greenwich Village, but Mr. Mishaan aims to replicate the uptown experience. He will transform the store four times a year. “We’ll lighten things up for summer,” he said, “and have more-substantial pieces for the holidays.” The mix includes contemporary and vintage furnishings, as well as Mr. Mishaan’s own, more-affordable furniture designs for Bolier and lighting for Urban Electric. The store will be arranged in vignettes. “I want to give people design ideas and start a dialogue,” he said. 56 University Place (East 10th Street), (212) 744-7705, homerdesign.com.

headline: On the Road Again
keywords: ['Camps and Camping', 'Recreational Vehicles', 'Mobile Homes and Trailers']
abstract: Sleeker than an Airstream, and now with solar panels and Wi-Fi, this trailer can be yours for $100,000.
lead_paragraph: The Bowlus Road Chief makes an Airstream look about as design forward as a dogcart. The glittering, riveted-aluminum, lozenge-shaped trailer was engineered by an aircraft designer named William Hawley Bowlus in the 1930s (he also built the Spirit of St. Louis).

headline: Precision Engineering for Beer
abstract: Designing an I.P.A.-specific glass that alters the beer-drinking experience.
lead_paragraph: The German glassmaker Spiegelau, in partnership with Sam Calagione, the founder of Dogfish Head, and Ken Grossman of Sierra Nevada brewery, has introduced an I.P.A.-specific beer glass, perhaps the world’s first, surely the most obsessively considered.

headline: Sales at Stark, Alessi and Others
abstract: Discounts on carpets, fabric, accessories and more.
lead_paragraph: Rugs, fabric and wall coverings are up to 75 percent off at Stark through Sunday (wool broadloom, regularly $180 a square yard, is $99 a square yard): Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, (212) 752-9000, stark-home.com.

headline: O to Honor a Jazzman, With a Very Difficult Name to Spell
abstract: Ken Biberaj isn’t a big jazz fan, but his success at having the city replace a street sign carrying an apparently erroneous rendering of the first name of Thelonious Monk is now part of his campaign for City Council.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Ken Biberaj, a candidate for City Council, was preparing for a town-hall meeting to be held in the Amsterdam Houses near a cul-de-sac on West 63rd Street.

headline: At the Vortex of Music and Fashion
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Parties (Social)', 'Disc Jockeys', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Music']
abstract: Honey Dijon, the popular house-music D.J., finds herself a role model for transgender people.
lead_paragraph: “There are so many of these girls in fashion nowadays who call themselves a D.J.,” said the house-music D.J. Honey Dijon with a sigh. She was at S’Nice, a vegetarian cafe in the West Village, dressed casually in a sleeveless black Alexander Wang shirt and a slouchy beanie from Supreme.

headline: Share Your Fashion Week Instagrams
abstract: If you are documenting the scenes of New York Fashion Week on Instagram, tag your images with #NYTFashion. The New York Times Times is publishing a selection of your photos on nytimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Are you planning to attend New York Fashion Week? If not, will you be getting a glimpse of the action outside the tents, on the streets of New York or at the parties? From Thursday, Feb. 7 through Feb. 14, we will be featuring a gallery of your Instagrams from Fashion Week. Share your photos with us — scenes, portraits, details — by tagging them on Instagram with #NYTFashion. Remember, we are looking for images that represent the whole culture of Fashion Week, from the runway, behind the runway and beyond. Start snapping!

headline: Crew-Only 787 Flight Is Approved by F.A.A.
abstract: Federal regulators approved one flight of a Boeing 787, with a crew but no passengers, as engineers study ways to reduce the risks of another battery fire.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators said on Wednesday that they had approved one flight of a Boeing 787, with a flight crew but no passengers, as the company’s engineers study possible changes to the plane’s electrical systems that could reduce the risk of another battery fire.

headline: The Mascara Crowd Muscles In
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Beauty', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries']
abstract: Rarely on the front row, beauty bloggers nevertheless make their presence known.
lead_paragraph: It has become commonplace to see fashion bloggers in the front row of runway shows, whether it’s Man Repeller’s Leandra Medine at Yigal Azrouël, Tavi Gevinson at Rodarte or Bryanboy at D & G.

headline: Player Ratings: Honduras (2) vs. U.S. (1)
abstract: Rating the performance of the U.S. players in Wednesday’s World Cup qualifying match at Honduras.
lead_paragraph: The United States men’s national team opened the final round of regional World Cup qualifying in poor form Wednesday, losing to Honduras in San Pedro Sula.

headline: Walt Sweeney, All-Pro and Critic of N.F.L., Dies at 71
abstract: Sweeney, a star with the San Diego Chargers in the 1960s and ’70s, accused the team of handing out drugs to players and fostering his own addiction.
lead_paragraph: Walt Sweeney, an All-Pro guard for the San Diego Chargers in the 1960s and ’70s who accused the team of handing out drugs to players and fostering his own addiction, died on Saturday at his home in San Diego. He was 71.

headline: English Hospital Report Cites ‘Appalling’ Suffering
abstract: The report, which examined conditions at Stafford Hospital over a 50-month period between 2005 and 2009, found that many of the problems were due to the efforts of the hospital to meet health-service targets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shockingly bad care and inhumane treatment at a hospital in the Midlands led to hundreds of unnecessary deaths and stripped countless patients of their dignity and self-respect, according to a scathing report published on Wednesday.

headline: Trimming the Trends
abstract: Designers hint at purging collections of showy trims and prints.
lead_paragraph: Designers hint at purging collections of showy trims and prints.

headline: Group of Young Immigrants Seeks a Direct Path to Citizenship for All, Regardless of Age
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Law and Legislation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Leaders of the United We Dream network said Wednesday that it would press for a seven-year pathway to citizenship for all 11 million illegal immigrants in the country.
lead_paragraph: A national organization of young immigrants said Wednesday that it would press for a “direct and straightforward” seven-year pathway to citizenship for all 11 million illegal immigrants in the country, and would not support measures that only offered citizenship to young people brought to the United States as children.

headline: Brooklyn Event Expanding Into a Four-Race Series
abstract: The Red Hook Criterium has evolved into one of New York City’s biggest cycling events and will have races at the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal, Brooklyn Navy Yard, in Barcelona and in Milan.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly night in March 2008, a dozen or so cyclists sped through Brooklyn’s industrial Red Hook neighborhood on fixed-gear bicycles, dodging city buses and parked cars as bewildered neighbors looked on. The clandestine race was coined the Red Hook Criterium, but it was more spectacle than sporting event.

headline: Look for Thrills Without the Frills
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Industry insiders share a conviction that this week the runways will show designers who have purged their collections of showy trims and cacophonous prints in favor of a pared-down, genteelly nuanced look.
lead_paragraph: It’s a cherished maxim in the retail trade. “Buyers tell me all the time that their customers like things with stuff on it,” said Sharon Graubard, a fashion trend forecaster in New York. How else to explain collections last year that groaned with fancy trims: faux gems, fringe and enough gilt to trick out a mini-Versailles?

headline: Can You Squeeze In One More?
abstract: Organizers at fashion shows are seeking ever more creative ways to increase their front-row seating, without offending clients or violating fire-safety laws.
lead_paragraph: Getting a front-row seat during New York Fashion Week offers attendees the chance to be photographed by paparazzi before the show begins, to actually see the clothes on the models as they strut by, and to exchange a self-congratulatory glance with Anna Wintour (even if that glance goes unacknowledged by the Vogue editor).

headline: Seeking Redress for a Mother’s Life in a Workhouse
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Forced Labor', 'Apologies', 'Laundry and Laundromats', 'Human Trafficking', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Labor', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The daughters of a woman who was held in one of Ireland’s notorious Magdalene Laundries have been campaigning for an apology from the state for 10 years.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Samantha Long and her twin sister, Etta Thornton-Verma, were born in 1972 and adopted at 9 months. They never knew their birth mother and decided to try to track her down in the mid-1990s. “Nothing prepared us for what we found,” Ms. Thornton-Verma, who lives in New York, recalled in a telephone interview last week.

headline: Report Clouds the Picture on Yankees’ Catching
abstract: Francisco Cervelli, a leading candidate to be the Yankees’ starting catcher, has been linked to the Miami clinic being investigated for dispensing performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ thin catching corps was left more vulnerable when it was revealed Tuesday that Francisco Cervelli, one of the two leading candidates to be the team’s starting catcher, had visited a Miami clinic under investigation for dispensing performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Justice’s Plans for Event Tied to Pepsi Stir Outcry by Yale Alumni
abstract: Justice Sonia Sotomayor, a graduate of Yale Law School, is scheduled to make remarks at a conference sponsored by PepsiCo, a company some alumni see as a health threat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A long-running dispute between Yale University and some of its alumni over the university’s connections to PepsiCo, the giant beverage and snack company, has — in a way — reached the Supreme Court.

headline: Portraits From ‘Silver: A State of Mind’
abstract: When she turned 60, Vicki Topaz found herself wondering how other women of her generation were experiencing aging. Here is a sampling of their images and comments.
lead_paragraph: When she turned 60, Vicki Topaz found herself wondering how other women of her generation were experiencing aging. Here is a sampling of their images and comments.

headline: Italian Bank Confirms Loss of $985 Million in Secret Deals
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The Italian bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena confirmed earlier estimates of losses from secret transactions intended to conceal the bank’s problems.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Monte dei Paschi di Siena, an ancient Tuscan bank whose troubles have shaken Italian politics and caused jitters around the euro zone, on Wednesday confirmed earlier estimates of losses from a series of secret transactions that were used to conceal the scope of the bank’s problems.

headline: Silver Becomes Her, in a Show’s Portraits
abstract: Graying women, their hair cropped or cascading past their shoulders, are the subjects of portraits in an exhibition by Vicki Topaz, a San Francisco photographer.
lead_paragraph: Amy Hempel’s silver white hair is a fact of life. But more than that, it is a banner of identity. Ms. Hempel, the short story writer, recalled recently that a former beau had spied her as she was running to meet him for a movie date. As she caught up with him, he murmured appreciatively: “I knew that was you. I saw that flag of hair.”

headline: Tutu’s
abstract: Tutu’s, a neo-rustic bar/restaurant/club that opened last October, is a harbinger of normalization.
lead_paragraph: Bushwick’s industrial blocks are a haven for raves, after-hours parties and other grubby creatures facing extinction in Manhattan. But Tutu’s, a neo-rustic bar/restaurant/club that opened last October, is a harbinger of normalization.

headline: Berlusconi’s Brother Uses a Racial Slur for Mario Balotelli
abstract: Paolo Berlusconi’s remarks about the soccer star attracted little attention in the Italian news media, even though Italy has a growing problem with attitudes toward its expanding immigrant population.
lead_paragraph: ROME — It was considered a coup, politically as well as athletically, when Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister, shelled out 20 million euros last month to land Mario Balotelli, the star striker, for his soccer team, A. C. Milan. But some of the bloom was lost this week when Paolo Berlusconi, the brother of the former prime minister, referred to Mr. Balotelli in loose translation as “the little black boy,” using a word that is clearly derogatory in Italian.

headline: Vonn Aims for a Full Recovery While Ligety Wins
abstract: As the American skier Lindsey Vonn prepared for surgery, her teammate Ted Ligety won an unexpected super-G world championship in Austria.
lead_paragraph: SCHLADMING, Austria — One day after Lindsey Vonn’s season-ending crash, she said she planned to come back better than ever for the 2013-14 World Cup season.

headline: Guy F. Tozzoli, 90, Who Led Team That Built Twin Towers, Is Dead
abstract: It seemed, one article said, as if Mr. Tozzoli had personally willed the trade center into existence, outfoxing enemies, bullying colleagues and maneuvering around problems.
lead_paragraph: “You are going to build the trade center,” Guy F. Tozzoli was told on his 40th birthday in 1962 by the head of the Port of New York Authority. Eleven years later, he had.

keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Nails (Body Part)', 'Beauty', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries']
abstract: When creative minds form partnerships, both sides benefit.
lead_paragraph: French Twist

headline: A Hospital Offers a Grisly Lesson on Gun Violence
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Education (K-12)', 'Hospitals', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: A program brings in teenagers from around Philadelphia in the hope that seeing the effects of violence will deter them from reaching for a gun to settle a score.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In a darkened classroom, 15 eighth graders gasped as a photograph appeared on the screen in front of them. It showed a dead man whose jaw had been destroyed by a shotgun blast, leaving the lower half of his face a shapeless, bloody mess.

headline: Multinational Search in Bulgaria Blast
abstract: The two presumed Hezbollah members are believed to be behind a deadly bombing of a bus full of Israeli tourists in Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Law enforcement and intelligence officials from several countries are working to find two presumed Hezbollah members, a Canadian and an Australian, both of Lebanese descent, who are believed to be behind a deadly bombing of a bus full of Israeli tourists in Bulgaria.

headline: Veronica Beard: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: At 31, a Fast Start on Tour; at 17, a Big Debut
abstract: James Hahn and Si Woo Kim were both born in South Korea, but their stories of trying to succeed on the PGA Tour sharply differ.
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — They are two South Korean-born golfers whose pursuit of the American dream has brought them to the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, but from there the stories of James Hahn and Si Woo Kim sharply diverge.

headline: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The White House’s order to release classified documents came on the eve of the Senate hearing for John O. Brennan, President Obama’s choice to be C.I.A. director.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Wednesday directed the Justice Department to release to the two Congressional Intelligence Committees classified documents discussing the legal justification for killing, by drone strikes and other means, American citizens abroad who are considered terrorists.

headline: Leaving Behind Malibu in Search of a New Dream Home
abstract: Mattel’s new campaign will culminate with a disclosure of Barbie’s new home, which will come out in the fall.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the best-known residents of Malibu, Calif., alongside billionaires like David Geffen and Larry Ellison, is embarking on a national promotional effort to help sell her home there for the eye-popping price of $25 million.

headline: U.S. Wilts in Honduras in a World Cup Qualifier
abstract: Although the Americans struck first, they struggled in the heat of  Honduras and lost in the opening game of the final stage of World Cup qualification.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — The phrase was repeated like a mantra here this week: “Get the job done,” the American players said, until the words nearly lost their meaning.

headline: De Blasio Donors Hit Maximum, but Keep Giving
abstract: About two dozen supporters who have contributed as much as allowed to the mayoral campaign of the public advocate, Bill de Blasio, have donated more to defray debts from his 2009 race.
lead_paragraph: In an aggressive bid to increase contributions from major supporters, Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, has been taking donations to defray old campaign debts from people who have already given the maximum permissible amount to his current campaign for mayor.

headline: Governor of Illinois Tells Legislators Pension Costs Put State at ‘Critical Juncture’
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Elections, Governors', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Gov. Pat Quinn used his State of the State address on Wednesday to implore legislators again to curb pensions costs that he said were “squeezing out” other vital services.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — After a year of unfruitful attempts to solve Illinois’s fiscal crisis, Gov. Pat Quinn used his State of the State address on Wednesday to implore legislators again to curb pensions costs that he said were “squeezing out education, public safety and other vital services to the tune of $17 million a day.”

headline: Chris Brown Goes to Court, With Rihanna in the Front Row
abstract: Chris Brown went before a judge to answer allegations that he had failed to complete a sentence of community service after pleading guilty to assaulting Rihanna in 2009, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: As Rihanna sat in the front row and blew him a kiss, Chris Brown went before a judge on Wednesday to answer allegations from prosecutors that he had failed to complete a sentence of community service after pleading guilty to assaulting her in 2009, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Justice(s) at Work
keywords: ['Collective Bargaining', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: A little-noticed Supreme Court decision last summer raises concerns about the future of labor law in the hands of an anti-union conservative majority.
lead_paragraph: This column is prompted by the eye-catching headline that appeared two weeks ago: “Share of the Work Force in a Union Falls to a 97-Year Low, 11.3%.” As the article explained, many factors – global, domestic, economic, political – have contributed to the steep decline in the unionized work force, in both the private and public sectors. The trend, while accelerating, isn’t new. And on the surface, certainly, it has little to do with the Supreme Court.

headline: My Kingdom for a Corpse
abstract: The news about Richard III should give us all hope. It’s never too late to turn your life around!
lead_paragraph: Richard III is staging a comeback.

headline: Putin’s Vision of Olympic Glory Meets a More Earthbound Reality in Sochi
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The 2014 Olympic Games have been a pet project for President Vladimir V. Putin, but critics see Russia’s role as inviting international scrutiny on issues like human rights and civil liberties.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Cranes, dump trucks and more than 70,000 construction workers are now toiling 24 hours a day to transform this once sleepy Black Sea resort into its new role as sleek host of the 2014 Winter Olympics.

headline: The Priest That Preyed
keywords: ['Priests', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Fiction can never match the sexual abuse visited upon children in the Catholic Church in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

headline: Hunter Defends His Union Record
abstract: Billy Hunter, the embattled executive director of the N.B.A. players union, said he plans to “to exercise all my options” following his suspension for improper business practices.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The first hint that Billy Hunter’s 16-year tenure running the N.B.A. players union might be over came in an unsigned letter, delivered to his Harlem home last Friday morning.

headline: Hip-Hop Speaks to the Guns
abstract: In some places, senseless shootings remain a corrosive constant. Hip-hop tells the story.
lead_paragraph: The work of the rapper Kendrick Lamar should enjoy heavy rotation in the White House these days. In this time of Tucson, Aurora, Colo., and Newtown, Conn., Lamar’s major-label debut album, “good kid, m.A.A.d city,” gives us a broad reckoning with the meaning of everyday gun violence unfolding far from the tragic spectacle. “Good Kid” has earned its share of praise from critics and hip-hop fans, but it perhaps has the most to offer to those shocked into action by the senseless massacres we’ve endured over the past few years.

headline: Rachel Comey: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The Questions Brennan Can’t Dodge
abstract: The administration must openly discuss the legal basis for America’s campaign of targeted killings of terrorism suspects.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind.

headline: Study Seeks Biomarkers for Invisible War Scars
abstract: The goal of a five-year study, based at New York University’s medical school, is to find reliable, objective evidence of “invisible injuries” of war.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, about half a million veterans have received diagnoses of post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury. Thousands have received both. Yet underlying the growing numbers lies a disconcerting question: How many of those diagnoses are definitive? And how many more have been missed?

headline: Fix the Sink Before December
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Editorials', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: If Mayor Bloomberg could actually eliminate the huge backlog in the city’s public housing repairs, he would leave an important legacy.
lead_paragraph: With less than a year left in office, Mayor Michael Bloomberg would leave an important legacy if he could actually eliminate the huge backlog in repairs needed in New York City’s public housing — home to more than 400,000 people.

headline: No Snail Mail on Saturday
abstract: As lawmakers dither over reforms needed to cut ballooning deficits, the Postal Service wisely went ahead and eliminated Saturday delivery.
lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service is wisely going ahead with a long-debated plan to eliminate Saturday mail delivery, with or without Congress’s blessing. The public, increasingly reliant on Internet communication, has registered 70 percent approval in opinion surveys of the cutback as a no-brainer in modern life that would mean an estimated savings of $2 billion a year.

headline: Storm’s Toll Creeps Inland, 4 Tiny Feet at a Time
abstract: The fate of New York City’s rats remained something of a mystery after Hurricane Sandy. Now, several exterminators say they know what happened.
lead_paragraph: At first, Sarah Heming thought it was one of her dogs pitter-pattering across the second floor of her two-story rental in Brooklyn Heights late at night. But the sounds intensified in places where the dogs just couldn’t go; there was frantic scrabbling in the walls, followed by weighty thuds, and squeaks. There was scampering under the stove.

headline: Drug Inquiry Focuses on Athletes’ Ties to Team at University of Miami
abstract: Miami, already under investigation by the N.C.A.A., is drawing interest from Major League Baseball as it studies reports linking players to performance enhancers.
lead_paragraph: The University of Miami named its baseball stadium after Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez after he donated $3.9 million to renovate the field. One of baseball’s premier hitters, Ryan Braun, played for the university from 2003 to 2005 before leaving to begin his professional career. The Washington Nationals star pitcher Gio Gonzalez calls an assistant for the university’s baseball team his “off-season strength coach.”

headline: Court Urged to Reverse a Ruling on Terror
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Terrorism', 'Detainees', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The Obama administration on Wednesday urged a federal appeals court to overturn a ruling that blocked enforcement of a statute related to the indefinite detention without trial of terrorism suspects.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Wednesday urged a federal appeals court to overturn a sweeping ruling by a district judge that blocked the government from enforcing a statute related to the indefinite detention without trial of terrorism suspects.

headline: Europe’s Plan for GPS Limps to Crossroads
abstract: The European Union’s commitment to Galileo, a project designed to end reliance on America’s navigation system, is to be decided at budget talks this week.
lead_paragraph: FUCINO, Italy — With lofty dreams of European unity increasingly grounded by economic woe and the weight of narrow national interests, an array of computer screens here in central Italy blinks with faint signs that — far away in space, at least — Europe’s often quarreling nations can still sometimes find common cause.

headline: Immigration and the Middle Ground
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The first House hearing on immigration reform offered little encouragement for reaching a bipartisan deal.
lead_paragraph: The House Judiciary Committee held its first hearing on immigration on Tuesday, and it was not encouraging.

headline: Lighter Menus Appeal to Diners and Owners
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Calories', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Fast Food Industry']
abstract: Pressured by looming regulations, restaurants across the United States are shrinking portion sizes, a move that is paying off financially.
lead_paragraph: Driven by pressures like consumer demand and looming federal regulations that will require them to post calorie counts on menus, restaurant chains around the country are adding more nutritious choices and shrinking portion sizes.

headline: Tavares Plans to Take the Islanders Back to the Top
abstract: John Tavares, taken first over all by the Islanders in the 2009 N.H.L. draft, addressed his only significant weakness by improving his skating last season.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — It says everything about the makeup of Islanders center John Tavares that he believes they can reach the playoffs for the first time in six seasons, despite all the evidence to the contrary.

headline: A Plan Aims to Reconnect Residents With the East River Waterfront
keywords: ['Brooklyn Bridge (NYC)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Included in a blueprint to be announced by the Manhattan borough president are proposals for new beaches and boat launches, as well as for adding marshlands.
lead_paragraph: As New Yorkers have watched the waterfront around Manhattan open up in recent years, one stretch has lagged: the East River waterfront, especially from the Brooklyn Bridge north to 38th Street, where the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive impedes access, bike lanes are squeezed by development and, now in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, storm surges threaten parkland.

headline: For Hagel, a Distinction Comes With an Asterisk
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama, in nominating Chuck Hagel, said he would be the “first person of enlisted rank” to run the Pentagon, but at least four defense secretaries were, too.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared at the White House on Jan. 7 that Chuck Hagel, his nominee to be secretary of defense, would be the “first person of enlisted rank” to run the Pentagon. The distinction, which Mr. Obama called “historic,” quickly made its way into news media reports around the globe, including in The New York Times.

abstract: What effect have public-sector job cuts had on the economy? Could governments have responded to the recession in any other way?

headline: Pakistani Militant, Price on Head, Lives in Open
abstract: The United States has offered $10 million for help convicting Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the Pakistani founder of the group behind the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Ten million dollars does not seem to buy much in this bustling Pakistani city. That is the sum the United States is offering for help in convicting Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, perhaps the country’s best-known jihadi leader. Yet Mr. Saeed lives an open, and apparently fearless, life in a middle-class neighborhood here.

headline: With Care, Newtown Tries to Move On Amid Tokens of Grief
abstract: Almost two months after the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, residents and officials are trying to figure out what to do with thousands of letters and other items.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — In the 1,500 or so cards and letters in Box 58 at the Newtown Municipal Center, a mother named Ursula recalled the 6-month-old she lost in an auto accident; a 9-year-old, Hayden Toland-Yeh, pondered mortality; and Robert M. Sutton, a lawyer from Myrtle Beach, S.C., wrote movingly about the gun violence that ravaged his family when he was 6.

headline: Armstrong in Discussion to Tell Details to Doping Officials
abstract: The United States Anti-Doping Agency gave Lance Armstrong a two-week extension to provide information that may curtail his lifetime ban from competition.
lead_paragraph: Less than one month after confessing to using performance-enhancing drugs throughout his career, Lance Armstrong is in talks with the United States Anti-Doping Agency to possibly disclose who helped him dope and how he covered up his doping for nearly a decade.

abstract: Winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Those Created Equal
abstract: A reminder that we are not Ken Jennings, by David Levinson Wilk.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Let’s start out by talking about Germany. Because clearly we’ve got ourselves a trend here.

headline: Smoking, Once Used to Reward, Faces a Ban in Mental Hospitals
abstract: After decades in which smoking by people with mental illness was supported and even encouraged, a move in Louisiana reflects a broader effort to reverse course.
lead_paragraph: MANDEVILLE, La. — Annelle S., 64, who has paranoid schizophrenia, took an urgent drag on a cigarette at a supervised outdoor smoke break at Southeast Louisiana Hospital.

headline: After Down Year, Giants Cut Bradshaw and Canty
abstract: After failing to reach the playoffs, the Giants began making changes in earnest  with the release of running back Ahmad Bradshaw and defensive tackle Chris Canty.
lead_paragraph: After a season in which they deteriorated from Super Bowl champions to a perplexing, uneven team unable to reach the playoffs, the Giants began making changes in earnest Wednesday with the release of running back Ahmad Bradshaw and defensive tackle Chris Canty.

headline: Drone Strikes Under Scrutiny
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: There are a lot of questions for the Obama administration to answer. John Brennan, the nominee for C.I.A. director, can get started at his confirmation hearing.
lead_paragraph: In more than a decade at war since Sept. 11, 2001, the United States has relied increasingly on drones to kill people away from the battlefield. It has faced few constraints. Now an overdue push for greater accountability and transparency is gathering steam, propelled by growing unease that America’s drones hit targets in countries with whom it is not formally at war, that there are no publicly understood rules for picking targets, and that the strikes may kill innocent civilians and harm, not help, American interests.

headline: Asbury H. Sallenger Jr., Coastal Risks Expert, Dies at 63
abstract: Mr. Sallenger led research into the causes and effects of sea level rise, storms and other coastal hazards and was an adviser “in the post-Superstorm Sandy era.”
lead_paragraph: Asbury H. Sallenger Jr., a leader in the nation’s research on the causes and effects of sea level rise, storms and other coastal hazards, collapsed and died on Tuesday at his home in Oldsmar, Fla. He was 63.

headline: New Rove Effort Has G.O.P. Aflame
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The strategist Karl Rove and his allies have drawn ire for creating the Conservative Victory Project, their effort to help rebuild the Republican Party and win control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Their battle with Democrats will have to wait. For now, Republicans have their hands full fighting one another.

headline: The Knicks Can’t Stop Wall, Who Stops the Knicks’ Winning Streak
abstract: John Wall, who was out when the Knicks easily beat the Wizards earlier in the season, had 21 points on Wednesday to help them snap the Knicks’ five-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Knicks’ objective was the same with each Wizards possession in the fourth quarter: stop John Wall. They tried different tactics — double-teaming Wall on the pick-and-roll, or trapping him when he dribbled over midcourt. Raymond Felton, J. R. Smith and Iman Shumpert all had their chance to guard Wall. All three failed.

headline: In Chile, Video Appears to Show Sailors Vowing to Kill Foreigners
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The spread of the video comes at an awkward time for Chile, traditionally among Latin America’s largest arms importers, as the country faces territorial disputes with Bolivia and Peru.
lead_paragraph: The military establishment was put on the defensive on Wednesday after a video shared widely on social networks appeared to show Chilean sailors chanting, “I will kill Argentines, I will shoot Bolivians, I will behead Peruvians.” The short video, which apparently was made in a coastal area of Chile where the sailors were on a training run, drew quick condemnations. Cecilia Pérez, a spokeswoman for President Sebastián Piñera, called the images “shameful.” The commander of Chile’s Navy, Edmundo González, said the video’s authenticity was under investigation. The spread of the video comes at an awkward time for Chile, traditionally among Latin America’s largest arms importers, as the country faces territorial disputes with Bolivia and Peru.

headline: With A.L.S. in Family, Chief at Bloomberg Joins Fight
abstract: Daniel L. Doctoroff, a former deputy mayor, has enlisted Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in a drive to research the disease that killed Lou Gehrig.
lead_paragraph: Daniel L. Doctoroff watched in pain as his father developed a limp one day, was found to have Lou Gehrig’s disease, and died within two years. Then an uncle also developed symptoms of the same disease, and died soon after.

headline: Trial of Former College Quarterback Accused of Rape Starts Friday in Montana
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Football (College)', 'College Athletics', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: The trial extends a cloud of scandal that has hung over the campus for two years.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — The trial of Jordan Johnson, a former starting quarterback at the University of Montana accused of raping an acquaintance, begins in Missoula, Mont., on Friday, extending a cloud of scandal that has hung over the campus for two years.

headline: E-Mails Imply JPMorgan Knew Some Mortgage Deals Were Bad
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: E-mails and employee interviews filed as part of a lawsuit show that JPMorgan Chase flouted quality controls as it bundled mortgages into complex financial instruments.
lead_paragraph: When an outside analysis uncovered serious flaws with thousands of home loans, JPMorgan Chase executives found an easy fix.

headline: U.S. Increases Pressure of Economic War on Tehran
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Iranian Rial (Currency)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The United States blacklisted several organizations in Iran on Wednesday, widening the American effort to pressure the government over its nuclear program and human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — All over this city of 12 million people, high-rises are under construction, local engineers and Chinese contractors are rushing to finish a multilevel highway, and the streets are lined with billboards promoting the latest tablets and washing machines made by South Korean companies like Samsung and LG. Supermarkets are fully stocked, and it seems as if new restaurants and fast food joints are opening up every day, and never lacking for customers.

headline: California: Archdiocese Will Release More Files
abstract: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles says that it will release more documents and undo redactions in response to complaints that the files it released last week were incomplete.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles says that it will release more documents and undo redactions in response to complaints that the files it released last week on priests accused of sexual abuse were incomplete or that the names of church officials who had handled abuse cases had been blacked out. J. Michael Hennigan, a lawyer for the archdiocese, said that he had no idea why the documents were missing, but that as journalists, lawyers and victims caught the omissions, the archdiocese would add the information to the files it had posted online. Last week the archdiocese, under court order after a six-year dispute, made public internal church documents on 124 priests accused of abuse.

headline: Nets Win but Don’t Look Very Sharp in Doing It
abstract: The Nets had to shake off a quick turnaround after a loss to the Lakers, a string of early turnovers and spotty shooting, but they were able to claim a victory.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — By the fourth quarter, Nets Coach P. J. Carlesimo’s joke seemed prophetic. Speaking before the game Wednesday against the Detroit Pistons, Carlesimo mentioned his team’s inability to put away lesser opponents.

headline: Five Online Courses Are Eligible for College Credit
abstract: The American Council on Education and Coursera announced on Wednesday that five Coursera offerings were similar enough to traditional college courses to be eligible for credit.
lead_paragraph: The American Council on Education, the leading umbrella group for higher education, and Coursera, a Silicon Valley provider of online education, announced on Wednesday that five Coursera offerings were similar enough to traditional college courses to be eligible for credit. Students who want to take the free classes for credit would have to pay a fee to take an identity-verified, proctored exam, and for a transcript to submit to the college of their choice. Similar transcripts are accepted by 2,000 colleges and universities for courses offered by the military or by employers. The Coursera classes are the first MOOCs — for massive open online courses — to be declared eligible.

headline: Colorado: Contested Gas Leases Are Delayed
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: Facing a public outcry, federal officials announced Wednesday that they would not put thousands of acres of public lands in Colorado’s North Fork Valley up for bid at auction this month for oil and gas drilling.
lead_paragraph: After facing a public outcry over plans to lease thousands of acres of public lands in Colorado’s North Fork Valley for oil and gas drilling, federal officials announced Wednesday that they would not put the parcels up for bid at auction this month. Officials at the Bureau of Land Management, which regularly auctions energy leases on public lands across the West, said their decision had removed 20,555 acres from  bidding. Residents in the valley told federal officials they worried that the arrival of hydraulic fracturing on public lands could taint their air and water quality, and threaten their reputation as a budding haven for organic farms and orchards.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Feb. 7, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, Feb. 7, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I move about like an ordinary person — that’s my style. My fate is in the hands of God, not America.”

headline: Microsoft Attacks Google on Gmail Privacy
abstract: Microsoft plans to unveil a new advertising campaign that will highlight research that shows most people don’t know that Web e-mail providers like Google scan the contents of their messages to deliver personalized ads to them and, when they do find out, they don’t like it.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Microsoft plans to unveil a new print, television and online advertising campaign that attacks Google on an issue that Microsoft believes is one of its great vulnerabilities: privacy. The ads will showcase research that shows most people don’t know that Web e-mail providers like Google scan the contents of their e-mail messages to deliver personalized ads to them — and when they do find out, they don’t like it.

headline: The Persistence of Racial Resentment
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Elections (US)', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: We have elected and re-elected a black president, but the percentage of people holding anti-black attitudes is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: Although there was plenty of discussion during the 2012 presidential campaign about the Hispanic vote and how intense black turnout would be, the press was preoccupied with the white vote: the white working class, white women and upscale whites.

headline: Profound Weight of Layoffs Is Seen in Work Trends Survey
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Almost eight in 10 participants in a Rutgers University study said that they had lost a job in the last few years, or were close to someone who had.
lead_paragraph: Layoffs have touched nearly every American household in some fashion over the last few years, according to new survey data to be released Thursday by the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University.

keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Doctors', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hallucinations', 'Hospitals', 'Paranoia', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Urinary Tract']

lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you solve the mystery of a middle-aged man recovering from a serious illness who suddenly becomes frightened and confused?

headline: Investigators Say Menendez Intervened on Friend’s Behalf
abstract: Twice in the last four years, Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey helped a close friend in a Medicare billing dispute, federal investigators said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey intervened with federal health officials on two occasions in the last four years in an effort to help a close friend in a billing dispute with Medicare, federal investigators said Wednesday.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:30 P.M. (MoreMax) THE DESCENDANTS (2011) Matt King (George Clooney, in an Oscar-nominated role), a real estate lawyer whose family tree includes the earliest white settlers in Hawaii as well as indigenous royalty, struggles to make the right decision regarding his family’s birthright: a pristine and picturesque tract on Kauai. Should it be sold to developers? In the meantime his wife, Elizabeth (Patricia Hastie), is in a coma in a Honolulu hospital after a boating accident. Not long after her doctors inform Matt that he is about to become a widower and a single father to two difficult daughters, Scottie (Amara Miller) and Alex (Shailene Woodley), he learns that Elizabeth was having an affair. Robert Forster portrays Elizabeth’s enraged father, who blames his daughter’s condition on Matt’s tightwad ways; Matthew Lillard plays Brian, the object of Elizabeth’s affection; Judy Greer is Brian’s wife; Nick Krause (above, with, from left, Mr. Clooney, Ms. Miller and Ms. Woodley) is Alex’s goofy sidekick; and Beau Bridges is Matt’s cousin. Mr. Clooney’s actorly instincts “have never been keener or more generous,” and Ms. Woodley gives “one of the toughest, smartest, most credible adolescent performances in recent memory,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama directed by Alexander Payne and based on the novel by Kaui Hart Hemmings. He added: “Mr. Payne, with a light touch and a keen sense of place — this Hawaii is as real and peculiar as the Nebraska of ‘About Schmidt’ or the California wine country of ‘Sideways’ — has made a movie that, for all its modesty, is as big as life. Its heart is occupied by grief, pain and the haunting silence of Elizabeth, whose version of events is the only one we never hear. And yet it is also full of warmth, humor and the kind of grace that can result from our clumsy attempts to make things better.”

headline: Child Sexual Abuse Rampant and Untreated in India, Report Says
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: When children do report abuses, the police and government response often adds more trauma, Human Rights Watch said.
lead_paragraph: Child sexual abuse continues to be “disturbingly common” in India, despite widespread awareness of the problem, because of “social stigma and negligence,” Human Rights Watch said in a report issued Thursday.

headline: In Worldwide Soccer Corruption Scandal, an Asian Tie
abstract: The reputation of soccer, beloved of many, has been seriously tarnished by a report of massive match-fixing that includes top European games, with the epicenter of the trouble in Asia, investigators said.

headline: Fight Expands in Damascus as Diplomatic Hopes Sink
abstract: Clashes between Syrian insurgents and loyalist troops in Damascus raged for a second day on Thursday and spread to the suburbs and other areas, activist groups reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Clashes between Syrian insurgents and loyalist troops in Damascus raged for a second day on Thursday and spread to the suburbs and other areas, activist groups reported. They said fighting also erupted in the large Palestinian refugee neighborhood of Yarmouk on the capital’s southern outskirts, which has been drawn into the civil war at least twice in the past few months.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 7
abstract: Protests in Tunisia after an opposition leader is killed; an overhaul of European fisheries; a crossroads for the Galileo navigation system; and the Sri Lankan women’s cricket team stuns India.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Tunisian officials moved quickly Wednesday to contain the fallout after a leading opposition figure was assassinated outside his home. They announced that they would restructure the Islamist-led government and form a national unity cabinet as thousands took to the streets in protests that security forces beat back with tear gas. Monica Marks reports from Tunis, and Kareem Fahim from Cairo.

headline: Five Questions for: Author Tahar Ben Jelloun
abstract: The French author on his latest book and his occupational hazards.
lead_paragraph: Tahar Ben Jelloun is a Moroccan-born poet and novelist who writes in French and lives in Paris. His book “Racism, as Explained to My Daughter,” was translated into Hindi and Urdu. The award-winning writer first visited India 20 years ago, and he plans to write about what has changed in India since then. He spoke to India Ink during the Jaipur Literature Festival through a French translator.

headline: Alcatel-Lucent Chief Resigns as Company Posts Loss
keywords: ['Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Company Reports']
abstract: The telecommunications equipment maker said it lost $1.85 billion in 2012, and announced the resignation of Ben Verwaayen, its chief executive since 2008.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Alcatel-Lucent said Thursday that its chief executive, Ben Verwaayen, would step down as the company, a maker of telecommunications equipment, posted a big loss for the fourth quarter.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 7, 2013
abstract: Can you choose the correct verb to complete the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “The Author Himself Was a Cat in the Hat.”

headline: Meet the New Monopoly Token, and Mourn the Old
abstract: What Monopoly token was voted out of the classic game this week, and what token was voted in?
lead_paragraph: For One Monopoly Token, the Days Are Numbered, wrote Vijai Singh on Feb. 4. On Feb. 6 Hasbro announced which one, and introduced the new token that will take its place. Use both articles to answer the questions below.

headline: Byker in Black and White
abstract: Sirkka-Liisa Konttinen, a Finnish photographer, began taking pictures of her new neighborhood in Newcastle, in northeast England, in 1969, having no idea the area was slated for demolition.
lead_paragraph: On clear days in Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, a small yet bustling working-class city in northeast England, the view from the hills of Byker can be spectacular. That shabby neighborhood’s rows of brick houses and terraced streets overlook a historic city center, the river and sometimes far beyond.

headline: A Hollow Case for Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: What purports to be a research paper on the necessity of too-big-to-fail banks neglects all the current research and lacks credibility, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: What’s the Most Memorable Thing You Ever Got in the Mail?
abstract: The announcement that the Postal Service will stop delivering letters and other mail on Saturdays prompts us to ask you, what’s the best, most interesting, or most memorable thing you ever got in the mail, or sent yourself?
lead_paragraph: A love letter? A present? An award? A school acceptance? A check? A note from a long-lost friend?

headline: New Uncertainty Grips Tunisia After Assassination
abstract: A day after a leading opposition figure was assassinated, Tunisia’s dominant party said it opposed a plan to dissolve the government, according to news reports.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s governing Islamist-led party on Thursday rejected a proposal by the prime minister to form a government of national unity, deepening the country’s political crisis a day after a leading opposition politician was assassinated outside his home.

headline: What I Wish My Financial Aid Applications Revealed
abstract: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student in New Delhi who is applying to universities in the United States, wants to assure her prospective colleges that she is “a worthy investment who will give them manifold returns.”
lead_paragraph: In the post-independence, patriarchal society of India, women from the working classes were rarely educated. My grandmother, for example, attended school until only the eighth grade; she was married off soon after.

lead_paragraph: President Obama may have run his last political campaign, but that does not relieve him of his obligations to the Democratic Party.

headline: 4 Years After Crisis, Ireland Strikes Deal to Ease a Huge Debt Load
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Irish government reached a deal on Thursday with the European Central Bank to restructure debt tied to local struggling banks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Irish government, trying to lighten the staggering debt burden of bailing out some of its biggest banks four years ago, reached a deal on Thursday with the European Central Bank to give the country more time to repay some of those loans.

headline: Just Like That, Ahmad Bradshaw Is Gone
abstract: The Giants lavished running back Ahmad Bradshaw with praise, but their move Wednesday sent a different message: they released him.
lead_paragraph: It may not seem right, but running back Ahmad Bradshaw is no longer a Giant. He appeared to be the least-surprised person in the tristate area.

headline: To Protect Your iPhone, Added Armor and a Honeycomb
abstract: Moshi has new iPhone 5 cases: the iGlaze Armor, with an aluminum back plate that brings a sophisticated look, and the Origo, made of form-fitting silicone that offers more shock absorption.
lead_paragraph: Moshi, a maker of stylish accessories for digital devices, has expanded its line of cellphone cases with a couple of new designs for the iPhone 5.

headline: Economic Growth in India to Fall to 5 Percent
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: Sluggish performance in manufacturing, agriculture and services contributed to the drop.
lead_paragraph: India’s gross domestic product is expected to drop significantly to 5 percent for the fiscal year ending in March, according to advance estimates released by India’s Central Statistics Office on Thursday, declining from the 6.2 percent growth rate seen in fiscal year 2012.

headline: Tip of the Week: A Quick Trip Through the iTunes Libraries
abstract: You can ignore the Library pop-up menu in iTunes 11 and jump between the music, movies, TV shows and other libraries with keyboard shortcuts.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s iTunes 11 program moves all the various media libraries from a vertical panel on the left side of the window to a small Library pop-up menu in the top-left corner. For a quicker way to switch between media types instead of moving the mouse up to the menu, Apple has also included iTunes keyboard shortcuts to jump instantly to the desired collection.

headline: Sloshing Around the Shows
abstract: Thursday marks the official start of New York Fashion Week, where more than 300 designers will present their fall 2013 collections. Here’s what to expect from our reporters, editors and photographers.
lead_paragraph: The fashion crowd is in for a long and wet week. But neither stormy weather nor a flu epidemic can pose a threat to the flock of fashion designers, editors, buyers and fans that will storm New York on Thursday. More than 300 designers will present their fall 2013 collections at Lincoln Center, Made Studios and other venues in the city. From crowded back stages to crammed front rows, all eyes and minds will be on the fall shows.

headline: The Wheat Lowdown
abstract: Reconsidering the whole-wheat loaf. The first step: Knock off the kneading.
lead_paragraph: Those of us who cook believe that you have to cook to eat; baking bread is different. With so many relatively decent loaves readily available in stores, bread-baking is more of a hobby. The result, of course, will be eaten and enjoyed — and bakers know the rewards of blowing people’s minds with a good loaf: “You made that?” — but baking is not mandatory. (I say that having just paid four bucks for a “baguette” that would serve better as a kitchen sponge.)

headline: With This Start-Up, Your Favorite Novel Never Has to End
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Small Business', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Small Demons catalogs and cross-indexes the people, places and things that appear in books, encouraging readers to explore a world one of the founders calls “the storyverse.”
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Valla Vakili fell in love with a French crime novel. He was so fascinated by “Total Chaos” and its antihero, a hard-drinking detective from the slums of Marseille, that he rerouted a planned vacation through that city, which is France’s second-largest. There he immersed himself in the character’s world.

headline: Frank Ocean Can Fly
abstract: Being the hottest thing in pop music means believing you can do absolutely anything you want.
lead_paragraph: Frank Ocean did not want to ride in my rented Ford Fusion; that much was clear. After I parked the car, he met me outside his modernist apartment building in Los Angeles and led me to the garage where he rents three parking spots for three different BMWs. He was dressed casually — gray hoodie, jeans, high-top Vans with red laces, baseball cap — and he jumped lightly from the curb to the parking blocks as we walked toward his late-model blue BMW M3. Ocean no longer had driving privileges as a result of some recent violations, on top of which he was cited for marijuana possession a few weeks earlier. “You can drive,” he said, though I could tell that it was killing him.

headline: This Robot Does Do Windows
abstract: The Winbot 7 series cleans windows, like a floor cleaning robot for vertical surfaces.
lead_paragraph: The robots at this year’s Consumer Electronics Show fell largely into two categories: floor cleaners and toys. But there was an exception.

headline: Weaker Yen Helps Sony Trim Losses for Quarter
abstract: The earnings at Sony reflect a revival in the fortunes of other struggling Japanese electronics manufacturers, and its shares have surged almost 60 percent in 2013.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Sony pared losses in the last quarter of 2012 and stood by an upbeat profit forecast for its full financial year Thursday, thanks to a weak yen that helped compensate for disappointing sales of its cameras, flat-panel televisions and video game consoles.

headline: Britain’s Embrace of Gay Rights
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The debate over gay marriage has showcased the weird spectacle of religion intruding into politics in a country where religion has not been a political factor for a generation or more.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was after I jotted down the words on the placards being waved at the pro-gay-marriage demonstration — “Who do you think made your wedding dress?”; “Sexual orientation is not a belief” — that I realized the downside of taking a toddler to work.

headline: Rate-Rigging Investigation Rolls On
abstract: The global rate-manipulation inquiry has emboldened prosecutors to pursue banks. | Documents in a lawsuit show JPMorgan Chase flouted quality controls as it packaged mortgage deals. | Credit Suisse to increase cost-cutting. | A huge buyout may be taking shape in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The global investigation into interest-rate manipulation has emboldened prosecutors to crack down on banks, and the settlement with the Royal Bank of Scotland on Wednesday underscored that strategy. “I want financial institutions to know that this department will absolutely hold them to account,” said Lanny Breuer, head of the Justice Department’s criminal division. As part of the $612 million deal that American and British authorities reached with R.B.S., the bank’s Japanese unit was required to plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing, echoing an earlier action taken against a subsidiary of UBS. “These cases represent the first units of a big bank to agree to criminal charges in more than a decade,” DealBook’s Mark Scott and Ben Protess write.

headline: E.C.B. President's Comments Send Euro Lower
abstract: Mario Draghi cited the rising value of the euro as a threat to the region's economy, which investors interpreted as meaning the E.C.B. could take action if it rose too much.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The president of the European Central Bank on Thursday cited the rising value of the euro as a possible threat to the region’s economic recovery, comments that immediately sent the euro down sharply against the dollar and yen.

headline: May Cause Greed, Lust or Retirement
abstract: Steven Soderbergh’s “Side Effects” follows twists and turns involving a fictitious antidepressant (which has its own real Web site).
lead_paragraph: The marketing campaign for “Side Effects,” Steven Soderbergh’s tight and twisty new pharma-caper, includes a Web site for a fictitious antidepressant called Ablixa. You can tell the site is fake because the “professional consultation” it offers is provided by Jude Law, who plays a psychiatrist in the film. But the embedded commercial is a perfect parody of something that has become very familiar in recent years: a vague and seductive montage of sad and happy scenes accompanied by new-agey music and, interrupting the inspiring sales pitch, a sotto voce recitation of warnings and possible complications.

headline: K.K.R.’s Earnings Rise 22% on Investment Gains
abstract: K.K.R. said on Thursday that it earned $347.7 million in the fourth quarter, as all of its businesses showed strong gains. For the year, the firm reported earning $2.1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Improving markets lifted the fortunes of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in the fourth quarter, as the investment firm reported a 22 percent rise in profit.

headline: Opinion Report: Drones
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: Straight Outta Congress: A Hip-Hop Tribute to ‘House of Cards’
abstract: Adam WarRock salutes the Netflix political thriller (and his addiction to it) in “I Can’t Stop Watching House of Cards.”
lead_paragraph: One week into its release, “House of Cards” continues to knock down boundaries: this political thriller is the first original series to be commissioned by Netflix, the streaming video service; the first to make all 13 episodes of its debut season available at once; the first whose finale could be spoiled online almost as soon as you could watch the pilot. And now it appears to have set a record for the speed at which it has inspired a hip-hop tribute: “I Can’t Stop Watching House of Cards” is the creation of Adam WarRock (the nom de rap of Eugene Ahn) and it has already earned an endorsement of sorts from the “House of Cards” show runner, Beau Willimon. For the uninitiated, the video won’t spoil any crucial “House of Cards” plot points, though it will give you a thorough introduction to the series star Kevin Spacey’s fluctuating Southern accent.

headline: Asset Sales Help Lift Profit at New York Times Company, but Ad Revenue Declines
abstract: The New York Times Company’s results were aided by a gain on the sale of the company’s stake in Indeed.com, a jobs search engine, and the sale of the About Group, the online resource company.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company reported a big jump in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, largely because of gains from asset sales.

headline: On Our Radar: What Happened to All the Moose?
abstract: Citing a sharp decline in the animal’s numbers, Minnesota officials ban moose hunting,
lead_paragraph: Minnesota officials ban moose hunting indefinitely, citing a steep decline in the animal’s population. The number of moose has fallen by 52 percent since 2010 — not because of hunting, the state says, but possibly because of unusually hot summers or the spread of a tick-borne disease. (The moose are now being tracked with G.P.S. collars.) [NBC News]

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A New York woman away at college discovered that while city biking skills come in handy, some city expressions don’t travel.

headline: Lazard’s Profit Surges as Deal Assignments Pick Up
abstract: The independent investment bank said on Thursday that its adjusted profit rose to $81.6 million in the fourth quarter, up from $1.4 million the period a year earlier, as deal-making improved.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a year has made for Lazard.

headline: Talking About Lee
abstract: Sofia Coppola, Giambattista Valli and Peter Beard share their favorite moments with Lee Bouvier Radziwill.
lead_paragraph: Sofia Coppola, Giambattista Valli and Peter Beard share their favorite moments with Lee Bouvier Radziwill.

headline: Daily Report: Europe’s Plan for GPS Limps to Crossroads
abstract: Europe’s commitment to a new, European-controlled satellite navigation system will be decided in Brussels this week, when European leaders will try to hash out a long-term budget for the 27-nation bloc.
lead_paragraph: With lofty dreams of European unity increasingly grounded by economic woe and the weight of narrow national interests, an array of computer screens in central Italy blinks with faint signs that — far away in space, at least — Europe’s often quarreling nations can still sometimes find common cause, reports Andrew Higgins in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: The Gun Report: February 7, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: One thing that’s been a little surprising since we began the Gun Report seven days ago is how many Second Amendment absolutists have been commenting. “Don’t you realize that more people are likely to die from drowning in the bathtub than from an accidental gun shot?” they argue. “Can’t you see that criminals will always find a way to get a gun, and the law-abiding will be rendered helpless? Isn’t it unfair to focus on gun deaths instead of, say, deaths by auto accident?”

headline: The Real Lee Radziwill
abstract: One of Truman Capote’s swans, the sister of Jackie Kennedy and a European princess. The inimitable Radziwill offers a rare, personal glimpse into her world.
lead_paragraph: While she has long captivated the public as one of Truman Capote’s swans, the sister of Jackie Kennedy and a European princess, with romantic liaisons from Peter Beard to Aristotle Onassis, not one of those labels begins to capture the true woman. The inimitable Radziwill — direct, free spirited and true to her own ideals — offers a rare, personal glimpse into her remarkable world.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Cable Lifts Earnings at Time Warner and News Corp. and the Surprise Seller of a Malibu Mansion
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Barbie (Doll)', 'Cable Television', 'Company Reports', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Strong cable television gains prove a boon for Time Warner and News Corp, the owner of a rather gaudy $25 million home that hit the market in Malibu may surprise you and Melena Ryzik chats with Steven Spielberg about the difficulties of filming “Lincoln.”
lead_paragraph: Cable television propelled Time Warner to a 51-percent increase in net income during the final quarter of 2012, offsetting weaknesses in magazine publishing and movies, Amy Chozick reports. Revenue rose 5 percent for the company’s television networks, which include TNT, TBS and CNN, even as Time Inc., the nation’s largest magazine publisher, prepared to lay off 6 percent of its work force. Revenue at the Warner Brothers studio fell 4 percent, despite strong performances by “Argo” and “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey.” The results point to a widening gap between the rapidly growing cable television industry and the troubled magazine and, to a lesser extent, movie businesses.

headline: Einhorn Sues Apple Over Plan to Discard Preferred Stock
abstract: David Einhorn sued Apple to block a plan to eliminate preferred shares, showing deep dissatisfaction with the company’s once-explosive stock.
lead_paragraph: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

headline: Flights and Trains Canceled as Storm Heads to Northeast
abstract: Local authorities from New York City to Maine were preparing Thursday for what forecasters said could be the heaviest snowfall to hit some cities in the Northeast in a century.
lead_paragraph: As snow began falling on Friday morning, local authorities from New York City to Maine were making preparations for what forecasters said could be the biggest blizzard for some cities in the Northeast in a century.

lead_paragraph: The Economist: According to the magazine’s Big Mac index, which measures the strength of international currencies against the United States dollar, the Japanese economy is moving in the right direction. — Julia Moskin

headline: Calling Henry Higgins: School Makes a Case for Standard English
abstract: As one British school seeks to boost the use of the Queen’s English, local traditionalists grumble that proud regional dialects are under threat. In an increasingly standardized world, should we all learn to speak the same way?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A school in northeastern England has opened a can of worms by urging parents to make sure their offspring learn when to use the Queen’s English rather than their distinctive local dialect, if they want to get on in life.

headline: Feeling For | Salvatore Ferragamo Butterfly Bracelet
abstract: Just in time for Valentine’s Day, the brand debuts the latest in its On Love’s Wings collection.
lead_paragraph: Designed exclusively for Valentine’s Day, this silver butterfly cuff from Salvatore Ferragamo’s limited edition complements understated style with the tiniest hint of coquettishness. The butterfly is the symbol of the brand’s latest online initiative, On Love’s Wings, which features a fun web interactive video that lets the viewer direct his own love story.

headline: Theater Talkback: Stepping Into the Spotlight
abstract: Ben Brantley on what it was like to be called onstage as an extra in “The Suit.”
lead_paragraph: Limelight is to theater critics as sunlight is to vampires. We reviewers feel safest crouched in the shadows while we feast on the lifeblood and talent (or lack thereof) of the performers on the bright stage before us. Legend has it that if you drag a critic into the glare of the other side of the proscenium, he will hiss, shrivel and disintegrate like Dracula at dawn.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Lift Ev’ry Voice and Sing
abstract: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “Lift Ev’ry Voice and Sing” a poem by James Weldon Johnson, with “Songs of Freedom,” an Opinion piece by Angelique Kidjo.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “Lift Ev’ry Voice and Sing” a poem by James Weldon Johnson, with “Songs of Freedom,” an Opinion piece by Angelique Kidjo.
