headline: Drones Are Focus as C.I.A. Nominee Goes Before Senators
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: Members of the Senate Intelligence Committee pressed John O. Brennan, the nominee for director of the Central Intelligence Agency, on the secrecy of targeted killings and their legal basis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Engaging a high-ranking Obama administration official for the first time in an extensive public discussion of the use of drones for targeted killing, members of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday pressed John O. Brennan, President Obama’s nominee for director of the Central Intelligence Agency, about the secrecy of the strikes, their legal basis and the reported backlash they have produced in Pakistan and Yemen.

headline: Supreme Leader of Iran Rejects Direct Talks With U.S.
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei dismissed the idea of bilateral talks with the United States on Thursday, while scoffing at Iranian officials who might consider such negotiations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, rejected any idea of bilateral talks with the United States on Thursday, in a speech in which he seemed to dismiss the views of Iranian officials — including the country’s foreign minister — who had advocated for such negotiations.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: A guest’s outrage over a fake wedding thrown to get gifts and how to word the invitation to include both sets of parents.
lead_paragraph: A ‘Wedding’ Fit for the Hall of Shame

headline: Baron Von Fancy Goes to Paris
abstract: The artist and fashion designer Baron Von Fancy’s name may belong in an 18th-century German royal court, but he owes his budding career to Instagram.
lead_paragraph: PARIS—Baron Von Fancy’s name may belong in an 18th-century German royal court, but he is very much a 20th-century child. He’s a multimedia artist who lives in New York and surfs on the vintage-is-cool wave, using social media as his manager, agent and public relations firm.

headline: Video Broadcast on State Television Was Downloaded From U.S. Drone, Iran Says
abstract: Iran’s state television showed what it described as video recorded by the American surveillance drone that crash-landed about 140 miles from the country’s border with Afghanistan in late 2011.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 2:17 p.m. Iran’s state television broadcast Wednesday what it described as video recorded by the American surveillance drone that crash-landed about 140 miles from the country’s border with Afghanistan in late 2011.

headline: Football Winners, Soccer Losers
abstract: On signing day, optimism at Ole Miss. In Honduras, a discouraging day for U.S. men’s soccer.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that sports news gives you such a clear choice in emotions in a single day, but you can thank the United States men’s national soccer team and college football’s national signing day for providing us such diametrically opposed options. Yes, you can read about the U.S. team’s humbling loss in Honduras and choose premature-bordering-on-irrational panic about the Americans’ World Cup qualifying chances. Or, you can read the breathless reports of who signed with what college team and find reason for premature-bordering-on-irrational glee about the future of _____ (insert your favorite team here).

headline: Flying Ford Fiesta STs to Compete in Global RallyCross
abstract: The Fiesta ST racecar was developed in conjunction with Olsbergs MSE AB of Sweden, a company that develops, builds and racescars in rallycross and extreme sports events.
lead_paragraph: Ford will show a racing version of its Fiesta ST at the Chicago auto show, which opens to the public on Saturday. The automaker announced on Wednesday its intention to compete with the performance subcompact in Global RallyCross Championship events as part of an expanded 2013 G.R.C. program for the brand. No newcomer to the series, Ford won the G.R.C. manufacturer’s championships in 2011 and 2012.

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Declan Walsh talks about his interview with the founder of the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba.

headline: More States Weigh Digital Car Insurance Cards
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Identification Devices', 'Mobile Applications', 'State Legislatures', 'States (US)']
abstract: Digital auto insurance cards may help those who forget to put paper cards in their wallets.
lead_paragraph: I was stopped a while back by a police officer because the registration sticker on my car’s license plate had expired. After digging my dog-eared insurance card out of my wallet, I realized that it was out of date, too. My policy was current, but I hadn’t put the new card into my wallet when it was mailed to me.

headline: House Ethics Committee Investigates 2 Lawmakers
abstract: The panel released reports regarding the actions of Representatives Aaron Schock, a Republican, and Bill Owens, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Aaron Schock, Republican of Illinois, may have improperly solicited a $25,000 donation last year from the House majority leader for a political group seeking to oust incumbent Republicans, an ethics report released Wednesday says.

headline: A Sensible Change in Taxing Derivatives
abstract: A proposal being considered by Congress would help eliminate a tax loophole on certain financial contracts that some investors have used in order to avoid taxes, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that I’m happy with Congress.

headline: Defying Wagner With Buckets of Blood
abstract: Reputed to be undirectable, Wagner’s “Parsifal” is returning to the Metropolitan Opera in a new production led by François Girard.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon Jonas Kaufmann stood in his dressing room at the Metropolitan Opera holding up his hands, which were stained red. He had just rehearsed Act II of a new production of “Parsifal,” in which he sings the title role, and although he had stripped off the makeup and slipped into jeans and a crumpled shirt, there were parts of his skin where the stage blood just wouldn’t come off.

headline: Cardiss Collins, Fighter in Congress for Equality and the Poor, Dies at 81
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Mrs. Collins, after succeeding her husband and becoming Illinois’s first black congresswoman, served from 1973 to 1997.
lead_paragraph: Cardiss Collins, who reluctantly ran for a Chicago Congressional seat left vacant when her husband died in a plane crash and went on to become Illinois’s first black congresswoman, serving for nearly 25 years as a voice for racial and gender equality and expanded health care for the poor, died on Sunday in Arlington, Va. She was 81.

headline: A Climate Proposal: Bundling Consumer Buying Power
abstract: To promote sustainable practices, a new nonprofit corporation proposes to help people team up when buying standard services.
lead_paragraph: Each year, an estimated 46 percent of the population is responsible for 77 percent of discretionary spending in the United States. To strengthen individual buying power, a Santa Barbara-based entrepreneur and philanthropist has proposed a new social enterprise to finance climate change solutions, among other social justice and humanitarian issues.

headline: Senate Hearing Draws Out a Rift in U.S. Policy on Syria
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first term, President Obama presided over an administration known for its lack of open dissension on critical foreign policy issues.

headline: Katherine Boo: By the Book
abstract: As a child, the author of “Behind the Beautiful Forevers” appreciated books in which “the weak were rarely bullied for long, and the bad guys didn’t get away.”
lead_paragraph: As a child, the author of “Behind the Beautiful Forevers” appreciated books in which “the weak were rarely bullied for long, and the bad guys didn’t get away.”

headline: A Front-Row Celebrity Whose Scent Is Hard to Follow
abstract: I had never given much thought to the smell of a celebrity until I spoke recently to the perfume star Frédéric Malle.
lead_paragraph: I had never given much thought to the smell of a celebrity until I spoke recently to the perfume star Frédéric Malle. We met at the Viand Coffee Shop on Madison Avenue as breakfast sizzled on the grill. I’ve known Frédéric since he opened his first perfume shop, in Paris, more than a decade ago. And I remember my first trip to Antwerp, Belgium, a little later, when I visited Dries Van Noten’s handsome looking store and saw a display of the Malle perfumes, with their distinctive black caps and romantic-sounding names. In taste and temperament, Frédéric and Dries were kindred souls, and it made sense that, apart from Barneys New York and Frederic’s own store, you could find his perfumes only at Dries Van Noten.

headline: U.S.: Thursday Morning Centerback
abstract: A failure to communicate, and act, cost the U.S. a point in its World Cup qualifying match in Honduras on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: There has been a lot written, tweeted and commented upon in the hours after Honduras defeated the United States, 2-1, in the opening game for both teams in the final round of regional World Cup qualifying Wednesday afternoon in San Pedro Sula.

headline: Seeing San Juan
abstract: Paddle, cycle and stroll around Puerto Rico’s historic capital.
lead_paragraph: Paddle, cycle and stroll around Puerto Rico’s historic capital.

headline: 36 Hours in San Juan, Puerto Rico
abstract: In this pastel-hued capital city, you can sample cocktails and culture, shopping and surf, all in a single weekend.
lead_paragraph: Trying to sample the pleasures of some cities over a weekend can be a bit like entering a pie-eating contest. Sounds like a madcap lark, but after a while you’re likely to feel overstuffed, foolish and maybe a little sick. Sure, you could do Paris without the Louvre, but why? Even negotiating the fabled museum itself in that time frame would be a challenge. San Juan, the capital of Puerto Rico, poses no such problems. True, as with any major metropolis, you could pass a week in the city and still not probe all its corners. (As it turned out, I did: planning a weekend visit, I was forced to extend my stay a few days when Hurricane Sandy struck.) But the major highlights of San Juan can be easily accommodated in 36 hours, even accounting for the leisurely pace that seems appropriate to the tropics.

headline: It’s a Bird, It’s a Plane, It’s a Dirty Blond: Musical Revival Casts Its ‘Superman’
abstract: Edward Watts, who played the dual roles of Robert Semple and David Hutton in the recent Broadway musical “Scandalous,” will portray Superman and Clark Kent in the Encores! revival of “It’s a Bird … It’s a Plane … It’s Superman.”
lead_paragraph: Faster than a speeding bullet, more powerful than a locomotive and with somewhat fairer coloring than we’ve come to expect from the Man of Steel, the Encores! revival of “It’s a Bird … It’s a Plane … It’s Superman” has found the actor to play the costumed DC Comics champion of its title.

headline: In Istanbul, a Spray of Style
abstract: The waterside Karakoy district, once a gray docklands area, has begun to attract a stylish crowd.
lead_paragraph: The waterside Karakoy district, once a gray docklands area, has begun to attract a stylish crowd.

headline: Living With Cancer: Waking in the Dark
abstract: Before cancer, I slept through the night. Now, I wake in the dark because of the pull of stitches, the pain of drains or the need to empty some bulb or bag attached to my body.
lead_paragraph: A slant of light bifurcates the bedroom ceiling. Its source, a night light in the bathroom, slices through the ceiling fixture, slivering all the way to the far corner over my side of the bed. Before cancer, I slept through the night. Now, I wake in the dark because of the pull of stitches, the pain of drains or the need to empty some bulb or bag attached to my body.

headline: Warner Music Group Buys EMI Assets for $765 Million
abstract: Warner will now own Parlophone, the historic label that is home to Coldplay, Blur and Kylie Minogue.
lead_paragraph: 12:02 p.m. | Updated The Warner Music Group, the smallest of the three remaining major record companies, said on Thursday that it had reached an agreement to pay $765 million for the Parlophone Label Group, a collection of EMI assets that includes artists like Coldplay, Pink Floyd and the Beach Boys.

headline: Theater Company Takes Richard III Back to the Parking Lot
abstract: The Drilling Company will produce “Richard III” this summer as part of its annual Shakespeare in the Park(ing) Lot season.
lead_paragraph: Richard III has only just extricated himself from ignominious burial under an English parking lot. But if a Manhattan theater troupe has its way, to the parking lot he will return, at least temporarily.

headline: Bitter Sweets
abstract: Cakes cored with red bean and custard, crusted in sugar, slit down the middle and grouted in cream.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, my brother and I spent a lot of time at my grandparents’ house. They lived next door so when Mom and Dad worked weekends, it was up to them to keep us out of trouble. Most afternoons, we’d sprawl out on their living room floor in front of the television — the Chinese-language radio station going in the kitchen — while my grandfather paced the back garden or my grandmother sat on the porch with a bowl of alfalfa sprouts in her lap.

headline: U.S. Official Faults F.A.A. for Missing 787 Battery Risk
abstract: As a transportation official said tests in 2007 failed to anticipate potential incidents, the Federal Aviation Administration approved flights of the Boeing jet to collect data.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top transportation safety official said on Thursday that the Federal Aviation Administration accepted test results from Boeing in 2007 that failed to properly assess the risks of smoke or fire from the batteries on Boeing’s new 787 jets.

headline: For N.Y.U., Another Memorable Win
abstract: The N.Y.U. men’s basketball team may not make the N.C.A.A. tournament this season, but its victory over No. 1 Rochester is one it will long remember.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, after a 14-year dry spell, the New York University men’s basketball team was at last able to savor something long-denied: a bid to the N.C.A.A. Division III tournament.

headline: Rings of Unemployment
abstract: Four out of five Americans have relatives or friends who were laid off during the last few years or were laid off themselves, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: Four out of five Americans know relatives or family friends who were laid off during the last few years or were laid off themselves, as I reported in an article on a new report from the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University.

headline: One Critic’s Argument: Anne Hathaway, Worst of the Supporting Actresses
abstract: A critic argues that Anne Hathaway’s performance is the worst of the best supporting actress contenders.
lead_paragraph: In a video essay on who should really win, Fandor’s insightful Kevin B. Lee breaks down the Oscar hopefuls — and we do mean breaks down.

headline: ‘Mrs. Keckley Has Met With Great Success’
abstract: The story of a former slave who became Mary Todd Lincoln’s adviser and confidant.
lead_paragraph: Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln” has cast a spotlight on a remarkable African-American woman who played a key role in influencing the president’s views on emancipation, bought her way out of slavery and fought to improve the lot of her people. And yet, when heroes of the Civil War era and the anti-slavery movement are celebrated, Elizabeth Keckley (portrayed in “Lincoln” by the actress Gloria Reuben) has been generally overlooked.

headline: Stark Numbers Reveal the Scale of Elephant Killings
abstract: The stream of news about elephant killings and increasingly massive ivory seizures has been so relentless that it has become numbing. A new study, however, still has the power to shock.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The past couple of years has seen a stream of news about elephant killings and increasingly massive ivory seizures, a stream so relentless that it has become numbing.

headline: Ackman to Herbalife: You’re Not the Girl Scouts
abstract: William A. Ackman, head of the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management, posed a new set of questions to the nutritional-supplements company.

lead_paragraph: Following in the footsteps of Manolo Blahnik’s recent revival, the classic pointy-toe black heel is back.

headline: Growing Work Force Accounts for High Jobless Rate, Study Says
abstract: A study by the Independent Budget Office seeks to explain the discrepancy between New York’s job growth and its high unemployment rate.
lead_paragraph: It has been one of the economic mysteries of post-recession New York: If the city is creating so many jobs, why has the unemployment rate stayed so high?

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 7
abstract: A snow covered field in Gulmarg, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Restored Payroll Tax Pinches Those Who Earn the Least
keywords: ['Payroll Tax', 'United States Economy', 'Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'Income Tax']
abstract: At street level, the pain from the expiration of a two-percentage-point break in Social Security taxes in 2011 and 2012 is evident.
lead_paragraph: Jack Andrews and his wife no longer enjoy what they call date night, their once-a-month outing to the movies and a steak dinner at Logan’s Roadhouse in Augusta, Ga. In Harlem, Eddie Phillips’s life insurance payment will have to wait a few more weeks. And Jessica Price is buying cheaper food near her home in Orlando, Fla., even though she worries it may not be as healthy.

headline: Answers for the Wandering Boomer
abstract: Tackling mountains despite arthritis, grasping the challenges of safaris and other issues are addressed by a travel expert.
lead_paragraph: [Updated Feb. 8, with new material at the top.] Kurt Kutay, who took questions about adventure travel for the older traveler, is the founding president and chief executive of Wildland Adventures and is the director of the nonprofit Travelers Conservation Trust. He has traveled and guided throughout the world since 1975 and served on the boards of the Adventure Travel Trade Association and the International Ecotourism Society. He is currently the president of the International Galapagos Tour Operators Association. With its outsized demographics and yearnings for adventure, the baby boom generation has been reshaping the travel industry for decades, from shoestring student trips in the ‘60s to singles resorts in the ‘70s and the luxury hotel boom of the ‘90s. Now, as the economy slowly recovers, the travel industry is hoping that boomers will indulge their wanderlust. [Questions are no longer being accepted.]

headline: Fate of the Earth Takes Center Stage
abstract: Works like “This Clement World,” a new play at St. Ann’s Warehouse, could start to transform the theater world’s attitude about climate change.
lead_paragraph: Where is the great American play about climate change? Is there even a good one?

headline: Led by Celebrity Titles, Magazine Newsstand Sales Slide
abstract: People, US Weekly, Cosmopolitan and Glamour all suffered double-digit decreases in the second half of 2012.
lead_paragraph: 5:00 p.m. | Updated As the magazine industry continues to suffer from declining circulation, celebrity gossip magazines and young women’s titles have taken some of the biggest hits.

headline: Young Voices in Brooklyn
abstract: The Brooklyn Youth Chorus and its Young Men’s Ensemble have been reinvigorating classical music for a new generation of listeners in the borough.
lead_paragraph: Commentators on the cutting edge of pop culture never seem to tire of naming Brooklyn as the place to see, or to become, next year’s Grizzly Bear, Dirty Projectors or Fiery Furnaces. Thus the Miser is now more than used to sharing L trains stuffed with the young gig-bag-laden legions plying their trade in Brooklyn’s numberless bars.

headline: The Ingénue Is Having a Second Act
abstract: Judy Kuhn, a onetime Cosette, has grown beyond her ingénue fame and is eager for mature roles like the coming Fosca in “Passion.”
lead_paragraph: There are few tales in theater more depressing than the plight of the aged ingénue, the terrible transformation of a once spry young thing into a weary war horse, as looks petrify, roles dry up and optimism curdles into nostalgia.

headline: Bundling Up
abstract: A few major cruise lines are bundling extras in with the price of the trip.
lead_paragraph: A few major cruise lines are bundling extras in with the price of the trip, reducing the sticker shock of your debarkation bill. Celebrity Cruises (above) is covering drinks (including alcohol), tips or shipboard credits with the price of a ticket booked by Feb. 18 for travel through April 2014. Those headed to Europe this summer can choose two of the options; those in the Galápagos are excluded, but everyone else can pick one. Another cruise line, Regent Seven Seas, includes beverages (alcoholic), shore excursions, tips and airfare in their pricing.

headline: Keeping Score: Durant Getting Better? His Stats Say Yes
abstract: The Thunder’s star forward is putting up numbers that match those of players like Larry Bird, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Wilt Chamberlain, LeBron James and Michael Jordan.
lead_paragraph: It’s not common for a player to significantly improve coming off a season in which he made the All-N.B.A. first team and was runner-up for the league’s Most Valuable Player award. Then again, Oklahoma City’s Kevin Durant is far from a common player.

headline: At Prayer Breakfast, Obama Issues Call for Humility
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: At the National Prayer Breakfast, President Obama meditated on the role of faith and humility in leadership.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered a contemplative call for humility, driven by faith and abiding respect for those who disagree, at a national prayer gathering Thursday morning in Washington.

headline: 2 Detectives’ Killer Is Eligible for Death Penalty, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Ronell Wilson, who was sentenced to be executed for the 2003 murder of two undercover police officers on Staten Island, was found to be mentally competent for the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: A New York City man who was sentenced to be executed for the murder of two undercover police officers in 2003 — and who made headlines once again this week after it was revealed he impregnated one of his prison guards — was found by a judge on Thursday not to be mentally retarded and therefore eligible to be put to death.

headline: Line Up, Shut Up, and Maybe Mr. Jeter Will Sign
abstract: Armed with jerseys, baseballs, folding chairs and coffee, baseball fans and memorabilia dealers gathered before dawn near a training facility to await the Yankees’ iconic shortstop.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Shortly before noon Tuesday, a week before spring training was to begin, a Yankees employee named John Johnson received word on his two-way radio that Derek Jeter had wrapped up his work for the day and would be leaving the team’s minor league complex here. Johnson went straight to the sidewalk out front, where 40 people stood in line.

headline: Iowa Congressman Pushes Back Against Rove Group
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Steve King of Iowa, who is weighing whether he will be a Republican candidate for the state’s open Senate seat, is asking his supporters to contribute money to push back against efforts by Mr. Rove and other party strategists to keep him out of the race.
lead_paragraph: Karl Rove’s endorsement was once seen as a gold-plated seal of approval for Republican political candidates. So how much is his scorn worth?

headline: U.S. and Allies Conduct Drills in Persian Gulf, a Signal to Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The exercise included a simulation to test the policy-making and coordination of the American military and two dozen other nations, as well as drills at sea, in the air and on land.
lead_paragraph: Deterring Iran is a delicate balance of diplomacy, sanctions and military muscle-flexing, all intended to send a strong signal – without proving so provocative that the region is pushed toward war. One piece of the effort – halting the proliferation of illicit weapons – got a practice run in the Persian Gulf this week.

headline: Grammy Dramas to Watch For
abstract: There are plenty of minidramas to watch for at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, even though no one dominates the field.
lead_paragraph: NO one dominates the field of contenders for the Grammy Awards this year as Adele did a year ago. And so far there has been little drama leading up to Sunday night’s ceremony that can rival the sudden death of Whitney Houston last year or Adele’s much-talked-about return from vocal surgery.

headline: Guns N’ Roses to Fill Out Governors Ball Lineup
abstract: Organizers had kept secret the name of the band that would join Kanye West and Kings of Leon as the festival’s headliners.
lead_paragraph: When the Governors Ball Music Festival announced the lineup for its third annual installment in January, Kanye West and Kings of Leon were listed as two of the top three headliners, with the third kept tantalizingly secret: the festival’s poster showed only a black bar where the band’s name should have been. Now the festival has announced that Guns N’ Roses will fill out an already varied lineup that also includes some 60 bands and performers, among them Nas, the Avett Brothers, Animal Collective, the Lumineers, Beirut, Grizzly Bear and Young the Giant.

headline: Fed Governor Raises the Specter of a Bubble in Junk Bonds
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Junk Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A Federal Reserve governor, Jeremy Stein, said in a speech that some credit markets are showing signs of overheating as investors take larger risks in response to  low interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Some financial markets are showing signs of overheated speculation as investors take larger risks in response to the persistence of low interest rates, a senior Federal Reserve official said in a speech on Thursday.

headline: Watch: John Brennan’s Opening Statement
abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committee is questioning John O. Brennan, the president’s pick for C.I.A. chief.
lead_paragraph: 5:25 p.m. | Updated John O. Brennan’s confirmation hearings, which began Thursday afternoon in the Senate Intelligence Committee, have proved rougher than expected. First, the nominee for C.I.A. director was interrupted by protesters. Then, after he resumed his own remarks, he came under unexpectedly intense questioning from both Democrats and Republicans about drone strikes, leaks of classified information and his knowledge of the agency’s former interrogation program.

headline: Helping Employees See Why We Do What We Do
abstract: Inevitably, someone on the team will ask, Why are we here? Why does this organization exist? It’s good to have an answer.
lead_paragraph: American workers average approximately 2,000 hours at work each year. They work hard for their employers and strive to achieve the goals that have been set for them. But to find real meaning in what they do, and to believe that it matters, they need to understand why they do it.

headline: NBC Shuts Down Hyperlocal Web Site
abstract: EveryBlock, a pioneering Web site for hyperlocal data-driven journalism, shut down on Thursday, disappointing longtime fans.
lead_paragraph: EveryBlock, a pioneering Web site for hyperlocal data-driven journalism, was shut down on Thursday by its owner, NBCNews.com, disappointing longtime fans of the site.

headline: Needing an Armed Convoy to Make a Film
abstract: Kim Nguyen, the director of “War Witch,” nominated for a foreign-language Oscar, explains what it took to make a film in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: If the Academy Awards were like some Olympic events and took degree of difficulty into account, Kim Nguyen’s “War Witch,” one of the five nominees for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, would surely be awarded extra points. A decade in the making, “War Witch,” which represents Canada, was researched and filmed in some of the most troubled parts of Africa and addresses one of that continent’s most heartbreaking problems: the violent conscription of child soldiers.

headline: Beaver Gets Busy at Botanical Garden
abstract: The Critter Cam at the New York Botanical Garden recently captured one of the garden’s resident beavers engaging in beaverish behavior.
lead_paragraph: The folks at the New York Botanical Garden and the Bronx River Alliance had been wondering what was up with José and Justin, the beavers who first made headlines in 2007 when they turned up in the Bronx River – the first exemplars of New York’s state animal to be spotted alive in New York City in 200 years.

headline: White House Director of Faith-Based Office Is Leaving His Post
abstract: Joshua DuBois, the young Pentecostal minister who has led President Obama’s Office on Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships, is leaving, Mr. Obama said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced on Thursday morning at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington that Joshua DuBois, the young pastor he appointed four years ago to lead the White House Office of Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships, would step down on Friday.

headline: Manhunt On for Ex-Officer Accused of Police Vendetta
abstract: The Los Angeles police said a former officer was targeting members of the department and their families. His truck was found burned near a ski area east of Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A former Navy reservist who was fired from the Los Angeles Police Department in 2008 has gone on a murderous rampage aimed at police officers and their families, law enforcement officials said Thursday, killing at least three people — including an 11-year veteran of the Riverside Police Department — and setting off a huge manhunt across Southern California.

headline: Indian Government Faulted on Child Sexual Abuse
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Politics and Government', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Human Rights Watch said that child protection laws were not properly enforced, and that many cases went unreported.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Sexual abuse of children is “disturbingly common” in India, and the government’s response to it has fallen short, both in protecting children and in treating victims, Human Rights Watch said in a report released Thursday.

headline: Barraca
abstract: Inside the casual new tapas restaurant in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: Inside the casual new tapas restaurant in the West Village.

headline: Art Without the Drama
abstract: At this casual new tapas spot in the West Village, what you see is what you get, and for the most part, the food is straightforwardly delicious.
lead_paragraph: It hardly seems the work of a culinary modernist once likened to Salvador Dalí, this dish of four shrimp, simply grilled with olive oil, lemon and garlic, placidly curling as their kind have done for millenniums. Yet there it is, on the table at Barraca, Jesús Núñez’s casual new tapas spot in the West Village. Mr. Núñez, a native of Spain who ran three notable restaurants in Madrid, first appeared on the New York dining scene two years ago at the high-end Graffit (later renamed, less mellifluously, Gastroarte), where he disguised cauliflower purée as an egg, and squid-ink-blackened falafel as truffles in pulverized-olive “dirt.”

headline: Ford Expects 900 Dealers for Its Plug-Ins by the Spring
abstract: The 900 dealerships represent about a third of the company’s total sales outlets in the United States, Ford said.
lead_paragraph: Ford said Wednesday that it expected to increase the number of dealers certified to sell its plug-in hybrid and battery electric vehicles to more than 900 in all 50 states by this spring. Amanda Zusman, a Ford spokeswoman, said in an interview that Ford was now “closing in” on 500 certified dealers. “It’s moving very quickly,” she said. The 900 dealerships represent about a third of the company’s total sales outlets in the United States, Ford said.

headline: Rat-Size Ancestor Said to Link Man and Beast
abstract: A lowly occupant of the fossil record, Protungulatum donnae, had anatomical characteristics for live births that anticipated all placental mammals, a Science report says.
lead_paragraph: Humankind’s common ancestor with other mammals may have been a roughly rat-size animal that weighed no more than a half a pound, had a long furry tail and lived on insects.

headline: Targeted Killings Under Scrutiny
abstract: Two voices in the drone debate — a lawyer at the American Civil Liberties Union and an expert on drone warfare — discuss the merits of the program and whether greater transparency is needed.
lead_paragraph: Two voices in the drone debate — a lawyer at the American Civil Liberties Union and an expert on drone warfare — discuss the merits of the program and whether greater transparency is needed.

headline: Fashion Week Parties Kick-Off
abstract: amfAR kicks off New York Fashion Week with a gala honoring Janet Jackson, Heidi Klum and Kenneth Cole.
lead_paragraph: amfAR kicks off New York Fashion Week with a gala honoring Janet Jackson, Heidi Klum and Kenneth Cole.

headline: N.F.L. Reinstates Williams, Who Joins Titans Staff
abstract: The N.F.L. reinstated coach Gregg Williams after he served a year-long suspension for the Saints’ bounty scandal and he accepted a job with the Titans.
lead_paragraph: The last of the Bountygate punishments passed into history Thursday as the N.F.L. reinstated former New Orleans defensive coordinator Gregg Williams, who was hired by the Titans as a senior defensive assistant.

headline: New vs. Old Deli
abstract: How traditional does a deli have to be to be good?
lead_paragraph: The food writers David Sax and Josh Ozersky riff on whether old-style delis trump newer ones, as they eat at Katz’s Delicatessen and Mile End in Brooklyn to compare pastrami sandwiches. The Jewish Daily Forward invited the two to consider the modern twists on the traditional delis. Mr. Ozersky called Katz’s the “alpha and the omega of deli food,” and Mr. Sax said of Mile End, “at the end of the day this place will succeed not because it’s hip but because the food is delicious.”

headline: Ideas for English Language Learners | What Does It Mean to Be a Citizen?
abstract: With Presidents’ Day just ahead and an immigration overhaul on President Obama’s second-term agenda, Larry Ferlazzo suggests ideas for having students deepen their definition and understanding of the idea of citizenship.
lead_paragraph: The presidential inauguration and Martin Luther King Jr. Day have just passed, Presidents’ Day is just ahead, and an immigration overhaul is high on President Obama’s second-term agenda: perfect timing for a citizenship-themed edition of Larry Ferlazzo’s monthly collection of lesson ideas.

headline: Don’t Make Poison Pills More Deadly
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission should avoid any changes that would make it easier to adopt poison pills that cap ownership at low levels, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Under a publicly announced agenda for 2013, the Securities and Exchange Commission is to examine the rules governing when shareholders must disclose the acquisition of a significant position in a public company. An unintended and harmful effect of such a change may be that it will help companies adopt so-called low-threshold poison pills – arrangements that cap the ownership of outside shareholders at levels like 10 or 15 percent. The S.E.C. should be careful to avoid such an outcome in any rules it may adopt.

headline: The Targeted Killing Memo and the Problem of Secret Law
abstract: President Obama is still not committing to full disclosure, betraying a promise of his 2008 campaign and a fundamental element of American democracy.
lead_paragraph: After NBC news published the targeted killing “white paper,” a bipartisan group of senators led by Ron Wyden, the Democrat from Oregon, asked the White House to release the actual legal opinions outlining why the president has the right to authorize the killing of American citizens during the course of counterterrorism operations.

headline: Helping Start-Ups With Local Support and National Networks
abstract: Startup America Partnership, a nonprofit organization started in January 2011, seeks to offer entrepreneurs practical help, like brainstorming and connecting with clients in other states.
lead_paragraph: When Will Fuentes planned an extended business trip to Seattle last year, he tapped into the local chapter of a national networking group there. Within hours, Mr. Fuentes, who founded the Arlington, Va., software company Lemur Retail, had secured a work space, introductions and even restaurant recommendations via the group, the Startup America Partnership.“Before I flew out there, I already had five or six meetings set up with potential clients and other key contacts, as well as one potential acquirer,” Mr. Fuentes said.

headline: Love Is in the Air, and in the Art
abstract: With Valentine’s Day just around the corner, there are plenty of manifestations of love in art to see in New York City.
lead_paragraph: What is love? Is it a trick that nature plays on us to ensure the survival of our species? Or is it, as some religions hold, the metaphysical glue holding everything together as one great whole?

headline: Looking for Love
abstract: An art critic sets out to find notable images of love.
lead_paragraph: An art critic sets out to find notable images of love.

headline: Photos of The Moment | BCBG Max Azria
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: William Janeway: A Golden Age, if We Want It
abstract: A giant of tech investing says innovation isn’t dead, but it is thoroughly misunderstood. If we’re going to make great new discoveries, William Janeway says, we have to get government back into basic scientific research as a demanding customer.
lead_paragraph: William H. Janeway, one of the great tech investors, would be the first to tell you that being smart and lucky is the best of breaks. “I came to Wall Street in 1970 while still finishing my doctoral dissertation for Cambridge University because I knew what I did not want to do,” he writes in his book, “Doing Capitalism in the Innovation Economy.” His doctorate was in economics, and what Mr. Janeway didn’t want to do was spend his career inside academia. Instead, he made himself and others a great deal of money by investing in technology.

headline: Obama Tells House Democrats He Will Confront Republicans on Taxes
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama vowed Thursday to confront Republicans over the issue of closing tax loopholes, saying that he would relish a debate with those who insist Congress has done all it should to get more tax revenue from wealthy individuals and corporations.
lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va. – President Obama vowed Thursday to confront Republicans over the issue of closing tax loopholes, saying that he would relish a debate with those who insist that Congress has done all it should to get more tax revenue from wealthy individuals and corporations.

headline: Bangladeshi Admits Trying to Blow Up Federal Bank
abstract: Quazi Mohammad Rezwanul Ahsan Nafis pleaded guilty in a plot last year that involved an undercover federal agent.
lead_paragraph: A Bangladeshi man who tried to blow up the Federal Reserve Bank of New York remotely only to find that the bomb was fake and his plot had been under the constant surveillance of federal agents pleaded guilty on Thursday to terrorism charges.

headline: In Germany, Dortmund Stays Hot
abstract: In Germany, Borussia Dortmund continues to chase an uncatchable Bayern Munich.
lead_paragraph: Clichés aplenty rang true in Germany last weekend when Borussia Dortmund — the cream of any neutral’s Bundesliga fascination — finally rose to the top, or at least above Bayer Leverkusen, to second place in the German table, after a convincing 3-2 away victory against its North Rhine rivals.

headline: The ‘Monday Morning’ Medical Screaming Match
abstract: In the new medical TV drama “Monday Mornings,” senior doctors publicly attack their younger colleagues. Such heated exchanges may make for good television, but new strategies have emerged for dealing with medical mistakes.
lead_paragraph: I did not think I would ever see another “morbidity and mortality” conference in which senior doctors publicly attacked their younger colleagues for making medical errors. These types of heated meetings were commonplace when I was a medical student but have largely been abandoned.

headline: Finding Life in a Polar Desert
abstract: In the seemingly lifeless surroundings of Lake Untersee in Antarctica, there is still life to be found if you know where to look for it.
lead_paragraph: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee in Antarctica.

headline: Fashion Week Begins With a Conservative Touch
abstract: There is only one way to approach the start of the fall 2013 fashion season in New York, with a month of runway shows and an endless parade of clothes to follow. That is to dive right in and enjoy the scenery.
lead_paragraph: There is only one way to approach the start of the fall 2013 fashion season in New York, with a month of runway shows and an endless parade of clothes to follow. That is to dive right in and enjoy the scenery.

headline: The Bartok Challenge, Faced With Enthusiasm
abstract: Andris Nelsons led the New York Philharmonic in three pieces, notably a standout performance of Bartok’s “Concerto for Orchestra.”
lead_paragraph: Some pieces of music bring out the best in players. Bartok’s “Concerto for Orchestra,” for instance. The five-movement firestorm of virtuosity that spreads across all sections of a large symphony orchestra is terrifying and glorious to play. It’s difficult but rewarding: for a moment every musician is a soloist. Orchestrated to the max, with extra woodwinds, percussion and a second harp, it’s also an occasion for an ensemble to come together in its entirety and take stock of just what it is capable of.

headline: Indecision on Gays for the Boy Scouts
abstract: Parents like Kelly Williamson say the Boy Scouts of America should stick to traditions and keep out gay scout leaders, while others like Jon Langbert want the Scouts to embrace diversity.
lead_paragraph: Parents like Kelly Williamson say the Boy Scouts of America should stick to traditions and keep out gay scout leaders, while others like Jon Langbert want the Scouts to embrace diversity.

headline: Documents on New Zealand Labor Talks Related to Films May Be Made Public
abstract: New Zealand’s ombudsman has recommended that the government release the documents from 2010 that touch on negotiations with the director Peter Jackson and Warner Brothers over changes to the labor laws.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—The New Zealand Council of Trade Unions and Radio New Zealand has won a crucial ruling in their request for documents touching on the New Zealand government’s 2010 negotiations with Peter Jackson and Warner Brothers over changes to the country’s labor laws. Jonathan Handel, an avid chronicler of Hollywood labor news, reports in the Hollywood Reporter that New Zealand’s ombudsman last month recommended that the government make public the documents, which include exchanges with the Jackson and Warner camps. Warner and Mr. Jackson, who sought the labor law adjustment as they were deciding whether or not to film the Hobbit movies in New Zealand, have objected to the disclosure, Mr. Handel wrote in a Thursday morning post. But, in light of the ombudsman’s recommendation, the documents will go public on or about March 1, unless New Zealand’s governor-general blocks the release.

headline: Brennan Interrupted by Protesters
abstract: President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director, John O. Brennan, faced protesters during the opening statement of his Senate confirmation meeting.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director, John O. Brennan, faced protesters during the opening statement of his Senate confirmation meeting.

headline: Large Visions in a Large Space
abstract: The father-son exhibition “Dieter Roth. Björn Roth” is the inaugural show at the large new Hauser & Wirth space in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Another ginormous art gallery has entered the West Chelsea space race. The 24,700-square-foot chunk of real estate — the second floor of a garage on West 18th Street — was once home to the Roxy roller rink-nightclub. Now it is New York’s latest trophy gallery, thanks to Hauser & Wirth, which already has impressive showplaces in Zurich and London and on the Upper East Side.

headline: Avoiding Valentine’s Day Flower Woes
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Florists', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Shopping and Retail', "Valentine's Day"]
abstract: Consumer experts suggest going to a local florist for delivery of Valentine’s Day flowers rather than a big-name online floral site.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year again, when people rush to send bouquets of roses to that special someone. Last February, I wrote about the post-holiday howling and hand-wringing over flowers that were ordered online but went undelivered — or were delivered late — for Valentine’s Day.

headline: A Personal Quest to Make Guns’ Toll More Visible
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: Representative Jim Langevin of Rhode Island, made a quadriplegic at 16, sees the State of the Union address as an opportunity to show the high toll guns take.
lead_paragraph: WARWICK, R.I. — It happened a few minutes before the beginning of Jim Langevin’s junior cadet shift back in 1980.

headline: Brennan’s Opening Statement
abstract: After a delay due to protesters, President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director, John O. Brennan, made an opening statement at his Senate confirmation hearing.
lead_paragraph: After a delay due to protesters, President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director, John O. Brennan, made an opening statement at his Senate confirmation hearing.

headline: When Dancing Ended, and Disaster Set In
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Alan S. Blinder, an economics professor and a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, looks back at the 2008 financial crisis and why the Bush and Obama administrations responded as they did.
lead_paragraph: The title of Alan S. Blinder’s highly readable new book on the financial crisis (yes, a readable book about economics) refers to an infamous remark made in July 2007 by Charles O. Prince III, then the chief executive of Citigroup. “When the music stops, in terms of liquidity,” he said, “things will be complicated. But as long as the music is playing, you’ve got to get up and dance. We’re still dancing.”

headline: Westboro Baptist Daughters Leave Their Church
abstract: Two members of a nationally reviled church group in Kansas defy their parents.
lead_paragraph: Two Westboro Baptist daughters are leaving the church.

headline: Among the Fixed-Income Also Rans
abstract: Credit Suisse’s fourth-quarter results contain bad news for fixed-income wannabes, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse’s fourth-quarter results contain bad news for fixed-income wannabes.

headline: Sandy-Ravaged Totonno’s to Get a Helping Hand
abstract: Help is coming in from all corners to help the damaged Coney Island pizza restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Some of the money that two restaurants raised to help Governor, which last week gave up its struggle to repair the damage done by Hurricane Sandy, will be sent to another embattled Brooklyn restaurant.

headline: Makers vs. Takers: An Update
abstract: A survey suggests that even those who might have the greatest need for government assistance subscribe to a mentality of self-reliance and bootstrapping.
lead_paragraph: The last election cycle brought a lot of talk about “makers versus takers” in America: a dichotomy featuring entrepreneurial, taxpaying, self-reliant Americans who work hard and keep the economy going, as opposed to those who mooch off the government.

headline: (Missed) Appointment With a Dictator
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: According to a Haitian judge, Baby Doc Duvalier should face trial for misappropriating public funds, but not for abusing human rights.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-seven years to the day after he fled Haiti for exile in France, Jean-Claude Duvalier was supposed to appear at a hearing this morning in a Port-au-Prince appeals court.

headline: Michelle Obama to Attend Funeral for Chicago Teen Slain After Inauguration
abstract: Michelle Obama will attend the funeral for Hadiya Pendleton, the inauguration performer whose killing last month has become symbolic of Chicago’s struggle with guns and gang violence.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama plans to attend the funeral for a Chicago high school student killed last month in a shooting a week after performing for President Obama’s second inauguration.

headline: Obama Fund-Raiser Said to Be Cabinet Candidate
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Penny Pritzker, an heiress to the Hyatt hotel fortune, withdrew her name from consideration for the same post in 2008.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Penny Pritzker, an heiress to the Hyatt hotel fortune, is a leading candidate to become President Obama’s next commerce secretary as the president slowly moves to complete his second-term economic team.

headline: My Touchstone and a Heart of Gold
keywords: ['Dating and Courtship', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: Learning that whoever treated the tortoise with love and care was a keeper.
lead_paragraph: I never intended to get a tortoise.

headline: Touch of Color
abstract: A discreet pop of tomato red, tangerine or pale blush gives everyday monochromatic dressing a graphic lift.
lead_paragraph: A discreet pop of tomato red, tangerine or pale blush gives everyday monochromatic dressing a graphic lift. See the interactive.

headline: The Team With the Difficult Name
abstract: Worth watching: A symposium today at the National Museum of the American Indian about racist stereotypes and sports team names.
lead_paragraph: Worth watching: A symposium today at the National Museum of the American Indian, in Washington, about racist stereotypes and sports team names and mascots.

headline: New Stuff I’ve Learned Since My Facebook Privacy Tool Kit
abstract: More tools to help you decide for yourself how much you want to share on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: For Thursday’s New York Times, I wrote a Tool Kit column about ways to protect privacy on Facebook. Since I wrote the article, I’ve discovered two new tools (via Twitter) that are aimed at Facebook users concerned about their digital footprints.

headline: Kimberly Ovitz: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: In Actions, S.&P. Risked Andersen’s Fate
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: A federal suit paints Standard & Poor’s as willing to cut corners to keep its customers — much as the accounting firm did in the Enron scandal.
lead_paragraph: They were the gatekeepers, with a clear conflict of interest — the people they were supposed to check up on were also the ones who hired and paid them. The need to protect their reputation was supposed to assure that the conflict would not lead to bad behavior.

headline: Suburban Perfection, With Warts
abstract: “The Playroom” is a drama about a seemingly ideal family in the 1970s that has several cracks below the surface.
lead_paragraph: “The Playroom” captures the malaise of mid-’70s suburbia with a merciless accuracy not seen since Ang Lee’s 1997 film, “The Ice Storm.” This small, taut, perfectly cast family drama was directed by Julia Dyer from a screenplay by her sister, Gretchen, who died in 2009. It focuses on the Cantwells, a middle-class clan living in a messy house that feels so claustrophobic you can practically smell the stale cigarette smoke clinging to the furniture.

headline: A Foie Gras and Truffle Indulgence for Two
abstract: Beyond Valentine’s Day, this recipe makes a fine special-occasion first course or midcourse to serve pampered guests.
lead_paragraph: Share a bottle of Côte de Nuits with your Valentine. A lovely rack of lamb with lush potatoes would do it justice. Or consider denting the budget a bit more with a foie gras and truffle indulgence for two. By using either tinned or fresh preserved foie gras, as in a mousse with truffles or a nice portion of foie gras au torchon, you can dress some pappardelle or tagliatelle in deep velvet and create a dish that seeks the acidity and sleek fruit of these wines. As for the truffle, fresh black is not required. A less costly tinned or jarred truffle provides juice to enhance the sauce. Both the foie gras and truffle can be found at a fancy food shop or online. And beyond Valentine’s Day, the recipe makes a fine special-occasion first course or midcourse to serve four pampered guests.  FLORENCE FABRICANT

headline: Excerpt: 'The Job'
abstract: Five contestants face a potential employer in the CBS reality show competition.
lead_paragraph: Five contestants face a potential employer in the CBS reality show competition.

headline: Anti-Everybody and Pro-Individual
abstract: The Neue Galerie has tried to corral German Expressionism, a messy, complicated movement with numerous stylistic and philosophical variations, into a tidy overview.
lead_paragraph: German Expressionism was a messy, complicated movement, with numerous stylistic and philosophical variations. It’s not easily corralled into a tidy overview, despite the best efforts of the Neue Galerie in “German Expressionism 1900-1930: Masterpieces From the Neue Galerie Collection,” currently occupying the museum’s third floor.

headline: Einhorn’s Apple Suit Fits a History of Public Calls
abstract: The hedge fund manager David Einhorn made his name publicly challenging big companies like Lehman Brothers. Here is a look at some of his moments in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: When David Einhorn sued Apple on Thursday, it was a rare rebuke by a hedge fund manager against the world’s most valuable company.

headline: Burgundy’s Wealth of Riches
abstract: A vintage like 2010 demonstrates that the quality of the red wines has never been higher or more consistent, emphasizing finesse and balance.
lead_paragraph: In a dozen years of tastings, the Dining section wine panel had seldom if ever faced a joyous trove like this one. We each had before us 20 glasses of red Burgundy from the 2010 vintage, all from villages in the Côte de Nuits, somewhat modest wines in the Burgundian hierarchy yet beautiful nonetheless.

headline: Spending Cuts and Monetary Policy
abstract: This time is different, predictably.
lead_paragraph: I’ve often argued on this blog and in the column that now is a particularly bad time to cut spending, because unlike in normal times, the adverse effects on demand can’t be offset by cutting interest rates. One way to highlight the point is to compare where we are now with a historical episode: the fairly large cuts in federal purchases of goods and services that took place in the early 1990s, as the US military shrank with the end of the Cold War. Here’s federal consumption and investment spending as a share of potential GDP (blue, left scale) versus the Fed funds rate (red, right scale):

headline: 45 Years Ago, a Stand That Turned Deadly
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Football', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Football (College)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: On the 45th anniversary of the Orangeburg Massacre, the commitment of South Carolina State football players and the price they paid remains notable.
lead_paragraph: On a February night 45 years ago, a linebacker on the South Carolina State football team named Robert Lee Davis went with three or four teammates to a bowling alley just off the black college’s campus in Orangeburg. Theirs was not an act of recreation but of political protest.

headline: The New Uncanny
abstract: A grim, stupendous magic is at work in the stories in Karen Russell’s “Vampires in the Lemon Grove.”
lead_paragraph: Start with a mustard seed of irrelevant fact. Rutherford Hayes’s wife, Lucy, was the first American president’s wife to be referred to as the first lady. Scribble this on a scrap of paper and present it to Karen Russell. Tell her she has to write a story about this old dead guy and reincarnate him as a horse. Give her a couple of pencils. Put her in a locked safe à la Houdini. Tie one arm behind her back. Give her the sniffles. Let her go after a modest interval and see what she comes up with: the hilarious, impossibly realized, even moving, story “The Barn at the End of Our Term.”

headline: Bishops Reject Birth Control Compromise
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Roman Catholic hierarchy said the White House compromise on health insurance coverage of birth control did not do enough to protect religious institutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s Roman Catholic bishops on Thursday rejected the latest White House proposal on health insurance coverage of contraceptives, saying it did not offer enough safeguards for religious hospitals, colleges and charities that objected to providing such coverage for their employees.

headline: Collector Says He’s Found Upper Half of Courbet’s ‘Origin of the World’
abstract: An unidentified collector in France is said to have found a painting of a woman’s face by Courbet that matches up to the artist’s “Origin of the World,” a vivid portrait of a woman’s genitalia.
lead_paragraph: As lower halves of human torsos go, it is one of the most famous in art history, recycled in too many naughty cartoons to count: the plump belly and splayed thighs intersecting in the unmistakably feminine crotch that make up “The Origin of the World,” Gustave Courbet’s 1866 barnburner of a nude.

headline: The Sockeye’s Secret Compass
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Geography', 'Magnets and Magnetism']
abstract: After two years at sea, salmon find their way back to their native river by sensing a familiar magnetic field, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Every summer, millions of sockeye salmon flood into the Fraser River in British Columbia, clogging its shivering waters with their brilliant blushing bodies.

headline: Poolside Manners
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Bathing Suits', 'Gifts', 'Dating and Courtship']
abstract: Settling matters of poolside protocol, wedding gifts, a laundry list of issues, giving thanks and greener grass.
lead_paragraph: I am a 22-year-old man working at a new job on Wall Street. My boss is a very attractive 30-year-old woman. We happen to exercise at the same gym at the same time. We both swim, and the first time we ran into each other, she was wearing a one-piece bathing suit, and I was wearing a classic Speedo. I saw her look me up and down. The next week, she started wearing a thong bikini. Isn’t this a power thing? Jim, Fort Lee, N.J.

headline: And a Child Will Lead Them. But Where?
abstract: “Touch,” with Kiefer Sutherland as a widower raising a mute son who has a special gift, has become considerably darker and more complex as it starts its second season.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, before the premiere of the Fox drama “Touch,” Tim Kring, its creator, was talking about the possibilities inherent in the show’s core relationship, between a father and his mute, somewhat mystical son. As the series progressed, Mr. Kring said, there were lots of things he might do to deepen that relationship. Maybe the boy would even speak at some point.

abstract: A former Los Angeles police officer’s Facebook page detailed plans to kill officers on the force.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 7:30 p.m. With three people dead, an extensive manhunt is under way for a former Los Angeles police officer and Navy reservist who has threatened in an online manifesto to kill police officers and their family members in retaliation for being fired.

lead_paragraph: “The Job,” CBS’s awful new post-Super Bowl schedule filler, does have one redeeming aspect: It makes clear why so many Americans are unemployed. Some of them, it turns out, don’t know how to make themselves worthy of hiring.

headline: How to Use Windows 8? Search for It
abstract: David Pogue is mystified why Windows 8 forces a user to search for nearly everything.
lead_paragraph: I’m deep, deep into Windows 8. When you write a book about an operating system, you wind up rummaging around in dark corners of it that very few people ever see. You learn its quirks and virtues just as you would a person you live with.

headline: Mood Indigo: A Playlist for the Mind
abstract: “Blues for Smoke” at the Whitney Museum of American Art explores contemporary art through the filter of the blues and the culture that has embraced its idioms.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a music-loving family. A lot of what we loved was blues of one kind or another, sung mostly by women: Bessie Smith, Billie Holiday, Maria Callas. I thought of Callas as a blues singer who happened to do Verdi. She sang about love, death and rising up just as Bessie and Billie did.

headline: Jets Make Two Coaching Moves
abstract: Brian VanGorder, Auburn’s defensive coordinator last season, will coach the Jets’ linebackers next season and Bobby April III will be a defensive quality-control coach.
lead_paragraph: Brian VanGorder, who spent four years as Atlanta’s defensive coordinator before holding the same position at Auburn last season, will coach the Jets’ linebackers next season. VanGorder takes over for Bob Sutton, who left to be the defensive coordinator in Kansas City. The Jets also hired Bobby April III, the son of the longtime N.F.L. special teams coach of the same name, as a defensive quality-control coach, the same job he held the last two seasons in Philadelphia.

headline: Mr. Spielberg, Connecticut Objects!
abstract: Connecticut actually supported the 13th Amendment, though “Lincoln” suggests otherwise. Now a congressman is asking for a correction.
lead_paragraph: 8:43 p.m. | Updated  Steven Spielberg has said he was hoping for a high degree of authenticity with “Lincoln,” and certainly his production team worked hard on their antiquing. But there is at least one place where the movie diverts from the historical record, as a Connecticut congressman, Joe Courtney, noted. In the film, two of Connecticut’s representatives are shown voting against the 13th Amendment – voting, in effect, for slavery to continue.

headline: A Woman Who Unleashes Her Inner Medusa on an Everyman
abstract: In “Identity Thief” Melissa McCarthy plays Diana, who wreaks havoc on a milquetoast, Sandy Patterson (Jason Bateman), by stealing his credit cards and more.
lead_paragraph: “Identity Thief,” a lazy comedy about a naughty woman and the uptight man she has her way with, has no business being funny. The story turns on a thief who sometimes goes by Diana (Melissa McCarthy), who wreaks havoc on a milquetoast, Sandy Patterson (Jason Bateman), by stealing his credit cards and more. The two become one of those belligerent odd couples who are forced on the road together chockablock with stereotypes, gun violence, visual clichés and cruel comedy. Diana, a kewpie doll with a crazy smile and five-alarm blaze of hair, is the target of most of the jokes, but until the filmmakers put out her fire with a bucket of tears and sentimental slop, she’s also the movie’s bliss.

headline: Bro-Folk Rock, Organic in a Digital Age
abstract: Mumford & Sons played from their second album, “Babel,” in a sold-out show on Wednesday night at the Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: A few songs into Mumford & Sons sold-out show at the Barclays Center on Wednesday night, the group played “Hopeless Wanderer,” from its second album, “Babel” (Glassnote), which was released last year. Like many of the band’s songs, this one began delicately, with Ben Lovett, the group’s keyboardist, set up at a piano and leading the arrangement, until the song shifted to a roar a couple of minutes in. There was no going back from there. The sound remained intense, manic, dizzying, ending with what felt like the sort of heaving gasp an Olympic sprinter collapses into following the 100 meter finals.

headline: Toasting History in a Cellar Saloon

lead_paragraph: Something exciting happens in a museum when its objects and displays take on a life of their own, when they seem almost too large, too various or too unruly for scripted roles or predicted places. Sometimes this happens because they are seen with new eyes or because they are understood in new contexts; sometimes it is because they possess an aesthetic grandeur that resists any interpretive grid.

headline: No Ordinary Trip to Grandma’s House
abstract: In “Lore,” which is not a fairy tale but feels like one, five children cross Germany in 1945.
lead_paragraph: Cate Shortland’s “Lore” is not a fairy tale, but it feels like one: a dark, mysterious fable of hungry, frightened children making their way through a perilous enchanted forest inhabited by demons. The film sustains an air of overarching mystery in which the viewer, like the title character, is in the position of a sheltered child plunked into an alien environment and required to fend for herself without a map or compass.

headline: The Audience Pays, but So Do the Actors
abstract: Want to be in a musical? The AfterWork Theater Project has a proposition for even the most limited of performers.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the curtain went up last Friday on the AfterWork Theater Project’s revival of “Hair,” it looked like any other modestly budgeted version of that 1967 flower-power musical. “Aquarius” opened the show. Young women wore patchwork skirts pulled from their mothers’ closets; fringed vests covered men’s bare chests. There were songs about Krishna and sodomy. Anyone who buys a ticket for the final four performances this weekend might think that it’s a solid community theater production.

headline: Past, Present, Future, All at the Same Time
abstract: “Night Across the Street,” the final film from the director Raúl Ruiz, focuses on a young boy in love with cinema.
lead_paragraph: “Why do you go to this cinema if you don’t know anything about the film you’ve just seen?” This question is posed by Beethoven, who has befriended a young boy named Celso (Santiago Figueroa) in mid-20th-century Chile. Celso’s other companions include the fictional pirate Long John Silver, a French teacher who may or may not be the novelist Jean Giono (Christian Vadim) and his own elderly self (Sergio Hernandez). Beethoven’s question is perhaps meant to apply to “Night Across the Street,” Raúl Ruiz’s elegiac, enigmatic and mischievous final film.

headline: A Movie Has No Plot. So What?
abstract: In “Once Every Day,” the avant-garde playwright Richard Foreman confounds moviegoers’ expectations about narrative and offers patterns and themes instead.
lead_paragraph: It seems appropriate that the first words you hear in “Once Every Day,” a fascinating thicket of images, sounds and ideas from the formidable avant-garde playwright and director Richard Foreman, are “Help me!” The words are emphatically delivered, more a demand than a plea, by an off-screen woman and dropped repeatedly into the movie’s visual and aural slipstream. Sometimes the words brush up against other words, creating a glimmer of larger meaning; at other times, they bob along alone. The sound quality of the two words is muddy enough that I initially thought that the woman was yelling, “Hell me!,” which suggested that we were being readied for a tumble down the existential rabbit hole.

headline: Battling Self-Immolations, China Makes More Arrests
abstract: The crackdown in Qinghai Province comes as the number of self-immolations approached 100, with the government stepping up its campaign to quell protests by those seeking greater freedom for Tibetans.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The police in a restive Tibetan area have arrested 12 people and detained dozens more accused of playing a part in acts of self-immolation by Tibetan monks and others protesting Chinese rule, the state-run news media said Thursday, as the government stepped up its campaign of attributing the protests to a plot inspired by the exiled Dalai Lama.

headline: Italian Oil Giant Caught Up in Corruption Investigation
abstract: Milan prosecutors have extended their investigation of alleged corruption in Algeria involving Saipem, ENI's oil services subsidiary, as well as to ENI and its chief executive, Paolo Scaroni.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Italian oil giant Eni said Thursday that Milan prosecutors had expanded their investigation of alleged corruption in Algeria involving Saipem, the company’s oil services subsidiary, to include ENI itself and its chief executive, Paolo Scaroni.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Talking Talent | Ellen Burstyn
abstract: The Oscar, Emmy and Tony award-winning actress reflects on her return to the stage more than half a century since she made her debut.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-, Emmy- and Tony Award-winning actress Ellen Burstyn, who made her Broadway debut more than half a century ago, has returned to the stage as Helen Potts in William Inge’s “Picnic,” playing at Roundabout Theater Company’s American Airlines Theater through Feb. 24. Although her role in the Pulitzer Prize-winning play is not a lead, Burstyn felt an immediate connection with Mrs. Potts who, much like herself, is filled with wisdom and life experience that she shares with great passion. As the co-president and artistic director of the famed Actors Studio, Burstyn is very much Hollywood royalty.

headline: Bellevue Hospital Fully Returns 99 Days After Evacuation
abstract: Bellevue Hospital Center, New York City’s flagship public hospital, lost even its backup generators when its basement flooded, and it reopened piecemeal.
lead_paragraph: Ninety-nine days after it was evacuated in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, Bellevue Hospital Center fully reopened on Thursday.

headline: A Fish, Er, Storm Named Nemo
abstract: The Weather Channel has bestowed storms with names like Athena, Caesar, Freyr, Iago, and Kahn. This one brings to mind the adorable orange fish in the Disney/Pixar film, “Finding Nemo.”
lead_paragraph: 1:39 p.m. | Updated  “We’re ready for Nemo,” the Twitter account for the New York City mayor Michael Bloomberg asserted on Thursday before listing all the tools at the city’s disposal for the blizzard that is bearing down on the Northeast.

headline: Deep Thoughts on Holmes & Yang
abstract: The nice thing about Holmes & Yang is that their designs do not, and should not, require a lot of thought.
lead_paragraph: Entering a hotel suite on the 43rd floor of the New York Palace Hotel, we see the actress Katie Holmes and the stylist Jeanne Yang amid some luxurious surroundings, a big comfy couch, Gershwin tunes on the sound system, a commanding view of Midtown and a plate of six deli muffins on a coffee table between us.

headline: The Mets Embrace Tradition, Again
abstract: The naming rights for the Mets’ spring training stadium once again belong to a Florida real estate developer.
lead_paragraph: The Mets apparently have not heard the phrase “once bitten, twice shy.” On Thursday, they announced that Tradition Florida, a real estate developer, would buy the naming rights to the Mets’ spring training stadium in Port St. Lucie.

headline: A Vote for the East Village
abstract: After looking in Morningside Heights for an apartment to buy, Kat Gang realized she did not want to leave the East Village after all.
lead_paragraph: Kat Gang was happy in her 300-square-foot studio on St. Marks Place. She lived on the top floor, the sixth, one floor higher than the surrounding buildings. With a view north to Midtown, and great light, “It was like a watchtower,” she said. She enjoyed hanging out with the smokers and other neighbors who gathered on the front stoop.

headline: Donovan Conspicuous by His Absence
abstract: The United States felt the absence of the nation’s all-time leading scorer during its 2-1 loss to Honduras in a World Cup qualifier.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — In the wake of the United States’ national team’s 2-1 World Cup qualifier loss to Honduras on Wednesday, the absence of Landon Donovan, the nation’s all-time leading scorer, became all the more conspicuous.

headline: When the Couch Has an Attitude
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Moving and Moving Industry', 'Furniture']
abstract: Tight squeezes keep the New York Couch Doctor company in business.
lead_paragraph: After Sal Giangrande and his team finish performing surgery — after their drills, screw guns, rubber mallets, pliers and reciprocating saws are tucked away and the customized safety blankets are stowed for future use — he has a surefire methodology for determining whether the operation was a success: he sits on the patient.

headline: A Fading District Pins Its Hopes on a Bobsled
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Olympic Games (2014)']
abstract: A group of small-factory owners in the ailing Ota district of Tokyo has built a bobsled in an effort to show others that a better future lies in a shift to producing precision products.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It seems an unlikely source of salvation for this city’s run-down, industrial Ota district: a black two-person bobsled about the size of a sofa that sits in a cramped workroom tended by men in blue jumpsuits. Yet, if its creators’ dreams come true, it will race in the Winter Olympics next year as proud proof that this area’s tiny, family-run manufacturing workshops can build a better bobsled than the world’s leading sled makers, a group that includes the likes of Ferrari and BMW.

headline: Islanders Get Thomas, but Salary Rules Are the Motivation
abstract: In a trade designed to guarantee that they reach the salary floor, the Islanders acquired Tim Thomas, the Bruins goalie who is sitting out the season to be with his family.
lead_paragraph: In a trade expressly designed to guarantee that they reach the salary floor by Friday’s N.H.L. deadline, the Islanders on Thursday acquired Tim Thomas, the Bruins goalie who is sitting out the season to be with his family.

headline: Gobbled Up by a Great Lawn
abstract: Traces of the Yorkville Reservoir can still be found in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need a lot of snow, just the lightest dusting around the Great Lawn in Central Park, to see a remnant of old New York. If the wind is right, the snow catches on a long, mysterious ridge on the east side, leading north to a strange half-pyramid of stone. These are the traces of the long-gone 1842 Yorkville Reservoir.

headline: Are Awards Worth the Hype?
abstract: Do awards dictate too often what we decide to view, listen to or read? Or do they lose their power and appeal once the hype wears down?
