headline: In Italy, a Factory Too Fragile for Its Time
abstract: For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory produced singular, handcrafted and elegant porcelain tableware, but the factory was declared bankrupt in January.
lead_paragraph: SESTO FIORENTINO, Italy — For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory here produced singular, handcrafted and elegantly decorated porcelain tableware. Its pieces have graced museums and the tables of the world’s wealthy and aspiring middle class. In March, the Pitti Palace, in Florence, will exhibit Ginori porcelain from the Napoleonic occupation of Tuscany.

headline: An Unlikely Path to Palestinian Fatherhood
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Doctors', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls', 'Smuggling']
abstract: A Palestinian fertility doctor said he is helping 50 women to become pregnant by smuggling their husbands’ sperm out of Israeli prisons.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian fertility doctor said Thursday that he was helping about 50 women conceive children using sperm smuggled out of Israeli prisons, that four of the women were now pregnant after in vitro fertilization, and that one delivered a boy last summer, named Muhannad.

headline: Lawmakers and Lobbyists Tied by Blood
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a capital where moving from the Legislature to the lobby is unremarkable, it is also common to find legislators’ relatives working with the government.
lead_paragraph: John Pitts has a provision in his lobby contracts that tells his clients they are hiring him to lobby everyone at the Texas Capitol — except for the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

headline: Performers Urge Russia to Permit Adoptions
abstract: A panel of respected figures from Russia’s art world issued an emotional appeal to President Vladimir V. Putin to make an exception to a recent ban on adoptions by Americans.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A panel of respected figures from Russia’s art world issued an emotional appeal to President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday to make an exception to a recent ban on adoptions by Americans, and allow children to join American parents they have already come to know.

headline: Edun: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: It’s Not All in His Head; He Actually Is a Mess
abstract: “A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III” stars Charlie Sheen as a graphic designer who wants to win back his true love.
lead_paragraph: The protagonist of Roman Coppola’s visually snazzy comedy “A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III” tools around Hollywood in a vintage Cadillac, one side of which is painted with fried eggs, the other with strips of bacon. The character, a wildly successful graphic designer, is inspired partly by Charles White III, the renowned airbrush illustrator much admired for his album covers of the 1970s. The other inspiration is the louche reputation, as well as the name, of the movie’s star, Charlie Sheen, who looks much the worse for wear.

headline: When Lawmakers Influence Politics in Their Private Jobs
abstract: Despite a law passed by the Texas Legislature 10 years ago, some elected officials continue to act as lobbyists in their private work and to influence political outcomes.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, the Texas Legislature passed laws to restrict the lobbying of state agencies by lawmakers on behalf of private clients. Despite the reforms, some elected officials continue to lobby.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Feb. 8, 2013
abstract: The New York Times critics on “Side Effects,” “Identity Thief” and “Lore.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics on “Side Effects,” “Identity Thief” and “Lore.”

headline: Water-Reuse Ideas Go Forward, Despite ‘Toilet to Tap’ Concerns
abstract: Texas cities are moving ahead with the technology for turning sewage into drinking water, with some experts arguing that the process is safe and others deriding the idea as “toilet to tap.”
lead_paragraph: WICHITA FALLS — The idea of turning treated sewage into drinking water may give some people pause.

headline: A Film Classic
abstract: Alan’s Alley Video has been a neighborhood staple in Chelsea for 25 years.
lead_paragraph: Alan’s Alley Video has been a neighborhood staple in Chelsea for 25 years.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Alan’s Alley Video
abstract: Alan’s Alley Video, in Chelsea, is open seven days a week, 365 days a year.
lead_paragraph: Alan’s Alley Video, in Chelsea, is open seven days a week, 365 days a year.

headline: An Audience Lingers in the Aisles
abstract: Alan’s Alley Video, one of the last independent rental businesses in the city, endures, even in the age of instant streaming and on-demand cable.
lead_paragraph: The old woman sits in her winter coat amid towers of VHS tapes and DVDs, watching neglected Hollywood classics on the television above her. The shop’s staff can say little about her except that she appears regularly and knows a lot about movies, but has rarely if ever rented one from them. This does not bother them.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON

headline: International Court Demands Custody of Qaddafi’s Intelligence Chief
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: Abdullah al-Senussi, who has been charged with crimes against humanity, also faces charges in Libya and the government insists on trying him in a Libyan court.
lead_paragraph: Judges at the International Criminal Court have ordered the Libyan government to hand over immediately Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s former intelligence chief, who has been charged with crimes against humanity. The former spy chief, Abdullah al-Senussi, also faces charges in Libya, and the government insists on trying him in a Libyan court. The international court’s order, published Thursday, rejected Libya’s request for more time to argue its case for trying Mr. Senussi in Libya. He is being held largely incommunicado in a jail in Tripoli. The new court order also ordered Libya to let Mr. Senussi see a British lawyer appointed by the court to represent him.

headline: A Beat-Generation Star Who Won’t Answer to the Name
abstract: The documentary “Ferlinghetti: A Rebirth of Wonder” looks at the poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti, publisher of Allen Ginsberg and a founder of the City Lights bookstore in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Most of his admirers consider the poet, publisher, activist and San Francisco eminence Lawrence Ferlinghetti one of the last major Beat Generation figures standing, but he doesn’t. “Don’t call me a Beat,” he warns in “Ferlinghetti: A Rebirth of Wonder.” “I never was a Beat poet.”

headline: How Much Snow Will Fall This Weekend
abstract: Snow forecasts for this weekend’s storm.
lead_paragraph: Snow forecasts for this weekend’s storm.

headline: Clinging to His Non-mainstream Identity
abstract: The documentary “A Rubberband Is an Unlikely Instrument” follows a Brooklyn musician who plays in the subway and would rather buy a rare guitar than medical insurance.
lead_paragraph: As offbeat as its title, the documentary “A Rubberband Is an Unlikely Instrument” immerses us in the life and thoughts of Walter Baker, a Brooklyn musician at odds with modernity and the demands of raising a family.

headline: Cities of Leicester and York Argue Over Where to Rebury Richard III
abstract: Anticipating potential tourism revenue, the cities are fighting over the remains of King Richard III just days after his bones were found in a parking lot.
lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — Just days after the yellowed bones found in a municipal parking lot here were declared to be those of King Richard III, a less-than-seemly tug of war has broken out between the cities of Leicester and York to claim the remains.

headline: Some States Push Measures to Repel New U.S. Gun Laws
abstract: Statehouses from South Carolina to North Dakota are trying to pass bills that would call for them to ignore or resist federal measures.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A tide of anger at Washington’s gun-control efforts is sweeping through statehouses from South Carolina to North Dakota, taking the form of laws that would let states ignore — or at least resist — any new national gun restrictions.

headline: Looted Libyan Arms in Mali May Have Shifted Conflict’s Path
abstract: Recent photographs from Mali suggest that weapons from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s looted stockpiles may have found their way to militants in sub-Saharan Africa.
lead_paragraph: Since the war that toppled Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi began in 2011, arms-tracking analysts have warned that weapons looted from the colonel’s stockpiles could find their way to militants in sub-Saharan Africa.

headline: Coach Has Gophers Golden Again
abstract: Four years after a debilitating illness endangered his career and two years after fans wanted him fired for missing the N.C.A.A. tournament for consecutive seasons, Don Lucia has led Minnesota’s hockey team to a No. 1 ranking.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — At precisely 1:27 p.m. Wednesday, Don Lucia, the Minnesota men’s hockey coach, skated onto the ice at Mariucci Arena and began writing on a dry-erase board hanging by the bench. Six players had already gathered by the blue line, on one knee leaning on their sticks, when Lucia blew his whistle two minutes later to summon the rest of the team.

headline: Pastor Apologizes to His Denomination for Role in Sandy Hook Interfaith Service
abstract: Rob Morris, a Lutheran pastor who lost a congregation member in the Sandy Hook massacre, apologized after he took part in an interfaith service, violating a denominational rule.
lead_paragraph: A Lutheran pastor who participated in an interfaith prayer service in Newtown, Conn., in the days after the Sandy Hook massacre has apologized after being criticized by the leader of his denomination for violating its prohibition against joint worship with other religions.

headline: Second-Generation Americans: A Portrait of the Adult Children of Immigrants
abstract: A new Pew Research poll shows that the children of immigrants are having an impact on the nation’s communities and workforce.
lead_paragraph: A new Pew Research poll shows that the children of immigrants are having an impact on the nation’s communities and workforce.

headline: Success of Immigrants’ Children Measured
abstract: A study shows that second-generation Americans outperform the foreign born by many socioeconomic standards.
lead_paragraph: Americans who were born to immigrant parents, many of them the adult children of an enormous wave of immigrants who began arriving in the 1960s, are doing better than the foreign born on important measures of socioeconomic success, and in at least one area — education — have outperformed the population as a whole.

headline: A Truculent Man in a Wheelchair and a Diaper
abstract: “Porfirio,” a sort of documentary-fiction hybrid by Alejandor Landes, has a script, but the story is that of its subject-actor, a paraplegic in Colombia with a startling past.
lead_paragraph: Vividly depicting the indignities of the flesh, “Porfirio” offers a harshly sensual portrait of a man imprisoned by paralysis and the callousness of the state.

headline: Tensions Flare as Japan Says Russian Planes Entered Airspace
abstract: The episode underscores the two nations’ tangled territorial claims related to an island chain near the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido that have been controlled for decades by the Soviet Union and then Russia.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan said that Russian fighter planes violated its airspace briefly on Thursday, and it scrambled its own military jets in response. The episode caused a flare in tensions in a longstanding territorial dispute that had been relatively quiet in recent months.

headline: Hunter and His Lawyer Take an Audit to Task
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Nepotism', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: The longtime executive director of the N.B.A. players union addressed the allegations in a 469-page audit that faulted his judgment and leadership.
lead_paragraph: Billy Hunter, the longtime executive director of the N.B.A. players union, is fighting for his career and his reputation, on multiple fronts. An independent audit faulted his judgment and leadership. He is under investigation by federal prosecutors. He has been suspended indefinitely by the union. He could be fired as soon as Feb. 16, when the players meet during All-Star weekend.

headline: A Long Struggle for Equality in Schools
abstract: A federal judge approved a plan intended to lift a long-standing desegregation order that has served as a reason and an excuse much that has gone wrong in a Tucson district.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Looking back at the school desegregation case he took as a young lawyer, Rubin Salter Jr. sees a pile of wasted money and squandered opportunities. After almost four decades in court and nearly $1 billion in public spending, little has changed for the black children whose right to a good education he had labored to defend.

headline: A Long Overdue Discussion
abstract: Unfortunately, the right questions about the Obama administration’s counterterrorism policies were not asked of the C.I.A. nominee, and his answers were unsatisfying.
lead_paragraph: John Brennan’s confirmation hearing as director of the Central Intelligence Agency has forced a long overdue discussion of some of the most controversial aspects of the Obama administration’s counterterrorism policy, including the killing of American citizens suspected of terrorism. Unfortunately, on Thursday, members of the Senate Intelligence Committee didn’t always ask the right questions and the nominee’s answers were frequently unsatisfying.

headline: Detroit, the Billionaire’s Playground
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Detroit now faces the prospect of running out of cash. Welcome to the Commonwealth of Belle Isle?
lead_paragraph: DETROIT

headline: America’s Genius Glut
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Visas', 'Science and Technology', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Yes, our immigration system needs serious reform. But let’s not fix what isn’t broken in the process.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: Bail Reform in New York State
abstract: Too many poor defendants who pose no risk to public safety are require to post bail, a system that is unfair and expensive.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Judiciary address this week, Jonathan Lippman, the state’s chief judge, said that on any given day, “nearly 30,000 people are held in local jails in New York State.” Many get locked up because they lack the financial means to post bail, even when the amounts are as low as $500. The annual cost of holding such large numbers of people in pretrial detention is around $570 million, money that could be better spent on other public services.

headline: Russian Winter Olympics Hit a Snag Over Time
abstract: A proposal to go back to using daylight saving time could mean increased television revenue for the Games in 2014, but hurt the legacy of President Vladimir V. Putin’s predecessor.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — A year before the world’s top ski racers are due to rocket down the Rosa Khutor alpine track here in the Caucasus Mountains, a sharp debate is under way among senior Russian officials over how to keep time at next year’s Winter Olympics — not the time on the race clocks, but the actual time of day.

headline: A New Front in Global Trade Wars
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Intellectual Property', 'Editorials']
abstract: Legally approved piracy is not the answer to a decade-old trade dispute between the United States and Antigua and Barbuda.
lead_paragraph: A 10-year trade dispute between the United States and the Caribbean nation of Antigua and Barbuda involving online gambling has reached an important turning point that could set a disturbing precedent for global commerce. Last week, the World Trade Organization authorized Antigua and Barbuda to violate intellectual property protections on American movies, books, pharmaceuticals and other goods as compensation for United States policies that harmed the islands’ online gambling business.

headline: Rice’s Diplomatic Skills Extend to Golf Course
abstract: The former U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice was teamed with Jason Bohn at the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — In the week after learning he was paired with Condoleezza Rice in the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, Jason Bohn compiled questions and contemplated how to greet someone who had served as national security adviser and secretary of state. When he finally met Rice on Thursday morning, less than a half-hour before their tee time, her first words to him, he said, were, “Roll Tide.”

headline: Mary Jo White at the S.E.C.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: She has smarts and guts, but she needs to make clear that she can be a strong regulator of Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has nominated one of the nation’s best lawyers, Mary Jo White, to be the next chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Kick That Can
abstract: Given the state we’re in, now is not the time for spending cuts.
lead_paragraph: John Boehner, the speaker of the House, claims to be exasperated. “At some point, Washington has to deal with its spending problem,” he said Wednesday. “I’ve watched them kick this can down the road for 22 years since I’ve been here. I’ve had enough of it. It’s time to act.”

headline: Florence and the Drones
abstract: As we debate the ethics of using drones, it might be surprisingly useful to take a page out of Machiavelli’s tough-minded view of human nature.
lead_paragraph: This winter I’m taking part in a great course at Yale called Grand Strategy. We’re reading strategic thought from Sun Tzu and Pericles straight through to Churchill and George F. Kennan. This week we read Machiavelli.

headline: In Russia, Protester in May Rally Arrested
abstract: The protester, Ilya Guschin, grabbed a police officer by his uniform and tried to throw him to the ground and could  be sentenced to up to 13 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A Moscow district court on Thursday arrested a participant in a protest last May on charges of rioting and attacking the police. Investigators said they had video evidence that the protester, Ilya Guschin, 24, grabbed a police officer by his uniform and tried to throw him to the ground during a confrontation between hundreds of demonstrators and the police in Moscow. If convicted of both charges, he could be sentenced to up to 13 years in prison. Mr. Guschin is one of 20 people facing similar charges after nine months of investigations into the protests against Vladimir V. Putin shortly before he returned to the presidency.

headline: A $10K Degree (Your Price May Vary)
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article, “My Valuable, Cheap College Degree.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Samsung, the electronics company from South Korea, is teaming with fashion designer Alexander Wang to help a New York art charity and to send a message to consumers.
lead_paragraph: THE fashion designer Alexander Wang is joining forces with Samsung to create a new print based on doodles, sketches and photographs that are being contributed via smartphone by some of the top names in fashion.

headline: Mystery Deepens as Staten Island Woman’s Body Is Returned From Turkey
abstract: Sarai Sierra kept up with friends and family via social media when she traveled to Turkey, and that connectedness may have given her a false sense of security.
lead_paragraph: In a zinc-plated coffin, Sarai Sierra’s body was flown back from Turkey on Thursday, a belated tragic return that brought a wife and mother home to Staten Island for burial, but left unanswered many questions about her death.

headline: Ranchers Find Hope in Flightless Bird’s Fat
abstract: Emu oil, which comes from a block of fat that covers most of the bird’s body, has proved a boon for ranchers in an industry struggling with decline.
lead_paragraph: HAMILTON, Mont. — The Wild Rose Emu Ranch is a survivor in an unusual business.

headline: Business and Labor Unite to Try to Alter Immigration Laws
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Foreign Workers', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Two oft-feuding groups, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Chamber of Commerce, have formed an alliance to find a way for immigrants illegally in the United States to gain citizenship.
lead_paragraph: After decades of friction over immigration, the nation’s labor unions and the leading business association, the Chamber of Commerce, have formed an unusual alliance that is pushing hard to revamp American immigration laws.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Feb. 8, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, Feb. 8, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "The U.S. is pointing a gun at Iran and wants us to talk to them. The Iranian nation will not be intimidated by these actions.”

headline: Company Sues to Recoup Money From Armstrong
abstract: SCA Promotions, which paid Lance Armstrong millions of dollars in bonuses for winning the Tour de France, is seeking its money back because Armstrong was stripped of his titles.
lead_paragraph: An insurance company that paid Lance Armstrong millions of dollars in bonuses for winning the Tour de France sued him Thursday in a Dallas court, seeking its money back because Armstrong was stripped of his Tour titles and admitted using performance-enhancing drugs for all seven of his Tour victories.

headline: In California, Reading the Snow to Tell the Future for the Water Supply
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Water', 'Winter (Season)', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: California’s snowpack, which supplies water to more than 25 million people and almost one million acres of farmland, is measured monthly in the winter.
lead_paragraph: PHILLIPS, Calif. — Along Highway 50 in the Sierra Nevada, elevation 6,820 feet, a California winter ritual unfolded here on a recent morning. In the snow-blanketed meadow of a local homeowner’s backyard, reporters representing news organizations from across the state followed a man on skis who kept plunging an aluminum tube into the snow.

headline: States’ Group Calls for 45% Cut in Amount of Carbon Emissions Allowed
abstract: The Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, a nine-state collaboration to trim carbon emissions, suggests reducing the limit on emissions as incentive for electric utilities.
lead_paragraph: The Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, the country’s first regional system for capping carbon emissions and creating a market in carbon allowances, proposed a fundamental change on Thursday to increase electrical utilities’ incentive to cut emissions from fossil-fuel plants by raising the cost of compliance.

headline: Suspect in Texas Veteran’s Killing Was Hospitalized
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Veterans', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Eddie Ray Routh, accused of killing Chris Kyle, the author of “American Sniper,” had been released from a hospital over his parents’ objections just days before the shooting, his lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Eddie Ray Routh, the former Marine corporal accused of killing Chris Kyle, an author and retired Navy SEAL sniper, had been released from a veterans hospital here four days before the shootings over the objections of his parents, Mr. Routh’s court-appointed lawyers said.

headline: The Work of Stuart Freeborn
abstract: A look back at the career and characters created by Stuart Freeborn, the makeup artist.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the career and characters created by Stuart Freeborn, the makeup artist.

headline: Stuart Freeborn, ‘Star Wars’ Makeup Artist, Dies at 98
abstract: Mr. Freeborn created characters like Yoda and did extensive work on dozens of other films. George Lucas, the “Star Wars” director, called him “a makeup legend.”
lead_paragraph: Stuart Freeborn, a movie makeup artist whose alchemy helped shape the outlandish space creatures that stalk the “Star Wars” films — including the big-eared, big-brained little Yoda, whom he modeled after himself and Albert Einstein — died on Tuesday in London. He was 98.

headline: Heavenly Measurement
abstract: Fun and frustration with Barry C. Silk.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Every time I solve a crossword puzzle, I make a list of entries that I need to research in order to better define them in my mind, primarily because it’s much easier to make fun of things when you actually understand what they mean. Sometimes the list is very short, and sometimes the list is quite long.

headline: Corrections: February 8, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 8, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Rocker on the Eve of Destruction
abstract: In “Clive,” by Jonathan Marc Sherman, Ethan Hawke plays the title character and also directs the New Group production of an update of Brecht’s “Baal.”
lead_paragraph: Ethan Hawke has been dying a lot in recent months. Having taken on the depressive, suicidal title character of Chekhov’s “Ivanov” late last year, he is now portraying another existentially challenged, terminal case in “Clive,” Jonathan Marc Sherman’s latter-day variation on Brecht’s “Baal.” While there are big differences — it is now Brecht instead of Chekhov, after all — the road to the grave, as mapped by Mr. Hawke, feels much the same: fretful, feverish and, ultimately, fatiguing.

headline: For a Global Life, Bloomberg Builds His Own British Empire
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, imagining life after City Hall, is exporting vast quantities of financial, social and political capital to London, where he has long yearned for influence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is the biggest development in this city’s buzzing financial district, and even Olympics-jaded Londoners call it grandiose: two bronze-and-stone towers, connected by sky-bridges atop the ruins of a 2,000-year-old Roman temple.

headline: For Democrats in G.O.P.-Led House, a New Congress Means Some New Muscle
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With Republicans often sharply split on big issues like spending and taxes, Democratic votes have been decisive in getting major legislation through the House.
lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va. — After more than two trying years in the political wilderness, House Democrats who gathered here for their annual retreat are starting to appreciate a new political reality that few of them expected: They matter.

headline: School Mistakenly Shared Private Admissions Data
abstract: In a letter that discussed fund-raising plans, the Dalton School inadvertently provided information on whether the children of some alumni had been accepted for entry.
lead_paragraph: Private schools are fund-raising pros. They keep detailed tabs on families and alumni so they know whom to ask for annual funds, auctions and capital campaigns.

headline: In Teeth of Winter, Fixing a Broken Beach for Summer
abstract: The parks department, busily repairing the boardwalk, moving mountains of sand and clearing debris, has vowed to reopen Rockaway Beach by May 24.
lead_paragraph: One day last fall, Veronica M. White looked up and it was Thanksgiving. In a minute, it would be Christmas. Five minutes later, Memorial Day. Ms. White had just taken over as commissioner of parks and recreation for New York City when Hurricane Sandy struck. Suddenly, the summer of 2013 was galloping straight at her and the beaches of New York were broken. Take, for instance, Rockaway in Queens. Boardwalks washed away. Sand carried on wind and water to houses, yards and playgrounds. Public restrooms in ruins, concession stands buried, the lifeguard shack all but wrecked.

headline: H.P. Directs Its Suppliers in China to Limit Student Labor
abstract: New rules from Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other tech products, reflect a major shift in how electronics companies view Chinese labor practices.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China. The move, following recent efforts by Apple to increase scrutiny of student workers, reflects a significant shift in how electronics companies view problematic labor practices in China.

headline: Peter Hauri, Psychologist Who Focused on Insomnia, Dies at 79
abstract: Dr. Hauri was one of the first researchers to study the mechanics of a good night’s sleep.
lead_paragraph: Peter Hauri, a psychologist who was among the first researchers to study the mysterious mechanics of a good night’s sleep, and who established widely used guidelines for avoiding insomnia without drugs, died on Jan. 31 in Rochester, Minn., where he had been director of the Mayo Sleep Disorders Center until he retired in 2000. He was 79.

headline: Brooklyn Legislator to Lose $67,000 for False Travel Filings
abstract: Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. claimed to be in Albany on 609 days but was elsewhere, said the comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, who is withholding future reimbursements.
lead_paragraph: Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. has run afoul of the authorities to an extent that is unusual even for the caldron of scandal that is New York’s capital.

headline: Iran Shows Video It Says Was Made by U.S. Drone
keywords: ['Television', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The state television broadcasted clips from what was described as encrypted video footage extracted from the camera of an unarmed American surveillance drone.
lead_paragraph: In what Iran is calling a new demonstration of its military advances, state television has broadcast clips from what was described as encrypted video footage extracted from the camera of an unarmed American surveillance drone, which was seized in Iranian territory in December 2011.

headline: N. Hoolywood: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Fleeing a Grim Reality, and Returning to Rise Above It
abstract: For Ramon Galloway, Philadelphia represented circumstances he had once tried to leave behind. But he has moved back to play at La Salle, a move that has allowed him to play in front of his father, who is blind.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It was still early, but the crowd noise at Tom Gola Arena had begun to taper, and Gerald Galloway could sense things were not heading La Salle’s way.

headline: Pro-Palestine Speakers at Brooklyn College Attract Protests Outside
abstract: Controversy has grown at the college, where nearly a fifth of the undergraduate population is Jewish, over the event organized by a student group, Students for Justice in Palestine.
lead_paragraph: Tensions were evident everywhere as two pro-Palestinian speakers arrived Thursday night at Brooklyn College. Protesters began gathering across the street from the student center, where the college-sponsored talk was scheduled, more than an hour before the event was to start. And police officers were stationed at the entrance to the building, searching bags and checking attendees’ names and identifications against an approved list.

headline: A More Significant Minority
abstract: Two significant votes in the House this year have passed with most Republicans voting no. Since 1991, just 33 bills have passed without the support of most of the majority party.
lead_paragraph: Two significant votes in the House this year have passed with most Republicans voting no. Since 1991, just 33 bills have passed without the support of most of the majority party.

headline: Prosecutor’s Appeal for a 7th Term: ‘We’re Not Done’
abstract: Charles J. Hynes, the longtime Brooklyn district attorney, officially announced what is shaping up to be his toughest re-election bid.
lead_paragraph: Charles J. Hynes, the longtime Brooklyn district attorney, officially announced on Thursday that he would seek a seventh term as the borough’s top law enforcement officer, setting him up for the toughest re-election campaign of his nearly 24-year career.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: These are the winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Garden Debut, 19-Year-Old Ranger Earns Hat, if Not Quite Hat Trick
abstract: Playing only his second N.H.L. game, the 19-year-old center J. T. Miller led the Rangers past the Islanders with two goals.
lead_paragraph: J. T. Miller, playing in his second N.H.L. game, gave an electrifying performance Thursday night, scoring two goals to lead the Rangers to a 4-1 victory over the Islanders at Madison Square Garden.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Architect of Bounties Is Hired by Titans
keywords: ['Football', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: The N.F.L. reinstated the former New Orleans Saints defensive coordinator Gregg Williams, who was hired by the Tennessee Titans as a senior defensive assistant.
lead_paragraph: The last of the bounty punishments passed into history Thursday as the N.F.L. reinstated the former New Orleans Saints defensive coordinator Gregg Williams, who was hired by the Tennessee Titans as a senior defensive assistant.

headline: A Problem Continues to Blow Past the Knicks
abstract: John Wall, who led the Wizards with 21 points and 9 assists Wednesday, was another in a list of speedy point guards who have sliced through the Knicks’ defense.
lead_paragraph: None of the Knicks wanted to give John Wall all the credit for ending their five-game winning streak Wednesday night.

headline: Doubts About Players and Suspected Drug Provider
abstract: Baseball investigators are talking to associates of Anthony Bosch, whose anti-aging clinic is at the center of a major doping scandal. A few associates have doubts about his suspected involvement.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, as Major League Baseball has tried to solve its doping riddle, its investigators have repeatedly encountered vivid tales of star players using banned substances.

headline: Schilling Talks About Banned Substance Offer
abstract: In a radio interview, Curt Schilling said that an employee for the Red Sox once approached him about using banned substances.
lead_paragraph: In a radio interview on Wednesday about doping in baseball, Curt Schilling said that an employee for the Red Sox once approached him about using banned substances.

headline: Mariners and Hernandez Closing In on a Record Deal
abstract: Seattle is on the verge of giving Felix Hernandez a contract extension that could pay him $25 million per season.
lead_paragraph: The price for elite pitching will soon cross a new threshold. Felix Hernandez and the Seattle Mariners were on the verge of a contract extension Thursday that would make him the first pitcher in baseball history to earn $25 million per season on a multiyear deal.

headline: Even for the Dead, There’s a Race to Make the A-List at Oscars
abstract: A spot on the yearly scroll of recently deceased movie luminaries has become one of the most hotly contested honors of the Oscar show.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Oscar night everyone is dying — sometimes literally — to win something.

headline: 19-Year-Old Claims a Milestone for Black Nascar Drivers
abstract: Darrell Wallace Jr. will compete in the Camping World Truck Series this season, becoming only the third black driver in the 65-year history of Nascar to secure a full-time ride in a national series.
lead_paragraph: Darrell Wallace Jr. will become only the fourth black driver in the 65-year history of Nascar to race full-time in a national series when he competes in the Camping World Truck Series this season.

headline: Aging Easy Riders Beware
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Elderly', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: Motorcyclists 60 and older are three times as likely to be severely injured in a crash than younger riders.
lead_paragraph: If you’re over 40 and planning to hop on a motorcycle, take care. Compared with younger riders, the odds of being seriously injured are high.

headline: Jets Hire Coaching Assistants
abstract: Brian VanGorder will coach the Jets’ linebackers next season. The Jets also hired Bobby April III as a defensive quality-control coach.
lead_paragraph: Brian VanGorder, who spent four years as the Falcons’ defensive coordinator before holding the same position at Auburn last season, will coach the Jets’ linebackers next season. He replaces Bob Sutton, now the defensive coordinator in Kansas City. The Jets also hired Bobby April III as a defensive quality-control coach. He held the same job the last two seasons in Philadelphia.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) SHAKESPEARE UNCOVERED Actors and directors tour some of Shakespeare’s greatest works in this series, which continues here as David Tennant, who recently starred in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production of “Hamlet,” compares notes with Jude Law, above right with Mr. Tennant, on the challenges of the role and tries to master the meaning of the play alongside Simon Russell Beale and Ben Whishaw. At 10 on Channel 13 and at 11 on Channel 49, the series concludes as Trevor Nunn, who has directed 30 of Shakespeare’s 37 plays and is determined to stage them all before he retires, explains the magical world created in “The Tempest,” Shakespeare’s last complete play, with the help of Helen Mirren and the director Julie Taymor, who collaborated on a 2010 film adaptation.

headline: China Denies Directing Radar at Japanese Naval Vessel and Copter
abstract: The denial was China’s first substantial response to the claim that it had aimed radar capable of aiding weapon strikes at a Japanese naval vessel and helicopter near disputed islands.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China on Friday denied Japanese accusations that its ships directed a radar capable of aiding weapon strikes at a Japanese naval vessel and helicopter near disputed islands recently, then lobbed its own accusation: that Japan was trying to fan tensions. The latest exchange underscored the depth of a festering discord between the two countries, and trading partners, over the territorial dispute.

headline: Settlement Between Armstrong and Company
abstract: A 2006 settlement agreement between Lance Armstrong and SCA Promotions regarding a dispute over a bonus payment. SCA had withheld that bonus payment for Armstrong’s 2004 victory because of doping allegations.
lead_paragraph: A 2006 settlement agreement between Lance Armstrong and SCA Promotions regarding a dispute over a bonus payment. SCA had withheld that bonus payment for Armstrong’s 2004 victory because of doping allegations.

lead_paragraph: SCA Promotions filed a lawsuit against Lance Armstrong, seeking repayment of the bonuses the company paid him for his Tour de France victories.

headline: News Quiz | February 8, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Torture on the One Hand, Abuse on the Other
abstract: “Would You Rather,” directed by David Guy Levy, centers on a gruesome parlor game with desperate players that is masterminded by a creepy Croesus.
lead_paragraph: Makers and takers — or at least the far-right definition of same — square off against one another in “Would You Rather,” a derivative horror movie with highfalutin pretensions.

headline: Hazards of Reporter’s Job Include Puck to Face
abstract: Hockey players are known to be among the toughest athletes, but hockey reporters can shrug off a little blood to do their jobs, too.
lead_paragraph: Hockey players are known to be among the toughest athletes, but hockey reporters can shrug off a little blood to do their jobs, too.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 8
abstract: Hewlett-Packard imposes limits on student labor in China; Russia gears up for the 2014 Olympics; a possible ancestor for humankind; and building bobsleds in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China. The move, following recent efforts by Apple to increase scrutiny of student workers, reflects a significant shift in how electronics companies view problematic labor practices in China. Keith Bradsher reports from Hong Kong and David Barboza from Shanghai.

headline: Five Questions for: Author and Filmmaker Laleh Khadivi
abstract: The Iranian-born writer on dealing with critics and more.
lead_paragraph: Laleh Khadivi is an author and filmmaker who was born in Esfahan, Iran, and grew up in California. Her first novel, “The Age of Orphans,” received the Whiting Award for Fiction, the Barnes and Noble Discover New Writers Award and an Emory Fiction Fellowship, and it was translated into eight languages. Her latest novel, “The Walking,” will be published in March. Her debut documentary film, “900 Women,” premiered at the Human Rights Watch Film Festival in 2001. India Ink interviewed Ms. Khadivi at the Jaipur Literature Festival.

headline: European Leaders Agree, Finally, to a Lower Budget
abstract: The slimmer budget maintains Europe’s climate of austerity, but the colossal effort that was required to reach a deal raises serious questions about the limits of European integration.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS

headline: At Least 26 Killed in Bombings Across Iraq
abstract: A series of explosions struck across Iraq amid worsening sectarian tensions before elections in April.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A series of explosions across Iraq killed at least 26 people on Friday, continuing a spate of violence that has marked recent political turmoil and witnessed demonstrations now on seven consecutive Fridays.

headline: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Feb. 8, 2013
abstract: What word is missing from the blank in the first line of this article?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Katherine Schulten, and comes from the article “Even for the Dead, There’s a Race to Make the A-List at Oscars.”

headline: Questions About the U.S. Drone Campaign
abstract: What are some of the questions that the United States’ use of targeted killing raises?
lead_paragraph: In “Drone Strikes’ Risks to Get Rare Moment in the Public Eye,” Robert F. Worth, Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane report on the United States’ drone campaign in Yemen. The program is receiving additional scrutiny this week because of the Senate’s confirmation hearing of John O. Brennan for director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Use this article, and the articles linked in questions below, to understand this complex issue.

headline: Bringing Color to Newcastle
abstract: Sirkka-Liisa Konttinen’s black-and-white photos of Newcastle’s industrial past helped newcomers to the English town adjust to life. She returned, after decades, to photograph them — in color.
lead_paragraph: When Sirkka-Liisa Konttinen moved to Byker, an English neighborhood in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, she was drawn to the laughter, the children playing in the streets, the energy. For her, this blue-collar community brimmed with life.

headline: What Food Would You Like to Judge in a Taste-Off?
abstract: What delectable details and savory hints would you look for as you judged the food?
lead_paragraph: Spicy pepperoni pizza? Creamy coconut popsicles? Crispy mac and cheese? Or subtly sweet black cherry soda?

headline: Azerbaijan Is Rich. Now It Wants to Be Famous.
abstract: Oil-rich, velvet-rope-poor Azerbaijan, a country about the size of South Carolina on the Caspian Sea, would very much like to be the world’s next party capital.
lead_paragraph: In March 2010, Ibrahim Ibrahimov was on the three-hour Azerbaijan Airlines flight from Dubai to Baku when he had a vision. “I wanted to build a city, but I didn’t know how,” Ibrahimov recalled. “I closed my eyes, and I began to imagine this project.” Ibrahimov, one of the richest men in Azerbaijan, is 54 and has a round, leathery face with millions of tiny creases kneaded in his brow and the spaces beneath his eyes. He walks the way generals walk when they arrive in countries that they have recently occupied. In the middle of his reverie, Ibrahimov summoned the flight attendant. “I asked for some paper, but there wasn’t any. So I grabbed this shirt in my bag that I hadn’t tried on. I took the tissue paper out, and in 20 minutes I drew the whole thing.”

headline: Tunisians’ Anger on Display at Funeral
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The killing of Chokri Belaid, a harsh critic of the ruling Islamist-led party, has led to fears that polarization and growing political violence will imperil Tunisia’s transition.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — In a show of anger at Tunisia’s Islamist-led government, tens of thousands of people filled a hilly cemetery in the capital on Friday to bury Chokri Belaid, an opposition politician whose assassination this week stirred fears here and throughout the Arab world that political violence could subvert the uprisings born in Tunisia two years ago.

headline: The Problem With Playing the Scholarship Game
abstract: College isn’t about chastising yourself for failing to meet arbitrary standards; it’s about affirming what is strong and good within you and working to nurture and guide what is not.
lead_paragraph: Decades ago, the Oscars were acknowledged to be a self-congratulatory publicity blitz with a thin veneer of drama, sometimes intended to authenticate the managerial efforts of Hollywood’s money men. The honors were meted out beforehand, with the ceremonial excess tacked on as an afterthought three months after the winners had been announced.

headline: Virginia Cavalry Canters Into N.A.S.L.
abstract: Mark Simpson, who has been a part of three titles with D.C. United, is now running a new club — the Virginia Cavalry of the N.A.S.L.
lead_paragraph: Mark Simpson is an ambitious man, but that should be expected. A three-time M.L.S. Cup winner with D.C. United as well as an accomplished indoor player, he has a new project — the Virginia Cavalry of the North American Soccer League.

headline: 8 Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Baku
abstract: The magazine, not the city.
lead_paragraph: In this Sunday’s magazine, Peter Savodnik explores Baku’s attempt to become a new hub for the itinerant filthy rich. In some sense, the article was born a couple years ago when Peter and I worked on a piece for Bloomberg Businessweek about Eurovision, the pan-European song contest in which “American Idol” meets Davos with drum machines. Azberbaijan, which isn’t even really in Europe, was hoping to use its 2011 victory to jump-start a nation rebranding campaign. As it happens, it might just work out.

headline: Daily Report: H.P. Directs Its Suppliers in China to Limit Student Labor
abstract: New rules from Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other tech products, reflect a major shift in how electronics companies view Chinese labor practices.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China, report Keith Bradsher and David Barboza of The New York Times.

headline: Power Outage at Delhi Airport Affects Flights
abstract: Radar was disrupted, and some travelers reported delays.
lead_paragraph: An electrical power failure at the Indian capital’s main airport disrupted the radar system on Friday, delaying some flights.

headline: Is This Business for Sale Too Good to Be True?
abstract: This company appears to have achieved an outstanding level of profitability in three ways.
lead_paragraph: My post last week that asked whether you would pay $6.2 million for a specific heating, ventilation and air-conditioning business brought a lot of great comments with lots of smart analysis. Some readers — including Fred T and vulcanalex — say that the profits this business claims to be generating sound too good to be true.

headline: Pakistan’s Media Police
abstract: It’s becoming harder to tell whether Pakistan’s media are concerned with entertaining or censuring the public.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD — Maria Khan, the host of a Pakistani television talk show, raided a massage parlor in a private residence in Lahore last week and accused the women working there of being prostitutes. Accompanied by the police, Khan and her “Baat Say Baat” camera crew threatened the employees with arrest, rifled through their purses, and cross-examined them about their work. The women’s faces were caught on camera despite their repeated requests not to be filmed. Khan made racist comments about the parlor’s Chinese owner, and even went so far as to contact the father of one employee and accuse him of pimping out his daughter.

headline: A Sportswriter and the ‘Gay Super Bowl’
keywords: ['Football', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Super Bowl']
abstract: The battle over gay rights became a surprising subplot during Super Bowl week. A sportswriter, Chuck Culpepper, reflected on the issue in a personal way.
lead_paragraph: Pointing you in the direction of this fine column by Chuck Culpepper of Sports on Earth on Thursday.

headline: The Executor’s Assistant
abstract: An executor of an estate quickly learns that every step — even with a small, simple estate that owes no taxes and includes no real estate or trusts — is more complicated than expected.
lead_paragraph: I’m serving as executor for my father’s estate, a role few of us are prepared for until we’re playing it, so I was grateful when the mail brought “The American Bar Association Guide to Wills and Estates” — the fourth edition of a handbook the A.B.A. began publishing in 1995.

headline: Horse Meat in Food Stirs a Furor in the British Isles
keywords: ['Horses', 'Meat', 'Food', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The scandal has fueled worries about what has been going into cheaper burgers consumed in millions in British schools, hospitals and prisons.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Few things divide British eating habits from those of Continental Europe as clearly as a distaste for consuming horse meat, so news that many Britons have unknowingly done so has prompted alarm among shoppers and plunged the country’s food industry into crisis.

headline: Storm’s Heavy Snow and High Winds Lash at the Northeast
abstract: After a day of pelting wet snow, five states had called states of emergency, and Massachusetts had banned cars from every road in the state. Conditions quickly worsened after dusk fell.

headline: Whaling: Who Gets to Decide if Cultural Tradition Justifies Slaughter?
abstract: An animal rights group says that the Japanese government is now subsidizing the country’s controversial whale hunting industry as young people lose the taste for whale meat and whale-watching tourism grows.
lead_paragraph: Japanese whaling is losing money, in part because younger generations are losing their appetite for whale meat. As a result, the Japanese government is subsidizing the controversial industry.

lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Answers for Boomers Affected by the Great Recession
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Age, Chronological', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Phillip B. Levine answers questions related to his study that adds a health aspect that baby boomers are the greatest victims of the Great Recession.
lead_paragraph: Phillip B. Levine is an economics professor at Wellesley College and an associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research, an affiliate of the National Poverty Center. Last fall he was one of the authors of a study that adds a health dimension to the idea that baby boomers are the greatest victims of the Great Recession. Dr. Levine and his co-authors, Courtney C. Coile and Robin McKnight, concluded that the life expectancy of boomers ages 57 to 61 who lose their jobs (and health insurance) may be decreased by as much as three years. The life expectancy of those 62 and older, however, who lose jobs is unaffected — in part because Social Security and Medicare provide a safety net to cushion the blow. Dr. Levine took questions this past week about the research.

abstract: King Norodom Sihanouk was a deeply flawed leader with one quality that endeared him to Cambodians: He genuinely loved his people.
lead_paragraph: King Norodom Sihanouk was a deeply flawed leader with one quality that endeared him to Cambodians: He genuinely loved his people.

Mr. Einhorn, head of Greenlight Capital, filed a lawsuit on Thursday to block a plan by Apple to eliminate preferred shares and urged fellow shareholders to join him. “The standoff sets up an unusual clash between two sides who can each claim a huge following on Wall Street,” DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes.

lead_paragraph: With notable speed after the Nov. 6 presidential election, a number of Republican politicians and opinions makers — from House Speaker John A. Boehner to the talk show host Sean Hannity — altered their positions on immigration and expressed a new openness to comprehensive reform.

headline: French Communists Abandon Hammer and Sickle

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Communist Party of France has sparked a revolution among the comrades by removing the hammer and sickle from their membership cards.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Oscar Race Beyond the Grave, and Crowdsourcing Design
abstract: The fight to secure a place on the Oscar memorial list can be as contentious as trying to win an award, Alexander Wang teams up with Samsung to promote creativity and smartphones and whom to watch in this year’s Grammy awards on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has learned that selecting deceased movie figures for their Oscar night memorial reel can be as fraught as picking winners, Michael Cieply writes in The New York Times. Lobbying tends to be fierce, even though the committee that chooses whom to include is a closely guarded secret, and feelings tend to get hurt. This year’s awards will almost certainly include Ernest Borgnine, Charles Durning, Nora Ephron, Tony Scott, Richard Zanuck and Marvin Hamlisch, but since the Academy expanded the list to include notable film industry figures like makeup artists and publicists, there are often unpredictable honors and snubs. The commemoration of lesser-known figures has led to the exclusion of Corey Haim, Farrah Fawcett and Bea Arthur, among others, omissions that can feel less like benign neglect than a slight. The Academy maintains a much longer obituary list on Oscars.com.

headline: With a Technological Boost, How To Keep It Simple and Not Sound Stupid
abstract: A British scientist’s digital aid has those in various fields testing whether complicated ideas can be conveyed using only the most popular words in the language.
lead_paragraph: A new text-editing widget has thrown down a gauntlet to advocates of simple writing, and gone viral on Twitter. What part of that don’t you understand?

headline: Helping a Worrier Become a Warrior
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Parenting', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: For parents of worriers, one question looms over the discussion of why some children thrive on the stress of testing while others implode: Can we help our children feel better, as well as do better, under stress?
lead_paragraph: Is your child a warrior, or a worrier?

headline: The Gun Report: February 8, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The big news on Thursday, of course, was of the ex-Navy reservist who, four years after being fired from the Los Angeles Police Department, vowed to kill his former colleagues. Christopher Jordan Dorner, 33, posted a 6,000-word manifesto on his Facebook page promising a “violence of action” before shooting and killing the daughter of a former L.A.P.D. captain who Dorner blamed for his firing, her fiancé, and a police officer. Dorner also shot and wounded two officers. A sprawling manhunt ensued, and in the confusion, two women were accidentally shot by police.

headline: Cold Trail and Blizzard Hamper Search for Ex-Officer in California Killings
abstract: As no new traces of Christopher J. Dorner, wanted in three shooting deaths, were found, the authorities wondered if he had somehow slipped through their fingers.
lead_paragraph: BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif. — The search for the former Los Angeles police officer wanted in three killings continued throughout Friday here, even as a blizzard covered the mountains with a foot of snow. But as no new traces of the suspect were found, the authorities wondered if he had somehow slipped through their fingers.

headline: Full Spectrum of a Photographer Who Made Color Cool
abstract: A retrospective at the Maison Européenne de la Photographie in Paris shows off the work of Joel Meyerowitz, one of the pioneers who made color photography a legitimate form of fine art.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A half century ago, when photographic purity was seemingly defined by the classical black-and-white images of Henri Cartier-Bresson, Ansel Adams and Marc Riboud, the American artist Joel Meyerowitz’s first step in his chosen career looked like a serious mistake: He shot in color.

lead_paragraph: KOCHI— Demands for a fresh investigation of an Indian politician accused of raping a teenager in 1996 gained momentum after the young woman’s mother urged the Congress Party’s leader to dismiss the lawmaker.

headline: Delacroix’s ‘Liberty Leading the People’ Is Defaced in France
abstract: The authorities have detained a woman who wrote graffiti on the painting, and the Louvre said any damage to the artwork may be easily removed.
lead_paragraph: The famous Delacroix painting “Liberty Leading the People” has been defaced by a vandal, BBC News reported, but the authorities say they have detained a woman accused of writing on the artwork and that any damage to it may be easily removed.

headline: Corporate Hoarding and the Slow Recovery
abstract: Could be a big deal.
lead_paragraph: Lots of talk now about Apple’s cash hoard, which is actually kind of amazing: this is supposedly our cutting-edge technology company, and it apparently can’t find things it wants to invest in. Or more accurately, given its incredible profits, it can’t find enough things to do with all the money it makes.

abstract: What should soccer officials do about widespread match-fixing? How might the discovery of the skeletal remains of Richard III inspire a reappraisal of the long-reviled king? What is “professional peer pressure,” and how might it fix voting flaws?

lead_paragraph: The markets have been kind to private equity firms, and Apollo Global Management is no exception.

abstract: Anand Giridharadas, an IHT columnist, and Marcus Mabry, editor of Rendezvous, discuss the costs of the West’s emphasis on the individual’s freedom of choice.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN — Can we have too much freedom?

headline: Post Office Slows Rate of Losses for Quarter
abstract: The agency, which announced an end to Saturday mail service this week, was helped by holiday shipping and election mailings, but its financial woes continued.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Holiday shipping and the 2012 election helped the Postal Service stem its losses, but the agency’s financial woes continued in the first quarter, which ended Dec. 31.

headline: Finally It’s the Academy’s Turn to Vote
abstract: Voting on the Oscars begins today, amid possible whisper campaigns and backlashes.
lead_paragraph: With all the momentum-building and repeat-speechifying, it may seem as if the Oscar winners are a foregone conclusion. But fear not, latecomers and fans of movies that aren’t “Argo”: Academy members do not even begin voting on the nominees until today.

headline: Moscow on Ice
abstract: Skaters make the most of the city’s efforts to transform its public spaces.
lead_paragraph: Skaters make the most of the city’s efforts to transform its public spaces.

headline: Snoops and Cheaters
abstract: Sneaking peeks.
lead_paragraph: I shared a hotel suite with my 20-year-old stepson, a sophomore in college. I couldn’t resist reading the texts on his phone, which he left in the bathroom, and deduced that he and his friends were cheating on tests. I want to tell my husband (his dad), but if we confront him, my stepson will know I was checking his phone. Knowing we violated that trust will drive a wedge in an already tenuous relationship. Yet we find cheating abhorrent. Do we confront my stepson? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

headline: Jodi Picoult Does Not Write Chick Lit
abstract: The best-selling author on misused labels and the trouble with “white male literary darlings.”
lead_paragraph: Terrible things happen to your characters. Your new book, “The Storyteller,” features a woman in Auschwitz. Past characters have included victims of a school shooting and parents of kids born with horrible diseases. Is it a little sadistic to put your characters through all this?  I don’t think I’m sadistic. I’m superstitious. There’s a part of me that illogically believes if I write about a child with cancer, then my kids are going to be safe. If I write about a school shooting, it won’t happen where we live. If I write about infidelity, then my marriage is going to be safe. Of course it does not work that way, and I know that.

headline: Why Would You Ever Give Money Through Kickstarter?
abstract: The success of crowdfunding sites defies the rules of supply and demand — which is why we can learn so much from them.
lead_paragraph: For about three years, between the ages of 12 and 15, I spent much of my free time on Internet forums devoted to the collectible-card game Magic: The Gathering. It became an obsession, consuming my mind and becoming the only thing I wanted to talk about. And once I realized that nobody I ever met face to face was particularly interested in a long debate on the merits of Zuran Orb vis-à-vis Claws of Gix, I turned to the Web.

headline: My Twinkie Barricade
abstract: In a sugar rush, I hid from punishment.
lead_paragraph: I smelled like nondairy cream filling, my fingers slick with oils. I felt spongy. I had eaten an entire box of Twinkies after school, a month’s ration of treats, and I was in a world of consequences. I stood in the kitchen stunned by my own lapse in control and surrounded by the evidence of my savagery. I watched the clock. My father was on the way home to a debris field of plastic wrappers and a boy with near crystalline blood sugar. When he arrived, inflated in his quilted parka, he saw the story quickly, and sighed.

headline: How Tough Is Daniel Day-Lewis?
abstract: Valentine’s meh; Hootie without the Blowfish.
lead_paragraph: The Big Profile By Dave Itzkoff

headline: Return of a Tabloid Dreamscape
abstract: Thomas Adès’s “Powder Her Face,” which opens next week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is especially relevant in these times of class warfare.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Adès’s operatic version of “The Tempest,” which had its premiere in 2004 at the Royal Opera House in London and arrived at the Metropolitan Opera last fall, was conceived as a capital-M Masterpiece: three acts, big cast, full chorus, Shakespearean source.

headline: The 1.27.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: HELPING VICTIMS OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY

headline: A Secretary to Match the Setting
abstract: Sally Jewell, the president’s nominee to head the Interior Department, shares the passions of the people who use the 500 million acres of public land.
lead_paragraph: The emperor of the American outdoors usually wears a cowboy hat, for the lashing dust and searing sun in the domain of the Interior Department, one-fifth of the United States. James Watt, the most small-minded head of that agency in modern times, wore one. So did Ken Salazar, the outgoing secretary.

headline: Who Made That Zipper?
abstract: Plus: Erica Jong on the erotic state of “ziplessness.”
lead_paragraph: In the 1900s, Gideon Sundback, a Swedish émigré who worked at the Automatic Hook and Eye Company of New Jersey as an engineer, began to tackle one of the most difficult technical problems of his time — fastening clothing. For a woman of the era, getting dressed meant a struggle with a gantlet of buttons and hooks that stretched from bodice to skirt. Her boots alone might require navigating 20 to 30 buttons. An inventor named Whitcomb Judson had tried to solve this problem in the 1890s by designing a mechanism that allowed you to pull on a tab and automatically fasten or unfasten all the hooks. But the hooks had a tendency to pop open.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Details: Yet another roundup of cocktail trends declares that the speakeasy is passé. Also, canned beer is apparently in. (But was it ever really out?) — Robert Simonson

headline: How Dell Tried to Avoid Potential Buyout Pitfalls
abstract: While credit must be given for going the extra mile in the acquisition process, in many ways, it was an easy thing for Michael S. Dell to give.
lead_paragraph: If a runner is the only person in a race and runs really hard, can there still a winner? That’s the feeling I had reading through the acquisition agreement for Dell filed late Wednesday.

headline: The Bag Men of Chinatown
abstract: The men selling fake Celines and Chanels manage to combine the ease of ordering at a Vietnamese restaurant with the paranoid complexity of a West Baltimore hand-to-hand.
lead_paragraph: The salesman, who just sold me a knock-off Celine bag, said something I couldn’t understand into a walky-talky hanging from the wall. He had to check if the coast was clear, he explained. After his co-worker up front squawked back to him, he led us out of the cramped back room, through the secret door cut into the store’s false rear wall and back out onto Canal Street. It was the second false wall my friend and I had passed through that day on our quest to buy knock-off designer bags for the magazine’s Fashion Week-inspired Nine of a Kind, in this Sunday’s issue.

headline: Google Changes Its Ad Program to Try to Solve the Mobile Ad Riddle
abstract: Google made the biggest change to its AdWords program in years, forcing advertisers onto mobile devices and raising protests from some digital ad companies.
lead_paragraph: Google has a mobile problem, and it is trying to fix it.

headline: Who Wants to Be No. 1? Anyone?
abstract: In college basketball, five No. 1 men’s teams have fallen in five consecutive weeks. It’s March madness a month early.
lead_paragraph: The way college basketball is headed these days, March has some company in the madness department. January got the silliness started and now February is staging its own string of wild endings and unpredictable matchups and all the glorious byproducts of parity run amok. How do you explain five No. 1 teams falling in five consecutive weeks? How does the latest temporary No. 1, Indiana — coached by a Harbaugh brother-in-law! — forget how to play defense on the final play, making Illinois’s buzzer-beater an open layup? Why are all those big-name coaches walking around with glassy stares and throbbing headaches?

headline: Storm Watch Hits Fashion Week
abstract: Designers, like everyone else in the city, are keeping a close eye on the weather this morning as the Northeast braces for a potentially crippling snowstorm.
lead_paragraph: Designers, like everyone else in the city, were keeping a close eye on the weather Friday morning as the Northeast braced for a potentially crippling snowstorm. Even if the storm’s impact on New York is minimal, designers were warning that their shows might be delayed at Fashion Week. At the very least, it will be difficult for the hundreds of retailers, editors, models and makeup artists to get around Manhattan during shows scheduled Friday through 10 p.m.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Creatures of the Wind
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Marcelo Gomes.
