headline: Poet and Prophet of El Barrio May Soon Be a Pauper
abstract: Side Street: Jesus “Papoleto” Melendez, 62, one of the founders of the Nuyorican Poetry movement, is three months behind on rent and finding that work opportunities for a poet are few.
lead_paragraph: Update, Feb. 12 | Many readers have expressed interest in donating to Mr. Melendez. Here is his address: P.O. Box 268, New York, N.Y. 10029-0260. Also, a fellow poet, Roberto Garcia, has begun an online fund-raising campaign through the site fundly.com. Click for his fund-raising campaign.

headline: Safety Agency Investigating Brake-Light Problem in Pontiacs
abstract: Car owners have reported that brake lights illuminate when the brake pedal is not depressed.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether General Motors should have included an additional 550,000 vehicles when it recalled about 8,000 cars in 2009 for a brake-light problem, according to a report the agency posted on Friday on its Web site.

headline: The Lumineers, Top 40’s Unlikeliest Act
abstract: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The Times, talks to host Ben Ratliff about his sojourn in Denver with the folk-rock band the Lumineers, one of the most rapid and instructive success stories of 2012.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The Times, talks to host Ben Ratliff about his sojourn in Denver with the folk-rock band the Lumineers, one of the most rapid and instructive success stories of 2012.

headline: Fire Destroys Offices of Israeli Soccer Team
abstract: The police suspect arson in the blaze at the offices of Beitar Jerusalem, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned protests by soccer fans over the addition of the Muslim players.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday condemned as “shameful” the recent protests by soccer fans here of their team’s recent recruitment of two Muslim players, hours after the offices of the team were burned in what the police suspected was arson by some of those fans.

headline: In the Rockies, Growing Support for Renewables
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Land Use Policies', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Wind Power']
abstract: Across the region, poll respondents tended to favor investment in wind or solar power over investment in fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: A new poll tracking the conservation attitudes of residents of the six Rocky Mountain States shows that support is strong for greater protection of public lands and investment in renewable energy. It also offers some clues to why public policy does not dovetail with public opinion in those areas.

headline: Updates on the Winter Storm
abstract: A ferocious storm system buried some some parts of the Northeast in more than two feet of snow and left hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses without power. Journalists from The Times are reporting on the storm and its aftermath and providing updates.
lead_paragraph: A ferocious storm system buried some some parts of the Northeast in more than two feet of snow and left more than 650,000 homes and businesses without power. Journalists from The Times reported on the storm and its aftermath.

headline: Better Not Rely on Style Points
abstract: Managers in the upper echelons of soccer tend to be an unstylish bunch, with wardrobes that speak less of Savile Row than of the bargain rack on the Island of Misfit Clothes.
lead_paragraph: Managers in the upper echelons of soccer tend to be an unstylish bunch, with wardrobes that speak less of Savile Row than of the bargain rack on the Island of Misfit Clothes.

headline: Patient Voices: Eating Disorders
abstract: Anorexia, bulimia, binge eating and excessive exercising — eight men, women and children discuss living with and recovering from an eating disorder.
lead_paragraph: Anorexia, bulimia, binge eating and excessive exercising — eight men, women and children discuss living with and recovering from an eating disorder.

headline: To Make a Good Parm Sandwich, Stick to the Basics
abstract: A line cook talks about how to make up to 100 parm sandwiches in one shift.
lead_paragraph: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

headline: Instagramming Fashion Week
abstract: A selection of your Instagram photos from New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: A selection of your Instagram photos from New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Crucible
abstract: In Jim Crace’s novel, the threat of change brings suspicion and unease to an insular agrarian community.
lead_paragraph: Jim Crace grew up along London’s northern perimeter in a housing estate that felt, he has said, like the last building before the countryside began. In one direction stretched an interminably rural England, in the other an interminable metropolis. Through this accident of childhood, Crace developed an edgeland imagination that has powered his writing ever since, attracting him to dramatic showdowns between clashing values. His characters typically face some encroaching, inhospitable new order, as in “Harvest,” his glorious new novel, where they must scramble to adapt or be mowed down.

headline: Macmillan Will Settle a Lawsuit on E-Books
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The publisher said the potential cost of fighting and losing a government lawsuit was too great to risk, so it agreed to terms similar to those imposed on other major publishers who had settled.
lead_paragraph: 7:31 p.m. | Updated

headline: Call of the Wild
abstract: There’s an intimate connection between the works of Shakespeare and Maurice Sendak.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when I was teaching at Berkeley, I received a peculiar note circulated among faculty members by the head of the humanities center. Maurice Sendak had been invited to give a public lecture, the note said, and he was scheduled to arrive on campus very soon. But he had asked for a NordicTrack machine and 12 down pillows, items that my colleague was scrambling to find. I had no down pillows to spare, but I did, as it happened, have a NordicTrack gathering dust in my basement. Thus began my acquaintance with Maurice, an acquaintance I treasured, though it never blossomed to the point where I dared ask him what he wanted with all of those pillows.

headline: Cellphone Service Without Signing on the Dotted Line
abstract: Even if you have to pay full price for the phone, avoiding a contract for cellphone service may save you money in the long run.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, I upgraded my son’s cellphone — something he had looked forward to with breathless anticipation ever since his last cellphone drowned in a California pool over the summer.

headline: U.N. Says 5,000 Syrians a Day Are Now Fleeing War
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The surge brought the total number of registered refugees this week to 787,000, officials said, with many living in dire conditions without adequate humanitarian support.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Syria’s conflict is now driving 5,000 people out of the country each day in an increasingly desperate scramble for safety, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday as it reported a surge in their numbers to nearly 800,000.

headline: Penn Station Project
abstract: Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick responds to a news article, “New Idea for Penn Station Entails Relocating a College.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fashion Weak: Give That Coach’s Outfit a Red Card
abstract: The way the coaches dress, there’s no mistaking the English Premier League sideline for a fashion runway.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Alex Ferguson pulled a woolly hat around his ruddy face. Rafael Benitez stood in a snowstorm in a suit that did not fit. The usually suave André Villas-Boas resorted to covering his legs with a grandpa-by-the-fire-style blanket.

headline: Democracy, Hacked
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Corporate interests keep us from facing problems, Al Gore writes.
lead_paragraph: In a little more than a decade, since he won the popular vote but lost the presidential election to George W. Bush in 2000, the former vice president and Tennessee senator Al Gore has been a best-selling author; starred in an Oscar-winning documentary, “An Inconvenient Truth” (2006); won the Nobel Peace Prize, in 2007, for his environmental activism; and made a fortune some have estimated to be bigger than Mitt Romney’s, thanks in part to the recent sale of his stake in the Current TV network to Al Jazeera. In “The Future: Six Drivers of Global Change,” Gore takes on a subject whose scale matches that of his achievements and ambition.

headline: When Dinner Is Over, and a Child Is ‘Still Hungry’
abstract: Do you close down the kitchen after meals, or let your children make their own choices about what to eat and when?
lead_paragraph: I’m quandary snatching today.

headline: Hard-Luck Cases
abstract: Lost fathers and redemptive con men have their day in Jess Walter’s first story collection.
lead_paragraph: The men in Jess Walter’s pungent new story collection, “We Live in Water,” are coming apart. These men — and they are exclusively men, save a few catalytic female characters — are what society (and ex-wives) commonly label disappointments. Trading in ill-considered choices, they have made a habit of letting folks down — their women, their kids, their friends, their creditors and, chiefly, themselves. Walter’s protagonists endure a buffet of self-­inflicted misfortune, everything from meth addiction to dodgy parenting, often served in a combo platter with a side of unlucky in love. His characters are all searching, with varying levels of commitment and insight. None succeed.

headline: Lady Lazarus
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Five decades after her suicide, two biographies re-examine Sylvia Plath’s life.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to believe that if Sylvia Plath had not taken her own life — in 1963, at the age of 30 — she would quite possibly still be alive today. Her rival Adrienne Rich, three years her elder, died just last year. But how could Plath live to comb gray hair? Her suicide does not seem like something that just happened to happen. In her poetry, she forces us to see her death as a destiny and a culmination: “The woman is perfected. / Her dead /Body wears the smile of accomplishment, / The illusion of a Greek necessity,” she wrote in her last poem, “Edge,” just six days before she died.

headline: Spread the Word
abstract: In a collage-like work of autobiography and criticism, David Shields considers the reading and writing life.
lead_paragraph: When you read David Shields, the first thing you learn is that he takes literature very seriously. The second thing you learn is how seriously he takes his taking seriously of literature. There’s a striking moment in the closing pages of his new book, “How Literature Saved My Life,” when he tells us that he is interested only in literature that obliterates the boundary between life and art. “Acutely aware of our mortal condition,” he writes, “I find books that simply allow us to escape existence a staggering waste of time (literature matters so much to me I can hardly stand it).” If there were such a thing as a quintessentially Shields­ian pronouncement, this may be it, with its odd tonal mixture of the bombastic and the beseeching. Shields wants you to know that he is a writer for whom neither life nor art is a matter to be taken lightly.

headline: A Public Discussion of Secret Strikes
abstract: The Senate confirmation hearing of John O. Brennan, President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director, focused on drones and targeted killing.
lead_paragraph: The Senate confirmation hearing of John O. Brennan, President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director, focused on drones and targeted killing.

headline: War Machines
abstract: A new history of the tactics and technological innovations that secured an Allied victory in World War II.
lead_paragraph: The historian Daniel Boorstin once complained to me about the Smithsonian Institution’s decision in 1980 to delete the final two words from the name of its Museum of History and Technology. Boorstin had a point. Scholars of other fields do often tend to underestimate the influence of technology. Although most of us know that World War II brought us radar, the literature of that titanic conflict is by no means exempt from this phenomenon. For instance, the biographer Joseph P. Lash subtitled his 1976 wartime account of Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill “The Partnership That Saved the West,” in response to which I once heard a British scholar carp, “If Lash is right, then why did all those scientists and intelligence officers and factory workers bother working so hard?”

headline: Avoiding Defeat
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Did gifted generals really save the day for the United States in Iraq and Afghanistan?
lead_paragraph: Two graphs introduce the text of “The Endgame,” Michael R. Gordon and Bernard E. Trainor’s instructive yet analytically shallow account of the Iraq war after the fall of Baghdad. The first depicts weekly attacks in Iraq from early 2004 to mid-2010, the second civilian deaths from January 2006 to May 2010. The graphs present identical images: bad news getting worse until early 2007, then pronounced improvement. The message is clear: In early 2007 a decided turn occurred. As with the Civil War after Gettysburg or the war in the Pacific after Midway, a conflict that had been going badly suddenly started heading in the right ­direction.

headline: Attention, Shoppers
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Books and Literature', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Elizabeth L. Cline surveys the cultural, economic and environmental consequences of our never-ending hunt for low-priced clothing.
lead_paragraph: In her introduction to “Overdressed: The Shockingly High Cost of Cheap Fashion,” the journalist Elizabeth L. Cline recalls buying “seven pairs of $7 shoes” at Kmart. Regret follows, and soon afterward, a wardrobe inventory. When Cline cleans out her closet she discovers, among other things, 61 tops, 60 T-shirts, 15 cardigans and hooded sweatshirts, 21 skirts and 20 pairs of shoes, most of which she never wore.

headline: Leaving the Man Cave Hand in Hand, Laugh by Laugh
abstract: Pamela Taylor and Eames Yates were married six years ago. Their bond has been strengthened as they have weathered illness and loss together.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Taylor and Eames Yates were married in Snowmass, Colo., in 2006, a few days after a howling September snowstorm. Yet the wedding took place outside as planned, in a grove of evergreen trees, with 200 shivering guests.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
abstract: New books by Tim Crothers, Peter A. Galuszka, Ngugi wa Thiong’o and Lauren Slater.
lead_paragraph: THE QUEEN OF KATWE  A Story of Life, Chess, and One Extraordinary Girl’s Dream of Becoming a Grandmaster.  By Tim Crothers.Scribner, $26.

headline: Working Stiffs
abstract: The characters in “The Rage,” Gene Kerrigan’s new police procedural, are struggling to get by in Dublin.
lead_paragraph: Gene Kerrigan’s new police procedural, THE RAGE (Europa, paper, $17), isn’t your typical Irish crime novel with moody cops and colorful crooks who talk like poets and act like animals. The singular characters who go about their business in Dublin’s crippled economy may be on opposite sides of the law, but in Kerrigan’s book they’re all working-class stiffs struggling to get by.

headline: See for Yourself
abstract: Creatures big and small (and metallic) venture beyond their cozy confines to explore exciting places and make new friends.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to picking children’s books, I am a lot like those old ladies you see in Upper West Side supermarkets, tapping, squeezing and smelling the melons on display: “Is it ripe, dear?” Bringing a children’s book into your home is not something to take lightly. An obliging parent may be asked to read it a hundred times. Nay, a thousand times. The big-eyed sheep that seemed so cute while you were flipping through pages in the store soon begins to vex. Over time, reading the book becomes like ripping off a Band-Aid. Even small defects — an irritating drawing, the misuse of the word “presently,” a character who speaks in rhyme — can form blisters on the parental soul. No, darling, not again. Let’s pick another book, please. I’ve seen the best minds of my generation destroyed by the 38th reading of “Knuffle Bunny Too.”

headline: Common Goals
abstract: African immigrants bring new life to a small-town soccer team.
lead_paragraph: A small town in Maine is flooded with Somali refugees looking for a better way of life. The soccer team gets a jolt of inspiration and outstanding play from its new, non-English-speaking players. They might just have a chance to beat their archrivals! At least, so says Tom Bouchard, the handsome, nice-guy team captain and narrator. Getting in the way are Tom’s nasty, dimwitted girlfriend Cherisse, his hapless bad-boy friend Donnie, and prejudices and culture clashes on both sides.

headline: Daughter of the House
abstract: Ruta Sepetys’s heroine grows up in a New Orleans brothel.
lead_paragraph: As a girl, I was obsessed with prostitutes. The hookers I saw on television wore silk kimonos and had cigarettes permanently attached to their lips — mean on the outside but like bruised baby birds on the inside. My experiences baby-sitting showed me I wasn’t the only girl interested in a so-called life of sin. At 12, I once picked up a daisy-covered address book, to find only one entry, under P, Prostitute, followed by a list of massage parlor numbers.

headline: Seven Stories
abstract: In this young adult novel, characters encounter one another again and again.
lead_paragraph: Vampires have had their moment in young adult literature, as has dystopia, so it takes an idea of real originality to stand out from the vamp/love/fate/doom pack. In this book, the idea is sevenfold and the talented writer who works his considerable magic is Marcus Sedgwick, author of other acclaimed Y.A. novels including “White Crow” and “Revolver.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SANDALWOOD DEATH (University of Oklahoma, paper, $24.95) and POW! (Seagull, $27.50), by Mo Yan. Translated by Howard Goldblatt. Abuse of power, gross materialism, corruption and venality are the targets of the Chinese Nobelist’s satirical novels.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: HORSESHOE CRABS AND VELVET WORMS: The Story of the Animals and Plants That Time Has Left Behind,  by Richard Fortey. (Vintage, $16.95.) A paleontologist, Fortey has spent most of his life looking at fossils. Here he pursues the distinguished groups of organisms that have survived the many cataclysms thrown at them over the past 450 million years: horseshoe crabs and velvet worms, but also lungfish, musk oxen, jellyfish and cockroaches.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Sister Souljah, best known in some circles as the rapper whom Bill Clinton criticized during the 1992 presidential campaign, has her third consecutive best seller with her new novel, “A Deeper Love Inside.”
lead_paragraph: HER MOMENT: Sister Souljah’s new novel, “A Deeper Love Inside,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 7. Souljah is having a good run: this is her third consecutive best seller, and earlier this month the Web site For Harriet included her debut novel, “The Coldest Winter Ever,” on its list of 100 recommended books by black women. (Other authors on the list included canonical figures like Toni Morrison, Octavia Butler and Zora Neale Hurston, as well as celebrated younger ones like Edwidge Danticat, Martha Southgate and ZZ Packer.)

headline: Up Front
abstract: Allison Glock knew early on that she wanted to be a writer.
lead_paragraph: Allison Glock, who reviews Jess Walter’s new story collection this week, knew early on that she wanted to be a writer. “My mother is a former beauty queen turned shrink,” she explained via e‑mail. “If that isn’t fodder for a writing career — coupled with the fact that I would never be a beauty queen or shrink — I don’t know what is. When I was very young, working in my grandfather’s corner grocery in West Virginia, I would sneak on top of the giant freezers and hide so I could watch folks come in and out, listening to what they said, what they didn’t say, my grandfather at the register in his apron, smoking, or in the back making ‘hamburg’ from an entire side of beef. (After breaking down the cow, cleaver in hand, he’d flex his biceps and dare me to hang off of it.) I remember feeling like everything I was watching was operatic somehow. Like I was privy to secrets. I knew even then that if I kept quiet and paid attention, my world would be filled with stories. That this suggestion of boundless possibility happened in a tar-strip-road factory town was an additional gift. Stories that count are everywhere, all the time. Beauty too.”

headline: Stargazing: New York Fashion Week, Day 1
abstract: The predicted blizzard of 2013 was still a day away when New York Fashion Week started on Thursday, yet it was already the main subject of conversation as the shows began at the tents at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The predicted blizzard of 2013 was still a day away when New York Fashion Week started on Thursday, yet it was already the main subject of conversation as the shows began at the tents at Lincoln Center. Topic A: What would the snow mean for those carefully planned outfits of the front-row regulars?

headline: Live Streaming Now: Jason Wu
abstract: Check in daily to see in-the-moment backstage, on and off the runway photos from select New York Fashion Week shows.
lead_paragraph: Check in daily to see in-the-moment backstage, on and off the runway photos from select New York Fashion Week shows.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Beautyblender Cosmetic Sponge
abstract: A makeup artist at Costello Tagliapietra talks about her favorite tool for a flawless, even-toned face.
lead_paragraph: “In the fall and winter, don’t women want velvety skin?” asks makeup artist Maki Ryoke, who turned out one pristine complexion after another backstage at Costello Tagliapietra. The answer is obvious; the challenge, however, is actually achieving a flawless, even-toned face that looks completely natural. Want Ryoke’s advice? Put down the foundation brush, forget about using your fingertips and opt for her favorite skin-perfecting tool: the Beautyblender cosmetic sponge. Designed to be used in a dabbing motion, “It gives you the effect of actual skin texture, so it amazingly looks like you’re not wearing anything,” she says. In addition, its rounded egg-shape allows you to blend makeup without leaving behind a single streak. For the Costello Tagliapietra runway show yesterday, Ryoke gave the models’ faces a slightly dewy finish by first wetting the sponge with mineral water. “I’m quite lazy, and the sponge does all the work,” she says with a laugh.

headline: The Church and the Mandate
abstract: The U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops isn’t too keen on the president’s latest contraception compromise.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, President Obama offered religious leaders his latest (unnecessary) compromise on the so-called birth control mandate.

headline: A Million Pieces of Home
abstract: The Ghanaian artist El Anatsui, whose retrospective exhibition just opened at the Brooklyn Museum, invented a new art form using Nigerian-made liquor bottle tops.
lead_paragraph: Unless there’s terrible news Africa doesn’t get much notice in this part of the world. But at the Venice Biennale six years ago it was the object of thousands of beauty-bedazzled eyes, even if some of those eyes didn’t know at first what they were looking at.

headline: The Art of El Anatsui
abstract: The Ghanaian artist El Anatsui is the subject of a retrospective exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Ghanaian artist El Anatsui is the subject of a retrospective exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Buy, Buy, Buy
abstract: Analysts have been overwhelmingly bullish on Apple stock, even at $705 a share. Now that the stock has dropped 36 percent, they still recommend investors buy it, though some are starting to waver.
lead_paragraph: Analysts have been overwhelmingly bullish on Apple stock, even at $705 a share. Now that the stock has dropped 36 percent, they still recommend investors buy it, though some are starting to waver.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Karen Russell talks about “Vampires in the Lemon Grove”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Adam Kirsch discusses two new biographies of Sylvia Plath; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Karen Russell talks about “Vampires in the Lemon Grove”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Adam Kirsch discusses two new biographies of Sylvia Plath; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: A Valentine’s Day-themed cooking class for singles and couples at BLT Fish, 21 West 17th Street, in Chelsea, will cover how to shuck oysters on Saturday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Amy Eubanks, the executive chef, will offer tips on how to open the bivalves during the class, which includes a three-course lunch at $80 per person or $130 per couple. To book a seat, call (212) 691-8888 or e-mail info@bltfish.com.

headline: Fighting Off the Coffee Curse
abstract: Experts differ on the cause of an orange “rust” that is decimating crops in Central America.
lead_paragraph: Until this year, John Vandermeer, an ecologist and coffee researcher at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, had never lost a tree to fungus.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Kenneth Cole
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Activism at Its Best: Greenpeace’s Push to Stop the Pulping of Rain Forests
keywords: ['Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Paper and Pulp', 'Tigers']
abstract: Old-style environmentalism shows its worth in the imperiled forests of Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: There’s much about 20th-century-style environmentalism that doesn’t work in this era. Demonizing Big Coal or Big Oil in climate campaigns gives a pass to those of us filling up our gas tanks or relying on electricity at home.

headline: Online Abuse of Teen Girls in Kashmir Leads to Arrests
abstract: Swift police response to men who taunted rock band members on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR —Online abuse and a fatwa aimed at a rock band of Muslim teenage girls in Kashmir have led to arrests and a threat of a lawsuit.

headline: Shakespeare’s Globe to Stage ‘Henry VI’ at Historic Battle Sites
abstract: The production will tour to sites that are featured in plays that make up Shekespeare’s trilogy.
lead_paragraph: Hot on the heels of the news that a New York theater company will be staging “Richard III” in a suddenly historically correct parking lot, Shakespeare’s Globe has announced that it will take a touring production of the Henry VI trilogy to four English battle sites that figure in the plays.

headline: Bad Hair Days at Pixar
abstract: The mass of red ringlets belonging to Merida, the heroine of “Brave,” took the animators at Pixar years to create.
lead_paragraph: Alongside “Life of Pi” and “Game of Thrones,” “Brave” was a big winner at the Visual Effects Society’s VES Awards, held on Tuesday in Los Angeles and honoring yes, visual effects. Pixar’s story of the archery-loving reluctant princess earned four prizes, including best animated feature and best animated character, for its heroine, Merida. It should’ve really earned a prize for her hair.

headline: Off the Charts: It’s a Man’s Recovery
abstract: Women lost fewer jobs than men during the recession, but since the total number of workers hit bottom in December 2009, the bulk of the new jobs have gone to men.
lead_paragraph: Women lost fewer jobs than men during the recession, but since the total number of workers hit bottom in December 2009, the bulk of the new jobs have gone to men.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Feb. 8
abstract: Times critics on “Side Effects,” “Identity Thief” and “Lore.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the new Steven Soderbergh film “Side Effects,” the comedy “Identity Thief” and a drama set in postwar Germany, “Lore.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: The Cookie Titan of Tucson
abstract: Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, examines the power of sales on a door-to-door mission with Mary Ruiz, a 10-year-old Girl Scout cookie-selling powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, examines the power of sales on a door-to-door mission with Mary Ruiz, a 10-year-old Girl Scout cookie-selling powerhouse.

headline: Popcast: The Lumineers, Top 40’s Unlikeliest Act
abstract: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The Times, talks to host Ben Ratliff about the Lumineers.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The Times, talks to host Ben Ratliff about his sojourn in Denver with the folk-rock band the Lumineers, one of the most rapid and instructive success stories of 2012.

headline: SUNY Trustees Vote Unanimously to Shutter Long Island College Hospital
abstract: The trustees said the hospital is in such bad shape financially that it threatens the viability of the university’s Brooklyn medical school.
lead_paragraph: The State University of New York trustees voted unanimously Friday to close Long Island College Hospital, saying it was in such bad shape financially that it threatened the viability of the university’s Brooklyn medical school and related facilities.

headline: A Shortage of Apartments for Sale
abstract: The number of real estate listings in Manhattan reached a 10-year low last month.
lead_paragraph: The number of real estate listings in Manhattan reached a 10-year low last month.

headline: Buyer Rivalries Resume
abstract: Because inventory is scare, bidding wars are again raging in some sectors of the market.
lead_paragraph: Here’s another byproduct of the apartment shortage: bidding wars are back.

headline: Dear Owner: Please Sell
abstract: Tight inventory is forcing brokers to be ever more resourceful in scaring up homes for their clients.
lead_paragraph: A shortage of New York City apartments for sale is forcing real estate agents to take extreme, if not desperate, measures in order to conjure up listings.

headline: Filed Under Awesome Use Cases
abstract: Via GigaOM, an article about how researchers are using Times archives to predict the future.
lead_paragraph: Via GigaOM: How two scientists are using the New York Times archives to predict the future

headline: Bookshelf: Be Mine
abstract: New picture books celebrate romantic and friendly affection.
lead_paragraph: New picture books celebrate romantic and friendly affection.

headline: Family Foundations Prepare for the Next Generation
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: As older generations transfer wealth to their children and grandchildren, it will transform how family foundations function from within.
lead_paragraph: AS parents, we worry about our children. And if we have more than one, we worry about how they will interact with each other, not just when they’re young but when they’ve grown up. Independence is great; interdependence is what keeps them together when we’re gone.

headline: Bookshelf: Be Mine
abstract: New picture books celebrate romantic and friendly affection.
lead_paragraph: I HAIKU YOU  Written and illustrated by Betsy E. Snyder. 32 pp. Random House. $9.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 8)

headline: Calendar: Coming Cruises in Japan, China, Honduras
abstract: A weekly capsule of events across the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Kyoto, Japan The Clipper Odyssey, a 118-passenger cruise ship owned by the luxury travel company Abercrombie & Kent, will travel around Japan, departing from Kyoto on May 24. Because of its small size, the ship will be able to dock in shallow ports like the one on Miyajima Island, home of the Itsukushima Shrine. But it’s not too small to fit a library, gym, outdoor pool, a hair salon and other amenities onboard. Rather than a fading mega-band, the star attraction is Geoffrey Kent, the owner of the travel outfitter, right, who will be on hand to take credit (or blame) for the journey. (abercrombiekent.com)

headline: Movie Review | ‘Side Effects’
abstract: A Times critic reviews “Side Effects.”
lead_paragraph: A Times critic reviews “Side Effects.”

headline: How Children Learn to Sell
abstract: Bucks readers share their own stories of how they and their children learned to make a sales pitch and close a deal, all before they turned 18.
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column and an accompanying video, I highlight the exploits of Mary Ruiz, a 10-year-old girl in Tucson who sold more Girl Scout cookies last year than nearly any other child in the United States. But you don’t need to be a Girl Scout to pick up all of the skills that come from looking people in the eye and trying to get them to part with their money through sheer force of verbiage.

headline: Images From the Kumbh Mela
abstract: The banks of Ganges River in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, host the world’s largest congregation.

headline: Seven Days on the Queen Mary 2
abstract: Sex, food and the allure of the wintry North Atlantic aboard the biggest ocean liner in the world.
lead_paragraph: The first rule about traveling between America and England aboard the Queen Mary 2, the flagship of the Cunard Line and the world’s largest ocean liner, is to never refer to your adventure as a cruise. You are, it is understood, making a crossing. The second rule is to refrain, when speaking to those who travel frequently on Cunard’s ships, from calling them regulars. The term of art — it is best pronounced while approximating Maggie Smith’s cut-glass accent on “Downton Abbey” — is Cunardists.

headline: A Winter Voyage on the Queen Mary 2
abstract: Dancing, dining and even a moment when time disappears during a trip on the giant ship.
lead_paragraph: Dancing, dining and even a moment when time disappears during a trip on the giant ship.

headline: Pelosi to Bring Sandy Hook Guest to State of the Union
abstract: The House minority leader will join Representative Jim Langevin’s effort to raise awareness of gun violence.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jim Langevin’s effort to bring victims of gun violence to the State of the Union address has a high-profile new participant, Jeremy W. Peters reports:

headline: Packing for Sea and Sun
abstract: From shorts to sweaters, two cruise veterans share what they plan to pack for coming voyages.
lead_paragraph: From shorts to sweaters, two cruise veterans share what they plan to pack for coming voyages.

headline: Scenes From a Cruise
abstract: The peculiar world of life on a boat, as seen through the lens of Damon Winter, a Pulitzer-winning Times photographer.
lead_paragraph: The peculiar world of life on a boat, as seen through the lens of Damon Winter, a Pulitzer-winning Times photographer.

headline: Rethinking Payphones With NYTimes APIs
abstract: The New York Times co-sponsored Payphone Hack Day, an effort to rethink the use of the thousands of payphones throughout NYC.
lead_paragraph: Recently, The New York Times was one of many partners involved in a hack day to generate ideas for rejuvenating and repurposing New York City’s 11,412 payphones. Ultimately, the goal is to contribute meaningfully and geekily to the larger effort to make the phones relevant to 21st-century city dwellers.

headline: One Dish, One Hour
abstract: Want fast food? Try cooking up one of these one-dish, one-hour meals from Martha Rose Shulman.
lead_paragraph: Fast-food from a restaurant is not as fast as you think. There is drive time to and from the restaurant, waiting time to pay and collect your food, and then it still takes a few minutes to sort through it and set it on the table at home. (Assuming you don’t just eat it in the car.) But if you are willing to invest a few more minutes of time for a more healthful option, you can still make a homemade meal from scratch in less than an hour, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health column:

headline: Comfort Food for a Blizzard
abstract: What to eat when the weather outside is frightful.
lead_paragraph: The snowstorm is approaching, and weather forecasters say it’s going to be one of the worst in a century. We know you’re going to be home-bound, and everyone will be hungry, so we picked three of our favorite comfort food recipes to help you get through it.

headline: Is There Anything We Can’t Do on a Cruise?
abstract: Looking to lure a wide group of travelers, the cruise industry is offering everything from Broadway-style shows to Barbie-themed cabins.
lead_paragraph: Cruise lines keep adding to their itineraries in an industry push to get travelers of all stripes on deck. While many voyages still accommodate the middle-aged vacationer content to see the Caribbean from a chaise longue, an increasing number offer less-sedentary vacationers everything from glacier treks to trips to the ballet.

headline: More Than Pushing Cookies
abstract: Selling Thin Mints and Samoas has brought Mary Ruiz self-esteem, money skills, a sense of accomplishment and some great electronic gear. Not bad for a 10-year-old.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — When you buy a box of Girl Scout cookies and devour 10 in a single sitting, as untold numbers of people will in the next month, you are propping up a pretty sizable enterprise.

headline: Movie Review | ‘Identity Thief’
abstract: A Times critic reviews “Identity Thief.”
lead_paragraph: A Times critic reviews “Identity Thief.”

headline: Migrating Back to the Wilds of the Stage
abstract: Jennifer Monson is bringing her nature-inspired “Live Dancing Archive” to the Kitchen on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Among the many unusual aspects of Jennifer Monson’s “Live Dancing Archive,” which opens a two-weekend run at the Kitchen on Thursday, it takes place inside a theater. Unusual, that is, for Ms. Monson, an esteemed choreographer and improviser who, for the past decade or so has situated most of her work outdoors.

headline: Over 80 Cruises and Counting
abstract: Richard Brooks, who spends about a quarter of the year on a cruise ship, shares his favorite, and most terrifying, moments on the water.
lead_paragraph: When Richard Brooks retired in 1989 from a banking career in England, he embraced life on the sea. His first cruise was in 1985; he now estimates that he’s taken more than 80. He and his wife, Valerie, live part of the year in Wheathampstead, a small village 20 miles north of London, and in Marbella, Spain. Below are excerpts from a conversation about the highs and lows of cruising, and where the values lie.

headline: His Perfect Role Is His Current One
abstract: Danny Burstein, a self-described “working stiff,” takes on the lead role in “Talley’s Folly,” showing he is a go-to actor for dramas as well as musicals.
lead_paragraph: “This is already the hardest show I’ve ever done,” Danny Burstein said, wolfing down a burger and a beer after a recent day of rehearsal for “Talley’s Folly.” It’s tough to take this busy actor entirely seriously — not because Lanford Wilson’s 1979 play isn’t daunting. It requires Mr. Burstein to share the stage with a single co-star, Sarah Paulson, in a tense romantic pas de deux, for roughly 100 uninterrupted minutes.

headline: Spend a Year With a Football Coach, and He May Change Your Mind
abstract: Spending a year with the Valdosta High football program changed author Drew Jubara’s sour opinion about the value of football coaches.
lead_paragraph: It has been quite a month for football coaches. Nick Saban’s joyless visage, already set in bronze on the Alabama campus, filled TV screens after the Tide’s latest title as a kind of national avatar for excellence’s grim rewards.

headline: Movie Review | ‘Lore’
abstract: A Times critic reviews “Lore.”
lead_paragraph: A Times critic reviews “Lore.”

headline: The Netflix Fix
abstract: With deep pockets and a keen eye, Ted Sarandos is fusing Hollywood and Silicon Valley into a new TV paradigm.
lead_paragraph: With deep pockets and a keen eye, Ted Sarandos is fusing Hollywood and Silicon Valley into a new TV paradigm.

headline: Court Hears Arguments on Judge’s Rejection of S.E.C.-Citigroup Deal
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: In an unusual hearing before the federal appeals court in Manhattan, lawyers for the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup argued that Judge Jed S. Rakoff exceeded his authority in rejecting an agency settlement that allowed Citigroup to avoid an admission of wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: 4:56 p.m. | Updated

headline: At Retreat, Bill Clinton Tries to Rally House Democrats
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton visited Leesburg, Va., on Friday morning to inject a healthy dose of energy and dispense some tough love.
lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va. – “We miss you!” someone in the audience of House Democrats shouted at the 42nd president of the United States.

headline: Onstage, Trying to Connect to a Faraway War
abstract: Through the lens of theater, 15 New York University students have the opportunity to explore issues that will remain critical long after the last troops return home.
lead_paragraph: Three blocks from Washington Square Park and more than 6,000 miles from Afghanistan, a group of graduate acting students ran through lines and tried to imagine something that for many in their generation is unimaginable: What’s it like to go to war and return home to a society that doesn’t understand what you’ve been through?

headline: Following a Herd of Bulls on Apple
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Sarbanes-Oxley Act', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Even with reforms meant to reduce conflicts of interest, many analysts failed to foresee a plunge in Apple’s shares.
lead_paragraph: Last September, Apple shares hit a record $705. And to the overwhelming majority of Wall Street analysts, that meant one thing: buy.

headline: Leaving Las Vegas
abstract: The Mercedes SL in the 1950s helped turn the company into a luxury powerhouse, but the modern SL has grown fat, rich and happy.
lead_paragraph: The Mercedes SL in the 1950s helped turn the company into a luxury powerhouse, but the modern SL has grown fat, rich and happy.

headline: On Our Radar: Snowstorms and Climate Change
abstract: As a blizzard develops in the Northeast, scientists reach out again to people who might believe that heavy snows counter evidence of global warming.
lead_paragraph: A re-examination of the interrelationships between weather patterns like Friday’s impending blizzard in the Northeast, greenhouse gas emissions and climate change. [Union of Concerned Scientists]

headline: Respect for the Past, and Adventure in Their Future
abstract: Two Washington lawyers, both from families that had fled Vietnam, find happiness in shared values and a sense of adventure.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, Caroline Trang Nguyen and Daniel Tran Gien epitomize the melding of cultures, interests and attitudes for which this nation is so widely known. Their early years were deeply influenced by the crucible that was the long conflict in Vietnam, from which their parents escaped, hers to Germany and his to Canada.

headline: The Rockets Catch Fire
abstract: Led by James Harden and Jeremy Lin, the Houston Rockets have become one of the N.B.A.’s most exciting teams, scoring more than 100 points in seven consecutive games.
lead_paragraph: It was one year ago this week that a little-known Taiwanese-American point guard from Harvard became a global superstar.

headline: New BlackBerry Will Definitely Not Be Big in Japan
abstract: BlackBerry, which has a miniscule market share in Japan, has no plans to release its newest smartphone in that country.
lead_paragraph: Although Japanese consumers are among the world’s most voracious consumers of smartphones, BlackBerry said on Thursday that they won’t be getting its new line of phones.

headline: Week in Review: Just CC the Justice Department on Those E-Mails
abstract: David Einhorn sues Apple over its plan for stocks. | E-mails imply JPMorgan knew some mortgage deals were bad. | A guilty plea and a big fine for the Royal Bank of Scotland in the rate-rigging case. | A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.
lead_paragraph: David Einhorn sues Apple over its plan for stocks. | E-mails imply JPMorgan knew some mortgage deals were bad. | A guilty plea and a big fine for the Royal Bank of Scotland in the rate-rigging case. | Big law firms are backing away from trusts and estates. | S.&P. e-mails on the mortgage crisis show alarm and gallows humor. | Taking Dell private is the biggest challenge yet for its founder. | Investors seek Herbalife’s elusive sales data.

headline: These Doctors Make Condo Calls
abstract: At one condominium building in Brooklyn, a program offers on-site doctor consultations — and services like nutrition counseling, acupuncture and personal fitness training.
lead_paragraph: Changes in modern medicine largely ushered out the era of the family doctor decades ago, but at one condominium building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, doctors are once again making house calls.

headline: Library Chairman: Renovation Budget Still A Work in Progress
abstract: The New York Public Library’s cost projections have been one focus of the debate over the project, with critics calling for more financial detail beyond the current estimate of $300 million.
lead_paragraph: The budget plan for the New York Public Library’s renovation project is preliminary and imprecise at this point, Neil L. Rudenstine, the library’s chairman, acknowledged in a letter last month to trustees that was obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Mets Sign Lyon for Bullpen
abstract: Brandon Lyon, who pitched for the Astros and the Blue Jays last season, has been signed by the Mets.
lead_paragraph: The Mets announced they signed right-hander Brandon Lyon to join a bullpen restocked with veteran arms.

headline: Amish Sect Leader Sentenced to 15 Years in Hair-Cutting Attacks
abstract: Samuel Mullet Sr. and 15 followers were sentenced to prison for a series of assaults that prosecutors said were motivated by religious intolerance.
lead_paragraph: The leader of a dissident Amish sect was sentenced on Friday to 15 years in prison for a series of bizarre beard- and hair-cutting attacks on other Ohio Amish that drew national attention.

headline: Wave of Arson Attacks in Brazil Is Tied to Reports of Inmate Abuse
abstract: Police installations, public buses and even the homes of prison officials have been targeted in Santa Catarina State, which has traditionally ranked among the country’s safest regions.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A wave of arson attacks is spreading across a state in southern Brazil, largely targeting police installations, public buses and even the homes of prison officials in a region that has traditionally ranked among the country’s safest.

headline: French Landmarks
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: France’s carmaking tradition, which might be described as ignoring tradition altogether, is on full display at Retromobile in Paris. Here are some highlights of this year’s exhibition.
lead_paragraph: France’s carmaking tradition, which might be described as ignoring tradition altogether, is on full display at Retromobile in Paris. Here are some highlights of this year’s exhibition.

headline: Chinese Workers’ Rights
abstract: Students at Hewlett Packard factories in China may now complain about unfair practices.
lead_paragraph: Call it a Lunar New Year’s present to Chinese students. Hewlett Packard issued new guidelines Friday, days before the start of the annual holiday when much of that country shuts down, requiring is suppliers to only employ high school and college students who actively volunteer to do the work. Students should also be free to leave “upon reasonable notice” and have the ability to complain about unfair practices.

headline: U.N. Calls on Papua New Guinea to Curb Violence After Burning Death of Woman
keywords: ['Witchcraft', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Vigilantes', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: The killing of a woman accused of sorcery is part of a pattern of vigilante attacks in the country, the United Nations human rights office said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Spurred by the killing this week of a young woman accused of witchcraft in Papua New Guinea, the United Nations on Friday called on the country to address increasing vigilante violence against people accused of sorcery and to revoke a controversial sorcery law.

headline: BMW Designers Bring Their Approach to Olympic Bobsled
abstract: Although bobsleds don’t have wheels, the project turned on BMW’s skills with carbon fiber, aerodynamics and computer analysis of forms in action.
lead_paragraph: It’s never too soon to start promoting the Olympics, especially if you’ve paid what NBC and its partners have paid for the television rights — $775 million — to next year’s winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

abstract: From the Museum of Modern Art, A. O. Scott and David Carr “go rogue” and examine some of the more interesting works on view.
lead_paragraph: From the Museum of Modern Art, A. O. Scott and David Carr “go rogue” and examine some of the more interesting works on view.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: By Gender and by Age, an Unequal Recovery
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Since the American job market hit bottom in December 2009, men have benefited disproportionately from the recovery, and middle-aged women have done particularly poorly.
lead_paragraph: SINCE the job market in the United States hit bottom more than three years ago, men have benefited from the recovery far more than woman have, with middle-aged women doing particularly poorly.

headline: Japanese Still Seeking Cause of 787 Smoke
abstract: Investigators aren’t sure if a battery that failed on a 787 in Japan had the same problem as one that started a fire on a jet in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s investigation of a battery that was smoking on a Boeing 787 flight there last month has not yet determined if the incident started in the same way as a fire on another 787 in Boston, a Japanese official said Friday.

headline: Social Media Updates From Tunisia, as an Opposition Leader Is Buried
abstract: Activists, bloggers and journalists in Tunisia posted a stream of images on social networks Friday, showing thousands of mourners packed into the largest cemetery in the capital, Tunis, for the funeral of Chokri Belaid.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 3:44 p.m. Activists, bloggers and journalists in Tunisia posted a stream of images on social networks Friday, showing thousands of mourners packed into the largest cemetery in the capital, Tunis, for the funeral of Chokri Belaid, a leading opposition figure whose assassination two days ago triggered a wave of street protests against the Islamist ruling party.

headline: Travel and the Storm
abstract: As the winter storm disrupts travel in the Northeast, share your experiences as you try to get around.
lead_paragraph: The winter storm dubbed Nemo by some has wreaked havoc on travel, leading to the cancellation of thousands of flights in the Northeast, the suspension of Amtrak service between New York City and Boston, and a ban on driving after 4 p.m. in Massachusetts. The Times will continue to report on the storm’s impact on travel in its live storm updates through the weekend.

headline: In the West End, Directors in Residence
abstract: Taking a page from Kevin Spacey, Michael Grandage has set up shop at the Noël Coward Theater and Jamie Lloyd at the Trafalgar Studios, each bringing along a parade of big-name actors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—“That’s that theater taken care of, then!”

headline: Counselor’s Penalty for Child Sexual Abuse Is Halved, to 50 Years
abstract: The state corrections department, citing a legal maximum, reduced the 103-year sentence given to Nechemya Weberman of Brooklyn, who was convicted of molesting a girl for three years.
lead_paragraph: The state’s corrections department has reduced by more than half the prison sentence of Nechemya Weberman, the unlicensed Hasidic counselor from Brooklyn who was convicted in December of child sexual abuse charges.

headline: Passing On the Family Business
abstract: Bucks readers discuss how they managed the transition from one generation to the next of the family business or something else of worth.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, discusses the issues raised when wealthy families bring their children into the family foundation. For one, the next generation may favor different types of charities than their parents. And then, there are the families that have trouble getting along.

headline: Living In | Millstone, N.J.
abstract: Because of strict zoning, many neighborhoods in this Monmouth County township consist of just a few large houses on sizable properties.
lead_paragraph: Because of strict zoning, many neighborhoods in this Monmouth County township consist of just a few large houses on sizable properties.

headline: Street Lighting by Mother Nature
abstract: This Monmouth County township has an off-the-grid atmosphere and not much in the way of streetlights.
lead_paragraph: Driving through Millstone, one will stop for a crossing deer — or maybe even a horse — before having to worry about a traffic light. That’s because this town of 37 square miles doesn’t have any, or much in the way of streetlights, either.

headline: Success and Failure, Fashionably Speaking, in the Premier League
abstract: Sarah Lyall of The Times writes about the fashion successes (few) and failures (many) among Premier League managers.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Lyall of The Times has a delightful article online now about the fashion successes (few) and failures (many) among Premier League managers. A taste:

abstract: The classic uptown ponytail, worn low and over the ears, was modernized with some downtown texture.
lead_paragraph: The classic uptown ponytail, worn low and over the ears, was modernized with some downtown texture.

headline: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
abstract: White House officials described as dire the effects of the automatic, across-the-board cuts to defense and domestic spending that will kick in on March 1 unless Congress and President Obama agree on a plan to put them off.
lead_paragraph: 5:12 p.m. | Updated With a real blizzard bearing down on New England, the policy wonks in the White House tried every which way they could on Friday to warn of the dangers of a different kind of storm.

headline: Big Ticket | An Architectural Mash-Up Sold for $19.5 Million
abstract: A full-floor apartment, with five bedrooms and two terraces, in a building designed by the Mexican starchitect Enrique Norten, was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor condominium at One York, the glassy 21st-century tower that uses a pair of 19th-century TriBeCa loft buildings as its base and launching pad — the Mexican “starchitect” Enrique Norten’s bold interpretation of an architectural mash-up — sold for $19.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Southeastern Asset Management to Fight Dell’s Takeover
abstract: In a filing, Dell’s largest outside investor argues that the management-led buyout is too low and essentially robs shareholders. It is threatening to wage a campaign to kill the $24 billion deal.
lead_paragraph: 7:44 p.m. | Updated One of the biggest investors in Dell said on Friday that it would oppose the company’s plans to go private, setting up a major potential roadblock for the biggest buyout since the financial crisis.

headline: Young Conductor With a Mind of His Own
abstract: The young Spaniard Pablo Heras-Casado led the Orchestra of St. Luke’s at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: In recent years the orchestra world has been galvanized by two exciting conductors in their 30s: Gustavo Dudamel and Yannick Nézet-Séguin. Before long people may be talking about another conductor in that age bracket: the Spaniard Pablo Heras-Casado, 35, who led an impressive concert with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

headline: Bazaar Bomb Claimed by Taliban Kills at Least 11 in Northwest Pakistan
abstract: A Pakistani Taliban commander was quoted as saying that the targets were tribal elders who had helped organize a militia to resist Taliban encroachment in the area.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A car bomb ripped through a town bazaar in northwestern Pakistan’s tribal belt on Friday, killing 11 people and wounding at least 31, local officials said. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility.

headline: When Can a Child Go Solo at a Ski Lodge (or Anywhere Else)?
abstract: A mother responds to her husband’s question: “So, what would you think if I set the kiddo up in the lodge with some hot cocoa and an iPad while I took a solo run down the mountain?”
lead_paragraph: “So, what would you think if I set the kiddo up in the lodge with some hot cocoa and an iPad while I took a solo run down the mountain?”

headline: A German Rushes Past Skiing’s Dominant Woman
abstract: Maria Höfl-Riesch of Germany beat the overall World Cup leader, Tina Maze of Slovenia, to win the super-combined at the Alpine skiing world championships.
lead_paragraph: SCHLADMING, Austria — Maria Höfl-Riesch of Germany beat the overall World Cup leader, Tina Maze of Slovenia, to win the super combined on Friday at the Alpine skiing world championships with an aggregate time of 2 minutes 39.92 seconds. The 2010 Olympic gold medalist in the discipline, Höfl-Riesch edged Maze, who was tied for first with Anna Fenninger of Austria after the downhill leg, by 46-hundredths of a second.

headline: Just a Storm? Not After the Hurricane
abstract: As the storm approached, disaster preparation was tinged by a fresh sense of vulnerability in a region that has learned not to underestimate nature.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps in any other year, the nor’easter would have been met with little more than a shrug in the New York region. Sure, some people would still have stocked up on batteries, water, food and snow shovels. But even they would have salted these purchases with knowing complaints about too much hype.

headline: Chocolate Mousse
keywords: ["Valentine's Day", 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Chocolate', 'Desserts', 'Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Food']
abstract: Melissa Clark shows how to make a chocolate mousse for Valentine’s Day that doesn’t use cream or butter.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark shows how to make a chocolate mousse for Valentine’s Day that doesn’t use cream or butter.

headline: With No Confirmed Medicare Chief for 6 Years, Obama Tries Again
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: President Obama has renominated Marilyn B. Tavenner, now the acting leader, to run the agency in charge of Medicare and Medicaid.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has renominated Marilyn B. Tavenner to run the agency in charge of Medicare and Medicaid, and his action provided a reminder that the agency has been without a Senate-confirmed chief for more than six years.

headline: For Your Sweetheart, and More
abstract: Passionate cooks might shun going out, confecting tête-à-tête meals in their own homes instead.
lead_paragraph: There may be one true love, but there is no one true way to do dinner on Valentine’s Day. If you’re paired off, you could book the traditional table for two at a restaurant. It will be filled with other couples doing the same, attempting to ignore one another while pitching woo over oysters on the half shell.

headline: Grammys Will Honor Music Teachers
abstract: The Grammy Awards are adding a new trophy for music teachers, to be awarded in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Awards are adding a new honor for music teachers. Neil Portnow, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, announced the new award for music educators, which will be presented for the first time next year. He made the announcement on Thursday evening at an event for the Grammy Foundation’s Music Preservation Project at the Saban Theater in Los Angeles.

headline: A Good and Simple Chocolate Mousse
abstract: This recipe has one ingredient: chocolate.
lead_paragraph: For years, chocolate mousse was off the menu in our house. My husband, Daniel, doesn’t eat cream or milk, which pretty much meant than unless I wanted to substitute tofu or coconut milk (been there, won’t be back), that fluffy dessert was something I’d only be eating in restaurants.

headline: Some Ratings Twists for ‘Americans’
abstract: After a strong start, the new FX series about undercover K.G.B. agents saw the live viewership of its second episode tumble.
lead_paragraph: Everything is not what it seems when it comes to the plot and characters of “The Americans” on FX, a spy thriller that follows a pair of K.G.B. agents living undercover in the suburbs of Washington D.C. during the Reagan era, and that appears to be the case for the show’s ratings as well.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Lynda Barry’s ‘Freddie Stories’
abstract: Ms. Barry’s book hits the hardcover list at No. 3.
lead_paragraph: Two books are new on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. “The Freddie Stories,” by the cartoonist Lynda Barry, is at No. 3. It chronicles the ups and downs of Freddie, the teenage member of the dysfunctional Mullen family. It is published by Drawn & Quarterly. At No. 4 is the deluxe edition of “The Books of Magic,” by Neil Gaiman. It is published by DC Comics. It is illustrated by a quartet of powerhouse artists — John Bolton, Charles Vess, Paul Johnson and Scott Hampton. The story is about Timothy Hunter, a young boy on a tour through the magical realms of the DC Universe as mystical forces try to determine whether he will be the world’s most powerful mage.

headline: A Bold Fowl, and It’s Not Chicken
abstract: Guinea hen is just as easy to roast as a chicken, and has a deep flavor that most Americans haven’t even tasted.
lead_paragraph: IT IS JUST AS EASY to roast as a chicken, but tastes immeasurably better. It is quite popular in Canada and Britain, and in France and Italy every butcher has it (cheaper than chicken, too).

headline: Bolshoi Ballet Considers Suing One of Its Own
abstract: Bolshoi Ballet officials are considering a lawsuit after one of its dancers made public criticisms of the theater’s management.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Bolshoi Ballet administration threatened to file a lawsuit against the dancer Nikolai Tsiskaridze on Friday, after he called for the theater’s top executives to be dismissed over its response to the Jan. 17 acid attack on the ballet’s artistic director, Sergei Filin.

headline: Braving the Elements for Jason Wu
abstract: Fashion Week is proceeding as normal, despite the icy sidewalks, a serious storm threat and the sudden absence of all of the beautiful people in their beautiful clothes and stilettos.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week is proceeding as normal, despite the icy sidewalks, a serious storm threat and the sudden absence of all of the beautiful people in their beautiful clothes and stilettos.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Karen Russell’s Uncanny Stories
abstract: Ms. Russell discusses her new collection, “Vampires in the Lemon Grove.”
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Joy Williams reviews “Vampires in the Lemon Grove,” the new collection of short stories by Karen Russell. Ms. Williams writes:

headline: French Ingenuity on Four Wheels
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: The French have a rich car history, which they show off at Retromobile, the vast classic car exhibition in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Paris — Soon after the turn of the 20th century, Marcel Leyat, like many mechanically inclined young men, decided to build a motorcar.

headline: Stalled Out on Tesla’s Electric Highway
abstract: Tesla Motors has opened fast-charging stations between Washington and Boston that would, in theory, allow an E.V. road trip along the East Coast. But a test of that theory in a Model S also involved a tow truck.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Having established a fast-charging foothold in California for its electric cars, Tesla Motors has brought its formula east, opening two ultrafast charging stations in December that would, in theory, allow a speedy electric-car road trip between here and Boston.

headline: Like an Aging Elvis, Star Retains Its Power
abstract: The 2013 Mercedes SL is powerful and technically advanced, yet it is to sports cars as the Vegas Elvis is to rock ’n’ roll — a flashy, bulging facsimile, as much about comfortable seats as about hip-shaking performance.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz couldn’t have known it at the time. But from the moment the SL300 flashed its novel gullwing doors at the New York auto show of 1954, this sports car began building Mercedes from an American obscurity into the luxury powerhouse it is today.

headline: Succeeding With Excess
abstract: The makeover of the Mercedes SL550 by the AMG division adds $40,300 to its donor car’s base price of $106,405 and raises horsepower to 530, from 429. You pay $400 for each additional pony.
lead_paragraph: Long America’s most popular six-figure convertible, the Mercedes-Benz SL-Class has counted many doctors among its owners.

headline: Cooking for Hizzoner
abstract: A young chef serves a new mayor.
lead_paragraph: She was 24 years old and working as a personal chef for the first time ever. He was newly elected as New York’s mayor, and therefore also new to the role of chief occupant and host of Gracie Mansion. Rozanne Gold worked for Edward I. Koch only 10 months, but they were formative for her as a young chef.

headline: AARP Will Embrace Life’s ‘Possibilities’ During Grammys
abstract: Its new campaign, with a budget estimated at $25 million to $30 million, will introduce the theme “Real possibilities.”
lead_paragraph: AARP will seek to cultivate a more contemporary image with a big new brand campaign that, to underline the message the advertising intends to convey, will make its debut during the CBS broadcast of the Grammy Awards on Sunday night.

headline: Dear Valentine, I Hate It When You ...
abstract: Want to improve your marriage? Write about your next fight.
lead_paragraph: HAVE you decided what to get for your valentine this year? You could try something classic, like chocolates. Or something blingy, like earrings. Or sexy, like lingerie.

headline: Newtown Survivor to Attend State of the Union Address
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: Natalie Hammond, a teacher who was shot during the rampage at Sandy Hook Elementary School, will be in the House chamber during the president’s speech.
lead_paragraph: Among the victims of gun violence who will be sitting in the House chamber on Tuesday night when President Obama delivers his State of the Union address will be a teacher who survived the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

headline: Rooting for Fighting Irish, Even While at Duke
abstract: Thinking about his devotion to Notre Dame basketball, a writer finally made sense of his father’s love for Yale football.
lead_paragraph: What makes you fall head over heels in love with a team? The usual fairy tale involves fathers and hometowns and afternoons spent at the ballpark, a closeness that rarely happens in other contexts.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Confused and Terrified Patient Solved
abstract: Readers solve the mystery of a 55-year-old man who was recovering from a terrible injury and suddenly became confused and paranoid.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out the diagnosis for a 55-year-old man who was recovering from a terrible injury and suddenly became confused and paranoid. More than 250 readers wrote in with some very thoughtful assessments of this patient’s problem. Remarkably, 70 readers were able to make the diagnosis.

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 1
abstract: VFiles celebrates at Bow, and Richard Chai parties at Mister H.
lead_paragraph: VFiles celebrates at Bow, and Richard Chai parties at Mister H.

headline: Photos of The Moment | General Idea
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 8
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including an Austrian’s celebration on a home ski course.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including an Austrian’s celebration on a home ski course.

headline: Do We Detect a Bit of a Chill?
abstract: Party veterans grumbled about several holes in the week’s calendar: no new hot spots, no secret bashes. Luckily, there were still some exclusive invitations to choose from.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the killer flu, the snowstorm or the decision by Marc Jacobs to delay his show to the last day. Whatever was to blame, New York Fashion Week doesn’t seem to be living up to the hard-nosed partying for which it is known.

headline: Clip: ‘Like Someone in Love’
abstract: A scene from “Like Someone in Love,” directed by Abbas Kiarostami.
lead_paragraph: A scene from “Like Someone in Love,” directed by Abbas Kiarostami.

headline: Jason Wu: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tunisia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Tunisia, Bangladesh, Georgia and West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Tunisia, Egypt, Bangladesh and Georgia.

headline: Master of Illusions Faces His Own Mirage
abstract: The Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami challenges himself, filming in another country using actors with whom he can’t communicate directly.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami is no stranger to the possibility of misunderstanding. You might even say that he courts the creative potential of not knowing all the facts.

headline: On TV, an Everyday Muslim as Everyday American
abstract: An advertisement featuring a Muslim portrays him not as a security risk, but as an appealing, everyday American.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday afternoon several months ago, I was engaged in one of my favorite religious rituals, watching pro football on television. During a break in the game, I reflexively clicked the “mute” button on the remote control. But my eyes stayed fixed on a startling commercial.

headline: Brooklyn College Protest
abstract: Pro-Palestinian speakers drew anger and support over a talk by the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement at Brooklyn College. The group calls for sanctions on Israel.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Palestinian speakers drew anger and support over a talk by the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement at Brooklyn College. The group calls for sanctions on Israel.

headline: Updates on the Winter Storm
abstract: Updates on the winter storm bearing down on the East Coast on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the day on Friday, which for many was a rainy, sloshy mess, New Yorkers salted sidewalks, stocked up on supplies and lined up at gas stations to fill their tanks, as local authorities from New York City to Maine activated their plans to battle the snow as it began to pile up.

headline: Latecomer in Mayor Race Has Business Titans’ Buzz
abstract: In Joseph J. Lhota’s Republican campaign for New York mayor, he faces the disadvantages of a late start, low name recognition and a huge Democratic registration edge.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth G. Langone, the billionaire co-founder of Home Depot, has pledged his financial backing. Peter S. Kalikow, the real estate investor, has cut a big check. And James S. Tisch, the chief executive of the Loews Corporation, is on board.

headline: Orchestrating Each Grammy Detail
abstract: Ken Ehrlich brings young and old (and sometimes new) artists to a show that is a labyrinth of logistics, creating what some call “Grammy moments.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Something was wrong with the video playing behind the R&B singer Frank Ocean as he rehearsed this week for Sunday’s Grammy Awards. The video was projected on a screen behind Mr. Ocean and onto a three-sided box around the keyboard in front of him, creating the surreal illusion that he was running down a desert road while he sang. But the images were slightly out of sync with the recorded track over which Mr. Ocean vocalized: his torso and his legs didn’t quite line up. Rather than dreamy, the effect was disjointed.

headline: Ferrari Museum Honors Sergio Pininfarina
abstract: The exhibit, at Ferrari’s museum in Maranello, Italy, runs through Feb. 24.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the classic partnerships in automotive history: Two Italian nameplates, Ferrari and Pininfarina, automaker and design house, have long been associated with cars that many enthusiasts consider to be the greatest sports machines ever made.

headline: Yigal Azrouël: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: One Prism on the Undoing of Pinochet
abstract: “No,” the Chilean entry in this year’s foreign-film race of the Academy Awards, has received critical praise — but also plain criticism in its home nation.
lead_paragraph: The blunt title of “No,” directed by Pablo Larraín and one of the five nominees for best foreign-language film in this year’s Academy Awards, refers to an inspiring moment in the history of Chile, his native land. In a straight up-or-down, yes-or-no plebiscite there in 1988, the citizenry ended the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet by voting him out of power, 15 years after he had seized control in a bloody American-backed coup.

headline: A Detour on the Road to an Electric Future
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: A small municipal electric provider in Connecticut says its experience with electric vehicles leaves room for skepticism.
lead_paragraph: When I embarked on a test of Tesla’s new East Coast electric vehicle charging network, I did not expect to become a rate-paying customer of Norwich Public Utilities, a small municipal electric provider in Norwich, Conn. But my Tesla Model S was running dangerously low on juice and I needed a quick fill-up to make it to the Tesla Supercharger station in Milford, Conn., about 60 miles away.

headline: To Earth, Seeking Goodness
abstract: Taylor Mac and Lisa Kron are among the cast of the Foundry Theater’s production of Brecht’s “Good Person of Szechwan,” at La MaMa.
lead_paragraph: A small fire broke out during a preview performance of the Foundry Theater’s enchanting production of Bertolt Brecht’s “Good Person of Szechwan.” Alarms clanged; the actors stood still. Eventually performers and audience members dutifully trooped out of the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa, to return only after a small phalanx of firefighters had clomped in and out.

headline: Blizzards as Teachers
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Weather']
abstract: Lessons slowly learned from blizzards past.
lead_paragraph: Watching the snowfall forecasts from the potent blizzard sweeping into the Northeast (we’re at the western edge of the robin’s egg 12-24 inches zone), I can’t help but think back to March, 2010, when we lost power for five days after the Hudson Valley and other regions were paralyzed by several feet of snow. Here’s a look back at my ridiculously inefficient effort to keep the toilets flushing by melting heaps of snow on the propane stove:

lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week, ranging from the New York City Ballet to a performance by Mumford & Sons.

abstract: Grand Central Terminal set the scene last night for T’s celebration of Deborah Needleman’s inaugural issue.
