headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 8
abstract: Subjects include the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, repairs to the Rockaway Boardwalk and an increase in the number of rats in New York City since Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, repairs to the Rockaway Boardwalk and an increase in the number of rats in New York City since Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Ira Rubin, Champion Bridge Player, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Rubin learned bridge, in German, at 9 from a group of refugees in Lake Placid, N.Y..
lead_paragraph: Ira Rubin, one of the world’s greatest bridge players, died on Wednesday in Edison, N.J., after a long illness. He was 82.

headline: John Ford’s Portraits of Loss and Redemption
abstract: Two John Ford films reappear in new Blu-ray editions: “How Green Was My Valley” and “The Quiet Man.”
lead_paragraph: One film is a devastating study of loss — of a family destroyed, a romance interrupted and an idyllic, rural community obliterated by industrialization and corporate greed. The other is an uplifting fantasy of a traditional community that continues to thrive by resisting modern encroachments, of a magnificent couple born out of conflict, and of a broken man who finds redemption by escaping the past and embracing the present.

headline: Steak au Poivre Makes a Comeback
abstract: At Ma Maison Brasserie in Millburn, N.J., a pungent steak au poivre and a light noix de Saint-Jacques are among the reasonably priced entrees.
lead_paragraph: When I was young, French dining reigned; if you wanted to eat fancy, you ate French. Then the restaurant landscape changed dramatically, and French restaurants, whether classic or more casual, became increasingly rare. That was one reason the opening of Ma Maison Brasserie in downtown Millburn in July generated so much enthusiasm. Another was that its chef and owner, Franco Ammirati, also owns the town’s beloved Café Luna, an intimate Italian-style restaurant with a distinctive European feel.

headline: The Show Goes on, Despite Showstopper Choruses in All Those Tunes
abstract: Chita Rivera, Joel Grey, Marin Mazzie and Jason Danieley sang on Wednesday in a Kander and Ebb tribute at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The vamp, an insistent musical motif that signals an imminent stampede, is a Broadway songwriting convention that the team of John Kander and Fred Ebb wielded with special force to announce the arrival of an imminent showstopper. Think of the instrumental tease that starts spreading the news in “New York, New York.” It is a shot of adrenaline that brings audience members to their feet, wired to sing along the instant the tune begins. Those who don’t heed the message had better get out of the way.

headline: A Comedian as Artist
abstract: A lesser-known persona of Andy Kaufman — stand-up innovator, satirist and cult figure — is on view in “Creating Reality, by Andy Kaufman.”
lead_paragraph: When Andy Kaufman, the entertainer, so-called anti-comic and Elvis impersonator extraordinaire, died in 1984 at 35, he left behind two very distinct if connected personas.

headline: Life Inside an Oil Boom
abstract: The photographer Alec Soth and the filmmaker Isaac Gale collaborated on a short film while Soth was on assignment in North Dakota.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 8
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: New York Teams Sign Spanish Players
abstract: On Friday, the Red Bulls signed Ruben Izquierdo, and the Cosmos signed Ayoze.
lead_paragraph: On a day when a comically named winter storm slammed the New York metropolitan area, leave it to two local soccer teams to remind fans of warmer days ahead.

headline: Not Always Fun and Games
keywords: ['Toys', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Children and Childhood', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Games', 'Gun Control', 'Firearms']
abstract: In light of the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School, foam-dart guns have some parents mulling what to say when their children reach for the toy holster.
lead_paragraph: Walk into Walmart and you can usually find it: an aisle of weaponry, with names like the Firestrike, Rampage and Hail-Fire, advertising quick firing, ammunition clips and “semi-auto” capability. “Build your arsenal!” read the box for one, sitting next to a “tactical vest” meant to repel barrages of ... foam darts.

headline: When Is a Gym More Than a Gym? When It’s a Brand
abstract: Candles, scarves, nail polish — non-workout accessories and even skin care are being offered along with a fitness routine.
lead_paragraph: When Jaime Gleicher travels, she likes her room to smell like home. So she brings a $42 grapefruit-scented candle from the place she considers her second one: SoulCycle, the group cycling chain.

headline: Video: Protests at Brooklyn College
abstract: Pro-Palestinian speakers drew anger and support over a talk at Brooklyn College by members of the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement. The group calls for sanctions on Israel.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Palestinian speakers drew anger and support over a talk at Brooklyn College by members of the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement. The group calls for sanctions on Israel. A video captured the scene as protesters gathered at the event.

headline: In These Ballets, There’s Nowhere for Dancers to Hide
abstract: New York City Ballet restored to repertory three Balanchine symphonic ballets that let gifted dancers shine but are unforgiving to lesser ones.
lead_paragraph: Although choreographers were using chunks of Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony to accompany story ballets back in the 1820s, dancing to entire symphonies was essentially an innovation of the 20th century. Isadora Duncan first danced to Beethoven’s Seventh in 1904; Fyodor Lopukhov choreographed “Dance Symphony” in 1923; both were controversial.

headline: Defying Boundaries of Place and Time
abstract: Brooklyn post-punk, Puerto Rican salsa and Texas bulldozer post-metal are featured in new albums.
lead_paragraph: Parquet Courts

headline: They’re From the Future, and Canada
abstract: “Continuum,” on Syfy, is a slick Canadian science-fiction drama recently imported to the United States.
lead_paragraph: SQUAMISH, British Columbia — The people behind “Continuum,” a slick Canadian science-fiction drama recently imported to the United States by Syfy, are very conscious that their growing international audience is a demanding, detail-oriented bunch. But the other day during the filming here of a Season 2 scene that had actors in a drainage tunnel with a roaring helicopter at one end, one detail was beyond anyone’s control.

headline: Oh, Baby! That Duke Sure Is a Dreamboat in the New ‘Rigoletto’
abstract: The Met production of “Rigoletto” not only is set in 1960s Las Vegas, but also pushes the boundaries of the libretto by translating seat-back titles into Rat Pack-speak.
lead_paragraph: My sights are set on a swingin’ girl,So hop on, baby, let’s take that whirl!

headline: Simple Décor, Ambitious Kitchen
abstract: Roots Bistro Gourmand offers an ambitious menu of French cuisine, nearly all of which is prepared from scratch.
lead_paragraph: Roots Bistro Gourmand  in West Islip is a spare, almost rustic-looking place with food that is anything but simple. As Philippe Corbet, one of the owners, explained in a telephone conversation after my visits, the “roots” in the name refers to the restaurant’s preparation of nearly everything, including sauces and desserts, from scratch. The bistro gourmand designation suggests that while this is a place with bistro classics like burgers and moules frites, the cooking is often more ambitious.

headline: A Merlot That May Best Its Precursor
abstract: Bedell Cellars’ 2010 merlot, a highlight of a recent sampling of four of the winery’s releases, may ultimately outshine the 2009.
lead_paragraph: It seems possible that the 2010 merlot from Bedell Cellars, in Cutchogue, may ultimately outshine the charming 2009 merlot, which was served at the Congressional lunch in the Capitol after President Obama’s public inauguration last month. The reason: many producers consider 2010 the most outstanding grape-growing season in the 40-year-old Long Island wine industry’s history.

headline: Fans Have Their Say, Loudly, After U.S. Loss
abstract: If Jurgen Klinsmann has spent any time on the Internet since his team’s 2-1 loss to Honduras on Wednesday, he has most likely encountered passionate — even outraged — fans of the United States national team.
lead_paragraph: Jurgen Klinsmann does not tolerate complacency — in his players, in the news media and even within the United States national team’s fan base. He said as much last June, after the United States defeated Antigua & Barbuda, 3-1, in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Lew’s Cayman Islands Fund a Likely Issue at Confirmation Hearings
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As recently as 2010, Jack Lew, President Obama’s nominee to be the next Treasury secretary, had $56,000 invested in a CitiGroup venture capital fund based in the Cayman Islands.
lead_paragraph: As recently as 2010, Jack Lew, President Obama‘s nominee to be the next secretary of the Treasury, had $56,000 invested in a CitiGroup venture capital fund based in the Cayman Islands’ notorious Ugland House, a building whose mailboxes are home to nearly 19,000 corporate entities, many of them tax shelters.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire
abstract: And if the snow buries our, our neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: I’m in New York, there’s a blizzard warning, so if ever there was a time for this …

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 8
abstract: Subjects include the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, repairs to the Rockaway Boardwalk and an increase in the number of rats in New York City since Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, repairs to the Rockaway Boardwalk, and an increase in the number of rats in New York City since Hurricane Sandy.

headline: The Secret Art of George W. Bush
abstract: Thanks to a hacker’s worming his way into the computer of the 43rd president’s sister, W. turns out to be a serious amateur painter.
lead_paragraph: W. paints! Who would have thought it? Thanks to a hacker known as Guccifer who wormed into the computer of the 43rd president’s sister, the world has learned that George W. Bush is an amateur – I would say serious amateur – painter. He may be some people’s least favorite president since Hoover, but as an artist he is, well, a heck of a lot better than any number of world leaders whose names spring to mind, foremost Winston Churchill and Adolf Hitler.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bush Hacking, and Online Gambling From New Jersey
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include Bluefin Labs’ genesis in a study of how a baby learned language, an indicator of the profitability of smartphone makers and a Web site that allows online tracking of plows in New York City during the big snowstorm.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: ‘Pump Boys’ Won’t Open On Broadway This Season
abstract: Producers cite a “crowded landscape” on Broadway for the decision to postpone the revival of the 1981 country music-themed musical.
lead_paragraph: Producers for the revival of “Pump Boys and Dinettes” announced late Friday that the show’s Broadway opening, scheduled for April 8, had been postponed indefinitely.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Jason Wu
abstract: Bold sapphire-hued eye makeup experienced a resurgence on the spring 2013 runways, and it looks like Jason Wu is still feeling blue for fall.
lead_paragraph: Bold sapphire-hued eye makeup experienced a resurgence on the spring 2013 runways, and it looks like Jason Wu is still feeling blue for fall. At his show earlier today, the makeup team, led by Diane Kendal, decked out models’ eyelids in a stunning indigo shade — a limited-edition eye shadow from his forthcoming cosmetics collaboration with Lancôme (available this September). “There’s a beautiful purplish-blue dress in the finale of the show, and Jason wanted to tie in that color with all the girls,” Kendal explains. The rest of the face was kept muted: a touch of foundation on the skin, a light sweep of rosy-pink blush on the apples of the cheeks, and nude lips topped off with lip balm. “The neutral elements of the face make the bright blue eyes look modern instead of retro,” Kendal says. “The eye shadow has a feathery effect to it as well, so the edges are softer — not as harsh as in years past.”

headline: Birth Control and Religious Freedom
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Responses from the American Civil Liberties Union, the National Organization for Women, New York City chapter, a Catholic priest and Catholics for Choice.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Dog’s Turn to Die

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cause Found for Blackout in Big Game
abstract: A relay installed to protect the Superdome from a cable failure has been identified as the culprit for the darkness that fell over the stadium in the third quarter Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The power failure that plunged the Super Bowl into darkness and halted play for more than a half-hour Sunday was caused by a device installed specifically to prevent a blackout.

headline: Clinical Trials to Determine the Safety of Drugs
abstract: Readers react to an Op-Ed essay saying that many studies are never made public.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Bad Deal With Uzbekistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A reader says leaving military supplies there is risky.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Christina Applegate Leaves ‘Up All Night’
abstract: Ms. Applegate announced Friday she has decided to quit the series on NBC rather than continue in a new format, which will transform the comedy from a single camera filmed show, to one filmed on tape in front of a studio audience.
lead_paragraph: NBC appears to be moving ahead with its revamped edition of the comedy “Up All Night,” despite losing not only the original creator of the series, Emily Spivey, and its most recent show-running producer, Tucker Cawley, but as of Friday, also its star, Christina Applegate.

headline: Wanted: Six Smiling Robbery Suspects
abstract: The police are looking for the women who stole a phone from one victim and an iPod from another near a Far Rockaway shopping center last month.
lead_paragraph: Six young women are being sought by the police for a robbery in Far Rockaway, Queens.

headline: The Storm on Instagram
abstract: A selection of Instagram photos submitted by readers of scenes from the winter storm in the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: A selection of Instagram photos submitted by readers of scenes from the winter storm in the Northeast.

headline: Women in Combat: Policy Catches Up With Reality
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: In the military, the roles of women and gays have been closely associated.
lead_paragraph: AT his confirmation hearing on Jan. 31, Chuck Hagel, President Obama’s nominee for defense secretary, stated unequivocally, “I will work with the service chiefs as we officially open combat positions to women, a decision I strongly support.”

headline: Can Big Data From Epic Indian Pilgrimage Help Save Lives?
abstract: A team of doctors, epidemiologists and quantitative analysts are at the Kumbh Mela, a gathering of up to 100 million religious pilgrims in India, to study when, where and how they fall ill. The data will be used to build new ways of measuring epidemics among large transient populations.
lead_paragraph: Big data, meet humanity.

headline: Personal Statement
abstract: Maryam Nassir Zadeh brings her eclectic sensibilty to a new collection of women’s wear at her namesake Lower East Side emporium.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: How the Post Office Made America
abstract: Do we want the mail to remain a vital American institution in the digital age?
lead_paragraph: THE Postal Service’s announcement that it plans to end Saturday mail delivery reminds us of its vulnerability to the technological convulsions of the information age. The agency lost nearly $16 billion last year; stopping Saturday delivery, starting in August, would save about $2 billion a year. To preserve the letter of the law, which requires six-day service, the agency would continue Saturday parcel delivery — a shrewd decision, since, thanks to booming e-commerce, the parcel business is one of the few sectors that is actually growing.

headline: Making a Child, Minus the Couple
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: People who are single yet wish to have biological children are increasingly turning to nonromantic co-parenting arrangements.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Hope is 5-foot-9 and likes yoga, dance and martial arts. A real estate developer and freelance writer in Los Angeles, Ms. Hope, 41, is seeking a man who lives near her, is healthy and fit, and “has his financial stuff together,” she said. Parker Williams, the 42-year-old founder of QTheory, a charity auction company also in Los Angeles, would seem like a good candidate. A 6-foot-2 former model who loves animals, Mr. Williams is athletic, easygoing, compassionate and organized.

headline: Off The Runway: Day 2
abstract: Scenes from day two of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from day two of New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Archbishop Rebukes the Cardinal
abstract: Cardinal Roger Mahony’s removal was necessary after newly released records revealed a cover-up, but it wasn’t sufficient.
lead_paragraph: It was an extraordinary moment in Catholic Church history — the rebuke of Cardinal Roger Mahony by his successor in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles following fresh documentation of the hierarchy’s cover-up of the rape and abuse of children by priests. Cardinal Mahony, two years into retirement, was unceremoniously relieved of all public duties last month by Archbishop José Gomez, who described “brutal and painful” records of “evil” deeds during the Mahony years.

headline: Alabama: Suit Seeks to Stop Naming of Immigrants
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Illegal Immigrants']
abstract: A coalition of civil rights groups have filed a lawsuit to stop Alabama from publishing the names of all illegal immigrants arrested in the state.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of civil rights groups have filed a lawsuit to stop Alabama from publishing the names of all illegal immigrants arrested in the state. The suit was filed on Thursday on behalf of two men and two women who were arrested on charges of fishing without a license, a misdemeanor. Alabama’s immigration law requires the State Department of Homeland Security to publish an online database of illegal immigrants who are charged with any crimes. The Web site has not yet been created. Lawyers with the American Civil Liberties Union, the Southern Poverty Law Center and the National Immigration Law Center said the site amounted to a “black list” from which individuals had no way to remove their names.

headline: Drones, Brennan and Obama’s Legacy of Secrecy
abstract: The U.S. administration makes all the right noises about transparency and respecting the rule of law. But the secrecy surrounding its drone program leaves a different impression, as John Brennan’s hearing this week confirmed.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — John O. Brennan’s testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday was representative of the Obama administration’s approach to counter-terrorism: right-sounding assurances with little transparency.

headline: Blue-Ribbon Day With Outfit to Match
abstract: Karolina Kurkova, a model and coach on Oxygen’s new reality show, “The Face,” says that she does not have just one look.
lead_paragraph: Karolina Kurkova, 28, has been posing for cameras since she was 15, experience that comes in handy for her latest role as a coach on Oxygen’s new reality show for would-be supermodels, “The Face,” which makes its debut Feb. 12. Ms. Kurkova, born in Decin, Czech Republic, is now living in Manhattan and Fisher Island, Fla. She is married to Archie Drury, a film producer.

headline: A Psychic’s Legal Problems Grow, Perhaps Not Unforeseeably
keywords: ['Fortune Telling', 'Psychics and Psychic Phenomena', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: In her latest brush with the law, Sylvia Mitchell, a New York fortuneteller, stands accused of cheating a woman out of more than $120,000.
lead_paragraph: Police officers and psychics more or less stay out of each other’s way in New York City. But an entire cottage industry of law enforcement has grown up around the 38-year-old fortuneteller and evil-spirit exterminator Sylvia Mitchell, and it was on full display in Manhattan Criminal Court this week.

headline: Demonstrators Attack Allies of Georgian President, Injuring at Least 5
abstract: At least five lawmakers from the party of President Mikheil Saakashvili were reported injured after an angry crowd of protesters attacked in Tbilisi.

headline: California: Sheriff’s Deputies in Clique to Be Fired
abstract: The Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department moved to fire seven deputies who are accused of being part of a group that allegedly celebrated aggressive tactics and shootings.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department moved to fire seven deputies who are accused of being part of a secret internal group known as the Jump Out Boys, which allegedly celebrated aggressive tactics and shootings. Sheriff Leroy D. Baca began the termination process against the deputies this week after reviewing results of an internal affairs investigation. The deputies can appeal the firings to the state’s civil service board. While investigators did not find any criminal behavior by the group, officials have recently begun to discipline such cliques because of concerns that they encourage unethical, ganglike and violent behavior and hurt the department’s reputation, particularly in black and Latino neighborhoods. A pamphlet explaining the group’s creed said members were “not afraid to get our hands dirty,” according to The Los Angeles Times, which first reported on the group’s existence. The seven deputies were removed from duty with pay last year, officials said.

headline: Innovation Nation at War
abstract: Can one federal judge put a stop to the dumb smartphone patent battles?
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO

headline: Fitness for Office
abstract: How do we measure a good governor? Some people seem to think physical fitness and waist size is a good place to start.
lead_paragraph: Our topic for today is: How much do we care about physical fitness in an elected official?

headline: Power Plays Rising as Referees Show Less Tolerance, Even Late in Games
abstract: Three weeks into a compressed season, N.H.L. teams are averaging a combined 8.4 power-play opportunities per game, compared with 6.6 last year, with fighting up.
lead_paragraph: Devils defenseman Andy Greene has never been a hockey scofflaw. So after his team lost an early-season game against the Montreal Canadiens, he complained about the hooking penalty he received in the last minute of overtime that set up the winning power-play goal.

headline: Report Faults U.S. Use of Mexican Battery Recyclers
keywords: ['Lead', 'Batteries', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: An environmental agency’s report says United States companies send spent lead batteries to recycling plants in Mexico that do not meet American standards.
lead_paragraph: United States companies are sending spent lead batteries to recycling plants in Mexico that do not meet American environmental standards, according to an environmental agency created under the North American Free Trade Agreement, putting Mexican communities at risk.

headline: A Hunter’s Menu Served With Colonial Charm
abstract: Adrienne Fine American Dining offers venison, rabbit, quail and pheasant, with slight cosmopolitan touches, in an 18th-century building with broad plank floorboards and numerous fireplaces.
lead_paragraph: Having perfected her cooking during stints in Hawaii; Manhattan; New Orleans; Phoenix; Santa Fe, N.M.; and Telluride, Colo., Adrienne Sussman, the owner and chef of Adrienne Fine American Dining, settled in New Milford in 1996, largely because she found an eighteenth-century building there that could house her restaurant and herself. “One of the reasons I’m still surviving in this economy is I can live upstairs,” Ms. Sussman said.

headline: Nursing Home Plans Riverdale Apartments; Some Neighbors Opposed
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Nursing Homes', 'Elder Care']
abstract: The Hebrew Home plans a 300-unit “continuing-care retirement community,” but some northern Bronx residents fear it would mean noise, traffic and impaired views.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of amenities offered by New York City apartment buildings, from wine cellars to rock-climbing walls and even private spas for pets.

headline: Newspaper Wrestles With M.L.B.’s Request for Documents
abstract: Commissioner Bud Selig dispatched two of his top advisers to Miami to ask the editor of a weekly newspaper to share documents that reportedly link a number of player to performance enhancers.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of George J. Mitchell’s damning report in 2007 on doping in baseball, Commissioner Bud Selig created a department of investigations to serve as Major League Baseball’s police unit.

headline: Shooting Suspect’s Racism Allegations Resound for Some
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Whatever the changes since the days of rampant racism and corruption at the Los Angeles Police Department, an alleged killer’s charges — however unhinged — have struck a chord.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For the Los Angeles Police Department, the allegations of departmental corruption and racism by a former police officer now accused of a revenge-fueled killing rampage are the words of a delusional man, detached from the reality of the huge improvements the force has undergone over the years.

headline: Timothy White’s Photography
abstract: In a career that spans three decades, Mr. White has photographed Harrison Ford, Sophia Loren, Audrey Hepburn, Paul McCartney, Axl Rose, Whitney Houston and many more.  Here are some examples.
lead_paragraph: In a career that spans three decades, Mr. White has photographed Harrison Ford, Sophia Loren, Audrey Hepburn, Paul McCartney, Axl Rose, Whitney Houston and many more.  Here are some examples.

headline: Have Banter, Will Travel
abstract: At 57, the photographer Timothy White is adding a new subject to his portfolio: his parents.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, after meeting on the set of “Mr. and Mrs. Smith,” Timothy White and Brad Pitt went on a five-day motorcycle ride in the Mojave Desert. The adventure was partly for fun (both love bikes) and partly for work (Mr. White took along a stylist, racks of clothes and two assistants, who followed in a Winnebago for a photo shoot).

headline: A Growing App Lets You See It, Then You Don’t
abstract: The photos and messages sent through an app called Snapchat vanish in seconds. And that disappearing act has made the tiny start-up a technology hit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The ephemeral now has value, at least for users of cellphones.

headline: Artisanal Food, and Beer Made Downstairs
abstract: Peekskill Brewery recently moved to a larger riverfront location, and its restaurant and brewery each have their own floor.
lead_paragraph: When I first reviewed Peekskill Brewery, in 2008, it had recently opened on the Peekskill riverfront. A leader of the booming gastro pub trend, it had a great burger, delicious bratwurst and an impressive lineup of craft beers. But what gave it an extra edge was a less common offering: its own beer, made on the premises.

headline: Debating a Court to Vet Drone Strikes
keywords: ['Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Some want to apply the model of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court, which reviews eavesdropping on American soil, to the targeted killings of terrorism suspects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since 1978, a secret court in Washington has approved national security eavesdropping on American soil — operations that for decades had been conducted based on presidential authority alone.

headline: Trial of 2 Liu Supporters Is Set in Campaign Fund-Raising Case
abstract: Proceedings were delayed because one of the defendants, Xing Wu Pan, had been “involuntarily committed” to a hospital.
lead_paragraph: The trial of two allies of the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, will start on April 15, a judge said Friday after ruling that one defendant, now in the hospital, was competent to stand trial.

headline: Bringing Ultra-Orthodox Traditions to Israel’s Parliament, Olive Branch in Hand
abstract: Dov Lipman is both an ultra-Orthodox rabbi and a newly elected member of Parliament who is hoping to help bridge the divisions between the secular and ultra-Orthodox in Israel.
lead_paragraph: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel

headline: Bill Cunningham | Shape Shift
abstract: As New York Fashion Week opened, women seemed to be making a silhouette statement, adding to the mystery of where fashion will go as the collections unfold.
lead_paragraph: As New York Fashion Week opened, women seemed to be making a silhouette statement, adding to the mystery of where fashion will go as the collections unfold.

headline: Boy Scouts Say Gay Debate Was Ignited by a Leak
abstract: Early word of a proposal to end a national ban on gay members thwarted the executive board’s plan to discuss the matter quietly, leading to a delay, leaders said.
lead_paragraph: A leak from inside the Boy Scouts of America last month about discussions on possibly ending the group’s national ban on gay members changed the debate itself by creating an impression that change was imminent, according to scouting officials and taped comments from a meeting of scouting’s executive board obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Teacher’s Aide Admits Making Pornographic Video of a Student
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Pornography', 'Education (K-12)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Child Pornography']
abstract: Taleek Brooks, who worked at Public School 23 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, faces 15 to 50 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A teacher’s aide at a public school in Brooklyn who was accused last year of making videos of a child performing sex acts in classrooms pleaded guilty on Friday to federal child-pornography charges.

headline: Survivors’ Stories of Abuse, Sewn Tight
abstract: The Human Rights Institute Gallery at Kean University has on view through May 10 an exhibition of 20 quilts made from survivors of human rights abuses around the world.
lead_paragraph: Art exhibitions with a human rights theme can be “really depressing — kind of in-your-face and gruesome,” said Neil Tetkowski, director of university galleries at Kean University in Union.

headline: Mississippi: State Health Exchange Is Disallowed
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Obama administration will not allow Mississippi to run its own health insurance exchange because of a disagreement between the state’s governor and insurance commissioner.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration will not allow Mississippi to run its own health insurance exchange because of a disagreement between Gov. Phil Bryant and Mike Chaney, the state’s insurance commissioner. Mr. Chaney had been planning a state-based exchange over the objections of Mr. Bryant, a fellow Republican. But federal officials decided it was not feasible without Mr. Bryant’s cooperation. The alternatives are for the federal government to run an exchange for Mississippi or to run one jointly with the state. President Obama’s health care law requires all states to have exchanges — online markets where people can shop for private health insurance and seek federal subsidies to help pay for it — by January 2014.

headline: Reversing Course on Reports About a Classic
abstract: Reports before the release of “The Pride of the Yankees” said the film had been flipped to make Gary Cooper resemble the left-handed Lou Gehrig. A researcher isn’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: Before the release of “The Pride of the Yankees,” the 1942 biographical film about Lou Gehrig, there were reports that movie magic had been needed to solve a critical problem: making Gary Cooper, a right-handed movie star who was definitely not a ballplayer, into a credible version of the left-handed Gehrig, a Hall of Fame slugger with a .340 career batting average.

headline: Left Behind Meets Upwardly Mobile in Boston
abstract: “Good People,” by David Lindsay-Abaire, who grew up in South Boston, is a study in character and class, and the mouthing-off sounds authentic.
lead_paragraph: David Lindsay-Abaire’s plays, whether wacky or heartbreaking in their particulars, often focus on a woman facing adversity. “Fuddy Meers” was a funny romp with a chronic amnesiac, while the Pulitzer Prize-winning drama “Rabbit Hole” observed a suburban mother mourning a dead child.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: Fall 2013 Menswear
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: After Just Two Episodes, NBC Cancels ‘Do No Harm’
abstract: The premiere a week ago attracted the fewest viewers ever of any new network drama in a regular season — just 3.1 million.
lead_paragraph: After drawing two of the smallest viewing audiences in network history, the new NBC drama “Do No Harm” will not get a third try. NBC announced late Friday that it is cancelling the show, which was a retelling of the Dr. Jeykll and Mr. Hyde tale.

headline: Nicole Miller: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The Daily Shoe | Tabitha Simmons
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Today’s pick: Tabitha Simmons’s wintry ivy heel.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Venezuela Devalues Currency by a Third Amid Shortages and Inflation
abstract: The devaluation will set the bolívar at 6.3 instead of 4.3 to the dollar. The expected move was aimed at solidifying government finances and easing a tight market for dollars.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela announced Friday that it was devaluing its currency, a step that had long been deemed necessary but could push the spiking inflation even higher.

headline: Mr. Menendez’s Ethics Problem
abstract: The New Jersey senator’s dealings with a major Florida donor raise serious concerns about misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez was never a distinguished choice for chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the position he ascended to this month by virtue of seniority. Concerns about that quality gap have sharply escalated amid new disclosures about Mr. Menendez’s use of his position to advance the financial interests of a friend and big donor. Instead of trying to protect Mr. Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, needs to remove his gavel, at least pending credible resolution by the Senate Ethics Committee of the swirling accusations of misconduct.

headline: Rag & Bone: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Rejected by Sotheby’s, Florida Pastor Is Arrested in New York Over Sale of Counterfeit Art
abstract: The police arrested the pastor after they were notified by the auction house that the works he was trying to sell by the British artist Damien Hirst were forgeries.
lead_paragraph: To hear Damien Hirst’s critics tell it, his works may be among the easiest to duplicate in the art world.

headline: A Look at Turkey’s Past Gives Some Insight Into Its Unresolved Troubles
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Photography', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A photo exhibition on the political turbulence in Turkey during the 1970s and ’80s resonates with the suicide bombing of the American embassy in Ankara last week.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Two galleries in this city’s old European quarter recently opened exhibitions that showcase the political violence that convulsed the country in the 1970s. The echoes for contemporary Turkey were unmistakable.

headline: An Assassination in Tunisia
abstract: Hopes of a democratic future are shaken after the murder of an outspoken critic of the governing party.
lead_paragraph: Tunisia is where the Arab Spring began just over two years ago. Until now it has set an encouraging example of progress toward democracy and pluralism. Free elections brought to power a coalition government pledged to pragmatic cooperation between a moderate-led Islamist party, Ennahda, and smaller, secular coalition partners.

headline: Holiday Parking
abstract: The Asian Lunar New Year has prompted a suspension of New York City street-cleaning rules.
lead_paragraph: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Sunday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Preppy Style and Joe Flacco at the Tommy Hilfiger Show
abstract: There was a snow delay at Tommy Hilfiger’s men’s show on Park Avenue on Friday evening as many editors were slogging their way uptown from the previous show in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: There was a snow delay at Tommy Hilfiger’s men’s show on Park Avenue on Friday evening as many editors were slogging their way uptown from the previous show in Chelsea. So those who arrived on time were faced with an enormous and elaborate set design that made it seem as if they were walking into Mr. Hilfiger’s library (only the books lining the walls at a height of two stories were part of a mural, so there was nothing to read but the program).

headline: Views of Intolerance in Many Forms
abstract: The exhibition, “Hidden and Forbidden: Art and Objects of Intolerance; Evolving Depictions of Blacks in America,” starts with a section on slavery and ends on a more hopeful note.
lead_paragraph: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — A new exhibition at the Suffolk County Historical Society includes objects and images that “are rarely or never seen in a museum,” said Kathryn Curran, executive director of the society.

headline: Suspect in Botched Shooting Bought Gun Legally Despite Mental Illness
keywords: ['School Shootings', 'Gun Control', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Teachers at Ashley Hall in Charleston, S.C., remained on edge, trying to grasp how Alice Boland, a woman with a public history of mental illness, managed to buy a gun a week earlier.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The gentle pace of life on the campus of Ashley Hall, South Carolina’s only all-girls preparatory school, appeared to be back on Friday. Parents lined up in the shade of the live oaks to pick up their children. A luncheon for alumnae of the school, which was founded in 1909, went on as planned.

headline: Improper Efforts to Limit Competitive Drugs
abstract: States should not move to limit access to biosimilar drugs before the F.D.A. has issued final safety guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Two big biotechnology companies, Amgen and Genentech, are lobbying state legislatures to limit competition to their biological drugs that will lose patent protection in the next several years. Before taking any action, lawmakers should wait for guidance from the Food and Drug Administration, the agency that reviews all drugs and their generic versions for safety and effectiveness.

headline: Jason Wu Moves to the Grown-Up Table
abstract: A fashion review of the first New York Fashion Week fall 2013 showings, including Jason Wu, Richard Chai, Rachel Comey and Creatures of the Wind.
lead_paragraph: Jason Wu said he never gave the storm much thought. “What could we do?” he asked before his show on Thursday in a Park Avenue church. “We didn’t have a contingency plan.” In fact, looking around at the hairdressers and models backstage, you’d think it was a normal scene.

headline: Being Thom Browne: His Moment Is Now
abstract: For almost a decade, the idiosyncratic designer has been a force within the fashion world but little-known outside it. That changed on Jan. 21.
lead_paragraph: “Do you know this man? Do you know who he is?” Julian Niccolini, the irrepressible co-owner and the host of the Four Seasons said one late January evening. Standing beside a corner banquette in the Grill Room — the prime power seat in a restaurant that, fully 54 years after Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson designed it, has yielded none of its luster to time — Mr. Niccolini put his hand on the shoulder of a shy, smallish man with a lantern jaw, a John Glenn crew cut and a suit that looked as though the laundry had shrunk it with him inside.

headline: More on Guns, With Readers
abstract: It’s fair to ask: what rough beast is gnawing at America’s soul?
lead_paragraph: It’s happened again. I’m impressed by my readers.

headline: Seizure of Antiaircraft Missiles in Yemen Raises Fears That Iran Is Arming Rebels There
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: These missiles, never before seen in the hands of militants, would threaten military and commercial aviation and mark an escalation in illegal arms trafficking in the Arabian Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: Photographs recently released by the Yemeni government suggest that an interdiction last month by the United States Navy and Yemen’s security forces seized a class of shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles not publicly known to have been out of state control.

headline: Warm Memories for Past Champions of Westminster
abstract: Away from the arena, some recent best-in-show champions acted as both friends and companions.
lead_paragraph: J. R. and Stump were retired housemates and congenial bedfellows in Houston who shared a singular distinction: each won best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: A Storm Is ‘No One,’ and Means Very Little
abstract: The Weather Channel named the Northeastern blizzard Nemo, and the Internet pictured a cute orange fish and erupted in giggles.
lead_paragraph: Humor was not The Weather Channel’s intent when it started to give names to winter storms a few months ago. But humor is what it has provided — along with no small amount of controversy.

headline: There’s No Dressing Up a Bland Start
abstract: Many designers are counting on deliveries of fabrics and samples from Europe this weekend, so the storm will mean some last-minute scrambling to get pieces made.
lead_paragraph: Many designers are counting on deliveries of fabrics and samples from Europe this weekend, so the storm will surely mean some last-minute scrambling to get pieces made (if fabrics arrive in time, that is) and eliminating other outfits altogether. Marc Jacobs moved his show from Monday to Thursday evening, but other companies won’t have that flexibility.

headline: Wanted in Officer’s Trial: Difficult-to-Shock Jurors
abstract: About 90 people who showed up for jury duty were exposed to images of cannibalism and told that, if selected, they would have to be ready to delve into “sexually violent and sexually deviant conduct.”
lead_paragraph: Have you visited Web sites like darkfetishnet.com, yumchat.com or girlsinabind.com was one of the questions on the form. Would evidence about “highly sexualized violent conduct, bondage and sadomasochism” make it difficult for you to be fair and impartial was another. The form, distributed in a Manhattan courtroom on Friday, also included an illustration showing a naked woman lashed to a spit being turned over a fire.

headline: Giving New Meaning to the Term ‘Character Actors’
abstract: Two actors play a plethora of characters in “Stones in His Pockets,” a comedy wrapped around a tragedy.
lead_paragraph: The giant screen is the first hint. It is multiplex-size, slightly tilted, spanning most of the upstage wall at the Yale Repertory Theater, showing a rich blue Irish sky at first. Then there is the AstroTurf-like floor, rising to create a little hill, representing the greenness of the Emerald Isle. There are a couple of big klieg lights and a towering movie-set crane.

headline: For Some Landlords, Real Money in the Homeless
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Homeless Persons', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: Alan Lapes, a major private operator of homeless shelters in New York City, runs them as a for-profit organization, charging the city many times what the rooms would normally rent for.
lead_paragraph: Willy Machan acknowledges he is a gadfly, someone who writes bristling letters to local officials to get conditions improved in his grim single-room-occupancy building. But he was surprised by what his landlord offered last July to persuade him to move out of the room he has lived in since 1984 and for which he pays $371 a month.

headline: Gunmen Kill Nigerian Polio Vaccine Workers in Echo of Pakistan Attacks
abstract: The killings at two clinics, with similarities to attacks that killed nine women in Pakistan, presented another setback for the global effort to eradicate polio.
lead_paragraph: At least nine polio immunization workers were shot to death in northern Nigeria on Friday by gunmen who attacked two clinics, officials said.

headline: Number of Frisks Fell in ’12, Police Data Show
abstract: The decrease came amid mounting criticism from civil-rights advocates who have argued that the practice of stop and frisk unfairly targeted minorities.
lead_paragraph: The number of times New York City police officers stopped, questioned and frisked people in 2012 dropped by 22 percent from the previous year, according to statistics the Police Department released on Friday.

headline: Knicks Hope to Get Back for Game at Garden
abstract: After visiting the Timberwolves on Friday, the Knicks are scheduled to play the Clippers on Sunday at Madison Square Garden. But weather and travel problems could intervene.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The snowstorm that hit New York and the rest of the Northeast on Friday had the Knicks thinking they might have to stay here overnight after their game with the Minnesota Timberwolves. Whether the storm jeopardizes Sunday afternoon’s scheduled game between the Knicks and the Los Angeles Clippers at Madison Square Garden depends on when airports reopen in the New York area.

lead_paragraph: There used to be a political truism: Democrats fall in love, while Republicans fall in line.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Carl Levin, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, told the committee’s top Republican on Friday that he and other Senate Republicans were out of bounds for demanding additional financial information from Chuck Hagel, President Obama’s choice to be defense secretary.

lead_paragraph: The Nets could bolster their bench scoring and loosen their frontcourt logjam under a proposed trade with the Charlotte Bobcats.

lead_paragraph: Jesse L. Jackson Jr., the former congressman who resigned last year citing ill health, has signed a plea agreement with federal prosecutors who had been investigating his possible misuse of campaign funds, a person familiar with the case said Friday.

headline: Portraits of a Continent’s Vitality, Past and Present
abstract: “Malian Portrait Photography” and “Photo-Rapide: François Deschamps” are on view at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art at the State University of New York at New Paltz through April 14.
lead_paragraph: Photography was invented in England and France at the height of the Industrial Revolution, but the 1990s brought a startling discovery to the international art world: some of the most artful portraiture ever created was produced in Africa over the last century. “Malian Portrait Photography” at the Samuel Dorsky Museum in New Paltz, N.Y., offers a small roundup of some of the newly acknowledged African masters, like Seydou Keïta and Malick Sidibé, and introduces lesser known ones like Hamidou Maïga, Abdourahmane Sakaly and Tijani Àdìgún Sitou. A companion exhibition, “Photo-Rapide: François Deschamps,” features work by Mr. Deschamps, an American photographer and SUNY New Paltz professor who lived in Mali during 2010 to 2011 on a senior research Fulbright fellowship, and extends the dialogue between African photography and contemporary practice.

headline: Nets Find Out How Much Better Wall Makes the Wizards
abstract: The turbocharged John Wall led the suddenly surging Wizards to their third straight win. They outscored the Nets, 30-11, in the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Wizards’ John Wall stepped in front of C. J. Watson near midcourt early in the second quarter to swipe a loose ball and take it the other way, the play seemed harmless enough. Turnovers happen in basketball games, and Watson watched as Wall raced in for a two-handed dunk.

headline: The Value of an Empty Beer Can
abstract: Collectors will pay thousands of dollars for some vintage beer cans.
lead_paragraph: Q. My cousin collects beer cans. (Yes, I know.) I was wondering what New York City beer can is considered the most valuable as a collectible?

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 9, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Canada: Spy for Russia Sentenced
abstract: A Canadian naval intelligence officer, who gave Russia secrets from five nations, including the United States, was sentenced to 20 years in prison on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian naval intelligence officer, who gave Russia secrets from five nations, including the United States, was sentenced to 20 years in prison on Friday. The officer, Sub-Lt. Jeffrey Paul Delisle, 41, said he began selling secrets in 2007 while distraught over marital problems. He was also fined $111,817, the amount Russia paid him. The nature of the information he sold has not been disclosed.

headline: Pretty Obvious
abstract: A crunchy Saturday by Peter Wentz.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, I just thought this one by Peter Wentz was the CAT’S MEOW. Crunchy, fun, lots of unique entries, and a few easy entries with which to grab a toehold, making this grid tough but solvable.

headline: Russia: Officer Jailed in Coup Plot
abstract: A Moscow court sentenced a former Soviet intelligence officer on Friday to 13 years in a prison colony for plotting an armed coup against the Russian government.
lead_paragraph: A Moscow court sentenced a former Soviet intelligence officer on Friday to 13 years in a prison colony for plotting an armed coup against the Russian government. The officer, Vladimir Kvachkov, a former colonel in the Soviet military intelligence service, was convicted of plotting to seize weapons from military caches and launch an attack on Moscow with a small group of ultranationalist supporters in 2010. Mr. Kvachkov told the RIA Novosti news agency shortly after his arrest that he was accused of trying to lead two groups of men armed with crossbows against government troops. He denied the charges. Earlier in 2010, he was acquitted of charges of trying to assassinate Anatoly Chubais, the architect of Russia’s unpopular market reforms, in 2005.

headline: China: Uighur Scholar Monitored
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Ilham Tohti, a scholar at a Beijing university who has been prevented from going to the United States, says that he is being closely watched by China’s security forces.
lead_paragraph: Ilham Tohti, an outspoken ethnic Uighur scholar at a Beijing university who has been prevented from going to the United States, says that he is being closely watched by China’s security forces and that his Web site has been hacked, according to a report on Thursday by Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the American government. Mr. Tohti was detained on Feb. 2 when he tried to board a flight to the United States, where he was to be a visiting scholar at Indiana University. His teenage daughter was able to board the flight and is now in the United States. Mr. Tohti was released after being questioned for eight hours. The Uighurs say they are oppressed by Chinese policies and experience discrimination from China’s dominant ethnic group.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: For a Broadway Fan, Once Is Not Enough
abstract: Aimee Kislin, an assistant store manager in New Jersey, is obsessed with Broadway shows and has seen the musical “Once” 95 times and “American Idiot” 146 times.
lead_paragraph: Aimee Kislin wears two guitar picks around her neck from her two great loves.

headline: Senegal: Trial for Chad’s Ex-Ruler
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: An internationally backed court opened on Friday in Senegal, and its judges will prepare a case against the former ruler of Chad, Hissène Habré, who has been living in exile in Senegal.
lead_paragraph: A new internationally backed court opened on Friday in Senegal, and its judges will prepare a case against the former ruler of Chad, Hissène Habré, who has been living in exile in Senegal. Three countries have indicted Mr. Habré, 70, for crimes against humanity; Chad sentenced him to death for killings and torture carried out during his rule from 1982 to 1990. Senegal’s president, Macky Sall, agreed to set up the ad hoc court in Dakar, the capital, where Mr. Habré is to be tried by African judges under Senegalese law. European countries are paying two-thirds of the court’s $10 million budget; the African Union has been criticized for paying for only 10 percent of the court’s costs.

headline: Berlusconi Remains Wild Card in Italy Race
abstract: With two weeks to go, the Italian campaign has become surreal, with former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi trailing the front-runner by single digits in recent polls.
lead_paragraph: ROME — One candidate promised to drop an unpopular new property tax and refund all prior payments in cash. Another called that proposal a “poisoned meatball,” disconnected from reality. A third suggested that Al Qaeda blow up the Italian Parliament — then backtracked — and the man generally considered the front-runner is campaigning on vague promises of stability, so has often been ignored.

headline: A Faceless Teenage Refugee Who Helped Ignite Syria’s War
abstract: A young man from Dara’a, Syria, carries a burden — maybe an honor, too: He knows that he and his friends helped start an uprising.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — In a listless border town, the teenager goes unnoticed, one of the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have fled the Syrian civil war, dashing across villages and farms to land in Jordan, just five miles from home.

lead_paragraph: The assassination of Chokri Belaid has stirred fears in Tunisia and throughout the Arab world.

lead_paragraph: Stapleton, named in 1836, is a trove of memories, political, familial and architectural.

headline: A Composer Who Talked for Hours
abstract: A review of books about Leonard Bernstein, Manhattan’s geography and the civil liberties at stake during an anti-communism purge in the early 1950s.
lead_paragraph: “Unlike almost any other classical performer of recent times, Leonard Bernstein adamantly, and sometimes controversially, refused to compartmentalize and separate his emotional, intellectual, political, erotic and spiritual longings from the musical experience,” Jonathan Cott writes in “Dinner With Lenny: The Last Long Interview with Leonard Bernstein” (Oxford University Press, $24.95).

headline: The Brewer Kings of Staten Island
abstract: Stapleton, named in 1836, is a trove of memories, political, familial and architectural.
lead_paragraph: Even before Hurricane Sandy struck, the north shore of Staten Island called out for attention and appreciation. Plans to encourage the local economy include building a 60-story Ferris wheel near the St. George Ferry Terminal and, a short walk away in Stapleton, redeveloping the old Navy Homeport site. But Stapleton remains curiously trapped in its past, with remarkable buildings and an interesting if slightly down-at-heel commercial center.

headline: Amid a Bloody War, Syrian Videos Show a Glimpse of Fun
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Music', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Two videos that show Syrian soldiers and rebels dancing and singing have provoked sharply different political reactions.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The video has gone viral in recent days: Syrian government soldiers, in camouflage gear, carrying rocket-propelled grenades and brandishing rifles, mugging for the camera while dancing in a circle to Usher’s hit song “Yeah!”

headline: After Sluggish Defense, Anthony and Knicks Deliver Rousing Comeback
abstract: The Knicks were slow in defending pick-and-rolls and trailed Minnesota by 11 in the fourth quarter, but Carmelo Anthony led a 24-7 closing run.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Knowing they would be stranded here overnight by the snowstorm in New York City, the Knicks played Friday’s game with the Minnesota Timberwolves as if determined to make their unscheduled stay as miserable as possible.

headline: Chocolate, Lollipops, Maybe Striped Bass
abstract: The chocolatier Jacques Torres uses his down time to bicycle, ride a motorcycle and fish.
lead_paragraph: The chocolatier Jacques Torres, who started Jacques Torres Chocolate in 2000 as a small factory in Dumbo with his business partner, Ken Goto, now has five shops around the city. Mr. Torres, 53, who grew up in the South of France, shares an apartment in Hell’s Kitchen with his wife, Hasty, 37, who runs a chocolate business in California; in milder weather, he spends as much time as he can on his boat, docked in Jersey City, near the Statue of Liberty. On Sundays, Mr. Torres rides his bike and his motorcycle, checks up on his shops and often cooks dinner.

headline: John E. Karlin, Who Led the Way to All-Digit Dialing, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Karlin, a Bell Labs industrial research psychologist, was also instrumental in the shortening of telephone cords and the creation of rectangular keypads for touch-tone models.
lead_paragraph: A generation ago, when the poetry of PEnnsylvania and BUtterfield was about to give way to telephone numbers in unpoetic strings, a critical question arose: Would people be able to remember all seven digits long enough to dial them?

headline: Beer and Change on Arthur Avenue
abstract: The Bronx Beer Hall is bringing craft brews and fresh faces to an Italian market that has been a Bronx mainstay.
lead_paragraph: Cousins in Yankees caps greet each other with bear hugs and banter in Italian while their wives buy chops and cheese. Customers from Westchester and Milan stroll beside bins of mushrooms, past stacks of sopressata and beneath dried peppers hanging like witnesses to the shopping rituals of the last 72 years.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 9
abstract: Deal on European budget; horse meat fears in Britain; Berlusconi surges in Italy; the unstylish coaches.
lead_paragraph: After a failed attempt to set spending targets at a summit meeting in November and in a 24-hour marathon of talks this week, European leaders finally agreed late Friday to a common budget for the next seven years. The new budget, which is slightly smaller than its predecessor — the first decrease in the European Union’s history — reflects the climate of austerity across a Continent still struggling to emerge from a crippling debt crisis. James Kanter and Andrew Higgins report from Brussels.

headline: Paul Tanner, Musician With ‘Good Vibrations,’ Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Tanner, a trombonist for Glenn Miller, played the electro-theremin for the Beach Boys and became a music educator at the University of California, Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Paul Tanner, a former trombonist for the Glenn Miller Ochestra who played an unlikely role in the history of rock ’n’ roll when, using a device he helped invent, he performed the famous electronic accompaniment on the Beach Boys’ signature recording “Good Vibrations,” died on Tuesday in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 95.

headline: John Kerr, Star of ‘Tea and Sympathy,’ Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Kerr was a Tony Award winner known for roles in the 1950s that challenged bigotry.
lead_paragraph: John Kerr, a Tony Award-winning actor who was best known for roles that challenged bigotry in the 1950s in films like “Tea and Sympathy” and “South Pacific,” and who turned down a starring movie role because of ideological differences with its subject, Charles Lindbergh, died on Feb. 2 in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: A Guide in the Darkness
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: For some parents of children with mental illnesses, navigating the warren of hospitals, insurers, courts and social services can be overwhelming. A Manhattan lawyer offers assistance.
lead_paragraph: When a life starts to unravel, where do you turn for help?

headline: After Hurricane, a New Calling for Mothers
abstract: Many former stay-at-home mothers have thrown themselves into volunteer work for the victims of Hurricane Sandy, some devoting seven days a week to the task.
lead_paragraph: God could not be everywhere, as the proverb goes, so he created mothers. Fathers misplace their children at the supermarket; mothers miraculously transform tofu to make it palatable to 3-year olds. Mothers grow indignant when the world isn’t as it should be. They carry placards and mobilize, often seeing themselves as the only custodians of sanity and efficiency left. Progressive movements through much of recent history have been testaments to the force of maternal will and tenacity.

headline: In Camp, Reading ‘Les Miserables’
abstract: Victor Hugo’s novel, published in 1862, did not go unnoticed among participants in the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Victor Hugo’s “Les Miserables” was published in 1862 and English translations of the five parts that constitute the novel began to appear in America by year’s end. Hugo had begun the sprawling novel in the 1840s, put it aside, and come back to complete it between 1860 and 1862. He was an opponent of slavery, and in 1859 defended John Brown. “Insurrection,” he said, was a “sacred duty.” In the novel, Hugo name-checked Brown in a list of celebrated revolutionaries that included Washington, Bolivar and Garibaldi. Hugo’s focus was the July Revolution of 1830, but it is possible he had the American conflict in mind when he wrote, “Civil war … What did the words mean? Was there any such thing as ‘foreign war?’ Was not all warfare between men warfare between brothers?”

headline: Storm Leaves Northeast Reeling and Digging
abstract: A midwinter storm buried several states in snow, leaving behind a debilitated region digging through plump white drifts and reeling from gale-force winds.

headline: Love and the 7:04 to White Plains
abstract: As part of the Transit Museum’s celebration of Valentine’s Day at Grand Central Terminal, Metropolitan’s Alan Feuer will be reading from his Missed Connections poetry.
lead_paragraph: As part of the Transit Museum’s celebration of Valentine’s Day at Grand Central Terminal, Metropolitan’s Alan Feuer will be reading from his Missed Connections poetry. The poems, “found” in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org, are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added. In honor of the venue, Mr. Feuer will be reading a transit-focused selection. (Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal, Thursday, Feb. 14, 6 to 8 p.m. Tickets are $10 in advance, $7 for members, $15 at the door.)

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Sundance) IN THE LOOP (2009) While giving an interview to the BBC, the British minister of international development (Tom Hollander) departs from the official line and becomes the focus of tensions between Britain and the United States as they gear up to invade a Middle Eastern country. Given a chance to backtrack, he digs himself in deeper. Peter Capaldi plays a British press officer. James Gandolfini (above, with Mimi Kennedy) is a dovish Pentagon general. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said, “The genius of ‘In the Loop,’ directed by Armando Iannucci and written by a crack team of British wits, is that it turns this mountain into a series of festering molehills.” While the film is “a highly disciplined inquiry into a very serious subject,” he added, “it is also, line by filthy line, scene by chaotic scene, by far the funniest big-screen satire in recent memory.”

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Himachal Pradesh: Heavy snowfall for three straight days in the hill state has shut down several arterial roads in the interior areas on Thursday, affecting vehicular traffic, according to an IANS report on the NDTV Web site. In Shimla, a popular holiday destination, at least 10 people, most of them tourists, were injured while walking on the slippery roads, the report said.

headline: Amid Protests, India Executes Man in ’01 Parliament Attack
abstract: Afzal Guru, a 43-year-old militant, had been convicted of conspiracy in an attack in which nine people were killed, including security officials and one journalist.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India hanged a man on Saturday who had been convicted of involvement in a 2001 attack on Parliament that killed nine people.

abstract: Bruce Springsteen uses some personal charm to raise money for indigent performers.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen was honored as the MusiCares Person of the Year at an annual concert in Los Angeles on Friday, where an all-star lineup of performers did songs from his catalog to raise money for indigent musicians.

headline: Revisiting Guns, the N.F.L. and Costas
abstract: Bob Costas used a halftime show to talk about an unhealthy “gun culture” and the N.F.L.’s part in it. Then Newtown happened.
lead_paragraph: Bob Costas told the nation in early December that the N.F.L. was part of an unhealthy “gun culture.”

headline: Hungry Enough to Eat a Horse?
abstract: British supermarkets are pulling “beef” products off their shelves after they were found to contain horse meat. But is there anything intrinsically wrong with eating horse? And, if you’re an adventurous foodie, where would you draw the line?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As new revelations emerged in the great horse meat scandal gripping the European food industry, there was no indication it would dim the enthusiasm of Continental foodies for their favorite equine delicacies.

headline: Weddings, Indian Style
abstract: Sonal Shah, who operates one of the premier Indian wedding planning services in New York, says there is no room for error on that special day.
lead_paragraph: In a ballroom at the Hilton Hotel in Pearl River, N.Y., four small women wearing black suits were carrying large tote bags and talking quietly into headsets. “We have another five minutes; they’re going to do the throwing of the rice,” one of them said into her mouthpiece, as though it were a military directive.

headline: Scientists Explore Options as Polar Bears Face New Threats
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'Bears', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Global Warming', 'Ice', 'Polar Bears']
abstract: A closer look at steps that may be taken to aid polar bears as the Arctic warms.
lead_paragraph: The surge of hunting that depleted many polar bear populations in the 20th century is largely under control. But just as the species has been recovering from that threat, global warming is creating new pressures through the loss of summer sea ice and other impacts on the bears’ preferred maritime habitat.

headline: Japanese Relative Performance
abstract: Aging matters.
lead_paragraph: More notes to myself. When people try to assess how Japan has done since its late-80s bubble burst, they often look at per capita GDP. But this can be deeply misleading, because of Japan’s low birth rate and aging population. In the figure below I compared the ratio of Japanese to US GDP per capita (from Total Economy Database) with the ratio of Japanese to US GDP per adult aged 15-64:

headline: Profits and Business Investment
abstract: High profits, not weak investment.
lead_paragraph: And another notes to myself post. Below are corporate profits (after tax and inventory valuation adjustment) and nonresidential fixed investment (roughly speaking, business investment), both measured as shares of GDP. These aren’t exactly matched figures, because not all business investment comes from corporations. Still, I think they illustrate an important point. Business investment isn’t actually all that low; you expect it to be relatively weak in a weak economy with excess capacity, but in fact it’s about as high a share of GDP as in the middle Bush years. What’s really out of line with previous experience is the level of corporate profits, which is arguably serving as a kind of sinkhole for purchasing power.

headline: The Legacy of a Camera-Toting Huckster
abstract: “The Kidnappers Foil,” by a traveling filmmaker of the early 20th century, exists in many versions made in many different towns. And more versions are likely out there to be discovered.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in the 1930s the Texas-born filmmaker Melton Barker spent nearly four decades scurrying across America with a script and a camera, methodically making and remaking the same two-reel film. This might seem like a story of creative obsession — a compulsive monomaniac so intent on achieving aesthetic perfection that he became subsumed by his work — but Barker, one of at least several itinerant filmmakers working in the first half of the 20th century, was more huckster than auteur.

headline: Washington Officials Join in Mourning a Young Shooting Victim in Chicago

abstract: Michelle Obama was among those at the funeral of Hadiya Pendleton, who performed at President Obama’s inauguration, and whose death has come to represent the cost of gun and gang violence.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — By the hundreds, mourners filed into the pews of a packed church on this city’s South Side on Saturday, clutching one another, weeping and wearing buttons adorned with the smiling face of Hadiya Pendleton, a 15-year-old girl whose death has come to represent the miserable cost of gun and gang violence.

headline: Honoring a ‘Picasso in Pinstripes’ in a Sketchbook

lead_paragraph: There is no telling how many get-well wishes Mariano Rivera has received while recovering from knee surgery. But at least 608 of them — including ones from a Mister Softee man in New York and some hardened Red Sox fans in Boston — have not yet been delivered.

Michelle Obama will also attend the funeral.

headline: Plugging In, Dutch Put Electric Cars to the Test
abstract: The Netherlands, with its small size and $8.50-a-gallon gas, may be the ultimate feasibility test for electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — When Patrick Langevoort’s company issued him an electric vehicle two years ago, the first months were filled with misadventure: he found himself far from Amsterdam, with only a 25 percent charge remaining, unable to find the charging point listed on a map. Though the car was supposed to travel 100 miles on a full battery, he discovered that cold weather and fast driving decreased that range.

headline: Six Killed in Shelling of Iranian Refugee Camp in Iraq
abstract: Hezbollah in Iraq claimed responsibility for the attack on the camp, which houses members of Mujahedeen Khalq, or M.E.K., an Iranian opposition group.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Six people were killed and more than 50 were wounded on Saturday when several dozen mortar shells fell on a refugee camp for members of an Iranian opposition group, according to an Iraqi police official.

headline: Variety: A Sound Acrostic
abstract: A sound acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, that was easy. Maybe it’s because I am a music lover, and there was so much here that was musical. Even so, I appreciated the melodic solve, as well as the quote that harkens back to the time of Victrolas and cylinder phonographs.

headline: The Land of the Binge
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: With sequestration around the corner and bacon on every plate, America could use a dose of moderation.
lead_paragraph: AROUND the time that Netflix released an entire season of “House of Cards” at once, so that viewers could gorge on all 13 episodes, a friend sent me a plaintive e-mail about the way that foodie-favored restaurants give her no option other than gorging.

headline: Cold, Hungry and Stuck on the L.I. Expressway
abstract: By Saturday morning, cars were littered across the expressway, some abandoned on the side of the road, and officials estimated that hundreds of drivers had been stranded.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGVILLE, N.Y. — Lorna Jones decided to brave the blizzard on Friday, venturing onto the Long Island Expressway as the snow began piling up. So did many others here in Suffolk County.

headline: Holding States and Schools Accountable
keywords: ['No Child Left Behind Act', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Education (K-12)', 'States (US)']
abstract: The federal education law has still not been reauthorized, as controversy continues over its last version, No Child Left Behind, and its requirements on student progress and teacher evaluations.
lead_paragraph: As Congress contemplates rewriting No Child Left Behind, President George W. Bush’s signature education law, legislators will tussle over a vision of how the federal government should hold states and schools accountable for students’ academic progress.

headline: Safety Concerns Stoke Criticism of Kennel Club
keywords: ['Breeding of Animals', 'Dogs', 'Cruelty to Animals', 'Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show']
abstract: The American Kennel Club is best known as the go-to place for registering purebreds and as the governing body for dog shows. But the club is coming under increased scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Margaret and James Hamilton were a dog power couple, seemingly the perfect people for raising and selling purebreds. Margaret was a breeder and a dog show judge who owned prizewinning Chihuahuas. Some of her litters were registered with the American Kennel Club, a stamp of approval from an organization charged with maintaining breed standards and registering purebreds around the country. Her husband, James, was a leader in a local A.K.C. Rottweiler club.

lead_paragraph: In the year of the snake, Bulgari revisits its iconic Serpenti jewelry collection, which produced sinuous charmers like this 1960s enamel, gold and ruby watch.

headline: Benh Zeitlin
abstract: The writer and director of “Beasts of the Southern Wild” on Yoruba mythology and mummified rats.
lead_paragraph: Benh Zeitlin is the writer, director and soundtrack composer of the fantasy drama “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” which has been nominated for four Oscars. It was made for a fraction of the cost of other Oscar-nominated films, with scenes shot primarily in Louisiana swampland and with leading roles played by amateur actors.

abstract: Legislators have tried to open the world of credit-ratings agencies to more competition. But for one small firm, it’s been tough to gain federal recognition.
