headline: Once Again, a Ranger Starts Off With a Bang
abstract: It is too soon to tell whether J. T. Miller’s trajectory will follow the somewhat bumpy path experienced by other young Rangers.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — J. T. Miller said he did not expect to score on his first shift at Madison Square Garden as an N.H.L. player, and he certainly did not expect to hear fans chanting his name.

headline: The Pyongyang’s All Here
abstract: What Google’s map of North Korea tells us about ourselves.
lead_paragraph: Google has now mapped the surface of Mars and the bottom of the ocean. So what’s left, a person has to wonder — what remains uncharted?

headline: After Ron Paul, Then What?
abstract: The libertarian wing of the Republican Party wants to shape its reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: RON PAUL, Republican of Texas, has retired from the House, after winning more than two million presidential primary votes in 2012. He took the party’s libertarian wing from ignorable fringe to significant faction. His son, Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, is angling to lead that faction, very possibly as a presidential candidate himself.

headline: Svindal Navigates Ice and Fog to Win Men’s Downhill Title
abstract: Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway won the men’s downhill title at the Alpine skiing world championships Saturday in Schladming, Austria.
lead_paragraph: SCHLADMING, Austria — Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway continued his assault on men’s ski racing, winning the downhill at the Alpine world championships on Saturday for his second medal in two events.

headline: In Nigeria, You’re Either Somebody or Nobody
abstract: Nigerians are brought up to believe that some are born to own and enjoy, while others are born to toil and endure.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria

headline: To Tear Down Walls, You Have to Move Out of Your Office
abstract: Robert LoCascio, founder and C.E.O. of LivePerson, says a set of core values helps his staff avoid infighting and a bureaucratic focus on “getting offices and titles.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Robert LoCascio, founder and chief executive of LivePerson, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: German Fascination With Degrees Claims Latest Victim: Education Minister
abstract: Annette Schavan resigned on Saturday, the second time a minister has quit the government of Chancellor Angela Merkel for plagiarism in less than two years.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For 32 years, the German education minister’s 351-page dissertation sat on a shelf at Heinrich Heine University in Düsseldorf gathering dust while its author pursued a successful political career that carried her to the highest circles of the German government.

headline: The Secret to Fixing Bad Schools
abstract: The striking achievement of Union City, N.J. — bringing poor, mostly immigrant kids into the educational mainstream — argues for reinventing the public schools we have.
lead_paragraph: WHAT would it really take to give students a first-rate education? Some argue that our schools are irremediably broken and that charter schools offer the only solution. The striking achievement of Union City, N.J. — bringing poor, mostly immigrant kids into the educational mainstream — argues for reinventing the public schools we have.

headline: It’s Sunday in the City: Let’s Play Two
abstract: Starting at 1 p.m. in New York, four of the N.B.A.’s top teams will play two games, over 10 hours, in two boroughs, about six miles apart.
lead_paragraph: New York considers itself the mecca of basketball — a conceit infused by street ball legends, a deep roster of native-born N.B.A. stars and the mere existence of Madison Square Garden. The city requires no external validation on this point.

headline: When E-Mail Turns From Delight to Deluge
abstract: E-mail used to make our day; now it buries us. It may help to rethink the way we use this communication tool.
lead_paragraph: IN the not-so-distant past, the chipper AOL sound of “You’ve got mail!” filled me with giddiness and glee. I would eagerly check my in-box, excited to see what message had arrived.

headline: In Bed With the President of Ghana?
abstract: It is unsettling to be implicated in a national scandal, but any debate on homosexuality in an African country is itself progress.
lead_paragraph: WHEN my husband-to-be and I met the Ghanaian politician John Dramani Mahama at a friend’s wedding near Accra eight years ago, I liked him immediately. I kept up with his fortunes mostly through mutual friends, and I was happy to learn in 2009 that he had been elected his nation’s vice president.

headline: Spying on Law-Abiding Muslims
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Muslim-Americans', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Police', 'Editorials']
abstract: Once again, the courts may need to stop the New York Police Department from illegal surveillance activities.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years ago, the federal courts had to place limits on New York City police surveillance to protect law-abiding citizens who happened to be politically engaged on civil rights and other issues. Based on new court filings in a longstanding suit challenging police surveillance techniques, the courts may need to intervene to stop the New York Police Department from spying on law-abiding citizens once again, this time Muslims.

headline: For John Westwood, Father’s Day in February
abstract: Lee Westwood has turned the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am into “Take Your Father to Work Week.”
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — One Thursday every April is designated for children to accompany their parents to their jobs. Then there is the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, which Lee Westwood has turned into “Take Your Father to Work Week.”

headline: India in the Slow Lane
abstract: Reviving the economy requires New Delhi to make hard regulatory reforms.
lead_paragraph: India’s economy is about to clock its slowest annual growth rate in a decade. The government said recently that gross domestic product would likely grow at just 5 percent in the fiscal year that ends in March, a sharp fall from the 9-plus-percent growth rates of the mid-2000s.

headline: The Body Under the Rug
abstract: The characters in a memoir inevitably feed on the blood of the living.
lead_paragraph: The week I finished the manuscript of my family memoir, I had a terrible nightmare: a dead body turned up in my hotel room. “I didn’t kill this person,” I thought to myself, “but everyone will think I did.” I went outside to clear my head and when I came back the body was gone. But dead bodies don’t just disappear; as I was packing up to leave, I couldn’t find my camera and, looking around, noticed a lump in the rug. Thinking the camera might have somehow ended up under the carpet, I lifted it to find a man’s head, or rather the front third of a man’s head, like a bloody mask. I put the rug down in horror. “Now, they are definitely going to think I killed this person,” I thought, before waking up.

headline: The Daily Do | Rag & Bone
abstract: Rag and Bone runway hair appears effortless — a deep, side-swept part and a twisted chignon, but with a slept-in look.
lead_paragraph: Rag and Bone runway hair appears effortless — a deep, side-swept part and a twisted chignon, but with a slept-in look.

headline: America’s Beer Duopoly
keywords: ['Beer', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Editorials']
abstract: Blocking the country’s largest brewing company from acquiring one of its competitors will benefit consumers.
lead_paragraph: Consumers will benefit from the Justice Department’s antitrust suit to block Anheuser-Busch InBev, the country’s largest brewing company, from acquiring one of its competitors. This kind of action was seen less frequently in the Bush administration.

headline: Digital Tags Help Ensure the Price Is Right
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Liquid Crystal Displays', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Despite the potential cost savings, the use of digital price tags has yet to catch on in stores in the United States.
lead_paragraph: SOME decades ago, a grocery store’s aisles were often filled with “chunk-a-chunk-a” sounds, as clerks stamped prices to the tops of cans and boxes before putting them on shelves. It was a labor-intensive operation, but it did result in a price being affixed to most every item in the store.

headline: Russian Protest Leader Put Under House Arrest
abstract: Sergei Udaltsov, leader of the radical socialist Left Front movement, faces a charge of conspiracy to incite mass disorder and faces up to 10 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Moscow district court ordered Sergei Udaltsov, a prominent opposition leader, to be placed under house arrest on Saturday, in one of the most assertive legal measures to date against a leader of the anti-Kremlin protests that began more than a year ago.

headline: The Gradual Selling of America the Beautiful
abstract: It’s a big country, but commercial interests have been chipping away at it. So far, President Obama hasn’t done enough to protect the public’s land.
lead_paragraph: Of the 2.27 billion acres that constitute the land area of the United States, a little less than 30 percent — about 640 million acres — belongs to you, the American citizen. It is land acquired over the years by treaty, conquest or purchase by the federal government acting on behalf of the people, and indisputably belongs to neither the states nor individuals. But in the last few decades no part of the American land mass has stirred greater controversy.

headline: Lost in the Stars of a Hotel’s Rating
abstract: Three stars? Two stars? 2.5? A Hotwire customer describes a frustrating search for answers about a hotel’s rating, and enlists the Haggler’s help.
lead_paragraph: THE Internet deserves credit for creating new and cash-saving ways to handle mundane tasks, like booking a hotel. But these innovations can come at a price, and the price is often insanity. Other times it’s rage. More often, it’s rage’s slightly mellower cousin, frustration.

headline: Give Me Your Tired, Your Poor and Your Economists, Too

headline: The Dice Are Rolling on Dell’s Legacy

lead_paragraph: IN 1984 — the year Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook creator, was born — Michael S. Dell started a tech company in his dorm room, dropped out of college and changed the world.

headline: Russia Detains 271 People During Security Raid in St. Petersburg
abstract: The raid was carried out to check residency permits and eliminate networks of religious extremists, officials said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian police and security officials in St. Petersburg detained 271 people, mostly migrants from Central Asia and the North Caucasus region, during a raid on Friday on Muslim prayer rooms at a central market. They said the raid was carried out to check residency permits and to eliminate networks of religious extremists planning terrorist attacks.

headline: Steaks, the Family Business

lead_paragraph: MY family has been in the meat business for five generations, starting in the 1860s. My grandfather’s family business specialized in beef. And my grandmother’s family specialty was veal. Both families were in the Bronx.

headline: Baseball’s Recurring Narrative: Every Year They Write the Book
abstract: With spring training camps starting this week in Arizona and Florida, here are the prevailing narratives for each of the 30 teams.
lead_paragraph: The use of the word “narrative” seemed to rise sharply last season, at least in the press box and on blogs. It usually referred to a preconceived story arc and the tendency of reporters to shape articles through that frame. One player, R. A. Dickey of the Mets, used the word often, but Dickey was a writer, too; he released his autobiography before the season.

headline: The Tax Deal That Simplified Nothing

abstract: A New Year’s Day agreement on tax rates only added to the system’s complexity. Still, lawmakers from both political parties may now have incentive to move ahead with tax reform.
lead_paragraph: IF 2012 was the beginning of a long, inevitable slide toward tax increases, 2013 might just turn out to be the lurching start of tax reform.

headline: Be It Enacted: A Tax on the Taxing
abstract: Economists talk about taxing “negative externalities”; why not expand that to include all the annoyances, like the slowpokes in a checkout line, that build up during the day?
lead_paragraph: I LEARNED a new word the other day: pigovian. It has to do with economic theories of taxation and annoyance.

headline: Captivity in Black and White
abstract: A Union prisoner in Texas and the limits of Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 1, 1863 – the effective date of the Emancipation Proclamation – a Massachusetts private named Alexander Hobbs recorded these words in his journal: “I have now to chronicle an event which will be remembered by us all while we live.” But Hobbs was not referring to emancipation. He wrote instead of a New Year’s Day battle in Texas and a story of captivity that revealed how fragile freedom could be, even after Lincoln’s proclamation.

keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Capital Gains Tax']
abstract: By sifting through recent changes in the law, taxpayers can make some strategic moves toward the next filing season.
lead_paragraph: IF you’ve gathered up the documents and compiled the data for your 2012 tax return, congratulations. The next part, of course, may be painful: actually calculating your taxes.

headline: Recovering Unevenly as Region Looks Ahead
abstract: While some airports and mass transit options in the New York City area returned quickly, some cars were still stranded on Long Island.

headline: A Doubly Trying Tax Season for Same-Sex Couples
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: Even if a state recognizes same-sex marriage, federal law doesn’t — resulting in a maddening array of tax complications for gay couples.
lead_paragraph: FOR Colette Hayward and Margaret Selby, the problem is this: Maryland recognizes their 2009 marriage, but the federal government does not.

abstract: Three of the best-known tax preparation programs — TurboTax, H&R Block at Home and TaxAct — are taken for a spin.

abstract: A number of changes passed on Jan. 1 set higher rates on several taxes that affect small-business owners, while also giving new life to some credits and deductions.
lead_paragraph: TAX planning can be difficult for a small business, all the more so when a lot of the work is left until the last minute — not by the owners or their accountants, but by Congress.

keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Taxation']
abstract: Taxing wealth — household assets like property, stocks, art and yachts — in addition to income may be a way to make sure the rich contribute a higher share to government coffers.
lead_paragraph: INCOME tax rates have recently been raised slightly for some affluent people, and there is pressure for additional increases. But some economists say raising marginal income tax rates on high earners may miss the mark.

headline: The Five Stages of Retirement Planning Angst
abstract: The realization that we’re not saving enough for retirement can lead, in short order, to denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance.
lead_paragraph: I HAVEN’T a clue what kind of psychiatrist Elisabeth Kübler-Ross was. But I do know she was a terrific financial planner.

keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Tax', 'Insurance', 'Disasters and Emergencies']
abstract: Those who declare tax losses from Hurricane Sandy will run into limits on what they can claim, as well as the question of what constitutes fair value.

headline: Fund Let Voices Be Heard, and for One Boy That Was Enough
abstract: The latest campaign of the Neediest Cases Fund had the extra task of helping hurricane victims, but it also performed its customary role of helping those people whose everyday lives are filled with struggles.
lead_paragraph: For more than 100 years, the stories of struggle that make up The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund’s annual campaign have inspired readers to help New Yorkers in dire financial need.

headline: Venezuela, Despite Troubles, Proudly Seizes on a Hat
abstract: A baseball cap worn by an opponent of President Hugo Chávez in the last election has returned, adopted by Mr. Chávez’s cadre as the “cap of the revolution.”
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela seems to lurch from one crisis to another. President Hugo Chávez has virtually disappeared since going to Cuba for cancer surgery more than eight weeks ago. Last month, 58 people were killed in a prison when inmates clashed with soldiers. Inflation is spiking, the government just announced a currency devaluation and lurid murders are the stuff of daily headlines.

headline: An Instagram Moment
abstract: A number of shows have altered their typical runway cadence so editors have the opportunity to photograph outfits using their cellphones to post on social media.
lead_paragraph: A new trend has emerged in the staging of runway shows, one that acknowledges the way that many editors now view them. In addition to looking for trends of the season and the best looks for their magazines, almost everyone is scouting for that one outfit that will make a great post on Twitter or Instagram.

headline: In Address, President Will Focus on the Middle Class

headline: A School Band With History Crams for Carnival

But not around McDonogh 35 High School in the Seventh Ward, where neighbors say the band remains in school, hunched over its music and cramming for Carnival parades.

headline: ‘The Winter Ball’
abstract: Soccer in the winter in the New York City area may now be a novelty, but at one time teams tried to play even in bad weather.
lead_paragraph: Soccer in most of the world is played through the winter (at least in the Northern Hemisphere), and when foul weather intrudes it most often only dampens the field. At times, though, snow blankets the pristine playing surfaces, and “the winter ball” has to be rolled out.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Liu Wen at Jason Wu
abstract: The model Liu Wen transforms with the help of Diane Kendal and Odile Gilbert.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2013 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Liu Wen for Marilyn Agency before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Diane Kendal and hair by Odile Gilbert.

headline: A Favorite May Win; Long Shots Surely Will
abstract: The entrants are set for the N.B.A.’s annual 3-point contest, an integral part of the league’s upcoming All-Star weekend, but determining who will be the favorite is difficult, given past results.
lead_paragraph: The entrants are set for the N.B.A.’s annual 3-point contest, an integral part of the league’s upcoming All-Star weekend, but determining who will be the favorite is difficult, given past results.

lead_paragraph: Zynga struggles to successfully migrate its games to mobile devices, Slovenia gives loan guarantees to several businesses and more restaurants add healthier options to their menus.

headline: I Heard You the First Time
abstract: Yay us! A Patrick Berry Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Can you hear the echo? Patrick Berry is calling to us.

headline: Blackhawks Thrive Away From Home
abstract: Despite a schedule that has them playing all but 2 of their first 11 games on the road, the Chicago Blackhawks have posted a 9-0-2 record.
lead_paragraph: With the 48-game N.H.L. season about one-quarter complete, the Chicago Blackhawks are the league’s top team, despite a schedule that put them on the road for 9 of their first 11 games. Previously scheduled events like concerts and circus performances have limited their access to United Center, so the Blackhawks have played as many games at Phoenix as they have played at home.

headline: Return of Wall Has Wizards Thinking the Unthinkable: A Run at the Playoffs
abstract: John Wall is back from injury and leading Washington back to respectability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Wizards’ John Wall was rehabilitating his injured left knee this season, he did what he could to stay involved with the team. He went to road games. He attended practice. He watched game film on a monitor whenever he climbed on the team’s antigravity treadmill.

headline: Fuel and Food Are Quick, but the Fealty Is Forever
abstract: The comforts of two chains of convenience stores — Wawa in the east, and Sheetz to the west — inspire Pennsylvanians to choose sides.
lead_paragraph: SELINSGROVE, Pa. — The fat columns and thick canopy are a neon Stonehenge, beckoning travelers to gather in pagan adulation. Out-of-staters passing by on Route 15 may be mystified by the name, but to residents of central Pennsylvania the brightly lighted Sheetz convenience store, stocked with Utz chips and a Cupo’ccino machine, is a source of pride — no, passion.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 10
abstract: Lawmakers from both parties will appear on the Sunday talk shows to offer insight ahead of the president’s State of the Union Address.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers from both parties will appear on the Sunday talk shows to offer insight ahead of President Obama’s State of the Union address. They will also weigh in on the hot topics in Washington this week, including drones, torture and the emerging threat of cyberwarfare.

keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Government Bonds', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Property Taxes', 'Building (Construction)', 'State Legislatures', 'Community Colleges', 'Municipal Bonds']

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — School officials in Santa Ana were in a bind several years ago: they wanted to build hundreds of new classrooms, but feared that voters would rebel against tax increases to pay for the construction.

abstract: A powerful snow storm hit the Northeast. More than half a million people lost power and mass transit was halted.

headline: James Muri, Bomber Pilot Honored for Valor in Battle of Midway, Is Dead at 94
abstract: The World War II pilot bombed a Japanese aircraft carrier in the Pacific and then survived by flying his B-26 bomber directly over the enemy ship’s deck.
lead_paragraph: James Muri survived the first half of June 4, 1942, on the strength of his Army Air Forces pilot training. That was the day of his first combat mission, and the first day of the Battle of Midway. He piloted an unwieldy B-26 twin-engine bomber through heavy antiaircraft fire, maneuvered it close to a Japanese aircraft carrier, dropped a torpedo and pulled away into a sky filled with enemy shells just as his bomb detonated.

headline: Starr Saphir, Bird-Watching Guide in Central Park, Dies at 73
abstract: Ms. Saphir was reknowned among birders, thousands of whom followed her through Central Park on the tours she led four times a week for nearly four decades.
lead_paragraph: When Starr Saphir looked up at the star-speckled night sky, she thought of the multitude of moths, mosquitoes and other insects being pursued by swooping nighthawks.

headline: From Fluff to Faux Fur
abstract: Christian Siriano started his show with surprisingly understated and conservative designs for the first few looks, which might expand his customer base for the future, but returned to the vibrant designer we all know and love.
lead_paragraph: In the five years since he started having runway shows, Christian Siriano has gone from fluff to faux fur.

headline: Huge Blizzard Buries Northeast
abstract: The powerful storm that swept through the Northeast on Saturday buried some areas under as much as three feet of snow and forced evacuations of coastal areas in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The powerful storm that swept through the Northeast on Saturday buried some areas under as much as three feet of snow and forced evacuations of coastal areas in Massachusetts.

headline: Snedeker Stays on Roll at Pebble Beach
abstract: Brandt Snedeker, the runner-up last week at the Phoenix Open, carded a four-under 68 to remain atop the leader board at the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am at 12 under.
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — Two top-three finishes and a 68.3-stroke average were not enough to earn Brandt Snedeker a player of the month nomination in January. With more of the same play here, Snedeker, the FedEx Cup points leader, has established himself as February’s front-runner.

headline: A Snow Day in the Park
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']

lead_paragraph: New York City Department of Parks and Recreation held a Snow Day in parks throughout the city, a day after a snowstorm swept through the Northeast.

headline: Leaving the Legislature, but Not Going Very Far
abstract: Some legislators say it is time to stop the practice of former lawmakers going straight into lobbying jobs and are suggesting, at the least, a cooling-off period, which 35 states already require.
lead_paragraph: It is a familiar sight at the start of every legislative session in Austin.

headline: Milestones for Matteau and Brodeur and a Big Win for the Devils
abstract: Stefan Matteau, 18, scored his first goal and Martin Brodeur played in his 1,200th regular-season game as the Devils ended the Penguins’ five-game winning streak to move into first in the Atlantic Division.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Devils fans came to dread the name of Stephane Matteau when he netted two overtime goals for the rival Rangers during the 1994 Eastern Conference finals. His heroics included one of the most celebrated moments in Rangers history, when he beat the rookie goaltender Martin Brodeur with a wraparound in the second overtime of Game 7 at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Perry Swoops Down on California Business, and Jerry Brown Is Not Impressed
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Labor and Jobs', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Governors (US)']
abstract: Gov. Rick Perry’s four-day “business recruitment trip” to California escalates his raids on the state’s economy.
lead_paragraph: What could be more fun than a throwdown between Governor Goodhair and Governor Moonbeam?

headline: Space Heater Causes Fire, Killing Boy, 8
abstract: Neighbors in Flatbush, Brooklyn, were awaked by screams during the blaze, which eight other people escaped.
lead_paragraph: An 8-year-old Brooklyn boy died early Saturday after a space heater started a fire in his house, the Fire Department said.

headline: Boeing 787 Completes Test Flight
abstract: The flight was the first since the Federal Aviation Administration gave Boeing permission on Thursday to conduct in-flight tests.
lead_paragraph: A Boeing 787 test plane flew for more than two hours on Saturday to gather information about the problems with the batteries that led to a worldwide grounding of the new jets more than three weeks ago.

headline: A Sellout Crowd for George Washington, but a Win for Butler
abstract: The Butler Bulldogs are the Beatles of the new-look Atlantic 10, and they got all they could handle from the Colonials before holding on for a victory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Saturday afternoon, members of the George Washington men’s basketball team ventured outdoors, in uniform, to hand out Revolution-era, tricornered hats to students who were waiting in line to get into Smith Center. It was a very long line.

headline: Sierra Club Taking Aim at East Texas Coal Plants
abstract: Environmentalists are escalating a campaign to close Luminant power plants in Freestone, Rusk and Monticello in Titus Counties.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD — Staring across a lake at the oldest coal-fired power plant in Texas, Mayor Roy W. Hill thinks back to the early 1970s, when his father helped bring the plant to the area.

headline: Following the Money Trail for the World’s Best Players
abstract: Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, is also the game’s best-paid player, according to a recent analysis by a fellow competitor.
lead_paragraph: There is a simple way to determine the No. 1 player in the world: the World Chess Federation rates and ranks the competitors. It is not so easy trying to figure out the game’s best-paid player.

headline: Snapshots of an Angry Sea, and a Ride in a Front-End Loader
abstract: The storm system that walloped New England has also aggravated the sea, placing much of the east coast under a coastal flood warning and inundating some low-lying areas.
lead_paragraph: SALISBURY, Mass. — When high tide came on Saturday morning, Nancy Bemis was photographing the sea, as she does every storm, standing at the porch door to her apartment, which is tucked into the tangle of power lines and buildings where residents crane to see the sea from the shoreline of this small beach community.

headline: Texas Country’s ‘First Couple’ and Their Love Songs
abstract: Bruce Robison and Kelly Willis, who are releasing their first full-length album together, name their half-dozen favorite love songs.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Robison and Kelly Willis have been married for 16 years, but they will tie the knot professionally on Tuesday with the release of “Cheater’s Game,” their first full-length album together.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Giffords Eases Steadily Into New Life, and Cause
abstract: Gabrielle Giffords, the former Democratic congresswoman from Arizona, is settling into the third act of her public life as she shifts to dedicate her career to reducing gun violence.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Gabrielle Giffords looked slightly stricken as she considered the question: Would she feel bad about starring in a political advertisement against her former House colleagues who declined to stand with her on guns? “Yes,” she said, it would be painful.

headline: Clues From Alexander Wang
abstract: The Alexander Wang collection’s strong points were the mohair knits (shrugs and sweat pants), the more streamlined of the coats and some terrific evening separates in duchess satin — simply draped and vented tops in black or white satin with a wide banded hem.
lead_paragraph: With Alexander Wang preparing his first collection for Balenciaga, it was tempting to read clues into his own line, shown Saturday evening. First, there was the august setting–the ornate lobby of the Cunard building in lower Manhattan. You might not sail for France aboard a Cunard ship but the name certainly has the tingle of adventure and broken Champagne glasses. Then there were the couture satins and drop-waist, 1920s silhouette of coats that combined wool and leather or fur. This vintage coat style, with a martingale or sometimes a double martingale, was occasionally beefed with a mohair shrug and a knitted hoodie or cap.

headline: At Boys’ Home, Seeking Graves, and the Reason
abstract: A Florida home for wayward boys was once synonymous with horrific conditions. Now, some are trying to discern what occurred by digging for bodies on the campus’s grounds.
lead_paragraph: MARIANNA, Fla. — Nobody is quite sure how many boys’ bodies lie beneath the grounds of the notorious Arthur G. Dozier School for Boys, or which one is Thomas or Owen or Robert.

headline: Looking for Answers and Bodies in the Ground
abstract: Nobody is quite sure how many boys’ bodies lie beneath the grounds of the notorious Arthur G. Dozier School for Boys in Florida, or which one is Thomas or Owen or Robert. The causes of their deaths are equally mysterious, often listed as “unknown” or “accident,” and many were buried with great haste.
lead_paragraph: Nobody is quite sure how many boys’ bodies lie beneath the grounds of the notorious Arthur G. Dozier School for Boys in Florida, or which one is Thomas or Owen or Robert. The causes of their deaths are equally mysterious, often listed as “unknown” or “accident,” and many were buried with great haste.

keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Police']

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles Police Department will reopen its investigation into the 2007 episode that led to the firing of Christopher J. Dorner, the former police officer who is wanted in three killings, department officials said Saturday night.

headline: James DePreist, a Pioneering Conductor, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. DePreist, one of the few black conductors to achieve international renown, refused to let disability derail his career.
lead_paragraph: Even in the motorized wheelchair he rode to the podium, or seated on the low swivel chair from which he conducted, James DePreist cut an imposing figure, one that usually got the best from the orchestras he led — whether major ensembles like the New York Philharmonic and the Oregon Symphony, or student groups at the Juilliard School, where he was director of conducting and orchestral studies for seven years.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Portrait of Newton, Hold the Gravity
abstract: The playwright Lucas Hnath discusses “Isaac’s Eye,” his comedy about one of Isaac Newton’s more outlandish experiments.
lead_paragraph: Lucas Hnath didn’t plan a career as a playwright. He arrived at New York University determined to pursue a pre-med degree in 1997. But then he saw “Benita Canova” by the avant-garde director Richard Foreman. “After that I decided I had to transfer into dramatic writing because I wanted to make things like that,” he said.

headline: Joseph Altuzarra: Mean Streets
abstract: However the ideas of Alexander Wang and Joseph Altuzarra seem to bleed together, Mr. Altuzarra has worked hard to stake out his own territory in New York. He should be looking for more ways to separate himself from the pack.
lead_paragraph: Ponchos, parkas and now fur mittens and double-layered coats: are pals Alexander Wang and Joseph Altuzarra doing a runway two-step?

headline: Obama’s Turn in Bush’s Bind
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A onetime critic of his predecessor, President Obama finds himself justifying muscular defense policies while detractors complain that he has sacrificed core values.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If President Obama tuned in to the past week’s bracing debate on Capitol Hill about terrorism, executive power, secrecy and due process, he might have recognized the arguments his critics were making: He once made some of them himself.

headline: Obama’s Plan to Visit Mideast Stirs Hopes, Slightly
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Palestinians']
abstract: President Obama and his new secretary of state’s plans have signaled that the United States is re-engaging in the Middle East, but both sides remain skeptical that much will change.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For more than two years, many Israeli and Palestinian leaders have placed blame for their stalemated peace process not only on one another but on a lack of engagement by the Obama administration. But now that President Obama and his new secretary of state have signaled plans to visit, both sides still remain skeptical that much will change.

headline: Mali War Shifts as Rebels Hide in High Sahara
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Expelling the Islamist militants may have been the easy part of retaking Malian towns. Now French forces are focusing on a harsh mountain range where many of those militants are hiding.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Just as Al Qaeda once sought refuge in the mountains of Tora Bora, the Islamist militants now on the run in Mali are hiding out in their own forbidding landscape, a rugged, rocky expanse in northeastern Mali that has become a symbol of the continued challenges facing the international effort to stabilize the Sahara.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Feb. 10
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Feb. 10.
lead_paragraph: “I think it is fair to say we were very lucky.”

lead_paragraph: Today, the people outside fashion shows are more like peacocks than crows. It’s dizzying enough to make even the most seasoned critic call a timeout.

Mizeur, a delegate representing Montgomery County in the Maryland General Assembly.

headline: U.S. Women Beat Scotland in Sermanni’s Debut
abstract: Christen Press scored twice in the first 32 minutes of her United States women’s national team debut Saturday night, a 4-1 victory over Scotland that made Tom Sermanni a winner in his first game as the Americans’ coach.
lead_paragraph: Christen Press scored twice in the first 32 minutes of her United States women’s national team debut Saturday night, a 4-1 victory over Scotland that gave Tom Sermanni a victory in his first game since replacing Pia Sundhage as United States coach.

headline: Sharper Tongues in China’s Year of the Snake?
abstract: As China begins the Year of the Snake on Sunday, its “snake” president-to-be, Xi Jinping, calls for sharper criticism of the Communist Party and far less corruption in the future. Is something shifting?
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Snake is determined and smart, according to traditional Chinese beliefs. Today is New Year’s Day in China, the first day in the Year of the Snake, and a good day to ask: Will Xi Jinping, a “snake” set to become president in March (Mr. Xi was born in a Year of the Snake, in 1953) bring change to China?

headline: Wawa or Sheetz? A Matter of Convenience
abstract: Two popular convenience stores in the Northeast, Wawa and Sheetz, have loyal followings that hew closely to their geographic range. At left, locations for both chain stores in the region.
lead_paragraph: Two popular convenience stores in the Northeast, Wawa and Sheetz, have loyal followings that hew closely to their geographic range. At left, locations for both chain stores in the region.

headline: Meditations on the F1 Season to Come — and on 20 Seasons Run
abstract: What do I expect for the coming Formula One season after watching the first winter pre-season tests? The unexpected.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 2013 Formula One season has not really begun. The first race takes place March 17 in Melbourne. But with the launches of the new cars and the first four days of test sessions ending Friday, the seeds have been planted. What kind of plant will grow is not easy to figure out.

headline: Japan and the Whale
abstract: Japan snares trouble in the East China Sea.
lead_paragraph: Japan snares trouble in the East China Sea.

headline: Ready for a Redskins Name Change?
abstract: The controversy over Washington’s mascot may be picking up steam. But what does Robert Griffin III have to do with it?
lead_paragraph: “The NFL franchise assigned to Washington, D.C., has a name that is both racist and offensive. Most Americans have become desensitized to that fact. But it is a fact.” Mike Florio of ProFootballTalk.com

headline: Anxiety Grows as Thousands Remain Stranded and in the Dark After Storm
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Weather', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: Emergency crews in the Northeast continued to work Sunday to restore power to the region and to clear highways after a storm dumped more than three feet of snow in some areas.
lead_paragraph: Grabbing shovels large and small, residents and emergency workers across the Northeast struggled to dig out on Sunday after a gigantic midwinter storm left much of the region buried under drifting snow.

headline: Live Photo Streaming Now: Victoria Beckham
abstract: We are now live streaming from backstage and beyond at Victoria Beckham, tune in.
lead_paragraph: Check in daily to see in-the-moment backstage, on and off the runway photos from select New York Fashion Week shows.

headline: Meet the Staves
abstract: This trio of singing sisters evokes Woodstock-era troubadours and is worth a listen.
lead_paragraph: After earning indie cred opening for Bon Iver, this singing sister act from just outside London comes out next month with “Dead & Born & Grown” (Atlantic), a neo-folk album that drew raves when it made its British debut last fall. With otherworldly harmonies and retro strums, the trio — Camilla, 23; Emily, 29; and Jessica Staveley-Taylor, 26 — evokes Woodstock-era troubadours like Joni Mitchell and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young. “We’ve been listening to this kind of music for years,” Jessica says. Indeed, the siblings were raised on a steady diet of family singalongs. “For years, we thought our parents wrote ‘The Times They Are a-Changin,’ ” Camilla says.

headline: Double Duty
abstract: On spring runways, the top-handle purse was regularly reinvented as a clutch.
lead_paragraph: Who knew that a bag needed to come with carrying instructions? Nearly every top-handle purse that came down the spring runway, like this all-American version by Michael Kors, was carried like a clutch, with the wrist through the strap.

headline: With a Focus on Its Future, Financial Times Turns 125
abstract: The Financial Times is celebrating its 125th birthday on Wednesday. While the print editions are fading, the news organization has figured out how to make money from new outlets.
lead_paragraph: It was a time when the financial markets were growing and globalizing rapidly. Gossip, speculation and misinformation abounded. There was a need for a “friend to the honest financier and the respectable broker.” From 1888, when it began publishing under that motto, The Financial Times has seen continuity in its mission.

headline: Hong Kong TV Drama Plays Out Uneasy Ties With China
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Television', 'International Relations', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: A Hong Kong series has tapped into the tensions between the city's residents and mainland Chinese visitors, striking a nerve on both sides of the border and drawing the attention of Chinese censors.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The tensions between residents here and mainland Chinese visitors dominate the headlines of the city’s papers, with mainlanders blamed for a shortage of school slots, bad manners in stores and a hypercharged property market.

headline: E-Mails of Reporters in Myanmar Are Hacked
abstract: Several journalists who write about Myanmar have received warnings from Google that their Gmail accounts may have been hacked by “state-sponsored attackers.”
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Several journalists who cover Myanmar said Sunday that they had received warnings from Google that their e-mail accounts might have been hacked by “state-sponsored attackers.”

headline: Paterno Family Challenges Accusation of Cover-Up
abstract: The family of the former Penn State football coach Joe Paterno issued its own review, challenging claims that he helped conceal child sex abuse allegations against Jerry Sandusky.
lead_paragraph: A report commissioned by the family of Joe Paterno, a former Penn State football coach, said he was unfairly tarnished and implicated in the sexual abuse scandal involving Jerry Sandusky, a longtime assistant who was convicted last year of sexually assaulting 10 boys.

headline: Disruptions: Where Apple and Dick Tracy May Converge
abstract: Though such a device has been lost to science fiction comics and spy movies of a pre-smartphone era, the smart watch might soon become a reality, in the form of a curved glass device made by Apple.
lead_paragraph: Dick Tracy had one. As did Inspector Gadget and James Bond. A watch that doubled as a computer, two-way radio, mapping device or television.

headline: Cool Blue
abstract: Stella Ishii’s debut collection includes the perfect tomboy jeans sewn from the best Japanese and Italian denim.
lead_paragraph: Stella Ishii has helped start labels like Alexander Wang, 3.1 Phillip Lim and The Row. Now she’s introducing her own collection, 6397, which includes the perfect tomboy jeans — sewn from the best Japanese and Italian denim — slouchy cashmere-cotton tees and relaxed boyfriend sweaters. Available at Ikram in Chicago, Maxfield in Los Angeles and United Arrows in Tokyo.

headline: A Different Kind of Labyrinth in the London Underground
abstract: The artist Mark Wallinger unveiled his newest work this week: a commission from the London Underground, for which he has created 270 panels, one for every Tube station. It’s an intriguing, if subtle, addition to the impressive world of Underground art. Have you spotted any yet?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The artist Mark Wallinger has a few strings to his bow: he spent 10 days in a bear suit in 2004 in the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin; he won the Turner Prize in 2007; he enjoyed a few days of media admiration/derision in 2009 when he proposed a 50-meter white horse as a public art project in Ebbsfleet in Kent.

headline: Reflecting on an Asteroid’s Really Close Encounter with Earth (Closer than Some Satellites)
abstract: A really close encounter between a small asteroid and Earth provides a reminder that rare, but big, threats need to be seriously confronted.
lead_paragraph: [Feb. 15, 3:22 p.m. | Updated | There’s a double-barreled burst of news, of course, with the flyby today and the near simultaneous meteor explosion. Here’s relevant news coverage: “Shock Wave of Fireball Meteor Rattles Siberia, Injuring 1,000” and NASA’s vital Asteroid Watch site and @asteroidwatch Twitter feed.]

headline: Stargazing: New York Fashion Week Days 2 and 3
abstract: When it comes to sleet and snow, nothing keeps the fashion crowd from its appointed rounds.
lead_paragraph: Forget the Postal Service (especially after it announced that it would eliminate Saturday service later this year): When it comes to sleet and snow, nothing keeps the fashion crowd from its appointed rounds.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 55TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS L L Cool J returns as host of this ceremony honoring artists in country, hip-hop, jazz, pop and rock and broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. The group Fun. (including Nate Ruess, above left, with Jack Antonoff); Jay-Z; Mumford & Sons; Frank Ocean; and Kanye West lead the pack with six nominations each. Miguel and the Black Keys have five. Zac Brown, Brittany Howard of the Alabama Shakes, Elton John, Mumford & Sons and Mavis Staples will pay tribute to Levon Helm, who died in April, with a performance directed by T Bone Burnett. Dr. John, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, the Black Keys, Stanley Clarke, Chick Corea and Kenny Garrett will honor Dave Brubeck, who died in December. Justin Timberlake, Alicia Keys, Maroon 5, Frank Ocean, Carly Rae Jepsen, Katy Perry, Rihanna, Bruno Mars, Sting, Taylor Swift, the Lumineers, Carrie Underwood and Jack White are expected to perform. Red carpet coverage begins at 5 on E! and TV Guide.

headline: Sport Spectacular
abstract: Stella McCartney is capitalizing on the paddle boarding craze with expansion into swimwear and surf wear.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to Stella McCartney, who has an uncanny way of having her finger on the pulse, to capitalize on the paddle boarding craze. This spring, the fashion designer has expanded her sportswear collection for Adidas to include a broader range of swimwear and surf wear. Bathing suits, wet suits, water pants and rash guards now come in bright, coral-reef colors like orange and blue, with bits of very pretty, very graphic leopard and botanical prints. “I want my sport-swim to look feminine,” she says. “Animals in the jungle, tropical flowers, it all has a sort of warm and sensual feel to it.” McCartney, who personally prefers light exercise (biking, horseback riding) to high endurance, first picked up paddle boarding in Brazil a few years ago. Here’s to hoping she gets into skiing by fall.

headline: More Than Two Dozen Killed in Kumbh Mela Stampede
abstract: Train delays and a broken railing cause of deaths, festival attendees say.
lead_paragraph: ALLAHABAD, Uttar Pradesh — As many as 30 people were killed Sunday in a stampede at a train station here as millions gathered for a Hindu religious festival.

headline: Rising Voice of Gun Ownership Is Female
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Women and Girls', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Firearms']
abstract: Amid the national debate over regulation, women’s participation in shooting sports has surged in the last decade, while many gun dealers said the number of female customers went up in 2011.
lead_paragraph: PAINESVILLE, Ohio — Mary Ann Froebe stood feet apart with knees slightly bent and aimed the .22-caliber Ruger semiautomatic.

headline: Confessions of a Troubadour: You Love, You Die
abstract: The singer (and sometime actor) Bonnie Prince Billy performed at the Allen Room in the Lincoln Center American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: While watching Bonnie Prince Billy at the Allen Room on Thursday evening I had the fleeting image of this singer, songwriter and actor, a k a Will Oldham, as a free-spirited troubadour roaming the world with only the clothes on his back and a guitar. But it’s not that simple.

headline: The Daily Do | Altuzarra
abstract: At Saturday’s show, wispy, shaggy tresses were perfectly imperfect.
lead_paragraph: It was all about Daria and her newly shorn locks at Altuzarra’s show. Wispy, shaggy tresses were perfectly imperfect.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The Intrepid Get a Treat for the Ears
abstract: Susanna Phillips unleashed her many vocal qualities while performing a range of material at Weill Recital Hall.
lead_paragraph: “I feel like we should have started with ‘Stormy Weather,’ ” the soprano Susanna Phillips said during her concert at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening, when many New Yorkers had already hunkered down to avoid the impending blizzard. While there were empty seats, those who braved the snow were rewarded with engaging performances by Ms. Phillips and Myra Huang, her remarkable pianist.

headline: The Way They Tell It, Science Is Spelled F-U-N
abstract: “Bang Goes the Theory,” on BBC America, tries to present science in a way that makes it less intimidating.
lead_paragraph: There has been a desperate rush in recent decades to make science enjoyable and layman-friendly via books with catchy titles (“Elephants on Acid, and Other Bizarre Experiments”) and perky television shows, most of them featuring Neil deGrasse Tyson.

headline: New Mexico Inches Toward Stricter Gun Controls
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A new bill aims to close the so-called gun-show loophole by requiring background checks in sales at such events.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — As state lawmakers around the country wrestle with whether to tighten gun laws, the fierce debate has not always fallen neatly along party lines — especially in the West.

headline: Derek Lam: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Militants Battle Malian and French Troops in Liberated Town
abstract: Gunfire rang out in the streets of the strategic town of Gao in northern Mali two weeks after French forces appeared to have chased radical Islamists out of the town.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Gunfire rang out in the streets of the strategic city of Gao in northern Mali on Sunday, two weeks after French troops appeared to have chased radical Islamists out of the city, which is at the edge of the desert and is the largest population center in the north.

headline: ‘Identity Thief’ Tops Weekend Box Office
abstract: “Identity Thief” succeeds at the box office despite storm.
lead_paragraph: Despite storm-shuttered theaters in the Northeast, “Identity Thief” took in a super-sized $36.6 million at the weekend box office, offering a counter example to the widespread belief in Hollywood that smart marketing can’t overcome dismal reviews in the Twitter age. Universal Pictures backed this relatively inexpensive comedy (budget: $35 million) with a deft ad campaign; billboards, for instance, featured a smiling Jason Bateman with the slogan “Is this the face of a sucker?” plastered across his forehead. And audiences responded, overlooking sharply negative reviews. The movie’s increasingly popular female lead, Melissa McCarthy, also helped turn out ticket buyers, particularly in the Midwest, analysts said. Making the film’s large debut even more impressive: Universal estimated that the gigantic winter storm that struck the Northeast on Friday took a 10 percent bite out of sales.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander Wang
abstract: The Wang fall show featured supersleek ponytails with burnt-orange-hued extensions.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the russet locks of the model Irina Kravchenko, who opened Alexander Wang’s show last season, Wang, along with the editorial hairstylist Guido Palau, decided to create supersleek ponytails featuring burnt-orange-hued extensions for his fall show. “All the extensions were dyed by Larry [Raspanti] at Whittemore House Salon, and it’s sort of the idea of seeing hair as a cosmetic,” Palau says. “The fakeness of the extensions is a part of the look; it’s about taking away each girl’s individual personality and creating a uniformity.” To give the hairstyle a futuristic feel, the front portion was tightly slicked back with loads of styling gel, and Palau amped up the shine factor even further by applying a small amount of Redken Diamond Oil (available in May) onto each model’s head right before she stepped out onto the runway.

headline: The Death Of Protectionism
abstract: I went back to trade policy, and my subject was gone.
lead_paragraph: Not especially relevant to any current debate, just interesting. In doing course prep for trade policy, I looked, as I always do, at the latest edition of the USITC publication on the economic effects of import restrictions — and discovered that my subject was gone. At least according to the ITC estimates, there’s almost nothing left to talk about:

headline: Rhythms Enlivened by Echoes of Haiti
abstract: The pianist Bobby Avey led a jazz quintet through “Authority Melts From Me,” an hourlong suite drawing on Haitian voodoo drumming traditions, at Symphony Space.
lead_paragraph: By nature if not by definition jazz musicians are tireless consolidators: of languages and rituals, of literatures and styles. Some artists exercise that impulse entirely within the jazz tradition, building on roughly a century of precedent (or, in too many cases, just a choice decade or two). Others seek purpose in charting unexpected routes or teasing out unlikely connections — something you may have noticed more of lately, especially among musicians under 40, and especially in New York.

headline: Still Say’s Law After All These Years
abstract: The primitive fallacy that just won’t die.
lead_paragraph: When John Maynard Keynes wrote The General Theory, three generations ago, he structured his argument as a refutation of what he called “classical economics”, and in particular of Say’s Law, the proposition that income must be spent and hence that there can never be an overall deficiency of demand. Ever since, historians of thought have argued about whether this was a fair characterization of what the classical economists, or at any rate his own intellectual opponents, really believed.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: American and US Airways May Announce a Merger This Week
abstract: The match would create the nation’s biggest airline and concentrate even further a once-fragmented industry.
lead_paragraph: After months of negotiations, American Airlines and US Airways appeared likely to announce a merger this week, which would create the nation’s biggest airline and concentrate even further a once-fragmented industry.

headline: What to Expect at Tonight’s Grammy Awards
abstract: The 55th Annual Grammy Awards will be broadcast on CBS on Sunday starting at 8 p.m. Join us here on ArtsBeat for live-blogging of the event from Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES –When the 55th Annual Grammy Awards are announced on Sunday, music fans should be in for a wild ride. There is no heavy favorite to sweep the awards like Adele did last year, and the nominees this year for the big awards — best new artist, album, record and song of the year — include a heavy presence of alternative bands and young artists that are not yet household names.

headline: Northeast Digs Out After Winter Storm
abstract: More than three feet of snow fell in parts of Connecticut, and more than two feet accumulated on Long Island and in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: More than three feet of snow fell in parts of Connecticut, and more than two feet accumulated on Long Island and in Massachusetts.

abstract: Army shades of green and khaki green are being paired with black and chic silhouettes on the runway.
lead_paragraph: Army shades of green and khaki green are being paired with black and chic silhouettes on the runway. Here, the feminine military look by Prabal Gurung, Jason Wu and Altuzarra.

headline: Richard Artschwager, Painter and Sculptor, Dies at 89
abstract: At a time when most artists worked in clearly determined styles, Mr. Artschwager slyly confounded the usual categories.
lead_paragraph: Richard Artschwager, a painter and sculptor whose witty, contradictory mixing of artistic genres made him one of the most critically admired artists to emerge in the 1960s, died early Saturday in Albany. He was 89.

headline: Anthony Scores 42, but Clippers Shut Him Down When It Counts
abstract: Carmelo Anthony scored only 4 of his game-high 42 points in the fourth quarter, allowing the Clippers to send the Knicks to their second loss in three games.
lead_paragraph: In some games, Carmelo Anthony can overpower teams with his superior skills on offense. He did just that two days ago against the Minnesota Timberwolves, when he scored 36 points to rescue the Knicks for a much-needed victory.

headline: Putting Everyday Cruelties in Focus
abstract: Harrison Atelier and a Merce Cunningham alumnus collaborate on an installation.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years Harrison Atelier, a design collective led by the husband-and-wife team Seth and Ariane Harrison, has eased its way into the dance world with collaborations with choreographers like Jonah Bokaer and Silas Riener, both former Merce Cunningham dancers. But while Mr. Bokaer’s work is all about control and optimal efficiency, Mr. Riener, unafraid of fraying seams, shows a wilder side.

headline: Remembering Marshall Miles, Player and Writer
abstract: Marshall Miles of Redlands, Calif., one of the most imaginative bridge players, died on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Marshall Miles of Redlands, Calif., one of the most imaginative bridge players, died on Tuesday. He was 86.

headline: Stravinsky Inspired, a Dance Aims High
abstract: “The Oracle,” a dance inspired by Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” was a star vehicle for the soloist Paul White.
lead_paragraph: Anyone making yet another dance to “The Rite of Spring” better have a good reason. The 100th anniversary of Stravinsky’s 1913 score isn’t enough. That event is surely among the reasons “The Oracle,” a 2009 “Rite” solo conceived and directed by the Australian choreographer Meryl Tankard, had its New York premiere at the Skirball Center on Thursday.

headline: Fusions That Defy Categories
abstract: The composer Sarah Kirkland Snider shared a bill with the vocalist Shara Worden, the indie-pop singer D M Stith, Clogs and Orchestra for the Next Century at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: The musical world has changed surprisingly quickly since New Amsterdam, a vital composer-led record label and live-event presenter, teamed up with the Kaufman Center to produce the first Ecstatic Music Festival in 2011. The fundamental notion of the series was to facilitate and encourage collaboration among musicians with disparate styles, bridging art-music and vernacular traditions.

headline: By Vivaldi and Company, Prizes From a Watery City
abstract: Venice Baroque Orchestra coaxed unusual sounds from instruments like the soprano recorder and bassoon at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: There was no grand thought or theme to unify the Venice Baroque Orchestra’s program at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, unless it was a sheer delight in virtuosity. For 21st-century listeners the elements of the ensemble’s name point most readily to Vivaldi, who occupied the first half of the program.

headline: Michael Cerveris to Join ‘Nikolai and the Others’
abstract: Lincoln Center Theater has found the cast for its production of Richard Nelson’s new play, “Nikolai and the Others.”
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center Theater has found the cast for its production of Richard Nelson’s new play, “Nikolai and the Others,” which depicts a fictional gathering of the real-life Russian émigrés who collaborated on the ballet “Orpheus.” Among others, the play will feature Michael Cerveris (“Evita”), above, as the choreographer George Balanchine, John Glover (“Death of a Salesman”) will be the composer Igor Stravinsky, and Stephen Kunken (“Enron”) is to be the composer Nicolas Nabokov. David Cromer (“Our Town,” “The House of Blue Leaves”) is the director. Tickets will go on sale March 10 with previews set to begin on April 4 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

lead_paragraph: Bulgari celebrates Serpenti exhibit; Altuzarra hosts after party.

abstract: Marion Rolland of France raced to victory in the downhill, an event the Americans were favored to dominate at the Alpine world championships, even without the injured Lindsey Vonn.
lead_paragraph: SCHLADMING, Austria — The most successful women’s speed squad in United States ski team history failed to win a medal on Sunday in the downhill, an event it was favored to dominate at the Alpine world championships.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Judge for Westminster Dog Show Dismisses Doubts About Fairness
abstract: James Moses, a renowned handler of German shepherds, acknowledged his close ties to many competitors but said his critics were “crybabies.”
lead_paragraph: WENTZVILLE, Mo. — In the world of dog shows, few wield as big a leash as James Moses. With a tug here or there, his influence can be felt among the people who spend much of their time, or all of it, in the quest for ribbons and silver bowls.

headline: A Crook With a Big Debt to Pay
abstract: The title character of Roger Hobbs’s “Ghostman” is a career criminal named Jack who’s helped many bank robbers escape over the years and is an expert in “the business of disappearing.”
lead_paragraph: A crucial clue in this smoking-fast new thriller is turned up by a “wheelman” — or car expert — who takes a BlackBerry photo of some muddy car tracks and using only his memory and an Internet connection is able to identify the tires that made those tread marks with 90 percent certainty in 10 minutes. “Wheelmen think differently from normal people,” says the novel’s narrator, known as Jack, who’s no slouch himself when it comes to details. “They see the little things.”

headline: Saying Hello to the Spirit of America, Kate Smith
abstract: In a concert at Lincoln Center the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe reprised her American Songbook show of standards made popular by Kate Smith.
lead_paragraph: While listening to the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe pour her heart and soul into songs associated with Kate Smith at the Allen Room on Saturday evening, I wondered if it were possible for any contemporary singer to embody the nation’s optimistic, can-do spirit with the force and purity that Smith brought to “God Bless America.” To what degree does such a feeling even exist anymore?

headline: Warner to Show 3-D Film Trailers at Truck Stops
abstract: To advertise the 3-D effects of “Jack the Giant Slayer,” the studio is buying space on Travel Plaza TV, distributed in about 300 gas stations and Pilot Flying J truck stops in 42 states.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Brothers marketers are hot in pursuit of … truckers?

headline: Tracy Reese: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Optimum Pipa Plucking, Surrounded by Friends
abstract: Wu Man and the Knights performed in concert at the Asia Society on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: As a rule critics pay little attention to friendship in music. Instead we talk about collaboration, with its implicit emphasis on labor, as if ensemble music were a task on a par with roofing a house. Thursday evening’s concert by Wu Man and the Knights at Asia Society was a refreshing reminder of how much music gains when it is performed by friends who delight as much in their art as in one another’s company.

headline: Cutting and Restitching Works to Create Fresh Perspectives
abstract: Bradley Teal Ellis and Neal Beasley added a twist to the Splice series at Dance New Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: Like most double-bill dance series, Dance New Amsterdam’s Splice normally pairs two choreographers or companies with little in common, apart from being not quite ready to handle an entire show alone. Last week’s Splice, however, was different.

headline: For a Composer’s Birthday, a Tribute at Full Blast
abstract: The Juilliard Orchestra paid a 75th-birthday tribute to the composer John Corigliano.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a little piece of paper attached to your program, but I have still been asked to say there will be a gunshot fired — a blank, of course,” the composer John Corigliano announced from the Carnegie Hall stage on Saturday night.

headline: Zany Quest for Laughs, the Chinese Version
abstract: “Lost in Thailand” reteams the actors Xu Zheng and Wang Baoqiang in their cross-country odd-couple shtick from the 2010 hit “Lost on Journey.”
lead_paragraph: What makes a hit? An unexpected blockbuster in China, the road comedy “Lost in Thailand” has beaten out the 3-D juggernaut “Avatar” there for the record of most tickets sold. Presumably to appeal to New Year celebrators here, the Chinese-owned AMC theaters hurried the film into a limited United States release, on Friday, without critics’ previews. Like many broad successes this unremarkable movie proves decidedly reluctant to yield any golden secret to box-office bonanzas, unless you count tried-and-true chase formulas and a moral about rethinking priorities.

headline: Wang’s Going-Away Present
abstract: Alexander Wang presents his last collection before crossing the Atlantic at (where else?) the Cunard Building.
lead_paragraph: There was splendid irony in Alexander Wang’s bon voyage collection, shown in the former ticketing hall of the Cunard Building in Lower Manhattan. He’s off to France to design Balenciaga.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: 2 Top British Awards Go to Affleck’s ‘Argo’
abstract: “Argo” continued its awards-season winning streak at the British Academy Film Awards in London on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: “Argo” continued its awards-season winning streak at the British Academy Film Awards in London on Sunday, winning two major prizes: best film and best director (for Ben Affleck). The awards were the latest in a run for “Argo” that includes top honors at the Golden Globes, Directors Guild and Producers Guild Awards. Daniel Day-Lewis won best actor for “Lincoln” and Emmanuelle Riva took best actress for “Amour.” The Baftas have been accurate predictors of the Oscars in recent years, naming eventual best picture winners like “Slumdog Millionaire,” “The King’s Speech” and “The Artist.”

headline: Apple’s Big Spending Competitor
abstract: The closest competitor to the iPhone is Samsung’s Galaxy. But the Korean manufacturer’s business model bears little resemblance to Apple’s. Samsung’s product line is extensive, and it spends a lot more than Apple on research and advertising.
lead_paragraph: The closest competitor to the iPhone is Samsung’s Galaxy. But the Korean manufacturer’s business model bears little resemblance to Apple’s. Samsung’s product line is extensive, and it spends a lot more than Apple on research and advertising.

headline: Watching the 2013 Grammy Awards
abstract: All the winners and running commentary from Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times, and Dave Itzkoff, a culture reporter.
lead_paragraph: Mumford & Sons won album of the year for “Babel,” Gotye’s “Somebody That I Used To Know” won record of the year and Fun. took home the best new artist award.

headline: Makes You Go ‘Hmm …’
abstract: Hail to Gary Cee.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t know about you, but I look forward to Monday puzzles. Early week puzzles are like the ascent of a roller-coaster car. There’s that teetering-at-the-top feeling after Wednesday or Thursday, when the trickiness builds up and the diabolical cluing kicks in, on Friday and Saturday we plunge full speed ahead, losing the theme that might help us gain a toehold in the grid, and then there’s the Sunday. The Sunday puzzle, while fun, requires stamina. It requires us to be in the zone. Some Sundays, it seems like it requires extra hydration and an energy bar.

headline: Youth in the Age of Obama
abstract: Young people have voted more Democratic since the 2004 election of George W. Bush, and they are much more likely than other groups to support a larger role for government.
lead_paragraph: Young people have voted more Democratic since the 2004 election of George W. Bush, and they are much more likely than other groups to support a larger role for government.

headline: Scenes From a Mall
abstract: Sometimes the show before the show is as fun as the show itself. This is often the case at Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the show before the show is as much fun as the show itself. This is often the case at Fashion Week, as we were reminded while chugging across the farthest reaches of West 22nd Street for at least the sixth time in four days.

headline: NPR Campaign Seeks the Quirky Listener
abstract: The public radio network aims to match its shows to potential listeners with even the oddest interests.
lead_paragraph: Are you a sky diving algebra teacher? A Sudoku-playing barista? NPR has a new ad campaign aimed at you.

headline: Longtime Wall Street Deal Maker Expands Advisory Firm

lead_paragraph: During his 29-year career on Wall Street, Robert Wolf has amassed a contact list full of boldface names from the worlds of finance and politics, up to and including President Obama.

headline: Deadly Stampede at Hindu Festival That Draws Millions
abstract: As many as 30 people were killed in India during a dash to get to the Hindu festival of Kumbh Mela, which was expected to draw 80 million pilgrims.
lead_paragraph: ALLAHABAD, India — The pilgrims came, millions upon millions of them, in the greatest tide of humanity ever seen. Again and again, the vast crowds threatened to press too close, to trample the smallest. Then it happened.

headline: The Enlightenment’s ‘Race’ Problem, and Ours
abstract: When we learned that witches did not exist, we threw out the category. So why do we cling to the discredited notion of race?
lead_paragraph: In 1734, Anton Wilhelm Amo, a West African student and former chamber slave of Duke Anton Ulrich of Braunschweig-Wolfenbüttel, defended a philosophy dissertation at the University of Halle in Saxony, written in Latin and entitled “On the Impassivity of the Human Mind.” A dedicatory letter was appended from the rector of the University of Wittenberg, Johannes Gottfried Kraus, who praised “the natural genius” of Africa, its “appreciation for learning,” and its “inestimable contribution to the knowledge of human affairs” and of “divine things.” Kraus placed Amo in a lineage that includes many North African Latin authors of antiquity, such as Terence, Tertullian and St. Augustine.In the following decade, the Scottish philosopher David Hume would write: “I am apt to suspect the Negroes, and in general all other species of men to be naturally inferior to the whites. There never was any civilized nation of any other complection than white, nor even any individual eminent in action or speculation.”Hume had not heard of Amo, that much is clear. But we can also detect a tremendous difference between Hume’s understanding of human capacities and that of Kraus: the author of Amo’s dedicatory letter doesn’t even consider the possibility of anchoring what individual human beings are capable of doing to something as arbitrary as “complection.” For Kraus, Amo represents a continent and its long and distinguished history; he does not represent a “race.”

headline: Measure to Protect Women Stuck on Tribal Land Issue
keywords: ['Violence Against Women Act (1994)', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'United States Politics and Government', 'Domestic Violence', 'Native Americans', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: Some House Republicans object to allowing Native American police and courts to pursue non-Indians who attack women on tribal land.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At 26, Diane Millich fell in love with and married a white man, moving with him in 1998 to a home on her native Southern Ute reservation in southern Colorado where, in short order, her life was consumed by domestic violence.

headline: Damascus on Edge as War Seeps Into Syrian Capital
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: For months, Damascus has hunched in a defensive crouch as fighting raged in suburbs, but a rebel advance has created a new level of alarm and disorder.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Unkempt government soldiers, some appearing drunk, have been deployed near a rebel-held railway station in the southern reaches of this tense capital. Office workers on 29th of May Street, in the heart of the city, tell of huddling at their desks, trapped inside for hours by gun battles that sound alarmingly close.

headline: Doubting if Tomorrow Will Ever Come for Taxi
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: The Taxi of Tomorrow, a nearly complete redesign, faces a legal challenge that claims the non-hybrid vehicle violates New York City’s administrative code.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s attempt to reimagine its taxicab experience, perhaps the least divisive of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s legacy-making transportation efforts, now appears to be the most at risk.

headline: Samsung Emerges as a Potent Rival to Apple’s Cool
abstract: After sweeping the market with the iPhone and the iPad, Apple has only one real competitor. And Samsung, unlike Apple, does think people know what they want.
lead_paragraph: Apple, for the first time in years, is hearing footsteps.

headline: Ira Rubin, Champion and the Beast of the Bridge Table, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Rubin, an innovator in bidding theory who earned 20 national or world team titles, was nicknamed the Beast for the emotional intensity of his play.
lead_paragraph: Ira Rubin, a champion bridge player and an innovative theorist who was nicknamed the Beast because of the emotional intensity of his play, died on Wednesday in Edison, N.J. He was 82.

headline: A New Swimsuit Issue Feature
abstract: The popular annual issue will contain a style guide to help women recreate the looks in the magazine, and Target is a marketing partner.
lead_paragraph: In addition to the usual array of leggy models in skimpy bikinis in exotic locations, Sports Illustrated’s swimsuit issue this year, due on Tuesday, has a surprising new feature: a small style guide geared toward the issue’s legions of female readers.

lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Breaking the Silence of Stillbirth
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Stillbirth']
abstract: Telling strangers about my stillborn daughter leaves me feeling like I’ve punched them. They cry. They try to shuffle away from me. I end up apologizing.
lead_paragraph: “Is she your only child?”

headline: When Anthony’s Output Shrinks, So Does Knicks’ Margin for Error

abstract: In a trend that is surprising pollsters and jangling the nerves of Republicans, a majority of young people embraces President Obama’s notion that government can be a constructive force.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — This funky college town, nestled along two rivers where five mountain ranges converge, has long been a liberal pocket, an isolated speck of blue in a deeply red state. Now Montana is electing more politicians who lean that way, thanks to a different-minded generation of young voters animated by the recession and social issues.
