headline: Fish in the Global Balance
abstract: The fillet on your plate is more likely to be farmed these days, but that doesn’t mean wild fish are off the hook.
lead_paragraph: At some point this year, humans will for the first time consume more farmed fish than wild-caught fish, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. This is a milestone of sorts, and also an inevitable transition resulting from the overfishing of wild fish stocks and a 30-year boom in aquaculture.

headline: The Conscience of a Corporation
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Corporations', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Stretching religious freedom to the breaking point.
lead_paragraph: DAVID GREEN, who built a family picture-framing business into a 42-state chain of arts and crafts stores, prides himself on being the model of a conscientious Christian capitalist. His 525 Hobby Lobby stores forsake Sunday profits to give employees their biblical day of rest. The company donates to Christian counseling services and buys holiday ads that promote the faith in all its markets. Hobby Lobby has been known to stick decals over Botticelli’s naked Venus in art books it sells.

headline: The Ignorance Caucus
abstract: The G.O.P. refuses to live in an evidence-based world.
lead_paragraph: Last week Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, gave what his office told us would be a major policy speech. And we should be grateful for the heads-up about the speech’s majorness. Otherwise, a read of the speech might have suggested that he was offering nothing more than a meager, warmed-over selection of stale ideas.

headline: Revitalizing Manhattan’s Midtown East
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Zoning', 'Editorials', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The area is due for rezoning, but a new development plan should not be rushed.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years have passed since New York City planners established the zoning rules for the glamorous swath of Manhattan known as East Midtown, an area that is home to Madison Avenue, Park Avenue, the Waldorf-Astoria and Grand Central Terminal. Much of the office space is aging and, in Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s view, cannot compete for global business with the West Side of Manhattan, let alone major cities in other countries.

headline: With Inquiry, an Attempt to Reassure Los Angeles
keywords: ['Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Police', 'Discrimination', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: As a manhunt continues, a new inquiry is intended to ease concerns about police misdeeds in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Police Chief Charlie Beck stood in front of a bank of television cameras on Sunday afternoon facing what seemed like two impossible tasks: luring in a fugitive former police officer accused of three murders and simultaneously assuring the public that his department was not backsliding on accusations of racism and corruption.

headline: Helicopter Crash Kills 3 TV Crew Members

lead_paragraph: A helicopter crash in Southern California on Sunday killed three men who were working on the production of a coming reality show for the Discovery Channel.

lead_paragraph: SCITUATE, Mass. — The monster snowstorm that buried the Northeast shut down all power to this seaside town on the South Shore of Boston and left Pearl Low without a warm bed.

headline: Ho-Hum for 39 Minutes, Then Game Got Interesting
abstract: Notre Dame’s win in five overtimes over Louisville was full of unusual events, including 158 shots attempted and a critical 12 points in 47 seconds by the Irish’s Jerian Grant, who had not hit a field goal until then.
lead_paragraph: It was after 1 a.m. Sunday when Casey Murdock finally left Notre Dame’s Purcell Pavilion, hoarse and exhausted and $18,000 richer.

headline: A Fashionable, if Safe, Red Carpet at the Grammy Awards
abstract: CBS warned music stars not to show too much flesh, and many of those who attended the show appeared to take the message to heart.
lead_paragraph: Last week, CBS issued a dress code for the 55th Annual Grammy Awards, threatening the often adventurous and revealing looks that have historically peppered the red carpet. Showing too much flesh was apparently among the list of no-nos. A dress code for the Grammys? Were things getting that out of hand? Unlike the Golden Globes and the Oscars, the Grammys red carpet has always been a place where an alternative expression of glamor was welcomed, even for men.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Amra Cerkezovic at Monique Lhuillier

keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Perhaps the reason so many people are in the dark about deadly drone strikes is because they want to be.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the debate over drone strikes broke out into plain view during the confirmation hearings for John O. Brennan, President Obama’s choice to head the Central Intelligence Agency. Given that the program has been operating largely under the public radar, a question has been raised whether the news media have done their job in keeping the American public informed about this radically different approach to warfare.

headline: An Arctic Awakening With Song and Soul
abstract: Chythia Hopkins’s latest piece, “This Clement World,” includes original songs and video footage that she shot during a three-week Arctic expedition.
lead_paragraph: Inviting friends over for dinner and then sitting them down to watch a slide show of your vacation photos was once a surefire way to turn intimates into acquaintances. Now, thanks to the wonders of social media, we can all share snaps of our fabulous trip to Nepal in a less oppressive style. But the quirky performer and writer Cynthia Hopkins takes the traditional route in her new show, “This Clement World,” a singing sermon preaching the evils of global warming.

headline: Obama to Renew Drive for Cuts in Nuclear Arms
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty']

Though it was Dr. Safyer who had banned candy, soda and deep-fried foods from hospital premises, as part of an anti-obesity campaign, he simply waited for the tirade to end and then stepped up to pay for his bag of cashews.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Robert Menendez sought to discourage any plan by the United States government to donate port security equipment to the Dominican Republic, citing concern that the advanced screening gear might undermine efforts by a private company — run by a major campaign contributor and friend of his — to do the work.

headline: Nets Fans Make a Lot of Noise, but This Time, It’s a Negative Message
abstract: The Nets have had an extended honeymoon in this maiden season in Brooklyn, but they were booed Sunday night as the Spurs pulled away for a 25-point victory.
lead_paragraph: The fade was gradual and then instant — a few harmless missteps, followed by a sudden, spectacular free fall. Tony Parker charged. The Nets stumbled and wheezed. And the Barclays Center soundtrack morphed from the warm, familiar “Brook-lyn” chant to something more wrathful: “Booooo.”

headline: With New Control, General to Focus on Withdrawal in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In a ceremony, Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. took command from Gen. John R. Allen in managing the withdrawal of American and international troops from Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. took command of both the American and the international military missions in Afghanistan in a traditional handoff ceremony on Sunday, becoming the 15th general to lead the international command here — and he is expected to be its last.

headline: Scoring Early, Late and Often, the Rangers Rise Above .500
abstract: Carl Hagelin scored two of the Rangers’ five goals against the reeling Tampa Bay Lightning at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: For the first time this season, in which they are expected to contend for the Stanley Cup, the Rangers rose above .500. They achieved that modest but essential goal on Sunday night with a 5-1 victory over the reeling Tampa Bay Lightning at Madison Square Garden, probably the Rangers’ most complete performance this season.

headline: Shumpert, Hearing Trade Rumors, Tries to Shrug Them Off
abstract: Iman Shumpert, who has played 12 games after recovering from knee surgery, has been struggling to find his rhythm on the court and his place with the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: Iman Shumpert was not his usual boisterous self after the Knicks’ 102-88 loss to the Los Angeles Clippers on Sunday. He spoke softly, sometimes responding to questions with one-word answers. Shumpert spent a majority of his time in the locker room with his head down.

headline: Conspiracy Buffs Gain in Court Ruling on Crash
abstract: Conspiracy buffs received some vindication when Italy’s highest court implicitly acknowledged a theory that a missile fired by a warplane hit Itavia Flight 870 in 1980.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Itavia Flight 870 was entering the final leg of a routine domestic trip from Bologna, Italy, to Palermo, Sicily, one clear summer evening when it suddenly plunged into the Tyrrhenian Sea near the small island of Ustica, killing all 81 people aboard.

headline: The Death of a Prodigy and the Limitations of Talent
abstract: As a young reporter, the author believed that talent provided immunity. He later learned otherwise.
lead_paragraph: I keep thinking of Aaron Swartz, the 26-year-old computer genius who apparently hanged himself last month. At the time, he was charged with being a cyber thief — downloading scholarly journals available by subscription fee only. Federal officials said he intended to distribute the articles and charged him with 13 felony counts and up to 35 years in prison. There was no allegation that he sought to profit, but rather that, rightly or wrongly, he was acting on the principle that such information should be free to the public.

headline: Yankees Opening Day: From Mantle to Jeter

lead_paragraph: The Yankees open this season against the Boston Red Sox in the Bronx on April 1— the same day, and same hour, as the Mets at home. The Yankees have had their share of good and bad moments on opening day, whether at Yankee Stadium or on the road. Below is a look at some of those. Share your favorite, or least favorite, Yankees opening day memories in the comments below.

headline: Mumford & Sons Win Album of the Year
abstract: In a year that seemed to tilt toward youth, the blues duo the Black Keys and the British folk-rockers Mumford & Sons took home top honors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Black Keys and their frontman, Dan Auerbach, emerged as the big winners at the Grammy Awards, taking home four trophies, including best rock album, but it was the British folk-rock group Mumford & Sons that won the coveted album of the year for “Babel.”

headline: Rabbi David Hartman, Champion of an Adaptive Judaism, Dies at 81
abstract: A charismatic teacher and prolific author, he encouraged students to question tradition and urged people of different backgrounds and ideologies to pore over Jewish texts together.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Rabbi David Hartman, an American-born Jewish philosopher who promoted a liberal brand of Orthodoxy and created a study center that expressed his commitment to pluralism by bringing together leaders from all strains of Judaism, died on Sunday at his home here. He was 81.

lead_paragraph: ‘Peony: the Knot of Shame,’ an original watercolor by the French artist Jean-Michel Othoniel, above, inspired by a new piece by the American poet Brenda Shaughnessy.

headline: Picking Addiction Help
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: There are many factors to consider before starting a treatment program for addiction. In a helpful new book called “Now What? An Insider’s Guide to Addiction and Recovery,” William Cope Moyers explains that “there’s no one-size-fits-all approach” to addiction treatment.
lead_paragraph: “Treatment is not a prerequisite to surviving addiction.” This bold statement opens the treatment chapter in a helpful new book, “Now What? An Insider’s Guide to Addiction and Recovery,” by William Cope Moyers, a man who nonetheless needed “four intense treatment experiences over five years” before he broke free of alcohol and drugs.

headline: Mets Opening Day: From Hodges to Santana
abstract: Hoping to turn around their fortunes, the Mets will open their season at home on April 1 against the San Diego Padres — the same day and hour as the Yankees at home.
lead_paragraph: The Mets open this season on April 1 against the San Diego Padres in Queens, at the same time, and hour, as the Yankees open at home in the Bronx. Like the Yankees, the Mets have had their share of memorable moments on opening day, good and bad, at home and on the road. Below is a look at some of those. Share your favorite, or least favorite, Mets opening day memory in thecomments below.

headline: New Appreciation for the Old Days: A Little Bit Raw
abstract: Grammy voters want popular music to have credibility, breadth and a kind of moral weight. But they are also, and always have been, tired of new complications.
lead_paragraph: Grammy voters want popular music to have credibility, breadth and a kind of moral weight. But they are also, and always have been, tired of new complications. It’s not just that they are behind the curve; they are starting to bet that things really were better in the old days. Simple preference has turned into style. They are perforce becoming antiquarians.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO2) SHAME (2011) A handsome Manhattanite named Brandon (Michael Fassbender, above) hooked on sex finds his routine disrupted by the arrival of his sister (Carey Mulligan), whose neediness threatens his detached self-control — and whose self-destructive tendencies fuel his own — in this drama from the director Steve McQueen. “We’re not bad people,” she says in a teary message on his cellphone. “We just come from a bad place.” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times: “Is ‘Shame’ the name of something Brandon does feel, or of something the filmmakers think he should feel? The movie, for all its displays of honesty (which is to say nudity), is also curiously coy. It presents Brandon for our titillation, our disapproval and perhaps our envy, but denies him access to our sympathy. I know, that’s the point, that Mr. McQueen wants to show how the intensity of Brandon’s need shuts him off from real intimacy, but this seems to be a foregone conclusion, the result of an elegant experiment that was rigged from the start.”

headline: The 2013 Grammy Awards
abstract: Gotye’s “Somebody That I Used To Know” won record of the year, while Fun. won best new artist and Kelly Clarkson won best pop vocal album for “Stronger.”
lead_paragraph: Gotye’s “Somebody That I Used To Know” won record of the year, while Fun. won best new artist and Kelly Clarkson won best pop vocal album for “Stronger.”

headline: ‘Les Miz’ Meets ‘Gangnam Style,’ and YouTube Cheers
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Movies']
abstract: Millions have watched a parody of “Les Misérables” put out by the South Korean Air Force and inspired by the “Gangnam Style” video.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The “Gangnam Style” video has spawned seemingly endless remakes; there are even sites that allow viewers to insert photos of themselves onto the animated bodies of people performing the famous horse dance.

headline: News Quiz | February 11, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: For Delhi Elite, a Glut of Police Protection
abstract: A dozen police officers for each Delhi V.I.P., report says.
lead_paragraph: When Nandita Mukerjee, a suburban mom, joined the throngs protesting in New Delhi in December, hours after a gang rape victim died, she said she came in part because she feared for her young daughter’s safety.

headline: Builder of China’s ‘Great Firewall’ Finds His Holiday Greetings Spurned
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: When Fang Binxing, a major architect of China’s system of Internet censorship, sent netizens New Year’s greetings over the weekend, many told him to “go to hell.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Fang Binxing is known here as the “Father of the Wall,” that is, the Great Firewall — the sprawling system of technological controls in China that has created a parallel online world, or “Chinternet,” where global favorites such as YouTube, Twitter and Facebook are blocked.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 10
abstract: A view of the day in sports, from rugby to dogs.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, from rugby to dogs.

headline: Deadly Stampede at Hindu Festival That Draws Millions
abstract: As many as 36 people were reported killed in India during a dash to get to the Hindu festival of Kumbh Mela, which was expected to draw 80 million pilgrims.
lead_paragraph: ALLAHABAD, India — The pilgrims came, millions upon millions of them, in the greatest tide of humanity ever seen. Again and again, the vast crowds threatened to press too close, to trample the smallest. Then it happened.

headline: Deadly Stampede During Hindu Religious Festival
abstract: Those who bathe in the conjoined waters of the Ganges and Yamuna Rivers are cleansed of their sins and given blessings that extend through several generations, Hindus say. The Kumbh Mela event happens once every 12 years.
lead_paragraph: Those who bathe in the conjoined waters of the Ganges and Yamuna Rivers are cleansed of their sins and given blessings that extend through several generations, Hindus say. The Kumbh Mela event happens once every 12 years.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 11
abstract: Damascus under siege; Scotland faces hurdles to independence; adjuncts’ rights at American universities in France; Olivetti in Milan; and Suzy Menkes on New York fashion week.
lead_paragraph: NEWS For months, Damascus has hunched in a defensive crouch as fighting raged in suburbs, but a rebel advance has created a new level of alarm and disorder. An employee of the New York Times reports from Damascus and Anne Barnard reports from Beirut.

headline: Public Grooming at the Met
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: During intermission at the Metropolitan Opera, a theater-goer felt the need for a shave.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Message From a Sadhu: Detach From Family to Avoid Sadness
abstract: The mystics who come to the Kumbh are part of religious orders that were once mercenary armies, who severed all social ties.
lead_paragraph: ALLAHABAD, Uttar Pradesh — Do your duty, but stop worrying so much about parents, wife and children.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 11, 2013
abstract: Can you estimate the number of kilometers François Gabart sailed to win the Vendée Globe, a solo, nonstop, around-the-world sailing race?
lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “A Worldwide Race Has a Winner, but Is Not Over.”

headline: Music’s Brightest Stars Shine at the Grammy Awards
abstract: Who won Grammy Awards on Sunday evening?
lead_paragraph: In “New Appreciation for the Old Days: A Little Bit Raw,” Ben Ratliff reports on the 55th Annual Grammy Awards show.

headline: Hakon Invest to Buy Stake in Nordic Retailer for $3.1 Billion
abstract: The Swedish company Hakon Invest has agreed to buy the remaining stake in the Nordic retailer ICA that it does not already own for $3.1 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Swedish investment company Hakon Invest agreed on Monday to buy the remaining stake in the Nordic retailer ICA it did not already own for 20 billion Swedish kronor, or $3.1 billion.

headline: Province by Province, a Portrait of China
abstract: A Swiss couple thought it would be a good project to photograph all of China’s provinces. They got a great portrait series, and then some.
lead_paragraph: When the Swiss photographers Mathias Braschler and Monika Fischer took a six-month road trip across the United States for their portrait series “About Americans,” it was a journey through a foreign land. Sort of.

headline: Does Your Life Leave You Enough Time to Relax?
abstract: Could you change your daily routine so that you had more time to rest?
lead_paragraph: Imagine your life with more sleep, longer breaks from school and all your other obligations, maybe even regular naps.

headline: Grammys Measure Present by the Past
abstract: The structure of the award-giving, in which representatives of yesteryear weigh in on the acts of today, precludes the Grammys from capturing the shape, scale and range of modern music.
lead_paragraph: Imagine, if you will, the Grammy Awards of 2045. The winners will be a diverse lot: young pop-rappers who sound like suburban Wiz Khalifas; dance-music producers using the dubstep drop ironically; all manner of Taylor Swift revivalists; pop-R&B-hip-hop hybridizers who sample Drake, maybe Mumford & Sons.

headline: Scotland Faces More Hurdles if It Approves Independence
abstract: A legal opinion from the British government could intensify the debate over the terms under which Scotland might achieve a divorce from Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Scotland would have to renegotiate membership in the European Union and other international organizations if it votes for independence in a referendum next year, according to legal advice published on Monday by the British government.

headline: Tips for First-Generation College Applicants
abstract: Admissions officers seek a diverse student body and want to hear what has shaped a student’s life, including if you are the first in your family to attend college.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Michele Hernandez is the former assistant director of admissions at Dartmouth College, co-founder of Application Boot Camp On-Demand, and the author of several books on college admissions.

headline: The Underpopulation Bomb
abstract: It’s not a low fertility rate but rather the failure of public policies to provide sufficient support for parents that is troubling, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.“

headline: The Early Word: Reinvigorate
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times

headline: Q.& A.: Checking a PC’s Graphics Card
keywords: ['Computer Chips', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Desktop Computers', 'Laptop Computers']
abstract: A quick visit to the Windows 7 Control Panel tells you how much memory your computer has dedicated to graphics and video.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: A Statement Rocks Rome, Then Sends Shockwaves Around the World
abstract: The pope’s announcement, made at a routine meeting, came “like a bolt out of the blue,” said a participant.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The decision, delivered in Latin and in unemotional tones by Pope Benedict XVI to a gathering of cardinals on Monday, came “like a bolt out of the blue,” one of the participants said, and it soon ricocheted around the world.

headline: The Media Is the Message
abstract: “A journalist is tasked with making money for those who hired him,” says Russia’s deputy minister of communications.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — “A journalist has to be fully aware that he is not tasked with making the world better.” So said Alexei Volin, deputy minister of communications and mass media, a keynote speaker at a conference called “Journalism in 2012: The Profession and Its Function in Society,” held this past weekend at Moscow University’s Journalism Department.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Free Furniture!
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Small Business', 'Start-ups', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A Super Bowl promotion costs one business owner $600,000 in free furniture. Manufacturing surges, home prices rise, and Mark Zuckerberg offers lessons in entrepreneurship. Will you notice when the Postal Service stops delivering on Saturdays?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jeff Himmelman on Frank Ocean Wanting It Clean
abstract: The author of this week’s cover story discusses the differences between Frank Ocean the singer-songwriter (emotionally open) and Frank Ocean the person (in control).
lead_paragraph: Jeff Himmelman, the author of “Yours in Truth,” a biography of Ben Bradlee, wrote this week’s cover story about the singer-songwriter Frank Ocean. Himmelman last wrote for the magazine about the solar-power industry.

headline: Guilt Trip
abstract: Guilt is our inner police force, but if we give it too much emotional power, we risk turning into a police state.
lead_paragraph: Guilt will never make the grade as an A-list emotion. No one has ever written a sonnet or a power ballad about how they haven’t called their mother in over a week and their expensive-bought-off-QVC exercise bike is being used to dry their underwear. Yet somehow, this peevish little C-lister of the emotional spectrum manages to punch way above its weight.

headline: Daily Report: Samsung Emerges as a Potent Rival to Apple’s Cool
abstract: Apple, the maker of iPhones, iPads and iPods, has never faced a challenger able to make a truly popular and profitable smartphone or tablet — until Samsung Electronics. Yet these two rivals could not be more different, Brian X. Chen reports in Monday’s New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Apple, for the first time in years, is hearing footsteps, reports Brian X. Chen in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 11, 2013
abstract: Every Monday morning, we publish a New York Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see and why in our comments section.
lead_paragraph: Update: Feb 12, 2013

headline: Austere Indeed
abstract: And it undermines recovery.
lead_paragraph: An annoyed Ryan Avent combats claims that we aren’t seeing any real federal spending cuts. Indeed — for those of us who warned that premature austerity would undermine recovery, it’s frustrating to see the other side shift from “Austerity is expansionary!” to “Austerity? What austerity?” when it turned out that austerity did, indeed, undermine recovery.

headline: Is Europe’s New Budget Really 20 Percent Green? Opinions Differ
abstract: The European Union claims that one out of every five euros across its proposed budget goes toward fighting climate change. But austerity has provoked cuts too.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s proposed budget for 2014-20, fiercely negotiated in Brussels until Friday, is smaller than its predecessors — a first for a European budget and the surest sign that Continent-wide austerity has seeped into one of the most important documents of the union.

headline: In M.L.S., New Season, New Shirts
abstract: Major League Soccer kicks off Jersey Week on Monday, Feb. 25, when 12 of the league’s 19 teams will unveil new primary, secondary or third shirts.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer has designs for putting some new shirts on your back. To be specific, new team jerseys from 12 of the league’s 19 teams that will be unveiled in a uniform manner (sorry!) beginning next Monday through Feb. 28. The league’s 2013 season opens with six games on March 2 and three on March 3.

headline: Opinion Report: Midtown Rezoning
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: Challenging the Deal for Dell
abstract: The deal to take Dell private faces a major roadblock. | American Airlines and US Airways may announce a merger this week. | Barclays is to announce an overhaul of its business units on Tuesday. | Many Americans, chasing higher returns, have turned to speculative investments promoted by aggressive financial advisers, leading to steep losses and accusations of fraud.
lead_paragraph: The deal to take Dell private faces a major roadblock. Southeastern Asset Management, the company’s largest outside shareholder with an 8.5 percent stake, said on Friday that it would oppose the buyout plan, contending in a letter to the board that the offer of $24.4 billion, or $13.65 a share, was too low. Saying the company was worth closer to $24 a share, Southeastern laid out a range of possible tactics, including a proxy fight and lawsuits, to block the “ill-advised transaction,” DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports.

headline: Malian and French Troops Reassert Control in Key City
abstract: Soldiers filled the city of Gao on Monday after a firefight Sunday suggested that the quick French campaign against Islamist extremists in Mali was not over.
lead_paragraph: GAO, Mali — French and Malian troops appeared on Monday to have reasserted control of this strategic settlement in northern Mali after a protracted firefight with Islamist extremists who infiltrated the city after being chased from it two weeks ago.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Folk and Rock are Ascendant at the Grammys, and a Belated Focus on Drones
abstract: The Grammy Awards celebrated rock and folk almost to the exclusion of other genres; current scrutiny of the government’s drone program points out the lack of attention paid to it thus far; and NBC Universal will rebrand one of its cable channels the Esquire Network.
lead_paragraph: Blues-rock band the Black Keys and their frontman Dan Auerbach were the big winners at the Grammy Awards Sunday night, walking away with four statues, but folk-rock group Mumford & Sons won the album of the year for “Babel,” James C. McKinley Jr. writes. Belgian-Australian songwriter Gotye won three trophies, including record of the year and best pop duo, and Fun. won best new artist and song of the year for “We Are Young.” Adele became the first woman since Barbra Streisand to win the award for best pop solo performance two years in a row, Frank Ocean won for best contemporary urban album, and Kanye West and Jay-Z won three awards for their collaboration album, “Watch the Throne.” The nominations for the top four awards favored rock and folk while ignoring electronic dance music, hip-hop and country.

headline: Toward a Cure for Range Anxiety
abstract: A report suggests ways of building out the electric car infrastructure in the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: Judging from John M. Broder’s harrowing account of driving a Tesla Model S up Interstate 95, the range anxiety that discourages acceptance of all-electric vehicles in the Northeast is well-founded.

headline: Prep With an Edge From Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: Tommy Hilfiger’s women’s show Sunday night at the Park Avenue Armory continued his vision of the classic American preppy look with an unexpected edge.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Hilfiger’s vision of fashion is that of an American designer who is also an Anglophile, and whose work, somewhat ironically, has in recent years been most appreciated by European customers who are fans of the American preppy sportswear look.

headline: Latest Updates on Pope’s Resignation
abstract: The Lede is providing updates on Pope Benedict XVI’s announcement on Monday that he intends resign on Feb. 28, less than eight years after he took office, the first pope to do so in six centuries.
lead_paragraph: The Lede is providing updates on Pope Benedict XVI’s announcement on Monday that he intends to resign on Feb. 28, less than eight years after he took office, the first pope to do so in six centuries. (Turn off auto-refresh to watch videos.)

headline: Monday Reading: Relax! You’ll be More Productive
abstract: Relaxing in order to be more productive, a doubly taxing season for same-sex couples, new fraud targets ordinary retirement savers and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: More About US Austerity
abstract: Too little spending in the face of severe shocks.
lead_paragraph: Following up on this post, you get an even better picture if you include state and local government spending. Yes, states and localities generally have to more or less balance their budgets — but the feds could and should have provided much more aid, so s&l austerity was also a policy choice. If we look at total government spending as a share of potential GDP, we get this:

headline: Mission Creep in Mali
abstract: French leaders initially promised that the maximum number of soldiers would be 2,500. Now the figure is put at 4,000. And while the initial French military action seemed to claim dramatic successes, a resurgence of fighting in Gao on Sunday, followed by an explosion on Monday, deepened suspicions that the rebels were far from beaten.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—When a mysterious explosion rocked the northern Mali city of Gao early on Monday, the reverberations echoed in Paris, raising anew the question of whether the French troops who claimed initial successes in evicting Islamist militants from the desert region would be able to meet their government’s deadline to withdraw in March.

headline: British Regulators to Investigate Accounting at Autonomy
abstract: The Financial Reporting Council, Britain’s accounting watchdog, says it will investigate accounts at the British software maker Autonomy after accusations from Hewlett-Packard that Autonomy inflated its financial figures.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British accounting regulators said on Monday that they would investigate the financial reporting at the British software maker Autonomy before its $11.1 billion acquisition by Hewlett-Packard in 2011.

headline: History of Early Christianity Named Best Scholarly Book in Arts and Sciences
abstract: Peter Brown’s 800-page “Through the Eye of the Needle” has also become a best-seller for a book of its type.
lead_paragraph: It may be easier for a rich man to enter the kingdom of heaven than for an 800-page, heavily footnoted scholarly book about early Christianity to enter the best-seller list.

headline: Dinosaur Bones
abstract: A jewelry designer has debuted dazzling pieces built around fossil fragments.
lead_paragraph: Monique Péan — jewelry designer and natural history fetishist — has already forged pieces from the horns of buffalo and fossilized tusks of woolly mammoth. Now she enters the late Jurassic era with dazzling pieces built around fossil fragments from stegosauruses and other giant reptiles that roamed the earth 150 million years ago.

headline: Goldman Names a New Co-Head of M.&A.
abstract: Goldman Sachs has named Gregg R. Lemkau as a new co-head of global mergers and acquisitions, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs named Gregg R. Lemkau as a new co-head of global mergers and acquisitions on Monday, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

headline: From the British, a Glimpse of  Winners to Come?
abstract: Though “Argo” led the Baftas, the British version of the Academy Awards spread the wealth among several films, including “Amour,” “Lincoln” and “Life of Pi.”
lead_paragraph: The British have spoken and they like the unabashedly Hollywood filmmaking of “Argo.”

headline: After Storm, Commuters Navigate Slick, Slushy Roads
abstract: Public transit systems were operating close to normal Monday morning, but the streets could be perilous, especially in Connecticut and on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: As the New York City region started a new workweek on Monday, some commuters, especially in Connecticut and on eastern Long Island, still had to cope with the aftermath of Friday’s mammoth snowstorm. The treacherous road conditions and the difficulty in removing vast amounts of snow also lead to numerous school closings.

headline: New Rove Group Could Backfire on G.O.P.
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An analysis of Republican Senate primaries in 2010 and 2012 suggests that money is usually the least pressing problem for the establishment candidates whom Karl Rove’s new “super PAC” might be inclined to support.
lead_paragraph: The strategist Karl Rove and his allies last week announced the formation of Conservative Victory Project, a new “super PAC” designed to lend support to what they see as more electable candidates in Republican Senate primaries.

headline: The Feminine Mystique Turns 50. So Where Are We Now?
abstract: On Tuesday, the Op-Ed columnist Gail Collins will host a live discussion about the state of feminism at nytimes.com/roomfordebate.
lead_paragraph: This month marks the 50th anniversary of Betty Friedan’s The Feminine Mystique — the book that’s been credited with igniting the second wave feminist movement of the 1960s. What’s left in the fight for gender equality in the United States? On Tuesday, Op-Ed Columnist Gail Collins, who wrote the book’s new introduction, will host a live video discussion on the state of feminism at nytimes.com/roomfordebate.

headline: A CBS Deal Bolsters Amazon’s Challenge to Netflix
abstract: Slowly but confidently, Amazon is building a library of television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, whose executives love to see the competition.
lead_paragraph: Slowly but confidently, Amazon is building a library of television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, whose executives love to see the competition.

headline: Beauty Blogging at N.Y. Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries']
abstract: At Fashion Week, beauty bloggers like Emily Weiss have become part of what she calls the “roving backstage circus.” Her Web site receives more than six million page views per month.
lead_paragraph: At Fashion Week, beauty bloggers like Emily Weiss have become part of what she calls the “roving backstage circus.” Her Web site receives more than six million page views per month.

headline: S.&P. Lawsuit Draws New Line in the Sand
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The government’s lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s over credit ratings suggests that we may see fewer settlements and more court cases involving financial institutions in the future.
lead_paragraph: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The Gray Report: The better the sake, the simpler and more elegant, W. Blake Gray reports. — Eric Asimov

headline: The Resignation of Pope Benedict XVI
abstract: The Times’s Rachel Donadio reports from Rome. | John T. McGreevy, a professor at Notre Dame, on challenges in the United States for the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Rachel Donadio reports from Rome. | John T. McGreevy, a professor at Notre Dame, on challenges in the United States for the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Bail Process Varies by Borough, Analysis Shows
abstract: An analysis by New York City’s Criminal Justice Agency found wide variations in whether defendants in felony cases are released at arraignment, detained until bail is paid or denied bail altogether.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Lippman, New York State’s chief judge, called last week for fundamental revisions in how bail is set. Among other changes, he would let judges take into account whether defendants pose a threat to the public, rather than only whether they are a flight risk.

headline: European Ministers at Odds Over Strength of the Euro
abstract: The currency’s rise is making Europe’s exports more expensive, a factor that could hamper growth.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Concern over the euro moved to the forefront Monday as finance ministers of the countries using the currency held their monthly meeting. But this time, with the European Union’s recession continuing, the topic was the strength of the euro rather than its many weaknesses.

headline: Starz Extends Deal With Sony Pictures
abstract: The pay cable channel has completed a deal with Sony Pictures Entertainment, extending an agreement for exclusive access to Sony movies through 2021.
lead_paragraph: 12:43 p.m. | Updated The pay cable channel Starz has completed a deal with Sony Pictures Entertainment, extending an agreement for exclusive access to Sony movies through 2021.

headline: Maybe You Don’t Really Need Investors
abstract: This owner was falling for the myth that comes from Silicon Valley and shows like “Shark Tank” — that you need investors to make great things happen.
lead_paragraph: I spoke recently with an entrepreneur who is trying to start a security business. He and his colleagues plan to offer high-end security to executives of large corporations, and they called us hoping we could help them find money.

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: Snapchat’s Path From Stanford to the Beach
abstract: How Snapchat went from a project of two roommates to a photo app sensation, with headquarters in a beach house on the Venice boardwalk in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, I reported about the recent successes of an up-and-coming start-up, Snapchat, that lets people send messages that disappear after they are viewed. I spent two days with the founders of the company, Evan Spiegel and Bobby Murphy, in Los Angeles, interviewing them and learning about their business.

headline: On Our Radar: Protesters Sue Japanese Whalers
abstract: An environmental group seeks $3 million in damages over the sinking of its vessel in Antarctic waters.
lead_paragraph: An antiwhaling group sues Japanese whalers in federal court in Oregon for ramming its protest vessel and causing it to sink in frigid waters off Antarctica three years ago. The whalers have said that the group, Sea Shepherd, was responsible for the accident. [OregonLive]

headline: ABC Wins First Interview With Amanda Knox
abstract: Diane Sawyer, the anchor of ABC’s “World News,” will conduct the interview of Ms. Knox, to be televised in prime time on April 30.
lead_paragraph: Years of jostling among television networks for the first on-camera interview of Amanda Knox ended on Monday when ABC said it had won.

headline: Samsung vs. Apple: The Capital Spending Battlefield
abstract: Executives at Samsung Electronics emphasize the company’s market research and design processes. But the other crucial parts to the company’s success are its huge investments in capital spending and marketing, far exceeding any other consumer electronics company.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times on Monday, I examined how Samsung Electronics has emerged to become a true challenger to Apple, the most profitable technology company in the world.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Nars Outremer Eyeshadow
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: At Thakoon, smoky blue eyes layered with glitter evoked summertime.
lead_paragraph: The designer Thakoon Panichgul asked the makeup artist Diane Kendal to integrate the feeling of summertime, the inspiration behind his fall collection, into the beauty look for last night’s show. “So we created a deep, smoky blue eye layered with three colors of glitter — bronze, a pink bronze and gold — that make it look like the eyes are reflecting the sun,” Kendal says. While the decision to add a dramatic dose of sparkle stemmed from Panichgul’s chosen theme, incorporating the rich cobalt shade — Nars Eyeshadow in Outremer, to be exact — was purely Kendal’s idea. “There wasn’t really any reference for it; I just love this blue!” she says. To best wear this ultra-pigmented hue, Kendal recommends applying a little foundation on the lid first. “When you put the color on top of it, the foundation will help with blending and smoothing,” she says. “Just do one layer of color at a time and gradually build it up, and then blend the edges with a clean makeup brush to get a soft effect.”

headline: Congressman Clarifies: He’s Pro-‘Argo,’ but It’s No Conspiracy
abstract: The Connecticut congressman who wrote a letter seeking a correction in the way “Lincoln” portrays his state’s vote on the 13th Amendment says he was not part of any effort to help “Argo.”
lead_paragraph: Congressman Joe Courtney, who spoke out against historical inaccuracies in “Lincoln,” has now come out in favor of its chief Oscar rival, “Argo.”

headline: A Third Act for Phillip Kirschen-Clark
abstract: The chef was at Vandaaq and then Demi Monde.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Kirschen-Clark, the peripatetic chef who made waves at Vandaag, then left and showed up for several months at the clubby Demi Monde near Wall Street, has a new job. He is now the chef at Judi Wong’s cozy Cafe Cluny in the West Village, preparing a mix of classic and locavore modern dishes, including a beet-and-pear salad with pickled walnuts, king salmon with salsify and romanesco cauliflower, and homemade cavatelli in a lobster bisque sauce.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb.11
abstract: Kashmir Valley under curfew for the third day in a row.

headline: Syfy Plans Adaptation of Philip K. Dick’s ‘Man in the High Castle’
abstract: “The Man in the High Castle,” Dick’s novel of alternate history and mysticism, and an early meditation on the nature of reality, is being developed for a television adaptation by Frank Spotnitz, a writer and producer of “The X-Files,” and Ridley Scott, the director of “Blade Runner.”
lead_paragraph: A world in which the Allies lost World War II may not sound like a pleasant place,  but it is the basis of one of Philip K. Dick‘s most celebrated works and, potentially, a mini-series for cable TV’s Syfy channel. Syfy said on Monday that it was developing a four-hour adaptation of “The Man in the High Castle,” Dick’s 1962 novel of mysticism, alternate history (and alternate histories within that alternate history) and an early meditation on what is or is not real from the future author of “A Scanner Darkly” and “Ubik.”

headline: The Gun Report: February 11, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: As Second Amendment absolutists continue to complain that this report is “one-sided” because we are not publishing examples of the many, many (oh-so-many!) instances of people who use guns to defend themselves, we throw down a challenge. My assistant Jennifer and I publish this report based simply on a daily Google search and occasional articles that we come across in the course of our day. If you send us examples of self-defense that you find, we will print them. You have to use the same rules we use: stick to simple online searches, and only use incidents that take place that day.  For all your complaining about our “distorting” reality, I predict that the number of shootings that are accidental, the result of rage or gang violence, that come from drive-by shootings, or are premeditated, will outnumber the self-defense examples by an order of at least 20 or 30 to 1. Go ahead, make my day: see if you can prove me wrong.

headline: Who’s the Met Calling Punk?
abstract: The Met arranged a brief Fashion Week preview of the Costume Institute’s next big exhibition, “Punk: Chaos to Couture,” opening May 9.
lead_paragraph: “Fashion, quite literally, is trash,” said Andrew Bolton, a curator at the Costume Institute, toward the end of his remarks at a news conference Monday morning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Millions May Be Affected by Credit Report Errors
abstract: Five percent of consumers may benefit from correcting errors in their credit reports by qualifying for better loan rates.
lead_paragraph: About 5 percent of consumers in a new study had errors in their credit reports that could lead to them paying higher rates for loans.

headline: The Idea of America Is Also Drones’ Collateral Damage
abstract: Torture, at least, is not usually fatal. Done out of sight, its true extent remains a dirty little secret. Drone strikes are exponentially different. Their very principle redefines America for a world that once expected something better.
lead_paragraph: In Washington, drones in dark suits continue to insist that remote-control murder and “enhanced interrogation” abroad are essential because they keep Americans safer at home. This is not evident on the receiving end.

headline: Why Buy a Condo You Seldom Use? Because You Can
abstract: The higher the price in the New York City market, the more common are absentee owners based in places like Monaco or Texas.
lead_paragraph: In the ornate lobby of the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, high heels clack across the marble floor, glasses clink at a bar in the corner, neatly dressed porters scurry back and forth, and the buzz of quiet conversation ripples through the room. But just around the corner, at the entrance reserved for residents of the Plaza’s condominium apartments, the gilded lobby stands all but silent. Here, very few people come and go, because most of the apartment owners live someplace else.

headline: The VIEWMONGOUS Puzzle
abstract: Sharp says its 80-inch LED TV has “more than double the screen area of a 55-inch TV.” Is this true?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Karim Ani, founder of Mathalicious, an online source for real-world math lessons for classroom teachers.

headline: 9/11 Case Is Delayed as Defense Voices Fears on Eavesdropping
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Lawyers in the case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others said they worry that their communications may be subject to government monitoring.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The tribunal case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others accused of being accomplices in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was delayed again on Monday as defense lawyers pressed forward with concerns that their confidential communications with their clients and other counsel may be subject to eavesdropping by the government.

headline: Price for a New Hip? Many Hospitals Are Stumped
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hips', 'Hospitals', 'Implants', 'Medicine and Health', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Surgery and Surgeons']
abstract: A new paper puts a spotlight on an opaque medical system in which prices are often hidden from consumers.
lead_paragraph: Jaime Rosenthal, a senior at Washington University in St. Louis, called more than 100 hospitals in every state last summer, seeking prices for a hip replacement for a 62-year-old grandmother who was uninsured but had the means to pay herself.

headline: Wheelies: The Petite Edition
abstract: Fiat will move all global production of the next-generation 500 minicar to Tychy, Poland, ending assembly of the model at Chrysler’s Mexico plant by 2015, Automotive News Europe reported Monday
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Russian Art Center Looks to the West for New Curator
abstract: The Garage Center for Contemporary Culture in Moscow, a nonprofit art center opened in 2008 by the heiress and collector Dasha Zhukova, has chosen Kate Fowle, a British-born curator who has been working for many years in New York.
lead_paragraph: As Russia’s power in the contemporary art world rises, it is beginning to draw curatorial talent from around the world. In the latest example, the Garage Center for Contemporary Culture in Moscow, a nonprofit art center opened in 2008 by the heiress and collector Dasha Zhukova, has chosen Kate Fowle, a British-born curator who has been working for many years in New York, to be its new chief curator.

headline: Catholics React With Shock, Sympathy and Muted Criticism
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Popes']
abstract: The news that Pope Benedict XVI would step down drew an immediate outpouring of tributes matched only by speculation about his health and the future of a church in transition.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — From his native Bavaria to the farthest corners of the earth he touched during his papacy, the Roman Catholic world greeted the news of Pope Benedict XVI’s departure Monday with surprise, concern for his health and more than a little understanding that an 85-year-old man no longer had the strength to lead a global flock of one billion faithful.

headline: The Daily Do | Victoria Beckham
abstract: Victoria Beckham traded her sleek and polished locks in favor of a tousled ponytail.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham traded her sleek and polished locks in favor of a tousled ponytail. Like her expertly cut knits, the best were accented with supershort, razor-cut childlike bangs draped across the models’ faces.

headline: The All-Singing, All-Dancing Oscars (With Room for ‘The Avengers’)
abstract: The producers of the Oscars telecast add several musical performers, though the cast of “The Avengers” will be on hand as well.
lead_paragraph: If the Grammys were a retro-flavored spectacle of revisionist rhythms, the Oscars may well follow suit.

headline: Carolina Herrera: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Swimming With Gentle Giants
abstract: I’m looking down into 200 feet of water and resting just below me is a 45-foot-long behemoth; a female humpback whale. From below her massive girth, a tiny calf peeks out.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Cartwright teaches biology at California State University Channel Islands and has studied trends in habitat use in humpback whale mother-calf pairs in Hawaiian waters.

headline: For Dessert, Winter Fruits Provide Inspiration
abstract: A variety of citrus-fruit based desserts to enjoy this winter.
lead_paragraph: I am knocking wood that the flu hasn’t felled me this winter. I am glad that I got the vaccine, but I am also taking extra measures: whenever there is Vitamin C to be had, I’m partaking, whether it’s Emergen-C after my morning swims (outdoors in a heated pool) or citrus throughout the day. A friend brought me a bag of oranges and Meyer lemons from his trees, I am using up the case of clementines I bought for my New Year’s Day party, and we are at the height of citrus season at our farmers’ markets.

headline: A Closer Look at the Creation of a Vast Pacific Shark Sanctuary
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Sharks']
abstract: A marine conservationist describes the path to creating the world’s biggest shark sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a Dot Earth postcard from the South Pacific, describing the final step in the creation of a vast international sanctuary for sharks. It’s written by Jessica Cramp, a young woman who, after working as a biologist in a drug discovery laboratory in San Diego for nearly a decade, decided it was time to pursue her passion for marine life. Cramp is now the program manager for the Pacific Islands Conservation Initiative, a nonprofit environmental group based in the Cook Islands:

headline: A Pope Lets Go
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI’s course of action is a startling departure from that of the pope before him.
lead_paragraph: To understand just how surprising Pope Benedict XVI’s decision to surrender his post is, you can look to numbers. It has been nearly six centuries since a pope resigned.

headline: Lemon and Blood Orange Gelée Parfaits
abstract: A beautiful, layered dessert.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by a wonderful dessert in the pastry chef Sherry Yard’s “Desserts by the Yard,” this is a beautifully layered jello. First make the lemon gelée – even better if you have Meyer lemons at your disposal – and let it set in the glasses (this will take about an hour, so plan accordingly). Then make the blood orange jelly and pour on top of the lemon layer. The lemon layer is thinner than the blood orange layer.

headline: Senate Armed Services Committee Schedules Hagel Vote
abstract: Senator Carl Levin of Michigan called for a committee vote on Tuesday afternoon on the nomination of former Senator Chuck Hagel to be the next secretary of defense.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated by Republican foot-dragging, Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, called Monday for a committee vote on Tuesday afternoon on the nomination of former Senator Chuck Hagel to be the next secretary of defense.

headline: The Temptation to Trade on Confidential Information
abstract: Two recent insider trading cases seem to indicate that the desire for quick profits is simply clouding our judgment, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Everyone loves a sure thing. And in the case of insider trading, the profits may be just too tempting.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Thakoon
abstract: Thakoon’s crisp white loafer was the perfect riff on the hint of the ’60s seen in New York this season.
lead_paragraph: Thakoon’s crisp white loafer was the perfect riff on the hint of the ’60s seen in New York this season. It felt just as right with trousers as it did with a dress — the kind of shoe you wear until you wear it out.

headline: Tangerine Sorbet
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Recipes', 'Citrus Fruits', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts']
abstract: A light, refreshing sorbet that can be made with a number of different fruits.
lead_paragraph: Tangerines, clementines, and mandarins are interchangeable for this light, refreshing sorbet.

headline: S.B.A. Administrator Announces Resignation
abstract: Karen Mills, who emphasized entrepreneurship and joined the Obama administration cabinet, did not say what she planned to do next.
lead_paragraph: Karen Mills, the administrator of the Small Business Administration, announced her resignation on Monday.

headline: Bipartisan Bill and Obama Speech to Put Spotlight on Gun Safety
abstract: Gun safety, just a year ago a third rail of American politics, will emerge as a central legislative issue in Washington this week.
lead_paragraph: Gun safety, just a year ago a third rail of American politics, will emerge as a central legislative issue in Washington this week. A bipartisan group of senators is close to finishing consensus legislation to enhance background checks on gun owners – which may well emerge as the chief Senate bill on gun safety – and President Obama will press his case for new restrictions on guns in his State of the Union address before Congress, where victims of gun violence will be peppered throughout the audience.

headline: R.B.S. Executives Testify in Rate-Rigging Case
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: British politicians sharply questioned current and former executives of the Royal Bank of Scotland on Monday about the management failures that led to the rate-manipulation scandal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British politicians took aim at the Royal Bank of Scotland for its role in a rate-rigging scheme, accusing management of fostering a profit-driven culture that encouraged traders to skirt the law.

headline: Fill-In | For a Broadway Fan, Once Is Not Enough
abstract: Fill in the blanks in the first eight paragraphs of the article “For a Broadway Fan, Once Is Not Enough” by Corey Kilgannon.
lead_paragraph: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first eight paragraphs of the article “For a Broadway Fan, Once Is Not Enough” by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Grilled by Galifianakis (or at Least Lightly Charred)
abstract: Naomi Watts, Christoph Waltz and others stop by “Between Two Ferns” to chat with Zach Galifianakis.
lead_paragraph: Everyone’s favorite lo-fi alt-comedian/linchpin of a $500 million comedy franchise, Zach Galifianakis, is back with a special “Oscar buzz” edition of his Web series “Between Two Ferns.” Guests include Jennifer Lawrence, Naomi Watts, Christoph Waltz (“Have you ever thought of changing your name to Christoph Breakdance?”) and Anne Hathaway. If their outfits are any indication, the installment was filmed on the same day as the Oscar nominees luncheon; Ms. Hathaway, purporting to be drunk, is still wearing her name tag. If that’s why these nominees didn’t chat with us, we consider their time better spent. Also, playing off an interviewee: dream move, Mr. G. See the video here.

headline: Why We Fear Simple Money Solutions
abstract: Complex investing, banking and other strategies and products may feel right, since they’re how we’ve always done things. But fear not the simple solution.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A reader questions why CBS chose not to run commercials during the Super Bowl XLVII blackout.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Grammy Awards Viewership Falls Sharply
abstract: The show took a steep fall from the huge audience it attracted last year, when it aired just a day after the death of Whitney Houston. But the broadcast still managed to draw a total of 28.37 million viewers, the second-best Grammy performance since 1993.
lead_paragraph: As expected, the Grammy Awards took a steep fall from the huge audience it attracted last year, when it aired just a day after the death of Whitney Houston. But the broadcast still managed to draw a total of 28.37 million viewers, the second-best Grammy performance since 1993.

abstract: The designer’s latest venture: a candy store called CuRious, which opened yesterday at her new Upper East Side boutique.

headline: French Plan to Add to Already Lengthy School Days Angers Parents and Teachers
abstract: Opponents of an edict to add a half day of school a week say it was created without their consultation, lacks details and fails to address the middling performance of French schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For more than a century, the lengthy school days of French children have been punctuated by a midweek day off, in recent decades for most children on Wednesdays, originally created for catechism studies.

headline: After Benedict: Don’t Get Your Hopes Up
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI may be stepping down, but don’t expect big changes in the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: To paraphrase Shakespeare, nothing became the papacy of Benedict XVI like his leaving it. I mean that as more than a backhanded tribute. How much suffering has mankind endured at the hands of leaders who could not bear to relinquish power, either because they feared the personal consequences of letting go or because they genuinely considered themselves indispensable? How rare are the big men who accept the verdict of time? In the Catholic Church they are once-in-six centuries rare. I have a soft spot for powerful people who know when to step down, and Benedict deserves respect for that.

headline: Donald Byrd, Jazz Trumpeter, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Byrd became successful and controversial in the 1970s by blending jazz, funk and R&B on the album “Black Byrd.”
lead_paragraph: Donald Byrd, one of the leading jazz trumpeters of the 1950s and early 1960s, who became both successful and controversial in the 1970s by blending jazz, funk and rhythm and blues into a pop hybrid that defied categorization, died on Feb. 4 in Dover, Del. He was 80.

headline: MegaRed Promotes ‘My Healthy Valentine’
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Oils and Fats', "Valentine's Day"]
abstract: A campaign for the MegaRed brand of krill oil supplement has a Valentine’s Day theme and fuses social media with product sampling to achieve — wait for it — social sampling.
lead_paragraph: Social media are rapidly changing the way marketers reach out to consumers, as can be seen by terms like social shopping. A campaign now under way is intended to fuse social media with product sampling in an example of, yes, social sampling.

headline: Painkillers Difficult to Trace in Horse Meat
abstract: The scandal over its inclusion in “beef” products is growing in the British Isles and other European countries.

headline: Arrests of 10 Women Praying at Western Wall Add to Tensions Over a Holy Site
abstract: Those detained were part of the group Women of the Wall, which has gathered each month for the past 24 years to protest the rule that only men may pray at the wall wearing traditional garb.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ten women, including two American rabbis, were detained by the Israeli police on Monday for praying at the Western Wall wearing prayer shawls that are traditionally used by men, in the latest escalation of a conflict over one of Judaism’s holiest sites.

headline: Alfred Fiandaca, Designer for Women in Politics and the Arts, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Fiandaca’s clients included Audrey Hepburn, Julie Andrews, Lady Bird Johnson and, notably during the 2012 presidential campaign, Ann Romney.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Fiandaca, an American fashion designer whose clients included Audrey Hepburn, Julie Andrews, Lady Bird Johnson and, notably during the 2012 presidential campaign, Ann Romney, died on Saturday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 72.

headline: Kushner Backs ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ Filmmakers
abstract: The “Lincoln” screenwriter is among those on a letter sent to the Senate protesting pressure brought by three Senators in regard to “Zero Dark Thirty.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES— Count Tony Kushner, the “Lincoln” screenwriter, among those who believe several United States Senators went too far when they suggested that Sony Pictures should somehow correct its depiction of torture in “Zero Dark Thirty.”

headline: Digital Notes: the Scorecard on Social Media’s Grammy Predictions
abstract: Who did better in predicting the Grammy’s — social media, or traditional experts. It turns out that the score was about even.
lead_paragraph: 5:19 p.m. | Updated Like any major awards show, the Grammys inspire no shortage of clairvoyants who claim to know how the Recording Academy’s fickle (yet conservative) voters think. They are often wrong, of course. One example: Two years ago virtually every expert was sure that Eminem would sweep the major categories; he won none of them.

headline: Grammy Dress Code? Try Again
abstract: When CBS issued a decency code for the 55th annual Grammy Awards last night, nominees and presenters responded with their own lens-fogging interpretations.
lead_paragraph: Performers are natural renegades. Crimp their style with a set of rules, and they’ll feel honor-bound to give those rules a vigorous tweak.

headline: Alternatives to Dell Deal Come With Too Little Certainty
abstract: Michael S. Dell and Silver Lake Partners have made a low-ball offer for the PC maker. Yet, it’s at a respectable 25 percent premium, and the company’s shares haven’t topped the $13.65-a-share deal price in months, the authors write.
lead_paragraph: Objectors to Michael S. Dell‘s $24.4 billion leveraged buyout of Dell are in a tight corner. The likes of Southeastern Asset Management are right that Mr. Dell, the company’s founder, and Silver Lake Partners have made a low-ball offer. Yet, it’s at a respectable 25 percent premium, and the company’s shares haven’t topped the $13.65-a-share deal price in months or Southeastern’s $23.72-a-share valuation in years.

headline: Report on Joshu Sasaki Allegations

headline: The Right’s Stuff
abstract: Even the conservatives are getting it.
lead_paragraph: Many conservatives, including old-line relatively moderate conservatives, were outraged by the political thesis of my book The Conscience of a Liberal (first published before the 2008 election) — which was that extreme movement conservatives took over the GOP a long time ago, were able to win elections by exploiting white resentment, but were on the verge of losing their grip thanks to demographic change.

headline: Gamers and School Violence, Algorithms of Love, Hearing Loss and Dementia

lead_paragraph: Ben Carey on what the research behind gaming and violence tells us — and what it doesn’t; John Tierney on eHarmony and the computerized search for love; Katherine Bouton shares a personal story of hearing loss and talks about how it might contribute to dementia.

headline: ‘Pi’ Special Effects Firm Heading for Bankruptcy
abstract: The special effects company behind “Life of Pi’ enters bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: 4:48 p.m. | Updated  The effects production company Rhythm & Hues has had a stellar week, creatively speaking: on Tuesday, it took home four awards from the Visual Effects Society for work on “Life of Pi,” much of which was also acknowledged by the Academy with multiple Oscar nominations in technical categories. On Sunday, it won the Bafta for visual effects. But behind the scenes, the company, based in El Segundo, Calif., was facing financial difficulties, and today it confirmed plans to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, according to Deadline.com.

headline: Tracing a Royal Y Chromosome
abstract: Mitochondrial DNA, passed through the female line, helped identify the remains of a skeleton as Richard III’s, but firmer proof will come from matching the Y chromosome.
lead_paragraph: Researchers last week developed DNA evidence to help identify the remains of a skeleton found under a parking lot in Leicester, England, as those of Richard III, the last English king to die in battle, in 1485. But the researchers’ work is only half-done. They have made a strong but not conclusive link through the female line, and are now turning to the male side for corroboration.

headline: 6 Centuries Ago, a Precedent for This Pope
abstract: Not since 1415, when Gregory XII stood down, has a pope surrendered the keys of St Peter. But Gregory’s resignation did not, of course, mark the end of the political centrality of the papacy in European affairs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – All but the most informed Vatican-watchers were scrambling for the references books on Monday to find a precedent for the resignation of Pope Benedict XVI, whose decision to step down stunned the Roman Catholic world.

headline: Mice Fall Short as Test Subjects for Some of Humans’ Deadly Ills
abstract: Mice have been the species of choice in the study of human diseases, but a new paper offered evidence that the mouse model has been misleading for sepsis, burns and trauma.
lead_paragraph: For decades, mice have been the species of choice in the study of human diseases. But now, researchers report evidence that the mouse model has been totally misleading for at least three major killers — sepsis, burns and trauma. As a result, years and billions of dollars have been wasted following false leads, they say.

headline: Theyskens’s Theory of Futurism
abstract: Like the faux marble runway, Olivier Theyskens’s designs for Theory are much lighter than they appear.
lead_paragraph: Guests at the Theyskens’ Theory show this afternoon had to navigate their way to their seats around a wide runway in a dark room. The runway appeared to be made of thick slabs of marble, so several people attempted to cross it, assuming its sturdiness.

headline: Inside City Grit
abstract: A setting that gives chefs the opportunity to burnish their credentials in New York.
lead_paragraph: A setting that gives chefs the opportunity to burnish their credentials in New York.

headline: At This Dinner Party, the Guest Is in the Kitchen
abstract: City Grit functions as a kind of permanent pop-up, giving both unknown and established chefs the opportunity to drum up news media attention in New York.
lead_paragraph: With two hours before dinner, Ned Elliott still had to deep-fry the julienne pig ears that would sit atop his beef-heart tartare. His business partner and ex-wife, Jodi Elliott, had to whip up dozens of black-pepper-and-Gruyère popovers. It had taken them nearly two days to prepare for the meal — that, after a four-hour flight to New York from Austin, Tex., where they own a restaurant.

headline: Could Hearing Loss and Dementia Be Connected?
abstract: Katherine Bouton talked about her own struggle with hearing loss, as well as new research that has found an association between hearing loss and dementia.
lead_paragraph: This interview has been edited and condensed for space.

headline: Government Panel in Afghanistan Confirms Widespread Torture of Detainees
keywords: ['Torture', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Detainees']
abstract: The findings were the first formal acknowledgment by Afghan officials of a widespread problem with abuse, after they initially denied the conclusions of a United Nations report.
lead_paragraph: An Afghan government panel on Monday acknowledged widespread torture of detainees, after a two-week investigation of a United Nations report citing rampant abuses.

headline: Another ’90s Fixture of Lower East Side Is Gone
abstract: The Pink Pony, a cafe on Ludlow Street near Houston, quietly locked its doors after its owner concluded that the neighborhood had changed too much to support it and the large rent increase sought by his landlord.
lead_paragraph: Quietly, without fanfare, another onetime fixture of downtown’s East Side has shut its doors. This time it is the Pink Pony, the sprawling, welcoming cafe on Ludlow Street just south of Houston.

headline: East Midtown, Below Ground
abstract: Mayor Bloomberg’s rezoning plan doesn’t really grapple with transit.
lead_paragraph: Unlike London and Hong Kong and Tokyo and nearly every city that would dare call itself a global economic hub, New York City has no express rail link between its airports and its central business districts. If you work in the Chrysler Building on Lexington Avenue, and you need to catch a flight at J.F.K., the quickest route is to take the 4/5/6 to the E to the AirTrain. By some estimates, the 4/5/6 is at 116 percent capacity.

headline: Shooting in the Dark
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)', 'Aggression (Behavior)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Research']
abstract: New research suggests violent games can stir hostile urges and aggressive behavior in the short term, but it is not clear whether the habit increases the likelihood of committing a violent crime.
lead_paragraph: The young men who opened fire at Columbine High School, at the movie theater in Aurora, Colo., and in other massacres had this in common: they were video gamers who seemed to be acting out some dark digital fantasy. It was as if all that exposure to computerized violence gave them the idea to go on a rampage — or at least fueled their urges.

headline: Straining to Hear and Fend Off Dementia
abstract: There is no clear explanation why, but compared with individuals with normal hearing, those with hearing loss have an increased risk of developing dementia.
lead_paragraph: At a party the other night, a fund-raiser for a literary magazine, I found myself in conversation with a well-known author whose work I greatly admire. I use the term “conversation” loosely. I couldn’t hear a word he said. But worse, the effort I was making to hear was using up so much brain power that I completely forgot the titles of his books.
