lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman shares his recipe for whole wheat flatbread.

headline: Successor to Benedict Will Lead a Church at a Crossroads
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI’s decision  to resign sets up a struggle between conservatives, who advocate a smaller church of more fervent Catholics, and those who believe that the  church can extend its reach.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI’s surprise announcement on Monday that he will resign on Feb. 28 sets the stage for a succession battle that is likely to determine the future course of a church troubled by scandal and declining faith in its traditional strongholds around the world.

headline: Are Vampire Bunnies Found on the Upper West Side?
abstract: “Bunnicula: A Rabbit Tale of Musical Mystery,” a children’s book adaptation with a script by Charles Busch, is a story of a curious rabbit who may be a vampire.
lead_paragraph: Like the best children’s stories, “Bunnicula: A Rabbit Tale of Musical Mystery,” a musical adaptation of Deborah and James Howe’s books about a rabbit who may be a vampire, is pitched slightly above the heads of its target audience. (It is advertised for ages 4 and older.)

headline: The Pope Abdicates
abstract: The implications of Benedict’s resignation.
lead_paragraph: During his pontificate and the years of influence that preceded it, Benedict XVI was often stereotyped as an arch-traditionalist, but his next-to-unprecedented decision to abdicate the papal throne may be one of the most striking concessions to modernity a recent pope has made. His statement of resignation basically acknowledges as much, citing the realities of “today’s world, subject to so many rapid changes and shaken by questions of deep relevance for the life of faith” as a particular reason why greater “strength of mind and body” than he now possesses is required of the successor to Saint Peter. These lines are an implicit nod not only to the particular challenges facing his pontificate, but also to the vast changes that mass media and global travel have wrought in the papacy’s role. Now that “globetrotting face of Catholicism” and “media-savvy C.E.O. of a controversial brand” have been added to the theological and administrative obligations inherent in the office, the burdens of age are arguably more of an impediment to papal effectiveness than ever before, and the mix of stasis and confusion created by a pontiff’s slow decline can have more immediately disastrous effects than they might have had in an era when papal incapacity could be a Roman secret rather than a global spectacle.

headline: Model Diary | Kati Nescher
abstract: The supermodel newbie talks exclusively to T about her life on and off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The supermodel newbie Kati Nescher has only been on the modeling scene for about two years but has already graced the cover of Vogue, walked the runway for the likes of Alexander Wang (most recently on Saturday) and Christian Dior, and stars in advertising campaigns for Fendi and Max Mara this season. Here, T’s exclusive interview with the 29-year-old kicks off this season’s Model Diary series during New York Fashion Week. Today’s a busy one for the West Village-based mother of a 2-year old: she was already in Belstaff this morning and Donna Karan this afternoon, and will be in the Marc by Marc Jacobs show tonight at Lincoln Center.

lead_paragraph: Roxy Music, the British band that thrived in the 1970s, built its audience — and then lost parts of it — by creating and then quickly confounding expectations. With a lineup that included the guitar, bass and drums standard in rock, as well as the electronica pioneer Brian Eno, and a reed player, Andy Mackay, whose oboe and saxophone lines gave the group a quirkily distinctive sound, Roxy Music often put a futuristic gloss on traditional song forms.

headline: Making Sure That a Kilo Is Always a Kilo
abstract: A platinum-iridium cylinder in France is the official standard for weight, but in 134 years it has gained a little weight, a fraction of that of a grain of sand.
lead_paragraph: A pint may be a pound the world around, but a kilogram is one kilogram only if it is the same weight as a 134-year-old cylinder of platinum-iridium alloy that sits in a vault at the International Bureau of Weights and Measures in Sèvres, near Paris.

headline: Environmental Groups Leverage Iowa 2016 Against Cuomo
abstract: A coalition of groups opposed to hydraulic fracturing is getting an early start on caucus season with an ad aimed at New York’s governor in The Des Moines Register.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly, for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, all politics are national.

headline: Nothing Is Sacred
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI announced he was stepping down at the end of the month. Why didn’t he break the news to his 1.5 million Twitter followers?
lead_paragraph: Why didn’t he break the news on Twitter? That was what much of the Twittersphere was wondering Monday morning after Pope Benedict XVI — with 1.5 million followers despite being on Twitter for less than a month, and with only 34 tweets to his account — announced he was stepping down at the end of the month. (The pope’s last tweet, on Sunday, gave no hint of the news to come.) Reaction was mixed, with some expressing sadness at his relatively short reign and others seeming grateful to see the back of him. And then there was the fashion publicist grateful that none of her clients was showing on Monday.

headline: Speakers With a Big Sound for Big Desks
abstract: KEF’s new X300A speakers for computers are very good, very large and very expensive.
lead_paragraph: The British loudspeaker maker KEF, a name well known to audiophiles, has broken out both the high-tech and marketing razzle-dazzle for its desktop X300A speakers.

headline: Group Seeks to Jump-Start Ocean Protections
keywords: ['Environment', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'International Relations', 'Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: A new body will call attention to the plundering of ocean resources, from overfishing to the mining of the seabed.
lead_paragraph: A group of prominent officials from several nations are creating an independent body dedicated to making environmental protection a top priority in global policymaking involving the high seas.

headline: Waste Is Seen in Program to Give Internet Access to Rural U.S.
abstract: A $4 billion federal program is extending high-speed Internet access to rural areas. But it is not always going where it is most needed.
lead_paragraph: AGATE, Colo. — The bank is gone from this once-thriving ranching and farming community on Colorado’s windblown eastern plain, as are the dairies, the hotel and the Union Pacific depot. The post office remains, at the corner of Main Street and First Avenue, the intersection of the town’s two paved streets.

headline: Executive Director of High Line Group to Step Down
keywords: ['High Line (NYC)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: Robert Hammond, who led the effort to save an abandoned elevated railway in the heart of Chelsea and turn it into a new kind of park, said he would step down by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Robert Hammond, who led the effort to save an abandoned elevated railway in the heart of Chelsea and turn it into a new kind of park, announced on Monday night that he would step down as executive director of Friends of the High Line by the end of the year.

headline: Liverpool Red-Faced
abstract: West Bromwich Albion scored two late goals Monday to defeat host Liverpool in England’s Premier League.
lead_paragraph: Luis Suárez took a dive and Liverpool was left gasping for air.

headline: Senate Votes Against Stripping Tribal Land Provision From Domestic Violence Measure
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Violence Against Women Act (1994)']
abstract: The Senate turned back a Republican effort to strip from the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act a provision that would expand the authority of Native American courts.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Monday evening turned back a Republican effort to strip from the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act a controversial provision that would expand the authority of Native American courts to prosecute non-Indians accused of abusing native women, but senators left final passage of the bill until Tuesday.

headline: S.E.C. Nominee Discloses Law Firm Wealth
abstract: Mary Jo White, who has been nominated to run the Securities and Exchange Commission, has also disclosed that her husband would relinquish his partnership at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, converting his interest in the firm from equity to nonequity status.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that the partners at the white-shoe law firms Debevoise & Plimpton and Cravath, Swaine & Moore earn a decent living. The financial disclosure form of Mary Jo White, the Obama administration’s pick to become the next chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, reveals just how decent.

headline: A Tribute to the Pope, and It Goes Well With Milk
abstract: There could be only one response at Artuso’s bakery in the Bronx to word that Pope Benedict XVI was resigning: make some cookies with his image on them like the ones sold when he said Mass at Yankee Stadium in 2008.
lead_paragraph: When Anthony Artuso heard the news of Pope Benedict XVI’s resignation plans on Monday, what else could he do but order up a batch of pope cookies.

headline: G.O.P. Chief in Florida Pleads Guilty
abstract: Jim Greer, the former party chairman in Florida, was charged with steering $125,000 in party money into his personal bank accounts.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Averting a prolonged and heated political drama, Jim Greer, a former chairman of the Republican Party of Florida, walked into an Orlando courtroom on Monday and pleaded guilty to grand theft and money laundering charges.

headline: The Naked Bird, Illustrated
abstract: In “The Unfeathered Bird,” Katrina van Grouw pulls back feather, skin and muscle to reveal beauty in avian form, evolution and function.
lead_paragraph: In “The Unfeathered Bird,” Katrina van Grouw pulls back feather, skin and muscle to reveal beauty in avian form, evolution and function.

keywords: ['Cats', 'Online Advertising', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Web-Original Programming', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Litter Genie, a cat product that was introduced in 2012, is the subject of a series of promotional videos on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: WATCHING cat videos is so popular that it has become shorthand for being unproductive, whether or not someone being distracted by the Internet is actually watching a cat riding a robotic vacuum or playing the piano.

headline: Flights of Winged Majesty
abstract: A new book looks under the feathers with detailed illustrations, and erudite explanations, of the astonishing anatomy of a variety of birds.
lead_paragraph: In the acknowledgments to her unsettling and irresistible book, “The Unfeathered Bird,” Katrina van Grouw pauses in her listing of names to say, “I must assure readers that no birds were harmed during the making of this book.”

headline: Where the Singles Are: A Dating Guide by ZIP Code
abstract: Las Vegas and San Jose are among the cities where single men most outnumber single women, according to a new data analysis by Trulia, a residential real estate Web site. In Washington, Boston and New York, single women outnumber men.
lead_paragraph: At Trulia, a residential real estate Web site, the analysts are constantly crunching data — home and apartment listings, prices, school ratings, crime rates and other numbers.

headline: Longer Spans Without Serious Airline Accidents
abstract: The last commercial airline accident that resulted in deaths of passengers was four years ago, the longest such span for decades. And the previous span between accidents was the longest before now.
lead_paragraph: The last commercial airline accident that resulted in deaths of passengers was four years ago, the longest such span for decades. And the previous span between accidents was the longest before now.

headline: Gun-Friendly New Mexico Considers Stricter Controls
abstract: A new bill aims to close the “gun-show loophole” by requiring background checks in sales at such events.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — As state lawmakers around the country wrestle with whether to tighten gun laws, the fierce debate has not always fallen neatly along party lines — especially in the West.

headline: Some Fresh Ideas, and Wearable Ones
abstract: Derek Lam and Ralph Rucci are making some news (and clothes you want to buy).
lead_paragraph: Each time I worm my way through the mob inside the tent at Lincoln Center, I tell myself: these are not fashion people. But I’m wrong. They are fashion, just as American Express, Coke and Fiber One are fashion. Everybody wants the love.

headline: Syrian Insurgents Claim to Control Large Hydropower Dam
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Tabqa Dam, Syria’s biggest, is considered a potent weapon in the battle for allegiances in the nearly two-year-old conflict.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian insurgents and opposition activists said Monday that rebel forces had taken control of Syria’s largest hydroelectric dam, an assertion that, if confirmed, would give them significant control over a vital reservoir and what remains of the sporadic power supplies in their war-ravaged country.

headline: Ankle Injuries to Sideline Williams for Two Games
abstract: The Nets’ Deron Williams will miss the final two games before the All-Star break because of inflammation in both his ankles, the team said Monday.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The struggling Nets announced Monday that their star point guard, Deron Williams, will miss the final two games before the All-Star break because of inflammation in both ankles.

headline: Russia: Explosion in Coal Mine Kills at Least 17
abstract: An explosion in a coal mine in northern Russia killed at least 17 miners in a shaft saturated with methane gas, rescue workers said Monday.
lead_paragraph: An explosion in a coal mine in northern Russia killed at least 17 miners in a shaft saturated with methane gas, rescue workers said Monday. The blast occurred about 2,500 feet underground near the city of Vorkuta. Rescue workers said 23 people had been in the shaft at the time. Officials blamed a buildup of methane gas, a common peril in coal mines, for the explosion. Rescue workers said that two miners had escaped on their own and that three others had been rescued. They recovered 17 bodies and were still trying to find one miner, the Interfax news agency reported.

headline: Novak Is Knicks’ Barometer Off the Bench
abstract: Steve Novak’s contributions on offense will be key to how the remainder of the season goes for the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: While the Knicks have a spectacular scorer (Carmelo Anthony) and a herculean rebounder/inside defender (Tyson Chandler), Coach Mike Woodson recognizes that significant bench contribution from players like Amar’e Stoudemire, J. R. Smith and Steve Novak is critical if the Knicks are to continue to challenge the Miami Heat for supremacy in the Eastern Conference.

headline: Mainlander Shoppers Met With Protests in Hong Kong
abstract: Are concerns over milk powder shortages and mainlanders’ shopping sprees symptoms of a wider malaise?
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG—There is little to distinguish Sheung Shui from the many suburbs studded with high-rises and elevated walkways that dot the northern parts of Hong Kong, except for one thing: It is the first stop on the local train link that comes in from the nearby border with mainland China.

headline: Gaza: Palestinians Begin Voter Registration Campaign
abstract: Palestinian officials on Monday began updating voter registration records in the Gaza Strip, a critical step toward ending the rift between the Fatah Party and the militant Hamas movement.
lead_paragraph: Palestinian officials on Monday began updating voter registration records in the Gaza Strip, a critical step toward ending the rift between the Fatah Party, which governs in the West Bank, and the militant Hamas movement, which controls Gaza. The Central Elections Commission, based in the West Bank, opened 257 centers throughout the Gaza Strip and will try to get 300,000 residents to update their electoral information. It was the first time that Hamas had allowed the commission to operate in Gaza since 2007. President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, the leader of Fatah, has said that voter registration is a critical precursor to elections that could unite the rival factions, but the broader reconciliation process appears stalled. Over the weekend at meetings hosted by Egypt, the Palestinian rivals failed to make progress on timetables for forming a new government and holding elections.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Belstaff
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s choice, a knee-grazing boot with sleek gold hardware.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: North Korea Draws New China Scrutiny
abstract: Pyongyang’s plans for a new nuclear test could force a showdown on the issue with a close ally.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government’s approach to North Korea appears to be the subject of heightened debate ignited by the North’s plans to proceed with a nuclear test, Chinese and American experts say.

headline: A Database of Names and How They Connect
abstract: Relationship Science is compiling a new computer database for the heavy hitters of business that lists a person’s associates, their political affiliations, their charity work and more.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like a Rolodex for the 1 percent: two million deal makers, power brokers and business executives — not only their names, but in many cases the names of their spouses and children and associates, their political donations, their charity work and more — all at a banker’s fingertips.

headline: As Numbers Add Up, Rutgers Coach Has Renewed Sense of Urgency
abstract: A victory Tuesday night would give Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer her 900th career win. But she is more focused on leading her team to the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, when C. Vivian Stringer was coaching at Iowa, she received in the mail what she described as a gold letter with a diamond on it from the university congratulating her for her 300th win.

headline: Candidates in Kenya’s First Presidential Debate Condemn Ethnic Politics
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Elections', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: One of the two front-runners in the election faces charges from the International Criminal Court, while the other says he was cheated out of winning last time in 2007.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — With a hotly contested, anxiously awaited presidential election only three weeks away, Kenya tried something new on Monday night: it held a debate.

headline: Airline Industry at Its Safest Since the Dawn of the Jet Age
abstract: It will be four years on Tuesday since the last fatal crash in the United States, a record unmatched since propeller planes gave way to the jet.
lead_paragraph: Flying on a commercial jetliner has never been safer.

headline: Maryland: Brief Delay in Terrorism Case
abstract: The military tribunal case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others who are accused of being accomplices in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was delayed.
lead_paragraph: The military tribunal case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others who are accused of being accomplices in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was delayed on Monday as defense lawyers pressed forward with concerns that their confidential communications with their clients and other counsel might be subject to eavesdropping by the government. The chief prosecutor, Brig. Gen. Mark S. Martins of the Army, has said “unequivocally” that no government entity is monitoring lawyer-client communications, and the judge, Col. James L. Pohl of the Army, expressed skepticism about the defense’s fears. But Colonel Pohl agreed to postpone a scheduled hearing on pretrial motions for a day so the defense lawyers could finish interviews with audio technology officials, who will be called as soon as Tuesday to testify about the systems at the military prison and the courtroom at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The court proceedings are being transmitted via closed circuit to Fort Meade and other locations.

headline: Thom Browne’s Passion Play
abstract: Capitalizing on his Michelle Obama inaugural moment, Thom Browne grabbed the spotlight with a jaw-dropping collection that was so ambitious in scale it seemed to be his bid to enter the pantheon of great designers.
lead_paragraph: Capitalizing on his Michelle Obama inaugural moment, Thom Browne grabbed the spotlight on Monday evening with a grand, jaw-dropping collection that was so ambitious in scale it seemed to be his bid for entrée into the pantheon of great designers.

headline: Partners of Gays in Service Are Granted Some Benefits
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: New privileges will include receiving military identification cards and gym access, but more expansive benefits, like health care, were not granted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon on Monday expanded benefits to same-sex partners of military personnel to include a range of services offered at various posts and bases, but it withheld more expansive benefits sought by gay and lesbian couples — in particular medical and dental coverage and housing allowances.

headline: For Two Senators, Petty Politics Comes First
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials']
abstract: Senators Lindsey Graham and James Inhofe are abusing their enormous power by trying to derail the nomination of Chuck Hagel as Pentagon chief.
lead_paragraph: Individual senators hold an enormous amount of power in Washington, which is exactly the way they like it. But when that power is abused, as two Republicans are now doing in trying to derail the nomination of a defense secretary, it has to be curtailed.

headline: TV Show Mirrors a Japanese Battery Maker’s Bind
abstract: The plot of the Japanese television series “Made in Japan” underscores the hopes the country has pinned on technologies like lithium-ion batteries.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For many viewers in Japan, the plot of the television series “Made in Japan” was all too real: a struggling manufacturer, Takumi Electronics, turns to advanced lithium-ion batteries to reverse its ailing fortunes.

headline: Shell Vessels Sidelined, Imperiling Arctic Plans
abstract: The company’s ambitious oil exploration program in the Arctic has been hindered by delays for the last seven years.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In another blow to its Alaskan Arctic drilling program, Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday that it had decided to tow its two drill vessels there to Asian ports for major repairs, jeopardizing its plans to begin drilling for oil in the icy northern seas next summer.

headline: Reward Spurs Many Tips on Ex-Officer
abstract: The authorities here have received more than 700 tips from the public about the whereabouts of Christopher J. Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer wanted in connection with three killings.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The authorities here have received more than 700 tips from the public on the whereabouts of Christopher J. Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer wanted in connection with three killings, police officials said on Monday.

headline: Academic Freedom Vindicated in Brooklyn
abstract: A controversial talk at Brooklyn College last week drew protests and veiled threats from politicians. They failed, and academic freedom won.
lead_paragraph: Debates about academic freedom almost always begin in confusion and end in confusion, but the recent controversy at Brooklyn College is a welcome exception to that rule. When the dust settled, the right thing had happened, the right things had been said, and the wrong things had been repudiated.

headline: The Change Upon Christ’s Rock
abstract: A papal resignation, and the future of the church.
lead_paragraph: BENEDICT XVI’s resignation might be the most unexpected papal decision since the convening of the Second Vatican Council in the early 1960s — which came about, Pope John XXIII said, not after long deliberation, but “like the flower of an unexpected spring.”

headline: The Pope Could Still Right the Wrongs
abstract: Pope Benedict has one last chance to right some of the wrongs of the recent past by forcing out Cardinal Angelo Sodano.
lead_paragraph: DURING his eight years as pope, Benedict XVI sought rebirth for the Roman Catholic Church by meeting with victims of predator priests and making several apologies for the church’s aching abuse crisis.

headline: Farewell to an Uninspiring Pope
abstract: I have watched the wealth of the Catholic Church turn into a subsidy for wrongdoing and a prop for the continuing campaign against women’s rights and homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: POPE BENEDICT XVI quit. Good. He was utterly bereft of charm, tone-deaf and a protector of priests who abused children. He’d been a member of the Hitler Youth. In addition to this woeful résumé, he had no use for women.

headline: For Husband of Woman Killed in Turkey, a Grim and Uncertain Odyssey
abstract: The last several weeks have amounted to an unlikely journey for Steven D. Sierra of Staten Island, who was suddenly cast 5,000 miles away, searching for his missing wife, Sarai Sierra, in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: For six desperate days, Steven D. Sierra crisscrossed the city of Istanbul, by foot and by car, in trains and on ferries, in search of his missing wife, a 33-year-old Staten Island woman who had never before been overseas.

headline: Carpe Diem Nation
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here’s hoping President Obama will frame his State of the Union address in terms of the present vs. the future.
lead_paragraph: Europeans who settled America gave their lives a slingshot shape. They pulled back so they could shoot forward. They volunteered to live in harsh conditions today so their descendants could live well for centuries. The pioneers who traveled West did the same thing. So has each generation of immigrants — sacrificing the present for the sake of the future.

headline: Chicago Mayor Seeks More Prison Time for Gun Crimes
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago urged Illinois lawmakers to increase minimum sentences for serious gun violations to three years in prison.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On a day when the authorities here filed murder charges in a case that had come to represent the painful price of gun violence, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Monday called on state lawmakers to increase minimum sentences for gun crimes in Illinois and require violators to serve the bulk of those prison sentences.

headline: A Spritz of Power

abstract: If our lawmakers are going to preen, they might as well do it fragrantly.
lead_paragraph: It’s kind of amazing, given our politicians’ obsession with self-promotion, that we haven’t yet seen a line of Congressional colognes.

headline: Zhuang Zedong, Skilled in China Foreign Relations and Ping-Pong, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Zhuang became a national hero by winning three world championships and eased China’s relations with the United States through sports.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, at the world table tennis championships in Japan, an American player mistakenly boarded a bus carrying the Chinese team. The team had been told not to talk to Westerners, and an awkward silence descended. Ten minutes elapsed. Then the best player in China stood, greeted the American and offered him a gift, a scarf.

headline: At Texas Service, Mourners Remember Slain Ex-Sniper as Warrior and Family Man
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: Thousands of people attended the service of Chris Kyle, a retired Navy SEAL sniper and author who investigators say was killed by a troubled veteran he was trying to help.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Military leaders, law enforcement officials and thousands of others gathered at Cowboys Stadium here on Monday to remember Chris Kyle, the retired Navy SEAL sniper and author who was killed with another man, investigators say, by a troubled veteran he was trying to help.

headline: A Turbulent Tenure for a Quiet Scholar
abstract: When it came to the major challenges facing the Roman Catholic Church in the real world, Pope Benedict XVI often appeared to carom from one crisis to the next.
lead_paragraph: When Benedict XVI became pope eight years ago at the age of 78, many Roman Catholic scholars predicted that he would be a caretaker. He would keep the ship sailing in the same direction as his beloved predecessor, John Paul II. And as the rare theologian who knew how to write for a broad audience, Benedict would keep the crew inspired and the sails billowing.

headline: Modernize Registration and Require Early Voting Periods
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Editorials', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: President Obama needs to make good on his promise to fix a broken election system.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has a long agenda for his State of the Union address, but it is important that he not forget the most fundamental democratic reform of all: repairing a broken election system that caused hundreds of thousands of people to stand in line for hours to vote last year. It is time to make good on his election-night promise.

headline: Move New York City’s Primaries to June
abstract: This would give the city’s dysfunctional Board of Elections plenty of time to prepare for a September runoff.
lead_paragraph: It should come as no surprise to New York City residents who endured the chaos at local polling places last year that the mayoral contest this year could also be a nightmare. As before, the problem is the city’s hopelessly dysfunctional Board of Elections, which says that it will not be able to manage a likely runoff vote in the time required by law. The State Legislature can fix the problem, but only if it moves quickly.

headline: New York Mayor Lauds Companies for Cutting Salt Content
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Kraft, Goya and 19 other producers had met the goal of a 25 percent reduction in salt content in foods since 2010.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in the midst of a long-running campaign to change the eating habits of New Yorkers and consumers across the country, declared a victory against salt on Monday, as 21 companies, from Kraft and Goya to FreshDirect, said they had met the first stage in reductions in salt content in foods.

headline: Keeping Their Dogs From Looking Like Ours
abstract: For the Westminster Dog Show canines, it was just another day of staying clean and being styled for the show.
lead_paragraph: It was a difficult morning for Rudy, a 90-pound Old English sheepdog, who woke up at 6 a.m. Eastern on Monday to prepare for a 1:30 p.m. competition at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | 3.1 Phillip Lim
abstract: The focus: creating a natural yet luminous complexion.
lead_paragraph: “This season, we wanted to bring reality to the runway and create a look that’s effortless—but with an edge,” notes Francelle Daly, the lead artist at the 3.1 Phillip Lim show. To achieve a natural yet luminous complexion, she applied foundation to the face using her fingers, “so that it emulates the look of real skin;” swept a camel-hued shadow onto the eyelids to add depth; and blended a touch of highlighter over the cheeks, along the bridge of the nose, and on the Cupid’s bow of the lips. Now for the downtown-cool element: Daly saturated the entire lip with a coppery pencil, then went over it with a dark chocolate brown pencil. “Layering a brown tone on top of your lip color is a great way to take any shade a bit deeper,” she says.

headline: Former Deputy Mayor of Newark Is Sentenced
abstract: Ronald Salahuddin had been convicted in federal court of steering demolition contracts and work around the new Prudential Center arena to a favored contractor.
lead_paragraph: A former deputy to Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark was sentenced Monday to a year and a day in prison for conspiring to commit extortion.

headline: Ruling Islamists, Under Attack, Reject Blame for Tunisia’s Woes
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Facing public anger and internal divisions after the assassination of an opposition leader, the Ennahda party did not seem to look inward.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Facing public anger and internal divisions after the assassination of an opposition leader, Tunisia’s largest Islamist party, which leads a governing coalition, blamed the news media, secular elites and the remnants of the old government for its troubles.

headline: Watching Obama for Signs of Change
abstract: As the president readies his State of the Union address, many associates say he is exhibiting an assertiveness in contrast to the caution he showed most of his first term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Tuesday night, the president will address the nation and Congress on the state of the union. But many will watch as well for signs of the state of Barack Obama.

It will undoubtedly be a giant hit for Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, the owner of the “Die Hard” franchise.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Feb. 12, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, Feb. 12, 2013.

headline: How the Union’s State Got So ‘Strong’
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Presidents like to tell Congress the state of the union is “strong,” but it was not always so.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is likely to declare on Tuesday evening that the state of the union is strong. That word, strong, has become a ritual element of the annual address to Congress, intoned by Mr. Obama and his predecessors over the last 30 years even when things were not going that well.

headline: Sacramento Seeks Investors in Battle for N.B.A. Team
abstract: Mayor Kevin Johnson of Sacramento is looking to California billionaires as he prepares a counteroffer for the city’s N.B.A. franchise, which a group from Seattle has offered to buy.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — It’s being billed as a battle of the whales here in the state capital, an increasingly fierce contest pitting billionaire against billionaire. The prize is not California’s governorship or the fate of some ballot proposal, but ownership of the N.B.A.’s most troubled franchise, the Sacramento Kings.

headline: Militant Threats Test Role of a Pentagon Command in Africa
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Created to train African forces and build social, political and economic programs, the Pentagon’s Africa Command finds itself facing a new generation of Islamist militants.
lead_paragraph: NIAMEY, Niger — Created five years ago to focus on training the armed forces of dozens of African nations and strengthening social, political and economic programs, the Pentagon’s Africa Command now finds itself on a more urgent mission: confronting a new generation of Islamist militants who are testing the United States’ resolve to fight terrorism without being drawn into a major conflict.

headline: Snowbound Residents Improvise Their Escape
abstract: Improvised snow-removal strategies are certain to continue for days as people try to dig out sooner than city crews can get to them.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Savoy Street was still buried under more than 30 inches of snow on Monday. The word was it would stay that way until Friday or later. So what the city could not do, one man in a white Dodge pickup did on his own.

headline: A Housing Dispute, Generations Old
abstract: In “Luck of the Irish, ” tensions rise when an Irish family, which was paid to buy a house in an all-white Boston neighborhood for a black family in the 1950s, comes back to claim the house.
lead_paragraph: Race, class and real estate make for a predictably combustible combination in “Luck of the Irish,” a thoughtful but diffuse new play by Kirsten Greenidge that opened on Monday night at the Claire Tow Theater at Lincoln Center. The plot turns on the disputed ownership of a handsome house in a Boston suburb that has been home to an African-American family, the Taylors, since the late 1950s. A half-century later the descendants of the Taylors make the unhappy discovery that the title may never have been properly transferred from the white couple who bought it on behalf of their grandparents, seeking to sidestep the prevalent racism of the time, which kept such neighborhoods strictly segregated.

headline: Call On Me
abstract: Cruising with Dan Schoenholz.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome back to Monday. Not that there is anything wrong with that. Truth be told, I don’t see much difference between the perception of what makes a Monday puzzle and what makes a Tuesday puzzle. They are so similar that when I solve a Tuesday that is relatively easy, with a nice, well-constructed theme set and good fill, I’m satisfied. The tricks and misdirection are for later in the week.

lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who shot and killed a New York City police officer during a botched drug robbery was convicted of second-degree murder on Monday but acquitted of the most serious murder charge, suggesting that jurors had doubts about whether he intentionally killed the officer.

headline: Menopause, the Movie
abstract: If there were an instructional film for menopause, would it tell you to turn to your doctor for testosterone pills, or start knitting?
lead_paragraph: When I was in fifth grade, my Girl Scout troop watched an educational film entitled Becoming a Woman.  Its purpose was to prepare us for the onset of puberty. Of course, it did no such thing. We filed out of the auditorium with a little pink pamphlet published by Modess and a sample box of sanitary napkins with no more of an understanding of our reproductive organs than if we had spent the last half-hour weaving pot holders. “Modess because …” Because what? I distinctly remember going home and asking my mother why women bleed. “I don’t know,” she said, mixing ground chuck, bread crumbs and egg yolk with her bare hands, “I’ll have to ask your father.”

headline: Showing Off Their Manners on the Big Stage
abstract: The winning dogs of four categories — hounds, toy, nonsporting and herding — earned their spot in the Best in Show competition at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.
lead_paragraph: In its 137 years, the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show has been held at all four versions of Madison Square Garden. This year, though, the show was held for the first time at the newly renovated Garden, which included a reconfigured upper bowl but less space for the more than 2,700 entrants.

headline: North Korea Confirms It Conducted 3rd Nuclear Test
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: North Korea set off a nuclear test on Tuesday, its official news service said, and preliminary estimates suggested it was far larger than the previous two conducted by the North.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea confirmed on Tuesday that it had conducted its third, long-threatened nuclear test, according to the official KCNA news service, posing a new challenge for the Obama administration in its effort to keep the country from becoming a full-fledged nuclear power.

headline: At Marc by Marc Jacobs, a Modern Take on the ’70s
abstract: The designer’s younger-skewing collection, which he showed Monday night, was a romp of 1970s prints, teased hair, red-wine colors and spongy wool pants.
lead_paragraph: You’ll have to wait a few days more to see the big Marc Jacobs runway show, since the designer, citing delays in getting fabrics and accessories through customs, decided to switch positions on the calendar this season. It has been a weird season for designers, dealing with snow over the weekend and now a rainy Monday, but things at least are moving along. Mr. Jacobs will show his signature collection on Thursday night, and in his regular time slot on Monday night, he showed his younger-skewing collection, Marc by Marc Jacobs, instead.

headline: What’s On Tuesday

lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (ABC, Bloomberg, CBS, CNBC, CNN, C-Span, Fox, Fox Business, Fox News, MSNBC, NBC, 11, 13, 49) STATE OF THE UNION President Obama is expected to focus on restoring prosperity to the middle class and will unveil initiatives in education, infrastructure, clean energy and manufacturing, according to White House officials. He will also try to summon support for the passage of stricter gun laws and an overhaul of immigration policy. And he will confront the looming battle with Congress over his call to lower the deficit by cutting spending on Medicare, stabilizing Social Security and revamping the tax code.

headline: In China, Shock and Acceptance Over Pope’s Resignation
abstract: As news of the Pope’s resignation rippled into China, shock and acceptance, even approval, seemed the main feelings among Chinese Catholics.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In China, where official relations with the Vatican are a “never-ending crisis,” as the Vatican Insider put it recently, the news of the resignation of Pope Benedict has been slow to spread. The Chinese state doesn’t recognize the Pope as the leader of China’s Catholics and has had its own “patriotic” church since the Communist Revolution in 1949.

David E. Sanger reports from Washington, and Choe Sang-hun from Seoul.

headline: After North Korean Nuclear Test, China Must Deal  With Its Wayward Ally

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the aftermath of Tuesday’s nuclear test by North Korea, China will almost certainly join the United States in supporting tougher sanctions at the United Nations, accompanied by sterner reprimands from Beijing against its recalcitrant ally in Pyongyang.

headline: China Looms Over Response to Nuclear Test by North Korea
keywords: ['Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: China will almost certainly join the United States in supporting tougher sanctions for Pyongyang over Tuesday’s  test, accompanied by sterner reprimands from Beijing.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — At the United Nations, the desire to impose ever harsher sanctions on North Korea to try to curb its development of nuclear arms and ballistic missiles has long stalled in the face of Chinese opposition — the standard chain of events playing out here again on Tuesday after North Korea said it had carried out its third nuclear test.

lead_paragraph: Too little of the money the federal government spends on breast cancer research goes toward finding environmental causes of the disease and ways to prevent it, according to a new report from a group of scientists, government officials and patient advocates established by Congress to examine the research.

headline: Heavenly Oasis
abstract: In recent years, spas have sprouted up in Marrakesh in notable number.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a shortage of sybaritic pleasures in Marrakesh, but until recently spas were not among them. “It was just the local hammams,” says Sandra Zwollo, a Dutch expat who founded the women’s-only spa retreat Harem in 2011. But now that the Royal Mansour has set a new standard for ultraluxe pampering, every hotel is following suit. The Taj Palace — which served as the backdrop for Carrie and company’s escapades in “Sex and the City 2” — will soon open its 20,000-square-foot space with a pond-size green marble pool, twin hammams and traditional ayurvedic treatments. The Arabian Night aesthetic continues at Palais Namaskar, a 12-acre playground dotted with reflecting pools, orange-scented yoga gardens and a hammam that comes with a private steam room and its own fireplace. The spa at the Selman — a sprawling resort with a Jacques Garcia-designed hotel — complements the mellow Moroccan interiors (bronze lanterns, tadelakt walls) with a serious European health regimen by the French diet guru Henri Chenot. And at the new Delano Marrakech — the hotel’s first outpost outside South Beach — the 6,500-square-foot Pearl Spa is mosaic-tile fantasia offering services ranging from algae body wraps to ultrasound fat reduction.

headline: Lost and Found at the Kumbh Mela
abstract: Thousands of people separate and then reunite at every Kumbh.
lead_paragraph: ALLAHABAD, Uttar Pradesh— Most people know the heart-sinking feeling of losing someone in a crowded place. Imagine the feeling of being lost at the largest gathering of humanity in the world, the Kumbh Mela.

abstract: Can you choose the best synonym for “simulacrum,” as it is used in the sentence?

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Italy awoke Tuesday to yet another corporate scandal with political overtones, as prosecutors in Milan arrested the head of the state-controlled aerospace company Finmeccanica in an investigation related to the sale of 12 helicopters to India in 2010.

headline: Do Illegal Immigrants Actually Hurt the U.S. Economy?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Undocumented workers represent a classic economic challenge with a fairly straightforward solution.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month I met Pedro Chan at his small apartment above an evangelical church in Brooklyn’s Sunset Park neighborhood. Chan, who shares the place with three others, is short and muscular. He has a quiet voice and a patient demeanor that seems to have served him well on his journey to New York. In 2002, he left his Guatemalan village for a long trip through Mexico and, with the help of a smuggler, across the Texas border. In 2004, he made it to Brooklyn, where his uncle helped him find work on small construction crews.

headline: Picturing the End of Analog
abstract: The factories that churned out billions of rolls of film have imploded — much like the market. Robert Burley deftly captures the passing of an era.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in the Bronx, but I’ve never had any dewy-eyed nostalgia for the days of stickball and egg creams. My early life on the urban mainland in the 1960s was marked by rapid, hectic and at times heartbreaking change and loss.

headline: What Are Your Predictions for and Reactions to the State of the Union Address?
abstract: What do you predict President Obama will say about the progress the country has made over the past year? What priorities do you think he will set for the coming year?
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, President Obama will deliver his first State of the Union address for his second term in office.

headline: To Kick A Ball Down the Field
abstract: The soccer player Gabriel Kadiev is Muslim, and that’s made him the accidental hero of an Israeli drama about tolerance.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ten minutes before the end of the game the 19-year-old Gabriel Kadiev entered the field at Teddy Stadium. When he kicked the ball, screams rose from the bleachers — cheers of support from some quarters, of disapproval from others. Kadiev is no soccer star, but as a Chechen and a Muslim, he has become the accidental hero of an Israeli drama.

headline: Lively Online Reactions in China to Nuclear Test
abstract: Chinese netizens reacted mostly critically, in tens of thousands of posts, to the nuclear test by North Korea, its neighbor with which it shares good relations. But some were supportive.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As the world grapples with the news that North Korea has conducted a nuclear test, what is the reaction here in China, often considered North Korea’s one true friend, the ally that was as “close as lips and teeth”?

lead_paragraph: By announcing the detonation of a nuclear device, Kim Jong-un, the young leader of North Korea, seemed to be attempting to raise his status as a worthy leader at home and as a foe to be taken seriously among the countries his government considers its enemies.

lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: On TV, New Voice for Champions League
abstract: Gus Johnson, an American play-by-play announcer, will call his first soccer match for Fox when he is in the booth in Madrid on Wednesday for the Champions League match between Real Madrid and Manchester United.
lead_paragraph: The Champions League is back after a winter break for the Round of 16, with two games Tuesday (Juventus at Glasgow Celtic and Paris St.-Germain at Valencia) and two more Wednesday (Manchester United at Real Madrid and Borussia Dortmund at Shakhtar Donetsk) and four games next week.

headline: Peace Process
abstract: A new documentary unflinchingly examines 45 years of Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: Even before its release this month, “The Gatekeepers” was buzzing with critical acclaim and won an Oscar nomination for its concise and unflinching examination of 45 years of Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The documentary, by the Israeli director Dror Moreh, consists of interviews with six former heads of the Israeli internal security service, Shin Bet, whose astonishingly frank, sometimes harrowing testimonies reveal untold truths about events like the Kav 300 affair and the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, as well as their own moral conflict — and mounting frustration — over their government’s position. “Regardless of their political views,” Moreh said of his subjects, “they all agree it’s time to put an end to the occupation. Enough!” For the director, the film’s Israeli release holds even greater significance than the Oscar nod; he wishes it could change public opinion in his country. He has reason to be optimistic. After a screening at the Jerusalem Film Festival last summer, Moreh says a few Israeli settlers confessed to him that for the first time they were thinking about the political consequences of where they chose to live.

headline: Iran Is Said to Convert Enriched Uranium to Reactor Fuel
abstract: Because uranium converted into reactor fuel is more difficult to enrich to a weapon-grade purity, the move could limit the expansion of Iran’s stockpile.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As it prepares for two sets of negotiations with outsiders on its disputed nuclear program, Iran said on Tuesday that it was converting some of its enriched uranium into reactor fuel, the state news agency IRNA reported, potentially limiting the expansion of stockpiles that the West fears could be used for weapons.

headline: Why I Finally Decided to Make a Budget
abstract: Paul Downs says he had been too busy selling to do a good job of keeping track of where his money was going.
lead_paragraph: I read Ami Kassar’s recent post on sloppy bookkeeping with interest because I spent so many years struggling to figure out why I was always running out of money.

How is the school week organized in your country? Do you think shorter days and longer weeks are more conducive to learning, or do schoolchildren benefit from having a midweek break?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the second time in three weeks, primary school teachers here are on strike Tuesday, protesting a plan by the new French government to modify the rhythm of the school week for the country’s youngest pupils.

abstract: The magazine’s Drink columnist shares her favorite mixology bible and the novel that everyone loves and is still actually good.

headline: Nextdoor, a Network for Neighborhoods, Attracts Early Backer of Facebook and LinkedIn
abstract: Nextdoor, a San Francisco-based Web site for connecting neighbors, has something else in common with Facebook and LinkedIn, its far bigger and better-known peers in the social networking trade: the same early investor. Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm that made investments years ago in LinkedIn and Facebook, has led a $21.6 million funding round in Nextdoor.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is where people promote how cute their kids are, and LinkedIn is where they promote themselves. Nextdoor is where they promote their need to borrow a ladder.

headline: Firecrackers
abstract: It may be Chinese New Year, but it’s also austerity time and the Chinese government is clamping down on pyrotechnics.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Fireworks are exploding across Beijing every night this week to scare away spirits and usher in good luck for the lunar new year. Yet the sky is darker than in years past.

headline: Daily Report: Where the Broadband Roams
abstract: Edward Wyatt reports from Agate, Colo., about the $4 billion Broadband Technology Opportunities Program, part of the Obama administration’s 2009 economic stimulus effort.
lead_paragraph: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Edward Wyatt reports from Agate, Colo., on the $4 billion Broadband Technology Opportunities Program, part of the Obama administration’s 2009 economic stimulus effort. The aim of the grant program is to extend high-speed Internet access to parts of the country that had little or none of it because private companies said it was too expensive to build.

abstract: Part of the mission in Indonesia is to develop coastal eco-businesses and foster what some refer to as a “blue economy.”
lead_paragraph: Drew Harvell is associate director for environment at the Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future at Cornell University. She is studying the health of coral reefs and marine ecosystems in Indonesia, and is helping to plan a new project, Capturing Coral Reef Ecosystem Services, financed by the Global Environmental Fund/World Bank group.

Danglers and the subjunctive will get their turn soon. But for this week, I’ll shift from grammar to word use, with the latest in our file of sound-alike mix-ups.

abstract: Everyone I know says it, so it must be true.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait is boggled by Joe Scarborough’s latest rant. (Dear Jon: I am not “prickly”: I’m aggressive and annoying. But that’s by design, and I only do it when the situation calls for it.) What’s really striking is Scarborough’s certainty that we’re experiencing “explosive” spending growth, which is very much not the case:

headline: A New Strategy at Barclays
abstract: Barclays posts a big loss and announces a restructuring plan. | Mary Jo White says she and her husband have accumulated at least $16 million while working as law firm partners. | Relationship Science promises what is essentially a Rolodex for the 1 percent. | Obama’s State of the Union address is likely to focus on ways to support the middle class and promote economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: The British bank Barclays announced a restructuring of its operations on Tuesday, saying it would eliminate an additional 3,700 jobs, and reported a loss for the fourth quarter of 2012. In an effort to reduce its exposure to risky trading, Barclays said it would reduce the work force in its investment banking division by about 8 percent, or 1,800 jobs, this year, after already cutting 1,600 jobs from the unit. The bank is also cutting 1,900 jobs from its European retail and business banking unit, bringing the total expected layoffs to around 3 percent of the firm’s global work force, DealBook’s Mark Scott reports.

headline: Wastewater Is for Lovers
abstract: Invite that special someone to tour a sewage processing operation in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Love stinks.

headline: It’s Always 1923
abstract: And inflation is just around the corner, the same as it has been year after year.
lead_paragraph: David Glasner writes sensibly about the “currency war” issue and related subjects, set off by recent commentary by Irwin Stelzer. As Glasner says, expansionary monetary policy can cause currency depreciation — but it is not currency manipulation. There’s a world of difference between Chinese-style intervention-plus-tight-money and either the Fed’s quantitative easing or Japan’s new turn to inflation targeting.

headline: To Build Lasting Peace in Mali
abstract: In Mali, France faces the risk of “mission creep” — the possibility that its involvement could expand and that it might become difficult to end. Even if the military option works in the short term, other steps will be need to ensure stability, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Clashes between Islamic fighters and French troops in the Malian city of Gao may suggest that, after a swift campaign to liberate the north, France could be in Mali for the long haul.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Amazon Challenges Netflix, and an Advertiser Turns to Cat Videos
abstract: Amazon.com is quietly building a library of exclusive online content to rival Netflix, the champion of streaming media; cat videos are used to sell things rather than simply distract; and a Japanese television show captures the angst of a major lithium-ion battery manufacturer.
lead_paragraph: Amazon.com is slowly building a library of streaming television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, Brian Stelter writes. Amazon will not unveil its own original shows until fall at the earliest, but it has spent hundreds of millions of dollars to win exclusive Web rights on shows for its Amazon Prime streaming service, like “Downton Abbey” from PBS and “Falling Skies” from TNT. Amazon is a long way from matching Netflix in terms of TV and movie selection, but parts of the media business already see the company as Pepsi to Netflix’s Coke. Other companies, including Google, Sony, Intel and a new venture by Redbox and Verizon, are scrambling for a Snapple or Red Bull.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Hospitals Can’t Give Decent Price Quotes
abstract: Hospital cost estimates prove elusive, how advertising targets our children, the fiscal deal and the 1040 blues and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Where Do “Facts” Come From?
abstract: A 37 percent mystery.
lead_paragraph: Just a quick observation: for the past couple of days I’ve been seeing in a lot of places, including comments on this blog, the assertion that federal spending has risen 37 percent under Obama — that specific number. Does anyone know where it’s coming from? Because if I look at the actual data, I see federal spending rising from $3.475 trillion in fourth-quarter 2008 to $3.917 trillion in fourth-quarter 2012 — a rise of 12.7 percent.

headline: Benedict Will Live in Vatican City, but Many Details Remain Undecided
abstract: The unusual circumstance of Pope Benedict XVI’s plan to retire at the end of this month presents a series of questions for the Vatican to address.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Though it may have come as a shock Monday to the world’s one billion-plus Catholics, Pope Benedict XVI’s plan to retire on Feb. 28 appears to have been in the works for some time, and was known to a handful of close advisers.

headline: The Gun Report: February 12, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Two women were shot to death and two Capitol Police officers injured Monday when a gunman opened fire at the New Castle County Courthouse in Delaware. The shooter also is dead. One of the victims may be the shooter’s estranged wife. The gunman did not get past the building’s metal detectors before he opened fire in the public lobby. Numerous reports identified the gunman as David T. Matusiewicz, a disgraced optometrist, who grabbed headlines in for kidnapping his three young daughters from their mother and taking them on an 18-month journey to Panama, Costa Rica, Mexico and Nicaragua beginning in 2007.

abstract: The Exploratorium, the hands-on science museum in San Francisco, will open its doors in April at its new location at Pier 15 on the waterfront. On Monday, though, its second free iPad application will be available in Apple’s app store.
lead_paragraph: The Exploratorium, the hands-on science museum created by the physicist Frank Oppenheimer four decades ago, will open its doors in April at its new location at Pier 15 on the San Francisco waterfront.

headline: Ryanair Indicates Regulators Will Reject Aer Lingus Deal

headline: In Performance: Mercedes Herrero and Andy Paris of ‘The Laramie Project’
abstract: Mercedes Herrero and Andy Paris perform scenes from the Tectonic Theater Project’s piece on the murder of Matthew Shepard.
lead_paragraph: The Tectonic Theater Project’s 2000 docu-play, “The Laramie Project,” is based on interviews with 200 people after the 1998 murder of Matthew Shepard, a gay 21-year-old student in Laramie, Wyo. In 2010 the company went back to Laramie to interview several of those people again and then created “The Laramie Project: Ten Years Later.” The two works will be performed in repertory, featuring members of the original cast, at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Tuesday through Feb. 24th. In these scenes from “The Laramie Project,” Mercedes Herrero plays Reggie Fluty, the officer who discovered Matthew Shepard’s body, and Andy Paris plays Dr. Cantway, the doctor who tended to him.

headline: Decision on Afghan Troop Levels Calculates Political and Military Interests

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to remove 34,000 American troops in Afghanistan by this time next year represents a careful balancing of political interests and military requirements.

headline: Bourn and the Mets: What Was That All About?

headline: Home Is Where the Burritos Are
abstract: The writer Jim Gavin on his love for burritos and other SoCal specialties.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Jim Gavin made literary waves with “Costello,” a tragic, funny story in The New Yorker about a Southern California plumbing salesman. Now he’s publishing his debut collection, “Middle Men” (Simon & Schuster), and nearly all the tales mention Del Taco, the Mexican fast-food chain. Mr. Gavin, who lives a block from a Del Taco in Los Angeles, spoke about his love for certain SoCal specialties.

headline: How Frothy Is the Tech Boom?

lead_paragraph: Lots of start-ups in Silicon Valley aren’t just getting rich on paper. They are cashing out, long before they get to the public market.

headline: If It’s Thursday, Forget the Forks
abstract: At Jeepney, a Filipino gastropub in the East Village, flatware is replaced by fingers, plates by banana leaves, once a week.
lead_paragraph: On Thursdays at Jeepney, the new Filipino gastropub in the East Village, you eat with your hands. And it’s harder, and less intuitive, than you’d think. That’s because Thursday is Kamayan night, an East Village spin on a traditional pre-colonial communal feast. Flatware is replaced by fingers, plates by banana leaves, and napkins by hot, damp towels, handed to you at the beginning and end of the meal but never during.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Toronto, London, California
abstract: A weekly capsule of events across the globe curated by our writers and editors.

The Gladstone, sensing a wasted opportunity, has embraced the occasion with programming that does not feel like homework. In addition to a photo exhibition through Feb. 28 on Caribbean dance-hall (above, “Daddy Ants With Track, Youth Promotion Yard”), the hotel has scheduled a CD release party for a Cameroonian singer on Feb. 22 and a screening of “The Harder They Come” on Feb. 24. headline: ‘Comedy of Errors’ and Musical ‘Love’s Labour’s Lost’ on Shakespeare in the Park’s Bill
abstract: Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Hamish Linklater will star in “The Comedy of Errors,” Shakespeare’s farce about two sets of twins separated at birth, while a new musical of “Love’s Labour’s Lost” will reunite Michael Friedman and Alex Timbers, the team behind “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson.”
lead_paragraph: Long before television sitcoms and the modern families they depict there was Shakespeare’s “Comedy of Errors” and its farcical depiction of some convoluted bloodlines. The play — about two pairs of twin brothers, separated at birth and reunited in adulthood — is one of two works the Public Theater will present this summer as part of its annual Shakespeare in the Park series in a production featuring the comedy stars Jesse Tyler Ferguson (“Modern Family”) and Hamish Linklater (“The New Adventures of Old Christine”). But which twin is each actor playing? The Public isn’t saying just yet.

headline: After Delay, Yiddish Writer’s Papers Will Be Made Available to Public

headline: The Long, Long Run: Glenn Frey and Don Henley Reflect on ‘History of the Eagles’
abstract: Glenn Frey and Don Henley of the Eagles discuss their band’s career, which is told in a new Showtime documentary directed by Alison Ellwood and produced by Alex Gibney.
lead_paragraph: They were the band that simultaneously told listeners to take it easy and take it to the limit, and for the Eagles, the contradictions didn’t end there. Over a career filled with laidback hits like “Peaceful Easy Feeling,” “Lyin’ Eyes” and the enigmatic “Hotel California,” this best-selling rock group, led by Glenn Frey and Don Henley, was internally a caldron of professional determination and personal conflict. They spent the 1970s fighting, drinking and drugging while frequently revising their lineup and their sound, and seemed to split for good in 1980. Then, just to throw everyone for a loop, the band reunited in 1994 and has continued to tour and record ever since.

headline: Australian Report on Israel’s ‘Prisoner X’ Suggests Melbourne Man Was Mossad Agent
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Censorship', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation reported on Tuesday that a man referred to in Israel as “Prisoner X,” who was jailed and died under mysterious circumstances in 2010, might have been an Australian-born Israeli who worked for Israel’s secret service, the Mossad.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 2:53 p.m. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation reported on Tuesday that a man referred to in Israel as “Prisoner X,” who was jailed and died under mysterious circumstances in 2010, might have been an Australian-born Israeli who worked for Israel’s secret service, the Mossad.

headline: Photos: Baseball Is Back
abstract: People who checked their Twitter feed Tuesday probably could not help but notice that baseball is back, as pitchers and catchers began reporting to training camps.
lead_paragraph: People who checked their Twitter feed Tuesday probably could not help but notice that baseball is back, as pitchers and catchers began reporting to training camps.

headline: Guided by the Northern Lights
abstract: At Aska in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the cuisine is renovated Scandinavian, and there’s a sense that even the chef isn’t sure what will happen next.
lead_paragraph: A single blue icicle. An empty beach. Clouds in a blank pewter sky. Leafless birches. Someone rolling in the snow, naked.

headline: Illustrating the Importance of Words, Letter by Letter
abstract: In a new show, a Bronx artists’ group called the X Collective seeks to put a human face on illiteracy and other problems in the borough.
lead_paragraph: Arismendy Feliz used to hold monthly reading workshops at a struggling middle school in the South Bronx. It was not the students, but the parents — many of them Latin-American or West African immigrants — who needed help with the ABC’s.

headline: Ryanair Says Aer Lingus Bid Will Be Rejected
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Ryanair, which was making its third attempt to acquire the troubled Irish carrier, threatened to appeal the decision made by European regulators.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Even the third time may not be the charm for Ryanair’s attempt to take over Ireland’s flag carrier Aer Lingus.

headline: Outrage at a North Korean Nuclear Test
abstract: Richard Haass on the diplomatic fallout. | William Broad on what it means for the North’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Richard Haass on the diplomatic fallout. | William Broad on what it means for the North’s nuclear program.

headline: A Teaching Kitchen for Brooklyn Brewery
abstract: The space will accommodate classes and other events.
lead_paragraph: By the end of the year, Brooklyn Brewery will add a teaching kitchen for classes and events in 1,100 square feet of space on its second floor, overlooking the brewhouse. Steve Hindy, an owner, has hired Andrew Gerson, who was at Antica Pesa in Rome and in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to be the chef-instructor. Mr. Gerson plans to use local ingredients to highlight the beers. Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster, will also be involved. And unlike most teaching kitchens, Mr. Hindy said, it would have “a good draft system.”

headline: Don Johnson Settles ‘Nash Bridges’ Lawsuit
abstract: The actor has accepted $19 million in a settlement with Rysher Productions, the company that produced his long-ago CBS crime series, “Nash Bridges.”
lead_paragraph: In the seemingly perennial battle between producers of TV shows and the people who star in them, Don Johnson has notched a victory, quietly pocketing $19 million in a settlement with the company that produced his long-ago CBS crime series, “Nash Bridges.”

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 12
abstract: A view of the day in sports, as baseball training camps started filling up with pitchers and catchers in Florida.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, as baseball training camps started filling up with pitchers and catchers in Florida.

headline: Dreaming of a Custom Statuette for Every Winner
abstract: A new commemorative poster commissioned by the Academy imagines how each statuette would look if it were inspired by the actual best-picture winners.
lead_paragraph: Completists already planning their Oscar party have an array of décor options, especially if they’re into graphic design. The Academy just released its poster for this year’s ceremony, commissioned from the young British artist Olly Moss in collaboration with Gallery1988. His witty illustration for the 85th show includes a look back at the preceding decades, with 84 Oscar statuettes inspired by each year’s best picture winner. See if you can guess which one is “Shakespeare in Love” or “Crash.”

headline: The Charges Are Flying Over a Test of Tesla’s Charging Network
abstract: Some additional thoughts about a troubled test drive of the Tesla Model S along the East Coast.
lead_paragraph: The account in Sunday’s Automobiles section of The Times detailing my troubled East Coast road trip in a Tesla Model S sedan has generated quite a lot of commentary on the Internet, on Twitter and in the news media. Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, issued several tweets and was interviewed on CNBC Monday afternoon, where he disputed some aspects of the article.

abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.

headline: Why Is Verizon Reviewing Smartphone Apps?
abstract: Android phones have access to hundreds of thousands of apps, but not all are created equal. Verizon Wireless is stepping in to call out the ones that can cause problems like rapid battery draining, exposed privacy or unexpected high data usage.
lead_paragraph: Android phones have access to hundreds of thousands of apps, but not all are worth buying or downloading. Verizon Wireless is stepping in to call out the ones that are good and bad.

headline: A Small But Full-Featured Keyboard for the iPad Mini
abstract: While the size of the iPad Mini is part of its attraction, its glass keyboard is harder to type on than that of the full-size iPad. Logitech has created a diminutive keyboard with full-size features to help.
lead_paragraph: While the small size of the iPad Mini is its charm, it is also a liability. The challenge of typing on a glass keyboard increases as its size shrinks.

headline: Bitterly Divided Senate Panel Backs Hagel for Defense
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday approved the nomination of former Senator Chuck Hagel as defense secretary, sending it to the full Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a combative two-hour debate that tested the bounds of Senate collegiality, the Armed Services Committee on Tuesday approved the nomination of former Senator Chuck Hagel as defense secretary on a sharply partisan vote.

headline: 10 Questions: David Axelrod
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: David Axelrod sat down with John Harwood to discuss the president’s State of the Union and the state of American politics.
lead_paragraph: David Axelrod, President Obama’s longtime strategist, has completed his full-time White House service and overseen his last political campaign. But Mr. Axelrod still advises Mr. Obama even as he has started a new Institute of Politics at the University of Chicago.

headline: Francisco Says He’s ‘at Level Zero’ With Elbow
abstract: Until Frank Francisco’s return from inflammation in his elbow, Bobby Parnell will be the Mets’ closer, Manager Terry Collins said in a radio interview.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Frank Francisco will have to wait until some inflammation dissipates from his elbow before he can defend his assertion that he should be the Mets’ closer this season.

headline: Those Taking Higher Education Credits Can File Taxes on Thursday
abstract: Taxpayers claiming the American Opportunity Tax Credit or the Lifetime Learning Credit can begin filing their tax returns on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Taxpayers claiming higher education credits are getting a valentine from the Internal Revenue Service: They can begin filing their tax returns on Thursday, the agency announced this week.

headline: American Vermouth: Anything Goes
abstract: European law requires vermouth to be made with wormwood, but on this side of the Atlantic, makers are free to tinker.
lead_paragraph: At one time it shared equal billing with gin in the martini. But when that cocktail went dry, vermouth was relegated to the back of the bar. Worse than uncool, it became irrelevant.

headline: Politics in Bangladesh Jolted by Daily Demonstrations
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Thousands demonstrated again on Tuesday in Dhaka, fueled by anger over a recent ruling by the country’s special war crimes tribunal that they say was too lenient.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Huge daily demonstrations in the heart of Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, are upending the nation’s politics and illustrating how heavily the country’s bloody past still weighs on its present. Thousands of protesters, most of them college students and other young people, demonstrated again on Tuesday, fueled by broad public anger over a recent ruling by the country’s special war crimes tribunal that they say was too lenient.

headline: Satellites Reveal Depletion of a Vital Middle East Water Supply
abstract: A satellite probes one of the planet’s most turbulent regions and finds a new source of risk — declining groundwater supplies
lead_paragraph: Just in case you needed more reasons to be concerned about the stability of the Middle East, new research using data from NASA’s gravity-sensing Grace satellites shows a substantial decline in the volume of groundwater reserves in the Tigris and Euphrates river basins. Data gathered between 2003 and 2009 show the seasonal recharge of the region’s aquifers (the blue pulses in the illuminating animation above) but then the onset of a potent drought in 2007 followed by a persistent big drop in water amounts, 60 percent of which is ascribed to unsustainable rates of pumping in a study to be published on Friday in the journal Water Resources Research.

headline: In Europe, a Risk-Filled Choice for Britain
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: As the country’s economic fortunes sag, the prospect of leaving the European Union jeopardizes Britain’s access to trade with the Continent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BM Catalysts, a British producer of catalytic converters and other car exhaust parts, is an example of the kind of successful exporter that might seem to validate the historic gamble that Prime Minister David Cameron has taken by raising the prospect of Britain’s departure from the European Union.

headline: Stargazing: New York Fashion Week, Day 5
abstract: As the lights dimmed at Theyskens’ Theory show on Monday afternoon, a grizzled Olivier Zahm slipped into his seat near Terry Richardson, who was giving the photographers his trademark thumbs up.
lead_paragraph: As the lights dimmed at Theyskens’ Theory show on Monday afternoon, a grizzled Olivier Zahm slipped into his seat near Terry Richardson, who was giving the photographers his trademark thumbs up.

keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Gun Control', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: President Obama pledged to fight for a higher minimum wage, more government investment in schools and clean energy, and deficit reduction through spending cuts and tax increases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, seeking to put the prosperity and promise of the middle class at the heart of his second-term agenda, called on Congress on Tuesday night to raise the federal minimum wage to $9 an hour, saying that would lift millions out of poverty and energize the economy.

headline: Why a Victim of Sandy Doesn’t Want an S.B.A. Loan

lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about Ralph Lucci, owner of Automobile Film Club of America, a company that has supplied vehicles for film and television productions since 1993. Based in Stapleton, on Staten Island near the waterfront, the company’s lot and 57 cars were flooded last October during Hurricane Sandy’s surge.

headline: Apple Chief Hints at Shareholder Rewards to Come
abstract: Investors have been pressing Apple to distribute more of its vast cash hoard to its shareholders. Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said on Tuesday that the company was discussing the problem, suggesting that some kind of payout is likely soon.
lead_paragraph: Investors want more cash from Apple.
