headline: Never Mind the Dictionary: Justice Is Spelled With a Z
abstract: The Scottish troupe Visible Fictions brings “The Mark of Zorro” to life onstage with only three actors and a few props.
lead_paragraph: How can you lure children raised on computer-generated imagery and high-tech special effects to a swashbuckling adventure with only three actors, a few props and dozens of plastic cutouts? You’d need clever design, highly skilled performers and plenty of fancy footwork.

headline: Justin Bieber, Lady Gaga and Madonna Go Clubbing
abstract: “Totally Tubular Time Machine” is a mash-up of pop music set in 1989 that includes celebrity impersonators from today.
lead_paragraph: A disclaimer: Your humble critic usually doesn’t drink when reviewing shows. It can be challenging to wield the critic’s ax responsibly under the influence.

headline: White Paper on 340B Hospitals
abstract: In a white paper, pharmaceutical industry trade groups say that some hospitals have gone overboard in using a drug discount program known as 340B.
lead_paragraph: In a white paper, pharmaceutical industry trade groups say that some hospitals have gone overboard in using a drug discount program known as 340B.

headline: How MacFarlane and the Academy Help Each Other
abstract: The Oscar host Seth MacFarlane’s appeal, as judged by the Q Scores Company, is about on a par with that of Peyton Manning.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—Is Seth MacFarlane going to help the Oscars, or are the Oscars going to help Seth MacFarlane?

headline: A Top UBS Executive Is to Depart
keywords: ['Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: Carsten Kengeter, the former head of the investment bank of UBS, is resigning from the Swiss banking giant.
lead_paragraph: Carsten Kengeter, the former head of UBS‘s investment bank, has been on the outs at the Swiss banking giant for some time. On Tuesday, the bank announced that he was resigning.

headline: Do the Dinner Kits Deliver?
abstract: A two-week trial run of dinner kits yielded dishes that were usually ready in 30 to 40 minutes and tasted reasonably good.
lead_paragraph: THE TWO WEEKS I spent cooking dinner from the kits available in New York City were surprisingly pleasant. As a veteran of the scramble to feed a family of four after work, I found it restful to bypass the stress of choosing a recipe at work, mentally mapping the ingredients (is there still some chicken stock in the freezer?) and sprinting through the market on the way home.

headline: Everything but the Cook
abstract: A host of new services are delivering proportioned, ready-to-cook ingredients for recipes that can be prepared quickly at home.
lead_paragraph: Nick Taranto thinks you should cook your own dinner tonight. He even thinks you might pay him for the privilege.

headline: Rodarte and Diesel Make for Easy Riders
abstract: Tie-dye and beaded angels’ wings were the most graphic elements of a Rodarte collection that had people talking about skaters, goth and bikers.
lead_paragraph: Tie-dye and beaded angels’ wings were the most graphic elements of a Rodarte collection that had people talking about skaters, goth and bikers. There were a lot of disparate elements to digest in the multilayered outfits of the sisters Kate and Laura Mulleavy, and it might take some time to sort them all out.

headline: Palestine’s Democratic Deficit
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: The persecution of Facebook activists shows that the Palestinian Authority has little respect for democracy and freedom of speech.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, a 26-year-old Palestinian activist, Anas Awwad,  was sentenced in absentia by a court in Nablus, the West Bank, to one year in prison for “extending his tongue” against the Palestinian Authority’s president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Facebook. Thousands have joined a Facebook group to show their solidarity with Mr. Awwad, but the damage has been done. Free speech has been set back, and a chill sent throughout Palestinian society.

headline: Peter Som’s Digital Runway
abstract: The designer gave up his coveted spot at the tents for a digital presentation. The benefits, he believes, outweigh the sacrifices.

headline: Senate Votes Overwhelmingly to Expand Domestic Violence Act
keywords: ['Violence Against Women Act (1994)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Domestic Violence', 'Native Americans', 'Women and Girls', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: With broad bipartisan support, the Senate voted to expand the Violence Against Women Act by fortifying the power of Native American courts and protecting gay victims of abuse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate, with broad bipartisan support, voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to expand the reach of the landmark Violence Against Women Act of 1994 by fortifying the power of American Indian tribal courts and explicitly protecting gay victims of domestic abuse.

headline: Diesel Black Gold: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Choose Enough Body
abstract: A rich, juicy guinea hen pairs wonderfully with any number of wines, red and white.
lead_paragraph: The rich, juicy guinea hen in David Tanis’s column, along with the mouthwatering combination of rosemary, garlic and lemon, pairs wonderfully with any number of wines, red and white. For whites, I’d want deep rather than delicate, an Alsatian riesling, for example, which has enough body to match the hen, or a dry Vouvray from a riper vintage, like 2009. Good red choices abound: a cru Beaujolais, a Burgundy with enough age to be past its reticence or a savory St.-Joseph that hasn’t seen much new oak.

headline: Russia May Restrict Investing Abroad
abstract: A measure would ban senior Russian officials from holding bank accounts or stocks outside Russia in an effort to insulate the country’s governance from foreign influences.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin introduced a draft law on Tuesday that would bar senior Russian officials from holding bank accounts or stocks outside Russia, the latest in a series of recent measures intended to insulate the country’s governance from foreign influences.

headline: Dispute Develops Over Discount Drug Program
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Drug makers say a system of discounts intended for low-income and uninsured patients is being abused, but hospitals say they can’t do business without it.
lead_paragraph: When a private oncology practice in Memphis formed a partnership with a nearby hospital in late 2011, the organizations proclaimed that the deal would “transform cancer care” in the region.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Mali, Bangladesh and West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Mali, Bangladesh and West Bank.

headline: Comcast Buys Rest of NBC in Early Sale
abstract: The purchase completes a sales process that was expected to take several more years.
lead_paragraph: 9:28 a.m. | Updated Comcast gave NBCUniversal a $16.7 billion vote of confidence on Tuesday, agreeing to pay that sum to acquire General Electric’s remaining 49 percent stake in the entertainment company. The deal accelerated a sales process that was expected to take several more years.

headline: A 102-Year-Old Face of Voting Delays at the State of the Union
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A centenarian who waited three hours to cast an early vote in Florida will sit with Michelle Obama as the president pushes to make it easier to vote and register to vote.
lead_paragraph: In the first lady’s box at the State of the Union address on Tuesday night, Desiline Victor, 102, will be seated among Michelle Obama’s guests as a symbol of voters who faced long delays as they tried to cast ballots in last year’s elections.

headline: Unusual Moves in Confronting Apple’s Huge Pile of Cash
abstract: With $140 billion in cash at stake, Apple and the hedge fund manager David Einhorn have been acting strangely.
lead_paragraph: The fight over Apple’s $140 billion cash pile is proving the adage that money can make people do strange things.

headline: A Patch that Monitors the Body
abstract: BodyMedia, which makes the Link activity monitor, is preparing to release the Vue Patch, a disposable monitor in a stick-on patch that will collect a week’s worth of data on a user’s activity level, sleep patterns and calories burned.
lead_paragraph: The International Consumer Electronics Show had its share of activity measuring devices, from tiny clips that hang on a pocket to lanyards and wristbands that convert a phone into a private coach.

headline: Authorities to Determine if Remains Are of California Fugitive
abstract: Officials will begin forensic tests to determine if charred human remains in a burned-out cabin are those of Christopher J. Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer sought in the region’s largest manhunt.
lead_paragraph: BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif. — After a shootout and a forest standoff on Tuesday afternoon, Christopher J. Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer sought in the region’s largest manhunt, was apparently killed in a cabin as it burned down around him, but officials said they needed time to sort through the rubble.

headline: Coca-Cola Lifts Profit, but Shares Close Down
abstract: The company earned $1.87 billion for the fourth quarter of 2012, but its shares closed down 2.7 percent, to $37.56.
lead_paragraph: Facing challenges from foreign exchange rates, reduced demand for carbonated beverages and bumpy markets in Europe and China, Coca-Cola still managed to increase its fourth-quarter profit, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: For Science’s Sake, It’s ‘Mohawk Guy’
abstract: To highlight science education and memorable haircuts, one of the guests in Michelle Obama’s box during the State of the Union speech will be NASA’s Bobak Ferdowsi.
lead_paragraph: To highlight science education and memorable haircuts, one of the guests in Michelle Obama’s box during the State of the Union speech Tuesday night will be the “Mohawk Guy” — Bobak Ferdowsi, a member of the team operating NASA’s Mars Curiosity rover who is best known for his spiky, red- and blue-streaked haircut and the stars shaved on the side of his head.

headline: Read Any Good Web Sites Lately? Book Lovers Talk Online
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Commerce', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: The social media site goodreads.com is exploding in popularity as a platform for finding and sharing and, yes, marketing books.
lead_paragraph: Lori Hettler is a passionate reader, tearing through about 80 books a year. But as a resident of a Pennsylvania town and with a preference for fiction from small publishers, she can have trouble finding new books to feed her habit.

headline: A Museum Broadens Its Identity
abstract: In her first year as the Jewish Museum’s director, Claudia Gould has had to juggle expectations about her initiatives.
lead_paragraph: Directors of large institutions often spend their first year on the job mapping out their plans while their predecessors’ last projects hold the spotlight. Claudia Gould, the Jewish Museum’s new director, has had another task as well: juggling other people’s expectations and fears about her intentions for the museum, an unwanted distraction as she prepares to revitalize an institution that even its supporters admit has become staid.

headline: Silenced in Israel, Spy Tale Unfolds in Australia
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: An Australian news report that identified a mysterious prisoner as a Mossad agent is testing Israeli censorship.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The story had all the trappings of a spy thriller: an anonymous prisoner linked to Israel’s secret service, Mossad, isolated in a top-security wing originally built for the assassin of a prime minister. A suicide — or was it a murder? — never officially reported. A gag order that barred journalists from even acknowledging the gag order. And a code name to rival 007: Prisoner X.

headline: Pamela Druckerman’s Favorite ‘French Parenting’ Advice
abstract: Why talk more about “French parenting”? Because in the outcome-oriented world of the American parent, there’s something to be learned from an approach that considers the quality of the years you spend together.
lead_paragraph: Here is the thing about “French parenting”: many of us, people who will never, ever look good with a scarf tied around our necks, can get just a little defensive when the French are held up as an example.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, chocolates in the shape of ladybugs and bees, a carbon-steel paella pan and Brooklyn bouillon.
lead_paragraph: To Give: Just to Say: Valentine, You’re Cute as a BugRed ladybug truffles and golden bees with liquid honey caramel swarm the Bee My Lovebug collection from John & Kira’s, an artisanal chocolate company in Philadelphia. Or instead of bugging your Valentine, consider the Enchanted Garden, a box of colorful “fruit,” with oranges filled with orange and white chocolate, apples with a spiced chocolate filling, and cherries filled with a brandied ganache. The candies can be ordered in time for Thursday: $29 at johnandkiras.com, and at Chelsea Market Baskets.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16 Returns
abstract: Video highlights of Tuesday’s Round of 16 matches in the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: The UEFA Champions League returned Tuesday with the start of the Round of 16. After a winter break we continue a featurette in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say They Have Seized a Military Airfield and Its Warplanes
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Military Aircraft', 'Firearms']
abstract: The development, if confirmed, represents the second strategic setback for President Bashar al-Assad’s government this week.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian insurgents seized control of a northern military airfield on Tuesday and captured usable warplanes for the first time in the nearly two-year-old conflict, according to rebels and activist groups. The development, if confirmed, would represent the second strategic setback for President Bashar al-Assad’s government this week.

abstract: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Saving Karachi’s Street Children, One Goal at a Time
abstract: Whether they realize it or not, Karachi’s street children are freeing themselves from the clutches of lethal drugs, unconscionable abuse and gang violence by participating in the Street Child World Cup soccer competition in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Twisting themselves into funnel clouds, Karachi’s flies compete with scurrying cockroaches, frantic to feast upon the same garbage as the children. Children scavenge the piles of filth, braving the stench of urine, in search of something salvageable, wearable, edible, drinkable, inhalable. Imprinted on the lens of dust that permeates the city is the image of Karachi’s voiceless population: its street children.

headline: Updates on Christopher Dorner Manhunt
abstract: What appeared to be the last stages of the largest manhunt in Los Angeles Police Department history unfolded on live television on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Lede tracked the manhunt for Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer, on Tuesday.

headline: Victoria Beckham | Behind the Scenes
abstract: Shot in the style of her forthcoming website, T exclusively takes a peek at the moments before the models step out onto the catwalk at Victoria Beckham’s show at the New York Public Library.
lead_paragraph: Shot in the style of her forthcoming website, T exclusively takes a peek at the moments before the models step out onto the catwalk at Victoria Beckham’s show at the New York Public Library.

headline: In Shovels, a Remedy for Jobs and Growth
abstract: Economic growth remains blighted by the recession, and Washington’s policy makers could be doing more about it, like investing in infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The budget deficit in 2013 is expected to fall below $1 trillion for the first time in five years. Perhaps policy makers in Washington can now focus on the other $1 trillion deficit, one that gets next to no attention yet is much more threatening to the well-being of American families: our sluggish economic growth.

headline: Live Coverage of Obama’s State of the Union Address
abstract: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night and Times reporters are providing live updates and analysis.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night and Times reporters are providing live updates and analysis. “It is our unfinished task to make sure that this government works on behalf of the many, and not just the few,” Mr. Obama will say, according to brief excerpts that the White House released Tuesday evening.

headline: Silicon Valley and Immigrant Groups Find Common Cause

headline: Study Finds More Benefits of Folic Acid
abstract: Women taking folic acid, a B vitamin, before pregnancy were less likely to have children diagnosed with the most severe form of autism, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Women taking folic acid, a B vitamin, before pregnancy were less likely to give birth to children with the most severe form of autism, a new study has found. Researchers in Norway and at Columbia University followed more than 85,170 Norwegian mothers who gave birth between 2002 and 2008, recording their prenatal diets and surveying them for six and a half years on average. Among their children, the researchers identified 270 with autism spectrum disorders, including 114 with autism disorder. The researchers found that the risk of having a child with autism disorder was reduced by 40 percent among women who had taken folic acid supplements during the critical developmental period from four weeks before conception and continuing eight weeks into the pregnancy. Still, the absolute risk that a child would have autism disorder was very low: 0.2 percent among women not taking folic acid, versus 0.1 percent among those who did. The study was published online on Tuesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline: New Pope? I’ve Given Up Hope
abstract: Only the pope has the authority to make the changeless church change, but it is his authority that stands in the way of change.
lead_paragraph: THERE is a poignant air, almost wistful, to electing a pope in the modern world. In a time of discredited monarchies, can this monarchy survive and be relevant? There is nostalgia for the assurances of the past, quaint in their charm, but trepidation over their survivability. In monarchies, change is supposed to come from the top, if it is to come at all. So people who want to alter things in Catholic life are told to wait for a new pope. Only he has the authority to make the changeless church change, but it is his authority that stands in the way of change.

If the comptroller’s numbers are right — and the mayor’s Twitter robot moved quickly to mock him in a denial so substantive that it did not use up the entire 140-character allotment for posts — the city will come away with a dime on the dollar of the actual value of its land.

abstract: The measures considered most important by cybersecurity experts were not included in the executive order because they require Congressional approval.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama signed an executive order on Tuesday that promotes increased information sharing about cyberthreats between the government and private companies that oversee the country’s critical infrastructure, offering a weakened alternative to legislation the administration had hoped Congress would pass last year.

headline: The President’s Challenge to Congress
abstract: In the State of the Union address, Mr. Obama pointed to a way out of austerity and the stalemate on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: Americans who have become weary of Washington’s endless battles over spending and taxes — and the stagnating economy that stalemate has produced — got a chance to hear about a different path on Tuesday night. President Obama’s message in the State of the Union address was clear: It doesn’t have to be this way.

headline: Challenged for His Seat at 89, a Senator Does Not Go Gentle
abstract: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey has embraced his job with new vigor, even as Cory Booker, the mayor of Newark, has said that he will seek the seat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he approached his 89th birthday this year, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey was finally considering retirement, an option he had tried a decade earlier and hated so much that he jumped at the chance to return to political life.

headline: Rubio’s Rebuttal
abstract: The up-and-coming senator reminded voters that Republicans don’t like government or taxes.
lead_paragraph: Andy Borowitz’s humor column on how Fox News aired a scathing rebuttal to the State of the Union hours before its delivery was — in a case of politics imitating political satire — not too far off the mark. As is customary, Senator Marco Rubio wrote his “response” before President Obama even drove up to Capitol Hill, and sent advance excerpts to the press.

headline: A Secretive Country Gives Experts Few Clues to Judge Its Nuclear Program
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Experts don’t yet know if the latest detonation used plutonium or uranium, or if it was nuclear at all.
lead_paragraph: As scientists and world leaders scrambled Tuesday to judge the importance of North Korea’s claim that it had detonated a third nuclear bomb, the main thing that quickly became evident is how little is known about the country’s increasingly advanced atomic and missile programs.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Hundreds of police officers shut down the headquarters of the Interior Ministry in at least seven provincial capitals on Tuesday in a series of protests against what they called political exploitation by the government of President Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Rangers Surrender Two Late Goals but Do Not Give Up
abstract: Rick Nash and Ryan Callahan scored in a shootout, giving the Rangers a hard-earned, if nerve-racking, victory over the Bruins.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For 58-plus minutes, the Rangers were in command against the Boston Bruins primarily because of one man — goaltender Henrik Lundqvist. He was nothing short of sensational, and the Rangers, leading 3-1, were just a few ticks away from what would have been a rewarding victory at TD Garden.

abstract: An international meeting on Libya that was held in Paris focused on border control, weapon-smuggling and challenges posed by regional militias that have not disarmed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nearly two years after a revolt that ousted and killed the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya’s weak government is struggling to control its borders, stop the smuggling of weapons and manage regional militias that have refused to disarm, according to the conclusions of an international meeting on Libyan security here on Tuesday.

headline: Why Four Workouts a Week May Be Better Than Six
abstract: A fairly leisurely approach to scheduling workouts may actually be more beneficial than working out almost daily, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: A common concern about exercise is that if you don’t do it almost every day, you won’t achieve much health benefit. But a commendable new study suggests otherwise, showing that a fairly leisurely approach to scheduling workouts may actually be more beneficial than working out almost daily.

keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s proposal to raise minimum wage to $9 an hour directly addresses the country’s yawning levels of inequality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama called on Congress to raise the federal minimum wage to $9 an hour from $7.25 and to automatically adjust it with inflation, a move aimed at increasing the earnings of millions of cooks, janitors, aides to the elderly and other low-wage workers.

abstract: President Obama suggested Tuesday night that it was time to close out the politics of austerity and move to a more balanced approach on fiscal issues.

headline: No Ordinary Affenpinscher, Banana Joe Is Named Best in Show
abstract: Banana Joe defeated six dogs on Tuesday night to become the first affenpinscher to win the distinction at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.
lead_paragraph: Banana Joe, a black dog with a monkeylike face, became the first affenpinscher to win Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday night. He defeated six dogs, one a Portuguese water dog on the same night that Bo, who is the same breed, watched his master, President Obama, deliver the State of the Union address.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TMC) GOON (2012) Seann William Scott (above right, with Liev Schreiber) is Doug Glatt, a bouncer who discovers a second career as a minor-league hockey player who gains popularity not by scoring goals but by winning brawls in this comedy directed by Michael Dowse and written by Jay Baruchel and Evan Goldberg. Doug has a softer side off the ice, where he meets Eva (Alison Pill), a hockey fan who is only partly resistant to his goofy charm. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden described a moment when this movie “reveals its true colors and turns from a rowdy sports farce into something vaguely resembling the ‘Rocky’ of hockey movies.” He added: “Behind the film’s brass knuckles are tender fingers. Why else would ‘Goon’ use music from Puccini’s ‘Turandot’ to underscore critical dramatic moments?”

headline: Is There Another Way Forward Over North Korea?
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: As escalation grips Northeast Asia after North Korea set off a third nuclear explosion, some are asking: is there another way forward? Is providing North Korea with a sense of security the solution?
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Another nuclear test in North Korea. More United Nations-led sanctions. Increasing militarization in Northeast Asia, with South Korea planning to deploy cruise missiles capable of striking North Korea  and Pyongyang threatening unspecified “second and third measures of greater intensity” against the United States as punishment for persistent American “hostility,” with the nuclear test Tuesday just a first measure.

headline: Fugitive’s Threats Against Police Drew Enormous Response
abstract: As many as 500 officers — roughly 5 percent of the Los Angeles Police Department — spent the last week protecting one another from Christopher J. Dorner, now believed dead.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Christopher J. Dorner had a long list of grievances and potential victims, most of them police officers he had once worked with, and he was already suspected of killing the daughter of a retired police official and her fiancé. So law enforcement officials moved rapidly to protect their own, removing officers from the streets and setting up the largest security detail in any city in recent history.

headline: India’s Capital City Celebrates ‘Design Week’
abstract: The best of Indian design, showcased in New Delhi.
lead_paragraph: Art lovers have the India Art Fair and Francophiles have Bonjour India. And now interior design enthusiasts have a week to call their own in New Delhi.

headline: One for the Road
abstract: Designers Irving and Fine — queens of airy, relaxed fashions — are out with a new Lucky Brand collection.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Lisa Fine and Carolina Irving have been quietly perfecting the art of the airy caftan and the peasanty tunic with a fashion line that’s sold mostly at trunk shows and online. Their clothes convey a jet-set life where one flits breezily from Patmos to Punjab. Now Lucky Brand has tapped the duo to do a collection including flowy tops, delicately embroidered jackets and a souk-ready jute-and-leather tote that delivers the pair’s signature style at prices that are downright proletariat.

headline: Pope Ushers In Lent, Making Its Message of Sacrifice Personal This Year
abstract: In his first public appearance since the announcement of his resignation, Pope Benedict XVI said he no longer had the strength needed to carry out the duties of the papacy.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI presided over Ash Wednesday services, his final public Mass, at St. Peter’s Basilica, thanking the faithful for their support during his nearly eight-year pontificate, which will end on Feb. 28 when he becomes the first pope to resign in almost 600 years.

headline: Money for the Taking in the Niger Delta Swamps
abstract: Squeezed out of Nigeria’s lucrative oil economy, the people who live in the Niger Delta have resorted to refining their own bootleg fuel.
lead_paragraph: When night falls on the Niger Delta, hundreds of people set sail on hand-made wooden boats toward the oil pumps jutting out along the swampy creeks. Clouds of smoke float in the night air. Makeshift fuel refineries — with the same machines once used to distill palm oil into gin — begin churning crude oil into diesel fuel.

headline: Taking a Third Pass at Selling Movie Subscriptions
abstract: For a flat monthly fee of as little as $29, MoviePass users can go to a movie every day. But will the service make money?
lead_paragraph: Twice in 2011, Stacy Spikes tried to start a subscription service for going to the movies. Called MoviePass, it offered cinephiles nearly unlimited access to theaters – up to one 2-D film each day – for a flat monthly fee. Mr. Spikes hoped his service would transform the industry; he wanted to see it go big. But something always got in the way.

headline: Connie Britton Is a Late Bloomer
abstract: The 45-year-old known for her exemplary television marriage and amazing hair has built the rare career for an actress: one that gets better with age.
lead_paragraph: Connie Britton got over it a long time ago, the part that got away. But it’s a good story, and she still tells it with feeling: The year was 1995. Edward Burns, who had just directed her (and starred in) “The Brothers McMullen,” reached into his backpack one night over dinner and handed her a script that Cameron Crowe had sent him to read. Burns wasn’t interested himself, wanting to act in his own films instead. But he thought Britton was perfect for the romantic lead.

headline: How Napoleon Chagnon Became Our Most Controversial Anthropologist
abstract: Napoleon Chagnon tramped through a rain forest, uncovering the lives of indigenous tribes. But to some, he’s anything but a hero.
lead_paragraph: Among the hazards Napoleon Chagnon encountered in the Venezuelan jungle were a jaguar that would have mauled him had it not become confused by his mosquito net and a 15-foot anaconda that lunged from a stream over which he bent to drink. There were also hairy black spiders, rats that clambered up and down his hammock ropes and a trio of Yanomami tribesmen who tried to smash his skull with an ax while he slept. (The men abandoned their plan when they realized that Chagnon, a light sleeper, kept a loaded shotgun within arm’s reach.) These are impressive adversaries — “Indiana Jones had nothing on me,” is how Chagnon puts it — but by far his most tenacious foes have been members of his own profession.

headline: Do Violent Video Games Make People More Violent in Real Life?
abstract: Do you ever play violent video games? Do your friends?
lead_paragraph: Young people, especially boys, are playing bloodier and more realistic video games than ever before, and scientists are looking for links between real life violence and violent video games. However, the research so far is inconclusive.

The conference chairman interrupted the proceedings and apologized: The Italian journalists, most of them working the religion beat, had just received important news from the Vatican.

lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Hope in a Bottle
abstract: Personal reflections on the power of perfume and its particular ability to permeate the good times and the bad.
lead_paragraph: My late father once told me that a person who wants to be loved should get into smells and poetry. Like great advisers everywhere, he failed to take his own advice. (He smoked a brand of cigarettes called Sweet Afton, after the poem by Robert Burns. That just about covered the terrain of his advice. My mother emptied his ashtrays for 30 years, then didn’t speak to him for another 30.) But like any sentimental son, I sought to turn into wisdom the advice my father was too much himself to heed. And where my dad was merely trying it on, Baudelaire was for real. At an early age I developed, like him, a completely French sensitivity to the scent of skin and floating clothes. He called the male love of female smell “a kind of androgyny,” and he believed that a man without it ­— a man opposed to his feminine side — was really an “incomplete being.”

lead_paragraph: MADRID—The European Central Bank and its president, Mario Draghi, want to ensure that their voices get heard beyond the financial district of Frankfurt.

headline: Avoiding the Curse of the Oil-Rich Nations
abstract: When a nation is dependent on the production of oil, corruption and conflict often follow. But there are ways to put a country’s oil revenues to good use.
lead_paragraph: Every nation wants to strike oil, and after it happens, nearly every nation is worse off for it. It may seem paradoxical, but finding a hole in the ground that spouts money can be one of the worst things that can happen to a country.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Comcast Buys Rest of NBCUniversal, and Sites That Appeal to Book Lovers
abstract: Comcast bought the rest of NBCUniversal from General Electric for $16.7 billion; Web sites that help uncover new books, like Goodreads.com, have become indispensable for readers, writers and publishers; and Slacker, a digital music service, takes aim at Pandora in new advertisements.
lead_paragraph: 9:28 a.m. | Updated Comcast agreed to pay General Electric $16.7 billion to acquire their remaining 49 percent stake in NBCUniversal on Tuesday, Amy Chozick and Brian Stelter write. Brian Roberts, Comcast’s chief executive, said that the acquisition was a necessary step given the rapidly changing television business and the necessity of owning content. Comcast bought a 51 percent share in NBCUniversal in early 2011, with the option of buying the rest of the company over the next seven years; the process was accelerated at least in part by a clash in corporate cultures between G.E. and Comcast. The deal will also include 30 Rockefeller Plaza and the CNBC headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., for about $1.4 billion. Naming rights are included in the deal, so the red G.E. sign atop 30 Rockefeller Plaza could be replaced with a Comcast logo.

headline: Six More Journalists Held in British Hacking Case
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'News and News Media', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Scotland Yard said on Wednesday that the journalists, who previously worked for The News of the World tabloid, were arrested on suspicion of hacking into cellphone messages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Adding momentum to police investigations that have already cost Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper empire in Britain hundreds of millions of dollars, Scotland Yard said Wednesday that six more journalists who previously worked for The News of the World were arrested at dawn on suspicion of hacking into cellphone messages.

headline: Daily Report: Silicon Valley and Immigrant Groups Find Common Cause
abstract: Silicon Valley executives, who have long pushed for more visas for foreign-born experts in math and science, are joining forces with immigration advocates, Somini Sengupta reports.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley executives, who have long pressed the government to provide more visas for foreign-born math and science brains, are joining forces with an array of immigration groups seeking comprehensive changes in the law, reports Somini Sengupta of The New York Times.

headline: Rising From Ruins
abstract: Even as Israel neglects a major archaeological site in the West Bank, it is preventing the Palestinian Authority from tending to it.
lead_paragraph: SEBASTIA, West Bank — I spent last Sunday, a gorgeous early spring day, visiting a colonnaded street leading to a Roman theater, the 30 B.C. temple of Augustus and a church built to commemorate the martyrdom of John the Baptist, which supposedly occurred on this hill. These and many more ruins can be seen in Sebastia, an ancient city first settled in the Early Bronze Age less than ten miles northwest of Nablus.

headline: Now Streaming | Michael Kors Fall 2013 Women’s Collection
abstract: The Fall 2013 women’s collection from Michael Kors at New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Joyce Theater and the Brooklyn Academy of Music Announce Cuba Dance Partnership
abstract: Ronald K. Brown will travel to Cuba to select a Cuban dance company to create a new work, to be performed at the Joyce in May 2014.
lead_paragraph: A new, two-year project to promote an arts partnership between the United States and Cuba was announced Tuesday by the Joyce Theater Foundation and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The project is designed to offer Cubans arts administration training, internships and help creating a new dance work to be performed at the Joyce Theater.

headline: ‘Life of Pi,’ the Silent Version
abstract: The screenwriter of “Life of Pi” says he and the director, Ang Lee, considered making the middle section — the part set on the open ocean — silent.
lead_paragraph: David Magee is an Oscar nominee and a contender for a Writers Guild Award, this weekend, for his adaptation of the novel “Life of Pi.” But his fellow writers might look askance at his day job before becoming a screenwriter: he abridged books.

headline: Dependability Is Better Than Ever and Lexus Tops the List, J.D. Power Says
abstract: The J.D. Power study, in its 24th year, measures problems experienced by the original owners of three-year-old vehicles over the past 12 months.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 Vehicle Dependability Study, released today by J.D. Power & Associates, contains some surprises as well as things that should come as no surprise.

headline: Health Officials Urge F.D.A. to Limit Sweeteners in Sodas
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Corn Syrup and Sweeteners', 'Obesity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Led by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, the group says the scientific consensus is that the level of added sugars in soft drinks is unsafe.
lead_paragraph: A group of health advocates and public health officials from major cities around the country are asking the Food and Drug Administration to regulate the amount of caloric sweeteners in sodas and other beverages, arguing that the scientific consensus is that the level of added sugars in those products is unsafe.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The Columbus Dispatch: In this review of “Creamy and Crunchy,” a new history of peanut butter, it is revealed that the first commercial version was half peanut butter, half processed cheese. Shouldn’t this be on the snack menu of every retro-American restaurant, alongside the deviled eggs and beer cheese? — Julia Moskin

headline: Giddyup
abstract: “Noni the Pony” and “Rosie’s Magic Horse” are welcome additions to the shelf of children’s books about horses.
lead_paragraph: Horse fiction is a staple among school-age readers, particularly girls, but for some reason picture books about horses are less common. This makes two new picture books, “Noni the Pony” and “Rosie’s Magic Horse,” welcome additions to the genre. Each demonstrates the pleasures of horses and ponies for children whose feet do not yet reach the stirrups.

headline: Parnell Could Close for Mets
abstract: Bobby Parnell of the Mets could be the team’s closer if Frank Francisco begins the season on the disabled list.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Bobby Parnell received a call from Manager Terry Collins on Tuesday night, and the message was simple: If Frank Francisco has to begin the season on the disabled list, then you are the Mets’ closer.

headline: How to Help Veterans Succeed in College
abstract: Who should be responsible for informing veterans about the nuances of higher education? Once a veteran is on campus, it may be too late, argues Ryan Gallucci of the nonprofit organization Veterans of Foreign Wars.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, I returned from a year in Iraq to finish my undergraduate degree at the University of Rhode Island. Since I took more than a year’s leave of absence to deploy, I was forced to reapply to the university. While writing another entrance essay to explain how I spent my “year off,” I wondered why my school didn’t have a peer support system for its students who are veterans.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Bo Don at Thakoon
abstract: The model transforms, with makeup by Diane Kendal and hair by Odile Gilbert.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper517 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: A Bat Fungus on the March
keywords: ['Bats', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Fungi', 'Immune System', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: White nose syndrome has been discovered in three caves in Cumberland Gap National Historic Park.
lead_paragraph: A deadly bat fungus has spread to three caves in Cumberland Gap National Historic Park in Virginia, park officials have confirmed.

headline: Lost in Translation? Try a Google App
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Chinese Language', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Google Phone', 'Language and Languages', 'Mobile Applications', 'Translation', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Google’s Translate app proves its worth on a trip to China. But knowing your way around it in advance is a good idea.
lead_paragraph: The slow boat to Chongqing left at 4 the next morning, according to Tan Kao, a helpful young man who approached me in the bustling port of Fengjie, a Yangtze River town not accustomed to foreign visitors. But his English maxed out there, and I still had no idea how to book a ticket (and was deeply reluctant to return at 3 a.m. without one).

headline: Rubio’s Thirst Trumps His Message
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio’s big nationally televised moment has been eclipsed Tuesday by his simple decision to take a sip of water during his speech, an act that either made him look human or not ready for prime time, depending on one’s point of view.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican of Cuban heritage, may be the “savior” of the Republican Party, as Time Magazine recently declared.

headline: Lady Gaga Postpones Concerts Because of Illness
abstract: The singer postponed concerts in Chicago, Detroit and Hamilton, Ontario, because she is suffering from severe joint pain brought on by an injury.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga has postponed four concerts in Chicago; Detroit; and Hamilton, Ontario, over the next week because she is suffering from severe joint pain brought on by an injury, the singer announced Tuesday on her Web site.

headline: A Meal Discount for Well-Behaved Children?
abstract: Some restaurants reward families with well-behaved children with discounts.
lead_paragraph: Last summer while enjoying an anniversary dinner at a lovely — and pricey — waterfront restaurant, my husband and I realized that guests at a nearby table had two children who appeared to be under age 10. They had been so quiet and orderly — no one was demanding ketchup or complaining loudly — that it was an hour into our meal before we realized they were there.

headline: At SAP Open, a Showcase for the Next Generation
abstract: The SAP Open in San Jose, Calif., will feature a lineup of young American tennis players.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Over the weekend, Andy Roddick donned a knitted hat and a white golf glove at a celebrity pro-am in Pebble Beach, Calif., America’s one-time tennis poster boy trading in his workman’s racket for leisure and a nine iron.

headline: Cervelli Gives Brief Account of Visit to Clinic
abstract: Of his connection to the Biogenesis clinic in Coral Gables, Fla., that is being investigated by Major League Baseball, Yankees catcher Francisco Cervelli said, “I just went there, talk, and that’s it.”
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Francisco Cervelli understands he made a mistake. What he will not say is who urged him to make it.

headline: Bill Clinton to Present Film Society’s Chaplin Award to Barbra Streisand
abstract: Mr. Clinton, a longtime fan of Ms. Streisand’s, will present the Chaplin Award to her at a gala held by the Film Society of Lincoln Center on April 22.
lead_paragraph: Now that he’s got a little more time on his hands these days, former President Bill Clinton seems to have a reignited passion for motion pictures. First, he turned up at the awards ceremony for the Golden Globes to sing the praises of Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln,” and now he’ll be giving a coveted film prize to Barbra Streisand. The Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Wednesday morning that Mr. Clinton will present its Chaplin Award to Ms. Streisand at a gala ceremony on April 22. Ms. Streisand, the actress, singer and director whose movies include “Funny Girl,” “The Way We Were,” “Yentl” and “The Prince of Tides,” was announced last month as the 40th recipient of the Chaplin Award. That honor has previously been given to artists like Catherine Deneuve, Sidney Poitier, Michael Douglas, Tom Hanks and Meryl Streep. The Film Society said its awards gala, to be held at Lincoln Center, would be attended by other celebrity guests and feature film clips and interviews celebrating Ms. Streisand’s career.

headline: Paris to Madrid Gets Faster
abstract: The first direct Madrid-Barcelona-Paris high-speed train service is set to begin in April.
lead_paragraph: The first direct Madrid-Barcelona-Paris high-speed train service is set to begin in April, cutting the current standard service running time to 9 hours from 15 hours. Spain inaugurated its first high-speed line connecting the country to France last month, an improvement heralded by Prince Felipe, but passengers currently have to transfer from Spain’s AVE trains to France’s TGV trains near the border.

headline: After the State of the Union
abstract: Examining reaction to President Obama’s address
lead_paragraph: Examining reaction to President Obama’s address

headline: Extending a Theme, Obama Promotes Resurgence in U.S. Manufacturing
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: President Obama traveled to North Carolina on Wednesday to promote the resurgence of American manufacturing, a core message from his State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — The day after President Obama charted an expansive new view of the government’s role in society, it seemed less and less likely that many of his proposals would survive the political riptide on Capitol Hill.

headline: If You Like Janis Ian, Try Emily Hurd
abstract: Like Janis Ian, Emily Hurd of the new band Stone Blind Valentine offers emotion with a bittersweet edge.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: 200 Years of ‘Pride and Prejudice’
abstract: Cover designs say a lot about the cultural reach of Jane Austen’s classic.
lead_paragraph: Cover designs say a lot about the cultural reach of Jane Austen’s classic.

headline: Madoff Continues to Affect Owners of the Mets
abstract: Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the Mets, have missed out on money paid to those who invested with Bernard L. Madoff.
lead_paragraph: These days, the Mets could use a little extra cash. They are operating like a small-market club, preferring to stock up on low-salaried players and not acquiring major free agents.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 13
abstract: A ‘Safe Sex Awareness’ campaign in New Delhi on International Condom Day.

headline: Calmly, Pick for Treasury Offers Replies to Senators
abstract: Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s pick to lead the Treasury Department, faced questions about his approach and his work on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s nominee for Treasury secretary, faced some fierce questioning on Wednesday from the Senate Finance Committee on his tenure at the bailed-out Citigroup and on an investment based in the Cayman Islands. But the even-tempered, bookish Mr. Lew parried the blows and appeared likely to win the committee’s approval and Senate confirmation.

headline: Not Just a ‘Feminine Mystique': What Hasn’t Changed Enough for Women and Family?
abstract: Forty years ago, 10 years after she wrote “The Feminine Mystique,” Betty Friedan said “housework and child-rearing will have to be more equally shared by husband, wife and society.” How outraged are you that we’re still not there?
lead_paragraph: On The Times’s Room for Debate online forum, Gail Collins led a discussion among five women about the 50th anniversary of “The Feminine Mystique.” Betty Friedan, she said, wrote a cry of rage and frustration about feeling trapped in her role. She asked her debaters, “What’s your cry of rage today?” and they answered, with passion you can see and hear (watch their discussion, a Google Plus video debate, here).

headline: RHA Earphones Cut Frills and the Price
abstract: RHA, which makes some good-quality earphones at a modest price, has adapted some key components from its higher-end earphones to produce the budget-price MA150.
lead_paragraph: RHA, the Glasgow headphone company that makes some good-quality earphones at a modest price, has in a sense, downscaled. It has adapted some key components from its midprice earphones to produce the budget-price MA150.

headline: The 200-Year Jane Austen Book Club
abstract: “Pride and Prejudice” has been published with radically different covers over the course of two centuries.
lead_paragraph: Let’s just be honest about our superficiality. Even when it comes to the high-­minded business of literature, people do judge books by their covers. Perhaps that’s why Amazon produces glossy mock “covers” for its disembodied e-books, to be inspected and decided upon alongside the traditional print offerings.

headline: Keeping Up the Pressure on Gun Violence
abstract: The Times’s Megan Liberman sits down with Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia, president of the United States Conference of Mayors, to talk about his hopes for tougher gun legislation.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Megan Liberman sits down with Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia, president of the United States Conference of Mayors, to talk about his hopes for tougher gun legislation.

headline: Only Scandinavian Sharks Were Used in the Making of This Film
abstract: The makers of “Kon-Tiki” are still exhilarated from the Oscar nominees’ luncheon, when they sat next to Steven Spielberg, whose “Jaws” inspired scenes in their film.
lead_paragraph: Joachim Ronning and Espen Sandberg, who jointly directed “Kon-Tiki,” one of the five nominees for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film, came naturally to their subject, the explorer Thor Heyerdahl’s 1947 voyage across the Pacific Ocean on a balsawood raft. Friends since they were 10 years old, both men are from a small town in southern Norway that neighbors Heyerdahl’s birthplace, and as boys were enthralled when they visited the Kon-Tiki Museum in Oslo.

headline: Westminster’s Best in Show Hits Broadway: Banana Joe in ‘Drood’ for a Night
abstract: Banana Joe, the affenpinscher who was named Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, will appear in Wednesday evening’s performance of “The Mystery of Edwin Drood.”
lead_paragraph: You know how these show-business success stories go: one day you’re just a hound nobody’s heard of, the next you’re making your debut on Broadway. In the latest chapter of the tale of Banana Joe, the affable affenpinscher who was named Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday night, this newly minted celebrity pooch is heading from Madison Square Garden to Studio 54 on Wednesday, where he will be joining the cast of “The Mystery of Edwin Drood,” the Broadway musical adapted from the unfinished Charles Dickens novel.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Rodarte
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Well Flu Quiz
abstract: What surface is the most friendly to the flu virus? Where’s the best place to stand when you’re talking to a sick person? And how are Australians curbing germs in schools? To find out these answers and more, take the Well Flu Quiz.
lead_paragraph: What surface is the most friendly to the flu virus? Where’s the best place to stand when you’re talking to a sick person? And how are Australians curbing germs in schools?

headline: What Sort of Leader Was Lincoln?
abstract: To understand the president properly, one must understand his vision on constitutional government.
lead_paragraph: What kind of a leader was Abraham Lincoln? This is a question that has bedeviled every student of Lincoln who has ever considered it, even today, 204 years after his birth. There is virtual consensus that Lincoln was an exemplary leader, but opinion differs on the lessons to be drawn from his leadership. Did he exert features of moral grandeur and heroism necessary to steer the country through its deepest political crisis? Or was he an aspiring tyrant, especially in his use of executive power?

headline: Curfew Lifts in Some Areas of Kashmir
abstract: Several shops still remained shut and security personnel continued to man the streets, locals said.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Jammu and Kashmir — Authorities eased the curfew in the Kashmir Valley on Wednesday, its fifth day, lifting restrictions in several areas of the summer capital of Srinagar as well as the districts of Budgam, Pulwama and Kupwara.

headline: In Speech, Obama Tempers Expectations of Syria’s Future
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: President Obama appeared to moderate his predictions for change in Syria in Tuesday’s State of the Union speech.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Having overruled top advisers who had argued for arming the opposition in Syria, President Obama appeared to moderate his expectations for change in that war-torn country in Tuesday’s State of the Union speech.

headline: Memorable Moves by Nash in Rangers’ Win
abstract: Rick Nash of the Rangers plays a game of highlights.
lead_paragraph: When the Rangers acquired Rick Nash in the off-season, much was said about him being the missing piece of the puzzle — another playmaker who would help a team that struggled to score goals. So far this season the Rangers are scoring at a similar clip to last season (2.67 goals per game vs. 2.71 last season). But the Rangers, known more for their grinding play than their grace, have become a highlight reel presence thanks to Nash’s fancy footwork.

headline: A Cookie Workout
abstract: Watch the chef Christina Tosi and the model Karlie Kloss work out and make cookies — at the same time.
lead_paragraph: In what may be the first official collaboration between a pastry chef and a prominent model, Christina Tosi of Momofuku Milk Bar and Karlie Kloss are traveling around the city today in a truck to pass out cookies and mark the end of Fashion Week. Lucky Peach features Ms. Tosi and Ms. Kloss in a video (with a cameo from Danny Bowien of Mission Chinese) making Perfect 10 Kookies, a gluten-free confection, in vintage Jane Fonda aerobics gear.

headline: Alderson Talks About Mejia and Santana
abstract: Pitcher Jenrry Mejia cannot leave the Dominican Republic, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson said, and the team is reviewing whether to allow Johan Santana to pitch in the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson spoke to reporters Wednesday morning and answered a variety of questions that lingered as spring training got under way.

headline: Using Federal Oil Revenues to Cut America’s Oil Use
keywords: ['Energy Efficiency', 'Royalties', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Energy experts speculate about what how an “energy security trust” could be financed and forge new paths.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union message on Tuesday night, President Obama proposed the creation of an “Energy Security Trust” to find alternatives to dependence on oil for the nation’s transportation needs. The trust would be financed from revenue from oil and gas royalties that the federal government collects from companies that drill on federal land.

headline: 11 Afghans Killed in Military Actions Near Pakistan Border
abstract: International military officials are investigating two episodes  of civilian deaths in what appeared to be American-led military actions.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — International military officials are investigating two episodes in which as many as 11 Afghan civilians may have been killed in what appeared to be American-led military actions.

headline: Comcast’s Prime-Time Deal
abstract: Comcast is valuing NBCUniversal at about nine times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, assuming growth continues at a similar pace, roughly where Barclays analysts peg Disney.
lead_paragraph: Comcast has smartly ad-libbed on an already winning script. Back in 2009, the cable operator engineered a complex, multistep deal with General Electric to buy NBCUniversal.

headline: Collateral Damage? Researching a Connection Between Video Games and Violence
abstract: In this lesson, students read about studies exploring how video games affect gamers, and then evaluate the evidence that both supports and rejects the connection between violent video games and aggression. In the activity, students discuss the issue in a talk show or debate.
lead_paragraph: Overview | Do violent video games promote aggressive or hostile behaviors among gamers? How have social scientists tried to answer this question? Is it answerable?

headline: Regulator Explains Decision to End Flawed Foreclosure Review
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Thomas J. Curry, the comptroller of the currency, shed light on the recent decision to scuttle an independent review of bank foreclosures, portraying the flawed process as a boon to outside consultants and a barren maze for homeowners.
lead_paragraph: A top regulator shed light Wednesday on his decision to scuttle an independent review of bank foreclosures, portraying the flawed process as a boon to outside consultants and a barren maze for homeowners.

headline: Bibhu Mohapatra: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: When Action Is the Family Business
abstract: Bruce Willis takes his fifth turn playing John McClane, this time in Moscow, in the stunt-loaded film “A Good Day to Die Hard.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s not 1986 anymore,” a sneering Russian villain (one of several in “A Good Day to Die Hard”) says to John McClane. “Reagan is dead.”

headline: The Gun Report: February 13, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The big news of the day, of course, was the firefight between law enforcement officials and a man presumed to be Christopher J. Dorner in Big Bear, resulting in the shootings of two police officers, one fatally. Lost in the furor were a number of  multiple-casualty shootings of the sort that seem to take place every day.  I guess that’s why they’re not big news anymore – multiple shootings have become a dog-bites-man story. Here’s our daily report:

headline: Meet the Morgan Stanley C.F.O. Candidates
abstract: Among the leading internal candidates are said to be Paul Wirth, Jonathan Pruzan, Dan Simkowitz and James A. Rosenthal.
lead_paragraph: Who will be the next chief financial officer at Morgan Stanley?

headline: The Struggle for Control of the Right
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: The G.O.P. and the Tea Party gave dueling responses to President Obama’s State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: The rise of the Tea Party, which burst into national politics in 2009 and scored its first major electoral victories in 2010, set off a struggle within the Republican Party over just how far to the right the G.O.P. was willing to go. With that question settled — really, really far — we are now seeing the outlines of a struggle for control of the far right.

headline: As James’s Game Takes Off, Comparisons Are Harder
abstract: With six consecutive basketball games in which he has scored at least 30 points and shot 60 percent or higher, LeBron James is on a great roll for any field.
lead_paragraph: Since LeBron James was in high school, the name on the tip of everyone’s tongue has been Michael Jordan.

headline: College Tips for Juniors From an Ivy League Dean
abstract: Eric Furda, the dean of admissions at the University of Pennsylvania, was on the “Today” show and shared admissions tips with college-bound students and their families.
lead_paragraph: Our Counselor’s Calendar tells us that now is the time for juniors to begin their college search in earnest. So it was very timely to see that Eric Furda, the dean of admissions at the University of Pennsylvania, appeared on NBC’s “Today” show on Wednesday to share admissions tips with college-bound students and their families. Watch the full interview below.

headline: Bureaucrats Express
abstract: Brussels Airlines is adding direct Brussels-to-Washington flights five days a week in June.
lead_paragraph: Brussels Airlines is adding direct Brussels-to-Washington flights five days a week in June, linking the United States capital with the seat of the European Parliament (above). The flights will be in addition to current ones the carrier offers through an agreement with United. The route comes a year after Brussels Airlines began offering its first trans-Atlantic route, from Brussels to New York. As flights are defined by their frequent passengers, this one will most likely be tame: expect bureaucrats on smartphones in “airplane” mode.

headline: A Documentary About a Palestinian Village Sets Off a Dispute
abstract: A Palestinian filmmaker and an Israeli director made the documentary “5 Broken Cameras,” but their collaboration has led to misleading descriptions in the news media, they say.
lead_paragraph: No sooner had “5 Broken Cameras,” a close-in look at the effect of Israeli occupation on life in a Palestinian village on the West Bank, been nominated for an Academy Award in the best feature-length documentary category than it set off a political dispute in the Middle East. With two directors — the Palestinian Emad Burnat and the Israeli Guy Davidi — was it a Palestinian film or an Israeli film? Just the whiff of Israeli involvement was enough for some Arab countries to ban its exhibition.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Houndstooth
abstract: A Saville Row classic, houndstooth is getting updated this season at Thom Browne, Rag & Bone and Tommy Hilfiger.
lead_paragraph: A Savile Row classic, houndstooth is getting updated this season: Thom Browne did it in dramatic molded, voluminous shapes; Tommy Hilfiger printed it on pony (another trend from this week); and Rag & Bone blew up the traditional check.

headline: Excerpt: Holland Taylor in ‘Ann’
abstract: Holland Taylor in the Kennedy Center production of her solo show about Ann W. Richards, the former governor of Texas. The production opens on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont Theater on March 7.
lead_paragraph: Holland Taylor in the Kennedy Center production of her solo show about Ann W. Richards, the former governor of Texas. The production opens on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont Theater on March 7.

headline: Nanette Lepore: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Should the Minimum Wage Be Raised for Waiters?
abstract: What will a higher minimum wage do for restaurant workers? Twitter users had many opinions.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama said in his State of the Union address Tuesday that he wanted to raise the minimum wage, the chef Tom Colicchio took to Twitter to lend his support.

headline: Executive Steeped in Print Joins Online Ad Venture
abstract: Steve Sachs, who held several top posts at the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner until he left almost a year ago, is joining OneSpot, a start-up based in Austin, Tex. that specializes in what is called content advertising.
lead_paragraph: A former senior manager at a print industry leader is becoming the chief executive of a company that specializes in one of the most popular trends in online advertising.

headline: In First Disclosure, Getco Reports Years of Sagging Profit
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Getco, the privately held high-frequency trading firm, released its financial results for the first time as part of its impending purchase of Knight Capital Group.
lead_paragraph: One of the most powerful firms in the secretive high-speed trading industry reported on Wednesday that its profit and revenue had been declining steadily since the financial crisis.

headline: Giving Congress Information
abstract: Brooks and Collins dissect the State of the Union address and discuss how it made John Boehner feel.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, how did you like the State of the Union address? I’m normally not a big fan of them, but I have to say I thought President Obama was great this year.

headline: In Policy-Heavy Speech, Obama Appeals to Emotion on Guns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: President Obama’s State of the Union address will probably be most remembered for his repeated demands for a Congressional vote on behalf of the victims of gun violence
lead_paragraph: If there is one moment that is sure to be remembered from President Obama‘s State of the Union address on Tuesday, it will probably be his repeated demands for a Congressional vote on behalf of the victims of gun violence.

headline: Vain Glorious | La Fille de Berlin
abstract: A new scent takes inspiration from the resilience of women during the Soviet occupation of postwar Germany.
lead_paragraph: The famed perfumer Serge Lutens’s latest offering may be ruby red in color and set to hit counters tomorrow on Valentine’s Day, but make no mistake, this isn’t a sentimental homage to love. La Fille de Berlin takes its inspiration from the brave resilience of women during Soviet occupation in postwar Germany. Centered on a rich and powdery rose note and spiked with a hint of red pepper, the scent evokes both the feminine and formidable sides of a woman. “Beauty is the moment in which you rise up,” Lutens recently explained. “It is the moment when you pick up your head, stride through your own ruins and climb up the mountain.”

headline: Blogging With Video, Hoping to Go Viral
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: The first rule for would-be video bloggers: Don’t let your ego get between the camera and the audience.
lead_paragraph: It would take 72 hours to watch all the videos uploaded to YouTube every minute by would-be commentators, comedians, cosmetologists and various other content creators all hoping for a breakout hit.

headline: Redskins Address the Name Issue (but Not Directly)
abstract: On the Web site of the N.F.L.’s Redskins, other teams with that name get a turn in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: As a response to a festering controversy, this is an odd one. The Washington Redskins’ team name, long criticized by many, recently prompted the mayor of the District of Columbia to say that the name would have to be discussed if the Redskins were to pursue a move to the district from their current home in Landover, Md. Now, the team has launched a series of stories on its own Web site, Redskins.com, designed, it seems, to defend the name by writing about how proud many high schools are to call themselves Redskins.

headline: Michael Kors: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Trade Puts Distance Between Family, Dog and Pitcher
abstract: Blue Jays pitcher Mark Buehrle will live apart from his wife and two children this baseball season because of the family’s pit bull — and the trade from the Marlins.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — The first thing Mark Buehrle said Wednesday about his brief and bitter experience with the Miami Marlins is that he knew he was taking a risk. The Marlins have a longstanding policy of refusing to give no-trade clauses, and he did not get one with his four-year, $58 million deal before last season. But he took the team at its word.

headline: The Splashes and Roars of ‘Life of Pi’
abstract: Eugene Gearty, a sound editor of “Life of Pi,” discusses his process.
lead_paragraph: From the crashing waves to the tiger roars to the flopping of flying fish, the lost-at-sea adventure “Life of Pi,” directed by Ang Lee, is as much an aural spectacle as a visual one. And 2 of its 11 Oscar nominations recognize those sound efforts, for mixing and editing. The distinctions can be confusing, but the sound editing process involves recording and preparing individual sounds, while the mixing process combines those recordings with dialogue and other elements to create a final soundtrack.

headline: Ex-State Senator Files 2nd Guilty Plea in Fraud
abstract: Shirley L. Huntley of Queens, who is awaiting sentencing on a related federal charge, admitted in state court to trying to cover up the theft.
lead_paragraph: A former New York State senator pleaded guilty on Wednesday to falsifying evidence in an attempt to cover up the theft of taxpayer money from a nonprofit agency that she founded, ending a prominent corruption case that included charges in federal and state courts.

headline: Debt Mounting, Postal Service Asks to Alter Business Model
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The postmaster general asked Congress to let the Postal Service run its own health plan, modify a mandate on a benefit fund and end Saturday mail delivery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saying that its debt could reach $45 billion by 2017 if Congress does not act, the Postal Service on Wednesday called on lawmakers to give it the flexibility to change its business model to keep itself solvent.

headline: Wilpon Asserts Rebound for Mets Is Near
abstract: Although the Mets’ owner generally avoids the spotlight, allowing others to address the team’s competitive and financial struggles, Fred Wilpon answered his critics at spring training.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Fred Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, appeared at the team’s spring training complex Wednesday morning and did his best to paint a rosy portrait of a team that has not finished above .500 since 2008, has not been in the postseason since 2006 and continues to deal with questions about its ability to spend money to improve its unimposing roster.

abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.

abstract: Photo: a pair of muscovies tried their footing on the frozen lake Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: A successful skating session calls for a celebration.
