headline: A Whodunit Committed by a Whole Classroom
abstract: A yearlong workshop at Sarah Lawrence College is devoted to collectively writing “Naked Came the Post-Postmodernist,” which has a publisher and is to come out this year.
lead_paragraph: The first dead body simply had to be a math professor, said Rebecca Shepard, 20, a sophomore at Sarah Lawrence College.

headline: On the Issues: A Guide to Obama’s Proposals
abstract: A guide to The Times’s coverage of the policy areas President Obama discussed in his State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: From gun violence to the campaign against terrorism, from climate change to the minimum wage, here is a guide to The Times’s coverage of the policy areas President Obama discussed in his State of the Union address.

headline: Dos and Don’ts for Successful Web Videos
abstract: Are your online video views low? Here are some tips — from production tricks to content editing — to keep your audience engaged.
lead_paragraph: Are your online video views low? Here are some tips — from production tricks to content editing — to keep your audience engaged.

headline: Video of California Shootout Is Captured by CBS News Crew
abstract: As the manhunt for the former Los Angeles police officer Christopher Dorner drew to a close, a news crew recorded video of a gun battle between officers and the suspect that took place in front of them.
lead_paragraph: While the final stage of the manhunt for Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer, unfolded on live television Tuesday evening — with local news channels broadcasting helicopter views of the cabin in the San Bernardino Mountains engulfed in flames — the authorities pressed the media to keep reporters at a distance, because, they suggested, the suspect could have been monitoring broadcasts of the operation as it unfolded.

headline: After Cameo, Poland Spring Uncaps a Response
abstract: When Senator Marco Rubio, the Florida Republican, reached for a bottle of Poland Spring water on Tuesday night during the Republican response to President Obama’s State of the Union address, social media exploded with mentions of the brand. Poland Spring offered a comment in social media on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The phenomenon of brands reacting in real time in social media is fascinating to watch as it changes in real time.

headline: Leading Off: Wrestling Is Ready to Defend Itself
abstract: Coaches are angry about the decision to drop wrestling from the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, between the actual Games that make it relevant, the International Olympic Committee rears its indecipherable head and creates news that makes people slap their foreheads in wonder. Monday’s version of this was the decision to drop wrestling as one of the Olympics’ core sports. Never mind that wrestling is one of the original ancient Olympic sports, is the kind of pure competition that has created indelible Olympic moments through the years and has not been riddled with doping scandals that have turned sports like weight lifting and road cycling into pharmacological contests as much as athletic ones.

headline: Rivera at Spring Training Debut: ‘I Feel Good’
abstract: Yankees pitcher Mariano Rivera threw off a mound on the first day of workouts in Tampa.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mariano Rivera could not stop smiling. On the first day of workouts for Yankees pitchers and catchers, Rivera completed the most mundane of drills with a boundless joy usually reserved for children.

headline: Farm to Table | MacKenzie-Childs’s Aurora Collection
abstract: To commemorate its 30th anniversary, the brand is out with a toile-like tribute to the Finger Lakes.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate its 30th anniversary, MacKenzie-Childs, which is known for its whimsically decorated and patterned home accessories and furnishings, has introduced the Aurora collection of enamelware for the table and kitchen. Named after the Finger Lakes town in New York where the company is based, Aurora is a toile-like, vintage-inspired pattern in pastel colors that depicts pastoral scenes from MacKenzie-Childs’s headquarters, a 65-acre former dairy farm that overlooks Lake Cayuga. (If you look closely, you can spot silhouettes of the company’s famous teapots in the trees.) And in the more-is-more spirit, Aurora is intended to mix with bolder designs like the classic Courtly Check. Prices for the collection, which includes plates, serving bowls, teakettles, and canisters, among other items, range from $36 to $108.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Bragging Rights
abstract: Paul Broun, Republican of Georgia, said in a fundraising letter that he was the first member of Congress to call the president “a socialist.”
lead_paragraph: Via The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

headline: Discounting a Meal for ‘Well-Behaved Kids’
abstract: The “well-behaved kid” discount is cute, but let’s not get carried away.
lead_paragraph: Via the Bucks blog and The Consumerist comes a story of a restaurant that rewarded a family with a discount for “well-behaved kids” printed right there on the receipt.

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 6
abstract: CR Fashion Book fetes 2nd issue, Rodarte parties in East Village, Purple Magazine takes over the Standard.
lead_paragraph: CR Fashion Book fetes 2nd issue, Rodarte parties in East Village, Purple Magazine takes over the Standard.

headline: Groban’s ‘All That Echoes’ Is No. 1
abstract: The pop-classical singer Josh Groban has a No. 1 album with his latest collection of heart-swelling ballads and tenor showpieces.
lead_paragraph: In time for Valentine’s Day, the pop-classical singer Josh Groban has a No. 1 album with his latest collection of heart-swelling ballads and tenor showpieces.

headline: Scott Brown Becomes a Fox News Contributor
abstract: Mr. Brown will make his debut as a paid pundit on Wednesday night’s edition of “Hannity,” the channel’s 9 p.m. program.
lead_paragraph: Fox News on Wednesday added the former Republican Senator Scott Brown to its contributor ranks, two weeks after Mr. Brown decided against another run for a Senate seat in Massachusetts.

headline: Keystone XL Protesters Seized at White House
abstract: Four dozen activists were handcuffed and led away while calling on President Obama to reject construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Four dozen environmental activists succeeded in getting themselves arrested outside the White House on Wednesday afternoon to draw attention to their demand that President Obama reject construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada.

headline: ArcelorMittal Rejects Europe’s Pressure on Job Cuts
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Steel and Iron', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A top European Union official has called on the steel maker to delay moves to reduce operations, but the Indian company has refused.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Alarmed by the speed at which the steel industry is becoming a symbol of Europe’s economic decline, a top European Union official has called for the world’s biggest steel maker to postpone planned job cuts and factory closings.

headline: Cybercrime Network Based in Spain Is Broken Up
abstract: Europol, the European police agency, said that it had dismantled a successful cybercrime organization led by Russians who extorted money from computer users.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Europol, the European police agency, said Wednesday that it had dismantled one of the most efficient cybercrime organizations to date, led by Russians who had managed to extort millions of euros from online users across more than 30 countries — mostly European — by persuading them to pay spurious police fines for abusive use of the Internet.

headline: Brooklynite Hits France, With Plans to Seduce
abstract: Brooklyn Brewery’s strategy is to start small and offer its specialty beers in carefully chosen outlets in the wine-loving country.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Garrett Oliver popped the cork of one of his specialty brews, swirled the amber liquid into a wine glass and took a hearty sniff.

headline: The Dawn of Computer Love
abstract: In 1959, two undergraduate engineering students, Philip Fialer and James Harvey, created one of the first computer matching dating services for a class at Stanford University.
lead_paragraph: In 1959, two undergraduate engineering students, Philip Fialer and James Harvey, created one of the first computer matching dating services for a class at Stanford University.

headline: Model Diary | Julia Nobis
abstract: The 20-year-old Sydney native stars in the current Proenza Schouler campaign while separately studying medicine.
lead_paragraph: You’ve seen her on runways for Derek Lam, Victoria Beckham and Alexander Wang over the past few days of New York Fashion Week. Tonight, 20-year-old Julia Nobis walks in Proenza Schouler, and stars in their current spring 2013 campaign. When she’s not in front of the camera, Brooklyn-based Nobis focuses on college courses in medicine.

headline: Time Warner Considers Spinning Off Some of Its Magazines
abstract: Early discussions involve putting most of its titles — but not Time, Fortune or Sports Illustrated — into a separate company with Meredith magazines.
lead_paragraph: 12:15 p.m. | Updated 9:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Natasha’ and ‘Kid Who Would Be Pope’ Win Musical Theater Prizes
abstract: Musicals by Dave Malloy and the brothers Tom and Jack Megan are winners of the Richard Rodgers Award for Musical Theater.
lead_paragraph: The musicals “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812,” by Dave Malloy, and “The Kid Who Would Be Pope,” by Tom and Jack Megan, are the winners of the 2013 Richard Rodgers Awards for Musical Theater. The prizes, announced this week by the American Academy of Arts and Letters, are intended to help talented composers and playwrights get work produced in New York City.

headline: On Our Radar: The Earth’s Surface, in Sharper Detail Than Ever
abstract: Like other satellites in NASA’s Landsat program, the L.D.C.M. allows for the continual acquisition of high-resolution multispectral data on a global basis.
lead_paragraph: A satellite with new, far more powerful technology for monitoring the Earth’s changing climate, water supplies and agriculture will reach its orbit within two months, NASA says. [NASA]

headline: How Social Media Affects Journalistic Objectivity
abstract: The public editor travels to Harvard’s Shorenstein Center. With audio.
lead_paragraph: I spoke Tuesday at Harvard University’s Shorenstein Center, where the former Timesman Alex S. Jones runs the show. My talk was called “The New Objectivity: How Social Media Is Changing Traditional Reporting,” a subject I’ve written about frequently in blogs and columns.

headline: Try a Little Tenderness
abstract: Philosophers have written tomes on love. So why have they, and most of us, left tenderness — that blossom of love — out in the cold?
lead_paragraph: The philosophers, the lovers of wisdom, have pondered and written a lot about love, even erotic and romantic love, but they have given a cold shoulder to that offshoot of love — tenderness. Indeed, I don’t believe I have ever heard a member of the Socrates guild even mention the lovely word in a remotely philosophical context.

headline: Microcars From Georgia Museum Going on the Auction Block
abstract: This week, some 200 microcars are set to be sold by RM Auctions. They are the collection of the Bruce Weiner Microcar Museum.
lead_paragraph: Microcars are the Munchkins of the car world, the vehicles seized on by cartoon makers for comic relief. (The Isetta for “Cars” and the Zündapp Janus for “Cars 2.”)

headline: Fresh From the Internet’s Attic
abstract: Quirky fixtures of the Web sites from the early Internet, GIF files are enjoying a renaissance.
lead_paragraph: The Internet, it seems, has found its version of vinyl chic.

headline: Kerry Says Trip Will Focus on Finding Syria Solution
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said he planned to raise his ideas  about how to persuade President Bashar al-Assad to agree to a political transition during a trip this month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday that he planned to use his first foreign trip to advance new ideas about how to persuade President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to yield power and agree to a political transition.

headline: ‘Bolero’ on Instruments Ravel Never Dreamed Of
abstract: Ensembles of the Afghanistan National Institute of Music performed at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: During the course of Ravel’s haunting “Bolero,” the slinky, repeated theme is played in turn by a flute, a clarinet, a saxophone and more. But Ravel, a master of orchestration, would surely have been fascinated to hear the tune played on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall by a rubab, the national instrument of Afghanistan, plucked like a lute to produce a sound both tender and tart.

headline: State of the Night Life? Healthy
abstract: As dowdy citizens hunkered down to watch President Obama’s State of the Union speech, the oligarchs entrusted with dressing the nation spent Tuesday night celebrating what turned to be the busiest night of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: As dowdy citizens hunkered down to watch President Obama’s State of the Union speech, the oligarchs entrusted with dressing the nation spent Tuesday night celebrating what turned to be the busiest night of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Visiting the Doctor, Virtually
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Nursing and Nurses']
abstract: One health system has found that online medical visits can be effective and save money.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all wished at times that we could just chat with a doctor from our office, instead of taking time away from work to drive to the clinic. Now, a case study of medical care delivered online suggests that virtual visits can effectively treat some common ailments at a lower cost than in-person visits.

headline: An Arresting Way for Boomers to Protest
abstract: Lawrence MacDonald, founder of a new group for baby boomers, hopes to recruit them to engage in civil disobedience on climate change and other causes.
lead_paragraph: Arguments about generational debt and how baby boomers might make amends usually revolve around Social Security and Medicare. But Lawrence MacDonald has another idea: get arrested, the way you did in the protests of your youth.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Michael Kors
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a perforated leather pump, both ladylike and sporty.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Few States Look to Extend Preschool to All 4-Year-Olds
keywords: ['Education (Pre-School)', 'Head Start Program', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'States (US)']
abstract: While supporters herald President Obama’s plan to extend preschool, critics argue that providing universal access could result in federal money being squandered on ineffective programs.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s call in his State of the Union address to “make high-quality preschool available to every single child in America” rallied advocates across the country who have long argued that inequity in education begins at a very young age.

headline: A Look at Rubio's Bilingual Rebuttal
abstract: A mixed reaction from Spanish-Language media for Senator Marco Rubio’s State of the Union response.
lead_paragraph: A mixed reaction from Spanish-Language media for Senator Marco Rubio’s State of the Union response.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: With Yankees in Ticket Resale Market, Elbows Are Out
abstract: The Yankees seem to have entered another fierce rivalry: with StubHub, the ticket reseller.
lead_paragraph: The escalating war between the Yankees and StubHub continues. On Monday the Yankees said that they had formed their own ticket resale marketplace with Ticketmaster as a way to tamp down on speculators who they claimed were driving down prices and giving fans one less reason to buy from the team.

headline: An Expensive but Logical Cable Deal
abstract: The revelation that Vodafone of Britain is looking at Germany’s biggest cable operator has understandably unnerved its shareholders, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: A 10 billion euro bid by Vodafone for Kabel Deutschland would be logical — and expensive.

headline: Makeup With a Rebellious Hue
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Nails (Body Part)', 'Skin', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Themes like grown-up grunge and dazzling eye makeup dominated New York’s fall 2013 collections.
lead_paragraph: As with the clothes, makeup at fashion shows is increasingly a smorgasbord, rather than one look being in or out. Still, several strong themes seem to have emerged from the New York fall 2013 collections.

headline: Indian Music Service, Taking Page From Spotify, Goes Pro
abstract: Saavn, a Spotify-like streaming service that specializes in Indian music, and has garnered 10.5 million monthly users with advertising-supported free listening. This week it will announce that it has taken another page from Spotify’s book, by offering a premium version at $4 a month.
lead_paragraph: Western music fans have no shortage of digital music services to choose from, and that abundance is spreading around the world. Apple’s iTunes is now in 119 countries, and others are racing to plant their digital flags everywhere. This week, for example, Spotify opened in Italy, Poland and Portugal, bringing its reach to 23 countries.

headline: Cisco Struggles to Adapt, Even as Profit Rises
abstract: Like other tech giants, Cisco is struggling to adapt to a new world in which customers want their technology suppliers to offer sophisticated services, not just equipment.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Cisco Systems is trying to pull off one of the toughest tricks in high technology, adapting a big legacy business to a vastly different future.

headline: Jeremy Scott: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Practice for ‘The Voice’ by Using Yours With Mobile Karaoke
abstract: Mobile apps give singers access to song lyrics and backing tracks, and at least one provides voice coaching.
lead_paragraph: Singing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember, partly because I love it and partly thanks to my Welsh heritage (we’re traditionally belting vocalists). But it’s been years since I last sang in a choir, and my singing is now confined to the shower and the occasional family game of SingStar on the PlayStation.

headline: High Notes in a Clutch of Familiar Melodies
abstract: John Lloyd Young, who played Frankie Valli on Broadway in “Jersey Boys,” shows off a one-in-a-million tenor in his show at the Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: When does a karaoke performance transcend itself? Or a wedding band’s faithful re-creation of an oldie but goody surpass an original recording whose grooves were etched in memory when you were a lonely teenager baying at the moon? These questions roiled in my head while watching the opening-night performance of John Lloyd Young’s show “My Turn,” at the Café Carlyle.

headline: Print on Print
abstract: Sometimes personal style means choosing one strong pattern and sticking with it.
lead_paragraph: Personal style isn’t always about effortlessly mixing color and texture. Sometimes it’s about choosing one strong pattern and sticking with it.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Day 2
abstract: Highlights of Wednesday’s games in the Round of 16 of the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: Day 2 in the Round of 16 in the UEFA Champions League.. After a winter break we continue a featurette in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: On the Magic Side of Brooklyn
abstract: Anthony Edwards stars in “Zero Hour,” a mystery series with a looming Armageddon, on ABC.
lead_paragraph: You probably think that Anthony Edwards has starred in more television series than he actually has — that’s what eight seasons and 180 episodes of a show like “ER” will do for an actor’s reputation. In fact, “ER” is the only show he has headlined; before that he’d done 10 episodes of “Northern Exposure” and a season of the 1982 sitcom “It Takes Two,” in which he was the teenage son of overworked parents played by Richard Crenna and Patty Duke.

headline: J. Mendel: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Art, Sport, Dead Animals: It’s Competitive Taxidermy
abstract: Two new reality shows on AMC, “Immortalized” and “Freakshow,” direct viewers toward the strange.
lead_paragraph: The bombast of professional wrestling and the dolefulness of roadkill may have never struck you as a logical pairing, but perhaps they will once you’ve seen “Immortalized,” an aggressively strange new show on AMC that may be landing at just the right time. Football season is over, baseball season hasn’t started, basketball and hockey aren’t for everybody, so why not competitive taxidermy?

headline: The Creative Elation Embedded in Source Material
abstract: Ronald K. Brown’s company Evidence performed the premiere of “Torch” during its opening night at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: In the program notes for the current run at the Joyce Theater by his company, Evidence, Ronald K. Brown quotes a former teacher who told him “not to give in to the pressure to create something new” and always to “show people where you have come from.” It’s sound advice when your dances and dancers are as extraordinary as Mr. Brown’s.

headline: Pouring Ribbons
abstract: A cocktail bar in the East Village doesn’t invest its energy in ambience.
lead_paragraph: CHANNELING NOSTALGIA for atmosphere, New York night life has seen its share of faux speakeasies, filament light bulbs and mustachioed mixologists who resemble Dickensian chimney sweepers. At Pouring Ribbons, a second-story bar that opened last fall in the East Village, there’s little interest in conjuring a Prohibition-era ambience — or really much ambience of any kind.

headline: How Do You Document Your Trips?
abstract: Twitter users tells us their favorite ways of saving and sharing travel memories.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Getaway column, Stephanie Rosenbloom wrote about apps that help travelers document their trips digitally.

headline: Like Fish in Waterfalls, Exploring Climate Types
abstract: In “Scattered,” video screened onto a concave structure gives the illusion that the performers are climbing to the top of a waterfall or slipping down it.
lead_paragraph: Seven dancers appear in “Scattered,” a 2009 dance-theater work by the British company Motionhouse, and no offense to their hard-won bodies, but the most important element is the set.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Feb. 14
abstract: Jessica Hart, a model on what she’s wearing now; James Colarusso, a painter, discovered jewelry making; Phillip Lim is making muscle T-shirts and blanket scarves from Louis Vuitton.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Hart, a model on what she’s wearing now; James Colarusso, a painter, discovered jewelry making; Phillip Lim is making muscle T-shirts and blanket scarves from Louis Vuitton.

headline: Opposites Attract, and Neither Is Left Unscathed
abstract: “Autobiography of Us,” Aria Beth Sloss’s first novel, traces the friendship between two girls who appear to have little in common.
lead_paragraph: At the start of Aria Beth Sloss’s debut novel, two 14-year-old girls meet at school and strike up a rocky, intense friendship that lasts a lifetime. If this sounds like an unremarkable premise, it is. So is the way these two characters begin as diametrical opposites.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Vatican, Syria, Mali and Colombia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Vatican, Syria, Mali and Colombia.

headline: Talking Points on Gus Johnson’s Talking
abstract: Gus Johnson made his soccer debut in Wednesday’s Champions League game on Fox Soccer.
lead_paragraph: Call it a draw. For Manchester United. For Real Madrid. And for Gus Johnson.

headline: Homes for $5 Million
abstract: Properties in Laguna Beach Calif., Austin, Tex., and Boston, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Properties in Laguna Beach Calif., Austin, Tex., and Boston, Mass.

headline: What You Get for ... $5 Million
abstract: A duplex in coastal California, a lakefront house in Austin and a Victorian in Boston.
lead_paragraph: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF.

headline: At New York Philharmonic, a Night to Celebrate China
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, led by the Chinese conductor Long Yu, held a Chinese New Year celebration on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Doomsayers have long proclaimed the demise of classical music, although given the myriad high-quality concerts almost every night in New York, it seems the genre must be dying elsewhere. The graveyard is certainly not in China, which has seen a surge of interest in Western classical music in the last decade. The New York Philharmonic has paid tribute in recent years to this enthusiasm with a gala event celebrating the Chinese New Year.

headline: TV Is Stingy With the Roses and Chocolate
abstract: The Valentine’s Day lineup of evening television offers little that’s heartwarming, but matters of the heart do surface in some harsh ways.
lead_paragraph: If your Valentine’s Day plans are already made, and they involve Champagne, limousines, prix fixe menus and generally gallant behavior, you can stop reading. There’s nothing here for you.

headline: Tenacious Playwright Is Creating His Moment
abstract: Paul Downs Colaizzo, 27, used hard work and networking to bring his play “Really Really” to New York.
lead_paragraph: Fresh out of New York University in 2007 and anxious about his prospects as an actor, Paul Downs Colaizzo was too poor to afford therapy, so he opted for “the $12.95 version” — self-help books. He read dozens of them, absorbing mantras like “don’t take anything personally” and “be impeccable with your word,” and developing the youthful moxie that has led to his unexpected emergence as an Off Broadway playwright.

headline: Her Date Is a Single Dad; His, a Possible Killer
abstract: The romantic thriller “Safe Haven” is the eighth film adaptation of a Nicholas Sparks novel.
lead_paragraph: The romantic thriller “Safe Haven” plays like an extended infomercial for the lulling charms of Southport, N.C., where the movie was filmed. This picture-perfect town is presented as the go-to destination for terrorized damsels in distress. Here in this tiny paradise, where gentle waters lap the shore and gold-and-purple sunsets stretch all the way to heaven, a new beginning awaits.

headline: Catching Eyes Away From the Runway
abstract: The fashion-show veterans were out in force over the past week in New York.
lead_paragraph: At the Rodarte show on Tuesday afternoon, the sixth day of New York Fashion Week, among the usual collection of editors, stylists and the occasional celebrity (Kim Gordon, Lizzie Tisch, Terry Richardson) sat a man in the front row, dressed in a slim-cut dark suit, open-necked white shirt and white sneakers, and looking a little out of place.

headline: Love in an Edible Garden
abstract: A urban garden created by two men has become home to their wives and families.
lead_paragraph: A urban garden created by two men has become home to their wives and families.

headline: Manhunt and Obama’s Address Bolster CNN’s Ratings
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: Over all, in terms of total viewers, the ratings for the speech were down on most of the networks that carried it, but CNN’s viewership was up sharply, gaining 36 percent over the audience that viewed the speech a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps aided by its live coverage of the manhunt in California, CNN had a good night Tuesday covering the State of the Union address as well.

headline: Ding, Dong! The Witch Is Cute
abstract: “Beautiful Creatures” has sweet young things and supernatural shenanigans.
lead_paragraph: The otherworldly inhabitants in “Beautiful Creatures,” a pop Southern Gothic amusement about teenage love and other powerful magic, tend to look fairly average, just paler and more dandified than average folks. Everyone else would call them witches, but they prefer Casters, as in spell casters, probably because the authors of the book on which the movie is based wanted a new name for that old black and white magic. Despite their rebranding, Casters move through a familiar genre world of ghosts, enchantments and honey-dipped accents, with slithering gators, trees shrouded in Spanish moss and lives wreathed in mystery. This being a PG-13 diversion, the bodies come draped too.

headline: Their Trip to Bountiful
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Turning a barren lot into a place women couldn’t resist.
lead_paragraph: HOLYOKE, Mass. — It was the build-it-and-they-will-come principle that inspired two self-described plant geeks to buy a soulless duplex on a barren lot in this industrial city 10 years ago and turn it into their own version of the Garden of Eden. Their Eves, they figured, would show up sooner or later.

headline: Where the Bonbons Are Buried
keywords: ['Confessions', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Privacy', 'Families and Family Life', 'Books and Literature', "Valentine's Day"]
abstract: Somewhere in your home, your partner may be concealing something, whether it is an appetite for junk food or a smoldering flame.
lead_paragraph: Soon after they moved in together, a woman we’ll refer to simply as Ashley noticed that her boyfriend had amnesia when it came to remembering where household items were kept. If he needed a bandage, for example, he would ask her where to find it — repeatedly. “I’ll say, ‘It’s in the box in the bathroom, where it always is,’ ” Ashley said.

headline: No More Antlers, Please
abstract: In a Williamsburg home, going easy on the Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In a Williamsburg home, going easy on the Brooklyn.

headline: Brooklyn, but Not by Design
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Lighting', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The couple set their hearts on a “nice, clean modern look,” with limited taxidermy.
lead_paragraph: To hear Elizabeth Sayner tell it, Brooklyn isn’t just a borough. It’s a design aesthetic, like midcentury modern or Beaux-Arts.

headline: Barnes & Noble Warns of Lower Revenues
abstract: The nation’s largest brick-and-mortar book retailer is warning that it will not meet expectations for another quarter.
lead_paragraph: More bad news from Barnes & Noble Inc.

headline: Fur Slinks Along Underground Tracks
abstract: With cold weather here, fur goes from black-tie affairs to the morning subway commute.
lead_paragraph: On a recent frigid morning, when the thermometer barely reached 11 degrees in New York, the sidewalk glimmered with ice, fruit peddlers were absent and dogs shied away from the leash. Underground, however, the city was in its usual rush.

headline: Shopping for Red Accessories
abstract: Alessandra Branca explains that when adding red to a room, use it in moderation.
lead_paragraph: Alessandra Branca explains that when adding red to a room, use it in moderation.

headline: Market Ready
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Brick and Tile', 'Kitchens', 'Floors and Flooring', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: We renovated our kitchen and now the old tile floor looks outdated. Is there an inexpensive way to redo it that won’t look cheap?
lead_paragraph: Q. We renovated our kitchen and now the old tile floor looks outdated. Is there an inexpensive way to redo it that won’t look cheap?

headline: Red Accessories
abstract: Using red like a spice, in moderation, to accent rooms grounded in black and white.
lead_paragraph: FOR MOST OF US, Valentine’s Day is a good excuse for an extra splash of red, even if it’s just a bunch of roses or a heart-shaped box of chocolates. But for those who really love red, like Alessandra Branca, there’s no need for an excuse, today or any other day.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Touch Technology and Flu Googling
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include how Sergey Brin’s and Larry Page’s relationships to Google have changed over the years, New York again coming in a solid second to Silicon Valley in deal value and why Google Flu Trends may need some adjustments.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Tool Belts, Stud Finders and Sighs
abstract: Sandy Dias is the foreman of a crew of male models moonlighting as construction workers on “Built.”
lead_paragraph: Recently the Style network introduced “Built,” a reality TV series starring five male models who moonlight as construction workers. (The slogan: “A great remodel starts with the right stud.”) Teaming up with Kim Gieske, an interior designer, the Hott and Handy crew, as it’s known, tackles a renovation project each week, from a 1,000-square-foot clothes closet for a handbag hoarder named Adina to an outdoor room for a know-it-all contractor named Damon. The foreman of the group is Sandy Dias, a 34-year-old Hugo Boss model. Speaking on his hands-free car phone last week, Mr. Dias described his double life.

headline: Christine Quinn on Tapping New York’s Vein of Design
abstract: In May, a 12-day festival called NYC x Design will present the work of local designers and architects in events and settings extending over all five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: After months of vigorous planning, New York will have a 12-day celebration of design this spring extending over all five boroughs. NYC x Design will run from May 10 to 21, to coincide with the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and Frieze New York art fair on Randalls Island. Pronounced “NYC by Design” and interdisciplinary in scope, it will present the work of local designers and architects in museum exhibitions, conferences, studio tours, showroom displays, pop-up stores, art installations and a design film festival.

headline: A Birthday Gift for Formica
abstract: Formica turns 100 and is celebrated with four new designs from Pentagram.
lead_paragraph: A hundred years ago, a plastic-coated fabric was swapped for the mica commonly used in electrical insulation. Welcome, Formica. Eventually made of paper layers and used as a laminate, it went on to enjoy a long, sly life imitating wood grain and stone. It’s “a no-nonsense, absolutely reliable kind of material,” said Abbott Miller, who has designed four new Formica patterns to honor the centenary.

headline: Wheelies at the Museum
abstract: From Brooklyn Cruiser, a limited-edition red bicycle available at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: “When we were planning the spring catalog, I came across a Brooklyn Cruiser parked in SoHo,” said Emmanuel Plat, merchandising director of the retail division of the Museum of Modern Art, explaining how a bright red bicycle happened to be among the MoMA Store’s latest offerings. “We liked the idea of supporting a local company with an attractive and affordable bike that is great for commuting.”

headline: Full-Throttle Porcelain
abstract: Called Rallye 24, the 49-piece collection of jewel-colored dishes has a pattern of ellipses reminiscent of speedways.
lead_paragraph: Hermès introduced its Rallye 24 dishes last month in a Paris garage stocked with vintage sports cars. And rightly so. The 49-piece collection of jewel-colored porcelain has a pattern of ellipses reminiscent of speedways. (Closer inspection also reveals a reference to the classic 1938 Hermès anchor-chain bracelet, with its bisected oval links.)

headline: How a Meredith-Time Warner Joint Venture Would Work
abstract: What Time Warner is discussing with Meredith appears to be less a sale of its non-news publications and more the creation of a new joint venture housing substantially all of their magazines, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.
lead_paragraph: Many analysts have questioned how the Meredith Corporation could afford to buy a business as big as Time Warner‘s non-news magazine titles.

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Desiron, Aero and Others
abstract: Discounts on cookware, furniture and more.
lead_paragraph: A large selection of cookware and tools is up to 55 percent off, through Monday, at Broadway Panhandler (a Cuisinart French classic 5.5-quart sauté pan, usually $180, is about $100); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: In Tech, Does I.T. or Marketing Rule?
abstract: A new study finds that just 13 percent of companies enjoy strong, respectful relationships between information technology managers and the rest of the top brass. The strain is worst between marketing and tech, reflecting how much sales and corporate image have become digital businesses. Now, how to resolve the conflict?
lead_paragraph: Doesn’t anyone want to talk with the Chief Information Officer?

headline: Awkward Bedfellows: Politics and Films
abstract: The screenwriters of three politically tinged Oscar-nominated films discuss their work.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — As “Zero Dark Thirty,” his narrative about the hunt for Osama bin Laden attracts scrutiny, the screenwriter Mark Boal has consoled himself with brouhahas of movies past. Warren Beatty came under fire for “Bonnie and Clyde,” in which he starred, because it was considered sensationalist and was pilloried for glamorizing violence. Demonstrators protested the depiction of the Vietnam War in “The Deer Hunter,” and protesters were arrested outside the 1979 Oscars. “Apocalypse Now” was a cultural punching bag for years during its much-delayed production. All of these films were, of course, judged differently by history.

headline: New Republic Literary Editor to Split $1 Million Prize
abstract: Leon Wieseltier will share the Dan David Prize, which is given annually to honor “contributions to humanity,” with the French philosopher Michel Serres.
lead_paragraph: Leon Wieseltier, the longtime literary editor of The New Republic, is among this year’s winners of the prestigious Dan David Prize, which is given annually to honor “contributions to humanity” and carries a $1 million dollar award.

headline: Diverging Opinions on Business Conditions
abstract: Opinions on business conditions expressed by small and large businessmen have diverged in the last several years, according to surveys of the two groups — with small-business owners becoming more pessimistic.
lead_paragraph: Opinions on business conditions expressed by small and large businessmen have diverged in the last several years, according to surveys of the two groups — with small-business owners becoming more pessimistic.

abstract: Romance reigns with fishtail braids woven and twisted together in a low chignon.
lead_paragraph: Romance reigned at Philosophy di Alberta Ferretti with fishtail braids woven and twisted together in a low chignon.

headline: Remember, City Council, Forever Is a Really Long Time
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Pennsylvania Station (NYC)', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The operators of Madison Square Garden are asking for a permit in perpetuity, a plan that could seal Penn Station’s fate underground.
lead_paragraph: The owners of Madison Square Garden are now looking to New York City to renew — in perpetuity — the special permit that allows them to operate an arena atop Penn Station, the country’s busiest transit hub.

headline: Dunes and Drama on a Drive Through Oman
abstract: During a weeklong road trip, camping by the sea, getting saved from the sand and learning about camel-bender insurance.
lead_paragraph: Just out of reach of the Arabian Sea’s hammering surf, we built a campfire on a deserted beach below the Queen of Sheba’s ruined palace. Then, exhausted after a day of driving, we unrolled our sleeping bags, and talked until late beneath an ocean of stars.

headline: How to See India by Train
abstract: Monisha Rajesh, author of “Around India in 80 Trains,” on how to plan a trip and some of her favorite routes.
lead_paragraph: India’s 65,000 kilometers of train tracks embroider the subcontinent, connecting thousands of cities. In 2010, Monisha Rajesh, a London-based journalist, set out to discover the railways, detailing her adventures in her new book, “Around India in 80 Trains.”

headline: Reed Krakoff: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: He Sings. She Acts. They Date.
abstract: Each generation seems to have at least one music-acting power couple of note.
lead_paragraph: When he picked up the Grammy for best new artist on Sunday night, along with his band mates from Fun., Jack Antonoff joined a rarefied subsection of the dating world: rock stars who are almost as famous as their actress girlfriends. Each generation seems to have at least one music-acting power couple of note and Mr. Antonoff and his current girlfriend, Lena Dunham of “Girls,” appear to have taken that spot for the millennials. (Though perhaps not without some competition from Marcus Mumford of Mumford & Sons, and his wife, the actress Carey Mulligan, and, to a lesser degree,Kate Hudson and Matt Bellamy, the Muse frontman.) Here’s a look at the Antonoff-Dunham union and two other high-profile couples who predated them:Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin of Coldplay, and the little-remembered Faye Dunaway and Peter Wolf, of the J. Geils Band.

headline: Ira Rubin at the 1968 Vanderbilt Knockout Teams
abstract: Ira Rubin died last week at 82 and was inducted into the American Contract Bridge League’s Hall of Fame in 2000.
lead_paragraph: While looking for a deal featuring Ira Rubin, who died last week at 82 and was inducted into the American Contract Bridge League’s Hall of Fame in 2000, I found the following from the final of the 1968 Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in New York City.

lead_paragraph: It is the most humble of vessels for New York City foodstuffs, ubiquitous at Chinese takeout joints and halal street carts. In pre-Starbucks days, coffee came packaged in its puffy embrace.

headline: Obama’s Path from Rhetoric to Reality on Energy and Climate
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Natural Gas', 'Speeches and Statements', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Exploring how President Obama can move from rhetoric to real-world action on energy and climate.
lead_paragraph: On energy and human-driven global warming, President Obama’s State of the Union address (and the background sheet providing detail behind the talking points) had something for everyone, making it hard — outside of a couple of specific proposals — to figure out how much action might follow the smoothly delivered rhetoric.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 7
abstract: Scenes from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: North Carolina Approves Steep Benefit Cuts for Jobless in Bid to Reduce Debt
abstract: In a debt-reducing effort, the Republican-controlled legislature voted to cut maximum weekly benefits to $350 from $535, a 35 percent drop.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina lawmakers approved deep cuts to benefits for the jobless on Wednesday, in a state that has one of the nation’s highest unemployment rates.

headline: Model Apartments: Runway to Real Estate
keywords: ['Models (Professional)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: Trish Goff, a supermodel in the ’90s, is now a real estate broker who attracts a hip and upscale clientele, mostly culled from her connections in fashion.
lead_paragraph: Trish Goff, a supermodel in the ’90s, is now a real estate broker who attracts a hip and upscale clientele, mostly culled from her connections in fashion.

headline: Model Apartments: Runway to Real Estate
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Models (Professional)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Trish Goff, a supermodel in the ’90s, is now a real estate broker who attracts a hip and upscale clientele, mostly culled from her connections in fashion.
lead_paragraph: With her wide-eyed all-American looks, Trish Goff was atypical among the second wave of supermodels of the 1990s. Exotic, heroin chic, angular, grunge — these did not describe Ms. Goff. But her extracurricular activities really set her apart from the pack.

headline: Small Businesses Still Struggle, and That’s Impeding a Recovery
abstract: Loans are still tight, consumers are timid, and the action — or lack of it — in Washington has heightened pessimism among small-business owners.
lead_paragraph: In the recovery so far, small businesses have largely been left behind. Initially, loans were hard to come by and consumers weren’t shopping. Now, small-business owners say, Washington is throwing up additional roadblocks.

headline: Why Are Small Businesses Less Optimistic Than Big Ones?
abstract: For one thing, big businesses have a larger global footprint, which gives them greater exposure to growth in places like China and Brazil.
lead_paragraph: In an article just published by The Times, Catherine Rampell notes that when it comes to optimism about the economy, there is a big gulf between small and large companies. Ms. Rampell reports that while measures of optimism for big companies now exceed prerecession levels, a recent survey from the National Federation of Independent Business found that expectations for business conditions six months from now were at their fourth-lowest level in nearly 40 years.

headline: Steve Madden Is Back
abstract: It’s been a decade since Mr. Madden was famously sentenced to 41 months in prison for stock fraud. He is now creative and design chief of the shoe empire he founded in 1990.
lead_paragraph: One crisp morning last month, the shoe titan Steve Madden was ruminating over two sandals laid out on his desk in his factory in Long Island City, Queens: one black with a thin sole; the other creamy beige, its heel thick as sliced bread.

headline: A New Medal Honors Drone Pilots and Computer Experts
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: The announcement by the departing defense secretary, Leon E. Panetta, of the Distinguished Warfare Medal recognized the changing nature of warfare.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If drone pilots and computer experts had any doubts that they truly are central to the new way of combat, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta used his valedictory Pentagon news conference on Wednesday to make it clear: he established a new medal just for them.

headline: Live Photo Streaming Now: Proenza Schouler
abstract: We are now live streaming the Fall 2013 collection from Proenza Schouler at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Check in daily to see in-the-moment backstage, on and off the runway photos from select New York Fashion Week shows.

headline: Protesters in Dresden Block Neo-Nazi March on Anniversary of Deadly Allied Firebombing
abstract: Thousands of anti-fascist protesters blocked a neo-Nazi march in the German city on the 68th anniversary of the British and American air campaign that killed 25,000 people in 37 hours.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of anti-fascist protesters blocked a neo-Nazi march in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday night, on the 68th anniversary of the British and American air campaign that killed an estimated 25,000 people in 37 hours of bombing.

headline: Comptroller Criticizes Budget Plan of Governor
abstract: Thomas P. DiNapoli said Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposal depended on federal aid that might not materialize and counted on wage and job growth bringing big increases in tax revenues.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, questioned parts of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s budget proposal on Wednesday, asserting that the spending plan relied on optimistic economic projections and would burden the state with even greater debt.

headline: Out of Sight, but Making His Presence Known
abstract: A fashion review of the Rodarte, Narciso Rodriguez, Michael Kors, Oscar de la Renta and Vera Wang collections.
lead_paragraph: Necks craned at Oscar de la Renta’s show to see if two men would take their bow. If you haven’t heard, John Galliano spent the last month working in the de la Renta studio, a first move to possibly salvaging his wrecked career.

headline: A Course That Woods Has Yet to Master
abstract: Tiger Woods made his first PGA Tour appearance as a teenager at Riviera Country Club, but he has not played a competitive round at Riviera since 2006. The course is one he now conspicuously avoids.
lead_paragraph: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif.

headline: Cardinal Dolan Calls Pope’s Resignation a Sign of Humility
abstract: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, who celebrated Mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral on Ash Wednesday, told worshipers that Benedict XVI was “aware of his own limitations, as we all have to be.”
lead_paragraph: On a day when Roman Catholics around the world had ashes pressed to their foreheads as a mark of humility and penance, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, said the resignation of Pope Benedict XVI was a living example of the day’s message.

headline: Obama Resubmits Appointees for Labor Board
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The president asked the Senate to confirm Sharon Block and Richard Griffin to the N.L.R.B. after their nominations were rejected by an appeals court.
lead_paragraph: Despite opposition from nearly all Senate Republicans, President Obama asked the Senate on Wednesday to confirm two Democrats whose recess appointments to the National Labor Relations Board were ruled unconstitutional by a federal appeals court last month.

headline: In High-Tech Japan, the Fax Machines Roll On
abstract: The reluctance to give up fax machines offers a revealing glimpse into an aging nation that can often seem quietly determined to stick to its tried-and-true ways.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan is renowned for its robots and bullet trains, and has some of the world’s fastest broadband networks. But it also remains firmly wedded to a pre-Internet technology — the fax machine — that in most other developed nations has joined answering machines, eight-tracks and cassette tapes in the dustbin of outmoded technologies.

headline: Inspector in 2008 Crane Collapse Gets Probation
abstract: A judge said Edward J. Marquette’s case fell into a difficult category for sentencing, one in which people who have led good lives do something very wrong.
lead_paragraph: He was arrested amid great fanfare nearly five years ago, a city employee accused of fabricating an inspection report of a towering crane, which later collapsed and killed seven people.

headline: SAC Capital Manager Awaits Word on Charges
abstract: Federal authorities are deciding whether to charge Michael Steinberg, a longtime portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, in an investigation of insider trading at the firm.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are nearing a decision whether to bring criminal charges against Michael Steinberg, a longtime portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, the giant hedge fund owned by the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen.

abstract: A new commercial features a Rube Goldberg machine that imitates the daily routine at a Panera.
lead_paragraph: A new commercial features a Rube Goldberg machine that imitates the daily routine at a Panera.

headline: Obama Bid for Europe Trade Pact Stirs Hope on Both Sides
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Tough economic times and a perceived need to unify Europe’s frayed union — and the growing economic might of China — could help a free-trade agreement succeed now, experts said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — President Obama’s call for a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union has unleashed a wave of optimism on both sides that a breakthrough can be achieved that would lift trans-Atlantic fortunes, not just economically but politically.

headline: To Survive I.O.C. Cut, Pentathlon Changed
abstract: The International Olympic Committee eliminated wrestling from the Summer Games but preserved the modern pentathlon, a century-old competition.
lead_paragraph: This week, unfamiliar horses prevailed over familiar wrestlers.

abstract: The Republican Party should go back to its beginnings as the party of freedom.

headline: Preventing a Currency War
abstract: The way to revive stagnant economies is with stimulus, not by manipulating exchange rates.
lead_paragraph: The Group of 7 industrialized countries appeared to tamp down talk of a currency war in a statement this week that said markets should determine exchange rates and that countries should use fiscal and monetary policies to achieve faster growth. It may help curb fears that stagnant economies will devalue their currencies to make their exports more affordable relative to competitors.

headline: The Real Obama
abstract: This is how politicians who needn’t worry about re-election look: more like themselves.
lead_paragraph: Is this the real Barack Obama? I hope so. I like this one.

headline: Selling Products by Selling Shared Values
abstract: Panera is among the companies that are using purpose marketing to persuade potential customers that they operate in a socially responsible manner.
lead_paragraph: THE purpose of marketing is to sell products, but there is also a new way, known as purpose, or purpose-based, marketing, to do it.

headline: A Court for Targeted Killings
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: If national security policy is going to adhere to the rule of law, the White House cannot be both the judge and executioner of terror suspects.
lead_paragraph: No American prosecutor can imprison or execute someone except on the orders of a judge or jury. That fundamental principle applies no less to the suspected terrorists that the executive branch chooses to kill overseas, particularly in the case of American citizens.

headline: A Workout Booster, and a Lawsuit
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Exercise', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection']

lead_paragraph: For the last few weeks, GNC, the dietary supplements retailer, has run a special on its Web site for a workout booster called Jack3d. “Hot Buy, Hot Buy, Hot Buy,” reads a red banner splashed across the product’s page.

headline: A Tentative Step by a Fallen Star to Come Back
abstract: The presence of John Galliano, disgraced after an anti-Semitic tirade in Paris, was felt in Oscar de la Renta’s fall 2013 fashion show in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The disgraced fashion designer John Galliano was nowhere to be seen at Oscar de la Renta’s fashion show on Tuesday night, though the luminaries in attendance, including Anna Wintour, Valentino and Diane von Furstenberg, were certainly aware of his presence, as were the paparazzi lined up three deep on the sidewalk 25 floors below on West 42nd Street.

headline: A Heartbroken Temp at Brides.com
abstract: My nuptials were off, but at work, weddings were everywhere.
lead_paragraph: DRIVING across the George Washington Bridge in the spring of 2006, with everything I owned in the trunk and Manhattan shining in the distance, I might have been the most clichéd girl in America. I tried not to dwell on the fact that I had no money, no apartment, no job.

headline: Seeking Growth, Nurses’ Union Links to Teachers’ Union
abstract: The National Federation of Nurses expects to gain more political clout and money by affiliating with the American Federation of Teachers.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s largest nurses’ unions — the National Federation of Nurses — plans to announce on Thursday that it will affiliate with the far larger American Federation of Teachers.

headline: Reducing Health Care Costs
abstract: The president of the American Hospital Association suggests the best ways to do so.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The President’s Second-Term Agenda
abstract: Readers comment on the State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 100th Self-Immolation Reported Inside Tibet
keywords: ['Immolation', 'Buddhism', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: A former monk killed himself to protest Chinese rule, advocacy groups said on a day when another Tibetan, this one in exile, set himself on fire in Nepal.
lead_paragraph: A former Tibetan Buddhist monk protested Chinese rule by killing himself through self-immolation this month, becoming the 100th person to do so inside Chinese-governed Tibet, according to reports on Wednesday by Tibet advocacy groups.

headline: Final Plea for Mercy
abstract: The Supreme Court should stay the execution of Warren Lee Hill Jr. because Georgia’s burden of proof for retardation is too high.
lead_paragraph: Warren Lee Hill Jr., with an I.Q. of 70, is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday in Georgia. The Supreme Court should stay the execution, as his lawyers have requested, and recognize that Georgia makes it too hard for an offender to prove retardation.

headline: Another Step Toward Fairness
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The limited expansion of benefits will improve the treatment of gay and lesbian military personnel and their families.
lead_paragraph: Leon Panetta, the departing secretary of defense, took an important step on Monday to improve treatment of gay and lesbian military personnel and their families.

headline: Ponikarovsky Returns to Devils
abstract: The Devils reacquired the 6-foot-4 forward Alexei Ponikarovsky, who helped them reach the Stanley Cup finals last season before he signed with the Winnipeg Jets.
lead_paragraph: The Devils reacquired the 6-foot-4 forward Alexei Ponikarovsky, a key member of the team that reached the Stanley Cup finals last season, General Manager Lou Lamoriello said Wednesday night.

headline: Soccer Fixing Inquiry Hinges on a Shadowy Singaporean
abstract: European authorities are homing in on Tan Seet Eng, called “the boss,” as they examine a scandal that could involve hundreds of soccer games.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Near the beginning of an Italian soccer match in Tuscany on May 23, 2010, a man from Singapore named Tan Seet Eng spoke on the phone with a Croatian associate. He told the associate he needed at least three goals to be scored in the match between Grosseto and Reggina.

headline: In India, Kisses Are on Rise, Even in Public
abstract: Indian couples have not always embraced kissing in front of others. Recent studies, backed by interviews with sociologists and psychiatrists, suggest that is changing.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India may be the birthplace of the Kama Sutra, the ancient how-to manual on kissing and sex. But for many years, Indian couples did not widely embrace kissing, at least not in public. Now that is changing.

headline: Quinn’s Affordable Housing Plan Revisits Tax Caps Once Rejected by Bloomberg
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'State of the City Message (NYC)', 'Property Taxes', 'Income Tax']
abstract: City Council speaker Christine C. Quinn’s proposal would impose a 30-year cap on real estate taxes for landlords who set aside 20 percent of their apartments for below-market rents.
lead_paragraph: A centerpiece of Christine C. Quinn’s plan to keep housing affordable in New York City is a variation on a proposed tax subsidy for landlords that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg forcefully rejected two years ago as an unacceptably generous giveaway to the real estate industry.

headline: On Second Thoughts
abstract: President Obama and Karl Rove have both paid a political price for strategic errors that they are now striving to overcome.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is pushing hard to persuade Congress to back off from the brutal spending cuts — $1.2 trillion — mandated by the sequestration provisions of the Budget Control Act, which he signed into law on Aug. 2, 2011.In a simultaneous but unrelated development, Karl Rove is pressing top Republican donors to back his Conservative Victory Project, an organization designed to snuff out the candidacies of right-wing extremists in Republican primaries who, in 2010 and 2012, prevented the party from winning a Senate majority.

headline: Scorecard for Colleges Needs Work, Experts Say
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Tuition']
abstract: As President Obama promised, the White House unveiled a College Scorecard Web site on Wednesday, but experts said it had many holes that needed to be filled.
lead_paragraph: The steps that President Obama promised in his State of the Union address to control college costs and give consumers more information on the prices and values of individual colleges drew tepid responses on Wednesday from educational groups, who said the measures seemed generally positive but had many blanks to be filled in.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Feb. 14, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, Feb. 14, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “If you use a gun, you usually don’t get a second chance.”

headline: State-Financed Preschool Access in the U.S.
abstract: In his State of the Union address, President Obama called for preschool education access for every child in America. Nationally, 28 percent of 4 year-olds are enrolled in state-financed preschools, but not all states offer programs.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address, President Obama called for preschool education access for every child in America. Nationally, 28 percent of 4 year-olds are enrolled in state-financed preschools, but not all states offer programs.

headline: Anger That a Herod Show Uses West Bank Objects
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians', 'Museums', 'Israeli Settlements', 'ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Palestinian Authority says the exhibition is a violation of international law because much of its material was taken from the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In one room sits a sarcophagus of reddish-pink limestone believed to have held the body of King Herod, painstakingly reconstructed after having been smashed to bits centuries ago. In another, there are frescoes from Herod’s elaborate underground palace, pieced together like a jigsaw puzzle. Throughout, elaborate animated videos show the king’s audacious construction — atop the desert fortress Masada; at his burial place, Herodium; and his most famous work, the Second Temple of Jerusalem.

headline: New Jersey Assembly Panel Backs Tougher Gun Laws
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Opponents dismissed the nearly two dozen bills as “feel-good legislation” that would accomplish little, and Gov. Chris Christie could veto any that pass.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Legislature took up a collection of nearly two dozen bills on Wednesday that would tighten gun controls, prompting angry protests from hundreds of gun rights advocates who crowded the State House.

headline: Detroit Mayor Says City Is Making Progress on Debt
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Local Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Dave Bing says that despite his city’s financial troubles, “the picture is not all doom and gloom.”
lead_paragraph: With a crucial review of Detroit’s financial circumstances expected within days and the possibility of a state-appointed financial manager looming, Mayor Dave Bing on Wednesday evening made the case for his city, arguing that Detroit’s finances are getting better, bit by bit.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: For Dickey and the Blue Jays, the Moment Is Now
abstract: The Blue Jays, who were 73-89 last season, went on a shopping spree they hope will carry them to the postseason for the first time in 20 years.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla.

headline: Some ‘Affordable’ Units Too Costly, Report Says
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: About two-thirds of the city’s recently developed units were found to require occupants to have minimum income levels that were higher than median incomes in the areas.
lead_paragraph: In a city that measures wealth in square feet, even apartments marketed as “affordable housing” can still be too expensive for many New Yorkers.

headline: Corrections: February 14, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 14, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Welcoming Symbol
abstract: Welcoming back Jules P. Markey.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Alert! Will Shortz has written the intro to a wonderful new project, American Red Crosswords. Some of my puzzle buddies have donated their incredible talents to this wonderful cause, which will donate all funds earned to survivors of Hurricane Sandy. Hat tip to Michael Sharp/Rex Parker for captaining the project. Click here to find out more.

headline: Prosecutor Who Assaulted Ambulance Worker Avoids Jail Sentence
abstract: A Brooklyn assistant district attorney pleaded guilty to assault and was sentenced to 10 days’ community service.
lead_paragraph: Before a courtroom filled with dozens of emergency medical workers, a prosecutor in the Brooklyn district attorney’s office was sentenced to 10 days of community service on Wednesday after pleading guilty to assaulting an ambulance worker as the prosecutor was being taken to a hospital.

headline: Booker Assails an Attack and Those Who Kept Silent
abstract: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark denounced those who witnessed the whipping of a man in August, or saw a video of it, and did nothing.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Beating his fist on a lectern Wednesday, Mayor Cory A. Booker railed not only at three men charged with forcing another man to strip naked before savagely whipping him and capturing it on video, but especially at those who knew about the attack and did not tell the police.

headline: Hitching a Name to a Star, Then Watching It Set
abstract: The German town where Pope Benedict XVI was born never prospered as much as it hoped from its famous son, and it seems likely to get even fewer visitors after he steps down.
lead_paragraph: MARKTL AM INN, Germany — If we rebuild it, they will come, thought the residents of Marktl am Inn, Pope Benedict XVI’s hometown, and for a while they did. But visitors to the museum in the house where he was born, brightly repainted in the white and yellow colors of the Vatican, had begun to taper off well before his abrupt resignation this week.

headline: Senate Democrats, Accusing G.O.P. of Obstruction, Try to Force Hagel Vote
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: After a close committee vote on Chuck Hagel’s nomination to be defense secretary, Republicans demanded more information before a decision.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Accusing Republicans of a new level of obstruction, Senate Democrats moved on Wednesday to force a vote on President Obama’s nomination of Chuck Hagel to be secretary of defense.

headline: Sexual Harassment Case Against Lopez Sent to Legislature
abstract: State regulators who found ethics violations in the sexual harassment case against New York Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez have forwarded the matter to two ethics panels.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — State regulators referred ethics violations in the sexual harassment scandal surrounding Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez to the Legislature on Wednesday, but did not specify what charges had been made in the case.
