headline: Excerpt: ‘Zero Hour’
abstract: Anthony Edwards stars in a new ABC suspense series.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Edwards stars in a new ABC suspense series.

headline: Russian Parliament Ethics Chief Steps Aside Over Reports of Undisclosed Properties
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Luxury Goods', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The chairman, Vladimir A. Pekhtin, is the owner of expensive real estate, including an oceanfront apartment in Florida and property in Russia that was not listed on disclosure forms.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The chairman of the ethics committee in Russia’s lower house of Parliament temporarily relinquished his authority on Wednesday after bloggers posted a raft of documents on the Internet showing him as the owner of expensive real estate, including a luxury oceanfront apartment in South Beach, part of Miami Beach, as well as valuable property in Russia that he did not list on required disclosure forms.

headline: Iranian Reported Killed Near Syrian Border
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The Iranian official, Hossam Khosh Newes, was reported killed while driving from Syria to Lebanon, in reports that drew attention to suspicions of Iran’s role in the Syrian civil war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least one senior Iranian official was reported killed in an attack while driving from Syria to Lebanon on Wednesday, in separate and at times conflicting reports that drew attention to suspicions of Iran’s role in the Syrian civil war.

headline: The State of the 4-Year-Olds
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: When it comes to preschool, everything old is new again. And again.
lead_paragraph: One of the big moments of the State of the Union address was President Obama’s call for “high-quality preschool” for 4-year-olds.

headline: Nets as Baffling as Ever, but This Time They Win
abstract: There is no simple explanation for a Nets season in which the team has looked dominant and listless. On Wednesday, the Nets appeared unstoppable as they routed the Nuggets.
lead_paragraph: P. J. Carlesimo is a coach of many words, with a knack for weaving expansive answers out of mundane questions, and even longer soliloquies when the subject is complex. Assessing the Nets’ prospects at the All-Star break took a lot of words, even by Carlesimo’s standards, perhaps understandably.

headline: Falling Far Short of the Whole Truth
abstract: The British law firm that hired Soma Sengupta discovered that she had lied about her age — and from there found that many things were not as she had claimed.
lead_paragraph: In a stately, old London courtroom, Soma Sengupta was finally living her dream.

headline: Proenza Schouler: A Sense of Softness
abstract: Even at close range, the clothes in this clever Proenza Schouler show could deceive you — and then seduce you.
lead_paragraph: Even in the backstage confines of the Proenza Schouler show, as models were getting dressed, the clothes didn’t look exactly soft and touchable. After all, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez had made dresses embroidered in vertical lines of chain. And some of their new ostrich skirts and coats looked pretty rigid.

headline: A Painful Decision for Pettitte
abstract: Andy Pettitte said Yankees Manager Joe Girardi and General Manager Brian Cashman discouraged him from taking part in the World Baseball Classic, and he reluctantly went along with them.
lead_paragraph: At 40, Andy Pettitte has done virtually everything he set out to do as a major league pitcher, compiling 245 career victories, winning 20 games twice and earning five World Series rings. But one thing remained for him: representing the United States in international competition.

headline: Yankees Add a Reliever
abstract: The Yankees bolstered their middle relief by acquiring the right-hander Shawn Kelley from Seattle for the minor league outfielder Abraham Almonte.
lead_paragraph: Late Wednesday, the Yankees bolstered their middle relief by acquiring the right-hander Shawn Kelley from Seattle for the minor league outfielder Abraham Almonte.

headline: General Urged to Take Time to Decide on NATO Post
abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta told Gen. John R. Allen that he should not rush into a decision because he had been under  “tremendous” pressure in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta disclosed Wednesday that he met this week with Gen. John R. Allen, the outgoing commander in Afghanistan, and urged him to take time off with his family before deciding whether to accept or decline the president’s nomination to be the senior NATO commander.

headline: Jake McNiece, Who Led Incorrigible D-Day Unit, Is Dead at 93
abstract: The Filthy 13 were famed during World War II as model soldiers, except for maybe the obeying orders part.
lead_paragraph: D-Day started early for Sgt. Jake McNiece and his fellow paratroopers. Not long after midnight on June 6, 1944, they parachuted behind German lines just ahead of the invasion of Normandy. Their goal was to destroy Nazi supply lines and escape routes. Some called it a suicide mission. The paratroopers called themselves the Filthy 13.

headline: Nets’ Taylor Is Eager to Prove He’s No One-Game Fluke
abstract: With Deron Williams out of the Nets’ lineup Monday against the Indiana Pacers, Tyshawn Taylor stepped in and provided a sudden, unexpected glimpse at his N.B.A. potential.
lead_paragraph: The first big break of Tyshawn Taylor’s career, one might say, arrived at a playground in Clearwater, Fla., when Taylor was 8, shooting hoops alone outside his housing complex.

headline: A New Orleans-Washington Handshake Turns to Fists
abstract: Months after reaching an agreement with the Justice Department to transform its troubled police department, New Orleans wants out of the deal, saying it’s too expensive.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Two days after his inauguration in May 2010, Mayor Mitch Landrieu sent a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. that began: “I am writing today to ask for your support and partnership in transforming the New Orleans Police Department into one of the best police forces in the United States.”

headline: Alan Sharp, Writer of Dark Screenplays, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Sharp wrote scripts for films starring Gene Hackman, Liam Neeson and other Hollywood notables.
lead_paragraph: Alan Sharp, a screenwriter whose brand of dark, lyrical and densely plotted work, including the screenplay for Arthur Penn’s “Night Moves,” made him a critically admired if largely unknown figure in Hollywood, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

headline: Four Years Later, Slain Abortion Doctor’s Aide Steps Into the Void
abstract: An activist who was Dr. George R. Tiller’s spokeswoman plans to reopen his Kansas clinic, which has been abandoned since Dr. Tiller was shot in 2009.
lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — For nearly four years the site has been abandoned, a low-slung, windowless, beige building just off a highway on the east side of town. But the overpowering smell of fresh paint inside hints of activity soon to come.

headline: Guns and Suicide
abstract: Researchers have noted that states with higher rates of gun ownership tend to have higher rates of suicide than states with less gun ownership.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have noted that states with higher rates of gun ownership tend to have higher rates of suicide than states with less gun ownership.

headline: Key Talks Set Over N.H.L. Participation in Olympics
abstract: At issue is whether the N.H.L. will take a break of 16 days or more to allow its players to travel to Russia for the Olympic men’s ice hockey tournament, which will begin in 51 weeks.
lead_paragraph: The debate over whether N.H.L. players will participate in the 2014 Sochi Olympics will enter a critical stage with a series of meetings between league and Olympic officials in New York on Thursday and Friday.

headline: To Reduce Suicide Rates, New Focus Turns to Guns
abstract: Despite the attention on mass shootings and assault weapons, far more Americans die by turning firearms on themselves.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Wyo. — Craig Reichert found his son’s body on a winter morning, lying on the floor as if he were napping with his great-uncle’s pistol under his knee. The 911 dispatcher told him to administer CPR, but Mr. Reichert, who has had emergency training, told her it was too late. His son, Kameron, 17, was already cold to the touch.

headline: Quinnipiac Hits No. 1 With Lots of Whiskers and Up-Tempo Game
abstract: The Bobcats, who have not lost in 21 straight games, are the top-ranked team in men’s college hockey. Players credit their ascent to Muzzy Power, referring to their mustaches.
lead_paragraph: In early November, the Quinnipiac men’s hockey team was 3-3-1, disjointed and selfish. Then it began to believe in a full-sprint offense, in killing penalties and blocking shots. Many players summoned what they called Muzzy Power, and the team’s goalie harnessed his “positive energy cells” to help heighten his focus.

headline: Knicks Start Slow and Finish Even Worse
abstract: In the last game before the All-Star break, the Knicks lost to Toronto with too many missed layups, 3-pointers and free throws in the final three minutes. The sellout crowd grew increasingly annoyed, groaning and booing every mistake.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony did not make excuses. That would not be the right way to assess the Knicks’ deflating 92-88 loss to the Toronto Raptors on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Use of Morning-After Pill Is Rising, Report Says
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Plan B (Contraceptive)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The finding is likely to add to the debate over rules that require most employers to provide free coverage of birth control to female employees.
lead_paragraph: The use of morning-after pills by American women has more than doubled in recent years, driven largely by rising rates of use among women in their early 20s, according to new federal data released Thursday.

headline: Word of the Day | exceptionable
abstract: This word has appeared in one New York Times article in the past year.
lead_paragraph: exceptionable •\ik-ˈsep-sh(ə-)nə-bəl\• adjective

headline: Sports Illustrated’s New Swimsuit Issue Rouses Ire Over ‘Ethnic Props’
keywords: ['Bathing Suits', 'Discrimination', 'Magazines', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Sports Illustrated’s swimwear issue has long drawn rebukes from some for objectifying and sexualizing women. But is this year’s, photographed around the world, also using non-Westerners as “ethnic props”?
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Sports Illustrated magazine’s swimsuit issue has drawn criticism from feminists and other women, and some men, for unnecessarily sexualizing women and exhibiting bad taste. Or good taste, depending on your point of view.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:30 A.M. (Encore) GREMLINS 2: THE NEW BATCH (1990) The Gremlins take Manhattan in this sequel to the 1984 original. Billy and Kate (Zach Galligan and Phoebe Cates, above) are now working at the Clamp Center, a Midtown skyscraper that becomes overrun by the titular critters. In The New York Times, Janet Maslin wrote that the film, directed by Joe Dante, “speaks to the gleeful hell-raising monster in each of us, and it speaks with much more verve, cleverness and good humor than the film on which it is based.” She added that Christopher Lee, in his role as a scientist, is an “irresistibly ghoulish presence, and the precise nature of his medical experiments — cows listening to self-help tapes, rats using their energy to run light bulbs — give the film an added measure of fun.”

headline: A Volatile Brahmaputra River Will Grow Only More So
abstract: The impact of climate change on the river and its tributaries will be dramatic, scientists predict.
lead_paragraph: ELOPA, Arunachal Pradesh — Amid a desert of volleyball-sized boulders, Jibi Pulu bounces his Tata jeep over a trickling nullah. In his childhood, just 30-odd years ago, this stream used to irrigate his family paddy fields right here in the flatlands and provide fresh water to his ancestral village in the hills above the floodplain of the Dibang River, a major tributary of the Brahmaputra.

headline: News Quiz | February 14, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 13
abstract: A view of the day in sports, from snowboarding to spring training.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, from snowboarding to spring training.

headline: 100th Self-Immolation Reported Inside Tibet
abstract: A former monk killed himself to protest Chinese rule, advocacy groups said on a day when another Tibetan, this one in exile, died after setting himself on fire in Nepal.
lead_paragraph: A former Tibetan Buddhist monk protested Chinese rule by killing himself through self-immolation this month, becoming the 100th person to do so inside Chinese-governed Tibet, according to reports on Wednesday by Tibet advocacy groups.

headline: BNP Paribas Earnings Fall on Write-Downs
abstract: France’s largest bank, BNP Paribas, reported a 33 percent decline in fourth-quarter profit, to $688 million, as it wrote down the value of its Italian unit and booked an accounting charge on its own debt.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – BNP Paribas, France’s largest bank, posted a fourth-quarter profit far below estimates on Thursday as it wrote down the value of its Italian unit and booked an accounting charge on its own debt.

headline: A Nation Reels as a Star Runner Is Charged in Girlfriend’s Death
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Paralympic Games', 'Track and Field']
abstract: The paralympic champion Oscar Pistorius was charged with murder after his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, was fatally shot in his home in Pretoria, according to South African police officials.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — She was a platinum-haired model on the cusp of the big time, about to make her debut on a reality television show. He was a global sports hero who, despite having had both legs amputated at the knee as an infant, ran so fast that in a 2011 Nike advertisement he declared, “I am the bullet in the chamber.” Reeva Steenkamp, the model, and Oscar Pistorius, the Paralympic champion and Olympic competitor, were glamorous young fixtures on the South African celebrity scene.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 14
abstract: Optimism about a trans-Atlantic free trade agreement; Tunisians question their country’s progress since the Arab Spring; Japan still loves the fax machine; Galliano touches in an Oscar de la Renta collection; a Singaporean suspect in the soccer match-fixing investigation.
lead_paragraph: NEWS President Obama’s call for a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union has unleashed a wave of optimism on both sides that a breakthrough can be achieved that would lift trans-Atlantic fortunes, not just economically but politically. Nicholas Kulish reports from Berlin, and Jackie Calmes from Washington.

headline: Economy in Europe Contracts More Than Expected
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The 0.6 percent decline in G.D.P. during the fourth quarter means the euro zone has effectively been in recession since 2011.
lead_paragraph: European economies shrank in the fourth quarter at their fastest rate since the depth of the financial crisis in 2009, new data showed on Thursday, with both strong and weak countries falling short of expectations and raising anxieties of a longer, deeper recession.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 14, 2013
abstract: Can you identify the part of speech of “indefinitely,” as it is used in the article?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Jessica Lahey. It comes from the article “Regulators Around the Globe Ground Boeing 787s.”

headline: Barbarians at the Gate
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Germany’s harsh asylum law reveals its lingering discomfort with “ausländer,” or foreigners.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — There’s a refugee camp in the center of the German capital filled with people who have fled conflicts around the world. They sleep in tents and eat donated food. Almost all of them are breaking German law just by being here.

headline: Nuclear Watchdog Says No Deal Reached With Iran
abstract: An International Atomic Energy Agency official said that inspectors had not been given access to a site that they suspect may have been used to test bomb triggers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A senior official of the United Nations nuclear supervisory body said Thursday that talks a day earlier in Iran had ended inconclusively and that international inspectors had not been given access to a site that they suspect may have been used for testing bomb triggers.

headline: Banana Joe, Best in Show
abstract: Who is Banana Joe?
lead_paragraph: In “No Ordinary Affenpinscher, Banana Joe Is Named Best in Show,” Richard Sandomir writes about the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: Knowing That Fly on the Wall
abstract: Turning Point: Brad Vest discusses his inspiration, Jim Goldberg of Magnum Photos, whose book, “Raised by Wolves,” showed Mr. Vest that photography is about immersion.
lead_paragraph: Brad Vest is a freelance photojournalist based in Concord, N.H. He has spent the last several years working on “Adrift,” a project for his master’s thesis at Ohio University. The series documents the life of Travis, a father who is trying to put his life back together after being incarcerated. Mr. Vest, 27, was a photo intern at The New York Times last summer and at National Geographic last fall. In 2012 he won the prestigious Cliff Edom Award in NPPA’s Best of Photojournalism contest.

headline: The Convergence of George Will and Sherrod Brown
abstract: A growing chorus of voices from across the political spectrum is criticizing the size, impact and policies of the largest banks, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Can the Republicans Be Saved From Obsolescence?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: To drag the G.O.P. into the 21st century, young, tech-savvy dissidents may have to overthrow their party’s disconnected old guard.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon last month, I paid a visit to two young Republicans named Bret Jacobson and Ian Spencer, who work in a small office in Arlington, Va., situated above an antique store and adjacent to a Japanese auto shop. Their five-man company, Red Edge, is a digital-advocacy group for conservative causes, and their days are typically spent designing software applications for groups like the Heritage Foundation, the Republican Governors Association and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Lately, however, Jacobson and Spencer have taken up evangelizing — and the sermon, delivered day after day to fellow conservatives in the form of a 61-point presentation, is a pitiless we-told-you-so elucidation of the ways in which Democrats have overwhelmed Republicans with their technological superiority.

headline: Read Any Good Books Lately?
abstract: Do you read for pleasure? What are some of your favorite books? Do you have a community of fellow readers with whom you share recommendations?
lead_paragraph: Do you read for pleasure? What are some of your favorite books? Do you have a community of fellow readers with whom you share recommendations?

headline: South Korea Shows Military Muscle in Sparring With North
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Tests', 'International Relations']
abstract: South Korea on Thursday staged large military drills and disclosed a new cruise missile capable of hitting any target in North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea staged large military drills and disclosed a new cruise missile capable of hitting any target in North Korea, just days after the North said it detonated its third nuclear device and as Pyongyang became increasingly candid about its intentions to build intercontinental ballistic missiles tipped with nuclear warheads.

headline: Asahi Sues 2 Private Equity Firms Over $1.3 Billion Deal
abstract: The Asahi Group has accused two private equity firms of falsifying financial data when they sold New Zealand’s Independent Liquor to Asahi in 2011.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – The Japanese beer and beverage maker Asahi Group filed a lawsuit on Thursday in Australia against two buyout firms over its purchase of a liquor company for 1.53 billion New Zealand dollars two years ago.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Revises $20.1 Billion Takeover Plan
abstract: Anheuser-Busch InBev has revised its $20.1 billion deal for Grupo Modelo, the Mexican maker of Corona beer, as it seeks to persuade American antitrust authorities to let the deal proceed.
lead_paragraph: 7:20 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Early Word: On the Road
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:

headline: What She Wore
abstract: With an all-access pass to Elizabeth Taylor’s closet, the photographer Catherine Opie created an exclusive window into the actress’s world.
lead_paragraph: In November 2010 the fine art photographer Catherine Opie gained entree into Elizabeth Taylor’s closet through their shared accountant, of all people. Opie, known for her documentary style, spent six months shooting the star’s myriad possessions at her Bel Air home — from her countless furs and many negligees to the famous La Peregrina pearl necklace, a gift from Richard Burton. Opie’s all-access pass was honored even after Taylor died in the middle of the art project. “I was there the day Christie’s staff came in with shopping bags to take it all away,” the photographer recalls. And while the sale earned Taylor’s estate a whopping $183.5 million, Opie’s exclusive window into the actress’s world — the images will eventually be published as a book — is priceless. See the interactive slideshow

headline: In Alabama, a Model for Obama’s Push to Expand Preschool
keywords: ['Education (Pre-School)', 'Head Start Program', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: President Obama’s plan would involve the federal government working with states to help families get access to preschool.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s call in his State of the Union address to “make high-quality preschool available to every single child in America” rallied advocates across the country who have long argued that inequity in education begins at a very young age.

headline: Having Dosas? Then Drink Champagne, of Course!
abstract: Pairing Indian food with wine can be tricky, but here’s some specific suggestions.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to finding the perfect glass of wine to go with French, Italian or American cuisine, the options are endless. Finding the ideal match for Indian food, however, is more complicated.

headline: A New Commission: Time to Cheer or Yawn?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Long-Term Care Insurance']
abstract: In place of the Class Act, Congress has created a new Commission on Long-Term Care. Some doubt it will lead to anything.
lead_paragraph: The fate of the Class Act, which would have established the nation’s first voluntary public long-term care insurance program, was sealed in 2011 when the Obama administration shut it down, essentially calling it unworkable.

headline: Horse Meat Found in British Food
abstract: Britons are unsure what to expect next on the dinner table.
lead_paragraph: Britons are unsure what to expect next on the dinner table.

headline: Hanging of Militant Raises Questions in India
abstract: A death sentence throws a glare on the justice system in India — and the weakening liberal voice in the country.
lead_paragraph: In my latest column in the International Herald Tribune, I argue that the Indian justice system, which includes shoddy police investigations and the powerful influence of political calculations, is not competent nor fair enough to grant India the moral right to hang a man, assuming that any society can have such a right in the first place.

headline: Cruise Line’s Woes Are Far From Over as Ship Makes Port
abstract: For 4,200 hungry, scared people whose ship limped into dock Thursday, an ordeal was finally ending. For Carnival Cruise Lines, the work was just beginning.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — Thousands of hungry and unwashed passengers gathered on the decks of the lifeless Triumph cruise ship, singing “Sweet Home Alabama,” waving towels and cheering as the vessel was pulled into dock here late on Thursday. For 4,200 passengers and crew, the fetid ordeal of five days adrift in the Gulf of Mexico was over.

headline: When Small Businesses Try to Attract Big Partners
abstract: Finding “a human” to connect with at these organizations has been difficult, said one owner in the She Owns It business group.
lead_paragraph: Small-business owners often maximize their resources and extend their reach by teaming up with larger organizations. But to partner with a larger organization, they first have to get through to one. Alexandra Mayzler, who owns Thinking Caps Tutoring, is trying to do just that. She talked about the challenges of getting a foot in the door at the last She Owns It business group meeting.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Crazy, Unsexy Cancer Tips
abstract: Every few weeks I host a “girls’ night” at my apartment in Lower Manhattan with a group of friends who are at various stages in their cancer treatments. But one topic that doesn’t come up as often as you might think — particularly at a gathering of women in their early 20s and 30s — is sex.
lead_paragraph: Every few weeks I host a “girls’ night” at my apartment in Lower Manhattan with a group of friends who are at various stages in their cancer treatments. Everyone brings something to eat and drink, and we sit around my living room talking to one another about subjects both heavy and light, ranging from post-chemo hair styling tips, fears of relapse or funny anecdotes about a recent hospital visit. But one topic that doesn’t come up as often as you might think — particularly at a gathering of women in their early 20s and 30s — is sex.

headline: Tip of the Week: Adjusting Facebook Photo Previews
abstract: If you do not like the way a photo preview appears on your Facebook Timeline page, you can change it.
lead_paragraph: Hate the way Facebook seems to arbitrarily crop photos you post on your Timeline to fit the square preview windows? On the desktop version, you can change which part of the picture shows in the preview when you’re using Facebook through your Web browser.

headline: The Best Beers of Winter
abstract: Tall, dark strangers that justify forgoing whiskey.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you also went through that phase. The one when you kept an eye on an ominous bucket in a dark corner of your kitchen until the time came to invite over friends, tap it and drink it. Maybe your friends also gulped it, smiled stiffly and said something like, “It’s . . . interesting.” And maybe they also grimaced as if they had just sucked down a rotten egg. I didn’t blame them. The brown ale I concocted during my brief foray into home brewing was dreadful stuff — syrupy, unbalanced and weird.

headline: Such a Chowder!
abstract: Straight from the appetizing counter, a smoked-salmon chowder that tastes of old New York.
lead_paragraph: Russ & Daughters, which has been located at 179 East Houston Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan since 1923, is what is known as an appetizing store. “Appetizing” is a noun. It denotes the prepared foods, most often served cold — smoked salmon, herring in sauce, whitefish salad, caviar, cream cheese — that can accompany every public gathering in the life of a Jew living in New York City, from “bris to shiva,” as Niki Russ Federman, one of the owners, puts it.

headline: Glimpses of Jean Arp’s World
abstract: While his peers were working in Montmartre, Jean Arp headed to the suburbs, where visitors who make the brief trek from Paris can see where he lived and worked.
lead_paragraph: CLAMART, France —The street is typical French suburbia, gray and peaceful, a far stretch from the narrow sidewalks, rooftops and, in the early 20th century, the artists’ studios of Montmartre, but only a few kilometers from Paris. Yet, in the 1930s, up this steep and curvy stretch, lived two members of the avant-garde — Jean Arp and Sophie Taeuber. Joan Miró, Max Ernst, Marcel Duchamp and James Joyce were among their visitors.

headline: Japan’s Central Bank Defends Policy on the Yen
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Yen (Currency)']
abstract: The recent monetary push by Japan seeks to stabilize the economy, not influence currencies, the central bank said.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The recent monetary push by Japan does not amount to currency manipulation and is a legitimate and much-needed effort to lift its economy out of deflation, the country’s central banker said on Thursday after new figures showed an unexpected economic contraction in the fourth quarter.

headline: Malaysians Encircle Militia Intruders From Philippines
abstract: The Malaysian police said they were in a standoff in the eastern state of Sabah with at least 80 militiamen from the Philippines who were seeking to stay by right of historic claims on the island of Borneo.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The police in Malaysia were in a standoff late Thursday with at least 80 militiamen from the Philippines who were seeking to stay by right of historic claims on the island of Borneo, the police said.

headline: 2 Airlines Announce Merger
abstract: American Airlines and US Airways announce a $11 billion merger deal. | Time Warner is in early talks to shed much of Time Inc. | Federal prosecutors are closer to deciding whether to bring charges against a longtime portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors. | Anheuser-Busch InBev has revised its bid for Grupo Modelo.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines and US Airways announced on Thursday that they planned to merge in an $11 billion deal. Under the terms of the deal, US Airways shareholders would own 28 percent of the combined airline, with the remainder held by stakeholders, creditors, labor unions and employees of AMR, the parent company of American. The merger would create the nation’s biggest airline, in position to compete against United Airlines and Delta Air Lines, which have grown through mergers of their own.

headline: Opinion Report: Currency War
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: Builders Travel to Asia to Court Buyers for New London Homes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Britain has a languishing economy and residents wary of buying property. Meanwhile, Asian consumers are increasingly affluent and in search of places to park their cash.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Wanted: deep-pocketed Asian investors for fledgling London property developments.

headline: Immersion Politics: Being Ann Richards
abstract: “Ann,” a solo show written by and starring Holland Taylor, is part of a resurgence of interest in Ann W. Richards, the former governor of Texas.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The sun was setting in the Hollywood Hills as Holland Taylor whisked a visitor into a front room of her home, a window overlooking the public garden across the street. Golden in the fading light, the den was overflowing with stacks of videotapes, dusty transcripts, books and photographs.

headline: The Boy With the Golden Touch
abstract: The designer behind J. W. Anderson has leapfrogged to the forefront of London’s fashion scene by challenging notions of masculine and feminine dressing, aligning himself with industry powerhouses and keeping his eye on the international prize.
lead_paragraph: The designer behind J. W. Anderson has leapfrogged to the forefront of London’s fashion scene by challenging notions of masculine and feminine dressing, aligning himself with industry powerhouses and keeping his eye on the international prize.

headline: Faith, Loss, Luck and Tragedy at the Kumbh Mela
abstract: A first person account from the largest gathering of humanity in the world.
lead_paragraph: ALLAHABAD, Uttar Pradesh—The sun rose on Leader Road, Allahabad, which leads to Allahabad Junction Railway Station, warming up a chilly Monday morning. Several local men had already begun to prepare generous shares of potato curry and puris to offer to Kumbh Mela pilgrims free of cost. As I stood at the corner of the street holding an early morning newspaper that reported on the stampede that had killed 36 people the previous night, a short, frail woman meekly approached me.

headline: Bracing for a New England Trawling Decision
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: NOAA will decide whether to reopen some New England waters to trawling and dredging for groundfish.
lead_paragraph: In late December, the New England Fisheries Management Council, a body made up largely of commercial fishermen, voted to recommend that bottom trawling and dredging be allowed to resume in more than half of the protected waters that currently shelter New England’s recovering groundfish stocks. The issue now goes up to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline: Thursday Reading: Using Your Phone as a Personal Translator
abstract: Use your phone as a personal translator, test your knowledge of the flu, uncovering secret hiding places at home and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Berkshire and 3G Capital in a $23 Billion Deal for Heinz
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway, the giant conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, said on Thursday that it would buy the H. J. Heinz Company for about $23 billion. Berkshire is teaming up with 3G Capital, a Brazilian investment firm that already owns most of Burger King.
lead_paragraph: 8:56 p.m. | Updated

headline: Horse Meat Scandal: Is the Era of Cheap Food Over?
abstract: Europe’s horse meat scandal has underlined the reality that, in an era of higher food prices, consumers will have to pay more or adjust their diet if they want to be sure of what they are eating.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With Europe’s expanding horse meat scandal escalating from a drama to a crisis, consumers are being warned that the era of cheap food may be over.

headline: More Marcoeconomics
abstract: More bad doctrine at odds with evidence.
lead_paragraph: No, that’s not a misspelling of “macroeconomics”.

headline: G.M.’s Profit Rises Despite Weakness in Europe
abstract: G.M. said it had net income of $900 million in the fourth quarter, compared with $500 million in the same period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors said its profit in the fourth quarter increased slightly as continued losses in Europe offset positive results in North America.

headline: As Troops Leave, an Uncertain Future for U.S. Aid in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama’s announcement on Tuesday of his plan to draw down United States troops in Afghanistan over the next year puts new focus on the sustainability of aid programs in Afghanistan as the military presence there diminishes.
lead_paragraph: It has given most of Afghanistan access to health care for the first time, even if it is weighed down by corruption and waste. It has drawn violent reprisals from the Taliban but educated a generation of Afghan girls. Accused of fostering a dependency culture, it has nonetheless provided the foundation for a functioning economy.

headline: A Valentine Sandwich Board
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young man with a sign asked subway riders not for money, but for advice on how to win his ex-girlfriend back.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:Some people wear their heart on their sleeve; one subway passenger wore his on a cardboard sign over his winter coat.

headline: A Farewell, Whispered and Roared
abstract: Maurice Sendak wrote “My Brother’s Book” in memory of his brother, but it also feels like an elegy for his companion.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Sendak (1928-2012) cultivated an image as a curmudgeon. “I’m not Hans Christian Andersen,” he told Bill Moyers. “No one’s going to make a statue in the park with a lot of scrambling kids climbing up me. I won’t have it.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Time Warner Considers Shedding Some Magazines and Panera Appeals to Consumers’ Decency
abstract: Time Warner may spin off most of Time Inc.’s magazines in a deal with Meredith Corporation; Panera Bread Bakeries is the latest company to appeal to consumers through good works; and discussions of the sounds and near-silence of “Life of Pi.”
lead_paragraph: Time Warner is in talks with the Meredith Corporation to spin off much of Time Inc., the country’s largest magazine empire and the foundation on which the $49 billion media conglomerate was built, Amy Chozick and Michael J. de la Merced write. The deal would move the bulk of Time Inc.’s magazines, including titles like People, InStyle and Real Simple, into a separate, publicly traded company that would include Meredith publications like Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies’ Home Journal. The new company would borrow money to pay a one-time dividend of about $1.75 billion to Time Warner, making the transaction resemble a sale. Time Warner would continue to control the newsmagazines Time, Sports Illustrated, Fortune and the magazine Money. The deal is one of several options under consideration to reduce Time Warner’s troubled publishing unit.

headline: The Kids Are Alright
abstract: Dystopia not.
lead_paragraph: Via Brad DeLong, I see that Nick Eberstadt has written more about America’s moral collapse. Eberstadt, readers may recall, was responsible for the “nation of takers” meme that did so much to ensure victory for … Barack Obama.

headline: Daily Report: In High-Tech Japan, the Fax Machines Roll On
abstract: The old-fashioned fax machine remains popular in Japan, long after the rest of the world has abandoned it. The government says that almost all business offices and nearly half of private homes had a fax machine as of 2011.
lead_paragraph: Japan is renowned for its robots and bullet trains, and has some of the world’s fastest broadband networks. But Martin Fackler reports that the country also remains firmly wedded to a pre-Internet technology — the fax machine — that in most other developed nations has joined answering machines, eight-tracks and cassette tapes in the dustbin of outmoded technologies.

headline: Don’t You Be My Valentine
abstract: Pakistan goes to war with the day of love.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — While much of the world celebrates Valentine’s Day on Thursday, Pakistan’s religious political parties are exhorting the country’s youth to celebrate a “day of modesty” instead. On Tuesday, the student wing of Jamaat-e-Islami, a major religious party, condemned Valentine’s Day in Peshawar for encouraging “immodesty” and threatened to shut down any celebrations if law enforcement agencies failed to take action first.

headline: David Leonhardt, Washington Bureau Chief, Answers Readers’ Questions
abstract: David Leonhardt answered readers’ questions on Feb. 14 about the economy and President Obama’s legislative agenda.
lead_paragraph: David Leonhardt, Washington bureau chief for The New York Times, answered readers’ questions on Thursday about the economic landscape and President Obama’s prospects to enact the ambitious legislative agenda he laid out in his State of the Union address.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Bette Franke at Derek Lam
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Orlando Pita.

headline: The Most Important Problem Facing Small Businesses
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Small Business']
abstract: For years industry groups have complained that government regulations and taxes were at the root of the weak recovery, but survey data consistently showed that demand was actually far and away the biggest problem. Until recently.
lead_paragraph: For years industry groups have complained that government regulations and taxes were at the root of the weak recovery, but survey data consistently showed that demand was actually far and away the biggest problem. Until recently.

headline: The Gun Report: February 14, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Here is our sampling of gun violence for February 13:

headline: Britain Says Equine Drug May Have Entered Food Chain
abstract: British officials said on Thursday that a banned substance commonly used in horses and potentially harmful to humans may have entered the food chain in small quantities.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The scandal over horse meat in the European food chain widened Thursday from a case of mislabeling to one of food safety as public health authorities in Britain said that a powerful equine painkiller, potentially harmful to human health, “may have entered the food chain” in France.

headline: The Brazilians Behind the Heinz Deal
abstract: Warren E. Buffett’s partner in the Heinz deal, the Brazilian-backed investment firm 3G Capital, has, like Mr. Buffett, shown a hankering for iconic American businesses.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett’s $23 billion acquisition of H. J. Heinz, a quintessentially American company, is almost a caricature of a Buffett acquisition.

headline: Keystone Protests Resume, But None Against Oil Imports from Nigeria?
abstract: White House protests resume over a pipeline from Canada even as oil keeps flowing to the U.S. from despoiled Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: I’ve got nothing against the passions of those — including friends of mine — pushing hard to persuade President Obama not to let the Keystone XL pipeline move forward and carry bitumen from Canadian deposits to United States Gulf Coast refineries. More were arrested this week.

headline: The Air That Kills in India
abstract: A new analysis shows that a common fine-particulate haze is a graver health threat than had been feared.
lead_paragraph: The thick haze of outdoor air pollution common in India today is the nation’s fifth-largest killer, after high blood pressure, indoor air pollution (mainly from cooking fires), smoking and poor nutrition, according to a new analysis presented in New Delhi by the Boston-based Health Effects Institute. In 2010, outdoor air pollution contributed to over 620,000 premature deaths in India, up from 100,000 in 2000.

headline: Confessions of a Domestic Gigolo
abstract: My wife and I struck a dubious-sounding pact that went on to revolutionize our marriage: sex for cleaning.
lead_paragraph: A romantic Valentine’s is close. Like, broom-closet close. All you need for a sexy good time is a bucket of cleaning supplies and maybe a notary public — depending on how litigious you are. My wife and I are horrible at paperwork, so we struck our deal with a handshake. It was a dubious-sounding pact that went on to revolutionize our marriage: sex for cleaning.

headline: Five Questions for: Author Uday Prakash
abstract: Mr. Prakash is one of the few Hindi writers to be published by an American publisher.
lead_paragraph: Uday Prakash is an award-winning poet and writer who has published more than 20 books in Hindi. His most recent book “The Walls of Delhi,” originally written in Hindi, was a finalist for this year’s DSC Prize for South Asian Literature. His writings have been translated into several languages including Urdu, English, German and Japanese.

headline: Record Label Apologizes for Lil Wayne’s Obscene Reference to Emmett Till
abstract: A remix of “Karate Chop” by Future and featuring an appearance by Lil Wayne had drawn criticism from the family of Emmett Till, whose murder was a crucial incident in the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Epic Records has offered its regrets and said it would go to “great efforts” to pull down an online version of a widely criticized track on which the rapper Lil Wayne makes an obscene analogy involving Emmett Till, whose murder was a crucial incident in fomenting the civil rights movement.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘What Isn’t Mine’
abstract: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “What Isn’t Mine,” a poem by Jill Alexander Essbaum, with “A Bond Forged in Crucible of the Art World” by Michael Winerip.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “What Isn’t Mine,” a poem by Jill Alexander Essbaum, with “A Bond Forged in Crucible of the Art World” by Michael Winerip.

headline: Bonded by Motherhood and Workplaces
abstract: The lead actress and executive story editor of “Nurse Jackie” are joining forces onstage.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you wrote a new play. It’s only your second, but it’s got a great part for an actress who can win over the audience to a character who can be unsympathetic, someone who can convey existential malaise at the same time as tough-day-at-work frustration.

headline: Studio in the Woods
abstract: Fixtures of the downtown New York fashion scene, the Proenza Schouler designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez retreat to 100 quiet acres in the Berkshires to create their collections in splendid isolation.

headline: For a Character Lost at Sea, an Expert Who Knew the Feeling
abstract: The screenwriter of “Life of Pi” consulted an author who had spent 76 days alone on a lifeboat in the open ocean.
lead_paragraph: David Magee’s day job, abridging books for audio versions, turned out to be pretty good preparation for screenwriting: he’s an Oscar nominee and a contender, this weekend, for a Writers Guild Award for his adaptation of Yann Martel’s allegorical novel “Life of Pi.” But Mr. Magee needed more than that experience when it came to his title character, a boy lost at sea with only a menacing tiger for company.

headline: It’s Hard to Find a Hero
abstract: Murder charges against Oscar Pistorius provided more doubts about the sports myth machine.
lead_paragraph: Even in a sports world that reminds us daily of its heroes’ flaws, of the dangers of dialing into the television-fueled myth machine, the news that the Olympic sprinter Oscar Pistorius is being charged with murdering his girlfriend in South Africa was still the kind of headline that makes you blink and shake your head to make sure you read it right.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Wired: In praise of blue milk and Yoda’s funky fireside stew: as part of a cover package in the magazine, Alton Brown looks at the food of “Star Wars.” — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Conservatives Skeptical of Expanding Preschool
abstract: Some Republicans said they feared the creation of another federal entitlement program.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — President Obama’s plan to expand preschool for the nation’s children faces deep skepticism among Republicans, who fear the creation of another federal entitlement program that they say could add to the nation’s deficit and swell the ranks of the teachers’ unions.

headline: Approve Caitlin Halligan for the D.C. Circuit Today
abstract: The Republicans are out of shameless, enormously time-wasting excuses to sabotage Ms. Halligan’s nomination.
lead_paragraph: The D.C. Circuit now officially has four vacancies out of 11 seats, as a result of another judge taking senior status this week. Imagine the U.S. Senate with 36 empty seats, which would be the equivalent. We can be quite confident that the Senate would address the problem expeditiously.

headline: With Heinz Deal, an ‘Elephant’ for Berkshire
abstract: When Berkshire Hathaway agreed to buy the H.J. Heinz Company on Thursday, the deal had some of the classic hallmarks of Warren E. Buffett. Here is a look at some of Berkshire’s deals in recent years.
lead_paragraph: When Berkshire Hathaway agreed to buy the H.J. Heinz Company on Thursday, the deal had some of the classic hallmarks of Warren E. Buffett.

headline: A Warm Croon Wrapped in an Enigma
abstract: The group Rhye has been hard to pin down. Its debut album, “Woman,” may help clear things up — to a degree.
lead_paragraph: Everyone loves a good a mystery — even music journalists. Early last year they got one, when a band called Rhye began posting recordings on the Internet. Information about Rhye was scarce; the group’s singles arrived online with alluring promotional photographs — a woman’s bare back, a woman’s bare torso — and meticulously produced videos, but no images of the musicians themselves.

headline: Pope Says He Will Be ‘Hidden to the World’ in Retirement
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI took his leave of parish priests and clergy of the diocese of Rome and indicated that he would not hold a public role once his resignation becomes official on Feb. 28.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Saying he would soon be “hidden to the world,” Pope Benedict XVI took his leave of parish priests and clergy members of the Diocese of Rome on Thursday as he offered personal, and incisive, recollections of the Second Vatican Council, the gathering of bishops 50 years ago that set the Roman Catholic Church’s course for the future.

headline: A Nose for Prose
abstract: Jean-Claude Ellena, the official perfumer of Hermès, shares his thoughts on perfume in his new memoir.

headline: What’s the State of Your Block in 2013?
abstract: The mayor has his State of the City, but City Room wants to hear how you think your immediate area is doing.
lead_paragraph: At noon today, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his final State of the City address.

lead_paragraph: The author of “Vampires in the Lemon Grove” recently met Louise Erdrich, but all she could say was something like “Hey, Louise, are these pimentos in the dip?”

headline: New Center Hosts a Food Conference
abstract: The Laurie M. Tisch Center for Food, Education and Policy at Teachers College, a graduate division of Columbia University, was started with a grant from Ms. Tisch.
lead_paragraph: Some big players in urban food policy — including the New York City Council speaker, Christine Quinn; Newark’s mayor, Cory Booker; and the Manhattan borough president, Scott Stringer — will debate the issues at a conference today at 11:15 a.m. The conference is the inaugural event for the new Laurie M. Tisch Center for Food, Education and Policy at Teachers College, a graduate division of Columbia University.

headline: More Fun With the Filibuster
abstract: Republicans are attempting to derail the nomination process for the two most important national security posts in the government.
lead_paragraph: The attempted-derailing of the nomination process for the two most important national security posts in the government, which started with petulant time-wasting, has mushroomed into yet another Republican-created checks-and-balances crisis.

headline: Rivera Shines on His First Day, but Cervelli Is Shadowed by Suspicion
abstract: Cervelli fielded questions on his his involvement with an embattled clinic near Miami, while  Mariano Rivera bounded through his first team drills since his injury in May.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The juxtaposition of emotions was striking.

headline: Ronald Dworkin, Scholar of the Law, Is Dead at 81
abstract: Professor Dworkin, a public intellectual with liberal views who taught at New York University and University College, London, influenced many judges on a number of courts worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Dworkin, a legal philosopher and public intellectual of bracingly liberal views who insisted that morality is the touchstone of constitutional interpretation, died on Thursday in London. He was 81.

headline: Time Inc., the Unwanted Party Guest Being Pushed Out the Door
abstract: Time Inc. has been an integral part of the Time Warner brand, but it long ago lost salience as a significant component in the company’s business.
lead_paragraph: 12:43 p.m. | Updated How toxic have print assets become? This toxic: Media companies have begun to quarantine them.

headline: A Trans-Atlantic Trade Pact
abstract: Analyzing the impact of a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Analyzing the impact of a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union.

headline: Fund-Raising for Schools, Using Old Class Photos
abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.
lead_paragraph: Remember that class photo from second grade that went missing — the one in which you are smiling, without any front teeth? Wouldn’t you like to have another copy of it?

headline: Lady Gaga Cancels Tour Because of Hip Injury
abstract: A hip injury that will require surgical repair led to the cancellation of her Born This Way Ball tour.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga has torn soft tissues in her hip joint and the injury has forced her to cancel the rest of her Born This Way Ball tour to have surgery and recover, Live Nation Global Touring announced Wednesday.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 14
abstract: A vendor selling roses on Valentine’s Day in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Paging Belmondo, or a Horse
abstract: Can you believe Anna Sui, of all people, is a latecomer to the genre of Nouvelle Vague cinema?
lead_paragraph: Can you believe Anna Sui, of all people, is a latecomer to the genre of Nouvelle Vague cinema? She only recently got around to watching the 1960s films of Jean-Luc Godard, but when Ms. Sui dives into a subject, she immerses herself completely.

headline: American and US Airways Frequent Fliers: Relax.
abstract: Dear frequent fliers, your miles are safe — for now.
lead_paragraph: Dear frequent fliers, your miles are safe — for now.

headline: Foundation Says It Regrets Payment to Disgraced Journalist
abstract: The Knight Foundation says it should not have paid Jonah Lehrer $20,000 for a speech.
lead_paragraph: The Knight Foundation says that it regrets paying a $20,000 honorarium to Jonah Lehrer, the disgraced journalist whose appearance at a Knight conference in Miami on Tuesday drew sharp criticism on Twitter and elsewhere.

headline: Digital Artists Behind ‘Life of Pi’
abstract: Melena Ryzik pays a visit to Rhythm & Hues, the production studio that created the Oscar-nominated visual effects for “Life of Pi.”
lead_paragraph: Melena Ryzik pays a visit to Rhythm & Hues, the production studio that created the Oscar-nominated visual effects for “Life of Pi.”

headline: Afraid to Speak Up to Medical Power
abstract: Aspiring doctors quickly learn whose opinions, experiences and voices count, and it is rarely their own. But such an overly developed sense of hierarchy comes at an unacceptable price: good patient care.
lead_paragraph: The slender, weather-beaten, elderly Polish immigrant had been diagnosed with lung cancer nearly a year earlier and was receiving chemotherapy as part of a clinical trial. I was a surgical consultant, called in to help control the fluid that kept accumulating in his lungs.

headline: Here’s Sally Field, Star of ‘Linkin Park’
abstract: “Between Two Ferns” continues its fake interviews with real nominees.
lead_paragraph: Zach Galifianakis is back with Part 2 of his Oscar edition of “Between Two Ferns,” and it contains perhaps the best interview you’ll ever see with Sally Field (star, of course, of “Linkin Park”), Jessica Chastain (“ ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ is that a movie about Chris Brown?”) and a memorable appearance by Bradley Cooper, Mr. Galifianakis’s co-star in “The Hangover” franchise, the next installment of which could take a slightly darker, plant-hating turn. See it here.

headline: Airline Consolidation Continues
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The deregulation of the airline industry in 1978 led to a wave of mergers that continues to this day. In the latest, American Airlines and U.S. Airways have agreed to merge and would become the largest airline in terms of total passengers flown this year.
lead_paragraph: The deregulation of the airline industry in 1978 led to a wave of mergers that continues to this day. In the latest, American Airlines and U.S. Airways have agreed to merge and would become the largest airline in terms of total passengers flown this year.

headline: Model Diary | Jamie Bochert
abstract: The downtown chic model, often considered by industry insiders to be Marc Jacobs’s muse, has hometown advantage for New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Bochert, the downtown chic model often considered by industry insiders to be Marc Jacobs’s muse, has hometown advantage for New York Fashion Week. For the last day of shows, T asked the dark-eyed beauty, 34, a little about her life here off the runway. She doesn’t tweet or Instagram; but if she did, she may have told you that she is in tonight’s Marc Jacobs show, which was originally scheduled for Monday but got postponed due to inclement weather.

headline: Video: Mayor Bloomberg’s Final State of the City Address
abstract: Watch Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg deliver his final State of the City address from the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Watch Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s final State of the City address, delivered Thursday from the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. Watch the speech here.

headline: One Hundred Times ‘Forever Dusty’
abstract: The musical “Forever Dusty” celebrated its 100th performance with an audience singalong.
lead_paragraph: The musical “Forever Dusty” celebrated its 100th performance at New World Stages on Wednesday night. Audience members were invited to sing along with the performers, led by Kirsten Holly Smith as Dusty Springfield. The show’s producers said that the first 10 fans to arrive dressed as the singer would receive free admission.

headline: Chrysler Is Recalling 278,000 Pickups and S.U.V.’s
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: The rear differential could fail, causing the driver to lose control, Chrysler said in a report.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler is recalling about 278,000 pickups and sport utility vehicles because the rear differential could fail, causing the driver to lose control, according to a report posted on Thursday on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Former BlackBerry C.E.O. Sold All Company Shares
abstract: Jim Balsillie, the former co-chief executive and co-chairman of BlackBerry, has sold all of his shares in the struggling company he co-founded, a regulatory filing indicated on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Jim Balsillie, the former co-chief executive and co-chairman of BlackBerry, has sold all of his shares in the struggling company, a regulatory filing indicated on Thursday.

headline: Cardinal Health Is Buying Large Medical Supplier for $2 Billion
abstract: Cardinal Health, a distributor of prescription drugs, plans to expand into the growing home health care market with the acquisition of AssuraMed.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Health, the second-largest distributor of prescription drugs, announced on Thursday that it was buying a large medical supplier in a $2 billion deal aimed at expanding the business into the growing area of home health care.

headline: Creating the Nation's Largest Airline
abstract: With a merger, American Airlines ends a yearlong courtship of US Airways.
lead_paragraph: With a merger, American Airlines ends a yearlong courtship of US Airways.

headline: Referee Played Music in His Funeral Parade
abstract: In 1920, a referee was the guest of honor in his own funeral procession (hint: he was not dead).
lead_paragraph: No one loves the soccer referee. In fact, he is universally hated. A humorless actor, he is jeered and insulted in all corners of the globe.

headline: TimesCast: Creating the Nation’s Largest Airline
abstract: Ending a yearlong courtship by US Airways, American Airlines agreed to merge with the smaller carrier, paving the way for the creation of the nation’s largest airline.
lead_paragraph: Ending a yearlong courtship by US Airways, American Airlines agreed to merge with the smaller carrier, paving the way for the creation of the nation’s largest airline.

headline: John Kerry Potential Winner in Heinz Deal
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry — married to Teresa Heinz Kerry, an heir to the Heinz ketchup fortune — held $3 million worth of shares in the company last year.
lead_paragraph: The $23 billion takeover of H.J. Heinz on Thursday featured a familiar cast of characters save for one unlikely victor: Secretary of State John Kerry.

headline: In My 2013 Win-a-Trip Contest, We Have a Winner!
abstract: I have my winner for my annual win-a-trip contest: a journalism student at University of Wisconsin at Madison who blogs and produces videos — and has spent a couple of years in the Peace Corps in Kyrgyzstan.
lead_paragraph: I’m delighted to announce that my 2013 win-a-trip contest winner is Erin Luhmann, a Minnesotan who is now a straight-A graduate student of journalism at University of Wisconsin in Madison. Erin earlier studied English at Gustavus Adolphus College, in St. Peter, Minn., and then spent two years teaching English in the Peace Corps in Kyrgyzstan in central Asia — which, as she pointed out in her application, means she won’t have a problem with whatever toilets we encounter. Erin is a lovely writer, blogger and video producer who plans on a career as a foreign correspondent, ultimately aspiring to help train overseas journalists to reach a global audience. She’s deeply committed to amplify overseas voices and encourage Americans to engage with important global news stories. She’s also a hard worker: When I called her up with the news that she had won, she immediately asked for a reading list and inquired whether she should start studying French in case we visit a French-speaking country.

headline: Could the Kardashians Enter Baku Even If They Really Wanted to?
abstract: An article about the captial of Azerbaijan’s ambition to become a new hub for the global 1 percent sparked some questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, the magazine published my article with the print headline, “If They Build It, Will the Kardashians Come?” The story, about Baku’s ambition to become a new hub for the global 1 percent, focuses on Khazar Islands, a $100 billion megadevelopment being built on the Caspian, and the headline flicks at the development’s target audience — celebrities and, mainly, people who want to be celebrities — while touching on the unavoidable globalizing and liberalizing effect this sort of project will have.

headline: LIPA Customers Are the Most Dissatisfied in the Country, a Study Says
abstract: A survey of utility customers, the first since Hurricane Sandy, shows that, as a group, businesses in the Northeast lost a lot of faith in their power providers last year.
lead_paragraph: The results of the first survey of utility customers since Hurricane Sandy are in, and they indicate that the New York metropolitan area is a hotbed of dissatisfaction.

headline: G.O.P. Blocks Vote in Senate on Hagel for Defense Post
abstract: The move to stall Chuck Hagel’s nomination for defense secretary was likely to worsen partisan tensions while keeping the White House from assembling its national security team.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked President Obama’s nominee to lead the Pentagon in a defiant move likely to further strain partisan tensions while preventing the White House, at least temporarily, from assembling its second-term national security team.

abstract: Maria Dizzia and Greg Keller, the leads of Amy Herzog’s drama “Belleville,” are used to playing a couple together, though they aren’t one offstage.
lead_paragraph: Greg Keller was trying to pay Maria Dizzia a compliment, and she was having none of it.

headline: The M Bar at the Mansfield Hotel
abstract: The M Bar at the Mansfield Hotel, where the mixed drinks are a mixed bag, is just O.K., but sometimes that’s enough.

headline: Graphic: The 10 Biggest Food Deals
abstract: The food industry has long been a fertile area for deal activity. How does the acquisition of Heinz rank?
lead_paragraph: The food industry has long been a fertile area for deal activity. Companies that can offer well-known brands and strong steady cash flows are attractive to both strategic buyers and private equity firms. Food, along with tobacco, was at the heart of one of the fiercest corporate takeover battles — the fight for RJR Nabisco, as famously chronicled in “Barbarians at the Gate.”

headline: Hands-on Cooking Lessons
abstract: Why some videos go viral, like this cooking one.
lead_paragraph: There are 72 hours worth of videos uploaded to YouTube every minute,  writes our colleague Kate Murphy, much of it “cringe-worthy.” In her article, she breaks down what makes a video go viral and what doesn’t work.

headline: The Adrenaline-Fueled Life of Oscar Pistorius
abstract: When I spent a week with Oscar, he was not like most big-time athletes. He was far nicer. But he was an adrenaline freak at a level I had never seen before.

headline: Ahoy, Ralph Lauren
abstract: The S.S. Ralph Lauren pulled into port this morning on the final day of New York Fashion Week, depositing enough peacoats, admiral coats, passementerie, sailor pants and fisherman sweaters on his runway to make you think it was Fleet Week.
lead_paragraph: The S.S. Ralph Lauren pulled into port this morning on the final day of New York Fashion Week, depositing enough peacoats, admiral coats, passementerie, sailor pants and fisherman sweaters on his runway to make you think it was Fleet Week, not Fashion Week. In other words, there was a light nautical theme to the collection, along with an assortment of beaded gowns and velvet dresses in dark mossy tones.

headline: Heinz: A Bonanza for Independent Advisers
abstract: The sale of H.J. Heinz to Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital is big in many ways — the headline price of $23 billion, for one. But one notable fact is that most of the banks putting the deal together aren’t bulge-bracket firms.
lead_paragraph: The sale of H.J. Heinz to Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital is big in many ways — the headline price of $23 billion, for one. But one notable fact is that most of the banks putting the deal together aren’t bulge-bracket firms.

headline: Hotel and Carrier Meet Cute
abstract: Delta and Starwood have paired up to offer a joint rewards program starting March 1.
lead_paragraph: Delta and Starwood have paired up — their loyalty programs, that is. The Crossover Rewards program offers a number of perks starting March 1. Among them: Gold-tier members of Starwood’s loyalty program get points for every dollar spent on a Delta flight; members of Delta’s frequent-flier program receive miles for every dollar spent at a Starwood hotel, in addition to miles earned in flight. Starwood’s brands include standbys like Westin and Sheraton as well as the W hotels, Aloft and Meridien.

abstract: Tina Turnbow demonstrates how to create a flawless and natural look.
lead_paragraph: Tina Turnbow demonstrates how to create a flawless and natural look.

keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The two publishing companies cleared an important hurdle in their effort to merge when the Justice Department said it was ending its review of the deal “without conditions.”
lead_paragraph: The merger of Penguin and Random House cleared a big hurdle Thursday.

headline: New York Philharmonic Names Principal Clarinetist
abstract: The Philharmonic hired Stephen Williamson away from the Chicago Symphony.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s solution is now the Chicago Symphony’s problem. The Philharmonic addressed its four-season lack of a principal clarinetist by hiring Stephen Williamson away from the Chicago Symphony, the orchestra disclosed on Thursday. Mr. Williamson was one of the first appointments made under the watch of Chicago’s music director, Riccardo Muti, and is in the middle of only his second season there. Chicago will now have to find a replacement, although a Chicago Orchestra spokeswoman said Mr. Williamson officially was on a one-year leave.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: From Bloomberg, a Warning of Life After Bloomberg
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg discussed new proposals related to police stops and the environment, as well as his accomplishments during 11 years in office.
lead_paragraph: In an unabashed and relentless tribute to his own municipal stewardship, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday declared victory over 12 years of “obstructionists” and “naysayers” who sought to block his vision for New York City, and warned that an era of political independence might leave City Hall when he did.

headline: Mother Water, Fish Water
abstract: As big fish in the Mekong grow rarer, fishermen harvest the smaller ones to feed the region’s appetite.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been following the tale of our family quest down the Mekong River, this thought may have occurred to you: traveling long days in a small boat with two children is not a dream vacation. This thought also occurred to me – quite regularly around midnight during many sleepless nights before our departure.

headline: A Laboratory for Revitalizing Catholicism
abstract: Some quarters of the Catholic Church in Brazil are confronting threats from evangelicalism and secularism by enlivening worship with charismatic practices.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — At one new megachurch in São Paulo, a Roman Catholic priest who was a personal trainer before joining the clergy energetically belts out songs, rock-star style, before 25,000 worshipers. Other Brazilian priests are donning cowboy hats and crooning country tunes at Mass or writing best-selling advice tomes emblazoned with heartthrob photographs on the cover.

headline: Video: Digitally Creating the Meerkats (and Tigers) of ‘Pi’
abstract: The visual effects whizzes of “Life of Pi” explain how they whipped up waves and animated the animals.
lead_paragraph: Three years were spent working on the 3D effects in “Life of Pi,” and, given his top billing, you’d think much of that was spent on the tiger, Richard Parker. But the ocean turned out to be a much more demanding star; the constantly shifting waves and whitecaps presented many more challenges to the effects wizards at Rhythm & Hues. They worked with the director Ang Lee to give the ocean moods — hopeful, or melancholy, or operatically dramatic. In this video, Bill Westenhofer, the movie’s visual effects supervisor, explains how they amped up or scaled back their creations, and why the scenes with meerkats were a highlight of the project.

headline: Now Hear This: Library of Congress Issues Plan to Preserve Recordings
abstract: The plan is a result of the National Recording Preservation Act of 2000.
lead_paragraph: If you listen to music, the state of recorded sound may strike you as healthy and robust. Whether you hear it in a club, on the radio, on mp3, compact disc or LP, and whether the recording was made last week or decades ago, the sound is solid and the experience can be immersive.

headline: The Two Julias
abstract: The unknown story of Ulysses S. Grant’s wife – and her slave.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 11, 1863, Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant faced a challenge more urgent than capturing Vicksburg, Miss., his current military objective. “This morning I met with a great loss,” he wrote his wife Julia from temporary quarters aboard the steamer Magnolia, anchored near the Mississippi River town. “Last night, contrary to my usual habit, I took out my teeth and put them in the wash and covered them with water. This morning the servant who attends to my stateroom, blacks my boots, &c.” came into my room “about daylight and finding water” in the basin “threw it out in to the river, teeth and all.” Grant thought his dentist, a Dr. Hamline, might be in Memphis, and since Julia was there, Grant urged her to try to find him and “tell him of my misfortune.”

headline: Track Star Charged in Killing
abstract: Michael Sokolove, a writer who profiled Oscar Pistorius, discusses the dark turn for the South African runner.
lead_paragraph: Michael Sokolove, a writer who profiled Oscar Pistorius, discusses the dark turn for the South African runner.

headline: Gaming the System
abstract: Some college students unanimously boycotted their final exam and all got A’s under a grading curve loophole. It’s a great example of game theory at work.
lead_paragraph: Inside Higher Ed had a fascinating article a couple days ago about some college students who unanimously boycotted their final exam and all got A’s under a grading curve loophole. It’s a great example of game theory at work.

headline: The President Revives an Old Debate About Privacy
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Executive Orders', 'Law and Legislation', 'Privacy', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Are we safer if we give up a bit of privacy? President Obama’s executive order on cybersecurity this week has resurrected the debate between privacy and security, which computer scientists, policy makers and civil liberties groups have been having for years.
lead_paragraph: Few expect Internet privacy legislation in Congress this year. But many were heartened that the “p” word came up at all in the State of Union address Tuesday night.

headline: ‘Detropia’ and Sword Dancing
abstract: “Detropia,” a documentary about Detroit, will be shown at the Maysles Institute in Harlem, and sword dancing displays will be presented in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Many see Detroit as a supreme symbol of the Rust Belt, to which the recession delivered a merciless coup de grâce, but if there’s an American city whose cultural contributions are more underrated, the Miser would love to know about it.

headline: A New Chef at the Beatrice Inn
abstract: Hillary Sterling will replace Brian Nasworthy as executive chef.
lead_paragraph: The Beatrice Inn, Graydon Carter’s latest West Village restaurant, has hired Hillary Sterling as its executive chef, replacing Brian Nasworthy, who recently left. Ms. Sterling worked at Mesa Grill and Lupa, and was chef de cuisine at A Voce.

headline: No Ice or Skates, but There Are Goals
abstract: The Mofo Hockey league, for street players, has become a viable option for fans who want to play the sport, even if it’s not on ice.
lead_paragraph: TANAHEY PARK, nestled between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges on the Lower East Side, is a gathering spot for skateboarders and basketball players. On weekends, even during the winter, street-hockey players sweep in with a clatter.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra to Record for Deutsche Grammophon
abstract: The orchestra, under the leadership of Yannick Nézet-Séguin, will release its first recording on a major label in 16 years.
lead_paragraph: Ah, a conductor with benefits. Riding the train called Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Philadelphia Orchestra said it will release its first recording on a major label in 16 years, on Deutsche Grammophon. Mr. Nézet-Séguin is the orchestra’s new music director, a rising star in the conducting world who has been recording for Deutsche Grammophon since 2008.

headline: ‘Surrounded by Love All Day’
abstract: For James Mitchell, the main officiant at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, the busier he is the more he likes it, and the couples he marries appreciate him.
lead_paragraph: Loving one’s work is always important, but especially so when that work involves being in constant contact with people who are in love. It helps, too, that James Mitchell, who officiates at more than 200 weddings a week at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, is happily married himself.

headline: The F.D.A. Approves a Bionic Eye
abstract: The Argus II allows Barbara Campbell, who lost her sight 20 years ago, to see the world through patterns of light. Scientists hope it is the beginning of even more treatments.
lead_paragraph: The Argus II allows Barbara Campbell, who lost her sight 20 years ago, to see the world through patterns of light. Scientists hope it is the beginning of even more treatments.

headline: For CNN, Cruise Ship Coverage by ‘Air, Land and Sea’

abstract: The cable news channel threw everything it had on Thursday at the odyssey of the Carnival Cruise Line ship Triumph, which was being towed toward port in Mobile, Ala., after four days stranded at sea.
lead_paragraph: There are a number of ways to get ahead in the cable news world. One way is partisan talk about the news, as exemplified by shows on MSNBC and Fox News. Another way is personality-based — think Bill O’Reilly, Joe Scarborough and Rachel Maddow.

headline: Device Offers Partial Vision for the Blind
abstract: Regulators on Thursday approved the first method for giving some people who are blind the ability to discern shapes, using a technology called the artificial retina.

headline: Traces of Anxiety Drug May Affect Behavior in Fish
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'Water Pollution', 'Research', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Researchers in Sweden reported that fish exposed to Oxazepam became less social, more active and ate faster, behaviors they said could have long-term consequences for aquatic ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: Traces of a common psychiatric medication that winds up in rivers and streams may affect fish behavior and feeding patterns, according to a study in the journal Science published Thursday.

headline: A Modern Setting With Rustic Aspirations
abstract: The padded white walls at Parish Hall in Williamsburg are an example of its subdued aesthetics.
lead_paragraph: The walls are padded and white in the immaculate back dining room of Parish Hall, which calls to mind a sanitarium run by Shakers. All is subdued: the lights, the maple surfaces, the waiters’ footfalls across concrete floors, the conversations at tables set diplomatically apart.

headline: Merck Settles Suits Over Cholesterol Drug
abstract: The drug maker agreed to pay $688 million to settle two lawsuits that said it had harmed investors by delaying the release of unfavorable study results for a cholesterol drug.
