headline: Judge Accepts Transocean Guilty Plea in Gulf Oil Spill
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A federal judge in New Orleans approved Transocean’s guilty plea and $400 million in penalties for its role in the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil well blowout.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A federal judge in New Orleans approved on Thursday Transocean’s agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to a misdemeanor charge and pay $400 million in criminal penalties for its role in the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil well blowout that left 11 workers dead and resulted in a yearlong moratorium on deepwater drilling.

headline: Russia Seeks the Arrest of a Politician From Georgia

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian authorities issued an arrest warrant for a Georgian politician, Givi Targamadze, on Thursday, charging that he had incited riots in Russia, in particular by helping to organize an antigovernment march last May that culminated in a confrontation between protesters and the riot police.

headline: East Asian Physical Traits Linked to 35,000-Year-Old Mutation

headline: For Alabama, a Recruiting Title
abstract: After another national championship, Alabama has the top-ranked recruiting class.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks after winning its second consecutive national championship — and the third in four seasons — Alabama won the 2013 recruiting title, at least according to the sites ESPN.com, Rivals.com and 247Sports.

headline: Dispersing Steichens Across the Country
abstract: More than 140 vintage photographs by Edward Steichen are being donated to museums in New York, Los Angeles and Evanston, Ill.; the Queens Museum is undergoing a $68 million renovation.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago the Los Angeles financier Richard Hollander and his wife, Jackie, bought more than 500 Edward Steichen photographs directly from his estate. And in one fell swoop the Hollanders became known for having what experts say is the world’s largest private collection of Steichen works. Their holdings cover all periods — the celebrity and fashion images, the early landscapes and city scenes, the fantastical ads — and each image was printed by Steichen himself, which makes the collection highly coveted.

headline: 36 Hours in Melbourne, Australia
abstract: Home to street art, buzzing cafes and a cool bar scene, Australia’s second city is charged with creative energy.
lead_paragraph: The fact that Melbourne, the capital of the Australian state of Victoria, regularly appears near the top of lists ranking the world’s most livable cities says a lot about its efficiency, cleanliness and safety. What that recognition doesn’t immediately reveal is how Melbourne is now arguably the most exciting city for food Down Under — something the annual Melbourne Food and Wine Festival (melbournefoodandwine.com.au), running March 1 to 17 this year, should help highlight. But even more noteworthy is the city’s distinctive creative energy, manifested everywhere, from flourishing street art and a cool bar scene to homegrown boutiques and buzzing back-street cafes. When even cosmopolitan Sydney talks of “Melbournising,” it’s clear that something special is happening in Oz’s second city.

headline: Melbourne, From Art to Vinyl
abstract: On a trip around the Australian city, shop boutiques, browse museums and even grab a drink in the middle of a river.
lead_paragraph: On a trip around the Australian city, shop boutiques, browse museums and even grab a drink in the middle of a river.

headline: Teaching Orwell and ‘1984’ With The Times
abstract: Why does Orwell still endure? What does “1984” have to say to us today? Use our teaching ideas and lists of Times resources past and present to help … and find a list of many more works of literature we suggest “teaching with The Times.”
lead_paragraph: The famous “1984” Apple Macintosh commercial, which ran during that year’s Super Bowl.

headline: The Great Refrainer
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Amity Shlaes depicts Calvin Coolidge as a paragon of a president, less for what he did than for what he did not do.
lead_paragraph: This past December the Claremont Institute convened a forum at the Ronald Reagan Building in Washington to discuss the presidential election. The mood among the conservative stalwarts during the reception may have ranged from pensive to glum, but it brightened somewhat when Clare­mont’s panelists contemplated a return to true Republican principles as advanced by the last president to slash both taxes and the federal budget — Calvin Coolidge. James Ceaser, a political scientist at the University of Virginia and a regular contributor to The Weekly Standard, said it was important to revive the “moral stigma” of debt, and added, “I want to go back to Coolidge and even McKinley.” The Claremont fellow Charles Kesler, author of “I Am the Change,” a recent book denouncing President Obama and liberalism, agreed: “We’re in for a Coolidge revival.”

headline: Transforming a Once-Seedy Stretch of Venice, Calif.
abstract: In this bohemian Los Angeles enclave, boutiques, design stores and even a curiosity or two are popping up along Rose Avenue.
lead_paragraph: In this bohemian Los Angeles enclave, boutiques, design stores and even a curiosity or two are popping up along Rose Avenue.

abstract: A kindness movement advocates surprising strangers with small gifts or nice behavior.
lead_paragraph: It may be Valentine’s Day, but this morning still felt like most mornings do at my house — that is, like a fire drill.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Berry Lip
abstract: On the runway this week: deeply stained lip smacks at 3.1 Phillip Lim, Vera Wang and Oscar de la Renta.
lead_paragraph: A deeply stained lip smacks with film-noir-like allure and Park Avenue polish: 3.1 Phillip Lim presented an option for every woman; Vera Wang kept it modern with a clean face and flowing tresses; and Oscar de la Renta had his girls recall golden-era Hollywood starlets with slicked hair and chandelier earrings.

headline: How Lightning Tightens Apple’s Control Over Accessories
abstract: When the iPhone 5 was released in September with the new Lightning connection port, all those docks and accessories that longtime Apple customers had been collecting for years were suddenly obsolete. But it has taken a long time for new accessories compatible with Lightning to hit the market. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: When the iPhone 5 was released in September with the new Lightning connection port, all those docks and accessories that longtime Apple customers had been collecting for years were suddenly obsolete. But Lightning-compatible accessories have been trickling in more slowly than the typical flood of Apple accessories that comes after a new iPhone release. Why?

headline: Can You Capture the Soul of Your Business in a Photo?
abstract: If so, send it to us. No product shots, no marketing shots. We want photos that capture what it means to run a small business.
lead_paragraph: Introducing the Small Picture.

headline: Lautenberg, Oldest Member of Senate, Won’t Run Again
abstract: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, 89, of New Jersey, will vacate a seat that Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark has said he will pursue.
lead_paragraph: Facing a fight for his seat from within his own party, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey said Thursday that he will retire rather than seek a sixth term next year.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Government Malware and Education Disruption
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include a growing global market in previously unknown security flaws in popular software, an app that erases your old lover from Facebook (just in time for Valentine’s Day) and an expert on innovative disruption saying education is next.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Love Conquers All, Except the Partisan Divide
abstract: A new Fox News poll finds that when Americans look for someone to share Valentine’s Day with, odds are they are not casting their eyes across the political aisle.
lead_paragraph: A new Fox News poll has found that when Americans look for someone to share Valentine’s Day with, odds are they are not casting their eyes across the political aisle.

headline: $5 Million Gift to Aid Juilliard Program for Minority Students
abstract: A $5 million gift from Harriet Heyman and Michael Moritz will help the school’s Music Advancement Program.
lead_paragraph: The Juilliard School said on Thursday that it had been promised a $5 million gift that will go a long way toward guaranteeing the survival of music lessons for poor minority schoolchildren. The money comes courtesy of a former journalist turned venture capitalist, Michael Moritz, and his wife, Harriet Heyman, a writer.

headline: Fat Dad: Baking for Love
abstract: My grandmother Beauty always told me that the way to a man’s heart was through his stomach, and I had no doubt that when the time came, and I liked a boy, that a batch of my gooey, rich, chocolaty brownies would cast him under a magic spell, and we would live happily ever.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother Beauty always told me that the way to a man’s heart was through his stomach, and by the look of pure delight on my dad’s face when he ate a piece of warm, homemade chocolate cake, or bit into a just-baked crispy cookie, I grew to believe this was true. I had no doubt that when the time came, and I liked a boy, that a batch of my gooey, rich, chocolatey brownies would cast him under a magic spell, and we would live happily ever.

headline: Europe Rejects Critics of ‘Robin Hood’ Tax

abstract: Algirdas Semeta, the European commissioner drafting the rules, said the levy on financial transactions was “fully compliant with international tax law.”
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European regulators on Thursday defended plans to create the first international tax on financial transactions after business groups in the United States warned that the levy could break international agreements.

headline: Weighing Down Heinz With Debt
abstract: The buyout deal for Heinz will turn it into a much riskier company that will have to operate with a much larger amount of debt on its books.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett deployed his avuncular charm on Thursday when talking about Berkshire Hathaway’s proposed acquisition of H.J. Heinz. The food company’s chief executive, William R. Johnson, said the deal was a natural next step that wouldn’t lead to big upheavals any time soon.

headline: When Calvin Klein Met Glen Plaid
abstract: As the dark, dark, fall collections enter their home stretch, we may as well go ahead and declare a winner as Fashion Week’s MVT. (That is Most Valuable Trend.) He is Mr. Glen Plaid.
lead_paragraph: As the dark, dark, fall collections enter their home stretch, and even with the big Marc Jacobs show still to come tonight, we may as well go ahead and declare a winner as Fashion Week’s MVT. (That is, Most Valuable Trend.)

headline: Syrian Rebels Claim Near Control of a Key Province
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: Dominating the oil-rich Hasaka province would mark a third major gain this week by insurgents, who also took a hydropower dam and an air base.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian insurgency claimed on Thursday to have near-total control of a strategically important province in the country’s northeast, home to some of the few remaining domestic oil production facilities that supply fuel for President Bashar al-Assad’s military forces, after ferocious clashes that lasted for three days.

headline: Oscar Pistorius, the Blade Runner in Repose
abstract: Outtakes from Pieter Hugo’s photo shoot with Oscar Pistorius, the South African runner.
lead_paragraph: Pieter Hugo, whose photographs accompanied Michael Sokolove’s profile of the South African runner Oscar Pistorius last year, shared with us these outtakes from his photo shoot. Hugo recently photographed the South African businessman and politician Cyril Ramaphosa for the magazine.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. and A. With Diane Kendal
abstract: The British-born, Brooklyn-based makeup artist is the go-to pro for many of New York’s hottest young designers.
lead_paragraph: The British-born, Brooklyn-based makeup artist is the go-to pro for many of New York’s hottest young designers including Jason Wu, Thakoon and Alexander Wang. T caught up with Diane Kendal backstage at the Proenza Schouler show and asked her about the look she created, what inspires her work and her Fashion Week experience.

headline: Updates on the Disabled Carnival Cruise Ship
abstract: The Lede talked to passengers and posted reaction as the ill-fated Carnival cruise line makes its long journey back to land on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Carnival Cruise Line ship Triumph has reached port in Mobile, Ala., and for the 4,200 hungry, scared and unwashed people who were hoping finally to get off the lifeless Triumph cruise ship by Friday morning, the fetid ordeal of five days adrift in the Gulf of Mexico should soon be over.

lead_paragraph: A ski area report card issued this week by an environmental coalition ranks Utah’s Park City Mountain Resort first, granting it an A, and Arizona Snowbowl in Flagstaff dead last, with a D.

headline: One Step Toward Rethinking Taxes
abstract: A proposal by Dave Camp of the House Ways and Means Committee would change the way derivatives are taxed and the way capital gains are calculated.
lead_paragraph: Tax reform, at least in American politics these days, is generally discussed at only the most abstract level. There is general agreement that it would be nice to lower tax rates while broadening the base by getting rid of loopholes. The latter, of course, are seldom specified in any detail, and are very much in the eye of the beholder.

headline: Bloomberg Endorses Preparing Parking Spaces for E.V. Charging
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Parking', 'State of the City Message (NYC)']
abstract: The mayor says he wants New York City to be a “national leader” in electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: In his final State of the City address on Thursday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced plans to make New York City a “national leader” in electric vehicles. He said he would work with the City Council to amend the building code and require up to 20 percent of all new public parking spaces be set up for electric vehicle charging, which could lead to “10,000 parking spots for electric vehicles over the next seven years.”

headline: Youkilis Arrives Early, Colorful History in Tow
abstract: Kevin Youkilis, who was acquired in the off-season to play third base, arrived early to Yankees training camp, eager to get the lay of the land.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The new guy walked purposefully through the Yankees’ clubhouse Thursday morning, his face framed by a white shirt and golf cap. He looked passably familiar, like a casual acquaintance you have not seen in a while, and it took most people a few seconds to put Kevin Youkilis’s name to the clean-shaven face.

headline: Theater Talkback: Better Off Buried
abstract: In the last couple of seasons the New York theater has taken its love affair with its own past to perverse new extremes by trying to resurrect notorious flops.
lead_paragraph: It’s news to nobody that the contemporary theater thrives on nostalgia. Scan the offerings of any Broadway season of the past decade or so and you’ll probably find more revivals than new shows. This season alone we’ve seen spectacularly unnecessary celebrity-fueled productions of “Glengarry Glen Ross,” “The Heiress” and “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.” Money-minting duds, all three of ’em.

headline: Interpreters’ Accomplishments Fail to Translate Into Visas
abstract: On the battlefield, individuals with language skills are rare and highly prized. Once their job is done, however, they do not always receive much protection from the militaries they serve.
lead_paragraph: On the battlefield, individuals with language skills are rare and highly prized. “Your interpreter is way more important than your weapon,” explained Cory Schulz, an Army major embedded with Afghan troops. Indeed, an adept interpreter can help a soldier avoid the need to use a weapon in the first place. An interpreter in the field not only translates sentences from one language into another, but can help identify a local accent or tell soldiers what the graffiti on a wall means while peering out of a moving vehicle. Small actions like these, while not technically even part of the interpreter’s job description, often protect troops by keeping them out of harm’s way.

lead_paragraph: A Bahraini teenager was shot and killed during clashes with the kingdom’s security forces Thursday, on the second anniversary of the start of the protest movement calling for reforms on the Arab island.

headline: Memories of Bubble Denial Past
abstract: Barney Frank inflated the bubble we insisted didn’t exist!
lead_paragraph: A further thought on the “Barney Frank did it” view of the housing crisis that has become GOP orthodoxy, and was regurgitated by Marco Rubio: at the time when evil liberals were supposedly forcing helpless bankers to lend into a housing bubble, leading to crisis, pretty much the very same people now claiming that it was all the government’s fault were vehemently denying that there was a bubble — and asserting that the only reason anyone even imagined that there might be a housing crisis looming was the malign impact of the biased liberal media.

headline: The Gift Was as Flimsy as My Rationale
abstract: The parameters for a Valentine’s Day gift seem to have narrowed, making choosing one for someone you love even more challenging.
lead_paragraph: Like most people, I try to be pragmatic when it comes to buying gifts. I’m told that I tend to over-think things like this, which may have something to do with my having Asperger syndrome, but I fail to see the problem with my over-thinking. On the contrary, devising a formal process for gift giving has made my life easier in a number of ways, especially when shopping for my wife, Kristen.

headline: Worth Your Weight
abstract: Dealing with gym discounts, background checks on the Internet, helpful warnings, incorrect responses to e-mail and which bathroom to use.
lead_paragraph: An acquaintance told me he was interested in joining my gym. I asked if he would mention my name when he did, because I would receive a free month as a referral bonus. He said he would like a cut of it. I thought he was joking and told him there was no cash involved, and the conversation ended. Recently, he let me know he had joined my gym and used my name, and would like part of my bonus. How should I respond? I never agreed to anything.

headline: Beer Duopoly Averted
abstract: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the country and world’s largest beer company, announced concessions in its bid to take full control of Groupo Modelo.
lead_paragraph: The threat of an unassailable American beer duopoly has receded. In response to a Department of Justice lawsuit, Anheuser-Busch InBev, the country and world’s largest beer company, announced significant concessions on Thursday in its bid to take full control of Groupo Modelo, a Mexican brewing company. The changes should go a long way toward addressing the competition concerns of American regulators, though they will do little to address the growing concentration of the beer industry globally.

abstract: The call for “peace through dialogue” with the Pakistani Taliban came after a day of talks by representatives of 27 political parties.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Representatives from many of Pakistan’s political parties Thursday called on their government to engage in peace talks with the Pakistani Taliban, on a day when continuing militant violence in the country’s northwest killed at least 18 people.

headline: A Lincoln for Our Time
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In “Lincoln’s Tragic Pragmatism,” John Burt highlights the difficulties Lincoln confronted in steering between philosophical principle and practical politics.
lead_paragraph: There have been many ways to think about Abraham Lincoln, our most enigmatic president, but the image of him as a moral philosopher is not the most obvious. We have “Honest Abe,” the great rail-splitter of American legend, Lincoln the political operative and architect of the Republican Party, and Lincoln the savvy wielder of executive power as portrayed in Steven Spielberg’s recent film.

headline: Senate Democrats Offer a Proposal to Head Off Automatic Cuts
abstract: Even though Senate Democrats reached agreement on a $110 billion mix of tax increases and spending cuts, the chances of a deal to head off automatic spending cuts have still receded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democratic leaders reached agreement Thursday on a $110 billion mix of tax increases and spending cuts to head off automatic spending cuts through the end of the year. But with even some Democrats tepid on the proposal, the chances of a deal before the March 1 deadline have receded.

headline: Try Freedom: Less Filling! Tastes Great!
abstract: The campaign to remove Pinochet from rule in Chile becomes an advertiser’s job in “No,” with Gael García Bernal.
lead_paragraph: Marshall McLuhan called advertising the greatest art form of the 20th century. In “No,” Pablo Larraín’s sly, smart, fictionalized tale about the art of the sell during a fraught period in Chilean history, advertising isn’t only an art; it’s also a way of life. That’s certainly true for the young adman, Rene Saavedra (Gael García Bernal), who skateboards through the movie, pausing now and again to care for his son or dash off another ad campaign. When approached to help create one to oust Gen. Augusto Pinochet, he signs on. Rene may be vaguely interested in selling the country on life without Pinochet, but what reels him in is the challenge of pitching a superior product.

headline: That Tesla Data: What It Says and What It Doesn’t
abstract: About three hours into the trip, the reporter placed the first of about a dozen calls to Tesla personnel expressing concern about the car’s declining range.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla Motors, has now responded in detail to the account of my test drive of his Model S electric car, using the company’s new East Coast Superchargers, that was published in The Times on Feb. 10. His broadest charge is that I consciously set out to sabotage the test. That is not so. I was delighted to receive the assignment to try out the company’s new East Coast Supercharger network and as I previously noted in no way anticipated – or deliberately caused – the troubles I encountered.

headline: Tenderness, and Steely Flint
abstract: If Patti LuPone were to be cast in certain roles in “Funny Girl” or “Music Man” ... well, she’s prepared, with a repertory of her favorite songs.
lead_paragraph: When Patti LuPone sang “My Way” at 54 Below on Wednesday evening, one phrase elicited a spontaneous burst of laughter from the packed house: “To think I did all that; and may I say, not in a shy way.”

headline: A Little Wizardry and Some Label-Defying Muscle
abstract: Toro y Moi moved away from chillwave in a show at Webster Hall on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Chillwave may or may not have been a proper wave, but it was definitely chill. A couple of years ago, artists were saddled with that tag for making music that was downtempo, cloudy, melancholy, anesthetizing. One could rightly have floated through the time period, lightly lulled and never challenged.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Feb. 15-21
abstract: A selected guide to art exhibitions and installations in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Art

headline: Proust, for Those With a Memory
abstract: “Marcel Proust and ‘Swann’s Way’: 100th Anniversary,” at the Morgan Library, celebrates the centennial of the first volume of “Remembrance of Things Past.”
lead_paragraph: A cosmos is compressed into cryptic hieroglyphs in the Clare Eddy Thaw Gallery of the Morgan Library & Museum. Here is an exhibition so condensed, so distilled and in some ways so abstract and well suited to the gallery’s geometric space (which is a perfect cube), that unless you arrive properly prepared, you might leave as bewildered as prospective French publishers were when they rejected Marcel Proust’s “Du Côté de Chez Swann” (“Swann’s Way”), more than a century ago.

headline: Michael Bastian and Mark McNairy Walked Into a Bar …
abstract: Michael Bastian makes classic American sportswear for men with exceptionally well-tailored proportions and a jigger of wit. So does Mark McNairy.
lead_paragraph: Michael Bastian makes classic American sportswear for men with exceptionally well-tailored proportions and a jigger of wit. So does Mark McNairy. And yet no two designers could possibly come up with results that appear more different, even though we are only talking about sweaters and suits here.Mr. Bastian’s collection, which was shown Tuesday, was one of his strongest, and it also appeared more extravagant than usual, staged inside a dilapidated ballroom in the Hotel Pennsylvania with a goth edge to the styling. Mr. Bastian is a designer who takes any opportunity to shine a sunny light on a well-defined abdomen, so it was surprising to see him in such a dark mood, hating on preps.

headline: A Roar, From the Side Without the Lions
abstract: A proposal for the New York Public Library raises a question: Can a building’s back be its best side?
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of shouting going on at the New York Public Library. But the argument is not about the sumptuous marble face — it’s about the utilitarian backside. If the New York Public Library has its way, this facade will no longer stand guard over a warehouse of books, but a light-flooded reading room.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Grand Lighting
abstract: Chandeliers fit for the palaces of French royalty set a romantic ambiance and lit designer’s visions at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Grand chandeliers fit for the palaces of French royalty softly lit designer’s visions setting a romantic ambiance. Jason Wu had his girls in gowns walk around his Phantom of the Opera-esque version; Tory Burch kept things posh at the Pierre for her uptown woman; and Ralph Lauren took a trip to Aspen via Moscow with his staghead candelabras.

headline: A Time of Danger and Pain, Two Long Decades Ago
abstract: “NYC 1993” is the New Museum’s big time-capsule show of art of an unusually urgent moral and political texture.
lead_paragraph: History is written by the winners, which in contemporary art means the market. It’s often also written by people who weren’t on the scene and have to take the winners’ word for what happened and what mattered. Such is the case in the exhibition called “NYC 1993: Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star” at the New Museum, a big time capsule of a show — it fills the museum top to bottom — assembled by curators who were in their teens or younger during the year examined.

headline: A Fateful Day in 1963: A Composer’s View
abstract: Steven Mackey’s “One Red Rose” was given its premiere during a concert by the Brentano String Quartet on Tuesday at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: “My name is Franz Joseph Haydn, and I wrote the piece you just heard,” the composer Steven Mackey brightly announced from the Zankel Hall stage during a concert by the Brentano String Quartet there on Tuesday evening.

headline: No Charges for Detective in a Killing of a Driver
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A Queens grand jury voted not to indict the detective, who fired at the motorist during a highway traffic stop in October.
lead_paragraph: A Queens grand jury voted to not indict a decorated detective who fatally shot an unarmed driver during a highway traffic stop last year, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said on Thursday.

headline: Another Cog in the Machinery of Divahood
abstract: The autobiographical documentary “Beyoncé: Life Is but a Dream,” Saturday on HBO, is a song-and-dance defense brief on behalf of a celebrity who is feeling misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of great performers who can be likened to Beyoncé, but Nina Simone isn’t one of them.

headline: Tony Awards Eligibility Panel Skirts an Orphan vs. Orphan-Keeper Battle
abstract: Lilla Crawford, the title star of “Annie,” will be eligible for the best actress in a musical prize, while Katie Finneran, the show’s Miss Hannigan, will be eligible for the supporting actress award.
lead_paragraph: Little orphan Annie and the villainous Miss Hannigan may be arch-enemies in the Broadway musical “Annie,” but the actresses playing them will not be facing off this spring at the 2013 Tony Awards.

headline: The Seriousness of Fun in Postwar Japan
abstract: “Gutai: Splendid Playground,” at the Guggenheim Museum, is the first large, in-depth exhibition devoted to the postwar Gutai movement and the first to cover so thoroughly its panoply of mediums.
lead_paragraph: Color is taking it easy at the start of the Guggenheim Museum’s “Gutai: Splendid Playground,” a mind-shifting exhibition about Japan’s best-known postwar art movement. From the entrance you can see it almost lolling about overhead in the form of jewel-like dollops of water tinted red, yellow blue or green. Each occupies one of 16 tubes of plastic that stretch across the rotunda like see-through hammocks.

headline: Performers From the West Coast Serve Up Balanchine
abstract: Pacific Northwest Ballet brings an all-Balanchine program to City Center.
lead_paragraph: When pure-dance choreography is realized powerfully, physics becomes drama: the way bodies meet time and space becomes galvanizing, suspenseful, momentous. And when the choreographer is George Balanchine, this drama is pursued by marrying high-density ballet classicism with music. The choreography’s geometries continually transform the feel of the whole box of air above and around the dancers onstage. At every moment new beams, arcs and paths open, as if to demonstrate the rhythms and structures of the music.

headline: Lovable Old Buffoon Tries to Buy Love
abstract: The Juilliard Opera’s fully staged production of “Don Pasquale,” Donizetti’s comedy, is directed by James Robinson and conducted by Stephen Lord.
lead_paragraph: While May-September relationships can happily flourish, the moral of Donizetti’s “Don Pasquale” is otherwise: Men of a certain age, steer clear of young spouses. Instead of appearing virile with a trophy wife at his side, the title character is humiliated as the sweet young girl he weds to produce heirs morphs into a “Real Housewives” shrew who has him fleeing back to bachelorhood.

headline: Service Cuts May Follow Merger of Airlines
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Some consumer advocates are warning that the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, if approved, could bring rising fees and fares as well as service cuts to smaller cities.
lead_paragraph: And then there were three.

headline: Glimpses of a Rave, Spasms of Distress
abstract: The first thing attendees learned when they arrived to watch Trajal Harrell at the Museum of Modern Art was that they would have to remove their shoes.
lead_paragraph: The first thing attendees learned when they arrived to watch Trajal Harrell’s “Used, Abused, and Hung Out to Dry” at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday night was that they would have to remove their shoes. The second was that they would not be watching “Used, Abused, and Hung Out to Dry.”

headline: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 15-21
abstract: A selected guide to events in New York for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘SESAME STREET LIVE: ELMO’S SUPER HEROES’

headline: Icahn Reveals His Stake in Herbalife
abstract: Carl C. Icahn has built up a 12.98 percent stake, or 14 million shares, in Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company, according to a filing on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn officially has a dog in the Herbalife fight.

headline: Just Another Deal Becomes Complicated
abstract: “Like Someone in Love” is a complicated triangle involving a prostitute, her pimp and a john.
lead_paragraph: According to Martin Scorsese, “cinema is a matter of what’s in the frame, and what’s out.” The Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami applies this axiom with particular rigor. In the first scenes of Mr. Kiarostami’s latest feature, “Like Someone in Love,” we are very much aware of what is not in the frame. We are in a Tokyo bar, listening to a series of conversations that involve a woman we cannot see.

headline: Wake Up, Princess, the Spell Is Over
abstract: The New York City Ballet opened its two-week run of Peter Martins’s sleek 1991 version of “The Sleeping Beauty,” which features one intermission and two acts instead of three.
lead_paragraph: Only at the New York City Ballet could the prospect of a two-week run of “The Sleeping Beauty” seem an unsatisfying turn of events, but this season’s array of mixed bills has been a luxurious escape from a cold and hard winter. Sara Mearns’s richly danced (and mimed) Lilac Fairy changed all that.

headline: Spare Times for Feb. 15-21
abstract: A listing of walking tours, readings, cultural events and more in  New York.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: Duke Energy Loan for Democrats’ Convention Remains Unpaid
abstract: Though President Obama pledged that Democrats would not take corporate money for their convention in Charlotte, a $10 million loan from Duke Energy has not been repaid.
lead_paragraph: When Duke Energy extended a $10 million line of credit to the committee organizing the Democratic convention in Charlotte, N.C., last summer, it seemed to be a sign that President Obama would not make good on his pledge to keep his party’s nominating festivities free of corporate favor banking.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Deborah Mace
abstract: The model Deborah Mace for Elite transforms, with makeup by Tina Turnbow.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper317 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: At the Altar of Renaissance Tuscany
abstract: “Piero della Francesca in America,” at the Frick Collection, reunites six panels from a single altarpiece, painted by Piero in the mid-to-late 15th century.
lead_paragraph: According to local legend, the Tuscan town of Sansepolcro was founded when relics carried by two pilgrims returning from the Holy Land suddenly appeared in the branches of a tall tree. The pilgrims decided to stay put, building an oratory for the treasures; a village took shape around this miraculous site.

headline: The Naked Face
abstract: Achieving the new natural look requires a specific arsenal of nearly-there makeup. A primer on minimalism.
lead_paragraph: Does anyone remember Way Bandy? It’s been more than three decades since the publication of his best-selling book, “Designing Your Face,” and more than two decades since he died in 1986 at age 45. Bandy, who, from the early 1970s on, worked on the faces of models and celebrities — everyone from Cheryl Tiegs to Cher — was the first maestro of maquillage. In an age before Pat McGrath and Bobbi Brown, before the invention of the superstar makeup artist (Kevyn Aucoin worshiped him), Bandy was paid thousands an hour and flown far and wide for his skills with applying pigment. He did so in such a way that the personality of the woman was felt to come through, enhanced by his touch — although he was also known for his ability to transform a woman’s face entirely, when the occasion called for it. Read on …

headline: CBS Corp. Set Record In Earnings For Quarter
abstract: Although the company’s overall results improved in most financial categories and divisions, they fell short of some analysts’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: The CBS Corporation set records in the fourth quarter for operating income and adjusted operating income, the company said Thursday, but the results were short of some analysts’ expectations and its share price fell in after-hours trading.

headline: Powering an Enclave With Dosas
abstract: Between the plates of spiced chickpeas, flatbreads and black pepper cashews, Usha Foods provides the taste of a homeland for immigrant South Asian families.
lead_paragraph: After much debate, it was decided: masala dosas all around.

headline: 2 Female Biographers ‘Find’ 2 Female Historians
abstract: Two new biographies cover the female antiquarians Sarah Losh and Alice Morse Earle, who invented themselves and became famous but unfortunately did not preserve their own archives.
lead_paragraph: Nineteenth-century female historians with minimal formal education but ambition and numerous servants documented world events in ways that are still admired and quoted.

headline: Death Spoke to a Painter, as Life Did, Too
abstract: “Artist and Visionary: William Matthew Prior Revealed,” at the American Folk Art Museum, consists of portraits illustrating this painter’s idealism and versatility.
lead_paragraph: Antique folk art is usually admired for its soulful simplicity and unaffected directness. It seems to reflect a kind of life — traditional, rural, organic — that our hyper-complicated times have left far behind. What, then, are we to make of William Matthew Prior (1806-1873), the subject of a fascinating exhibition, “Artist and Visionary: William Matthew Prior Revealed,” at the American Folk Art Museum?

headline: Correctional Association, Now a Producer of a Lament Against the Police
abstract: Bryonn Bain has written and performs “Lyrics From Lockdown,” a solo show that’s the story of his unjustified 2002 arrest and detainment by the New York Police Department.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that you see the Correctional Association of New York listed among the producers of an Off Off Broadway show, much less a truly polished, meaningful and entertaining one. But there it is on the program of “Lyrics From Lockdown,” right below the National Black Theater and right above the father-and-daughter team Harry and Gina Belafonte. And for this subject, it makes sense. Bryonn Bain (whose first name rhymes with Leon) has written and performs the story of his ridiculously unjustified 2002 arrest and detainment by the New York Police Department as a spoken-word-poetry and musical solo show, heavy on the hip-hop but including calypso and blues. He has style and considerable talent, and his lyrics — a stirring mix of lament and demand — pack a punch.

headline: Studios Have Differing Responses to Visual Effects Company’s Financial Woes
abstract: Two studios that are supplied by the company, called Rhythm and Hues, are extending credit, but a third, Warner Brothers, is not.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—As expected, Rhythm and Hues, the El Segundo, Calif.-based visual effects supplier, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, and the filing shows that its principal customers—20th Century Fox, Universal Studios and Warner Brothers—have split in their approach to the company’s financial woes.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 8
abstract: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Theater Listings for Feb. 15-21
abstract: A selected guide to theater performances in New York, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Theater

headline: Environmental Group Targets Spewing Buildings in Pollution Report
abstract: The Urban Green Council is calling largely for greater efficiency and common-sense moves to reduce carbon emissions in New York City, where homes and offices release more carbon than motor vehicles.
lead_paragraph: When people consider the prime sources of carbon gas emissions in New York City, cars, trucks and buses belching smoke are often the first culprits to come to mind.

headline: S.E.C. Looks at Trades a Day Before Heinz Deal
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is said to have opened an insider trading inquiry to scrutinize unusually robust options trading ahead of the $23 billion takeover of the food company H.J. Heinz.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are scrutinizing unusual trading surrounding the planned $23 billion takeover of the food company H. J. Heinz, raising questions about potential illegal activity in one of the biggest deals in recent memory, a person briefed on the matter said.

headline: After Strong I.P.O., Russia’s Main Stock Exchange Begins Trading
abstract: The exchange priced near the bottom of the expected range, valuing the company at about $4 billion.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s main stock exchange has garnered enough investor interest for an initial public offering, another milestone in the country’s capitalist evolution.

headline: What I Wish My Financial Aid Applications Revealed
abstract: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student in New Delhi who is applying to universities in the United States, wants to assure her prospective colleges that she is “a worthy investment who will give them manifold returns.”
lead_paragraph: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student from New Delhi, is part of “The Choice” class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her seventh post is below. — Tanya Abrams

headline: The Mother Country Knows Best
abstract: In “Shanghai Calling” a haughty Chinese-American corporate lawyer gets his comeuppance when he is sent to China to work on a big deal.
lead_paragraph: On the surface Daniel Hsia’s “Shanghai Calling” traces an American’s moral comeuppance. But underneath it is a plug for the emerging China, manifested in its most populous city.

headline: After Strong I.P.O., Russia’s Main Stock Exchange Begins Trading
abstract: The Moscow Exchange, better known by its original name, Micex, for the Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange, is scheduled to begin trading Friday in Moscow on its own trading platform.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s main stock exchange has garnered enough investor interest for an initial public offering, another milestone in the country’s capitalist evolution.

headline: With an Income Stream in View
abstract: Pamela Capalad and Brian Kushner decided to buy a two- or three-family house in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Pamela Capalad moved to New York, her mother urged her to buy a house rather than pay rent. That was five years ago.

headline: Now Streaming | Marc Jacobs Fall 2013 Women’s Collection
abstract: The Spring 2013 women’s collection show from Marc Jacobs at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Bloomberg’s First and Last State of the City Addresses
keywords: ['State of the City Message (NYC)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: New York City was a vastly different place when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave his first State of the City address in 2002, and his focus has shifted on various issues.
lead_paragraph: New York City was a vastly different place when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave his first State of the City address in 2002, and his focus has shifted on various issues.

headline: Bloomberg’s State of the City Speeches
abstract: A look at the evolution of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his stewardship of New York City.
lead_paragraph: A look at the evolution of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his stewardship of New York City.

headline: Blackstone Keeps Most of Its Money With SAC
abstract: The Blackstone Group said it would keep most of its $550 million with SAC Capital Advisors for three more months, as the hedge fund’s clients faced a regularly scheduled quarterly deadline on Thursday to decide whether to continue investing.
lead_paragraph: 9:06 p.m. | Updated

headline: Getting to Know a Serial Killer
abstract: Chris James Thompson’s documentary uses restraint to explore about the skin-crawling crimes of Jeffrey Dahmer from three wildly different — yet equally intimate — perspectives.
lead_paragraph: Viewing the crimes of its subject from three wildly different — yet equally intimate — perspectives “The Jeffrey Dahmer Files” compellingly illuminates how the monsters among us leave more than corpses in their wake.

headline: The Shape of Memory, Both Fragile and Fierce
abstract: In the gorgeous new production of “The Glass Menagerie” at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., something both momentous and commonplace has happened.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The movement is small, abrupt and oddly graceful for an act of clumsiness. It happens so fast that you’re surprised that you didn’t miss it. Then again, how could you have?

headline: Blackhawks’ Road Feat Has Home Fans Roaring
abstract: Chicago returned from a six-game trip with a 10-0-2 record, and its season-opening 13-game stretch without a regulation loss is three games from an N.H.L. record.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — During the national anthem at Chicago Blackhawks home games, the fans not only rise, but cheer, hoot and holler at the top of their lungs.

headline: The Benefits of Combining
abstract: American Airlines and US Airways currently have hubs in complementary regions. If the merger between the two airlines is approved, the combined carrier will have a strong presence across the nation.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines and US Airways currently have hubs in complementary regions. If the merger between the two airlines is approved, the combined carrier will have a strong presence across the nation.

headline: The Man Who Protected Lincoln
abstract: In “Saving Lincoln” Salvador Litvak tells the story of Lincoln’s de facto bodyguard, using a process that puts actors into virtual sets created from vintage Civil War photographs.
lead_paragraph: Note to filmmakers: Just because you can do something doesn’t necessarily mean you should do it. A case in point is Salvador Litvak’s “Saving Lincoln,” a film about Abraham Lincoln and his de facto bodyguard that was made with a new process that involved filming actors in front of a green screen then inserting them into virtual sets created out of vintage Civil War photographs.

headline: U.S. Report Criticizes Battery Company’s Grant Management
abstract: The plant in Holland, Mich., has yet to “manufacture battery cells that could be used in electric vehicles sold to the public,” a memo with the report says.
lead_paragraph: A new federal report released Wednesday painted a devastating portrait of how a battery supplier, LG Chem Michigan, handled a 2010 grant of more than $150 million in Recovery Act financing to build a battery cell plant. The report describes an idled company with workers using company time to volunteer for organizations like Habitat for Humanity, animal shelters and nature centers, to watch movies and to play board and video games. The company says that slower-than-expected electric vehicle sales are to blame.

headline: You Have to Be There to Feel It
abstract: The designers at Proenza Schouler demonstrate that fashion is still a tactile experience.
lead_paragraph: Much of fashion is now designed, produced and experienced on a computer. When Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler held up a fuzzy sweater seamlessly connected to a leather hem and said, “It’s done on a computer,” he meant that literally. A machine had been programmed to punch fine hairs of yarn into leather until the harder surface of the leather gradually dissolved into a soft knit.

headline: ‘NYC 1993’
abstract: Images from the New Museum’s exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Images from the New Museum’s exhibition.

headline: Uphill Road for Plan to Cut Government’s Drug Costs
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Medicaid', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Extending Medicaid’s drug discounts to low-income seniors on Medicare is likely to face staunch opposition.
lead_paragraph: In just a handful of words in his State of the Union address, President Obama renewed a proposal to lower the amount that the federal government pays for drugs taken by low-income seniors — a measure that supporters say would save the government more than $150 billion over the next decade. But it faces formidable opposition from Republicans, some Democrats and the powerful pharmaceutical industry, making passage unlikely.

headline: Holiday Monday
abstract: Washington’s Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday, Feb. 18.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday, Feb. 18.

headline: Rem I. Vyakhirev, Former Chief of Gazprom, Dies at 78
abstract: As chief of the large Russian energy company, Mr. Vyakhirev resisted efforts by Russian reformers to break up and privatize it.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Rem I. Vyakhirev, who as chief executive of the huge Russian energy company Gazprom during the 1990s resisted efforts by reformers to break up and privatize it, only to end his tenure a billionaire owning valuable pieces of the company himself, died on Monday. He was 78.

headline: Bill Eadington, Economist and Gambling Expert, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Eadington was one of the first academics to study gambling, as both a force for economic development and a challenging social problem.
lead_paragraph: Bill Eadington, an economist who was one of the first academics to study gambling, as both a force for economic development and a challenging social problem, died on Monday in Crystal Bay, Nev. He was 67.

headline: A New Laundry Worry: Invisible Stains
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps']
abstract: Wisk, the detergent once known for its “Ring around the collar” ads, is beginning an online campaign focused on unseen spots from sweat and body oil.
lead_paragraph: SO memorable was the “Ring around the collar” campaign introduced by Wisk in 1968 that the laundry detergent continued to use it for more than three decades. But while removing stains remains a popular claim from detergents today, Wisk is now hanging such claims out to dry.

headline: City Eligibility Policy for Homeless People Seeking Shelter Was Enacted Illegally, Court Says
abstract: A state appeals court did not rule on New York City’s policy requiring homeless adults seeking shelter to prove they had no alternative housing, only on how it was put into effect.
lead_paragraph: A state appeals court ruled on Thursday that the way New York City enacted a policy requiring homeless adults to prove that they had no alternative housing before being allowed into shelters was illegal.

headline: Three’s Company, Twice Over
abstract: In mostly two unbroken takes Sam Neave’s “Almost in Love” looks at three friends whose relationships are strained by love and sex.
lead_paragraph: In the opening of Robert Altman’s 1992 classic, “The Player,” a studio executive bemoans the MTV-induced tendency toward overediting: “Cut, cut, cut, cut,” he complains. This is not a problem in Sam Neave’s “Almost in Love,” a fascinating exercise in which the camera hovers around a group of young adults, drifting between conversations, only fading to leap from a Staten Island high-rise terrace at dusk to a beachfront Hamptons home at sunrise months later. Mostly the film is two unbroken takes and a bravura display of hand-held camerawork, sound design and improvisational performance.

headline: Utility Critics Seek Advocate for Customers in New York
abstract: Saying New York utilities are poorly prepared for storms like Hurricane Sandy, consumer advocates want Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to create an independent office to fight for residents’ interests.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, New Yorkers have harshly criticized their utilities, saying they are poorly prepared for big storms and respond too slowly to repair the damage. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has sympathized and has called for comprehensive changes, including dissolving the Long Island Power Authority and increasing the powers of the state’s main regulator of utilities, the Public Service Commission.

headline: Proposal Gives Banks More Freedom to Value Assets
abstract: A plan by the Financial Accounting Standards Board would substantially reduce the use of market values in financial statements.
lead_paragraph: The board that sets American accounting rules moved on Wednesday to substantially reduce the use of market values in financial statements. The move, if adopted, would give banks more freedom to value financial assets as they deem appropriate.

headline: Threatened by Foe and Friend
abstract: An arms deal gone sour lifts the lid on a rat’s nest of espionage for a North Korean spy who’s been left out in the cold in “The Berlin File.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Berlin File,” a film with a title out of a paperback spy thriller, the South Korean filmmaker Ryoo Seung-wan (“The Unjust”) brings his brand of muscular action and quicksilver agility to the shifting battleground of international espionage. A North Korean spy left out in the cold must negotiate threats posed by friend and foe alike, as a bone-crunching story of survival emerges, almost too late, out of the fog of intrigue.

headline: See Photos Now: Marc Jacobs
abstract: See photos now of the Fall 2013 collection from Marc Jacobs at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: See backstage, on and off the runway photos from select New York Fashion Week shows.

headline: Israel’s Prisoner X Is Linked to Dubai Assassination in a New Report
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: A report from Kuwait says Prisoner X, identified as an Australian-Israeli man, was involved in a 2010 assassination in Dubai and had provided “names and pictures” to the authorities there.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Australian-Israeli man recently identified as Prisoner X — found dead in 2010 in a maximum-security prison cell — may have been involved in the assassination of a Hamas leader that year, an episode that was among the most embarrassing in the history of Israel’s intelligence agency, Mossad.

headline: Governments Look for New Ways to Pay for Roads and Bridges
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Gasoline Tax (US)', 'States (US)', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Bridges and Tunnels']
abstract: As revenues from gasoline taxes fail to keep pace with the costs of transportation infrastructure, governments look for new solutions.
lead_paragraph: In the great taxation debate of 2013, there is another issue that is bedeviling lawmakers at the state and federal level.

headline: USA Hockey Waiting on N.H.L.’s Decision
abstract: Planning for the United States Olympic men’s hockey team is on hold until the N.H.L. decides whether to send its players to the Sochi Games next February, a USA Hockey official said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Planning for the United States Olympic men’s hockey team is on hold until the N.H.L. decides whether to send its players to Sochi, Russia, next February, a USA Hockey official said Thursday.

headline: Athlete’s Near-Death From Sepsis, and His Mysterious Recovery
abstract: The case of Ryan Eisner leaves questions about why the drug that saved him failed with other patients.
lead_paragraph: Five doctors hovered at the bed of Ryan Eisner, a cloud of white coats throwing a dark shadow over the star college athlete.

headline: Two Pitchers for Yanks Face Pivotal Season
abstract: The Yankees’ Phil Hughes, a first-rounder in 2004, and Joba Chamberlain, a 2006 first-rounder, are useful pitchers who could be elsewhere next season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: Confidence on Upswing, Mergers Make Comeback
abstract: Bankers and lawyers warn that it is still too early to declare a mergers-and-acquisitions boom like those during the junk bond craze of 1989, the dot-com bubble of 1999 and the leveraged buyout bonanza of 2007.
lead_paragraph: The mega-merger is back.

headline: Downton and Downward
abstract: While upward mobility in class-conscious Britain, and most of Western Europe, is rising, the American dream of opportunity is vanishing.
lead_paragraph: Like everyone else with a perverse curiosity about a castle-bound community fussing over whether to use a bouillon or a melon spoon, I’ve been consumed by the turns in “Downton Abbey,” the latest export from England to keep American public television afloat.

headline: Suicide Made Easier
abstract: When law-abiding gun owners don’t have foolproof controls at home, their families may be at risk.
lead_paragraph: The current gun control debate is focused, not surprisingly, on the carnage from rapid-firing assault weapons, like the one used in the Connecticut school massacre. But beneath the surface lies a disturbing reality: nearly two-thirds of the 30,000 gun deaths each year are not the work of deranged mass shooters but the  suicides of troubled individuals with easy access to firearms, often in quiet family homes.

headline: Pittsburgh’s Time of Transition
abstract: Pittsburgh has changed from an industrial city with many manufacturing jobs to a municipality with the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center as its largest employer.
lead_paragraph: The sprawling H. J. Heinz headquarters in Pittsburgh was turned into apartment lofts for the city’s growing creative class long ago. The famous five-story neon ketchup bottle that stood outside the headquarters has been moved to the wall of the city’s history museum.

headline: Why Syria’s Islamists Are Gaining
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In Aleppo, Islamists win support by showing a sense of direction and providing social services, while the Free Syrian Army displays no vision for the future.
lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria

headline: Official Details French Role in Mali
abstract: A senior State Department official said French forces would be needed for counterterrorism operations in the north.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — French military forces will probably be needed to carry out operations against militants in Mali even after a United Nations peacekeeping force is organized to secure the country, a senior State Department official told Congress on Thursday.

headline: Momentum and Uncertainty in Connecticut Gun Debate
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Law and Legislation', 'School Shootings', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: At a rally to expand state gun-control measures, advocates and lobbyists said they believed lawmakers wanted to pursue a bipartisan plan first and expand to more far-reaching legislation later.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — The chants echoed from more than 5,000 proponents of gun-control legislation who were gathered on the plaza and on 15-foot-tall mounds of snow on the north side of Connecticut’s ornate Capitol: “Now. Now. Now. Now.”

headline: Rubio and the Zombies
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Republican response to the State of the Union sure was revealing.
lead_paragraph: The State of the Union address was not, I’m sorry to say, very interesting. True, the president offered many good ideas. But we already know that almost none of those ideas will make it past a hostile House of Representatives.

headline: A Defense Secretary, Blocked by Politics
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Editorials']
abstract: Republicans use the filibuster to deny a vote on Chuck Hagel, President Obama’s nominee to lead the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: For the last four years, Senate Republicans have used the power of the filibuster to block legislation, bottle up nominees to courts and government departments, and strangle federal agencies, even though they are in the minority. On Thursday, they hit a new low. They successfully filibustered Chuck Hagel, President Obama’s nominee for defense secretary, the first time a cabinet nominee for this post has been prevented from receiving an up-or-down vote.

headline: Report Sees Journalists Increasingly Under Attack
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Committee to Protect Journalists said 70 news workers were killed on the job last year, a 43 percent rise from 2011.
lead_paragraph: A leading press advocacy group reported an alarming rise in the number of journalists killed and imprisoned around the world in 2012, attributing the trend to repressive laws, government intolerance of dissent and outright impunity for the killers that are endangering independent reporting in many countries.

headline: Health Care’s Good News
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Reform and Reorganization']
abstract: Shout it from the rooftops: costs are finally stabilizing.
lead_paragraph: THINK about it. When was the last time you heard the phrases “good news” and “health care costs” in the same sentence?

headline: Bloomberg's Last Annual Address
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his final State of the City address Thursday from the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his final State of the City address Thursday from the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Main Hurdle in Afghan Withdrawal: Getting the Gear Out
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: After 11-plus years of war, the American military faces a huge task in getting more than 600,000 pieces of equipment out of a landlocked country with bad roads.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the military begins carrying out President Obama’s order to cut force levels in Afghanistan by half over the next year, getting 34,000 troops out is the easy part: just deliver them to an airfield, march them by the hundreds onto transport planes and fly them home.

headline: When Families Fail
abstract: President Obama’s new prekindergarten initiative focuses on reform, as it should.
lead_paragraph: Today millions of American children grow up in homes where they don’t learn the skills they need to succeed in life. Their vocabularies are tiny. They can’t regulate their emotions. When they get to kindergarten they’ve never been read a book, so they don’t know the difference between the front cover and the back cover.

headline: Pistorius Has Inspired and Divided
abstract: In the world of track and field, Oscar Pistorius was inspiring and polarizing. Now, he is in police custody on murder charges.
lead_paragraph: A perp-walk photograph of Oscar Pistorius, accused of murder, his face shrouded by a hooded sweatshirt, provided a jarring contrast to a morning last August in London when he walked into Olympic Stadium, waving to the applause of 80,000 spectators.

headline: American Airlines Bulks Up
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Editorials']
abstract: Antitrust regulators should scrutinize a merger that could hurt consumers.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines and US Airways announced Thursday that they would merge, creating the world’s largest airline. The deal should cause antitrust regulators and the flying public grave concern because it would leave more than 70 percent of the passenger business in the hands of four behemoth airlines, which would have unassailable holds on most of their hub airports.

headline: San Diego Ex-Mayor Confronts $1 Billion Gambling Problem
abstract: Maureen O’Connor blamed an addiction aggravated by a brain tumor for a gargantuan spree that she financed in part by taking from her husband’s charity.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A former mayor of San Diego spent the last decade wagering more than a billion dollars at casinos across the country, eventually liquidating her savings, auctioning her belongings, selling off real estate, borrowing from friends and taking more than $2 million from a charity set up by her late husband, a fast-food tycoon.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg’s Latest
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Plastics', 'State of the City Message (NYC)', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new proposal to ban plastic foam containers makes sense for the environment and the city budget.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York, who has battled trans fats, smoking and giant-size sodas during his 11 years in office, has now proposed a citywide ban on plastic foam containers. Tucked into his State of the City address Thursday, along with other environmentally useful ideas, the proposal seeks to banish the ubiquitous plastic foam coffee cups and clamshell food containers from delicatessens, bodegas and school cafeterias.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: With most American and NATO troops set to leave by 2014, advocates of aid warn against a sharp cutoff of financing from the United States and its allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to bring home more than half of the American troops in Afghanistan over the next year is setting off intensified debate over an issue with big consequences for Afghanistan’s future: how long the United States and its allies should pour civilian aid into the country.

lead_paragraph: Jurors in the trial of a New York police officer charged with plotting to kidnap, cook and eat women will not be shown certain gruesome images and other evidence that could prejudice them against the defendant, a judge ruled on Thursday.

headline: China: 2 Tibetan Protesters Die
abstract: A Tibetan man died Wednesday after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese rule, bringing the total number of Tibetans who have carried out similar protests since 2009 to 101.
lead_paragraph: A Tibetan man died Wednesday after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese rule, bringing the total number of Tibetans who have carried out similar protests since 2009 to 101, according to a report on Thursday by Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government. The latest protest took place in Sangchu County, known in Chinese as Xiahe, in Gansu Province. The area is the home of Labrang Monastery, an important center of religious study in Tibet. Radio Free Asia reported that the man, Drukpa Khar, 26, was survived by a father, mother and three children. On Thursday, a Tibetan man who set himself on fire on Wednesday in Katmandu, Nepal, where many Tibetans in exile live, died at a hospital, according to news reports. The police are still trying to identify him, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Powerful State Lawmakers Push for a New Public-School Scholarship Program
abstract: Top state lawmakers are taking another look at an underutilized scholarship program meant for students in poorly performing schools who want to transfer.
lead_paragraph: A scholarship to help those students trapped in failing public schools to attend a school of their choice is near the top of the legislative agenda for several top lawmakers.

headline: Bahrain: Young Protester Killed
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: A teenager was killed during clashes with security forces on Thursday, on the second anniversary of the start of the protest movement calling for democratic change in Bahrain.
lead_paragraph: A teenager was shot and killed during clashes with the kingdom’s security forces on Thursday, on the second anniversary of the start of the protest movement calling for democratic change in Bahrain. Human rights activists and the Interior Ministry said the young man was killed in the village of Al Daih, outside Manama, the capital. The Bahrain Center for Human Rights posted an image of a death certificate online that said the youth, Hussein Ali Ahmed, 16, was killed at 8:30 a.m. on Thursday by gunshot. The group also added his name to a list of 88 fatalities since the protest movement began two years ago. Maj. Gen. Tariq Hassan al-Hassan, Bahrain’s chief of public security, acknowledged the death of a “rioter” in a statement that blamed protesters for “several incidents of violent attacks on police officers, attacks on citizens, destruction of property and blocking of roads.” The statement said that the death would be investigated. International human rights groups have criticized Bahrain’s use of force in its crackdown on dissent.

headline: Clean Energy Faces Hurdles in Legislature
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif. — Brandt Jobe began his workday pounding golf balls into the pitch black, the symbolism of which was easy to see once the sun rose and he set out on his round at Riviera Country Club.

headline: A Tiny Village Where Women Chose to Be Single Mothers
keywords: ['Single Mothers', 'Parenting', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Marriages', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The fierce desire of a group of women to become mothers upended centuries-old gender rules and may have helped open the door for Vietnam to redefine parenthood.
lead_paragraph: LOI, Vietnam — They had no plan to break barriers or cause trouble. But 30 years ago in this bucolic village in northern Vietnam, the fierce determination of one group of women to become mothers upended centuries-old gender rules and may have helped open the door for a nation to redefine parenthood.

headline: Election Opponents Team Up on Panel to Fix Voting System

abstract: President Obama hopes that bipartisan leadership on a new commission led by two of the nation’s pre-eminent election lawyers — Robert Bauer and Ben Ginsberg — will yield results.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert Bauer and Ben Ginsberg, two of the nation’s pre-eminent election lawyers, have long been on opposing sides of legal arguments. Last fall they were quarreling over voter registration, early voting laws and how the debates should be staged between their respective clients, President Obama and Mitt Romney.

abstract: For the past four months, Charlie Beljan has been known for the panic attack he weathered on the way to winning the 2012 PGA Tour finale outside Orlando. After his four-under-par 67 at Riviera Country Club on Thursday, he hopes the focus will shift to his golf.

abstract: The N.B.A. is unveiling a redesigned, fully sortable engine — free to the public — that contains every box score, allows fans to analyze lineups and includes advanced metrics.
lead_paragraph: Basketball’s statistical revolution — a movement begun in board rooms and on blogs and independent Web sites — has, at long last, reached its logical destination: the N.B.A.’s home page.

abstract: Nerlens Noel, projected by some to be the N.B.A.’s top draft choice this year, tore a knee ligament Tuesday and helped renew debate over limitations on college athletes’ insuring themselves.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, the results of the magnetic resonance imaging test on the left knee of Kentucky center Nerlens Noel came back, and the news was not good.

headline: Illinois Senate Votes to Back Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The vote was seen not just as a hard-fought victory for gay-rights advocates, but as part of a broader shift in public opinion.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With a Valentine’s Day vote, the Illinois Senate approved a bill on Thursday that would legalize same-sex marriage, inching the home state of President Obama closer to becoming the 10th in the nation, plus the District of Columbia, to allow gay couples the right to wed.

headline: Starting in 2nd Period, Isles Change Luck at Garden

lead_paragraph: The Islanders had been outscored, 35-11, in losing eight consecutive games to the Rangers at Madison Square Garden. They appeared headed for another bitter defeat Thursday night when they fell behind by two goals while not managing so much as a shot in the opening 14 minutes of play.

headline: Legal Clashes at Hearing for Defendants in 9/11 Case

lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The retired admiral who runs the military commissions system was called to testify at a tribunal hearing on Thursday in the case involving the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001 — and ended up arguing with a lower-ranking Navy defense lawyer about his handling of the matter.

headline: Vermont: Senate Advances Bill for Cases in Which Patients Choose to End Lives
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Doctors', 'Law and Legislation', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide']
abstract: The State Senate gave final approval on Thursday to a measure that would exempt doctors from criminal or civil liability when treating terminally ill patients who choose to end their lives.
lead_paragraph: The State Senate gave final approval on Thursday to a measure that would exempt doctors from criminal or civil liability when treating terminally ill patients who choose to end their lives. Any person present during the self-administration of a lethal dose of legally prescribed medication would also be exempted. The legislation, known as a “death with dignity” measure, was an amendment replacing a longer bill, modeled on Oregon’s end-of-life law, that supporters said included more safeguards for patients. The bill now goes to the House, which supporters hope will put forth a bill more like the original legislation. Passage would make Vermont the first state to approve an end-of-life measure by legislative act alone. Both Oregon and Washington have end-of-life laws that were approved by voters.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa’s Art of Perfection
abstract: Fashion’s ultimate independent finally comes to terms with his singular legacy.
lead_paragraph: In the hands of Azzedine Alaïa, a dress is so much more than stitched fabric. It’s an exaltation of the female form. A technical masterpiece. A unique vision. Over lunch in Paris, fashion’s ultimate independent finally comes to terms with his singular legacy.

But with a series of controversial hirings, firings and acquisitions, he’s pulled off the rare feat of besting the patriarch and creating a fashion empire.
