headline: Knicks’ Anthony Shows No Pain at All-Star Gathering
abstract: Despite a biceps injury, Carmelo Anthony kept shooting at a fan event Thursday, just as he did the night before in the Knicks’ loss to the Raptors.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Carmelo Anthony smiled as children raced past him to show off their shooting and passing skills Thursday as the N.B.A. began its annual All-Star weekend festivities. Anthony talked with fans, signed autographs and answered a few questions from youngsters during an N.B.A. jam session with his teammate Steve Novak.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Glow and Tell
abstract: Marc Jacobs closed Fashion Week with a thoughtful presentation, and some rather beautiful clothes.
lead_paragraph: When Marc Jacobs referred to the “weather project” after his show on Thursday night, I thought he meant the weather, which has been pretty lousy of late. But he meant The Weather Project, a 2003 installation at the Tate Modern by the artist Olafur Eliasson. I had to look it up, but that’s okay. Mr. Eliasson’s big artificial sun — 18,000 watts of sodium-yellow street light bulbs — explained a lot.

headline: Rabbi Arrested After Trying to Lure Teenage Girl
abstract: Rabbi Nathan David Rabinowich of Brooklyn was accused of sending sexually explicit messages to a person he thought was a 14-year-old girl but who was actually an undercover New York police detective.
lead_paragraph: A rabbi has been arrested after sending sexually explicit messages online to a person he thought was a 14-year-old girl and arranging to meet her in Queens for sex, the district attorney’s office said on Thursday. Instead, a New York police detective had impersonated the girl, the authorities said.

headline: James Scores 39 in Victory, but Shooting Streak Ends
abstract: LeBron James led the Heat to a 110-100 win at the Thunder, but a late miss dropped his field-goal percentage below 60 for the first time in seven games.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James’s record-setting streak of high scoring and efficiency came to an end Thursday night, but he still led the way as the visiting Miami Heat beat the Oklahoma City Thunder, 110-100, in a rematch of last season’s N.B.A. finals.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2 P.M. (Cinemax) CONTAGION (2011) A mysterious pathogen sets off a global pandemic after catching a flight from Hong Kong to Chicago in this Steven Soderbergh film. Gwyneth Paltrow, above, plays one of the first casualties, an executive who has traveled to Hong Kong. Matt Damon is her husband, who watches as the disease cuts down seemingly everyone who has been within touching, kissing or handshaking distance of a carrier. The cast is filled out by Laurence Fishburne, Kate Winslet and Jennifer Ehle as employees of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; Marion Cotillard as a doctor for the World Health Organization; and Jude Law as a writer looking to turn a profit from the crisis. Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called the movie a “smart, spooky thriller about a thicket of contemporary plagues — a killer virus, rampaging fear, an unscrupulous blogger,” adding that it is “as ruthlessly effective as the malady at its cool, cool center.”

headline: News Quiz | February 15, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Kerala’s Tangled Tryst With International Affairs
abstract: Examining the impact on Kerala a year after Italian marines allegedly shot two fishermen.
lead_paragraph: Indian states, though powerful in matters of internal administration, rarely deal with foreign governments. A bizarre shooting near Kerala’s coast involving Italian marines last year, which killed two Indian fishermen, gave the state a crash course on international diplomacy, one that also tested Kerala’s political standing with the central government.

headline: Shock Wave of Fireball Meteor Rattles Siberia, Injuring 1,200
abstract: Scenes from a city rocked by a shock wave when a meteor hit the atmosphere offered a glimpse of an apocalyptic scenario that scientists said had never before hurt so many people.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gym class came to a halt inside the Chelyabinsk Railway Institute, and students gathered around the window, gazing at the fat white contrail that arced its way across the morning sky. A missile? A comet? A few quiet moments passed. And then, with incredible force, the windows blew in.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 15
abstract: The horse meat scandal widens; China’s new leader invokes the Soviet Union’s collapse as a warning; European regulators defend their “Robin Hood” tax plan; and Afro-Brazilian drumming in Salvador, Brazil.
lead_paragraph: NEWS The scandal over horse meat in the European food chain widened Thursday from a case of mislabeling to one of food safety as public health authorities in Britain said that a powerful equine painkiller, potentially harmful to human health, “may have entered the food chain” in France. Dan Bilefsky reports from Paris, and Stephen Castle from London.

headline: Spectacular Videos of Meteor Over Siberia
abstract: As a meteor streaked across the sky above Siberia on Friday, Russians recorded remarkable video of the event on their cameraphones and dashboard-cams.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:40 p.m. As our colleagues Ellen Barry and Andrew Kramer report, Russians recorded video of a bright flash, apparently debris from a meteor, “streaking through the sky in western Siberia early on Friday, accompanied by a boom that damaged buildings across a vast area of territory.” Hundreds of injuries were reported, mainly from breaking glass.

headline: Italian Copter Scandal Puts Defense Deals Worth Billions in Jeopardy
abstract: Finmeccanica is pursuing $12 billion in additional deals in India.
lead_paragraph: Finmeccanica risks losing contracts in a significant market if India determines that the Italian aerospace group bribed Indian government officials to win contracts, analysts said.

headline: Tearful in Court, Pistorius Later Disputes Murder Charge
abstract: The prosecution in the case against Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee track star, planned to charge him with premeditated murder. A statement released by Pistorius’s agent said he disputed the murder charge.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The prosecution in the case against Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star accused of fatally shooting his girlfriend, said Friday that it planned to charge him with “premeditated murder,” the most serious murder charge under South African criminal law, as Mr. Pistorius made a tearful appearance at a courtroom in the South African capital, Pretoria.

headline: Crippled Ship Makes Port
abstract: After five days without power in the Gulf of Mexico, the cruise ship, Carnival Triumph, arrived in Mobile, Ala., late Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: After five days without power in the Gulf of Mexico, the cruise ship, Carnival Triumph, arrived in Mobile, Ala., late Thursday night.

headline: Test Yourself | A Note to Our Readers, and a New Type of Question
abstract: We’re suspending our Critical Thinking questions for a semester, but we have a new idea we hope you’ll like.
lead_paragraph: As of Feb. 15, we’ll be posting new questions each Friday that test your editing skills. To learn more about why we are substituting these for the critical thinking questions we’d previously asked, see our note, below.

headline: In South Africa, an Olympian Is Charged With Murder
abstract: Who is Oscar Pistorius?
lead_paragraph: In “Pistorius Charged With Murder in Shooting of Woman,” Lydia Polgreen and Alan Cowell write about a woman’s killing that involves a world-famous athlete.

headline: In His Hometown of Chicago, a Policy Speech by Obama Turns Personal
abstract: In Chicago on Friday, President Obama will outline an initiative to select 20 communities as laboratories for better coordination of federal, local, nonprofit and private-sector investments.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — President Obama came home on Friday for a policy speech that inevitably turned personal: He spoke of teaching law nearby, meeting his wife, Michelle, raising their daughters less than a mile away and then, most recently, watching the first lady return for the funeral of a vivacious teenager gunned down in a park.

headline: Should All Children Be Able to Go to Preschool?
abstract: Do you think government-financed preschool programs are a good use of taxpayer dollars? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: President Obama made preschool a focus of his State of the Union address this week, saying that all 4-year-olds should be able to attend a “high-quality preschool.” He pointed to states like Oklahoma and Georgia that are already trying to achieve that goal.

headline: To Avoid Delay, Airbus Drops Lithium-Ion Batteries
abstract: The problems Boeing is having with lithium-ion battery technology has led Airbus to change its plan, and use a conventional battery, made of nickel-cadmium.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the volatile new lithium-ion battery technology, Boeing and Airbus are heading in different directions.

headline: Japan’s Pollution Diet
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Japan was once as polluted as China is today. Now it’s among the world’s cleanest advanced economies. How did it do it?
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Seeing Beijing wreathed in smog throughout the winter, it has been hard not to worry about the costs of China’s rapid economic growth. As Jon Stewart pointed out on The Daily Show: Can’t a country capable of lifting hundreds of millions of people out of poverty find a way to keep its own capital safe for habitation?

headline: From Gulag to Goulash
abstract: While working on her recent doorstop history, a chronicle of the Eastern Bloc that was a finalist for the National Book Awards, Anne Applebaum also found time to publish a pretty cookbook on the pleasures of Polish cuisine.
lead_paragraph: While working on her recent doorstop history, a chronicle of the Eastern Bloc that was a finalist for the National Book Awards, Anne Applebaum also found time to publish a pretty cookbook on the pleasures of Polish cuisine.

headline: Health Care as an Economic Stabilizer
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Lost in the continuing discussion of the rising costs of health care is the stabilizing effect those costs have on the economy, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: The Early Word: Blocked
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:

headline: Q&A: Creating Customized Shortcuts for Microsoft Word
abstract: Microsoft Word comes with plenty of built-in keyboard shortcuts for common menu commands, but you can also make your own shortcuts.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: U.S. Signals Support for Japan’s Yen Policy
abstract: The debate over a currency war arrived in Moscow as finance officials from the Group of 20 sparred over Japan’s proposed expansive policies.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, strongly indicated on Friday that the United States did not intend to censure Japan for weakening its currency over the last several months, something that has aided Japanese exporters and angered its competitors.

headline: What It Was Like to Spend Time With Oscar Pistorius
abstract: Michael Sokolove got to know Oscar Pistorius, the pioneering South African athlete now charged with the murder of his girlfriend. Rendezvous’ editor, Marcus Mabry, spoke with him about the sports star’s tragic turn.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Michael Sokolove got to know Oscar Pistorius, the pioneering South African athlete now charged with the murder of his reported girlfriend. Rendezvous’ editor, Marcus Mabry, spoke with him about the sports star’s tragic turn.

headline: It’s All in the Cards
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Playing at the economic crisis with the new Portuguese game “Here Comes the Troika.”
lead_paragraph: LISBON — “We’re sick of hearing about the crisis, but we do like talking politics,” said Vincent, a 25-year-old Portuguese marketing student, as he, his friends Vincent and Diogo, and I gathered in a café in the upscale Lisbon neighborhood of Restelo to play cards.

headline: Mooring Deployed, Now We Wait
abstract: The drop of the anchor was swift and true, and the mooring is now in place to record data on turbulence in Chilean waters.
lead_paragraph: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes and wrote about his expedition to the North Pacific in the fall.

headline: Big Deals Are Back
abstract: Wall Street deal makers and chief executives are getting their groove back. | Despite an investigation into suspicious trading, SAC Capital Advisors is holding on to its largest outside investor, the Blackstone Group. | Carl C. Icahn officially has a dog in the Herbalife fight. | Elizabeth Warren grilled top banking regulators in her inaugural appearance as a member of the Senate Banking Committee.
lead_paragraph: THE RETURN OF BIG DEALS  |  Wall Street deal makers and chief executives are getting their groove back. After a fallow few years following the financial crisis, merger activity has roared back to life in the opening weeks of 2013, DealBook’s Peter Lattman writes. On Thursday, Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway teamed up with the Brazilian firm 3G Capital to buy H. J. Heinz for $23 billion, as American Airlines and US Airways agreed to merge in an $11 billion deal. Those transactions came on the heels of the $24 billion agreement to take Dell private and the $16 billion deal by Liberty Global to buy Virgin Media.

headline: The ‘One Billion Rising’ on the Streets of Delhi
abstract: Pink bands, a flash mob, and powerful speeches marked the event in the national capital.
lead_paragraph: On Valentine’s Day in Delhi, the pink band was ubiquitous, tied around arms, on wrists and foreheads, around necks and backpacks. Printed on it were the words “Enough! No More Violence Against Women.”

headline: Modern in Mumbai
abstract: A multibrand fashion and home store has brought a contemporary Western aesthetic to the affluent Indian shopper.

headline: It’s Scotch, but the Owners Live Elsewhere
keywords: ['Scotch (Whiskey)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Foreign Investments', 'Sales and Excise Taxes']
abstract: Scottish whisky distillers are weighing a “bottle tax” for companies outside the country that control about four-fifths of the global market for Scotch.
lead_paragraph: BALLINDALLOCH, SCOTLAND — George S. Grant markets malt whisky made in the shadow of the snow-capped Ben Rinnes, the same spot where, five generations ago, his family bought a distillery in 1865 for £511.

headline: Friday Reading: A Green Report Card for Ski Resorts
abstract: A green report card for ski resorts, more debate about a New York Times reporter’s test drive of a Tesla, swimming to ease back pain and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: An Orthodoxy of One
abstract: I am legion.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thoma sends us to a piece by Douglas Holtz-Eakin that is both sad and funny.

headline: App Smart Extra: Apps to Improve Your Singing
abstract: You don’t have to sing out of tune when there are apps to help you train your voice.
lead_paragraph: This week in my App Smart column, I talked about a few karaoke apps that can replicate many of the features of a full-fledged karaoke machine. I also mentioned one app that can help you train your singing voice.

headline: Earth May Not Be Ready for the Next Close Encounter
abstract: Earth experienced one suspected collision and one near miss from outer space on Friday. The events reinforced calls for greater international cooperation to combat the asteroid threat.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The suspected meteor shower that blasted Siberia early Friday somewhat stole the thunder of another chunk of space rock that was due to stream past Earth later in the day.

headline: Disco-era Macroeconomics
abstract: Keynes had nothing to do with it.
lead_paragraph: There was another sad thing in that Holtz-Eakin piece calling me an orthodoxy all by myself; it was really disappointing to see DHE pulling the old “Keynesian policies caused stagflation” line.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: CBS Sets Earnings Record, and Publishing Merger Gets O.K.
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Company Reports', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Movies', 'Television']
abstract: CBS set records in the last quarter of 2012; the Justice Department has approved a merger of Random House and Penguin, possibly creating the largest book publisher in the world; and Time Warner’s efforts to push Time Inc. out the door like a wayward party guest represents a singular moment in the shifting media landscape.
lead_paragraph: The CBS Corporation set records in the fourth quarter for operating income and adjusted operating income but still fell short of some analysts’ expectations, leading to a decline in its share price in after-hours trading, Bill Carter writes. The adjusted net earnings of $414 million produced earnings of 64 cents a share, also a quarterly record for CBS. The company announced an additional stock buyback of $1 billion, bringing the amount of stock it has committed to repurchasing this year to $2.2 billion. CBS, which is still the most-watched network on television, attributed the gains to a jump in advertising revenue in the last quarter, probably because of election commercials. Simon & Schuster, CBS’s publishing unit, remained a troubling area with revenue declining to $215 million from $229 million in 2011.

headline: Bellevue Hospital Briefly Limits Emergency Cases
abstract: UPDATE: Bellevue Hospital Center, one of the city’s busiest trauma centers, temporarily stopped accepting non-psychiatric emergency patients as a result of a computer problem, the hospital said.
lead_paragraph: 9:56 a.m. | Updated Bellevue Hospital Center, one of the city’s busiest trauma centers, was temporarily forced to stop accepting most emergency care patients on Thursday night because of a computer problem, the hospital said on Friday morning.

headline: The Gun Report: February 15, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: We were reminded yesterday that not every gruesome murder takes place in the United States. In South Africa, Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee who ran in the Olympics and became a global sport sensation, was charged with murdering his girlfriend. The early rumors were that he had shot her by accident, mistaking her for an intruder. But it was quickly revealed that there had been a number of domestic incidents at that address. “It is a big shock for everyone,” Hennie Kotze, a former coach, told the New York Times.

headline: Campaign Promotes New Bank Service for N.B.A. Fans
abstract: BBVA Compass, the American franchise of the Spanish bank, and the NBA will unveil a campaign on Friday to promote online consumer checking and savings accounts.
lead_paragraph: 9:29 a.m. | Updated BBVA, the official bank of the National Basketball Association, will announce on Friday that it is extending its services from the league to its fans.

headline: Like Father, Like Daughter
abstract: A French illustrator and his handbag-designer daughter both employ painstaking workmanship in their distinct crafts.

headline: Elegiac Images From North Dakota’s Boom
abstract: In words and photography, Elizabeth Farnsworth and Terry Evans document North Dakotans’ sense of prosperity and loss.
lead_paragraph: For Elizabeth Farnsworth, the story began when she was walking her dog at a highway rest stop off Interstate 94 in North Dakota.

headline: The World’s Best News Photos for 2012
abstract: A dramatic photo of a procession for two children killed in Gaza City has been named 2012’s World Press Photo of the Year.
lead_paragraph: Paul Hansen’s dramatic image of a funeral procession in Gaza has been named 2012’s World Press Photo of the Year. The photo shows a group of men carrying the corpses of two children who were killed in Gaza City in November when their house was destroyed in an Israeli missile strike. Their father’s body is carried behind on a stretcher.

headline: Daily Report: Device Offers Partial Vision for the Blind
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new technology that is the first to give limited vision to people who are blind, Pam Belluck reports.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first treatment to give limited vision to people who are blind, involving a technology called the artificial retina, reports Pam Belluck in Friday’s New York Times.

headline: Why I Have No Health Insurance
abstract: Too busy trying to start a company, Adriana Herrera struggled to find the money for insurance and the time to see a doctor.
lead_paragraph: Three days after we established the Fashioning Change house in Santa Monica, I was in a car accident. I was rear-ended, and upon impact I felt like I had the wind knocked out of me. Despite the pain, I didn’t give it much thought. I assumed it was because the seat belt had done what it was supposed to do.

headline: No Better Place to Schlep
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young woman tells a stranger in the subway how excited she is to be back in New York after eight years.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Details: Now that Valentine’s Day has passed, is it true what they say about oysters? — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Older Workers Could Benefit if Companies Drop Insurance
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: If employers are no longer on the hook for the health insurance costs of their employees, older job candidates — who consume more health care — may start to look more attractive.
lead_paragraph: As I’ve written before, older workers, once unemployed, have an extraordinarily difficult time finding re-employment. But they may get one unexpected employment booster next year: the health insurance exchanges put in place by the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Fewer Illegal Immigrants in New York, Study Finds
abstract: New York by the Numbers: The Center for Migration Studies estimates the city was home to 750,000 of the nation’s 11.7 million unauthorized immigrants in 2010, compared with 2.9 million in California, 1.6 million in Texas and 1 million in Florida.
lead_paragraph: New York has far fewer illegal immigrants than California, Texas and Florida, and their ranks have been declining, according to a new analysis by the Center for Migration Studies’ International Migration Review.

headline: Total Discloses Origins of a Gas Leak in the North Sea
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Wells', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: The natural gas leak at a well in the French oil company’s flagship Elgin-Franklin field resulted from corrosion that produced stress cracks, the company said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Total, the French oil company, has disclosed the findings of its investigation into the causes of a natural gas leak at a well in the North Sea, which has shut down production on the company’s flagship Elgin-Franklin field for almost a year.

headline: Actors in Search of Good Roles
abstract: Black actors are still struggling to find roles that acknowledge their full capabilities.
lead_paragraph: Black actors are still struggling to find roles that acknowledge their full capabilities.

headline: Still Too Good, Too Bad or Invisible
keywords: ['Movies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Discrimination', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Several of this year’s Oscar-nominated films raise the age-old question of whether white filmmakers are ready to grant agency to black characters.
lead_paragraph: A black slave is torn apart by dogs as a crowd of white overseers savors the sight and a black bounty hunter watches passively behind shades. A black father makes his little girl crack open a crab with her bare hands then flex her tiny muscles like a pint-size N.F.L. linebacker. A black pilot snorts a line of cocaine after a night of debauchery and, just a few minutes before liftoff, knocks back several miniature bottles of alcohol. A black woman tells President Lincoln that God will guide him as he pushes legislation that will end slavery but not dent notions of white supremacy.

headline: Unsolicited Advice for Sally Jewell
abstract: President Obama’s surprise nominee to run the Interior Department should realize that conservation does not loom large at the White House.
lead_paragraph: Here is some unsolicited advice for Sally Jewell, President Obama’s surprise nominee to run the Interior Department: She should read her prospective boss’s State of the Union address very carefully. What she will find there is the strong suggestion that the public lands she will be asked to manage wisely and for all Americans serve one purpose and one purpose only: to produce energy, whether oil or gas or solar  or wind. The idea that these lands are also valuable as national parkland, as habitat for thousands of animal and plant species, as sources of clean water, as wilderness fully protected from all but the hardiest backpackers (as Ms. Jewell is said to be) is nowhere mentioned in that speech.

headline: Saving Mr. Lincoln
abstract: How an early plot to assassinate Abraham Lincoln was foiled.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln has been dead for nearly a century and a half, but we still seem fixated on what happened to him — or what might have happened to him, as we read in Daniel Stashower’s swift and detailed rendering of the first credible effort to end the life of the 16th president of the United States.

headline: The Odd Couple
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In “Ike and Dick,” Jeffrey Frank writes about the strange relationship that would help shape America’s foreign and domestic agenda for much of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: It may be the closest of political relationships, but it rarely ends well. Vice President Thomas Jefferson challenged President John Adams for the top spot in the vicious campaign of 1800. President Andrew Jackson mused sardonically about executing Vice President John C. Calhoun. In the modern era, Lyndon Johnson seethed at slights real and perceived during John Kennedy’s thousand days, then turned around and humiliated his own vice president, Hubert Humphrey. Even Dick Cheney and George W. Bush fell out by the end of their tumultuous terms. But perhaps the most intriguing — and dysfunctional — political marriage in history was the one between the subjects of Jeffrey Frank’s meticulously researched “Ike and Dick.”

headline: Reducing Your Carbon Footprint
keywords: ['Energy Efficiency', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Energy-saving strategies are often free or inexpensive, and technology makes it easier to follow through on advice.
lead_paragraph: Many people believe that Hurricane Sandy made the consequences of climate change painfully clear, so it might be tempting to think that stricter emissions standards and renewable-energy investments could lead to a less stormy future. But while these high-level policy initiatives are important, changes on the home front matter, too.

headline: The Icahn Effect on Herbalife Shares
abstract: Shares of Herbalife surged after the disclosure that Carl C. Icahn had taken a big stake. But that enthusiasm appeared to fade a bit once Mr. Icahn appeared on CNBC to explain his reasons for investing in the nutritional supplements company.
lead_paragraph: 1:43 p.m. | Updated

headline: Fire in the Russian Sky
abstract: The Times’s Ellen Barry and Richard P. Binzel, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor, discuss the explosive event over western Siberia on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Ellen Barry and Richard P. Binzel, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor, discuss the explosive event over western Siberia on Friday.

headline: Does My Bargain-Hunting Hurt Those in Need?
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Thrift Shops', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A thrift-store thrill seeker and a gym-rat neighbor.
lead_paragraph: I make a good salary and can afford to shop and buy new clothes at a regular retail store, but I enjoy shopping at a particular thrift store where I find great bargains. I sometimes buy items that I don’t need. My question concerns my enjoyment versus the needs of others who are less fortunate (and are now deprived of the opportunity to buy items that they probably need more than I do). Am I guilty of fulfilling a shadow pleasure at the expense of those in need? JAY THOMPSON, TOMS RIVER, N.J.

headline: Who Made That Toothbrush?
abstract: The story of one of the most reinvented of human objects.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t have any of those toothbrushes that went to the moon,” says Dr. Ben Swanson, former president of the American Academy of the History of Dentistry. He was speaking from his basement, where he stores his trove of 40,000 artifacts related to dental history. Swanson once dreamed of owning every kind of toothbrush in existence, but ended up stockpiling only a few hundred. “I had to give up because there were so many of them,” he says. In fact, it would be nearly impossible to collect every specimen; the toothbrush is one of the most reinvented of human objects, with thousands of patents on file.

headline: My Oracle at Ludlow
abstract: He was drinking whiskey, neat. And reading my mind.
lead_paragraph: I don’t believe in ghosts or the paranormal, but in the spring of 2007, I encountered a human oracle.

headline: Tammy Duckworth’s Deadly Hot Cocoa
keywords: ['Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Veterans']
abstract: The congresswoman and Iraq vet on her political battles and women in combat.
lead_paragraph: You soundly defeated Joe Walsh, a Tea Party Republican, in November. He was known for yelling on cable news, even at his own constituents. Did you feel lucky to be running against him?  Oh, no, not at all. Joe Walsh had two sides to him. There was the media side, but he also can be very charming in person. He tapped into a strand of fear that was present throughout the country with the economy.

headline: The 2.3.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: In what was an overwhelming response to Susannah Meadows’s article about treating her son’s juvenile idiopathic arthritis with conventional and alternative treatments, we heard from the medical community and from families of children who have the condition. Some were complimentary; others were critical of an article they felt made a case for alternative treatment at the expense of mainstream medicine. The article portrayed one family’s desperation to halt the progression of their son’s disease and the range of treatments they tried. In a case with few certainties, it was nonetheless clear that the source of this type of arthritis, and thus its cure, remains elusive for many. THE EDITORS

headline: The Belles of the Brawl
keywords: ['Mixed Martial Arts', 'Women and Girls', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Women are finally crashing the mixed-martial-arts party at the U.F.C.
lead_paragraph: Women are finally crashing the mixed-martial-arts party at the U.F.C.

headline: What Makes a Writer Want to Rock Out?
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Music', 'Books and Literature', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Literary fiction and indie music used to be worlds apart, but no longer.
lead_paragraph: My secret life in rock music at last collided with my literary career during a phone call in 2003. I was talking with my editor, discussing possible avenues for publicity for my coming book, a collection of 100 very short stories. This volume’s slightness was overshadowed only by its even slighter potential for earning back its advance. The situation demanded creative thinking. It was an overseas call, and had so far cost about a third of the advance. Impulsively, I said, “I’ll record an album of 100 songs!”

headline: Up Front
abstract: Charles Joseph Scarborough, known to almost everyone as “Joe,” is a man of many parts.
lead_paragraph: Charles Joseph Scarborough, known to almost everyone as “Joe,” is a man of many parts. Born in Georgia in 1963, educated at the University of Alabama and the University of Florida School of Law, Scarborough served in the United States Congress from 1995 to 2001 before going on to host his highly successful MSNBC talk show, “Morning Joe,” and to write two nonfiction books, including the best seller “The Last Best Hope: Restoring Conservatism and America’s Promise.” One of Scarborough’s biggest fans is Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who said of him: “Joe speaks his mind without fear or favor, because he puts his country before his party. . . . That independence is what makes Joe Scarborough such a valuable voice in American politics.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Almost half a century after his death in 1967, the folk singer Woody Guthrie hits the extended hardcover fiction list with the novel “House of Earth,” new at No. 20.
lead_paragraph: THIS LAND: Almost half a century after his death in 1967, the folk singer Woody Guthrie hits the extended hardcover fiction list with the novel “House of Earth,” new at No. 20, about young farmers determined to build an adobe home in Dust Bowl Texas. Guthrie finished the book in 1947 but never tried to publish it — possibly aware that its explicit sex and leftist politics would be a hard sell in the McCarthy era. They’ve received a warmer welcome in the Internet age.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: HAITI: The Aftershocks of History,  by Laurent Dubois. (Picador, $20.) Even before the devastating 2010 earthquake, Haiti was known as a benighted place of poverty and corruption, insurrection and suppression. In this authoritative history, Dubois, the author of “Avengers of the New World: The Story of the Haitian Revolution,” traces the “authoritarian political habits” and mercenary intrusions of foreign powers that have hamstrung the nation since it declared independence in 1804.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: VAMPIRES IN THE LEMON GROVE: Stories,  by Karen Russell. (Knopf, $24.95.) A grim, stupendous, unfavorable magic is at work in Russell’s uncanny collection, in which the innocent do not fare well and adults, when they are not evil, are noncontenders.

headline: Women on the Verge
abstract: Stories about women dealing with shortages (of housing and more) by the Russian writer Ludmilla Petrushevskaya.
lead_paragraph: For years, acceptable portrayals of Soviet women in art were limited to the ideal proletariat, a strong-jawed woman with flashing eyes and scythe in hand, or the fairy tale Snow Queen in furs.

headline: Jane’s World
abstract: Paula Byrne’s biography uses everyday objects to explore influences on Austen’s work.
lead_paragraph: “And, after all, we have lives enough of Jane Austen.” This verdict, delivered by Virginia Woolf at Cambridge in 1928, should give any Austen biographer pause. Yet Austen’s appeal has proved irresistible. Since Woolf’s pronouncement, countless editions, studies and adaptations of her novels have appeared. Her 160 extant letters have been frequently collected, most notably by R. W. Chapman (in 1932 and 1952) and by the mother of all Janeites, Deirdre Le Faye (in 1995 and 2011). Recent biographies similarly abound, varying in aim and quality: Lord David Cecil’s elegant and unassuming “portrait” in 1978; Park Honan’s scrupulous ­“cradle-to-grave” history in 1987; Claire Tomalin’s brisk, superlative “life” and David Nokes’s lengthier, more imaginative account, both in 1997. (Carol Shields’s regrettable hash, published in 2001, is perhaps best forgotten.) Austen’s Hampshire plot was small enough to begin with; has any ground been left unbroken?

headline: Commerzbank Chief Gives Up Bonus Amid Lackluster Results
abstract: The chief executive of Commerzbank, Martin Blessing, said Friday he would not take a bonus for 2012, after the bank reported a net loss of 716 million euros, or $959 million, in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The chief executive of Commerzbank, one of Germany’s largest banks, on Friday became the latest in a series European bank leaders to recognize that collecting a big bonus might appear unseemly while banks struggle with layoffs and financial losses.

headline: Cape Fear
abstract: André Brink imagines the life of a slave who was owned by one of his ancestors.
lead_paragraph: “Philida” is the latest offering from the South African author A­ndré Brink, whose anti-­apartheid novels — along with those of such contemporaries as Nadine Gordimer and J. M. Coetzee — have challenged readers to reflect on the intimate brutalities of a society founded on a dehumanizing ideology. Like several of Brink’s historical novels, “Philida” probes South Africa’s more distant sordid past, animating real figures from the Cape Colony’s days of white settlement, when the enslavement and indentured servitude of local black and indigenous populations, as well as people brought over from the Dutch East Indies, were entirely routine.

headline: Apostolic Transgression
abstract: Garry Wills maintains that the Roman Catholic priesthood has arrogated to itself powers unimagined by Jesus and his disciples.
lead_paragraph: Garry Wills wants us to know that he really bears no animus toward priests. Truly. Some of his best friends, not to mention his mentors, are priests. His quarrel is not with priests but with the specious notion of the priesthood, which, he argues, finds no precedent in the early church and precious little warrant in the New Testament.

headline: Tribal Warfare
abstract: The American anthropologist Napoleon A. Chagnon defends his decades of work with an indigenous group in the Amazon.
lead_paragraph: As I read “Noble Savages,” Napoleon A. Chagnon’s memoir of his years among the Yanomamö, an isolated Amazonian tribe, I started hearing Linda Ronstadt’s cover of “Poor, Poor Pitiful Me,” first as a low background hum that grew louder and more insistent across the book’s 500-plus pages.

headline: Lost in Space
abstract: These four stories capture the pathos of life in the Internet age.
lead_paragraph: The Internet: from my vantage it’s both arbitrary and sovereign, an open sewer and a global Yellow Pages — but what is it? It can’t be reduced to its technical components, whatever they are. It’s metaphysical, yet without fixed or transcendent meaning. It’s a crystal ball, without any clairvoyance. Who hasn’t arrived at the logically borne-out if senseless belief that in the oceanic swell of Google lies hidden the answer to one’s most private problem? In his latest book, “Four New Messages,” Joshua Cohen takes on the experiential properties of the “online” modality, its textures and tautologies, its effects on language and thus on humans and meaning. This seems at once a fundamental and ambitious place to begin mapping this void of a thing that we pretend, by not writing about it in literature, doesn’t have much place in life, when the dirty truth is otherwise.

headline: The Joads’ Cousins
abstract: Susan Straight’s characters have fled to California.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, in a Big Read discussion of “The Grapes of Wrath,” Susan Straight observed that Steinbeck’s classic novel “reminds us really of how timeless the fight is for land and for dignity and for survival.” That fight, on the grittiest urban and rural terrain of Southern California, has been a recurrent theme in much of Straight’s own fiction. In her eighth novel, “Between Heaven and Here,” she continues the story of the Picards and their kin — black, French-speaking refugees from violent Jim Crow Louisiana who headed west, literary relations of the Joads, struggling to realize their own version of the American dream.

headline: Modern Safeguards for a Family-Owned Business
keywords: ['Family Business', 'Small Business', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: The Phelan Brothers, owners of Taconic Farms, which breeds rodents for lab use, created a holding company as a way to maintain some family control over the business.
lead_paragraph: NO family wants to build a business only to see it disappear when family members get tired of running it. But let’s face it, what that business really represents is a large majority of the family’s wealth.

headline: On Our Radar: Is Styrofoam Doomed in New York?
abstract: Mayor Bloomberg calls for a ban, pointing out that plastic foam “is virtually impossible to recycle” and never biodegrades.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says he will push in his final year in office for more recycling and electric vehicles, a curbside food-composting program and a ban on Styrofoam food packaging. Plastic foam, he says, is “something that we know is environmentally destructive and that may be hazardous to our health, that is costing taxpayers money and that we can easily do without, and is something that should go the way of lead paint.” [Bloomberg News]

headline: Recognizing Signs of Abusive Dating Among Teenagers
abstract: Domestic abuse among teenagers is not readily understood within an adult framework. And confusing possessiveness with love is among the most common teenage mistakes leading to dating violence.
lead_paragraph: I wish February had been Teen Dating Violence Awareness Month when I was growing up. I might have realized that in the era before e-mails or cellphones, my boyfriend’s demand that we speak on the telephone every night was unreasonable. I was in college and my life revolved around those phone calls.

abstract: Galbi, or Korean short ribs, is a fine thing to eat in a restaurant, but with a traditional marinade, it also makes for a wonderful home-cooked meal.
lead_paragraph: February may or may not be grilling season, depending upon your temperament and the climate where you live. I like to grill year-round, sometimes on an outdoor barbecue (even if there’s snow), sometimes in the fireplace. Also handy is a ridged stovetop grill, and of course there’s the broiler if need be. This means that kebabs, wings and even grilled vegetables are always an option, sunshine or not.

headline: Death, Divorce, Disease. Children’s TV?
abstract: The Prix Jeunesse Suitcase series takes prizewinning children’s TV shows on the road, exploring social mores and values.
lead_paragraph: The first of the day’s many jolts arrived at about 9:05 a.m. Several dozen producers, writers and researchers for American children’s television had barely taken their seats in a basement screening room across the street from the United Nations. Soon after the lights dimmed, the screen filled with a group of children gathered in a wood shop. Completely unsupervised by adults, they unsteadily but zestfully wielded saws, hammers and nails to build miniature houses in a cheerfully produced segment from the German program “Ene Mene Bu” (“And It’s Up to You”).

headline: Trying to Make Sense of  the Pistorius Story
abstract: The murder charge against an Olympic hero is difficult to comprehend. Other sports this week were less of a surprise.
lead_paragraph: In the day following the arrest of the Olympic sprinter Oscar Pistorius on a murder charge, the work began to make sense of the story. That is a nearly impossible task, of course, with a day to pivot from nearly universal admiration and inspiration to a scene where he could have gunned down his girlfriend in cold blood, which is what the South African police are saying with premeditated muder charges. A haze of disbelief still hangs over the whole tragic turn, the man who inspired the world last summer now sobbing in a courtroom while his country tries to shake this into focus.

headline: Now Onstage in Spain: Austerity
abstract: Spain’s cultural institutions have been hit particularly hard by deep cuts in government subsidies.

headline: Recreating the Reign, the Better to Fall
abstract: Martha Graham’s 1935 solo “Imperial Gesture” has been reconstructed — as much as possible based on research — for performances at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Martha Graham always insisted that she was apolitical, but in 1935 she took a choreographic stand. The solo “Imperial Gesture,” created around the same time she turned down Nazi officials’ invitation to perform at the 1936 Olympic Games, showcased Graham as a monarch demonstrating absolute power before losing control and toppling to the floor.

headline: Between Love and Valentine
abstract: Archies cards have come to redefine love for many in India.
lead_paragraph: Back in my hometown of Ranchi, it was outside the Archies Gallery in the Church Complex that the angry-eyed young men of the Bharatiya Janata Party’s militant wing, the Bajrang Dal, positioned themselves on Valentine’s Day. Except all they found was a sad trickle of people – those habitually late, and those who were the utterly naïve. Everyone else would have come a week earlier, edging past shelves overflowing with Linda Goodman mugs and George Michael posters to the special corner that lay at the far end of the shop where a placard — in red, obviously, and shaped like a heart — would announce: “14 Feb is Valentine’s Day.”

headline: ‘This American Life’ Looks at a High School Marooned in Violence
abstract: At Chicago’s Harper High School, 29 current or former students were shot last year. “This American Life” spent five months at the school, and begins a two-part special report this weekend.
lead_paragraph: One of the discussions that comes up every time there is a mass shooting at a suburban school or a movie theater is how underreported other, equally disturbing killings are — like the ones at urban high schools and in city neighborhoods. Those deaths don’t come in a single spasm, but instead are part of a chronic drip of bloodshed, day in and day out.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy']
abstract: China, with an 8 percent gain, posted faster growth in exports than the United States. Canada reported a small gain, but other countries showed declines.
lead_paragraph: WORLD trade slowed last year, as major countries like Japan and Germany shipped exports that were worth less than those in 2011. The United States bucked the trend to some extent, but the 4.5 percent increase in exports was far smaller than the 15.8 percent jump in 2011.

headline: Rio, With Eyes Open
abstract: The city is billed as “new,” ready to welcome the world. For a first-time visitor and her young daughter, it was lush, exciting and more complicated.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know why people come to Rio de Janeiro, and came even during its years of bloody, decadent decline, stand on the Arpoador Beach promenade at day’s end. Before you lies an orchestral finale of a sunset: iridescent water, pastel-streaked skies and hazy silhouettes of cliffs to the west. Behind you are swarms of Cariocas, as Rio natives are known: men with phones tucked into the fronts of their bathing suits, swimmers shaking off droplets of water before ordering caipirinhas at an outdoor bar. At the moment when the neon-pink sun slips below the horizon, everyone stops, stands and claps: a nightly salute to city, beach and sky.

headline: Sun, Surf and Soccer in Rio
abstract: See scenes from the city as it prepares for two big turns on the world stage.
lead_paragraph: See scenes from the city as it prepares for two big turns on the world stage.

headline: In Grenada, Ocean Views With a Spice Scent
abstract: Venture beyond the beach on this Caribbean island and you’ll find everything from nutmeg and cocoa to hidden waterfalls.
lead_paragraph: All I wanted to do in Grenada was veg on the beach. I had a stack of paperbacks, SPF 70 and reservations for a Balinese massage. It was my first time back to the Caribbean in 10 years, and my first beach vacation in nearly as long. The prospect of eternal days of sunshine, frothy novels and morning yoga to keep me from morphing into a true sloth seemed like heaven.

headline: Skiing Old Trails of the New Deal
abstract: On mountains across New England, a chapter of Great Depression-era history is revealed to skiers willing to work for it.
lead_paragraph: I climbed the final few feet to the top of the slope and turned around just in time to watch the last rays of sun set the town of Adams aglow, 2,000 feet below. I had arrived at the base of Mount Greylock, Massachusetts’ highest peak, on a gorgeous, bluebird January afternoon, just a few days after a storm had dumped a thick coating of fresh powder across New England. And I had made good time skinning up the trail.

headline: In Zurich, a Short Trip to Japan
abstract: Carefully selected local ingredients are mixed with specialty items imported from Japan at Shinwazen, a small minimalist restaurant opened in July.
lead_paragraph: As expected from a restaurant owner who moonlights as the president of a local Slow Food chapter, Markus Baumgartner obsesses over his kitchen’s ingredients. He has direct relationships with all his purveyors, from a former banker who now raises salmon out of terraced ponds 25 miles from Zurich’s city center to a cattle farming family 60 miles away whose small herd gets massages twice daily.

headline: An Idyllic Retreat in a Tuscan Hamlet
abstract: You may (will?) get lost on your way to Hotel Monteverdi, but just consider that part of its bountiful rustic charm.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Lies to Win British Post Earn Conviction in New York
abstract: Soma Sengupta, who worked in Manhattan and falsified her résumé to gain entry to the British bar, was found guilty of forgery and other charges.
lead_paragraph: A New York lawyer who lied about her work experience and shaved nearly 20 years off her age in an effort to gain admittance to the British bar was convicted of all counts she faced by a judge in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: 2Chainz Arrested on Marijuana Charges on Way to Concert
abstract: The rapper was accused of possessing drug paraphernalia and marijuana after being stopped by the Maryland State Police.
lead_paragraph: The rapper 2Chainz was arrested on drug charges on Thursday night, said the Maryland State Police, who briefly detained him as he traveled to perform at a concert. A police spokesman, Sgt. Marc Black, told The Associated Press that troopers had stopped a van for speeding on Route 50 near Easton, Md. The officers said they smelled marijuana in the car, conducted a seach and found a backpack with a marijuana grinder and trace amounts of the drug inside it.

headline: Buffett’s Kind of Deal
abstract: How Pennsylvania law has helped structure a favorable buyout for Warren E. Buffett and 3G Capital Management.
lead_paragraph: It is by now almost trite to say that there are deals and then there are Buffett deals. And the $23 billion acquisition of H.J. Heinz is certainly a Buffett deal.

lead_paragraph: If you’ve secretly harbored the belief that Nico, the sultry German chanteuse who sang briefly with the Velvet Underground, was a major but sadly unappreciated cultural icon, your moment may be at hand.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Nasty Newcomer

abstract: Ted Cruz, a Republican freshman with a leading role in the fight against Chuck Hagel, typifies the knee-jerk belligerence that blots his party.
lead_paragraph: WHEN a Vesuvius like John McCain tells you that you belch too much smoke and spew too much fire, you know you’ve got a problem.

headline: For a Weekend, at Least, Anthony and Garnett Unite
abstract: As Carmelo Anthony and Kevin Garnett put aside their differences before Sunday’s All-Star Game, Hall of Fame finalists were announced, including the former Knick Bernard King.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Carmelo Anthony walked into the grand ballroom of the Hilton Americas hotel on Friday wearing a white and gold long-sleeve shirt and big brown sunglasses. Anthony captured what All-Star weekend is all about for many players: enjoying the spotlight.

headline: Indian Troops Kill Pakistani Soldier in Kashmir Border Clash
abstract: An Indian Army statement said Indian soldiers returned fire from an intruder and later found a dead Pakistani soldier, whose body has been returned.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian troops have shot and killed another Pakistani soldier at the de facto border between the two countries in Kashmir, adding to an unusually tense period in the disputed region.

headline: U.S. Soccer Player Opens Up About Being Gay
abstract: It was unclear whether Robbie Rogers was planning to retire from soccer or simply take a break from playing, though the emotional toll of his decision to come out was evident.
lead_paragraph: It was around 11 a.m. Friday when David Testo’s cellphone began to vibrate constantly. There were missed calls. Voice mail messages. E-mails.

headline: Beans With Bacon
abstract: It’s winter. It’s cold. It’s perfect weather for a warming meal. Melissa Clark shows how to make red wine pinto beans with bacon.
lead_paragraph: It’s winter. It’s cold. It’s perfect weather for a warming meal. Melissa Clark shows how to make red wine pinto beans with bacon.

headline: Sun City It’s Not
abstract: Some buildings on the Upper West Side are NORCs — naturally occurring retirement communities.
lead_paragraph: When the co-op conversion wave began in New York City in the 1960s, singles and young married couples flocked to the Upper West Side hoping to get a piece of the action. Some of those people, now in their 70s, are still there, cemented in place by apartments bought for a song or equally treasured rent-stabilized units.

headline: Beans and Red Wine: Party Hearty
abstract: An impressive party dish that is easy, inexpensive and can be served in a big pot or over polenta or rice.
lead_paragraph: It started with a question from a friend.

headline: Caught for Posterity in Love
abstract: Couples were invited to the Bronx Documentary Center on Thursday to pose for photographs.
lead_paragraph: “Torture” is the word Sandy Herrera uses to describe being photographed. “I hate taking pictures,” Ms. Herrera, 21, said. “I guess I’m insecure.” Which is why her boyfriend of two years, Sergio Ramirez, 23, was floored when she suggested they pay a Valentine’s Day visit to the Bronx Documentary Center, which had invited couples from across the borough to pose for photographs.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Marc Jacobs
abstract: François Nars brought smoky eyes and strong eyebrows to the show’s New York Fashion Week runway this season.
lead_paragraph: “The beauty look is very Marc Jacobs: edgy, cool, very underground with a touch of rock,” says the makeup artist François Nars, who works exclusively with Jacobs each season. Naming Marianne Faithfull and Joan Jett as the muses for the smoky-eyed, monochromatic look, Nars says the process of arriving at this concept was quite easy: “We both love the ’60s and ’70s era. There were so many great characters at that time!” The focus on black-and-white tones not only referenced the punk-rock chic inspiration, but was also a practical consideration. With the first part of the runway show taking place under a sepia glow, Nars needed to come up with an idea that would look striking in both types of lighting. “So we did a black smoky eye with white pencil used on the inner rim to make the eyes pop and look bigger, and the eyebrows are strong and defined,” he says. “The skin is totally matte, and at the last minute I put a little grease on top of the eye makeup and clear gloss on the lips so it looks like the girl went out, stayed out all night and got her makeup a little sweaty.”

headline: When to Salt Your Beans
abstract: Before boiling, or during?
lead_paragraph: There are many opinions about when to add salt to a pot of simmering beans. Some experts say to wait until the beans soften before adding salt, otherwise the beans won’t cook through. Others advise adding the salt right at the beginning of the cooking in order to season the beans through and through.

headline: Fall Fashion: From Gray to Technicolor
abstract: Eric Wilson presents the highlights of New York Fashion Week for fall 2013.
lead_paragraph: Eric Wilson presents the highlights of New York Fashion Week for fall 2013.

headline: Texas Senator Goes on Attack and Raises Bipartisan Hackles
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, has quickly made his presence felt with brash moves that have raised the hackles of colleagues from both parties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Senate edged toward a divisive filibuster vote on Chuck Hagel’s nomination to be defense secretary, Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, sat silent and satisfied in the corner of the chamber — his voice lost to laryngitis — as he absorbed what he had wrought in his mere seven weeks of Senate service.

headline: SAC Clients Said to Seek $1.7 Billion in Refunds
abstract: The outflows are a blow to the fund founded by Steven A. Cohen, which has one of the best investment track records on Wall Street, but they are expected to have little effect on its business.
lead_paragraph: Clients of SAC Capital Advisors have asked to withdraw $1.7 billion from the giant hedge fund as the government’s insider trading investigation intensifies, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Mexican Revolution
abstract: Mérida, Mexico, might not offer much on the outside, but a clutch of creative insiders has transformed the faded colonial town into a sophisticated escapist retreat.
lead_paragraph: On arriving in the sleepy Mexican town of Mérida, one might wonder what all the recent fuss is about. The historical center, with its faded limestone mansions, narrow cobblestoned streets and monumental cathedral — one of the oldest in all of the Americas and built out of limestone rocks from ancient Mayan structures — is indeed picturesque. And the handful of modest-looking restaurants in town can certainly serve up a decent bowl of lime and tortilla soup. And if you’re in the market to unload some pesos on a colorful hammock or an embroidered blouse, a few mom-and-pop tourist shops can help you do just that. But in truth, there’s not much to shake a stick at here in this remote corner of the Yucatán.

headline: Pablo Larraín Discusses 'No'
abstract: Pablo Larraín, the director of "No," talks about using vintage video cameras to shoot his film.
lead_paragraph: Pablo Larraín, the director of "No," talks about using vintage video cameras to shoot his film.

headline: Digital Diary: Are We Suffering From Mobile App Burnout?
abstract: The App Store used to be a virtual candy store of cool new games and services to test out and download. Is that appeal wearing thin?
lead_paragraph: At last count, I had 259 applications on my iPhone.

headline: Relinquishing Purse Strings
abstract: Orlando Bagwell is stepping down from his post at JustFilms, the Ford Foundation’s nonfiction-film-financing arm, to return to directing documentaries.
lead_paragraph: As a substitute teacher in Boston during the 1970s school-busing crisis there, Orlando Bagwell was attacked by a mob and kicked into the street. He was rescued by a bus driver. Shortly thereafter Mr. Bagwell, a fledgling filmmaker, was hired by public television to work on a piece about a South Boston protester who had changed her mind and was advocating peace. Her son, it turned out, was one of Mr. Bagwell’s attackers.

headline: Herbalife a Playground for Activist Investors
abstract: When it comes to Herbalife, whose business is hard to comprehend and which operates in a constantly challenged gray area, it is easy to alter investor perceptions.
lead_paragraph: Herbalife has become the ultimate financial plaything.

headline: What Makes Manhattan Cost So Much
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: The biggest driver of Manhattan’s high cost of living compared with other areas is housing, which costs more than four times the average for urban areas in the United States.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard the stat before: The cost of living is twice as high in New York as it is in the rest of the country. In the Council for Community and Economic Research’s latest cost of living report, we find out exactly what that means, and what the biggest distortions are.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A New Superhero Power Couple
abstract: Volume two of “Justice League” is No. 1 on the hardcover list this week.
lead_paragraph: At the top of our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week is Vol. 2 of “Justice League,” the latest collection featuring the top heroes of DC Comics. In these stories, the heroes confront a new villain and readers get a glimpse into a new power couple, whose relationship will have repercussions for everyone. Vol. 1 of the series hits our paperback list at No. 7.

headline: School Bus Drivers End Strike, in Win for New York Mayor
abstract: Union leaders said drivers suffered a toll from weeks of picketing for job protections while losing income, and they would try their luck with Mayor Michael M. Bloomberg’s successor.
lead_paragraph: The main union for New York City’s school bus drivers ended its monthlong strike Friday, handing a victory to the Bloomberg administration, which had refused to give in to the union’s demands for job protections.

keywords: ['Neo Nazi Groups', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Documentary Films and Programs']

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The workers came from across Europe to pack boxes for the online retailer Amazon at distribution centers in Germany during the Christmas rush. They did not expect to be watched over — some say intimidated — by thugs in neo-Nazi-style clothing and jackboots.

headline: Was that Fireball a Meteor or a Meteorite?
abstract: A guide to near-earth-object terminology.
lead_paragraph: As Russian speakers will be aware, more and less profane versions of the question “What was that?” punctuated many of the spectacular videos recorded in and around the Siberian city of Chelyabinsk on Friday, as what NASA calls “the Russian fireball” screamed across the sky.

headline: Why We Love Beautiful Things
abstract: If designers understood more about the mathematics of attraction, the mechanics of affection, all design could both look good and be good for you.
lead_paragraph: GREAT design, the management expert Gary Hamel once said, is like Justice Potter Stewart’s famous definition of pornography — you know it when you see it. You want it, too: brain scan studies reveal that the sight of an attractive product can trigger the part of the motor cerebellum that governs hand movement. Instinctively, we reach out for attractive things; beauty literally moves us.

headline: For Whitney Cummings, Good and Bad Ratings News
abstract: With three shows in two years, the comedian faces a mixed ratings bag.
lead_paragraph: When you have created or helped create three shows on television in less than two years, as the comedian Whitney Cummings has, the ratings can bring good news and bad news simultaneously.

abstract: The pickup truck market is crowded with many formidable competitors, but the 2013 Ram 1500 trumps them with an impressive blend of comfort and convenience.

lead_paragraph: NEW MILFORD, CONN. — It’s a reality of auto restorers’ existence that their handiwork is often scattered far from where the makeover was performed. Seldom are the cars reunited in the way that the creations of a painter or sculptor are assembled for a retrospective show.

headline: Here Comes the Giant Artificial Sun
abstract: Marc Jacobs’s show featured some props, lights and mirrors. The clothing on display was comfortable ... and likable.
lead_paragraph: The yellowish glow from the huge disc was visible through the front doors of the armory on Lexington Avenue. Within minutes of entering Marc Jacobs’s show, people were aware that they looked different and perhaps felt different, since the light robbed them of their natural color — the colors of their skin, hair, clothes.

lead_paragraph: A conversation with Ian Fisher, the former Rome bureau chief, and the religion correspondent Laurie Goodstein about reporting on the selection of a new pope.

headline: Navigating With Devices That Know Landmarks
abstract: With its Real Directions feature, some Garmin GPS units now give directions using landmarks, saying, for example, to turn left at the Starbucks.
lead_paragraph: An important goal for makers of GPS navigation devices is to deliver maps and route guidance that will not be dangerous distractions for drivers.Spoken directions would seem to be a good solution, but telling people “Turn right at Baker Street” might just make people ignore the road ahead while straining to read street signs.

headline: More Traction for Fuel-Efficient Tires
abstract: One path to fuel efficiency is through equipping cars with low-rolling-resistance tires. Such tires can improve fuel economy by as much as a mile or two per gallon.
lead_paragraph: The engineers who create gallon-squeezing cars like the Toyota Prius use every available method to comply with the ever-tightening fuel-economy standards they must meet. Those solutions may include the use of hybrid powertrains, adopting lightweight materials, cutting aerodynamic drag and minimizing the friction losses of moving parts.

headline: Lavish Lifestyle of a Lawmaker Yields Federal Charges
abstract: Documents said Jesse L. Jackson Jr., the former Illinois congressman, used about $750,000 in campaign funds to buy items like a Michael Jackson fedora.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the span of four years starting in 2007, Jesse L. Jackson Jr., then a representative from Illinois, amassed a collection of celebrity memorabilia, furs, jewelry and furniture.

headline: Sauce for the Goose, French Style
abstract: A European official says it is critical for the United States to adopt international accounting rules. But he isn’t about to give up Europe’s self-declared right to depart from such rules.
lead_paragraph: Michel Barnier, the Frenchman who is the European Commissioner for internal market and services, spoke in New York on Friday at a luncheon sponsored by the Atlantic Council and the Clearing House, and made the plea for the United States to adopt International Financial Reporting Standards, something that now seems very unlikely.

headline: Why Is Gaia Angry With Me?
abstract: When researchers tried to calculate carbon dioxide emissions by age group in the United States, baby boomers scored worst.
lead_paragraph: You may not carry a laptop case made out of recycled fixed-gear bicycle tires. And it has probably been a while since you used yak dung to heat your home. But, hey, you’re an environmentalist. At least, that’s what you and your fellow boomers tell those pollsters whenever they ask.

headline: Kenyan Court Rejects Suit Against Presidential Candidate
keywords: ['Elections', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A lower court says it does not have the jurisdiction to decide whether to disqualify Uhuru Kenyatta and his running mate because of charges brought by the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The presidential election is less than three weeks away, yet a major question that could decide the outcome hangs in the balance: should two top candidates accused of committing grave crimes be allowed to run?

headline: Movie Review | 'Like Someone in Love'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Like Someone in Love.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Like Someone in Love.”

headline: Furor Over Use of Horse Meat Grows in Britain Despite Testing
abstract: Only a small percentage of horse meat was found in products labeled as beef, but only a quarter of those products have been tested.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Battling to contain the mounting crisis over horse meat in products labeled as beef, Britain’s food safety agency said Friday that more than 2,500 tests conducted by the food industry had shown that just 29 samples contained more than 1 percent horse meat.

headline: U.S. Players Rally Behind Robbie Rogers on Twitter
abstract: Twitter reaction of current and former United States national team players to the news that Robbie Rogers had announced he was gay and “stepping away” from soccer.
lead_paragraph: Still think a gay athlete like Robbie Rogers wouldn’t be accepted in the locker room? Some of Rogers’s teammates showed their support on Friday via Twitter.

headline: Its Passengers Departed, Cruise Ship to Undergo Inspection
abstract: An investigation that experts say could last months will focus on the engine fire that knocked out power and plumbing for the Carnival cruise ship Triumph.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — After five days aboard the lifeless cruise ship Triumph, most of the 4,200 passengers and crew members finally reached their homes on Friday as Carnival Cruise Lines hauled the Triumph to a shipyard for inspection and repairs.

headline: The Boy Wonder of BuzzFeed
abstract: Ben Smith shocked many when he left Politico to take the top editorial job at the Web site BuzzFeed, where he has shown that politics and cat GIFs can happily coexist.
lead_paragraph: “BenSmithing is now an official term!” shouted Michael Hastings, a BuzzFeed reporter and author, at his book release party in Chelsea on a subfreezing night in January. The roomful of young reporters, ad salesmen and b-list political gadflies (Meghan McCain turned heads all night) hooted in approval.

headline: Dashboard Cameras, Meant to Record Accidents and Mayhem, Capture Cosmic Event
abstract: Russia has a reputation for crazy motorists and stupefying traffic accidents, leading many drivers to install dashboard cameras, which document every minute on the road.
lead_paragraph: Many of the detailed video images viewed around the world on Friday showing the explosive meteor in Russia can be traced to what may seem like an unlikely source: the country’s reputation for crazy motorists, stupefying traffic accidents and corrupt police officers. This has led many drivers in Russia to install dashboard cameras, which document every minute on the road.

headline: Famous Faces Make a Splash, Again and Again
abstract: Every season, at least one or two celebrities seem to be everywhere at New York Fashion Week, skipping from one front row to another, often with a major outfit change in between.
lead_paragraph: Didn’t we just see her? There at the Marchesa fall 2013 show at the New York Public Library on Wednesday evening was Jada Pinkett Smith, in a sexy strapless black dress, sharing the front row with Miley Cyrus, the Cosmopolitan editor in chief Joanna Coles and Lake Bell.
