abstract: New York Fashion Week has ended, but we leave you with some of our favorite designers taking their much-deserved bows.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week has ended, but we leave you with some of our favorite designers taking their much-deserved bows.

headline: In Spain, Graft Inquiry Is Widening
abstract: A high-level corruption scandal has focused Spaniards’ anger on a formerly obscure bookkeeper, and it has also shined an uncomfortable light on officials’ relations with the corporate elite.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — For 20 years, Luis Bárcenas toiled in obscurity for Spain’s governing Popular Party, working as a bookkeeper and treasurer. These days when he walks the streets of Madrid in his signature chesterfield coat, strangers lash out at him with just one word: “Envelope!”

headline: From Has-Been to Life of the Party
abstract: The Hollywood Reporter, taking a page from Vanity Fair’s playbook, now sponsors or stages glittering parties that attract the top stars — and money.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Janice Min, the editor of The Hollywood Reporter, looked a little dazed as she stood outside Spago the other night. And so what if she was? Facing a firing squad of 16 photographers and 7 TV cameras will do that to a person.

headline: Today’s Body Language With Yesterday’s Steps
abstract: Ronald K. Brown and his troupe are performing at the Joyce Theater through Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Ronald K. Brown and his company, Evidence, open their second program of the season at the Joyce Theater with Mr. Brown’s 2001 work “Walking Out the Dark.” Few dances begin more thrillingly.

headline: Testifying to the Power of Gospel’s Folk Wing
abstract: At the Allen Room on Thursday night, Mavis Staples added her brand of righteous joy to Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: More than half a century of American social history is embodied in the warm, earthy voice of the great R&B gospel singer Mavis Staples, who appeared at the Allen Room on Thursday evening as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series. Beyond being embracing and visceral, that voice is determined.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Vine Artists and Digital 2013
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include musings on the Steve Jobs action figure (retail: $200), fine art as emoticons on Twitter and security weaknesses in the Emergency Alert System as illustrated by fake zombie attack messages.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital announce a blockbuster deal for H.J. Heinz, American Airlines and US Airways announce a merger, and Brooklyn Brewery sets its sights on France.
lead_paragraph: Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital announce a blockbuster deal for H.J. Heinz, American Airlines and US Airways announce a merger, and Brooklyn Brewery sets its sights on France.

headline: Livestrong Not Immune From Turmoil Surrounding Its Founder
abstract: Lance Armstrong has experienced an extraordinary fall from grace in recent months, and the cancer-fighting foundation he founded has experienced some turbulence.
lead_paragraph: Craig Staley could barely keep up with the demand for Livestrong merchandise at Mellow Johnny’s Bike Shop in Austin, Tex., in 2008, when Lance Armstrong announced that he would return to professional cycling after a brief retirement. Customers at the store, co-owned by Armstrong, stocked up on yellow bracelets, T-shirts, sunglasses, hats and water bottles bearing the name of Armstrong’s foundation, Livestrong, which had raised millions to aid cancer research and survivors.

headline: A Night for Romantics
abstract: Alan Gilbert led the New York Philharmonic and the pianist Rudolf Buchbinder at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: By most measures Alan Gilbert, now in his fourth season as the music director of the New York Philharmonic, has brought fresh artistic vision and purpose to the orchestra. But for some, Mr. Gilbert’s performances of repertory staples, though always strong, have lacked the excitement that he can bring to contemporary music, or to personal passions like the symphonies of Carl Nielsen or the early works of Schoenberg.

headline: Photo Replay: February 15
abstract: Photo Replay: February 15
lead_paragraph: Photo Replay: February 15

headline: Easing the Passage From Prison
abstract: A Harlem “re-entry court” graduated 53 parolees, who received help with everything from getting a MetroCard to rebuilding battered family relationships and rewiring criminal thinking.
lead_paragraph: As family and friends made their way through the metal detector and past the uniformed guards, Lloyd Williams sat off to the side, going over his speech, mumbling to himself. In a few moments, the courtroom in the Harlem Community Justice Center would be filled with parolees turned graduates. After spending half his life in prison, Mr. Williams, 46, wearing a crisp suit and tie, was the valedictorian of sorts, one of the night’s guest speakers.

headline: Public Domain, My Dear Watson? Lawsuit Challenges Conan Doyle Copyrights
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Holmes, Sherlock (Fictional Character)']
abstract: A leading Sherlock Holmes scholar argues that many licensing fees paid to the estate have been unnecessary, since the main characters are no longer under U.S. copyright.
lead_paragraph: Some 125 years after his first appearance, Sherlock Holmes remains a hot literary property, inspiring thousands of pastiches, parodies and sequels in print, to saying nothing of the hit Warner Bros. film starring Robert Downey Jr. and such television series as “Elementary” and the BBC’s “Sherlock.”

headline: Facebook Says Hackers Breached Its Computers
abstract: Facebook on Friday admitted that its servers had been hacked by sophisticated malware over the last month, but said no user data was compromised in the attacks.
lead_paragraph: Facebook admitted that it was breached by sophisticated hackers in recent weeks, two weeks after Twitter made a similar admission. Both Facebook and Twitter were breached through a well-publicized vulnerability in Oracle’s Java software.

headline: Condom-Giveaway Program Celebrates Birthday
abstract: After six years, the city’s health department has increased the number of prophylactics it distributes to 30 million a year.
lead_paragraph: At an art gallery, placing four condom cakes by the front door sets a certain tone. At the event Friday morning celebrating the sixth birthday of the city health department’s NYC Condom campaign, that tone was fun mixed with triumph.

headline: Music Companies Fight Over the Scraps of EMI
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Music', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Sanctuary Records, which owns classic albums by the Kinks and Black Sabbath, was snapped up by BMG Rights.
lead_paragraph: After the main course, the leftovers.

headline: From Abroad, High Doses of Adrenaline
abstract: The Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra performed works by Mahler and Bartok on Wednesday and by Strauss and Bruckner on Thursday in concerts at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Today concerts of works by Mahler and Strauss hardly count as adventurous programming. But when the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra was founded in 1888, these composers were grateful to find in it a passionate champion of their music at a time when it was by no means self-evident to encounter, as Strauss did with relief, “an orchestra capable of playing all passages.”

headline: Boy Scouts Job Application
abstract: While a criminal conviction is not an automatic bar to getting a job with the organization, the group will not employ “known or avowed homosexuals.”
lead_paragraph: It turns out that the Boy Scouts of America — which has postponed making a decision about changing its policy of barring openly gay people from participation as scouts or scoutmasters — has another retrograde anti-gay policy.

headline: Big Ticket | Towers of Limestone, Sold for $32.5 Million
abstract: A four-bedroom apartment that includes several en-suite bathrooms, along with views of Central Park.
lead_paragraph: The luster and lure of the statuesque limestone towers Robert A. M. Stern designed at 15 Central Park West have not diminished, nor apparently has the supply of well-heeled buyers who do not flinch at the notion of spending $7,000 or more per square foot for the privilege of residing there whenever they drop into town. A four-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath condominium with multiple Central Park vistas has sold for $32.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The original listing price last June was $36 million.

headline: How the West Was Won: A Day-to-Day Struggle
abstract: An author responds to a column by David Brooks, “Carpe Diem Nation.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Saturday Reading: No Mail Today?
abstract: Readers respond to the prospect of the end of Saturday letter delivery.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn Exits
abstract: A list of the artsier Hudson River suburbs that Brooklynites are colonizing.

headline: Creating Hipsturbia
abstract: As Brooklyn bohemians reach parenting age, some are moving to the suburbs and bringing a little of their borough with them.
lead_paragraph: A yoga studio opened on Main Street that offers lunch-hour vinyasa classes. Nearby is a bicycle store that sells Dutch-style bikes, and a farm-to-table restaurant that sources its edible nasturtiums from its backyard garden.

headline: Errors in Credit Reports
abstract: The Consumer Data Industry Association says the information is largely accurate and can be disputed when it is not.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Making Voting Easier
abstract: The president of the New York State Bar Association discusses its recommendations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New Identity, Same Old History
abstract: Marcel L’Herbier’s “Late Mathias Pascal” (1926), an avant-garde adaptation of an early modernist novel by Luigi Pirandello, is restored for Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: The Late Mathias Pascal

headline: Under Colorful Lights, a Fusion Mix
abstract: Miyabi, an Asian bistro and sushi bar, is a popular weekend spot decorated like Hollywood’s idea of a nightclub.
lead_paragraph: Occupying a convenient spot around the corner from the Jacob Burns Film Center and across the street from the railway station, Miyabi is Pleasantville’s newest restaurant. It bills itself as an Asian bistro and sushi bar, a fusion mix that diners have seen before. What is surprising about Miyabi, however, is the décor and its atmosphere, which is like Hollywood’s idea of a nightclub.

headline: Madison Square Garden, Permit Lapsed, Faces New Planning Pressure
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Pennsylvania Station (NYC)', 'Signs and Signage', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Zoning']
abstract: Calls for the arena to be moved from atop Pennsylvania Station are being renewed, and the local community board voted to deny the requested extension.
lead_paragraph: Madison Square Garden has been operating without a zoning permit for three weeks and will keep doing so in the near future.

headline: A Crisis in Germany?
abstract: A reader says the German news media are fueling outrage at the missteps of politicians.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 8
abstract: Pamela Love’s jam at Milk Studios; Susanne Bartsch and Patricia Field’s party at Marquee.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Love’s jam at Milk Studios; Susanne Bartsch and Patricia Field’s party at Marquee.

headline: Let’s Shut Down the Catwalks and Dance
abstract: Plenty of parties around the city allow a well-dressed group to let their hair down.
lead_paragraph: After the final walk at the Marc Jacobs show Thursday night, many in the fashion set bolted home, either to catch up on sleep or to pack for London Fashion Week. But some partygoers were determined to finally let loose and celebrate the end of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Kim Gordon Looks Back
abstract: The Sonic Youth singer and bassist reflects on New York in the mid-’90s.
lead_paragraph: “I wasn’t joking when I said I’m not interested in talking about 1993,” said Kim Gordon, singer and bassist of the band Sonic Youth.

headline: Five-Year High Power Prices
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: The price of electricity in New England is running way above normal because the price of natural gas, which is used to generate electricity, has spiked.
lead_paragraph: The price of electricity in New England is running way above normal because the price of natural gas, which is used to generate electricity, has spiked.

headline: ‘Grazing Menu’ Goes Beyond Tacos
abstract: Bodega Taco Bar in Darien has a menu and atmosphere that wander far afield of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: I had a moment of déjà vu as I entered Bodega Taco Bar in Darien from the rear parking lot. The narrow passageway that leads to the dining room reminded me of the previous occupant of the space, Café D’Azur.

headline: CNN’s Cruise Ship Coverage Lifts Ratings
abstract: The channel, which usually loses to MSNBC and Fox News on a daily basis, easily beat MSNBC and came much closer to Fox than it usually does.
lead_paragraph: CNN’s decision to cover one story — of a stranded Carnival cruise ship in the Gulf of Mexico — like no other channel could on Thursday appeared to pay off when the Nielsen ratings came in on Friday.

headline: Nice Aliens, Evil Human
abstract: In “Escape From Planet Earth,” space-traveling blue beings are lured to Earth by an evil general seeking to steal their technology.
lead_paragraph: Another Smurf movie is due out this summer, but apparently someone’s market research indicated that the public appetite for blue animated characters might need sating before then. The result is “Escape From Planet Earth,” a children’s movie about space-traveling blue beings that has lots of high-flying escapades but fairly low aspirations.

headline: Remembering the Natty Times
abstract: Tommy Hilfiger’s father, a natty dresser, bequeathed the designer, among other things, a striped tie.
lead_paragraph: NOSTALGIA HAS BECOME — apologies to baseball — the great American pastime. So it’s slightly ironic that the 1998 film “Pleasantville,” about two modern-day teenagers accidentally transported to the 1950s black-and-white world of an old sitcom, was so ahead of its time. It even had the ambivalence right: at the film’s end, the sister, played by Reese Witherspoon, decides she actually prefers the 1950s to the 1990s, while the brother, played by Tobey Maguire, decides to go home in time.

headline: Cambodia Sees Ethical Conflict in Import Panel
abstract: Cambodia has asked that Jane A. Levine, who sits on a State Department panel on cultural property issues, recuse herself because her employer, Sotheby’s, is named in a lawsuit over an ancient Khmer statue it seeks to sell.
lead_paragraph: Cambodia has asked that a Sotheby’s executive who sits on a State Department panel that advises that agency on cultural property issues recuse herself from its deliberations on import restrictions for Cambodian antiquities.

headline: How Wrestling Lost the Olympics
abstract: Poor leadership allowed the sport’s enemies to take it down.
lead_paragraph: IN A.D. 393, the ancient Olympic Games were abolished — they had become too corrupt. Wrestling was among the first sports in those ancient Games; wrestling was also included at the start of the modern Olympics, in 1896.

headline: In This House, Don’t Fixate on the Views
abstract: In the Bollywood thriller “Murder 3,” a photographer attracts women to his gorgeous estate, but then they tend to disappear.
lead_paragraph: The best attribute of “Murder 3,” described by the Bollywood press machine as an “erotic thriller” (hmm to both of those), is its primary setting: a gorgeous estate that deserves two thumbs up from the folks at Architectural Digest. Ah, that kitchen, that porch, that bedroom: It’s house porn worthy of the films of Nancy Meyers (“It’s Complicated,” “Something’s Gotta Give”).

headline: Bill Cunningham | Playing Footsie
abstract: At New York Fashion Week showgoers were climbing over slush and snow in their exotic stiletto heels, some with open toes and backs.
lead_paragraph: At New York Fashion Week showgoers were climbing over slush and snow in their exotic stiletto heels, some with open toes and backs.

headline: Ira Rubin at the 1962 Cavendish Invitational Pairs
abstract: A deal in 1962 featured an excellent defensive play by Ira Rubin’s partner, Philip Feldesman.
lead_paragraph: Here is another deal I found while researching Ira Rubin, who died on Feb. 6 at 82. This one occurred during the Cavendish Invitational Pairs in 1962, played in New York City. It featured an excellent defensive play by Rubin’s partner, Philip Feldesman.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 15
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show']
abstract: Subjects include a gigantic Northeast snowstorm, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg’s retirement announcement and the Westminster Dog Show at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gigantic Northeast snowstorm, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg’s retirement announcement and the Westminster Dog Show at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Lawsuit Against Prosecutor to Proceed
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Elections, District Attorneys', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: A judge’s ruling means the suit by a man wrongfully convicted of murder could require Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, to defend his policies in the middle of a re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled on Friday that a lawsuit by a wrongfully convicted man against the office of the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, and the New York Police Department could proceed, setting the stage for a trial in which Mr. Hynes could be called to testify in defense of his policies amid a heated re-election campaign.

headline: Lincoln, the Play and Everything After
abstract: “Killing Lincoln,” on the National Geographic Channel, mixes narration by Tom Hanks with re-enactments to chronicle the plot to kill the president.
lead_paragraph: Tom Hanks, Steven Spielberg’s frequent collaborator, snags himself a seat on Mr. Spielberg’s bandwagon on Sunday when he turns up as the narrator of “Killing Lincoln,” a docudrama on the National Geographic Channel.

headline: Two Observations on the Politics of the Minimum Wage
abstract: Message: They don’t care, and they probably can’t fake it.
lead_paragraph: It looks as if President Obama has successfully set a political trap over the minimum wage. Raising the minimum is very popular — even a narrow majority of Republicans (pdf) are for it. But Republican leaders are opposed. And they’d like people to believe that their opposition is driven by sincere concern for workers who might lose their jobs.

headline: New York Fashion Week: About Extremes
abstract: Cathy Horyn takes a look at the fall 2013 collections.
lead_paragraph: Cathy Horyn takes a look at the fall 2013 collections.

headline: Incomes Flat in Recovery, but Not for the 1%
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Minimum Wage', 'United States Economy', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: New data show uneven benefits from the economic recovery of 2010-11, with a big rise for the highest earners and little change for others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Incomes rose more than 11 percent for the top 1 percent of earners during the economic recovery, but not at all for everybody else, according to new data.

headline: Unfashionable Yet Visionary
abstract: The German artist A. R. Penck, member of a school on the outs with art historians, returns to New York with some of his best paintings in years.
lead_paragraph: With the way art history is being written and rewritten these days, Neo-Expressionism is pretty much the odd man out. For one thing, its perpetrators were mostly painters and mostly male. For another, they tended to approach their work without the obvious Conceptual underpinnings that are now so de rigueur. Among the Germans, only the consistently subversive and innovative Sigmar Polke, never really a card-carrying Neo-Expressionist, has genuine street cred right now, while Anselm Kiefer has settled into a particularly overbearing style and a gassy form of art stardom.

headline: Public Recreation Centers Looking to Stem Exodus
abstract: New York City’s parks department lost 45 percent of its members after it doubled its prices a year and a half ago, losing about $200,000 instead of making $4 million in new revenue.
lead_paragraph: Under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the city has made fighting obesity and improving public health one of its top priorities.

headline: Friday Night Music: Take the F Train
abstract: We’re broke in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Lone Bellow calls what they do “Brooklyn country music”; here they let their bridge-and-tunnel flag fly:

headline: Stargazing: The Finale
abstract: The end of another New York Fashion Week brings about a collective sigh of relief (and some final celebrities).
lead_paragraph: The Ralph Lauren runway show always brings about a collective sigh of relief. There is the smooth check-in process, the generous riser-style runway seating and, in its usual time-and-day slot, the signal that you have survived another New York Fashion Week.

headline: Welcome to Change
abstract: It goes without saying that we’ve updated the magazine to please you. We sincerely hope it will.
lead_paragraph: T is a magazine about style in all its dimensions. As such, it aspires not merely to reflect the times we live in, but to illuminate cultural shifts in a thought-provoking and exciting way. Style, to us, encompasses all the elements of life that aren’t absolutely necessary, but without which life would be less charmed, less beautiful and certainly not as fun.

headline: Pan-Asian, With Dim Sum Every Day
abstract: Ting has kept much of the décor of the previous restaurant at its location, including rock gardens, vaulted gold-tiled ceiling and chandeliers.
lead_paragraph: There are some locations that seem to have a revolving door, with restaurants opening and closing in rapid succession. In Huntington, 92 East Main Street is one of them. The current occupant, Ting, a pan-Asian entry like its predecessors, opened in October and is owned by Yu Mei Zheng, a first-time restaurateur.

headline: A Night’s Toll: Two Teeth and $2,800
abstract: The victim of the Upper West Side robbery, a bartender who had been drinking, had no recollection of what had happened.
lead_paragraph: He awakened in his apartment two Wednesdays ago in agony. “Searing pain,” he said later. He found a mirror. Two of his teeth — a front one and one beside it — were missing.

headline: Amid Turmoil at Museo del Barrio, Its Director Steps Down
abstract: Margarita Aguilar’s departure as El Museo del Barrio’s director comes as the museum cuts operating hours and staff.
lead_paragraph: Margarita Aguilar, the director of El Museo del Barrio since August 2011, has left the position amid turmoil at the museum, which in recent months has slashed its days of operation and instituted layoffs and furloughs, museum officials confirmed on Friday.

headline: South African Star Reflects on Pistorius Case
abstract: Charl Schwartzel says he is aware of the long shadow that violence casts in his home country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They are both A-list sports celebrities in South Africa, but Charl Schwartzel, the 2011 Masters champion, said he has never met Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star accused of fatally shooting his girlfriend.

headline: Elizabeth and James: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: For the ‘Cake Boss,’ Real-World Growth
abstract: Carlo’s Bake Shop Ridgewood is the first full-service offshoot of Carlo’s, the bake shop run by Buddy Valastro, the man behind two reality-television shows.
lead_paragraph: THE LINE OUTSIDE Carlo’s Bake Shop Ridgewood last Sunday morning is not likely to be an everyday occurrence, according to Adam Bourcier, a spokesman who was guarding the door against occupancy overload. The presence of the throng had to do with who was inside for the grand opening, he said.

headline: When the New You Carries a Fresh Identity, Too
keywords: ['Names, Personal', 'Families and Family Life', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: More women are changing their names, celebrities included, particularly at the time of divorce, thanks to the name change order in the decree.
lead_paragraph: When I was 5, my older brother informed me my last name wouldn’t always be Wood. My father confirmed it. “If your husband’s last name is Peabody, you’ll have to become Mrs. Peabody,” he teased. I hid behind my bedroom door to process this startling information privately. If I could so easily become a Peabody, did that mean I was worth less to my family than my two brothers, who would go forth and propagate the world with more children bearing the last name Wood? And just who was this Mr. Peabody and what was so great about him that I would give up my name to marry him?

headline: Scorer’s Touch, Gone Missing in Philadelphia, Returns in Toronto
abstract: James van Riemsdyk, the No. 2 pick in the 2007 N.H.L. draft, is thriving with the Toronto Maple Leafs, who acquired him from Philadelphia in a summer deal.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — James van Riemsdyk grew up in New Jersey, played in college at New Hampshire and began his N.H.L. career in Philadelphia. But it took a move to Toronto to get van Riemsdyk playing like the power forward he was expected to be when he was selected No. 2 over all in the 2007 draft.

headline: A Big Menu, Starring Fresh Seafood
abstract: At Tsuru Japanese Cuisine, the menu is expansive and the shape of the dining room is out of the ordinary.
lead_paragraph: Tsuru Japanese Cuisine is tucked into an ersatz village in Basking Ridge, but don’t let the antiseptic surroundings deter you. If two visits are any indication of this place, there’s nothing fake about the experience. Tsuru is a friendly spot offering simple, well-prepared food, especially fresh and delicious sushi and sashimi.

headline: Child Abuse at Reservation Is Topic for 3 Lawmakers
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Spirit Lake Tribe (Sioux)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Native Americans']
abstract: North Dakota’s senators and a congressman will attend a town hall meeting this month to discuss the child sexual abuse problem on the Spirit Lake Indian Reservation.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials will hold a town hall meeting on the Spirit Lake Indian Reservation in North Dakota this month to discuss the reservation’s child sexual abuse problem, which last year led the federal government to take over the tribe’s social services program.

headline: Collins Opens Door to Byrd in Outfield
abstract: Marlon Byrd, who signed with the Mets this winter, says he’s happy to be playing for a spot on the roster, but Manager Terry Collins sees bigger possibilities.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Marlon Byrd arrived at the Mets’ spring training center on Friday afternoon, and though his stay there has no guarantees, it started with a ringing endorsement that spoke to the team’s underwhelming talent in the outfield.

headline: In New England, a Natural Gas Trap
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Heating']
abstract: The region’s reliance on natural gas for power generation has collided recently with a surge in demand for heating.
lead_paragraph: Electricity prices in New England have been four to eight times higher than normal in the last few weeks, as the region’s extreme reliance on natural gas for power supplies has collided with a surge in demand for heating.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Good Fit for Today’s Little Screens: Short Stories
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Writing and Writers', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The short-story collection, often an underappreciated literary cousin of novels, is now enjoying the limelight, thanks to digital media.
lead_paragraph: The Internet may be disrupting much of the book industry, but for short-story writers it has been a good thing.

headline: 19th-Century Perspectives on Two Great Rivers
abstract: “The Panoramic River: The Hudson and the Thames,” an exhibition at the Hudson River Museum, offers a virtual tour of the 19th century’s fascination with traveling without moving.
lead_paragraph: In an age when the mere push of a button or the click of a mouse can summon a satellite view of just about any place on the planet, how can we understand the thrill that 19th-century Londoners felt as they gazed at painted views of the Catskills, or the excitement of New Yorkers looking at 3-D photographs — called stereographs — of Hyde Park?

headline: Senators Overboard!
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: What’s going on with the process of getting us a new secretary of defense? Sometimes Washington really is a Carnival.
lead_paragraph: We seem to be short one secretary of defense.

headline: As Fisheries Struggle, Debate Heats Up Over How to Help
abstract: The prospect of millions of dollars in aid, aimed at reviving the fishery industry, has divided fishermen and officials in Gloucester, Mass., over the future of the area’s shoreline economy.
lead_paragraph: GLOUCESTER, Mass. — B. G. Brown, a second-generation fisherman who chases cod and haddock from this port city, spent a recent morning rigging up his 31-foot commercial vessel to be manned alone. He had just lost his only crew member to the more lucrative lobster fishery, days after fishery regulators last month approved a 77 percent cut in the amount of cod that can be harvested from the Gulf of Maine waters here.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: All Bundled Up, but With Hearts on the Wing
abstract: A production of John Cariani’s “Almost, Maine” at TheaterWorks Hartford does a lovely, witty job of showing off its romantic but unsentimental heart.
lead_paragraph: There are things you should know about the weird and wondrous Maine town called Almost. It is the sort of place where a young woman, if she had a broken heart, might put all 19 pieces inside a brown paper bag and carry it around. The kind of town where a guy cannot deny that he has fallen in love because he suddenly starts falling down. (Collapsing completely. Over and over. Can’t stand up for more than a few seconds.) A town where you can get up from a park bench, walk around the world and return by the end of Act II. Where the local hangout is the Moose Paddy and, as the waitress points out, “Drinks are free if you’re sad.”

headline: T’s Spring Women’s Fashion
abstract: The latest issue of T highlights elegance and simplicity.
lead_paragraph: The spring women’s fashion issue of T marks the unveiling of a redesigned magazine, from its features to its logo. Emphasizing elegance and simplicity, the issue begins with a profile of the 79-year-old style icon Lee Radziwill, photographed in her Paris apartment, and moves onto another Parisian paragon of style, the designer Azzedine Alaïa, whose perfectly simple clothing is among fashion’s most celebrated. Also in the issue is a peek into the working lives of the duo behind the label Proenza Schouler, who are at their most creative at their Berkshires farmhouse; a profile of the PPR head François-Henri Pinault; and an introduction to Jonathan Anderson, a front-runner in a talented pack of new British designers. Additional highlights from the magazine include the best accessories of the season, an unexpectedly sophisticated retreat in Mexico and one of the chicest houses in London. See all from the issue ->

headline: Kentuckians Don’t Rule Out a Star as a Potential Senator
abstract: The actress Ashley Judd, a possible challenger to Senator Mitch McConnell, has already become a target of a Republican “Super PAC.”
lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ky. — It would seem like a Republican fantasy: a famous actress, who has been described by her own grandmother as a Hollywood liberal, is floated as a Senate candidate in one of the country’s most conservative states, where she does not even live.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.

headline: Rise of Drones in U.S. Drives Efforts to Limit Police Use
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Police', 'States (US)']
abstract: Drones are becoming a darling of law enforcement officials across the country. But they have prompted  fears of government surveillance, often even before they take to the skies.
lead_paragraph: They can record video images and produce heat maps. They can be used to track fleeing criminals, stranded hikers — or just as easily, political protesters. And for strapped police departments, they are more affordable than helicopters.

headline: Getting Preschool Education Right
abstract: President Obama’s proposal for expanding high-quality preschool education, which aims at excellence, deserves a fair hearing.
lead_paragraph: Even before the cost estimates and program details have been made public, President Obama’s proposal for expanding high-quality preschool education has encountered criticism from House Republicans. Yet decades of research has shown that well-designed preschool programs more than pay for themselves by giving young children the skills they need to move ahead. The challenge at the federal level will be to make sure that taxpayer dollars flow to proven, high-quality programs instead of being wasted on subsidies for glorified day care.

headline: Transition in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States military faces tough challenges in one outpost as the draw down begins.
lead_paragraph: The United States military faces tough challenges in one outpost as the draw down begins.

keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Gun Control', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'School Shootings']
abstract: The pension fund’s board voted to get rid of holdings from five gun companies, making the fund the biggest in the country so far to shed such holdings.
lead_paragraph: The New York City teachers’ pension fund, reacting to an outcry that has intensified since the school shootings in Newtown, Conn., has voted to shed its portfolio of five gun companies despite the objections of a representative for a prominent gun-control advocate: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Showing Gifts to Mark an Anniversary
abstract: After recently mounting a show to commemorate the university’s 75th year, the directors of the museum will focus on recent gifts from a diverse group of donors for its 50th year celebration.
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — The Hofstra University Museum, founded in 1963, had a decision to make as its 50th anniversary approached: Of the more than 5,000 works in its collection, which would be put on display to celebrate the event?

lead_paragraph: Across the country, state securities regulators are reporting an upsurge in fraud cases involving retirement savers who have been lured by brokers into complex investments.

abstract: The lacrosse team, coming off a 2012 championship, sprinted up and down hills, tossed medicine balls and carried teammates during off-season workouts to build targeted strength and endurance.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When the Loyola men’s lacrosse team beat Maryland, 9-3, in the May heat of Foxborough, Mass., it won the university’s first Division I championship in any sport.

headline: U.S. Military Faces Fire as It Pulls Out of Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As American troops get ready to speed up their withdrawal, it is clear some of it will happen under fire, as Taliban fighters try to strike in areas where the idea of Afghan-led security remains an abstraction.
lead_paragraph: STRONG POINT HAJI RAHMUDDIN II, Afghanistan — When the last American soldiers to occupy this squat, lonely outpost in southern Afghanistan pulled out this week, they left the same way earlier units had arrived: ready for a fight.

headline: Free Tuition at Cooper Union May Be Near End
abstract: The prestigious college in New York is known for charging its students nothing, but financial problems may have made that practice unaffordable.
lead_paragraph: The new academic building was glamorous, its perforated metal skin shooting up dramatically from the streets of the East Village, then swerving around a daring gash of glass. It made a statement about just how far the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art had come, from its 19th-century origins as a charity for the poor to one of the most selective colleges in the nation.

headline: Renew the Violence Against Women Act
keywords: ['Violence Against Women Act (1994)', 'Domestic Violence', 'Native Americans', 'Editorials', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The reauthorization of the Senate bill provides a refreshing demonstration of bipartisanship that the House would do well to emulate.
lead_paragraph: This week’s 78-to-22 vote in the Senate to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act provided a refreshing demonstration of bipartisanship that the House would do well to emulate. Last year, the Republican-led House blocked the act’s renewal over objections to new protections for gay, immigrant and American Indian victims of domestic violence and sexual assault. It falls to Speaker John Boehner to see that this does not happen again.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Feb. 16, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, Feb. 16, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "It was a light which never happens in life; it happens probably only in the end of the world.”

headline: Heading for a Hotter Time in Rio Than Expected
abstract: More than a play about three sex tourists, “Carnaval” reveals backgrounds and secrets, and adds serious tension at the end.
lead_paragraph: Three friends take a pleasure trip to Brazil. One man behaves like an immature jerk. Another is in over his head with disreputable business associates. The third is the requisite goody-goody. Lives are changed, for good and bad, but maybe not quite enough.

headline: A Strange Show in the Sky Over Siberia
abstract: Hundreds were injured, most of them by glass shattered by the shock wave created when a meteor exploded as it entered the atmosphere.

headline: Exonerating the Scottsboro Nine
abstract: The Alabama Legislature finally moves to grant posthumous pardons, a confirmation of the travesty 80 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Decades too late, the Alabama Legislature is moving to grant posthumous pardons to the Scottsboro Boys — the nine black teenagers arrested as freight train hoboes in 1931 and convicted by all-white juries of raping two white women.

headline: Don’t Mythologize Christopher Dorner
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: He is the wrong emblem for those wronged by the system.
lead_paragraph: I am no stranger to people’s glomming on to deadly criminals and celebrating them as heroes. Bonnie and Clyde were killed just south of the town where I grew up. There was that movie made about the couple, as well as a musical and more songs that I can count. And every year the town celebrates the duo and their killing with a festival and a shootout.

headline: New Scrutiny for a Bequest to an Order of Catholics
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: A Rhode Island judge ordered documents to be released in a lawsuit over a widow’s $60 million gift to the Legion of Christ, whose founder molested seminarians and fathered children.
lead_paragraph: When Gabrielle D. Mee, a wealthy Rhode Island widow, left her $60 million fortune to a powerful Catholic order called the Legion of Christ in 2008, revelations had already begun to surface that its charismatic founder, the Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado, had molested under-age seminarians and fathered several children.

headline: A Reminder of Personal Connections, Not Tarnished Brand
abstract: Lance Armstrong’s confession of drug use has, for some, done little to diminish the meaning of the tattoos that bear the name of his foundation to raise cancer awareness.
lead_paragraph: As Jax Mariash went under the tattoo needle to have “Livestrong” emblazoned on her wrist in bold black letters, she did not think about Lance Armstrong or doping allegations, but rather the 10 people affected by cancer she wanted to commemorate in ink. It was Jan. 22, 2010, exactly a year since the disease had taken the life of her stepfather. After years of wearing yellow Livestrong wristbands, she wanted something permanent.

headline: Ecuador’s President Shows Confidence About Re-election, Too Much for Some
abstract: If President Rafael Correa’s party wins a majority in the National Assembly, critics fear it will only allow him to concentrate power.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the final analysis, Edwin Tatés supports President Rafael Correa of Ecuador and wants him to be re-elected. He just does not want it to be too easy.

lead_paragraph: Every Sunday in the Metropolitan section, a photographer offers a new slice of New York.

headline: High School Junior Makes Mile the Race to Watch
abstract: Mary Cain, who holds several high school girls track records, will highlight the women’s field at Saturday’s Millrose Games.
lead_paragraph: The high point of the Millrose Games is typically the men’s Wanamaker Mile, the finale of the country’s best known indoor track and field meet. At this year’s meet, which will be held Saturday at the 168th Street Armory in Upper Manhattan, the highlight may end up being the women’s mile, which will be run more than an hour earlier.

headline: Syrian Opposition Group Is Open to Talks, With Conditions
abstract: The group formally endorsed an initiative to pursue a political solution with the government, provided that President Bashar al-Assad is excluded.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s main opposition body on Friday formally endorsed an initiative to pursue a political solution through talks with members of the Syrian government — provided that Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, and security and military leaders involved in his bloody crackdown are excluded.

headline: Yankees Practice Patience With Pineda’s Return
abstract: Michael Pineda’s torn labrum has dictated a slow, methodical approach toward his regular-season debut with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The rehabilitating pitchers always go first. Half the Yankees pitchers and catchers were still getting dressed or eating breakfast when Michael Pineda walked into the clubhouse Friday morning, toweled off his sweaty face and ditched his cap in his locker before heading to the training room.

headline: Dr. Wheelchair Is In
abstract: Mike Acevedo leads a team that builds, repairs and maintains wheelchairs for most of the 1,300 patients at the Coler-Goldwater Specialty Hospital and Nursing Facility on Roosevelt Island.
lead_paragraph: On Roosevelt Island, Mike Acevedo, 54, is known as Dr. Wheelchair, because he has been keeping patients at the Coler-Goldwater Specialty Hospital and Nursing Facility rolling since 1976.

headline: Pope Names German Industrialist to Head Vatican Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI has named Ernst von Freyberg, a German aristocrat and industrialist, as the new head of the Vatican Bank, reducing the Italian presence there.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In one of his last official acts, Pope Benedict XVI on Friday named Ernst von Freyberg, a German aristocrat and industrialist, as the new head of the Vatican Bank, reducing the Italian presence in a secretive institution that has struggled to restore its credibility and meet international transparency norms.

headline: A Flash in Russian Skies, as Inspiration for Fantasy
abstract: Past and present practitioners of fantasy fiction in print and movies reacted to the views of the meteor that whistled and boomed across Russian skies on Friday with awe — and some new ideas.
lead_paragraph: Life is scariest when it imitates science fiction. The stunning video of the meteor that whistled and boomed across Russian skies on Friday unnerved even those with long experience imagining catastrophic events. Past and present practitioners of fantasy fiction in print and movies reacted to the views with awe — and some new ideas.

headline: Of History and Romance
abstract: At Harlem Public on upper Broadway, three girlfriends celebrated one’s acceptance to a doctoral program and traded guy talk over craft beers and burgers.
lead_paragraph: On upper Broadway, where hair salons and barbershops bustle well into the evening and markets sell plantains in outdoor bins, a bar with incongruous chic invites the neighborhood in for a beer. Step inside Harlem Public on Broadway at 149th Street and the trendy touches borrowed from elsewhere in the city are easy to spot. There are 16 taps of craft beer and about a dozen whiskeys from local distilleries. The décor is made from reclaimed wood and corrugated metal. An ambitious menu includes avocado fries, a peanut butter burger and a decadent grilled cheese sandwich. Right now the cast iron gas fireplace, which took months of wrangling to install, is on the fritz. But the six-month-old bar generates its own heat, humming to an alternative soundtrack. And on Feb. 24, it will start brunch service.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Size of Blast and Number of Injuries Are Seen as Rare for a Rock From Space
abstract: The meteor that exploded over Russia was said to have set off the largest explosion of its kind in more than a century. And  more unusual, it left many people hurt, mostly from flying glass.
lead_paragraph: The meteor that exploded over Russia on Friday set off the largest explosion of its kind in more than a century, at least according to Western scientists. And even more unusual for a meteor, it caused numerous injuries, mostly from flying glass, as the shock wave violently jolted the city of Chelyabinsk below.

headline: 2 Prostituted by Force, Officials Say
abstract: The Queens district attorney said a couple kidnapped two women and forced them into prostitution for about three months.
lead_paragraph: A Queens couple held two young women in a foreclosed home, and used threats and violence to force them into prostitution for months, the district attorney said Friday.

headline: Shadow Morton, Songwriter and Producer, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Morton, with songs like “Remember (Walking in the Sand)” and “Leader of the Pack,” helped propel the Shangri-Las, a 1960s girl group from Queens, to stardom.
lead_paragraph: Shadow Morton, a songwriter and producer who for a brief, luminous period in the 1960s poured the discontents of adolescence into original hit songs, including “Leader of the Pack” and “Remember (Walking in the Sand),” died on Thursday in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 71.

headline: Edith Houghton, Rare Woman Among Baseball Scouts, Dies at 100
abstract: A shortstop at 10, Ms. Houghton later became a pioneer with the Philadelphia Phillies.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Phillies were perennial cellar-dwellers in 1946 when Edith Houghton, a slim, dark-haired young woman in her 30s, walked into the team office without an appointment and talked her way into an unlikely job. She became one of the first women — and to this day one of the only women — to scout for a major league baseball team.

headline: Afghan Insurgent Is Killed on U.S.-Led Military Base
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Coalition forces in Afghanistan are investigating the death of a tribal leader who was shot at a military base after being questioned and released.
lead_paragraph: KABUL — American Special Operations Forces stopped a tribal leader as he was driving with his brother and 6-year-old son in an area rife with Taliban in southern Afghanistan on Wednesday. A quick examination of his identity documents confirmed that he was a wanted man.

headline: Off the Court, and With the Family
abstract: For New York Knicks center Tyson Chandler, an ideal Sunday is full of food, family, photography and more food.
lead_paragraph: A dozen years into his N.B.A. career, the New York Knicks center Tyson Chandler, 30, has quietly accrued some shiny hardware: an N.B.A. championship ring, an Olympic gold medal, and a Defensive Player of the Year trophy. But this season, Mr. Chandler, 7-foot-1, can no longer “fly under the radar,” as he likes to say. He was named to his first All-Star team and is playing, along with his teammate Carmelo Anthony, in Sunday’s game in Houston. Rare is the Sunday off from Knicks practice when he can spend the full day with his wife, Kimberly, 31, and their three children, Sacha-Marie, 6; Tyson II, 4; and Sayge Jozzelle, 2, in their Upper East Side apartment. His ideal Sunday is full of food, family, photography — and more food.

headline: Richard L. Murphy, Who Aided Disadvantaged Youths, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Murphy helped tens of thousands in New York City through his community organization in Harlem and as the city’s youth commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Richard L. Murphy, a social policy innovator who aided tens of thousands of disadvantaged New York City children and teenagers through his community organization in Harlem and as the city’s youth commissioner under Mayor David N. Dinkins, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 68.

headline: A New Crime, but Convictions Are Elusive
keywords: ['Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: A 2010 law aimed at domestic violence increased penalties for choking. But though it is now easier to charge someone with a felony for choking, the act can leave few marks, making it hard to prove.
lead_paragraph: First, the victim testified, her boyfriend bashed her head against the bathtub. In the bedroom of her Upper East Side apartment, she said, he slammed her down so hard on the bed that the frame broke, punched her all over her body, and spat in her face.

headline: Iran: Pistachio Exports Are Suspended
keywords: ['Nuts', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Pistachio nuts, one of Iran’s most profitable products, appear to be latest victim of domestic inflation, so much so that the government has ordered a moratorium on exports.
lead_paragraph: Pistachio nuts, one of Iran’s most profitable products, appear to be latest victim of domestic inflation, so much so that the government has ordered a moratorium on exports as part of an effort to increase the supply at home and reduce the price, which has doubled just in the past month. The Associated Press quoted Vice President Mohammad-Reza Rahimi as saying the export ban would last for six months. But it was unclear whether the move, which he announced Friday, would reduce domestic prices, particularly in time for Nowruz, the coming New Year holiday when pistachios are in especially high demand. It was also unclear to what extent the higher price reflected the declining value of the rial, Iran’s currency, which has been weakened by the effects of Western sanctions and what critics call the government’s economic mismanagement. The chairman of Iran’s chamber of exports, Asadollah Asgaroladi, was quoted by the Fars News Agency as calling the export moratorium a mistake that would do little to ease the price and probably cost Iran more than $500 million in lost export revenue. He was also quoted as saying the ban would only strengthen the competitiveness of pistachios from the United States, which surpassed Iran in total pistachio production last year.

headline: Keeping Reggae Alive
abstract: For 30 years, Watty Burnett, the roots reggae artist, has been living in Dix Hills, Long Island, working as a part-time electrician. He has three new albums on the way.
lead_paragraph: For 30 years, Watty Burnett, the roots reggae artist, has been living in Dix Hills, Long Island, working as a part-time electrician. He has three new albums on the way.

headline: Colombia: Rebels Release Captives
abstract: The country’s largest guerrilla group released two police officers it had taken captive in an action that appeared to have briefly threatened the group’s peace talks with the government.
lead_paragraph: The country’s largest guerrilla group on Friday released two police officers it had taken captive in a recent action that appeared to have briefly threatened the group’s peace talks with the government. The police officers were captured by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, in January, shortly after the group ended a two-month unilateral cease-fire. Government peace negotiators reacted angrily to the officers’ capture and the FARC quickly promised to release them. The FARC and the government began talks last fall to end their nearly 50-year war. Also on Friday, another rebel group, the National Liberation Army, or ELN, released five mining company contractors it kidnapped last month, said the International Committee of the Red Cross, which assisted with the release. In a Twitter post President Juan Manuel Santos criticized the ELN for not also releasing a Canadian captive.

headline: Off Reggae’s Grid, Back on the Map
abstract: Watty Burnett, a Jamaican reggae musician and the baritone vocalist for the Congos, is making a musical comeback after decades as a family man on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: In Rastafarian culture, Babylon symbolizes the corruption of Western society. Bob Marley sang of its oppressions; the Melodians wept by its rivers. But for Watty Burnett, a Jamaican reggae musician who recorded with Mr. Marley, these days Babylon is just a Long Island town nine miles down the road.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 16
abstract: Meteor damage in Russia; corruption in Spain; challenge in Afghanistan; Scottish whiskey fight.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Around 1,200 Russians were injured after a meteor hit the atmosphere, and residents of Chelyabinsk were left to deal with memories that seemed to belong in science fiction. The scenes from Chelyabinsk, rocked by an intense shock wave when a meteor hit the Earth’s atmosphere Friday morning, offer a glimpse of an apocalyptic scenario that many have walked through mentally, and Hollywood has popularized, but scientists say has never before injured so many people.  Ellen Barry and Andrew E. Kramer report from Moscow.

headline: U.S. Embassy Denies Intervening in Mexico Cabinet Choice
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']

lead_paragraph: The United States Embassy in Mexico on Friday issued a statement denying an article in The New York Times that reported that Ambassador Anthony Wayne had met with senior Mexican officials to discuss American concerns about the possible appointment of Gen. Moisés García Ochoa of Mexico as that country’s defense secretary.

headline: Online Battle Over Sacred Scrolls, Real-World Consequences
keywords: ['Dead Sea Scrolls', 'Imposters', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Raphael Haim Golb, 53, is headed to jail for waging an Internet campaign against his father’s academic rivals over the origins of the Dead Sea Scrolls.
lead_paragraph: There is a saying about academia that the disputes are so vicious because the stakes are so low. In the case of Raphael Haim Golb, a son of a Dead Sea Scrolls scholar, the last few years have provided ample support for the first half of the saying. But the second half is less accurate.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:50 P.M. (Encore) WATERWORLD (1995) “Dry land is a myth!” Or so they say in this post-apocalyptic action film, in which the oceans seemingly cover the entire planet, and the last vestiges of humanity struggle for survival. Kevin Costner is the Mariner, an enigmatic misanthrope who nonetheless becomes the protector of a child (Tina Majorino, above with Mr. Costner and Jeanne Tripplehorn) who could lead the way to dry land, if he can fend off the Deacon (Dennis Hopper) and his army of jet-ski-driving commandos. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said that the film was “a big, brawny, overzealously bizarre epic punctuated by daring action scenes, which are sloppily assembled (the sky or ocean color seldom matches in any two consecutive scenes) but still exciting.”

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: A week-long curfew in the Kashmir Valley that was imposed after the execution of the militant Muhammad Afzal was lifted Saturday, NDTV reported. Supporters of Mr. Afzal, who hailed from the Sopore town of Baramulla district, believed that he received an unfair trial for his role in the deadly Parliament attack case of 2001. Internet and television services have been restored in Kashmir after having been shut down, the report said.

headline: New Era for U.S. Women’s Team
abstract: The U.S. women’s national team has a new coach and a bunch of new players, but the goal is the same — win the next Women’s World Cup.
lead_paragraph: In the first United States women’s national team games of 2013, four players got their first caps, during which time we also celebrated Abby Wambach’s 200th. Jane Campbell, 17, got her first call-up and trained alongside Christie Rampone, 37, who has been a part of the team since Campbell was a toddler. Sydney Leroux and Whitney Engen got their first starts, and Christen Press scored three goals in her first two national team appearances.
