headline: The Nassau Coliseum Starts Its Long Goodbye
abstract: Nassau Coliseum has served as the home of the Islanders since 1972, but the team will move to Barclays Center in Brooklyn beginning with the 2015-16 season.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — To enter Nassau Coliseum is to step back in time. It has been the Islanders’ home since their inception in 1972 and retains the intimacy of an Original Six rink.

headline: Prospect Eager to Hold Tigers’ Fate in Hands
abstract: Bruce Rondon, who has pitched only eight innings above Class AA, is expected to open the season as the closer for the American League champion Tigers.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — The minor leaguers of the Detroit Tigers mostly stay in a dormitory on the Tiger Town campus at spring training. It is a short walk from the major league clubhouse at Joker Marchant Stadium, but most of the Tigers can go through their workday without ever seeing it.

headline: Renewed Push for Afghans to Make Peace With Taliban
abstract: Eight countries’ diplomats are refocusing on talks between Afghanistan and the Taliban before NATO troops leave, but sharply different visions for peace have hindered the effort.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Suddenly, the effort to strike a deal with the Taliban is very publicly back on the front burner.

headline: The Future of Sprint Cup Waits to Take the Next Step
keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series', 'Dating and Courtship']
abstract: Ricky Stenhouse Jr., the First Boyfriend of auto racing, is leading a wave of young drivers who could transform Nascar as a generation of champions nears the end of their careers.
lead_paragraph: Ricky Stenhouse Jr. wears a cowboy hat and western boots and dates Danica Patrick. So even before he straps in for the Daytona 500 next Sunday, the first race of his rookie season in the Sprint Cup series, he already stands out in the Nascar garage.

headline: Can Rivals’ Hatred Become Teammates’ Amity? It’s Happened
abstract: After Sal Maglie joined the Dodgers, he and Carl Furillo reconciled, though their battles were graver than those of Joba Chamberlain and Kevin Youkilis, now a Yankee.
lead_paragraph: The pinstriped teammate treaty between Kevin Youkilis, the Yankees’ new third baseman and former Red Sox star, and Joba Chamberlain, once suspended for firing two fastballs over Youkilis’s head, evolved from a kindergarten spat compared with what went on between Carl Furillo and his longtime tormentor, the New York Giants right-hander Sal Maglie, before they suddenly became teammates on the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1956.

headline: Karzai to Ban Afghan Forces From Requesting Foreign Airstrikes
abstract: President Hamid Karzai said he would issue a decree barring the Afghan military from asking international troops to carry out airstrikes under “any circumstances.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai said Saturday that he would issue a decree forbidding his military forces from turning to NATO or American forces to conduct airstrikes, and he condemned the use of torture on detainees by his security forces.

headline: Keiko Fukuda, a Trailblazer in Judo, Dies at 99
abstract: Ms. Fukuda learned judo from its founder and went on to become the sport’s highest-ranked woman.
lead_paragraph: Keiko Fukuda, who learned judo from its inventor and went on to become the sport’s highest-ranked woman, died on Feb. 9 at her home in San Francisco. She was 99.

headline: In Chicago, Especially, Jordan Still Reigns Supreme
abstract: The Bulls finally have another marquee star, Derrick Rose, but he is six championships behind Michael Jordan, who turns 50 on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Michael Jordan’s 50th birthday falls on Sunday, the day of the 62nd N.B.A. All-Star Game.

headline: 17-Year-Old Takes All the Attention in Stride
abstract: Jahlil Okafor, ranked the top high school junior by MaxPreps, has his eyes locked on the N.B.A. but handles the peripherals with as much aplomb as he handles double teams.
lead_paragraph: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Jahlil Okafor is a 17-year-old basketball star from Chicago with the bulk to knock opponents down and the explosiveness to jump over them, but he prefers to use a quiver of throwback moves and nimble size 17 feet to whisk around them.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon return with a new Cryptic Crossword.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I do enjoy an Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon puzzle, and today’s cryptic crossword puzzle was no different. My wavelength was a bit off, so this one was a little harder for me than past Hex cryptics, yet the answers made me laugh.

headline: Pope Electors Are Sizing Up a Field of Peers
abstract: The cardinals who will file into the Sistine Chapel next month to elect a new leader of the Roman Catholic church have been quietly evaluating potential successors for years.
lead_paragraph: There is no formal nominating process for choosing the man to succeed Pope Benedict XVI, and campaigning for oneself is counterproductive. But the cardinals who will file into the Sistine Chapel next month to elect a new leader of the Roman Catholic Church have been quietly sizing up potential candidates for years.

headline: The Mets’ C.C. Embraces Low Profile
abstract: Like their crosstown rival Yankees, the Mets’ now have a C. C., Collin Cowgill — only minus C. C. Sabathia’s star power and pedigree.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The best chance for the Mets to add a flashy name to their roster dissolved when Michael Bourn, a two-time All-Star and two-time Gold Glove center fielder, signed with the Cleveland Indians.

headline: American, 17, Wins in Slalom and Makes Herself a Favorite in Sochi
abstract: The American teenager Mikaela Shiffrin became the youngest women’s slalom world champion in 39 years on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: One day after the American Ted Ligety became the first man in 45 years to win three events at one world championship, his 17-year-old teammate Mikaela Shiffrin became the youngest female world champion in 28 years with a come-from-behind victory in the slalom.

headline: Inquiry on Democratic Senator Started With a Partisan Push
abstract: Charges of favoritism have emerged against Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat of New Jersey, since a team of Republicans put him in its cross hairs.
lead_paragraph: FALLS CHURCH, Va. — Sandwiched between two doctors’ offices at a roadside plaza here is the headquarters of a small team of veteran Republican investigators, operating almost as a private detective squad, who since late last year have had a determined goal: bringing down Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey.

headline: In Mali, the Peril of Guerrilla War Looms
abstract: Militant forces that once controlled major towns appear to have taken refuge in smaller villages nearby.
lead_paragraph: GAO, Mali — Aguissa Ag Badara, a former tour guide, now rides around the city on the back of a motorcycle looking for Islamist militants who may still be lurking about. He even wears a pin to advertise his mission. It reads, “Vigilance Brigade: Patrollers of Gao.”

headline: Explosion in Crowded Market Kills Dozens in Pakistan
abstract: The bombing in Quetta occurred in an area dominated by a Shiite ethnic minority that has suffered many attacks at the hands of Sunni militants.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — A devastating explosion ripped through a crowded market in the western city of Quetta on Saturday, killing at least 63 people and wounding at least 180, the police said.

headline: After Assault From the Heavens, Russians Search for Clues and Count Blessings
abstract: As the government pursued the scientific mysteries of Friday’s exploding meteor, residents reacted to their survival with giddy relief and humor.
lead_paragraph: CHEBARKUL, Russia — After a brilliant flash illuminated the sky on Friday morning like a second sun, Alyona V. Borchininova and several others in this run-down little town in the Siberian wilderness wandered outside, confused and curious.

headline: Age and Size Stand Out, but So Does Talent
abstract: The wild contrast of the 11-year-old point guard Julian Newman’s stature on the court with his varsity teammates has brought global attention.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Downey Christian School varsity basketball team bursts from the locker room in single file, led by a boy 14 inches shorter than the next smallest player, four years younger than the next youngest.

headline: Stronger Gun-Control Measures Clear First Votes in the Colorado House
abstract: A state with deep conservative and independent streaks has also been the site of two of the nation’s most notorious mass shootings, one in 1999 and one last summer.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Lawmakers moved closer on Friday to passing a package of new gun restrictions in Colorado, a state that has lived under the shadow of two of the worst mass shootings in United States history.

headline: The 115 Men Who Will Choose the Next Pope
abstract: Cardinal electors from every region of the world will gather to choose the man to succeed Pope Benedict XVI. See how they add up.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal electors from every region of the world will gather to choose the man to succeed Pope Benedict XVI. See how they add up.

headline: California Eases Tone as Latinos Make Gains
abstract: As Congress begins debating an overhaul of immigration, many sense that the country is beginning the same evolution California experienced over the last two decades.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A generation ago, California voters approved a ballot initiative that was seen as the most anti-immigrant law in the nation. Immigrants who had come to the country illegally would be ineligible to receive prenatal care, and their children would be barred from public schools.

headline: Subverted Classics
abstract: Some of fashion’s most iconic and feminine staples have been tweaked for a sexy twist.
lead_paragraph: Some of fashion’s most iconic and feminine staples — demure heels, delicate pearls, evening clutches — have been tweaked for a sexy twist. See the interactive.

headline: Nets and Knicks Centers Become 2-Way Threats
abstract: Brook Lopez of the Nets and Tyson Chandler of the Knicks play the same position in the same city, but their styles could hardly be more different.
lead_paragraph: If the N.B.A. season ended today, the Nets and the Knicks would have home court advantage in the first round of the playoffs. A key component of each team’s success is that rare commodity: a 7-footer who can change the game on either end of the floor.

headline: The Real Cost of Shrinking Government
abstract: The budget sequester will soon affect American life in hundreds of painful ways.
lead_paragraph: In less than two weeks, a cleaver known as the sequester will fall on some of the most important functions of the United States government. About $85 billion will be cut from discretionary spending over the next seven months, reducing defense programs by about 8 percent and domestic programs by about 5 percent. Only a few things will be spared, including some basic safety-net benefits like Social Security, as well as pay for enlisted military personnel.

headline: The Health Benefits That Cut Your Pay
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Medicare', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Many Americans might not understand that the largest effect of our health care system is to reduce the amount of money they actually take home.
lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, a 23-year-old woman joined my company as an assistant in the advertising sales department at a starting salary of $35,000. Smart, ambitious and poised, she should have a promising future. Unfortunately, her earnings prospects are threatened. Like many Americans, she’s unaware of how much of her compensation is being eaten up by health care costs, and how much this share will grow as long as the increase in health costs exceeds growth in gross domestic product. That’s just math.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: U.S. Policy Toward Russia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Constitutions']
abstract: Readers react to Gary Hart’s urging of patient diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: Readers react to Gary Hart’s urging of patient diplomacy.

headline: The Oscar for Best Fabrication
abstract: Why are Hollywood’s makers of historical films such slaves to fiction?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: Vast Throng in Bangladesh Protests Killing of Activist
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: An organizer’s death reignited demonstrations demanding the death penalty for those found guilty of war crimes in the nation’s 1971 independence fight.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Tens of thousands of people resumed mass demonstrations in Bangladesh’s capital on Saturday, intensifying their demands for more severe punishment for war criminals from the country’s 1971 liberation war, while also demanding justice for the slaying of a blogger who had been a leading organizer of the protests.

headline: The End of a Catholic Moment
abstract: Both Republicans and Democrats are losing interest in the church’s ideas.
lead_paragraph: THE last time the Chair of St. Peter stood vacant, during Pope John Paul II’s funeral in 2005, the Roman Catholic Church enjoyed a wave of unusually favorable coverage from the American press. The Polish pope had a way of disarming even his most stringent critics, and that power extended beyond his death, turning his funeral into a made-for-television spectacle that almost felt like an infomercial for the Catholic faith.

headline: Leonid Tishkov
abstract: The avant-garde Russian artist on “SpongeBob” and social media.
lead_paragraph: Leonid Tishkov is a Moscow physician turned avant-garde artist. His latest project, “Private Moon,” is a series of stylized and sentimental photographs of himself with a large illuminated crescent moon taken at various locations around the world.

headline: The Gun Report: Wayne LaPierre Edition
abstract: A day in the life of armed America: fact-checking edition.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Wayne LaPierre, the executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, wrote a remarkable editorial for The Daily Caller entitled “Stand and Fight,” filled with the kind of paranoia and fear-mongering that he has become so well known for. My assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I decided it would be a useful exercise to annotate it, a kind of fact-checking exercise for our readers. The Gun Report will return Monday morning with its usual round-up of gun violence.

headline: Syrians Freed in Abductions That Stoked Fears of More Strife
keywords: ['Kidnapping', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Hostages']
abstract: The recent kidnappings of more than 140 have demonstrated not only the high level of insecurity in the area, but also the determination of residents to defuse tensions.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The tit-for-tat kidnappings of more than 140 people have provoked fears of expanded sectarian conflict in Syria’s northern Idlib Province in recent days, but one set of hostages was released in good condition on Saturday after negotiations between residents of two of the affected villages, according to a rebel commander.

headline: Dreadful, Dreadful Arsenal
abstract: Blackburn Rovers on Saturday eliminated Arsenal from this season’s F.A. Cup.
lead_paragraph: Will eight seasons without a trophy be enough for Arsenal to send Manager Arsène Wenger and his full-length bubble down coat packing?

headline: Al Qaeda’s AARP?
abstract: What’s really behind the decision to exempt passengers older than 75 from having to remove their shoes to pass through airport security.
lead_paragraph: “Travelers younger than 12 years old and older than 75 no longer have to take off their shoes to pass through airport security.”

headline: Fascination Lingers for Three Stars of Warriors’ Brief Run
abstract: In the Bay Area in the 1980s, the Golden State Warriors cornered the market on cool for sports.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1980s, the Bay Area was a thriving sports scene. The San Francisco 49ers won back-to-back Super Bowls and the Oakland Athletics appeared in three consecutive World Series, winning one.

headline: How to Unparalyze Us
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Taxation']
abstract: A new Grand Bargain is just what we need. And to reach one, President Obama is going to have to lead from the chin.
lead_paragraph: I WAS struck by one particular moment during President Obama’s State of the Union address. The president proposed a $1 billion investment to build a new National Network for Manufacturing Innovation to spur high-tech manufacturing in America. I’m sure that would be helpful, and I’m sure the president will have to beg to get any such funding out of Congress. Yet sitting up there in the balcony listening to the president’s speech was the chief executive of Apple, Tim Cook. Apple is currently sitting on $137 billion of cash in the bank. There are many reasons Apple has not spent its cash hoard, but I’ll bet anything that one of them is the uncertain economic and tax environment in this country. Think about how much better we’d all be if Apple, and the many other companies sitting on cash, felt confident enough in the future to spend it. These are the most dynamic companies in the world. They don’t need any government help to innovate.

headline: My Life With Boxes
keywords: ['Moving and Moving Industry', 'Writing and Writers', 'Containers and Packaging']
abstract: Why do I need empty cartons? Because I am always on the move.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE Dumpster dived. I have walked my dog, pretending he is just looking for a place to pee, on trash night, to see what treasures people have left curbside. I have a great chair (circa Somerville, Mass., 1978), which cost me a fortune to reupholster, that the dog did not pee on and that I did get into the trunk of my car. Pride? Now I’d worry about bedbugs, but in my idealistic youth, I just wanted free furniture.

headline: The Queen of the West
abstract: A family of officers and a strange warship face life and death along the Civil War Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: At 19 years old, Charles Rivers Ellet was one of the Union Army’s youngest colonels. In a Feb. 2, 1863 report, Rear Adm. David Porter characterized him as “ the kind of man I like to command,” a “gallant and daring officer” who “will undertake anything I wish him to without asking questions.” But, Porter added, “The only trouble I have is to hold him in and keep him out of danger.” That same day, Porter had ordered the Queen of the West, a steam-powered wooden ram under Ellet’s command, south past the Confederate batteries at Vicksburg to reconnoiter the lower Red River and destroy any Confederate ships he encountered.

headline: How Europe Bankrolls Terror
abstract: The same European nations that helped fight the Taliban in Afghanistan have financed terrorists in Africa by paying ransoms for hostages.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON

headline: Retirement: Scarier Than Freddy Krueger
abstract: Talk about tipping points. My retirement tipped me right over the edge.
lead_paragraph: I’M used to horror. I’m the father of Freddy Krueger, for Pete’s sake. But the horror of retirement? I didn’t see that one coming at all.

headline: Bus Strike Put Damper on Field Trip Attractions
abstract: The New York City school bus drivers’ strike, which has ended, left exhibitions empty and revenues down at museums and other cultural institutions that usually pack their halls during the week with groups of students.
lead_paragraph: At the New York Hall of Science in Queens, the button-operated skateboard that children use to test their balance has been sitting still for most of the week.

headline: Equal Opportunity, Our National Myth
abstract: The upwardly mobile American is becoming a statistical oddity.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s second Inaugural Address used soaring language to reaffirm America’s commitment to the dream of equality of opportunity: “We are true to our creed when a little girl born into the bleakest poverty knows that she has the same chance to succeed as anybody else, because she is an American; she is free, and she is equal, not just in the eyes of God but also in our own.”

headline: Soriano Begins to Settle In With Nationals
abstract: Rafael Soriano is with a new team after recording 42 saves for the Yankees season while filling in for the injured Mariano Rivera.
lead_paragraph: VIERA, Fla. – It was a few minutes before nine on Saturday when Rafael Soriano stepped into his new spring training clubhouse, passport issues resolved and many save opportunities for the Washington Nationals ahead.

headline: Some Chinese Are Souring on Being North Korea’s Best Friend
abstract: The sense of fraternity appears to be souring as ordinary people express anxiety about possible fallout from North Korea’s nuclear test last Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: YANJI CITY, China — Beds shook and teacups clattered in this town bordering North Korea, less than 100 miles from the site where the North said it detonated a nuclear test that exploded midmorning in the midst of Chinese New Year festivities.

headline: The Slugfest in the Executive Suite
abstract: Mixed martial arts has become hugely popular — and lucrative — on television. That is leaving media giants locked in a battle over the future of the sport.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY

headline: Minimum Wage Economics
abstract: Surprisingly good policy.
lead_paragraph: I’m doing this kind of backwards, writing about the politics first. But I wanted to have my intellectual ducks — or rather, my lucky duckies — in a row before taking on the economics. And while I was grubbing around, Mike Konczal produced the perfect post summing it all up.

headline: Don’t Blink, or You’ll Miss Another Bailout
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: A deal involving Bank of America that came to light recently shows how bank bailouts have continued, even if in a much quieter form than in the depths of the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: MANY people became rightfully upset about bailouts given to big banks during the mortgage crisis. But it turns out that they are still going on, if more quietly, through the back door.

headline: In Colorado, a Step on Gun Regulation
abstract: Lawmakers moved closer to passing a package of new restrictions, in a state that has lived in the shadows of two mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers moved closer to passing a package of new restrictions, in a state that has lived in the shadows of two mass shootings.

headline: Why Gender Equality Stalled
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Work-Life Balance', 'Working Hours', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Family Leaves', 'Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Betty Friedan prompted a revolution in attitudes.  But our system still favors old stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: THIS week is the 50th anniversary of the publication of Betty Friedan’s international best seller, “The Feminine Mystique,” which has been widely credited with igniting the women’s movement of the 1960s. Readers who return to this feminist classic today are often puzzled by the absence of concrete political proposals to change the status of women. But “The Feminine Mystique” had the impact it did because it focused on transforming women’s personal consciousness.

headline: The Essay, an Exercise in Doubt
abstract: Whether writing essays or just going about daily life, I am constantly second-guessing myself.
lead_paragraph: I am an essayist, for better or worse. I don’t suppose many young people dream of becoming essayists. Even as nerdy and bookish a child as I was fantasized about entering the lists of fiction and poetry, those more glamorous, noble genres on which Nobels, Pulitzers and National Book Awards are annually bestowed. So if Freud was right in saying that we can be truly happy only when our childhood ambitions are fulfilled, then I must be content to be merely content.

headline: Where Ice Lights a Fire in the Economy
abstract: The ice fishing scene in Minnesota has been more lively this year, thanks to more snow and colder temperatures.
lead_paragraph: The ice fishing scene in Minnesota has been more lively this year, thanks to more snow and colder temperatures.

headline: Seeing Double, and Triple, at Yankees Camp
abstract: With 84 players expected in camp and 19 numbers held out of circulation for varied reason, the Yankees do not have enough uniform numbers to go around. So they doubled up.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. – The old line that you can’t tell the players without a scorecard is even more prevalent at this year’s Yankees camp. To be safe, you might need two.

headline: In the Quest for Love, Costs vs. Benefits
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In “Dollars and Sex,” the economist Maria Adshade posits that the forces of supply and demand loom large in the implicit market for romantic partners.
lead_paragraph: IS love for sale? Maybe not quite as directly as sex is, but economists believe that the quest for a romantic partner obeys essentially the same cost-benefit logic that governs every other market.

headline: So Why Are You at Your Desk on a Sunday?
abstract: Daniel T. Hendrix, the head of a carpet tile company, says a former boss taught him a valuable lesson about delegating duties — and finding a work-life balance.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Daniel T. Hendrix, president and C.E.O. of Interface Inc., a designer and maker of carpet tile, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Jumping Aboard the Train, as if There Won’t Be Another
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: Ominous developments in Washington haven’t seemed to crash the stock market’s party. But a strategist says that while the bull market will continue, it may be in a final stage.
lead_paragraph: THE economy may be lurching into another crisis, but you wouldn’t know it from the stock market, where an epic party is under way.

headline: Popular Restaurant Is Hit by Bomb in Somali Capital
abstract: Witnesses and the police reported that a Somali soldier had been killed and up to three other people wounded.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A bomb ripped through a popular seafood restaurant on Saturday at a beach that is perhaps the greatest symbol of Mogadishu’s recent renaissance, with witnesses and the police reporting that a Somali soldier had been killed and up to three other people wounded.

headline: If You’re Collecting Our Data, You Ought to Protect It
abstract: How opponents of NASA background checks unwittingly became campaigners for workplace data privacy and security.
lead_paragraph: LAST summer, employees at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration received an in-house newsletter illustrated with mock front pages of USA Today and The Washington Post and seemingly hyperbolic headlines like: “NASA Laptop Stolen, Potential Compromise of 10,000 Employees’ Private Information!”

headline: Cabernet and Jerky, in the Same Sentence
abstract: Jon Sebastiani, in the fourth generation of a Sonoma Valley wine family, sees his new company, Krave Jerky, as a way to change attitudes about a snack food.
lead_paragraph: IF you think of beef jerky as a last-resort protein to be bought at a gas station, Jon Sebastiani wants to change your mind.

headline: When You’ve Had One Meeting Too Many
abstract: A management consultant argues that too many meetings consume too much time with too few tangible results — and that it’s time to revolt against them.
lead_paragraph: HAVE you started holding meetings in the office restroom?

headline: All the Planets in a Row
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Sabbaticals and Career Breaks']
abstract: At different points in his career, a C.E.O. has seen signs that everything was falling into place.
lead_paragraph: I WAS born in Cuba, and I was 2 when my parents brought me to the United States in 1962 with my baby brother, Jorge.

headline: Sabathia and Rivera Pass Another Test
abstract: C. C. Sabathia, coming off elbow surgery, and Mariano Rivera, who had knee surgery, were pleased after they each threw about 30 pitches in the bullpen.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The most notable Yankee pitchers coming off surgery, C. C. Sabathia (left elbow) and Mariano Rivera (right knee), each threw about 30 pitches in bullpen sessions on Saturday. It was Sabathia’s first time on a mound since Dr. James Andrews removed a bone spur arthroscopically last Oct. 26.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 17
abstract: Denis McDonough, the White House chief of staff, will be on three shows talking about the president’s plan for his second term — and the roadblocks that stand in his way.
lead_paragraph: President Obama hit the road last week to promote the proposals he unveiled during his State of the Union address. His chief of staff, Denis McDonough, will appear on three of the Sunday talk shows to discuss the obstacles facing Mr. Obama’s second-term agenda.

headline: N.B.A. Players Dismiss Union Leader
abstract: Billy Hunter was fired by the N.B.A. players union on Saturday, ending his long and sometimes tumultuous tenure as executive director.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Billy Hunter was fired as executive director of the N.B.A. players union on Saturday, with a bold, decisive vote and a public rebuke.

headline: 30 Seconds With Greg Anthony
abstract: An interview with Greg Anthony, who was the Knicks’ first-round draft choice in 1991, and is now an analyst on Nets telecasts on the YES Network.
lead_paragraph: A year after winning a national championship at Nevada-Las Vegas, Greg Anthony was the Knicks’ first-round draft choice in 1991, and he became a spark plug on their defense. He played with five other N.B.A. teams before retiring in 2002.

headline: A Difficult Path for an Education
abstract: Wu Yiebing and Cao Weiping have made huge sacrifices to improve their child’s education, as millions of other Chinese families have done.
lead_paragraph: Wu Yiebing and Cao Weiping have made huge sacrifices to improve their child’s education, as millions of other Chinese families have done.

headline: Mark My Words
abstract: Ian Livengood and the J.A.S.A. class mark up our Sunday solve.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Now this was a neat one, even if I do seem to have an issue with my built-in rebus detector. For those just tuning in, yes, this technically counts as a rebus. A rebus is anything other than a single letter per square, so numbers or odd characters like today’s punctuation marks count. And then, of course, we have the Down entries, which is a whole other ball of punctuation marks.

headline: In China, Families Bet It All on College for Their Children
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Families and Family Life', 'Education', 'Series']
abstract: Millions of Chinese sacrifice heavily for their children’s education, but as graduates saturate the job market, the security they seek is increasingly elusive.
lead_paragraph: HANJING, China — Wu Yiebing has been going down coal shafts practically every workday of his life, wrestling an electric drill for $500 a month in the choking dust of claustrophobic tunnels, with one goal in mind: paying for his daughter’s education.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Woman, 19, Dies After Seeking Refuge in Apartment Lobby
abstract: A police official said the woman had been visiting bars in the East Village and was let into the building by the doorman, who said he later found her on the floor and called 911.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old woman died early Saturday morning in the East Village after seeking shelter in the lobby of an apartment house, the police said.

headline: Development Grant Sales Are Brisk in Los Angeles
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: The buying and selling of federal community development grants has been longstanding practice in Los Angeles County, but not everyone agrees that it is the best use of the money.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Malibu, Calif., was one of several thousand communities across the country that received federal grants intended to improve the lot of low- and moderate-income residents. But instead of putting the $54,866 it received to work on an eligible project, like restoring houses, the city did what dozens of other well-off municipalities have done: it sold its grants to other communities in exchange for smaller purses that had no strings attached.

headline: When Elite Tournaments Were Rare and Noteworthy
abstract: Baden-Baden, Germany, played host to three of the most important tournaments in chess history in an era when it was difficult for the best players to face off against one another.
lead_paragraph: Tournaments that bring together the best players at the same place at the same time became possible only in the jet age. There are now so many elite tournaments that few of them are actually memorable.

headline: The White House Continues Working on Immigration Legislation of Its Own
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Aides are working on a bill that would offer illegal immigrants a pathway to citizenship — a measure intended as a backup in case a bipartisan effort by Congress stalls.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is working on early drafts of a comprehensive bill that would offer 11 million illegal immigrants a pathway to citizenship along the lines of the principles that the president laid out in Las Vegas several weeks ago, administration officials said.

headline: Left to Right, Capitals’ Ovechkin Has a New Angle
abstract: The Capitals moved Alex Ovechkin to right wing at the start of the season because he had become predictable on the left. Despite only five goals this season, he is slowly adjusting to the switch.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Alex Ovechkin wore gray as he took line rushes at practice here Saturday. Gray is the color designated for the Capitals’ second line.

headline: In Awe of Star Playing Partners, Beljan Goes On to Beat Them
abstract: If Charlie Beljan was nervous playing with Phil Mickelson and Ernie Els on Saturday, it didn’t show in his score. He carded a three-under-par 68, four strokes better than Mickelson and five strokes ahead of Els.
lead_paragraph: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif. — Charlie Beljan checked his pinging smartphone Friday night, and his heart started pounding when he read the text message informing him of his third-round pairing at the Northern Trust Open. Beljan, a one-time PGA Tour winner who was playing on third-tier tours two years ago, was in a group with Phil Mickelson and Ernie Els, who have a combined 60 tour victories, including eight majors.

headline: Leading After Three Rounds, Haas Aims for a Repeat and a Milestone
abstract: The third-round leader at the Northern Trust Open, Bill Haas would be a repeat champion if he holds on, a feat never accomplished by his father, Jay, a nine-time PGA Tour winner.
lead_paragraph: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif. — Trying to carve your own niche in golf when your great-uncle is the 1968 Masters champion and your father is a nine-time PGA Tour winner can be an exercise in futility, like trying to whittle a piece of wood using a plastic knife.

headline: Ayatollah Says Iran Will Control Nuclear Aims
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: But Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said nothing could stop his country from building nuclear weapons, should it choose to do so.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader said Saturday that his country was not seeking nuclear weapons but added that if Iran ever decided to build them, no “global power” could stop it.

headline: Big Talent, Tiny Point Guard
abstract: Julian Newman is a 70-pound, 4-foot-5 fifth grader who plays varsity basketball with high schoolers at Downey Christian School in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Julian Newman is a 70-pound, 4-foot-5 fifth grader who plays varsity basketball with high schoolers at Downey Christian School in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Barnaby Conrad, Man of Many Hats and a Cape, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Conrad was also a painter, Sinclair Lewis’s personal secretary, and owner of the nightclub El Matador in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: As a 19-year-old art student one summer in Mexico City, Barnaby Conrad attended a bullfight, and, with a whimsical bolt of Hemingwayesque bravado, leapt into the ring and challenged a bull himself, using his Brooks Brothers raincoat as a cape.

headline: UConn Denies Rutgers’s Stringer Her 900th Win

lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — C. Vivian Stringer’s 900th victory — and the new contract she seeks to extend her 18-year tenure at Rutgers — must wait.

lead_paragraph: The directions to the rural North Texas home of Jim Marrs, an author and conspiracy researcher, certainly sound like something from an old episode of “The X-Files”: “Go north about seven miles, and watch for a sign on a green metal gate at the top of a steep hill.”

headline: Starting New Businesses Behind Bars Creates an Incentive for Texas Inmates
abstract: More than 100 students are now enrolled in the Prison Entrepreneurship Program, in which Texas inmates learn skills including market research, finance and business etiquette.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — As Christopher Holbert danced down the aisle of a Cleveland Correctional Center classroom, dozens of other prisoners in matching dark blue uniforms flanked him, clapping and cheering. When he reached the front of the classroom, he spoke for 10 minutes on his business plan for Adrenaline Indoor Paintball, an idea he worked on over the last year.

headline: Vindication for Entrepreneurs Watching Sky: Yes, It Can Fall

lead_paragraph: For decades, scientists have been on the lookout for killer objects from outer space that could devastate the planet. But warnings that they lacked the tools to detect the most serious threats were largely ignored, even as skeptics mocked the worriers as Chicken Littles.

headline: Colleges Become Major Front in Fight Over Carrying Guns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Colleges and Universities', 'School Shootings', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Though weapons are banned from most public universities, pro-gun forces have made gains on the issue in a handful of states, most recently Colorado.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — Public colleges and universities have become a major front in the nation’s debate over guns as gun-rights advocates press to expand the right to carry concealed weapons, a campaign that gained steam after the 2007 shooting rampage at Virginia Tech, which left 33 people dead. And though guns remain banned from most state colleges, pro-gun forces, in a series of high-decibel legal and political battles, have made inroads on the issue in a handful of states, most recently Colorado.

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Bucking a trend in which states have been seeking to restrict abortion, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is putting the finishing touches on legislation that would guarantee women in New York the right to late-term abortions when their health is in danger or the fetus is not viable.

By 3:30 on Saturday morning, more than 200 were waiting. As they huddled together along Prince Street, an early morning drizzle turned the pavement to glitter.

headline: Stanley and the Crazies
abstract: Being right doesn’t matter.
lead_paragraph: Dylan Matthews has an interesting piece suggesting that Stan Fischer might become our next Fed chairman. Fischer would indeed be highly qualified (as would Janet Yellen or Christy Romer, to name two other obvious candidates). But Matthews also suggests that Fischer might have a leg up in the confirmation process, because he has been a highly successful governor of the Bank of Israel who worked well with Netanyahu.

headline: Bruce Willis Shows Strength at the Box Office
abstract: “A Good Day to Die Hard” was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in about $25 million.
lead_paragraph: Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone went kersplat in their recent bids for  renewed box-office glory, but another 1980s-era star — Bruce Willis — has shown that he’s still kicking. “A Good Day to Die Hard,” starring Mr. Willis in a role he created 25 years ago, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in about $25 million. The film, which cost 20th Century Fox about $90 million to make, has sold $33.2 million in tickets since opening on Valentine’s Day, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

lead_paragraph: A day after pieces of meteorites apparently landed in a lake in the small Russian town of Chebarkul, residents gathered at the shore with a mix of awe and pride.

headline: Former Israeli Foreign Minister Pleads Not Guilty in Fraud Case
abstract: Avigdor Lieberman pleaded not guilty to charges of fraud and breach of trust in a criminal case that leaves his political future hanging in the balance.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s tough-talking former foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, pleaded not guilty on Sunday to charges of fraud and breach of trust in a criminal case that leaves his political future hanging in the balance.

headline: Still Lonely in a World With More ‘Onlies’
abstract: I am an only child, and the parents of only children often ask me how I felt about it. I never tell them what I really think.
lead_paragraph: I am surrounded by junior versions of me, only children racing around playgrounds, shoveling scoops of sand into their own individual piles. In the ’70s, the era of my childhood, I was a freak in a world of four-child families. Now my time has come, and parents of these onlies often ask how I felt about being an only child. Their children are lovely, well-adjusted parent-pleasers. It is easy to see that sibling or no sibling, they will have happy lives, and that is what I emphasize.

headline: A Widower Presses Life’s Reset Button
abstract: A widower vacations in London with hopes of sexual adventure but winds up finding something else among an assortment of endearing characters in “Off the King’s Road,” a play by Neil Koenigsberg.
lead_paragraph: Matt Browne has come prepared for his London vacation — with Viagra, Valium, condoms, mouthwash, a blowup doll and a framed photo of Betty, the wife to whom he was faithful for 38 years. Betty, who looked vaguely like Frances Sternhagen, died six months ago. And Matt (Jack Davidson), the lonely American protagonist of Neil Koenigsberg’s “Off the King’s Road,” is rewarded or punished, depending on your point of view, with an alarming amount of incident.

headline: Hard to Call Anyone a Winner, When Medals Are Lost to Doping
abstract: Retroactive has become the new active in this polluted, convoluted sports era, in which you can too rarely be sure whether the race or game or shot-put contest you just watched was legitimate.
lead_paragraph: It was August 2004. The Athens Olympics were in full roar, and a few of us boarded a bus in the darkness, made the long, overnight ride to the site of the ancient Games in Olympia and reported on a feel-good shot-put competition that turned out — like too many modern competitions — to be a sham.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Preen by Thornton Bregazzi
abstract: Val Garland brought a graphic tomboyish look to the show’s London Fashion Week runway this season.
lead_paragraph: “Delicate punk ” is how makeup artist Val Garland described the mood at Preen this morning. Gray powder eye shadow was mixed with water to create a liquid liner, which was drawn in a sharp diagonal line on either the upper or lower lid. ‘It’s quite painterly and graphic,” explains Garland, who used an artist’s brush to create the precise look. To emphasize the eyes, the skin, lips, eyebrows and hair were kept muted. “There’s a sense of androgyny in the collection. You get the feeling that’s she’s a bit of a tomboy,” says hairstylist Anthony Turner. Turner dampened models’ hair before drying it with his fingers for a soft, natural effect. L’Oreal Professionnel’s Fresh Dust dry shampoo was then spritzed over locks to add texture and a pretty, flyaway finish. “So when the girls walk, it almost looks a little static,” he says, adding “it’s all very cool and very easy.”

headline: A Gusher in Edmonton: Oilers Attempt 85 Shots in Rally to Beat Colorado

It’s pretty cool to be a part of a record, especially being able to set one with this organization, which has some pretty tough records to beat,” said Edmonton’s Ryan Nugent-Hopkins, after the Oilers recorded a team-record 56 shots on goal while attempting an astounding 85 shots.

headline: Dark Nights of the Soul in the Kingdom of the Holy Grail
abstract: Wagner’s “Parsifal,” among the most metaphysical, ambiguous and profound, if inexplicable, operas ever written, is presented by the director François Girard in a post-apocalyptic setting.
lead_paragraph: In the stage directions for Act I of “Parsifal,” set near the sanctuary of the knights of the grail in a mythical region of medieval Spain, Wagner writes that the scene depicts a forest with a deep-set lake in the background. This glade should be shady and solemn, he indicates, but not gloomy (“doch nicht düster”).

headline: At Camp, Jeter Details Challenges Of Recovery
abstract: Arriving at Steinbrenner Field, Derek Jeter offered insight into the progression of his ankle injury and vowed to be ready for opening day.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — One of the toughest guys in Yankee Stadium could not bring himself to look.

keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Global Warming', 'Oil Sands']
abstract: In deciding whether to approve the Keystone oil pipeline, President Obama faces a choice between alienating environmental advocates or causing a deep rift with Canada.
lead_paragraph: President Obama faces a knotty decision in whether to approve the much-delayed Keystone oil pipeline: a choice between alienating environmental advocates who overwhelmingly supported his candidacy or causing a deep and perhaps lasting rift with Canada.

headline: Could Wind Power Cool New England’s Price Fever?
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Natural Gas', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Wind Power']

lead_paragraph: As I reported in Saturday’s paper, New England is experiencing a remarkable spike in electricity prices brought on by high heating demand and rising natural gas prices for electric generators.

headline: Taming the Runaway U.S. Budget
abstract: To assure markets and reign in what will be a disastrous deficit over the long-term, action needs to be taken soon. But cuts do not have to take place immediately.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Democrats and Republicans can’t agree on a deficit reduction plan, in two weeks automatic budget cuts will kick in that could severely weaken the U.S. economy and the American military.

abstract: At 24, the Nationals star Stephen Strasburg has a new season and, body willing, roughly 200 innings ahead of him for the first time.

headline: Stalking a Most Prolific Phantom
abstract: The journalist Will Ellsworth-Jones’s book “Banksy: The Man Behind the Wall” examines the conundrums behind the graffiti artist Banksy and the growing Banksy brand.
lead_paragraph: The graffiti artist Banksy’s work is immediately recognizable: clever, funny, sometimes political stencils and artworks that have popped up on walls (and occasionally in museums and galleries) in cities around the world — giant rats clutching paint brushes or umbrellas or boom boxes; chimps wearing placards (“Laugh now, but one day we’ll be in charge”); trompe l’oeil windows/holes (opening out onto a mountain vista or a picturesque beach or a pretty cloudscape) on barrier walls in the West Bank; children wearing gas masks or chasing after balloons that are floating away.

headline: A Duchess Who Made Blue Blood Curdle
abstract: Thomas Adès’s opera “Powder Her Face,” based on a 1950s British sex scandal, is at Brooklyn Academy of Music in a City Opera production.
lead_paragraph: The chatter about “Powder Her Face,” the British composer Thomas Adès’s 1995 debut opera about a real-life sex scandal among the British aristocracy, generally gravitates toward a single, conspicuous point in the work: an aria that not only accompanies an act of oral sex but simulates it.

keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'States (US)']

lead_paragraph: If there was any question whether Danica Patrick could make an impact in Nascar’s premier Sprint Cup Series, the answer came Sunday with a performance that put her in the record books.

lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Galaxy announced on Sunday that midfielder Landon Donovan would return to the club in the final week of March, nearly a month into the regular season.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Ben Folds to Write a Short Musical
abstract: Ben Folds will write a 15-minute musical that is to be cast, written, rehearsed and performed in a single day as part of the fifth production of “The 24-Hour Musicals.”
lead_paragraph: The Exchange and the 24 Hour Company are to announce on Monday that Ben Folds will write a 15-minute musical that is to be cast, written, rehearsed and performed in a single day as part of the fifth production of “The 24-Hour Musicals.” The process will begin the evening of April 28 and continue around the clock until a total of four planned musicals are performed at the Gramercy Theater at 8 p.m. on April 29. Other participants have yet to be announced. Tickets are scheduled to go on sale in March, and proceeds will benefit the nonprofit Orchard Project, which helps develop new theater work. Information is at 24hourplays.com.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: 2 Lovers, 2 Houses and 2-Handed Squiggles in Old Verona
abstract: The Pacific Northwest Ballet performed Jean-Christophe Maillot’s 1996 Monte Carlo “Roméo et Juliette” in two shows at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Prokofiev’s celebrated score for “Romeo and Juliet” has never sounded better in the theater, in my experience, than at Pacific Northwest Ballet’s two performances on Saturday at City Center. True, at the matinee a horn cracked briefly during a hard ascent in the Act II wedding scene at Friar Laurence’s cell, and yet that was one of many passages where you couldn’t miss the proud, affectionate and detailed phrasing of the Pacific Northwest Ballet Orchestra. Emil de Cou, conducting both performances, shaped the score superbly.

headline: Hafner, Hard-Hitting North Dakotan, Joins Yankees
abstract: It may be surprising to learn that Travis Hafner, the former Cleveland Indians slugger, is the greatest home run hitter born in North Dakota because another left-handed-hitting North Dakotan occupies a cherished place in Yankees lore.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The greatest home run hitter born in North Dakota slipped into Yankees camp quietly Wednesday night. It may be surprising to learn that Travis Hafner, the former Cleveland Indians slugger, tops the extremely short list because another left-handed-hitting North Dakotan occupies a cherished place in Yankees lore.

headline: A Game Aims to Draw Attention to Women’s Issues
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Women and Girls', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Prostitution', 'Human Trafficking', 'Female Genital Mutilation']
abstract: A new social game intended to raise awareness about issues like female genital mutilation and child prostitution will be introduced on Facebook in March.
lead_paragraph: Social cause gaming, or the use of games to promote awareness of societal problems, has been growing since pioneer online projects like Food Force, the United Nations World Food Program’s 2005 game about confronting famine, and Darfur Is Dying, MTV’s 2006 offering in which players navigate the terrors of a Sudanese refugee camp.

headline: Suez Canal Kept Open in Spite of Egypt Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: The protests are the closest that chaos has come to threatening the operations of the critical shipping artery over the last two years.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Thousands of demonstrators shut down the administrative buildings of the Suez Canal terminal in the city of Port Said on Sunday, as part of a general strike protesting the death sentences handed down three weeks ago to 21 local soccer fans for their roles in a deadly riot last year.

headline: High-Pitched Warble
abstract: A Monday puzzle by Jeffrey Harris.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m in a quandary (actually, I’m in my office, but you know what I mean). I don’t believe that the theme for this puzzle works, but I like Jeffrey Harris’s puzzles and I like Monday puzzles, so I’m going to have to think about the way I want to talk about today’s offering. There’s not a lot that is innately wrong with it, but when the theme is quirky it takes most of the fun out of the solve for me. As always, your mileage, etc., etc.

headline: Film Feast: Eclectic and Rare
abstract: The Film Comment Selects series of the Film Society of Lincoln Center brings together movies that have slipped below the radar because they are too eccentric, too tough, too indefinable or sometimes just too good.
lead_paragraph: The new and the vital brush up against the lovingly exhumed in Film Comment Selects, a strong cinematic sampler that starts Monday at the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Each year the brain trust at Film Comment magazine brings together this diverse, pleasure-driven series mostly made up of work that has recently played on the festival circuit, from Berlin to Toronto. Although some selections, including the opening-night movie (the icky “Simon Killer”) and closing-night selection (its opposite, “The We and the I”), have distribution, others have slipped below the radar because they are too eccentric, too tough, too indefinable or sometimes just too good.

headline: Searching for Bootstraps for Pulling Up
abstract: “The Powerbroker: Whitney Young’s Fight for Civil Rights,” part of the PBS series “Independent Lens,” revisits the contributions of a less-celebrated black leader during the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: The civil rights movement had the so-called big six, but with the passage of time and the temptation to resort to historical shorthand it sometimes seems as if that club of influential black leaders really had only one member, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Perilous Reminders as War Nears End
abstract: “Inside Combat Rescue” on National Geographic and “Glory Hounds” on Animal Planet serve as up-close reminders of how brutal the war in Afghanistan can be.
lead_paragraph: It’s awfully late in the cycle of embedded and ride-along war journalism, the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan having been covered by news organizations and documentarians to the point, some might say, of oversaturation. And the Pentagon is certainly adept at using its gatekeeper ability on such coverage to whip up support for troops and the budgets that support them.

headline: Logging Off to Trace a Web Photo to Its Source
abstract: A photo of exploding manhole covers in Omaha that took over the Web last month prompted two responses: wonder and skepticism.
lead_paragraph: When photographs of spontaneous events miraculously appear on the Web, it generally prompts two responses: wonder and skepticism.

headline: Dog Expert’s Dos and Don’ts for Pet Owners in China
abstract: Cesar Millan, the star of the “Dog Whisperer” television series, is planning an extensive celebrity branding campaign in China.
lead_paragraph: It has not always been easy for dogs in China. They have been beaten, eaten and, once, were banned in Beijing.

lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Economic data to be released include the Producer Price Index for January and housing starts for January (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, the Consumer Price Index for January, used home sales for January, the Philadelphia Fed index for February and leading economic indicators for January (Thursday).

headline: Inquiry Into China Film Trade Unnerves Hollywood
keywords: ['Movies', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A chill between Hollywood and China remains almost a year after word leaked about an S.E.C. investigation into possible corrupt practices.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hunkered down. Lawyered up. Looking over your shoulder for the prosecutors.

headline: Of Cannibals, Kings and Culture: The Problem of Ethnocentricity
abstract: Our tendency to view our own culture as superior to others need not lead us down the path of skepticism and moral relativism.
lead_paragraph: In August of 1563, Michel de Montaigne, the famous French essayist, was introduced to three Brazilian cannibals who were visiting Rouen, France, at the invitation of King Charles the Ninth. The three men had never before left Brazil, had just been subjected to a long interrogation by the king (who was 13 years old at the time), and if they had not already contracted some dangerous European illness, they were surely undergoing a rather severe case of culture shock. Despite this, they still had enough poise to lucidly respond to Montaigne’s questions about what they thought of their new surroundings.

headline: ‘Fast & Furious’ Stresses Social Side of Fandom
abstract: Universal’s “Fast & Furious” series is a second-class citizen in Hollywood, but not online, where it has more Facebook “likes” than any active film series except “Avatar.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Despite selling $1.8 billion in tickets, Universal’s “Fast & Furious” car-racing series is Hollywood’s equivalent of a second-class citizen.

headline: New York Parks in Less Affluent Areas Lack Big Gifts
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Philanthropy', 'Budgets and Budgeting']

lead_paragraph: Last year, Central Park received what is believed to be the largest gift ever given to an American park, $100 million, from the hedge fund manager John A. Paulson.

headline: Bill Eadington, Economist and Gambling Expert, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Eadington was one of the first academics to study gambling, as both a force for economic development and a challenging social problem.
lead_paragraph: Bill Eadington, an economist who was one of the first academics to study gambling, as both a force for economic development and a challenging social problem, died on Feb. 11 in Crystal Bay, Nev. He was 67.

headline: Schools Ask: Gifted or Just Well-Prepared?
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tutors and Tutoring']
abstract: Admissions testing for gifted programs is a fraught process, where administrators seeking authentic measures of intelligence can barely keep ahead of test-prep companies.
lead_paragraph: When the New York City Education Department announced that it was changing part of its admissions exam for its gifted and talented programs last year, in part to combat the influence of test preparation companies, one of those companies posted the news with links to guides and practice tests for the new assessment.

headline: In Arduous Officer Course, Women Offer Clues to Their Future in Infantry
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Marine Corps is assessing female volunteers in a grueling training course to see whether women can make it in the infantry.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, two newly minted female lieutenants joined about 100 men in Quantico, Va., for one of the most grueling experiences that soldiers not in war can experience: the Marine Corps’ Infantry Officer Course.

headline: When a Pope Retires, Is He Still Infallible?
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI’s decision to resign has puzzled the faithful and scholars, who wonder how a pope can be infallible one day and fallible again the next.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — What will he be called? Will he keep his white robes and trademark red loafers? And in the last absolute monarchy in the West, how does the dramatic resignation of Benedict XVI, the first pope to step down willingly in six centuries, change a role long considered by the Roman Catholic Church to be that of God’s representative on Earth?

headline: Rem Vyakhirev, Former Chief of Gazprom, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Vyakhirev, as chief executive of the huge Russian energy company during the 1990s, resisted efforts by reformers to break up and privatize it.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Rem I. Vyakhirev, who as chief executive of the huge Russian energy company Gazprom during the 1990s resisted efforts by reformers to break up and privatize it, only to end his tenure a billionaire owning valuable pieces of the company himself, died on Feb. 11. He was 78.

headline: Netanyahu Defends Handling of Prisoner X
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu  suggested the threats Israel faces justified the handling of an Australian-Israeli who was held under a pseudonym in a maximum-security prison until he committed suicide in 2010.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday defended his government’s handling of an Australian-Israeli who was held under a pseudonym for months in a maximum-security prison until he committed suicide in 2010, suggesting that the threats his country faces justify the extraordinary measures and the secrecy shrouding the case.

lead_paragraph: Business Insider, the online news franchise started by Henry Blodget nearly six years ago, is appointing an executive editor for the first time as it grapples with a good problem: growth.

headline: Back in a Swing State, This Time for Sport

lead_paragraph: PALM CITY, Fla. — It was not his motivation, certainly, but President Obama is honoring his modern predecessors on this Presidents’ Day weekend by doing what many of them liked to do on breaks: chill out in Florida with the guys — including, in his case, one of golf’s most famous guys, Tiger Woods.

headline: In Russia, Ruins and Property Spared by Meteor, Side by Side
abstract: Infrasound waves, scientists say, would explain the apparent randomness of phenomena like cracked dishes and dead electronics behind unscathed windows.
lead_paragraph: CHELYABINSK, Russia — The shock wave from a meteor that exploded above Siberia last week somehow sheared the roof off a brick and steel factory building while leaving a nearby glass facade unscathed.

headline: Some Employers Could Opt Out of Insurance Market, Raising Others’ Costs

abstract: Officials are worried that companies with healthy employees will self-insure, leaving commercial insurers with disproportionate numbers of sicker people, driving up premiums.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal and state officials and consumer advocates have grown worried that companies with relatively young, healthy employees may opt out of the regular health insurance market to avoid the minimum coverage standards in President Obama’s sweeping law, a move that could drive up costs for workers at other companies.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Look out Las Vegas, here comes FarmVille.

abstract: Banks have found a clever way to “forgive” mortgages — while still foreclosing on struggling homeowners.
lead_paragraph: IN January, federal regulators announced an $8.5 billion agreement with 10 mortgage servicers to settle claims of foreclosure abuses, including bungled loan modifications and the wrongful evictions of borrowers who were either current on their payments or making reduced monthly payments.

headline: Young Mets Pitchers Considered Equally Confident, but They’re Not Two of a Kind
abstract: Matt Harvey and Zack Wheeler, young right-handers viewed as critical to the Mets’ future, are on “opposite ends of the spectrum” in terms of personality, Dan Warthen says.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In many ways, they have seemed inextricably tied, Matt Harvey and Zack Wheeler, two right-handers expected to be at the forefront of the Mets’ renaissance, if one ever occurs. Together their names rest on the tips of fans’ tongues, quickly spoken when talk turns to a happier future for the club. At the team’s spring training complex, they dress at adjacent lockers, in whispering distance of Johan Santana’s.

headline: Assault, Battery and Government Liability
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Immunity from Prosecution', 'Editorials']
abstract: A federal inmate’s claim of being abused by prison guards has caught the attention of the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Kim Millbrook, an inmate in a federal prison in Pennsylvania, alleged that in 2010, he was beaten up and forced to perform oral sex on a prison guard while another guard immobilized him in a chokehold and a third stood watch. Mr. Millbrook contended that the officers said they would kill him if he told anyone about the assault and battery.

headline: From the Bottom Up
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Editorials']
abstract: Raising the minimum wage can help ensure fair pay and stimulate the economy, yet it remains a political challenge.
lead_paragraph: President Obama was right about the need to increase the federal minimum wage, but it was too bad that he pulled his punches in calling on Congress to lift the wage only to $9 an hour by the end of 2015, from $7.25 an hour, where it has been since 2009.

headline: When Irish Hands Are Helping an Enclave in County Queens
abstract: Breezy Point, Queens, known as the Irish Riviera, remains a popular cause in the homeland more than three months after Hurricane Sandy sparked devastating residential fires.
lead_paragraph: For generations the residents of Breezy Point, Queens, have clung to their emerald roots. The gated community they called the Irish Riviera — or to those who prefer the language of the Old World, “cois farraige,” Gaelic for “beside the sea” — has remained one of the most proudly Irish communities in America.

headline: Rangers Take Their Time Getting a Lead, but Hold On to It
abstract: Rick Nash had an assist, Carl Hagelin scored his fifth goal in four games and Derek Stepan added the winner as the Rangers beat Braden Holtby and the Capitals.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers beat a last-place team by a single goal at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, but it was still a victory to be proud of. They dominated practically the entire game, solved a hot goalie and had a stellar performance from Rick Nash, even though he was nursing an injury.

headline: In Kabul’s ‘Car Guantánamo,’ Autos Languish and Trust Dies
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Police', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: Behind high stone walls are thousands of cars, trucks, vans, motorcycles and even bicycles, lined up in vehicular purgatory after falling afoul of the Kabul traffic police.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — On the northern edge of Kabul, down a road riddled with mammoth potholes, is a secure site that bears all the marks of a prison: high stone walls topped with concertina wire, police officers barking into walkie-talkies, forsaken visitors pacing the compound’s edge, waiting for a sign of hope.

headline: Voting Rights Act Is Challenged as Cure the South Has Outgrown
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: An Alabama county contends that a main provision of the law that requires it to get permission before making changes that affect voting, has outlived its purpose of protecting minorities.
lead_paragraph: EVERGREEN, Ala. — Jerome Gray, a 74-year-old black man, has voted in every election since 1974 in this verdant little outpost of some 4,000 people halfway between Mobile and Montgomery. Casting a ballot, he said, is a way to honor the legacy of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, a civil rights landmark born from a bloody confrontation 70 miles north of here, in Selma.

keywords: ['Extraordinary Rendition', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'Editorials']
abstract: Many countries are complicit in America’s brutal treatment of terror suspects.

headline: President Correa Handily Wins Re-election in Ecuador
abstract: The vote showed the broad popularity of President Rafael Correa’s government’s social programs and support for the poor.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Rafael Correa of Ecuador swept to re-election on Sunday in a vote that showed the broad popularity of his government’s social programs and support for the poor in a country to which he has brought stability after years of political and economic turmoil.

headline: Raise That Wage
abstract: A higher minimum wage is good policy.
lead_paragraph: President Obama laid out a number of good ideas in his State of the Union address. Unfortunately, almost all of them would require spending money — and given Republican control of the House of Representatives, it’s hard to imagine that happening.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Four Seasons Lobby, a Jewelry Heist in Plain Sight
abstract: Two thieves, one wielding a sledgehammer, stole pieces that the police said were valued at $166,950 from a Jacob & Company display case early Saturday.
lead_paragraph: As a crime, it may not deserve comparison to the meticulously planned hotel heists of past decades, when well-dressed robbers cleaned out safe deposit boxes of jewels and cash. Yet the sheer brazenness of two jewel thieves at the Four Seasons Hotel on Saturday set their crime apart from the run-of-the-mill hotel larceny.

headline: Speaking Up, Star Becomes the Most Valuable of Players
abstract: When LeBron James “practically cross-examined” lawyers during Saturday’s meeting to restore the players’ union, the room fell silent. Players respect James not just for his talent, but his business savvy and ability to connect.

headline: At Riviera, the Safe Play Proves a Winning Gamble
abstract: John Merrick, a native of Long Beach and a product of U.C.L.A., became the first golfer with Los Angeles-area roots to add his name to the list of winners at the Northern Trust Open.
lead_paragraph: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif. — From the tee box, the 10th hole at Riviera Country Club looks like another vanilla par 4 on the PGA Tour, a 315-yard test that is no match for today’s generation of swashbuckling players.

headline: Seeking Love When It’s in Front of You
abstract: The Theater for a New Audience’s production of “Much Ado About Nothing” features the British actor Jonathan Cake in a stylish performance as Benedick.
lead_paragraph: There are occasions when the title of Shakespeare’s “Much Ado About Nothing” seems all too apposite. Such is the unhappy case with the Theater for a New Audience production that opened on Sunday night at the Duke on 42nd Street, spreading mirth only sporadically, thanks primarily to a stylish performance by the British actor Jonathan Cake as an effervescent, audience-beguiling Benedick, a mismatched foil for the sparkle-free Beatrice of Maggie Siff.

headline: When Being Jobless Is a Barrier to Finding a Job
abstract: A growing number of unemployed New Yorkers say they are not being given a fair shot by employers, and New York City is considering more efforts to help the long-term unemployed.
lead_paragraph: The sign outside the diner said help wanted. But when Albert Mango said he was out of work, he was told there was no opening there.

headline: Obama Seeking to Boost Study of Human Brain
abstract: The Obama administration is planning a decade-long scientific effort to examine the workings of the human brain and build a comprehensive map of its activity.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is planning a decade-long scientific effort to examine the workings of the human brain and build a comprehensive map of its activity, seeking to do for the brain what the Human Genome Project did for genetics.

headline: The Cherokees Free Their Slaves
abstract: How the Indian nation navigated emancipation – and how its decisions resonate today.
lead_paragraph: Following on the heels of the Emancipation Proclamation, in February 1863 the Cherokee Nation declared that all slaves within its limits were “forever free.” In 1983, the descendants of these slaves, known as the Cherokee Freedmen, were removed from tribal membership rolls and prohibited from voting in Cherokee elections. A series of protracted legal battles over Freedmen citizenship ensued and continue today.

headline: Catholicism Inc.
abstract: The church is a troubled business. Maybe it should act like one.
lead_paragraph: Behold a global business in distress — incoherently managed, resistant to the modernizing forces of the Internet age, tainted by scandal and corruption. It needs to tweak its marketing, straighten out its finances, up its recruiting game and repair its battered brand. Ecce Catholicism Inc.

headline: 2 Senate Opponents Vow to End Bid to Block Hagel
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham, one of the most vociferous critics of Chuck Hagel’s nomination as secretary of defense, said he would stand aside because Mr. Hagel had disavowed comments about Israel.
lead_paragraph: Two of the most outspoken Republican critics of Chuck Hagel’s nomination as secretary of defense indicated Sunday that they would no longer hold up his Senate confirmation.

headline: Chandler Savoring His First All-Star Game
abstract: The Knicks’ Tyson Chandler, already a former N.B.A. champion and Olympic gold medalist, savors adding an All-Star appearance to his résumé.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Tyson Chandler had already become one of the league’s best centers before he became an All-Star this season. He had already won an N.B.A. title with the Dallas Mavericks. He was last season’s defensive player of the year. And he won an Olympic gold medal with the United States national team last summer in London.

headline: Player Overcomes Bullying and a Hiatus
abstract: Rebecca Marino has a fresh mind-set after taking a break from the WTA Tour because of threats and harsh criticism on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, at an indoor tournament in Memphis, Rebecca Marino of Canada made her first WTA final. Marino, then 20 years old, was seen as a rising star on the tour. She and her countryman Milos Raonic, who also made the Memphis final that year as a 20-year-old, inspired unprecedented optimism for Canadian tennis.

headline: Tony Sheridan, Colleague of Beatles, Is Dead at 72
abstract: Mr. Sheridan was a guitarist and singer in Hamburg in 1960 when he met the Beatles, who were his backup group on recordings.
lead_paragraph: Tony Sheridan, the British guitarist, singer and songwriter who was the star on the Beatles’ first commercial recording — they were the backup band — died Saturday in Hamburg, Germany. He was 72.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Feb. 18
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Feb. 18.
lead_paragraph: “It has become a huge Irish-American issue. It’s another county of Ireland.”

headline: The Shortest and Youngest on the Court, a Girl Sparks the Boys Team
abstract: Holly Marschke is 14 and 5 feet 2 inches, but her coach calls her the leader of the boys’ junior varsity squad at the New York School for the Deaf-Fanwood.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Holly Marschke sized up the opposing team moments before tipoff of a junior varsity basketball game last week. Every member of the St. Luke’s team from New Canaan, Conn., was taller than every member of her team from the New York School for the Deaf-Fanwood.

headline: The Next Great One?
abstract: Connor McDavid, a 16-year-old star in his first season in the Ontario Hockey League, is an early favorite to be selected first in the 2015 N.H.L. entry draft.
lead_paragraph: Connor McDavid, a 16-year-old star in his first season in the Ontario Hockey League, is an early favorite to be selected first in the 2015 N.H.L. entry draft.

headline: Software Assistants for Doctors Are Making Progress
abstract: Medical decision-support technology has shown real progress recently. Watson, I.B.M.’s clever question-answering computer, is training to be an intelligent doctor’s helper. But there are also a flurry of achievements by university researchers and start-ups. The software of one such company, PeriGen, has been able to match human experts in analyzing fetal heart patterns, according to an assessment by the National Institutes of Health being presented on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Doctors have long been in the high-stakes information management business. They must quickly sort through a patient’s symptoms, comments, test results, records and history to come up with a diagnosis. The physician brings to each diagnostic encounter a storehouse of knowledge and experience, all that he or she has read and learned over years.

headline: Certain Television Fare Can Help Ease Aggression in Young Children, Study Finds
abstract: Children grow less aggressive the more time they spend watching television shows that encourage empathy, according to new study published in the journal Pediatrics.
lead_paragraph: Experts have long known that children imitate many of the deeds — good and bad — that they see on television. But it has rarely been shown that changing a young child’s viewing habits at home can lead to improved behavior.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Smoking’s Gender Gap Closes
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Lung Cancer', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: New data find that female smokers are now even more likely than male smokers to die of lung cancer.
lead_paragraph: The title of a recent report on smoking and health might well have paraphrased the popular ad campaign for Virginia Slims, introduced in 1968 by Philip Morris and aimed at young professional women: “You’ve come a long way, baby.”

headline: 2 Reports on Chinese Rulers’ Wealth Are Among 2012 Polk Award Winners
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Polk, George, Awards', 'News and News Media']
