headline: A Prodigy on the Way to Stardom
abstract: Connor McDavid is skilled but not yet strong, respected but innocent and naïve. He is only 16 but is widely considered the favorite to be chosen first in the 2015 N.H.L. entry draft.
lead_paragraph: ERIE, Pa. — Three hockey lifers watched Connor McDavid from worn, creaky seats at the far end of the ice. All was quiet when a crisp swoosh, the sound of a skate shredding ice, cut through the air. It sounded like paper tearing. Practice seemed to stop.

headline: Below Freezing Links
abstract: Links for the dead of winter.
lead_paragraph: Statewide G.M.O.-labeling initiatives are still going strong. Seeing the future, some of the major food companies—and Walmart—have been discussing lobbying for a national labeling program. Across the pond, Great Britain’s health department is backing standardized front-of-package nutrition labels.

headline: U.S. Under-20s Looking to Show Progress
abstract: The United States under-20 national team is set to open its World Cup qualifying tournament on Monday against Haiti, and the pressure is mounting on the team to reverse a recent string of unsuccessful results for U.S. Soccer at the youth level.
lead_paragraph: The United States under-20 national team is set to open its World Cup qualifying tournament on Monday against Haiti in Puebla, Mexico, and the pressure is mounting on the team to reverse a recent string of unsuccessful results for American men at the youth level.

headline: A Rare Defensive Stop Makes for a Highlight
abstract: Kobe Bryant blocked a jumper by LeBron James to help seal a victory for the West in the N.B.A. All-Star Game in Houston.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The N.B.A. All-Star game is often more about colorful sneakers and powerful dunks than one-on-one defense. When Sunday’s game was to be decided in the final minutes, fans were given the perfect matchup: the Los Angeles Lakers’ Kobe Bryant versus the Miami Heat’s LeBron James, two stars in the post-Michael Jordan era often compared to him.

headline: Thomas Friedman Answers Your Questions
abstract: The NYT columnist responds to readers’ queries about India.
lead_paragraph: New York Times op-ed columnist and author Thomas L. Friedman recently wrapped up a week-long trip to India, where he met with business executives, government ministers and other officials, entrepreneurs and development groups. Even as India’s economy has slowed considerably, Mr. Friedman remains a big believer in what he calls the “miracle of India.’’

headline: Kill These Characters at Your Own Risk
abstract: “Downton Abbey” fans shocked by the killing of a popular character can take solace in this: shows that shake up their viewers often thrive.
lead_paragraph: The shocking ending of this season’s “Downton Abbey” — shocking at least for those who managed to avoid the news when the finale was shown in Britain in December — most likely left thousands of the show’s fans mourning the loss of a beloved character and angry with the show’s creators for erasing him from their lives.

headline: Julian Fellowes Discusses a Season of Comings and Goings at ‘Downton Abbey’
abstract: Julian Fellowes, the creator and writer of “Downton Abbey,” talks about some key departures on the series and how he is thinking about his own exit from the show.
lead_paragraph: These have been dark days for the Crawleys and their household staff at “Downton Abbey.” (And for heaven’s sake, don’t read any further if you don’t want the events of Season 3 of this PBS “Masterpiece” series spoiled for you. This goes double if you’re Maggie Smith, in which case you should really go back and start with Season 1.)

headline: Global Health Threat Seen in Overuse of Antibiotics on Chinese Pig Farms
abstract: The “unchecked” use of antibiotics in Chinese farms poses risks that “may spread worldwide through manure and fertilizer run-off,” an article finds.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As Europe continues to recoil at the “horseburger” scandal, focusing minds on the risks in long food-production chains, a new study has found that high use of antibiotics in Chinese pig farms is producing antibiotic-resistant genes that pose “a potential worldwide human health risk.”

headline: Happy Presidents’ Day
abstract: For this national holiday, we won’t be publishing on Feb. 18, but here are three ideas to celebrate the day.
lead_paragraph: We’re taking the day off on this national holiday — and, since many schools will be out this week, we’re also suspending daily lesson plans until Monday, Feb. 25.

headline: Russians Wade Into the Snow to Seek Treasure From the Sky
abstract: On Friday, terror rained from the skies in Siberia, but by Monday, what fell from the sky had turned to gold for people who rushed to retrieve meteorite fragments.
lead_paragraph: DEPUTATSKOYE, Russia — Ever since the meteor exploded somewhere over this impoverished Siberian town, Larisa V. Briyukova wondered what to do with the fist-size stone she found under a hole in the roof tiles of her woodshed.

headline: Capital Losses
abstract: A Buenos Aires landmark may be destroyed because of an ill-conceived mass transit project — and a political system that favors point-scoring over sound policy-making.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina’s capital may be about to lose what is arguably its most iconic sight: A new project by the city government led by Mayor Mauricio Macri is turning the 9 de Julio Avenue into a shadow of itself in the name of an ill-conceived public transportation project.

headline: U.N. Rights Officials Urge Syria War Crimes Charges
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Carla del Ponte, a United Nations human rights investigator, said that those responsible for war crimes in Syria should be held to account at the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations Security Council should refer Syria to the International Criminal Court in The Hague to prosecute those responsible for war crimes and other abuses committed in nearly two years of conflict, Carla del Ponte, a United Nations human rights investigator, said Monday.

headline: The Choice Takes a Midwinter Break
abstract: With at least some of our readers on a midwinter break from school, The Choice is taking a holiday, until Feb. 25.

headline: Preschool Economics
abstract: It makes good economic sense, as well as good public policy, to expand early-childhood education and defend early-childhood programs against budget-cutters, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.“

headline: Latika Mandal, the Teacher From West Bengal
abstract: Seeking spiritual fulfillment, Mrs. Mandal traveled for two days on a train and a bus to come to the Kumbh Mela.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of Indians, sometimes entire villages, brave the crowds to attend the Kumbh Mela? India Ink interviewed some of the estimated 100 million pilgrims who traveled to this year’s Kumbh Mela at Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, a 55-day pilgrimage during which Hindus take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins.

headline: Militants Attack Khyber Office in Pakistan
abstract: Militants disguised as police and wearing suicide vests mounted an attack in Peshawar on Monday, killing five people.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Militants disguised as tribal police officers and wearing vests packed with explosives mounted a coordinated attack on a central office of the tribal administration in Peshawar on Monday, killing five people and wounding seven others.

headline: From Stay-at-Home Moms to Back-to-Work Lawyers
abstract: Retraining programs and internships are helping onetime lawyers get back in the profession.
lead_paragraph: Since 2007, the Pace University School of Law in White Plains has been running a program aimed at helping lawyers who had left the field — typically stay-at-home mothers — re-enter the legal profession. Called New Directions, the course consists of 11 weeks of classroom refresher training and then an 11-week internship working as a lawyer in any of a number of settings, including law firms, government and nonprofit agencies and corporate offices. Pace offers two sessions a year, typically of 12 to 18 lawyers each. About 95 percent are women, and the average age is about 50. To date, 150 people have completed the training, with about half going on to paying jobs as lawyers. The cost is $7,000; participants may qualify for retraining grants of up to $3,000 from the United States Department of Labor. Another school offering a similar program includes the American University Washington College of Law Lawyer Re-Entry Program. That course is six days, spread over three weeks, and costs about $1,500; there are no internships.

headline: Face It

lead_paragraph: This comic is about putting things in perspective. For me, anxiety brings on an overwhelming tunnel vision. It can be scary but I try to let go and take a look around when I’m anxious.

headline: Fatalistic, Reckless, Distrustful
abstract: What a meteor’s fall revealed about the Russian character.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There is nothing like a meteor to showcase national character. When one blew up in the sky over Chelyabinsk on Friday morning, the defining traits of Russian citizens emerged for all to see.

headline: Chávez Returns to Venezuela, Trailing Doubts
abstract: The predawn homecoming of President Hugo Chávez more than two months after having cancer surgery did little to dispel the uncertainty over who was running the country.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In a surprise predawn homecoming, President Hugo Chávez returned to Venezuela on Monday more than two months after having cancer surgery in Cuba, potentially clearing up some of the legal questions that have roiled the nation during his long absence but doing little to dispel the deep uncertainty over who is running the country.

lead_paragraph: A new report from the Government Accountability Office elevates the problem of looming gaps in satellite weather data to a “high risk” concern for the federal government

headline: Anti-Apartheid Leader Forms New Party in South Africa
abstract: Mamphela Ramphele announced the formation of Agang, meaning “build,” in a challenge to the governing African National Congress.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Mamphela Ramphele, a respected veteran of the struggle against apartheid, announced on Monday that she had formed a new political party to compete against the governing African National Congress, calling on South Africans to “join me on a journey to build the country of our dreams.”

headline: Incumbent Is Likely Victor in Vote for Armenian Leader
abstract: Armenians went to the polls on Monday in a presidential election that seemed certain to return President Serzh Sargsyan to office for a second five-year term.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Armenians went to the polls on Monday in an election that seemed certain to return President Serzh Sargsyan to office for a second five-year term, and to maintain stability in a country that has become an increasingly important, if uneasy, United States ally in monitoring Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Tech Industry Looks to Online Gambling and Business Insider Appoints an Executive Editor
abstract: The technology industry has set its sights on online gambling, Business Insider names Joe Weisenthal as executive editor and authenticating an online photo in Omaha takes more shoe leather than tech savvy.
lead_paragraph: Developers across the technology industry are focusing on online gambling as their next billion-dollar business, David Streitfeld reports. Online poker and sports betting are certainly nothing new, but developers from giants like Zynga to specialists like Betable are creating more casual games on which users can bet, from casino staples like slots and roulette to considerably more creative diversions. Developers are currently aiming their products at foreign markets while trying to make inroads in the United States, where online gambling is still largely illegal. Legislation to legalize the practice is slow, facing headwinds from brick-and-mortar casinos and traditional antigambling factions.

headline: The Great Dollar Decline
abstract: Mostly not about us.
lead_paragraph: Matt O’Brien is covering the continuing Scarborough freakout over bearded prophets of non-doom; better him than me. I would say that JoScar is making progress. He seems to have graduated from frantic appeals to imagined authority — nobody else is saying what that guy says! — to efforts to make his case with actual data. Unfortunately, you really need some background knowledge — actually, quite a lot of background knowledge — before you try using economic data to tell stories, a point O’Brien makes abundantly clear.

lead_paragraph: The birthrate among women in the United States reached a record low in 2011, led mainly by the decline in births among immigrant and native-born Hispanic women. That decline, along with the opportunity that the Hispanic community represents  for advertisers, is at the heart of a new campaign from First Response to promote its pregnancy planning tools.

And while this would be notable because she is the first woman to accomplish that, this became news just by actually being news.

headline: Research: A ‘Media Diet’ Can Lead to Less Aggressive Behavior in Children
abstract: Parents who worked with researchers to change the “media diet” of 3- to 5-year-olds observed a small but meaningful reduction in their more aggressive behaviors.
lead_paragraph: When researchers helped parents choose a better “media diet” for 3- to 5-year-olds, the results were encouraging. In a randomized trial, the children who watched less violent programs and whose parents paid closer attention to what the children were watching were less aggressive than those in a control group, and they scored higher on “measures of social competence” as much as a year later.

They teamed for another stunner Sunday, as Patrick, embarking on her first full season in Nascar’s Sprint Cup series, won the pole position for the Feb. 24 Daytona 500.

headline: Problems With Precision and Judgment, but Not Integrity, in Tesla Test
abstract: The public editor looks into a test drive of an electric car that caused a storm.
lead_paragraph: As promised, I’ve spent the past several days looking into the reporter John M. Broder’s test drive of the celebrated electric car known as the Tesla Model S. The article, which focused on two new “superchargers” on the East Coast, was understandably disturbing to the company and to the car’s many admirers. The test drive, it’s safe to say, did not go well. In fact, its publication was accompanied by a startling photograph of the Model S on a flatbed truck, onto which it was loaded after depleting its battery charge on the last leg of the trip.

But if you look around, you will see signs of a neighborhood changed.

headline: The Oldest No. 1, and the Newest Rivalry
abstract: However you analyze it, Serena Williams’s return to No. 1 should rank high on a list of career achievements that already includes 15 Grand Slam singles titles.
lead_paragraph: As Victoria Azarenka beat Serena Williams, it looked from afar as if Azarenka’s shots down the stretch were more accurate than her celebration.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 18
abstract: British Prime Minister David Cameron begins three-day visit to India.

headline: Savory Winter Pies
abstract: Savory pies filled with vegetables are one way to add more produce to your diet.
lead_paragraph: This week I slowed down and made pies: savory ones filled with vegetables. I was just back from the annual Worlds of Healthy Flavors invitational conference that the Culinary Institute of America and Harvard School of Public Health organize for the food service industry and was eager to get back to cooking the kinds of foods that the conference organizers are trying to help the food industry focus on. An entire general session was devoted to increasing menu emphasis on produce, with presentations by marketing specialists, nutritionists and, of course, chefs. This theme resonated throughout the three-day conference: if restaurant chains devoted more of their menu space to produce they could eliminate or reduce some of the less-than-healthy fare they are known for.

headline: Walkabout – 2/18: The costs of airlines merging and a perk for turning 40
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: When Two Become One  While executives of American Airlines and US Airways argue that the two companies’ merger will benefit customers by offering more destinations, some economists and consumer advocates say it will come at a cost. (The New York Times)

headline: Bucking a Trend, Supreme Court Justices Reject Video Coverage
abstract: Justices have defended their viewpoint of not allowing video in the courtroom by saying most Americans would not understand the workings of the court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Sonia Sotomayor, populist, revealed a paternalistic streak this month, announcing that she had rethought her enthusiasm for video coverage of Supreme Court arguments.

headline: Daniel Day-Lewis, Magazine Editor
abstract: Ahead of the Oscars, the stylish men’s quarterly Port Magazine tells T that the actor is guest-editing its film issue, which hits newsstands on March 14.
lead_paragraph: For one of cinema’s most reclusive talents, Daniel Day-Lewis has certainly been making the rounds. Now, ahead of the Oscars, the stylish men’s quarterly Port Magazine tells T that the actor is guest-editing its film issue, which hits newsstands on March 14. “Having Daniel share his friendships with me has been a humbling experience which sometimes left me speechless. On occasion, such as a lunch interview with Ray Winstone, which turned into a two day party, I was left legless,” says Port’s editor, Dan Crowe. “The fact that he was able to do this during the awards season and all the work he had on with ‘Lincoln’ is incredible.” Port and Day-Lewis even convinced Winstone, the lovable Cockney rogue, to introduce the issue in the following video clip.

headline: ‘War and Peace’ to Get BBC Miniseries Treatment
abstract: The six-hour series will be faithful to the novel’s setting in war-torn 19th-century Russia but focus more on romance and family conflicts than on its philosophical elements.
lead_paragraph: For anyone who cannot get enough of “War and Peace,” the BBC on Monday announced that its latest drama project is an adaptation of this Tolstoy classic. The long novel will become a long series: six hourlong episodes scheduled to be broadcast on BBC One in 2015.

headline: Drug Makers, in Shift, Join Fight Against Doping
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies are helping to develop tests for illicit use in order to keep their offerings from being abused by athletes.
lead_paragraph: The blood-enhancing drug EPO has improved the lives of millions of anemia patients, but Lance Armstrong and other top cyclists have turned the medicine into a byword for doping.

headline: Goat Cheese, Chard and Herb Pie in a Phyllo Crust
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Chard (Vegetable)', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: A garlicky mix of greens and your choice of herbs inside a crispy phyllo crust.
lead_paragraph: Instead of making a top crust for this phyllo pie I take the overhanging layers of phyllo and scrunch them around the rim to make a nice crisp border for the pie. I didn’t want to put on a top layer of phyllo because the filling is quite liquid before it bakes and sets up, and I was afraid that the phyllo would become too soggy.

headline: Twins Don’t Need C-Sections
keywords: ['Caesarean Section', 'Medicine and Health', 'Multiple Births', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Twins']
abstract: A new study of 2,800 women showed that outcomes in successful births, births with serious medical problems and deaths were similar for both vaginal and Caesarean section deliveries.
lead_paragraph: Obstetricians increasingly recommend planned Caesarean sections for women having twins, but a new study has found that a C-section for healthy twins usually provides no advantage over vaginal delivery.

headline: The Intersection of Coffee and Cocktails in Long Island City
abstract: A new bar that will serve coffee in the daytime, and cocktails in the evening.
lead_paragraph: The coffee and cocktail contingents of Long Island City are joining forces.

headline: Vitamin Labels May Be Wrong
abstract: The amounts of vitamin D present in supplements sold over the counter often bear little resemblance to the descriptions on the bottle labels, a new study concludes.
lead_paragraph: The amounts of vitamin D present in supplements sold over the counter often bear little resemblance to the descriptions on the bottle labels, a new study concludes.

headline: Reader’s Digest Files for Bankruptcy, Again
abstract: The magazine’s parent company filed for Chapter 11 protection late on Sunday in another attempt to cut down the debt that has plagued the pocket-sized publication for years.
lead_paragraph: Executives at Reader’s Digest must be hoping that the magazine’s second trip to bankruptcy court in under four years will be its last.

headline: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
abstract: The best N.B.A. games of the week include the Oklahoma City at Houston, Miami at Chicago and the Clippers at San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

headline: Young Drinkers Prefer Beer
abstract: A nationwide survey found that the favorite alcoholic beverage of underage drinkers is beer, and their favorite beer is Budweiser.
lead_paragraph: While it has long been clear that many adolescents drink alcohol, despite its illegality, experts have never been certain what they are drinking. Now a nationwide survey finds that the favorite alcoholic beverage of underage drinkers is beer, and their favorite beer is Budweiser.

headline: Christie’s Raises Its Commissions
abstract: Typically, when one auction house increases its fees the others follow.
lead_paragraph: 5:54 p.m. | Updated It’s about to get more expensive to shop at Christie’s. On Friday the auction house sent an e-mail to its clients announcing that it was increasing its so-called buyer’s premium — the fee it charges buyers — for the first time since 2008.

headline: When to Retire a Running Shoe
abstract: Every runner has an opinion, but the facts to support them are few.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Hall, one of the world’s best distance runners, used to pride himself on wearing his running shoes into nubs. No more. Now he assiduously replaces his shoes after running about 200 miles in them. He goes through two pairs a month.

headline: The Daily Do | Matthew Williamson
abstract: Williamson’s English roses wore easy, disheveled braids with haphazard bobby pins, to keep flyaways from their faces.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Williamson’s English roses (naturally) felt authentically undone in easy, disheveled braids with haphazard bobby pins, to keep flyaways from their faces.

headline: Finding Answers, or More Mystery, Through DNA Sequencing
abstract: As genetic sequencing becomes cheaper and more accessible, more families are using it to try to determine the cause of rare disorders. With it comes hope of answers and a small chance of treatment.
lead_paragraph: As genetic sequencing becomes cheaper and more accessible, more families are using it to try to determine the cause of rare disorders. With it comes hope of answers and a small chance of treatment.

headline: DNA Test for Rare Disorders Becomes More Routine
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: As the cost of genetic sequencing plunges, more people, especially parents, are using it to find disease-causing mutations.
lead_paragraph: Debra Sukin and her husband were determined to take no chances with her second pregnancy. Their first child, Jacob, who had a serious genetic disorder, did not babble when he was a year old and had severe developmental delays. So the second time around, Ms. Sukin had what was then the most advanced prenatal testing.

headline: Rattlestick Adds ‘Buyer & Cellar,’ With Michael Urie, To Its Season
abstract: The comedy by Jonathan Tolins is about a struggling actor who bonds with a superstar while cataloging her collectibles.
lead_paragraph: Michael Urie, who has become something of a New York stage regular (“Angels in America,” “The Cherry Orchard”) since the conclusion of the TV series “Ugly Betty” (not to mention the quick cancellation of his recent “Partners”), will be back this spring in a new play by Jonathan Tolins (“The Twilight of the Golds,” “Secrets of the Trade”).

headline: The Myth of Reagan’s Miracle
abstract: Misplaced Republican nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: Ramesh Ponnuru has a rather sad piece in today’s Times, urging Republicans to revitalize themselves by emulating Reagan’s spirit rather than his specifics. Actually, it’s sad on two fronts.

headline: Republican Senator From Nebraska Won’t Run in 2014
abstract: Senator Mike Johanns, who is in his first term, on Monday became the fifth lawmaker to bow out of a Senate that has become increasingly bitter and dysfunctional.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mike Johanns, a Nebraska Republican who is in his first term, announced on Monday that he would not seek re-election next year, the fifth lawmaker to bow out of a Senate that has become increasingly polarized and dysfunctional.

headline: Kleybanova Plots Return After Two-Year Cancer Fight
abstract: Alisa Kleybanova of Russia hopes to resume her career this season after spending two years fighting Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
lead_paragraph: Alisa Kleybanova of Russia, a former top-20 player who has won two WTA singles titles, plans to return to competition by the middle of this season, a considerable accomplishment for an athlete who has been fighting cancer for the past two years.

headline: Taking on Mystery Diseases, Sociology of Prison Time
abstract: How genetics changing the fight against childhood diseases and how social science is changing the way we think about crime and punishment.
lead_paragraph: How genetics changing the fight against childhood diseases and how social science is changing the way we think about crime and punishment.

headline: Now Showing | London Designers to Watch
abstract: A look at three artists who sent sponsored collections down the runway at the Tate Modern today courtesy of Fashion East, a non-profit for young talent.
lead_paragraph: London has long been known for its embrace of young, emerging designers. So in 2000, Lulu Kennedy founded Fashion East, a nonprofit that helps fledgling British talent find their wings by covering everything from production to a show during London Fashion Week. Today, these three artists to watch sent Fashion East-sponsored collections down the runway at the Tate Modern.

headline: Burberry Prorsum: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Winter Wakefulness
abstract: Insect metabolism for many species slows drastically in the cold or in other unfavorable conditions, a shutdown called diapause.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do stink bugs remain alert indoors through the winter while apparently doing without food or liquid?

headline: Talking Talent | Niia
abstract: The 25 year-old musician, who has garnered a cult following for underground James Bond themed musical performances, has a voice that was born to sing torch songs.
lead_paragraph: If you have not heard of Niia, the jazz trained pianist and vocalist, you will very soon. Her first single, “Made for You,” made its debut last week on the Fader’s Web site and is available now on iTunes. Tony Kaye, of “American History X” fame, directed the rather dark “Made for You” video, complete with silicone life-size sex dolls. The 25-year-old musician, who has toured with Wyclef Jean and has garnered a cult following for underground James Bond-themed musical performances, has a voice that was born to sing torch songs.

headline: Really? Probiotic Supplements Can Lower Cholesterol
abstract: Probiotics may improve digestive health, but it is not yet clear whether they can reduce cholesterol levels.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: Criticisms of a Classic Abound
abstract: Scholars have been doggedly chipping away at the foundations of Betty Friedan’s “Feminine Mystique,” on the plight of American housewives.
lead_paragraph: When the proposal for a book about the plight of the American housewife by a little-known journalist named Betty Friedan began circulating at the publishing house W. W. Norton in early 1959, not everyone was convinced that it was a world-changing blockbuster.

headline: Office Space, by the Hour
abstract: For some hotels, lobbies, business centers and meeting areas have become an untapped source of additional revenue and new customers who live and work nearby.
lead_paragraph: Seasoned business travelers are used to booking a place to sleep. But a couch in the lobby?

headline: Iberia Airline Workers Protest Job Cuts and Disrupt Madrid Airport
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Strikes', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Several hundred protesters managed to create chaos and frustration for many passengers affected by the strike.
lead_paragraph: Striking ground workers and flight attendants for Iberia, the money-losing Spanish airline, clashed with riot police officers at Madrid-Barajas Airport on Monday, the first day of work stoppages to protest a plan to eliminate more than 3,800 jobs.

headline: Critics of Executive Pay Put Pressure on Novartis
abstract: The drug maker plans to pay Daniel Vasella, its departing chairman, $78 million to prevent him from sharing knowledge with competitors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A plan by Novartis, one of Switzerland’s biggest drug makers, to pay its departing chairman $78 million to keep him from sharing his knowledge with competitors has added fuel to an already heated debate about executive pay.

headline: Murphy to Miss Time With Midsection Discomfort
abstract: Mets second baseman Daniel Murphy said he thought the issue was related to mechanical tweaks in his swing.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets’ first injury concern of the year was revealed after the team’s first full squad workout of spring training Monday afternoon.

headline: Draghi Seeks to Ease Talk of Global Currency War
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency', 'Euro (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, urged financial officials not to say anything that would contribute to fears of a global currency war.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The president of the European Central Bank sought on Monday to ease fears that countries including Japan were deliberately weakening their currencies.

headline: Luongo on Luongo (on Twitter)
abstract: Vancouver goalie Roberto Luongo, the source of constant debate whether he is starting or backing up, pokes fun at himself on perhaps the most hilarious Twitter feed by a player anywhere.
lead_paragraph: The mystery started mysteriously enough last offseason: a hilarious Twitter account by the name @strombone1. The profile picture is an outline of a hockey goalie with a ? in place of the number. And its posts were all about Vancouver goalie Roberto Luongo, often poking fun at the drama around whether he would be traded after the Canucks demoted him to backup.

headline: Chrysler to Offer Diesel in 2014 Ram 1500 Pickup
abstract: The 3-liter turbocharged V-6 will be paired with an 8-speed automatic transmission.

headline: Photo Replay: February 18
abstract: The day in sports includes a tough day for the American tennis player Sloane Stephens, spring training stretches and Indian children playing through a fog.
lead_paragraph: The day in sports includes a tough day for the American tennis player Sloane Stephens, spring training stretches and Indian children playing through a fog.

headline: A Mole’s Nose Knows, With Stereo Sniffing
abstract: Previous research indicated that rats can smell in stereo, and there are suggestions that sharks and ants can, too.
lead_paragraph: Humans and many other mammals see and hear in stereo. But what about smell?

headline: Model Diary | Maria Bradley
abstract: The 18-year-old, seen on the runway at Marc Jacobs and at Giles, shares a few of her favorite things.
lead_paragraph: Maria Bradley – the part-time Brooklynite who walked in last Thursday’s Marc Jacobs show, the luminous finale to New York Fashion Week – kicks off the London series of Model Diary for T. With two years of modeling under her belt, the 18-year-old from Wichita, Kansas, walked in the Giles show today.

headline: Picasso’s Masterpieces Made With House Paint
abstract: Physicists used a high-energy X-ray instrument to analyze pigments taken from the artist’s paint.
lead_paragraph: Scientists using a high-energy X-ray instrument say they have solved the long-running debate over what kind of paint Picasso used in his masterpieces.

headline: Pro-Gun Lawmakers Are Open to Limits on Size of Magazines
abstract: Lawmakers in both parties view an assault weapons ban as politically toxic, but many seem more amenable to restricting the kinds of high-capacity devices used in recent rampages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Christopher S. Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, is haunted by many things that emerged from the investigation of the December mass shooting at a Newtown elementary school. Among them is the nagging question of what prompted the gunman, Adam Lanza, to put down his rifle after killing 20 children and pick up the pistol he used to end his own life.

headline: The 2014 SS: Chevrolet Answers a Question, but Was Anybody Asking?
keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Automobiles', 'Daytona 500 (Auto Race)', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series', 'New York International Auto Show', 'North American International Auto Show']
abstract: Chevrolet shows Nascar fans its first rear-drive performance sedan since the 1996 departure of the Impala SS.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. – Blame booming Chevrolet, which has more new vehicles to introduce than it knows what to do with, that the all new 2014 Chevrolet SS rear-drive performance sedan was introduced to the public and the media in the infield of Daytona International Speedway hours before the Nascar version of the SS was to debut on track in the first race of the season, a preliminary to the Daytona 500.

headline: Dangers of Too Much Calcium
abstract: New research suggests that older women who take large calcium supplements may be at increased risk of heart disease and death.
lead_paragraph: Calcium is an important nutrient for bone health, but new research suggests that older women who take large amounts may be at increased risk of heart disease and death.

headline: In Europe, Mounting Debt May Push Companies to Public Markets
abstract: European companies are considering public stock offerings as part of broader plan to pay down debt and bolster profit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The steady revival in European stocks is offering hope to the region’s highly indebted companies seeking to raise money on the public markets.

headline: Light Bulbs and Luminaries: Star Turns Onstage
abstract: Benedict Nightingale’s “Great Moments in the Theatre” is more a theater lover’s journal than a history lesson, but it puts an engaging spin on the chronology of the Western stage.
lead_paragraph: They may have dug up the bones of Richard III, but the original performance of the play that made him famous will always remain something of a mystery.

headline: Top Enforcement Officer of N.C.A.A. Is Ousted
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'College Athletics', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The removal of Julie Roe Lach came after the N.C.A.A. said its investigators had violated its own rules while examining accusations that a booster provided improper benefits to students.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, the N.C.A.A. has faced mounting criticism and broad challenges to its authority, with concerns raised about how it has conducted high-profile investigations.

headline: Paul McCarthy’s Take On Snow White Among Armory’s New Season Highlights
abstract: The armory, which converted itself into a performance, concert and art space in 2007, is drawing heavily this year on visual artists this season.
lead_paragraph: A phantasmagorical Snow White forest, a play about Garry Kasparov and Deep Blue and an electronic music opus staged in an idealized lunar landscape (the audience will slip on white robes) are a few of the highlights announced Monday by the Park Avenue Armory for its 2013 season.

headline: Russian Legislator’s Body Is Found in a Barrel Filled With Concrete
abstract: The Moscow police said the body of Mikhail Pakhomov, a city legislator and construction tycoon missing since last week, was found in a private basement garage.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The body of a missing city legislator and construction tycoon was found in a private basement garage on the city’s outskirts, inside a rusted metal barrel filled with concrete, the police said Monday.

headline: King’s Case for Hall of Fame Still a Good One
abstract: Quirks of the game: Bernard King is again a finalist for the Basketball Hall of Fame, but whether he will — or should — make the final cut remains an open question.
lead_paragraph: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on the Times sports blogs.

headline: An Anthropologist’s War Stories
abstract: The anthropologist Napoleon A. Chagnon tries to answer questions about human evolution in his 35-year study of the Yanomamö of Venezuela and Brazil.
lead_paragraph: What were our early ancestors really like as they accomplished the transition from hunter-gathering bands to more complex settled societies? The anthropologist Napoleon A. Chagnon may have come closest to the answer in his 35-year study of a remarkable population, the Yanomamö of Venezuela and Brazil.

headline: Albums by Portal and Iceage
abstract: The band Portal has a new release that is relatively less jarring, while Iceage hopes to live up to higher expectations on its latest record.
lead_paragraph: PORTAL

headline: Goldbugs, Greece, and Affinity Fraud
abstract: Stock tips and bad economics, best friends forever.
lead_paragraph: Joe Weisenthal tries to understand why Barron’s, which he describes as a “quiet financial newspaper”, has a hysterical cover story about Obama turning America into Greece, Greece I tell you. So you might want to note that they’ve done this before. I don’t regularly read Barron’s or even notice what they’re saying, but I did note their frantic calls for a rise in interest rates back in October 2009, that’s right, 2009 — because inflation! confidence!

headline: The Average American Knows How Many People?
abstract: Researchers used a clever method to estimate the size of the average social network.
lead_paragraph: The average American knows about 600 people. How do we know this? Researchers led by my Columbia colleague Tian Zheng posed a series of questions to a representative sample of 1,500 Americans: How many people do you know named Kevin? How many named Karen? How many named Shawn or Sean, Brenda, Keith or Rachel?

headline: A Citywide Retrospective for the Poet and Playwright Sekou Sundiata
abstract: “Blink Your Eyes: Sekou Sundiata Revisited,” which will begin in April, is a collaboration among more than 50 artists, educational institutions and 18 cultural organizations.
lead_paragraph: Sekou Sundiata, the poet, playwright, performer and educator who died in 2007 after a career featuring his signature themes of race, power and identity, will be the subject of a seven-month citywide retrospective, set to begin in April.

headline: Susan Love’s Illness Gives New Focus to Her Cause
abstract: Dr. Susan Love, a breast cancer specialist, says her experience battling leukemia has emboldened her in her quest to focus on the causes of disease rather than new drugs to treat it.
lead_paragraph: During a talk last spring in San Francisco, Dr. Susan Love, the well-known breast cancer book author and patient advocate, chided the research establishment for ignoring the needs of people with cancer. “The only difference between a researcher and a patient is a diagnosis,” she told the crowd. “We’re all patients.”

headline: Uproar Over Netanyahu’s Ice Cream Is Welcome in One Parlor
abstract: A $2,700 allowance for a year’s worth of premium desserts for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has angered a public facing economic struggles.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — His foreign minister had to resign after being accused of fraud. He was sharply criticized for his government’s handling of Prisoner X, who committed suicide in prison. And now this, which made front-page news in Israel over the weekend: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stands accused of dipping into state coffers for an ice cream budget of $2,700 a year.

headline: Stung by ‘Argo,’ Iran Backs Conference Denouncing ‘Hollywoodism’
abstract: Tehran invited more than a hundred foreign guests to discuss what was described as the hidden agenda behind major American movies to make Iranians look bad.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — As the trailer for “Argo,” an Oscar contender and a thorn in the side of the Iranian government, played in a conference room in a hotel here this month, Mehdi Tondro shook his head in disapproval.

headline: Recent Developments in Health and Science News
keywords: ['Pluto (Dwarf Planet)', 'Moon', 'Space', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Mice', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Water Pollution', 'Chemicals']
abstract: “The Week” highlights recent developments in health and science news and glances at what’s ahead. In this column: help for the blind and a gene mutation that may explain the appearance of East Asians.
lead_paragraph: It was a momentous week for asteroids — one that struck Earth, and one that didn’t.

headline: French Cite Recession in Delaying Budget Goal
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The Socialist government is emphasizing cutting spending, despite pressure from other officials.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Citing a Europe-wide recession, France’s Socialist government is moving away from its promise to bring its budget deficit down to 3 percent of gross domestic product this year, arguing that the recession creates an exceptional circumstance requiring less austerity.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Christopher Kane
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a Chelsea boot with inky blue feathers.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Prison and the Poverty Trap
abstract: Many social scientists no longer think that America’s shift to longer prison terms has been a help to poor neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Why are so many American families trapped in poverty? Of all the explanations offered by Washington’s politicians and economists, one seems particularly obvious in the low-income neighborhoods near the Capitol: because there are so many parents like Carl Harris and Charlene Hamilton.

abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Office Depot and OfficeMax Are Said to Be Discussing a Merger
abstract: Office Depot and OfficeMax are in talks to combine in an all-stock deal that may be announced as soon as this week, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Two of the big names in office supplies are hoping that a merger can make the business of selling staplers and toner more profitable.

headline: Obama Could Revisit Arming Syria Rebels as Assad Holds Firm
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: With President Obama apparently running out of ways to speed President Bashar al-Assad’s exit,  American officials may revive a debate on giving weapons to his opponents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama rebuffed four of his top national security officials who wanted to arm the rebels in Syria last fall, he put an end to a months of debate over how aggressively Washington should respond to the strife there that has now left nearly 70,000 dead.

headline: New Polio Strains That Protect Vaccine Factory Workers
abstract: The strains have the same ability to invoke an immune reaction as the live viruses now used to make vaccine do, but with no risk to vaccine factory employees.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have created new strains of polio intended to protect workers in factories that make polio vaccine. The new strains have the same ability to invoke an immune reaction as the live viruses now used to make vaccine do, but there is virtually no risk anyone will get polio if one of the new strains somehow escapes.

headline: Committed to an Old Sound and Riffing on the Past
abstract: The trance-rock band Endless Boogie played at Cameo Gallery on Friday in a performance including tracks from its new album, “Long Island.”
lead_paragraph: Endless Boogie isn’t exactly a jam band. It’s even less charismatic than that: a rehearsal band, maybe. Its music can sound like private catalogings of very specific taste. Its set on Friday at Cameo Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn — like the group’s entire project — took the shape of consistently repetitive, one-chord riff-rock: it descended from music recorded between 1968 and 1974, more or less. Sometimes a chorus expanded a song to blues form, but that was about it for chord changes.

headline: A Grab Bag of Sound
abstract: The Royal Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra performed at Carnegie Hall on Friday.
lead_paragraph: When the Finnish conductor Sakari Oramo led the New York Philharmonic for the first time in 2004, Anthony Tommasini ended a rave review in The New York Times by looking toward the future.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. and A. With Karlie Kloss
keywords: ['Beauty', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: T caught up with the Midwestern beauty backstage at Burberry Prorsum to talk about her new short do and makeup essentials.
lead_paragraph: At just 20 years old, the model Karlie Kloss is already an industry veteran and remains one of the most in-demand models on the show circuit. T caught up with the Midwestern beauty backstage at Burberry Prorsum to talk about her new short do and makeup essentials.

headline: Diners, Seedy Motels and TV Industry In-Jokes
abstract: The new CW series “Cult” focuses on ambient creepiness and TV-industry in-jokes.
lead_paragraph: “Cult,” a new series on CW, is about the mysterious circumstances surrounding a fictional television show — also called “Cult,” and also on CW. Sometimes when the characters in the real show are watching the fictional show, two CW logos appear on the screen at the same time. The scariest thing about this mildly ominous thriller may be the shameless heights to which it takes network self-promotion.

headline: From Victor Hugo and Maybe a Batman Villain
abstract: The Stolen Chair Theater Company is presenting “The Man Who Laughs,” its 2005 adaptation of Victor Hugo’s play, at Urban Stages.
lead_paragraph: Victor Hugo’s 1869 novel, “The Man Who Laughs,” has been adapted several times for the screen, notably in 1928 by the German Expressionist Paul Leni, with Conrad Veidt (“The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari”) in the title role. Leni’s film, made in Hollywood, qualifies as swashbuckler, romance and horror movie.

headline: A Network and Its Modern, Manly Goals
abstract: The Esquire Network needs to avoid the pitfalls of other TV programming geared toward men.
lead_paragraph: You can imagine the excitement among modern men when the announcement came last week that finally, more than 65 years into the television age, we are about to get a TV network intended just for us. So surprising was this news that we had not even prepared a suitable celebratory gesture. Chest bump? Too Neanderthalic. Forearm bash? Too steroidal. High five? Too unsophisticated. Fist bump? Too passive aggressive.

headline: Exploring Gun Violence in Wake of Sandy Hook
abstract: A package of shows on PBS, presented as “After Newtown,” examines the gun issue in America and possible solutions.
lead_paragraph: The national PBS schedule is a placid thing, sketched out well in advance and usually subject to only minor tweaking. So the weeklong programming effort titled “After Newtown,” arriving two months after the mass killings at the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., represents a major effort in high-metabolism reporting and producing for a network accustomed to moving at a more deliberate pace.

headline: Looking Back at a Domestic Cri de Coeur
abstract: Reading Betty Friedan’s “Feminine Mystique” for the first time, 50 years after its publication, a critic found that the book still has the power to surprise and unsettle.
lead_paragraph: On my first day of work at The New York Times, a young reporter spied me in the newsroom and rushed up to say hello. “Hey!” she said. “It’s another one of us!” We were both in our 20s at a time when young women at The Times were a novelty, and that big smile from Anna Quindlen was an amazingly generous icebreaker. That was that: friends for life.

headline: A Surreal Fish Tank With a Frogman, a Masochist and Bing Crosby
abstract: Three of the original cast members of the Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch company are performing in Bausch’s 1985 piece “Two Cigarettes in the Dark” at Sadler’s Wells in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The curtain rises on a spare white room framed on three sides by large glass windows. Behind one is a feverish jungle of foliage, behind another is a lone cactus on sand, and a third is filled by a fish tank. Into this spare whiteness steps Mechthild Grossmann, in a long, cream-colored dress.

headline: Acoustic or Electric, Sounds That Call for Jumping Up and Down
abstract: The guitarist and singer Tom Morello performed as the Nightwatchman on Saturday as part of the Lincoln Center American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: There is a direct line of descent from Woody Guthrie through Bruce Springsteen to Tom Morello, the guitarist for Rage Against the Machine, whose alter ego, the Nightwatchman, is a militant left-wing acoustic folkie.

headline: Industries Targeted by the Hackers
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A new study by Mandiant, an American computer security firm, identified more than 140 organizations that have been compromised over the past six years by a single hacking group, called “Comment Crew’' or “Shanghai Group.’' Mandiant has assembled a circumstantial case that links Comment Crew to Unit 61398 of the People’s Liberation Army.
lead_paragraph: A new study by Mandiant, an American computer security firm, identified more than 140 organizations that have been compromised over the past six years by a single hacking group, called “Comment Crew’' or “Shanghai Group.’' Mandiant has assembled a circumstantial case that links Comment Crew to Unit 61398 of the People’s Liberation Army.

headline: Steuart Pittman, Head of Fallout Shelter Program, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Pittman was appointed by President John F. Kennedy to create enough shelters to protect every American in the event of a nuclear attack.
lead_paragraph: Steuart Pittman, a Washington lawyer who was appointed by President John F. Kennedy in 1961 to create enough fallout shelters to protect every American in the event of a nuclear attack, and who resigned in frustration three years later amid heated debates over the feasibility, the cost and even the ethics of such a program, died on Feb. 10 at his family farm in Davidsonville, Md. He was 93. The apparent cause was a stroke, said his wife, Barbara.

headline: Senators Rally to Topple Devils in Shootout
abstract: In his first shootout, the rookie Jakob Silfverberg delivered and lifted the Senators, without three of their biggest stars, to a victory.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Games and seasons that can be decided by penalty-shot contests still rankle old-school N.H.L. fans eight years after they were introduced. But the shootout is a fact of life as the Devils found again Monday in a 2-1 loss to the Ottawa Senators at Prudential Center.

headline: The State of the Block Response
abstract: Readers offered their views in answer to City Room’s request for assessments of the individual blocks where they live, and the vast majority of the responses were negative.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his 12th and final State of the City address last week, which turned into a celebration of sorts of his three terms as mayor of New York. Because such speeches are, by nature, broadly cast, City Room reached out to readers for a more granular assessment, asking, “What’s the state of your block?”

headline: Amazon Cuts Links to Company Facing Furor Over Security
abstract: The announcement that Amazon had ceased its relationship with Hensel European Security Services came after a television documentary raised questions about Amazon's treatment of foreign workers.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The online retailer Amazon on Monday severed all contact with the security company whose guards are alleged to have worn clothing associated with neo-Nazis and intimidated immigrant temporary workers.

headline: Morgan Stanley Strives to Coordinate 2 Departments Often at Odds
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Financial Brokers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Pressure mounts to coax greater profits from the low-margin brokerage business by finding ways for retail and investment banking to work better together.
lead_paragraph: Several hundred Morgan Stanley retail branch managers descended on the JW Marriott Orlando Grande Lakes resort in Florida early this month for a retreat. They were greeted by an unlikely colleague, Colm Kelleher, who runs the company’s sales and trading and investment banking departments.

headline: Iran: Death Sentences for Fraud
abstract: An Iranian court on Monday confirmed the death sentences for four people convicted of participating in a $2.6 billion embezzlement scheme, the biggest fraud in Iran’s history.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian court on Monday confirmed the death sentences for four people convicted of participating in a $2.6 billion embezzlement scheme, the biggest fraud in Iran’s history. The four bankers and businessmen, including Mahafarid Amirkhosravi, the chief executive of the Arya Investment Group, were convicted of “disturbing the country’s economic system through collusion and corruption in the banking network.” They cannot appeal the court’s decision. Twenty-five other people, including two government officials, have been sentenced to long prison terms and large fines, the spokesman of Iran’s judiciary announced Monday.

headline: Israel: Obama to Receive Award
abstract: President Shimon Peres plans to give President Obama a special award at a state dinner next month when Mr. Obama is expected to visit Israel.
lead_paragraph: President Shimon Peres plans to give President Obama a special award at a state dinner next month when Mr. Obama is expected to visit Israel. Mr. Obama would be the first sitting American president to receive the award, Israel’s Presidential Medal of Distinction. Previous recipients include Henry A. Kissinger and the conductor Zubin Mehta. “Barack Obama is a true friend of the State of Israel, and has been since the beginning of his public life,” Mr. Peres said in a statement.

headline: The Daily Do | Tom Ford
abstract: At Tom Ford: slick, sinuously twisted and tucked hair so discreet that it was like a disappearing act.
lead_paragraph: As slick as his trademark aesthetic, the hair at Tom Ford sinuously twisted once and tucked under itself so discreetly that it was like a disappearing act.

headline: For His Second Act, Japanese Premier Plays It Safe, With Early Results
abstract: Analysts say Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s success hinges on whether he can lead his Liberal Democratic Party to victory in upper house elections in July.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Since taking office less than two months ago, Japan’s outspokenly hawkish new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has been in what some political analysts are calling “safe driving mode.” He has carefully avoided saying or doing anything to provoke other Asian nations, while focusing instead on wooing voters with steps to revive the moribund domestic economy.

headline: Some Major Colleges Fear Looser N.C.A.A. Recruiting Rules
abstract: Under N.C.A.A. legislation, college coaches would be able to exchange unlimited phone calls and text messages with prospects, among other rule changes.
lead_paragraph: Greg McGarity, the University of Georgia athletic director, gathered the coaches from various teams in his office one morning several weeks ago to discuss the pending deregulation of recruiting in college athletics.

headline: Is There Room for Varied Approaches to Energy and Climate Progress?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Pipelines']
abstract: “My way or the highway” environmentalism and the Keystone pipeline fight.

headline: Fuel Surcharges Push Up International Airfares
abstract: A wave of discounts for air travel has faded in the face of the rising cost of fuel and dwindling capacity.
lead_paragraph: IN the first week of January, I was talking about fluctuations in fares for trans-Atlantic travel with Orit Keren, the president of OKT Travel, and Aik-Meng Tan, the vice president for sales.

headline: W. Watts Biggers, Creator of ‘Underdog’ Cartoon, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Biggers, an advertising account manager, also wrote the infectious “Underdog” theme song.
lead_paragraph: W. Watts Biggers, who with a partner created the 1960s cartoon “Underdog” as a way to sell cereal and wrote its infectious theme song, died on Feb. 10 at his home in Manomet, Mass. He was 85.

headline: Burberry: Merchandised Sin
abstract: To look at the clothes that Christopher Bailey presented (in a tent in Kensington Park) is to realize again how much the needs and imagery of the Web have influenced design.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bailey doesn’t seem to have confidence that a woman can look sexy in an ordinary trench coat and a pair of kitten heels, though at one time in his career at Burberry he did. On Monday he opened his fall show with a translucent rubber pencil skirt and rubber bits on the famous trench. There were also animal-print trenches and secretarial skirts with tucked-in sweaters, all with low, wedge heels. Even if you didn’t see the Christine Keeler reference on the press notes, you would have recognized the plain feminine shapes from early 1960s British films. The hair in the show was straight and natural looking, another reference to the era.

headline: Nascar Drivers Speak Up, Aiming to Attract New Fans
abstract: Nascar replaces its advertising agency to attract younger, urban fans while maintaining its traditional base.
lead_paragraph: NASCAR had come a long way from the days when it was dismissed as Southerners driving around in circles turning left. There was rising attendance at tracks, increasing television ratings for races and growing demand from marketers to be sponsors.

headline: Yemen, Hailed as Model, Struggles for Stability
abstract: In some ways, the country’s transition has achieved relative calm two years since the start of its uprising, yet many Yemenis doubt anything substantial has changed.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The tents at the heart of this city’s Change Square are now almost empty of protesters, and the canvas flaps quietly in the breeze. Two years after the start of its democratic uprising, Yemen has a new president and is in the midst of a lumbering transition process that has been held up by the Obama administration as a model for resolving Syria’s bloody civil war.

headline: Strangers on a Flight, Just Taking a Fling
abstract: Brian Balthazar, director of programming at HGTV, likes business travel. He says when you fly a lot, almost anything can happen.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in a small town, just northeast of Scranton, Pa. In the past 20 or so years, I’ve worked in buildings that had more people in them than my hometown. To say I don’t like business travel would be a lie. It’s a rush to fly someplace, and stay in a decent hotel. I’m like a child about it.

headline: Like the Ohio River, a Bridge Project Divides a Community
abstract: A $2.6 billion plan to build two bridges linking Louisville, Ky., and southern Indiana splits the region into two camps.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Long ago, the Ohio River helped make this Rust Belt city a national pacesetter in manufacturing and transportation, providing it with an identity and an anchor. But as American life shifted toward the automobile, the river also became an impediment.

headline: Unabated Violence Poses Challenge to Mexico’s New Anticrime Program
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Recent violence, including gang rapes and the killing of police officers, has put pressure on Mexico’s new leader as he rolls out a less militaristic crime prevention initiative.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The new Mexican president, Enrique Peña Nieto, campaigned on a promise to reduce the violence spawned by the drug trade and organized crime, and to shift the talk about his nation away from cartels and killings.

headline: No Country for Old Age
abstract: The rapid expansion of retirement benefits for elderly Chinese has created alarm over who will pay for it, and how.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS who fret about the wave of baby-boomer retirements should consider this: Since 2009, when China enacted a nationwide program of rural pensions, some 325 million Chinese have been promised retirement benefits. That’s more than the entire population of the United States.

headline: Italy Votes on Its Future
abstract: The country’s upcoming election is being haunted by a figure from its past, Silvio Berlusconi.
lead_paragraph: Silvio Berlusconi, who resigned as Italy’s prime minister 15 months ago, is staging an appalling comeback. With less than a week to go before national elections this weekend, polls show that Mr. Berlusconi’s coalition has surged into second place, trailing the center-left coalition by single digits.

headline: Finding Out Who Pays Your Doctor
abstract: A new health care rule issued by the Obama administration will let the public in on payments that might influence treatment.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration issued a new rule this month that requires the makers of prescription drugs and other medical products to disclose what they pay doctors for various purposes, like consulting or speaking on behalf of the manufacturer. This overdue rule adds much-needed weight to previous, more limited disclosure requirements.

headline: Unjust Mandatory Minimums
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: When low-level offenders are unfairly being given sentences equal to those of major criminals, it’s time for reform.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. recently said that his top priority is to improve the criminal justice system. He can start by pushing Congress and the United States Sentencing Commission to fix the unfair problem of excessive mandatory minimum sentences.

headline: Democrats’ Man for Battles Will Lead New Senate Charge
abstract: Guy Cecil, who led the way to unlikely Senate victories for Democrats in 2010 and 2012, has a goal for next year: “To hold the majority, that’s it,” he said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After two grueling election cycles, Guy Cecil, the brains behind the Democrats’ improbable Senate showings in 2010 and 2012, was expected to set aside his political combat boots for tasseled loafers and a sinecure somewhere in this city that pays handsomely for success.

headline: Jeter Is Back on the Field and Keeping the Faith
abstract: Yankees fans want to keep Derek Jeter in that untainted, just-can’t-imagine category of athletes. But to play at that level, Jeter must fully heal from an ankle injury.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: The Pope’s Muffled Voice
keywords: ['Priests', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Don’t let the media frenzy fool you. American Catholics pay only glancing attention to the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: There were reports over the weekend that cardinals might tweak the rules and begin the conclave to choose Pope Benedict XVI’s successor sooner than March 15, which had been the earliest date mentioned. That would be a blessing. Already in the American news media it’s all pope all the time, a tsunami of papal coverage, and until a new pope is named, the tide won’t quit. You’d be forgiven for concluding that he’ll actually have significant sway over Catholics in this country.

headline: Iran: Rivals Forced to Apologize to Supreme Leader
abstract: Rival politicians apologized to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei over the weekend for having been embroiled in an unusually public feud involving secret tapes and a tit-for-tat impeachment.
lead_paragraph: Rival politicians apologized to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei over the weekend for having been embroiled in an unusually public feud involving secret tapes and a tit-for-tat impeachment. On Sunday, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad; the Parliament speaker, Ali Larijani; his brother, Sadegh Larijani; the chief of Iran’s judiciary; and all members of Parliament sent letters expressing sorrow and promising renewed allegiance to Ayatollah Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran. The written apologies, reported by the state-run press, came a day after the ayatollah criticized both Mr. Ahmadinejad and the Larijanis for letting their own mutual animosity become public, raising speculation of irreparable rifts. The ayatollah had said in a speech that the whole matter “made me feel sad.”

headline: What Data Can’t Do
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Research', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Data can’t account for everything in our experience, nor serve as the only guide for our thinking, planning and decision-making.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I was at a dinner with the chief executive of a large bank. He had just had to decide whether to pull out of Italy, given the weak economy and the prospect of a future euro crisis.

headline: Body Found on a Beach Was Tied Up
abstract: The woman was identified as 24-year-old Marisha Cheong, a Queens resident and a student at Long Island University, who had disappeared in December.
lead_paragraph: The body of a woman that washed up on a beach in Breezy Point, Queens, had been bound by green rope at the hands and the feet, the police said on Monday.

headline: Leak in Fuel Line Was Cause of Stricken Cruise Ship’s Trouble
abstract: The fire that resulted destroyed the Carnival Triumph’s generators, leaving it stranded in the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: A United States Coast Guard official said Monday that the fire that disabled the Carnival Triumph cruise ship began when a fuel line connected to one of the vessel’s engines sprang a leak.

headline: ‘Drones for America!’
abstract: In this animated satire, a former K.G.B. agent welcomes a future in which Americans live under the watchful eyes of drones.
lead_paragraph: When I began thinking of this animated Op-Docs video, I had two things in mind. The first was the adoption of drones by the Seattle Police Department. (The program has since been scuttled.) The second was Yevgeny Zamyatin’s 1924 novel “We,” which was a forerunner to dystopian novels including George Orwell’s “1984,” Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” and Kurt Vonnegut’s “Player Piano.”

headline: House Approves Storm Aid for Religious Institutions
abstract: Opponents of the bill worry that federal aid to rebuild churches and synagogues damaged by Hurricane Sandy could violate the doctrine of separation of church and state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives has overwhelmingly approved legislation that would allow the use of federal money to rebuild churches and synagogues damaged by Hurricane Sandy, despite concern that such aid could violate the doctrine of separation of church and state.

abstract: Yemen’s transition has been held up as a model for resolving Syria’s civil war, but beyond the capital, the country is more rudderless than ever.

headline: How Not to Fix Climate Change
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil Sands', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Stopping the Keystone XL oil pipeline is actually counterproductive in more ways than one.
lead_paragraph: After much back and forth, James E. Hansen and I had agreed on a date to meet. Hansen, the director of NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies, is the scientist most closely associated with climate change activists like Bill McKibben, who has led the charge against the Keystone XL pipeline, and Michael Brune, the executive director of the Sierra Club. In Hansen’s view, the country needs to start moving away from fossil fuels now, before the damage becomes irreversible.

headline: Step-by-Step Instructions for Crime-Solving in the City
abstract: The New York Police Department has been moving, through a series of memos, to standardize detective work and codify crime-solving tactics that had mostly existed as an oral tradition.
lead_paragraph: Detective work is measured in hunches followed, stories picked apart, doors knocked on and shoes worn through. Equal parts art and science, such tradecraft has long been passed down informally, one generation of investigators to the next.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Trouble With Online College
abstract: Education via the Internet has been overrated and could produce more dropouts than degrees.
lead_paragraph: Stanford University ratcheted up interest in online education when a pair of celebrity professors attracted more than 150,000 students from around the world to a noncredit, open enrollment course on artificial intelligence. This development, though, says very little about what role online courses could have as part of standard college instruction. College administrators who dream of emulating this strategy for classes like freshman English would be irresponsible not to consider two serious issues.

headline: Greco-Roman Wrestling Program May Be a Factory Without a Future
abstract: Elite wrestlers train at Northern Michigan University with hopes of Olympic glory. But after a vote to drop the sport from the Games, the program might be in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: MARQUETTE, Mich. — When he heard the news last Tuesday, Barrett Stanghill retreated to his dormitory room on the third floor of Meyland Hall at Northern Michigan University and reconsidered his future. The executive board of the International Olympic Committee had voted to eliminate wrestling from the Summer Games, starting in 2020, and Stanghill found it almost impossible to process.

headline: Test Run: Mining Your Calendar to Cut Taxes
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Business Travel', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: A new Web service, MileLogr, which launched, on Monday is designed to help road warriors who rack up thousands of business miles a year in their personal vehicles save money on their taxes.
lead_paragraph: If you’re like me, you’ll wait until a few days before taxes are due in April before filling out your returns. I can get away with procrastinating, in part, because I don’t have to worry about some of the more tedious tax chores, like figuring out how many miles I drove last year in my personal vehicle for work purposes. That’s because my employer reimburses me for those expenses.

headline: Lamb Raiser
abstract: Barry Franklin and Sara Kaplan have some questions for us.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The title of today’s post comes from the clue for 30 Down, which reminds me of one of the possible names tossed around for the BBC television show that eventually became “Monty Python’s Flying Circus.” For a brief moment, the show that deeply influenced my life was called “The Toad Elevating Moment.” You can elevate as many toads as you like, I believe, but if you raise a lamb, you’re a EWE.

headline: Chinese Army Unit Is Seen as Tied to Hacking Against U.S.
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: An overwhelming percentage of the attacks on American companies and government agencies start in a building on the edge of Shanghai, say cybersecurity experts and American intelligence officials.

headline: Little Red Beacon for Immigrant Laborers Shines On
abstract: A shack in Bensonhurst has served not only as a physical space where immigrants find work, but also as a rare symbol of empowerment.
