headline: Patrick Was Leading Way Even Before Winning Pole
abstract: Danica Patrick, known for her GoDaddy.com Super Bowl commercials as well as for her racing, has become the show at the Daytona 500 after winning the pole.
lead_paragraph: On the first day that drivers arrived at Daytona International Speedway for Speedweeks, the Daytona 500 and the celebrated start of Nascar’s 2013 Sprint Cup season, the story making headlines was Danica Patrick’s romantic relationship with the driver Ricky Stenhouse, Jr.

headline: From the Bronx, Planning a Long-Shot Run for Mayor
abstract: Adolfo Carrión Jr. says that the time may be right for an independent candidate who can offer a moderate alternative to his Republican and Democratic rivals.
lead_paragraph: For Adolfo Carrión Jr., the magic number in the 2013 mayor’s race is not 40 (the percentage of primary votes needed to avoid a runoff), or $6.7 million (the maximum that candidates who receive public financing can spend).

headline: Gym Class Isn’t Just Fun and Games Anymore
abstract: It is no longer enough in some schools for students to run around during gym. Now they are often taught math or English or health at the same time.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — On a recent afternoon, the third graders in Sharon Patelsky’s class reviewed words like “acronym,” “clockwise” and “descending,” as well as math concepts like greater than, less than and place values.

headline: TV Anchor Accused of Choking His Wife
abstract: Rob Morrison, a news anchor for WCBS-TV, was charged with strangulation, threatening and disorderly conduct — charges he and his wife called “greatly exaggerated.”
lead_paragraph: Rob Morrison, a news anchor for WCBS-TV, was arrested Sunday on charges of choking his wife during a domestic dispute at their Connecticut home, the police said on Monday.

headline: The Owner Who Made the N.B.A. Cool Again
abstract: Jerry Buss, the former Lakers owner with 10 N.B.A. titles,  recognized that basketball was entertainment. He was a visionary in the art of marketing the game.
lead_paragraph: The enduring, clichéd myth of the Los Angeles Lakers — perpetuated mostly by envious fans in other cities — is that the franchise owes its aura to its surroundings. That Hollywood made the Lakers cool, and the sunshine made them desirable. That the city made the dynasty.

headline: Mindy McCready, a Singer Long Troubled, Dies at 37
abstract: Ms. McCready rose to stardom, only to find depression and battles with drugs and alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Her life was one of those aching odysseys sermonized about across the musical landscape in which she performed. The rocket rise to stardom. The volcanic men. The depression. The drugs and booze. The brushes with the law. The heartbreak. The suicide attempts.

headline: Nets’ Williams Acknowledges His Limits but Plans to Play
abstract: Point guard Deron Williams returned to practice after an ankle procedure and said he would be in the lineup against the Bucks. Coach P. J. Carlesimo wasn’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A week after he had plasma therapy for his balky ankles, Nets point guard Deron Williams returned to practice Monday feeling a shade closer to his former self.

headline: There Are Rings in Mets’ Future
abstract: The Mets’ chase for championship rings was preceded this season by another search for rings. Six Mets players proposed to their significant others.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Before the Mets opened spring training this month, half a dozen of their players stopped playing the field.

headline: Ford Turns to the ‘Crowd’ for New Fiesta Ads
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Automobiles', 'Crowdsourcing (Internet)', 'Online Advertising', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: Executives of Ford Motor Company plan to announce on Tuesday that they intend to recruit 100 socially-connected consumers to produce a year’s worth of advertising for the next Fiesta.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the Ford Motor Company brought out the Ford Fiesta subcompact with an innovative program that recruited young drivers – members of the target audience for the new car – to help introduce it through blogs and other social media. Now, that effort is being expanded into the realm of marketing as Ford plans a crowdsourcing initiative to create advertising for the 2014 Fiesta.

headline: Word of the Day | exhilarating
abstract: This word has appeared in 842 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: exhilarating •\ig-ˈzi-lə-ˌra-tiN\• adjective

headline: Flyers Roll Over Islanders
abstract: Claude Giroux, Matt Read and Jakub Voracek combined for 3 goals and 10 points, helping the Philadelphia Flyers break a slump with a 7-0 victory over the Islanders.
lead_paragraph: The line of Claude Giroux, Matt Read and Jakub Voracek combined for 3 goals and 10 points, helping the Philadelphia Flyers break a slump with a 7-0 victory over the Islanders. Evgeni Nabokov made several key saves to keep the deficit at 1-0, but things got out of control in the game-turning second period. Philadelphia scored three times on only six second-period shots.

headline: Kalyan Anand, the Sadhu From Madhya Pradesh
abstract: The ascetic who has been a regular at the Kumbh for 20 years, seeks purity.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of Indians, sometimes entire villages, brave the crowds to attend the Kumbh Mela? India Ink interviewed some of the estimated 100 million pilgrims who traveled to this year’s Kumbh Mela at Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, a 55-day pilgrimage during which Hindus take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins.

headline: U.N. Report Shows Fewer Killings of Afghan Civilians, Suggesting Shift in War
abstract: The annual United Nations report on civilian casualties found that the number killed in 2012 dropped last year, though the number of injured rose.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the first time in six years the number of civilians killed in Afghanistan declined, according to the annual United Nations report on civilian casualties.

headline: Women Killed as ‘Witches,’ in Papua New Guinea, in 2013
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Nuns', 'Occult Sciences', 'Torture', 'Witchcraft', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A traditional belief in sorcery endures in a society hit by uneven economic development, high unemployment and social dislocation.
lead_paragraph: “They’re going to cook the sanguma,” or witchcraft, “mama!”

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:40 P.M. (Starz) KILL BILL: VOL. 1 (2003) Uma Thurman, above, is the Bride in this film written and directed by Quentin Tarantino, and David Carradine is Bill, the man whose life she would like to bring to a premature end. Of course, that will have to wait until “Vol. 2.” First, she must battle two of his assassins (Lucy Liu and Vivica A. Fox) and a horde of masked samurai. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film, “a densely referential pastiche of B-movie attitudes and situations, is above all an exercise in style.” He added, “But while being so relentlessly exposed to a filmmaker’s idiosyncratic turn-ons can be tedious and off-putting, the undeniable passion that drives ‘Kill Bill’ is fascinating, even, strange to say it, endearing.”

headline: News Quiz | February 19, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Maoists Block Deal to Break Nepal’s Long Political Deadlock
abstract: A tentative deal to have the chief justice lead the government and hold new elections has fallen apart.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nepal’s major political parties failed on Tuesday to complete an expected agreement to settle a years-long political standoff, after Maoists insisted that the accord include amnesty for past crimes.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 19
abstract: The Chinese army may be involved in hacking U.S. targets; Obama may reconsider arms for Syrian rebels; Iberia Airline workers strike; two shows for Tiepolo; and a milestone for Serena Williams.
lead_paragraph: NEWS An overwhelming percentage of online attacks toward U.S. companies, organizations and government agencies originate from one area of a Shanghai neighborhood, home to a Chinese army unit, according to a report by the computer security firm Mandiant. David E. Sanger, David Barboza and Nicole Perlroth report.

headline: Incumbent Wins Easy Victory in Armenia
abstract: Armenians returned President Serzh Sargsyan to office for a second five-year term, with preliminary results showing him with about 59 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: President Serzh Sargsyan of Armenia easily won re-election to a second five-year term, according to preliminary returns released on Tuesday by the Central Election Commission.

headline: In Affidavit at Bail Hearing, Track Star Denies He Intended to Kill Girlfriend
abstract: Oscar Pistorius, a double amputee track star, maintains that the killing of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, was an accident.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — Early on Feb. 14, Oscar Pistorius says, he heard a strange noise coming from inside his bathroom, climbed out of bed, grabbed his 9-millimeter pistol, hobbled on his stumps to the door and fired four shots.

headline: Orix of Japan in $2.6 Billion Deal for Rabobank’s Asset Management Unit
abstract: The Orix Corporation said the acquisition of a 90 percent stake in the Robeco Group, which is based in the Netherlands and has 189 billion euros in assets under management, represented its “most significant strategic acquisition to date.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Orix Corporation, a Japanese financial services company, said on Tuesday that it would pay 1.94 billion euros ($2.6 billion) to acquire the asset management business of the Dutch lender Rabobank.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 19, 2013
abstract: Can you choose the best synonym for “elegiac,” as it is used in the article?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the television review “Another Cog in the Machinery of Divahood.”

headline: Can Graffiti Ever Be Considered Art?
abstract: How do you determine what, to you, is art?
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know what art is, but….” People have been finishing this sentence with “I know what I like” or “I know it when I see it” for a long, long time.

headline: Motherhood, Reborn and Everlasting
abstract: Rebecca Martinez photographs baby beauty contests, baby showers, baby owners and baby artisans. Baby owners and artisans? Yes — these babies are “reborn,” lifelike handmade dolls that are treated as real people.
lead_paragraph: Most human beings swoon at the first sight of a baby. No matter how homely — or loud — they elicit a primal response from pretty much everyone.

headline: In Russia, Clues About the Type of Damage a Meteor Can Wreak
abstract: Why do the people who witnessed the explosion in Chelyabinsk, Russia consider themselves lucky?
lead_paragraph: In “In Russia, Ruins and Property Spared by Meteor, Side by Side,” Andrew E. Kramer reports on the aftermath of the explosion that occurred in Siberia on Friday.

headline: Nestlé Removes  2 Products in Horse Meat Scandal
keywords: ['Horses', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Meat', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Food', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Nestlé, one of the world’s best-known food companies, said it was removing pasta meals from store shelves in Italy and Spain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — First centered on Britain and Ireland, the scandal over beef products adulterated with horse meat escalated across Continental Europe on Tuesday after Nestlé, one of the world’s best-known food companies, said it was removing pasta meals from store shelves in Italy and Spain.

headline: BMW Recalls More Than 500,000 Cars for Cable Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker says the problem is caused by the wear and tear on the cable to the battery, which is located in the trunk. That could cause the engine to suddenly shut down.
lead_paragraph: An investigation by the Canadian automotive safety agency, Transport Canada, led BMW to recall almost 505,000 vehicles in the United States for a possible loss of electrical power that could cause the engine to stall.

headline: Who Pays the Corporate Income Tax
abstract: With the prospect of a Congressional debate on corporate taxes, there is no agreement even among economists about the extent to which customers, workers or shareholders bear the ultimate cost when companies are taxed, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Q and A: Nina Hoss, at Home at the Berlinale
abstract: The German actress Nina Hoss has been a fixture at the Berlinale film festival. She has won a best actress award, served on the jury, and this year she returned with a role in “Gold,” a neo-western directed by Thomas Arslan about German fortune seekers in the Klondike hinterlands.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German actress Nina Hoss has been a fixture at the Berlinale in recent years. She won the best actress prize in 2007 for Christian Petzold’s “Yella,” served on the jury in 2011 and starred in one of the most acclaimed titles in last year’s competition, “Barbara,” also directed by Mr. Petzold (with whom she has made five movies in the past dozen years).

headline: Novartis Scraps Non-Compete Payment to Departing Chairman
abstract: The Swiss drug company faced criticism from shareholders and lawmakers for agreeing to pay Daniel Vasella $78 million over six years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Novartis, one of Switzerland’s biggest drug makers, said Tuesday it scrapped a planned $78 million payment to its departing chairman because of pressure from shareholders and lawmakers.

headline: Q&A: Controlling Access to a Kindle Fire HD
abstract: Amazon’s Kindle Fire tablets include parental controls to limit a child’s access to videos and other content on the device.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Simone Rocha: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: This Week in Small Business: Dish Mobs
abstract: A $3 billion surplus? Slower growth in health costs? The top 10 most-taxed cities in America. And is your company planning to make a Harlem Shake video?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Britain Names Head of New Bank Regulator
abstract: Andrew Bailey, who had been interim chief executive of the Prudential Regulatory Authority, was appointed as the agency’s full-time head on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Andrew Bailey was appointed on Tuesday as head of a new British regulator in charge of overseeing the country’s largest banks.

headline: European Parliament Approves Plan to Bolster Carbon Trading
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A committee approved legislation to strengthen the sagging prices of permits by cutting supply. Had the vote gone the other way, an analyst said, the Emissions Trading System would have been “more or less dead.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Lawmakers in Brussels moved on Tuesday to shore up the sagging market for carbon emissions permits, a central component of the European Union’s efforts to reduce air pollution.

headline: Office Supply Retailers Weigh a Merger
abstract: Office Depot and OfficeMax are hoping a merger can help protect profitability. | Guilty pleas recently secured from units of big banks represent a new government approach. | Steven L. Rattner is re-emerging as a power player. | Morgan Stanley is under pressure from shareholders to make its business units work better together.
lead_paragraph: Two of the big retailers of office supplies, Office Depot and OfficeMax, are hoping that a merger can help protect profitability in the age of the Internet and bulk discounters. The companies are in talks “to combine in an all-stock deal that may be announced as soon as this week, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday,” DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. The talks, while at an advanced stage, may still fall apart, this person cautioned.

headline: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: In Transit
abstract: People seem to be on the move all the time, in both cities.
lead_paragraph: Most great cities in the world are marked by their spirit of dynamism. New York and Mumbai, often counted among the world’s fastest cities, are no different. Both these cities are in a constant state of flux, always moving, always in transit.

headline: Opinion Report: Mandatory Minimums
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: A Recipe for Pone
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Cassava pone turns into a production, from finding the right ingredient to checking it at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Celebrating Your Big Sober Gay Birthday
abstract: Newly in recovery, a gay man wonders: cancel the party or carry on?
lead_paragraph: Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: More Season 3 Conversation With ‘Downton Abbey’ Creator Julian Fellowes
abstract: Julian Fellowes talks about his approach to writing Season 3 of “Downton Abbey,” characters who may (or may not) be returning for Season 4, and other “Downton”-related projects he may (or may not) be working on.
lead_paragraph: In the first installment of an interview with the “Downton Abbey” creator and writer Julian Fellowes, he discussed how some key departures from the series occurred in Season 3, and how he is starting to think about his own exit from the show.

headline: A Strategy to Prevent the Next Fukushima
keywords: ['Explosions', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Hydrogen', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Silicon']
abstract: Researchers weigh the possibility of using a ceramic material to replace potentially explosive zirconium in reactor components.
lead_paragraph: Among the most striking elements of the catastrophe at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors in Japan were the hydrogen explosions that destroyed the upper parts of some of the reactor buildings. The hydrogen was released by a metal called zirconium in the overheated core.

headline: Deconstructing Herod
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Museums', 'Palestinians', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Talmud']
abstract: How did Herod go from villain to hero in the Israeli imagination?
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — King Herod killed many people in his time, among them wives, sons and, according to the New Testament, all the male newborns of Bethlehem. He had more victims beyond the grave: In 2010, the archaeologist Ehud Netzer died from a fall at Herodium, Herod’s magnificent desert palace, after spending his life studying the king and searching for his tomb.

headline: Marco Rubio: The Electable Conservative?
abstract: The reason to watch Mr. Rubio carefully for 2016 is that, among the candidates who will be deemed reliably conservative by Republican voters and insiders, he may stand the best chance of maintaining a reasonably good image with general election voters.
lead_paragraph: Some commentators have expressed surprise upon learning about the very conservative voting record of Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who delivered the Republican response to the State of the Union address last week.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Erdem
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week diary of Rory van Millingen.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Other Quality of Mercy
abstract: Is the Turkish prime minister’s overture to the military just a tactical manoeuver?
lead_paragraph: Istanbul — The quality of mercy, famously, is not strained. Yet it can be confused. At least that’s my conclusion after a recent instance of Turkish officialdom trying to show compassion.

headline: A Conversation With: Journalist and Author Rahul Pandita
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: In his memoir, Mr. Pandita chronicles the plight of Kashmiri Pandits who fled the valley in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Rahul Pandita, an associate editor with the Open magazine in Delhi, is a journalist and author who belongs to the Kashmiri Pandit community, Hindus who had to flee the Kashmir Valley in the early 1990s during a separatist insurgency by the Muslim majority.

headline: Swift Diving in Bali
abstract: The expedition ends in Bali, with a dangerous dive to both healthy and troubled reefs.
lead_paragraph: C. Drew Harvell is associate director for environment at the Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future at Cornell University. She is studying the health of coral reefs and marine ecosystems in Indonesia, and is helping to plan a new project, Capturing Coral Reef Ecosystem Services. This is her final post.

headline: Tom Ford in High-Definition
abstract: Tom Ford said that his fall collection was about the mash-up of cultural styles — Inuit with Japanese and so on — and a little of the usual high-low mix.
lead_paragraph: Before Tom Ford jumped on a plane to Los Angeles early on Tuesday morning, I asked him to explain his fall collection. People hurried from Lancaster House in a complete state of puzzlement, if not panic that they would miss J.W. Anderson’s show.

headline: Accusations of Chinese Hacking in Coke’s Failed Big Deal
abstract: A new report on Chinese hackers depicts a wide-ranging cyberwar campaign against many American targets. One of them apparently was the Coca-Cola Company, which failed in a bid to buy a Chinese beverage maker.
lead_paragraph: A new report on Chinese hackers depicts a wide-ranging cyberwar campaign against an array of American targets, from computer security providers to power plant suppliers.

headline: Tuesday Reading: When to Retire Your Running Shoes
abstract: When to retire your running shoes, fuel charges push up international airfares, mining your calendar to cut taxes and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Russia’s Meteor Shower
abstract: Russia is left reeling after a spectacular meteor shower.
lead_paragraph: Russia is left reeling after a spectacular meteor shower.

headline: Brazen Jewel Robbery at Brussels Airport Nets $50 Million in Diamonds
abstract: Armed men disguised as police officers drove onto an airport tarmac and stole from a shipment of diamonds being loaded onto a plane, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — They arrived at Brussels Airport armed with automatic weapons and dressed in police uniforms aboard two vehicles equipped with blue police lights. But their most important weapon was information: the eight hooded gangsters who on Monday evening seized diamonds worth tens of millions of dollars from a passenger plane preparing to depart for Switzerland knew exactly when to strike — just 18 minutes before takeoff.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Nascar Tries to Expand Its Audience and Esquire Network Defines the Modern Man
abstract: Nascar tries to captivate a younger, urban, multicultural audience; the Esquire Network tries to define and cater to that inscrutable creature, the modern man; and First Response pregnancy tests advertise for a Spanish-speaking audience for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Nascar has begun a new advertising push to attract young, urban and multicultural fans to augment their current audience of predominantly older, rural, white men, Stuart Elliott writes. Nascar hired Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, a sophisticated Madison Avenue giant, to handle a campaign that would include commercials in Spanish and emphasize online offerings like Nascar.com and the 2013 edition of Fantasy Nascar. The initiative will be formally introduced on Sunday during coverage of the Daytona 500 on Fox and will feature television commercials with drivers standing in dramatic poses making emotional statements for the camera.

headline: The Gun Report: February 19, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Someone asked in a comment posted Monday why the gun deaths by Slate’s gun-death tracker since Newtown – 1,903 and counting – seemed to imply so many more deaths than our daily Gun Report. The answer is simple: We are not trying to be comprehensive. We are simply doing a Google search a few times a day and selecting a handful of representative examples of that day’s gun violence. Sadly, we have many more examples to choose from than what we publish.

headline: Daily Report: Chinese Army Unit Is Tied to Hacking Against U.S.
abstract: An overwhelming percentage of the attacks on American companies and government agencies start in a building on the edge of Shanghai, headquarters of a Chinese army cyber warrior unit, say American intelligence officials and cybersecurity experts.
lead_paragraph: A growing body of digital forensic evidence — confirmed by American intelligence officials who say they have tapped into the activity of the army unit for years — leaves little doubt that an overwhelming percentage of the attacks on American corporations, organizations and government agencies originate in and around the headquarters of the People’s Liberation Army in Shanghai.

headline: Europe Moves to Cap Bank Bonuses, Britain Hesitates
abstract: Highly paid bankers have become the target of popular hate since the financial crisis. But some commentators argue that the latest European moves to curb excessive bonuses in the sector could backfire.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is hard to imagine any European politician losing votes these days by promising to curb bankers’ pay, which may explain why members of the European Parliament are enthusiastically pushing for the toughest restrictions on bank bonuses since the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: For S.E.C., Obstacles Aplenty in Pursuit of ‘Suspicious’ Heinz Trading
abstract: In seeking to prove insider trading was behind a well-timed purchase of options in H.J. Heinz, the S.E.C. will need to figure out who was actually involved in the trading, then link that person or group to a source of information about the deal.
lead_paragraph: Just a day after the buyout of H.J. Heinz was announced, the Securities and Exchange Commission took aim at an account, claiming it was used to trade on inside information about the deal to reap potential profits of over $1.7 million.

headline: Talk of a Big Merger Gives Office Suppliers’ Stocks a Lift
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Office Supplies and Equipment']
abstract: Shares of Office Depot and OfficeMax were up significantly in early trading on Tuesday, amid reports that the two were in talks to combine in a stock-for-stock deal.
lead_paragraph: 9:51 a.m. | Updated

headline: With Cutbacks Days Away, Obama Tries to Pressure G.O.P.
abstract: President Obama turned the powers of the presidency toward shaming Republicans into a deal to avoid broad cuts, but they were declining to engage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days away from another fiscal crisis and with Congress on vacation, President Obama began marshaling the powers of the presidency on Tuesday to try to shame Republicans into a compromise that could avoid further self-inflicted job losses and damage to the fragile recovery. But so far, Republicans were declining to engage.

headline: Data, Stimulus, and Human Nature
abstract: Don’t blame the numbers.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks writes about the limitations of Big Data, and makes some good points. But he goes astray, I think, when he touches on a subject near and dear to my own data-driven heart:

headline: In Performance: Taylor Mac of ‘Good Person of Szechwan’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from the Foundry Theater’s production of Brecht’s drama about living a virtuous life in a corrupt society.
lead_paragraph: Bertolt Brecht’s “Good Person of Szechwan” asks what it means to live a virtuous life in a corrupt society. In the Foundry Theater’s new production, the actor Taylor Mac takes on dual roles: Shen Te, a hospitable prostitute turned shopkeeper and, in disguise, Shui Ta, her more pragmatically minded male cousin. In this scene near the end Shen Te reveals that she has taken on both identities and asks: “Why is suffering reserved for the good and why is so much wickedness rewarded?” The show runs through Feb. 24 at the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa.

headline: He’s Talking to You: Scorsese to Give Jefferson Lecture for National Endowment for the Humanities
abstract: Martin Scorsese, the celebrated director of “Taxi Driver,” “Goodfellas” and “The Departed,” is the first filmmaker to give the lecture, following authors and dramatists like John Updike, Arthur Miller, Toni Morrison and Henry Louis Gates Jr.
lead_paragraph: Speak to Martin Scorsese for even a few minutes on one of his favorite subjects — movies; rock music; the best way for Robert De Niro to break down an door in “Raging Bull” — and you are likely to get an enthusiastic barrage of verbiage as rich and dense as any academic lecture. (With, perhaps, a few colorful words that your college film professor would never say.)

headline: Rihanna Steals the Attention at London Fashion Week
abstract: For the thousands of young fans who packed New Oxford Street in central London on Saturday night during London Fashion Week, there was only one fashion designer who mattered this week: Rihanna.
lead_paragraph: 3:31 p.m. | Updated The big news this London Fashion Week was supposed to be the return of Tom Ford to the runway, the London debut of L’Wren Scott (complete with a dinner Sunday night at the Café Royale co-hosted by her boyfriend, Mick Jagger), the buzz surrounding such rising stars as Christopher Kane and JW Anderson and the emergence of the young British model Cara Delevingne as “the next Kate Moss.”

headline: Oscar Contenders Are a Hit at the Box Office
abstract: The best-picture nominees have taken in more than $900 million at the box office, up 55 percent from the contenders’ take last year.
lead_paragraph: No matter who wins the most awards on Sunday, there are already a huge numbers of winners this year: producers, distributors and theater owners. The nine best picture contenders have, en masse, grossed $918 million at the box office, according to Gitesh Pandya of BoxOfficeGuru.com.(Vote for, share and keep track of your Oscar favorites with The Times’s interactive awards ballot. Start Your Oscar Ballot)

headline: A Meteorite Rush
abstract: In a small Siberian village, residents are finding that rock fragments that rained down after Friday’s meteor over Russia have monetary worth.
lead_paragraph: In a small Siberian village, residents are finding that rock fragments that rained down after Friday’s meteor over Russia have monetary worth.

headline: Irish Government Apologizes in Laundry Scandal
abstract: An apology was given to survivors of the so-called Magdalene laundries, where 10,000 young women and girls worked in conditions akin to slavery between 1922 and 1996.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Prime Minister Enda Kenny offered an unreserved state apology on Tuesday over Ireland’s failure to protect thousands of young women and girls consigned to virtual slavery in the so-called “Magdalene laundries” between 1922 and 1996.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: USA Today: Following a media and consumer backlash to its recent announcement that it would decrease the alcohol content of its bourbon by 3 percent, Maker’s Mark reversed itself, saying it would leave well enough alone. — Robert Simonson

headline: Meadham Kirchhoff: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Donald Richie, 88, American Expert on Japan, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Richie is best known for introducing the English-speaking world to the golden age of Japanese cinema, including the director Akira Kurosawa.
lead_paragraph: Donald Richie, a prominent American critic and writer on Japan who helped introduce much of the English-speaking world to the golden age of Japanese cinema in 1959 and recounted his expatriate life there spanning seven decades, died on Tuesday in Tokyo. He was 88.

headline: Pakistani Shiites End Protest After Authorities Vow to Take On Extremists
abstract: A deadly sectarian bombing in Quetta had prompted outrage at the government for not doing more to protect a vulnerable minority population.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Shiites ended three days of protest across Pakistan on Tuesday after the government promised to hunt down sectarian extremists responsible for a devastating bombing that killed 89 people in the western city of Quetta on Saturday.

headline: Australia’s Best Reds Are Slow to Arrive
abstract: Recent tastings of exceptional, restrained red wines are belying the stereotype of the heavy-bodied, high-octane Australian wine.
lead_paragraph: Stereotypes are always troubling, and wine stereotypes are no different. I bristle when I hear some European winemaker assert that Americans make only big, powerful, alcoholic wines. Of course, many Americans say the same thing about Australian wines: the reds are all heavy-bodied and high-octane, overwhelming combinations of thick fruit flavors, oak and alcohol. Or, in their inexpensive, mass-market manifestations, they taste like artificial confections.

headline: The Small Picture: Meet Pumbaa, One Lucky Pig
abstract: Pumbaa lives at Whynot Farm on Snow Creek, where the owner calls him “a sweet hog whom we cannot bring ourselves to slaughter.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, we asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the essence of their businesses in a single shot. The results have started to pour in, and the photographs are great — many with moving explanations of why the owners do what they do.

headline: A True Hollywood Story
abstract: Jerry Buss, who made the Lakers what they are, was larger than life — even by show business standards.
lead_paragraph: As the tributes flowed in from everywhere, the sports world stopped to honor a giant now gone. The death of the Lakers’ owner Jerry Buss Monday at age 80 brought out all the usual remembrances, which included the proper credit for creating the Lakers phenomenon out of almost nothing, for spawning much of what we recognize as the modern N.B.A. out of so much magic dust. The tales of the man behind all that, though, were so colorful and so unlikely, it is worth taking a second to realize that if Jerry Buss had not been real, Hollywood would have had to make him up.

headline: NBC News Hires David Axelrod as Political Analyst
abstract: The chief political strategist for both Obama presidential campaigns will appear on NBC and MSNBC
lead_paragraph: NBC News announced Tuesday that it had hired David Axelrod, the chief political strategist for both of Barack Obama’s presidential elections, as a full-time political analyst for the news organization.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Erdem
abstract: The beauty muse was Wednesday of the Addams Family; the translated look: “moonlit” skin and glassy, ironed-straight manes.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long for the designer Erdem Moralioglu and the makeup artist Hannah Murray to decide who their beauty muse was this season. “Wednesday Addams was the name that instantly came up,” Murray says. “It’s the first time Erdem hasn’t done color, so we knew we had to do something that was spooky but still beautiful.” To create the illusion of “moonlit” skin, Murray applied Nars new Radiant Creamy Concealer highlighted with Copacabana Multiple for a luminous finish. “The look is meant to be a little eerie, so I’ve made all the girls uniform — each one has the same strong, dark brow,” she says. Using a technique that she likened to wiggling a mascara wand, Murray brushed Nars’s brow gel (available in August) through to make individual hairs stand out. Teamed with glassy, ironed-straight manes by the stylist Luke Hersheson, the effect was utterly bewitching.

headline: Can There Be a Catholic Moment?
abstract: Imagining scenarios in which Catholicism enjoyed more influence over American life than it does today.
lead_paragraph: My weekend column made the case that Catholicism’s influence on American political culture went into steep decline across the eight years of Benedict XVI’s pontificate, as the Republicans turned from the solidarity-inflected language of compassionate conservatism to the rhetoric of “makers versus takers” and the Democrats swung leftward on abortion and picked religious-liberty fights with Catholic institutions. The American Conservative’s Rod Dreher agrees with me, but basically argues that it was inevitably going to be thus, because the patterns of American modernity make any hope a “Catholic moment” in our politics or culture essentially chimerical:

headline: Does the ‘House of Cards’ All-You-Can-Eat Buffet Spoil Social Viewing?
abstract: The great thing about Netflix’s “House of Cards”? You can watch it all at once. That may be the bad thing, too. How do you gather around a water cooler and talk about a moving target?
lead_paragraph: For many viewers, one of the pleasures of watching the favorite-of-the-moment TV series is gathering around the digital water cooler to hash out the plot points, quibble with the details (“How could the truck not hear Matthew coming? Did they have mufflers in 1920?”) or share the satisfaction when a character gets his comeuppance.

headline: Army Rocket in Syria Kills at Least 19, Rebels Say
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Anti-Assad activists also reported that at least two mortar rounds had exploded near one of the presidential palaces in Damascus.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian antigovernment activists said on Tuesday that an army rocket had leveled several buildings in a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo, killing at least 19 people and possibly leaving dozens more buried under rubble. The attack appeared to have caused one of the worst civilian tolls in the embattled city since its university was struck in a multiple bombing a month ago.

headline: Israel Releases Part of Report on Prisoner X’s Death
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Details from a government investigation into the 2010 suicide of an Australian-Israeli man cited gaps in prison procedures that created “a suicidal window of opportunity.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The man known as Prisoner X was found dead at 8:19 p.m. on Dec. 15, 2010, hanging by his neck in the shower of his cell. The noose was fashioned from a wet bedsheet, rolled and tied to the window bars. There was a hint of a sedative in his stomach and a wound on his left hand, but neither contributed to his demise, which was caused by asphyxiation.

headline: ‘My Mother Gives Me Parenting Advice From Nazis’
abstract: That is not a euphemism for overly strict, by-the-book experts. No, my mother gives me parenting advice from an actual member of the National Socialist Party — and we’re Jews.

No, my mother gives me parenting advice from an actual member of the National Socialist Party — and we’re Jews.

lead_paragraph: Not until I’d tried sweet potatoes with butterscotch peas and curls of tender sepia; twirled dan-dan noodles in a hot-and-sour vinaigrette; turned velvety spinach and bluefoot shrimp around and around in Mozambican peanut sauce; slashed the yolk of a poached egg so it would spill out over crunchy rice and sour kimchi; and felt my mouth water at the first bite of tart passionfruit curd — not until then did it occur to me that I had been eating a tasting menu.

But it starts with getting the right people on the team, and that’s the theme I will address in my next few posts.

headline: The Sequester Is Not an Abstraction
abstract: As the president made clear today, indiscriminate spending cuts hurt people.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s plea this morning to avert the $85 billion sequester before March 1 was instantly ridiculed by Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, as a “campaign event.” That’s presumably because the president spoke in front of a group of emergency responders whose livelihoods are threatened by the indiscriminate spending cuts, just as he often used middle-class Americans as backdrops on the campaign trail.

headline: PEN World Voices Festival to Focus on Art and Politics
abstract: The festival will bring more than 100 writers from around the world to New York City to discuss art and politics from April 29 through May 5.
lead_paragraph: With Salman Rushdie returning as chairman, the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature will bring more than 100 writers from around the world to New York City to discuss both their art and politics this spring, from April 29 through May 5. One major theme of this year’s edition of the festival, the ninth, will be the notion of bravery in those realms, with panel discussions and other events honoring writers who have shown courage in their lives and work.

headline: For Office Supply Stores, an Obvious Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Office Supplies and Equipment', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Consolidation in the sector is long overdue, as the encroaching power of the likes of Amazon and Target has been evident for years, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Office Depot and OfficeMax are lucky to have each other. Uniting the two purveyors of pens, paper clips and printer toner is about as obvious as it gets in mergers and acquisitions. The potential synergies could be worth more than the market value of the two companies combined. As the Internet ravishes retailing, at least this corner can cling to life by merger.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Simone Rocha
abstract: Today at Simone Rocha’s show, the artist Shinobu presented her take on this season’s bare-faced makeup.
lead_paragraph: The minimalist mantra “less is more” has become a prevailing beauty theme of the fall 2013 London collections. Today at Simone Rocha’s show, the artist Shinobu presented her take on this season’s bare-faced makeup. “I originally wanted to bring the pink from the clothes to the skin,” she says, referencing the offbeat Pepto-Bismol palette of Rocha’s collection. “However it became too pretty, so I switched to monochrome brown tones for a more sophisticated feel.” M.A.C.’s concrete eye shadow was blended over eyelids, right up to the brows, which were defined with M.A.C.’s new Velux brow pencil. “I’ve drawn a straight line on top, then brushed the color down to the bottom before fading it out to the end,” Shinobu explains. To finish, lip conditioner was patted over mouths and cheeks for a subtle, dewy shine. Sometimes the simplest look makes the most powerful statement.

headline: When Mutant Mosquitoes Attack
abstract: Genetically modified parasites could help eradicate deadly diseases. But then what?
lead_paragraph: It’s no wonder that Goethe wrote “The Sorcerer’s Apprentice” near the dawn of the industrial age. The poem, which most of us now learn from Mickey Mouse, tells the story of a young man who, left to his own devices, mimics his boss’s spell for making brooms fetch water pails. Once the task is done, he doesn’t know how to stop the thing, so he chops the broom in half, which only enables it to work double duty. The sorcerer eventually returns, fixing the mess his subordinate has made (his situation never got quite as out of hand as Mickey’s). Lesson learned: Solutions to problems at hand can create new, sometimes unforeseeable, challenges in the future.

headline: Korean War Veteran Is Buried Six Decades After He Disappeared
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Korean War', 'Missing in Action', 'Missing Persons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Cpl. James R. Hare was reported missing on Feb. 13, 1951. His remains were identified last month using military forensic science.
lead_paragraph: The passengers aboard Delta Air Lines Flight 2125 didn’t get up when the plane taxied into its gate at Baltimore Washington International Airport earlier this month. They didn’t retrieve their bags from the overhead bins. Instead, they looked out the right side of the aircraft, where an honor guard and black hearse were waiting to escort the remains of Cpl. James R. Hare home, the final portion of a journey that spanned nearly 7,000 miles and six decades.

headline: Palestinians in Prisons Refuse Meals in a Protest
abstract: The one-day protest was held as the Palestinians sought to pressure Israel before President Obama’s visit to the region next month.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Hundreds of Palestinian security prisoners in Israeli jails refused meals on Tuesday in solidarity with four hunger-striking detainees, and supporters held protests in the West Bank, as the Palestinians sought to pressure Israel before President Obama’s visit to the region next month.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA —The college degree is becoming the new high school diploma: the new minimum requirement, albeit an expensive one, for getting even the lowest-level job.

headline: Will You Watch ‘Raising Adam Lanza’ on ‘Frontline’?

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday at 10 p.m. Eastern time, PBS’s “Frontline” will air its episode “Raising Adam Lanza,” which follows two Hartford Courant reporters as they interview people close to the Lanza family and attempt to uncover something about the gunman who fatally shot 26 people, including 20 children, at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., last December. (Check PBS’s local schedule for times.)

headline: European Solar Importers Defend Chinese in Anti-Dumping Case

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Importers of inexpensive solar panels from China said on Tuesday that imposing tariffs would lead to hundreds of thousands of job losses in the European Union, the biggest export market for the Chinese equipment.

headline: Mantel’s ‘Plastic’ Princess Remarks Ruffle Feathers in England
abstract: Journalists have taken sides over the “Wolf Hall” novelist’s remarks about Kate Middleton, which were a small part of an essay about the monarchy recently published in The London Review of Books.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Mantel has won two Man Booker Prizes and huge sales for her novels “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies,” with their acidic portrait of the doomed schemer Anne Boleyn. But her recent comments about another dark-haired royal wife, the Duchess of Cambridge, are getting some less than flattering reviews.

headline: A Tropical Madeleine
abstract: Puffy, sweet buns summon teenage days shopping in Old San Juan, and the treats savored afterward.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 1970s, I was a teenager growing up in Puerto Rico and my mother was young, strong-willed and fashion-conscious. She was always ready to dress me in the latest fads, as best as we could afford, like midi skirts with suede boots and a gown straight from a bridal magazine for my quinceañera.

headline: The Small Picture
abstract: Photographs from small business owners that explain why they do what they do.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from small business owners that explain why they do what they do.

headline: Before Adele, There Was Lulu
abstract: The British singer made her first New York appearance in a 50-year career on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Adele (and Duffy, Amy Winehouse, Emeli Sandé and Paloma Faith) probably know that she is part of the second wave of British women with a deep affinity for American pop and soul music. The first was in the ’60s, when the great triumvirate was Petula Clark, Dusty Springfield and Lulu, who made her first New York appearance in a 50-year career Saturday night at B.B. King’s.

headline: Meteor Videos Set Online Viewing Record
abstract: An online measurement firm reported Tuesday that videos of last week’s Russian meteor have collectively topped 138 million views on the video-sharing sites it tracks, like YouTube and DailyMotion. The firm said the meteor was “the fastest video event ever to reach 100 million views.”
lead_paragraph: How did you watch the videos of the meteor that lit up the sky over Siberia last week? If you’re like many people, you went straight to YouTube, where dozens of amateur videos were uploaded soon after the rare occurrence.

headline: Model Diary | Katlin Aas
abstract: For the last day of shows in London, the 20-year-old model tells T about life without a home-base.
lead_paragraph: Katlin Aas, the Estonia-born model whose four-year career includes a Marc Jacobs campaign and various runways ranging from Jean Paul Gaultier to Givenchy, has already been in more than 20 shows this season (including yesterday’s Christopher Kane and Giles shows). And fashion month is only halfway over. For the last day of shows in London, the 20-year-old model tells T about life without a home base. “I don’t really have a home at the moment,” she says, “but I spend a lot of time in New York.”

headline: Palestinian Blogger Chips Away at Israel’s Image, One Ill-Advised Instagram at a Time
abstract: An Israeli soldier’s Instagram snapshot of a boy’s head in the cross-hairs of a sniper rifle, discovered last week by a Palestinian-American activist, is another self-inflicted blow to Israel’s effort to use the Web to burnish its image.
lead_paragraph: A young Israeli soldier was reprimanded by his superiors this week after his urge to share his military life with friends and strangers online led him to post a photograph on Instagram offering a view of the back of a Palestinian boy’s head in the cross hairs of a sniper rifle.

headline: Warner Music Makes a Deal With Small Labels
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Music', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Warner, which acquired most of the EMI assets that Universal was ordered to dispose of last year, has struck an agreement with two independent trade groups to sell or license “a significant portion” of that music to small companies.
lead_paragraph: When the Universal Music Group agreed to pay $1.9 billion for EMI’s recorded music business in late 2011, it faced major opposition from independent groups, who feared that Universal — already the biggest music conglomerate — would gain too much market power. Last year, European regulators ordered Universal to sell about a third of EMI’s recorded assets as a condition for approving the transaction.

headline: Why Are We Maybe About to Start Tweeting About Male Nail Polish?
abstract: Prepare yourself: Adam Sternbergh is taking control of @NYTmag.
lead_paragraph: If you follow the magazine on Twitter, you generally know what you’re in for. Descriptions of our latest articles, retweets of the glowing praise of our latest articles, calls for you to send us your first-day-of-school photos or words that should be banned, that sort of thing. This week, all expectations are about to be blown up. (Or maybe they won’t! Who knows? That’s the thing about doing away with expectations!) We’re turning over the Twitter controls to our culture editor, Adam Sternbergh. In part this momentous power shift relates to the fact that the Oscars are coming up, so people probably care even more about Adam’s great movie wisdom this week than they normally do. In (larger) part it’s because Adam needs a bigger platform to which to spread his insight about male nail polish.

headline: Former BAM President to Receive Handel Medallion
abstract: Harvey Lichtenstein, who led the Brooklyn Academy of Music for more than 30 years, is to receive New York City’s highest award for achievement in the arts at a ceremony on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Lichtenstein, the larger-than-life former president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music who transformed Fort Greene into a cultural hub and redefined the role of a performing arts center, is to receive the city’s highest award for achievement in the arts on Wednesday from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Big, Dense Reds to Pair With Earthy Beans
abstract: The earthy beans, smoky bacon and rich red-wine reduction are ideal flavors to pair with dry, robust red wines.
lead_paragraph: The earthy beans, smoky bacon and rich red-wine reduction are ideal flavors to pair with dry, robust red wines. Two things to avoid: oakiness and sweet, jammy flavors.

headline: New York Producers Mull a Broadway Transfer for ‘Glass Menagerie’
abstract: The window to move the American Repertory Theater production of the Tennessee Williams play is tight before this season’s Tony Awards cutoff date.
lead_paragraph: The American Repertory Theater is in talks with New York producers about transferring its current revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Glass Menagerie” to Broadway in the near future, according to a theater executive familiar with the discussions.

headline: State Control Draws Closer for Detroit After Fiscal Review
abstract: If Gov. Rick Snyder concurs with the findings of a Michigan panel, officials will appoint an emergency manager with relatively broad powers to reshape Detroit’s budget.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A review team appointed by the State of Michigan has concluded that Detroit is mired in serious financial problems, a step that draws the city ever closer to emergency oversight by a state-assigned financial manager.

headline: Tofu Mushroom ‘Quiche’
abstract: A vegan dish with a deep, rich flavor
lead_paragraph: This is a vegan quiche filled with a savory mix of blended tofu and mushrooms. It has a deep, rich umami flavor. No eggs are necessary to bind it; the tofu stiffens up when it bakes. You can use the crust of your choice. The yeasted crust is not vegan, as it contains an egg.

headline: One on One: Susan P. Crawford, Author of ‘Captive Audience’
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: For Americans, getting on the Internet or using a cellphone keeps getting more expensive. But for service providers like AT&T and Verizon Wireless, new technologies have made wireless data cheaper to deliver. So why the higher costs? Ms. Crawford explains.
lead_paragraph: Using the Internet or a cellphone keeps getting more expensive. But for network providers like AT&T and Verizon Wireless, new technologies have made services cheaper to deliver. So why the higher prices?

headline: F.B.I. Said to Be Looking at Suspicious Heinz Trades
abstract: The F.B.I.’s involvement adds to the scrutiny surrounding the auspiciously timed options trades, by an investor or investors who have not yet been identified.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened a criminal inquiry into suspicious trades placed ahead of the $23 billion acquisition of H.J. Heinz, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Apple Computers Hit by Sophisticated Cyberattack
abstract: Apple says its systems were attacked by the same group that hit Twitter and Facebook. Like Facebook, Apple confirmed that its employees’ computers were infected with malware when they visited a Web site for mobile developers.
lead_paragraph: Cyberattacks, apparently, happen in threes.

headline: Report of the Detroit Financial Review Team
abstract: A review team appointed by the state of Michigan has concluded that Detroit is mired in a serious financial problem, a step that draws the city closer to emergency oversight.
lead_paragraph: A review team appointed by the state of Michigan has concluded that Detroit is mired in a serious financial problem, a step that draws the city closer to emergency oversight.

headline: WWS 543, International Trade Policy: Class 5
abstract: When globalization went backwards.
lead_paragraph: The interwar trade collapse (pdf).

headline: Photos of The Moment | Simone Rocha
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Rory van Millingen.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Jury Awards Mystery Writer Patricia Cornwell $50.9 Million
abstract: Ms. Cornwell sued her former financial management company for negligence.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling mystery author Patricia Cornwell on Tuesday was awarded $50.9 million in a federal lawsuit, according to The Boston Globe.

headline: General Allen’s Tenure in Afghanistan
abstract: Gen. John R. Allen has had more than his share of crises, including a video of Marines urinating on Taliban corpses; the burning of Korans by American soldiers; civilian deaths in allied airstrikes; the massacre of 16 civilians, in which an American soldier has been charged; and a spate of insider attacks by Afghan forces on NATO troops.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans probably know of him only as a secondary character in the sweeping drama of David H. Petraeus’s affair with his biographer, Paula Broadwell. But Gen. John R. Allen, who announced Tuesday that he would retire from the Marine Corps rather than become the top commander of NATO, was for more than a year and a half the commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan. And when he said farewell to the job recently, he made clear that he wanted to be remembered for more than his bit role in that scandal.

headline: Sudan Troops Battle Rebels in Border Area
abstract: Sudanese forces said that they had captured an area from rebels in the state of Blue Nile in fierce fighting that led to the deaths of 66 rebels and several government soldiers.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Sudanese forces said late Monday that they had captured an area from rebels in the restive state of Blue Nile in fierce fighting that led to the deaths of 66 rebels and several government soldiers.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 3
abstract: Arsenal hosted Bayern Munich and Malaga played at Porto on Matchday 3 in the Round of 16 of the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: Matchday 3 in the Round of 16 in the UEFA Champions League. After a winter break we continue a feature in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Feathers
abstract: Feathers were everywhere in London: whimsical at Christopher Kane, mysterious at Erdem and jewel-like at Giles.
lead_paragraph: T spots the latest trends on the runway.  At London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane used feathers to create whimsical trims, Erdem had them peaking out of silk and organza overlays and at Giles, they dangled from dresses like metal jewels.

headline: NetSpend Sold to Payment Provider for $1.4 Billion in Cash
abstract: NetSpend, a publicly traded provider of prepaid debit cards, is being sold to Tsys for $1.4 billion, the companies announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: NetSpend, a publicly traded provider of prepaid debit cards, is being sold to Tsys for $1.4 billion, the companies announced on Tuesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Yemen, Gaza Strip and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Yemen, Gaza Strip and the Philippines.

headline: Court Gives Investor an Edge in a Lawsuit Against Apple
abstract: A federal judge says he is leaning toward the hedge fund magnate David Einhorn’s contention in a lawsuit that Apple violated securities regulations by improperly bundling several shareholder proposals into one matter.
lead_paragraph: 7:47 p.m. | Updated

headline: Russia Aims to Defuse Conflict Over Schneerson Collection
abstract: President Vladimir Putin said that the thousands of books and religious papers in the Schneerson Collection belonged to the Russian state.
lead_paragraph: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin said on Tuesday that he blamed “unjust rulings by the judicial authorities of another country” for the tensions over a collection of books and manuscripts that is being sought by the Brooklyn-based Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic group, but offered to defuse the situation by transferring the works to a new Jewish center in Moscow.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: A new pizza place in Midtown will offer dairy but no meat; Birch Coffee is getting a new outpost; and Luke’s Lobster reopens.
lead_paragraph: Headliner Pizza da Solo

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, a kit for making sushi hand rolls, “Dinner With Churchill,” promoting Malaysian cuisine and more.
lead_paragraph: To Covet: I Dreamed I Was a Sushi Chef

headline: The Language Is the Thing
abstract: Four actors play all the roles in this Bedlam production of “Hamlet,” which hews true to Shakespeare’s verse even while cracking wise at Access Theater.
lead_paragraph: Four actors play all the roles, audience members move seats every act and Polonius is in sneakers? Don’t worry: The Bedlam company’s “Hamlet” is not as gimmicky as it sounds.

headline: Iran, Where Wrestling Is King, Mourns Loss of Sport in Olympics
abstract: The decision to drop wrestling from the 2020 Olympics hits hard in Iran, where the sport is deeply embedded in the national cultural narrative.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Not much has changed in the Marqoobkar wrestling club in South Tehran for decades. On a recent afternoon, boys in their wrestling singlets ran circles on a yellow mat, as they do every day, the tallest leading, followed by two dozen others and a tiny 9-year-old trailing behind. The canvas squeaked under their bare feet.

headline: 2 Masters of the Business That Is Recorded Music
abstract: In “Hitmaker: The Man and His Music,” by Tommy Mottola, and “The Soundtrack of My Life,” by Clive Davis, two industry executives look back on their careers.
lead_paragraph: Who put the bomp, Barry Mann asked in his 1961 single, in the bomp bah bomp bah bomp? Mr. Mann wanted to shake that person’s hand.

headline: F.B.I. File on Times Publisher Was Destroyed Before His Death
abstract: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the Times publisher during whose long tenure the Pentagon Papers were published, had drawn the attention of federal investigators.
lead_paragraph: The files kept by the Federal Bureau of Investigation about Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who led The New York Times as its publisher during its landmark publication of the Pentagon Papers, were destroyed 10 months before his death, according to records requests filed by a reporter.

headline: Improvising, a Mover Lets You See Her Think
abstract: “Live Dancing Archive” uses a live performance, a video and an online archive as tools for exploration.
lead_paragraph: In “Live Dancing Archive,” one part of an excellent three-tiered production that opened at the Kitchen on Thursday night, Jennifer Monson, wearing a furry vest and nude fishnets, dives headfirst onto the floor. She puts on a platinum wig to sing along faintly to Antony and the Johnsons’ haunting “Bird Gerhl.” And she runs in loping steps that scrape the tops of her toes on the floor only to halt suddenly, lift a foot and raise her arms until every part of her remains calm but her twitching fingers.

headline: Laughs Can Be Cheap at a Comedy Theater
abstract: Upright Citizens Brigade Theater has become a major player in the comedy world partly by not paying some performers.
lead_paragraph: How did the comedy juggernaut Upright Citizens Brigade Theater solve the most intractable problem of live theater today, the inexorable rise of ticket prices?

headline: Dolan Says It’s ‘Highly Possible’ the Next Pope Could Be a Non-European
abstract: As he has since Pope Benedict XVI announced his resignation, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, 63, played down the idea that he might himself be chosen.
lead_paragraph: CardinalTimothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, said on Tuesday that he believed it was “highly possible” that the next pope could come from a non-European country.

headline: A Princess Skips Ahead to a Dream Come True
abstract: New York City Ballet’s production of Peter Martins’s 1991 “Sleeping Beauty” adheres to the policy of making the ballet short and fast.
lead_paragraph: There may be no ballet harder to get right in the theater than “The Sleeping Beauty.” It’s made up of innumerable details — musical, choreographic, decorative — that cover a wide range of what ballet theater can be, from pure classicism to scenic magic. New York City Ballet’s production of “The Sleeping Beauty” — first staged by Peter Martins in 1991 and little altered since — is a strangely conflicted experience. Its designs are largely of unusual loveliness. Many of its directorial decisions, grand or tiny, show intelligence and discrimination seldom found in this ballet.

headline:
Justices Take Case on
Overall Limit to
Political Donations
abstract: The Supreme Court will examine caps on aggregate contributions by individual donors, setting the stage for what could end up as the most important campaign finance case since the 2010 decision in Citizens United.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear a challenge to federal campaign contribution limits, setting the stage for what may turn out to be the most important federal campaign finance case since the court’s 2010 decision in Citizens United, which struck down limits on independent campaign spending by corporations and unions.

headline: As the Cantatas Unfurl, a Reprieve Is Affirmed
abstract: Music at Trinity and Tenet are collaborating on a series of concerts on the Lenten period.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to believe that just a year ago the wide-ranging music programs of Trinity Church, one of New York’s major spiritual and cultural centers, were threatened with extinction. Even wealthy nonprofit institutions have felt the press of the economic downturn, and the church’s robust programming was evidently thought unsustainable.

headline: A Work by John Cage: Times Have Changed
abstract: John Cage’s “Apartment House 1776” was performed on Saturday as part of the Avant Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic presented the city’s premiere of John Cage’s “Apartment House 1776,” in November 1976, the headline for a review in The New York Times by Allen Hughes — “Hundreds Walk Out of Premiere of John Cage Work at Fisher Hall” — illustrated in stark terms Cage’s status among conservative concertgoers.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Found Money and Seeing in the Dark
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include a lot of questions about an American scientist dead in Singapore, a neuroscientist who says no computer will ever replicate the human brain and the sites that tie the Web together.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Playing Beethoven, and Finding the Bar High
abstract: The Endellion String Quartet’s concert series of Beethoven works is being presented along with a Beethoven lecture series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: “Framing Beethoven” is the title of a lecture series that the Metropolitan Museum of Art is currently presenting alongside a six-concert survey of the complete Beethoven string quartets by the Endellion String Quartet. If there is a crime Beethoven is being set up for, it is, in the words of the museum’s publicity brochure, “his impact on the death of Classicism.”

headline: Photos of The Moment | Ostwald Helgason
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Wild Oats
abstract: Once-humble granola is now a high-end growth industry as chefs pair it with everything from yogurt “leather” to foie gras.
lead_paragraph: For many years, granola was the lumpy woolen sweater of the food world.

headline: How Do You Granola?
abstract: Just about everyone who makes granola has a secret of some sort. What’s yours?
lead_paragraph: Some use butter. Others use olive oil. And for at least one trailblazing California chef, the process involves pickled mango and a scattering of Fruity Pebbles.

headline: Supreme Court Appears to Defend Patent on Soybean
keywords: ['Genetic Engineering', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Seeds', 'Soybeans']
abstract: The case, over a farmer who reproduced and saved seeds patented by Monsanto, questions whether natural replication can constitute patent infringement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A freewheeling and almost entirely one-sided argument at the Supreme Court on Tuesday indicated that the justices would not allow Monsanto’s patents for genetically altered soybeans to be threatened by an Indiana farmer who used them without paying the company a fee.

headline: After Olympic Disappointment, an Overhaul
abstract: After a last-place finish in the London Games, the United States women’s field hockey program changed coaches and its structure.
lead_paragraph: The months leading to last summer’s London Olympics had been exceptionally promising ones for the United States women’s field hockey team. In fact, it did not seem unreasonable that the team would contend for a medal, which would have been only its second.

headline: A Hip-Hop Moment, but Is It Authentic?
abstract: Macklemore’s “Thrift Shop” and Baauer’s “Harlem Shake” are wildly popular, signifying either a tremendous cultural victory for hip-hop or the moment when hip-hop has begun to lose its meaning.
lead_paragraph: Even though hip-hop has countless shades, colors, splinter wings and internal dissenters, it’s still often spoken about as if it were an undifferentiated mass. Many consider it an outsider phenomenon, even though hip-hop has effectively become the center of pop music. This attitude partly stems from age, race and other things, but mainly from a refusal to see the world as it has become.

headline: BHP Billiton Chief to Retire; an Insider Will Succeed Him
abstract: The mining company said Marius Kloppers would retire this year and be succeeded by Andrew Mackenzie, one of his first hires after becoming chief executive in 2007.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BHP Billiton said on Tuesday that its chief executive, Marius J. Kloppers, would retire this year after almost two decades at the company.

headline: ‘Currency War’ Is Less a Battle Than a Debate on Economic Policy
abstract: Big countries are responding to their own economic downturns by easing monetary policies, but emerging market economies cannot respond with similar effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: Never mind about North Korea; the talk in some quarters is that the biggest threat to Asia and the rest of the world today may very well be a “currency war,” in which countries race to devalue their currencies in a desperate attempt to stimulate growth.

headline: Why the School Bus Never Comes in Red or Green
abstract: The standardization dates back to 1939, when Prof. Frank W. Cyr convened a national conference.
lead_paragraph: A question came to mind as school bus drivers prepared to start their engines on Wednesday on 7,700 public-school routes in New York City and end their monthlong strike: Why are most school buses yellow?

headline: Minnesota Congressman Meets Somali President
abstract: Representative Keith Ellison, a Muslim whose district is home to one of the world’s largest concentrations of Somali emigrants, was fulfilling a campaign promise.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Representative Keith Ellison, Democrat of Minnesota, visited Mogadishu on Tuesday and met with Somalia’s president, Hassan Sheik Mohamoud, in a rare visit to the strife-plagued country by a member of Congress.

headline: At the Garden, a Long-Awaited Father and Son Reunion
abstract: The author and his father met up for a Knicks game, where a loss wasn’t quite as traumatic as it was in his childhood.
lead_paragraph: It’s as American as a Norman Rockwell print: Dad and son trundle down to the ol’ baseball park, glove in tow, to root for the home team. It’s a bond that’s pure, the love of a team passed down from one generation to the next.

headline: Coalition to Apply Election Strength to Immigration Debate
abstract: A coalition of labor, Latino and other groups that helped re-elect the president hope to push the Senate to include a pathway to citizenship for those here illegally in its immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: In a new nationwide campaign, groups that favor a path to citizenship for most of the nation’s 11 million illegal immigrants will seek to mobilize the same coalition that helped to carry President Obama into his second term, while treading lightly enough to avoid disrupting the delicate immigration overhaul negotiations in the Senate.

headline: Kelly Clarkson Assails Clive Davis Over His Memoir
abstract: She says his account of how he managed her career was full of “memory lapses and misinformation.”
lead_paragraph: 9:27 a.m. | Updated

headline: A Composer So Fond of the Novel, He Hoped It Wouldn’t Be a Film
abstract: The “Life of Pi” composer Mychael Danna says he loved the novel so much, he felt a burden in getting the music right.
lead_paragraph: As a first-time nominee, the composer Mychael Danna has made a good showing: he was recognized twice, for his score for “Life of Pi” and for the original song “Pi’s Lullaby,” from Ang Lee’s adaptation of the Yann Martel novel.

headline: Prust Speaks: Tortorella Is ‘Just Another Coach’
abstract: Brandon Prust, who left the Rangers as a free agent for Montreal, spoke to reporters before his first game back at the Garden.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Prust, the combative, effective wing who left the Rangers as a free agent last summer to sign a four-year, $10 million contract with Montreal, spoke Tuesday, two hours before he returned to Madison Square Garden for the first time. He was as well-spoken and quietly funny as he was in his two and a half seasons with the Rangers. His question-and-answer session with reporters follows.

headline: Tom Hanks Makes His Broadway Debut
abstract: The star of the play “Lucky Guy,” written by Nora Ephron, sits down with Patrick Healy at the Broadhurst Theater.
lead_paragraph: The star of the play “Lucky Guy,” written by Nora Ephron, sits down with Patrick Healy at the Broadhurst Theater.

headline: Cemetery Fixtures Stolen, Police Say, but Not Carried Away
abstract: The police said a man who frequented St. Raymond Cemetery in the Bronx had stolen $189,000 worth of air vents and brass door handles.
lead_paragraph: Update, Wednesday | Mr. Peduto, who is homeless, was arrested inside 3178 Tremont Avenue in the Bronx on Tuesday, around the corner from the cemetery, on charges of larceny and possessing burglary tools and drugs, the police said.

headline: Obama Works the Phones to Calm Tensions on Immigration Plan
abstract: After a rebuke from Senator Marco Rubio, President Obama’s calls represented an acknowledgment of laggardly outreach to Republicans working on immigration.
lead_paragraph: After a Presidents’ Day weekend whodunit of who leaked what and why — not to mention a he-said, she-said back-and-forth on the Sunday shows and in news releases — President Obama took to the phones Tuesday afternoon to quell rising tensions with Senate Republicans after a draft of a White House immigration plan was somehow leaked to the news media.

headline: Nanotubes Seen as Alternative When Silicon Chips Hit Their Limits
abstract: Carbon nanotubes may prove to be the material of the future when today’s silicon-based chips reach their fundamental physical limits.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the next decade or so, the circuits etched on silicon-based computer chips are expected to shrink as small as they can physically become, prompting a search for alternative materials to take their place.

headline: China’s Cyberwarriors
abstract: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, interviews David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent, on the efforts of Chinese hackers to infiltrate critical American infrastructure, from electrical grids to oil and gas pipelines.
lead_paragraph: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, interviews David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent, on the efforts of Chinese hackers to infiltrate critical American infrastructure, from electrical grids to oil and gas pipelines. Is there a cyber-Cold War under way?

headline: Iwan Baan’s Inclusive Eye
abstract: A solo exhibition of Baan’s lush large-scale images of cities and their people and buildings opens this week at the Perry Rubenstein Gallery in Los Angeles.
