headline: ‘Downton’ Finale Seen by 8.2 Million Viewers
abstract: Sunday’s audience surpassed even the audience for the third season premiere in January, when about 7.9 million viewers tuned in, a 20-year record for PBS.
lead_paragraph: The third season finale of “Downton Abbey” attracted 8.2 million viewers to PBS on Sunday night, giving the public broadcaster even more reason to celebrate the surprise British hit.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Meadham Kirchhoff
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Rory van Millingen.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: PGA Tour Members Voice Opposition to Ban on Anchored Putting Stroke
abstract: The U.S.G.A. and Royal & Ancient asked for the players feedback before making official their proposed ban of the anchored stroke.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — The PGA Tour members have spoken and now the anchored putting stroke is in the hands of the United States Golf Association and Royal & Ancient. The game’s guardians wanted feedback before making official their proposed ban of the anchored stroke, and they got it from tour players who, by all accounts, voiced a collective opposition to it.

headline: ‘Locally Grown’ Gets Tricky in the Cold
abstract: Some local-movement chefs muscle through the colder months, while others make compromises.
lead_paragraph: Locally grown. Market-sourced. Farm to table: These phrases have become the mantras of the American menu, promising ingredients that are supremely fresh, in season and produced within a tight radius of the restaurant.

headline: Mayweather Moving to Showtime
abstract: Floyd Mayweather agreed to move to Showtime after more than 15 years at HBO for a pay-per-view revenue-sharing agreement that is believed to significantly exceed the financial guarantees that HBO offered to retain him.
lead_paragraph: Floyd Mayweather agreed to move to Showtime after more than 15 years at HBO for a pay-per-view revenue-sharing agreement that is believed to significantly exceed the financial guarantees that HBO offered to retain him. The deal is for Mayweather to fight six times, including May 4 against Robert Guerrero, over 30 months. He has fought only once in each of the last four years. He last fought two bouts in a year in 2007.

headline: College Premium: Better Pay, Better Prospects
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: College graduates earn more per hour than high school graduates. But they are also more likely to be employed, and probably more likely to work the number of hours they wish.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written before about the growing wage premium for college degrees: how the wage gap between workers with a bachelor’s degree and workers with no more than a high school diploma has been growing over the years.

headline: A Great Debate
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Philosophy', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Is there a way to make genuine debates, in which politicians must do more than just repeat talking points, part of our political culture?
lead_paragraph: This is the year of what should be a decisive debate on our country’s spending and debt. But our political “debates” seldom deserve the name. For the most part representatives of the rival parties exchange one-liners: “The rich can afford to pay more” is met by “Tax increases kill jobs.” Slightly more sophisticated discussions may cite historical precedents: “There were higher tax rates during the post-war boom” versus “Reagan’s tax cuts increased revenues.”

headline: Supreme Court Gives F.T.C. a Win on Hospital Mergers
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Hospitals', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling that strengthened the power of the Federal Trade Commission could limit the ability of public hospital authorities to claim immunity from federal antitrust laws.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Tuesday strengthened the power of the Federal Trade Commission to block hospital mergers, issuing an opinion that could limit the ability of public hospital authorities to claim immunity from federal antitrust laws.

headline: Jets Release Pace and Scott
abstract: Shedding the contracts of Calvin Pace and Bart Scott moved the Jets below the projected salary cap, roughly $121 million.
lead_paragraph: Once symbols of the Jets’ free-spending habits and an aggressive win-now approach, linebackers Calvin Pace and Bart Scott are now casualties of a salary-cap crunch created, in part, by their contracts. The team released Pace, Scott, the safety and special-teams ace Eric Smith and offensive lineman Jason Smith, clearing about $31 million in cap space.

headline: Union and N.F.L. Face a Trust Divide
abstract: Any progress on issues facing the N.F.L. — like H.G.H. testing — will have to overcome what appears to be a lack of trust between the players and the league.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s scouting combine begins Wednesday night in Indianapolis, with the first groups of players — including the offensive linemen, one of the strengths of this class — arriving for the initial round of X-rays and orientation and 15-minute interviews with teams.

headline: Critique of a Duchess Rubs Some the Wrong Way
abstract: The Daily Mail set out after the British historical novelist Hilary Mantel for what the tabloid said was “an astonishing and venomous attack” on the Duchess of Cambridge.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is not often that sophisticated literary discourse is the topic of banner headlines on the front page of one of Britain’s hell-raising tabloids. And it is still less common for a prime minister to weigh in with his own stiffly reproving critique, turning the affair into dinner table talk across the country.

headline: Rubio’s Place in the G.O.P.

Despite his recent support for immigration reform, Mr. Rubio has generally sided with most other Republicans since winning his Senate seat.

abstract: Predictions that the Barclays Center would bring a surge in crime, unruly crowds and chaos to Brooklyn have not come to pass, but nuisances abound, residents say.
lead_paragraph: It is perhaps telling that the worst commotion the neighborhood has experienced since the Barclays Center opened in Brooklyn has not been stirred up by rowdy Nets fans or hip-hop devotees, but by teenage girls milling for hours outside a Justin Bieber concert in November.

lead_paragraph: In canvassing for its next potential Olympic city, the United States Olympic Committee sent letters to the mayors of 35 American cities on Tuesday to gauge their interest in making a bid for the 2024 Games.

headline: German Officials Signal Berlusconi Isn’t Their Man
abstract: In Berlin, the possibility that former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi could play a role in the next Italian government is viewed with chagrin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Asked in September if she feared a comeback by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany appeared at pains to hold back a smile as the room erupted in laughter. “I am, as you know, a democratic politician and respect the outcome of elections in every country,” she told reporters in Berlin.

headline: In the End, He Stole Nothing and Gave Plenty
abstract: Richard L. Murphy, a Dinkins administration official who died last week, faced false accusations, but he’ll be remembered for the community centers he helped create.

headline: Overdose Deaths Continue to Climb
abstract: Drug overdose deaths in the United States increased for the 11th consecutive year in 2010, rising 3.6 percent from 2009, federal officials reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Drug overdose deaths in the United States increased for the 11th consecutive year in 2010, rising 3.6 percent from 2009, federal officials reported Tuesday. There were 38,329 drug overdose deaths in 2010. Prescription drugs were involved in more than half of all overdoses, with 22,134 deaths from them, up 6 percent from 2009. Of those deaths, opioids, like oxycodone and morphine, were involved in an overwhelming majority, with 16,651 deaths in 2010, up 7 percent from 2009. Deaths from prescription drug overdoses quadrupled from 1999 to 2010.

headline: Dozens of PGA Pros Say Drug Testing Is Limited
abstract: The PGA Tour does not require players to give their whereabouts, making it difficult for testers to collect samples outside of competition sites.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — The player most likely to be subjected to rigorous testing under the PGA Tour’s antidoping program would figure to be Tiger Woods, a 14-time major champion and one of the brightest stars in the sporting firmament.

headline: Top Member of Taliban in Pakistan Is Captured
abstract: The capture of the long-sought Maulvi Faqir Muhammad is likely to further improve relations between Afghanistan and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghanistan authorities have captured a senior member of the Pakistan Taliban in a stretch of mountains near the frontier between the two countries, Afghan and Pakistani officials said on Tuesday. One Afghan official said the militant, Maulvi Faqir Muhammad, had been arrested after American airstrikes, some carried out via drones, had flushed him out of a more remote haven.

It had been his goal all along to rejoin the team by the end of the season.

headline: Reproductive Rights in New York
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo aims to re-establish the state’s pre-eminence on equal rights with an omnibus agenda on women’s equality, starting with a bill to ease limits on abortion.
lead_paragraph: New York State once led the nation in advancing women’s rights. Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to re-establish that pre-eminence with an omnibus agenda on women’s equality. The most important piece of that agenda would essentially enshrine in state law existing federal protections for abortion rights.

headline: China’s Cybergames
abstract: Though President Obama is taking steps to deter hacking into computer networks by the Chinese, negotiations with Beijing are also needed.
lead_paragraph: Washington has not had much success persuading Beijing to rein in its hackers even though American officials and security experts have long known that China is the main source of cyberattacks on the United States. Two recent developments, however, should raise the political costs for China and may cause it to alter its calculus. Refusal to change its conduct could make its relations with the United States even more difficult than they are.

headline: Obama’s Forecast on Cuts Is Dire, but Timing Is Disputed
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Government Employees']
abstract: President Obama painted a picture of immediate devastation from across-the-board spending cuts set to take effect March 1, but other officials anticipate more gradual reductions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday painted a dire picture of federal government operations across the United States should automatic budget cuts hit on March 1: F.B.I. agents furloughed, criminals released, flights delayed, teachers and police officers laid off and parents frantic to find a place for children locked out of day care centers.

headline: Now Batting: A Stronger, Mandatory Helmet
abstract: For Rawlings, the official provider of helmets to Major League Baseball, the S100 Pro Comp is the latest and best attempt at protecting players at the plate.
lead_paragraph: The beanball is one of the scariest plays in sports, a baseball hurtling at the head of a batter who cannot get out of the way. Over the years, they have led to concussions, skull fractures and, in a handful of cases, deaths.

headline: After Adopted Boy Dies in U.S., Russian Officials Accuse Texas Woman
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'United States International Relations', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Russian officials on Tuesday accused a Texas woman of fatally beating the 3-year-old boy, setting off a new wave of outrage in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian officials on Tuesday accused a Texas woman of fatally beating a 3-year-old boy she had adopted from Russia, setting off a new wave of outrage in a country already focused on American adoptions that have culminated in neglect or abuse.

headline: Campaign Donations and Political Corruption
abstract: The Supreme Court has decided to review a campaign finance ruling that it should have left alone.
lead_paragraph: In a deeply worrisome move, the Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear a new campaign finance lawsuit that challenges long-established federal caps on the total amount an individual can contribute to federal campaigns in a two-year cycle. In a ruling last year, a special court in Washington correctly upheld those limits, which in some form have been included in federal law since 1974.

headline: The Belly Dancing Barometer
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Democracy definitely isn’t easy. Just look at how Egypt today is more divided than ever.
lead_paragraph: The Daily News of Egypt reported that the national administrative court ruled last week that the popular Al-Tet “belly dancing channel” be taken off the air for broadcasting without a license. Who knew that Egypt had a belly dancing channel? (Does Comcast know about this?) It is evidently quite popular but apparently offensive to some of the rising Islamist forces in Egypt. It is not clear how much the Muslim Brotherhood’s party had to do with the belly ban, but what is clear is that no one in Egypt is having much fun these days.

keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AIRPORTS', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Storage', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']

lead_paragraph: With the Federal Aviation Administration’s grounding of the 787 Dreamliner fleet in its fifth week, Boeing now faces a problem of where to store the airplanes that continue to roll off the assembly line at its giant factory 30 miles north of Seattle.

lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s prime minister resigned on Tuesday after failing to form a new government, saying the country’s political leaders, including those in his governing Islamist party, had “disappointed” Tunisians with squabbling that had led the country into a political crisis.

abstract: Florida Atlantic University will name its football building GEO Group Stadium, after the prisons corporation, leading critics to wonder just how far colleges and teams will go for revenue.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, where stadium naming rights could be sold, universities and professional sports teams have sold them — to airlines and banks and companies that sell beer, soda, doughnuts, cars, telecommunications, razors and baseball bats. This led to memorable examples like Enron Field, the KFC Yum! Center and the University of Phoenix Stadium.

headline: French Family Kidnapped in Cameroon
abstract: The family, including four children, was seized in the north, the second hostage-taking in the region in four days.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Seven French tourists, including four children, were kidnapped in northern Cameroon on Tuesday, the second large-scale hostage-taking in the region in four days. The French president and foreign minister pointed the finger at Islamist terrorist groups operating across the border in northeast Nigeria, possibly including the deadly Boko Haram organization.

headline: A Dazzling Priest’s Lurid Fall, to Drug Case Suspect
abstract: Msgr. Kevin Wallin, formerly pastor of the Diocese of Bridgeport’s mother church in Connecticut, is charged with dealing crystal methamphetamine.

As a confidant to two bishops and then as the erudite and clubbable pastor of two churches, Msgr. Kevin Wallin was a towering figure in the Roman Catholic Church in southwestern Connecticut.

headline: Millions of Dollars Later, Landlords Reopen After Deluge

lead_paragraph: More than three months after Hurricane Sandy flooded Manhattan’s financial district, forcing the closure of about a quarter of its offices, all but a handful of those buildings have come back to life, defying predictions of a drawn-out recovery.

headline: Fast New Test Could Find Leprosy Before Damage Is Lasting
abstract: A simple, cheap screening offers the hope of diagnosing and curing leprosy, even in the poorest places, before victims are permanently disabled or disfigured.
lead_paragraph: A simple, fast and inexpensive new test for leprosy offers hope that, even in the poorest countries, victims can be found and cured before they become permanently disabled or disfigured like the shunned lepers of yore.

headline: 3 Men Arrested in Scheme to Sell Counterfeit Car Parts

lead_paragraph: Federal authorities arrested three men Tuesday on charges of selling counterfeit brake pads and other automotive parts to repair shops, including those that service the city’s yellow taxis and licensed livery cabs, officials said.

headline: Israel: Deal Gives Netanyahu Rival Palestinian Portfolio
abstract: The party of Ms. Livni, who will serve as justice minister, is the first to sign an agreement with Mr. Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced Tuesday night that Tzipi Livni, the former foreign minister who has long been a harsh critic of his handling of the Palestinian conflict, would join his next government, serving as justice minister and leading negotiations with the Palestinians.

headline: Battle Lines Drawn for BP’s Day in Court
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: A collection of cases on the Deepwater Horizon spill are headed for federal court, where they are expected to have a broad effect on environmental law.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Unless the Justice Department and BP reach a last-minute settlement, the British oil company will return to court on Monday to face tens of billions of dollars in civil claims from the 2010 explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig in the Gulf of Mexico that could cripple the company for years to come.

headline: Germany: Court Backs Adoption by Same-Sex Couples
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The law should not differentiate between parents of the same sex, united in a civil union, or a man and a woman in a traditional marriage, the nation’s highest court said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Children do not differentiate whether their parents are of the same sex, united in a civil union, or a man and a woman in a traditional marriage, and therefore neither should the law, the nation’s highest court said Tuesday, placing Germany on a growing list of European countries to expand the rights of same-sex couples. The Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe ruled in favor of a doctor from Münster who had challenged existing laws that forbade her to adopt her same-sex partner’s daughter, who was raised by both women. The judges ordered the government to draw up legislation by June 2014 to allow such adoptions within same-sex unions.

headline: School Bus Drivers See No Gain From Strike
abstract: Leaders of the bus drivers’ union said the job action was the start of a long war that would spread to other fronts, like Albany.
lead_paragraph: They lost pay, watched bills pile up at home and endured cold days and nights on picket lines. They weathered criticism in some quarters as holdouts for archaic and costly job protections. And, perhaps most stingingly, the struggle bore no immediate fruit.

lead_paragraph: Nickelodeon has spent the last two years asking 9- and 10-year-olds what they want to watch on the iPad. The result: Very little actual television.

headline: Ex-Ranger Shows Scrappiness His Former Team Now Lacks

lead_paragraph: The Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens are two very different teams from last season. Brandon Prust, the tough, scrappy wing, is perhaps the biggest reason.

headline: Bronx Leader Wants a Public Registry for Offenders in Gun Crimes
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Firearms', 'Law and Legislation', 'Freedom of Information Act']
abstract: The borough president, Ruben Diaz Jr., compares his proposal to sex-offender registries.
lead_paragraph: New York State already keeps a public registry of sex offenders. Now a Bronx political leader is calling for a statewide registry to be created for people found guilty of another type of crime: gun violence.

headline: On Hudson, Bank’s Ferries Are Finally in Service
abstract: Goldman Sachs’s new ferries began making trips on Tuesday after an unexplained two years spent bobbing, unused, on the river.
lead_paragraph: It is a mystery that has drifted around New York Harbor for two years: Why did one of the world’s biggest investment banks buy two custom-made ferry boats and leave them bobbing, unused, on the Hudson River?

headline: Community, Returning to Life, Asks, ‘Where Is Everybody?’
abstract: Repairs are coming along, but some fear that Red Hook — a place of pioneers and craftspeople who were artisanal before the word went mainstream — has become less desirable because of the storm.
lead_paragraph: There weren’t enough people in Red Hook, residents said to one another in worried tones. The Brooklyn neighborhood felt lonely. Dwellers in the garden apartments along Pioneer Street, which took on about eight feet of water during Hurricane Sandy, were long gone. Dog walkers’ clients had moved, taking their canine charges with them. At least one restaurant was having trouble finding enough workers to reopen. Demand from would-be home buyers had ebbed.

headline: Home Solar Systems to Be an Option for Honda Customers
abstract: Honda is teaming up with the installer SolarCity to make the offer, which consists of leasing the power system long term at little or no initial cost.
lead_paragraph: Automakers have long resorted to incentives like zero-percent financing, rewards points and rebates to inspire customer loyalty. Now Honda is offering a different deal: inexpensive home solar power systems for customers.

headline: Johnson Beats the Buzzer, Twice, to Lift the Nets
abstract: Joe Johnson made a 3-pointer with time running out in regulation before hitting the winning shot at the buzzer in overtime against the Bucks on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: As energy sources go, Joe Johnson is fantastically deceptive, all sleepy eyes and shrugs and coy smiles, without a single signature exclamation in his emotional arsenal. There is nothing particularly electric about him, until the game is on the line and the seconds are ticking away and the ball is in his hands.

headline: Woods and Obama, a Weekend Pairing That Can’t Help but Draw Attention
abstract: Tiger Woods on Sunday partnered with President Obama, who was on a weekend getaway, for a round at The Floridian in Palm City, for a friendly competition.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — In the first round of the Accenture Match Play Championship, Tiger Woods will play Charles Howell III, who is well known in the golf world but not nearly as distinguished as the player Woods was paired with in a friendly competition Sunday in Florida.

headline: Petro Vlahos, Special-Effects Innovator, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Vlahos developed the blue-screen and green-screen process that creates illusions in movies and other formats.
lead_paragraph: Petro Vlahos, a special-effects pioneer who developed the blue-screen and green-screen process that allowed Dick Van Dyke to dance with penguins in “Mary Poppins,” the blue-skinned Na’vi to live among floating mountains in “Avatar,” and TV weather reporters to point at sun and rain symbols that only their viewers can see, died on Feb. 10 in Los Angeles. He was 96.

headline: No Consensus on a Common Cause of Foot Pain
abstract: The mysteries of the heel and arch pain of plantar fasciitis underscore how little is understood, medically, about overuse sports injuries in general and why they remain so insidiously difficult to treat.
lead_paragraph: There are more charismatic-sounding sports injuries than plantar fasciitis, like tennis elbow, runner’s knee and turf toe. But there aren’t many that are more common. The condition, characterized by stabbing pain in the heel or arch, sidelines up to 10 percent of all runners, as well as countless soccer, baseball, football and basketball players, golfers, walkers and others from both the recreational and professional ranks. The Lakers star Kobe Bryant, the quarterback Eli Manning, the Olympic marathon runner Ryan Hall and the presidential candidate Mitt Romney all have been stricken.

lead_paragraph: The clue — a simple fingerprint on a juice bottle stolen from Whole Foods — was routine. But that, along with some creative undercover work, helped the authorities unravel the brazen daylight theft of a Dalí drawing from an Upper East Side gallery that had gone unsolved for months.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (13, 49) AFTER NEWTOWN This PBS initiative exploring gun laws, mental illness and school security continues with a “PBS NewsHour” report by the science correspondent Miles O’Brien about adolescent brain development and the factors that can lead to violent behavior. In “Mind of a Rampage Killer,” on “Nova” at 9, Mr. O’Brien investigates theories about circumstances that would cause a person to enter a public place and open fire — and how science can help us recognize danger signs. And “The Path to Violence,” at 10, looks at the Safe School Initiative, a Secret Service program that has helped schools detect problem behavior, and examines how findings can be applied to the families of violent individuals. Sam Waterston narrates. Above, a scene from “The Path to Violence.”

headline: News Quiz | February 20, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Irene Genovese, the Traveler from Italy
abstract: A first-time traveler to the Kumbh is astounded by the number of people.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this year’s 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

headline: Pistorius Defense Rebuts Police Testimony at Bail Hearing
abstract: The prosecution’s push to solidify charges that Oscar Pistorius had murdered his girlfriend deteriorated as its main witness withered under cross-examination at a bail hearing.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — What began on Wednesday as a day for the prosecution to solidify what it had described as an irrefutable case of premeditated murder against Oscar Pistorius, the Paralympic champion, turned into a near rout by the defense, which attacked the testimony of the state’s main witness, the chief police investigator.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 20
abstract: European solar panel importers resist tariffs; a Taliban leader is captured; a rebuilt Titanic; Tom Ford on the runway; and a celebration of Trisha Brown.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Importers of inexpensive solar panels from China said Tuesday that imposing tariffs would lead to hundreds of thousands of job losses in the European Union, the biggest export market for the Chinese equipment. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

abstract: Muhammad Afzal Guru’s widow, Tabassum, on her husband’s execution and her fight to retrieve the body.

headline: After Bulgarian Protests, Prime Minister Resigns
abstract: Prime Minister Boiko Borisov of Bulgaria submitted his government’s resignation on Wednesday after a tumultuous week of public anger and protests.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boiko Borisov of Bulgaria submitted his government’s resignation on Wednesday after a tumultuous week of public anger over rising electricity prices, corruption and worsening living standards that ignited mass protests nationwide and led to bloody clashes with the police on Tuesday night.

headline: Cameron Calls Colonial-Era Massacre in India ‘Shameful’
abstract: David Cameron is Britain’s first serving prime minister to voice regret about the 1919 Jallianwala Bagh massacre in Amritsar, where hundreds of Indians were killed.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Britain’s prime minister laid a wreath on Wednesday at the site of a notorious 1919 massacre that cost the lives of hundreds of Indians and has long been seen as one of the British Empire’s most shameful episodes.

headline: Should Reading and Math Be Taught in Gym Class Too?
abstract: Do you think pushing academic instruction into gym class might defeat its primary purpose of getting students to be physically active?
lead_paragraph: Gym class is for playing sports, like kickball and tennis, and running around. Or is it? Some gym teachers are incorporating reading, writing and math into their curriculum alongside traditional physical activities to help students meet new academic standards.

abstract: We’re asking for high school students to help create a 21st century portrait of America — turning their cameras on their neighborhoods, families, friends and schools.

headline: China Says Army Is Not Behind Attacks in Report
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Computer Security']

lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A day after a United States security company accused a People’s Liberation Army unit in Shanghai of engaging in cyberwarfare against American corporations, organizations and government agencies, China’s defense ministry issued a strong denial and insisted that the report was flawed.

headline: Greek Workers Walk Out in Fresh Austerity Protest
abstract: The first nationwide protest against austerity this year shut schools, reduced staffing at state hospitals and disrupted transportation.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Thousands of Greek workers walked off the job on Wednesday in the first nationwide protest against austerity this year, shutting schools, reducing staffing at state hospitals and disrupting transportation.

headline: Cameron Calls Colonial-Era Massacre in India ‘Shameful’

keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: China considered using a drone strike to kill a Myanmar drug lord wanted in the murders of 13 Chinese sailors, but decided instead to capture him alive, according to reports.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China considered using a drone strike in a mountainous region of Southeast Asia to kill a Myanmar drug lord wanted in the murders of 13 Chinese sailors, but decided instead to capture him alive, according to an influential state-run newspaper.

headline: North Korean Video Shows Obama in Flames
abstract: A new North Korean propaganda video shows President Obama and United States troops in flames.
lead_paragraph: North Korea has released a new propaganda video that shows President Obama and United States troops in flames and credits Washington with leading the impoverished country to become a proud nuclear power.

headline: Mullin Museum Showcases Work of Gabriel Voisin
abstract: The Voisin automobiles are the focus of the museum’s exhibition, but large story boards and other displays show the range of his creative capabilities.
lead_paragraph: OXNARD, Calif. — Peter Mullin’s car museum is like a geode, a rock that looks like a ball of dried mud until you crack it open and discover the gemlike structures hidden inside. From the outside, the Mullin Automotive Museum looks like any other building in any other industrial park in any other suburban development. But walk inside and you are dazzled by the cars, which really are rolling sculptures and are displayed just as you might have seen them had you attended one of the Paris auto salons in the Art Deco era between the world wars.

headline: The Reluctant Caregiver
abstract: Many caregivers don’t want the job — and feel guilty about that.
lead_paragraph: Now and then, I refer to the people that caregivers tend to as “loved ones.” And whenever I do, a woman in Southern California tells me, I set her teeth on edge.

keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Taxation', 'Wages and Salaries']

lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

lead_paragraph: 8:39 a.m. | Updated On Wednesday, Yahoo introduced a fresh new home page with Marissa Mayer’s stamp all over it.

headline: What I Took Home in 2012
abstract: Last year started well, so I decided I would pay myself a reasonable salary. But sales started to slump after two months, and I ended up stopping my salary in April.
lead_paragraph: A year ago I wrote a series of posts that dissected my company’s finances and culminated with a detailed accounting of how much money I made in 2011 — $246,626, generated from revenue of $2,155,193. The event that prompted the analysis, writing an application for college financial aid, just happened again this weekend. So I’m going to give you an update on how 2012 went and whether I was able to match what was by far my most rewarding year.

headline: The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food
abstract: Inside the hyperengineered, savagely marketed, addiction-creating battle for American “stomach share.”
lead_paragraph: On the evening of April 8, 1999, a long line of Town Cars and taxis pulled up to the Minneapolis headquarters of Pillsbury and discharged 11 men who controlled America’s largest food companies. Nestlé was in attendance, as were Kraft and Nabisco, General Mills and Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and Mars. Rivals any other day, the C.E.O.’s and company presidents had come together for a rare, private meeting. On the agenda was one item: the emerging obesity epidemic and how to deal with it. While the atmosphere was cordial, the men assembled were hardly friends. Their stature was defined by their skill in fighting one another for what they called “stomach share” — the amount of digestive space that any one company’s brand can grab from the competition.

headline: Robin Roberts Returns to ‘Good Morning America’
abstract: Nearly six months after signing off ABC’s “Good Morning America” to fight a life-threatening illness, Robin Roberts made her return to the top-rated morning show on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: 6:00 p.m. | Updated “Now,” Robin Roberts said to the staff of her top-rated morning show, “Good Morning America,” right after it wrapped on Wednesday, “we can resume regular programming.”

headline: Tunnel Vision

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian military’s recent flooding of tunnels at the border between Egypt and Gaza is its most aggressive attempt yet to restrict smuggling since Israel imposed a blockade on the Palestinian territory in 2005. Sewage water is reportedly being used to weaken the tunnels’ structure, sometimes trapping smugglers inside.

headline: Europe’s Rift on Overfishing and Subsidies

lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, the European Parliament voted overwhelmingly to require that the 27-nation bloc’s fisheries be managed on a sustainable basis within a few years.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A senior lawmaker from Russia’s governing party, who was also the chairman of Parliament’s ethics committee, resigned from the legislature on Wednesday over revelations that he owned more than $1.3 million worth of luxury real estate in Florida that he did not list on required disclosure forms.

headline: Arizona Senators Return to Fray on Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Senators Jeff Flake and John McCain, two Arizona Republicans who once led broad efforts on an immigration overhaul and then retreated, are back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The political risks of supporting an immigration overhaul have long been apparent to Senator John McCain, as evidenced by his evolving position on the topic over the years. This week offered another sharp reminder of what getting out in front of the issue can mean when crowds at back-to-back town-hall-style meetings in Arizona turned hostile toward Mr. McCain’s plan to introduce legislation that could lead to legal residency for some who broke the law in entering the country.

headline: Tom Hanks, Broadway’s New Kid
abstract: Mr. Hanks is making his Broadway debut in “Lucky Guy,” written by his friend Nora Ephron.
lead_paragraph: Tom Hanks swears. Not a blue streak, no, but it’s bracing to hear profanity from the man who has defined decency for three decades in Hollywood, playing white knights in “Splash,” “Forrest Gump,” “Apollo 13” and the “Toy Story” series. If he is grandma-friendly on screen, he is looser and less predictable in person — as his old friend Nora Ephron was reminded several years ago when she sent him the screenplay for a biopic, “Lucky Guy.” Mr. Hanks took an instant dislike to his character, Mike McAlary, the muckraking columnist of New York City tabloids in the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: True or False? The Tussle Over Ping Fu’s Memoir
abstract: The memoir can be a contentious genre. Ping Fu’s “Bend, not Break,” an account of her childhood in China and becoming an entrepreneur in the United States, fits the bill.
lead_paragraph: Did Ping Fu, a prominent Chinese-American businesswoman and author of a recent memoir, “Bend, not Break,” make up her horrible experiences during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution in order to gain United States citizenship? Did they help her become an American by claiming political asylum?

headline: Questions About Hearing Loss? A Help Desk
abstract: Neil J. DiSarno, chief staff officer for audiology at the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, is answering reader questions.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Ask the Expert features Neil J. DiSarno, who will answer questions about hearing loss. [Update: The first set of Dr. DiSarno’s answers can be found here. This feature is now closed to further questions.] Dr. DiSarno is the chief staff officer for audiology at the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association. From 1998 to 2012 he was chairman of the department of communication sciences and disorders at Missouri State University. Following are the types of questions that Dr. DiSarno is prepared to answer.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Children’s App Breaks Ground for Viacom, and Essay on Royals Causes Uproar
abstract: Nickelodeon’s plans for an iPad app could mean big things for Viacom, an article by Hilary Mantel about the former Kate Middleton draws a response on The Daily Mail’s front page and an attempt to subpoena outtakes from a Ken Burns documentary fails.
lead_paragraph: The children’s channel Nickelodeon plans to release an iPad app Thursday that could have serious implications for its parent company, Viacom, Amy Chozick writes. It represents Viacom’s first attempt at a streaming app and could indicate how they will approach apps for channels like Comedy Central and MTV. The most interesting thing about the app is that Nickelodeon’s research indicated that 9- and 10-year-olds were more interested in associated content, like music videos, games and video clips, rather than watching full episodes on a tablet. So the app contains a lot of accessible content beyond streaming episodes of Nickelodeon favorites like “SpongeBob SquarePants” and “iCarly,” even for users who do not subscribe to a cable company that provides Nickelodeon.

abstract: A program developed in Australia is proving how intensive parenting and family interventions can reduce violence against children, and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Is there a science to parenting?

headline: The Gun Report: February 20, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The gun rights folks like to talk (and talk and talk) about how people need guns to protect themselves from, you know, the bad guys. Oscar Pistorius has single-handedly shown why this type of thinking is misguided (I’m being kind). In his second court appearance since being charged with murdering his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp, Pistorius explained in an affidavit why he shot her four times through his closed bathroom door. He thought an intruder had come in through the bathroom window – so of course he opened fire without so much as switching on a light. So there are two possibilities: the police version, which is that he murdered her in cold blood after a violent argument, or the Pistorius version, which is that it was a regrettable accident. Either way, if there was no gun in the house, Steenkamp would still be alive. By the way, did you know he tweeted in November, “Nothing like getting home to hear the washing machine on and thinking its an intruder to go into full combat recon mode into the pantry! waa.” Wayne LaPierre should testify in his defense.

headline: Now Noshing | Jaffa Port Market
abstract: Local cuisine meets Seventh Avenue and Broadway at this Tel Aviv street market.
lead_paragraph: If unpredictability is a constant in the Middle East, so is the dash to find the next hot spot to nosh — and that’s where Tel Aviv rarely disappoints. Ditto for Jaffa, a part of the Tel Aviv municipality where the Jewish and Arab communities mercifully mix, and often to scrumptious effect. It was in the sea opposite Jaffa that Jonah was famously swallowed by a whale, but now the serious nibbling is happening onshore at the large Jaffa Port Market, which after a partial opening in August is now in high gear.

headline: Daily Report: Health Data Swells Profits in an Industry
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: As doctors and hospitals struggle to make new records systems work, the winners are big companies that lobbied for the legislation that allowed their sales to soar, Julie Creswell reports.
lead_paragraph: As doctors and hospitals struggle to make new digital health records systems work, the clear winners are big companies like Allscripts that lobbied for that legislation and pushed aside smaller competitors, reports Julie Creswell of The New York Times.

headline: Finding Peace During Noisy Trips
abstract: From squawking cellphones to bawling babies, noise is a big part of our travel soundtrack. Here are some ways to find a quiet place within.
lead_paragraph: IT’S CALLED THE QUIET ZONE. Introduced this month by AirAsia X, a budget airline based in Malaysia, this eight-row oasis offers soft lighting and a promise: no children younger than 12 allowed. The cost of keeping them out? An extra $11 to $36 a ticket.

headline: Making Guns in Montana
abstract: Kalispell, Mont., has become the center of a growing firearms industry, particularly for high-end rifles and industrial rifle parts.
lead_paragraph: Kalispell, Mont., has become the center of a growing firearms industry, particularly for high-end rifles and industrial rifle parts.

headline: In Montana Town’s Hands, Guns Mean Cultural Security
abstract: Kalispell, a town in northwestern Montana where gunsmithing helps drive the economy, is not immune to the debate over gun control.
lead_paragraph: BIGFORK, Mont. — Jerry Fisher’s big and careful arms cradled a polished cutout of English walnut, which was aging in his workroom like a fine wine. The slight tapering along one edge gave a ghostly hint of its future as the stock of a handmade hunting rifle.

headline: Treasure Hunters in Uniform: ‘Monuments Men’ Remembered
keywords: ['Art', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Looting']
abstract: As the Germans bombed and invaded Europe during World War II, they also stole millions of works of art from museums, churches, universities and homes. A relatively unknown Allied unit known as the ‘Monuments Men’ tracked down many of these spoils of war–often at great personal risk.
lead_paragraph: We don’t tend to think of World War II as a setting for one of history’s biggest art thefts. Now some veterans of that war are being honored for recovering some of the most famous – and not so famous – art of the Western world: so much of it, in fact, that there’s a good chance you’ve seen some of the thousands of works they have tracked down.

headline: Step 1: Watch a Movie a Day for Two Years. Step 2: Make a Documentary.
abstract: David France says that to make the Oscar-nominated “How to Survive a Plague,” he first had to learn how to make movies.
lead_paragraph: For a first-time filmmaker, David France has had an impressive run with his initial effort, “How to Survive a Plague,” which has ended up being one of the five nominees for the Academy Award for best feature-length documentary.

headline: Health Care Aside, Fewer Jobs Than in 2000
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Without employment in the health care sector, which has added more jobs than any other sector, the United States would have fewer jobs than it did in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Uwe Reinhardt had a fascinating post Friday about the buffer that health care spending has provided in the last few years. Health care has provided a steady contribution to gross domestic product even as other sectors cut back dramatically. He also notes that in the last two decades, it has created more jobs on a net basis than any other sector.

lead_paragraph: Using an iPad as a cash register sounds nifty, but businesses will still need additional gear to swipe credit cards and print receipts. headline: Questioning the Motives Behind Your Financial Decisions
abstract: It is time to give ourselves permission to think about why we make financial decisions and to do so without judgment.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

lead_paragraph: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts plans to add nine new hotels to its roughly 100 properties in the coming year. Much of the expansion is taking place in Asia (including a hotel to open in Zhengzhou, China, rendered above), where six new Meridiens will open. The Starwood-owned brand is among several hotels, including the Marriott and the W, that have announced significant expansions in Asia.

headline: Families in Wartime
abstract: “Red Kite, Blue Kite” and “Fish for Jimmy” are moving examples of why and how picture books can convey the impact of profound historical events.
lead_paragraph: A child needn’t know the historical context, complexity or details of either the Cultural Revolution in China or the Japanese internment in America to sense the trauma they wrought. Even adults recoil from contemplating it. Yet two new picture books offer narratively strong, visually arresting and moving examples of why and how picture books can convey with immediacy and resonance the impact of profound historical events.

headline: Settling Is Not the Only Way to Resolve an Employee Lawsuit
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: A small-business owner need not do anything wrong to be sued. But there are several ways to avoid lawsuits, and to minimize damages if they do occur.
lead_paragraph: Many small-business owners respond to employee lawsuits with grudging acceptance that, regardless of whether the company broke any laws, the sooner it pays a plaintiff to go away, the better. As repugnant as this may sound, it is a cost of doing business. That, at least, is one approach.
