headline: A Quiet Meal, Polluted by Noise
abstract: If you’re driving down the freeway and Aretha comes on, you’re supposed to turn it up. But sometimes loud music is just a pain in the ears.
lead_paragraph: I recently met a friend for lunch at a popular bistro new to both of us. We arrived and quickly found seats by the window. The décor was lovely, and the menu looked terrific.

headline: Same Old Drill? Let Them Wrestle
abstract: The N.F.L. prospects know what kind of tests they are going to face in the combine, so a two-time Super Bowl champion who spent 14 seasons in the league proposes a few changes to the predraft workouts.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Pryce played in the N.F.L. from 1997 to 2010.

headline: Debating Money in Politics
abstract: Nicholas Confessore on the implications of the Supreme Court's decision to hear a challenge to federal campaign contribution limits.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Confessore on the implications of the Supreme Court's decision to hear a challenge to federal campaign contribution limits.

headline: A Funky Gospel Sound Is Resurrected
abstract: The Relatives, once a forgotten gospel group, have been resurrected. Their burning gospel — with touches of psychedelic rock, heavy R&B and 1970s funk — has been released on a new album, “The Electric Word.”
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Gean West says he feels like Abraham, whom God made a father in his dotage. It’s been 43 years since he and his brother Tommie formed the gospel group the Relatives in Dallas and 33 years since the band broke up after releasing a few funky singles but scoring no hits.

headline: The Rove Machine
abstract: Newt Gingrich attacks Karl Rove in yet another example of the fracturing of the right wing.
lead_paragraph: In the continuing struggle for control of the right, the Tea Party Patriots, a Georgia-based group, sent out a fundraising email portraying Karl Rove as a Nazi — and later apologized, claiming an outside vendor had added the doctored image without their knowledge.

headline: Graphic Pop | Anya Hindmarch
abstract: Anya Hindmarch created a domino set extravaganza to show off her graphic-inspired accessories this week in London.
lead_paragraph: Anya Hindmarch created a domino set extravaganza to show off her graphic-inspired accessories this week in London.

headline: How Do You Handle Employee Litigation?
abstract: Do you settle and move on? Or do you fight?
lead_paragraph: For many small-business owners, it has become conventional wisdom that the best way to deal with employee litigation is to settle quickly and move on, regardless of whether the owner or the company has done anything wrong. But that was not the approach taken recently by Jeffrey Herold of West Coast Trends.

headline: Game On at Anya Hindmarch
abstract: The always-whimsical designer Anya Hindmarch created a domino set extravaganza to show off her graphic-inspired accessories this week in London.
lead_paragraph: The always-whimsical designer Anya Hindmarch created a domino set extravaganza to show off her graphic-inspired accessories this week in London. Hindmarch collaborated with set designer Rachel Thomas and world champion domino expert Robin Weijers, who arranged nearly 50,000 colored tiles in the space. As the dominoes tumbled and weaved, the various pieces from the collection were revealed. It was an eye-popping experience, to say the least. Herewith, an exclusive video.

headline: Jesse Jackson Jr. Pleads Guilty: ‘I Lived Off My Campaign’
abstract: As part of a plea agreement, prosecutors will recommend that former Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. receive a sentence of 46 to 57 months in prison.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jesse L. Jackson Jr., the former Democratic representative from Illinois, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to one felony fraud count in connection with his use of $750,000 in campaign money to pay for living expenses and buy items like stuffed animals, elk heads and fur capes.

headline: Amid Confusion, School Bus Drivers Return to Work After Monthlong Strike
abstract: Bus service for New York City students resumed Wednesday, the first of three school days scheduled during what was supposed to be a weeklong winter break.
lead_paragraph: Several drivers could not find their buses. Some of the big yellow vehicles seemed ill prepared for the road, lacking license plates or inspection stickers. At a bus depot in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a driver for Reliant Transportation turned a key in his vehicle’s ignition, but it failed to start.

headline: Street Style: Neon Beanies
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Feb. 11.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Feb. 11.

headline: Trial Offers Rare Look at Work of Hezbollah in Europe
abstract: Hossam Taleb Yaacoub said he staked out locations frequented by Israelis in Cyprus and acted as a courier for Hezbollah inside the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — In a little-noticed trial in a small courtroom here on Wednesday, a 24-year-old man provided a rare look inside a covert global war between Israel and Iran, admitting that he is an operative of the militant group Hezbollah, for which he acted as a courier in Europe and staked out locations in this port city that Israelis were known to frequent.

headline: Caffeine Linked to Lower Birth Weight Babies
abstract: Drinking caffeinated beverages while pregnant may raise the risk of having a lower birth weight baby, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: New research suggests that drinking caffeinated drinks during pregnancy raises the risk of having a low birth weight baby.

headline: Harriet Jacobs’s War
abstract: What a slave-turned-activist aid worker found in Northern Virginia.
lead_paragraph: By early 1863, the former slave Harriet Jacobs was in better health than she’d been in years. Nearly two decades earlier, she had escaped to freedom after years hidden away in the garret above her grandmother’s home in Edenton, N.C. The confinement – within a crawlspace 9 feet long, 7 feet wide and 3 feet high – had been physically punishing, she noted in her narrative, “Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl.”

headline: Carbon Trading Program Falters in Europe
abstract: As Europe’s experience has shown, getting carbon pricing right is not easy. Is carbon pricing and the trading of permits the best way to cut greenhouse gasses?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just as President Barack Obama is trying to persuade Americans that a cap and trade system is the way to curb carbon emissions, the world’s flagship program in Europe is in danger of failing. The price of carbon traded in Europe has collapsed to around 5 euros per metric ton compared with 30 euros a few years ago, as I discuss in my Green column.

headline: A Revolving Door in Washington With Spin, but Less Visibility
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The important fights in Washington are happening away from the media gaze. For lobbyists, the real targets are regulators and staff members for lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Obsess all you’d like about President Obama’s nomination of Mary Jo White to head the Securities and Exchange Commission. Who heads the agency is vital, but important fights in Washington are happening in quiet rooms, away from the media gaze.

headline: Yankees Cautious After Hughes Injures His Back
abstract: Pitcher Phil Hughes, penciled in as the No. 4 starter for the Yankees, injured his back on Monday in a fielding drill and could be sidelined for two weeks.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Phil Hughes arrived at camp penciled in as the Yankees’ No. 4 starter, and he felt his work over the winter had put him in good shape. After refining his mechanics and dropping that troublesome cutter from his repertory, he looked forward to playing a steady role this season.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 20
abstract: A demonstration by railway porters in New Delhi.

headline: Still in Previews on Broadway, ‘Cinderella’ Took In $1 Million Last Week
abstract: The Broadway musical “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” achieved a relatively rare feat last week, grossing more than $1 million even though the show is still in preview performances.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” achieved a relatively rare feat last week, grossing more than $1 million even though the show is still in preview performances and has no star actors, according to box office data released on Tuesday.

headline: The Miami Mess, Unraveled
abstract: University of Miami president Donna Shalala has pushed back against the N.C.A.A.
lead_paragraph: I don’t do this very often – and certainly not as often as I should – but this blog post, by Vishnu Parasuraman, who writes for a University of Miami fan site called Sebastian’s Pub, is worth a read. It is a devastating analysis of the N.C.A.A.’s bogus investigation into its own unethical behavior in conducting its investigation of the University of Miami’s basketball and football programs. I couldn’t have said it better myself.

headline: Biden Says Get a Double-Barreled Shotgun
abstract: During an online forum on Facebook hosted by Parents magazine, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. commented on gun ownership for personal protection.
lead_paragraph: During an online forum on Facebook hosted by Parents magazine, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. commented on gun ownership for personal protection.

headline: Adding Fitness to Your Itinerary
abstract: Struggling to stay healthy while logging heavy miles on the road? An exercise physiologist offers travel fitness tips that start with what you do at home.
lead_paragraph: Heavy dinners. Endless meetings. Delayed flights. Uncomfortable hotel beds. Business travelers contend with them all, and that takes a toll.

headline: In West Vancouver, a Corner Apartment With Pacific Views
abstract: A two-bedroom on the 12th floor of a high-rise is on the market for $1,587,000.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom on the 12th floor of a high-rise is on the market for $1,587,000.

headline: House Hunting in ... Canada
abstract: Concerns about global financial turmoil have made buyers cautious.
lead_paragraph: TWO-BEDROOM WITH OCEAN VIEWS IN WEST VANCOUVER

headline: What Front-Page Choices Say About The Times’s Priorities
abstract: There is little overlap among the major newspapers — at least on this day.
lead_paragraph: In the digital age, the matter of what stories are picked for front-page display in the print edition may seem archaic. Who cares, one might reasonably ask.

headline: The Voting Is Over: Those Jazzy Envelopes, Please
abstract: The Academy’s deadline for voting, Tuesday afternoon, has officially passed. So let the non-campaign-oriented parties begin.
lead_paragraph: The hard part of the 85th Oscar season is over, finally — and that includes referring to it as the 85th season.

headline: Biden Shotgun Advice Draws Quizzical Response
abstract: Not every American has Secret Service protection, so Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has some advice for protecting one’s self and home: Get a shotgun, just as he has.
lead_paragraph: Not every American has Secret Service protection, so Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has some advice for protecting one’s self and home: Get a shotgun, just as he has.

headline: Palestinian Filmmaker Detained at Los Angeles Airport
abstract: The co-director of “5 Broken Cameras” was detained with his family at Los Angeles International Airport even after they produced his official Oscar invitation.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian filmmaker Emad Burnat, the co-director of the Oscar-nominated documentary “5 Broken Cameras,” was detained at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday.

headline: Lebanese Ex-Minister and Syrian Official Accused of Death Plot
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A Lebanese military court charged a former government information minister and a Syrian security official of a conspiracy to kill political and religious leaders and foment sectarian strife.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Lebanese military court investigative judge on Wednesday charged a former government information minister and a high-ranking accomplice in the Syrian military of a conspiracy to kill Lebanese political and religious leaders and foment sectarian strife, recommending the death penalty for both.

headline: Leading Off: A Push and a Shove
abstract: After Cal Coach Mike Montgomery shoved a star player to make him play better, some sports columnists pushed back and the coach voiced his regrets.
lead_paragraph: Is it ever O.K. for a college coach to shove a player?

headline: Big Sensor, Small Body: A Concept That Works
abstract: Sony introduces the RX1, the first compact full-frame camera. But “compact” and “full frame” can’t coexist, or can they?
lead_paragraph: When you’re shopping for a camera, you have a million specs and features to consider. Size, weight, battery life, megapixels, zoom power. ... Can you guess which aspect consumers consider most important?

headline: Cleaning Up Kunming’s Waterways
abstract: Millions of dollars have been spent to clean up the waterways around Kunming, the largest city in Yunnan Province. But hurdles remain.
lead_paragraph: Millions of dollars have been spent to clean up the waterways around Kunming, the largest city in Yunnan Province. But hurdles remain.

headline: Banksy Work, Taken From London Wall, Turns Up in Miami, for Auction
abstract: A 2012 work by the British artist Banksy has vanished from a wall in London and turned up at an auction house in Miami.
lead_paragraph: “Slave Labor (Bunting Boy),” a 2012 work by the mysterious British graffiti artist Banksy, has vanished from a wall outside a discount store in London, and turned up at an auction house in Miami. And the town council in Haringey, the north London borough where the Banksy work appeared last May and disappeared last week, say that they want the piece returned.

headline: Pope Considers Speeding Up Succession Process
abstract: The Vatican said Wednesday that Pope Benedict XVI was considering passing a law that would begin the conclave to elect the next pontiff sooner than currently allowed.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — A week ahead of his expected resignation, Pope Benedict XVI is considering changing the rules for the election of his successor, potentially making the process start sooner, the Vatican said on Wednesday.

headline: Fewer Bags Went Astray
abstract: Mishandled baggage was at an all-time low for air travelers in 2012, according to a Department of Transportation report.
lead_paragraph: Lost, damaged, delayed or pilfered luggage is a perennial headache for many air travelers, but 2012 was a good year. The nation’s 15 largest airlines reported the lowest annual rate of mishandled baggage in 25 years. The carriers posted an average rate of 3.09 reports of mishandled baggage per 1,000 passengers, the lowest rate since this data was first reported in September 1987, according to a recent Air Travel Consumer Report issued by the Department of Transportation. The carriers with the best rates last year were Virgin America, AirTran Airways and JetBlue Airways.

headline: Hispanics: California’s Next Majority
abstract: How the state’s demographics have changed since 1980.
lead_paragraph: How the state’s demographics have changed since 1980.

headline: Report Says Stanford Is First University to Raise $1 Billion in a Single Year
abstract: The California university announced earlier this month that its five-year capital campaign took in $6.23 billion.
lead_paragraph: Stanford last year became the first university to raise more than $1 billion in a single year, according to the Council for Aid to Education’s annual college fund-raising survey.

headline: Two Plays Planned for Broadway Are Delayed
abstract: Larry Kaye, who had planned this spring to produce both “The Miss Firecracker Contest” by Beth Henley and “The Velocity of Autumn” by Eric Coble, said that he still hoped to bring them to Broadway, but had no firm plans.
lead_paragraph: Two plays that had been announced for Broadway this spring – Beth Henley’s “Miss Firecracker Contest” and Eric Coble’s “Velocity of Autumn” – have been postponed, according to the lead producer of both shows.

headline: Talking Talent | Dane DeHaan
abstract: The actor and face of Prada’s spring/summer campaign talks about his work, fitness routine and music tastes.
lead_paragraph: With a slew of films scheduled for 2013, his golden good-boy looks (reminiscent of a young Leonardo DiCaprio) and a coveted role in next year’s “The Amazing Spider Man” sequel, Dane DeHaan is topping every director’s wish list. The 26-year-old Pennsylvania native (he also happens to be the face of the spring/summer Prada campaign) will star opposite Bradley Cooper and Ryan Gosling in “The Place Beyond the Pines,” as well as play Lucien Carr, a pivotal member of the Beat Generation, in “Kill Your Darlings.”

headline: F.C.C. Moves to Ease Wireless Congestion
keywords: ['Radio Spectrum', 'Wireless Communications', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The commission proposed to make a big part of the spectrum, some of which is in government hands, available for unlicensed devices like Wi-Fi routers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission took a step on Wednesday to relieve growing congestion on Wi-Fi networks in hotels, airports and homes, where Americans increasingly use multiple data-hungry tablets, smartphones and other devices for wireless communications.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 20
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including pictures from baseball training camps in Florida and ski areas in Italy.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including pictures from baseball training camps in Florida and ski areas in Italy.

headline: In Search of Republican Reformers
abstract: Conservative reformers have ideas, but conspicuously lack a standard-bearer.
lead_paragraph: In the last week there have been not one but four impressive pieces on fixing the Republican Party’s policy problem — one by Ramesh Ponnuru in the pages of this newspaper, one by James Pethokoukis in National Review, a lengthy essay by Pete Wehner and Michael Gerson in Commentary, and a sketch of a right-of-center health care reform by Douglas Holtz-Eakin and Avik Roy for Reuters. The proposals vary a bit, but there’s an essential unity to the ideas that they promote. To borrow Gerson and Wehner’s language, they’re all addressed to voters who “now regard the Republican Party as …wholly out of touch with ordinary Americans,” and they all take the obligations of governing more seriously than a lot of recent right-wing rhetoric has done. This, from the Commentary essay, is a solid formulation of the pieces’ common theme:

headline: Back in Her 'G.M.A.' Anchor Seat
abstract: After battling a life-threatening illness, Robin Roberts goes back to work. | Blogger Andrew Sullivan on “The Dish.” | Nickelodeon releases a new app. | David Pogue reviews the Sony Cyber-shot RX1.
lead_paragraph: After battling a life-threatening illness, Robin Roberts goes back to work. | Blogger Andrew Sullivan on “The Dish.” | Nickelodeon releases a new app. | David Pogue reviews the Sony Cyber-shot RX1.

headline: Deal Between Office Depot and OfficeMax Not Quite Ready for Release
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Office Supplies and Equipment']
abstract: The botched announcement is only one reason the deal looks half-baked. The companies also didn’t clearly address the issues of governance and antitrust.
lead_paragraph: The just-announced merger of Office Max and Office Depot has some unfortunate signs that the deal was not ready for prime time.

headline: Tibetan Teenagers Die in Double Self-Immolation
abstract: The two were among the youngest Tibetans to kill themselves in protest, and the act was a rare instance in which Tibetans committed self-immolation together.
lead_paragraph: Two Tibetan teenagers killed themselves by self-immolation on Tuesday to protest Chinese rule in Tibet, according to reports on Wednesday by a Tibet advocacy group and Radio Free Asia. The two were among the youngest Tibetans to kill themselves in protest, and the act was a rare instance in which Tibetans committed self-immolation together.

headline: Stage Scenes: Laura Osnes
abstract: A look at some of the actress’s past stage performances.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the actress’s past stage performances.

headline: A Small Camera, but It’s Big Inside
abstract: The Sony’s Cyber-Shot RX1 fits in a coat pocket, but it has a full-frame sensor that lets it take low-light pictures and blurry-background portraits perhaps better than any other pocketable camera. It’s expensive ($2,800), but it’s also astonishing.
lead_paragraph: The Sony’s Cyber-Shot RX1 fits in a coat pocket, but it has a full-frame sensor that lets it take low-light pictures and blurry-background portraits perhaps better than any other pocketable camera. It’s expensive ($2,800), but it’s also astonishing.

headline: Google Will Offer Its Glasses to Select Few
abstract: Google will make Glass, its augmented reality glasses, available to people who apply, are chosen and willing to pay $1,500 to try them.
lead_paragraph: Google is letting a larger segment of the public test its futuristic eyeglasses.

headline: Even Clowns Can Have Aging Knees
abstract: Decades after they created the Broadway success “Fool Moon,” the clown-actors Bill Irwin and David Shiner have reunited to create “Old Hats,” now playing at Signature Center.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, while he was performing on Broadway in “Fool Moon,” the rascally clown David Shiner dumped a bucket of popcorn on my head. Last month he tried to steal my wallet.

headline: Alberta Ferretti: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Walters Art Museum Names New Director
abstract: Julia Marciari-Alexander, deputy director for curatorial affairs at the San Diego Museum of Art, is replacing Gary Vikan.
lead_paragraph: Julia Marciari-Alexander, deputy director for curatorial affairs at the San Diego Museum of Art, has been appointed executive director of the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore. Ms. Marciari-Alexander is replacing Gary Vikan, who is stepping down after more than 27 years at the Walters, 18 of them as its director.

headline: Can Republicans Win the Senate in 2014?
abstract: Twenty-one of the 35 Senate seats up for election in 2014 are now held by Democrats, and most of those 35 states are Republican leaning. But that is not necessarily enough to make Republicans the favorite to win control.
lead_paragraph: Democrats, faced with a daunting set of Senate races in 2012, not only survived but thrived, adding two seats to their majority.

headline: Fed Meeting Shows Dissent on Measures to Lift Job Growth
abstract: A vocal minority of Federal Reserve officials has questioned moves to reduce joblessness, but supporters of those efforts remain firmly in control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are widening divisions among officials of the Federal Reserve over the value of its efforts to reduce unemployment, but the authors of its bond-buying policy remain firmly in control, according to an official account of the January meeting of the Fed’s policy-making committee.

headline: Conservative News Outlets Cite Fake Group in Opposition to Hagel
abstract: In their opposition to the nomination of Chuck Hagel to be defense secretary, several conservative news outlets have cited a report that Mr. Hagel received money from ‘Friends of Hamas,’ which does not exist.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, the conservative Web site Breitbart.com reported that former Senator Chuck Hagel had received financing from a group called “Friends of Hamas.’’

headline: Now Showing | Karl Lagerfeld for Fendi
abstract: This new video for Fendi features the brand’s spring collection, and airs exclusively on T.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld’s new video for Fendi, which is called “Peplum People” and features the brand’s spring collection, stars models Kati Nescher, Saskia De Brauw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier. Watch it exclusively here.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld for Fendi
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld’s exclusive new video for Fendi, which features the brand’s spring collection, stars Kati Nescher, Saskia De Braw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld’s exclusive new video for Fendi, which features the brand’s spring collection, stars Kati Nescher, Saskia De Braw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier.

headline: Cat Trapped?  Call in the Spelunkers
abstract: A pet that didn’t come home after the Feb. 8 snowstorm needed rescuing when he was heard crying in a shaft between two buildings in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: For most New Yorkers, the Feb. 8 snowstorm was at worst a mild inconvenience. But one Brooklynite – a Norwegian forest cat named Venusaur – braved the snow while trapped in a deep crevice only two feet wide between two buildings.

headline: ‘Hobbit’ Makeup, Yak Hair and All
abstract: Peter Swords King, a makeup designer for “The Hobbit,” discusses his Oscar-nominated work on the film.
lead_paragraph: The dwarfs who accompany Bilbo Baggins in “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey” may be small, but their hair and beards live large. Pounds of yak hair were used to create their elaborate wigs, and an intricate plan was followed to make sure every braid, and every bulbous prosthetic nose, was in place.

headline: Homes for $700,000
abstract: Properties in New Orleans, New Mexico and Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: Properties in New Orleans, New Mexico and Wisconsin.

headline: Apologies All Around for Office Depot Announcement Mishap
abstract: “When two big Fortune 500 companies merge, occasionally mishaps happen,” says OfficeMax’s chief executive, Ravi Saligram.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Office Depot‘s inadvertent announcement of its $1.19 billion deal for OfficeMax, it’s all apologies.

headline: Unexpected Detour Leads to a New Home: Israel
abstract: Ramel Bradley grew up in Brooklyn dreaming of an N.B.A. career. He is playing professionally at 28, but he plays for a team in Israel, not the United States.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Brooklyn dreaming of playing in the N.B.A., Ramel Bradley, now 28, never imagined he would one day have his name on the back of an Israeli league jersey.

headline: What You Get for ... $700,000
abstract: A 19th-century cottage in New Orleans, a converted church in New Mexico and a Tudor in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Getting Along Without God
abstract: In this week’s briefs: the failure of “ethics beyond religion”; love in other realms; Ronald Dworkin, and more.
lead_paragraph: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Datsyuk vs. Five Nashville Players; Datsyuk Wins
abstract: Detroit’s Pavel Datsyuk scored one of the best goals of the season Tuesday night against Nashville.
lead_paragraph: By the end of most seasons, Detroit forward Pavel Datsyuk has contributed several candidates for goal of the year. He registered a leading contender in Tuesday night’s game against Nashville, which was mesmerizing even by Datsyuk’s high standards. He basically grabbed the puck in the Red Wings’ zone, stick-handled past every one of the five Predators on the ice and bounced a puck past goalie Pekka Rinne.

headline: An Interview With Andrew Sullivan
abstract: The editor and founder of The Dish discusses how his readers, and not advertisers, are financing his newly independent blog.
lead_paragraph: The editor and founder of The Dish discusses how his readers, and not advertisers, are financing his newly independent blog.

headline: Young Drivers Most Likely to Pay Insurance Penalty
keywords: ['Insurance', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: Just 15 percent of drivers 50 and older faced higher insurance rates after getting a ticket, a survey finds.
lead_paragraph: Younger drivers are the most likely to get hit with higher insurance rates after getting a ticket, a new report finds.

headline: TimesCast: An Interview with Andrew Sullivan
abstract: The editor and founder of The Dish discusses how his readers, and not advertisers, are financing his newly independent blog.
lead_paragraph: The editor and founder of The Dish discusses how his readers, and not advertisers, are financing his newly independent blog.

headline: Sanford’s South Carolina Campaign Begins With Appeal for Second Chance
abstract: Mark Sanford acknowledges the scandal that all but destroyed his political career in his first ad for a United States House race, a tactic tried by some other politicians seeking a comeback after infidelity.
lead_paragraph: In a Congressional race with 16 Republicans, high name recognition is key. Though in the case of Mark Sanford, South Carolina’s former governor whose very public confession of marital infidelity seemed to end his national political aspirations less than four years ago, there can also be a downside.

headline: WCBS-TV Anchor Resigns After Arrest
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: Rob Morrison, who denied that he assaulted his wife, announced that he had left WCBS-TV a day after his arraignment on charges of strangulation, threatening and disorderly conduct.
lead_paragraph: Rob Morrison, a news anchor for WCBS-TV in New York, said on Wednesday that he had resigned from his job after his weekend arrest on charges of choking his wife during a domestic dispute at their home in Darien, Conn.

headline: Self-Discovery in a Silk Tracksuit
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coats', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Sneakers']
abstract: At the new Lanvin men’s store, pushing the edges of comfort without being immune to it.
lead_paragraph: It is possible to like a look and not crave it, to appreciate it and yet know it’s for someone else. Clothes, like photographs and poems and reality TV shows, work on several levels. Sometimes it’s best to stand back, out of the blast radius.

headline: Jane Lynch Will Be Miss Hannigan in ‘Annie’
abstract: The actress, best known for her role on television’s “Glee,” will join the Broadway production for eight weeks beginning May 16.
lead_paragraph: Jane Lynch, who knows a thing or two about keeping young women in line as the fearsome cheerleading coach Sue Sylvester on “Glee,” will soon have a new brood to boss around: Beginning May 16, she will portray the blustery orphan-keeper Miss Hannigan in the Broadway revival of “Annie.”

headline: Armstrong Refuses to Meet With U.S. Anti-Doping Agency
abstract: The cyclist Lance Armstrong did not notify the United States Anti-Doping Agency by Wednesday’s deadline that he would agree to provide it full disclosure about his doping.
lead_paragraph: Lance Armstrong has refused, once again, to meet with the United States Anti-Doping Agency and give testimony under oath about the doping practices that fueled most of his career as a cyclist.

headline: With Roberts Back, ‘Good Morning America’ Looks to Widen Ratings Gap Over ‘Today’
abstract: Though no one at the network said so aloud on Wednesday, ABC is hopeful that having Ms. Roberts back on the set will help “Good Morning America” widen the ratings gap with its archrival, NBC’s “Today” show.
lead_paragraph: Robin Roberts is back from a nearly six-month medical leave of absence, a fact that ABC’s “Good Morning America” celebrated with a special broadcast on Wednesday.

headline: Shia LaBeouf Withdraws From Broadway’s ‘Orphans’
abstract: Mr. LaBeouf, a star of films like “Transformers,” “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” and “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” was to have made his Broadway debut in the play alongside Alec Baldwin.
lead_paragraph: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

headline: Designers of Aston-Martin Rapide S Embrace Golden Ratio
abstract: “Balanced from any angle, each exterior line of Rapide S works in concert and every proportion is precisely measured to create a lithe, pure form,” the automaker says.
lead_paragraph: With the first Aston Martin Rapide, which went on sale in 2010, Marek Reichman, the Aston design chief, and his staff impressed their colleagues around the world. They figured out how to stretch a classic two-seater sports car, the DB-9, to accommodate four without making it look gawky or awkward.

headline: Immigration Debate Hits Home
abstract: Ashley Parker reports on John McCain’s push for an immigration overhaul in Washington while facing strong resistance at home in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Parker reports on John McCain’s push for an immigration overhaul in Washington while facing strong resistance at home in Arizona.

headline: Model Diary | Karmen Pedaru
abstract: The green-eyed face of Gucci’s spring campaign splits her time between New York and Rome.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Milan Fashion Week! Karmen Pedaru is the green-eyed 22-year-old Estonian beauty who walked in today’s Gucci show — she’s also the face of the current spring campaign. Before her career on the catwalk, she was a goalkeeper on her national soccer team. She’s had a busy few weeks so far, having clocked Michael Kors and Marc Jacobs in New York and Burberry and Tom Ford in London, so don’t be surprised if you see her relaxing somewhere like the bar at Hotel Principe di Savoia, her favorite watering hole in Milan.

headline: Taxing Carbon
abstract: A Xinhua report suggests the Chinese government is working on a relatively modest tax on carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: Long considered the biggest holdout in climate change negotiations, China said this week that the country would implement new taxes designed to curb greenhouse gas emissions. Officials in Beijing provided few details, but a report by the state-owned Xinhua news service suggested that the government is working on a relatively modest plan.

headline: Teachers’ Union Sues Over State’s Tax Cap
keywords: ['Property Taxes', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: New York State United Teachers filed a lawsuit asserting that a property tax cap, one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s signature measures, interferes with local control of schools.
lead_paragraph: The New York State teachers’ union filed a lawsuit on Wednesday challenging the constitutionality of the state’s cap on annual increases in local property taxes, one of the signature measures of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s time in office.

headline: Mother Asks Putin to Return 2nd Son After Death in Texas
abstract: The birth mother of a 3-year-old boy who died in Texas pleaded with the Russian president to restore her parental rights over her 2-year-old son, Kirill.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian mother of two young boys who were adopted by a Texas couple requested on Wednesday that the younger child be returned to her, after his brother died under unclear circumstances in a case that has given new impetus to a long-running controversy over foreign adoptions.

headline: Nurturing a Star of Opera’s Next Generation
abstract: Hao Jiang Tian, a 19-year veteran of the Metropolitan Opera, has helped  Guanqun Yu, a young singer, find success on the same stage.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Lawyers Question New York Cardinal in Milwaukee Suits
keywords: ['Priests', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Timothy M. Dolan, the New York archbishop, spent hours in a legal deposition concerning the sexual abuse of children by priests in the last archdiocese he led.
lead_paragraph: A week before Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan is set to leave New York for Rome, where his name is being floated as a candidate for pope, he was questioned in Manhattan for three hours on Wednesday behind closed doors in a legal deposition concerning the sexual abuse of children by priests.

headline: Moving Pictures, and the Empty Spaces Left Behind
abstract: One of the Britain’s most significant photography collections is on the move, and Pete James is documenting it on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: I’m an avid Instagram follower, and every day I look forward to posts by Pete James, curator of photographic collections at the Library of Birmingham in England, which for nearly 40 years has housed one of Britain’s most significant photography collections. The collection, which comprises approximately 3.5 million images spanning from 1841 to today, is currently closed to the public as the staff prepares for a move to a new building, which is still under construction but expected to open on Sept. 3.

headline: After First Round, Mother Nature Is in the Lead
abstract: Sleet that turned to snow suspended play for the day at the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship in Marana, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — Jason Day stood on the seventh hole at the Golf Club at Dove Mountain, staring at a sky that looked like a pewter carpet unfurling. Mother Nature was coming up quickly on Day and his first-round opponent, Zach Johnson. They clearly were going to have to let her play through at the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship.

headline: Quel Brouhaha! A Diatribe on Unions Irks the French
abstract: An American executive delivered a broadside as he rejected France’s plea to take over a Goodyear plant scheduled for closure.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “How stupid do you think we are?”

headline: Effects of Bullying Last Into Adulthood, Study Finds
abstract: Victims of bullying, and bullies themselves, are more likely to have an anxiety disorder, panic disorders and other psychiatric problems as adults, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Victims of bullying at school, and bullies themselves, are more likely to experience psychiatric problems in childhood, studies have shown. Now researchers have found that elevated risk of psychiatric trouble extends into adulthood, sometimes even a decade after the intimidation has ended.

headline: Times Company to Sell New England Media Holdings
abstract: The company said the sale of the properties, which include The Boston Globe and Boston.com, would allow it to focus its energy and resources on its flagship newspaper.
lead_paragraph: 9:22 p.m. | Updated

headline: James Beard Awards: Geography vs. Quality
abstract: Of the 29 semifinalists for Best New Restaurant award, only one is in New York City.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to live in New York to believe that the city has some of the best restaurants in the country. This is widely acknowledged by just about everybody who keeps up to date on food — everybody except, apparently, the men and women who oversee the restaurant and chef awards given by the James Beard Foundation.

headline: A Farmers’ Market in Warmer Climes
abstract: In Southern California, a year-round farmers market where the customers are wearing flip-flops.
lead_paragraph: We know you’re tired of winter, that you want to toss off your coat and go out to the farmers’ market for the kind of fresh produce you can find around New York only in the summer. Maybe it will help to watch this video by Jacob Mann, of the SoCo Farmers’ Market in Costa Mesa, Calif., where the stalls are piled high with fresh strawberries, cucumbers and red and golden cherries, and a girl in a sleeveless dress waits her turn at a truck selling baked goods. The video comes via The Huffington Post.

headline: Where the Nudity Is Just Skin Deep
abstract: Juliana F. May and her troupe, Maydance, presented her “Commentary = not thing” at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: The first sounds we hear in Juliana F. May’s “Commentary = not thing” are heavy footsteps. Three dancers take purposeful strides across the stage before breaking into skipping runs. Not long after that comes heavy breathing. It’s the kind of dance in which effort is on defiant display, emotions run high, and bodies are heard as well as seen.

headline: A Peek at Works in Progress
abstract: The theater composer Adam Guettel unveiled some of his latest songs and performed some of his older ones at 54 Below, in a rare New York engagement.
lead_paragraph: The theater composer Adam Guettel is so overwhelmingly gifted that any news of his activities stirs the kind of fervent expectations that surround Stephen Sondheim, and before that, Leonard Bernstein. On Tuesday evening at 54 Below this handsome, smiling grandson of Richard Rodgers opened an exceedingly rare New York engagement in which he previewed several new songs from two works in progress: a musical based on the Danny Boyle movie “Millions,” and an adaptation of “Days of Wine and Roses.”

headline: Now Showing | Trevor Paglen
abstract: In his latest project — philosophically and technologically sophisticated — the artist tackles some huge questions.
lead_paragraph: In his latest project, “The Last Pictures,” the photographer Trevor Paglen tackles some huge questions: What is an image? What happens to an image when you detach it from history? And what is the future? Parts of the project, which began five years ago, are on display at Metro Pictures gallery in Chelsea. The project culminated last fall when a Russian space shuttle launched from Kazakhstan carrying 100 images (chosen or shot by Paglen) encoded onto a silicone disc that is meant to remain in orbit long after the planet is gone. In other words, short of some art-world space race, Paglen’s work will ostensibly be the only surviving piece of art history in the universe in a few billion years.

headline: Romney Will Address Conservative Conference
abstract: When Republican activists gather for the annual Conservative Political Action Conference in March, a long roster of the party’s rising stars will be on hand.
lead_paragraph: 3:59 p.m. | Updated  When Republican activists gather for the annual Conservative Political Action Conference in March, a long roster of the party’s rising stars will be on hand.

headline: Egyptians in Port City Reject President’s Effort to Mollify Them
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Demonstrators shut down a major port at the Mediterranean entrance to the Suez Canal, ignoring President Mohamed Morsi’s promises of economic development.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Thousands of demonstrators in the Egyptian city of Port Said temporarily shut down the road to a major port at the Mediterranean entrance to the Suez Canal on Wednesday, brushing off moves by President Mohamed Morsi to placate the city with promises of economic development.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: An angry bride confronts a wedding guest who did not bring a gift, and how to help guests reduce the cost of attending a destination wedding.
lead_paragraph: When the Guest Shows Up, but the Gift Doesn’t

headline: Boeing to Propose Redesign of 787 Battery to F.A.A.
abstract: A top executive will meet with agency officials on Friday to outline efforts to get the Boeing 787 back in the air.
lead_paragraph: Boeing has developed possible fixes for the battery problems in its grounded 787 jets and could have them back in the air within two months, industry and federal officials said Wednesday.

headline: Another Prize for Robert Caro
abstract: “Lyndon Johnson: The Passage of Power,” the fourth volume in Mr. Caro’s biography, has won a New-York Historical Society book prize.
lead_paragraph: Robert Caro will add yet another item to his groaning literary trophy cabinet in April when he collects the New-York Historical Society’s American History Book Prize for “Lyndon Johnson: The Passage of Power,” the fourth volume in his continuing biography of the 36th president. The award, previously won by Doris Kearns Goodwin, Ron Chernow and Drew Gilpin Faust, among others, comes with a $50,000 prize, an engraved medal and the title “American Historian Laureate.”

headline: Struggling Sabres Part Ways With Ruff
abstract: The Sabres fired Coach Lindy Ruff, the longest-tenured N.H.L. coach, in the middle of his 14th season behind the Buffalo bench.
lead_paragraph: 6:32 p.m. | Updated The Sabres fired Coach Lindy Ruff, the longest-tenured N.H.L. coach, Wednesday afternoon in the middle of his 15th season behind the Buffalo bench.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Sony RX1
abstract: David Pogue reviews Sony’s Cyber-shot RX1.
lead_paragraph: David Pogue reviews Sony’s Cyber-shot RX1.

headline: New Era for Coach, Team and Region
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Interscholastic Athletics', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: After 50 years at the helm, Vito Montelli, 80, stepped down last year as coach of the St. Joseph High School basketball team in Trumbull, Conn.
lead_paragraph: TRUMBULL, Conn. — Over the last 50 years, Vito Montelli led the boys basketball team at St. Joseph High School to 878 victories, the most by a New England high school basketball coach. St. Joe’s, as its devoted alumni call it, also won 11 state titles. The Basketball Hall of Fame announced this month that Montelli would receive a Morgan Wootten Lifetime Achievement Award.

headline: John McCain Faces Angry Town Hall
abstract: At a town hall in Tucson, Senator John McCain answered questions on immigration and border patrol from an angry crowd.
lead_paragraph: At a town hall in Tucson, Senator John McCain answered questions on immigration and border patrol from an angry crowd.

headline: A Newspaperman Dies. His Son Chases the Story.
abstract: “After Visiting Friends,” Michael Hainey’s investigation of his father’s death, leads him into the vanished world of Chicago newspapers.
lead_paragraph: Michael Hainey’s mother taught him about Michael Corleone. She loved “The Godfather,” and her favorite scene was its last one. She explained how the movie transformed Michael into the ruthless tough guy he never intended to be, and how at the end Michael devastatingly shuts out his wife, Kay. She asks Michael if he ordered the murder of his sister’s husband. “Don’t ask me about my business, Kay,” Al Pacino menacingly replies.

headline: A South Korean City Full of Food, History and Bargains
abstract: I spend my life looking for places like Jeonju, a city barely known to Western travelers. It’s a paradise for both lovers of Korean food and cheap prices.
lead_paragraph: There are two phrases to learn if you visit Jeonju, a 650,000-person city – and a paradise for Korean food-lovers — three hours by bus south of Seoul.

headline: Independent Booksellers Sue Amazon and Publishers Over E-Books
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The suit alleges that contracts between the big six publishers and Amazon restrict independent bookstores from getting into the e-book market.
lead_paragraph: Three independent, brick-and-mortar bookstores have filed a lawsuit against Amazon and the big six publishers, claiming that they are violating antitrust laws by collaborating to keep small sellers out of the e-book market.

headline: The Daily Do | Gucci
abstract: The modern, slippery-when-wet look of Gucci’s half-up is both sinuous and sophisticated.
lead_paragraph: The modern, slippery-when-wet look of Gucci’s half-up is both sinuous and sophisticated.

headline: MetroCards Become More Flexible
abstract: Bus and train riders can now fill their MetroCards with both unlimited-ride time and pay-per-ride dollars, and avoid the need for a second card, which soon will cost $1.
lead_paragraph: The bad news: subway and bus fares are still going up next month. The good news: paying them just got a little easier.

headline: A Stephen Burrows Retrospective
abstract: The designer, known for his disco-era look of rainbow jersey dresses, is once again having a moment.
lead_paragraph: The designer, known for his disco-era look of rainbow jersey dresses, is once again having a moment.

headline: Don’t Forget About Stephen
abstract: The pioneering African-American designer, Stephen Burrows wants to make a comeback, and a show at the Museum of the City of New York may help.
lead_paragraph: STEPHEN BURROWS IS NOT making another comeback. At least not right now, when he is once again having a moment.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
abstract: Highlights in style news from PPR’s new acquisition to Michael Kors’s new men’s wear store.
lead_paragraph: The French luxury conglomerate PPR  has acquired a majority stake in the label of the British fashion designer Christopher Kane.

headline: Will You Pass On Your Junk Food Addictions?
abstract: I know snack foods are engineered to create “crave.” But it’s the emotional connection that really makes me reach for the bag, and that’s a connection I don’t want my children to form.
lead_paragraph: Like so many of you, I clicked on the article in the middle of The New York Times’s home page, “The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food,” and the image that greeted me — unmistakably that of a nacho cheese Doritos chip — presented a problem.

headline: A Life in Basketball
abstract: Vito Montelli led the St. Joseph High School basketball team to 878 wins, the most by a New England high school basketball coach.
lead_paragraph: Vito Montelli led the St. Joseph High School basketball team to 878 wins, the most by a New England high school basketball coach.

headline: Staging Stories That Are Torn From the News
abstract: Two productions in Chicago, “Teddy Ferrara” and “columbinus,” exemplify the challenges that playwrights face when they draw on a specific real-life events.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Conflict, suffering, man’s reliable inhumanity to man: the world will never be without the raw material for wrenching drama. A single issue of a daily newspaper could supply fodder for at least a dozen stage tragedies. But there are many ways of writing about the sorrows of human experience, even when playwrights are drawing on a specific real-world calamity. Different challenges too. Stick to the facts, and the story may fail to take dramatic shape. Stray too far into the imagination, and it may lose the power it derives from allegiance to actual events.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 4
abstract: Video highlights of Wednesday’s Round of 16 matches in the Champions League between A.C. Milan and Barcelona; and Galatasaray and Schalke.
lead_paragraph: Matchday 4 in the Round of 16 in the UEFA Champions League. After a winter break, we continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: Playful Meets Artisanal in Paris
abstract: A former contestant on the French edition of “Top Chef” serves a bold, improvisational menu at his 42-seat restaurant, which opened in June.
lead_paragraph: As exciting new takes on the bistro, including Le Chateaubriand and Septime, began to attract food-conscious locals to the once-grungy 11th Arrondissement in Paris, the district matured, paving the way for other ambitious young chefs.

headline: On the Red Carpet, No Blemishes Allowed
abstract: In Hollywood, the rush is on for facials, which now involve some expensive, futuristic-sounding procedures.
lead_paragraph: With all the clamor about gowns and jewels, one element of Academy Awards preparation often goes unnoticed. In hotel suites, private houses and medical offices across Los Angeles, facialists and dermatologists are now wielding microcurrent wands, oxygen blasters and laser beams in a collective effort to deliver poreless, glowing complexions for the high-definition cameras on Sunday.

headline: A Bronze Look for Oscar Night
abstract: Actors turn to a number of tanning professionals ahead of their red-carpet close-ups.
lead_paragraph: Many actors and actresses appear to compete not only for the Oscar but also its golden glow, splurging on these tanning pros.

headline: An Interview With Bashar al-Assad
abstract: Excerpts of an interview with the Syrian president featured in a new documentary on the conflict by the filmmaker Hubert Seipel.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts of an interview with the Syrian president featured in a new documentary on the conflict by the filmmaker Hubert Seipel.

headline: Wipe Away the Tears, Pump Up the Beat
abstract: Tegan and Sara Quin’s two-night concert at the Beacon Theater featured songs from their new album, “Heartthrob,” a wholehearted jump onto the current electronic pop bandwagon.
lead_paragraph: Few bands have given themselves a more extreme makeover between albums than Tegan and Sara, who started a two-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. Tegan and Sara Quin, twin sisters from Canada who have been writing songs and recording together since the 1990s, had moved from folky guitar strumming to folky indie-rock over a decade. They write songs that console the vulnerable, singing about unstable relationships that are full of insecurities, apologies, pleas, tears and forlorn hope. And they have built the kind of devoted following that filled the Beacon with singalongs and squeals of recognition throughout Tuesday’s set.

headline: Scene City: Giants Among Social Animals
abstract: Explorer Club hosts a screening of “Battle for the Elephants.”
lead_paragraph: Explorer Club hosts a screening of “Battle for the Elephants.”

abstract: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, Yemen and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, Yemen and Greece.

headline: Vienna Jewish Museum Chided Over Nazi Loot
abstract: The Jewish Museum of Vienna has come under fire for its delay in returning many items looted by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: When the Jewish Museum of Vienna was founded in 1988 it was entrusted with safeguarding the art, books and Judaica that survived the Nazis’ attempt to exterminate their owners.

headline: Microchips and a Musician, Together in a Duet
abstract: The new-music specialist Vicky Chow performed Tristan Perich’s “Surface Image” at Roulette on Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: So many wires and power cords were tangled on the stage at Roulette on Tuesday evening that the piano appeared to be nestled in a giant serpent’s nest. Forty loudspeakers, 20 on each side of the stage, and each wired to hand-built electronics, framed the instrument.

headline: Rallying for the Elephants
abstract: At the Explorers Club, a gathering of animal lovers view a documentary showing the plight of African elephants.
lead_paragraph: When Kristin Davis, the actress, visited Africa for the first time several years ago, she had eyes for one animal above all others.

keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Hats and Caps', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Sunglasses']

lead_paragraph: Highlights from the fall collections, from playful handbags to practical gloves.

headline: Pentagon Warns of Widespread Civilian Furloughs
abstract: About 750,000 civilians would experience pay cuts of about 20 percent if budget cuts scheduled for March 1 are not averted, Pentagon officials warned.
lead_paragraph: Most of the Pentagon’s civilian employees will face a furlough in the coming months if the planned across-the-board budget cuts come to pass on March 1, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned Congress on Wednesday.

headline: The Daily Shoe | No. 21
abstract: Alessandro Dell’Acqua’s penny loafer with a dash of sparkle at No. 21 both feminized classic menswear and dressed up the casual flat.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Digital Update to Those Old Family Photo Albums
abstract: Apps on iOS and Android devices offer ways to modify, view and share photographs.
lead_paragraph: The days of sticking photos into the plastic pockets of a family album are all but gone, thanks to the rise of digital photography.

abstract: Melena Ryzik speaks with the comedian Carol Leifer about writing jokes for the Academy Awards telecast.
lead_paragraph: Melena Ryzik speaks with the comedian Carol Leifer about writing jokes for the Academy Awards telecast.

headline: Emeli Sandé Wins Big at Brit Music Awards
abstract: Emeli Sandé, a soulful Scottish-born newcomer on the British pop scene, won two top prizes at the 2013 Brit Awards, Britain’s version of the Grammys.
lead_paragraph: Emeli Sandé, a soulful Scottish-born newcomer on the British pop scene, emerged as the big winner at the 2013 Brit Awards in London on Wednesday, winning best British female artist and taking the album of the year prize for her debut “Our Version of Events,” according to wire reports.

headline: Fox Broadcasting Partners With YouTube Channel
abstract: WIGS, which was conceived last year as a channel for female-friendly dramas on the Web, is being taken under Fox’s wing as an incubator for new show ideas.
lead_paragraph: Big television networks are sometimes portrayed as being on one side of an invisible boundary, with Web video firmly on the other side. But that’s becoming less and less accurate, as an announcement on Tuesday by Fox Broadcasting and a YouTube channel called WIGS demonstrates.

headline: My Look, My Ego, My Brand
abstract: Those who write about fashion, or style it, now promote their own careers by drawing attention to their own looks.
lead_paragraph: They perch along the runways like birds on a wire, each with vivid markings: the celebrity editors Carine Roitfeld, working her swag of dusky hair, kohled eyes and killer stilettos, and Grace Coddington, her flame-colored mane framing her face like a cloud; and the photographer Terry Richardson, his downward-drooping mustache lending him the look of a ’70s porn king.

headline: Some Headphones Amplify Celebrities Over Sound
abstract: As the market for higher-price headphones grows, consumers say brands linked with musicians, sports stars and others count as heavily as sound quality.
lead_paragraph: If you are planning a $200 splurge on premium headphones — as millions of people are this year — who will give you the most for your money? Maybe a rapper like Dr. Dre, 50 Cent, Nick Cannon or Ludacris?

abstract: Two studio apartment owners approach the same 270 square feet from very different viewpoints.
lead_paragraph: The so-called micro-pad is now a buzz phrase and a cultural touchstone, thanks to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. But when single-room living was being sketched out in the floor plans of Manhattan’s first apartment buildings, particularly during the boom years of the 1920s, it was called the studio apartment.

abstract: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, a leading critic of President Obama’s health care law, said he now backed a three-year expansion of coverage for poor people.

Rick Scott of Florida reversed himself on Wednesday and announced that he would expand his state’s Medicaid program to cover the poor, becoming the latest — and, perhaps, most prominent — Republican critic of President Obama’s health care law to decide to put it into effect.

lead_paragraph: Between 9 p.m. Monday and 10 the next morning, a lot happened in London. Christopher Kane drank too much tequila. J. W. Anderson was kissed by Carine Roitfeld. Tom Ford boarded a plane for Los Angeles and the Oscars. Simone Rocha designed a dress for a girl waiting at a bus stop.

headline: Bold Tailoring and Patterns, and a Golden Girl
abstract: The looks included high-definition style, bold patterns and a nod to a golden girl.
lead_paragraph: London’s role in the global luxury market was a topic of conversation during the shows, but Tom Ford and L’Wren Scott seemed miles ahead. And though Christopher Bailey of Burberry lightly evoked a British sex scandal of the early ’60s, a leopard pencil skirt will probably fly anywhere.

headline: A Factory on Your Kitchen Counter
abstract: One word: plastics. There are still kinks to be worked out, but 3-D printers may be the home appliance of the future.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address last week, along with the standard calls for education reform and energy independence, President Obama gave a shout-out to a growing technology. In a lab in Youngstown, Ohio, the president said, “Workers are mastering the 3-D printing that has the potential to revolutionize the way we make almost anything.”

headline: Palestinian Filmmaker Describes Detention at Los Angeles Airport
abstract: The Palestinian filmmaker Emad Burnat, who had a hard time convincing immigration officers at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday that his invitation to the Academy Awards was real, described his brief detention in a statement.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian filmmaker Emad Burnat, who had a hard time convincing immigration officers at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday that his invitation to this weekend’s Academy Awards was real, described his brief detention in a statement on Wednesday.

headline: A Solid, Comforting Family Member
abstract: The centerpiece of my childhood home, a George Nakashima table, no longer fit into my life.
lead_paragraph: The last time I saw my family’s Nakashima dining table, it was upended on a dusty Dodge Ram, a gray blanket wrapped around it. The ropes that tied the bundle to the van’s roof didn’t seem up to the task of keeping the precious cargo from slipping off and crashing on the road somewhere

headline: A Devotion to Wooden Churches
abstract: Architectural photographer Richard Davies on saving Russia’s threatened onion-domed churches.
lead_paragraph: While communism, collectivism, worms, dry rot and casual looting failed to destroy the majestic wooden churches of Russia, it may be ordinary neglect that finally does them in. Dwindled now to several hundred remaining examples, these glories of vernacular architecture lie scattered amid the vastness of the world’s largest country. Just over a decade ago, Richard Davies, a British architectural photographer, struck out on a mission to record the fragile and poetic structures. Austerely beautiful and haunting, “Wooden Churches: Traveling in the Russian North” (White Sea Publishing; $132) is the result. Covering thousands of miles, Mr. Davies described how he and the writer Matilda Moreton tracked down the survivors from among the thousands of onion-domed structures built after Prince Vladimir converted to Christianity in 988.

headline: Anheuser-Busch and U.S. in Talks to Resolve Antitrust Concerns

headline: A Juicer Worthy of a Crush
abstract: Testing the new $400 juicer from Hurom.
lead_paragraph: If you find it hard to live in this decade without embarking on a juice fast, you might want to upgrade your juice-extracting technology. That’s what drove this reporter to try the Premium Slow Juicer/Smoothie Maker from Hurom ($400). Like previous versions, the machine crushes rather than whirls its contents, which uses less energy, obtains more juice and preserves more nutrients, the company says. This model also has a lever to control pulp.

headline: Japanese-Inspired Fabric for a Rhode Island Chair
abstract: Called Biwa, after a lake in Japan, the fabric is hand-printed to order.
lead_paragraph: Since Cade Tompkins opened her gallery space three years ago in her home in Providence, R.I., she has been using the mid-19th-century brick Italianate house, designed by Russell Warren, as more than just an installation site. It has become a collaborative device in her shows of contemporary artists like Beth Lipman, who covered Ms. Tompkins’s dining room walls with 30,000 pieces of glass, in a shimmering illusion of “wallpaper.”

headline: A Broadway Revival, Starring Orchids
abstract: A botanical exhibition of orchids and exotic plants and perennials begins Thursday.
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, Elle Ronis went to the Home Depot to buy caulk and came home with her first orchid. “When you buy an orchid that has a bud on it and you nurture it and it opens, it’s, like, addictive,” she said. Today she tends some 5,000 orchids in her basement in Connecticut and supports the habits of other gardeners with Blooms on Broadway, a botanical expo that opens Thursday and runs through Sunday.

headline: Survival of the Fittest, or Just of Coping Skills
abstract: “One Life,” a nature documentary from the BBC, examines the survival skills of some of the planet’s most clever animals.
lead_paragraph: The latest production from the BBC Natural History Unit is a typically eye-catching, years-in-the-making chronicle of animal life that is tainted by the urge to anthropomorphize. Despite its vague title, “One Life” holds a clear focus across its transcontinental series of short, dramatic segments: the intricate survival behavior displayed by the planet’s cleverer beasts (and one plant).

keywords: ['Beer', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']

headline: Louisiana: Nagin Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: The former mayor of New Orleans, C. Ray Nagin, pleaded not guilty in federal court on Wednesday to 21 counts of bribery, corruption and money laundering.
lead_paragraph: The former mayor of New Orleans, C. Ray Nagin, pleaded not guilty in federal court on Wednesday to 21 counts of bribery, corruption and money laundering. A federal grand jury last month charged Mr. Nagin with giving favorable treatment to city vendors and contractors in return for cash, trips and benefits for his family’s granite installation company. At the arraignment on Wednesday, Magistrate Judge Sally Shushan said that Mr. Nagin was allowed to go free on a $100,000 bond, and that his travel would be restricted to Texas, where he now lives, and Louisiana.

headline: 1 in 5 Passed Advanced Placement Tests
abstract: Nearly a third of the nation’s 2012 public high school graduates took at least one of the College Board’s Advanced Placement tests, according to the program’s annual report on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a third of the nation’s 2012 public high school graduates took at least one of the College Board’s Advanced Placement tests, according to the program’s annual report on Wednesday. Nearly one in five got a passing score — three or more, out of five — on one of the 34 subject exams. Last year was the first time in a decade that the average exam score increased from the previous year. The share of students earning at least a 3 also rose for the first time in that period, and the 14.2 percent earning a top score of five was also the highest in the decade.

headline: Renewal of AIDS Program Backed
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The 10-year-old program to fight global AIDS started by the Bush administration is doing a good job and should be funded again after it expires this year, a panel of medical experts recommended Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The 10-year-old program to fight global AIDS started by the Bush administration is doing a good job and should be funded again after it expires this year, a panel of medical experts recommended Wednesday. But countries getting aid should be pushed to manage more of their own programs and pay more of the costs, the panel said. The experts, from the Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academies of Science, were asked by Congress to evaluate the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, which has spent about $38 billion. In 2007, the institute criticized Congressional restrictions, saying too much money went to abstinence education. The new report said the program had become “increasingly flexible” about preventing H.I.V. infections, but needs to do more about sexual transmission. It also needs to do better at getting patients into medical care and assuring that they take their antiretroviral drugs daily.

headline: Amid Questions on Ethics, Battle-Tested Senator Digs In
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, has projected a business-as-usual appearance even as he has hired a team to defuse a crisis.
lead_paragraph: He has taken to little-used routes in the nation’s Capitol to avoid attention. His allies have hinted at conspiracies hatched against him, perhaps by shadowy enemies in Cuba. And he has even hired a prominent lawyer well versed in Congressional investigations.

headline: Missouri: Body Found in Rubble
abstract: A body was recovered in the bar area of the rubble of a popular Kansas City restaurant that exploded on Tuesday evening, officials said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A body was recovered in the bar area of the rubble of a popular Kansas City restaurant that exploded on Tuesday evening, officials said Wednesday. The identity had yet to be determined, the Kansas City fire chief, Paul Berardi, said during a news conference as he stood alongside Mayor Sly James. “Obviously, it is sad news,” Mr. James said. “We also can’t be sure, 100 percent, that we can account for every single person who may have been at JJ’s last night when the incident occurred.” The explosion at the restaurant, JJ’s, was caused by a broken gas main and left 15 people injured, three of whom remained in critical condition on Wednesday and one of whom was in serious condition. Investigators and the Fire Department were still sifting through the layers of broken glass, bricks and other debris, hoping to get as much as possible completed before an expected winter storm.

headline: Iceland Looks to Export Power Bubbling From Below
abstract: A huge and potentially lucrative market beckons, if Iceland can find a way to transmit electricity across 1,000 miles of frigid sea.
lead_paragraph: KRAFLA, Iceland — Soon after work began here on a power plant to harness some of the vast reserves of energy stored at the earth’s crust, the ground moved and, along a six-mile-long fissure, began belching red-hot lava. The eruptions continued for nine years, prompting the construction of a stone and soil barrier to make sure that molten rock did not incinerate Iceland’s first geothermal power station.

When the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum asked me to create a crossword puzzle for Kids Week 2013, I jumped at the chance. Kids love the interactive fun: Virtual Flight Zones, Cockpit Simulators, sports, entertainment, games. The Intrepid is an Essex-class aircraft carrier located @ 12th Avenue at 46th St. (it’s floating in the Hudson). The puzzle will be available through Sunday, Feb. 24.

headline: Irked British Judge Sets Retrial for Ex-Wife of Ex-Official
keywords: ['Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Speed Limits and Speeding']
abstract: A new trial is to begin on Monday in the case of a former energy minister and his ex-wife accused of exchanging responsibility for a speeding ticket.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After nearly 15 hours of jury deliberations over four days, a judge on Wednesday abruptly ordered a retrial for Vicky Pryce, the ex-wife of a former energy minister, who became entangled in a feud with her husband over a decision 10 years ago to accept responsibility for a speeding ticket he incurred on a highway outside London.

headline: Some Victims of Online Hacking Edge Into the Light
abstract: Few American corporations that have been hacked in recent years have publicly acknowledged it, but some are now stepping forward, reflecting new ways of judging such disclosures.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers have hit thousands of American corporations in the last few years, but few companies ever publicly admit it. Most treat online attacks as a dirty secret best kept from customers, shareholders and competitors, lest the disclosure sink their stock price and tarnish them as hapless.

headline: In Their First Game After the Break, the Knicks Fail at Everything

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The Knicks said they would change their losing ways. They vowed to be the team they were in November, not the one that struggled into the All-Star break, losing four of their last five games. They would smartly pass the ball to one another, make intelligent decisions and play defense. But sometimes, talk can be just that — talk.

lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Virginia lawmakers on Wednesday adopted a strict photo identification requirement for voters, a contentious issue nationally in last year’s presidential election.

headline: After Super Bowl Success, a New Local Ad for ‘Dunder Mifflin’
abstract: Quill.com, which licenses the name Dunder Mifflin – the make-believe paper company on the sitcom “The Office” – for a real-world line of office products, plans to run a spot in Utica, N.Y., during the Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: A new technique for gaining attention during the busy Super Bowl advertising season is to do the opposite of spending many millions of dollars to run a commercial nationally during the game: Spend a small sum to run a spot in a handful of local markets, perhaps even in only one such market.

headline: Routed by Katrina, Stuck in Quagmire of Rules
abstract: As people in the Northeast set off on the road back from Hurricane Sandy, Errol Joseph sees his story in New Orleans as a cautionary tale.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Errol Joseph has the doorknobs. He has the doors, too, as well as a bathtub and a couple of sinks, stacks of drywall, a hot water heater, pipes, an air-conditioner compressor, and big pink rolls of insulation. They are sitting in a shed.

headline: Nets Rally Past Bucks and Close in on Division Lead
abstract: Deron Williams scored 23 points and C. J. Watson added 17, helping the Nets come back from an 11-point deficit late in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — For three quarters Wednesday night, the Nets looked overmatched by the Milwaukee Bucks and their electric point guard Brandon Jennings.

headline: A ‘Go Local’ Focus Is Used to Resolve Unpaid Wages
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Worker advocates have persuaded Florida’s two most populous counties to pass ordinances making it easier for workers to recover unpaid wages from employers.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Compared with many other states, Florida has not been hospitable to the cause of worker rights.

headline: Universities Abroad Join Partnerships on the Web
abstract: The two largest ventures providing the online courses known as  MOOCs are announcing partnerships with universities in the Americas, Europe and Asia.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year, elite American universities have raced to stake out a place in the new world of free online courses — and now, universities around the globe are following suit.

headline: The Benefits of Exercising Outdoors
abstract: While the allure of the gym — climate-controlled, convenient and predictable — is obvious, especially in winter, emerging science suggests there are benefits to exercising outdoors that can’t be replicated on a treadmill, a recumbent bicycle or a track.
lead_paragraph: While the allure of the gym — climate-controlled, convenient and predictable — is obvious, especially in winter, emerging science suggests there are benefits to exercising outdoors that can’t be replicated on a treadmill, a recumbent bicycle or a track.

abstract: This word has appeared in 509 New York Times articles in the past year.
