headline: Children in U.S. Are Eating Fewer Calories, Study Finds
abstract: Health experts said the findings offered an encouraging sign that the obesity epidemic might be easing, but cautioned that the magnitude of the decline was small.
lead_paragraph: American children consumed fewer calories in 2010 than they did a decade before, a new federal analysis shows. Health experts said the findings offered an encouraging sign that the epidemic of obesity might be easing, but cautioned that the magnitude of the decline was too small to move the needle much.

headline: Chinese Ask About Cultural Revolution Case: What of the Ringleaders?
abstract: A rare trial a man accused of murdering a doctor in 1967 during the Cultural Revolution is raising an online debate among some Chinese, who ask whether the country’s leaders should be held responsible instead.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It’s reminiscent, perhaps, of the trials of people accused of Nazi-era crimes, a John Demjanjuk, or a Samuel K.: in China this week, a man was tried for murdering a doctor during the Cultural Revolution, The China News Service reported.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (HBO2) HANNA (2011) Saoirse Ronan, above, stars as a teenage assassin trying to elude a ruthless Central Intelligence Agency operative (Cate Blanchett) and her two huntsmen in this action movie from Joe Wright, who also directed Ms. Ronan in her Oscar-nominated role in “Atonement.” Eric Bana is the warrior father, wrapped in animal skins, who has trained Hanna from childhood in northern Finland to become a killing machine. “In the end there might not be much to this tale other than titillation, but there’s plenty to be said for Ms. Ronan, who was the best thing about ‘Atonement’ and holds her ground against forceful screen presences like Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Bana,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. That Ms. Ronan’s translucent blue eyes, transformed here into opaque pools, “don’t reveal much is part of the big surprise, as well as a liability in a movie that is by turns startling and generic, subtle and blunt, and consistently keeps you in its grip if not its heart,” Ms. Dargis added.

headline: In Praise of Bangla, My Mother Tongue
abstract: Bangla is not just a language, it’s a testament to Bangladesh’s freedom.
lead_paragraph: I take pride in the fact that despite being born and raised in New York City, I speak Bangla fluently. I credit this mostly to my Bangladeshi parents for being brutal in their approach to teaching my younger sister and me a language that that was so violently fought for.

headline: News Quiz | February 21, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Police Replace Pistorius Detective in Setback
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Track and Field']
abstract: A detective investigating the athlete Oscar Pistorius, who is accused of killing his girlfriend, is himself facing seven attempted murder charges, South African police said.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — In the latest in a series of abrupt twists in the Oscar Pistorius homicide case, the South African police replaced the lead investigator on Thursday after revelations that he was facing seven charges of attempted murder stemming from an episode in which police officers fired at a minivan.

headline: Fish Are Commonly Mislabeled, Study Finds
abstract: A new nationwide study by Oceana, a nonprofit ocean conservation group, has found that the mislabeling of fish sold in U.S. retail outlets is common.
lead_paragraph: A new nationwide study by Oceana, a nonprofit ocean conservation group, has found that the mislabeling of fish sold in U.S. retail outlets is common.

headline: Survey Finds That Fish Are Often Not What Label Says
keywords: ['Seafood', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: A new study of fish bought and genetically tested in 12 metropolitan areas in the United States found that about one-third of the samples were mislabeled.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Many Europeans are fretting these days over horse meat, and whether it might have adulterated their shepherd’s pie. Over here, it’s all about the red snapper.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 21
abstract: A rare look at Hezbollah in Europe; the head of Goodyear draws furor in France; Iceland investigates exporting its electricity; and a prize-winning novelist takes on the Duchess of Cambridge.
lead_paragraph: NEWS In a little-noticed trial in a small courtroom in Cyprus, a 24-year-old man provided a rare look inside a covert global war between Israel and Iran, admitting that he is an operative of the militant group Hezbollah, for which he acted as a courier in Europe and staked out locations that Israelis were known to frequent. Nicholas Kulish reports from Limassol, Cyprus.

headline: A Home for Fashion Nerds Gets a New Look
abstract: The blog The Business of Fashion seized on a niche, and found a wide readership.
lead_paragraph: Imran Amed started his blog The Business of Fashion about five years ago on his sofa. “I had no idea where it would lead,” he said the other day in London. Mr. Amed, a Harvard Business School graduate and a former McKinsey consultant, had decided to turn his career in another direction, or rather, perhaps, expand it. He is one for taking on several hats, including writer and teacher, at Central Saint Martins.

headline: One Last Pas de Deux for Stars of the Royal Ballet
abstract: Sergei Polunin and Tamara Rojo both left the company last year, setting the ballet world reeling. The chance to see them together once more is leaving Covent Garden audiences breathless.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—On Thursday night at Covent Garden, Sergei Polunin and Tamara Rojo will give their last performance, for the foreseeable future, with the Royal Ballet in Frederick Ashton’s “Marguerite and Armand,” a condensed retelling of the “Traviata” story that was created in 1963 for Margot Fonteyn and her much younger new partner, Rudolf Nureyev.

headline: VW Introducing a Hot Diesel Hatch for Europe
abstract: The Golf GTD will flaunt 17-inch wheels, side skirts, a rear diffuser and a roof spoiler.
lead_paragraph: To Americans with lingering memories of General Motors diesel cars of the 1970s and underpowered import oil burners of yesteryear, diesel performance may be an oxymoron. In Europe, that is not the case, and Volkswagen will underscore the diesel’s old-world performance credentials next month at the Geneva auto show when it introduces a new and more potent version of its Golf GTD sports hatch for the European market.

headline: As Indian Parliament Session Opens, Much Work to Be Done
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: India’s recent economic slowdown has been attributed, in part, to lawmakers inability to pass legislation.
lead_paragraph: India’s parliament starts a new session on Thursday with a massive agenda.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 21, 2013
abstract: Can you choose the verb that correctly completes the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “A Prodigy on the Way to Stardom.”

headline: More Companies Requiring College Degree for All Positions
abstract: What is “degree inflation”?
lead_paragraph: In “It Takes a B.A. to Find a Job as a File Clerk,” Catherine Rampell writes about how an increasing number of companies are requiring a college degree for all positions.

headline: Biswas Nath, the Cycle Shop Owner from Uttar Pradesh
abstract: A third-time visitor to the Kumbh Mela appreciates the devotion of the crowds.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this year’s 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

headline: New Leader of China Plans a Visit to Moscow
abstract: The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, has selected Moscow as his first foreign visit as president, to be followed immediately by a trip to South Africa.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, has selected Moscow as his first foreign capital to visit as president, to be followed immediately by a trip to South Africa for a summit meeting of the group of leading emerging-market countries.

headline: Looking Beyond the Literal
abstract: The photographer Armando L. Sanchez discusses how the work of László Moholy Nagy taught him to think past what’s literal and find the most beautiful image out there.
lead_paragraph: Armando L. Sanchez is a 25-year-old freelance photographer who was born and raised in Austin, Tex., and is now based in Chicago. He studied photography at Western Kentucky University and received a B.A in interdisciplinary studies last year. He has had four — yes, count them, four — newspaper internships: at The Tennessean in Nashville, The Saginaw News in Michigan, The State Journal-Register in Springfield, Ill., and most recently at The Chicago Tribune.

headline: Where Should Colleges and Sports Teams Draw the Line in Selling Naming Rights?
abstract: What value do stadium, event and team names have to a community? Is there any reason not to sell them to the highest bidder?
lead_paragraph: Companies often pay big money for the right to attach their name to a sports stadium, college football bowl game or even athletic team (think New York Red Bulls). But does corporate naming ever cross the line? This week, Florida Atlantic University announced its plan to rename its football stadium after a multibillion-dollar private prison corporation. What do you think?

headline: Twelve Angry Central Bankers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A proposal to toughen rules on money-market funds, issued by the regional banks of the Federal Reserve, would make the banking industry safer, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Classes Warfare
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: Most seats in India’s top nursery schools go to the children of the rich or the well-connected.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It was a widely awaited verdict: Tens of thousands of parents seeking admission for their children to nursery schools in New Delhi were hoping for some remedy against a system that rewards inherited privilege and access to political power. But the High Court of Delhi upheld the status quo on Tuesday.

headline: Italian Police Arrest Man in Soccer Match-Fixing Inquiry
abstract: The main charge against Admir Suljic is criminal association with the intention of committing international sports fraud, European law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The police in Singapore said Thursday that the Asian man thought to be at the center of a global soccer match-fixing network was now cooperating with them, even as the Italian police said they had made an important breakthrough, detaining a key suspect.

headline: One Phone Call From Disaster
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Financial Planners', 'Small Business', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: If you have business partners, a buy/sell agreement isn’t just important — it’s crucial.
lead_paragraph: One morning in May 2004, Steve Ciepiela, co-owner of a financial planning and wealth management firm, heard his phone ring while he was in his garage. It was the office manager. She told Mr. Ciepiela that his partner in the firm, Charles Stephens & Company, had just had a brain aneurysm and was in critical condition. Within 24 hours, he had died.

headline: On the Enduring Appeal of ‘Die Hard’
abstract: John McClane owes less to Marshal Dillon than he does to Scooby-Doo.
lead_paragraph: With the release of “A Good Day to Die Hard,” the fifth film in the “Die Hard” series, the cinematic life span of John McClane has been elongated to a robust 10 hours — longer than sturdy pop icons like Ellen Ripley, Indiana Jones and John Rambo (four films each) and Michael Corleone (three films and nine hours). Once you add in the fact that McClane has appeared on-screen in four different decades, he’s arguably the most durable contemporary American film character not named Batman or Rocky Balboa.

headline: How Come Martin Brodeur Is Still So Good?
abstract: One of the greatest hockey players ever is 40 years old and playing in Newark.
lead_paragraph: The best hockey player in the New York area right now is also one of the greatest hockey players ever, and he’s a Methuselah, a 40-year-old in a sport where pro careers typically last five or six years. Martin Brodeur, now in his 20th season with the New Jersey Devils, has played so well for so long that even hockey people have tended to take him a little for granted. He’s hardly an unknown, but he would be more fussed over and wondered at if he didn’t play in Newark and if his position were not the lowly, unglamorous one of goalie.

headline: The Sopranos of Montreal
abstract: Finally, a broad crackdown on Montreal city officials suspected of corruption, kickbacks and collusion with the mafia.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — “We ask everyone to kindly leave,” said the voice over the loudspeaker in Montreal’s City Hall on Tuesday. Minutes earlier, a fire alarm had gone off — even though there was no fire.

headline: Unlocking the Conspiracy Mind-Set
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Global Warming', 'Hoaxes', 'Research', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Researchers delve into why some climate skeptics are quick to latch onto conspiracy theories rather than merely express doubts.
lead_paragraph: When I first met the NASA climate researcher Gavin Schmidt a few years ago, we discussed the proliferation of material on the Internet attacking mainstream climate science. I asked him whether he thought climate contrarians were flirting with conspiracy theory in their views.

headline: Carlyle’s Profit Fell in 4th Quarter as Growth Slowed
abstract: The Carlyle Group said on Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 28 percent from the period a year earlier, as the growth of its portfolio companies slowed.
lead_paragraph: 11:18 a.m. | Updated Most of the publicly traded private equity giants proudly reported glowing fourth-quarter earnings.

headline: Tip of the Week: Search the Text on a Web Page
abstract: Most browsers include tools that help you quickly search and locate specific keywords and phrases within a Web page.
lead_paragraph: Search engines help find the Web pages you are looking for, but when it comes down to locating your keywords on the actual page, your browser can help. Most browser programs use the Control-F (Command-F on the Mac) to open a search box for finding certain words within the page itself, and most highlight the instances of the word (and number of time it appears). Google Chrome also displays yellow markers vertically along the scroll bar on the right side of the page so you can quickly see all the places the word or phrase appears.

headline: Car Bomb in Damascus Kills Dozens, Opposition Says
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: A blast on Thursday near the Damascus headquarters of President Bashar al-Assad’s ruling party killed mostly civilians but also security forces, opposition sources said.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Lebanon — At least three car bombs exploded in Damascus on Thursday, including a powerful blast near the downtown headquarters of President Bashar al-Assad’s governing party and the Russian Embassy that witnesses said shook the neighborhood like an earthquake.

headline: Bumps in the Office Supply Merger
abstract: The careful choreography of the Office Depot-OfficeMax merger went awry when the deal was accidentally leaked prematurely. | Anheuser-Busch InBev is in talks to try to resolve antitrust issues with its planned deal with Grupo Modelo. | The New York Times Company plans to sell The Boston Globe and its other properties in New England. | The Carlyle Group announced fourth-quarter results.
lead_paragraph: The announcement of the merger between Office Depot and OfficeMax had been carefully choreographed, with the intention of emphasizing that the deal was a transformative merger of equals. But that intention went awry when the deal was accidentally leaked in an errant earnings release from Office Depot early on Wednesday morning, sending bankers and lawyers scrambling, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports.

headline: U.S. Army in the Budget Battle
abstract: The dangers of American defense cuts.
lead_paragraph: The dangers of American defense cuts.

headline: Glass Slippers and Goody Two Shoes
abstract: For Laura Osnes, who has portrayed some of Broadway’s best-known ingénue characters and now plays the title role in “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella,” niceness is no act.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a chilly January morning Laura Osnes emerged from her Upper West Side apartment, bundled as tightly as the Saran-wrapped pan of chocolate-chip banana bread she had just baked to deliver to the Broadway Theater where she is playing Cinderella.

abstract: Food, history and bargains in South Korea; the benefits of exercising outdoors; air travelers lost fewer bags last year and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Daily Report: A New Candor In Disclosing Hacking Attacks
abstract: In recent weeks, a number of American companies have stepped forward to admit they have been the victims of hacking attacks, a departure from how companies used to keep these incidents secret, reports Nicole Perlroth in Thursday’s New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, a number of American companies have stepped forward to admit they have been the victims of hacking attacks, a departure from how companies used to keep these incidents secret, reports Nicole Perlroth in Thursday’s New York Times.Twitter, Facebook and Apple have all announced that they were attacked by sophisticated cybercriminals. The New York Times revealed its experience with hackers in a front-page article last month. The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post have also said they were attacked by what they believed to be Chinese hackers.

headline: After the Snowstorm, an Unexpected Lift
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Struggling to walk on the snowy streets, a woman received some unexpected help from a group of strangers.

headline: NATO Plan Tries to Avoid Sweeping Cuts in Afghan Troops
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: A proposal to expand NATO support of Afghanistan’s forces would help sustain 352,000 troops through 2018, many more than expected, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — NATO defense ministers are seriously considering a new proposal to sustain Afghanistan’s security forces at 352,000 troops through 2018, senior alliance officials said Thursday. The expensive effort is viewed as a way to help guarantee the country’s stability — and, just as much, to illustrate continued foreign support after the NATO allies end their combat mission in Afghanistan next year.

headline: Linn Energy to Buy Berry Petroleum for $2.5 Billion
abstract: Deal-making in the oil patch remains strong, as Linn Energy agreed on Thursday to buy the Berry Petroleum Company for about $2.5 billion in stock, expanding its presence in oil-rich shale formations.
lead_paragraph: Deal-making in the oil patch continued on Thursday, as Linn Energy agreed to buy the Berry Petroleum Company for about $2.5 billion, expanding its presence in oil-rich shale formations.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Times Co. Plans to Sell The Boston Globe, and Robin Roberts Returns
abstract: The New York Times Company plans to sell its New England Media Group, including The Boston Globe; Robin Roberts makes a triumphant return to “Good Morning America”; and the Oscars broadcast on Sunday will rival the Super Bowl as an advertising venue.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company announced Wednesday that it had retained Evercore Partners to manage the sale of the New England Media Group, which includes The Boston Globe, Boston.com, The Worcester Telegram & Gazette and Globe Direct, a direct-mail marketing company, Amy Chozick and Christine Haughney write. The Times Company paid $1.1 billion for The Globe in 1993, and for years the daily brought prestige and profits to the company, but the paper’s circulation has diminished by nearly half in the last decade. The Times Company is expected to seek a buyer in an auction, but there is no assurance that one will appear.

headline: The Early Word: No thanks.
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:The so-called “sequester,” an $85 billion bundle of across-the-board spending cuts, appears likely to take effect March 1, as House Republicans refuse President Obama’s call for Congress to enact a package of tax increases and spending cuts to prevent the reductions, Jonathan Weisman reports. Operating on the premise that the sequester will remain in effect for what may be the rest of the year, the House Appropriations Committee is expected to propose yet another stopgap spending measure as soon as next week to keep the government operating through Sept. 30.

headline: Fendi: Fall 2013 RTW

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: ‘Sticks and Stones’ Gives Parents Words to Talk Bullying
abstract: Emily Bazelon, author of “Sticks and Stones,” answers the question: should parents feel hopeful about bullying, or should we just curl up in a helpless ball and weep?
lead_paragraph: Bullying is a topic that strikes fear and despair into my parently soul, and I’m often reluctant to read about it (let alone write about it) because so much that’s out there feels hopeless, and I feel helpless. I don’t understand what motivates the bullies, or or what allows school administrators to stand by. I identify too strongly with the victims. And I fear that, especially with the increased opportunity for bullying social media provides, my children can’t help but number themselves among aggressors or victims one of these days — and I won’t know what to do about it.

headline: The Gun Report: February 21, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of guns were fired today but most of the victims appear to have survived; I guess that’s what counts for a good day. Here is our roundup of gun violence.

headline: Europe’s Jobless Youth: Should the Old Make Way?
abstract: Over-60s in Britain are being encouraged to study in order to keep working longer. But what does the prospect of a graying work force mean for Europe’s millions who are young and unemployed?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British minister has advised people aged over 60 to go to university and update their skills if they want to continue working.

headline: Going Off the Grid — but Not for Long
abstract: A Sunday column will look at editing The Times’s star columnists.
lead_paragraph: I will be out of the office and mostly off the grid until the end of next week. I won’t be blogging. I doubt that I can step away from Twitter altogether.

headline: Hard Times Come Again, With Song
abstract: “Hands on a Hardbody” and “Kinky Boots,” musicals with working-class themes, will both be setting up shop on Broadway this spring.
lead_paragraph: For much of its history the Broadway musical has given us license to pursue our romantic ideals, indulge sweet reveries, contemplate cloudless skies. Sink down in your seat, listen to the orchestra tune up for the overture, and put your daily cares out of your mind. Escape, for two acts, to a world where the troubles that come will invariably be solved by the finale ultimo. Tomorrow there will be time to worry about the broken dishwasher, the grim job market, the rising cost of living.

headline: Women With Something to Say
abstract: Women — from real life and fiction — will be the leading characters of several prominent Broadway productions (like “Ann,” “The Testament of Mary” and “Matilda the Musical”) this spring.
lead_paragraph: A brigade of outspoken women is poised to take over Broadway this season, turning big New York stages into personal podiums and, quite possibly, pedestals. For these are women (and one little girl) who have inspired veneration and emulation throughout the years — in one case through millenniums.

headline: Video: Writing the Oscar Host’s Punch Lines
abstract: Carol Leifer, a comic and a veteran writer of jokes for Oscar hosts, lets the Carpetbagger in on a few tricks of the trade.
lead_paragraph: As an Oscar host, Seth MacFarlane is bringing in his own team of writers, culled from his show “Family Guy” as well as “Modern Family” and “Real Time With Bill Maher.” But the telecast also has a stable of joke-slingers, reliable veterans who know how to polish the patter and move along the trophy-giving, year after year. Compared with other award shows, like the Grammys, the Oscars are easy to work on, one veteran writer said: “The Oscars is great actors leading to great clips, and very few production numbers.” (Judging by the hints offered by this telecast’s producers, though, this year may be more performance-heavy.)

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Serious Eats: A noble quest: which is the best tortilla chip on the market? — Julia Moskin

headline: Wal-Mart, Despite Profit Gain, Says Rise in Payroll Tax Hindered Shoppers
abstract: The chief executive of Wal-Mart said the current quarter had gotten off to a shaky start because of the government’s delay in processing income tax returns.
lead_paragraph: For Wal-Mart Stores, the tax code gave and the tax code took away.

headline: Two Explosions Kill at Least 11 in Hyderabad
abstract: The blasts came from two bicycles in what appeared to be a coordinated attack.
lead_paragraph: Two blasts near a bus stop killed at least 11 people and injured dozens in the south Indian city of Hyderabad on Thursday night, in what officials said might be a coordinated terrorist attack.

headline: In Miami Case, No One to Applaud
abstract: The N.C.A.A. has done the unthinkable in making the University of Miami appear somewhat sympathetic.
lead_paragraph: Today, let’s all stand up and give college sports a hearty applause. Because just when you thought the cesspool they wallow in couldn’t get any more polluted, circumstances conspire to exceed our most cynical expectations. We now have a hissing match between the combatants in the latest N.C.A.A. investigation/fiasco — the University of Miami president, Donna Shalala, and the N.C.A.A. president, Mark Emmert — over which organization is more corrupt. And because, both claim, the other is more corrupt than their treasured but completely compromised institution, they should be absolved of all wrongdoing.

headline: Jackie Collins: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Hollywood Wives” and, most recently, “The Power Trip,” believes “The Great Gatsby” is the best love story ever. Fitzgerald, she says, had sexual chemistry down.
lead_paragraph: The author of “Hollywood Wives” and, most recently, “The Power Trip,” believes “The Great Gatsby” is the best love story ever. Fitzgerald, she says, had sexual chemistry down.

abstract: Because there’s more to the design capital of Italy than the traffic jam between shows, T reveals how to make the most of the upcoming week in Milan.
