headline: Marino Steps Back From Tennis a Second Time
abstract: Rebecca Marino, a 22-year-old Canadian who had taken a seven-month hiatus in 2012, revealed that she had been struggling with depression for about six years.
lead_paragraph: Although it had seemed that she had moved forward in her path back to the top levels of professional tennis, Rebecca Marino said on Wednesday that she was “stepping back” from the sport indefinitely.

headline: Alan Simpson and Bernie Madoff
abstract: The press’s kind of guy.
lead_paragraph: As I’ve written on previous occasions, the Bernie Madoff phenomenon helped me understand a lot about the persistence of bad economics. Madoff flourished through “affinity fraud”; his investors thought he was their kind of guy, so they didn’t look hard at how he was allegedly making money. And I realized that a similar phenomenon explains the enduring popularity of goldbugs and fiscal doomsayers — including, say, the Wall Street Journal editorial page — despite years of being wrong about everything; their devotees, who consist in large part of cranky old white men, see kindred spirits and can’t see past that to the consistently terrible analysis.

headline: Readers Are Standing Less Firmly Behind ‘Lincoln’
abstract: In The New York Times Oscar pool, readers are going with “Lincoln” for several of the top categories, but they’ve started to have second thoughts on the less glamorous names.
lead_paragraph: (Vote for, share and keep track of your Oscar favorites with The Times’s interactive awards ballot. Start Your Oscar Ballot)The Carpetbagger’s predictions are yet to come, but more than 75,000 readers haven’t waited on her guidance to start their ballots. Even though “Argo” has surged among Hollywood insiders, the reader choice is clearly for “Lincoln” for best picture, director, actor and adapted screenplay.

headline: Southwest Offers Streaming TV
abstract: Southwest Airlines passengers can now download on-demand movies and popular TV shows to their personal electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines, which does not have seatback video players on its aircraft, began offering a service this month that allows passengers to watch on-demand movies and episodes of popular TV shows like “Downton Abbey” (above) and “30 Rock” on their own personal electronic devices. The feature is available on all 417 Wi-Fi-equipped aircraft. Movies are $5 each, and the television package, which includes on-demand programming and eight channels of live news and sports introduced last year, is $5 a day.

headline: Going Public With Cyberattacks
abstract: Nicole Perlroth reports on how companies hit by hackers are calculating the risks and benefits of disclosure.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Perlroth reports on how companies hit by hackers are calculating the risks and benefits of disclosure.

headline: Truth in Seafood Labeling
abstract: A senior scientist at Oceana discusses the group’s new study that found that about one-third of fish samples in 12 metropolitan areas were mislabeled.
lead_paragraph: A senior scientist at Oceana discusses the group’s new study that found that about one-third of fish samples in 12 metropolitan areas were mislabeled.

headline: Keeping Score: Opening Cap Space Hasn’t Derailed Hawks
abstract: The off-season trades of Joe Johnson and Marvin Williams did not bring any notable players in return, but the Hawks are in nearly the same position they were last season when they made the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Last season the Atlanta Hawks had a successful campaign, finishing second in the Southeast Division and fifth in the Eastern Conference. But not much was expected of the Hawks heading into this season, as the off-season trades of the All-Star guard Joe Johnson to the Brooklyn Nets and the starting forward Marvin Williams to the Utah Jazz did not bring any notable players in return.

headline: Student Crossword | Shakespeare
abstract: Learn about Shakespeare by playing our puzzle, online or in print.
lead_paragraph: Learn more about William Shakespeare by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Now Showing | Nick van Woert’s ‘No Man’s Land’
abstract: The artist’s first solo exhibition with OHWOW Gallery in Los Angeles explores post-apocalyptic terrain.
lead_paragraph: “No Man’s Land,” the sculptor and painter Nick van Woert’s first solo exhibition with OHWOW Gallery in Los Angeles, opens on Friday. The Nevada-born artist’s latest multimedia installation works address the frightening prospect that we might render the earth nearly uninhabitable. “Everything humans created was once made of monolithic materials: stone, wood, metal. Things just aren’t like that anymore,” van Woert says. “Many of the materials I use are substitutions for natural materials.” They include chlorine, orange soda, Muscle Milk, hair gel, cat litter and coal slag.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘On Being Brought From Africa to America’
abstract: To both honor another poet of color during Black History Month and commemorate Presidents’ Day on Monday, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “On Being Brought from Africa to America,” a poem by Phillis Wheatley, whose writing was praised by President George Washington, with “A Rare Haven for Gay Men and Lesbians in Harlem” by Gerren Keith Gaynor.
lead_paragraph: To both honor another poet of color during Black History Month and commemorate Presidents’ Day on Monday, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “On Being Brought from Africa to America,” a poem by Phillis Wheatley, whose writing was praised by President George Washington, with “A Rare Haven for Gay Men and Lesbians in Harlem” by Gerren Keith Gaynor.

headline: Puerto Rico U20’s Part of Changing Landscape
abstract: The growth of soccer on Puerto Rico recently has hit some speedbumps.
lead_paragraph: These are the best of times for soccer in Puerto Rico, and the worst. On an island better known for baseball or boxing, soccer has steadily gained participants at the youth level and made a splash on the international scene by staging and winning matches. Now, its under-20 men’s national team is participating in the Concacaf qualifying tournament in Mexico, looking to qualify for its first World Cup appearance, this summer in Turkey.

headline: If I Were in the Academy: Pat Kiernan’s Picks
abstract: Pat Kiernan would vote for “Argo” even if he, as a Canadian, can say why his countrymen had some complaints.
lead_paragraph: Pat Kiernan, the trusted NY1 morning news anchor and creator of the news aggregator Pat’s Papers, may not have time to see every contender. But he does cover box office earnings as part of his job and is a member of the Screen Actors Guild thanks to several movie cameos. He has even worked out an analytical approach to picking Oscar winners that involves anticipating the whims of the Academy.

headline: A Hint About Donovan’s National Team Future?
abstract: Speaking with a U.S.C. journalism class on Wednesday, Landon Donovan said he wanted to return to the United States national team.
lead_paragraph: Updated with video after jump.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 21
abstract: The budget session of the Indian Parliament started Thursday.

headline: The Ghost of Mussolini Haunts a Former Marshland
abstract: The coastal town of Latina, where many villagers say they see the ghost of Mussolini, has become a tourist site thanks to a book about the region.
lead_paragraph: Many villagers and farmers in the Italian  coastal town of Latina swear they often hear the rumbling of Benito Mussolini’s old, red Guzzi 500 motorcycle. Some even say they have been lucky enough to see him — a ghost in a leather hood and goggles — riding under the rain along the ancient Roman Via Appia. While Mussolini figuratively haunts Italy, which had to endure his Fascist rule, in Latina he’s literally a phantom.

headline: New Poll Shows Obama in Strong Position on Spending Cuts
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With just one week to go before the across-the-board spending cuts go into force, 49 percent say the automatic cuts should be delayed if no deal is struck by the deadline, and almost half say they would blame Republicans in Congress if there is no agreement.
lead_paragraph: A new poll released Thursday suggests that after the last few years of repeated financial crises and wrangling between Congressional Republicans and the president, Americans may be increasingly inured to threats of economic doomsday.

headline: Getting Patients to Think About Costs
abstract: When it came to their own treatment, patients did not want cost to play a role in decision-making, according to a new study in Health Affairs.
lead_paragraph: A colleague and I recently got into a heated discussion over health care spending. It wasn’t that he disagreed with me about the need to rein in costs; but he said he was frustrated every time he tried to do so.

headline: Theater Talkback: Old Works, Born Anew
abstract: A new production of “The Glass Menagerie” has a critic remembering other oft-seen plays that felt brand new thanks to a director’s interpretation or unusual casting.
lead_paragraph: They just keep coming, as regular and usually as travel-worn as buses on a high street. Reviving old brand-name plays with brand-name stars (of various vintage) has become Broadway’s default production mode, and, oh, what a weary formula it is. Another “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof”? Another “Glengarry Glen Ross”? Another “Heiress”?

headline: Buying a Gun? States Consider Insurance Rule
abstract: States weighing liability insurance mandates hope they would reward safe behavior, with lower rates for people with safety locks or less dangerous weapons.
lead_paragraph: Both sides in a nation sharply divided over guns seem to agree on at least one thing: a bigger role for the insurance industry in a heavily armed society. But just what that role should be, and whether insurers will choose to accept it, are much in dispute.

headline: Now Streaming | Prada Fall 2013 Women’s Collection
abstract: The Fall 2013 women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The Fall 2013 women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week. Delays may occur.

headline: A Downtown Renovation With a New Flavor
abstract: The World Financial Center is getting more eateries, ones that are new to the area.
lead_paragraph: A corner of Lower Manhattan that has long been thick with corporate towers but thin on interesting cuisine is about to get a vast new food court filled with the kind of small, idiosyncratic vendors normally found in Brooklyn or on the Lower East Side.

headline: In Qatar, a New Wave of I.P.O.’s Looks a Bit Ambitious
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The planned I.P.O. bonanza in Qatar is intended to foster a more responsible spending culture among its citizens, but there are concerns that the markets will not be able to absorb all the new issues, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Qatar’s planned bonanza of initial public offerings may be socially driven but it appears a bit ambitious from a financial standpoint. The emirate is planning a wave of new listings on the local exchange.

headline: Steps to Guard Against Identity Fraud
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Credit Scores', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Identity Fraud', 'Personal Finances', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: More than 12 million people were victims of identity fraud in 2012, a new report finds.
lead_paragraph: If you get a letter notifying you that your personal data was involved in a corporate data breach, you should pay close attention, a new report says.

headline: Love and Ambition in a Cruel New World
abstract: In “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia,” Mohsin Hamid tells a tale of love and ambition that also works as a larger, metaphorical look at sweeping changes.
lead_paragraph: Mohsin Hamid’s 2007 novel, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,”  was an artful tour de force, a lapidary monologue delivered by a young Princeton-educated Pakistani that opened out to become a puzzlelike exploration of identity, and a suspenseful, post-Sept. 11 meditation on the nervous, mutually suspicious dynamic between America and the Muslim world.

headline: A Handy Power Possibility for iPhone 5 Owners
abstract: A lack of battery life has been a common complaint of iPhone 5 owners, but accessory maker Mophie has addressed the problem iPhone5 case with a battery built in.
lead_paragraph: Battery life has been a common complaint of iPhone 5 owners.

headline: Biden Aids Governor in Push for New Gun Laws in Connecticut
abstract: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut used a forum with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to push for changes like a ban on the same type of weapon used in the Newtown massacre.
lead_paragraph: DANBURY, Conn. — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. took the Obama administration’s push for stricter gun laws to Connecticut on Thursday, delivering a forceful and often emotional appeal for stronger measures about 10 miles from the elementary school where a gunman killed 26 children and staff members on Dec. 14.

headline: Many Expect Budget Cuts to Hit Small Businesses Hard (But Not the N.F.I.B.)
abstract: The sequester would scale back programs at the S.B.A. According to the administration, loan guarantees would be reduced by $902 million. And the agency told the Senate Appropriations Committee that cuts to its counseling programs would force the agency’s partners to turn away at least 33,000 business owners seeking assistance.
lead_paragraph: Economists have been warning for months that if the $85 billion in indiscriminate budget cuts known as the sequester take effect, the consequences for the economy could be dire. But for small businesses, the prospects may be even worse.

headline: The Lecturer Has No Clothes
abstract: The goal of the locker room competition is to carry on an argument without acknowledging that everyone is naked.
lead_paragraph: The men native to the locker room of New York University’s Coles Sports and Recreation Center are a mixed bunch: old and young, fat and fit, smooth and hairy, N.Y.U. athletes, N.Y.U. professors, N.Y.U. administrators, the Polish, the Jewish, the Latino — each category with its complicated subdivisions, everyone in various stages of undress. The lockers are red and arranged somewhat symmetrically into U-shaped banks. Each locker bank has one low wooden bench running down its center where men sit, talking as they dress themselves, trying not to touch one another.

headline: Tom Thumb Gets Hitched
abstract: Away from the war, the marriage of America’s two smallest celebrities was the hottest news of 1863.
lead_paragraph: P.T. Barnum never passed up an opportunity to promote himself. So, when the top star in his showbiz empire, the midget performer Charles Stratton, announced plans to marry his fellow midget stage star Lavinia Warren in January 1863, Barnum celebrated the news by immediately starting a public-relations blitz.

headline: A New Music Experience: Let Your Shower Head Sing to You
abstract: Kohler has brought a whole new meaning to “streaming audio.” It has introduced a shower head with a built-in Bluetooth speaker system called the Moxie.
lead_paragraph: Kohler has brought a whole new meaning to “streaming audio.”

headline: An Invisible Wetsuit for Phones and Tablets
abstract: Nano coating can protect your phone from accidental dunkings, but they aren’t cheap.
lead_paragraph: It’s a little heart-stopping to watch someone purposely dunk a cellphone or tablet in a water tank. Seeing it continue to work underwater is astonishing.

headline: Paterson to Teach at Medical School
abstract: Former Gov. David A. Paterson will serve as a distinguished professor of health care and public policy at Touro College in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Two months after his radio show was canceled, former Gov. David A. Paterson has found a new, unexpected position: as a medical school professor.

headline: Twists and Turns in South Africa
abstract: Lydia Polgreen, the Johannesburg bureau chief, discusses the latest in the bail hearing for Oscar Pistorius.
lead_paragraph: Lydia Polgreen, the Johannesburg bureau chief, discusses the latest in the bail hearing for Oscar Pistorius.

headline: Palatable Period Rooms
abstract: The British food historian Ivan Day specializes in culinary exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: The British food historian Ivan Day specializes in culinary exhibitions.

headline: Setting a Place for History
abstract: Museums have discovered at least one secret ingredient to make their potentially snooze-inducing rooms more palatable: a chef of sorts.
lead_paragraph: The period rooms in art museums have the mustiest, dustiest of reputations. They are often seen as the cultural equivalent of grandma’s overstuffed couch that smelled like a fleet of cats.

headline: Return of Robin Roberts Brings Higher Ratings to ‘Good Morning America’
abstract: The show had its best morning in the ratings in three months when Ms. Roberts returned on Wednesday after a medical leave of absence.
lead_paragraph: “Good Morning America” had its best morning in the ratings in three months when Robin Roberts returned to the show on Wednesday after a medical leave of absence, according to preliminary Nielsen ratings.

headline: Reunited, the Rascals Bring Their Act to Broadway
abstract: After reuniting for a series of shows in Port Chester, N.Y., the blue-eyed soul band is bringing its act to Broadway in April.
lead_paragraph: Having recently reunited for a series of shows in Port Chester, N.Y., the 1960s blue-eyed soul band the Rascals are bringing their act to Broadway for a limited engagement in April at the Richard Rodgers Theater, the producers said on Thursday.

headline: 36 Hours in Davos, Switzerland
abstract: From skiing to solariums, art to fondue, you can find it in this sky-high Swiss city in the Alps.
lead_paragraph: Many equate Davos with the World Economic Forum and the masters of the universe who attend the yearly conference in this Swiss municipality perched 5,120 feet above sea level. But raise your eyes to the mountains and behold the inspiration for the adventures of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle (he wrote about skiing here in the late 1800s), the landscapes of the Expressionist painter Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, and the setting for Thomas Mann’s novel “The Magic Mountain.” For nearly 200 years, the crisp Alpine air drew patients to sanitariums that have since been converted to belle époque hotels with brilliant views. With an endless array of activities, from lounging in solariums and saunas to skiing the nearby mountains and visiting museums, travelers to Davos and its environs will find plenty to keep them busy.

headline: A Winter Escape to Davos
abstract: There’s much more to this Swiss mountain town than the World Economic Forum.
lead_paragraph: There’s much more to this Swiss mountain town than the World Economic Forum.

headline: Doctor Groups Issue List of Overused Medical Tests
abstract: Major medical specialty groups recommended that doctors greatly reduce their use of 90 widely used but largely unnecessary tests and treatments.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to change entrenched medical practices, 17 major medical specialty groups recommended on Thursday that doctors greatly reduce their use of 90 widely used but largely unnecessary tests and treatments.

headline: Flu Shot Tied to Healthy Pregnancy
abstract: Pregnant women who received the flu vaccine during the 2009 flu pandemic lowered their risk of delivering premature babies, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who received the flu vaccine during the 2009 flu pandemic lowered their risk of delivering premature babies, a new study found.

headline: In Israel, a Hint of New England
abstract: The Shalom Hotel and Relax in Tel Aviv mixes the décor of New England with the views of the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Creative Granola: Readers Share Their Ideas
abstract: From applesauce to cayenne pepper, here are a few of our readers’ suggestions, submitted via Twitter, on how to take ordinary granola a notch above the rest.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Dining section, Jeff Gordinier wrote about chefs, artisans and entrepreneurs who are doing  interesting things with granola. It turns out that some of our readers are also getting creative with their homemade granola. From applesauce to cayenne pepper, here are a few of our readers’ suggestions, submitted via Twitter, on how to take ordinary granola a notch above the rest.

headline: Caught on Camera, Two Bald Eagles Rebuild After the Storm
abstract: A pair of bald eagles, already something of an Internet sensation, have returned to Duke Farms in New Jersey after Hurricane Sandy destroyed their home.
lead_paragraph: HILLSBOROUGH, N.J. – The national bird has proved itself Jersey Strong.

headline: ‘You Can Actually Make a Lot of Money and Do a Lot of Good in the World’
keywords: ['Business Schools', 'Poverty', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Peter Henry, dean of N.Y.U.’s Stern School of Business, is staying idealistic.
lead_paragraph: You write in your book, “Turnaround,” that you were drawn to economics because you wanted to “help people in developing countries like my native Jamaica.” Wouldn’t you be better off, say, heading up an NGO than becoming dean of a business school?  There’s shareholder value, and there’s stakeholder value. The banking industry is worried about shareholder value, and NGOs are primarily interested in stakeholder value. But things that drive up shareholder value can actually be very good for society at large. We have to have a different way of thinking about the role of business in society.

headline: New Episodes of ‘For Better or Worse’ Planned for OWN
abstract: Oprah Winfrey’s OWN network is putting the sitcom “For Better or Worse” back into production, deepening the network’s relationship with the creator, writer and director of the series, Tyler Perry.
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey’s OWN network is putting the sitcom “For Better or Worse” back into production, deepening the network’s relationship with the creator, writer and director of the series, Tyler Perry.

headline: Sorbet Still Life
abstract: A nod to the Dutch Golden Age.
lead_paragraph: Outtakes is an occasional feature on the story behind the photographs in the Dining section.

headline: Union Chief Tweaks Mets on Payroll
abstract: After briefing the players, Michael Weiner addressed a number of subjects with the news media, including David Wright’s signing and the Mets’ payroll.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Michael Weiner, the head of the players union, began his annual tour of the 30 major league teams’ spring training facilities here Thursday, briefing the Mets on a variety of subjects before their morning workout.

headline: Hezbollah Courier Was Told to Track Israeli Flights
abstract: A Hezbollah operative, Hossam Taleb Yaacoub, said at his trial on Thursday that he was told to record the arrival times of flights from Israel to Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — A Hezbollah operative who worked as a courier for the group in Europe said at his trial on Thursday that he had instructions to record the arrival times of passenger flights from Israel to Cyprus, prompting Israel to press the European Union to formally declare the militant group a terrorist organization.

headline: Sign of a Comeback: U.S. Carmakers Are Hiring
abstract: Ford said it would spend $200 million to renovate a Cleveland plant to produce small, turbocharged engines for use in its top-selling models.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A few years ago, American automakers cut tens of thousands of jobs and shut dozens of factories simply to survive.

headline: Ben Foster Will Replace Shia LaBeouf in ‘Orphans’
abstract: Mr. Foster, who has never done a professional stage play, had auditioned for the part earlier.
lead_paragraph: The actor Ben Foster, who played a cold-blooded killer in the movie “3:10 to Yuma” and vulnerable young men in “The Messenger” and the HBO series “Six Feet Under,” will join the cast of the Broadway play “Orphans,” replacing Shia LaBeouf, the producers announced on Thursday. Mr. LaBeouf left the production a day earlier after backstage disagreements and an apparent lack of compatibility with the play’s star, Alec Baldwin.

headline: Deadly Bombings Hit Southern Indian City
abstract: Two bombs planted on bicycles killed at least 11 people and wounded 50 in a busy shopping district in Hyderabad Thursday night in what officials said may have been a coordinated attack.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two bombs on Thursday killed at least 13 people and wounded about 70 in a busy shopping district in the southern city of Hyderabad at the height of the evening rush hour, the largest terrorist bombing in India since September 2011.

headline: Patrol Car Kills Pedestrian While Responding to Emergency Call
abstract: The victim was crossing a street in Long Island City, Queens, when he was struck by the patrol car, which was responding to a report of a domestic dispute involving a knife.
lead_paragraph: A patrol car heading to the scene of a 911 call about a domestic assault in progress fatally struck a man in Long Island City, Queens, around 12:45 a.m. Thursday, the police said.

headline: Philharmonic Pours More of Its Archives Onto the Web
abstract: The project has made available public programs, scores and internal documents from 1943, when Leonard Bernstein made his debut with the orchestra, to 1970, the year after he left as music director.
lead_paragraph: Sheet music on music stands provide the road map for an orchestra’s performance, but scribbled annotations by the players impose a conductor’s ideas and serve as simple reminders to make an entrance or count correctly. Now, with more than half-million new digitized pages poured into the New York Philharmonic’s electronic archives, that world is open to inspection. It may prove interesting to concertgoers, and fascinating to musicians who may have to play those parts themselves.

headline: 15 G.O.P. Senators Urge Hagel’s Withdrawal as Democrats Push Toward Vote
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Despite the Republican move, Senate Democrats pushed ahead with plans to vote on Chuck Hagel’s nomination to be defense secretary, and he seemed likely to be confirmed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of 15 Republican senators insisted on Thursday that President Obama withdraw the nomination of Chuck Hagel to be defense secretary, the latest move in a contentious battle to block the confirmation of their former colleague.

headline: Living With Cancer: Arrivals and Departures
abstract: Perhaps we should gestate during endings, as we do during beginnings. Like hatchings, the dispatchings caused by cancer give people like me a final trimester, more or less, in which we can labor to forgive and be forgiven.
lead_paragraph: After being nursed and handed over, the baby’s wails rise to a tremolo, but I am determined to give my exhausted daughter and son-in-law a respite on this wintry evening. Commiserating with the little guy’s discomfort — gas, indigestion, colic, ontological insecurity — I swaddle, burp, bink, then cradle him in my arms. I begin walking around the house, swinging and swaying while cooing in soothing cadences: “Yes, darling boy, another one bites the dust, another one bites the dust.”

headline: Le Philosophe
abstract: Inside the NoHo restaurant that occupies a spiritual midpoint between Balthazar and La Grenouille.
lead_paragraph: Inside the NoHo restaurant that occupies a spiritual midpoint between Balthazar and La Grenouille.

headline: Tasting the Past, With Plenty of Butter
abstract: With dishes rich with butter and cheese, Le Philosophe in NoHo is not a place aiming for restraint.
lead_paragraph: It is a sinister dish, this ziggurat of bread, steak and foie gras, cloaked in black like a treacherous peak on the road to Mordor. At the base is a hulking crouton, topped by filet mignon, both slaked in butter; then comes foie gras; and finally all is drenched by a slow-moving sauce of bordelaise, truffles, veal stock and Madeira, which lends a sweetness and tang akin to balsamic vinegar. It is heavy, hobbling, a prelude to gout, an anachronism and a thrill.

headline: Rothschild Loses Fight for Control of Indonesian Mining Giant
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: Bumi shareholders voted against a major board change proposed by the British financier Nathaniel Rothschild, including his goal to replace 12 of Bumi’s 14 board members.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The battle for control over the mining company Bumi reached a climax on Thursday as shareholders voted against a major board change proposed by the British financier Nathaniel Rothschild.

headline: The Newest and Youngest Americans
abstract: John Moore, an experienced conflict photographer familiar with the difficulty of America’s immigration issue, took time to photograph a different aspect of the story — 300 children, born abroad, becoming citizens.
lead_paragraph: After spending 17 years of my career abroad, photographing immigration issues in America seemed like a natural fit for me when I moved back to the United States. In 2009, I began photographing undocumented workers in the fields of Colorado and the deserts of Arizona as well as deportation flights to Central America. This year, I’ve covered several naturalization ceremonies, ­like when I flew to Tampa, Fla., on Valentine’s Day to photograph 28 married couples who received their citizenship at a special lovers’ day event.

headline: Rick Scott Accepts Reality
abstract: Like Florida, all states will eventually agree to expand their Medicaid system.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives ridiculed Gov. Rick Scott of Florida as a traitor to their cause after he announced yesterday that he would expand the state’s Medicaid program with money from President Obama’s health care reform system. In fact, he simply accepted reality before they did. Eventually, all the holdout states will knuckle under and do exactly the same thing.

headline: What If  ‘Amour’ Wasn’t a Lock for the Foreign-Language Oscar?
abstract: Assessing the odds of the other films competing with “Amour” for best foreign-language film.
lead_paragraph: If a movie other than Michael Haneke’s “Amour” wins the Academy Award for best foreign-language film on Sunday, it will qualify as a major upset. Not that Mr. Haneke’s film is a lock or the rest of the field of five is weak, but “Amour,” which represents Austria even though its cast is French and the story takes place in Paris, has dominated this awards season in resounding fashion, perhaps even more convincingly than the Iranian drama “A Separation” did last season on its way to a triumph at the Oscars.

headline: The Small Picture: Smiles at the End of a Long Day
abstract: Maggie Winters, who owns a photography business, thinks she has the coolest job in the world.
lead_paragraph: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their business in a single shot.

headline: Test Scores of Hispanics Vary Widely Across 5 Most Populous States, Analysis Shows
abstract: A new analysis of nationwide tests in New York, California and other populous states shows shifts, including the growing number of Hispanic students.
lead_paragraph: Of all the changes sweeping through the American public education system, one of the most significant is simply demographic: the growing population of Hispanic students.

headline: For Michael Kors Insiders, Cashing Out Is Very Much in Fashion
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Since the I.P.O. of his fashion company in 2011, Michael Kors has sold roughly $650 million worth of his company’s stock. He still retains a roughly $300 million stake.
lead_paragraph: It took more than three decades for the clothing designer Michael Kors to reach the pinnacle of the fashion world. But it has taken just 14 months for him to become enormously rich.

headline: Martha O’Brien, Gilbert Lamphere
abstract: The bride owns a design consultancy and the groom is a partner in an investment firm.
lead_paragraph: Martha Janet O’Brien and Gilbert Hicks Lamphere were married Saturday at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Nielsen Adjusts Its Ratings to Add Web-Linked TVs
abstract: Americans who have spurned cable, but who have a television set hooked up to the Internet, will now be counted by the Nielsen Company.
lead_paragraph: 9:04 p.m. | Updated

headline: Reactions to the PlayStation-Less PlayStation 4 Event
abstract: The reaction to the Sony PlayStation 4 announcement, with no device to show, was not gentle.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was supposed to be a big day for Sony as it introduced the PlayStation 4, its first new game console in seven years. But with no actual PlayStation to show and a press conference that dragged on, Sony didn’t quite get the reaction that, say, Apple gets in its tightly choreographed and comparatively brief product announcements.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Fendi
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Front-Row Seat via Video
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: Video has become a source that helps the fashion industry determine which runway items will be hits in stores.
lead_paragraph: As the Belstaff runway show began in New York City last week, buyers, designers and bloggers crowded into their seats, jotted notes and took smartphone photos as the models strutted by.

headline: ‘Go Mighty’ or You Might Not Go at All
abstract: The “Go Mighty” group blog offers two messages I need to hear, often: Figure out what you want to do, and go after it — then stop to savor it when you get it.
lead_paragraph: Every school vacation reminds me that that which you do not set out to do, rarely gets done, while that which makes itself readily available to you expands to fit all the time you have and then some.

headline: The Tax Advantages Behind an Oil Deal
abstract: Linn Energy’s acquisition of Berry Petroleum is the first time an oil-producing master limited partnership has swallowed a whole exploration company.
lead_paragraph: A $4.3 billion oil deal parlays the financial engineering of an already financially engineered corner of the industry. Linn Energy’s $4.3 billion acquisition of Berry Petroleum, including debt, is the first time an oil-producing master limited partnership has swallowed a whole exploration company. The bold move leans on the tax advantages of such structures and raises their risk profile.

headline: She Loves Me Not?
abstract: Dealing with a hesitant girlfriend, a shy child, a same-sex date and a rival party host.
lead_paragraph: So, I got down on one knee at an expensive restaurant on Valentine’s Day and asked my girlfriend to marry me. My boss happened to be nearby, as well as my parents’ best friends. Her answer: “Not yet.” That pretty much destroyed the buzz in the restaurant. Now I feel like a total fool. And my girlfriend has been mostly unwilling to discuss what “not yet” means. Everyone in town is talking about me. What do I do? Tim

headline: Where the Republican Reformers Are, and Aren’t
abstract: Why the state-level G.O.P. is in better shape, and doing better work, than the national party.
lead_paragraph: Taking a break from issuing pungent critiques of Republican officeholders and ideas, Bloomberg View’s Josh Barro explains why America still needs the Republican Party, after all — and points to state houses as examples of G.O.P. governance done right:

headline: The Reality Behind Virtual War Zones
abstract: Discovering an artist who uses digital landscapes originally designed for combat video games as the basis for his work.
lead_paragraph: In my essay, “A War Zone I Can’t Escape,” which ran in the magazine a couple of weeks ago, I wrote about how the urban, decimated streetscape of the Middle East city in the combat video game that my stepson was playing had looked disquietingly similar to my native city Beirut, which during my childhood was enmeshed in a civil war between Lebanon’s innumerable, and irreconcilable, militias (outside forces, like Syria and Israel, also played considerable roles).

headline: American Kids Consuming Fewer Calories
abstract: New research from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that American children consumed fewer calories in 2010 than they had 10 years earlier, a hopeful trend in the battle against obesity.
lead_paragraph: New research from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that children in the United States consumed fewer calories in 2010 than they had 10 years earlier, according to a story by Sabrina Tavernise in Thursday’s Times. It is a hopeful trend in the battle against childhood obesity, though health experts warned that the decrease was small. “To reverse the current prevalence of obesity, these numbers have to be a lot bigger,” said Marion Nestle, professor of nutrition, food studies and public health at New York University. “But they are trending in the right direction, and that’s good news.” Read more.

headline: For Winter’s Gloom, a Healing Dose of Light in a Garden
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)', 'Weather', 'Winter (Season)']
abstract: Lynne Spevack, a plant lover and a psychotherapist, leads winter tours at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, consistent with her desire to get people outside to address a common problem, seasonal affective disorder.
lead_paragraph: One good measure of the effect winter weather has on New Yorkers can be found in the attendance numbers for the tours of Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Prada
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a retro peep-toe.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Amid Online Furor, Sheriff Responds to Death of Man With Down Syndrome
abstract: An outpouring of criticism online has prompted a local sheriff to post a statement on social media to try to reassure the public that his office was handling the matter responsibly.
lead_paragraph: Online furor over the death of a 26-year old Maryland man with Down syndrome, who was handcuffed and forced to the ground by sheriff’s deputies in a movie theater, has been so vigorous that a local sheriff took the unusual step this week of posting a statement on social media to try to reassure the public that his office was handling the matter responsibly.

headline: Yoga, With New Poses to Strike
abstract: Yoga classes in Manhattan are now flexible enough to incorporate hoops, belly dancing and trampolines.
lead_paragraph: THE first yoga class I took, over 20 years ago, was pretty straightforward. In those days yoga was typically a series of postures and stretches on a mat. But in recent years some new elements have been thrown into the mix. You can now find aerial, acrobatic, even laughter yoga.

headline: Visas Are Urged for Lower-Skilled Work
abstract: Two groups that have feuded in the past over an immigration overhaul outlined goals designed to show that they could reach a compromise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an effort to avert the bitter and public feuding between business and labor organizations that helped kill a broad immigration overhaul in 2007, representatives of the two groups released a statement on Thursday outlining shared goals designed to show that at least for now, they could reach a basic level of compromise.

headline: Symposium on ‘Feminine Mystique,’ and More
abstract: This weekend in Manhattan, symposiums free and open to the public include one about Betty Friedan’s classic book and another about the theory of interior design.
lead_paragraph: The rise of the massive open online course, or MOOC, has given curious minds an outlet for learning despite time, space or financial constraints. But for many, including the Miser, nothing quite beats the real-time, physical presence of a mentor and peers. This weekend downtown Manhattan will host several symposiums that are free and open to the public, though reservations are required.

headline: Prada: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Blurry Backgrounds, Big Sensors and Bokeh
abstract: David Pogue analyzes the debate on blurry photo backgrounds and how cameras get them.
lead_paragraph: In my New York Times column on Thursday, I reviewed the Sony RX1: the first compact digital camera with a full-frame (that is, HUGE) sensor inside.

headline: Emotional Sabres Try to Regroup Behind New Coach
abstract: For the first time since the 1996-97 season, Buffalo will have a different face behind its bench Thursday night when the interim coach Ron Rolson leads them against the Toronto Maple Leafs.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — For the first time since the 1996-97 season, the Buffalo Sabres will have a different face behind their bench Thursday night when they play the Toronto Maple Leafs. The interim head coach Ron Rolston takes over from Lindy Ruff, who was fired Wednesday afternoon.

headline: A Yank Returns to Ireland; Music and Ruckus Ensue
abstract: “Donnybrook!” is a revival of the 1961 musical that was an adaptation of “The Quiet Man,” a John Ford film.
lead_paragraph: The weather looks fine on James Noone’s set for “Donnybrook!” at the Irish Repertory Theater: A verdant landscape and blue skies back a white house dappled with light. It feels fresh, like a morning after rain in the west of Ireland.

headline: Seeking a Hollywood Audience for a Nollywood Film
abstract: Tony Abulu is hoping for a hit with his movie “Doctor Bello,” which will be shown at 20 theaters around the country. “This is where I become either Tyler Perry or just fade out into oblivion,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker was on his cellphone, his voice hoarse, his enthusiasm abounding. “It’s a Cinderella story!” he exclaimed. “Here’s a little guy who’s struggling!”

headline: Google Introduces a Touch-Screen Laptop
abstract: Google’s newest Chromebook, the Pixel, is priced to compete with expensive Apple and Microsoft laptops. Google made the touch-screen device, which requires users to live entirely in the cloud.
lead_paragraph: Google is stepping further into the laptop business, and moving way up the price scale.

headline: The Prelate as Scapegoat
abstract: Cardinal Roger Mahony, who covered up child abuse, wrote in a Wednesday blog post that he was working to accept his role as “scapegoat.”
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Roger Mahony of Los Angeles wants to participate in the election of the next Pope, and it seems likely that he will get his wish — even though he covered up child abuse when he was archbishop of Los Angeles and was officially relieved of public church duties at the end of January. Judging from the cardinal’s personal blog, if he travels to Rome he will arrive prayerfully accepting his role in the scandal — the role of “scapegoat.” He said on Wednesday that he is sustained lately by spiritual writings that focus on “the acceptance of being scapegoated, pointing out the necessary connection between humiliation and redemption.” It seems possible, however, that he prefers the role of martyr: “This scandal is putting us, the clergy and the church, where we belong — with the excluded ones; Jesus was painted with the same brush as the two thieves crucified with him.”

headline: Soledad O’Brien to Take on New Role at CNN
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Ms. O’Brien said Thursday that she will leave CNN’s morning show in the spring and form a production company to supply documentaries to CNN on a nonexclusive basis.
lead_paragraph: 4:45 p.m. | Updated Soledad O’Brien will leave CNN’s morning show in the spring, but she won’t be leaving the cable news channel altogether.

headline: In Apple Fight, Einhorn Unveils ‘iPrefs’
abstract: Apple has introduced perhaps more innovative consumer products than any other company has over the past decade, including the iPhone. Now, the hedge fund manager David Einhorn wants the company to roll out what he calls iPrefs.
lead_paragraph: 4:30 p.m. | Updated Apple Inc. has introduced more innovative consumer products than perhaps any other company has in the last decade: the iPod, the iPhone, the iPad.

headline: Photographic Artifacts of Black Civil War Troops
abstract: Images and artifacts pertaining to the experience of African-American troops in the Civil War are being spotlighted in current and coming museum exhibitions and auctions.
lead_paragraph: In the year’s most haunting image of black Civil War soldiers, the opening battlefield sequence in Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln,” Confederate forces massacre many fallen former slaves.

headline: Biden Speaks on Gun Control
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed a forum at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed a forum at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury.

headline: Syrian Television’s Most Outraged Bystander
abstract: The same man on the street has been featured in at least 19 reports on state-run television channels in Syria since the uprising began.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Friday, 2:41 p.m. In the aftermath of a deadly bombing in Damascus on Thursday, a man emerged from a small knot of bystanders crowded around a camera crew from Syrian state television to vent his anger at the foreign Islamist fighters he held responsible. “We the Syrian people,” he said, “place the blame on the Nusra Front, the Takfiri oppressors and armed Wahhabi terrorists from Saudi Arabia that are armed and trained in Turkey.”

headline: Charlotte Dumas: ‘Anima’
abstract: Charlotte Dumas’s collection contains portraits of the team of United States Army horses used to pull caissons in military funerals at Arlington National Cemetery.
lead_paragraph: Julie Saul Gallery

headline: CNBC Buys ‘Nightly Business Report’ From Atalaya
abstract: CNBC said Thursday it would buy the rights to the pioneering public television series from the investment firm Atalaya Capital Management for an undisclosed price.
lead_paragraph: “Nightly Business Report,” the pioneer public television series that has struggled in recent years, is getting a new, deep-pocketed commercial owner, the 24-hour business cable channel CNBC, a unit of Comcast’s NBCUniversal.

headline: Ragnar Kjartansson: ‘The Visitors’
abstract: Ragnar Kjartansson’s video installation is divided among nine channels, and it shows him and eight friends making music at the mansion Rokeby Farm, in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: Luhring Augustine

headline: Lucas Knipscher, Win McCarthy, Sigmar Polke
abstract: The young artists Lucas Knipscher and Win McCarthy collaborated in an arrangement of paintings, sculptures, photographs and other odds and ends.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Uffner Gallery

headline: Federal Spending Cuts Threaten Delays in Air Travel
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airport Security', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL']
abstract: Airlines and airports are preparing for across-the-board federal budget cuts as if they were a hurricane, with takeoff delays and slower security lines possible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Airlines and airports across the country are preparing for across-the-board federal budget cuts due to hit next week as if they were a hurricane, although with even less certainty about how many flights they will have to cancel and how many passengers will be stranded. The federal government is warning about delays that could begin in March, as the first cuts take effect, and reduced takeoffs and slower security lines that could worsen in April with furloughs.

headline: ‘Frozen Lakes’
abstract: “Frozen Lakes,” the current group show at Artists Space, is the 1977 “Pictures” show updated for the digital age.
lead_paragraph: Artists Space

headline: Declaring This a Year for Fixing and Rebuilding, H.P. Posts Lower Profit
abstract: Though Hewlett-Packard is battling a declining demand for personal computers, the computer maker’s quarterly results were better than expected.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett-Packard may have gained running room, but it remains unclear if it can leap successfully to technology’s new post-PC world.

headline: Mara Held
abstract: Mara Held’s easel-size abstractions are jammed with multilayered patterns — floral, watery, geological and gridded — and irradiated within by spacey colored lights.
lead_paragraph: Gary Snyder

headline: Getting I.R.S. Help in Spanish
abstract: Spanish-speaking taxpayers can also stay connected to the I.R.S. through Twitter, by following @IRSenEspanol.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service offers a variety of free taxpayer help in Spanish.

headline: Gnocchi With Squash
abstract: Mario Batali shares his recipe for gnocchi with butternut squash with Mark Bittman.
lead_paragraph: Mario Batali shares his recipe for gnocchi with butternut squash with Mark Bittman.

headline: Gnocchi of a Different Color
abstract: Variations on potato pasta, but all still “light as a cloud.”
lead_paragraph: A phrase often used (overused, really) to describe well-made gnocchi is “light as a cloud.” It’s not an especially instructive description for a piece of real food, and for cooks hoping to try their hands at gnocchi for the first time, it can be downright daunting. It’s true that gnocchi requires a bit of technique, but achieving that cloudlike texture — “light” is perhaps a simpler, less intimidating word — isn’t actually that difficult.

headline: A Child-Eye’s View of Life in 1970s China
abstract: In “11 Flowers” the director Wang Xiaoshuai draws on boyhood memories, including an encounter with a murderer, for a story set near the end of the Cultural Revolution.
lead_paragraph: Poised on the brink of sexual awareness and the waning of the Cultural Revolution, an 11-year-old boy struggles to interpret the signals from his changing body and an increasingly confusing world.

headline: Gifts and Purchases Help MoMA Close Gaps in Its Holdings
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art has recently acquired a disparate group of artworks that add muscle to its already world-class permanent collection.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art has recently acquired a disparate group of artworks, adding muscle to its already world-class permanent collection. Some were gifts promised years ago and only now finalized; others are newer additions that suggest the areas that curators feel need to be strengthened.

headline: Babies Across Borders
abstract: The documentary “Stuck” follows Americans’ quest to adopt orphans from Ethiopia, Haiti and Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: An unabashed sales pitch for international adoption, Thaddaeus Scheel’s “Stuck” aims for the heart much more than the mind. And while it’s hard to concentrate on systemic problems when faced with the rotting teeth of an adorable Vietnamese orphan, it’s those very problems that require our most intense scrutiny.

headline: Pearl Theater Puts Out Emergency Fund-Raising Call
abstract: The theater is experiencing a cash flow shortfall that threatens its current season and its overall financial health.
lead_paragraph: The Pearl Theater Company is an Off Broadway troupe best known for mounting classic plays. But according to a letter sent to subscribers this week, the theater is experiencing a classic problem: a cash flow shortfall that threatens to endanger its current season and its overall financial health. In the letter, J. R. Sullivan, the company’s artistic director, wrote that the theater’s board has raised over $200,000 since it began focusing on the financial shortfall in December, and that the company has undertaken “stringent cost-cutting measures.” But he said the company still needs to raise an additional $250,000 to enable it to have an “immediate future.” Its budget for the current season is $2.1 million.

headline: Counting Fewer Calories
abstract: Brian D. Elbel, a professor of population health and health policy at NYU Langone Medical Center, discusses an encouraging sign in the fight against childhood obesity.
lead_paragraph: Brian D. Elbel, a professor of population health and health policy at NYU Langone Medical Center, discusses an encouraging sign in the fight against childhood obesity.

headline: David Gregory Renews ‘Meet the Press’ Contract
abstract: Mr. Gregory revealed the news in an interview with The Associated Press on Thursday. NBC confirmed that he has agreed to a new contract, described only as “long term.”
lead_paragraph: David Gregory has renewed his contract with NBC News to serve as the anchor of television’s most venerable Sunday morning political discussion show, “Meet the Press.”

headline: The Envelope, Please: Leobardo Espinoza
abstract: A high school senior in Kansas is still undecided about a surprise scholarship offer from a university he considers a “fallback.”
lead_paragraph: A high school senior in Kansas is still undecided about a surprise scholarship offer from a university he considers a “fallback.”

headline: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
abstract: Candice Childress, a high school senior in Las Vegas, has been named a National Merit Finalist.
lead_paragraph: Candice Childress, a high school senior in Las Vegas, has been named a National Merit Finalist.

headline: You Can’t Escape the Past, and Other Truisms
abstract: “Inescapable,” directed by Ruba Nadda, takes the missing-daughter conceit of “Taken” and moves it to revolution-torn Syria.
lead_paragraph: For all the walking, running and tortured staring in Ruba Nadda’s “Inescapable” — a Canadian nonthriller that plays like a heavily sedated hybrid of “Taken” and “Not Without My Daughter” — the only people breaking a sweat are the invisible musicians laboring over the score. Unfortunately for everyone involved, hysterical violins and booming chords do not, on their own, equal excitement.

headline: Iran Is Said to Move to New Machines for Making Nuclear Fuel
abstract: Just days before new talks with the West, inspectors said Iran had begun installing upgraded equipment for enriching uranium that could help it produce fuel more quickly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days before Iran enters its first nuclear talks with the West since the summer, international nuclear inspectors said Thursday that the country has begun installing a new generation of equipment that should give it the ability to produce nuclear fuel much faster.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 21
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including downhill runs in Germany.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including downhill runs in Germany.

headline: Swiss Myths
abstract: Some free-market paradise.
lead_paragraph: Oh, my. Aaron Carroll is rightly very, very annoyed at Douglas Holtz-Eakin and Arik Roy for saying that Obamacare should be replaced with a free-market system, like Switzerland’s. As he points out, the Swiss system is nothing like their description. In particular, they denounce community rating — but Switzerland has community rating!

headline: N.F.L. Tries New Method for Testing Mental Agility
abstract: A psychological assessment, given in addition to the long-used Wonderlic test, resembles exams given to firefighters because they, like football players, must make quick decisions under stress.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — For decades, hundreds of college players have gathered each year at the N.F.L.’s scouting combine, where their strength is tested, their speed is timed and, in a test to measure their intelligence, they are asked questions like “When a rope is selling 20 cents per 2 feet, how many feet can you buy for 30 dollars?”

headline: U.S. Roster for Algarve Cup
abstract: Coach Tom Sermanni on Thursday announced the roster for the U.S. women’s national team that will play in the annual Algarve Cup in Portugal.
lead_paragraph: Coach Tom Sermanni on Thursday announced his 23-player roster for the United States women’s national team that will play in the annual Algarve Cup, a 12-nation tournament in Portugal.

headline: How Brill’s Health-Care Opus Jumped From The New Republic to Time
abstract: The author said he would never write for The New Republic again after his massive article was bumped from the cover by an interview with President Obama.
lead_paragraph: As Time Magazine’s 36-page cover story “Bitter Pill: Why Medical Bills are Killing Us” started to attract a storm of attention online and on television on Thursday, so did the story about how the article’s author Steven Brill came to write it for Time magazine.

headline: Britain Convicts 3 in Plot to Rival ’05 Transit Attack
abstract: Prosecutors said the three men, all British citizens from the industrial city of Birmingham, planned to detonate up to eight homemade bombs in rucksacks in crowded places.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three men accused of plotting what prosecutors said would have been the most devastating terrorist attacks in Britain since the London transit system bombings of July 2005 were convicted Thursday after a 12-week trial. The judge hearing the case told the men to expect life imprisonment.

headline: Bromance, Cricket and Sectarian Riots
abstract: The Bollywood movie “Kai Po Che” sets a story of three friends against the backdrop of the 2002 massacres of Muslims by Hindus in northwestern India.
lead_paragraph: Abhishek Kapoor’s “Kai Po Che” takes risks, not least in its choice of subject matter. Set in Ahmedabad, this tale of three friends making their way in the new India builds up to an ugly moment in recent history: the 2002 riots in Gujarat State in which Hindu mobs attacked Muslims, killing nearly 1,000.

headline: Lonely but Not Alone in the Big City
abstract: “Northeast” focuses on a newcomer to New York who spends a lot of time walking the streets aimlessly and picking up women.
lead_paragraph: Yet another young filmmaker has discovered the tired truths that it’s possible to live in a city of eight million people but feel alone, and that knocking about New York without a plan or ambition ultimately leads to emptiness. That might be a decent starting point for a movie, but Gregory Kohn makes it his whole movie, and the result, “Northeast,” is as tedious as the life of the film’s central character.

headline: In Outfield Trial, Yankees Swap Gardner and Granderson
abstract: Manager Joe Girardi said he wanted to get a look at a Yankees defense that has Curtis Granderson in left and Brett Gardner in center.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Manager Joe Girardi made official what was long expected, saying Thursday that he would experiment with Curtis Granderson in left field and Brett Gardner in center field as the Yankees close in on Saturday’s exhibition opener against the Atlanta Braves.

headline: ‘Impressionism, Fashion and Modernity’
abstract: Images from the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Images from the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: The Poetry in the Ruins of New York
abstract: An art reporter muses on his favorite ruins in New York, including the cemetery wall by St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral and the Brooklyn Lyceum.
lead_paragraph: Because New York City is so efficient at consuming its own past in the name of progress and profit, its ruins tend to hold the allure of rarities. Rome it will never be: a handful of abandoned subway stations; the crumbling old hospital buildings on Ellis and Roosevelt Islands; the Parachute Jump in Coney Island; Admiral’s Row at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, which will join the roster of ruins extinct when most of it is leveled this year to make way for a supermarket.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Mali, West Bank and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Mali, West Bank and Pakistan.

headline: For Music Industry, a Story of Two Googles
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Music']
abstract: When it comes to the music industry, there are two Googles — represented on one side by its suite of entertainment media services, and on the other by its mighty search engine.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the music industry, there are two Googles. And the difference between them leads to a complicated and fraught relationship.

headline: Celebrating the Upside of an Emotional Plunge
abstract: A teenager who is drawn to adventure, except in matters of the heart, finds the silver lining in a terrifying accident.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, I fell 100 feet into one of the steepest canyons in the United States. After tumbling 75 feet down the near-vertical canyonside, I dropped another 25 feet in free fall, landing in a dry stream bed between granite boulders.

headline: Before Wagner’s Cycle, but That Legend Has a Familiar Ring
abstract: Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, which is discussed but not heard in “Django Unchained,” takes on a new role in the context of slavery.
lead_paragraph: In Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained,” a film whose soundtrack echoes with the wide-vista twang of Ennio Morricone and some Rick Ross thrown in for good measure, one of the most important musical selections is one we never hear: Wagner’s “Ring” cycle.

headline: The Daily Do | Just Cavalli
abstract: Glamorous, combed-out curls read as pure ’70s sexiness as they bounced down the runway at Just Cavalli.
lead_paragraph: Glamorous, combed-out curls read as pure ’70s sexiness as they bounced down the runway at Just Cavalli.

headline: In the Spotlight
abstract: The Bieberesque 11-year-old hero of Teddy Wayne’s new novel is beginning to realize that he’s a confection — manufactured, managed and manipulated by a corporate team of adults.
lead_paragraph: Poor Jonny Valentine, the über-talented Bieberesque hero of Teddy Wayne’s new novel, “The Love Song of Jonny Valentine.” Sure, the 11-year-old singing, dancing heartthrob has money and fame, a cute fake girlfriend, six tour buses, even a namesake haircut. But it’s just beginning to dawn on Jonny that he’s a confection — manufactured, managed and manipulated by a corporate team of adults, led by his cool, carb-counting mother.

headline: K.K.R. Is Said to Bid $3.7 Billion for Gardner Denver
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has bid about $3.7 billion — or roughly $75 a share — for Gardner Denver, a maker of industrial equipment like blowers and compressors, a person briefed on the matter says.
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has bid about $3.7 billion for Gardner Denver, a maker of industrial equipment like blowers and compressors, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: How the Documentary Rule Changes Help ‘Sugar Man’
abstract: “Searching for Sugar Man” is the favorite to win the documentary Oscar, partly because of changes in rules governing how the winner is chosen.
lead_paragraph: Even if there hadn’t been a change in the Academy’s rules this year, “Searching for Sugar Man” would probably rank as the favorite in the race for the Oscar for best-feature length documentary. But the rules have been altered significantly, thereby broadening the types and numbers of Academy voters eligible to cast ballots in the category, and that decision appears to favor “Sugar Man,” made by the Swedish director Malik Bendjelloul on a shoestring budget.

headline: Newton’s New Vision
abstract: “Isaac’s Eye,” by Lucas Hnath, imagines Isaac Newton as an ambitious young man hoping to win admission to the Royal Society.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t you give points for originality?” Isaac Newton asks of his would-be mentor, a more senior scientist named Robert Hooke, in “Isaac’s Eye,” a new play by Lucas Hnath at the Ensemble Studio Theater.

headline: A Reunion, With Apologies for Last Time
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The Streetscapes column revisits the old New York Life Insurance Company after 20 years and finds its much improved.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, a Streetscapes profile of McKim, Mead & White’s magnificent 1898 headquarters for the New York Life Insurance Company remarked on the sorry condition of its once-grand interiors. The building, 346 Broadway at Leonard Street, was then as now owned and occupied by the City of New York.

headline: A Deal With the Devil to Save a Beloved Son
abstract: “Snitch” stars Dwayne Johnson as a company owner who enters the illegal-drug world to help reduce the sentence of his imprisoned son.
lead_paragraph: With his booming superhero voice and hulking physique, Dwayne Johnson, a k a the Rock, is an outsize cartoon figure, whether he likes it or not. And in “Snitch” — a grimy, realistic thriller with an agenda — he is simply too large for the role of John Matthews, the owner of a construction company somewhere in the heartland.

headline: Area Airports, Stalled by Hurricane, Missed a Record in 2012
abstract: More than 109 million passengers last year moved through the airports operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, a total that was about 600,000 shy of the high set in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Before Hurricane Sandy struck, the major airports in the New York metropolitan area were on pace to handle more travelers than they had in any previous year. But after the storm shut them down and forced the cancellation of thousands of flights, 2012 landed just short of the record set in 2007, before the recession.

headline: NBCUniversal Tells Madison Avenue Another Story From Curve Films
abstract: A nontraditional effort to reach out to advertising and media agencies in new ways is embarking on its second chapter.
lead_paragraph: A nontraditional effort to reach out to advertising and media agencies in new ways is embarking on its second chapter.

headline: Investigating Sex Discrimination
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Discrimination', 'Family Leaves', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Since a federal housing agency investigation, several lenders have reached agreements to settle complaints of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage lenders are not allowed to deny or delay a loan to a woman simply because she is on maternity leave. Yet the Department of Housing and Urban Development says it receives complaints that this is happening.

headline: Comedy Listings for Feb. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up and improv in New York.
lead_paragraph: Comedy

headline: The Cross-Dressing of Art and Couture
abstract: The Met’s exhibition “Impressionism, Fashion and Modernity” brings together great paintings, lavish garments and accessories to detail the entwined rise of modern painting, modern fashion and modern (upper middle-class) life in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: In name, at least, “Impressionism, Fashion and Modernity,” the thrilling, erudite show opening to the public on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, sounds like a double dose of pandering. Impressionism and fashion? The pairing portends blockbuster-bundling and seems so excessive as to be unhealthy — possibly illegal — like 32-ounce sodas. Brace for “Van Gogh and Motorcycles,” “Rembrandt and Fabergé” and “Norman Rockwell and Tim Burton.”

headline: Romance Can be Nice, but Rage Also Has Allure
abstract: “Body and Soul,” Carole J. Bufford’s new cabaret show at the Metropolitan Room, finds this singer using her hard-edge voice to explore a wide emotional scope.
lead_paragraph: If an award for “most likely to succeed” was up for grabs among the younger generation of New York cabaret performers, Carole J. Bufford would be high on the list of contenders. A doll-faced latter-day flapper with a broad sense of humor, Ms. Bufford radiates the unflappable (excuse the pun) confidence of a woman comfortable exerting power.

headline: Movie Listings for Feb. 22-28
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Movies

headline: Theater Listings for Feb. 22-28
abstract: A critical guide to plays running in New York, with special note of productions in previews or opening.
lead_paragraph: Theater

headline: Fendi: Is That a Rabbit in That Hat?
abstract: Displacement seems to interest Karl Lagerfeld more than usual this season.
lead_paragraph: “Leather, feather, fur!” said Karl Lagerfeld, and then broke into a laugh. Sitting backstage before the Fendi show, the designer took a moment to erase the Italian—or, maybe the French or German—version of the line from his brain. He simply meant that one thing can look like another. “Fashion is almost always about illusion,” he said.

headline: Pop Listings for Feb. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to rap, folk-rock, rock, pop, dream-pop and retro soul.
lead_paragraph: Pop

headline: It’s All About My Failed Romance
abstract: “Rubberneck” and “Red Flag,” two wispy, downbeat movies, were written and directed by Alex Karpovsky, the actor who plays Ray the barrista on the HBO show “Girls.”
lead_paragraph: Alex Karpovsky owes Lena Dunham big time. Without her, he would probably be just another struggling actor-filmmaker in the crowded indie marketplace. With her — and her HBO show, “Girls” (he plays Ray, the barrista) — he’s part of a cultural juggernaut.

headline: Apple Filed Patent for Flexible Wrist Display
abstract: Apple on Thursday filed a patent for a watchlike device that could wrap around someone’s wrist. The gadget comes with a touch screen and can list recent phone calls and text messages.
lead_paragraph: Forget sticking a fancy Apple television on your wall. It looks like we may be able to strap a display to our wrists in the not-too-distant future.

headline: Acquired Tastes of Asian Art
abstract: “No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia” shows off the Guggenheim’s global acquisitions campaign, with some works that reach across cultures, and others that need explanation.
lead_paragraph: Recently, and resoundingly, America’s big museums have shifted their collecting habits. Not only are they buying new art like mad, but a lot of that art also comes from outside the Western Hemisphere, particularly from Asia. The Guggenheim Museum, now embarked on a single-mindedly non-Western shopping spree, leads the pack.

headline: Jazz Listings for Feb. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Jazz

headline: Youthful Angst, Animated
abstract: The IFC show “Out There,” created by Ryan Quincy, a “South Park” animator, has a mopey 15-year-old protagonist and narrator.
lead_paragraph: Knowing that Ryan Quincy has spent more than a decade working as an animator and producer on “South Park” makes “Out There,” his new animated series for IFC, even more surprising. All that time he had this quiet, dreamy, charming, deeply personal tale inside him? Talk about cognitive dissonance.

headline: Looking Out for the Revelations
abstract: What gets actors to high-profile stage roles? Talent, persistence and a bit of luck.
lead_paragraph: What gets actors to high-profile stage roles? Talent, persistence and a bit of luck.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Feb. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to classical music and opera performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Classical

headline: A Painterly Eye Capturing a High-Flying Muse
abstract: “Miss La La at the Cirque Fernando,” at the Morgan Library, is part of a Degas retrospective featuring a late-19th-century aerialist.
lead_paragraph: Viewers catching their first glimpse of “Miss La La at the Cirque Fernando” will tend to agree with an early Degas biographer who called the painting “one of his most surprising canvases.”

headline: Dance Listings for Feb. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dance

headline: Inner Demons, Exorcised With Paint
abstract: A selection of 59 works by Jean-Michel Basquiat at the Gagosian Gallery demonstrates that his work is still vital and alive.
lead_paragraph: It is not true that only the good die young, but Jean-Michel Basquiat did at 27 in 1988. He was not only good; at his best he was one of the most original artists of his generation. If that sounds like an extravagant claim, you might have a look at the high-quality selection of 59 of his paintings at Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. There is not a lot of art from the ’80s that feels this alive today.

headline: Come Sit With Me While I Cook
abstract: Nicole and Brent Ferrin, apartment-hunting with a budget of about $1 million, decided that the financial district offered the most space for the money.
lead_paragraph: For four years, Nicole and Brent Ferrin were happy in their rented apartment in a postwar high-rise building on Murray Street in TriBeCa. They paid around $4,000 a month for a loftlike one-bedroom with around 1,200 square feet. They especially liked their two bathrooms.

headline: ‘Avatar: The Exhibition’
abstract: Images from a new show at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: Images from a new show at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Art

abstract: “Avatar: The Exhibition,” at the Liberty Science Center, examines the making of “Avatar” and some of the scientific principles from which that film draws.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — “Oeri nga kllkxem sìn kxetse!”

headline: Manhattan Rentals, Left Out in the Cold
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Ballooning land prices are giving developers little choice but to focus on building — or in some cases, converting to — high-end condos.
lead_paragraph: As developers continue to push the story line that New York’s luxury residential market is a high-end utopia that shows no signs of slowing, you might consider one seldom-discussed factor that is driving their decisions to build for the wealthiest buyers.
