abstract: A selected guide to cultural events in New York.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: The Latest in the Oscar Pistorius Case
abstract: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, talks with Lydia Polgreen, South Africa bureau chief, about the twists and turns in the pre-trial hearing of Olympian Oscar Pistorius.
lead_paragraph: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, talks with Lydia Polgreen, South Africa bureau chief, about the twists and turns in the pre-trial hearing of Olympian Oscar Pistorius.

headline: Wheelies: The Electric Network Edition
abstract: Estonia is the first country in the world to establish a nationwide network of fast chargers for electric vehicles, Reuters reports.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Prada: Done and Undone
abstract: The Prada show on Thursday night seemed to be drenched in shadow.
lead_paragraph: The Prada show on Thursday night seemed to be drenched in shadow. The lights on the raised wooden platform created shadows of the models, and some type of illuminated screen displayed the silhouette of a solitary woman and a cat and a flock of birds. Before the show, I stopped in the dressing room to see how the makeup artist Pat McGrath planned to interpret Miuccia Prada’s fall collection, and she said, inspecting a model’s face, “Done, undone beauty.” The tones — the wine-stained lips — looked as if they had faded away.

headline: A Tax That May Change the Trading Game
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A financial transaction tax could discourage the excesses of the trading system if Europe can pull it off.
lead_paragraph: To the dismay of the United States government — not to mention Wall Street — much of Europe seems poised to begin taxing financial trading as soon as next year.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Shunning Facebook, and Instagram Vision
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include a dress that becomes more transparent as the wearer becomes aroused, an estimate of the value of the “House of Cards” deal to Netflix and the all-male leadership of the not-all-male gaming industry.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: A Bar With a View, if You Look Up
abstract: The M Bar at the Mansfield Hotel, where the mixed drinks are a mixed bag, is just O.K., but sometimes that’s enough.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES an O.K. bar will do.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: The End of History
abstract: The End of History, a West Village shop, lures interior designers and international visitors.
lead_paragraph: The End of History, a West Village shop, lures interior designers and international visitors.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Police Brutality, Catalyst for Egypt’s Revolution, Continues Under Morsi
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: More than two years after Egyptians took to the streets to demand Hosni Mubarak’s resignation and an end to impunity for the security forces, activists say civilians are still raped, tortured and killed in police custody.
lead_paragraph: More than two years after tens of thousands of Egyptians took to the streets on Police Day to demand the resignation of Hosni Mubarak and an end to impunity for the security forces, activists report that civilians continue to be raped, tortured and killed in police custody.

headline: At a Loss on Refusing Medicaid Cash
abstract: Texas, by refusing to accept the federal government’s expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, would be shunning a pot of money.
lead_paragraph: Slogans can get in the way of politics. A number of the combatants in the quarrel over Medicaid expansion in Texas regularly tell voters that government should be run more like a business.

headline: Citigroup Toughens Executive Bonus Rules
abstract: After criticism of its pay practices, the bank will make compensation partly dependent on the company’s competitive performance.
lead_paragraph: Responding to anger over executive pay, Citigroup is changing the way it calculates the bonuses given to top executives. It announced on Thursday that part of the $11.5 million in compensation awarded to the new chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, would be closely tied to performance.

headline: States Planning to Expand Medicaid
abstract: Democratic governors have generally been more eager to expand Medicaid, ruled by the Supreme Court to be optional for states under the health care law. But seven Republican governors also have announced that they want to do so.
lead_paragraph: Democratic governors have generally been more eager to expand Medicaid, ruled by the Supreme Court to be optional for states under the health care law. But seven Republican governors also have announced that they want to do so.

headline: Obsessions in Color, Form and Glass
abstract: The End of History carries about 10,000 pieces of midcentury glassware and ceramics, organized by color and form.
lead_paragraph: “I call this an obsession turned into a business,” Stephen Saunders said on a recent Saturday evening. He was standing in the middle of the End of History, the West Village store he has owned since 1997, surrounded by the approximately 10,000 pieces of midcentury glassware and ceramics that make up his inventory.

headline: In El Paso County, Dairy Farming Ban Takes a Heavy Toll
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Dairy Products', 'Tuberculosis', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Now that Texas has regained its bovine tuberculosis-free status, Representative Mary González has introduced legislation to allow dairy farms back in El Paso and a sliver of Hudspeth County.
lead_paragraph: On most mornings, Eugene Licon drives 50 miles from his cows in Hudspeth County to his El Paso County cheese factory, shouldering extra fuel costs and man-hours that were not always required.

headline: Weighing Prospect of Changes in Graduation Requirements
abstract: Texas legislators are scrambling to scale back high school graduation requirements, a prospect that concerns some educators and pleases others.
lead_paragraph: Following backlash over the rocky institution of a new student assessment system last spring, Texas lawmakers are scrambling to scale back the requirements they passed four years ago. As the Legislature tackles such reform, attention is also focused on another area of education policy: high school graduation requirements.

headline: The Envelope, Please
abstract: With the bestowing of the Academy Awards looming, some last-minute handicapping of the competition for the major awards.
lead_paragraph: It’s been an eventful season. For the first time in recent memory the best picture Academy Award hopefuls are broadly popular: with critics, with moviegoers and with members of the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences, who anointed a revolving list of titles with front-runner status in the monthslong run-up to the Oscars on Sunday.

headline: Kicking Corzine Out of the ‘Club’ Proved to Be Not So Easy
keywords: ['Futures and Options Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The National Futures Association tried to impose a lifetime ban on Jon Corzine from the group. The problem, however: he was not even a member.
lead_paragraph: Jon S. Corzine could be the Groucho Marx of Wall Street.

headline: Another Renovation for Twins’ Ryan
abstract: Terry Ryan, who is starting the second season of his second stint as the general manager of the Minnesota Twins, is in full rebuilding mode.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla.

headline: Charges Filed in Peanut Salmonella Case
abstract: The charges against the former owner and several employees of the Peanut Corporation of America stemmed from an investigation into a deadly salmonella outbreak in 2009.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have filed criminal charges against the former owner and several employees of a now-defunct peanut company that was the source of a salmonella outbreak in 2009 that killed nine people and sickened more than 700.

headline: As the Competition Heats Up, So Does a Fight Over Homegrown Peppers
abstract: New Mexico lawmakers are seeking new ways to protect chile peppers, the state’s official vegetable, from competitors.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Chile peppers are to New Mexico what oranges are to Florida, apples are to Washington and peanuts are to Virginia: a defining source of chest-thumping pride. It is also the state’s official vegetable and the reason for such thing as the state’s official question — “Red or green?”

headline: Answers to Questions on Capital’s Top Topic
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A primer on the $85 billion across-the-board spending cuts due to take effect next month, which are dominating the political discussion in the capital.
lead_paragraph: Unless Congress intervenes, the law requires the Obama administration to impose $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts to military and domestic programs on March 1. Those cuts would be the start of $1 trillion in cuts over the next decade.

headline: A National Push Seeks to Separate Sake From Sushi
abstract: Ty Ku, a six-year-old sake brand, is hoping to change the perception of sake through nationally televised advertising.
lead_paragraph: FOR Americans who drink sake only at Japanese restaurants, the thought of ordering it at a bar or buying it at the supermarket may seem as out of place as using chopsticks to eat Cheerios.

headline: One of World’s Most Efficient Vehicles Unable to Enter U.S.
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: The regulations holding up the release of the vehicle are complex, but essentially the vehicle doesn’t comply with all government rules.
lead_paragraph: 12:35 a.m. | Updated One of the world’s most efficient vehicles and an X Prize winner has been unable to enter the United States since Jan. 25, held up at the Port of Los Angeles at the city’s international airport by the Environmental Protection Agency, United States Customs and the Transportation Department, people associated with the vehicle said on Thursday.

headline: Neighbors Kill Neighbors as Kenyan Vote Stirs Old Feuds
abstract: In less than two weeks, Kenyans will line up by the millions to pick their leaders for the first time since a vote in 2007, which set off clashes that killed more than 1,000 people.
lead_paragraph: MALINDI, Kenya — In a room by the stairs, Shukrani Malingi, a Pokomo farmer, writhed on a metal cot, the skin on his back burned off. Down the hall, at a safe distance, Rahema Hageyo, an Orma girl, stared blankly out of a window, a long scar above her thimble-like neck. She was nearly decapitated by a machete chop — and she is only 9 months old.

headline: Georgia: Emory Head Censured for Slavery Column
abstract: The president of Emory University, James W. Wagner, was censured Wednesday over a magazine column in which he wrote favorably about the three-fifths compromise over slavery.
lead_paragraph: The president of Emory University, James W. Wagner, was censured Wednesday over a magazine column in which he wrote favorably about the three-fifths compromise over slavery. Mr. Wagner’s column in Emory Magazine cited the 1787 compromise, which counted slaves as three-fifths of a person for determining representation in Congress, as an example of how leaders reach successful agreements. He apologized on Sunday for the “clumsiness and insensitivity” of the column, calling slavery “heinous, repulsive, repugnant and inhuman.” At a meeting of the faculty of the College of Arts and Sciences on Wednesday, faculty members debated a vote of no confidence in Mr. Wagner, but delayed that decision until next month, voting to censure him instead. At least one professor called for his resignation.

headline: Pennsylvania: Justice and Her Sister Are Convicted
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Elections', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: A suspended justice of the State Supreme Court was convicted Thursday of campaign corruption charges in a case that has engulfed a prominent Pittsburgh political family.
lead_paragraph: A suspended justice of the State Supreme Court was convicted Thursday of campaign corruption charges in a case that has engulfed a prominent Pittsburgh political family. Justice Joan Orie Melvin and her sister Janine Orie were accused of using Ms. Orie Melvin’s former court staff — as well as the staff of their sister former State Senator Jane Orie — to run two of her campaigns for the Supreme Court. Both of the sisters were found guilty of six counts, including theft of services and criminal conspiracy. Ms. Orie Melvin was charged in May and suspended without pay. Jane Orie was sentenced in June to 2.5 to 10 years in prison on charges related to her own use of her staff for her and her sister’s campaigns.

headline: Fairy Tales Come True, Even on Monday
abstract: Saving money is only one reason some couples are being married on weekdays.
lead_paragraph: What is a bride to do when she falls in love with a reception site that is beyond her budget? Start negotiating or consider a Thursday.

headline: Official Says Union Is Stalling on H.G.H.
abstract: Adolpho Birch, an N.F.L. senior vice president, said the union was stalling because it was unhappy with other aspects of the 18-month-old collective bargaining agreement.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Adolpho Birch, the N.F.L.’s senior vice president for law and labor policy, suggested Thursday that the players union was holding up an agreement to begin testing for human growth hormone because it was unhappy with other aspects of the 18-month-old collective bargaining agreement, including the commissioner’s authority in disciplinary matters.

headline: A Foot or More of Snow Slams Midwest States
abstract: A windy storm brought most travel to a crawl in parts of Kansas and Missouri, where emergencies were declared.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Lightning flashed and thunder rumbled as a frigid, windy winter storm whipped through the middle of the country on Thursday, dumping more than a foot of snow in some areas. Highways looked like obstacle courses with jackknifed trucks and other vehicles stuck on roads and in ditches.

headline: Vestige of Bygone Era Endures Time, and Talk of Its Demise
keywords: ['Signs and Signage', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The red neon of the Kentile Floors sign has long dimmed, but it is still alluring to aficionados of old Brooklyn, and a recent rumor of its end sent them into a tizzy.
lead_paragraph: The sign looms over the industrial landscape of Gowanus, Brooklyn, like an enigmatic message from another age.

headline: Teams Deal Sidekicks, but Stars Stay Put
abstract: Two dozen players changed teams at the N.B.A. trading deadline, but no full-time starters were dealt, with J. J. Redick the most prominent player traded.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-one players changed teams at the N.B.A. trading deadline Thursday, and none were named Dwight Howard or Josh Smith. Few of them even had names worth remembering.

headline: The Bus Strike, Phase Two
abstract: School buses are running, but the fight’s not over. The city should not give in to union demands on job protection.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg was right not to give in to union demands for job protection for New York City’s school bus drivers. The drivers went back to work this week after a monthlong strike that affected more than 100,000 students. But the dispute between the city and the union is clearly not over.

headline: Ambushed, a Few Steps Short of the Door
abstract: A Washington Heights man who usually takes a cab to get home late at night was beaten when he opted to travel underground.
lead_paragraph: “Steps from the subway,” the advertisement for the apartment had said, and so there James Fordyce was on Sunday night, trying to crawl up steps from the 190th Street stop on the A train. His brain was bleeding, his face was broken, his arms mashed. It was a night of bitter winds. Ahead of him, above the Hudson River, was a moon with the slashing whiteness of a frigid night.

headline:
Governors Fall Away
in G.O.P. Opposition
to More Medicaid
abstract: After vigorous lobbying by the health industry, seven Republican governors are moving to accept federal funds under the health care law to add medical coverage for more low-income people.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from the health care industry and consumer advocates, seven Republican governors are cautiously moving to expand Medicaid, giving an unexpected boost to President Obama’s plan to insure some 30 million more Americans.

headline: Making Some Painkillers Harder to Get
abstract: Widely abused prescription drugs like Vicodin need tighter restrictions to curb the epidemic.
lead_paragraph: Painkillers like Vicodin that contain hydrocodone are the most widely prescribed drugs in the United States — and the most widely abused because they are relatively easy to obtain. The Food and Drug Administration has an opportunity to help tighten restrictions on drugs whose use has spiraled out of control over the past two decades.

headline: The Carpetbagger’s 2013 Oscar Predictions
abstract: To prepare for Sunday’s Academy Awards broadcast, here’s the Carpetbagger’s inside look at the front-runners and back stories.
lead_paragraph: To prepare for Sunday’s Academy Awards broadcast, here’s the Carpetbagger’s inside look at the front-runners and back stories.

headline: Why Taxes Have to Go Up
abstract: Without new revenues, safe and sane deficit reduction is impossible.
lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans remain at odds on how to avoid a round of budget cuts so deep and arbitrary that to allow them now could push the economy back into recession. The cuts, known as a sequester, will kick in March 1 unless Republicans agree to President Obama’s demand to a legislative package that combines spending reductions and tax increases. As of Thursday, with the deadline a week off, Republicans seemed determined to say no to any new tax increases.

headline: The Case for a Higher Gasoline Tax
abstract: If our goal is to get Americans to drive less and use more fuel-efficient vehicles, and to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases, gas prices need to be even higher.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: To Fight India, We Fought Ourselves
abstract: At the heart of Pakistan’s troubles is the celebration of the militant. And the need of the hour, of the year, of the generation, is peace.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan

headline: Sequester of Fools
abstract: Here we go again! That terrible fiscal crisis we were warned about two years ago is just around the corner. Is anyone interested?
lead_paragraph: They’re baaack! Just about two years ago, Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson, the co-chairmen of the late unlamented debt commission, warned us to expect a terrible fiscal crisis within, um, two years unless we adopted their plan. The crisis hasn’t materialized, but they’re nonetheless back with a new version. And, in case you’re interested, after last year’s election — in which American voters made it clear that they want to preserve the social safety net while raising taxes on the rich — the famous fomenters of fiscal fear have moved to the right, calling for even less revenue and even more spending cuts.

headline: Top Cuomo Aide Delivers Public Rebuke of State Worker Who Talked to the Press
abstract: The aide, Howard B. Glaser, took to the airwaves about an engineer who broke a rule, faced disciplinary action and resigned.
lead_paragraph: Mike Fayette broke the rules. An engineer at the New York State Transportation Department, he gave an interview to a reporter from The Adirondack Daily Enterprise.

headline: The D.C. Dubstep
abstract: Politicians in both parties are dancing as though they’re secretly in love with sequestration, a total disaster for the country.
lead_paragraph: On July 26, 2011, Jack Lew, then the White House budget director, went to Harry Reid’s office for a budget strategy session. According to Bob Woodward’s book, “The Price of Politics,” Lew told the Senate majority leader that they had come up with a trigger idea to force a budget deal.

headline: McIlroy and Woods Fall in Match Play
abstract: After a 24-hour snow delay, Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods lost in their opening matches at the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — It was hard enough for Charles Howell III to keep calm and carry on when he knew he had a Wednesday date against Tiger Woods in the first round of the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship. Then the schedule was buried underneath four inches of snow, and Howell had another day and a half to ponder his match against Woods, whom he had never beaten in match-play competition or in their dozens of practice matches during the years they were neighbors in Orlando, Fla.

headline: For Obama and Team, Calm, Not Crisis, in Latest Fiscal Battle
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation', 'Law and Legislation', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: President Obama is just seven days away from the first significant test of his second term as deep spending cuts loom.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is just seven days away from the first significant test of his second term as deep spending cuts loom, yet inside the White House a clear sense of confidence stands in contrast to the air of crisis that surrounded previous fiscal showdowns with Republicans.

headline: F.A.A. Weighs Criteria for Allowing 787 to Fly
abstract: Experts say that Boeing’s proposals for the 787 are on the right track, but that without knowing what caused the jets’ batteries to fail, they cannot be sure the measures will work.
lead_paragraph: Within hours after a smoking battery forced a Boeing 787 to make an emergency landing on Jan. 16, Michael P. Huerta, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, wrestled with where to set the bar to allow the jets back in the air if he grounded them.

headline: Investigation of Spanish Duke Draws Royals Into Scandal
abstract: A corruption inquiry of Iñaki Urdangari, the Duke of Palma and the king’s son-in-law, has left the palace scrambling.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Web site of the Spanish royal family features pictures of the king, Juan Carlos I, in a blue sash, his bejeweled wife, Queen Sofía, and the couple’s three glamorous children. But most of the photographs of the dashing Duke of Palma, the king’s son-in-law, were scrubbed from the site last month.

headline: Brooklyn Construction Company Shortchanged Workers, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The SM&B Construction Company defrauded the School Construction Authority by paying workers far less than they were obligated to, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of a construction company were charged in federal court on Thursday with defrauding New York City’s School Construction Authority of more than $32 million, paying workers less than they were obligated to, and skimming the rest. Prosecutors said they laundered more than $3 million of the illegal profits to finance an investment in an amusement park in Pakistan.

headline: Smooth Recovery for Met, Who Seeks Same for Delivery
abstract: With questions about his health all but answered after a season-ending surgery last year, Dillon Gee is looking forward to addressing those about his performance.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Dillon Gee has come a long way since last summer, when a blood clot that turned his pitching hand purple made him wonder whether he would play baseball again.

headline: Deli King’s Downfall: $82 Million Check-Kiting Case
abstract: Prosecutors say Saquib Khan, a business owner in New York, carried out one of the largest check-fraud schemes in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Saquib Khan, the deli king of Staten Island, was in trouble.

headline: What Gov. Cuomo’s Budget Needs
abstract: A distressing hole is one of several concerns about the $142 billion state package for the 2013-14 fiscal year.
lead_paragraph: The latest budget package from Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, unveiled this week, has a distressing $500 million hole, caused by a change in the way the federal government will reimburse the state for the care of people with disabilities. Federal regulators have said that the state has been overbilling Medicaid for those services.

headline: Case Ends Against Ex-Blackwater Officials
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Firearms', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: Charges against three former officials of Blackwater Worldwide were dismissed, and two others agreed to plead guilty to reduced charges with no jail time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government’s three-year prosecution of five former officials of Blackwater Worldwide virtually collapsed on Thursday after charges against three of the officials were dismissed and the other two agreed to plead guilty to reduced misdemeanor charges with no jail time.

abstract: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce disagrees with a DealBook column urging that the tax be revived.

headline: Should Companies Tell Us When They Get Hacked?
abstract: Although hacking is common, it's rare for companies to talk about it. Would disclosure make consumers safer, or just help hackers?

headline: Patent System Isn’t Broken
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The general counsel of Qualcomm responds to a column by Joe Nocera, “Innovation Nation at War.”

headline: Don’t Judge a College’s Value by Graduates’ Paycheck

abstract: Drew Gilpin Faust, the president of Harvard, responds to a news article about the College Scorecard Web site.

headline: 3 City Leaders Squabble Over Fines for Businesses
abstract: A barbed back-and-forth involving three of the city’s most powerful elected officials hinted at the emerging fault lines of the 2013 race for mayor.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, it was a simple skirmish over New York’s rising fines against small businesses, an everyday nuisance of municipal life.

abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, Feb. 22, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "There are three reasons for this war: tribe, land and politics.”

headline: Despite Aid, Borrowers Still Face Foreclosure
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Thousands of homeowners who received help on their second mortgage are still facing foreclosure on their first mortgage, according to housing advocates.
lead_paragraph: A year after five of the nation’s biggest banks reached a pact with state and federal officials over claims of vast foreclosure abuses, the banks are taking credit for giving more than half a million struggling homeowners roughly $45.8 billion in relief.

headline: Deadbeat Father Pleads Guilty to Evading Child Support
abstract: A man who owed more than $1 million in child support and was labeled the nation’s most-wanted deadbeat parent by federal authorities could face prison time.
lead_paragraph: A man who owed more than $1 million in child support and was labeled the nation’s most-wanted deadbeat parent by federal authorities pleaded guilty on Thursday to traveling across state lines and overseas to avoid making his child-support payments.

headline: Judge Says State Cannot Withhold Aid to City Schools Over Teacher Evaluation Impasse
abstract: Justice Manuel J. Mendez ruled that a penalty, for New York City’s failure to agree on a teacher evaluation plan, could hurt the neediest children.
lead_paragraph: State officials, for now, cannot stop $260 million in aid from flowing into New York City’s schools as a penalty for the city’s failure to iron out a plan for evaluating public school teachers, a state judge ruled this week.

headline: Patrick, Primed for a Sunday Drive, Takes No Chances
abstract: Danica Patrick moved her No. 10 Chevrolet to the back of the pack in the first of the two Budweiser Duel 150’s, avoided a major crash and finished 17th.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — The only way to mar the heavily promoted storybook start to the 2013 Sprint Cup season would have been for the Nascar darling Danica Patrick to crash in a qualifying race Thursday at Daytona International Speedway and lose her place on the pole for Sunday’s season-opening Daytona 500.

headline: Lord of the Ring
abstract: Friday brain crunching with Martin Ashwood-Smith.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial A.C.P.T. Alert! If you plan to be in the New York area March 8-10 for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, there is still time to sign up for the Friday night Cru Dinner, an unofficial regular part of the festivities. Hosted by puzzlers who hark back to the old crosswords forum — and that’s a lot of harking, believe me — the Cru Dinner is a great way to meet your fellow puzzleheads if you’re a first timer, and a wonderful way to catch up with old friends if you’re a veteran. Click here for more information about how to register for the dinner.

headline: A Titan’s How-To on Breaking the Glass Ceiling
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Careers and Professions', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, is attempting to start a national discussion for women in the workplace with her new book, and a social movement.
lead_paragraph: Before Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, started to write “Lean In,” her book-slash-manifesto on women in the workplace, she rereadBetty Friedan’s “The Feminine Mystique.” Like the homemaker turned activist who helped start a revolution 50 years ago, Ms. Sandberg wanted to do far more than sell books.

headline: Court Temporarily Halts Plan to Close a Brooklyn Hospital
abstract: Plans by the State University of New York’s board to close  Long Island College Hospital have been stopped by a judge after hospital workers filed a complaint.
lead_paragraph: A state judge has temporarily halted plans to close the financially ailing Long Island College Hospital, giving a victory to hospital workers who say that its closing would be devastating to community health care.

headline: Sheryl Sandberg’s ‘Lean In’ Foundation and Movement
abstract: Documents circulated by Lean In to potential partners explain what Sheryl Sandberg is trying to do — and also suggest why she is already attracting criticism.
lead_paragraph: Documents circulated by Lean In to potential partners explain what Sheryl Sandberg is trying to do — and also suggest why she is already attracting criticism.

headline: The Rise of a Protest Movement Shows the Depth of Italy’s Disillusionment
abstract: A protest party draws support from voters who are fed up with politics, but its success could make governing Italy even harder than it already is.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For months, he has been shouting his way from piazza to piazza, drawing tens of thousands as he rails against tax collectors, corrupt politicians and financial speculation. And when he arrives in Rome on Friday for the final campaign rally of his “Tsunami tour,” Beppe Grillo, the Internet-savvy comedian turned populist rabble-rouser, may lead Italy’s third-most popular party.

headline: After Shipping Off Brewer, the Knicks Add Martin to an Already Volatile Mix
abstract: Ronnie Brewer was traded to Oklahoma City, and the Knicks agreed to terms with Kenyon Martin, 35, who was expected to sign a 10-day contract this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson wanted a roster infused with experience and passion. Lately, the experience has looked more like old age, and the passion has turned to volatility.

headline: A Retiring General Notes ‘the Price We Have Paid’
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Gen. John R. Allen, the former senior commander in Afghanistan, pointed to the American lives lost there and said the sacrifice had been worth it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a reflective farewell on Wednesday evening, Gen. John R. Allen recalled a recent trip to Section 60 of Arlington National Cemetery where, he said, “you can see the entire swath of the American experience in Afghanistan.”

headline: Russia Backs Off Claim of Murder in Death of Adopted Boy in Texas
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Russian officials retreated from accusing a Texas woman of murder in the death of a 3-year-old boy she adopted from Russia, as the cause of his death remained unclear.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian officials retreated from allegations of murder against a Texas woman whose 3-year-old son adopted from Russia died in late January, as investigators in the United States said the cause of the boy’s death remained unclear.

headline: Space Holiday by Powerful Robot
abstract: Video game companies like Powerful Robot, which has developed for clients in the United States, are finding a base in Montevideo, Uruguay.
lead_paragraph: Video game companies like Powerful Robot, which has developed for clients in the United States, are finding a base in Montevideo, Uruguay.

headline: D.E.D. by Trojan Chicken
abstract: D.E.D., a detective game in which players solve thefts of national heritage, is designed to be played on inexpensive laptops distributed to schoolchildren across Uruguay.
lead_paragraph: D.E.D., a detective game in which players solve thefts of national heritage, is designed to be played on inexpensive laptops distributed to schoolchildren across Uruguay.

headline: Pastoral Uruguay Yields a Crop of Digital Yetis and Adventures
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Engineering and Engineers']
abstract: The country may be better known for its flocks of sheep and herds of cattle, but attention is shifting to its growing start-ups that are engineering video games.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — For a start-up that has a hit video game for the iPhone, the new loft-style offices of Ironhide Game Studio are exactly what one would expect — a newly hired staff labors feverishly on software updates not far from a pinball machine and custom-built monster arcade cabinet intended for letting off steam.

headline: Robert C. Richardson, Laureate in Physics, Dies at 75
abstract: Dr. Richardson’s prize-winning work involved cooling helium to liquid form, a breakthrough that has enabled research into a variety of scientific problems.
lead_paragraph: Robert C. Richardson, who shared the 1996 Nobel Prize in Physics for coaxing a rare form of helium into a bizarre liquid state that had never been seen before, died on Tuesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75.

headline: Man Acquitted in Officer’s Death Gets 2 Years for Probation Violation
abstract: Michael Velez was acquitted in the 2011 shooting of Officer Peter Figoski, but was found guilty of violating his probation.
lead_paragraph: A man who was acquitted of murder last week for his alleged role as the getaway driver in the fatal shooting of a New York police officer was sentenced on Thursday to two years in prison for violating his probation in an unrelated case.

headline: Venezuela: Chávez Continues Treatment
abstract: President Hugo Chávez continues to be treated for breathing problems two months after having cancer surgery in Cuba, a government spokesman said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Hugo Chávez continues to be treated for breathing problems two months after having cancer surgery in Cuba, a government spokesman said Thursday. Mr. Chávez returned to Venezuela on Monday but has not been seen in public since before his Dec. 11 operation. “The respiratory deficiency that arose in the course of the postoperative period persists, and its tendency has not been favorable, for which reason he continues to be treated,” the information minister, Ernesto Villegas, said in the first official update on the president’s health since his return. He did not say what the treatment was, but last week he said the president had a tube inserted in his trachea to aid in breathing.

headline: Germany: Morning-After Pill Allowed for the Victims of Rape, Bishops Say
abstract: In a softening of their stance, Germany’s Roman Catholic bishops said that church-run hospitals could give women who had been raped versions of the pill that prevent fertilization.
lead_paragraph: In a softening of their hard-line stance toward the use of contraception, Germany’s Roman Catholic bishops said Thursday that hospitals run by the church could provide women who had been raped with versions of the morning-after pill that prevent fertilization. The Catholic Church has faced strong criticism after a rape victim was recently turned away by two hospitals it runs in Cologne, because staff members were concerned about having to counsel the woman about emergency contraception. In a statement issued Thursday, the bishops said they had not been aware that various forms of emergency contraception were available, and after consulting with medical experts and with the Vatican, agreed that administering drugs that in no way aborted a fertilized egg was justified in cases of rape. The bishops said the new policy would be discussed with hospitals run by the church to ensure that “women who have been the victims of rape are provided human, medical, psychological and pastoral support,” which could include “administration of the morning-after pill.”

headline: Somalia: U.S. Promises More Food Aid
abstract: An American delegation met with Somali leaders in Mogadishu, the capital, on Thursday and announced $20 million in new American food aid for Somalia.
lead_paragraph: An American delegation led by the administrator of the Agency for International Development, Rajiv Shah, met with Somali leaders in Mogadishu, the capital, on Thursday and announced $20 million in new American food aid for Somalia. Mr. Shah said that after two decades of conflict, famine and terrorism, it was necessary not only to address Somalia’s “critical emergency needs” but also to promote stability and recovery. “It is important now to build a government and capacity for this country to become self-sufficient and to prosper economically so that children don’t die because they don’t have food to eat,” Mr. Shah said. In January, Washington formally recognized Somalia’s government for the first time since 1991.

headline: C’mon, Knicks: Go Bold. Go Old.
abstract: The Knicks, who started the season as the oldest team in  N.B.A. history, just got older, by adding the 35-year-old forward Kenyon Martin. Here are some players the Knicks could have added who go way back.
lead_paragraph: As the N.B.A. trading deadline approached Thursday afternoon, the Knicks sent 27-year-old guard Ronnie Brewer to the Thunder for a draft pick. That left the Knicks with a roster spot to fill, and a few hours later they said they were going to sign 35-year-old forward Kenyon Martin, who has yet to play an N.B.A. game this season. By replacing Brewer with Martin, the Knicks, who started the season as the oldest team in N.B.A. history, got even older. Surely a team that in the off-season signed Rasheed Wallace, a 38-year-old who had been out of the N.B.A. for two years, has more vision than that. Here are some suggestions.

headline: Martin Zweig, Who Forecast ’87 Market Crash, Dies at 70
abstract: The investor, author and analyst had a history of accurately predicting the stock market.
lead_paragraph: Martin Zweig, an influential investor and television pundit who predicted the 1987 stock market crash, published a closely followed newsletter and in 1999 made what at the time was the most expensive residential purchase in New York history, died on Monday at his home in Fisher Island, Fla. He was 70.

headline: Otto Beisheim, German Retailing Pioneer, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Beisheim, who introduced the concept of selling wholesale goods directly to German consumers and built the country’s largest retailer, Metro, was known as intensely private.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Otto Beisheim, who revolutionized retailing in postwar Germany by introducing the concept of selling wholesale goods directly to customers and the builder of the country’s largest retailer, Metro, was found dead on Monday at his home in Bavaria. He was 89.

headline: Taking a Stand for 46 Hours
abstract: For two days, the participants of Thon, Penn State’s grueling charity event, stand, dance, sing, sweat, swell and ache, all for pediatric cancer care and research.
lead_paragraph: I was driving my daughter home from college last year when we stopped at Penn State to visit a couple of her friends. I treated them to breakfast when they urged me to do a story on Thon.

headline: First Winners of Kennedy Playwriting Prize Announced
abstract: Dan O’Brien’s “Body of an American” and Robert Schenkkan’s “All the Way” are the first winners of the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History.
lead_paragraph: Two plays, Dan O’Brien’s “Body of an American” and Robert Schenkkan’s “All the Way,” are the inaugural winners of the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History, Columbia University and one of the late senator’s sisters, Jean Kennedy Smith, will announce on Friday. The two writers will each receive $50,000 and collaborate with Columbia librarians to create Web sites featuring scholarly articles and discussion relating to the content of the plays.

headline: Pat Derby, Champion of Animal Welfare, Dies at 69
abstract: Ms. Derby was among the first animal rights advocates to champion performing animals, especially exotic species like elephants, apes, monkeys, lions and tigers.
lead_paragraph: Pat Derby, a former animal trainer for television shows like “Lassie” and “Flipper” who became a crusader against animal exploitation in entertainment and founded of one of the largest privately operated wildlife sanctuaries in the United States, died last Friday at her home in San Andreas, Calif. She was 69.

headline: Kevin Ayers, a Psychedelic Rocker, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Ayers helped shape early psychedelia, influencing Jimi Hendrix and Pink Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Ayers, a wayward, witty British rocker who helped shape early psychedelia and was admired throughout his hard-lived life as a musician’s musician with little appetite for stardom, died on Monday at his home in the town of Montolieu, in the South of France. He was 68.

headline: North Korea Widens Internet Access, but Just for Visitors
abstract: Pyongyang opens the door a bit more to cyberspace, but North Korean citizens are not the beneficiaries.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — North Korea will finally allow Internet searches on mobile devices and laptops. But if you’re a North Korean, you’re out of luck — only foreigners will get this privilege.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) SISTER ROSETTA THARPE: THE GODMOTHER OF ROCK & ROLL From the 1940s through the ’60s, Ms. Tharpe (1915-73), above, accompanying herself on a newly electrified guitar, introduced spiritual passion into the secular world of rock ’n’ roll and inspired stars like Chuck Berry, Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis and Little Richard. “American Masters” begins its 27th season with this chronicle of Ms. Tharpe’s life, from her impoverished childhood as the daughter of cotton pickers in Arkansas and her adolescence in Chicago, where she developed her distinctive performing style in church, to her move to New York. There she caught the eye of Cab Calloway and Duke Ellington through songs laden with sexual innuendo at the Cotton Club and Café Society. But soon she returned to her gospel roots and drew packed houses throughout the United States and Europe. Directed by Mick Csaky, this documentary merges archival performance footage with new interviews with Joe Boyd, the tour manager of the 1964 American Folk, Blues and Gospel Caravan; Howard Carroll of the Dixie Hummingbirds; Roxie Moore, a lifelong friend; and Gayle Wald, a Tharpe biographer.

headline: As Deaths Rise in Hyderabad Blasts, Questions Emerge Over Ignored Warnings
abstract: Disabled CCTV cameras were not repaired, and Delhi police and intelligence agencies warned attacks could come.
lead_paragraph: Updated at 3:00 p.m. ISTThe death toll from Thursday’s explosions in Hyderabad has risen to 16, officials said Friday, and the number of injured is more than 100.

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 22
abstract: Spain’s royal family is caught in an embezzlement scandal; Kenyans brace for elections; urban residents in Japan find a new way to earn retirement income; and an investigation into soccer match-fixing progresses.
lead_paragraph: NEWS In Spain, an intensifying investigation aimed at Iñaki Urdangarin, the Duke of Palma and the king’s son-in-law, has placed the palace under siege. Doreen Carvajal reports from Madrid.

headline: Warning Signs Seen Ahead of India Bombings
abstract: The death toll from the explosions in Hyderabad rose Friday to 16 people, as new information suggested the attacks had been long planned.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The death toll from Thursday’s explosions in Hyderabad, India, rose on Friday to 16 people, as new information about India’s deadliest bombing since 2011 suggested the attacks had been long planned, raising questions about whether they could have been prevented.

headline: Pistorius Is Granted Bail in Killing of Girlfriend
abstract: After hearing impassioned arguments, a South African magistrate set bail for Oscar Pistorius, the athlete accused of murdering his girlfriend, at about $112,000.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — After four days of combative hearings, a South African magistrate on Friday granted bail for Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, in a case that has horrified and fascinated the nation and much of the world.

headline: Can Doordarshan’s New Look Attract Profits?
abstract: India’s money-losing public broadcasting company has revamped to compete in a cutthroat media market.
lead_paragraph: After it became the first TV channel in India in 1959, the public broadcaster Doordarshan enjoyed a monopoly on viewership for decades. Even after the government opened the airwaves to private players in 1992, Doordarshan enjoyed a 90 percent share of the audience in the 1990s and had no reason to take the threat of competition seriously.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Feb. 22, 2013
abstract: The sentences from this article are out of order. In what order should they appear?
lead_paragraph: As of Feb. 15, we’re posting new questions each Friday that test your editing skills. To learn more about why we are substituting these for the critical thinking questions we’d previously asked, see our note.

headline: 3-D Printers Might Be the Must-Have Gadget of the Future
abstract: Why would you want a 3-D printer for your home?
lead_paragraph: In “A Factory on Your Kitchen Counter,” Steven Kurutz writes about 3-D printers available for the consumer market.

headline: Russia Sends Aid to Mali as Fighting Flares
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The planeload of humanitarian aid was dispatched after Russia’s foreign minister warned about the spread of terrorism in North Africa.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia sent a planeload of food, blankets and other aid to war-stricken Mali on Friday, a day after Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov warned about the spread of terrorism in North Africa, which the Russian government has linked to Western intervention in Libya.

headline: Chinese Buoys Are Focus of Latest Dispute Over Contested Islands
abstract: Japan has asked the Chinese government to explain why Chinese ships have strategically placed several buoys in the East China Sea near a group of disputed islands.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan has asked the Chinese government to explain why Chinese ships have strategically placed several buoys in the East China Sea near a group of disputed islands, a Japanese government spokesman said on Friday.

headline: Have You Ever Found Something Valuable?
abstract: What did you find? Where did you find it? What did you decide to do with it?
lead_paragraph: Residents in some Siberian towns in Russia are searching for meteorite fragments buried in deep snow and lodged in roof tiles after last Friday’s fiery explosion in the sky. Speculators are offering upward of a thousand dollars for pebbles, and Russians are pondering what to do with the treasure they find.

headline: Renewed Signs of Europe’s Economic Weakness
abstract: As a leading European official warned that the euro-area economy would shrink for a second year, Moody’s downgraded Britain’s government bonds from its top rating.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Despite growing confidence that Europe is managing its debt crisis and is poised to embark on a recovery, fresh developments on Friday indicated that the region continues to struggle to stimulate growth while cutting spending to pare deficits.

headline: Daily Report: Digital Access to Runway Fashion
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Fashion houses in recent years started to sidestep the middleman by giving the public a front-row seat via webcam video. While that was more of a marketing tool at first, live streaming — and other ways to give consumers digital access to runway fashion — is now being seen as a research opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week, which wrapped up last week in New York and moved on to London and to Milan this week, used to be an insular industry event. Buyers and editors attended and made calls as to what their customers would want months from now.

headline: For Traumatized Caregivers, Therapy Helps
abstract: Therapists said they often encountered symptoms of trauma among caregivers, even though research documenting this phenomenon is scarce.
lead_paragraph: I recently wrote about caregivers who experienced symptoms of traumatic-like stress, and readers responded with heart-rending stories. Many described being haunted by distress long after a relative died.

headline: Q&A: Moving the Mac’s Dock
abstract: Like the Taskbar in Windows, the Mac’s Dock can also be relocated to other edges of the desktop.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Bala Panditji, a Priest from Delhi
abstract: Religion means “understanding oneself,” one Kumbh Mela participant says.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this year’s 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

headline: Learning Social Media Tricks From the Big Boys
abstract: Once a year, Dell invites 10 of its loudest critics on an all-expenses-paid trip to Austin, Tex., to meet with the company.
lead_paragraph: If you still have doubts about whether social media marketing can be effective, here’s a quote from a recent Bain & Company study that you might find interesting: “Customers who engage with companies over social media spend 20 percent to 40 percent more money with those companies than other customers. They also demonstrate a deeper emotional commitment to the companies, granting them an average 33 points higher net promoter score, a common measure of customer loyalty.”

headline: General Electric Chief Remains Cautiously Optimistic About India
abstract: G.E. continues to invest in India and business will grow, Jeffrey R. Immelt predicts.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – On a visit to India, the head of one of the world’s largest companies painted a fairly optimistic portrait of India’s growth prospects, although he hinted that Indian policy makers had reasons for concern.

headline: The Meat of the Matter
abstract: If no matter what meat you choose at the supermarket, you get horse, perhaps it’s better to buy food you can’t choose from a local co-op.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The sun was shining in North London on Wednesday, but the wind was cold and biting, so the vegetable packers were working indoors. Two of them — a young man in a hooded top and a woman with long blond hair — were weighing onions and sorting them into brown paper bags.

headline: Would You Cut Down on Meat to Help the Environment?
abstract: A new study says our hunger for meat does even more environmental damage than we thought and scientists say there’s a relatively painless way you can help.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “I could eat a horse” has acquired a new meaning in Europe, where horse DNA has been found in products labeled as beef on supermarket shelves.

headline: For Kyrie Irving, a Milestone Week
abstract: Cleveland guard Kyrie Irving provided a glimpse of the future during All-Star weekend and his subsequent performances.
lead_paragraph: For a 20-year-old manning the game’s toughest position, Kyrie Irving has second-year numbers that have been increasingly eye-popping: 23.5 points, 5.5 assists, 1.7 steals, a true shooting percentage of just under 57 percent (including 42.5 percent on 3-pointers), and a player efficiency rating of 22.3.

headline: Critical Differences Belie Hopes for a Grand Bargain
abstract: As the latest fiscal deadline approaches the White House is signaling that it is still interested in a big deficit-reduction deal and as evidence of good faith has left on the table proposed Medicare and Social Security cuts that liberals hate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Even as President Obama lashes out at Republicans over the automatic spending cuts that take effect next week, he is simultaneously sending them a strikingly different message: he is still interested in a big deficit-reduction deal and as evidence of his good faith has left on the table proposed Medicare and Social Security cuts that liberals hate.

headline: Oscar Predictions, Election-Style
abstract: Our Academy Awards forecasts are based on the awards that were given out in the run-up to the Oscars, the closest equivalent to pre-election polls. But just as our election forecasts assign more weight to certain polls, we do not treat all awards equally.
lead_paragraph: Twice before, in 2009 and 2011, I sought to predict the Academy Award winners in six major categories based on a mix of statistical factors. My track record? Nine correct picks in 12 tries, for a 75 percent success rate. Not bad, but also not good enough to suggest that there is any magic formula for this.

headline: The Lichtenstein You Know, and the One You May Not
abstract: The first major retrospective of Roy Lichtenstein’s work since his death in 1997 travels to the Tate Modern, and holds some surprises.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At a preview of “Lichtenstein: A Retrospective,” at the Tate Modern earlier this week, a man pushed a toddler in a stroller as he considered the artwork. Both studied the paintings with apparently equal interest, which you could understand, since the bold patterns, the thick, graphic outlines and bright colors of Roy Lichtenstein’s work often resemble the simple, eye-catching illustrations of a child’s book or comic.

headline: Friday Reading: A List of Overused Medical Tests
abstract: A list of overused medical tests, words to help conversations about bullying, a bigger role for insurance in the gun debate and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: The National Futures Association faced an obstacle in considering a lifetime ban for Jon S. Corzine: he isn’t a member. | Citigroup, a closely watched player in the debate over Wall Street compensation, is changing how it calculates bonuses for top executives. | David Einhorn has a name for the preferred shares he wants Apple to give to shareholders: iPrefs. | Europe thinks it has found a way to keep firms from avoiding a proposed tax on financial transactions.
lead_paragraph: BANNING CORZINE PROVES PROBLEMATIC  |  The National Futures Association, the self-regulatory group for the futures industry, faced an obstacle in considering a lifetime ban for Jon S. Corzine, the former Democratic senator who ran the now-defunct MF Global: Mr. Corzine isn’t a member, DealBook’s Ben Protess writes.

headline: In Dell’s Waning Cash Flows, Signs of Concern
abstract: Going private may allow the company to slash costs, which preserves cash. But management may also feel liberated to spend more on initiatives, which could deplete cash initially.
lead_paragraph: The proposed Dell buyout may be motivated more by fear than greed.

headline: Russian Nationalists Say ‘Nyet’ to Foreign Words
abstract: A group of Russian legislators wants to halt a tide of English and other foreign words entering the Russian language by imposing fines on those who use them. How far can laws go to halt the onward march of English as the dominant international language?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nationalist Russian legislators have introduced a bill to hold back a tide of foreign words, specifically English ones, which they claim is swamping the Russian language.

headline: Running on Amnesia
abstract: The overriding characteristic of Kenya’s election campaign is shamelessness, with candidates asking the public to forget their past deeds.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI — I was negotiating one of Nairobi’s terrifying traffic circles — a maneuver that requires jumping over a lattice of open sewers while playing chicken with a line of trucks snorting their way toward Uganda and Congo — when I was confronted with a vision to chill the heart and drop the jaw.

headline: Cheating On the Delivery Guy
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A Midtown resident carrying takeout was embarrassed when he had to share the elevator with a chef from a different restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: What They Said: Could the Hyderabad Explosions Have Been Prevented?
abstract: Intelligence experts weigh in on the difficulty of preventing terror attacks, even when there is some warning.
lead_paragraph: As more information emerges about the most recent bombs in Hyderabad, many in India have begun to question the role of state and central government authorities, intelligence agencies and local police, asking whether they could have done more to prevent the attacks.

headline: NATO in Talks on Scale of Afghan Role After 2014 Deadline
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: NATO defense ministers on Friday were discussing a draft proposal that would keep in Afghanistan a force of up to 9,500 American troops and up to 6,000 more from other coalition nations.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — NATO defense ministers meeting here on Friday said they had made progress toward planning a military assistance mission in Afghanistan after the alliance’s combat role expires at the end of 2014, with some partner nations already offering to participate.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Nielsen Adds Web-Linked TVs to Ratings, and a Tight Oscar Race’s Final Recap
abstract: Nielsen expands its ratings to include people who watch TV via the Internet; one last look at where the contenders stand before the Oscars are handed out; and an ad campaign tries to universalize sake.
lead_paragraph: Nielsen announced that its TV ratings would begin including viewers who watch shows on Internet-connected TVs, and pledged to include those who use iPads or other mobile devices in the future, Brian Stelter writes. Although the percentage of TV viewers who rely on the Internet exclusively is negligible, television executives are concerned that many consumers are being missed regularly. Most Internet viewings of TV shows are not counted in Nielsen’s ratings because they are shown without commercials or with different commercials than when they aired on television — and new streaming services, like Aereo and one in the works from Intel, stream shows and ads without cable. The expanded ratings will allow executives to count customers that these types of services may steal away from cable.

headline: The Gun Report: February 22, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: There are some days when it is more difficult to read about gun violence than others. Yesterday was awful, filled with senseless shooting and the deaths of children, some shot by accident, others on purpose. Here is our report.

headline: Daria Strokous Transforms Backstage at Fendi
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Peter Phillips and hair by Sam McKnight.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper806 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: What Should the Parent of a Bully Do Next?
abstract: Looking for answers when your child is the one leaving nasty notes or snatching someone else’s lunch.
lead_paragraph: This week’s quandary comes partly from my conversation with Emily Bazelon, author of “Sticks and Stones: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy,” and partly from a conversation I had with another friend about the book.

headline: Alcatel-Lucent Names Chief to Lead a Major Downsizing
abstract: Michel Combes, a former Vodafone and France Télécom executive, said he would talk to employees and shareholders before forming a strategy for the company, which lost 1.4 billion euros in 2012.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Alcatel-Lucent, the struggling French telecommunications equipment maker, on Friday hired a former Vodafone and France Télécom executive, Michel Combes, to lead the company through what might be a major downsizing.

headline: More Swiss Myths
abstract: I wasn’t hard enough on those guys.
lead_paragraph: Oh, boy — it turns out that I, too, wasn’t nearly hard enough on Holtz-Eakin and Roy’s health care op-ed. In praising the allegedly more free-market Swiss system, they declare:

headline: Robert De Niro’s Tears and Other Campaign Moments
abstract: The “Silver Linings Playbook” team campaigned hard, with stops featuring the vice president and Katie Couric.
lead_paragraph: All the other best picture biggies went to Washington, so before the Oscar voting closed, the star and writer-director of “Silver Linings Playbook,” Bradley Cooper and David O. Russell, turned up inside the Beltway.

headline: National Parks on a Precipice
keywords: ['Camps and Camping', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Recreational Vehicles']
abstract: Absent a Congressional compromise to avert budget cuts, services will be significantly reduced starting March 1, park retirees warn.
lead_paragraph: Unless Congress can reach a budget agreement by March 1, the country’s national parks will be hit by a $110 million budget cut, resulting in shuttered campgrounds, shorter seasons, road closings and reduced emergency services, a parks advocacy group reports.

headline: Paul De Grauwe and the Rehn of Terror
abstract: Confidence!
lead_paragraph: Nobody has taught me as much about the euro crisis as Paul De Grauwe, who brought to the fore a crucial point almost everyone was overlooking: the importance of self-fulfilling debt panics in countries that no longer have their own currencies. Now he has a new paper with Yuemei Ji  following up on that insight, and offering yet more evidence of the incredible unwisdom of European economic policy.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Forktales: A melancholy post about searching for great food, and finding only great tango, in Buenos Aires. — Julia Moskin

headline: As Good as It Gets
abstract: Nominations for the most wishful Academy Awards category: Best Film About a Writer.
lead_paragraph: When I was 13 or so, I watched a movie in which a young writer (played by Frank Sinatra?) and his girlfriend go to an Italian restaurant to celebrate the acceptance of his first short story. The restaurant’s owner is celebrating too, as are all the people sitting at the other tables, which are covered with checkerboard tablecloths and lit by candles dripping wax. Everyone wishes the writer well, no one more so than I, who tried to foresee such a moment when I, too, would become a writer. The acceptance of the story. The cheers. The girl and the life of my dreams.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Micro Apartments
abstract: Children’s submissions of their very own, very small apartment, from a shoebox and other art supplies.
lead_paragraph: Children’s submissions of their very own, very small apartment, from a shoebox and other art supplies.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Jess Walter started his first novel in high school, but when he became a father at 19 he concluded that fiction was a “dicey way to support a child.”
lead_paragraph: Jess Walter, who reviews Teddy Wayne’s novel “The Love Song of Jonny Valentine” this week, was born into a blue-collar cattle ranching family in Spokane, Wash., where he still lives with his wife and three kids. “My dad worked his whole life at an aluminum plant,” Walter said in a recent e-mail, “but he managed to keep a piece of the old ranch. There are no cattle there now, but we go up to burn slash piles of fallen timber and pull old, rusted farm equipment out of creek beds. We’re slowly cleaning the place, returning it to some sort of natural state. Also, we just really like to burn things.”

headline: Ask Well: The Nutrients in Fruits and Veggies
abstract: The colorful skin of an apple, grape or tomato is certainly chockfull of nutrients. But by no means are the outer layers of most fruits and vegetables the prime source of their nutrition.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Eric Stoltz Is Still All Kinds of Wonderful
abstract: I was there to write about Connie Britton, but I was slightly more starstruck by meeting Eric Stoltz.
lead_paragraph: After I came back from spending time on the set of “Nashville,” I had to concede that yes, Connie Britton, the star of that show and subject of my recent profile, is cool, as nine million adoring blog posts, tweets and Tumblr accounts attest (many of those posts’ authors developed their admiration for her when she played Tami Taylor on “Friday Night Lights”).

headline: A Star’s Circle
abstract: Christine Sneed’s novel stars a 50-something movie star, an idol along the lines of Harrison Ford, and his family and colleagues.
lead_paragraph: I suspect I’m not alone in feeling as if, at some point, I accidentally earned a Ph.D. in Brangelina. It’s not just that I can tell you the names of Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie’s six children; I also can tell you their birth order and country of origin. I could write a dissertation, or perhaps teach a graduate seminar, on Pitt and Jolie’s past relationships, political activism and respective tattoos.

headline: The Scariest Thing I Did in India
abstract: A place where crossing the road is not for the faint of heart.
lead_paragraph: An auto-rickshaw is basically a lawn-mower engine encased in a cut-rate gazebo. It’s a three-wheeler intended for short journeys, which is why my three friends and I had some trouble driving one from the top to the bottom of India, a country famous for its road fatalities. With only a month to make the journey, we soon abandoned our scenic route (the burning ghats, the Taj Mahal) and instead pointed south.

headline: Who Made That Pantone Chip?
abstract: The creation of a unified color system.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, as Lawrence Herbert drove to work in a blue Cadillac with cherry red seats, he mulled over a problem: How to create a “universal language” of color. Herbert, the owner of the Pantone printing company, had just produced a retail display card that helped shoppers choose pantyhose. He had to hand-mix the subtle beiges of each swatch, because it was so difficult to buy the exact shade he wanted from an ink manufacturer. Each company defined colors differently, and when you ordered “wheat” or “taupe” or “cream,” you couldn’t predict what you’d get.

headline: The 2.10.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: FRANK OCEAN CAN FLY

headline: Should My Therapist Stop Cross-Examining My Love Life?
abstract: A loner on the couch and a loaner at the checkout.
lead_paragraph: I’m a middle-aged, never-been-married woman. I rarely, if ever, bring up an interest in men during therapy sessions. Still, my therapist diverts the conversation to cross-examine my efforts to find a husband. I am unsure whether my therapist’s matchmaking focus is because she believes I would be more fulfilled with a partner or because — in her culture — women are less whole without one. Is it unethical for a therapist to project their cultural values onto her client? NAME WITHHELD, BROOKLYN

headline: David Lynch Is Back … as a Guru of Transcendental Meditation
abstract: The director has released a musical album, exhibited his artwork, designed a nightclub and worked tirelessly for T.M. What he has not been doing is making movies.
lead_paragraph: Inside David Lynch’s bunker of a studio in Los Angeles, a small crowd of happy people gathered on a late summer morning to meditate and learn about the nature of consciousness. The dozen or so young actors and musicians and others were recent initiates of Transcendental Meditation, a trademarked form of relaxation that involves sitting quietly and saying a mantra to yourself for 20 minutes twice a day. T.M. initiation — a multiday instruction program that includes the bestowing of a secret personalized mantra — costs, on average, $1,000. But those gathered had been initiated as a gift of the David Lynch Foundation for Consciousness-Based Education and World Peace. Through its work, Lynch, who has been practicing T.M. for 40 years, hopes to teach meditation to the world and, as a result, create world peace.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN’S TRAGIC PRAGMATISM: Lincoln, Douglas, and Moral Conflict,  by John Burt. (Belknap/Harvard University, $39.95.) A work of history presented as an argument on moral conflict, and a work of philosophy presented as rhetorical analysis.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: A LAND MORE KIND THAN HOME,  by Wiley Cash. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $14.99.) Cash’s first novel, set in an insular Appalachian town, embeds a tender coming-of-age story within a chilling mystery. Its three narrators — an elderly midwife, a tormented sheriff and a precocious 9-year-old — are caught in a struggle against a local church and its pastor: a twisted, charismatic man whose frenzied religious services include snake-handling.

headline: Home Truths
abstract: In Jamaica Kincaid’s novel, an ugly divorce ends the domestic idyll of a New England family.
lead_paragraph: Writers make uncomfortable kin. Not only do they shut themselves off from family in what the novelist Jamaica Kincaid calls “the infernal room” from which their stories come, but, worse still, those stories are quite likely to deal one day with the dreams, terrors, tics and moral lapses of their loved ones. There’s a reflex in every writer that trumps even the maternal instinct, a part of her that, even while her newborn suckles at her breast, is cold-eyed, choosing words to describe the pit-bull clamp of its gums, the crusted globe of its skull, with the same dispassion with which she might describe fellow passengers on a bus.

headline: Me and My Shadow
abstract: James Lasdun describes the experience of being stalked by a disturbed former student.
lead_paragraph: For creative writing teachers, stalkers are such a basic condition of employment that, in the interest of full disclosure, they should probably be included in the job ad: Poor pay; negligible benefits (if any); and yes, you will be stalked. As James Lasdun discovers in this smart, rigorous and beautifully written memoir about being on the unwelcome end of someone else’s attention, it’s not always easy to determine that precise moment when the already peculiar relationship between a creative writing student and a teacher starts to go horribly wrong. Sometimes, the student might just be a bit too conscientious about doing the homework — and that homework turns out to be you.

headline: The No-Trade Deadline
abstract: After weeks of talk about N.B.A. moves, the biggest trade involved J.J. Redick.
lead_paragraph: That whistling sound you heard Thursday afternoon was the air going out of all those N.B.A. thought bubbles. You know, the ones popping up like crazy with all the wild and wacky trades that were going to happen at the deadline. Atlanta was going at one point to trade Josh Smith to every one of the other 29 teams in the league. Utah’s Al Jefferson was hopping all over the country and women and children everywhere were being warned that Kevin Garnett’s legendary mouth might be taking up new residence away from Boston. Heck, maybe Dwight Howard could have been traded by the Lakers to two teams at once!

headline: The Isles at the Center of the World
abstract: From ramshackle trading posts to the princely states of India, John Darwin examines 500 years of British expansion.
lead_paragraph: “An overseas empire produces a vast sea of paper,” John Darwin writes. That sea — wide, deep and often treacherous — is what remains of the British Empire for historians to trawl, though few attempt to chart the whole of it in one relatively compact volume. Darwin managed something similar with his previous books “The Empire Project: The Rise and Fall of the British World-System, 1830-1970” and “After Tamerlane: The Global History of Empire Since 1405” — emerging from the imperial brine with poise and balance where lesser historians would have beached themselves like lost whales or glugged down to the depths, tangled in the tentacles of a giant squid. In “Unfinished Empire,” he turns his attention to the British Empire’s why, who and how: small words that signify very big questions.

headline: The Awakening
abstract: In Will Self’s neo-modernist novel, a woman who has languished for decades in a mental hospital is briefly revived from oblivion.
lead_paragraph: “Umbrella” takes its title and epigraph from Joyce’s “Ulys­ses”: “A brother is as easily forgotten as an umbrella.” Umbrellas do play bit parts in Will Self’s ambitious new novel, but they also echo the fates of its characters, themselves bit players in the vast, indifferent dramas that dominate modern British life. Impersonal bureaucracies and brutal industrial processes serve less as backdrops than as the central obsessions of the book, which moves us through the munitions factories and killing fields of World War I, a psychiatric hospital and a creepily gentrified modern London where those who can’t afford exorbitant rents are ruthlessly pushed out. In this world, people are as disposable as umbrellas, which are “never contracted for, only mysteriously acquired, to be fleetingly useful, then annoying and cumbersome before eventually being lost.”

headline: Breakdown
abstract: A journalist and Detroit native searches for clues to the city’s fate.
lead_paragraph: Detroit is one of those taxing places that require you to have an opinion about them. This opinion expresses no mere preference. It amounts to a stance, from which may be inferred your electoral leanings, your racial politics, your union sympathies and the general sunniness of your disposition. The entire city signifies. It can get tiring.

headline: The Lives of Others
abstract: In this autobiographical novel, Christa Wolf wrestles with her ambiguous cooperation with the Stasi.
lead_paragraph: The German novelist Christa Wolf was a close observer and a survivor of two ignominious regimes. She grew up in Nazi Germany, fled her home at the end of the war and was rescued from starvation by the Soviet Army. In Communist East Germany, she bravely chronicled life under a dictatorship in novels like “Divided Heaven” and “The Quest for Christa T,” acts of nuanced dissent that earned her surveillance by the secret police, the Stasi. When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, she welcomed the collapse of the Communist government. Four years later, however, Wolf’s reputation was stained by a shocking revelation: she had collaborated with East German intelligence officers in the early 1960s. Wolf insisted, to widespread disbelief, that she had forgotten the episode.

headline: Secret Passages
abstract: This novel involves a dead rock star and an unsolved double homicide, nighttime trysts, affairs, embezzling and illicit recordings.
lead_paragraph: An enchanting, darkly mysterious ballerina. A dead rock star. An unsolved double homicide, decades old. A father felled by a shadowy past. An older sister as beautiful as she is mad. A gay vegetarian chef covered in tattoos. His transvestite lover. Secret passageways, nighttime trysts, affairs, embezzling, illicit recordings — all of it revolving around one 6-foot-8, humble, sincere, Ivy League-educated orphaned professional football player. Really, what more could you want?

headline: Model Mothers
abstract: A portrait of the origins of beauty.
lead_paragraph: A portrait of the origins of beauty.

headline: The Bank Job
abstract: Roger Hobbs’s “Ghostman” is named after the most elusive gang member — the guy who makes everything disappear.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to language, Irish poets place a distant second to the crooks in crime novels. Say you’re planning a big bank heist. The crew you recruit for the job is likely to include a jugmarker, the tactical genius who designs these delicate operations; a lip man to deliver the boss’s orders; a boxman to crack the safe; a bagman to handle the loot; a wheelman to drive the getaway car; and maybe a couple of buttonmen (“they hurt people”) to facilitate the whole enterprise.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
abstract: New books by Sarah Selecky, Whitney Otto, Lynne Sharon Schwartz, David Park and Christine Schutt.
