lead_paragraph: THIS CAKE IS FOR THE PARTY  By Sarah Selecky.  Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s Griffin, paper, $14.99.

headline: American Obsession
abstract: Glenn Frankel sorts through the layers of history in a classic film.
lead_paragraph: There are a few Hollywood movies so thematically rich and so historically resonant they may be considered part of American literature. “The Searchers” is one.

headline: Idol Gossip
abstract: A cultural history of movie stardom examines our worship and resentment of screen icons.
lead_paragraph: Admit it. You idolize George Clooney and know he’d be your close friend, or at least a good drinking buddy — if only you’d ever met. And that mass schadenfreude the culture indulges in whenever Lindsay Lohan crashes another car — isn’t that comforting? Stars may be rich or beautiful, but we get to feel sane in comparison.

headline: Jay-Z and Justin Timberlake Announce 12-City Tour
abstract: The duo will tour North America in July and August, including a performance at Yankee Stadium on July 19.
lead_paragraph: The dapper duet that Jay-Z and Justin Timberlake performed in black tie at the Grammy Awards earlier this month turns out to be just a warm-up: the two stars said on Friday that they will do a 12-city North American stadium tour this summer, Live Nation announced. That tour, “Legends of the Summer,” will start at the Rogers Center in Toronto on July 17 and continue through August 16, when it wraps up in Miami at the Sun Life Stadium. The show will come to Yankee Stadium on July 19. After a few years focusing on acting and the movie business, Mr. Timberlake is returning to music with “The 20/20 Experience,” his first album since 2006, which is expected to be released on March 19. The album’s first single, “Suit & Tie,” which features Jay-Z, has been a Top 10 hit on pop radio since its release six weeks ago. Tickets will go on sale to the general public for all shows but New York on Feb. 28, with some presale tickets available sooner.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Tiny Apartments, in 3-D
abstract: The city of New York may have picked a winning design, but the submissions we received for this special 3-D assignment of Kids Draw the News would have given any of the architects a run for their money.
lead_paragraph: The city of New York may have picked a winning design, but the submissions we received for this special 3-D assignment of Kids Draw the News would have given any of the architects a run for their money. Thanks to all who answered our call, and to those who were willing to have their masterpiece pictured at the Museum of the City of New York. Your pictures may be seen in the slide show that accompanies this post, and even more can be viewed here.

headline: Notes From the Recipe Tester: Mallorcas
abstract: The trick to making beautiful buns is in the shaping and baking.
lead_paragraph: Mallorcas, the exquisitely delicate, lightly sweet buns described in Mireya Navarro’s article in this week’s Dining section, are easy enough for a novice baker, but impressive enough to serve at a festive brunch or office party. The trick to making beautiful buns is in the shaping and baking.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | DSquared2
abstract: Makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury shares how the shiny, shimmery look at last night’s show was achieved.
lead_paragraph: Dean and Dan Caten, the designers behind fashion label DSquared2, wanted their models to shine all over at last night’s show. “They wanted the girls to look healthy,” the makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury says. So she highlighted the top of the cheeks with gloss, creating a glimmering architecture, and used pink balm and lip conditioner to emphasize the natural rose color of the lips. Even the chocolate-brown-painted eyelids were topped with lots of gloss. For the nails, the expert Antonio Sacripante used a shimmery, dark red polish — enriched with precious metals — called From Paris With Love. “This color will be one of the hottest hues next fall,” he predicts.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in London, Virginia, San Francisco
abstract: A weekly capsule of events across the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Victoria & Albert Museum, London It goes without saying that David Bowie, a musician who has adopted personas from the glam alien Ziggy Stardust, above, to the suave Thin White Duke, has a theatrical sense of style. It will soon be the subject of a survey at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, which will display Mr. Bowie’s elaborate costumes, music videos, set designs and other ephemera in “David Bowie Is” from March 23 to July 28. Curators combed Mr. Bowie’s archives for the show, choosing 300 objects meant to offer a window onto the musician’s creativity. Or meant as bait, to draw avid fans. (vam.ac.uk)

headline: Pistorius Not a ‘Flight Risk’
abstract: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Lydia Polgreen in Pretoria, South Africa, report on developments in the Oscar Pistorius case.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Lydia Polgreen in Pretoria, South Africa, report on developments in the Oscar Pistorius case.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a New Drug for Advanced Breast Cancer
abstract: The new type of drug combines the widely used breast cancer medicine Herceptin with a powerful toxin to more effectively kill cancer cells while potentially reducing side effects.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a new type of drug that combines the widely used breast cancer medicine Herceptin with a powerful toxin to more effectively kill cancer cells while potentially reducing side effects.

headline: A Deli King in Trouble
abstract: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Sam Dolnick report on a Staten Island businessman who, according to federal prosecutors, engaged in an $82 million check-fraud scheme.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Sam Dolnick report on a Staten Island businessman who, according to federal prosecutors, engaged in an $82 million check-fraud scheme.

headline: Depression May Stifle Shingles Vaccine Response
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Immune System', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Shingles (Disease)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Adults with untreated depression who received the shingles vaccine mounted a relatively weak immune response compared with their healthy age-matched peers, or to those taking antidepressants.
lead_paragraph: Depression may lower the effectiveness of the shingles vaccine, a new study found.

headline: In Tandem
abstract: Merger and acquisition activity tends to rise and fall with the stock market.
lead_paragraph: Merger and acquisition activity tends to rise and fall with the stock market.

headline: Found-Footage Nixon Documentary Will Conclude New Directors/New Films Series
abstract: “Our Nixon,” directed by Penny Lane, uses Super 8 film footage shot by H. R. Haldeman, John Erlichman and Dwight Chapin to tell the story of the Nixon presidency.
lead_paragraph: Just in case Richard M. Nixon was not doing enough documenting of his own presidency (with the occasional gap in the archives), his confidants H. R. Haldeman, John Erlichman and Dwight Chapin were also filming him, his family and his White House using Super 8 cameras. Now this footage has been used to create a new documentary that will be shown as the closing night feature of New Directors/New Films, the annual series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, those organizations said on Friday.

headline: Why Am I Still Getting Pimples?
abstract: High school seems so long ago, at least until you look in the mirror and see an old friend popping up on your forehead.
lead_paragraph: You no longer have to gaze over a school lunchroom, hoping to find a seat at a socially acceptable table. You don’t rush to get home at night before your junior license driving restrictions kick in. And you men no longer have to worry that your voice will skip an octave without warning.

headline: Promotions at New York City Ballet
abstract: The company announced that three dancers – Adrian Danchig-Waring, Chase Finlay and Ask la Cour – become principal dancers, and eight members of the corps de ballet are now soloists.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Ballet has reconfigured its roster with the promotion of 11 dancers, the company announced on Friday morning. Three of the dancers – Adrian Danchig-Waring, Chase Finlay and Ask la Cour – become principal dancers, and eight members of the corps de ballet are now soloists.

headline: Student Crossword | World War II
abstract: Learn about World War II by playing our puzzle, online or in print.
lead_paragraph: Learn more about World War II by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Johnny Marr, Inveterate Sideman, Takes the Spotlight
abstract: Larry Rohter speaks with Ben Ratliff about Johnny Marr, the ex-Smiths guitarist and songwriter who has also performed with The The, Modest Mouse, Electronic and many others. He is releasing his first solo album on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Larry Rohter speaks with Ben Ratliff about Johnny Marr, the ex-Smiths guitarist and songwriter who has also performed with The The, Modest Mouse, Electronic and many others. He is releasing his first solo album on Tuesday.

headline: Consumer Complaints May Offer Insight Into Pyramid Schemes
keywords: ['Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Regulators have given no indication of what they think about Herbalife’s business practices. But complaints against the company may offer some insight into the government’s assessment.
lead_paragraph: There is a big unknown at the heart of the debate over Herbalife: Regulators have given no indication of what they think about the diet supplement company’s business practices.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Teddy Wayne talks about his novel “The Love Song of Jonny Valentine”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Caryn James discusses “Gods Like Us,” Ty Burr’s new book about movie stardom; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Teddy Wayne talks about his novel “The Love Song of Jonny Valentine”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Caryn James discusses “Gods Like Us,” Ty Burr’s new book about movie stardom; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Postal Service Revs Up Another Automotive Stamp Issue
abstract: Five new postage stamps feature American muscle cars of the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Though the leaky, sputtering Postal Service may seem as broken down as Detroit’s Big Three during the financial crisis, our post office’s love affair with classic American automobiles keeps roaring along with a healthy enthusiasm.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 22
abstract: A mass wedding in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

headline: Join Us on Oscar Night
abstract: Beginning at 7 p.m. Eastern time, check out the real-time red carpet photos, behind-the-scenes posts and commentary from Melena Ryzik, live video with David Carr and A.O. Scott and more.
lead_paragraph: Join us on Sunday night for all things Oscar. Beginning at 7 p.m. Eastern time, check out the real-time red carpet photos, behind-the-scenes posts and commentary from Melena Ryzik (the Carpetbagger), Dave Itzkoff, Jon Caramanica, Eric Wilson, Simone S. Oliver, Brooks Barnes, Michael Cieply and other Times reporters and critics. We’ll also have winners, live video analysis throughout the show from David Carr and A. O. Scott, and other features.

headline: In Alaska, Fun on the Snow and Ice
abstract: From ice climbing to skijoring, sports help enliven the Alaskan winter.
lead_paragraph: From ice climbing to skijoring, sports help enliven the Alaskan winter.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Brandi Glanville, whose dishy new divorce memoir, “Drinking and Tweeting,” is at No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has been a vocal rival of the singer LeAnn Rimes.
lead_paragraph: BARED TEETH: If you want to call your book “Drinking and Tweeting” — that’s the title of a dishy new divorce memoir by Brandi Glanville of “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills,” at No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list — then you should probably make sure your Twitter account contains more scintillating entries than “Going back to sleep.” But never mind. Glanville’s book, written with Leslie Bruce, reinforces her reputation as a brash gossip unafraid to mouth off about the husband who ditched her for the “has-been country-music singer” LeAnn Rimes. Apparently a husband isn’t all the two women have shared, either. Two days after Rimes filed a malpractice suit against her former dentist, claiming his crown work had impeded her career, Glanville hit Twitter with a defense of the same practitioner: “My dentist of 17 yrs,” she wrote, “whom I love is perfect.”

headline: Primed for a Dramatic Return
abstract: James Levine is scheduled to conduct for the first time in two years, for a May 19 performance by the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: One of the most anticipated concerts of the spring is the Met Orchestra’s program at Carnegie Hall on May 19. James Levine is scheduled to conduct, two years after his last performance anywhere. But will he show up? Will he be the James Levine who led the Metropolitan Opera through 40 years of artistic growth and became the most important American conductor on the international scene since Leonard Bernstein?

headline: Vikings Come Ashore in a New Light
abstract: “Vikings,” History channel’s ambitious nine-part drama series from “The Tudors” creator Michael Hirst, brings their struggles extravagantly to life.
lead_paragraph: They are akin to NASA astronauts or the pioneers of Silicon Valley — except they lived 1,300 years ago, and it was the high seas that demanded navigation, not outer space or the Internet.

headline: Looks Familiar, but Something’s Funny
abstract: The work of the Brooklyn comedy troupe Sunset Television seem like transmissions from a twisted, satirical dimension of television.
lead_paragraph: On the Internet found material is often recycled as comedy: a decade-old commercial, a foreign music video, an amateur’s footage from the zoo. But for the Brooklyn comedy troupe Sunset Television the opposite is true. Its videos are meant to play like artifacts discovered in serpentine YouTube searches.

headline: Repertory Selected for Maximum Impact
abstract: With its expected mix of historical repertory and more contemporary works, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, led by Gustavo Dudamel, visits New York.
lead_paragraph: It should be chiseled above the doors of every symphony hall: What an orchestra plays matters as much as how it plays, if not more so.

headline: Success, Interrupted
abstract: Spring for Music, a classical festival in its third year that brings regional orchestras to Carnegie Hall, prepares for its finale.
lead_paragraph: In only its third season Spring for Music has already reached its autumn.

headline: Making Sounds That Bach Might Recognize
abstract: With its monthlong festival The Bach Variations, the New York Philharmonic celebrates Baroque music’s vital importance and draws attention to the approaches available to interpreters today.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic is hoping to become a little more hip this spring with the help of an unlikely ally: Johann Sebastian Bach. Well, make that HIP, as in historically informed performance.

headline: As Spring Approaches, the Core Is Hardening
abstract: Festivals from New York to Texas to Las Vegas are hosting hardcore bands this spring.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t seen so much energy around the hardcore scene in New York in a long while. Just for starters you’ve got an array of young New York bands: Perdition (agitated, crusty, fast, noise-caked assaults), Hank Wood and the Hammerheads (garage-punk, with Farfisa organ), Dawn of Humans and Crazy Spirit (sort of Germs-like — feckless/gargling/angry-baby singing, with propulsive and articulated drumming).

headline: The Season When the Sides Take Center Stage
abstract: Indie-rock projects new and old, including Sufjan Stevens in a new collaboration for a song cycle called “Planetarium,” plan to hit the road.
lead_paragraph: In indie rock, it seems, everyone has a side project: a break from the other band members, a chance to toy with different genres and recording methods, a fling with no long-term commitment.

headline: Bye, It’s Over (Over and Over)
abstract: Fleetwood Mac and New Kids on the Block are reappearing to hit the concert trail this season.
lead_paragraph: It’s so hard to say goodbye to yesterday. No, honestly — it’s practically impossible, especially in an age of cyclical nostalgia and Internet-assisted memories. Old musical acts have always gone on comeback tours, but these days the disappearances are getting shorter and nostalgia is fully taking its place alongside discovery as a valid aesthetic-appreciation strategy. Why listen to the new bands that sound like the old bands when the old bands will be back before you know it?

headline: R&B From Another Edge, Jazz When It Was Still Fusing
abstract: New albums from Bilal, the Stark Reality, the Underachievers, the Eels, Dan Friel and Holly Williams.
lead_paragraph: Bilal

headline: Lost in Back-of-the-Seat Translation
abstract: When operas — like the Met’s current “Rigoletto” — are moved to contemporary settings, the translated lyrics on the seat-back screens sometimes introduce vernacular, to mixed effect.
lead_paragraph: In the world of opera, when directors update repertory works to contemporary settings, they almost always remain true to the original music and libretto. This is in effect the bargain that production teams strike with passionate opera buffs, especially the more tradition-bound members of the audience.

headline: A Smith Asserts His Own Name
abstract: Johnny Marr, the former guitarist and a songwriter for the Smiths, is releasing his first solo album, “The Messenger,” 25 years after the band’s breakup.
lead_paragraph: What took so long? Twenty-five years after he left the Smiths, perhaps the most influential British pop band of the 1980s, the guitarist Johnny Marr has finally made a solo album.

headline: In a Warming World, Look to the Herbivores
abstract: A new study suggests that grazing by large herbivores like caribou could help maintain biodiversity as the planet warms.
lead_paragraph: In the unending quest for effective ways of adapting to climate change, it seems that musk ox and caribou may have some of the answers.

headline: Sometimes It’s Good Not to Forgive
abstract: How difficult is it, or should it be, to achieve redemption after a breach of trust?
lead_paragraph: IT seems, these days, that we can barely keep pace with the tales of the famous and near famous who climb to great heights, plummet to great depths and then try to work their way back into the public’s affection.

headline: Debating ‘House of Cards': What the Show Gets Right and Wrong About Journalism
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Washington is the chief character in the drama, but do the creators understand how the town works?
lead_paragraph: The Washington that majestically unfurls in the credits for “House of Cards” is recognizable to anybody who has spent time there. But even though it can be a monumental kingdom filled with portent, it can also be a fairly quotidian and sometimes ugly small town — but that’s not the kind of place you make a huge, expensive television show about.

headline: Mets Push Back Santana’s First Appearance
abstract: The Mets’ highest-paid player was scheduled to make his first start on March 2, but he will be pushed back to “the March 10 to 15 range,” General Manager Sandy Alderson said.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Around this time last year, the left-hander Johan Santana was the dominant talking point around the Mets’ spring training facility. He was rehabilitating his surgically repaired pitching shoulder, and it was unclear how much he might be able to contribute during the 2012 season or beyond. It was supposed to be different this time around. Santana was named the Opening Day starter when camp opened, and his spring training was going to unfold like those from more carefree times.

headline: Furthur to Play Eight Shows at Capitol Theater
abstract: Furthur, which includes Phil Lesh and Bob Weir from the Grateful Dead, will play a series of shows at the refurbished theater in Port Chester, N.Y., the site of memorable Dead shows in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: It is a sad fact that the Grateful Dead can never return to the Capitol Theater in Port Chester, N.Y., where they gave memorable concerts in the early 1970s, because the guitarist Jerry Garcia has joined the ranks of the actual dead.

headline: Growth Vanishes in Developed Economies
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported this week that the combined economies of its member countries shrank in the fourth quarter of 2012, the first time that has happened since the credit crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported this week that the combined economies of its member countries shrank in the fourth quarter of 2012, the first time that has happened since the credit crisis.

headline: Trying to Block Negative Exposure of Spain’s Royal Family
abstract: When Iñaki Urdangarin, the son-in-law of King Juan Carlos of Spain, makes his appearance Saturday in Palma, Majorca, for a widely anticipated day of private judicial testimony, it will be almost impossible for photographers to get an image of him.
lead_paragraph: In the post-modern world of the Spanish monarchy, a picture is worth a mighty kingdom.

headline: In the Developed World, Growth Contracts
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said the decline of the combined gross domestic product of its members is a sign of how far the global economy had weakened.
lead_paragraph: FOR the first time since 2009, the economies of major developed countries are shrinking.

headline: Get ‘Em While They’re Young
abstract: For those who really like to discover young designers ahead of everyone else, even before they’ve been featured in Vogue or discussed on a blog, there is an annual talent scouting event happening in Milan this week that might be worth your attention.
lead_paragraph: For those who really like to discover young designers ahead of everyone else, even before they’ve had a chance to be featured in Vogue or discussed on a blog, there is an annual talent-scouting event happening in Milan, Italy, this week that might be worth your attention.

headline: The Sound of East Harlem, in a Hardware Store
abstract: Side Street: Just steps off Lexington Avenue and 107th Street lies a gallery of mementos from the golden age of Latin music.
lead_paragraph: With all the changes that have washed over East Harlem, it was only a matter of time before the cowbells, maracas and drumsticks that once made music echo through the fabled neighborhood’s streets ended up under glass. Just steps off Lexington Avenue and 107th Street – inside a storefront still adorned by a sign declaring “HARDWARE STORE” — lies an array of instruments, pictures and other mementos from the golden age of Latin music.

headline: Thin Snowpack in West Signals Summer of Drought
abstract: Farmers, ranchers and officials across the area had hoped for plentiful snows to replenish the ground and refill rivers, but that has not come to pass.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — After enduring last summer’s destructive drought, farmers, ranchers and officials across the parched Western states had hoped that plentiful winter snows would replenish the ground and refill their rivers, breaking the grip of one of the worst dry spells in American history. No such luck.

headline: Mindful of Bubbles in a Boom for Deals
abstract: There have been over a thousand mergers and buyouts in the first months of 2013, leading some to wonder if the markets are overvalued.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett has teamed up with 3G Capital to buy the venerable H. J. Heinz Company for $23 billion. But the famed value investor isn’t exactly buying low: when the deal was announced on Valentine’s Day, Heinz shares were trading at a record high of nearly $61. Had Mr. Buffett and his partners bought a year ago, shares were selling for $53, a 13 percent discount.

headline: Book Review Podcast: An 11-Year-Old Heartthrob
abstract: Teddy Wayne discusses his new novel, “The Love Song of Jonny Valentine.”
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Jess Walter reviews “The Love Song of Jonny Valentine,” Teddy Wayne’s new novel about an 11-year-old singing heartthrob. Mr. Walter writes:

headline: Rolls-Royce Recalls Phantoms for Possible Fire Hazard
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Helmets', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker said the “anti-misfueling device” was missing on the fuel filler neck. The device prevents diesel fuel from being used and also discharges static electricity to reduce the chance of a fire.
lead_paragraph: Rolls-Royce is recalling 27 of its 2013 Phantom models for a possible fire hazard, according to a report the automaker sent to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Thanking Harvey Weinstein and God, in That Order
abstract: Statistically, the Academy doesn’t get thanked as often as you’d think, and for that you can thank a graduate student who did the research.
lead_paragraph: 1:23 p.m. | Updated  Thanks to the Academy, you can read (and watch) most of the winners’ acceptance speeches, going back decades. But you don’t have to, because a grad student at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta did it for you, all in the name of research.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Prada
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Royal Remains Draw the Curious to Leicester
abstract: The discovery of King Richard III’s skeleton has created a buzz of activity in this town north of London, with visitors taking tours and gawking at a now-famous parking lot.
lead_paragraph: The man with the job of protecting the most famous parking lot in the world was having a busy day a couple of weeks ago. “Sorry, guys,” Jake Jones said as the latest in a steady stream of onlookers tried to walk through the gates. “You’ll have to wait for the guided tour.”

headline: Video Game Inspired by Clashes in Egypt and Italy Allows Gamers to Fight the Police
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: After watching Egyptian protesters battle the police, and taking part in a demonstration in Italy, an Italian animator created Riot, a new video game.
lead_paragraph: Accompanied by ominous music, shouts and sirens, the video shows a series of turbulent scenes: a man throwing an explosive into a police car, someone kicking a shop window and uniformed officers launching projectiles and marching with shields.

headline: Extreme Alaska
keywords: ['Ice Climbing', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Snow-kiting, ice climbing and biking on snow: just a few ways to pass the time in a state where the chill just adds to the thrill.
lead_paragraph: The wind came from the northwest. It blew down from the glacier-studded peaks of the Alaska Range, through the icebergs of Turnagain Arm and across the frozen expanse of the Twenty Mile River. It was an unrelenting wind, the kind that fells trees, shapes mountains and drives people to their firesides. And there I was among the sculptured snow ridges and frozen grass on the banks of the Twenty Mile, attached to a giant kite, wearing a pair of skis.

headline: This Is a Hostel?
abstract: A new breed of hostels is emerging, built for design-conscious 20- and 30-somethings on a budget.
lead_paragraph: Grupo Habita, the Mexico City-based team behind the upscale Hôtel Americano in New York, is known for taking an unconventional approach to hospitality. Still, its latest property — Downtown Mexico, a hotel within a 17th-century palace in the Centro Histórico district of Mexico City — houses a bit of a surprise: the company’s first hostel, Downtown Beds.

headline: Hiking, Biking and Bubbly in South Africa
abstract: The Constantia Valley near Cape Town is awash in sensory pleasures, from wine to nature.
lead_paragraph: Breakfast is better with bubblies.

headline: Popcast: Johnny Marr, Inveterate Sideman, Takes the Spotlight
abstract: Larry Rohter speaks with Ben Ratliff about Johnny Marr, the ex-Smiths guitarist and songwriter who is releasing his first solo album on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s popcast, Ben Ratliff talks to Larry Rohter about his recent encounter with Johnny Marr, the guitarist and songwriter for the Smiths during the first half of the 1980s, and finally — at age 49 — in charge of a record under his own name, “The Messenger.” Mr. Rohter explains an unusual guitar hero, or “Godlike Genius,” as per the award just bestowed on him by England’s New Musical Express: one who has built his reputation around rhythm and texture rather than solos, around collaboration rather than leading, and around constant change rather than the creation of a static brand.

headline: ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ Through a Theological Lens
abstract: Aside from disputes about whether torture succeeds, theologians wonder if it should be accepted by society if it does succeed.
lead_paragraph: Almost nine years ago, journalists on “60 Minutes II” and at The New Yorker revealed a trove of photographs showing the abuse and humiliation of Iraqi detainees by American soldiers at Abu Ghraib prison. The images of inmates variously stripped, hooded, leashed like a dog, piled into naked heaps and forced to simulate oral sex then spread widely, causing international outcry.

headline: Where the Water Is Soft and the Tea Is Bold
abstract: To truly taste the tea of East Frisia, Germany, you may just need to go there yourself.
lead_paragraph: To truly taste the tea of East Frisia, Germany, you may just need to go there yourself.

headline: In Northern Germany, a Robust Tea Culture
abstract: Rock sugar, cream and a sense of local identity can all be found in a cup of tea in the East Frisia region of Germany.
lead_paragraph: For years, I was a green-tea snob who would drink only the freshest Dragon Well or Azure Conch Spring. Even worse, as a longtime Sinophile living in Beijing I aped Asian cultural practices, and when it came to tea, that meant fanatically seeking out the tender shoots harvested right after the first flush, usually in early April. Everything else was taboo. Black teas, especially, never crossed my tongue.

headline: Election Violence in Kenya
abstract: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Marc Lacey, a deputy foreign editor, discuss the ethnic clashes that erupt in Kenya during each election cycle.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Marc Lacey, a deputy foreign editor, discuss the ethnic clashes that erupt in Kenya during each election cycle.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: A pasta-making class for families will include a recipe demo for parents to watch while children can roll and stretch dough to make various shaped pastas at Giovanni Rana Pastificio and Cucina, 75 Ninth Avenue, in Chelsea. The hands-on class is on Sunday at 9:30 a.m. and is $60 for a child and an accompanying adult, and includes beverages and pasta dish. Call (212) 370-0975 for reservations.

headline: Government Joins Suit Against Armstrong
abstract: A whistle-blower suit claims that Lance Armstrong and his associates defrauded the government by allowing doping on the United States Postal Service team.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Friday joined a federal whistle-blower lawsuit claiming that Lance Armstrong, his former team manager and the company that owned his cycling team defrauded the government because cyclists on the team, sponsored by the United States Postal Service, were engaged in a systematic, covert doping scheme.

headline: In Battling Tax Dodgers, Britain Gives Shame a Try
abstract: The government published the names and addresses of scofflaws, but critics said the effort ignores the biggest offenders: big corporations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A hairdresser in Liverpool and a knitwear manufacturer in Nottingham were among the first nine people and companies publicly branded tax scofflaws by the British authorities as part of a government “name and shame” campaign.

headline: Torture, Lies and Hollywood
abstract: Portraying torture as effective risks misleading the next generation of Americans that one of our government’s greatest successes came about because brutality works.
lead_paragraph: I WATCHED “Zero Dark Thirty” not as a former F.B.I. special agent who spent a decade chasing, interrogating and prosecuting top members of Al Qaeda but as someone who enjoys Hollywood movies. As a movie, I enjoyed it. As history, it’s bunk.

headline: Why Oscar Will Snub ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
abstract: In trying to have it both ways, the film lost a large segment of thinking moviegoers.
lead_paragraph: Sunday night is Oscar night, the 85th Academy Awards, high holy day for America’s most influential cultural export. “Zero Dark Thirty,” once thought to be a favorite for best picture, has been pummeled on the way to the finish line. It increasingly looks like “Argo,” a tidy drama about an imaginative rescue mission in Ayatollah Khomeini’s Iran, will win.

headline: Intense Downpour Floods Athens and Strands Motorists
abstract: Rain of an intensity not seen in decades also led to the death of a woman who apparently suffered a heart attack in her car, and a freak accident at the Parliament building.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Torrential rain of an intensity not seen in decades flooded roads in Athens on Friday, overturning parked cars and stranding dozens of motorists, including a 28-year-old woman who died of what appeared to be a heart attack.

headline: What to Eat With Montsant Wines
abstract: A Spanish wine goes well with a dish that is Mediterranean in spirit.
lead_paragraph: Some people keep a “house wine” on hand. Montsant? Maybe. I have a friend who has a house dish, which she always serves for dinner parties. It’s the chicken Marbella with prunes and olives from “The Silver Palate Cookbook.” With this friend coming to dinner at my house, and Montsant to pour, I decided to do a riff on that decades-old recipe and made a chicken tagine with prunes and olives. I used only chicken thighs, which stayed moist. My dish had some of the Mediterranean spirit of the original and, not accidentally, of the wine.  FLORENCE FABRICANT

headline: Predicting a Crisis, Repeatedly
abstract: A paper by four economists is the latest to predict that the growing United States government debt burden is unsustainable.
lead_paragraph: Economists are not very good at predicting crises, but the problem is generally an absence of warnings. It’s not easy to anticipate which low-probability catastrophe will end up happening.

headline: Iglo and Birds Eye Pull Meals After Finding Horse Meat
abstract: The company that owns Iglo and Birds Eye brands withdrew a dozen types of prepared meals from stores in four European countries after finding traces of horse meat.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Another big food producer was ensnared in the scandal over horse meat in beef products Friday when the company that owns the Iglo and Birds Eye brands withdrew a dozen types of prepared meals from stores in four European countries.

headline: Emerging From the Shadows
abstract: Montsant has earned attention for red wines that resemble Priorat’s but for much less money.
lead_paragraph: The wine universe has been expanding at an accelerated rate over the last decade or so, and no place illustrates it better than Spain. New appellations have joined historic names. Forgotten regions have reinvented themselves. And everywhere, despite the country’s poor economy, new producers have jumped into the global fray.

headline: Roma Is Isolated in Transitional Uncertainty
abstract: Changes at Roma of Italy’s Serie A have seen the dismissal of the manager and a new infusion of money from the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: MILAN, Italy — Several hundred protesting Roma supporters awaited the manager, Zdenek Zeman, and his players outside Stadio Olimpico in Rome. His time at the helm of the capital club was all but officially over after a devastating defeat against Cagliari.

headline: Lynch by Lynch, the Film Director as Self-Portraitist
abstract: A Q. and A. with the director David Lynch, on the self-portrait he created for our article on him in this weekend’s issue.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s article about David Lynch’s efforts to promote Transcendental Meditation, a trademarked form of relaxation, we asked the film director to create a self-portrait. Our thinking was that while he is known mostly for his TV series “Twin Peaks” and films like “Eraserhead,” “Blue Velvet” and “Mulholland Drive,” Lynch is also a painter, printmaker, musician and photographer, so maybe he’d like to make some art to go with his profile. The result was the photo seen above, taken while Lynch was at the Idem printing studios in Paris working on a new set of lithographs. Recently I put to him a few questions about self-portraiture:

headline: Qualcomm Reveals Its Donations to Tax-Exempt Groups
abstract: The New York comptroller’s settlement with Qualcomm is seen as a victory for transparency advocates seeking to use shareholder groups to push for greater disclosure of corporate political spending.
lead_paragraph: Qualcomm, the country’s largest maker of computer chips for mobile devices, has voluntarily disclosed previously secret political contributions to tax-exempt groups under a settlement with the New York State comptroller that was announced on Friday.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A seven-bedroom Sea Cliff Victorian built in 1890, and a four-bedroom colonial in Old Greenwich.
lead_paragraph: A seven-bedroom Sea Cliff Victorian built in 1890, and a four-bedroom colonial in Old Greenwich.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Midwood, Brooklyn apartment on a tree-lined street, an Art-Deco one-bedroom on the Upper West Side and a Midtown South listing featuring a private elevator.
lead_paragraph: A Midwood, Brooklyn apartment on a tree-lined street, an Art-Deco one-bedroom on the Upper West Side and a Midtown South listing featuring a private elevator.

headline: Engagement Party
abstract: If you’re looking for a less traditional rock on your finger, there are plenty of indie options these days.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: In Push for Transparency, Law Firm Releases Financial Results
abstract: In a groundbreaking move, K&L Gates, one of the country’s largest law firms, disclosed its financial results online, as clients are asking more questions about the financial state of the firms they employ.
lead_paragraph: Call it the Dewey & LeBoeuf effect.

headline: Watching the Oscars With ...
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about what they’ll be doing on Sunday night for the Academy Awards. Care to join them for the glamour, the glitz and the upsets?
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about what they’ll be doing on Sunday night for the Academy Awards. Care to join them for the glamour, the glitz and the upsets?

headline: A Supporting Actress Upset and Other Surprising Predictions
abstract: Taking a look at what other prognosticators around the Web are expecting.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The awards machinery is in overdrive now, with nearly every possible angle explored, from the earliest moments of the nominees and their films to what productions would look like in pie-chart form. (What percent of “Life of Pi” is actually your stoned freshman-year roommate discussing his comparative religions class? It’s sizable!)

headline: White House Uses Air Delays as Budget Prod
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL', 'United States Politics and Government', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Delays (Transportation)']
abstract: The focus on disruptions if spending cuts take effect showed that the Obama administration believed that the threat of widespread travel problems could force Republicans to the bargaining table.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday warned of potentially severe disruptions in air travel if across-the-board spending cuts take effect in less than a week as President Obama intensified pressure on Congressional Republicans to entertain spending reductions and tax increases to avoid furloughing federal workers and limiting services.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 22
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including ski jumping in Italy and spring training baseball in Florida.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including ski jumping in Italy and spring training baseball in Florida.

headline: Q & A
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Insurance', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: Refinancing a Sponsor Unit; Co-op Wants to Break Service Contract; When an Insurer Denies Coverage.
lead_paragraph: Refinancing a Sponsor Unit

headline: Gay Marriage: Style and Substance
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Marriage-equality advocates are presenting themselves as champions of the human heart.
lead_paragraph: The AP announced on Thursday that it would treat gay and straight couples the same, stylistically. Its new “husband, wife” Stylebook entry reads: “Regardless of sexual orientation, husband or wife is acceptable in all references to individuals in any legally recognized marriage. Spouse or partner may be used if requested.”

headline: How A.O. Scott and David Carr Are Voting
abstract: A.O. Scott and David Carr share their picks for the Oscars on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The Times co-chief film critic A.O. Scott offered an early hint of “Argo’s” Oscar chances when he wrote about seeing it at the Telluride Film Festival last summer. The Media Equation columnist David Carr knows a thing or two about the Academy Awards from his former life as the Carpetbagger.

headline: The Consensus Candidate
abstract: A composite portrait of the 116 men who will elect Pope Benedict XVI’s successor.
lead_paragraph: A composite portrait of the 116 men who will elect Pope Benedict XVI’s successor.

headline: Starter: Bringing Vietnamese Flavor to Carroll Gardens
abstract: A passion project for the chef, Rob Newton.
lead_paragraph: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

headline: Reasons to Avoid Buying Stocks, and Why You Should Ignore Them
abstract: Investors are still scarred from the 2008 crash and they perceive stocks as risky, but stocks are more likely to provide a better return than bonds over the next few years.
lead_paragraph: THERE are always reasons not to buy stocks. Investors may think the Dow Jones industrial average is too high, as was the case in 1954 when the index topped 360. In 1941, there was Pearl Harbor. In 1962, the Cuban missile crisis. In 1997, the Asian financial crisis.

headline: Messiah Without a Cause, but With a Guitar
abstract: “Jesus in India,” by Lloyd Suh and starring Justin Blanchard, follows Jesus as a teenage runaway rocker.
lead_paragraph: So, like, Jesus is a total stoner and sometimes, you know, kind of a jerk. But he’s totally cute, and totally good on guitar.

headline: A Tale of Two Aston Martin DB5s
abstract: A star turn in “Skyfall” sends the value of an Aston Martin DB5 soaring.
lead_paragraph: Lot No. 200 at the RM Auction in London in 2010 was a British racing green 1965 Aston Martin DB5, which sold for £224,000 (about $385,000 at the time). That seemed a fair, if unspectacular, amount for such a car; it was in near-showroom condition, with full factory documentation and complete prior ownership information.

headline: A Life of Pie
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman shows us how to bake a pie and eat it too, without the guilt.
lead_paragraph: Pie is an indulgence often saved for holiday time. But this week Martha Rose Shulman shows us how to bake a pie and eat it too, without the guilt. She offers savory vegetable pies, showcased in whole grain crusts. She writes:

headline: Never Underestimate the Power of a Good Hug
abstract: Rachel Marcus went out with Robert Turetsky despite a photo of him with a ponytail. Good thing he cut it off by their first date.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Turetsky was growing up, there was always a degree of artistic ferment in his life: one of his grandmothers, Dora Wasserman, had founded a prominent Yiddish theater in Montreal, and Mr. Turetsky said he “essentially grew up sleeping in the aisles.”

headline: A Bleak Winter for Hourlong Series
abstract: Ratings for the networks’ midwinter entries have not been high as a rule, the exception being the viewership for “The Following,” on Fox.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long, cold winter for the broadcast television networks, for which almost every new series has been met with an equally chilly reception in the ratings.

headline: Photos of The Moment | DSquared2
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Sweet Spot: Watching the Oscars With …
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about what they’ll be doing on Sunday night for the Academy Awards. Care to join them for the glamour, the glitz and the upsets?
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about what they’ll be doing on Sunday night for the Academy Awards. Care to join them for the glamour, the glitz and the upsets?

headline: Patron of Siena Stumbles
abstract: Nowhere are Monte dei Paschi’s problems more acutely felt than in Siena. The bank has paid for charitable and civic works for as long as anyone can remember.
lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — Cut into the stonework of the imposing Palazzo Salimbeni is a name that has been entwined with the fortunes of this Tuscan city for five centuries: Monte dei Paschi, or Mount of the Pastures.

headline: Citigroup Pay Plan Raises the Bar Just a Bit
abstract: Under the new plan, the bank’s target for return on assets is still being set too low, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup’s new executive pay plan raises the bar, just not quite far enough. The bank’s board has put into effect a compensation scheme with more rigorous targets for the chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, and his lieutenants. One important performance metric, however, keeps expectations too low.

headline: Are Standardized Tests Worth the Stress?
abstract: Our commenters were split on the value of standardized tests. What do you think?
lead_paragraph: Po Bronson and Ashley Merryman’s Feb. 10 article on why some students are “worriers” (those who fall apart when under pressure) while others are “warriors” (those who thrive on it) generated 404 online comments. Central to the debate was whether standardized testing is beneficial or not.

headline: The Yankees’ One-Tool Player
abstract: Travis Hafner, who has not fielded a position since the summer of 2007, brings only a bat to work these days as the Yankees’ new designated hitter.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Travis Hafner, the Yankees’ new designated hitter, owns two baseball gloves. One is an outfielder’s glove, and the other is a first baseman’s mitt, which even has his nickname — Pronk — stamped on it in bright gold letters. The gloves collect dust in his locker.

headline: Little Money, Little Time, Big Visions
abstract: The dichotomy between Jeff Lipsky the filmmaker and Mr. Lipsky the acquisitions wizard is not lost on anyone, including his partners at Adopt Films.
lead_paragraph: No child in the history of mankind has ever said, “I want to be a film distributor when I grow up,” says Jeff Lipsky, and though he is a distributor, one with a compelling track record, he was no exception. “I always wanted to be a filmmaker. I just didn’t know it was going to take another 20 years.”

headline: Salley Offers a Healthy Assist
abstract: John Salley, a 6-foot-11 power forward and center, became a vegetarian in January 1991 after he felt he had to make changes in his lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: When Carmelo Anthony went on a vegetarian diet a few weeks ago and caused the biggest culinary conundrum in sports since fried chicken and beer had starring roles in the Red Sox clubhouse, John Salley could only shake his head.

headline: Hailing a Passing Flying Carpet
abstract: Douglas Fairbanks’s silent classic “The Thief of Bagdad” (1924) and the pioneering cinéma vérité documentary “Chronicle of a Summer” (1961) come to Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: The Thief of Bagdad

headline: The Last Word on Granola
abstract: Mark Bittman’s Crunchy Granola
lead_paragraph: We loved hearing your secrets for making tasty granola after Jeff Gordinier’s article this week on what chefs, artisans and entrepreneurs are doing with it. Your suggestions came through our blog, and on Twitter.

headline: Scud Missile Attack Reported in Aleppo
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The reported attack, which left at least 12 civilians dead, was the second time this week that the Syrian opposition has accused the military of using Scuds on Aleppo’s rebel-held areas.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Antigovernment activists in Syria said the military fired Scud missiles into at least three rebel-held districts of Aleppo on Friday, flattening dozens of houses, killing at least 12 civilians and burying perhaps dozens of others under piles of rubble.

headline: The Great Air Race
abstract: Air rights aren’t invisible if you are a developer. There is money in being able to build bigger and taller.
lead_paragraph: Because a room with a view has always been preferable to one without, the price of air in New York City is becoming more expensive. Yes, the air is for sale, but not on sale.

headline: South Korean Crossover in Hollywood
abstract: Three of South Korea’s best known and most honored directors have or will have their first English-language production released this year.
lead_paragraph: For nearly as long as there have been American movies there have been foreign directors making them, in a symbiotic arrangement that gives the visitors freedom, cash or exposure and the domestic film industry cachet and infusions of creativity. In Hollywood’s early years Europeans classed up the joint, particularly those from the center of the continent: von Stroheim, Lubitsch, Lang, Zinnemann. More recent waves of talent have washed in from Australia, Hong Kong and Latin America.

headline: Alive and Well at Merkin Concert Hall
abstract: A Belgian-reared critic takes in a performance of the songs of Jacques Brel, Belgium’s great singer-songwriter.
lead_paragraph: The Wafels & Dinges truck was getting ready to close for business when I hurried out of the subway at Lincoln Center this week, and the heady smell of burned sugar followed me as I turned north in the direction of the Kaufman Center. I was going to a New York Festival of Song concert, the first half of which was dedicated to the music of Jacques Brel, Belgium’s greatest gift — somewhat ahead of gaufres de Liège — to civilization. That prospect, in combination with the smell, turned knots in my stomach.

headline: Wearable Looks Emerge from the Cocoon
abstract: A year ago the fashion collections in New York and Europe seemed a coordinated effort to bury women in stuff. Now they are creating clothes that are relevant.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the fashion collections in New York and Europe seemed a coordinated effort to bury women in stuff. Remember Marc Jacobs’s oversize coats and head-gobbling Seuss hats? In Milan, Miuccia Prada layered up silk trousers and maxi-vests in diamond prints. Haider Ackermann’s lavishly composed outfits had editors raving, but, like a lot of fashion in recent seasons, you wondered why it needed to be so complicated.

headline: Deciding Whether to Dip a Toe in the Market
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Financial Planners', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Bucks readers discuss their investing strategy and their views about the stock market.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about all the reasons — and there are always reasons — that investors decide not to invest in the stock market. He names a few in his column, among them the Cuban missile crisis in 1962 and the Asian financial crisis in 1997, from a list compiled by Bel Air Investment Advisors for every year from 1934 to 2012.

headline: Islanders Reach Inevitable End with DiPietro and Waive Him
abstract: With eight years left on his ill-fated 15-year contract, the goalie Rick DiPietro was waived by the Islanders.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders waived goaltender Rick DiPietro on Friday, possibly ending one of the oddest and most expensive sagas in team history.

headline: Seeing Citizenship Path Near, Activists Push Obama to Slow Deportations
abstract: Activists say illegal immigrants are being forced out of the country at the wrong moment, as the promise of eventual citizenship seems around the corner in an overhaul of the immigration system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama intensifies his campaign for a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration system, advocates for America’s 11 million illegal immigrants are stepping up demands that he stop what has become one of the most aggressive and efficient efforts in decades to round up and deport people who are in the United States unlawfully.

headline: Permit Ready, Foundation Poured
abstract: One developer picks up where another leaves off, with plans to build a 15-story condominium on West 20th Street.
lead_paragraph: At their sagging, graffiti-tagged worst, the blue plywood fences that surround construction sites can be symbols of everything that went wrong in the housing bust, as stalled projects languish behind them.

headline: Taking Liberties With Cassoulet
abstract: You can substitute turkey legs and Great Northern beans for the classic French ingredients, but one remains constant: patience.
lead_paragraph: You need cold weather for cassoulet, that rustic, earthy and not-exactly-light slow-cooked indulgence. I make it at least once every winter, usually in February, when spring is still weeks away.

headline: Hossa Cleared to Play as Blackhawks Close In on Record
abstract: The Blackhawks’ star was knocked to the ice by by a forearm to the head Tuesday, but he was cleared to play Friday, when his team will attempt to set the N.H.L. record for most consecutive games with a point to begin a season.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The last time the Blackhawks’ Marian Hossa took a shot to the head, it was seven months before he was cleared to return. This time, it took just three days.

headline: After Heinz Deal, Other Food Companies Could Be Takeover Targets
abstract: Many big food companies have strong profitability and staying power, so mergers could offer good values for the right merger candidate, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: After the Warren E. Buffett-backed takeover of Heinz, Big Food merits a fresh look. Companies that are purveyors of meals, sauces and spreads may offer better value than is immediately obvious.

headline: Aerosmith and Foreigner Songwriters to Join Hall of Fame
abstract: Joe Perry and Steven Tyler of Aerosmith and Mick Jones and Lou Gramm of Foreigner are among seven songwriters being named to the Songwriters Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: The Songwriters Hall of Fame will honor members of Foreigner and Aerosmith during the 2013 induction ceremony to be held in New York this summer.

headline: Online Gambling Heats Up
abstract: Nevada and New Jersey are rushing ahead with online gambling, with Delaware not far behind. But the national landscape will not abruptly change until the bigger states get involved, which may take a while.
lead_paragraph: The two big casino states, Nevada and New Jersey, are racing into online gambling as a way of protecting their turf. They will in essence become laboratories for what is and is not feasible in Internet wagering.

headline: Dennis Hopper on One Kings Lane
abstract: Personal collections of the actor, director and artist, who died in 2010, will go up for sale on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The stylish home furnishings sale site One Kings Lane might seem an unlikely place to sell Dennis Hopper’s possessions. But tomorrow, an estate sale featuring items from the personal collections of the actor, director and artist, who died in 2010, will go live. And collect he did. Hopper, known for his screen roles from “Easy Rider” to “Blue Velvet,” spent decades amassing art and objects that filled his homes in Venice, Calif., Taos, N.M. and Wilmington, N.C.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 22
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book signing, the end of a citywide bus strike and a conference on gun violence in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book signing, the end of a citywide bus strike and a conference on gun violence in Connecticut.

headline: Week in Review: Sweeping Changes or a Symbolic Reprimand?
abstract: Prosecutors, shifting strategy, are building a new model for Wall Street cases. | Morgan Stanley is striving to coordinate two departments often at odds. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says Steven L. Rattner’s reputation, once sullied, has acquired a new shine.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors, shifting strategy, are building a new model for Wall Street cases. | Morgan Stanley is striving to coordinate two departments often at odds. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says Steven L. Rattner’s reputation, once sullied, has acquired a new shine.

headline: Palestinians Protest Route of Marathon to Sponsors
abstract: New Balance, a sneaker company, and a hotel chain were urged to withdraw sponsorship of the Jerusalem Marathon, which runs through territory considered occupied by Palestinians and much of the world.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A lawyer representing Palestinian government agencies sent letters this week to an American sneaker company and an international hotel chain threatening a boycott and legal action if they did not withdraw their sponsorship of the Jerusalem Marathon, which the Palestinians say violates international law.

headline: Judge Sides With Einhorn and Halts an Apple Shareholder Vote
abstract: A federal judge on Friday ordered Apple to halt collecting shareholder votes on a contentious proposal to change some of its corporate charter, handing a victory to the hedge fund manager David Einhorn.
lead_paragraph: 9:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: Here Comes Earnings Puffery. So Buy the Stock.
abstract: A hedge fund manager argues that A.I.G. stock is poised to soar, largely because he thinks the company will start manipulating earnings to make itself look good.
lead_paragraph: 5:36 p.m. | Updated with closing stock price.

headline: Rivera Pitches and Posada Jokes
abstract: While his former battery-mate watched, the Yankees’ closer threw his first live batting practice since injuring his knee.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Spring training had a nostalgic flair for the Yankees on Friday, as two familiar faces made returns of different types.

headline: Robert. Dad. Stepdad. What’s in a Name?
abstract: I don’t have stepchidren and biological children. I have children. Period. But four of my kids don’t call me “Dad.”
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a bubble. A slightly dysfunctional bubble. The term “broken home” was something I’d only heard of on TV. We had our share of problems, but they all stayed within the realm of the imaginable for me, and divorce was something I hadn’t really imagined.

headline: Ethnic War in Myanmar Has China on Edge
abstract: Chinese army units have been training near the border with Myanmar in anticipation of an ethnic war there spilling over, according to news media reports.
lead_paragraph: Chinese Army units have been undergoing intense training near the border with Myanmar in anticipation of an ethnic war there spilling into southwest China, according to official Chinese news media reports on Friday.

headline: A Brand-New Tradition
abstract: A showcase for the Bard College Conservatory of Music’s voice program featured talented young singers, Dawn Upshaw and a mischievous composer named Tamzin Elliott.
lead_paragraph: It is hard enough for a young composer to invent sounds. But Tamzin Elliott invented an entire culture.

headline: Major Overhaul for Nascar’s 2013 Models
abstract: In an attempt to revive interest in Nascar, the racing series is changing the shape of its cars, replacing the widely disliked Car of Tomorrow with what is being called Generation Six.
lead_paragraph: When a Daytona Beach gas station owner by the name of Bill France founded the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing in 1948, his immediate objective was to establish one set of rules for entrants in the race he was promoting. That principle — uniform, stable regulations — has been maintained through decades of Nascar’s rise to dominance, with the so-called stock cars barely changing even as the production models they were based on evolved.

headline: A New SS for Chevrolet and Nascar
abstract: The 2014 Chevrolet SS performance sedan was introduced at the Daytona International Speedway. The new car is the first Chevy to wear the SS name as its lone moniker.
lead_paragraph: Daytona Beach, Fla. — The 2014 Chevrolet SS performance sedan was introduced to the public and the press in the infield of Daytona International Speedway hours before its Nascar doppelgänger rolled onto track for the first race of the season, a preliminary to the Daytona 500. The car is the company’s first rear-drive performance sedan since the 1996 departure of the Impala SS.

headline: Tailoring a Look for Awards Season
abstract: Ginnifer Goodwin chose a dress because the designer, Misha Nonoo, was not a household name and because it mixed classicism with modern touches.
lead_paragraph: KNOWN FOR HER roles in “Big Love” and “Walk the Line,” the actress Ginnifer Goodwin, 34, currently plays Snow White on the ABC television series “Once Upon a Time.” Ms. Goodwin, a native of Memphis, lives in Los Angeles.

headline: Versace: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: For Pope: A Dude Like Dad
abstract: You don’t have to be a cardinal to lead the church, my dad used to point out.
lead_paragraph: BLOOMFIELD VILLAGE, Mich.

headline: Matchday 3: Johnson and Fox Soccer
abstract: Gus Johnson will call the third soccer game of his announcing career on Sunday when Manchester City plays Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Gus Johnson’s three-city European tour rolls into Manchester, England, where the newbie Fox Soccer announcer will settle in behind the microphone to call Sunday’s Manchester City-Chelsea Premier League match (8:30 a.m. Eastern).

headline: It Takes a Family to Adapt a French Novel
abstract: Justine Lévy, the author of the semi-autobiographical “Mauvaise Fille,” has adapted that work for screen with her partner, the actor and first-time director Patrick Mille.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In French “mauvaise fille” can mean both bad girl and bad daughter.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Moschino
abstract: Models sported peachy cheeks, courtesy of makeup artist Tom Pecheux.
lead_paragraph: Moschino’s models sported peachy cheeks on the catwalk this morning. “A very British and girlish mood inspired the collection, so I imagined a fresh look with blushy cheeks, doll lashes and a very healthy skin,” says the makeup artist Tom Pecheux. To achieve youthful, dewy skin, he used a dab of concealer and then a tiny bit of foundation. “We avoided any powder product and applied a creamy blush. Blended with the foundation, it gives a more natural look,” Pecheux explains. To finish the look, he applied M.A.C. Pro Eyes Gloss, a new product that will be available this fall, on the eyelids.

headline: Living In | Bath Beach, Brooklyn
abstract: The residential community on the borough’s shore is open to wide vistas of Gravesend Bay.
lead_paragraph: The residential community on the borough’s shore is open to wide vistas of Gravesend Bay.

headline: Assets Many, Listings Few
abstract: A former beach resort and neighborhood of melding communities where the most prevalent house style is the squared-off red-brick row house.
lead_paragraph: At St. Finbar Roman Catholic Church, the Rev. Michael Louis Gelfant presides over a flock that spans an old and new Bath Beach.

headline: A Hatch Marinated in Hot Sauce
abstract: The Ford Focus ST sticks sharp elbows into a perennial benchmark, the Volkswagen GTI. And while the Focus brings its own form of Euro sophistication, it adds a delightful layer of Yankee aggression.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2013 Ford Focus ST

headline: In Paid Family Leave, U.S. Trails Most of the Globe
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves', 'Children and Childhood', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The United States has among the world’s worst leave laws for new parents or for tending to a sick child, prompting some family advocates to seek an overhaul of the rules.
lead_paragraph: There I was, on the day my six months of maternity leave had ended, pushing my son’s stroller with one hand, clutching a jumbo box of 174 diapers with the other, doing my best to navigate through piles of slushy snow.

headline: Behind the Scenes: Models and Their Mothers
abstract: Howard Schatz discusses his ongoing project of photographing hundreds of model-mother pairs.
lead_paragraph: Howard Schatz is best known for dynamic photographs of athletes, like the one for Sam Anderson’s cover story on the Oklahoma City Thunder in November. But he also has a more contemplative side. For the past 12 years, Schatz, along with his wife and agent, Beverly Ornstein, has been working on a series of portraits of female models and their mothers, some of which are featured in this week’s Look. Schatz has photographed between 200 and 300 model-mother pairs, and he hopes to shoot 1,000, with the aim of publishing a book in a few years. I spoke with him about the project.

headline: The Red(head) Carpet
abstract: Jessica Chastain is but the latest titian-haired actress to provide a major brand boost for a high-end fashion house at Oscars time.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Chastain is but the latest titian-haired actress to provide a major brand boost for a high-end fashion house at Oscars time.

headline: Sending Out Smoke Signals
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The etiquette of marijuana smoking in social settings is largely uncodified, yet the world needs an Emily Post to hack a pathway through this thicket, particularly given pot’s increased presence in the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Not everyone at a gathering has the same reaction to the sight, or should I say stink, of marijuana. Some will lick their lips in anticipation of being propelled into a delicious psychosocial gavotte. Others will frown or skitter away, fearful they’re about to find out why the word “dude” is sometimes spelled “doood.” Some will simply think, “Midnight Express.”

headline: Food That’s Ready for a Close-Up
abstract: Wolfgang Puck will once again cater the Governor’s Ball after the Academy Awards ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Wolfgang Puck, second from left, offers the press a preview of dishes that will be served at the Governor’s Ball after the 85th Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday. This is Mr. Puck’s 19th year as the official caterer, and this year he will have a few vegan options to offer the 1,600 guests expected at the ball. And as always, his gold-dusted mini chocolate Oscars are on the menu.

headline: The Week in Pictures from Culture for Feb. 22
abstract: Photographs of cultural highlights from this week including exhibitions at the Morgan Library & Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of cultural highlights from this week including exhibitions at the Morgan Library & Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Starting on Campus, and Never Straying
abstract: John and Anne D Hederman met during her first week in Princeton, and in some ways grew up together.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 22
abstract: Photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: Growth in Deportations
abstract: Deportations under the Obama administration are on track to hit two million by the end of this year.
lead_paragraph: Deportations under the Obama administration are on track to hit two million by the end of this year.

headline: No Exit: China Uses Passports as Political Cudgel
keywords: ['Passports', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Travel Restrictions']
abstract: People who speak out against the government as well as members of minority groups are often barred from leaving or re-entering.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Greece, Mali, Syria and Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, Mali, Syria and Bangladesh.

headline: Former Canadian Ambassador Renews Criticism of ‘Argo’
abstract: The Canadian who was ambassador in Iran during the hostage crisis says “Argo” turns a Canadian story into an American one.
lead_paragraph: 5:52 p.m. | Updated  OTTAWA — The Iranians are not the only ones who feel slighted by the movie “Argo,” which recounts the hostage crisis of 1979. Some Canadians are grousing about the film as well.

headline: The Sweet Smell of Success
abstract: Jessica Chastain takes the next step in her branding as an international star, becoming the so-called global ambassador for Manifesto, the new fragrance from Yves Saint Laurent.
lead_paragraph: As she rose from her chair at the Calvin Klein fashion show in Midtown Manhattan the other week, Jessica Chastain was all but engulfed by an onrush of journalists and celebrity groupies imploring the lanky, flame-haired actress for a word, a glance, a nanosecond of her time.

headline: The Daily Do | Moschino
abstract: Today’s do: the utterly feminine, side-parted low pony at Moschino.
lead_paragraph: Moschino’s utterly feminine, side-parted low pony was slightly teased and tugged out, as if by winds after a Highland hike, yet still sleek enough for a Scottish royal.

headline: Surviving AIDS, but Not the Life That Followed
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Homosexuality', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: Did the battle to fight AIDS ultimately kill Spencer Cox, one of its early warriors? Mr. Cox appears in the documentary “How to Survive a Plague,” which has been nominated for an Academy Award.
lead_paragraph: In early December, the veteran AIDS activists Spencer Cox, Garance Franke-Ruta and Peter Staley had a reunion of sorts. They met in a packed auditorium at St. Luke’s Hospital on the Upper West Side, where a screening of “How to Survive a Plague,” the soon-to-be-Oscar-nominated documentary, was taking place.

headline: Volkswagen to Unveil 261 M.P.G.e. Production Car
abstract: Volkswagen says it “is redefining what is technically feasible in the automotive industry.”
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen says it plans to unveil its 261-miles-per-gallon XL1 plug-in hybrid, a two-seat sports machine that it will begin offering for sale this year, at the Geneva auto show on March 5.

headline: Decoded Fashion and CFDA Host Fashion Hackathon
abstract: On Super Bowl Sunday, when most New Yorkers were prepping for the big game, hundreds of fashion and technology devotees were going head to head.
lead_paragraph: On Super Bowl Sunday, when most New Yorkers were prepping for the big game, hundreds of fashion and technology devotees were going head to head.

headline: Europe’s Example
abstract: Anyone who thinks the sequester won’t hurt the economy should study the impact of austerity on the euro zone.
lead_paragraph: Analysts and lawmakers in Washington who are shrugging off the economic impact of the sequester — the $85 billion reduction in discretionary spending starting on March 1 — should direct their attention to Europe. Countries on the continent have been raising taxes and slashing budgets in a misguided effort to cut their deficits and revive their economies. For all their pains, however, what they are getting is a more prolonged recession.

headline: Crystal Goblets Set Stage for Whimsy and Religion
abstract: The New York Philharmonic presented a program of works by Christopher Rouse, Brahms and Ernest Bloch, with Jan Vogler as cello soloist.
lead_paragraph: The composer Christopher Rouse, in residence with the New York Philharmonic this season, has referred to his orchestral work “Phantasmata” as one of his “rabble-rouser pieces.” Like many of his scores, this triptych, inspired by dreams and completed in 1985, weaves lively rhythms, vivid colors and elements of popular music into a tightly wrought canvas.

headline: Pentagon Orders F-35 Jets Grounded
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'F-35 Airplane', 'Engines', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: Flights by the stealthy jets, being delivered to all three branches of the military, were suspended after an inspection found a crack in a turbine blade on a test plane.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said on Friday that it had grounded all of its stealthy new F-35 fighter jets after an inspection found a crack in a turbine blade in the engine of one of the planes.

headline: A Little Graham, Duncan and Mylar
abstract: Borrowing memorable moves of modern-dance matriarchs, Moriah Evans composes “Another Performance” at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: As the show begins, performers in ordinary clothes pace purposefully, carrying props and defining paths with 90-degree turns. One dancer kicks the pivoting to a higher level, slicing her arms through space, swinging a leg and slapping it down. Her dance is both arresting and familiar. It’s all another performance. More precisely, it’s “Another Performance,” by the budding choreographer Moriah Evans.

headline: The Visions of Fred Tomaselli
abstract: Tomaselli, known for his trippy paintings, donated work and discussed his art for a Paddle8 auction to benefit the Drug Policy Alliance.
lead_paragraph: Among drug advocates, there are your average stoners and there are gurus who proselytize about consciousness-expanding substances — people like Timothy Leary, who was branded “the most dangerous man in America.” That label came from President Richard Nixon, whose “war on drugs” persists: in 2011, according to the Drug Policy Alliance, more than 1.5 million Americans were arrested on nonviolent drug charges.

headline: Judge Upholds S.E.C. Freeze on Account Tied to Suspicious Heinz Trades
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Insider Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Privacy']
abstract: The hearing did nothing to illuminate the identity of the suspect trader, a mystery confounding regulators and complicating the case. No one appeared in court on Friday to represent or defend the traders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge has upheld the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s recent action against a Swiss account linked to possible insider trading in the $23 billion takeover of H.J. Heinz, the agency announced on Friday.

headline: Smoothing the Frictions Between Parent and Nanny
abstract: Lindsay Heller helps open the lines of communication between parents, who are sometimes of the celebrity set, and the nannies they hire.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t that Kimberly Van Der Beek’s new nanny was unqualified. She had come with sparkling references and a gold-star recommendation from her agency. She knew three languages and had philosophies about child development. She was nice and prompt and had an excellent driving record.

headline: As One Renaissance Door Closes, Others Open
abstract: Michelangelo’s Sistine Chapel may be closed to the public while a successor for Pope Benedict XVI is chosen, but Raphael’s rooms are on view in all their glory after a 30-year restoration.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — One of the most popular attractions of the Vatican Museums, Michelangelo’s Sistine Chapel, will be closed to the public over the next few weeks, as cardinals gather there to elect the successor of Pope Benedict XVI. But visitors will be able to find some artistic consolation by lingering in the rooms that Raphael painted in the second-floor apartment of the Pontifical palace used by Pope Julius II (and his successors until the mid-16th century), their 30-year restoration now finally complete.

headline: Koufax Dons Dodgers Uniform for First Time Since 1980s
abstract: The Hall of Fame pitcher is spending 10 days at training camp as a pitching instructor, lured back to the franchise by the team’s head of marketing and its president.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Ed Farmer, the voice of the Chicago White Sox, will tell you that as a teenager he heard the voice of God and that it belonged to Sandy Koufax, the Dodgers’ Hall of Fame left-handed pitcher.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wrapping Up
abstract: New York Fashion Week is a dazzling display of more than 200 designers proposing looks that the shows’ guests will soon make their own.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week is a dazzling display of more than 200 designers proposing looks that the shows’ guests will soon make their own.

headline: A Plain White Square, and Yet So Fascinating
abstract: The artist Rutherford Chang puts his obsession with the Beatles’s “White Album” on display at the Recess Gallery.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy afternoon recently Rutherford Chang sat at a desk near the window of the Recess Gallery in SoHo, listening to “The Beatles” — the two-disc set, released in 1968, and commonly known as “The White Album,” and showing a visitor a computer printout listing of several hundred copies of the album he owns.

headline: Art Gallery Sued Again Over Sale of Paintings
abstract: Knoedler & Company has been named in another lawsuit, this one by David Mirvish, a theatrical impresario who claims the gallery did not do enough to sell paintings he says are genuine.
