lead_paragraph: The once esteemed Knoedler & Company gallery has been sued five times since late 2011 by former clients who said it sold them forged paintings procured from a little-known Long Island dealer.

headline: Egypt’s President Could Win a Trip to Space, Whether He Wants One or Not
abstract: Egyptian activists disappointed by the performance of President Mohamed Morsi have hatched a scheme to send him into space.
lead_paragraph: A group of Egyptian activists who reluctantly endorsed Mohamed Morsi in last year’s presidential election, and have been bitterly disappointed by his performance in office, are again urging their fellow citizens to cast a vote for him. This time, however, a victory for Mr. Morsi would send him not to the presidential palace, but into space.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Versace
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: strappy mink stilettos.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: New York’s Export-Import World of Movement
abstract: The dancer Lil Buck and work by the choreographers Christopher Wheeldon, Paul Taylor and Mark Morris are among the highlights of the spring season in New York.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, who has worked extensively on both sides of the Atlantic, said in an interview that “New York has become quite conservative in a sense,” adding, “For me now London is, without question, the dance capital of the world.”

headline: Big Ticket | Spacious for Artwork, Sold for $21 Million
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A Manhattan duplex apartment, one of just 28 residences at 733 Park Avenue, has 4,250 square feet of space inside and 1,250 square feet of terraces.
lead_paragraph: An opulent and meticulously renovated Manhattan duplex penthouse owned by the same family of Impressionist art connoisseurs for decades at 733 Park Avenue sold for its $21 million asking price and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The amenities at the co-op building, a white-glove establishment with just 28 residences, include a wine cellar and a gym.

headline: Digging for Hagel Dirt: An Update
abstract: Conservative groups said they would use the weeklong recess to unearth damaging information about the defense secretary nominee. Turns out, that’s expensive work.
lead_paragraph: Conservative groups working to derail the nomination of Chuck Hagel as defense secretary said last week that they planned to use the Senate’s weeklong recess to unearth anything they could to block him.

headline: Distinct Paths, Same Destination
abstract: Justin Peck and Yasuko Yokoshi, using different methodology, are determined to keep classical dance alive within a contemporary framework.
lead_paragraph: Choreographically and personally Justin Peck and Yasuko Yokoshi don’t appear to have much in common. Mr. Peck, a native of San Diego, is a 25-year-old member of New York City Ballet, where he has recently made a name for himself as a creator of vibrant, rigorously structured dances. In the downtown world Ms. Yokoshi, originally from Hiroshima, Japan, has long been revered as an important experimentalist, a purveyor of form and subversive daring.

headline: Forces of Creation Moving in Unison
abstract: Surupa Sen and Bijayini Satpathy come to the Skirball Center in April; Souleymane Badolo plays New York Live Arts later in the month.
lead_paragraph: Presenting non-Western dances to Western audiences can be a difficult business. If an artist adjusts too much, a deep tradition can flatten into pandering tourist fare. If an artist adjusts too little, fidelity can get in the way of communication; a living art form can come across as a relic.

headline: No Tiptoeing Around His Opinions
abstract: The choreographer Paul Taylor has a new book out, “Facts and Fancies: Essays Written Mostly for Fun,” but he gives away no tricks of the trade.
lead_paragraph: This time a year ago the Paul Taylor Dance Company had its first season at Lincoln Center: a three-week engagement at the David H. Koch Theater. Around the theater you could find printed copies of a remarkable essay by Mr. Taylor, “Why I Make Dances.” Now, just as his company prepares to open its follow-up season at the Koch, Mr. Taylor has brought out a pocket-size book of his writings, “Facts and Fancies: Essays Written Mostly for Fun.” The opening piece, “Why I Make Dances,” is its first and most serious entry, covering a range of moods.

headline: What Price Fitness? You Get to Make the Call
abstract: Adam Rosante has introduced a pay-what-you-can approach to fitness classes in New York.
lead_paragraph: In the first six minutes of boot camp on a recent Tuesday night, the trainer Adam Rosante has a class of 27 audibly gasping for breath, already having exercised every muscle.

headline: Big Prices for Small Packages
abstract: Rob Sass evaluates five notable sales from the Bruce Weiner collection.
lead_paragraph: Rob Sass evaluates five notable sales from the Bruce Weiner collection.

headline: Laughing All the Way to the Bank
abstract: The vehicles from Bruce Weiner’s microcar collection may look like clown cars, but they sold for serious money.
lead_paragraph: The vehicles from Bruce Weiner’s microcar collection may look like clown cars, but they sold for serious money.

headline: Tiny Bubbles, Causing a Buzz
abstract: An auction of the world’s largest collection of microcars, the tiny vehicles that were made in Europe after World War II, brought in about $9 million.
lead_paragraph: Madison, Ga. — Bruce Weiner has driven Ferraris, Porsches and Jaguars. But he never got more attention on the road than in a banana-yellow 1963 Goggomobil TL-250 Transporter, the toylike microcar he nicknamed “the mailbox on wheels.”

headline: Exploring Climate Resilience and Energy Sense
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Water']
abstract: Adaption to heat is a prime imperative even as the much tougher task of moving beyond conventional use of fossil fuels is pursued.
lead_paragraph: I visited Los Angeles this week to discuss new approaches to environmental communication with students and faculty at the Institute of the Environment and Sustainability of the University of California, Los Angeles. I also joined two of the university’s professors — the climate scientist Alex Hall and the environmental historian Jon Christensen — for an onstage Zócalo Public Square discussion of this question: “Should we just adapt to climate change?” (The answer of course is…drumroll…no.)

headline: New Drone Base in Niger Builds U.S. Presence in Africa
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Terrorism', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: The new base, announced by President Obama on Friday, is an indication of the priority Africa has become in American antiterrorism efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Opening a new front in the drone wars against Al Qaeda and its affiliates, President Obama announced on Friday that about 100 American troops had been sent to Niger in West Africa to help set up a new base from which unarmed Predator aircraft would conduct surveillance in the region.

headline: U.S. Inquiries Over Automobile Safety Dragging On
abstract: Millions of car owners have been left in recall limbo because some of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s investigations have been taking years to complete.
lead_paragraph: Last year, owners of about 16.2 million cars and trucks received letters saying their vehicles had safety problems and were being recalled. But millions more were left in recall limbo because some of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s investigations into possible safety problems have been taking years longer than the agency’s self-imposed goal.

headline: After a Charging System Test, a Debate Erupts Online
abstract: A reporter’s adventure testing Tesla’s network of fast-charging stations for the Model S was detailed in the Automobiles section. The article resulted in a strong reaction on the Web and in the media.
lead_paragraph: When a drive in a budding automaker’s crucial new model leaves a newspaper reporter waiting for a tow truck, a report on the incident is bound to cause a stir.

headline: Single Works With Myriad Influences
abstract: Iona Rozeal Brown’s eclectic work, an intersection of Asian and African-American forms, will have a showcase with two new gallery shows.
lead_paragraph: Max Ernst wrote of collage, though he could just as easily have been referring to his painting, that it is “the noble conquest of the irrational, the coupling of two realities, irreconcilable in appearance.”

headline: Red Carpet Rumbles
abstract: The red carpet may look glamorous, but it’s a war zone with reporters and photographers on one side and publicists for the stars on the other.
lead_paragraph: The annual procession into the Academy Awards ceremony in Hollywood may captivate television viewers with its pageantry, but on the ground it can feel more like a skirmish between rival militias.

headline: Shocking Congress in the ’60s
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company is presenting a program on the theme of “Myth and Transformation” at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: The theme of the current season of the Martha Graham Dance Company is “Myth and Transformation” — how choreographers use old stories to make contemporary statements. The use of myth can be a powerful method for tapping into the timeless, but the transformations can also say more about the period when they were made than about the period in which they were set.

headline: High Profile, Simple Plan
abstract: Jonny Orsini has jumped from small Off Broadway parts to Nathan Lane’s love interest on Broadway in “The Nance.”
lead_paragraph: Jonny Orsini, 27, couldn’t have planned a speedier vault to Broadway had he been a ruthless careerist. After a couple of small Off Broadway roles (most recently in David Rabe’s “Early History of Fire”) he’s about to go mano a mano, romantically, with Nathan Lane in Douglas Carter Beane’s new play, “The Nance,” a serio-comic homage to the daring gay performers of 1930s burlesque.

headline: A Boy Finds His Love for Theater
abstract: Tim Federle, a musical-theater veteran, has written two children’s novels about a 13-year-old obsessed with the theater and offering support for young people discovering that they are gay.
lead_paragraph: Among the cliques in middle school, the theater nerds — kids who can recite Stephen Sondheim lyrics by heart and name the Broadway actresses who played Dolly Levi in order — are hardly on easy street. Tim Federle found that in 1994 when a suburban Pittsburgh classmate teased him about wearing tights in a local production of “Cats.” Mortified, 13-year-old Tim dropped out of the musical, citing only “personal reasons.”

headline: Americans Want to Cut Spending. They Just Don’t Know What to Cut.
abstract: As the sequester looms, it’s worth noting that there’s no significant federal spending category that a majority of Americans wants to cut, according to a new Pew poll.
lead_paragraph: As the sequester looms, it’s worth noting that there’s no significant federal spending category that a majority of Americans wants to cut:

headline: Fireballs in the Sky Are Not Exclusive to Siberia
abstract: The Russian fireball that injured 1,200 in Siberia last week seemed impossibly improbable and exotic, but the New York region has seen more than its share of meteors and meteorites.
lead_paragraph: “On Friday evening, a few minutes before 10 o’clock,” the account begins, “I was standing with a friend in Thirty-fourth-street, near the southwest corner of Madison-avenue, when we observed a luminous body rising rapidly from behind the houses on the southerly side of the street.”

headline: Alan F. Westin, Who Transformed Privacy Debate Before the Web Era, Dies at 83
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Mr. Westin was considered to have created, almost single-handedly, the modern field of privacy law.
lead_paragraph: Alan F. Westin, a legal scholar who nearly half a century ago defined the modern right to privacy in the incipient computer age — a definition that anticipated the reach of Big Brother and helped circumscribe its limits — died on Monday in Saddle River, N.J. He was 83.

headline: Arguing About the Keystone Pipeline
abstract: Sampling the responses to a column by Joe Nocera.

headline: A 9/11 Victim’s Family Raises New Objections to ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
abstract: Survivors of a flight attendant who died in the Sept. 11 attacks say filmmakers should apologize for using a recording of her voice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s not over yet for “Zero Dark Thirty” — at least, not in the complaints department.

abstract: A co-founder of a youth campaign to cut the debt responds to a column by Paul Krugman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: El Museo del Barrio Named in Discrimination Claim
abstract: The former director of El Museo del Barrio is in a legal battle with the museum after her dismissal last week and her claim with the State Division of Human Rights.
lead_paragraph: The former director of El Museo del Barrio and the board of that museum are in a legal battle, with her claiming gender discrimination and a hostile workplace while the museum says she was dismissed for poor performance.

abstract: Some beautiful heartbreak from The Head and the Heart.

abstract: Three-time national champion Rick Zucker and his partner, Sheila Cornstein of New York City, won the event in January.
lead_paragraph: When a pro-am pair wins a tournament, usually the professional offers a deal featuring himself. So it is always refreshing to see something played or defended well by the amateur.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 22
abstract: View a selection of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book signing, the end of a citywide school bus strike and a conference on gun violence in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book signing, the end of a citywide school bus strike and a conference on gun violence in Connecticut.

headline: Model Diary | Nadja Bender
abstract: The Danish model shares her favorite things with T.
lead_paragraph: Everyone’s talking about Nadja Bender who walked in everything from Alexander Wang to Tom Ford to Gucci. And the Danish model is really happy to be in Milan, where she walked in yesterday’s Fendi show.

headline: After One Success, Trying for Another
abstract: Heirloom Tavern in Glen Head, whose chef-owner already has a hit restaurant, offers choices big and small.
lead_paragraph: Kent Monkan has done it again. The chef-owner of the Brass Rail in Locust Valley — one of Long Island’s best restaurants, which opened in 2008 — Mr. Monkan added a second winner in January with the Heirloom Tavern in Glen Head. From openers to desserts, just about everything we sampled was outstanding.

headline: What Our Brains Can Teach Us
abstract: We have the world’s best model for futuristic technology inside our heads.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON

headline: A Window (or Several) on Indian Cuisine
abstract: Zaroka, in New Haven, offers a profusion of flavors and spices in a stunning setting.
lead_paragraph: In a corner of the entryway of Zaroka Bar and Restaurant in New Haven stands an Indian treasure box, gorgeously inlaid with bits of shiny colored glass. The treasure is revealed to be a profusion of Indian spices — green cardamom, coriander, peppercorns, cumin and black cardamom, to name a few. It is a fitting introduction to an Indian restaurant that offers good food in a stunning setting.

headline: DiPietro Timeline: A Promising Career Derailed by Injuries
abstract: A timeline of the career of the 31-year-old goaltender Rick DiPietro, who was waived by the Islanders on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders waived the 31-year-old goaltender Rick DiPietro on Friday. DiPietro, the No. 1 overall pick in the 2000 draft, has struggled to live up to expectations in a career troubled by injuries. Below is a timeline of his career.

headline: Statin Drug Production Resumes at Ranbaxy
abstract: Ranbaxy, which had more than 40 percent of the United States market for generic Lipitor in October, said it had been working with the F.D.A. to solve quality problems in making the drug.
lead_paragraph: The Indian drug maker Ranbaxy Pharmaceuticals announced Friday that it has started making a generic version of Lipitor again, saying that it was fixing the problems that led it to halt production of the anti-cholesterol drug after glass particles were discovered in pills.

headline: House G.O.P. Offers Violence Act With Fewer Specific Protections
abstract: In contrast to a version of the Violence Against Women Act passed in the Senate, a House version excludes specific protections for gay, bisexual or transgender victims of domestic abuse, and offers limited provisions for Native American women on reservations.
lead_paragraph: The version of the Violence Against Women Reauthorization Act that House Republicans unveiled Friday afternoon — which excludes specific protections for gay, bisexual or transgender victims of domestic abuse, and offers limited provisions for Native American women on reservations — is already facing fierce criticism from Democrats and women’s and human rights groups.

headline: Prada Goes With Her Feelings
abstract: Miuccia Prada underscores the difference between the collections of male and female designers.
lead_paragraph: A fashion show typically lasts about 10 minutes, and that’s just enough time to either be suicidal from boredom or convinced you haven’t even begun to live, since you never thought of wearing a black party dress over the gray cardigan you leave at the office because you, Ms. Mouse, are always cold.

headline: Terror in the Suburbs (and Job Market)
abstract: “Dark Skies,” directed by Scott Stewart, retools the haunted-house thriller for recessionary times.
lead_paragraph: You would have good reason to bring some skepticism to the horror thriller “Dark Skies,” beginning with its generic title. There’s also its familiar premise: a suburban family must confront a mysterious, malignant presence terrorizing its house. And there’s the fact that the film’s writer and director, Scott Stewart, previously directed “Legion” and “Priest,” effects-driven, comic-book-like opuses that may not suggest hidden depths to many.

headline: A Mediterranean Hearth With Local Appeal
abstract: O Lar, a modest Mediterranean-influenced restaurant, serves hearty, spirited food and swarms with appreciative diners.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of compelling reasons to eat at O Lar, a modest Mediterranean-influenced restaurant in a residential neighborhood of Piermont, in Rockland County, N.Y. (The name means “hearth” or “home” in Galician.)

abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Books as Artists’ Concepts: Time, Space, Performance
abstract: The volumes exhibited in “P Is for Performance,” at the Purchase College Library, are artists’ works with elements unexpected in traditional books.
lead_paragraph: PURCHASE, N.Y. — Page after wordless page, the drawing repeats: a monochromatic outline of an older woman stands protectively beside a younger woman, bordered by the lines of an unadorned stage set. Not until the last page is there a new image: now the young woman grimaces as a man holding a gun leads her away. Opposite is the sentence “Let’s all kiss mommy goodbye.”

headline: Confronting the Fact of Fiction and the Fiction of Fact
abstract: When movies like “Lincoln,” “Argo” and “Zero Dark Thirty” traffic in history, exactly what are their obligations?
lead_paragraph: They don’t call Hollywood the Truth Factory.

headline: Russian Who Led U.S. Adoption Ban Has Flair for Celebrity and Controversy
abstract: Long before becoming Russia’s child rights commissioner, Pavel A. Astakhov transformed himself into a celebrity lawyer with mass market appeal.

headline: Parental Leave: What Does Your Employer Offer?
abstract: Bucks readers are asked to help provide a progress report that will highlight paid parental leave policies at their employers.
lead_paragraph: June 7 | Updated with information from Wal-Mart.

headline: Underground Nuclear Tanks Leaking in Washington State
abstract: Six underground tanks holding radioactive waste are leaking at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in eastern Washington, Gov. Jay Inslee said.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Six underground tanks holding radioactive waste are leaking at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in eastern Washington, Gov. Jay Inslee said on Friday after a meeting with federal officials overseeing the cleanup of the nation’s most polluted nuclear site.

headline: What’s the Matter with Kenya?
abstract: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, and Marc Lacey, a deputy foreign editor, discuss the escalating ethnic violence in Kenya as elections approach.
lead_paragraph: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, and Marc Lacey, a deputy foreign editor, discuss the escalating ethnic violence in Kenya as elections approach.

headline: Clouds Gone By, Reconsidered
abstract: “Reflections on Constable’s Cloud Studies: Paintings by Mark Leonard” pairs 10 oils by the 19th-century painter John Constable with 10 works by a contemporary artist who was inspired by them.
lead_paragraph: When we consider the art of translation, we think about novels and plays, not paintings. But a fascinating show at the Yale Center for British Art contends that painters speak their own languages, too, and that a good translation can stand on its own even as it enlarges our perception of the original.

headline: U.S. Moves to Provide Quicker Access to Publicly Financed Scientific Research
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Research', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Scientific papers supported by federal funds will become freely accessible to the public within a year or so after publication.
lead_paragraph: If you paid for it, you should be able to read it. For publicly financed science research, the Obama administration agrees.

headline: The Week in Pictures From Business for Feb. 22
abstract: Protesters in Europe rallied against austerity measures, Google unveiled more information on Google Glass, and Sony announced its PlayStation 4 console without actually showing it.
lead_paragraph: Protesters in Europe rallied against austerity measures, Google unveiled more information on Google Glass, and Sony announced its PlayStation 4 console without actually showing it.

headline: In Fracas on Train, Parolee Found That Hitting Back Was a Risky Option
abstract: A man confronting the teenagers who bumped into him on a subway train soon found himself in a fight with his assailants, one of whom said she was on her way to get a sonogram.
lead_paragraph: “You could have at least said, ‘Excuse me.’ ”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Retirement and Food Substitutes
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include the United States’ early history of technology theft, Sergey Brin showing Mark Zuckerberg how his Google glasses work and why Nevada’s legalization of online gambling will do little to help social games..
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Fear and Loathing in Indiana
abstract: How partisan struggles in Illinois and Indiana almost brought the Civil War to the North.
lead_paragraph: In February 1863, the states of Illinois and Indiana teetered on the precipice of revolution. So thought their governors, Republicans Richard Yates and Oliver P. Morton. Antiwar Democrats had won legislative majorities in the fall elections of 1862 in resounding fashion, energized by the public’s hostile reactions to the failing war effort and response to President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Georgetown Visits Syracuse Once More in Rivalry That Made Big East
abstract: The Orange will leave for the Atlantic Coast Conference next season, and there is no indication that they will play the Hoyas after that.
lead_paragraph: The Syracuse-Georgetown rivalry was born on a cold Tuesday night in Manley Field House in February 1980, or so the story goes. It is a nice opening chapter, but some dig a little bit deeper.

headline: A Prize-Winning Ethics Lesson?
abstract: The subject of a photo that helped earn Paolo Pellegrin top honors in the Pictures of the Year International contest has raised questions surrounding it.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Feb. 26: World Press stands by its decision to award Paolo Pellegrin second place in the general news category of their contest.

headline: A Modern Medal Is Met With Modern Protest
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Purple Heart (Military Decoration)']
abstract: The new Distinguished Warfare medal — immediately dubbed the Drone Medal — has spawned memes and an online petition.
lead_paragraph: It is only fitting that the announcement of a medal created for the digital age spawned its own Internet memes. As soon as Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta announced the creation of the new Distinguished Warfare medal — immediately dubbed the Drone Medal — images such as the one below began appearing on blog after blog; in tweet after retweet.

headline: Urban Memories; With John and Yoko
abstract: New books on New York include “An Enlarged Heart: A Personal History” by Cynthia Zarin; “The Surprising Design of Market Economies” by Alex Marshall; and “Days That I’ll Remember” by Jonathan Cott.
lead_paragraph: In her collection “An Enlarged Heart: A Personal History” (Knopf, $24.95), Cynthia Zarin delivers a dozen delightful essays set mostly in ephemeral Manhattan.

headline: Breaking with Tradition, Over and Over
abstract: “Mirrored Images,” a show of around 50 works drawn from the permanent collection of the Heckscher Museum of Art, suggests what has been at stake for painters engaged in the practice of realism.
lead_paragraph: THE TERM “REALISM” has been tossed around in art for centuries, although it gained particular traction in mid-19th-century France. What it meant for many artists at the time was the depiction of observed reality rather than the portrayal of biblical, mythological or historical subjects in a “realistic” (or naturalistic) manner, as the academic painting tradition prescribed. Realism’s radical stance was best summed up by Gustave Courbet, who set up his own pavilion outside the Salon of 1855, dedicated to Le Réalisme, and famously declared, “I cannot paint an angel because I have never seen one.”

headline: HTC Settles Privacy Case Over Flaws in Phones
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission charged HTC with customizing software on its phones in ways that could steal personal information and surreptitiously send text messages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 18 million smartphones and other mobile devices made by HTC, a Taiwanese company that is one of the largest sellers of smartphones in the United States, had security flaws that could allow location tracking of users against their will and the theft of personal information stored on their phones, federal officials said Friday.

headline: Sequester for Dummies
abstract: Don’t worry, Concerned Citizens. With all the gossip these days swirling around budget cuts, I’m prepared to answer all your important questions.
lead_paragraph: You’ve been having a tough year, Concerned Citizen. You keep waiting for Congress to take up immigration or guns — something you have an opinion about. All you get are arcane budget fights. Unless you live in the Beltway, it’s hard to build a dinner party around sequestration gossip.

headline: F.A.A. Sets Terms for Boeing’s Battery Fixes on the 787
abstract: After meeting with company executives, the Federal Aviation Agency said any proposal to get the 787 back in the air must assure that its lithium-ion batteries do not fail again.
lead_paragraph: After meeting with Boeing executives, top federal aviation officials said on Friday that they would not approve any fix to the battery problems on the 787 jetliner until they were certain that the batteries would not fail again.

headline: The Mummy Returns
abstract: With a new prime minister as well as a new pope in the offing, Italy is an opera of endless amazement.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was in college, there was an election for student body president in which one of the three top contenders was a joke candidate who campaigned with a paper bag over his head and went by a made-up name evoking a tumescent male appendage. He finished second, if memory serves. I thought I was watching a farce peculiar to the contest’s low stakes and the crude humor of students our age. I had no idea I was getting a preview of Italian politics.

headline: Former International Player Seeks Review of His Ineligibility at St. John’s
abstract: Orlando Sanchez, who briefly played for the Dominican Republic, wants reconsideration of a ruling that left him unable to play another year of college basketball.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Orlando Sanchez was the youngest member of the Dominican Republic national basketball team. He was 22, and though he stepped on the court for only a few minutes, making the team was a landmark achievement for Sanchez, who had nearly given up his basketball ambitions years before.

headline: Infusing a Grim Subject With Color and Whimsy
keywords: ['Art', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: To commemorate the 70th anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising, the George Segal Gallery at Montclair State University will show murals and paintings by Israel Bernbaum, a Holocaust survivor.
lead_paragraph: IN 2011, M. TERESA RODRIGUEZ, the director of the George Segal Gallery on the Montclair State University campus, received a call from the Holocaust Resource Center of the Jewish Federation of Greater Clifton-Passaic.

headline: Too Good a Deal to Pass Up
abstract: Seven Republican governors shed their ideology for compelling reasons and have embraced Medicaid expansion, a critical element of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Rick Scott, the Republican governor of Florida, did an about-face this week by agreeing to expand the state’s Medicaid program, a critical element of the Affordable Care Act. Three years ago, while running for governor, Mr. Scott, a former hospital executive, campaigned on his opposition to the health care reform law. Last year, after the Supreme Court ruled that expanding Medicaid was optional, he announced that Florida would not do so.

headline: Fed Officials Debate Bank’s Losses Once Economy Mends
keywords: ['Quantitative Easing', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities']
abstract: Last year, the Federal Reserve transferred $89 billion in profit to the Treasury, but it now faces the possibility of large losses as it sells off securities.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s plans for the eventual wind-down of its economic stimulus campaign could provoke a political reaction that will make it more difficult to control inflation, a current Fed official and a former Fed governor said Friday.

headline: Better Charter Schools in New York City
abstract: A new study shows how New York can build on its stronger-than-average record.
lead_paragraph: From a national standpoint, the 20-year-old charter school movement has been a disappointment. More than a third of these independently run, publicly funded schools are actually worse than the traditional public schools they were meant to replace. Abysmal charter schools remain open for years, even though the original deal was that they would be shut down when they failed to perform. New York City’s experience, however, continues to be an exception.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Catholics Gather in California, Haunted by Cardinal’s Scandal
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Priests', 'Cardinals (Roman Catholic Prelates)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: At the Religious Education Congress in Los Angeles, the nation’s largest annual gathering of Roman Catholics, many have been re-evaluating Cardinal Roger M. Mahony’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — For decades, Cardinal Roger M. Mahony was the convener and the star of the nation’s largest annual gathering of Roman Catholics, which opened here on Thursday.

headline: Drama and Comedy in a Pittsburgh Diner
abstract: “Two Trains Running” is one of a series of plays by August Wilson about the African-American experience in the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: MAYBE EVERYBODY SHOULD go see Aunt Ester. She will change your luck, get you a good price in your next business deal, cleanse you of the angry energy that makes you want to kill a family member — from all indications, make possible whatever you need. August Wilson introduced her to the world, albeit offstage, in “Two Trains Running,” the 1992 play that is Two River Theater Company’s dramatically and comically rich current production.

headline: Lifting a Town to Escape the Next Storm
abstract: Officials say that flood-prone Highlands, along the Jersey Shore, could be raised, to prevent damage from future hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLANDS, N.J. — If not for the most deadly natural disaster in American history, in Texas, and an innovative response to it, more than a century ago, one might briskly consign the proposal to save this oft-flooded borough at the northern end of the Jersey Shore to the realm of pigs with wings.

headline: Crossover Campaigning
abstract: In his campaign to be the next mayor of New York City, William C. Thompson Jr. is counting on strong support from Jewish voters, especially the Orthodox community.
lead_paragraph: In his campaign to be the next mayor of New York City, William C. Thompson Jr. is counting on strong support from Jewish voters, especially the Orthodox community.

headline: In Mayoral Bid, Thompson Hopes Old Ties Attract Jewish Votes
abstract: William C. Thompson Jr., who is running in a primary race without a major Jewish rival, is long known and liked by many Orthodox leaders in New York City.
lead_paragraph: William C. Thompson Jr. knows not to initiate a handshake with an Orthodox Jewish woman. He sprinkles Yiddish phrases into his conversations with observant Jews. He is familiar enough with the rituals that, on a recent Friday visit to a home in Midwood, Brooklyn, he commiserated with a woman about the work involved in preparing for the Sabbath.

headline: Internal Documents Portray BBC as Top-Heavy, Bickering and Dysfunctional
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Some 3,000 pages released Friday paint a picture of a top-heavy organization weighed down by mistrust, poor communication, buck-passing and squabbling.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A senior press officer for the British Broadcasting Corporation darkly volunteers to “drip poison” to discredit a BBC reporter he suspects of having leaked embarrassing information. The woman in charge of the corporation’s news divisions accuses Newsnight, a public-affairs program she oversees, of being out of touch and “sneery” toward rival BBC shows.

headline: As a Fired Coach Reels, So Do Fans in Buffalo
abstract: Lindy Ruff spent half of his life working for the Buffalo Sabres, as a player for 10 years and a coach for 16. His firing was not unexpected, but his dismissal has left fans, and Ruff, numb.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — The day after he was fired as coach of the Buffalo Sabres, the team he led for 16 years, Lindy Ruff drove around the suburbs here, going from doughnut shop to doughnut shop, trying to sort out his feelings. At home, he wore shorts that bore the Sabres logo. He tried to watch on television as Buffalo played the Toronto Maple Leafs, but he could not go through with it.

headline: A Video of Fighting 7-Year-Olds Leads to 2 Arrests
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Assaults', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Authorities charged two teenage girls with endangering the welfare of a child by forcing two 7-year-olds to fight in a Bronx park, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The two little girls — one in a white winter coat and pink pants, the other in a puffy black jacket and fuchsia boots — approach each other tentatively in a New York City park. They stand almost chest-to-chest, encircled by a group of clamorous teenagers who begin to goad them into fighting.

headline: A Proposal for a Propane Tank Looms Large Over a Maine Coastal Town
abstract: Supporters say the tank will bring much-needed jobs and boost the local economy; detractors warn it will be dangerous, blight the coastline, lower property values and drive away tourists.
lead_paragraph: SEARSPORT, Me. — In the winter of 2007, thousands of homes and businesses in rural Maine almost lost their heat because of a severe propane shortage.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Feb. 23, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Feb. 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “This is really, really serious for our nation. It’s serious for our economy. It’s affecting people’s lives. It’s time for Congress and the administration to sit down and work together to find a common path, but I’m worried that they may not.”

headline: Local Stop: NoMad
abstract: NoMad, a new name for the area north of Madison Square, seems perpetually in transition.
lead_paragraph: NoMad, a new name for the area north of Madison Square, seems perpetually in transition.

headline: Where the V.F.W. Is Both Tough and Feminine
abstract: Post 12097 in Buffalo, with a membership of 24 women and 8 men, is said to be the only current V.F.W. post that was specifically created for women in the military.
lead_paragraph: TONAWANDA, N.Y. — Members of the Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 12097 began a recent meeting in this Buffalo suburb as those at many of the organization’s 7,000 posts do — with a whirl of conversation, a recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance and a prayer.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Just the Place to Wander
abstract: The area now known as NoMad, or North of Madison Square, is tightly nestled among many neighborhoods and offers reasons to make you stop and stare.
lead_paragraph: NoMad, a new name for an old part of town, refers to the area north of Madison Square, the park once bordered by Stanford White’s enormous entertainment complex, Madison Square Garden. True to its name, the neighborhood seems perpetually in transition, with vestiges of its turn-of-the-century affluence butting against colorful wholesale and import shops; recently it has seen a patchy resurgence as a fashionable tourist haven.

headline: Valentine Will Add Athletic Director to His Résumé
abstract: Bobby Valentine, the former Red Sox manager, will join Sacred Heart University as the athletic director.
lead_paragraph: In October, standing next to the Yankee Stadium infield before one of his last games as manager of the Boston Red Sox, Bobby Valentine was asked what he would do next if he were fired when the season ended.

headline: Part of an Equitable Trade
abstract: Todd Gross rings us up.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Mesmerizing grid, isn’t it? And fairly tough, as a Saturday puzzle should be.

headline: Corrections: February 23, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Scope of a Search Warrant
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Editorials', 'Police']
abstract: The Supreme Court sensibly rules against letting officers detain someone no longer in the immediate vicinity of searched premises.
lead_paragraph: A 1981 Supreme Court decision allows police officers who have a warrant to search a home and “to detain the occupants of the premises while a proper search is conducted,” even if the officers do not have a warrant to hold the people. This week, in a 6-to-3 decision, the court sensibly ruled against allowing officers to detain a person who is no longer in the immediate vicinity of the place being searched.

headline: The Rebel at the Velvet Rope
abstract: Steve Sands, whom some consider New York’s most notorious paparazzo, has been going to celebrity affairs to document what he sees as abuse from security and the police.
lead_paragraph: On a midweek evening this month, the photographer Steve Sands went where he should not have: to the Ziegfeld Theater, in Midtown Manhattan, for a gala screening of the new Beyoncé documentary, “Life Is but a Dream.” Mr. Sands, who is sometimes called New York’s most notorious paparazzo, had been barred from the event by HBO but showed up nonetheless.

headline: U.N. Rejects Claim for Direct Compensation to Victims of Cholera Epidemic in Haiti
abstract: The organization’s lawyers cited diplomatic immunity against the claim, which is based on a theory that peacekeeping troops set off the disease.
lead_paragraph: There will be no direct financial compensation from the United Nations for the more than 8,000 Haitians who died and the 646,000 sickened by cholera since the disease struck the earthquake-ravaged country in October 2010, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon told the Haitian president this week.

headline: Dire Consequences and Denial
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There are two fundamentally different perspectives on a budget solution. Only one is supported by a majority of Americans.
lead_paragraph: It’s crunch time.

headline: Obama’s Backers Seek Big Donors to Press Agenda
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: President Obama’s political team is attempting to raise $50 million to convert his re-election campaign into a powerhouse lobbying group for his second-term goals.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s political team is fanning out across the country in pursuit of an ambitious goal: raising $50 million to convert his re-election campaign into a powerhouse national advocacy network, a sum that would rank the new group as one of Washington’s biggest lobbying operations.

headline: Ice Skating, Xbox and Lots of Cooking
abstract: Fatima Shama, commissioner of immigrant affairs in New York City, spends her Sundays with her husband and their three sons.
lead_paragraph: The daughter of a Brazilian Catholic mother and a Palestinian Muslim father, Fatima Shama, 39, grew up in the Bronx, attending Roman Catholic school during the week, Muslim “Sunday school” on Saturdays and church on Sundays. She speaks six languages, which comes in handy for her job as the commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs, a position she has held since 2009. (Recently, her office reached out to immigrant communities affected by Hurricane Sandy to help them navigate government resources and aid.) She lives in Turtle Bay in Manhattan with her husband, Ziad Mansouri, 42, who works at JPMorgan Chase, and their three sons, Samir, 8; Ibrahim, 5; and Omar, 2. She and her husband are raising them as Muslims, with a generous dose of other religious traditions.

headline: Japan and United States Reaffirm Their Close Ties
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: President Obama and Japan’s new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, met at the White House on Friday to discuss their mutual interests in curbing North Korea’s nuclear ambitions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Japan’s new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, met at the White House on Friday to show that their countries were putting relations back on solid footing after several years of friction, and at a time when the allies face the challenge of an increasingly powerful China.

headline: A Chance to Right a Wrong in Haiti
abstract: Evidence shows that the United Nations inadvertently started a cholera outbreak that has since killed 8,000 people. It has a moral obligation to help end the crisis.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON

headline: Rats That Won’t Stay Put
abstract: Hurricane Sandy may have sent rats scurrying, but no subspecies on the move has yet been dubbed Relo-Rat.
lead_paragraph: Of all the New Yorkers who have coexisted with the city’s enduring population of rats, few have had the upper hand like John James Audubon, who retired in the middle of the 19th century to a patch of uptown wilderness at what is now West 156th Street. He soon was shooting rats and painting them in a lively family tableau.

headline: Barkley Emerges as Face of Unpredictable Group
abstract: Matt Barkley of Southern California stands as a symbol of this year’s quarterback class that follows last year’s stars, like Andrew Luck and Robert Griffin III.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The shirt read 1 QB, an oddity because Matt Barkley, the Southern California quarterback who wore it at the N.F.L. scouting combine on Friday, was viewed once as a top quarterback prospect.

headline: Sunni Leader Arrested Over Sectarian Attacks in Pakistan
abstract: The Pakistani police detained the leader of a banned Sunni extremist group that had claimed responsibility for two bombings that killed nearly 200 people in the past six weeks.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — The Pakistani police on Friday detained the leader of a banned Sunni extremist group that had claimed responsibility for two sectarian bombings that killed nearly 200 people in the past six weeks.

headline: Fear of U.S. Cuts Grows in States Where Aid Flows
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Medicaid', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: State officials fear that the budget impasse in Washington will saddle them with spending cuts that threaten to slow their recoveries or thrust them back into recession.
lead_paragraph: States are increasingly alarmed that they could become collateral damage in Washington’s latest fiscal battle, fearing that the impasse could saddle them with across-the-board spending cuts that threaten to slow their fragile recoveries or thrust them back into recession.

headline: This War Is No Longer Invisible
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: An Oscar-nominated documentary shortchanges the military’s serious response to rape.
lead_paragraph: “The Invisible War,” a feature-length documentary about sexual assault in the military, is up for an Oscar Sunday night. Directed by Kirby Dick and produced by Amy Ziering, it is a searing, infuriating, unforgettable film.

headline: In a Slight Shift, North Korea Widens Internet Access, but Just for Visitors
abstract: The government will allow a company called Koryolink to give foreigners access to 3G mobile Internet service by next Friday.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — North Korea will finally allow Internet searches on mobile devices. But if you’re a North Korean, you’re out of luck — only foreigners will get this privilege.

headline: Raptors Finish Stronger, and Knicks Stay on Skid
abstract: The Knicks held a lead midway through the fourth period but lost their fourth straight game and fifth in their last six.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Coach Mike Woodson and the Knicks walked the walk of sorrow in the final seconds of their game with the Toronto Raptors on Friday night.

headline: Russians Demand Return of Brother of Adopted Boy Who Died in Texas
abstract: Russian lawmakers adopted a resolution calling for the return of the 2-year-old boy, whose brother, adopted by the same family, died in January in Texas.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian lawmakers on Friday demanded the return of a 2-year-old boy whose 3-year-old brother, adopted by the same family in Texas, died under murky circumstances in January, prompting allegations of abuse and an investigation.

headline: Nets Try to Plug Leaks, but a Burst by the Rockets Hands Them a Loss
abstract: The Rockets outlasted the Nets, who were without Joe Johnson, in a game that was a sprint all the way to the end.
lead_paragraph: Nets Coach P. J. Carlesimo so respected the Rockets’ James Harden and Jeremy Lin that before Friday’s game, he compared trying to stop them to the fable of the Little Dutch Boy. As the story goes, the boy discovered a leak in a dike and used his finger to plug the hole. In Carlesimo’s analogy, his Nets were the boy, and the Rockets were the unrelenting North Sea.

headline: Tunisia: Party Names Premier Candidate
abstract: The Islamist party that leads Tunisia’s constituent assembly nominated Ali Laarayedh, a former political prisoner, as the new prime minister.
lead_paragraph: The Islamist party that leads Tunisia’s constituent assembly nominated Ali Laarayedh, a former political prisoner who now runs the ministry overseeing the police, as the new prime minister. The assassination this month of a leftist opposition leader set off protests against the Islamist-led government. Many blamed the governing party, Ennahda, for failing to prevent the killing, in part by failing to crack down on more hard-line Islamist groups. In response, Prime Minister  Hamadi Jebali of Ennahda called for the replacement of the coalition government with a cabinet of technocrats. He resigned when his party overruled him. Some Tunisians fault Mr. Laarayedh, the interior minister, for failing to protect the assassinated opposition leader, Chokri Belaid, or to apprehend his killers. Mr. Laarayehd endured more than a decade of imprisonment and torture under Tunisia’s former dictator. He is considered among the least conservative members of his party, which is less conservative than most other Islamist parties in the region. President Moncef Marzouki has asked him to form a cabinet. It must be submitted for final approval by the constituent assembly, where the Islamists hold a plurality but not the majority of the seats.

headline: Russia: Foreign Assets Bill Advances
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The lower house of Parliament voted for a bill to bar government officials from holding bank accounts outside of Russia, signaling that the measure may win final approval.
lead_paragraph: The lower house of Parliament on Friday voted overwhelmingly for a bill to bar government officials from holding bank accounts or stocks outside of Russia, signaling that the measure is likely to win final approval. The vote, the first of three required to send the bill to the upper chamber, was 443 to 0. The bill was proposed by President Vladimir V. Putin, and supporters say it will help combat corruption. Critics say that the measure contains numerous loopholes and that rather than preventing officials from owning foreign assets, it will simply promote efforts to hide them. Efforts to regulate or scrutinize the assets of Russian officials have led to the resignations of several lawmakers, including a member of the majority party United Russia who had not disclosed that he owned an apartment worth nearly $1.3 million in Miami.

headline: Nascar Innovation Could Speed Drying of Racetracks
abstract: A system called the Air Titan could reduce the time it takes to dry a rain-soaked track, like the Daytona International Speedway,  to a half-hour from two and a half hours.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — The forecast for Daytona Beach, Fla., this weekend calls for partly sunny skies with a possibility of scattered storms. That means the Daytona 500, Nascar’s premier event, could be delayed again.

headline: Victory, Then Defeat
abstract: Corinne Narassiguin, a New Yorker who won election to the French National Assembly eight months ago, must step down because she and two other candidates violated French campaign-finance law.
lead_paragraph: France’s National Assembly saw the arrival of a longtime New Yorker to its floor just eight months ago. Now, it’s seeing her departure.

headline: Drone Pilots Are Found to Get Stress Disorders Much as Those in Combat Do
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Research', 'Pilots', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A study has shown that pilots of drone aircraft experience mental health problems much like those of pilots who are deployed to war.
lead_paragraph: In the first study of its kind, researchers with the Defense Department have found that pilots of drone aircraft experience mental health problems like depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress at the same rate as pilots of manned aircraft who are deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan.

headline: Picturing Life in Public Housing
abstract: A photographer from Lisbon was shocked by the conditions in which people were living, in the South Bronx, on the Lower East Side and in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: A photographer from Lisbon was shocked by the conditions in which people were living, in the South Bronx, on the Lower East Side and in Harlem.

headline: The Other Half, Considered Anew
keywords: ['Photography', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mold']
abstract: Ana Brigida has chronicled unattended repairs, mold and other poor conditions at buildings owned by the New York City Housing Authority in the South Bronx, the Lower East Side and Harlem.
lead_paragraph: THE WALLS LOOKED as if they were eating themselves, or decomposing like old film. Mildew invaded bathrooms, mold blossomed along ceilings, and children were masked with nebulizers to fend off asthma’s ills. The photographer Ana Brigida had seen similar decay in the old homes of Lisbon, where she is based. But she did not expect to find them in New York City. “I was more surprised,” said Ms. Brigida, who is 26. “You have these glamorous ideas of New York.”

headline: Sedatives and Pranks Preceded Australia’s Olympic Flop
abstract: James Magnussen and other Australian swimmers admitted to taking a banned prescription drug in London and engaging in behavior they described as “childish.”
lead_paragraph: There are the scandals caused by doping, and then there are the ones caused by dopes.

headline: Vonn Says Race Conditions Led to Her Injury
abstract: Lindsey Vonn, recovering from knee surgery, said landing in  loose snow during the super-G event in Schladming, Austria, caused her knee to buckle.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Vonn said that her surgically rebuilt right knee was recovering and that she expected to defend her Olympic downhill title in a year. But in her first public comments since her tumbling crash on Feb. 5, she also said that dangerous race conditions caused her injury.

headline: Rex Scouten, an Overseer of Presidential Households, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Scouten, a former Secret Service agent, served commanders in chief from Harry S. Truman to Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Rex Scouten, a former household staff director at the White House and onetime Secret Service agent who worked for 10 presidents, from Harry S. Truman to Bill Clinton, and never accepted any of the offers he received to publish a memoir about his 50 years in the service of presidential privacy, died on Wednesday in Fairfax, Va. He was 88.

headline: Born to Wait
abstract: In some New York neighborhoods, children not getting into activities, classes, sports teams and local schools has become a way of life.
lead_paragraph: The first parent lined up at 4 a.m. on a Sunday, when the only other people around were out just long enough to stumble from warm taxis through sobering 19-degree air into their homes.

headline: Magic Slim, Blues Singer and Guitarist Who Blazed Onstage, Dies at 75
abstract: Magic Slim, who moved to Chicago from Mississippi, was known for his intense live performances.
lead_paragraph: Magic Slim, a singer and guitarist acclaimed as a keeper of the flame of electrified Chicago blues, died on Thursday in Philadelphia. He was 75.

headline: Martin Could Heat Up Knicks, or Spontaneously Combust
abstract: The Knicks need Kenyon Martin’s rebounding, defense and passion. But Martin, a veteran forward, has also been known to alienate those around him with his words.
lead_paragraph: In their last turn as teammates, Jason Kidd and Kenyon Martin achieved the impossible, turning the Nets into an N.B.A. force, bringing life to the dreary Meadowlands and basketball artistry to East Rutherford, N.J. Kidd flung the lobs, Martin slammed them home and for a time the Nets soared over the Eastern Conference.

headline: Teacher, Juggler, Unicyclist
keywords: ['Circuses', 'Theater', 'ACROBATS AND ACROBATICS', 'Juggling and Jugglers', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Decades ago, Hovey Burgess, 72, ran away with the circus, and in a sense he has never left; he now teaches aspiring performers the skills of a clown at the Tisch School of the Arts.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years ago, when Hovey Burgess was an adolescent looking to run away with the circus for a year, a friend warned him, “You can’t just join for a year because it gets in your blood and you won’t be able to leave.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 23
abstract: Bank’s downfall in Italy; European growth stumbles; more horse meat fallout, and David Lynch branches out.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Since the days of the Medici family in Florence, the banking house of Monte dei Paschi has rained wealth on the people of Siena, Italy. For 541 years, it has endured war, plague and panic, and it stands today as the world’s oldest operating bank. But inside the stately offices of Monte dei Paschi di Siena, a thoroughly modern fiasco has done what the centuries could not. Monte dei Paschi, founded in 1472, has been brought to its knees by 21st-century finance. Jack Ewing and Gaia Pianigiani report from Siena.

headline: Once Only an Enforcer, Clarkson Has Battled to Become a Scorer
abstract: David Clarkson has stepped up to fill the hole left by Zach Parise to lead the Devils in overall goals and power-play goals this season.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The $98 million question facing the Devils at the start of the season involved how they would replace Zach Parise’s abundant offense after he signed a 13-year contract for that amount to join the Minnesota Wild as a free agent.

headline: Debating the Semantics of ‘Rape’
abstract: Two proposals in the New York State Legislature would redefine certain sex crimes, but some prosecutors worry that well-meaning changes might make their work harder.
lead_paragraph: “Makers: Women Who Make America,” an expansive, multipart documentary beginning Tuesday on PBS that chronicles the modern feminist movement, illustrates, among other things, how much of the ethos of the 1950s still coursed through the system in the decades that followed. It was not simply a pervasive distrust of female ability that lingered — and would, of course, carry on — but a more insidious rank dismissal of basic cognition: the belief, for instance, that a woman could not be considered a reliable narrator of the sexual violence that she had endured.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Because of Purim, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.
lead_paragraph: Because of Purim, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Candidates at a Forum All Support Mass Transit
abstract: Seven likely mayoral candidates met to discuss the city’s transportation at a forum at the City University of New York.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, recalled her grandfather’s work as a trolley car driver. William C. Thompson Jr., the former city comptroller, cited his long history as an A train rider. And in a moment perhaps unique to New York City, Bill de Blasio, the city’s public advocate, drew cheers when he said that he had spent much of his life without owning a car.

headline: No Plans to Retire, Coughlin Says
abstract: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin made it clear that he is not close to calling it a career in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Giants Coach Tom Coughlin bounced up the steps to the podium for his news conference at the N.F.L. combine, probably the first clue that the shuffleboard circuit is not in his immediate plans. One of his players, Terrell Thomas, had suggested that the 2013 season would be Coughlin’s last, and that he would retire after it.

headline: Blackhawks’ Hot Start Stretches Into a Record Streak
abstract: The Chicago Blackhawks notched their 17th straight game with a point in a win over the San Jose Sharks.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For the first 16 games this year, the Blackhawks found themselves on the right side of the bounces and breaks, smiled upon by the hockey gods, and without a loss in regulation. Chicago’s 13-0-3 run had put the team on the brink of N.H.L. history Friday night: with a win, they would set the league record for consecutive games with a point to open a season.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC) DREAMGIRLS (2006) Three Detroit singers, portrayed, above from left, by Anika Noni Rose, Beyoncé Knowles and Jennifer Hudson, discover the price of fame in Bill Condon’s adaptation of the Broadway musical of the same title. Jamie Foxx plays the musical entrepreneur who trades in Effie White (Ms. Hudson, in her Oscar-winning role), the lead singer of the Dreamettes, for her thinner, lighter-skinned sidekick, Deena Jones (Ms. Knowles). Eddie Murphy won an Oscar nomination for his turn as James (Thunder) Early, a soul man loosely based on James Brown. The film’s dramatic and musical peak — “the showstopper, the main reason to see the movie” — comes midpoint when Ms. Hudson sings “And I Am Telling You I’m Not Going,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “That song has been this musical’s calling card since the first Broadway production 25 years ago, but to see Ms. Hudson tear into it on screen nonetheless brings the goose-bumped thrill of witnessing something new, even historic.” Nevertheless, he wrote, “the music has the effect of compromising one of the crucial ambitions of the film: to refract the recent history of black America (and, by implication, America itself) through the prism of popular culture.”

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, chief of the moderate faction of Hurriyat Conference, a coalition of separatist groups in Kashmir, was allowed to return to the Kashmir Valley after being placed under house arrest in Delhi following the Feb. 9 execution of Muhammad Afzal, the militant convicted of conspiracy in the 2001 attack on the Indian Parliament, Kashmir Live reported. “The Mirwaiz was scheduled to visit the family of Afzal Guru after chairing a meeting of Hurriyat, but the government has imposed curbs on all his activities,” the report said.

headline: Chinese City Reports Second Bird Flu Fatality
abstract: A 31-year-old man who had contracted the deadly H5N1 bird flu died of organ failure in the south-central Chinese city of Guiyang.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China has reported a second fatality from the deadly H5N1 bird flu, a 31-year-old man who died of organ failure in the south-central Chinese city of Guiyang.

headline: More on Those Punks and Slobs
abstract: Has punk and sex-shop leather aged out, or just become part of the mainstream?
lead_paragraph: I bolted out of the Versace show on Friday night, about two steps behind Anna Wintour and her two bodyguards, who clearly were prepared for the squall of girls waiting in the street. The girls gave chase, cameras raised, but Ms. Wintour was more experienced in these matters. She kept her head down and hurried on to her hotel.

headline: ‘This City Is Cursed’
abstract: Residents of Hyderabad speak out after recent explosions.
lead_paragraph: Srinivas Mahesh, 28, was snacking outside his hostel near the Konark Theater in Dilsukhnagar, his usual hangout in Hyderabad, when he heard a loud explosion Thursday evening. Not long after, he saw smoke filling up the air. Once he realized it was a bomb blast, instead of rushing back to his hostel he resolved to helping the injured.

headline: The Weekend Word: One-of-a-Kind
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, a look at the president’s weekly address and the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: When Living Hand to Mouth Becomes a Career
abstract: Laura Williams, parts model, graces this week’s cover, her first of a national magazine.

headline: Ava Smith Transforms Backstage at Etro
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury and hair by Eugene Souleiman.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper434 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: The Gun Report: February 23, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Here is today’s sampling of gun violence in America. We will return on Monday with the weekend report.

headline: Sandberg, Feminism and the Politics of Class

headline: You Asked. Carnival Answered. (Sort Of.)
abstract: Stephanie Rosenbloom asks Carnival why the Triumph passengers weren’t evacuated and other questions from our readers.
lead_paragraph: 5:18 p.m. | Updated More than a week after I first asked about the capacity of the lifeboats on board the Triumph, Carnival told me that the ship had 24 lifeboats, 2 rescue boats, and 74 life rafts (primarily intended to accommodate crew) for a total lifesaving capacity of 6,670. Had the company decided to evacuate the ship, there would have been enough room for all the passengers.

keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'AQUIFERS', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Drought', 'Global Warming', 'International Relations', 'Irrigation', 'Water']

lead_paragraph: Jay Famiglietti, one of the authors of an important new study on the rapid depletion of aquifers under the Tigris and Euphrates river basins, has posted an excellent overview of the work and its context for policy, and noted that he and other authors are preparing for a two-week “water diplomacy” tour to discuss their findings in the affected region.

Meanwhile, however — and partly for my own reference — I discovered that I can do a similar exercise over a somewhat longer time horizon, which I’m posting in large part as a note to myself.

headline: Little Statesmen and Philosophers
abstract: Hobgoblins all around.
lead_paragraph: So, people want me to comment on the Moody’s downgrade of Britain. No real news there. As a guide to the future, ratings agency judgments are literally worse than useless; remember, US bond yields actually fell after the 2011 S&P downgrade. Still, it’s kind of a poke in the eye for Cameron/Osborne, who are subjecting their country to pointless austerity because confidence!

headline: Ice Fishermen Not Immune to Doping’s Reach
abstract: With an eye on an Olympic berth, competitors at the World Ice Fishing Championship had to submit to the same examinations as world-class sprinters and weight lifters.
lead_paragraph: With an eye on an Olympic berth, competitors at the World Ice Fishing Championship had to submit to the same examinations as world-class sprinters and weight lifters.

headline: Dope Tests in Ice Fishing? No, Beer Doesn’t Count
abstract: With an eye on an Olympic berth, competitors at the World Ice Fishing Championship had to submit to the same examinations as world-class sprinters and weight lifters.
lead_paragraph: WAUSAU, Wis. — The ice fishermen spent a week on the frozen lake, and on the last day, after emptying perch and bluegill from their buckets and scrubbing bait from their hands, several winners of the World Ice Fishing Championship were ushered into their rooms in the Plaza Hotel.

headline: Variety: An Explosive Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon blow us away.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I got a BIG BANG out of today’s acrostic, not only because it was an interesting way to learn how the phrase the “Big Bang” came into the lexicon, but because I can always be bought with food, and if no food is present, humor.

headline: Ozzie Sweet, Who Helped Define New Era of Photography, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Sweet was a photographic illustrator known for his use of fierce hues that emulated the emergent Technicolor palate of American movies, and helped define — visually, anyway — an era.
lead_paragraph: At the end of World War II, Ozzie Sweet’s picture of a friend posed as a German soldier surrendering appeared on the cover of Newsweek — “the magazine of news significance,” as it billed itself then. Not a stratagem that would pass muster in contemporary journalism, but Mr. Sweet, who had apprenticed to the Mount Rushmore sculptor Gutzon Borglum, appeared in a Cecil B. DeMille film and helped create promotional ads for the United States Army, found the art in photography to be in creating an image, not capturing one.

headline: When Moms (and First Ladies) Dance
abstract: Michelle Obama’s appearance with the talk show host Jimmy Fallon was an effort “to encourage parents everywhere to get up and get moving with their kids.”
lead_paragraph: The first lady, Michelle Obama, won rave reviews on Saturday for her dancing.

headline: French Intervention in Mali Raises Threat of Domestic Terrorism, Judge Says
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Some French citizens of black African ancestry have become more willing to fight under the banner of jihad, according to France’s most prominent investigative judge dealing with terrorism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French military intervention in Mali has increased the threat of domestic terrorism, with some French citizens of black African ancestry becoming more willing to fight under the banner of jihad, according to France’s most prominent investigative judge dealing with terrorism.

headline: A Tent City for Fun and Profit
abstract: At Duke, where crazy is cool and basketball is king, some administrators, faculty and students are asking if big-time sports is a big waste of time and energy.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Duke is an elite private university where the buildings are pretend Gothic, where tuition is $42,000 a year, and where hundreds of students eagerly and voluntarily spent five wintry weeks camping in the famed tent city known as Krzyzewskiville for one simple reason: to get a good seat for the basketball game against archrival North Carolina.

headline: Ahead of Trial, Talk of a BP Settlement in 2010 Oil Spill
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: With a major civil trial scheduled to start Monday against BP, federal officials and the five affected Gulf Coast states are trying to pull together to strike an 11th-hour settlement.
lead_paragraph: With a major civil trial scheduled to start Monday in New Orleans against BP over damages related to the explosion of an offshore drilling rig in 2010, federal officials and those from the five affected Gulf Coast states are trying to pull together to strike an 11th-hour settlement in the case.

headline: Scandals and Intrigue Heat Up at Vatican Ahead of Papal Conclave
abstract: The Vatican called recent speculative reports alleging scandal in the Church “deplorable” as cardinals from around the world arrived for a conclave to elect a new pope.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — As cardinals from around the world begin arriving in Rome for a conclave to elect a successor to Pope Benedict XVI, new shadows have fallen over the delicate transition, which the Vatican fears might influence the vote and with it the direction of the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Pompom Girl for Feminism
abstract: Feminism 4.0? Sheryl Sandberg launches a book tour designed to make her the Betty Friedan of the digital age.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON
