lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Emory University’s Leader Reopens Its Racial Wounds
abstract: An article by James W. Wagner praising the 1787 three-fifths compromise has been seized upon as another example of insensitivity from the school.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A reception on Friday at Emory University to celebrate the work of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in the years after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. could have been more poorly timed, but not by much.

headline: In the Wake of Emancipation
abstract: Even after Lincoln’s action, for men and women still in slavery things could get worse before they got better.
lead_paragraph: For many enslaved people, 1863 began not with freedom but with profound uncertainty. The legal and practical effects of the Emancipation Proclamation were a matter of dispute among white critics and observers, as they have been among historians for 150 years. If the proclamation applied only to areas under Confederate control, did it really free anyone right away? What, if anything, did it mean for border states and Union-occupied territory? For slaves who got their news in rumors, the proclamation’s details could seem especially unclear. As late as the summer of 1864, an enslaved woman in Maryland, Annie Davis, wrote to Lincoln himself for clarification: “Mr president,” she asked, “please let me know if we are free.”

headline: Model Diary | Liu Wen
abstract: The 25-year-old, seen Saturday on the runway at Robert Cavalli, shares a few of her favorite things.
lead_paragraph: Liu Wen feels like she lives from airplane to airplane, constantly traveling for work for the past five years. So this season, she’s making sure to take it easy and enjoy herself a little in each city. Saturday, the 25-year-old jet-setting model is in Milan, where she walked in Roberto Cavalli’s show in the morning. Sunday, she’ll walk in Dolce & Gabbana.

headline: In Italy, Illusion Is the Only Reality
keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Whether Silvio Berlusconi wins or loses, the country is determined to ignore uncomfortable truths.
lead_paragraph: IT takes a certain talent to live in happy denial, to slide toward the edge of a precipice and be perfectly relaxed about it. Of all the talents that Italians are renowned for, such nonchalance is perhaps their greatest. Their economy is in deep recession; more than one in three young adults are unemployed; they are unable to compete economically with their neighbors; yet they continue as if nothing were happening, or as if a small glitch in the dolce vita could be fixed with the wave of a wand.

headline: The Snowman
abstract: Jeremy Jones made his name in snowboarding by riding steep lines from helicopters. Now he’s reinvigorating the sport by climbing and riding mountains on his split-board.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Jones made his name in snowboarding by riding steep lines from helicopters. Now he’s reinvigorating the sport by climbing and riding mountains on his split-board.

headline: A Soft-Spoken Snowboarder Blazes Icy Trails
abstract: Jeremy Jones’s unconventional methods have allowed him to access mountains previously considered untouchable.
lead_paragraph: TRUCKEE, Calif. — The snowboarder Jeremy Jones arrived at the Atomfjella Mountains on Svalbard, an island above the Arctic Circle, after 30 hours of tundra crossing on a rattling snowmobile convoy in April 2011. He had invited Terje Haakonsen, known in the snowboarding world for his ability to ride almost anything, any style, to attempt the summit and first descent of a set of precipitously icy couloirs.

headline: Angry and Disillusioned, Italians Prepare to Vote
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: As Italian voters head to the polls on Sunday and Monday to elect the Parliament and three regional governments, the mood is one of anger and disillusionment.
lead_paragraph: ROME — As Italian voters head to the polls on Sunday and Monday to elect a new Parliament and three regional governments, the prevailing mood is one of anger and disillusionment.

headline: Chances Are Extra Work in Off-Season Involves Baseball, Not a Second Job
abstract: The Mets’ Collin McHugh has a winter job with an Atlanta fund-raising company, but what used to be common, like Stan Musial selling Christmas trees, is now a rarity.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Collin McHugh, a 25-year-old right-handed pitcher, achieved a lifelong goal last year when he was called up to the Mets.

headline: Notable Names Drinking Whiskey and Eating Carbs
abstract: J.J. Abrams, Octavia Spencer and others turned out for parties piggybacking on this Oscar moment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The convergence of so many stars makes Oscar weekend a magnet for all kinds of charities and causes hoping to piggyback.

headline: The Price of Public Violence
abstract: What is the effect on individuals — especially kids — who have been privy to the violence in our cities’ streets?
lead_paragraph: EVERY year, the Chicago Police Department issues a report with the macabre title “Chicago Murder Analysis.” It’s a short but eye-opening document. Do the calculations and you realize that in the past 15 years, 8,083 people have been killed, most of them in a concentrated part of the city. There’s one particularly startling revelation that gets little notice: in 2011, more than four-fifths of all murders happened in a public place, a park, an alleyway, on the street, in a restaurant or at a gas station.

headline: Yankees’ 1913 Season Was Sunk by a Rogue Captain
abstract: After the New York Highlanders were renamed the Yankees, sailing south to train in Bermuda for the first time, their season collapsed, mostly because of the wily ways of Hal Chase.
lead_paragraph: Setting sail a century ago from Pier 42 on the East River for spring training in Bermuda, the Yankees faced the 1913 season with considerable optimism.

headline: New York Builds Momentum in Sports
keywords: ['Stadiums and Arenas', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'New York City Marathon', 'Super Bowl', 'Athletics and Sports', 'ALL STAR GAMES', 'Basketball', 'Baseball', 'Football']
abstract: In the next few years, the metropolitan area will host a slew of marquee events, like All-Star Games and the first cold-weather Super Bowl. That is because of several new arenas and stadiums being built.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers like to think they live in the center of the universe, and when it comes to finance, theater, advertising and other areas, they may be right. But when it comes to sports, the argument is shakier. Sure, the Yankees are perennial contenders and the Giants, among others, have at times risen to the top. But for all the money in New York, many of its teams fail to grab the national stage.

headline: Congress Set to Consider Tighter Rules on Firearms
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'School Shootings', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: Congress will begin to consider legislation this week that is likely to include expanded background checks for gun buyers and increased penalties for those who purchase guns for criminals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of sometimes wrenching debate over gun safety, Congress will begin to consider legislation this week that is likely to include expanded background checks for gun buyers and increased penalties for those who purchase guns for criminals.

headline: Rays’ Price Is Realistic About His Worth and His Future
abstract: David Price expects his next contract to pay him the going rate for an elite pitcher, which makes it unlikely he will get that deal with Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — David Price was shooting a commercial for a home-security company at his house in Tampa on Feb. 7 when his brother, Damon, called. Price ignored him once, then twice. With the third call, he finally picked up. He figured it must be important.

headline: In Men’s Basketball, Scoring Suffers in Physical Game
abstract: To the coaches and players, scoring has become more difficult because the defense is too physical, coaches are choking the creativity out of offense, and players’ critical skills are deficient.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The basketball was so agonizing to watch that one coach buried his head in his hands, another dropped his head in dismay and fans shook their heads in disgust. Clemson shooters sailed balls past the rim, and Georgia Tech fans ridiculed them with chants of “air ball, air ball.” When a Tech player missed everything, the handful of Clemson fans bounced the barb right back: “air ball, air ball.”

headline: Coming to a Track (and Showroom) Near You
abstract: Auto manufacturers and Nascar teams made a multimillion-dollar investment to build racecars that look more like those at dealerships, in an attempt to connect with consumers.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Richard Petty competed in Nascar from 1958 to 1992, long enough to have won seven championships while driving dozens of racecar models. So he could not help chuckling when asked about the name of the racecar being introduced this season in the Sprint Cup series.

headline: Drew LeBlanc’s Comeback Lifts St. Cloud State Hockey
abstract: Drew LeBlanc, who broke his left leg in a gruesome injury in late 2011, led the nation in assists for the eighth-ranked Huskies.
lead_paragraph: ST. CLOUD, Minn. — The St. Cloud State hockey players and coaches who were there grimly recount the gruesome details of Nov. 5, 2011, the night when Drew LeBlanc, the team captain, broke his left leg.

headline: Primed for Controversy
abstract: Because relatively few replication studies appear in academic literature, it is difficult to know why several seemingly comparable experiments yield conflicting results.
lead_paragraph: IN 2005, the writer Malcolm Gladwell introduced readers to the phenomenon of “thinking without thinking” — the mental work we all do automatically — in his blockbuster book “Blink.”

headline: North Korea Threatens U.S. Over Joint Military Drill
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: North Korea warned that if the United States pressed ahead with joint military exercises with South Korea it could set off a war in which American forces would “meet a miserable destruction.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Saturday warned the top American military commander in South Korea that if the United States pressed ahead with joint military exercises with South Korea scheduled to begin next month, it could set off a war in which American forces would “meet a miserable destruction.”

headline: Emory University’s President Faces Criticism
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Slavery', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Students at Emory University protested for the removal of the school’s president, James W. Wagner, saying that a column he wrote — as well as recent sweeping budget cuts — both revealed Emory’s bias against minority students.
lead_paragraph: Students at Emory University protested for the removal of the school’s president, James W. Wagner, saying that a column he wrote — as well as recent sweeping budget cuts — both revealed Emory’s bias against minority students.

headline: Do Warriors Have a Secret Weapon Up Their Sleeves?
abstract: Wearing the unusual uniforms, Golden State won for the first time in 17 games with the Spurs, but the outfits attracted some derision.
lead_paragraph: Having lost 16 consecutive games to the San Antonio Spurs entering Friday’s contest, the Golden State Warriors would probably have tried anything to get a win. It turned out, all they needed were sleeves.

headline: Who Has the Guts for Gluten?
abstract: The prevalence of celiac disease has soared in the United States. Breast-feeding infants, while introducing small amounts of gluten, may help protect against it.
lead_paragraph: WE know that the proteins called gluten, found in wheat and other grains, provoke celiac disease. And we know how to treat the illness: a gluten-free diet. But the rapidly increasing prevalence of celiac disease, which has quadrupled in the United States in just 50 years, is still mystifying.

headline: Help for Veterans Twice Betrayed
abstract: New legislation seeks to undo the injustices faced by many service members who are sexually assaulted in the military.
lead_paragraph: This month, Representative Chellie Pingree, Democrat of Maine, and Senator Jon Tester, Democrat of Montana, introduced a bill that would make it easier for veterans to receive benefits for disabilities linked to sexual assault in the military. The bill is named for Ruth Moore, a Navy veteran who has been outspoken about what she calls her double betrayal.

headline: The Nuclear Agenda
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama needs to fulfill his promise and lead the way toward reducing arsenals around the world.
lead_paragraph: President Obama set an ambitious goal in his first term when he endorsed the vision of an eventual world without nuclear weapons. After some early achievements, namely the New Start treaty mandating cuts in deployed strategic weapons, the effort stalled for two years until he picked up the theme again in the State of the Union address this month. Now he needs to follow through with a more sustained commitment.

headline: Canadiens’ Renaissance Keeps Its Edge
abstract: Thursday’s overtime loss to the Islanders ended Montreal’s five-game winning streak, but the Canadiens entered the weekend tied for the lead in the N.H.L.’s Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Tuesday’s 3-1 victory against the Rangers vaulted the Canadiens into first place in the Eastern Conference, Montreal commuters waiting for the No. 107 bus were greeted by the words “BRAVO Canadiens” on the display where the route number usually appears.

headline: The Next Frontier Is Inside Your Brain
abstract: A sweeping new scientific initiative could help us understand dreams, memories and the very nature of consciousness.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is planning a multiyear research effort to produce an “activity map” that would show in unprecedented detail the workings of the human brain, the most complex organ in the body. It is a breathtaking goal at a time when Washington, hobbled by partisan gridlock and deficit worries, seems unable to launch any major new programs.

headline: Refugee Influx Threatens Balance in Lebanon
abstract: Many in Lebanon worry that the influx of up to 400,000 Syrian refugees, who are mostly Sunni, may disrupt the delicate balance in the country. Lebanon fought its own sectarian civil war from 1975 to 1990.
lead_paragraph: Many in Lebanon worry that the influx of up to 400,000 Syrian refugees, who are mostly Sunni, may disrupt the delicate balance in the country. Lebanon fought its own sectarian civil war from 1975 to 1990.

headline: A Mind of Their Own, and the Freedom to Speak It
abstract: Columnists get a loud microphone and wide latitude on the New York Times Op-Ed page.
lead_paragraph: SEVERAL years ago, the columnist Paul Krugman veered from his usual practice of writing about the economy and began writing columns about the war in Iraq.

headline: How Mexico Got Back in the Game
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Who knew our North American neighbor might one day become an economic rival to India and China?
lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico

headline: Stranger Than Fiction on the Cop Beat
abstract: The real world of crime was sadder, deeper and more absurd that I had expected.
lead_paragraph: In the late ’80s, I became the news clerk in The Miami Herald’s Fort Lauderdale bureau. I answered the phones, composed obits and even reviewed a Barry Manilow concert — that is, after every other single reporter on the paper declined.

headline: A World Without Work
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Food Stamps', 'Medicare', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Our jobless future may be more sustainable than we imagine.
lead_paragraph: IMAGINE, as 19th-century utopians often did, a society rich enough that fewer and fewer people need to work — a society where leisure becomes universally accessible, where part-time jobs replace the regimented workweek, and where living standards keep rising even though more people have left the work force altogether.

headline: Claire Chiang
abstract: The chairwoman of the Singapore Zoo and co-founder of Banyan Tree Hotels on using television as currency in negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Claire Chiang is chairwoman of the Singapore Zoo, considered among the world’s best because of its vast natural habitat exhibits. The daughter of Chinese migrants, Ms. Chiang is also co-founder and senior vice president of Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts, which has 40 luxury properties on 5 continents. She previously served as a member of Singapore’s Parliament as well as on the board of the country’s male-dominated Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

headline: Violent, Drunk and Holding a Gun
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Assaults', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Editorials', 'Series']
abstract: Focusing on mass murder and the mentally ill does not get at the broader issue of gun violence.
lead_paragraph: Multiple mass shootings by deranged young men have made keeping firearms out of the hands of mentally ill people a big part of the gun debate.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Future of Medicare
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers weigh in on problems with the health care program.
lead_paragraph: Readers weigh in on problems with the health care program.

headline: Tips for Public Speaking
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Public Speaking', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Focus on one person in the middle of the crowd throughout your speech. Afterward, trail him home.
lead_paragraph: Nearly everyone gets some anxiety about public speaking — even Oscar-winning actors. Here are some tips to help you through a big speech:

headline: Tennis: Love-Love
abstract: If I had to articulate the ethos, it would be something like: Play hard, try not to lose, but if you do, hey, it’s just a game.
lead_paragraph: Bounce, bounce, bounce. It’s four-all, 40-30, and I’m serving. I toss the ball high and in the act of reaching up I over-adjust my swing and hit it long. Fool. One more chance to redeem myself, to succeed, to set in motion, at the very least, an opportunity to win the point, the game, the set. Who knows what heights remain to be scaled, what triumphs lie in wait?

headline: Ultimate Sport
abstract: Ultimate Frisbee was founded in the heyday of hippiedom; leave it to a bunch of weirdos to invent the perfect game.
lead_paragraph: Founded in the late 1960s, in the heyday of hippiedom, ultimate Frisbee is often associated with pot smoking and people who don’t like rules. In college, ultimate is relegated to “club status,” the stepchild of athletic departments.

headline: Solitaire: Me vs. Me
abstract: It’s the writer’s game. You’re taking random elements and trying to put them together in a pleasing way, to make order out of chaos.
lead_paragraph: When friends tell me that they are trying to give up smoking, I suggest they take up solitaire. As a reward for having completed a task, as a mini-holiday from everyday stress, as a means of improving one’s mood without a doctor’s prescription, the game offers many of the same benefits as cigarettes, only it’s cheaper and doesn’t have the harmful effects of tar and nicotine. When I gave up smoking, it wasn’t because I’d replaced it with the pleasures with solitaire. It’s more that the pleasures of solitaire remind me of what I used to like about smoking.

headline: Poker Is America
abstract: Poker dealers and players can give lessons to the rest of the country about making the melting pot work.
lead_paragraph: Let’s start by getting this straight: poker is about money. If you took the money out of it, I wouldn’t play. But even when I lose, I’ve had a good time. I love playing poker as an escape from the world I usually live in, and I especially love playing at Hollywood Casino in Charles Town, W.Va., where you can find me about two afternoons a week.

headline: Weighing In on Sensor Size
abstract: My post about the relationship between sensor size and soft-focus background drew about 100 comments from people trying to make sense of a complex topic.
lead_paragraph: Wow. My post on Thursday about the relationship between sensor size and soft-focus background certainly lived up to its opening premise: “photographers online are a cantankerous lot. Photography, in the end, is something of a black art, and everybody’s got an opinion.”

headline: Ping-Pong: Head Game
abstract: The art of table tennis, Japanese-style.
lead_paragraph: A gold-toothed man of 76 polishes his $300 paddle. The tall, elegant gentleman who is used to overseeing maquiladoras in Tijuana silently pulls three-star balls out of a box. Mrs. Fukuoka, 80 next month, flicks shots into the corner at such cunning angles that she wins every other point. “I’m never tired,” she giggles, hiding her smile behind her bat, “because I never move.” At another of the eight championship tables, a bald guy and a grandmother exchange low forehand topspins with such relentless intensity they attain a rhythm that’s almost sexual.

headline: Ahead of Election in Cyprus, Gloom and Voter Apathy Tied to Financial Woes
abstract: Both candidates in the presidential race have promised to abide by a bailout deal that is widely seen as an unavoidable path to harsh austerity and recession.
lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — Evagoras Georgiou will go to the polling station at the Tsireio middle school in the St. John neighborhood here for Sunday’s presidential election. But he will leave his ballot blank, voting for neither of the two candidates in the runoff for Cyprus’s most powerful political office.

headline: The Invisible War: An Update
abstract: Some good news for a military rape survivor.
lead_paragraph: My column today, about rape in the military, centers on “The invisible War,” which features servicemen and women sharing brutal tales of sexual assault perpetrated by their colleagues and superiors. One of these victims, Kori Cioca, was a Coast Guard seaman when she was smacked across the face by her attacker with such force that it dislocated her jaw, relegating her to years of pain, unable to eat anything but soft foods like Jell-O and mashed potatoes. During the course of filming she tries to get the VA to pay for her treatment, but is ultimately denied.

headline: Lin Does a Lot by Not Doing Too Much
abstract: Jeremy Lin has been a solid, not exceptional, contributor for the Rockets with  12.8 points and 6.2 assists a game through Friday.
lead_paragraph: When the Houston Rockets outbid the Knicks for Jeremy Lin’s services in the off-season, Carmelo Anthony called Houston’s offer ridiculous. Lin had played well in his 25 starts, but the $25.1 million offer seemed outrageous to Anthony and many others.

headline: Don’t Call Him Mom, or an Imbecile
keywords: ['Men and Boys', 'Parenting', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: The hapless, bumbling father is a stock character in product marketing. The so-called daddy bloggers who attended the recent Dad 2.0 Summit are pushing to change that.
lead_paragraph: THE hapless, bumbling father is a stock character in product marketing. He makes breakfast for dinner and is incapable of handling, or sometimes even noticing, a soggy diaper. He tries desperately to hide the crumb-strewn, dirt-streaked evidence of his poor parenting before the mother gets home.

headline: Patrick Drawing Crowds Before the Engines Start
abstract: The buzz about Danica Patrick’s pole in Sunday’s season-opening Daytona 500 has overshadowed just about everything else this year.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — The window to the Nascar garage at Daytona International Speedway through which fans watch Danica Patrick’s crew work on her racecar is covered with marker messages.

headline: Seen as Nature Lovers’ Paradise, Utah Struggles With Air Quality
abstract: Topographic and meteorological factors combine to trap auto emissions and other air pollutants in the region, a problem with no easy solution.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Utah has long been known as an outdoor lover’s utopia. The skiing and mountain biking are among the best anywhere. And the snow-clotted mountains that tower around Salt Lake give this city a mythic quality during winter.

headline: How the Bagger Is Voting (Down to the Animated Shorts)
abstract: The Bagger shares her picks in every race, including the hard-to-call ones like original screenplay and animated short.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Can we begin with a caveat? This year’s ever-shifting race, with its wealth of good movies, has some really tight contests, like best original screenplay. Though Mark Boal (“Zero Dark Thirty”) won the Writers Guild Award in the same category, the consensus here seems to have shifted since we wrote about the race this week and now favors Quentin Tarantino, for “Django Unchained,” with a passionate faction going for Michael Haneke and “Amour.” So mark that one on your ballot at your own risk.

headline: As Cuts Loom, Governors Seek More Control of Federal Funds to Lessen the Pain
abstract: Governors of both parties pleaded with President Obama and Congress to give them more discretion over the use of federal money so they could minimize the pain for their citizens.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Governors of both parties said on Saturday that they knew federal budget cuts were coming, and they pleaded with President Obama and Congress to give them more discretion over the use of federal money so they could minimize the pain for their citizens.

headline: Reeva Steenkamp, Steve Biko and the Quest for Justice in South Africa
abstract: The hearing before Pretoria’s chief magistrate in the last weeks of 1977, like the one featuring Oscar Pistorius this week, centered on a killing that captured global attention.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The title of the presiding judge 35 years ago was the same, chief magistrate of Pretoria, and the venue for the hearing, a converted synagogue, was not far from the modern courthouse seen on television screens around the world in recent days as Oscar Pistorius, the gold medal-winning Paralympic athlete, fought for bail in the killing of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.

headline: Hard Budget Realities as Agencies Prepare to Detail Reductions
abstract: By the end of this week, federal agencies will notify governors, private contractors and other stakeholders of the dollars they would be about to lose if across-the-board budget cuts go into effect.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the first week of March, a laid-off person living on $300 a week in unemployment benefits is liable to find a surprise in the mailbox: notification from Uncle Sam that come April the check will be $33 lighter.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Dell’s Intentions Get a Hard Look
abstract: Outside shareholders who support an independent analysis of the company’s value are wary of dealings by Michael Dell that may take the business private.
lead_paragraph: IS Michael Dell trying to take over the computer company he founded on the cheap?

headline: Shifting Hats and Working in Small Teams
abstract: Lily Kanter, co-founder and chief executive of Serena & Lily, a home décor company, says she assigns no more than four employees for a project to drive innovation.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Lily Kanter, co-founder and chief executive of Serena & Lily, a home décor company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 24
abstract: Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood, Education Secretary Arne Duncan and a host of governors join the Sunday programs to talk about the looming across-the-board budget cuts.
lead_paragraph: With the federal government warning that the across-the-board budget cuts scheduled to take effect Friday could cause air travel delays and other problems, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood will join NBC’s “Meet the Press” on Sunday.

headline: Overcoming Obstacles to Better Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Malpractice', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Medicine and Health', 'Doctors']
abstract: Transforming the American health care system could include offering safe harbor from malpractice suits for doctors who demonstrate high-quality care.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS spend far more on health care than people in other countries and we have little to show for it. And as we live longer after retirement, the share that will be paid by the government will rise.

headline: An Average Traveler
abstract: Stephen Kaufer, the chief executive of TripAdvisor, developed his company after a frustrating search for hotel advice online.
lead_paragraph: I WAS born in Hollywood, Calif. — truly a shocking notion if you know how unstruck I am by stars.

headline: Where the Cuts Will Fall
abstract: Beginning March 1, automatic spending cuts were set to hit, trimming $85 billion from the 2013 fiscal year budget and even more from each annual budget for the next decade. Some areas will be hit harder than others, as many programs are exempt from the cuts.
lead_paragraph: Beginning March 1, automatic spending cuts were set to hit, trimming $85 billion from the 2013 fiscal year budget and even more from each annual budget for the next decade. Some areas will be hit harder than others, as many programs are exempt from the cuts.

headline: Ozzie Sweet, Photographer, 1918-2013
abstract: Mr. Sweet, whose work often appeared on the covers of Sport magazine, was less interested in capturing images than in creating them.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Sweet, whose work often appeared on the covers of Sport magazine, was less interested in capturing images than in creating them.

headline: How Offices Become Complaint Departments
abstract: Experts in workplace psychology say that some of the inevitable complaining by employees is helpful, even necessary, but that it can also become toxic.
lead_paragraph: THERE is the ideal life, and then there is life as it really exists. We have various ways of expressing discontent over this inevitable gap, and one of the most common is complaining.

headline: Buddhists, Reconstructing Sacred Tibetan Murals, Wield Their Brushes in Nepal
abstract: A project aimed at restoring the artwork of two sites in Lo Manthang, Nepal, has trained a team of local residents to revise historic works.
lead_paragraph: LO MANTHANG, Nepal — Dozens of painters sat atop scaffolding that soared toward the roof of an ancient monastery. With a swipe of their brushes, colors appeared that gave life to the Buddha. Gold for the skin. Black for the eyes. Orange for the robes.

headline: Calling Out the Robocaller
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Telemarketing', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit Cards', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Account Management Assistance offers to reduce credit card interest rates, but satisfied customers are scarce.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, the Haggler was sitting at home when the phone rang.

headline: Third Teenager Is Arrested Over Forced Fight Between 7-Year-Olds
abstract: A 14-year-old girl was charged with endangering the welfare of a child after a video of two girls being goaded into fighting in a Bronx park was posted online.
lead_paragraph: The police have made a third arrest in a case involving a group of teenagers goading two 7-year-old girls to hit each other in a Bronx park. A video of the fight was widely viewed after being posted to YouTube and other Web sites.

headline: Investors Rediscover Risk-Taking Abroad
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: As confidence in the global recovery grows, foreign investors who have long sought a safer place to put their money appear to be accepting more risk.
lead_paragraph: RISK-TAKING may be staging a comeback overseas.

headline: Last-Lap Crash in Nascar Race Injures Fans
abstract: Dozens of spectators at Daytona International Speedway were injured Saturday when a racecar hit the fence that surrounds the track and debris flew into the stands.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — At least 28 people were injured in a crash at the end of a Nascar race at Daytona International Speedway on Saturday afternoon, bringing the issue of safety at racetracks back to the forefront on the eve of Sunday’s season-opening showcase, the Daytona 500.

headline: I Surrender!
abstract: Giving up on backing down with Joe DiPietro.

headline: There Is an Algorithm for Everything, Even Bras
abstract: After a frustrating two-and-a-half-hour fitting room ordeal, Michelle Lam helped launch a company to match women with bras online.
lead_paragraph: THE two and a half miserable hours that Michelle Lam spent in a fitting room, trying on bras, one fine summer day in 2011 would turn out to be, in her words, a “life-changing experience.” After trying on 20 bras to find one that fit, and not particularly well at that, she left the store feeling naked and intruded upon.

headline: SimCity, for Real: Measuring an Untidy Metropolis
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Urban Areas', 'Sensors', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: An initiative at New York University is joining a global drive to apply modern sensor, computing and data-sifting technologies to urban environments.
lead_paragraph: THE notion of a “science of cities” seems contradictory. Science is a realm of grand theory and precise measurement, while cities are messy agglomerations of people and human foible. But science is precisely the ambition of New York University’s Center for Urban Science and Progress. Founded last year, the center has been getting under way in recent weeks, moving into new office space and firing off its first project proposal to the National Science Foundation.

headline: In-Law Says Spain’s Royal Family Had No Business Role
abstract: A princess’s husband testified in a fraud investigation that neither King Juan Carlos nor others in the household offered him advice about a foundation he ran.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A son-in-law of King Juan Carlos I denied Saturday that his wife and other members of the Spanish royal household had any direct involvement in his past business dealings, which have been at the heart of a fraud investigation that has embarrassed the monarchy.

headline: Veterinarian Squeeze
keywords: ['Veterinary Medicine', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: In the wake of the economic downturn, pet ownership and visits to veterinarians in the United States have declined. Meanwhile, the number of vets entering the work force has been increasing while their average debt load has risen and their starting salaries have fallen.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the economic downturn, pet ownership and visits to veterinarians in the United States have declined. Meanwhile, the number of vets entering the work force has been increasing while their average debt load has risen and their starting salaries have fallen.

headline: High Debt and Falling Demand Trap New Vets
keywords: ['Veterinary Medicine', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Student Loans', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The cost of veterinarian school has far outpaced the rate of inflation. Meanwhile, there is a boom in supply (that is, vets), and a decline in demand for services.
lead_paragraph: HAYLEY SCHAFER chose her dream job at the age of 5. Three years later, her grandmother told her that if she wrote it down, the dream would come true. So she found a piece of blue construction paper and scrawled on it with a pencil: “Veterianian.” “No one told me how to spell it,” she remembers. “They just said, ‘Sound it out.’ ”

headline: A Flood of Vets From the Caribbean
abstract: The Ross University School of Veterinary Medicine, located on the Caribbean island of St. Kitts, graduated 287 students last year, triple the number of many American schools.
lead_paragraph: The Ross University School of Veterinary Medicine, located on the Caribbean island of St. Kitts, graduated 287 students last year, triple the number of many American schools.

headline: Circus Arts, for the Stage
abstract: For nearly 50 years, Hovey Burgess has been teaching circus techniques to acting students at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, Hovey Burgess has been teaching circus techniques to acting students at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.

headline: Major Banks Aid in Payday Loans Banned by States
keywords: ['Payday Loans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Interest Rates', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Banking giants have become behind-the-scenes allies of Internet-based lenders that offer loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.
lead_paragraph: Major banks have quickly become behind-the-scenes allies of Internet-based payday lenders that offer short-term loans with interest rates sometimes exceeding 500 percent.

headline: Witness Accounts and Images of Crash at Daytona
abstract: The end of the Nationwide Series race at Daytona International Speedway in Florida was marred by a wreck that sheared the front from one of the cars and left debris in the stands, injuring spectators.
lead_paragraph: As our colleague Viv Bernstein reports, the end of the Nationwide Series race at Daytona International Speedway in Daytona Beach, Fla., was marred by a wreck that injured dozens of spectators and sheared the front from one of the cars. The impact of the crash was strong, ripping the car driven by Kyle Larson nearly in half and sending debris high into the stands.

headline: Languishing in Lebanon
abstract: Syrian refugees are making do in Lebanon with the help of aid organizations and some municipalities but little support from the Lebanese government.
lead_paragraph: Syrian refugees are making do in Lebanon with the help of aid organizations and some municipalities but little support from the Lebanese government.

headline: Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: As a tide of Syrians flees civil war, their soaring numbers threaten neighboring Lebanon’s precarious balance. And the Lebanese government’s anemic response leaves the refugees scattered and struggling to survive.
lead_paragraph: As a tide of Syrians flees civil war, their soaring numbers threaten neighboring Lebanon’s precarious balance. And the Lebanese government’s anemic response leaves the refugees scattered and struggling to survive.

headline: Swollen With Syrian Refugees, Lebanon Feels Its Stitching Fray
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: An influx of needy Syrians, seeming to fill Lebanon’s every nook and cranny, is heightening sectarian tensions in a nation haunted by refugee crises and loath to act.
lead_paragraph: QAA, Lebanon — Quietly but inexorably, a human tide has crept into Lebanon, Syria’s smallest and most vulnerable neighbor.

headline: Aleksei German, Director of Anti-Soviet Movies, Dies at 74
abstract: In movies like “Trial of the Road” and “My Friend Ivan Lapshin,” Mr. German captured the darkness of the Soviet era and especially Stalin’s rule.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei German, a Russian director known for grim, hypnotic films that captured the darkness of the Soviet era and especially Stalin’s rule, died on Thursday in St. Petersburg. He was 74.

headline: Dolan Deflecting Talk of a Possible Promotion
abstract: Visiting a new synagogue on the Upper West Side, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan made a series of self-deprecating jokes in response the chatter about his papal prospects.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, wearing a black cassock and a large pectoral cross, stood at the center of an Upper West Side synagogue on Saturday, stretched his arms toward the heavens with his palms facing up, and joked to the standing-room-only congregation, “Does this look papal enough?”

headline: Stringer Is Left With No Milestone, Again, and No Answers
abstract: After the Scarlet Knights’ fourth straight loss to St. John’s, Coach C. Vivian Stringer described their performance as “embarrassingly poor.”
lead_paragraph: With three minutes left, C. Vivian Stringer stood in front of her bench, arms folded, and slowly shook her head. After having so many answers during her 42-year, 899-victory coaching career, she seemed as baffled as her Rutgers team.

headline: Princeton Team Wins Title at a Top Amateur Event
abstract: The Princeton A team’s victory at the Amateur Team Championship hinged on a game that pitted Andrew Ng, a freshman, against a 10-year-old from New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The biggest social events of the chess world’s year are the amateur team tournaments held in four American cities over Presidents’ Day weekend.

headline: Big East Settles for Deal With ESPN
abstract: Two years ago, the Big East conference dreamed of television riches. That was before its members began defecting.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the Big East hoped for television riches. Now that dream is over.

headline: Fault-Finding Grows Intense as Cuts Near
abstract: With less than a week before what was once unthinkable — deep across-the-board spending cuts — both the White House and Congress are eager to say sequestration was the other’s idea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — First the White House and Congress created a potential fiscal crisis, agreeing more than a year ago to once-unthinkable governmentwide spending cuts in 2013 unless the two parties agreed to alternative ways to reduce budget deficits.

headline: Samsung’s New 8-Inch Tablet Takes on the iPad Mini
abstract: Samsung Electronics introduced a new 8-inch tablet Saturday, competing directly with Apple’s 7.9-inch iPad Mini. The Galaxy Note 8.0 will go on sale in the second quarter of this year.
lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics is taking yet another swipe at its longtime partner, Apple. The South Korean manufacturer on Saturday introduced a new 8-inch tablet, intended to compete directly with Apple’s 7.9-inch iPad Mini.

headline: Another Chapter in Rivalry Ends With Georgetown Win
abstract: With Syracuse heading to the Atlantic Coast Conference next season, the Orange and Hoyas battled for the last time as Big East rivals in the Carrier Dome.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — There was history on the court, on the sidelines, even in the deepest reaches of the Carrier Dome, where fans stretched out farther to watch basketball than ever before.

headline: Wheeler, Mets’ Top Prospect, Looks in Top Form in Spring Opener
abstract: Zack Wheeler, a 22-year-old right-hander, threw two strong innings in a 5-3 victory against the Washington Nationals.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As much as players and coaches and members of the news media like to play down its importance, the first game of spring training always brings a certain measure of excitement, if only as a sign that meaningful baseball rests on the horizon.

headline: Some See a Move by Cornyn to the Right
abstract: Observers say that John Cornyn, the senior Texas senator, has been burnishing his conservative credentials since Ted Cruz won a Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: After more than a decade representing blood-red Texas in the United States Senate, John Cornyn finds himself in an unusual spot: burnishing his conservative credentials.

headline: Martin Set to Prove to Knicks He Belongs
abstract: At his first interview, the Knicks’ Kenyon Martin acknowledged his fiery temper but spoke of his passion to play.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — About halfway through Kenyon Martin’s first interview session after he signed a 10-day contract with the Knicks, he was asked if he could once again embody the qualities of a warrior on the court.

headline: Church Helps Fill a Void in Africa
abstract: With 16 percent of the world’s Catholics now living in Africa, the church’s future, many say, lies in the continent.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — The young woman slept soundly on the cool marble floor before the altar, a break from the chaos at home. In the courtyard, neighborhood teenagers filled giant jerrycans with purified water from a stone fountain. In an aisle, a rail-thin young woman from a nearby slum said she had not eaten since yesterday but was expecting sustenance here.

headline: Dozens Hurt in Crash
abstract: As many as 28 people were injured in a crash at the end of a Nationwide Series race at Daytona International Speedway.
lead_paragraph: As many as 28 people were injured in a crash at the end of a Nationwide Series race at Daytona International Speedway.

headline: Advocates Seek Mental Health Changes, Including Power to Detain
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Capital Punishment', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The case of a man who killed his family but was not detained for psychiatric treatment he sought beforehand has led to calls for mental health codes in the state of Texas to be changed.
lead_paragraph: SHERMAN — A worried call from his daughter’s boyfriend sent Paul Boren rushing to her apartment on the morning of March 27, 2004. He drove the eight blocks to her apartment, peering into his neighbors’ yards, searching for Andre Thomas, Laura Boren’s estranged husband.

headline: At Scouting Combine, Te’o Faces First Interview Test
abstract: In front of more than 200 reporters and dozens of television cameras, Manti Te’o explained the dark days that had just passed him involving a hoax about a nonexistent girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Manti Te’o did double takes in the grocery store to see if people were staring at him, and it troubled him that his last name had been splashed everywhere. But by Saturday, Te’o said he was no longer embarrassed, or he would not have been able to do what had been anticipated since the story of a bizarre hoax about a nonexistent girlfriend was first revealed more than a month ago.

headline: Cervelli, Back Behind Plate for Yankees, Is Doing His Best to Stay There
abstract: The Yankees’ Francisco Cervelli is determined to win the hotly contested starting catcher’s job after the team sent him down to the minors last season.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — Francisco Cervelli was crushed last season when the Yankees sent him down to catch for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre. After spending most of the previous three seasons in the Bronx, he figured his roster spot was secure. He was wrong.

headline: Sometimes the Things Are Not All Aubusson
abstract: Estate sales can be a mixed bag — one where flashy household goods rub up against richer personal history.
lead_paragraph: I don’t usually respond to e-mail invitations from people I don’t know, but the one from Judy Robinson, who runs one of Houston’s A-list estate sale companies, was hard to resist: “Estate sale from the Houston residence of the late Mildred Yount Manion II, heiress from an important Texas oil family and Kentucky’s famous Spindletop horse farm.”

headline: A Conservative Provocateur, Using a Blowtorch as His Pen
keywords: ['Consultants', 'Campaign Finance', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Michael Goldfarb, a founder of a conservative online magazine called The Washington Free Beacon, has combined journalism, politicking and campaign finance into a potent mix.
lead_paragraph: At 11:42 a.m. on Feb. 14, a conservative online magazine called The Washington Free Beacon posted a dispatch about a speech Chuck Hagel gave in 2007 in which it said he called the State Department “an adjunct to the Israeli foreign minister’s office.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning numbers for Feb. 23, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 24
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 24.
lead_paragraph: “There’s something to be said for stabbing people in the front in a town where everybody goes around all day stabbing each other in the back.”

headline: Mark Dold, Edgar McIntosh
abstract: A stage and television actor and the principal of the Ardsley Middle School in Ardsley, N.Y., are married.
lead_paragraph: Mark H. Dold, the son of Mary L. Dold and Dr. Henry J. Dold of Glenview, Ill., was married Saturday evening to Edgar Joseph McIntosh, a son of Anne M. McIntosh of Amherst, Mass., and the late Robert E. McIntosh. Dr. Dold, who received a one-day solemnization authorization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated at the Red Barn on the campus of Hampshire College in Amherst.

headline: Danielle Rosenthal, Ashley Summer
abstract: The bride is an assistant general counsel for Honeywell International; the groom is a partner in a South Carolina law firm.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Shira Rosenthal and Ashley Boland Summer were married Saturday evening at the Old Courthouse in Cleveland. The Rev. Bob Javorsky, a minister of the Unity Church, officiated with assistance from Cantor Elliot J. Portner.

headline: Stephanie Miranda, James O’Donnell
abstract: The bride and groom graduated from Boston College, where they met.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Miranda and James Maitland O’Donnell were married in New York on Saturday. The Rev. Damian O’Connell performed the ceremony at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: Paula Kweskin and Yoni Weiss
abstract: The couple were married in Israel, where they work.
lead_paragraph: Persistence (and a bluff) pays off.

headline: Priscilla Flores, Harry Dohnert Jr.
abstract: The bride is a brand manager at Heineken; the groom is a sales and marketing manager at an energy supplier.
lead_paragraph: Priscilla Flores and Harry Joseph Dohnert Jr. were married Friday at St. Agnes Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. John M. Knapp, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Robert Wallace and Donald Witkowski
abstract: When the couple met in Sag Harbor, N.Y., in 1998, they said, the chemistry was immediate.
lead_paragraph: The attraction was immediate.

headline: Brad Hoylman and David Sigal
abstract: A career in politics meets one in the arts.
lead_paragraph: Brad Madison Hoylman and David Ivan Sigal were married Friday afternoon at Congregation Beit Simchat Torah in Manhattan. Rabbi Rachel S. Weiss performed the ceremony.

headline: Yoshino Woodard and Cameron White
abstract: The bride is an engineering consultant; the groom is a computer software engineer.
lead_paragraph: Yoshino Nashira Woodard and Cameron Rashod White were married Saturday at Canaan Baptist Church in New Castle, Del. The Rev. Christopher Alan Bullock, a Baptist minister, officiated with the Rev. Rudolph Varica Oliver, also a Baptist minister, assisting.

headline: Eliana Bavli and Samuel Tisch
abstract: The bride works for Google; the groom is studying for an M.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Eliana Yael Bavli, the daughter of Madeline Bavli and Dr. Samuel Bavli of Cedarhurst, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to Samuel Aaron Tisch, a son of Merryl H. Tisch and James S. Tisch of Manhattan. Rabbi Philip Hiat, the groom’s maternal grandfather, is to officiate at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan, with Rabbi Kenneth Hain taking part.

headline: Azmina Jasani and Faheem Madhani
abstract: The couple met at the Manhattan Ismaili Jamatkhana prayer center, where they will have a second ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Azmina Noorallah Jasani and Faheem Karim Amin Madhani were married Friday at Hotel El Convento in San Juan, P.R. The Rev. Cory Casterton, a nondenominational minister who was ordained by the Elim Fellowship, officiated. On Monday, the couple is to have a religious ceremony at the Manhattan Ismaili Jamatkhana, a prayer center where they met in 2009. Mayur Lakhani, a friend of the couple who is affiliated with the center, is to lead it.

headline: As Oscars Fever Builds, Some Chinese Ask: ‘What About Our Films?’
abstract: An annual prediction of Oscars winners by the actress Zhang Ziyi is drawing attention here as Oscars fever grows, and some mourn Chinese films aren’t present. They’re just not good enough, many say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As Oscar fever grows around the world with the 85th Academy Awards set to begin in Los Angeles just hours from now, excitement is building in China, even though it has no films in competition. There is also a sense of frustration here about why China’s movies aren’t nominated for the world’s biggest awards?

headline: Corrections: February 24, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 24, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: For Cream of the Bundesliga, a Week to Savor
abstract: Bayern Munich, Borussia Dortmund and Schalke continued the Bundesliga’s great run in this year’s Champions League.
lead_paragraph: “We didn’t think it would be so easy,” was the resonant battle cry that seemed to strike the tone of German soccer so perfectly last week after a resounding display from each of its three participants after the initial leg of the first knock-out round of this season’s UEFA Champions League.

headline: Making a Statement With Wool
abstract: Boiled and double-faced wool is big this season with designers, as seen in Bottega Veneta’s latest collection at Milan Fashion Week, while Jil Sander’s fall collection was all about control.
lead_paragraph: For his latest Bottega Veneta collection, the creative director Tomas Maier primarily used wool. He said he was interested in “the attitude of wool and the various ways it can be considered.” This meant various treatments like boiling and washing and, as if wool were not stiff enough, bonding it to another material. Some flannels were washed so many times that I thought an off-white dress smeared with a red collage of fabric bits might be muslin. But it wasn’t.

headline: In Last Sunday Address, Pope Says He Will Continue to Serve God
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI says he will continue to serve and love the church by praying and meditating after his abdication on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — In his last Sunday blessing before he retires, Pope Benedict XVI reassured Catholics that he was not abandoning them but would continue to serve the church even in his retirement.

abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: French Tax Proposal Zeroes In on Web Giants’ Data Harvest
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy']
abstract: Google and Facebook know that John Doe “likes” wine, is shopping for a Volkswagen and often e-mails Jane Doe. Soon, in France, they might have to pay for gathering that information.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Only a few weeks after the French Constitutional Council rejected one new tax idea — a 75 percent levy on annual incomes of more than 1 million euros ($1.3 million) — another began percolating through the halls of the finance ministry here: a proposal to tax the collection of personal data on the Internet.

headline: Opera for an Era When Money Is Tight
abstract: The Kammeroper has come roaring back this season with five new productions. In straitened times, “La Bohème” is a natural. But how to explain the turnaround? All it takes is seven singers.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA—Not long ago it looked as if cuts in arts funding would sound the death knell of the Vienna Chamber Opera, known in German as the Kammeroper, an ensemble esteemed for its chamber-scale productions in an intimate, inviting setting. The Austrian federal government’s decision to eliminate entirely its support, which constituted half of the company’s governmental subsidies (the other half coming from the city) effectively put the Kammeroper out of business.

headline: Debt, Spreads, and Mysterious Omissions
abstract: The euro makes all the difference.
lead_paragraph: Binyamin Applebaum reports on a new paper by Greenlaw et al alleging that bad things will happen to America, because debt over 80 percent of GDP leads to high interest rates, and is skeptical – but not skeptical enough. I found the paper amazing, and not in a good way.

headline: A Birth Mother With the Right Regrets
abstract: The birth-mother script tells us not to regret giving up our children, but my adoptee friends tell me that the regrets I do feel are what they want to hear.
lead_paragraph: My mother looked shocked and said, “I can’t raise this baby for you,” but I was ready with my reply.

headline: Sasha Luss Transforms Backstage at Moschino
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Sam McKnight.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper390 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: At the Spirit Awards, Love for ‘Silver Linings’ and, Well, Spirits
abstract: “Silver Linings Playbook,” a film with a Hollywood pedigree, cleaned up at the Independent Spirit Awards.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — A debut feature made by a neophyte director with a nonprofessional cast was overlooked in favor of a film with Hollywood names and a budget that was $20 million higher as “Beasts of the Southern Wild” lost several times over to “Silver Linings Playbook” at the Film Independent Spirit Awards here on Saturday.

headline: Palestinians Dispute Israel’s Findings on a Prisoner’s Death
abstract: Israeli authorities said the 30-year-old prisoner died of a heart attack, but Palestinian officials said he was tortured during his interrogation in an Israeli jail.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Health Ministry said Sunday night that preliminary autopsy findings could not determine the cause of death of a 30-year-old Palestinian prisoner, which Israeli officials had at first attributed to a heart attack. But Palestinian officials said the lack of heart damage coupled with bruising on the man’s chest, back and neck suggested that he was tortured during interrogation.

headline: Euro Delusions
abstract: Looking for vindication in all the wrong places.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been browsing through the collected speeches of Olli Rehn, the vice-president of the European Commission, who has emerged as the face of denialism when it comes to the effects of austerity. What I wanted to do is pinpoint what, exactly, he and those who share his position see as the evidence that their view is right. And I think it’s two things.

headline: Disruptions: Data Without Context Tells a Misleading Story
abstract: According to Google Flu Trends, at the flu season’s peak in mid-January, nearly 11 percent of the United States population had influenza — double the official federal estimates.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Google, aware of how many of us were sneezing and coughing, created a fancy equation on its Web site to figure out just how many people had influenza. The math works like this: people’s location + flu-related search queries on Google + some really smart algorithms = the number of people with the flu in the United States.

headline: In Artist’s Game Show, the Prize Is a Passport
abstract: Erika Harrsch of Queens envisions a borderless continent with an installation that tries to put participants into the position of the millions of people who try to leave their countries every year.
lead_paragraph: In a quiet museum in a placid Connecticut community, Lee Walther, 72, is shrieking. She clasps her hands in an Oscar-winning pose, then throws them wildly toward the air. She’s just discovered that she’s won a passport from the United States of North America, which will allow her to travel anywhere in the world.

headline: Feliciano Sidelined While Doctors Determine Heart Issue
abstract: The Mets’ Pedro Feliciano will be sidelined for two weeks while doctors determine the cause of some irregularity in his heart, General Manager Sandy Alderson said.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Pedro Feliciano will be sidelined for two weeks while doctors determine the cause of some irregularity in his heart, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson said Sunday.

headline: ‘Framework’ Announced for Peace in Congo
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The plan calls for greater cooperation between Congo’s neighbors — some of which are accused of supporting rebel groups — and political changes by its government.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Leaders of several African countries and United Nations officials on Sunday announced a new “framework” to tackle instability in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a war-torn country that has become synonymous with suffering and has eluded countless attempts to build a lasting peace over the years.

headline: Mozilla Builds an Operating System for a Firefox Smartphone
abstract: Mozilla, which created the Firefox browser, is coming out with a smartphone that costs less than one-fifth the price of an iPhone that is aimed at the developing world.
lead_paragraph: Apple and Google are getting a nonprofit competitor, which aims to swamp them by using Web-based technologies that act like smartphone apps.

headline: A Quiet Oscar Weekend at the Box Office
abstract: The No. 1 movie at North American theaters was “Identity Thief,” which continued its remarkable run, taking in about $14 million, for a three-week total of $93.7 million.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES— The Academy Awards, or “the Super Bowl for women,” as the media industry often refers to it, typically makes for a quiet weekend at the multiplex. This year was no exception, even though both new wide-release films were aimed at men.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 85TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Seth MacFarlane makes his debut as host of this ceremony, broadcast live from the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are predicting that Daniel Day-Lewis will take home the Oscar for his portrayal of Abraham Lincoln in Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln,” which earned 12 nominations, including best direction, picture, screenplay (for Tony Kushner), supporting actor (Tommy Lee Jones) and supporting actress (Sally Field). The best actress category ranges from 9-year-old Quvenzhané Wallis (of Benh Zeitlin’s “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” a debut feature that earned four nominations, including best directing and best picture) to Emmanuelle Riva, (of Michael Haneke’s “Amour,” which received five nods, including best direction, picture and foreign language film) who turns 86 on Sunday. The best picture category is filled out by Ben Affleck’s “Argo,” Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained,” Tom Hooper’s “Les Misérables,” Ang Lee’s “Life of Pi,” David O. Russell’s “Silver Linings Playbook” and Kathryn Bigelow’s “Zero Dark Thirty.” Mr. Lee and Mr. Russell are also nominated for best director. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 5 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Red-carpet coverage (above, the carpet being rolled out) begins at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E!

headline: Governors Issue Warning on Impact of Cuts
abstract: Governors in both parties warned of the potentially damaging consequences across the country if President Obama and Congress do not agree on a plan to avoid across-the-board spending cuts that are scheduled to take effect beginning on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Governors in both parties warned on Sunday of the potentially damaging consequences across the country if President Obama and Congress do not agree on a plan to avoid across-the-board spending cuts that are scheduled to take effect beginning on Friday.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Bruno Magli
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: sparkling stilettos that evoke Cinderella.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Lawmakers Dismiss China’s Denials Over Cyberattacks
abstract: In some of his strongest public remarks about the reported Chinese-sponsored cyber attacks on American companies and government agencies, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said that the situation was “as bad as I’ve ever seen it and exponentially getting worse.”
lead_paragraph: In some of his strongest public remarks yet about the cyberattacks on American companies and government agencies that are believed to have been sponsored by China, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said Sunday that the situation was “as bad as I’ve ever seen it and exponentially getting worse.”

headline: A Complex Role for Medicare in the Standoff in Washington
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A slowdown in health care costs and moderation in Republicans’ public stance may complicate President Obama’s effort to deliver a bipartisan compromise on entitlement spending.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In some ways, the partisan standoff over looming budget cuts resembles earlier links in the chain of fiscal battles that began two years ago.

headline: Model Diary | Drake Burnette
abstract: The model is walking in her first season of shows and already making waves in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Fashion week newcomer Drake Burnette is in her first season of shows and already making waves in the industry since opening for Christopher Kane days ago. T gets in on the conversation with the 27-year-old buzzworthy brunette, who was in her first movie just months ago (Larry Clarke’s “Marfa Girl”) and has gigs morning, afternoon and night today in Milan (Fendi, Dolce & Gabbana, and Ferragamo).

headline: Afghanistan Bars Elite U.S. Troops From a Key Province
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Officials cited complaints that Afghans working for American Special Forces had killed and tortured villagers in a strategically important province adjoining Kabul.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government barred elite American forces from operating in a strategic province adjoining Kabul on Sunday, citing complaints that Afghans working for American Special Operations forces had tortured and killed villagers in the area.

headline: Missoni: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: The Daily Do | Pucci
abstract: Emilio Pucci’s free-flowing fringe combined the gypsy bohemian feel of Anita Pallenberg with the cool, sleek modernity of Lou Doillon.
lead_paragraph: Emilio Pucci’s free-flowing fringe combined the gypsy bohemian feel of Anita Pallenberg with the cool, sleek modernity of Lou Doillon.

headline: After M.T.A. Setbacks, No-Swipe Fare Cards Are Still Stuck in the Future
abstract: Despite the rising cost of maintaining the MetroCard system, it is not going anywhere anytime soon, officials concede, because no one is sure what will replace it.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, coins were the currency in New York’s subway and bus system. Tokens carried the next 40 years, until the MetroCard first slid into riders’ wallets in 1993. The next big thing was to be a contactless fare card — no swipe required.

headline: Conservative Is Elected President in Cyprus
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The victor, Nicos Anastasiades, now faces crucial negotiations with international lenders over a bailout for his financially ailing nation.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — The conservative candidate in the Cyprus presidential election won a double-digit victory on Sunday, ahead of crucial negotiations between the financially ailing nation and international lenders over a bailout.

headline: Britain’s Economic Malaise Brought Ratings Downgrade
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: Britain has begun to trail its peers in Europe when it comes to lowering its budget deficit and making it attractive for other countries to buy its exports.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the root of Moody’s decision to downgrade Britain’s credit rating is a crucial economic reality: Britain has begun to trail its peers in Europe — even bailed-out euro zone economies — when it comes to bringing down its budget deficit and making it attractive for foreigners to buy its exports.

headline: An Unforgettable Day for Two Clubs That Had Come So Far
abstract: Swansea City defeated Bradford, 5-0, to win the English League Cup on Sunday, the first major trophy in the team's 100-year history.
lead_paragraph: LONDON

headline: As Wary Fans Return After Crash, Nascar Plans Safety Review
abstract: A review of catch-fence safety is planned after debris from a crash injured fans Saturday at Daytona International Speedway.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — It was Sunday morning and Fran McCabe of Ormond Beach, Fla., was back in her customary seat in Section H a few rows up from the catch-fence along the front stretch at Daytona International Speedway. That is where McCabe and her husband and son sit every year for the Daytona 500.

headline: Chilling View of Authority
abstract: A revival of Verdi’s “Don Carlo” had its moments, but the production at the Met could have been more consistent.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who doubts the old truism that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely should get to the Metropolitan Opera before March 16.

headline: The 100-Year Flood of Stravinsky’s ‘Rite’ Rolls On
abstract: The Philadelphia Orchestra’s performance of “Rite of Spring” at Carnegie Hall had a lot of excitement but little fresh insight.
lead_paragraph: Conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra in Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” on Friday night at Carnegie Hall, Yannick Nézet-Séguin kept the mysterious “Introduction” restrained and elusive to eerie effect. The elegiac melodies played a game of tease with slinky inner voices in the reedy woodwinds. Mr. Nézet-Séguin, in his first season as the orchestra’s music director, strongly emphasized the music’s primordial elements.

headline: He May Have Nothing to Hide, but He’s Always Under Watch
abstract: Ai Weiwei discusses “Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry,” a documentary that looks at his artistic and political activities.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese conceptual artist, sculptor, photographer and filmmaker Ai Weiwei has a company that bears the tongue-in-cheek name Fake Design, but the challenges he faces are all too real. As one of China’s most outspoken political dissidents he has been detained, arrested, beaten and repeatedly harassed and censored while trying to exercise rights supposedly enshrined in China’s constitution.

headline: Broken Arm Sidetracks Granderson Move
abstract: In his first at-bat of the spring, Curtis Granderson was struck by a pitch, temporarily wrecking the Yankees’ plan to move him to left field.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees were already trying to gird themselves for a season without a ton of power in their lineup, and then Curtis Granderson stepped into the batter’s box to face the Toronto Blue Jays’ J. A. Happ on Sunday.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: San Francisco Symphony’s Oboist Collapses During Performance
abstract: The musician, William Bennett, suffered a brain hemorrhage and was in the hospital in guarded condition, the Symphony said.
lead_paragraph: The principal oboist of the San Francisco Symphony collapsed in mid-performance of Richard Strauss’ oboe concerto Saturday night and was taken by ambulance to the hospital. An orchestra spokesman, Oliver Theil, said the musician, William Bennett, was standing on stage before the orchestra and performing when he passed out. He said Mr. Bennett, 56, suffered a brain hemorrhage and was in the hospital in “guarded condition” on Sunday. The oboist joined the symphony in 1979 and has been principal since 1987.

headline: Drug to Treat Asthma Could Relieve Hives Patients of a Chronic Itch, Study Says
abstract: Monthly injections by the drug Xolair significantly reduced hives and itchiness in patients who participated in a trial whose results were published online by The New England Journal of Medicine.
lead_paragraph: An asthma drug has shown promise in relieving itchiness for patients with chronic hives who do not get relief from traditional antihistamine treatment.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Wet Hair
abstract: In Milan, models’ hair appeared more wet than set, adding an undone element to deceptively skillful looks.
lead_paragraph: In Milan, models’ hair appeared more wet than set, adding an undone element to deceptively skillful looks.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Roberto Cavalli
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.
