headline: In Spring Game, a Glimpse of the Mets’ Future
abstract: Matt Harvey pitched to Travis d’Arnaud for the first time Sunday, and the Mets hope it will be a productive battery for years to come.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — For two innings Sunday at Osceola County Stadium, the Mets could see their future. Matt Harvey pitched to Travis d’Arnaud for the first time. The Mets hope it will be a productive battery for years to come.

headline: One Summer and One Girl Will Define Him Throughout His Lifetime
abstract: Stuart Nadler’s “Wise Men” follows a father and son on Cape Cod and their complicated relationship.
lead_paragraph: The title, setting and central romance of Stuart Nadler’s “Wise Men” are whoppingly bland. The novel is about two men, a father and son, whose surname is Wise. Its main setting is a pokey but fabulous seaside compound on Cape Cod. And at first it seems to be about That Summer, the time when a shy boy develops a hopeless crush on some unattainable woman and seems unlikely ever to get over her. Lots of gooey romances fit this description.

headline: Riffing on Prokofiev and Downsizing Schumann
abstract: The Argento Chamber Ensemble performed the United States premieres of works by Georg Friedrich Haas and Aureliano Cattaneo, and Schumann’s Third Symphony for chamber.
lead_paragraph: The Argento New Music Project took a circuitous route from the recent past to the near future at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music on Saturday evening, plunging deep into history along the way.

headline: Is That All There Is? And How. But That’s Plenty.
abstract: In “Give Me Fever: The Many Voices of Peggy Lee,” part of the Lyrics & Lyricists series, Billy Stritch and four female vocalists pay tribute to that sultry singer-songwriter.
lead_paragraph: Because a vocal signature is as distinct as a fingerprint, there is a crucial difference between shows that pay tribute to a singer and those that salute a songwriter. Unless the performer is a skilled impersonator, what you hear are distant echoes of a voice that only call attention to the absence of the musician being remembered. In the case of a songwriter the material speaks for itself.

headline: Clearheaded Again, Oldest Oriole Is Back
abstract: Brian Roberts is battling back from a barrage of injuries, including a debilitating concussion that forced him to miss the playoffs after he endured 11 losing seasons as an Oriole.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla.

headline: Twirling and Leaping, Before and After
abstract: In the series Stripped/Dressed the choreographer Doug Varone lets audience members in on the production aspect of putting on a show like “Mouth Above Water.”
lead_paragraph: Do you like your dances down and dirty or cleaned up with lights and costumes? In Stripped/Dressed the choreographer Doug Varone has created a series in which audiences are shown two sides of a production: the first half reveals inspirations behind a dance, while the second half showcases the piece itself.

headline: Dolan Offers Role Model for Choosing Next Pope
abstract: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, who will travel to Rome on Tuesday to begin the process of helping to select the successor to Pope Benedict XVI, says he has a simple, albeit perhaps tough, selection criterion: he wants the next pope to be like Jesus.
lead_paragraph: Some cardinals have a list of qualities they want in the next pope: an eager evangelist, master communicator, and deft administrator, with an ear for languages and a heart for the developing world.

headline: A JPMorgan Deal Maker Is Returning to the Law
abstract: James Woolery, co-head of North American mergers and acquisitions at JPMorgan Chase, will join the Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft firm as deputy chairman. That will leave Chris Ventresca as sole head of the JPMorgan unit.
lead_paragraph: 8:32 a.m. | Updated with memoOne of JPMorgan Chase’s most senior deal makers is heading back to the practice of law.

headline: It’s Her Day, but His Victory
abstract: Jimmie Johnson won his second Daytona 500, racing past the defending Nascar champion Brad Keselowski on the final restart, and Danica Patrick finished eighth.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — A day after a horrific crash took the focus away from racing and threatened to turn Nascar’s season-opening showcase, the Daytona 500, into an afterthought, Danica Patrick did what she does best. She put the focus right back on her.

headline: 11th Slava Memorial Cup in Moscow
abstract: The tournament is named in memory of Slava Grinuk, a promising Russian player who died of cancer at the age of 28 in 1999.
lead_paragraph: The 11th Slava Memorial Cup concluded in Moscow on Sunday. The tournament is named in memory of Slava Grinuk, a promising Russian player who died of cancer at the age of 28 in 1999.

headline: The Forgotten Emancipationists
abstract: Recent popular history has overlooked the critical role of abolitionists in ending slavery.
lead_paragraph: On the 150th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation, discussion over who freed the slaves, fueled by movies like “Lincoln,” have become commonplace. While historians have debated the relative roles of Abraham Lincoln and the slaves themselves in the coming of emancipation, few have paid attention to the abolitionists, the forgotten emancipationists in the story of black freedom.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Marni
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: An Oratorio of History With History of Its Own
abstract: Wynton Marsalis conducted a powerful and slightly streamlined version of a piece that once felt challengingly long and heavy.
lead_paragraph: By the time of Wynton Marsalis’s 1994 oratorio, “Blood on the Fields,” written for three singers and a 15-piece band, his scale for musical structure and organizational planning was big and getting bigger.

headline: Songs of Childhood With an Undertow of Fear
abstract: The Czech mezzo-soprano Magdalena Kozena, accompanied by the pianist Yefim Bronfman, brought her dusky sound to songs by Ravel, Rachmaninoff, Bartok and Mussorgsky.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening the mezzo-soprano Magdalena Kozena and the pianist Yefim Bronfman presented an elusive and poetic program of songs at Carnegie Hall. Their selections of works by Mussorgsky, Rachmaninoff, Ravel and Bartok brought to light absorbing facets of these composers and their relation to language. It was a sensitive and often unsettling performance that forced the audience to listen closely.

headline: The Next Cinematic ‘Annie’ Is Not an Unknown
abstract: Quvenzhané Wallis, the 9-year-old Oscar-nominated actress, has been cast in the title role of a new film adaptation of the musical “Annie,” Sony Pictures Entertainment announced on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Quvenzhané Wallis, the 9-year-old Oscar-nominated actress, has been cast in the title role of a new film adaptation of the musical “Annie,” Sony Pictures Entertainment announced on Sunday. Directed by Will Gluck (“Easy A”), the film is scheduled for release during the winter holiday season in 2014. In a statement Hannah Minghella, president of production for Columbia Pictures, said that Ms. Wallis, right, is, “an extraordinary young talent with an amazing range, not only as an actress but as a singer and dancer, and we can’t wait for audiences to further discover her.” Ms. Wallis has earned numerous accolades for her portrayal of Hushpuppy in “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” and is the youngest person ever to be nominated for the best actress Academy Award.

headline: Banksy Work Removed From Miami Auction
abstract: A stenciled work by the British graffiti artist Banksy was withdrawn from auction in Miami on Saturday after residents of a London community lobbied to reclaim it, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: A stenciled work by the British graffiti artist Banksy was withdrawn from auction in Miami on Saturday after residents of a London community lobbied to reclaim it, The Associated Press reported. The mural, “Slave Labor (Bunting Boy),” above, features a young boy using an old-fashioned sewing machine to create Union Jack flags. It appeared last May on a wall outside a discount store in Haringey, a north London borough, but subsequently vanished this month, leaving only a patch of exposed brick. After learning that the work would be auctioned, members of the Haringey Council sent an open letter to Fine Art Auctions Miami requesting that the work be returned. The piece was expected to fetch $500,000 to $700,000, but the auction house removed it from the planned sale without explanation. Claire Kober, who leads the Haringey Council, said the council wants to bring the work back to London.

headline: New Works and Repertory Play to Company Strengths
abstract: The Royal Ballet in London presents world premieres by Christopher Wheeldon and Alexei Ratmansky.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Who can reconcile the contradictions of today’s Royal Ballet? At the end of last week, in a bill of six ballets by the founding choreographer Frederick Ashton (1904-88), the most conservative of mid-20th century theater masters, the dancers looked unaffected, fulfilled and marvelously contemporary. Yet in a program of George Balanchine’s “Apollo” and world premieres by Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon, the two finest choreographers working internationally in ballet today, everybody applied lots of exaggerated facial expressions, as if nobody trusted the movement to speak for itself. I shall return to the Ashton program in a later review. Here I respond to the premieres and “Apollo.”

headline: To Test Some Boundaries, First You Charge Forward, and Then You Back Off
abstract: New York Theater Ballet performed works by Richard Alston, José Limón, Pam Tanowitz, Antony Tudor and Jerome Robbins at Florence Gould Hall on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A choreographer chatting about his work can make for a dull spot in a dance program. But at Florence Gould Hall on Friday, Richard Alston not only spoke illuminatingly about his own choreography, he also gave an accurate endorsement of the troupe performing it, New York Theater Ballet. “I like the company I keep here,” he said, meaning both the unpretentious dancers and the high-class repertory.

headline: Like a He-Man
abstract: Angela Olson Halsted flies solo.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Angela Olson Halsted made her 2011 New York Times debut on the puzzle page in a “bummer” of a collaboration with Doug Peterson (Across Lite, Solution, blog) and if you do the Los Angeles Times crossword, Ms. Halsted might also be familiar to you as PuzzleGirl, the former writer of the L.A. Times Crossword Confidential blog.

headline: A Campaign to Underscore Risk of War Coverage
abstract: An initiative to raise awareness and encourage prosecution of those who target journalists.
lead_paragraph: Friends of journalists who have died covering the violent Arab Spring uprisings are trying to put their grief to good use. They are putting together an online campaign called “A Day Without News?” to persuade the public to pay attention to the sacrifices journalists make.

headline: Top British Cardinal Faces Accusations of Committing ‘Inappropriate Acts’
abstract: Complaints by three priests and one former priest had reached the pope’s diplomatic representative in Britain the week before Pope Benedict XVI announced his resignation, the Observer newspaper reported.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s most senior Roman Catholic cleric, Cardinal Keith O’Brien, has been accused of committing “inappropriate acts” in his relations with three priests and one former priest, the newspaper The Observer reported Sunday. The accusations, which date back to the 1980s, have been forwarded to the Vatican.

headline: Barnes & Noble Weighs Its E-Reader Investment
keywords: ['Barnes & Noble Nook', 'Tablet Computers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: The company’s underperforming Nook Media division might signal that its substantial investment in its digital future has essentially run its course.
lead_paragraph: Even for a company with a lot of bad news lately, the bulletin from Barnes & Noble this month had an ominous feel.

headline: Morsi Moves Election Day in Egypt to Avoid Holiday Conflict
abstract: President Mohamed Morsi changed the dates for the parliamentary elections to avoid conflict with the Coptic Christian celebrations of Palm Sunday and Easter.
lead_paragraph: President Mohamed Morsi on Sunday changed the dates for the parliamentary elections to avoid conflict with the Coptic Christian celebrations of Palm Sunday and Easter on April 28 and May 5. The announcement last week that the elections would begin on April 27 and 28 and continue on May 4 and 5 set off an uproar among Coptic Christians because the overlap with their holidays would have put a special burden on Coptic voters. Mr. Morsi is a Muslim who led the Muslim Brotherhood’s political arm, and the scheduling decision also raised questions about his awareness of the concerns of Coptic Christians, who make up about 10 percent of Egypt’s 85 million residents. Almost any Copt could have told the government that the initial voting plan called for balloting on both holidays. Citing unnamed sources in the president’s office, Egyptian state media said the initial scheduling was an unintentional error and quickly fixed. The elections will now begin on April 22.

abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.

headline: For Stocks, an Upturn Is Battered by Doubts
keywords: ["Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: After looking ready to rocket past milestone levels just a few weeks ago, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is coming out of its first negative week of 2013.
lead_paragraph: The investor euphoria that began the year is beginning to seem like a hazy dream.

headline: A Mismatch Any Fan Could Love
abstract: Swansea beat Bradford City, 5-0, in England’s League Cup final to claim its first major trophy in its centenary year.
lead_paragraph: Rob Hughes writes about Sunday’s League Cup final at Wembley in London, a 5-0 victory by Swansea against fourth-tier Bradford City that was forgettable by competitive standards but unforgettable for supporters of any stripe. Read his article on the final here, and come back to comment.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'States (US)']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Merkel Raises Turks’ Hope Of European Union Entry
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has called for talks between Turkey and the European Union amid signals of decreasing resistance from her center-right party.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany arrived in Turkey on Sunday for talks with Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, holding out hope for new impetus in the stalled negotiations for the country to join the European Union.

headline: Italians Begin to Vote in Two-Day General Election
abstract: Anti-establishment parties are hoping to draw on the widespread anger and skepticism toward Italy’s old guard, but investors and Italy’s European Union partners worry about instability if no clear winner emerges.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italians began voting on Sunday in a two-day general election that is being closely watched by Italy’s European partners as well as investors, who share the concern that unless a clear winner emerges from the voting, a new period of political and market instability lies ahead.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Salvatore Ferragamo
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Riddle of the Human Species
abstract: What has allowed humans to thrive? One factor is the mental growth that began with the meat-eating, hunting and campsites of our evolutionary ancestors.
lead_paragraph: The task of understanding humanity is too important and too daunting to leave to the humanities. Their many branches, from philosophy to law to history and the creative arts, have described the particularities of human nature with genius and exquisite detail, back and forth in endless permutations. But they have not explained why we possess our special nature and not some other out of a vast number of conceivable possibilities. In that sense, the humanities have not accounted for a full understanding of our species’ existence.

headline: Nigeria Abuzz Over Who Paid for Beyoncé Concert
abstract: Increasing anger in Nigeria as President Goodluck Jonathan comes under fire for spending money on public relations and lobbying.
lead_paragraph: Did the Nigerian president, Goodluck Jonathan, divert $1 million from an anti-poverty program to finance a trip to Lagos by American pop stars Beyoncé Knowles and her husband Jay-Z?

headline: Two Precedents Republicans Can Look to
abstract: William F. Buckley and William Jefferson Clinton both moved to counter extreme elements in their movements — successfully.
lead_paragraph: In my Letter From Washington this week, I discuss Karl Rove’s efforts to minimize the role of radical elements in the Republican Party. William F. Buckley and former President Bill Clinton did something similar, to very different groups, decades ago.

headline: On Portugal Beach, Riding a Wave That Hits Like a Quake
abstract: The city of Nazaré is trying to cash in on a moment of fame to promote itself and its now famous beach, Praia do Norte, as a pre-eminent big-wave surfing spot.
lead_paragraph: NAZARÉ, Portugal — The big ones typically come only once a year, in the winter. Whipped up by powerful storms in the North Atlantic, they roll for days toward Europe, rising to seemingly impossible heights before crashing on the shores of Praia do Norte, a beach along the Portuguese coast just north of this picturesque fishing town.

headline: Panel on Health Care Work Force, Lacking a Budget, Is Left Waiting
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Doctors', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Shortages', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: A commission created to investigate the shortage of health care professionals has never met in two and a half years because it has no money from Congress or the administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the biggest threats to the success of President Obama’s health care law comes from shortages of doctors, nurses and other health care professionals. But a 15-member commission created to investigate the problem has never met in two and a half years because it has no money from Congress or the administration.

headline: In Thrifty Times for Publishers, Food Finds Success
abstract: With sales down for both magazines and Walmart, Delish — a magazine available only at the retailer’s stores — is having remarkable success.
lead_paragraph: DEMAND for magazines in retail outlets keeps weakening, and Wal-Mart Stores is worried because shoppers are holding a tight rein on spending. So a new magazine, available only at Walmart, should rank right up there among what Twitter users call #epicfails, yes?

headline: In Spring Escape, Mets Try to Catch Something Other Than Baseballs
abstract: Many of the Mets at spring training camp use their downtime to explore fishing holes around Port St. Lucie, Fla.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The pond sits hidden behind a barricade of greenery, and it is mostly quiet there, save for the crunch of yellow grass under sneakers and the rustling of reptiles and rodents through the shrubs.

headline: Syrian Opposition’s Complaints Shadow Kerry’s First Official Trip
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In his first foreign trip as secretary of state, John Kerry is set to meet with Syrian opposition leaders, but they are threatening to boycott the conference to protest what they see as fainthearted international support.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As John Kerry arrived at his first stop on his maiden trip as the United States secretary of state, American officials were struggling on Sunday to salvage an important meeting with the Syrian opposition.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Company Reports', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Economic data to be released includes durable goods and pending home sales for January on Wednesday, and personal income and spending for January on Friday.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller housing price index for December and the fourth quarter, new home sales for January and consumer confidence for January (Tuesday); durable goods for January and pending home sales for January (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, fourth-quarter G.D.P. (revised) and the Chicago P.M.I. for February (Thursday); and personal income and spending for January, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for February, the ISM manufacturing index for February and construction spending for January (Friday).

headline: Flash Mob in Times Square Honors Victims of Newtown
abstract: Amid startled tourists, a crowd of about 200 people in New York City’s theater district threw their hands in the air and sank to the ground in unison.
lead_paragraph: Many of those who briefly froze the bustling heart of Times Square in a flash mob on Sunday afternoon are used to being stared at. But not for this reason.

headline: Governor of New Mexico, and Now an Envoy for Republicans
abstract: The New Mexico governor, a Republican who will represent her party in efforts to recruit Latino candidates, is fighting to repeal a state law allowing illegal immigrants to get a driver’s license.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — If there is one trait of Gov. Susana Martinez, a Republican, that irks lawmakers on the opposite side of the aisle, it is her reluctance to negotiate. Ms. Martinez handles the Legislature in much the same way that she made a name for herself as a county prosecutor — a tough-as-nails approach that helped carry her all the way to the state’s highest government post.

headline: Nearly 100 Rebels Are Reported Killed in Mali Battle
abstract: Chad’s military said it had lost 23 soldiers in the firefight, apparently the deadliest ground encounter of the war.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nearly 100 Islamist fighters were killed in a firefight last week in the rugged northern reaches of Mali, the Chadian military announced on Sunday, in what appears to have been the single most deadly ground battle since the Malian war began in mid-January.

headline: Emergency Escape From a Cruise
abstract: Some of the largest cruise ships have a chute that helps evacuate passengers during an emergency.
lead_paragraph: Some of the largest cruise ships have a chute that helps evacuate passengers during an emergency.

headline: In Cyberspace, New Cold War
abstract: The Obama administration is escalating demands that China halt the state-sponsored computer hack attacks that Beijing insists it is not mounting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration circulated to the nation’s Internet providers last week a lengthy confidential list of computer addresses linked to a hacking group that has stolen terabytes of data from American corporations, it left out one crucial fact: that nearly every one of the digital addresses could be traced to the neighborhood in Shanghai that is headquarters to the Chinese military’s cybercommand.

headline: Giving Viewers What They Want
keywords: ['Television', 'Movies', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: In any business, the ability to see into the future is the killer app, and Netflix may be getting close with “House of Cards.”
lead_paragraph: In the television business, there is no such thing as a sure thing. You can have a gold-plated director, a bankable star and a popular concept and still, it’s just a roll of the dice.

headline: Turks Debate Modest Dress Set for Takeoff
abstract: Proposed new uniforms for Turkish Airlines flight attendants, including long dresses and Ottoman-style fez caps, have created an uproar over how the flagship carrier should be perceived.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When flight attendants first rode aboard Turkish Airlines in the late 1940s they wore cotton blouses under blue suits tailored to accentuate “the contours of the body,” as a fashion history of the airline puts it. In the ’60s and ’70s the trend continued with fashions straight off the Paris runway, designed to show Turkey’s European flair on its flagship airline.

headline: A Devil Once More, and Facing His Former Team
abstract: Alexei Ponikarovsky was with the Winnipeg Jets only a dozen games before the Devils reacquired him earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Devils’ Alexei Ponikarovsky looked across the ice Sunday at members of the Winnipeg Jets, recognizing them as teammates whom he hardly knew long enough to build lasting bonds.

headline: Lack of Backup Power Puts Cruise Passengers at the Ocean’s Mercy
abstract: Nearly all cruise ships lack backup systems to help a ship return to port should power fail because to install them would have cost operators more money.
lead_paragraph: It is becoming a familiar tale: When the cruise ship was towed into port, the endless hours for passengers of sleeping on deck and going without electricity or toilets were finally over.

headline: Raúl Castro Says His New 5-Year Term as Cuba’s President Will Be His Last
abstract: Mr. Castro, whose term will end in 2018, said he hoped to establish term limits and age caps for political offices, including the presidency.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — President Raúl Castro of Cuba announced Sunday that the five-year term he has just begun will be his last, giving the Castro era an official expiration date of 2018.

headline: A Costly and Unjust Perk for Financiers
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Income', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Private Equity', 'Hedge Funds', 'Venture Capital', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Taxation']
abstract: This huge tax benefit enriches an already privileged sliver of financiers and violates basic standards of fairness and common sense.
lead_paragraph: OF the many injustices that permeate America’s byzantine tax code, few are as outrageous as the tax rate on “carried interest” — the profits made by private equity and hedge fund managers, as well as venture capitalists and partners in real estate investment trusts. This huge tax benefit enriches an already privileged sliver of financiers and violates basic standards of fairness and common sense.

headline: Shared Wounds in Korea
abstract: Park Geun-hye is a symbol of a girl who grew up before the nation’s eyes, only to lose both parents violently, and then become the mother they had carried a torch for since her own mother’s martyrdom.
lead_paragraph: THE inauguration of South Korea’s first female president, Park Geun-hye, on Monday is a trip down memory lane for most South Koreans — especially those in their 50s and 60s, whose support at the polls ensured her election victory last December.

headline: CUNY Journalism Program to Lose Dean
abstract: Stephen B. Shepard said that he expected to remain a professor at the school and work on special projects like the university’s journalism book imprint.
lead_paragraph: Another major journalism school is starting a search for a new leader. The City University of New York plans to announce that Stephen B. Shepard, the founding dean of its journalism program, is stepping down at the end of the year.

headline: In Turnabout, NBC Prime Time Lands in the Cellar
abstract: As sweeps month nears its end, the network is struggling to recover from an embarrassing and potentially costly ratings plunge.
lead_paragraph: With every passing week, the sudden blossoming of prime-time success that NBC experienced last fall is looking more like a mirage.

headline: Common Sense in Connecticut
abstract: Gov. Dannel Malloy is taking a stand on reforming the state’s outdated gun control laws.
lead_paragraph: A little over two months after the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Gov. Dannel Malloy of Connecticut has asked Hartford’s balky Legislature to join him in reforming the state’s outdated gun control laws. “We have changed,” the governor said last week, referring to Sandy Hook’s impact on the nation and on his state in particular. “And I believe it is now time for our laws to do the same.”

headline: What Mortgage Relief?
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Banks have been structuring debt relief in ways that help their own balance sheets rather than borrowers.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, when the nation’s biggest banks settled with state and federal officials over claims of foreclosure abuses, the public was led to believe that the deal would allow millions of hard-pressed borrowers to escape the threat of foreclosure. It still hasn’t happened.

headline: Hope for the Teamless in Seattle
abstract: Seattle fans feel hopeful but also wary, and somewhat guilty, with the sale of the Sacramento Kings and the prospect of the SuperSonics’ return.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Back in the 1992 N.B.A. playoffs, poor Alton Lister stepped between Shawn Kemp and the basket, back when Kemp sprinted and jumped as if from another planet, back when he and the SuperSonics made the spectacular routine. Kemp approached, elevated and jammed home a signature dunk for Seattle sports.

headline: Austerity, Italian Style
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Credit and Debt', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: The country is trapped between comics and delusional Eurocrats.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, when Mario Monti stepped down as Italy’s prime minister, The Economist opined that “The coming election campaign will be, above all, a test of the maturity and realism of Italian voters.” The mature, realistic action, presumably, would have been to return Mr. Monti — who was essentially imposed on Italy by its creditors — to office, this time with an actual democratic mandate.

headline: Chinese Moving to East Harlem in a Quiet Shift From Downtown
abstract: A robbery string that focused on Chinese residents thrust into violent relief a demographic trend in the last decade.
lead_paragraph: For 10 days last month, a robbery pattern in East Harlem drew the heightened attention of the Police Department, which flooded the area with patrol officers and papered storefronts with wanted posters.

headline: Less Innovation, More Inequality
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Productivity', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: America’s peak years of indigenous innovation ran from the 1820s to the 1960s. A slowdown in dynamism since then has contributed to soaring inequality.
lead_paragraph: ONE source of the outsize inequalities in America is the dynamism that made economic activity so rewarding. An economy open to new concepts and novel ventures is bound to generate unequal gains. To tax all of those gains would close off the prospects for success that many entrepreneurs need if they are to undertake ambitious ventures — a big mistake. But it would also be a mistake to misunderstand the relation of inequality and innovation. It is less innovation — not more — that has widened inequality in the United States in recent decades.America’s peak years of indigenous innovation ran from the 1820s to the 1960s. There were a few financial panics and two depressions, to be sure. But in this period, a frenzy of creative activity, economic competition and rapid growth in national income provided widening economic inclusion, rising wages for all and engaging careers for most. Innovations gave workers better tools to work with and better products to make, thus lifting their wages. Then this innovation began to retreat, most of it to an area of land along the West Coast. In the early 1970s the rate of indigenous innovation (as measured by its estimated contribution to the rate of growth in labor productivity) dropped by about half — to around 1 percent since then, from about 2 percent before then.

headline: Defense and the Sequester
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Defense Contracts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The military budget not only can be cut, but should be cut, though not with this kind of political machete.
lead_paragraph: The arbitrary budget cuts known as the sequester will exact a toll on not only domestic programs but military spending as well. Hence the howls in Washington from the Pentagon chieftains and their ardent Congressional supporters. But the truth is that the military budget not only can be cut, but should be cut, though not with this kind of political machete and not in the way the service chiefs say they plan to wield it.

headline: DNA and the Constitution
keywords: ['Forensic Science', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials', 'Search and Seizure', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The Supreme Court should uphold a Maryland ruling protecting Fourth Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear argument about whether it is constitutional for a state to collect DNA from people charged with violent crimes but not yet convicted. Last April, the Maryland Court of Appeals ruled that a state law authorizing such collection violated the Fourth Amendment’s prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.

headline: As Governors Meet, White House Outlines Drop in Aid to States
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'States (US)', 'Governors (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Medicaid', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The White House warned on Sunday that automatic budget cuts scheduled to take effect this week would have a devastating impact on programs for people of all ages in every state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an effort to put pressure on Congressional Republicans, the White House warned on Sunday that automatic budget cuts scheduled to take effect this week would have a devastating impact on programs for people of all ages in every state.

headline: J. Crew Chief and American Express Invest in Warby Parker
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Eyeglasses', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Warby Parker, a start-up whose retro-style eyeglasses have been selling mostly through word of mouth, has been selective about its investors as it seeks to improve its profile.
lead_paragraph: Warby Parker, the hip purveyor of retro-style glasses, has solidified ties with two of its most prominent fans.

headline: In Impasse, New York Would Face Steep Cuts
abstract: If Washington fails to avert automatic spending reductions, New York, Connecticut and New Jersey could lose hundreds of millions of dollars for popular programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — New York, New Jersey and Connecticut face steep reductions in federal aid for education, childhood vaccinations, military operations, environmental protection and other programs if President Obama and Congress fail to reach agreement on a plan to avert a looming series of across-the-board cuts in spending.

headline: On Keeping On
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Vietnam War', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: One fighter pilot’s simple code for life.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I heard the story of John Borling’s poems, I thought of Samuel Johnson’s quip about a dog that walks on its hind legs: it doesn’t matter whether it is done well; the surprising thing is that it is done at all.

headline: As BP Trial Opens, Hints of Progress on a Deal

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — As the trial against BP stemming from the 2010 explosion of a drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico began here Monday morning, the details of a settlement offer by federal and state officials to the oil company to emerge.

headline: Eyes on Town After Tale of Strippers at a Teenage Party
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Strip Clubs and Strippers', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A November birthday party for a 16-year-old boy in South Glens Falls has gained an outsize level of notoriety because of the party favors offered that day: two exotic dancers.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH GLENS FALLS, N.Y. — At the southern end of town, about a mile and a half from Cooper’s Cave, a spot memorialized in James Fenimore Cooper’s “Last of the Mohicans,” a far less bucolic locale has dragged this small North Country community of 3,500 people into the limelight.

headline: Acceptance of Defense Cuts Signals Shift in G.O.P. Focus
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation']
abstract: Republicans are now ready to stand their ground on spending cuts that will hit the military hard, underscoring what some say was a miscalculation on President Obama’s part.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Congress unlikely to stop deep automatic spending cuts that will strike hard at the military, the fiscal stalemate is highlighting a significant shift in the Republican Party: lawmakers most keenly dedicated to shrinking the size of government are now more dominant than the bloc committed foremost to a robust national defense, particularly in the House.

headline: Twitter Hacking Puts Focus on Security for Brands
abstract: With attacks on the Twitter accounts of Burger King, Jeep and others, the site’s relatively lax security is a concern.
lead_paragraph: While most Americans were winding up their holiday weekends last Monday, the phones at the Vancouver headquarters of HootSuite, a social media management company, began to ring.

headline: Shaping a Gun Reform Agenda That Includes Teenagers and Handguns
abstract: Richard M. Aborn, the head of the Citizens Crime Commission of New York City, has spent decades focusing on the American gun plague.
lead_paragraph: “You mean, ‘Real men don’t use guns’?” Richard M. Aborn said. He had just been asked, over breakfast, what ever happened to the quaint idea of angry guys duking it out instead of shooting it out.

headline: Officers Who Interfere With Airwaves Face Punishment
abstract: The practice known as “keying the radio” was a common expression of disapproval within the New York Police Department until department leaders started punishing officers more stringently to send a message.
lead_paragraph: The police radio is an officer’s lifeline to the rest of the patrol force. A hoarsely shouted call for a 10-13, code for an officer needing assistance, will summon waves of uniformed backup.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning numbers for Feb. 24, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Two Sure-Thing Prospects, Still Unsure
abstract: Manny Banuelos and Dellin Betances, once part of the Killer B’s, are waiting for their turn again. Betances will pitch in the minors again, and Banuelos is out for the season after elbow surgery.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Manny Banuelos can remember when he was part of baseball’s most exciting set of pitching prospects. Coming up through the Yankees’ minor league system, the three players — Banuelos, Dellin Betances and Andrew Brackman — even had their own nickname.

headline: Anemia Drug Is Recalled After Allergic Reactions
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said it had received 19 reports of a severe allergic reaction to the drug, Omontys, and that three of the patients had died.
lead_paragraph: The suppliers of a new drug to treat anemia in patients undergoing kidney dialysis have recalled all lots of the product after reports that it had caused severe allergic reactions, including some that were fatal.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Last April, after being told that only a transplant could save her from a fatal lung condition, Rebecca S. Tomczak began calling some of the top-ranked hospitals in the country.

headline: Ex-Heisman Finalist Hoping for Fresh Start

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Tyrann Mathieu woke up at 4 a.m. for his drug test at the scouting combine, hoping to shed his reputation along with the nickname he now shuns.

lead_paragraph: Manhattan’s Chinatown remains a unique American neighborhood, but it is shrinking, as ethnic Chinese move to other parts of New York City.

keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The ascent of the leading black political family in the United States is inextricable from the unraveling of an older one.
lead_paragraph: When Barack and Michelle Obamawere married in Chicago two decades ago, Santita Jackson, a daughter of the Rev.Jesse L. Jackson, sang at their wedding. When Mr. Obama ran for his first national office, he made sure he was not stepping on the ambitions of her brother,Jesse L. Jackson Jr., who later became a co-chairman of his 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Firefighters Intervene in Cleaver Attack on Woman in Chinatown
abstract: Firefighters from Engine 9 and Ladder 6 subdued a man who began hacking furiously at his wife with a long meat cleaver, the police said; the victim fled.
lead_paragraph: The attack in Chinatown on Sunday morning unfolded in a terrifying moment. A man wielding a meat cleaver with a long blade began hacking furiously at a woman on Canal Street just west of Allen Street, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Nets Point to a Noncall, but Have Themselves to Blame in a Loss
abstract: The Nets were frustrated by their own ineptitude against the Grizzlies and incensed over the officiating, specifically the lack of a foul call after Deron Williams was hammered with 26 seconds to go and the game tied.
lead_paragraph: Forty-eight minutes of grinding against the Memphis Grizzlies’ impenetrable defense left the Nets grumbling, gimpy, grumpy and in some cases altogether silent. Some practically sprinted out of Barclays Center late Sunday, unwilling to discuss the ugly particulars of a 76-72 loss. Others could barely walk, or contain their fury.

headline: Adults Are Flocking to College That Paved Way for Flexibility
abstract: There are almost as many routes to a degree as there are students at Thomas Edison, which has offered adults higher-education alternatives since 1972.
lead_paragraph: In September, Jennifer Hunt of Brown County, Ind., was awarded a bachelor’s degree from Thomas Edison State College in New Jersey without ever taking a Thomas Edison course. She was one of about 300 of last year’s 3,200 graduates who managed to patch together their degree requirements with a mix of credits — from other institutions, standardized exams, online courses, workplace or military training programs and portfolio assessments.

headline: Shuffled Lineup Clicks, and Knicks Snap to Life
abstract: Coach Mike Woodson put Tyson Chandler on the court with his four regular reserves, helping the Knicks earn their first win since the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: Coach Mike Woodson had been asked repeatedly about whether he would alter his starting lineup as the Knicks searched for a way to end their two-week slump.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 24
abstract: A view of the day in sports, from baseball to women’s college basketball.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, from baseball to women’s college basketball.

headline: Wolfgang Sawallisch, Conductor, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Sawallisch, a conductor steeped in German tradition, gained a new lease on life at the Philadelphia Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Wolfgang Sawallisch, one of the last of the old-school German conductors, who led the Philadelphia Orchestra for nearly a decade and the Bavarian State Opera in Munich for two decades before that, died on Friday at his home in Grassau, Germany. He was 89.

headline: Daytona 500 Replay
abstract: A look at the 55th running of Nascar’s season-opening event.
lead_paragraph: A look at the 55th running of Nascar’s season-opening event.

headline: PGA Tour Resists Proposed Ban on Anchored Putting
abstract: The PGA Tour told the United States Golf Association that there was no evidence of a competitive advantage from a long-used technique, Commissioner Tim Finchem said.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — The PGA Tour commissioner, Tim Finchem, confirmed Sunday what had been hinted by a few players last week. The tour has informed the game’s governing bodies, the United States Golf Association and the Royal & Ancient, that its membership opposes their proposed ban on the anchored stroke that has fed the popularity of long putters.

headline: Paul McIlhenny, Head of a Tabasco Empire, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Ilhenny, the culinary instigator and chief executive of the McIlhenny Company, invited guests to lick fiery daubs of Tabasco sauce, earning them entry into the Not So Ancient Order of the Not So Silver Spoon.
lead_paragraph: Paul C. P. McIlhenny took joy in escorting visitors to his company’s warehouse, where wooden whiskey barrels filled with the aging pepper mash that is the main ingredient in Tabasco sauce were stacked six-high to the ceiling.

headline: Kuchar Overcomes Elements and Mahan to Capture Match Play Title
abstract: Matt Kuchar handed the defending champion, Hunter Mahan, a 2-and-1 defeat in the final of the Accenture Match Play Championship at the Golf Club in Marana, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — The desert weather was capricious, delivering snow on the first day and biting 30-mile-an-hour wind gusts on the last. Then there was the format at the Accenture Match Play Championship, which produced several winners so unpredictable the best way to pick them was out of a hat.

headline: Finding Ways to Say Thanks, Other Than Apple Pie
abstract: My mother’s baking reminded me of how important a thank you can be.
lead_paragraph: My mother, a school secretary, lived in the same house for 50 years, until her death at the age of 92. For the last 25 years she was alone — my father was dead, and my brother and I took jobs in other parts of the country after college.

headline: Silver Calls for Reversing Cuomo’s Cut in School Aid
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'State Legislatures', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Sheldon Silver, the Legislature’s top Democrat, opposes Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s insistence on penalizing New York City schools over a teacher-evaluation impasse.
lead_paragraph: In a rebuke to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan to withhold $260 million in school aid from New York City because it missed a deadline to finalize a system to evaluate teachers, the Legislature’s top Democrat said on Sunday that he would push to restore the money.

headline: Matt Mattox, Jazz Dance Pioneer, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Mattox, known for his “catlike agility” in “Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,” was also a pioneer of the art of jazz dancing.
lead_paragraph: Matt Mattox, a dancer, choreographer and teacher who helped shape contemporary jazz dance in the United States and Europe, died in France on Feb. 18. He was 91.

headline: Spotify Adapts Its Mobile App for Ford Vehicles
abstract: The partnership is the latest example of a digital media service embedding its product in car dashboards.
lead_paragraph: Coming soon to Ford cars: Spotify.

headline: Fandango Adds Service Aimed at Hispanics
abstract: NBCUniversal’s movie ticket service, with the Spanish-language broadcaster Telemundo, will introduce Fandango Cine, which will highlight movies, actors and video meant to resonate with Hispanics.
lead_paragraph: Hispanics buy a quarter of all movie tickets sold in the United States. But do they need their own place to buy them?

headline: Role Limited, Stoudemire Shows All That He Can Do
abstract: Twenty-three games into his season, Amar’e Stoudemire has had to return to shape and adapt to a new role. Thus far, he has done both.
lead_paragraph: Amar’e Stoudemire took off his goggles and planted them on the scorers’ table, like a laborer plopping his lunch pail down after a long day of work. There was time left on the clock, but his day was done, and he appeared satisfied with that.

headline: Michael J. Maye, Scrappy Leader of Firefighters’ Union, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Maye led the Uniformed Firefighters Association in the early 1970s, when fires in New York City increased by more than half and the number of firefighters decreased by a third.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, fires ravaged New York City as arson, neglect and racial tensions ran rampant. The city’s firefighters, almost all of whom were white, were sometimes attacked — with guns, rocks, peashooters and even refrigerators dropped from rooftops — when they responded to alarms in minority neighborhoods, where most of the blazes erupted. Adding insult to injury, hundreds of the alarms were false.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 15, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (TCM) FUNNY GIRL (1968) Barbra Streisand, who shared that year’s best actress Oscar with Katharine Hepburn in “The Lion in Winter,” plays the comedian Fanny Brice as she struggles to prove herself both as a Broadway star and as a romantic interest, despite her unglamorous appearance. Omar Sharif (above, with Ms. Streisand) is Nicky Arnstein, the suave gambler who brings his lady no luck. In “The Way We Were” (1973), at 3:30, Ms. Streisand, in another Oscar-nominated role, plays a fiery liberal fighting for the survival of her marriage to a preppy writer (Robert Redford) during the McCarthy era. The composer Marvin Hamlisch won for best score and, with Alan and Marilyn Bergman, best song for the title hit.

headline: Bank of Japan to Get a Critic as Its New Chief
abstract: Haruhiko Kuroda, head of the Asian Development Bank and an advocate of bold measures to fight deflation, is said to be Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s choice to head the Japanese central bank.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In an appointment that could finally turn the tide in Japan’s long battle against deflation, a global finance veteran and longtime critic of the Bank of Japan is set to be the government’s choice for the next central bank chief.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence Trips at the Oscars

lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lawrence trips while accepting her Oscar for best actress at the 2013 Academy Awards.

headline: Otfried Preussler, Children’s Book Author, Dies at 89
abstract: One of Mr. Preussler’s most famous creations was the thief Hotzenplotz and his nemesis, Dimpfelmoser the policeman.
lead_paragraph: Otfried Preussler, a German children’s author whose books about wizards, witches and water spirits sold 50 million copies and whose half-century-old word choices recently inspired fierce debate, died on Feb. 18 in Prien am Chiemsee, Germany. He was 89.

headline: Best Picture for ‘Argo’ in Varied Oscar Field
abstract: Hollywood gave its top honor to Ben Affleck’s “Argo,” which was once a long-shot contender, in an awards show that no one film seemed to dominate.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood gave its top honor to Ben Affleck’s “Argo” at a song-and-dance-filled Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday, completing a remarkable turnaround for a film that was once a long-shot contender.

headline: Hawkish Chinese General Joins Social Media Fray
abstract: A well-connected Chinese major general, Luo Yuan, has entered the rough-and-tumble world of microblogging, which he calls “a very important public opinion front.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A hawkish and well-connected Chinese major general, Luo Yuan, who last year reportedly recommended turning islands in the East China Sea claimed by both China and Japan into a shooting range, has debuted in China’s enormously popular world of microblogging with the announcement that “we must fight for our beloved fatherland, beloved party, beloved army and beloved people!”

headline: Sleeves and Straps Are Barely There
abstract: Sleeves were in short supply and straps were so unrepresented on dresses at the Oscars on Sunday night that they might as well have been outlawed.
lead_paragraph: Sleeves were in short supply and straps were so unrepresented on dresses at the Oscars on Sunday night that they might as well have been outlawed. But hold the envelope a moment: The verdict on this year’s red carpet is not all that bad. At least it wasn’t the usual monotonous parade of princess dresses.

headline: A Conversation With: Author and Mathematician Manil Suri
abstract: On his latest novel, growing up in Mumbai and his passion for writing.
lead_paragraph: The Indian-American author Manil Suri made a splashy entry into the world of writing in 2001 with “The Death of Vishnu,” which became a best seller and was a finalist for the prestigious PEN/Faulkner award. “The Age of Shiva” followed seven years later. This month, the 53-year-old mathematics professor, who teaches at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, released “The City of Devi,” the final part of a trilogy linked to Hindu gods.

headline: South Korean President Warns North Against Nuclear Pursuits
abstract: Park Geun-hye, who was sworn in Monday as South Korea’s first female president, urged North Korea to abandon its nuclear ambitions without delay.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The country’s new president, Park Geun-hye, was sworn into office on Monday, facing far more complicated fissures both within South Korea and with North Korea than her father did during his Cold War dictatorship, which ended with his assassination 33 years ago.

headline: A Mexican Photographer, Overshadowed but Not Outdone
abstract: Lola Alvarez Bravo was overshadowed, and often hindered, by her more famous partner, Manuel Alvarez Bravo, yet a new book reveals that she was a formidable artist and photographer in her own right.
lead_paragraph: The year 2007 was a pretty good one for rediscovering long-forgotten images in Mexico. Most people already know about Robert Capa’s Mexican suitcase, a trove of his work from the Spanish Civil War. But that same year an unknown archive of vintage prints by Mexico’s greatest photographers was also discovered, left behind in the longtime home of Lola Álvarez Bravo.

headline: What Investment Are You Willing to Make to Get Your Dream Job?
abstract: What sacrifices does your dream job require before you land it?

headline: Mediterranean Diet Shown to Ward Off Heart Attack and Stroke
abstract: Until now, evidence that the Mediterranean diet reduced the risk of heart disease was weak, and some experts had been skeptical that the effect of diet could be detected.
lead_paragraph: About 30 percent of heart attacks, strokes and deaths from heart disease can be prevented in people at high risk if they switch to a Mediterranean diet rich in olive oil, nuts, beans, fish, fruits and vegetables, and even drink wine with meals, a large and rigorous new study has found.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Moss on Addictive Foods and What He Eats for Breakfast
abstract: The author of this week’s cover article answers questions on the games the processed food industry plays with our tastebuds (and our health).
lead_paragraph: Michael Moss, a Pulitzer Prize–winning investigative reporter for The Times, wrote this week’s cover article on the processed-food industry. The article is adapted from his book, “Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us,” which will be published this month.

abstract: The expedition took advantage of a slack tide to fish for data.
lead_paragraph: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes and wrote about his expedition to the North Pacific in the fall.

headline: Top British Cardinal Resigns, a Day After Charges of ‘Inappropriate Acts’
abstract: Britain’s most senior Roman Catholic cleric, Cardinal Keith O’Brien, said he would step down and would not attend the Vatican conclave to elect a new pope.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Britain’s most senior Roman Catholic cleric announced his resignation on Monday, a day after being accused of “inappropriate acts” with priests, saying he would not attend the conclave to elect a new pope.

headline: A Hint of Horse Meat Has a Nation Squirming More Than Its Neighbors
abstract: With equine DNA detected around Europe in foods billed as containing beef, no one seems able to say exactly why the British are so much more upset about it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Seeking literary echoes of current predicaments, Britons can generally rely on Shakespeare. But one line in the national memory has proved curiously inappropriate.

headline: Religious Groups Urge Deficit Reduction and Protection of the Poor

lead_paragraph: Leaders from some of the nation’s largest and most influential Christian congregations are urging President Obama and members of Congress to end their fiscal brinkmanship and find a way to agree on new revenue and spending cuts that will reduce the deficit while protecting the poorest Americans.

headline: Laliji, the Octogenarian from Bihar
abstract: A God-fearing woman, who was bribed to vote for a candidate in the last election.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this year’s 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

headline: Cadwalader Attracts a Top Deal Maker
abstract: James C. Woolery is leaving JPMorgan Chase to join Cadwalader. | The recent spate of deals has come as the stock market hits record levels. | The latest round of financing for Warby Parker attracted two prominent names. | The old Italian bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena has been crippled by 21st-century finance.
lead_paragraph: James C. Woolery, the co-head of North American mergers and acquisitions at JPMorgan Chase, said on Sunday that he was leaving the bank after two years to become deputy chairman of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. In his new job, Mr. Woolery, who joined JPMorgan following 17 years at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, is a potential successor to the current chairman of Cadwalader, W. Christopher White, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. His departure from JPMorgan leaves Chris Ventresca as sole head of the North American mergers division.

lead_paragraph: “McKayla the not-impressed Olympian” sounds as if it might be the title of a song or a book. But as most Americans with access to a TV set, computer, smartphone or mobile device know, it is a reference to McKayla Maroney, an American gymnast at the 2012 Summer Olympics in London.

headline: Lumière | Dance Fever
