lead_paragraph: The Paris Opera Ballet, the oldest national ballet company in the world, dating to the 17th-century court of Louis XIV, has dared to break with tradition: for the first time in its history it is asking ordinary citizens for money.

headline: The Single Logic of Continuous Russian History
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Education (K-12)', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Parenting', 'Politics and Government', 'Russian Language']
abstract: Will my daughter’s generation will be the first and last in Russia to have a chance at growing up with a sane view of history?
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — I am living through one of the most enjoyable periods of parenthood: My middle child, who is 11, is discovering some of the books and stories that shaped me. She still wants tickets to Justin Bieber’s April concert in Moscow, but we are engaged in a daily conversation about the Soviet past, which means I am answering questions and explaining concepts that touch me deeply.

headline: The Gun Report: February 25, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Every day, when Jennifer Mascia and I compile this report, we are stunned at the number of children who are accidentally shot — and often killed — because a gun-owning adult in their household has put a loaded gun someplace where they can get their hands on it and shoot it. We have three such examples in today’s report, one of which resulted in the death of a 4-year-old in Houston. Other nations mandate that gun owners keep their firearms in safes bolted to the floor. Why don’t we?

headline: How Syria Is Becoming Bosnia
abstract: Two years after the uprising began, the death toll in Syria is approaching the roughly 100,000 dead of Iraq and Bosnia.
lead_paragraph: Typhoid and hepatitis outbreaks are spreading. An estimated 70,000 people are dead, and another 850,000 are refugees. After covering the battle for Damascus for a month, photographer Goran Tomasevic of Reuters declared the situation a “bloody stalemate.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: NBC Ratings Tumble and Twitter Hacking Can Undermine Brands
abstract: NBC’s ratings are the lowest of any broadcast network; brands are perturbed by Twitter hackings; and who won at the Oscars, and what they wore.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s ratings have plummeted since a great prime-time run last autumn, Bill Carter reports. NBC’s viewership has dissipated to numbers never before seen by any broadcast network — certainly not during sweeps month. In February NBC was not only well behind its competitors but also the Spanish-language channel Univision. The numbers are so bad that NBC may have to offer “make-goods,” or free advertising time, to cover shortfalls of ratings guarantees. Audiences for once-promising sitcoms like “Go On” have disappeared; new shows like “1600 Penn” have drawn little notice; and “Do No Harm” became the lowest-rated network drama on record before being canceled after two episodes. “Saturday Night Live,” the network’s highest-rated show even though it is 38 years old, was the only silver lining.

headline: Dislocation, Dislocation, Dislocation
abstract: Chinese investment on the Tibetan plateau brings opportunities for local nomads — and destroys a community.
lead_paragraph: GANGCA, China — It is 1 p.m. in the small Tibetan restaurant. Four middle-aged men crowd around a low table strewn with bottles of beer. As the afternoon goes on, more men join them, sporting gold teeth and thick sheepskin robes slung over jeans. They are resettled nomads, and without their flocks, I am told, they don’t have much else to do but drink.

headline: Horsemeat Scandal Grows More Serious and More Bizarre
abstract: From a modest proposal by some German politicians that the poor eat the suspect horsemeat products to the tainting of the iconic Ikea Swedish meatball, is nothing sacred?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As European governments struggle in vain to draw a line under the scandal over horsemeat being sold as beef, the affair seems only to be widening, in sometimes bizarre ways.

headline: A Tale of Two Adjustments
abstract: Why Spain now can’t be Germany in the past.
lead_paragraph: A commenter on my last euro post asks a good question: didn’t Germany once have a problem of excessive unit labor costs, which it cured with a protracted squeeze? And in that case, why is it so terrible if Spain is asked to do the same thing?

headline: The Ant, the Grasshopper and Electricity Prices in New England
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Natural Gas', 'Pipelines', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Standards and Standardization']
abstract: New England’s electricity shortage is rooted in disincentives for gas-fired generators to invest in pipeline capacity, experts say.
lead_paragraph: The electricity crunch in New England that I wrote about on Feb. 15 persists, and it is clearly related to a shortage of natural gas pipeline capacity relative to growing demand. But experts say the root cause is something more complicated: a structural flaw in the regional electric market.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: NPR: Despite the lingering drought, the U.S.D.A. is predicting a record corn harvest, up nearly 40 percent over last year’s yield. The only problem is that the agency made nearly the same prediction last year, but the weather failed to cooperate. – Glenn Collins

headline: The Daily Shoe | Bally
abstract: A new take on the Chelsea boot adds Italian polish to the English favorite.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Zeleny to Move From Times to ABC News
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Jeff Zeleny, a New York Times political reporter who covered the recent presidential election, will head to ABC News, where he will be senior Washington correspondent.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Zeleny, a top political reporter for The New York Times, was hired on Monday by ABC News, which said he will become the network’s senior Washington correspondent next month.

headline: From a Well-Traveled Chef, Pearl and Ash
abstract: Richard Kuo’s new restaurant is to open Monday on the Bowery.
lead_paragraph: The chef Richard Kuo has had a world of influences. Born in Taiwan, he lived in Australia before landing in New York, where his first job was at the wildly pioneering WD-50. Most recently, he took on New Nordic cusine at the short-lived Brooklyn pop-up Frej, with Fredrik Berselius.

headline: Iran Enters Nuclear Talks in a Freshly Defiant Mood
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Iran’s leaders believe that they have the upper hand in negotiations with the West in Kazakhstan on Tuesday, and are not likely to offer any new plans or suggestions.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — When Iran’s nuclear negotiating team sits down with its Western counterparts in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Tuesday, it will offer no new plans or suggestions, people familiar with the views of the Iranian leadership say. More likely, they say, the Iranian negotiators will sit with arms crossed, demanding a Western change of heart.

headline: For Seth MacFarlane, Thumbs Up From Fellow Comedians
abstract: Whatever you think of Seth MacFarlane’s performance as host of the Oscars, his fellow comedians and performers had nothing but praise.
lead_paragraph: 1:02 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES — Was Seth MacFarlane a terrible Oscar host or just a mediocre one? (He said it himself, onstage.) Or was he good? Our colleague Alessandra Stanley noted that as an M.C. he brought together old and new Hollywood, vaudeville-style shtick and contemporary humiliation humor. Other assessments are still trickling in along with the ratings (which early on, at least, show a rise), but backstage after the show, Jennifer Lawrence was certain.

headline: Marine Deleeuw Transforms Backstage at Marni
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Paul Hanlon.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper810 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: Reality Wins the Race
abstract: After fiery pieces of a two-ton racecar flew into the stands during the Nationwide on Saturday, it was hard to pretend everything was normal.
lead_paragraph: Daytona 500 week had been filled with so much hope for Nascar. Certainly this was the year, racing’s grand pooh-bahs had to be thinking, that we would not be talking about rain delays or potholes or jet dryers bursting into flames. No, this year the forecast was good. The starlet Danica Patrick had won the pole position. The other drivers seemed to be keeping their Danica fatigue under wraps. Combustible Twitter feuds seemed to quiet to a manageable simmer. The stars all seemed to align just so.

headline: The Promise and Peril of the ‘Data-Driven Society’
abstract: The prospect of a “data-driven society” was the subject of a gathering last Thursday at the M.I.T. Media Lab — the implications, the concerns and the unknowns. For example, the most important data that is becoming available on a vast new scale is information about people’s behavior: the social and economic connections among individuals.
lead_paragraph: A small group of academics, business executives and journalists gathered at the M.I.T. Media Lab last Thursday, and the purpose was to toss out ideas and discuss the concept of “Data-Driven Societies.” A daunting topic, ambitious and vague at once, it seems.

headline: A Troubled Papacy
abstract: The Times’s Laurie Goodstein discusses the resignation of Cardinal Keith O’Brien, Britain’s most senior Roman Catholic cleric, following accusations of “inappropriate acts.”
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Laurie Goodstein discusses the resignation of Cardinal Keith O’Brien, Britain’s most senior Roman Catholic cleric, following accusations of “inappropriate acts.”

headline: Look of The Moment | Oscars Edition
abstract: Starlets went strapless in all colors at last night’s Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Pocket of Manhattan Where No One Stays for Long
abstract: Of the top 20 most mobile ZIP codes in New York City, 6 were bundled in or around the financial district, an analysis found.
lead_paragraph: It seems like a perfectly nice apartment.

headline: Distance from Carnage Doesn’t Prevent PTSD for Drone Pilots
abstract: Researchers with the Defense Department have found that pilots of drone aircraft experience mental health problems like depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder at the same rate as pilots of manned aircraft.
lead_paragraph: As debate raged over whether drone operators deserve a new medal, researchers with the Defense Department have found that pilots of drone aircraft experience mental health problems like depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder at the same rate as pilots of manned aircraft.

headline: H&M’s Oscar Moment
abstract: There was one surprise at the Oscars this year. When Helen Hunt identified the designer of her navy silk satin strapless dress as H&M, many people thought she was joking.
lead_paragraph: While the Oscars red carpet was generally a success on Sunday night, there was a notable and disappointing absence of younger and more independent designer labels, like Zac Posen, Proenza Schouler and Joseph Altuzarra (at least not until the after-parties, where Madonna wore a look from Mr. Altuzarra’s fall show). It’s a challenge for smaller fish to compete in a pond that is dominated by big labels like Valentino, Dior and Armani.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 25
abstract: A priest offering prayers for the speedy recovery of the Hyderabad twin blast victims.

headline: Williamstown Festival Will Include ‘Animal Crackers’ and ‘Bridges of Madison County’
abstract: This summer, Williamstown Theater Festival will present a revival of “Animal Crackers,” the Marx Brothers farce, and a new musical based on “The Bridges of Madison County,” the best-selling Robert James Waller romance novel.
lead_paragraph: Hey, you got “Animal Crackers” in my “Bridges of Madison County”! No, you got “Bridges of Madison County” in my “Animal Crackers”! There may be no resolving this debate, but whether you’re a fan of madcap comedy or musicals adapted from best-selling romance novels, this summer’s Williamstown Theater Festival will have something to offer you, judging by Monday’s announcement of its lineup.

headline: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
abstract: The week’s best N.B.A. games feature the Lakers at the Nuggets, the Clippers at the Pacers and the Heat at the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

headline: The Onion Apologizes for Tweet About Quvenzhané Wallis
abstract: “No person should be subjected to such a senseless, humorless comment masquerading as satire,” Steve Hannah, the chief executive of The Onion, wrote in an apology to Quvenzhané Wallis, the 9-year-old star of “Beasts of the Southern Wild.”
lead_paragraph: The satirical publication The Onion apologized on Monday for a post published Sunday night on its Twitter account that made an obscene reference to Quvenzhané Wallis, the 9-year-old actress  nominated for an Academy Award for her performance in “Beasts of the Southern Wild.”

headline: Bob Hope Estate in Palm Springs Is Up for Sale
abstract: The huge Palm Springs estate of Bob Hope is being brought to market for the first time, at an asking price of $50 million.
lead_paragraph: The huge Palm Springs estate of Bob Hope, the comic icon of midcentury film and television, and his wife, Dolores, is being brought to market for the first time this month, at an asking price of $50 million.

headline: The Oscars: A Morning-After Report
abstract: The sheer star power of the Oscars ceremony, and the after-parties that follow, create a slightly surreal experience.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, at a lunch at the Beverly Hills home of Diane von Furstenberg and Barry Diller, where the guests ranged from Eddie Redmayne to George Hamilton, someone was talking about what it was like to attend the Oscars in person.

headline: Awaiting the Dimming of G.E. at 30 Rock
abstract: Comcast’s purchase of the rest of NBCUniversal from General Electric may spell the end of the G.E. logo atop the G.E. Building, just as G.E. took down the old R.C.A. sign in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: What do the Apollo Theater, Katz’s Delicatessen, the Chelsea Hotel, Pepsi and 30 Rockefeller Plaza have in common?

headline: As Oil Spill Trial Opens, Push for a Deal Continues
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Opening arguments cataloged BP’s failures in the 2010 disaster, but negotiators were said to be working on multibillion-dollar settlement.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — BP finally faced off in court Monday against an army of federal and state prosecutors, lawyers and even its contract partners over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill three years ago, contending that it alone should not shoulder blame for the rig explosion that killed 11 workers and soiled beaches and marshes from Louisiana to Florida.

headline: What Barnes & Noble’s Retail Arm Might Be Worth
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Now that Barnes & Noble’s chairman is planning to bid for the retailer’s physical stores, how much will he pay? According to some analysts, maybe not all that much.
lead_paragraph: Though Leonard S. Riggio has sought to push Barnes & Noble into the future by supporting its Nook e-reader business, the bookseller’s chairman has long held a soft spot for the retailer’s brick-and-mortar outlets.

headline: The Mathematics of Climate Change
abstract: Why is the Earth’s climate the temperature that it is? And could this temperature be lowered by putting a giant mirror between the Earth and the Sun?
lead_paragraph: Climate change is arguably the most important issue humanity has ever faced. The Earth’s average surface temperature continues to climb and weather is increasingly volatile. Our current trajectory looks perilous.

headline: On Our Radar: Prison Term for Biodiesel Fraud
abstract: A Maryland man is given a 12-year sentence for selling credits for renewable fuel he never manufactured.
lead_paragraph: A Maryland man is sentenced to 12 years in prison for selling $9 million worth of bogus renewable fuel credits. The fraud scheme undermined the reputation of a program intended to reduce the nation’s dependence on foreign oil. [Environmental Protection Agency]

headline: Michelle Obama Makes a Star Turn at the Oscars (via Satellite)
abstract: Michelle Obama made an appearance at the Oscars from the Diplomatic Room of the White House to present the best picture award to “Argo.”
lead_paragraph: 6:21 p.m. | Updated She may not have walked the red carpet, but Michelle Obama — all bangs and biceps and bling — had her own star turn during Sunday night’s Academy Awards ceremony, when she announced the winner for best picture via satellite from the White House.

headline: Too Many Pills in Pregnancy
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Doctors are concerned as studies find more women take medications during their pregnancies, including in the first trimester, when fetal organs are forming.
lead_paragraph: The thalidomide disaster of the early 1960s left thousands of babies with deformed limbs because their mothers innocently took a sleeping pill thought to be safe during pregnancy,

headline: At 125 Years, a Rechristening for The Herald Tribune
abstract: The New York Times Company said it was planning to rename The International Herald Tribune, its 125-year-old newspaper based in Paris, and would also redesign its Web site for international audiences.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company said on Monday that it was planning to rename The International Herald Tribune, its 125-year-old newspaper based in Paris, and would also unveil a redesigned Web site for international audiences.

headline: Pynchon Takes On Silicon Alley
abstract: A new novel by Thomas Pynchon, to be released in September, takes place in “the lull between the collapse of the dot-com boom and the terrible events of September 11,” according to its publisher.
lead_paragraph: New York’s technology scene is getting the Thomas Pynchon treatment.

headline: Kerry Vows Not to Leave Syria Rebels ‘Dangling in the Wind’
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said the Obama administration was mulling new steps to increase support for the Syrian opposition and hasten the departure of President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Monday that the Obama administration has been considering new steps to increase support for the Syrian opposition and hasten the departure of President Bashar al-Assad and that some of them would be decided at an international conference in Rome this week.

headline: Lindsay Lohan to Guest Star on ‘Anger Management’ With Charlie Sheen
abstract: Lindsay Lohan will play herself in a coming episode of “Anger Management,” in which she becomes romantically connected to the therapist played by Charlie Sheen.
lead_paragraph: In the surest sign that peace, calm and normalcy had been restored to Hollywood after a raucous Academy Awards ceremony, it was announced on Monday morning that Lindsay Lohan would appear in a coming episode of “Anger Management,” the FX sitcom starring Charlie Sheen.

headline: What if the Republicans Had Won the Senate?
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What would the political landscape in Washington look like if Republicans had won the Senate last November?
lead_paragraph: Alternative history is a popular niche in fiction. What would the world look like if Pickett had carried the day at Gettysburg?  What if the Japanese had prevailed at Midway? How different would current events be if President Kennedy’s assassination had been thwarted?

headline: Stars Celebrate at the Governors Ball
abstract: Winners basked in the limelight after the Oscars.
lead_paragraph: Winners basked in the limelight after the Oscars.

abstract: The Ozymandias of ideologies.
lead_paragraph: Import-substituting industrialization (pdf).

headline: After the First 100 Days of Xi Jinping
keywords: ['Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Three important political meetings will occur in the next two weeks, with pollution problems likely to be on the agenda of at least one of them.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping has been general secretary of the Communist Party of China for just over 100 days. Last week, official media praised Mr. Xi’s first 100 days in office and his focus on the “Chinese Dream” as well as people’s livelihood issues like health, education, property prices and corruption.

headline: Not Exactly the Social-Media Oscars
abstract: Twitter didn’t light up for the Oscars the way it did for the Super Bowl or the Grammys, according to tweet-per-minute stats.
lead_paragraph: Adele Performs – Skyfall – Oscars 2013 by IdolxMuzic

headline: Safety Agency Investigating 725,000 Fords
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Defective Products', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: Graco child safety seats and 88,000 Honda Pilots also come under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is opening or upgrading investigations into about 725,000 Ford cars and sport utility vehicles, almost 88,000 Honda Pilots and an undisclosed number of Graco child restraints, according to reports posted on the agency Web site over the weekend.

headline: Clock Ticking Down on ‘What is Time’ Contest
abstract: A contest seeks scientists’ answers to a fundamental question: What is time?
lead_paragraph: If you have or are pursuing a graduate degree in the sciences, you have until March 1 to help Alan Alda and the folks at Stony Brook University’s Center for Communicating Science answer this simple, but complicated, question: “What is time?”

headline: Photos of The Moment | Giorgio Armani
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.

headline: The Small Picture: ‘Mercy, We’re in Season!’
abstract: Headed for 7-Eleven, the shipment of sunglasses will bring Sequoia Licensed Products a much-needed infusion of cash. Oh, thank heaven …
lead_paragraph: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: Continuing the Conversation on Paid Parental Leave
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Family Leaves', 'Paid Time Off', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: The Times would like you to share your employer’s policy on paid parental leave.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of readers wrote to us with their company’s parental leave polices after reading the Your Money column, which discussed how American public and private organizations offer the least generous paid leave policies in the world.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Super Bowl commercials, good, bad and blah, usually generate heated debates. And so it is with the latest crop.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: And1, Aliso Viejo, Calif., the basketball footwear and apparel company, chose Catch New York as agency of record.
lead_paragraph: And1, Aliso Viejo, Calif., the basketball footwear and apparel company, chose Catch New York as agency of record. Billings were not disclosed. The assignment had previously been handled by Frank Creative, Portland, Ore.

headline: Dynamo’s Boniek Garcia Has the Name, and He Has the Game
abstract: Oscar Boniek Garcia helped Houston advance to last year’s M.L.S. Cup title game. Now he’s back for his first full season in M.L.S.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps only in soccer’s globalized realm could a guy from Honduras be named after a famous attacking midfielder from Poland and play professionally for a club team in the United States.

headline: G.O.P. Drafts Plan to Give Obama Discretion on Cuts
abstract: Congressional Republicans plan to counter President Obama’s warnings about the impact of $85 billion in automatic budget cuts with a bill to give the White House flexibility in instituting those cuts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans are preparing to counter increasingly dire warnings from President Obama about the impact of automatic budget cuts with a plan to give the administration more flexibility in instituting $85 billion in cuts, a proposal they say could protect the most vital programs while shifting more of the political fallout to the White House.

headline: For Autodesk, a Step Into a Nanoscale World
abstract: This week at the TED conference in Long Beach, Calif., Autodesk will take the first public step toward translating its computer design approach into the emerging nanoscale world of synthetic biology and materials.
lead_paragraph: Autodesk, a quirky software start-up in Marin County, north of San Francisco, rose to prominence in the early 1980s because of AutoCAD, its computer-aided design program that was intended for use on personal computers. Over the next decade, AutoCAD became the standard design tool for architects and engineers.

headline: How Will Magazine Titans Merge? Carefully
abstract: Time Inc. and Meredith, whose corporate cultures have already proved sharply discordant once, are creating a new company to house many of their magazines.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Griffin, the former president of the magazine company Meredith, took the reins at Time Inc., he threw a holiday party for his staff on the 34th floor of the Time & Life Building. For many employees at the famously hierarchal company, their first visit to the rambling executive suites that inspired the sets of “Mad Men” became known as “The Miracle on 34th.”

headline: In Performance: Ethan Hawke & Dana Lyn
abstract: Ethan Hawke and the violinist Dana Lyn perform the number “Aura Lee” from the New Group’s production of Jonathan Marc Sherman’s play “Clive.”
lead_paragraph: Ethan Hawke and the violinist Dana Lyn perform the number “Aura Lee” from the New Group’s production of Jonathan Marc Sherman’s play “Clive.”

headline: Healthy Bacteria in Babies
abstract: Infants may fail to develop a healthy mixture of intestinal bacteria if they are delivered by Caesarean section or do not drink breast milk, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: Infants may fail to develop a healthy mixture of intestinal bacteria if they are delivered by Caesarean section or do not drink breast milk, researchers are reporting.

headline: Are These Ads Worth the Paper They’re Not Printed On?
abstract: A campaign to promote the value of using paper at work moves its pitch out of the office.
lead_paragraph: A campaign to promote the value of using paper is turning to everyday situations to make its point after spending more than two years at the office.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Alejandro Ingelmo
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a ladylike heel with architectural angles.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: With Rent Ever Higher, Irish Pub Gives Up
abstract: The Emerald Inn, which survived as its Upper West Side neighborhood reinvented itself with pricier and pricier stores, is to close April 30 after 70 years.
lead_paragraph: In a neighborhood where shiny outposts of big-name retailers have displaced the little stores and restaurants where everybody seemed to know everybody else, a longtime holdout is finally planning a last last call.

headline: Videos and Recipes for Your Mediterranean Diet
abstract: These cooking videos and recipes offer an introduction to the Mediterranean diet, which includes foods with olive oil, nuts, beans, fish, fruits and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Good news for your heart, and taste buds: a rigorous study published Monday on The New England Journal of Medicine’s Web site shows that heart disease in high-risk patients can be prevented by following the Mediterranean diet, which is rich in nuts, beans, fish, fruits, vegetables and olive oil. Even a moderate quantity of wine is allowed. These cooking videos and recipes can help get you started.

headline: Will Yahoo Increase Productivity by Banning People From Working at Home?
abstract: A new policy at Yahoo requiring that people work in the office strikes some people as behind the curve, though the company says it will improve collaboration and momentum.
lead_paragraph: When Marissa Mayer swooped into Yahoo last year, she tried to make it a more desirable place to work, adding perks like free food and smartphones.

headline: German Central Bank Leader Joins Critics In Lecturing France on Government Debt
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Jens Weidmann was the latest prominent European to lecture the increasingly defensive French on how they should manage their economy.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The head of the German central bank said Monday that France should not give up trying to bring its government deficit below 3 percent of gross domestic product, adding to the criticism being heaped on President François Hollande of France from abroad.

headline: Root Vegetable Sweetness
keywords: ['Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health', 'Sweet Potatoes', 'Lentils', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: Even once they have started to go limp, root vegetables can be the basis of delicious, healthy meals.
lead_paragraph: Last week I got a Facebook message from a Recipes for Health fan that said: “Help! Drowning in pounds of root vegetables from CSA…would love recipes for sweet potatoes, yellow potatoes, and carrots…” Since root vegetables and tubers keep well and can be cooked up into something delicious even after they have begun to go limp in the refrigerator, this week’s Recipes for Health should be useful. Root vegetables, tubers (potatoes and sweet potatoes, which are called yams by most vendors – I mean the ones with dark orange flesh), winter squash and cabbages are the only local vegetables available during the winter months in colder regions, so these recipes will be timely for many readers.

headline: Walkabout – 2/25: Looming Budget Cuts Threaten National Parks and Airports
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: America’s Best Idea, Endangered Absent a Congressional compromise to avert budget cuts, the National Park Service will be significantly reduced starting March 1, park retirees warn. (The New York Times)

headline: Notes on the Decline of Work
abstract: Should we worry about the decline of workforce participation?
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column on America’s declining rates of workforce participation raised a provocative issue without addressing all the possible objections to my claim that this is something we should be concerned about. With that in mind, here are provisional responses to three questions that a careful reader might have about my argument.

headline: Visa Teams Up With Samsung on Mobile Payments
abstract: The idea of paying for things with a phone is still foreign to most people, but now Visa and Samsung Electronics are working together to make mobile payments easier.
lead_paragraph: The idea of paying for things with a phone is still foreign to most people, but now Visa and Samsung Electronics are working together to make mobile payments easier.

headline: An Inside View of How We Recruit (Without Recruiters)
abstract: There is one principle we all agree on: always be recruiting!
lead_paragraph: Last week my post, “Why We Never Use Professional Recruiters,” spawned a terrific discussion with many commenters taking the time to share their views on the best way to do recruiting. I’m grateful for each of the comments. As I said in my very first post for this column, “I am hopeful that together, we can discover how to build a great team.”

headline: Quiz: Do You Have a Mediterranean Diet?
abstract: Take this survey, as designed by the researchers from the University of Barcelona to determine if your current diet is heart healthy.
lead_paragraph: Take this survey, as designed by the researchers from the University of Barcelona to determine if your current diet is heart healthy.

headline: Italians Head to the Polls
abstract: Italians voted Sunday and Monday in a general election that is being closely watched to see whether a clear winner will emerge.
lead_paragraph: Italians voted Sunday and Monday in a general election that is being closely watched to see whether a clear winner will emerge.

headline: The Challenge of Sentencing White-Collar Defendants
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: A recent appeals court decision reflects an underlying tension in the sentencing white-collar criminals who present no real threat of physical harm to society and continue to lead productive lives after committing a crime.
lead_paragraph: Are white-collar defendants treated more favorably than other criminals when it comes to sentencing? A case involving the chief executive of a technology firm in Ohio that collapsed in 2003 after fraud allegations seems to indicate that perhaps there is such a thing as being too lenient, according to a Federal Appeals Court.

headline: Ask Charles Isherwood About the New Theater Season
abstract: Mr. Isherwood will answer selected questions from readers this week.
lead_paragraph: The spring theater season can be hard to pin down. Sure, Broadway’s got its share of celebrities, including Tom Hanks in “Lucky Guy” and Bette Midler in “I’ll Eat You Last: A Chat With Sue Mengers.” But there are also new plays and musicals about complex and compelling women and the worries of the working-class. Making decisions about what to see — Cinderella or Matilda? Ann Richards or the Virgin Mary? Diana Ross or drag queens? — won’t be easy.

headline: Pelfrey’s Fast Recovery Excites Twins
abstract: The former Mets pitcher Mike Pelfrey will make his spring debut Tuesday for the Twins, 10 months after Tommy John surgery. Recovery often takes at least a year.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The Mets drafted Mike Pelfrey with the ninth overall pick in the 2005 draft, and like all teams choosing that high, they hoped they were getting a star. In hindsight, a better choice would have been Andrew McCutchen, Matt Garza or Jay Bruce, who were all picked later in the first round, but Pelfrey had his moments. He won 50 games for the Mets.

headline: Have an N.H.L. Question? Slap Shot Has Answers
abstract: Jeff Z. Klein and Stu Hackel will answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: 4:48 p.m. | Updated Are the Blackhawks really this good? Are the Canadiens for real? What’s behind the Devils’ enduring success? And will any of it matter during the playoffs of a lockout-shortened season? Jeff Z. Klein, the national hockey writer for The Times, and longtime Slap Shot contributor Stu Hackel will answer questions from readers this week. Write your questions in the comments field below and answers will appear later this week on Slap Shot.Comments for this feature are closed.

headline: My Dear Michael, We’ve Discovered DNA
abstract: Writing to his son, Michael, Francis Crick tells of a “most important discovery.” (Related Article.)
lead_paragraph: Writing to his son, Michael, Francis Crick tells of a “most important discovery.” (Related Article.)

headline: The Daily Do | Gianfranco Ferré
abstract: Ferré’s double French twist felt sculptural yet undone.
lead_paragraph: Gianfranco Ferré’s double French twist felt sculptural yet undone, almost as if it had been caught in a wind tunnel.

headline: A DNA Lesson, From the Expert’s Pen
abstract: A letter from Francis Crick to his son, Michael, two weeks after solving the DNA puzzle in 1953, is the first written description of the code and is being put up for auction.
lead_paragraph: “Dear Michael, Jim Watson and I have probably made a most important discovery.”

headline: Minnesota Wins Duals Again
abstract: For the second consecutive year Minnesota defeated Iowa and Oklahoma State in the National Duals.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota wrestlers had their head coach back in their corner. And now they’ll have the National Duals championship back in their trophy case.

headline: Yahoo’s Blow to Work-Family Balance
abstract: By pulling flextime off the table, the Yahoo chief executive Marissa Mayer defies any expectation that new motherhood might make her sensitive to the needs of working families.
lead_paragraph: Yahoos.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: A selection of events for this week.
lead_paragraph: Cooking Classes and Kids

headline: H.P. and LG Put WebOS on Television
abstract: The much loved, little-used operating system is getting a new lease on life as part of futuristic televisions from a South Korean manufacturer. LG thinks it can make televisions a kind of hub for interaction with other devices. H.P. will keep operating a WebOS applications management business.
lead_paragraph: Maybe the little operating system that couldn’t will gain a new life inside televisions, cars and washing machines.

headline: Preparing Lemon Grass
abstract: The next time you come across a recipe that calls for lemon grass, don’t turn the page. Melissa Clark shows how to handle it.
lead_paragraph: The next time you come across a recipe that calls for lemon grass, don’t turn the page. Melissa Clark shows how to handle it.

headline: The Owl Comes Into Its Own
abstract: Only lately have scientists begun to understand owls in detail, and to puzzle out the subtleties of behavior, biology and sensory prowess that set them apart.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after a frigid, star-salted night spent tromping through the Alexandria woods with David Johnson of the Global Owl Project, and listening to the stridently mournful cries of wild barred owls that remained hidden from view, I stopped by the National Zoo around sunset to take visual measure of the birds I had heard.

headline: Hungry Photography
abstract: A food photographer, food bloggers and a chef offer suggestions on how to make mobile food photography more appetizing.
lead_paragraph: A food photographer, food bloggers and a chef offer suggestions on how to make mobile food photography more appetizing.

headline: Assemblyman Defends Wearing Blackface to a Party
abstract: Dov Hikind, a Democrat and a longtime power broker in the Orthodox Jewish community, wore an Afro wig and brown makeup to a party he hosted to celebrate the Jewish holiday of Purim.
lead_paragraph: A prominent state assemblyman from Brooklyn defended himself on Monday after wearing blackface to a party he hosted to celebrate the Jewish holiday of Purim, saying he did not mean to offend anyone.

headline: Vietnamese Shrimp, From Cane to Cake
abstract: Don’t let a lack of sugar cane keep you from enjoying a makeshift version of chao tom.
lead_paragraph: The hardest part about making Vietnamese shrimp on sugar cane, called chao tom, is finding the sugar cane.

headline: Making Money After the Oscars
abstract: Timescast Media+Tech: How studios and networks continue to profit after the Academy Awards. | Taking social media food photography to the next level. | NBC struggles after its ratings plunge.
lead_paragraph: Timescast Media+Tech: How studios and networks continue to profit after the Academy Awards. | Taking social media food photography to the next level. | NBC struggles after its ratings plunge.

headline: Buyout Offer Will Likely Not End Elan’s Deal Ambitions
abstract: Royalty Pharma’s $6.6 billion buyout offer is too small of a premium to tempt Elan’s management away from its own acquisition ambitions, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Royalty Pharma’s $6.6 billion indicative offer for the Elan Corporation probably won’t be enough to end the latter’s ambitious dreams. Elan has grand acquisition plans after selling most of the rights to its blockbuster drug, Tysabri, for $3.25 billion this month. Royalty Pharma may well use that cash more wisely than Elan’s management, but the 4 percent premium it offered won’t seal the deal.

headline: The Sequester, State by State
abstract: Across-the-board budget cuts will hurt all 50 states, but not equally.
lead_paragraph: The hatchet job on the federal budget commonly known as the sequester will hurt all 50 states both directly and indirectly, but it won’t hurt them equally.

headline: Really? Annoying Songs Get Stuck in Our Heads
abstract: A study found that the music people most often could not get out of their heads were songs they knew and liked (at least at first).
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: Split Vote Sends One Clear Message in Italy: No to Austerity
abstract: In elections marked by voter fury and low turnout, experts said the best-case scenario would be a shaky coalition that would again expose Italy, and the euro zone, to market turmoil.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian voters delivered a rousing anti-austerity message and a strong rebuke to the existing political order in national elections on Monday, plunging the country into political paralysis after results failed to produce a clear winner.

headline: Trusts Offer a Legal Loophole for Buying Restricted Guns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Firearms']
abstract: Shooting enthusiasts are creating legal trusts to acquire firearms whose sale is limited by federal law, a mechanism that can bypass the requirement for a criminal background check.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of shooting enthusiasts are creating legal trusts to acquire machine guns, silencers or other items whose sale is restricted by federal law — a mechanism that bypasses the need to obtain law enforcement approval or even undergo criminal background checks.

headline: Debating ‘House of Cards’ 2: How to Reap the Cable Whirlwind
abstract: “House of Cards” — the Recap. Today, Ashley Parker and David Carr take on episode two and tease apart the collaborations between the various estates in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to “House of Cards,” the Recap. Today, Ashley Parker and David Carr take on episode two and tease apart the collaborations between the various estates in Washington. Abundant spoilers so proceed at your own viewing peril. If you missed the first installment, you can read it here. More to come in the next few days and in the meantime, please consider weighing in with a comment below.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Making Money After the Oscars
abstract: How studios and networks continue to profit after the Academy Awards. Taking social media food photography to the next level. NBC struggles to recover from its ratings plunge.
lead_paragraph: How studios and networks continue to profit after the Academy Awards. Taking social media food photography to the next level. NBC struggles to recover from its ratings plunge.

headline: Taking Sides
abstract: Organs are perfectly arranged to carry out their tasks, experts say, including the asymmetrically arranged ones like the liver and heart.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why are some of our internal organs on one side rather than the other? Does anyone ever get an organ on the “wrong” side?

headline: Sigrid Agren Transforms Backstage at Jil Sander
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Lisa Butler and hair by Luigi Mureno.

headline: Through Owl Eyes; Pushing to Map the Mind; DNA Discovery in Crick’s Cursive
abstract: New science on a wise old bird, John Markoff on an effort to map the brain, and Nicholas Wade on Francis Crick’s letter to his son.
lead_paragraph: New science on a wise old bird, John Markoff on an effort to map the brain, and Nicholas Wade on Francis Crick’s letter to his son.

headline: An Out-of-Character Day-Lewis and a Characteristically Candid Lawrence
abstract: Daniel Day-Lewis says he’ll need a few years to recover from “Lincoln,” and Jennifer Lawrence explains her fall.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The pile-up of biggie awards at the end of the Oscars telecast last night meant that the major winners did not come back to be quizzed in the press room until well after the show was over. But they still had some choice comments before heading out to the parties.

headline: Connecting the Neural Dots
abstract: The Obama administration has set an ambitious goal to map the 85 to 100 billion neurons in the human brain, but scientists say they are long way from developing the necessary tools.
lead_paragraph: In setting the nation on a course to map the active human brain, President Obama may have picked a challenge even more daunting than ending the war in Afghanistan or finding common ground with his Republican opponents.

headline: Whistles May Harm Hearing, Study Shows
abstract: A study found referees were more likely to report symptoms of ringing in the ears and trouble hearing than people of the same age in the general population.
lead_paragraph: As a basketball referee in his spare time, Nathan Williams thought the whistles were unnecessarily loud.

headline: How to Prepare Lemon Grass for Cooking
abstract: Don’t turn the page if you come across a recipe that calls for lemon grass.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s column, I write about how to make Vietnamese shrimp on sugar cane without the sugar cane. My answer is to fry up the shrimp paste into cakes and serve it over rice noodles.

headline: A Healthy Diet That Includes, Yes, Chocolate
abstract: The Mediterranean diet offers some surprises along with its recommendations.
lead_paragraph: The Mediterranean diet that participants in the new study were told to follow differs in some respects from the advice people generally get about healthy eating. It allows people to eat as many nuts and eggs and even as much chocolate as they want, as long as it is chocolate with more than 50 percent cocoa. It permits unlimited consumption of fish, seafood, whole-grain cereals and low-fat cheese.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Jimmie Johnson Basks in Second Daytona 500 Victory
abstract: Johnson held off a hard charge by Dale Earnhardt Jr. and Mark Martin off the final turn.
lead_paragraph: Jimmie Johnson’s win at Daytona 500 on Sunday was his second in Nascar’s premier race; his first victory came in 2006. Johnson led only 17 of the 200 laps around the Daytona International Speedway tri-oval, but he remained out front when it mattered most, over the final 10 laps.

headline: With New Laws, a Focus on Nurturing the City’s Native Plants
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law on Monday three “green” bills, including measures on the city’s planting policy and the creation of a renewable energy portal.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law on Monday three “green” bills, one intended to increase the city’s native biodiversity.

headline: One-Upping His Dad, Josh Pettitte Throws No-Hitter
abstract: Josh Pettitte, the son of the Yankees pitcher, threw a no-hitter for his Texas high school on Friday.
lead_paragraph: He is only a senior at Deer Park (Texas) High School, but young Josh Pettitte has already earned one accomplishment in baseball his dad Andy, in 491 major league starts, has not. Last Friday, in a game against Boerne Champion High, Josh Pettitte struck out 10 batters and gave up no hits in a 9-0 victory.

headline: An Avian Tribe Apart
abstract: Scientists and bird lovers delve into the subtle and surprising world of owls.
lead_paragraph: Scientists and bird lovers delve into the subtle and surprising world of owls.

headline: Giving Voice to a Tale of Pursuit and Desire
abstract: Harry Bicket conducted the English Concert in a performance of Handel’s “Radamisto” on Sunday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable resurgence of Handel operas in the last quarter-century owes at least as much to their abundant opportunities for vocal display as to their overall musical quality, which can be spotty, or their dramatic persuasiveness, which is often feeble. So Carnegie Hall was well filled with voice aficionados on Sunday afternoon for a concert performance of Handel’s “Radamisto,” with the fine period-instrument band English Concert deftly conducted from the harpsichord by Harry Bicket.

headline: Online Piracy Alert System to Begin This Week
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: The Copyright Alert System, a program of escalating warnings against people suspected of online copyright infringement, is going into effect more than a year and a half after the plan was announced.
lead_paragraph: The Copyright Alert System, a program of escalating warnings and prods against people suspected of online copyright infringement, is finally going into effect this week, more than a year and a half after the plan was announced as part of an agreement between the entertainment industry and five major Internet service providers.

headline: Elevating the Land of Nod
abstract: Flat-bed seats for international fliers are not so special anymore. Now airlines are investing in perks like improved bedding.
lead_paragraph: Those flat-bed seats for international business-class fliers? Now that most airlines offer them, they are not so special anymore.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Letters to the editor.

headline: Scene City: After the Oscars
abstract: Vanity Fair’s must-stop party after the awards.
lead_paragraph: Vanity Fair’s must-stop party after the awards.

headline: Family Spectacle
abstract: Garrett Leight, the son of the Oliver Peoples co-founder Larry Leight, dabbled as a journalist and D.J. before starting his own line of retro optics in Venice, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Garrett Leight, the son of the Oliver Peoples co-founder Larry Leight, dabbled as a journalist and D.J. before giving in to fate in 2010 and starting his own line of retro optics in Venice, Calif. “My dad of course is my mentor from a design standpoint,” Garrett, 28, says. But while the father takes his inspiration from glamorous 1930s film stars, the son’s frames channel bespectacled rebels like Hunter S. Thompson and Charles Bukowski. In an industry where brand names seem to matter more than ever, Leight’s glasses — logo-less and hand-finished — embody understated cool.

headline: War of the Ants Intensifies in U.S.
abstract: An aggressive species is being displaced in North America by a more aggressive — and potentially dangerous — species, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: An aggressive species of ant may be losing ground in North America to a more aggressive — and potentially dangerous — species, according to a new study.

headline: Growing Wings and Rising Oceans
abstract: A look at coming events at the intersection of science and culture.
lead_paragraph: BOOK

headline: The Stars and Their Little Gold Men
abstract: Penny Marshall eats a burger; Quentin Tarantino likes Adele; Ang Lee says he needs a rest.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — It was around midnight when Ben Affleck found his little brother, Casey, near the bar. Oscar in hand, Ben, the director of the best picture winner, “Argo,” horsed around with his brother, while a jazz trio played. They posed for a few selfies as their wives, Jennifer Garner and Summer Phoenix, looked on.

headline: Benefits of DNA Testing (1 Letter)
abstract: A letter to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: American Catholicism: Decline But Not Exhaustion
abstract: The resilience of Catholic belief in an age of scandal.
lead_paragraph: Just to add some context to my exchange last week with Rod Dreher over the possibility of Catholicism’s ever exerting real influence again in late-modern America (and do read his follow-up here), these findings from a new Pew survey of American Catholics seem worth highlighting:

headline: Discord Over Scholar’s Tribal Research
abstract: An anthropologist has resigned from the National Academy of Sciences to protest the group’s decision to admit a researcher whose work he has long criticized.
lead_paragraph: The battle among scholars over an American anthropologist’s research on an Amazon tribe has spread to the National Academy of Sciences, the nation’s most prestigious scientific body.

headline: After Measles Success, Rwanda to Get Rubella Vaccine
abstract: Encouraged by Rwanda’s steady gains in curbing measles, donors are paying for a more expensive dual vaccine that will target rubella, too.
lead_paragraph: Rwanda has been so successful at fighting measles that next month it will be the first country to get donor support to move to the next stage — fighting rubella too.

headline: Heady Times for Compost Pioneers
abstract: As more cities like New York envision diverting waste from landfills to composting plants, companies see a big potential for growth.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to make a living by turning rotting food into usable compost while also helping to curb greenhouse gas emissions and reduce landfill disposal costs?

headline: Sad Day for Gotham City: Robin Will Die
abstract: Young Damian Wayne will bite the dust in issue No. 8 of “Batman Incorporated.”
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s time for Batman to consider going solo again. On Wednesday DC Comics will publish issue No. 8 of “Batman Incorporated.” The comic, written by Grant Morrison, will feature the death of Damian Wayne, the son of Bruce Wayne and the current Robin.

headline: Redefining Women’s Work
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: “Makers: Women Who Make America,” a three-hour documentary on PBS stations on Tuesday, surveys the last 50 years of the women’s movement in American history.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Steinem is the star. She always was.

headline: A Costume Too Far
abstract: New York State Assemblyman Don Hikind dressed up in blackface for a Purim party.
lead_paragraph: As Prince Harry learned a few years ago when he wore a Nazi armband to a friend’s “Colonial and Native” themed event, a costume party is no excuse for ignoring good taste and generally acting idiotic.  The prince eventually apologized, but the lessons of his faux pas apparently never reached New York State Assemblyman Dov Hikind in Brooklyn.

headline: House-Made With Niceties
abstract: The Lexington Social, where as busy as it may get, the niceties are still observed.
lead_paragraph: It was the blueberry jam that prompted the hesitation. The other ingredients in the drink called the Halley’s Comet seemed fine — Maker’s Mark, lemon, a sage leaf, nothing that a person would consider startling.

headline: For Encores, an Artist Invites Social Media Onstage
abstract: Hilary Hahn’s recital at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center included commissioned works and one from an online contest.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — An encore, of course, originally meant just that: “again.” It was the repetition of a piece that had garnered enough applause to be performed once more.

headline: With Its Eye on Infotainment, General Motors Is Upgrading OnStar
abstract: General Motors announced that it would provide 4G LTE mobile broadband connectivity in certain 2015 Chevrolet, Buick, GMC and Cadillac models.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Monday that it would provide 4G LTE mobile broadband connectivity in certain 2015 Chevrolet, Buick, GMC and Cadillac models. The broadband connection will be delivered through the AT&T system and will replace the 2G connection used by the automaker’s OnStar connectivity system.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the West Bank, Mali, Thailand and Kuwait.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the West Bank, Mali, Thailand and Kuwait.

headline: No Vitamin D and Calcium for Older Bones
abstract: A government task force formally recommended on Monday that postmenopausal women avoid taking low daily doses of vitamin D and calcium to ward off bone fractures.
lead_paragraph: A government task force formally recommended on Monday that healthy postmenopausal women avoid taking low daily doses of vitamin D and calcium to ward off bone fractures.

headline: Questions About Robotic Hysterectomy
abstract: Doctors promise that robot-assisted surgeries reduce complications and speed up recovery, but new studies show the differences with laparoscopic hysterectomy to be minimal, while the cost is significantly higher.
lead_paragraph: Ever since it was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2005, robotic surgery for hysterectomy has been heavily advertised. Surgeons promise that using the da Vinci robotic device will bring better results and an easier recovery, and many hospitals claim that patients will experience less pain and fewer complications, getting back on their feet faster.

headline: The Benefits of Olive Oil
abstract: The Times’s Gina Kolata on a study looking at a Mediterranean diet.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Gina Kolata on a study looking at a Mediterranean diet.

headline: Mapping Out the Path to Viral Fame
abstract: Jonah Berger’s new book explains what makes some ideas and products go viral, while others never gain traction.
lead_paragraph: How has the Korean pop star Psy’s wacky horse-dance video, “Gangnam Style,” managed to rack up more than 1.3 billion views on YouTube? Why did a 30-minute video by a small nonprofit group calling for the capture of the Ugandan warlord Joseph Kony become a media sensation, racing across Twitter and Facebook eventually to snag the top spot on Unruly Media’s list of the 20 most shared ads on social media in 2012?

headline: Children Toil in India’s Mines, Despite Legal Ban
abstract: Poverty, corruption and decrepit schools drive pervasive work by children in India, a problem with no better illustration than “rathole” mines in an isolated state.
lead_paragraph: KHLIEHRIAT, India — After descending 70 feet on a wobbly bamboo staircase into a dank pit, the teenage miners ducked into a black hole about two feet high and crawled 100 yards through mud before starting their day digging coal.

headline: Liquidation Authority and the Bankruptcy Clause
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Interstate Commerce', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The litigation challenging the orderly liquidation authority under the Dodd-Frank Act proceeds from the faulty notion that Chapter 11 bankruptcy provides a one-size-fits-all solution,
lead_paragraph: The litigation against the Dodd-Frank Act’s orderly liquidation authority continues, with an amended complaint filed last week, adding a few more states to the mix, and the deadlines with regard to the government’s motion to dismiss reset accordingly.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: San Quentin Entrepreneurs and Cyborg Roaches
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include an online magazine that is making a profit after one only a few month, how oil rigs may be threatened by malware, and job cuts and closings at Zynga.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: An Addendum on National Park Cuts
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Camps and Camping', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Rescues', 'Wildfires']
abstract: Automatic federal spending cuts would mean sharply reducing access to interpretive centers, campgrounds and the backcountry, the interior secretary says.
lead_paragraph: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar offered more details on Monday about how the automatic federal spending cuts set to take effect on Friday would hit national parks. With a budget cut of 5 percent, or $112 million, thousands of National Park Service employees would be furloughed and thousands more seasonal workers would not be hired, he said. That would mean sharply reducing visitor services and access to interpretive centers, campgrounds and hiking trails, he suggested.

headline: Bloodshed Before the Battle
abstract: Masks, comic-book drawings and a rock band are incorporated into a new production of “Iphigenia in Aulis” at La MaMa.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot going on in Edward Einhorn’s ambitious new adaptation of “Iphigenia in Aulis” — Puppetlike masks! Comic-book drawings! A rock band! — Euripides’ tragedy about the sacrifice of a young virgin required before the Greeks can set sail to Troy.

headline: In the Future, Everybody Will Be Commissioner for 15 Minutes
abstract: The premise of “Golden Boy,” a police drama on CBS, concerns the education of a young New York City detective who becomes commissioner in the not-too-distant future.
lead_paragraph: What is it with CBS and New York City police commissioners? It already has one, played by the 68-year-old Tom Selleck on “Blue Bloods.” On Tuesday night it adds a second, played by a British actor named Theo James (who’s 28), in the new series “Golden Boy.” It’s as if they were collecting a full set — next a middle-aged black man, then an Asian woman ...

headline: Link Eyed Between 1908 Siberian Fireball and Record Heat in New York
abstract: An amateur weather sleuth, prompted by the recent Russian meteor, turns up some surprising corollaries between the Tunguska Event of 1908 and strange weather on these shores.
lead_paragraph: Speaking of meteors and their local impact, as we were on Friday, the Siberian fireball brought the mind of Stephen Fybish, City Room’s Omniscient Weather Nudge, back to the Tunguska Event, a cosmic burp inflicted on Siberia in 1908 when the airburst of a still-unidentified object believed to be a meteor or a comet fragment flattened tens of millions of trees across 800 square miles.

headline: Skepticism Abounds as Six World Powers Resume Nuclear Talks With Iran
abstract: Since talks in Moscow last June, Iran has increased its stockpile of uranium, installed new centrifuges and has yet to complete an agreement on inspection of suspect military sites.
lead_paragraph: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — Talks between Iran and six world powers over its nuclear program resume here on Tuesday after a break of eight months, but there is a general atmosphere of gloom about their prospects for success, even if narrowly defined.

headline: Street Style: Military Inspired
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Feb. 18.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Feb. 18.

headline: Simple Only on the Surface
abstract: Despite centuries’ worth of efforts to penetrate the complicated thickets where health and beauty intertwine, there is always more to explore, as two new books make clear.
lead_paragraph: You never know what a little vanity will do for a person’s health. Some people bloom in their quest for physical improvement, others wither, and a few are completely destroyed. Despite centuries’ worth of efforts to penetrate the complicated thickets where health and beauty intertwine, there is always more to explore, as two new books make clear.

headline: Oscar Telecast Attracts 40.3 Million Viewers
abstract: The show, which featured Seth MacFarlane as host in an attempt to draw a younger audience, also did well in the 18-49 age group.
lead_paragraph: ABC’s telecast of the Oscars Sunday night didn’t get great reviews, but the ratings partly made up for it: the show attracted 40.3 million viewers, the most for any entertainment show on television in three years. Even more importantly for ABC, the audience surged among the viewers the network most wants to reach, viewers between the ages of 18 and 49.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 25
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including hair-raising drills at the N.F.L. combine.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including hair-raising drills at the N.F.L. combine.

headline: ‘The Turn of the Screw’ at BAM
abstract: New York City Opera’s updated version of Benjamin Britten’s 1954 chamber opera opened on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera’s updated version of Benjamin Britten’s 1954 chamber opera opened on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Vamped-Up Vans
abstract: Designers have remade the slip-on in leather, suede and mock croc, turning a skate-park staple into a lazy-man luxury.
lead_paragraph: Designers have remade the slip-on in leather, suede and mock croc, turning a skate-park staple into a lazy-man luxury.

headline: Accounting for 2/26 in a 9/11 Exhibition
abstract: Though there is no direct link between the ’93 and ’01 attacks on the World Trade Center, they will be treated as points on a continuum at the National September 11 Memorial Museum.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago Tuesday, a deadly calling card was left at the World Trade Center.

headline: Sneaky Dogs, a Cool Conference and More
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Science and Technology', 'Obesity', 'Medicine and Health', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Philanthropy', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news and glances at what’s ahead.
lead_paragraph: By age 14, Emily Dickinson had assembled a prodigious herbarium, a well-labeled collection of pressed flowers and plants. At the time, this was a voguish hobby. “Most all the girls are making one,” she wrote in a letter to a friend in 1845.

headline: Accusations of Anti-Semitism and Other Hosts Who’ve Crossed Lines
abstract: The Anti-Defamation League and the Simon Wiesenthal Center have issued complaints about some of the jokes in the Oscars telecast, though it’s worth remembering that jokes about religion aren’t new at the Oscars.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – As he predicted, Seth MacFarlane angered some people with his Oscar patter. Among the long list of isms that Mr. MacFarlane engaged in, perhaps the most expected was anti-Semitism. This is, after all, the guy who made a Hitler joke when he was announcing the nominees.

headline: Memo to Europe: What About T-Bills?
abstract: A transaction tax could work well for stocks, but not so well for Treasury bills
lead_paragraph: In my column on Friday, I looked at the proposed European transaction tax from a stock market perspective, and found it to be reasonable.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Golden Boy’
abstract: Theo James is an upstart detective in this new CBS series.
lead_paragraph: Theo James is an upstart detective in this new CBS series.

headline: Poltergeists Stalk a Murky Playroom
abstract: The New York City Opera interprets “The Turn of the Screw,” Britten’s ghostly chamber work, for the company’s second production of the season.
lead_paragraph: At the start of Britten’s chamber opera “The Turn of the Screw,” adapted from the Henry James novella, a character called the Prologue is supposed to stand before a lowered curtain and explain the back story. The opera, which had its premiere in 1954, tells of a Governess who comes to a country house in mid-19th-century England to care for two orphaned children.

headline: Albums From Atoms for Peace, Ana Moura and Antonio Sanchez
abstract: Reviews of new music including the album “Amok” by Atoms for Peace, “Desfado” by Ana Moura and “New Life” by Antonio Sanchez.
lead_paragraph: ATOMS FOR PEACE

headline: A Fresh Five Push Michigan Into the Title Picture
abstract: Reminiscent of the Fab Five of the early 1990s, five freshmen have helped make Michigan an N.C.A.A. tournament contender.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — The fun started last summer at the same moment Michigan basketball became cool again. It was the players’ first week together. They were spread across the gym, lounging after a scrimmage.

headline: India’s Child Labor Problem
abstract: Though a new law will mandate that children from the ages of 6 to 14 be in school, some 28 million are working instead, Unicef says.
lead_paragraph: Though a new law will mandate that children from the ages of 6 to 14 be in school, some 28 million are working instead, Unicef says.

headline: Academy Award Show Raises Ratings and Hackles
abstract: Seth MacFarlane delivered higher ratings as well as some controversy at this year’s Oscar show.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jewish, women’s and family organizations on Monday publicly flung knives at Seth MacFarlane’s off-color Oscar show. Hollywood for the most part stayed true to form and aimed its cutlery at his back.

headline: Even a Rock Star Has to Be Careful
abstract: Kelly Hansen, lead singer of Foreigner, has a No. 1 tip for air travel, regardless of the climate on the ground: a scarf.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE flown so much that most of my trips are routine. I’m either off to a concert or coming back from one. I’m actually very Zen-like when I fly. I just accept the delays since there’s nothing I can do about it. But all the travel is great because I love seeing new places and meeting new people. Or, sometimes, seeing people I’ve known for a long time.

headline: Not the Same Old Cup of British Tea
abstract: “Parade’s End,” beginning on Tuesday on HBO, looks like a lush elegy to the Edwardian age, but it’s not nearly as swoony and nostalgic as most others of the genre.
lead_paragraph: Saying that a television series depicts the English aristocracy on the brink of World War I and beyond is almost a disservice — the description sounds like yet another big Masterpiece Theater bore, or worse, an amusing one like “Downton Abbey.” “Parade’s End,” a co-production of the BBC and HBO that begins on Tuesday on HBO, looks like a lush elegy to the Edwardian age, but it’s not nearly as swoony and nostalgic as most others of the genre. Tom Stoppard adapted Ford Madox Ford’s tetralogy into a five-part series, streamlining and speeding up the story without dumbing it down.

headline: Parental Leave Policies at Some Big Technology Firms
abstract: Facebook’s benefits for new parents include $4,000 in “baby cash” per child.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Facebook’s chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, made waves with an interview about her new book, “Lean In,” which encourages women to take more responsibility for their own career advancement.

headline: A British Mainstay Current Beyond His Years
abstract: A program of six works by Frederick Ashton, the Royal Ballet’s founding choreographer, shows surprising freshness.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In his prime, the choreographer Frederick Ashton (1904-88) seemed a pillar of the British establishment. The founding choreographer of the Royal Ballet, he was honored by, and was a friend of, the royal family. Although he was certainly a master, some of his ballets appeared dated in his lifetime, and few appeared radical.

headline: Senate Committee Said to End ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ Inquiry
abstract: According to a news report, the Senate Intelligence Committee is no longer looking into the Central Intelligence Agency’s cooperation with the filmmakers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Citing an unnamed Congressional aide, the Reuters news service on Monday reported that the Senate Intelligence Committee had ended its inquiry into Central Intelligence Agency cooperation with makers of the film “Zero Dark Thirty.” The investigation began after three Senators—Dianne Feinstein, Carl Levin and John McCain—publicly objected to what they saw as the film’s incorrect portrayal of torture as having helped in the hunt for Osama Bin Laden. Those objections came at the height of an Oscar campaign that closed on Sunday with no major awards for “Zero Dark Thirty,” which was nominated for best picture and had once been seen as a strong contender. According to Reuters, the investigation was closed on Monday after it had gathered material indicating that C.I.A. officials did not actually tell the filmmakers that torture helped to find Bin Laden, though they helped in the development of the film’s characters.

headline: China: 2 Tibetan Monks Carry Out Fatal Protests
abstract: Two Tibetan monks have died in separate self-immolation protests in Tibetan regions of western China since Sunday, according to reports on Monday by two Tibet advocacy groups.
lead_paragraph: Two Tibetan monks have died in separate self-immolation protests in Tibetan regions of western China since Sunday, according to reports on Monday by two Tibet advocacy groups. Phagmo Dundrup, in his early 20s, set himself on fire at the Chachung Monastery in Qinghai Province on Sunday, according to a report by International Campaign for Tibet, a group based in Washington. On Monday, Tsesung Kyab, in his late 20s, set himself on fire outside the main temple of Shitsang Gonsar Monastery in Gansu Province. He was a relative of Pema Dorjee, 23, who carried out a similar protest at the same monastery last year. Since 2009, at least 106 Tibetans have set themselves on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibet. Most have died.

headline: Russia: Putin Signs Law to Ban Most Public Smoking
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has signed a law to ban smoking in most public places, the Kremlin announced Monday.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin has signed a law to ban smoking in most public places, the Kremlin announced Monday. The ban will be phased in starting June 1. Nearly 40 percent of Russian adults smoke, the World Health Organization says, and related health care costs are estimated to run nearly $50 billion a year. Cigarettes generally cost $1 to $2 a pack, and, by volume, Russia is the second-largest cigarette market in the world after China. The law, signed on Saturday, will ban smoking near the entrances of subway and railroad stations, and ultimately in restaurants, cafes, hotels, government buildings, universities and stadiums. It will also raise taxes on cigarettes and other forms of tobacco, restrict tobacco advertising and prohibit cigarette sales by street-side kiosks. Many kiosk owners say the law, coupled with a new ban on beer sales at kiosks, could put them out of business.

headline: Italy: Prosecutors Request Indictments for Cruise Ship Captain
abstract: Italian prosecutors on Monday asked a judge to issue an indictment on manslaughter charges for the captain of the luxury liner Costa Concordia that ran aground in January 2012 off the Tuscan coast.
lead_paragraph: Italian prosecutors on Monday asked a judge to issue an indictment on manslaughter charges for the captain of the luxury liner Costa Concordia that ran aground in January 2012 off the Tuscan coast, an accident that claimed the lives of 32 people. The prosecutors also want to try the captain, Francesco Schettino, on charges of causing a shipwreck and abandoning the vessel before its 4,229 passengers and crew members were safe. In addition, the prosecutors requested that five crew members be tried on manslaughter charges. The judge will rule in the coming months on whether to accept the indictment requests. Costa Cruises, accused of administrative offenses related to the charges against its employees, is trying to reach a plea-bargain agreement with prosecutors. A settlement could cost the company more than $1 million.

headline: Weapons From the Former Yugoslavia Spread Through Syria’s War
abstract: YouTube has been instrumental in allowing analysts to follow the influx of weapons previously unseen in the Syrian conflict.
lead_paragraph: The use of social media by opposition groups and activists in Syria has allowed those of us who follow these sources carefully to pursue a different form of insight into conflict reporting than had been possible before the time when opposition fighters reflexively videotaped their operations and posted them online. With hundreds of videos showing the activities of fighting groups now posted on YouTube each day, external analysts have been allowed to build a picture of events in Syria that in past wars have gone unrecorded. These videos, often shared via Twitter and Facebook, allowed analysts and arms spotters in 2012 to track almost in real time the escalation in the conflict on both sides, including the use of cluster bombs and incendiary bombs, as well as potential war crimes committed by the government and the opposition alike.

headline: Are We in Danger of a Beer Monopoly?
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: Contrary to popular belief, mergers are usually really good for consumers. So what’s wrong with a little beer marriage?
lead_paragraph: Every day, the Web site BeerPulse tries to list every single new beer available in the United States. And that’s harder than you might imagine. Recently, the site posted Cigar City’s Jamonera Belgian-style Porter, Odell Tree Shaker Imperial Peach IPA, as well as a rye lager, a cherry blossom lager and a barley wine. And the list goes on, and on. In 1978, there were 89 breweries in the United States; at the beginning of this year, there were 2,336, with an average of one new brewery per day. Most of them are tiny, but a handful, like Sam Adams and Sierra Nevada, have become large national brands. At the same time, sales of Budweiser in the United States have dropped for 25 consecutive years.

headline: Critiquing a Web Site That Tries to Keep It Simple
abstract: Larger companies are reluctant to sign up for Recruiterbox’s service without considerable hand-holding. Can the company afford to provide it?
lead_paragraph: It sounds easy. Sell your product online. Design it to tempt every visitor into becoming a buyer. Add an easy-to-use self-service interface that lets customers get answers without interacting with a salesclerk. Everything seems to happen magically, and everything goes smoothly, without any issues. There may be businesses that manage to accomplish this, but rarely without a few struggles. In this post, we look at one company, Recruiterbox, and its attempt to attract customers and interact with them seemlessly.
