headline: Table Talk | Le 6 Paul Bert
abstract: On a short, quiet street in the 11th Arrondissement, a modern bistro has emerged, offering comfort food with a cosmopolitan spin.
lead_paragraph: If you think French food has lost its laurels, next trip to Paris, head for the rue Paul Bert. Thanks to the shrewd and very amiable restaurateur Bertrand Auboyneau, this short, quiet street in the 11th Arrondissement offers a full house of addresses that will prove you wrong. The mother ship is Le Bistrot Paul Bert (No. 18), which has become an internationally renowned cult favorite for being the bistro that’s been ticking all the boxes on what the whole world thinks a Paris bistro should be ever since it opened some 10 years ago — we’re talking a gorgeous flea-market interior, great traditional French grub, a terrific wine list and service with just enough pouty posing attitude to let you know you’re in Paris. Then there’s the superb Ecailler du Bistrot (No. 22), which tips its hand to show why Paris is the best city in Europe for seafood lovers — it pulls in the best of France’s small boat catch daily, and the oysters come directly from the bivalve park of Auboyneau’s wife’s family in Brittany.

headline: The Gun Report: February 26, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: We continue to get complaints that our anecdotal approach overstates gun violence in comparison to other forms of death and injury, such as, you know, slipping in the bathtub. But yesterday, ProPublica published an interview with Dr. Mark Rosenberg, who led the Centers for Disease Control’s gun violence research until 1996, when Congress cut its funding after intense NRA lobbying. Before the funding was cut, Dr. Rosenberg said, the CDC’s research showed that “not only did having a firearm in your home not protect you, but it hugely increased the risk that someone in your family would die from a firearm homicide” by almost 300 percent. Having a gun in the home also raised the risk five-fold that someone in your household would commit suicide.

headline: A Musical Pitch to Albany to Raise Minimum Wage
abstract: In a video on YouTube, restaurant workers stacking dishes, shaking drinks, chopping onions and plating burritos take a moment to lip-sync and dance along to the 1959 Motown hit “Money (That’s What I Want).”
lead_paragraph: As the battle over whether to raise the minimum wage heats up in Albany, some laborers are pressing their case in a musical fashion.

headline: Did Democrats Get Lucky in the Electoral College?
abstract: The tendency of Democrats to cluster in urban areas has harmed them in the House of Representatives, but not in the Electoral College.
lead_paragraph: President Obama won the Electoral College fairly decisively last year despite a margin of just 3.8 percentage points in the national popular vote. In fact, Mr. Obama would probably have won the Electoral College even if the popular vote had slightly favored Mitt Romney. The “tipping-point state” in the election — the one that provided Mr. Obama with his decisive 270th electoral vote — was Colorado, which Mr. Obama won by 5.4 percentage points. If all states had shifted toward Mr. Romney by 5.3 percentage points, Mr. Obama would still have won Colorado and therefore the Electoral College — despite losing the national popular vote by 1.5 points.

headline: Comparing Asia’s Giants, China and India, on Rape
abstract: In today’s Female Factor Letter I explore rape in China and India, two Asian giants that more often are compared on population size and economic growth.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Women in China experience less sexual harassment in public places than women in India, two Asian nations with similar sized populations and fast economic growth which I compare, in terms of rape, in today’s Female Factor Letter.

headline: A Warning on Abuses of Shareholder Power
abstract: Martin Lipton, a top corporate lawyer, criticizes a hedge fund manager’s battle with Apple over its huge cash hoard. | A March confirmation hearing appears likely for Mary Jo White, the nominee to lead the S.E.C. | The nominee for Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, has sought to shore up support in Washington. | A federal appeals court will hear the case on Argentina’s debt.
lead_paragraph: The effort by the hedge fund manager David Einhorn to press Apple to return some of its huge cash hoard to shareholders did not sit well with Martin Lipton, one of the nation’s top corporate lawyers. In a scathing memorandum to clients, Mr. Lipton wrote: “The activist-hedge-fund attack on Apple — in which one of the most successful, long-term-visionary companies of all time is being told by a money manager that Apple is doing things all wrong and should focus on short-term return of cash — is a clarion call for effective action to deal with the misuse of shareholder power.”

headline: Nature, Re-engineered to Meet Energy Needs

lead_paragraph: Thousands of inventors, engineers and entrepreneurs gathered in a suburban Washington convention center on Monday for the annual three-day meeting of Arpa-E, the Advanced Research Projects Agency – Energy. It wasn’t quite the Oscars. At the registration desk, attendees received a goody bag that included a report on clean energy from the Pew Charitable Trusts and a refrigerator magnet that showed the periodic table of the elements.

headline: Slow Time Could Be a Real Problem
abstract: Columnists interpreted Notre Dame linebacker Manti Te’o’s 4.82 in the 40-yard dash as another blow to his draft stock.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the N.F.L. scouting combine is filled with coaches and personnel gurus who gather with their stopwatches and amateur psychology degrees and nod while the medical folks send every suspicious pinkie toe to the magnetic resonance imaging test machine for a look-see. Normally, this all only borders on the absurd. This year, thanks to Manti Te’o and his iffy grasp on reality, it took the express train to the heart of Absurdistan.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Bid to Privatize Barnes & Noble Stores, and a Magazine Merger’s Culture Clash
abstract: A possible bid for Barnes & Noble’s brick-and-mortar stores raises the company’s stock price, the merger of Time Inc. titles with Meredith Corporation could cause friction and liqueur makes its Oscar debut.
lead_paragraph: Leonard S. Riggio, Barnes & Noble’s 71-year-old chairman, is preparing a bid to buy the company’s 689 stores that would save them from a risky future in public markets, Michael J. de la Merced writes. The move would effectively separate the retail arm from Nook Media, the company’s struggling e-book division, although it seems probable that Nook devices would still be featured in the stores. Analysts thought the deal made sense only if Mr. Riggio paid a low price for the legacy stores, which analysts valued between $484.5 million to more than $1 billion. Investors appeared sanguine Monday, as Barnes & Noble shares jumped 11.5 percent, to $15.06.

headline: How the Bagger’s Predictions Worked Out

lead_paragraph: The Bagger has trouble with self-promotion (and also with referring to herself in the third person). Entertainment Weekly and The Hollywood Reporter tied for first. (See our ballot here. If only we’d gone with our gut on the short documentary category, we’d be No. 1!)

headline: Beware of Investments Promoted as ‘Just Like a C.D.’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Certificates of Deposit', 'Government Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The answer to the double whammy of investment losses in 2008-9 and low interest rates now on savings accounts is not some dubious new product.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: A Trimmer Trunk
abstract: Orlebar Brown’s swimwear designs provide alternatives to loud surf Jams and ill-fitting board shorts.
lead_paragraph: Between loud surf Jams and ill-fitting board shorts, American guys too often err when it comes to beachside style. Adam Brown, the British designer behind the culty swimwear brand Orlebar Brown, offers a corrective. His classic trunks — trimly tailored with a fixed waist and adjustable side tabs — come in three decreasingly daring lengths: the thigh-exposing Setter, as modeled by Daniel Craig in the most recent Bond flick (here in the new-for-spring Fiorentina print by the late designer David Hicks); the midlength Bulldog, for shyer sorts; and the Dane, a slimmed-down board short that marries Old World prudery with a New World fit.

headline: Benedict XVI to Be Known as Emeritus in Retirement
abstract: The Vatican spokesman, Rev. Federico Lombardi, told reporters that the pope would dress in a simple white cassock and no longer wear the papal red shoes.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI will keep the name Benedict XVI and become the Roman pontiff emeritus or pope emeritus, the Vatican announced on Tuesday, putting an end to days of speculation on how the pope will be addressed once he ceases to be the leader of the world’s 1.1 billion Roman Catholics on Thursday.

headline: Fantasies of Presidential Will
abstract: What does “exercising leadership” mean?
lead_paragraph: Greg Sargent is rightly disturbed by the latest meme in the effort to make the sequester a bipartisan failure. Pundits acknowledge that Republicans are being intransigent, while Obama has been willing to make concessions — but it’s nonetheless Obama’s fault, because he should be “exercising leadership”, whatever that means.

headline: Right to Marry
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Margaret Hoover, a Republican strategist, speaks about why she wants her party to support gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Hoover, a Republican strategist, speaks about why she wants her party to support gay marriage.

headline: Morrissey Cancels TV Performance, Citing ‘Animal Serial Killers’
abstract: The singer canceled an appearance on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” because he considers the other guests, stars of the reality series “Duck Dynasty,” to be “animal serial killers.”
lead_paragraph: Morrissey has canceled an appearance on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on Tuesday because he considers the other guests, stars of the reality series “Duck Dynasty,” to be “animal serial killers.” Morrissey, the singer and former leader of the Smiths, is a well-known animal-rights activist and vegetarian. His views on killing ducks for sport are pretty far from the bushy-bearded duck-hunting gang on “Duck Dynasty,” who manufacture calls and other gear for hunters.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Skipping 12th Grade
abstract: An educator says the senior year of high school is often wasteful and could be optional. Readers are invited to respond.

lead_paragraph: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

headline: Senate Panel Backs Treasury Choice
abstract: The Finance Committee approved Jacob J. Lew’s nomination, dismissing some Republican objections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - The Senate Finance Committee, dismissing some Republican objections, on Tuesday approved the nomination of Jacob J. Lew for Treasury secretary and sent it on to the full Senate for a confirmation vote in the days ahead.

headline: Nides Rejoins Morgan Stanley From State Dept.
abstract: Morgan Stanley has announced that Thomas R. Nides, who served as its chief operating officer until early 2011, will return as a vice chairman.
lead_paragraph: A former top Morgan Stanley official is coming back to the firm, after a two-year stint at the State Department under Hillary Rodham Clinton.

lead_paragraph: Sheryl Stolberg reported in the Times today that 75 prominent and fairly prominent Republicans are sending the Supreme Court a legal brief arguing that it should strike down California’s Proposition 8, which revoked the right of marriage to Californians who want to marry people of the same sex.

lead_paragraph: Federal immigration officials have released hundreds of detainees from detention centers around the country in recent days in a highly unusual effort to save money as automatic budget cuts loom in Washington, officials said Tuesday.

abstract: A 5-4 decision saying the plaintiffs lacked standing to sue over monitoring of international phone calls and e-mails illustrated how hard it is to mount court challenges to a wide array of antiterrorism measures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday turned back a challenge to a federal law that broadened the government’s power to eavesdrop on international phone calls and e-mails.

lead_paragraph: Virginia residents, ahead of President Obama’s visit to Newport News, are getting ready for possible spending cuts.

abstract: Her departure comes one day after ABC hired Jeff Zeleny, one of the newspaper’s best-known political correspondents, to be the network’s senior Washington correspondent.

headline: Roasted Carrots and Scallions With Thyme and Hazelnuts
abstract: Toasted hazelnuts add a crunchy texture and nutty finish to this dish.
lead_paragraph: I bought incredibly sweet, thick red scallions and multicolored bunches of carrots from a farmer at my market and roasted them with fresh thyme. Then I sprinkled on some crushed toasted hazelnuts, which contributed a nice crunchy texture and nutty finish to the dish. If you have a bottle of hazelnut oil or walnut oil on hand, a small drizzle just before serving is a welcome touch.

headline: Snowbirds

lead_paragraph: The Mulhouse Zoo in Alsace, France, was blanketed by a large snowstorm last month that gave some of its 1,200 animals a stunning white backdrop.

headline: On Our Radar: BP’s Gulf Spill Inquiry
abstract: A witness testifies that the oil company did not look at systemic problems that led to the 2010 spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: BP’s internal investigation of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill examined the direct cause of a rig blowout but ignored decisions that managers made leading up to the accident, a witness testifies in federal court in New Orleans. The witness, an engineering professor at Berkeley, was testifying on behalf of the plaintiffs in civil litigation against the oil giant. [The Wall Street Journal]

headline: Daily Variety, No Longer a Top Star, to Be Closed

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Daily Variety is dead. Long live Variety?

headline: Lhota, Hunting for Votes on Staten Island, Discusses Possibility of Deer Hunt
abstract: As wild deer run across Staten Island, Joseph Lhota, the former Metropolitan Transportation Authority chief and a mayoral hopeful, becomes ensnared by the topic.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:31 p.m. | After the publication of this post, City Room spoke to Joseph J. Lhota directly. He said that, contrary to the impression arising from the article in The Staten Island Advance, he did not support the legalization of hunting deer with bow and arrow on Staten Island and did not say or imply that he did when he spoke to The Advance’s reporter on Monday.

headline: Lexus Ranked No. 1 on Consumer Reports Annual Report Card

headline: Seth MacFarlane Says He Won’t Return as Host

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – It’s official: Seth MacFarlane will not be gracing the Oscar stage with his singing, dancing, overcompensatingly macho routine again.

headline: Hagel Approved for Defense in Sharply Split Senate Vote
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A narrow victory for Chuck Hagel, confirmed as defense secretary, raised questions about whether he would arrive a diminished leader as the Pentagon faces cuts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate confirmed Chuck Hagel as defense secretary on Tuesday after he survived a bruising struggle with Republicans. At the same time,President Obama’s nominee to be Treasury secretary moved closer to approval with bipartisan support, suggesting that the Republican blockade against the administration’s second-term nominees was beginning to ease.

abstract: Inside the new restaurant in the West Village, inspired by the chef’s German and Italian roots.
lead_paragraph: Inside the new restaurant in the West Village, inspired by the chef’s German and Italian roots.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Faced with bloated balance sheets and efforts to cut back on lending, the Continent’s largest financial institutions offer enticing opportunities for leading firms. But the banks aren’t playing ball just yet, top private equity executives indicated at the Super Returns conference in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN – Private equity is circling Europe’s banks.

headline: The Family Tree Spans a Border
abstract: Half of Harold Dieterle’s menu is inspired by his father’s German roots. The other half draws from the Italian cuisine of his mother and her relatives.
lead_paragraph: We have our swamis of salumi in New York restaurants, our chieftains of charcuterie, our sultans of sausage. But where are the wizards of wurst? Who will carry the flag for the multitude of cured and smoked meats that flourish in the German-speaking lands?

headline: Travel Sites Jump Onto the iPad
abstract: People buy items at rates higher on tablets than they do on smartphones, a trend that has made travel booking sites sit up and take notice.
lead_paragraph: After work, people who are finally untethered from the desktops they’ve been using all day creep back online for a second shift using tablets, a trend borne out by usage figures that comScore released in a report this month. And once on their iPads, people buy items at rates higher than they do on smartphones.

headline: An Aquarium in Brooklyn Will Partly Reopen in Spring
abstract: About half of the aquarium, which has been closed since being inundated by the storm surge from Hurricane Sandy, is to be open in the late spring.
lead_paragraph: The New York Aquarium in Brooklyn, which was closed after being inundated by the storm surge from Hurricane Sandy in the fall, will partly reopen in the late spring.

lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla.

headline: Tinder, a Dating App With a Difference
abstract: A new mobile dating application called Tinder appears to be taking off among college students for its simple and flirty interface. Its founders say the application is downloaded more than 20,000 times each day.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Tinder, a new mobile dating application, doesn’t seem much different from the dozens of other dating apps that are already out there, promising to help you meet nearby singles.

headline: Guest Post | Five Key Elements for a New Model of Apprenticeship
abstract: The writer Robert Greene retools the ancient idea of apprenticeship to suggest five ways for young people to succeed in their chosen fields today.
lead_paragraph: We invited Robert Greene, author of “Mastery,” to be a guest writer on the blog for us. His specialty, in this book and in previous ones like “The 48 Laws of Power” and “The 33 Strategies of War,” is to analyze the lives and philosophies of historical figures from Darwin to Michelangelo to Henry Ford to determine what causes certain people to excel, or become masters in their chosen field.

headline: Cablevision Sues Viacom in Battle Over Bundling of Channels
abstract: Cablevision sued Viacom, the owner of MTV and Nickelodeon, saying that the company violated antitrust law by bundling those big channels with barely known ones like Tr3s and Palladia.
lead_paragraph: 7:52 p.m. | Updated To all the cable customers who have ever wondered, “Why am I paying so much money for channels I never watch?” Cablevision has an answer: it’s Viacom’s fault.

abstract: The average cash bonus for people employed in New York City in the financial industry rose by roughly 9 percent, to $121,900, in 2012, the New York State comptroller said.
lead_paragraph: 7:39 p.m. | Updated

headline: At Trial, Officer’s Friend Recalls Abduction Threat
abstract: A witness testifies that she was warned that the defendant, Officer Gilberto Valle, planned to sell her into “white slavery.”
lead_paragraph: She had been friends with the New York police officer since their college days in Maryland, and they kept in touch mostly through text messages over the years. So when she was warned of his bizarre threat against her, she said, she immediately dismissed it.

headline: Candidate Who Backs Gun Control Wins Race
abstract: Gun control became a major issue in the race, and a “super PAC” formed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent heavily in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Riding a wave of “super PAC” spending that helped catapult her to the front of a crowded Democratic field, Robin Kelly, whose campaign called for tougher national gun laws, clinched her party’s nomination Tuesday in a special primary election for the House seat vacated by Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr.

headline: Are Body and Sex Education Books for Parents, or Kids?
abstract: Books written for teenagers and preteens about puberty sell — but are they actually read?
lead_paragraph: “The Care and Keeping of You: The Body Book for Girls” has just been updated and reissued, along with a companion book, “The Care and Keeping of You 2: The Body Book for Older Girls.”

headline: Memories of Floating Over Luxor, Now Tinged With the Macabre
abstract: A family hardly thought about danger when they booked a balloon ride, a staple of Luxor vacations. Less than two months later, a crash on one of those very balloons killed at least 18.
lead_paragraph: My 5-year-old son spent the entire hot-air balloon ride over Luxor, Egypt, crouched in the bottom of the basket, terrified of the flames that kept shooting into the balloon — the flames that produced the hot air that kept us afloat. He missed the glorious views: of the ancient ruins and the quilts of green grass, of the magnificent sunrise and the dancing shadows it created out of the dozens of other hot-air balloons with which we shared the early-morning sky.

headline: Schwab Promotes Lower Cost of Its Index-Only 401(k)
abstract: The reduced cost of the index-only funds are partly offset, though, by a fee for individual investment advice.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Charles Schwab began offering an index-fund-only 401(k) option for companies seeking a lower-cost retirement savings option for employees. Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, has written about the benefits of retirement plans that offer more index fund choices because the funds have lower investment management costs than actively managed funds. That generally means the employee keeps more retirement savings.

headline: ‘You’ve Got African-Americans, You’ve Got Hispanics’
abstract: The Supreme Court rejects a nasty case, with prejudice.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court almost never says why it refuses to take a case. On Monday, however, when the court denied a petition from the man convicted in Calhoun v. United States, Justice Sonia Sotomayor, joined by Justice Stephen Breyer, issued a rare explanatory statement.

headline: Apple Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Over App Purchases by Children
abstract: Apple has agreed to reimburse parents whose children purchased virtual goods in mobile apps without the parents’ knowledge. Apple and the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against the company in 2011 last week asked a judge to approve a settlement over such unauthorized “in-app purchases.”
lead_paragraph: Apple has agreed to reimburse parents whose children purchased virtual goods in mobile apps without the parents’ knowledge.

headline: Intel’s Big Data Push
abstract: The world’s largest maker of semiconductors has released its own version of an open source database designed for Big Data analysis, meant for easy use by mainstream companies.
lead_paragraph: As its mainstay business of equipping personal computers slows down, the Intel Corporation is scrambling for new ways to kick-start semiconductor sales. The company has financed development of new kinds of laptops, an effort that has been unsuccessful so far, and invested in Internet-based television. Now the chip maker is eyeing the boom in Big Data.

headline: Foils for the Heat

lead_paragraph: I love the vibrant freshness and balance of Vietnamese food. The characteristic herbal flavors and mild chile heat place it among the easier Asian cuisines to enjoy with wine.

headline: Cheap Bus Fare Lures Riders Despite Company’s Troubles
abstract: Passengers shrugged off concerns about Fung Wah Bus Transportation, a popular Chinatown bus line, though its fleet was ordered off the road because of safety problems.
lead_paragraph: For the dozens of people milling about on a sidewalk of Canal Street in Manhattan on Tuesday afternoon, reports that a popular Chinatown bus line was being shut down were drowned out by the siren song of a $15 fare to Boston.

lead_paragraph: Second floor: women’s shoes. Third floor: men’s suits. Sixth floor: prosecco, wood-oven pizzas, beef short ribs with polenta and Florentine gelato.

headline: ‘In America, You Have a Right to Be Stupid,’ Kerry Says in Defense of Free Speech
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: During a meeting with young Germans in Berlin on Tuesday, Secretary of State John Kerry explained just how far the limits of tolerance extend in blunt terms.
lead_paragraph: In a robust defense of free speech during a meeting with young Germans in Berlin on Tuesday, Secretary of State John Kerry explained just how far the limits of tolerance extend in blunt terms. “In America,” the country’s top diplomat explained, “you have a right to be stupid.”

headline: A Family Meal, With Your Peers
abstract: Think cooking for a big family can be stressful? What if the “family” is 50 of your restaurant colleagues?
lead_paragraph: Saying a little prayer to the gods of thermodynamics, I peered over my enormous vat of water, potatoes floating inside, and willed it to boil. Calm as a frozen lake.

headline: From Boehner, a Salty Demand That the Senate Act on Spending Cuts
abstract: House Speaker John A. Boehner used colorful language as he pressed Senate Democrats to pass some sort of alternative to the $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts set to go into effect on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner said in no uncertain terms Tuesday morning that he expected the Senate to pass some sort of alternative to the $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts set to go into effect on Friday before the House would take any more action.

headline: Chinese Intellectuals Urge Ratifying Rights Treaty
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Treaties']
abstract: More than 100 scholars, journalists, lawyers and writers signed a petition in the latest challenge from intellectuals seeking to curtail arbitrary Communist Party power.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — More than 100 Chinese scholars, journalists, lawyers and writers urged their national legislature on Tuesday to ratify a major human rights treaty, in the latest challenge from intellectuals seeking to curtail arbitrary Communist Party power.

headline: Measuring Your Health With Jawbone’s Up
abstract: The Up band, from Jawbone, is an electronic bracelet that measures your activity, what you eat and how much you sleep. It can help you develop a healthier lifestyle and stick to it.
lead_paragraph: The Up band, made by Jawbone, is an electronic bracelet that helps you log your activities, eating and rest, and it can record an awful lot of data. But the more detailed the data you want, the more work you’ll have to do to get it.

headline: Hidden After Offending, Mural at a State Office Is Back, for Peeks Only
abstract: “The Genius of America,” installed in a New York State building decades ago but later hidden after objections to its depiction of a slave, can now be seen on a limited basis.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — For the last decade or so, one of New York’s most curious and controversial pieces of public art has been hiding, Oz-like, behind a big green curtain.

headline: Next, 4-D Printers?
abstract: Just as 3-D printers catch on, the idea of 4-D printers is advanced. The fourth dimension is time — as in the space-time continuum described by the mathematician Hermann Minkowski early in the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Now that the promise of 3-D printing has landed on the national agenda, researchers want to increase the stakes — with so-called 4-D printing.

headline: Can You Say Hamantaschen?
abstract: The traditional Purim pastry can be prepared anytime.
lead_paragraph: Purim may be over, but it’s never a bad time to make hamantaschen, the triangular pastries that are traditionally eaten during the Jewish holiday. The Jewish cooking expert Joan Nathan demonstrates how to make them from scratch, filling and all, for Tablet Magazine. As she bakes, she dispenses her wry cooking commentary: “It’s mostly butter. How can that be bad?” says Ms. Nathan, who has also written about her cooking for The New York Times, as you can see here and here.

headline: ‘The Velocity of Autumn’ Set for Arena Stage
abstract: Eric Coble’s play, which was to come to Broadway this spring, is part of Arena’s 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: Eric Coble’s play “The Velocity of Autumn,” which had been announced for a spring opening on Broadway only to be postponed last week, will be part of the 2013-14 season at Arena Stage in Washington, the theater announced on Tuesday. Set to run Sept. 6 to Oct. 20, the production will star the Oscar winner Estelle Parsons and the Tony winner Stephen Spinella, and will be directed by Molly Smith, the Arena’s artistic director. All three had been announced for the show’s Broadway production.

lead_paragraph: Alarms sounded and lights flashed as control panel dials at a nuclear power plant in upstate New York warned that the power for safety equipment was failing. The room went dark until the emergency lights kicked in. But there was no reason to worry on this frozen winter morning.

headline: Italian Deadlock Rekindles Anxiety About Euro Zone

lead_paragraph: ROME — The political gridlock in Italy revives a question that hasn’t been heard lately: Is the euro zone crisis really over?

headline: App Smart Extra: More Slide Show Apps
abstract: Sifting through the many apps for mobile devices that can create photo slide shows.
lead_paragraph: Last week in App Smart I talked about the many apps that promise to turn photos from your smartphone or tablet’s digital photo album into an attractive photo slide show. These apps make looking at digital photos of a vacation, or perhaps an event like a wedding, into the modern equivalent of flipping through a photo album.
