lead_paragraph: We weren’t very far into “Little House on the Prairie” when it hit me: Ma was kind of a bummer.

headline: Tough Truths from China on CO2 and Climate
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A top Chinese climate policy official does the math showing why China will not be sharply cutting greenhouse gas emissions any time soon.
lead_paragraph: I’m way overdue to post excerpts here from an extraordinary recent China Dialogue with Zou Ji, the deputy director of China’s National Center for Climate Change Strategy. (China Dialogue is a fascinating independent dual-language blog with offices in London, Beijing and San Francisco that is supported by several foundations and other institutions.)

headline: A Really Horrible Boss Gets His Just Deserts
abstract: In a modernization of Lope de Vega’s “Fuenteovejuna” at Repertorio Español, oppressed office workers rise up against their tyrannical overlord.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, when the boss starts raping and pillaging in the office, the grunts just have to beat him to death with a calculator.

headline: Study Sees More Breast Cancer at Young Age
abstract: Statistics show that the number of women ages 25 to 39 with advanced breast cancer has increased slightly over the last 30 years, but researchers said the finding still needs to be verified.
lead_paragraph: The incidence of advanced breast cancer among younger women, ages 25 to 39, may have increased slightly over the last three decades, according to a study released Tuesday.

headline: Hilltop Town, a Host to Popes for Centuries, Prepares for an Eminent Retiree
abstract: Castel Gandolfo, for centuries the summer residence of popes, will receive Benedict XVI on Thursday, the last day of his papacy.
lead_paragraph: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy — This cramped hilltop town outside Rome is in its final preparations for the arrival on Thursday afternoon of an honored guest: Pope Benedict XVI, who will commence his new life as pope emeritus, one of the titles by which he will be known.

headline: The Pacers Pick It Up
abstract: Indiana has been known for its defense for years; now, the offense has become potent and the Pacers look like contenders.
lead_paragraph: Heading into this N.B.A. season, much of the Eastern Conference discussion revolved around one question: Which team, if any, could challenge the Miami Heat’s supremacy?

headline: A Report Card for Global Food Giants
abstract: Oxfam assigns grades in areas like land and water use, the treatment of small farmers and greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: The antipoverty group Oxfam has come up with a scorecard that evaluates the impact that the supply chains of behemoth food companies have on water consumption, labor and wages, greenhouse gas emissions and nutrition.

headline: After the Flood, Drying Off the Classics and Letting Them Fly
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company, which lost many original sets and costumes to Hurricane Sandy, revised some classic works at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy was hard on the Martha Graham Dance Company. In the West Village basement where most of its sets and costumes were stored, floodwaters nearly reached the ceiling. But this is a troupe driven by its mission to preserve masterpieces, and so sets were refurbished and costumes remade, and in the company’s current season at the Joyce Theater most of the important things look as good as they did before the deluge.

headline: Dolan Says Papal Conclave Should Be Occasion of Repentance
abstract: Before leaving for Rome, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan told his clergy and staff at a small service that there were many public reminders of “how much we need contrition, repentance, conversion of heart.”
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan spent the final morning before his departure to Rome to help select the next pope presiding over an intimate service with his clergy and staff in Manhattan on Tuesday, asking them for their prayers and telling them that he hoped the papal conclave would be an occasion of repentance for the church, its cardinals and its faithful.

headline: Heading to Portugal for the Algarve Cup
abstract: Our intrepid blogger is getting ready for a return to the U.S. national team and the Algarve Cup in Portugal.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — My first article for the Goal blog was posted on Feb. 9, 2010 and titled, “I’m Going to Portugal With the U.S. Women’s National Team.” As I read over my thoughts before heading to the Algarve Cup (the same tournament for which I am about to depart) not so long ago, I was taken aback by how these past three years have shaped me as a professional soccer player and changed my perspective about what I do every day.

headline: Revisiting ‘The Group’ by Mary McCarthy
abstract: Big City Book Club: This evening, from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. Eastern time, we will be discussing “The Group,” Mary McCarthy’s 1963 novel about an octet of Vassar graduates set loose on New York and the world.
lead_paragraph: 9:30 p.m. | Updated  Our live discusion about ‘The Group’ has concluded. You can find the conversation here.

headline: Instagram Your Local Escapes
abstract: Submit your photos to our gallery using the hashtag #NYTvoyage.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday we will publish our Voyages Issue, which includes photographs and articles from around the world. But we are also interested in travels closer to home — the nearby treasures that you can find over, say, a long lunch break. On Thursday, we will feature a gallery of Instagrams submitted both by readers and the photographers we assigned; we will continue adding new photos until Monday, March 4. Share your photos with us starting now by tagging them on Instagram with #NYTvoyage, and include in the caption a description of where the picture was taken and how far it is from your home. It needn’t be the biggest waterfall or the tallest mountain, or even an outdoor spot. We simply want to see your midday getaway, wherever it is in the world.

headline: The Wrong Way to Attack Mitch McConnell
abstract: Progress Kentucky, a group working to unseat the senator, sent out an offensive tweet targeting his wife.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader who pioneered the “no” strategy when President Obama was elected in 2008, and who encourages the worst instincts of the right wingers in his party, deserves plenty of criticism — but not the kind of criticism he received recently, which focused on his wife.

headline: McIlroy and Woods Play Their Own Match-Play Final
abstract: Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods played 36 holes on Sunday at Medalist Golf Club in Hobe Sound, a short drive from Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., the site of this week’s Honda Classic.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — As the Accenture Match Play Championship wound down Sunday outside Tucson, Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods contested their own match-play final at Medalist Golf Club in Hobe Sound, Fla., a short drive from PGA National, site of this week’s Honda Classic.

headline: Christie Says He’ll Take U.S. Money to Expand Medicaid
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a strident Republican critic of President Obama’s health care law, said his decision was financial, not philosophical.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Gov. Chris Christie, one of the most strident Republican critics of President Obama’s health care overhaul, announced on Tuesday that he would accept federal money to expand the Medicaid program in New Jersey.

headline: Gay Couples Face a Mixed Geography of Marriage
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'States (US)']
abstract: Now that nine states and the District of Columbia permit same-sex marriage, the borders and sharp disparities among states are a more complex issue for gay couples.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Idaho — The border with Washington State is just two miles from the home that Henry D. Johnston and his partner, Alex Irwin, own here in western Idaho, but for a gay couple it might as well be a thousand. Over there, just a brisk morning’s walk away, same-sex marriage was approved by a majority of statewide voters last fall; over here, the Idaho Constitution, through an amendment passed by voters in 2006, says that even a civil union granted elsewhere has no validity.

headline: A New Whiskey, Intensely Flavored
abstract: With Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel bourbon, the renowned whiskey distiller Jimmy Russell and his son Eddie introduce Wild Turkey’s first bourbon to eschew chill filtering.
lead_paragraph: With Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel bourbon, the renowned whiskey distiller Jimmy Russell and his son Eddie introduce Wild Turkey’s first bourbon to eschew chill filtering, the process by which whiskeys are rid of fatty acids (and, say detractors, some of their character). A high bottling proof of 110 further intensifies the rich flavor profile of vanilla, toffee and licorice. The whiskey, a permanent addition to the Russell’s Reserve line, has no age statement, but it is roughly eight to nine years old: Available in early March, $50 for a 750-milliliter bottle, wildturkeybourbon.com.

headline: On the Job, and Reading Between the Gritty Lines
abstract: Much of the material in Mathew Henderson’s first book of poems, “The Lease,” was inspired by his time working in Canadian oil fields.
lead_paragraph: Mathew Henderson is a young Canadian poet who has spent time working in his country’s oil fields, and he’s emerged with a spare and eloquent first book of poems, “The Lease,” that cuts into its primary subjects — grease, technology, physical labor, alienated sex, mud, fear, profound loneliness — like a welder’s oxyacetylene flame.

headline: Misogynistic or Retrogade? Discuss.
abstract: The choice of Seth MacFarlane as a host was meant to appeal to young men, but his jokes came at the expense of the broadcast’s biggest audience, women.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What’s a little boob humor before an audience of millions? The debate raging loudest over Seth MacFarlane’s Oscar performance is whether it was unabashedly misogynistic or just pleasingly retrograde, like an old Playboy cartoon come to life.

headline: Toward a Republican Synthesis
abstract: How to integrate the Tea Party era with the policy turn the G.O.P. needs to make.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been reading with interest the discussion the Claremont Review of Books is hosting on moderation, conservatism, and the Republican Party, which opens outward from William Voegeli’s review of Geoffrey Kabaservice’s recent history of moderate Republicanism, “Rule and Ruin,” and then loops in Steven Hayward and David Frum as well as Voegeli and Kabaservice for a wide-ranging conversation. This discussion is brought to a point in Voegeli’s concluding back-and-forth with Frum, which provides a neat capsule summary of two very different ways of thinking about the Tea Party/Ryan budget era in Republican politics, and how the G.O.P. candidates of 2014 and 2016 should approach their task. First, Voegeli:

headline: Feeling For | Reed Krakoff Stilleto
abstract: For those torn over which transparent shoes to pluck from both spring and fall runways this year, Reed Krakoff’s mesh and leather stiletto serves double duty for your wardrobe.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Met Will Lower Ticket Prices
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera plans to reduce ticket prices by an average of 10 percent next season to counter dropping attendance.
lead_paragraph: Attendance is down this season at the Metropolitan Opera, and officials there acknowledge that the fault is their own. They made going to the opera too expensive.

headline: A Look at the Hagel Confirmation Saga
abstract: The Times’s Jeremy W. Peters examines Chuck Hagel’s nomination for defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jeremy W. Peters examines Chuck Hagel’s nomination for defense secretary.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, a sweet apple with a touch of tartness, a cheesecake to serve 6, Tuscan prosciutto and more.
lead_paragraph: To Shop: A Butcher Shop Expands With Sausages and Game

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 26
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including skiing in Italy, the N.F.L. combine in Indianapolis and baseball spring training in Florida.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including skiing in Italy, the N.F.L. combine in Indianapolis and baseball spring training in Florida.

headline: Barbara Walters to Return to ‘The View’
abstract: After more than a month sidelined with chicken pox, Ms. Walters will return to the hit ABC daytime show starting next week.
lead_paragraph: After more than a month sidelined with chicken pox, Barbara Walters will return to her hit ABC daytime show, “The View,” starting next week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Vatican, Scotland, Egypt and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Vatican, Scotland, Egypt and Syria.

headline: Home, Where the Fizz Is
abstract: Soda-making machines are being hacked to produce sparkling wine, potent cocktails and artful pop.
lead_paragraph: It can take just 90 seconds and a rubber band.

headline: In Wall St. Tax, a Simple Idea but Unintended Consequences
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A financial transaction tax seems to be a winner for everyone, but a century of experience with the tax suggests that it is not as successful as thought.
lead_paragraph: Some say that a financial transaction tax is a cost-free way to kill many a bird with one stone — raising revenue, preventing financial crashes and making markets safer. But advocates of this neat idea conveniently ignore the century of less-than-successful experience with this tax, including New York State’s own failed attempt.

headline: Hacking Your Soda-Making Machine
abstract: Post your experiments with carbonators like the SodaStream and the SodaSparkle.
lead_paragraph: As SodaStreams and other home carbonators become more ubiquitous in American kitchens, so too have the hacks — anything that goes beyond using the machine for its intended purpose of turning tap water into sparkling water. Curious cooks have used their carbonators to make everything from herb-infused sparkling wine to fizzy cocktails to sodas with all-natural syrups. (It should be mentioned here that many home carbonators’ manufacturers warn against using anything but water; the warranty may be immediately voided if other liquids are used.)

headline: In Seoul, Gangnam Frugal Style
abstract: The Gangnam district, newly famous thanks to the hit song, is known for opulence. But there are bargains to be found beyond the bling.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Korea started singing along to “Gangnam Style,” by the K-pop star Psy. By October, my nephews in Maryland had joined the chorus. A couple of months ago in Chongqing, China, I saw women exercising by doing its signature horse-riding dance in a public square. In February, Psy performed before thousands at Brazilian Carnival.

headline: Yellow Cab Industry Joins City Against For-Hire Vehicle Operators’ Suit
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: The powerful Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade has moved to intervene to defend against a case that seeks to bar its cabs from accepting hails via smartphone apps.
lead_paragraph: A powerful group of yellow taxi fleet owners has moved to join the city’s defense against a lawsuit seeking to bar so-called e-hailing smartphone apps from yellow cabs.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Tough iWatch and Pynchon’s Alley
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include the first revenue increase for the music industry in this century, a call for more American defenders as awareness grows of cyberattacks from other countries and what some Yahoo employees are saying about the end of telecommuting.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: House Republican Expresses Support for Guest-Worker Program
abstract: Representative Robert Goodlatte, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said he could support a measure that would offer at least temporary legalization for illegal immigrants who are currently in the country working in agriculture.
lead_paragraph: Representative Robert Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia, appeared willing to carve out a sliver of middle ground on Tuesday in the debate over the future of the nation’s immigration system, offering up the possibility of a guest worker program as a trial case for how the country handles both legal and illegal immigration.

headline: World Trade Center Site, 12:19 P.M.
abstract: Former Mayor David N. Dinkins and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gathered on Tuesday for a ceremony commemorating the 20th anniversary of the bombing of the World Trade Center.

headline: Seared by a Flop, DreamWorks Animation Reports $82.7 Million Loss
abstract: Charges totaling $165 million, including a hefty write-down related to the underperforming movie “Rise of the Guardians,” resulted in a fourth-quarter loss for DreamWorks Animation.
lead_paragraph: 9:59 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES — Charges totaling $165 million, including a hefty write-down related to the underperforming movie “Rise of the Guardians,” prompted DreamWorks Animation to report an $82.7 million loss in the fourth quarter.

headline: The Fever Swamp of the Center, Continued
abstract: Desperately seeking sequester parity.
lead_paragraph: I love Jonathan Chait’s phrase “the fever swamp of the center”; it really is true that self-identified centrists are sounding crazier and crazier, as they try to reconcile their fanatical devotion to the proposition that both parties are equally at fault with the distressing reality that Obama actually advocates the policies they claim to want. And today’s WaPo editorial on the sequester takes the fever to a new pitch. The editorial admits that Obama is calling for exactly the polices the WaPo wants, while Republicans are off the deep end in refusing to consider any revenue; but the piece is nonetheless written as a criticism of Obama, because

headline: Now on ‘Idol,’ Viewers Can Tweet While Contestants Sing
abstract: “American Idol” is now encouraging viewers to tweet as a way to make live viewing more attractive.
lead_paragraph: These days, as more people watch television with a phone in hand or a computer in lap, it’s de rigueur for a network to have a Twitter hashtag on the screen. Television producers and stars — at least the ones with thick skins — appreciate the instant feedback, and now they’re figuring out ways to incorporate it into their shows, thereby completing the feedback loop.

headline: Wine Is a Joy, Not This Year’s Oat Bran
abstract: The healthful benefits of wine are not the primary reasons to drink it.
lead_paragraph: As a wine lover, I’m reassured to hear that moderate wine consumption can be part of a healthful diet, if only because the opposite would be so much worse. But honestly, whether science demonstrates the benefits of wine is largely irrelevant to me.

headline: When Diet Meets Delicious
abstract: The latest study backs up what we’ve known for 20 years. A diet low in red meat, low in sugar and low in junk has little downside, and it’s good for you.
lead_paragraph: The “How do I eat?” thing has become increasingly combative and confusing. Do you give up carbs, or fat, or both? Do you go vegan or paleo?

headline: Senate Republicans Fail to Reach Consensus on Alternative to Cuts
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senate Republicans emerged from a policy meeting deeply divided over what they should offer to replace or mitigate across-the-board spending cuts scheduled to hit Friday, probably postponing a Senate showdown on the parties’ two approaches.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans emerged from a policy meeting Tuesday deeply divided over what they should offer to replace or mitigate across-the-board spending cuts scheduled to hit Friday, probably postponing a showdown in the Senate on the parties’ two approaches.

headline: Women and Sex in ‘The Group’
abstract: Mary McCarthy missed the women’s movement just ahead of her. But she got sex right, the author James Collins says.
lead_paragraph: 9:30 p.m. | Updated Our live discusion about ‘The Group’ has concluded. You can find the conversation here. Read Ginia Bellafante’s first post on the book here. A response from James Collins, author of the novel “Beginner’s Greek,” is below.

headline: An Unusually Partisan Confirmation Vote
abstract: Former Nebraska Senator Chuck Hagel was confirmed as President Obama’s new secretary of defense, but his confirmation vote was far more partisan than others in recent history.
lead_paragraph: Former Nebraska Senator Chuck Hagel was confirmed Tuesday as President Obama’s new secretary of defense. Mr. Hagel — after failing to clear a Republican filibuster 12 days ago — cleared a cloture vote easily early Tuesday before being confirmed by the Senate by a vote of 58 to 41.

headline: Celebrity Collisions and a Possible Pinch
abstract: Solange Knowles and Doris Kearns Goodwin were among the many, many celebrities in the mix at the Vanity Fair Oscars party.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – From media titans (Rupert Murdoch) to reality competition mainstays (Tom Colicchio), the Vanity Fair Oscar afterparty contained more celebrity collisions than can be contained in a mere single post.

headline: Medicare Needs Fixing, but Not Right Now
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Baby Boomers', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'United States Economy']
abstract: New cost-saving methods have kindled hope among some scholars that Medicare could achieve savings just by cleaning out the health care system’s waste.
lead_paragraph: What’s the rush? For all the white-knuckled wrangling over spending cuts set to start on Friday, the fundamental partisan argument over how to fix the government’s finances is not about the immediate future. It is about the much longer term: how will the nation pay for the care of older Americans as the vast baby boom generation retires? Will the government keep Medicare spending in check by asking older Americans to shoulder more costs? Should we raise taxes instead?

headline: Ashleigh Good Transforms Backstage at Cedric Charlier
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Karim Rahman and hair by Laurent Philippon.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper883 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: CBS Finishes February Sweep Month on Top
abstract: For the first time since 1998, CBS will finish first during the official February sweep rating period in the most important category for advertising sales, viewers between 18 and 49.
lead_paragraph: With the Super Bowl, the Grammy Awards and the strongest regular lineup in television all on its schedule this month, it should be no surprise that CBS will be the big winner when the official February sweep rating period closes Wednesday night.

headline: A Live Conversation About ‘The Group’ by Mary McCarthy
abstract: Welcome to our live discussion of “The Group,” by Mary McCarthy.
lead_paragraph: 9:30 p.m. | Updated  We’re calling it a night. The live portion of our discussion has concluded. But you can still share your thoughts on the book in the comments section of this post. Thanks to James Collins and all our readers! — Ginia Bellafante

headline: Health Spending Slows
abstract: Medicare spending growth slowed sharply in the last few years, in line with the slowdown in health care costs. But the government expects it to rebound as economic growth recovers.
lead_paragraph: Medicare spending growth slowed sharply in the last few years, in line with the slowdown in health care costs. But the government expects it to rebound as economic growth recovers.

headline: Only Half of First-Time College Students Graduate in 6 Years
abstract: A new report from the National Student Clearinghouse Research Center looks at six-year graduation rates for first-time college students who enrolled in fall 2006.
lead_paragraph: As we’ve covered here many times before, there is an abundance of evidence showing that going to college is worth it. But that’s really only true if you go to college and then graduate, and the United States is doing a terrible job of helping enrolled college students complete their educations.

headline: Excerpt: 'Jackie'
abstract: Tina Benko in a scene from Elfriede Jelinek’s play “Jackie,” about Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.
lead_paragraph: Tina Benko in a scene from Elfriede Jelinek’s play “Jackie,” about Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

headline: Bags, Baubles and Bibs From the Milan Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: A selection of accessories from the Milanese runways.
lead_paragraph: A selection of accessories from the Milanese runways.

headline: This Awards Season, the Politics Didn’t End With the Oscars
abstract: A Senate investigation into “Zero Dark Thirty” ends and a photo of Michelle Obama at the Oscars gets the Iran Photoshop treatment.
lead_paragraph: In a stroke of timing that is either meaningless, fortuitous or suspicious, the Senate Intelligence Committee decided to end its investigation into “Zero Dark Thirty” on Monday, the day after the film took home only one statue at the Oscars.

headline: Desperate Hunt for Day Care in Japan
abstract: Japan subsidizes day care for families of varied incomes, but as more women work, they find themselves forced into an annual competition for coveted slots for their children.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Ayaka Okumura was barely pregnant when she began fretting over how she would hold on to the management job that would have been out of reach just a generation ago, when Japanese women were often relegated to dead-end “office lady” jobs pouring tea and greeting guests.

headline: Wave of Concussions Hits the N.H.L.
abstract: Penguins star Evgeni Malkin, the N.H.L.’s reigning most valuable player, is among 11 players believed to have sustained concussions in the past two weeks.
lead_paragraph: For the last two seasons, concussions and hits to the head were frequent talking points in the N.H.L., with the Pittsburgh Penguins star Sidney Crosby serving as the catalyst.

headline: N.F.L. Will Expand Concussion Efforts During Games
abstract: Starting next season, all 32 teams will use a concussion assessment tool available on an iPad, and independent neurological consultants will join team doctors on the sideline.
lead_paragraph: “Where are we?” “Who did we play in the last game?” “What is the date today?”

headline: Dimon Pledges to Change JPMorgan’s Practices on Payday Loans
keywords: ['Payday Loans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: At an investor meeting on Tuesday, Jamie Dimon, the chief of JP Morgan Chase, called payday lenders’ abuses “terrible,” and said the bank was examining the issue.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, vowed on Tuesday to change how the bank deals with Internet-based payday lenders that automatically withdraw payments from borrowers’ checking accounts.

headline: N.F.L. Concussion Test
abstract: The N.F.L.’s sideline concussion assessment tool will now be used in app form on an iPad by all 32 teams.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s sideline concussion assessment tool will now be used in app form on an iPad by all 32 teams.

headline: Does Bernanke Have the Best Inflation Record?
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke said he has the best inflation record of any postwar Fed chairman. An economist crunched the numbers to find out.
lead_paragraph: In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, boldly declared: “You called me a dove. Well, maybe in some respects I am, but on the other hand, my inflation record is the best of any Federal Reserve chairman in the postwar period, or at least one of the best, about 2 percent average inflation.” (To which the Twitterverse responded, #ohsnap.)

headline: Afghan Sign of Progress Turns Out to Be Error
abstract: The American-led coalition, which had said there was a 7 percent drop in attacks last year, said a clerical error meant the figure was wrong.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American officials, when looking to quickly illustrate progress in Afghanistan, have in the past few months highlighted a 7 percent drop last year in what they call “enemy-initiated attacks.” Fewer attacks, the reasoning went, meant Afghans were safer and the Taliban were weaker.

headline: BP Executive Testifies That a Rig Explosion in the Gulf Was a Known Risk
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Testifying for the company in a federal trial, Lamar McKay, the former president of BP America, concedes that a well blowout was identified as a hazard before the 2010 Gulf oil spill.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — On the first day of testimony in the BP Gulf of Mexico oil spill trial, BP’s top executive for North American operations at the time of the disaster acknowledged on Tuesday that a well explosion had been identified as a risk before it happened.

headline: Bernanke: By Unemployment, Not So Good
abstract: The Fed chairman’s tenure has produced low inflation and high unemployment. But the credit or blame may lie elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: As Catherine Rampell notes, Ben S. Bernanke pointed to the low inflation in his tenure in Senate testimony on Friday. Inflation has been lower during his tenure than during that of any postwar Fed chairman. But the Fed has a dual mandate:

headline: John Merwin, Angler With Story Angles, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Merwin lived to fish and chronicle it. An editor and writer for Field & Stream, he also founded Rod & Reel magazine and wrote a number of critically acclaimed books.
lead_paragraph: John Merwin, who learned to fish, then learned to write, then learned to write about fishing and spent the rest of his life doing so with distinction in magazines and books, died on Feb. 20 in Lebanon, N.H. He was 66 and lived most of his life in Dorset, Vt., not far from the Battenkill River.

headline: Oyster Farm in California Gets a Reprieve
keywords: ['Oysters', 'Fish Farming', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: An oyster farm can remain open while a federal appeals court decides whether its lawsuit challenging its eviction from Point Reyes National Seashore can go forward.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — An oyster farm can continue operating at Point Reyes National Seashore in Northern California for at least a few more months after a federal appeals court decision on Monday.

headline: Judge Can’t Play TV Bigot, New Jersey Argues
abstract: Vince A. Sicari, a South Hackensack municipal judge, is a stand-up comedian who has also played homophobic and racist characters to bait strangers on “Primetime” on ABC.
lead_paragraph: A man told his wife, who was at the beach and wearing a bikini: “You’re fat. You look pathetic. You look stupid.” He added, in case his point had not been made clear, “You look like Shamu.”

headline: Tunisia: Killer of Opposition Leader Remains at Large, Authorities Say
abstract: The police have arrested four ultraconservative Islamists as suspected accomplices to the assassination of the leftist leader Chokri Belaid this month.
lead_paragraph: The police have arrested four ultraconservative Islamists who are suspected of being accomplices to the assassination of the leftist leader Chokri Belaid this month, but they have not arrested the killer himself, Interior Minister Ali Laarayedh said Tuesday. Earlier reports citing unnamed sources had said the assassin was under arrest. Mr. Laarayedh said the police believed they had identified the killer as a hard-line Islamist who is still on the run.

headline: Florida: Court Blocks Drug Testing for Aid Seekers
abstract: A federal appeals court on Tuesday blocked a 2011 state law requiring applicants to undergo a drug test in order to receive public assistance.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday blocked a 2011 state law requiring applicants to undergo a drug test in order to receive public assistance. Gov. Rick Scott called the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit “disturbing” and said he would appeal. “Drug use by anyone with children looking for a job is totally destructive,” said Mr. Scott, a Republican. The ruling upheld a lower court’s decision in 2011 to temporarily block drug testing because it most likely violated the Fourth Amendment’s prohibition of unreasonable searches. The appeals court concluded that the state did not show a “substantial special need” in requiring that applicants be tested when no suspicion of drug use was evident. The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida sued the state over the policy on behalf of a Navy veteran, Luis Lebron. “The state can’t do what it wanted to do to me and my family without reason or suspicion,” Mr. Lebron said. “I’m glad that the court agreed.”

headline: Maryland: Judge Won’t Drop Charges in Leak Case
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A military judge at Fort Meade on Tuesday rejected a bid by lawyers for Pfc. Bradley Manning to have leak charges against him dismissed on the grounds that he had been denied a speedy trial.
lead_paragraph: A military judge at Fort Meade on Tuesday rejected a bid by lawyers for Pfc. Bradley Manning to have leak charges against him dismissed on the grounds that he had been denied a speedy trial. The military judge, Col. Denise R. Lind, noted that Private Manning had spent more than three years in jail awaiting trial on charges of providing some 700,000 confidential government documents to WikiLeaks. But she ruled that given the “almost unfathomable” complexity of the case and the government’s “reasonable diligence” in pursuing it, the delay had not violated Private Manning’s rights under the Constitution and law. His trial is currently scheduled for June 3.

headline: F.A.A. Is Not Ready to Approve 787 Test Flights
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Lithium (Metal)', 'Batteries', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Boeing has proposed several fixes for the troubled batteries on its new jetliner, but federal regulators have rejected a request to test them in the air.
lead_paragraph: Boeing is conducting laboratory tests on its proposed fixes for the lithium-ion batteries on its new 787 jets, and federal regulators said Tuesday that they would need to see the results before deciding whether to allow flight tests.

headline: After Report of a Mugging, a Very Different Account
abstract: A fallen man said he had been mugged, but a witness said he had simply stumbled to the ground.
lead_paragraph: Like a visual exhibit to go with James Fordyce’s account of being mugged outside a subway station last week, a map of violent injury was drawn across his face. Purple bruises circled his eyes and streaked along his cheekbones. Down the length of his swollen, broken nose was a line of scabs.

headline: Bradford Perkins
abstract: Mr. Perkins is a founder of Perkins Eastman, a planning, design and project management firm.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Perkins, 70, is a founder and chairman and chief executive of Perkins Eastman, a planning, design and project management firm. The company is working on the Willets Point redevelopment project in Queens and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering/Hunter College campus; several years ago the company designed the TKTS booth in Times Square.

headline: In Stamford, Gambling on an Office Complex Makeover
abstract: George Comfort & Sons is renovating and rebranding its Harbor Plaza development, despite uncertainty in the Stamford commercial realty market.
lead_paragraph: The New York-based firm George Comfort & Sons, perhaps best known as the landlord of the Worldwide Plaza complex in Midtown, is making a big bet on Stamford, Conn.

headline: After Years of Delay, a Lower East Side Gap Is Ready to Be Filled
abstract: In January, New York City released a request for proposals from developers, ending a long, bitter chapter its development history.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a century after a neighborhood of tenements on the Lower East Side was razed in the name of urban renewal, the area — which happens to be the largest undeveloped swath of city-owned land in Manhattan south of 96th Street — is finally poised for redevelopment. Last month, the city released a request for proposals from developers, ending a bitter chapter in New York City’s development history.

headline: Bradley Struggles and Says the Uproar Over His Putting Stroke Is to Blame
abstract: Keegan Bradley, who has become the public face over a proposed ban on the anchored stroke he uses to putt, has struggled this year.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Few golfers were happier to leave the West Coast behind than Keegan Bradley, and not just because this week’s Honda Classic, the first of four consecutive PGA Tour stops in Florida, is a short drive from his home in Jupiter.

headline: Rivalries Begin to Emerge in a New Seat of Power
abstract: Ro Khanna, a Democrat who served in the Commerce Department, is considering a run against Representative Michael M. Honda.
lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Home to Apple, Google and other high-tech pioneers, the 17th Congressional District here recorded a political first in last fall’s elections, becoming the first majority Asian-American district in the mainland United States.

headline: The Mets Like Flores in the Infield, Not in Left Field
abstract: Though the Mets lack depth in the outfield, they are grooming one of their more promising players, Wilmer Flores, to play two infield positions.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Wilmer Flores has continued to distinguish himself as one of the more promising hitters in the Mets’ organization. But he is a player who, at the moment, seems to lack an obvious position.

headline: Denis Forman, British TV Innovator, Is Dead at 95
abstract: Mr. Forman was the executive responsible for hit series like “The Jewel in the Crown” and “Brideshead Revisited.”
lead_paragraph: Denis Forman, a television executive who served as steward to some of the most ambitious and popular British programs ever made, including “The Jewel in the Crown,” “Brideshead Revisited” and the celebrated “7 Up” documentary series, which has revisited the lives of a group of Britons at seven-year intervals, died on Sunday in London. He was 95.

headline: Voting Act Challenge Hinges on a Formula
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The Supreme Court hears arguments on Wednesday in a case that challenges whether the Voting Rights Act of 1965 reflects changes in voting patterns and the broader culture.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is hearing arguments on Wednesday in a major voting rights case. Here is some of the history of the law and the issues that are likely to be raised before the court.

headline: S.E.C. Nominee Tries to Allay Skepticism
abstract: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s choice to lead the S.E.C., is telling Congress she can avoid conflicts of interest despite her long career on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White’s path to the Securities and Exchange Commission has reached a crucial juncture: the Congressional charm campaign.

headline: SFX Entertainment Buys  Electronic Dance Music Site
abstract: SFX Entertainment paid just above $50 million for Beatport, people briefed on the matter said. The site is the pre-eminent download store for E.D.M.
lead_paragraph: SFX Entertainment, the company led by the media executive Robert F. X. Sillerman, has agreed to buy the music download site Beatport, part of the company’s plan to build a $1 billion empire centered on the electronic dance music craze.

headline: Opposition Will Boycott Egypt’s Vote for Assembly
abstract: The National Salvation Front objected that the governing Islamists had set rules for parliamentary elections without its input.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s main opposition coalition declared Tuesday that it would boycott the coming parliamentary elections, all but ensuring that Islamists will continue to dominate the legislature and that their rivals will continue to question their legitimacy.

headline: Miami’s Surprise Season, Meticulously Planned
abstract: Coach Jim Larranaga, who led George Mason on an improbable trip to the Final Four in 2006, has the No. 5-ranked Miami Hurricanes pointed in that direction as well.
lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — Jim Larranaga always has a plan. He plans by the day, week, month and year. If anyone wonders how he stays so organized, Larranaga walks behind his desk here at BankUnited Center and opens two large cabinets, which house more than two decades’ worth of Franklin Covey daily planners: thick, three-ring monstrosities the size of dictionaries.

headline: Dependents of the State
abstract: Why do we loathe and fear some people’s reliance on the government but not others?
lead_paragraph: Of all the sins to which an American can succumb, the worst may be dependence on the state.

headline: Justices Wrestle Over Allowing DNA Sampling at Time of Arrest
abstract: “I think this is perhaps the most important criminal procedure case that this court has heard in decades,” Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About halfway through a Supreme Court argument on Tuesday over whether the police may take DNA samples from people they arrest, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. reflected on just how momentous the issue was.

headline: Revamped Warriors Use Small Fixes for Big Gains
abstract: After a season in which they won only 23 games for a .348 winning percentage, the Golden State Warriors are 10 games over .500 this season and have a talented young core of players.
lead_paragraph: Last season, the Golden State Warriors won 23 games in a lockout-shortened season, an equivalent to about 29 wins in a regular season, or four fewer than the Warriors (33-23) have already won this season.

headline: No Move Yet by U.N. Body After Test by Koreans
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: Diplomats said the process had bogged down mainly over bridging differences between China and the United States about how forcefully to respond.
lead_paragraph: The international expressions of anger and dismay that followed North Korea’s announcement of a nuclear test a few weeks ago, punctuated by a United Nations Security Council pledge to immediately work on “appropriate measures” in a new resolution, appear to have given way to slow-motion diplomacy and some frustration that not even a draft has been circulated among the Council’s 15 members.

headline: Plan to Pave Bronx Trail Has Some Standing in Way
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Running', 'Asphalt', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: Runners say the mile-and-a-half dirt trail is a rare exception in the city, but supporters of a plan to widen and pave a portion of the trail say it would improve accessibility.
lead_paragraph: In a city awash in asphalt and concrete, perhaps it is no surprise that such furor could erupt over a one-and-a-half-mile dirt trail that runs quietly through the northwest corner of the Bronx, along a brook, past a golf course and into the woods.

headline: U.N. Official Sees Desperation, Hunger and Fear on Visit to Mali
abstract: Jack Ging, a relief official, said some of the conditions in the north started to improve when a French-led military mission began last month.
lead_paragraph: A top United Nations relief official who just returned from a trip to northern Mali said Tuesday that desperation, hunger and fear had pervaded the region in the year since Islamist militant extremists seized control, and that only $17 million of the organization’s appeal for $373 million in emergency aid had been donated so far.

headline: Tensions Rising With North Korea, but Dennis Rodman Is There
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Basketball']
abstract: The frequently pierced former N.B.A. star known as the Worm embarked on a tour with three Harlem Globetrotters for a documentary film.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Rodman may not come across as the most natural choice for a sports star turned American diplomat, but North Korea apparently begs to differ. Rodman has traveled to Pyongyang along with three Harlem Globetrotters and a documentary film crew for some basketball exhibitions and, the film company hopes, an audience with the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, who is said to be a devoted basketball fan.

headline: G.O.P.’s Ideological Split Appears in Virginia Governor’s Race
abstract: The presumed nominee, Attorney General Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, has been called “outside the mainstream” by the state’s Republican lieutenant governor.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — As Republicans debate ways to appeal to voters whom their positions have pushed away, some Republican leaders in Virginia are warning that the party is poised to repeat the mistakes of last November, choosing a nominee for governor who turns off younger, female and nonwhite voters.

headline: New Report on Syrian Missiles Shows Extent of Death and Damage
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Human Rights Watch says the government last week fired at least four ballistic missiles that killed more than 141 people in Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government fired at least four ballistic missiles last week that hit civilian neighborhoods in Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, killing more than 141 people, including 71 children, according to a Human Rights Watch report released on Tuesday.

headline: Recalling Killing That Led Officers to Reclaim the City
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: More than a hundred officers gathered for the anniversary of the killing of Officer Edward Byrne, the 22-year-old rookie shot and killed in his car one morning in 1988.
lead_paragraph: The old police cruiser sat at the corner of 107th Avenue and Inwood Street in Queens, just as it did 25 years ago. On Tuesday afternoon, this throwback — a refurbished Caprice Classic — served not only as a powerful reminder of Edward Byrne, the 22-year-old rookie officer who was shot and killed inside it while on patrol one morning in 1988, but of the pervasive violence that defined the era.

headline: Out West, Reaching the Summit
keywords: ['Interscholastic Athletics', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Basketball']
abstract: The lanky Knights of Lone Peak are the No. 1 high school team in the nation. And they have not just been beating their opponents. They’ve been crushing them.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND, Utah — Here, among a string of quiet Mormon towns, where the spires of Latter-day Saints churches glint against the Wasatch Mountains, is the home of what many consider the nation’s best high school boys’ basketball team.

headline: After Fukushima, Tasks Remain for the American Nuclear Industry
abstract: Among safety proposals being discussed are hardened vents in older reactors and filters to trap radioactive particles.
lead_paragraph: Among safety proposals being discussed are hardened vents in older reactors and filters to trap radioactive particles.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Feb. 27, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, Feb. 27, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “How am I supposed to go about reporting something when the person I’m supposed to report to is the person who raped me?”

headline: Theft of Dalí Drawing Brings Guilty Plea
abstract: Phivos Istavrioglou, a fashion industry publicist, admitted that he had tucked the 1949 drawing, “Cartel de Don Juan Tenorio,” into a bag and walked out of an Upper East Side gallery.
lead_paragraph: A fashion industry publicist avoided a jail sentence by pleading guilty on Tuesday to stealing a drawing by the Surrealist artist Salvador Dalí from the wall of a newly opened Manhattan art gallery last year.

headline: An Eerie Silence on Cybersecurity
abstract: Most companies would tell investors if thieves made off with hundreds of millions of dollars in cash. So why not discuss cyberattacks, which are often more valuable?
lead_paragraph: Apart from a few companies like Google, which revealed that Chinese hackers had tried to read its users’ e-mail messages, American companies have been disturbingly silent about cyberattacks on their computer systems — apparently in fear that this disclosure will unnerve customers and shareholders and invite lawsuits and unwanted scrutiny from the government.

headline: Austerity Is Already Here
abstract: Federal government spending often falls after recessions and wars, but the current round of cuts in investment and spending on goods and services is unusually deep.
lead_paragraph: Federal government spending often falls after recessions and wars, but the current round of cuts in investment and spending on goods and services is unusually deep.

headline: The Latest Hurdle to Gun-Law Reform
abstract: Opposing the record-keeping requirement of private gun sales would render the background checks provision toothless.
lead_paragraph: Of all the proposals to reduce gun violence now pending in Congress, there was one that seemed most likely to bring the two parties together: requiring background checks for buyers in private gun sales. Republicans and Democrats said this measure would help keep guns out of the wrong hands, especially the proliferating handguns that now account for nearly three-quarters of gun deaths.

abstract: The Supreme Court severely damaged the rule of law when it rejected a challenge to the federal law that permits secret surveillance of international communications involving Americans.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court severely damaged the rule of law in its decision on Tuesday to disallow a lawsuit challenging the federal law that permits broad, secret surveillance and interception of international communications involving Americans. The suit, brought by lawyers, journalists and human rights activists, charged that the 2008 amendments to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act violate their rights to privacy and free speech.

keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'State Legislatures', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Politics and Government']

headline: Austerity Kills Government Jobs as Cuts to Budgets Loom
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The federal government is cutting back at a pace exceeded in the last half-century only by the military demobilizations after the Vietnam War and the cold war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government, the nation’s largest consumer and investor, is cutting back at a pace exceeded in the last half-century only by the military demobilizations after the Vietnam War and the cold war.

headline: Yankees Don’t Plan on Moving Nunez or Re-Signing Damon

lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — When word began to filter through the Yankees’ spring training complex Sunday that Curtis Granderson would be out 10 weeks with a broken arm, Eduardo Nunez wondered for a moment if Joe Girardi would ask him to play left field again.

headline: How Children Should Be
abstract: Daniel Kantor shows his flexibility.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — And now, a Tale from the Curmudgeon Files: When I was in high school, I was a member of the speech and debate team. One of the most valuable things our coach did for us — even though I resented it at the time — was to break us of the “like, y’know” habit when speaking.

lead_paragraph: Declaring that he was hungry for “common-sense solutions” to escape “the tired ways of doing business,” Adolfo Carrión Jr., once a rising Democratic star, officially began his third-party bid for mayor on Tuesday night before a raucous crowd in the Bronx.

headline: Body Parts of Bronx Woman Are Found in Bags on Street
abstract: A man out for a walk with his son and their dog discovered a duffel bag containing two hands and part of an arm.
lead_paragraph: It was the sort of macabre discovery usually reserved for police dramas set in New York: Out for an early morning walk with the dog on Tuesday, a man and his son found severed body parts packed into bags and dumped curbside on a Bronx street.

headline: Father Held in Visa Plot Stretching to Pakistan
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Marriages', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Mohammad Ajmal Choudhry was arrested in Brooklyn and accused of filing false immigration documents for a man his daughter said she had been forced to marry in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn woman said she was held captive for three years in Pakistan by relatives who threatened to kill her if she did not marry a Pakistani man. After the marriage, she escaped with the help of the American Embassy last month and came to a secret location in the United States, away from her father, who had ordered the union, she said.

headline: Yahoo Issues a Statement on Work-at-Home Ban
abstract: Yahoo, which caused a controversy when it issued a policy banning employees from working remotely, tried to distance itself from the broader national conversation about workplace flexibility by saying the decision is right for Yahoo at this point of time.
lead_paragraph: In a front-page article in The New York Times on Tuesday morning, Catherine Rampell and I wrote about Yahoo’s new policy banning employees from working remotely. The company declined to comment for that article, but on Tuesday afternoon, it issued a statement about the ban against work-at-home arrangements.

headline: What Housework Has to Do With Waistlines
keywords: ['Calories', 'Exercise', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Television Sets', 'Weight', 'Women and Girls', 'Working Hours']
abstract: American women not employed outside the home were burning about 360 fewer calories every day in 2010 than they had in 1965, according to a new analysis, with working women burning about 132 fewer calories at home each day in 2010 than in 1965.
lead_paragraph: One reason so many American women are overweight may be that we are vacuuming and doing laundry less often, according to a new study that, while scrupulously even-handed, is likely to stir controversy and emotions.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (Oxygen) WALK THE LINE (2005) Joaquin Phoenix, above, in his second Oscar-nominated performance, channels Johnny Cash, and Reese Witherspoon, who won for best actress, is Cash’s wife, June Carter Cash, in this biopic from James Mangold. “Well cast, competently written (by Mr. Mangold and Gill Dennis) and carefully costumed, it adheres to a familiar ‘Behind the Music’ formula,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, “following its subject through childhood trauma, marriage and divorce, alternating offstage melodrama with recreated performances that remind us why we should care about this guy in the first place.” And while Mr. Phoenix and Ms. Witherspoon give respectable if rarely transporting renditions of famous songs, “you have to wait until the final credits to be reminded of what Johnny Cash and June Carter really sounded like,” Mr. Scott added.

headline: Hong Kong Grapples With Aftermath of Deadly Balloon Accident
abstract: Officials were headed Wednesday to the site of a balloon crash in Egypt that took the lives of nine Hong Kong residents.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Relatives of nine Hong Kong residents who were killed in a fatal balloon accident in Egypt were headed to Cairo on Wednesday to claim the bodies, a day after the balloon exploded into a fireball while preparing to land.

headline: A Difficult Budget Balancing Act for India
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Elections', 'Foreign Investments', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Will the government please voters or cut the deficit?
lead_paragraph: India’s fiscal budget will be announced on Thursday amid slowing economic growth, soaring inflation, a growing fiscal deficit and flagging investor confidence. But with national elections only a year away, analysts fear that instead of cutting the deficit, the government will buckle under political pressure and increase spending on social programs.

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.

headline: As Negotiators Ease Demands on Iran, More Nuclear Talks Are Set
abstract: The talks ended with an agreement to convene technical experts in Istanbul in March and return to Almaty for full negotiations in April, a senior Western diplomat said.
lead_paragraph: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — Two days of talks between six world powers and Iran over its nuclear program ended on Wednesday with specific agreement for further meetings in March and April over a proposal that would sharply constrain Iran’s stockpile of the most dangerous enriched uranium, in return for a modest lifting of some sanctions.

headline: ‘Kai Po Che’ and the Strange Case of the Vanishing Villain
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Hinduism', 'Movies', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Does Chetan Bhagat’s new movie favor Narendra Modi and the B.J.P.?
lead_paragraph: “Kai Po Che,” or “Brothers for Life,” which opened in Indian theaters on Friday, isn’t a film about the Gujarati entrepreneurial spirit, or friendship, or cricket, or any of the various themes that the popular author Chetan Bhagat has suggested in press interviews over the past two weeks.

headline: Time for an Asian Pope?
abstract: The Catholic Church chooses a new pope soon. With the church in a stronger position in Latin America, Africa and parts of Asia than in Europe and North America, there are calls for a Pope from one of these places.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As details emerge about what Pope Benedict XVI plans for his imminent retirement  — he’ll be called “pope emeritus,” live in the Vatican next door to the radio station, keep his white papal cassock but swap his signature red shoes for brown loafers, according to the Vatican spokesman, the Rev. Federico Lombardi — a bigger issue is swirling: who will be his successor?

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 27
abstract: Evidence that the euro zone crisis isn’t over; Chuck Hagel is confirmed as the new Pentagon chief; a rocket fired from Gaza lands in Israel; and the fashion designer Alexander Wang brings his energy to Balenciaga.
lead_paragraph: NEWS The political gridlock in Italy revives a question that hasn’t been heard lately: Is the euro zone crisis really over? Judging by the panic that seized financial markets on Monday and carried over into European stock and bond trading on Tuesday, the answer seems to be no. Liz Alderman reports from Rome, and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt.

headline: Thousands Gather for Pope’s Final Public Address
abstract: Tens of thousands of believers gathered in St. Peter’s Square on Wednesday to catch a glimpse of Pope Benedict XVI a day before his resignation takes formal effect.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — He circumnavigated St. Peter’s Square in the popemobile for the last time. He gave his final waves to cheering masses. And most profoundly, Pope Benedict XVI bestowed his valedictory words to the world on Wednesday in a heartfelt, sometimes wistful address that highlighted the price of being a pope — and its rays of happiness.

headline: India Posts Optimistic Economic Projections Despite Slowdown
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: An improving global economy will boost India’s growth, government predicts.
lead_paragraph: India’s economy severely underperformed expectations over the past year, and has slowed considerably since 2008, but the government projected strong growth in the coming fiscal year.

lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “San Diego Ex-Mayor Confronts $1 Billion Gambling Problem.”

headline: Land and Loss in Colombia
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Land Use Policies', 'Law and Legislation', 'Photography', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A farmer without land is not a farmer, one landless peasant told Gustav Arvidsson, who has been documenting the plight of Colombians forced off their land through bureaucracy, chicanery and force.
lead_paragraph: Land is no small thing in Latin America. Dynasties flush with wealth and power have arisen from plantations and cattle ranches owned by a select few families. For those left on the margins, taking over a tiny, fallow plot long forgotten by its owners may be the only thing keeping their family alive.

headline: How Should Children Be Taught About Puberty and Sex?
abstract: How did you first learn about puberty, body issues and sex? What responsibility do parents and schools have to make sure that children get accurate information?
lead_paragraph: Puberty and sex are tricky subjects that often no one really wants to teach soon-to-be teenagers. But how should children learn about these very important topics? From parents? Teachers? Books or Web sites?

headline: What They Said: Are India’s Economic Predictions Realistic?
abstract: Analysts question growth targets released on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Economic Survey for the fiscal year 2012-2013, released on Wednesday, said that the Indian economy is likely to grow between 6.1 percent and 6.7 percent in the fiscal year that begins April 1, up from 5 percent in 2012-2013.

headline: Arab Spring Blues?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Say it with the Harlem Shake.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The Arab revolutions are going through a rough patch, from political uncertainty in North Africa to daily massacres in Syria. Egypt appears, at times, on the brink of either economic collapse or a military coup. Tunisia is still reeling from a political assassination and may face prolonged instability, as negotiations for the formation of a new government unfold with little chance of a consensus emerging. Many ordinary citizens in both countries are depressed and disoriented.

headline: 20 Afghan Police Officers Killed in 2 Attacks, Including a Mass Poisoning
abstract: One of the attacks was a mass poisoning in Ghazni Province that killed 17 people and was carried out by men described as Taliban infiltrators.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Twenty Afghan policemen were killed in two attacks on Wednesday, including a mass poisoning, in southeastern Afghanistan, officials said.

headline: Is the Pope Frail?
abstract: Paying attention to frailty makes sense for the rest of us and our elders.
lead_paragraph: White-haired at 85, Pope Benedict XVI looks a bit hunched in photos. He has had a pacemaker for years, the Vatican recently confirmed for the first time — an indicator of long-standing heart problems. His older brother has said that age is taking its toll.

headline: I’m Admitted. Now What?
abstract: The college admissions season is wearing down, and for the first time in my (quasi) adult life, I don’t know what happens next.
lead_paragraph: As the excitement of the college admissions season starts to wear down, and the realities of the second semester of my senior year start setting in, I can’t help but feel a little lost.

abstract: Five years later, I had three Inc. 500 plaques hanging on my wall — and I was divorced.

The good news is that there is a rather simple answer: “You can’t.” Save your money, and don’t waste your time on the books and coaches who want to sell you advice. Here is why.

headline: Shakti, the Religious Student From California
abstract: His faith means that drinking water from the Ganges River will not harm him, the 22-year-old said.
lead_paragraph: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this year’s 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.Shakti, 22, who described himself as “a student of religion,” was one among them. This is what he had to say.

headline: Still Reeling From the Death of Chris Kyle, a SEAL Brother
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Friendship', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: This generation of Navy SEALs has seen at least 50 members killed in Iraq or Afghanistan, possibly more than any generation since Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: It’s a strange place I find myself these days, in my late 30s, and faced with the reality of friends, SEAL brothers, lost and gone from my life. The most recent include my friend Chris Kyle, who was killed last month, and Glen Doherty, who died six months earlier. I find myself often rereading saved e-mails from the guys because they give me comfort and an occasion for a much-needed laugh or cry, and I’m not afraid to admit the latter.

See addendum for original language. |The Rhodium Group consulting firm has released a “report card” on China’s energy trends and policies that describes the country’s intensifying efforts to increase the proportion of renewable sources like wind and hydroelectric dams and boost the efficiency of coal use (essentially the metric called “greenhouse gas intensity” by President George W. Bush). The blunting upward trajectory in the graph above reflects progress, but a long path ahead.

headline: Conservatives’ Love Affair With Christie Is Over
abstract: In September 2011, when Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was considering making a last-minute entry into the presidential race, many conservatives cheered the possibility. Roughly 18 months later, the attitude toward Mr. Christie has changed.
lead_paragraph: In September 2011, when Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was considering making a last-minute entry into the presidential race, I pointed out an incongruity in Republican attitudes toward him. Many Republican organizations and activists, including some very conservative ones, were enthusiastic about the possibility that Mr. Christie might enter the presidential race. But Mr. Christie’s history of actions and issue statements was fairly moderate.

abstract: The shooting, the second such incident in Switzerland  this year, could revive the nation’s debate over gun control.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — At least three people were killed in a shooting at a Swiss factory on Wednesday, the police said, adding that the gunman was among the dead. The episode was the second mass shooting in Switzerland this year.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The recent press conference announcing the 2013 season at Shakespeare’s Globe on one level seemed like variations on an ongoing theme.

abstract: Corvex Management, a hedge fund run by Keith Meister, and The Related Companies, led by Jeff T. Blau, have filed a lawsuit to block a proposed stock offering by CommonWealth REIT and reiterated a proposal to buy the real estate company.
lead_paragraph: A pair of activist investors ratcheted up the pressure on CommonWealth REIT on Wednesday, filing a lawsuit to block a proposed stock offering and reiterating a proposal to acquire the real estate company outright.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Loss at DreamWorks Animation, and a Cute Interspecies Rescue Was Fake
abstract: DreamWorks suffered an earnings loss and talked about staff cuts; a heartwarming YouTube video of a pig rescuing a goat that was fodder for many news outlets was faked; and “American Idol” tries to close the feedback loop on TV hashtags.
lead_paragraph: DreamWorks Animation reported an $82.7 million loss in the fourth quarter after taking an $87 million write-down related to the flop “Rise of the Guardians,” Brooks Barnes reports. DreamWorks shares dropped 1.3 percent in regular trading and less than 1 percent in after-hours trading. Jeffrey Katzenberg, the company’s chief executive, said there would be layoffs of around 350 of the company’s 2,000 employees.

headline: The Gun Report: February 27, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Two police officers were shot and killed as they followed up on a sexual assault investigation in Santa Cruz, Calif., Tuesday. Sgt. Loren Butch Baker was a 28-year veteran of the department and Detective Elizabeth Butler was a 10-year veteran of the department. The suspect, who was also killed in the shooting, was identified as 35-year-old Jeremy Goulet.

headline: Waze’s Maps Now Change as Roads Close
abstract: A new feature from Waze, a mobile app built on information gathered from its users’ phones, will be able to change the app’s maps in real time, reflecting temporary road closings as they happen.
lead_paragraph: Even the best map is out of date the minute it is printed. But a new feature from Waze, a mobile app built on information gathered from its users’ phones, will be able to change the app’s maps in real time, reflecting temporary road closings as they happen.

headline: Kiss and Yell
abstract: If you prefer your jeans black and your hair messy, Richard Hell may be the most important musician you’ve never heard of.
lead_paragraph: If you prefer your jeans black and your hair messy, Richard Hell may be the most important musician you’ve never heard of. A founding father of the New York punk scene, Hell is often credited with establishing, along with the sound, the style of the movement. In his new memoir, “I Dreamed I Was a Very Clean Tramp” (Ecco, $26), he gives a candid, sometimes brutal tour of punk’s gritty early days: he dissects band dynamics, counts notches on his bedpost, relates his disturbing descent into addiction and debunks myths about his famously choppy hair. It’s like a testosterone-fueled “Just Kids.” Below, a few of the book’s juiciest bits.

headline: Will Turkey Make Peace With the Kurds?
abstract: In the latest step towards ending Turkey’s long-running conflict with Kurdish rebels, a reported peace plan includes a formal end to hostilities next month.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There is growing optimism that a ceasefire in Turkey’s three-decade war with Kurdish guerrillas will be declared to coincide with the Kurdish New Year in three weeks.

headline: Minority Rites
abstract: Turkey wants to open up to its Greek Orthodox citizens, but not if it means opening up to its Muslim minorities.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Princes’ Islands are a chain of volcanic droplets off the coast of Istanbul, famous for their grand Palladian-style wooden summer homes and sweet-smelling pine woods. From one of the hilltops of the second-largest, Heybeliada, “the saddle-bagged” island, the view across the water is of a metropolis in motion, growing higher and wider, eating into more and more green space every year. But on Heybeliada itself, the only distractions are the squawk of seagulls and the clip-clop of horse-drawn carriages (no cars allowed). There, it is easy to imagine that time has stood still.

headline: Brian Williams Comes Clean on ‘Pig-Gate’
abstract: The anchor of NBC’s “Nightly News” program explained to his audience that a viral video showing a pig rescuing a baby goat had been revealed as a hoax.
lead_paragraph: You can say this about the NBC “Nightly News” anchor Brian Williams: it takes more than a phony animal-rescue video to rattle his cage.

abstract: Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former officer in the K.G.B., died after ingesting a rare radioactive isotope in London in 2006.

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']

lead_paragraph: More than two dozen Republicans — including a top adviser to Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee — have added their names to a legal brief urging the Supreme Court to declare that gay couples have a constitutional right to wed.

headline: Big Decisions for India Amid Slowing Economy
abstract: The government is pinned between economists warning that tough fiscal steps are needed and politicians leery of introducing unpopular measures before elections.
