He got to march into India’s Parliament with the ceremonial briefcase bearing a budget stuffed with goodies.

headline: Putting a Number on Federal Education Spending
abstract: Official tallies of government expenditures on education are often misleading, and a close look shows that education represents about 3 percent of federal spending, a policy analyst writes.
lead_paragraph: Jason Delisle is the director of the Federal Education Budget Project at the New America Foundation.

headline: A Look at Edwardian Opulence
abstract: A new exhibit at the Yale Center for British Art offers a sweeping look into the visual and decorative arts in Britain during the reign of King Edward VII.
lead_paragraph: “Edwardian Opulence: British Art at the Dawn of the 20th Century,” which opens tomorrow at the Yale Center for British Art, offers a sweeping look into the visual and decorative arts in Britain during the reign of King Edward VII (1901-1910). The exhibition encompasses about 170 objects, from paintings to costume and jewelry, by artists and designers ranging from John Singer Sargent to Carl Fabergé. It aims to seek a middle ground between those who argue that the Edwardian era was the change-resistant tail end of the Victorian period and those who assert that it was in fact a time of important social and technological change. Whatever your position on that issue, you can still appreciate Giovanni Boldini’s glamorous “Portrait of a Lady (Mrs. Lionel Phillips),” William Orpen’s insightful “A Bloomsbury Family” or the sumptuously embroidered evening gown designed by the House of Worth in Paris for Lady Curzon, the Vicereine of India.

headline: When Deviants Do Good
abstract: The positive deviance approach, which identifies and builds on existing behaviors and practices that produce results, has worked to reduce malnutrition, hospital infection rates and other problems.
lead_paragraph: Jerry and Monique Sternin and their son were among the very first Americans to move to Hanoi when they arrived in Vietnam in 1990. They had come from the Philippines, where Jerry had been director of Save the Children’s program there.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Details: Quinoa is so five minutes ago; now, apparently, the cool kids are flying the freekeh flag. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Gun-Control Advocate’s Victory in Illinois Is Also One for Bloomberg
abstract: The primary victory of Robin Kelly, a candidate for Congress, suggests that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s attempt to become a one-man political counterweight to the National Rifle Association is gaining traction.
lead_paragraph: After a career that has spanned high finance, philanthropy and public office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may have found his next act: defeating candidates who oppose gun control.

headline: On Our Radar: The Last Coal-Fired Steamship
abstract: A deadline set for a steamship to stop dumping coal ash slurry in Lake Michigan passed in December. Now the E.P.A. must decide whether to extend it.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to rule soon on whether to allow a car ferry called the Badger to continue to dump ash into Lake Michigan. It’s the last coal-fired steamship operating in American waters. [Associated Press]

headline: Handling Luggage Problems, From Damage to Delays
abstract: Roughly two million pieces of luggage disappear, arrive late, become damaged or experience theft every year. Here’s how to deal with the airlines if it happens to you.
lead_paragraph: The airlines have been bragging about their improved handling of checked luggage recently, based on Department of Transportation data showing that only 3 out of every 1,000 passengers reported a bag lost, delayed, damaged or pilfered in 2012. Although that’s the lowest level of mishandled baggage since the government started collecting reports in 1987, this statistic doesn’t tell the full story.

headline: Don’t Blame Mothers for Birth Defects
abstract: To some parents, the phrase “10 percent or more of birth defects result from medications taken during pregnancy” sounds like an indictment.
lead_paragraph: Louise Kinross is mad.

headline: Stars Sling Guitars at a Benefit for Country Music Hall of Fame
abstract: On Tuesday night, some of the best performers in Nashville came to the Best Buy Theater in Times Square to raise money for the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum.
lead_paragraph: A guitar pull is a Nashville tradition in which songwriters and singers sit in a row on a stage with their acoustic instruments and take turns playing whatever song they feel like, usually preceded by a story about where it came from. It makes for a low-key, informal and often surprising show.

headline: Third Floor, Bombshells
abstract: Macy’s plans to carry Marilyn Monroe designs in 150 stores, targeting younger shoppers with updated styles for modern blond bombshells.
lead_paragraph: WHAT WOULD Marilyn Monroe wear today if she were out for a night in the meatpacking district?

headline: A Wireless Speaker With a Wi-Fi Connection
abstract: Wireless speakers still generally connect to players by Bluetooth, but Wi-Fi, which can carry a lot more information, can sound a lot better. The Libratone Zipp is a new speaker using Wi-Fi, but it has its quirks.
lead_paragraph: When we talk wireless speakers, we still generally mean speakers that connect to players by Bluetooth.

headline: Nordstrom Opens Its Cards to Mint and Others
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Credit Cards', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Users of the online money management site Mint can again use the service to monitor their Nordstrom accounts.
lead_paragraph: Holders of Nordstrom’s store credit card can once again monitor their accounts using Mint.com, the online money management site.

headline: Low Cost Airline Seeks Planes
abstract: Norwegian, the first low-cost, long-haul airline to connect the United States to Europe, is searching for planes to replace the Dreamliners.
lead_paragraph: Norwegian, the first low-cost, long-haul airline to connect the United States to Europe, is searching for planes to lease for its inaugural flights on May 30 after Boeing warned that the Dreamliners, above, on which the airline based its cheap fares may not be flying. After the planes were grounded by the F.A.A. on Jan. 16, the carrier offered refunds to travelers, but few changed their plans. Fares were as low as $379 for flights from New York to Stockholm or Oslo. Last fall, the airline’s chief executive, Bjorn Kjos, called the Dreamliner “the tool” that will enable “low cost airlines in Europe to grow very fast and get very big.”

headline: The Original Search Engine
abstract: In the days before Google, the New York Public Library hand clipped hundreds of thousands of photos and illustrations to create over 12,000 different files for its Picture Collection.
lead_paragraph: In the days before Google, librarians at the New York Public Library hand clipped hundreds of thousands of photos and illustrations from magazines and books to create over 12,000 different files for its Picture Collection. Visitors could search for images of, say, rat catching or handshaking. It was here that Diego Rivera sought inspiration for his monumental murals and Andy Warhol borrowed advertising images, occasionally not returning them, for his art. The photographer Taryn Simon, whose work focuses on cataloging (contraband items seized by airport customs officials, bloodlines of Bosnian genocide victims), has been archiving the collection as part of a series now on view at the John Berggruen Gallery in San Francisco and at the Gagosian Gallery in London. The contents of the folder “Beards & Mustaches,” shown here, is one of her favorites.

headline: Pope Benedict XVI’s Remarks
abstract: The English translation of Pope Benedict XVI’s final general audience.
lead_paragraph: Following is the English translation of Pope Benedict XVI's remarks during his final general audience, as provided by Vatican Radio.

headline: What Should Be Done About Hearing Loss?
abstract: Questions about hearing are answered by this week’s expert, Dr. Neil J. DiSarno of the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association.
lead_paragraph: Judging purely by the responses to Ask an Expert, hearing problems are an enormous concern for baby boomers, rivaled only by worries about memory. More than 200 people wrote to this week’s expert on hearing, Neil J. DiSarno. Dr. DiSarno is chief staff officer for audiology at the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, and from 1998 to 2012 was chairman of the department of communication sciences and disorders at Missouri State University.

headline: Frogs
abstract: Two new picture books about frogs are spectacularly illustrated. There the similarities end.
lead_paragraph: To speak of an insanely gorgeous book about frogs would seem to pose a contradiction in terms. To note two such books just seems silly.

headline: A Revolutionary Marketing Strategy: Answer Customers’ Questions
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Online Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: An installer of fiberglass pools uses an unconventional marketing approach to save his company and start a new venture.
lead_paragraph: It is an indelible image of the financial crisis: a bird’s-eye view of the backyards of foreclosed houses, their in-ground pools festering with algae and mosquitoes. In Northern Virginia, Marcus Sheridan was in the financial storm.

headline: Escaping a Mother’s Chaos, and Her Own
abstract: Domenica Ruta’s new memoir, “With or Without You,” details her complicated life and her drug-addicted mother.
lead_paragraph: DANVERS, Mass. — Domenica Ruta’s “With or Without You” is a recovery memoir in which the most vivid character doesn’t recover. She is Ms. Ruta’s mother, Kathi, a lifelong drug user and occasional dealer — a “narcotic omnivore” as Domenica calls her in the book, which came out on Tuesday.

headline: Wheelies: The Shameless-Use-of-Photo Edition
abstract: As many as nine crushed cars may have fallen off of a barge in Commencement Bay near Tacoma, Wash.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 27
abstract: A boat moving through the Dal Lake in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Vulnerable Personnel
abstract: The Times's James Risen discusses sexual assaults at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas.
lead_paragraph: The Times's James Risen discusses sexual assaults at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas.

headline: In the Hunt for Capital, Private Equity Executives Outnumber Investors
abstract: Networking at the Super Return conference in Berlin is an exhausting process, as private equity firms set up shop in private rooms, at tables and even at the bar in the conference hotel
lead_paragraph: BERLIN – For private equity managers in search of investors, networking at the Super Return conference in Berlin is an exhausting process.

headline: White House Counts on G.O.P. to Bend as Cuts’ Effects Are Felt
abstract: While President Obama’s team believes Republicans will be blamed as budget cuts set in, Mr. Obama risks the possibility that Americans will shrug at the slow-rolling reductions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s team concedes that the almost certain arrival of across-the-board budget cuts on Friday will not immediately produce the politically dramatic layoffs and airport delays that the administration has been warning about for days.

headline: Musicological Sparring, Courtesy of David Byrne and Questlove
abstract: The two musicians talked about the connection between Stravinsky and Public Enemy, reviews, success and more.
lead_paragraph: Because making music is, at heart, a formidable acting job — in which the performer projects a stage persona that may not be much like what he or she is like offstage — public interviews with musicians can be a gamble. One way around that is to find a couple of players who come from different musical worlds, yet have things in common that might not be immediately apparent, and let them quiz each other for 90 minutes. And you can rig the game by choosing musicians who are secret scholars of musical arcana, and who enjoy a bit of musicological sparring. That was the Public Theater’s strategy on Tuesday evening, when it presented the first installment of its Public Forum series at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University.

headline: A Race Against Loeb That Left Ackman Breathless
abstract: In an excerpt from his article in the latest Vanity Fair, William D. Cohan recounts what was supposed to have been a friendly long-distance bike ride involving William A. Ackman and Daniel S. Loeb in the Hamptons. It didn’t end well for Mr. Ackman.
lead_paragraph: Even before their battle over Herbalife, the hedge fund managers William A. Ackman and Daniel S. Loeb have had their share of competitions. Some of them, it turns out, were a bit on the petty side.

headline: Already Competing With the Boys, Girls Get Their Own Wrestling League
abstract: As demand for girls’ wrestling grows, the city’s Public School Athletic League is inaugurating a girls’ program with 16 teams that officials estimate will include about 300 girls.
lead_paragraph: The Taft Educational Complex, in the South Bronx, started a boys’ wrestling team in November, and along with the dozens of boys who attended a season-opening meeting, there was one girl, Samantha Torres, 16.

headline: Video of Pope Benedict’s Public Farewell
abstract: Video and photos from social media of Pope Benedict’s last general audience in St. Peter’s Square before he formally resigns.
lead_paragraph: As our colleagues, Rachel Donadio and Alan Cowell report, Pope Benedict XVI held his final general audience in St. Peter’s Square on Wednesday, a day before he withdraws from the public for a cloistered life of prayer and meditation.

headline: Mets Scratch Wheeler Because of Stiffness
abstract: After he complained of abdominal stiffness, the Mets scratched the spring training start of pitching prospect Zack Wheeler.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Zack Wheeler, the Mets’ top pitching prospect, was scratched from his spring training start on Wednesday after feeling stiffness in his abdomen, around his right oblique muscle.

headline: Lead Singer Fired by Stone Temple Pilots
abstract: Five years after reuniting, the ’90s rockers tersely announced that “they have officially terminated Scott Weiland.”
lead_paragraph: The Stone Temple Pilots have parted ways with their longtime lead singer Scott Weiland. The group put out a single-sentence news release on Wednesday: “Stone Temple Pilots have announced they have officially terminated Scott Weiland.”

headline: Is Answering Your Customers’ Questions the Best Marketing Strategy?
abstract: Why don’t more businesses do what worked for Marcus Sheridan?
lead_paragraph: In a small-business conversation we’ve just published, Marcus Sheridan talks about how the recession and its aftermath almost destroyed his pool business. By early 2009, orders had fallen at River Pools and Spas, a 20-employee installer of in-ground, fiberglass pools in Virginia and Maryland, from an average of six a month to barely two. That winter, four customers who had planned to install pools costing more than $50,000 each demanded their deposits back. For three weeks running, the company overdrew its bank account.

headline: Saving, Credit and Debt: Learning About Personal Finance With The Times
abstract: In recognition of America Saves Week, we put together a toolbox of activities and related readings to help students learn essential lessons about personal finance.
lead_paragraph: How can students learn to make informed decisions when it comes to saving money, using credit cards and taking on college debt?

headline: Ex-Mayor in Greece Gets Life in Prison for Embezzlement
abstract: The former mayor of Salonika, also known as Thessaloniki, and two of his top aides were found guilty of embezzling almost $23.5 million in state funds.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The former mayor of Greece’s second city, Salonika, and two of his top aides were sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday after being found guilty of embezzling almost 18 million euros, or $23.5 million, in public money — a rare conviction in a case involving the political corruption that has contributed to the country’s dysfunction and economic decline.

headline: Finding the Visible in the Invisible
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A team of scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has developed a computer program that reveals colors and motions in video that are otherwise invisible to the naked eye.
lead_paragraph: A team of scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has developed a computer program that reveals colors and motions in video that are otherwise invisible to the naked eye.

headline: On Conference’s Eve, Thailand Is Pressed to Halt Ivory Trade
keywords: ['Elephants', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Ivory']
abstract: The prime minister publicly accepts a petition for a domestic trade ban.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Erik Olsen just noted here, many threatened species will be competing for attention when officials from 177 countries open a conference on the trade in endangered species on Sunday in Bangkok.

headline: N.H.L. Presents Realignment Plan
abstract: The N.H.L. and the N.H.L. Players’ Association have been negotiating on a realignment plan in recent weeks and a decision is expected soon so the new system can be put in place for the 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. and the N.H.L. Players’ Association have been negotiating a realignment plan in recent weeks and a decision is expected soon so the new system can be put in place for the 2013-14 season.

headline: Minnesota Wrestler Loses His Eligibility by Selling a Song
abstract: Joel Bauman was found to have violated an N.C.A.A. rule that prohibits athletes from using their name, image or athletic status to promote the sale of a commercial product.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Two sticky notes dangle from the bottom of a flat-screen monitor in Joel Bauman’s off-campus apartment. In large printed handwriting, one reads, “I Will Inspire,” the other, “I Will Impact.”

headline: Voting Rights Law Draws Skepticism From Justices
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A central provision of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 may be in peril, judging by tough questions from the Supreme Court’s more conservative members.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A central provision of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 may be in peril, judging from tough questioning on Wednesday from the Supreme Court’s more conservative members.

headline: Court Overturns Settlement of James Brown’s Estate
abstract: The South Carolina Supreme Court said the agreement ignored Brown’s wish that all his money go to charity.
lead_paragraph: The long and tangled court fight over the estate of James Brown entered a new chapter on Wednesday when the South Carolina Supreme Court overturned a settlement dividing his fortune, saying the former state attorney general had failed to follow Mr. Brown’s wishes in brokering the deal, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Copenhagen Hotel That’s Cool, Not Warm
abstract: The Andersen Boutique Hotel, which opened last April, boasts modern design elements, but lacks attention to detail.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Mexican Fare With Flair in Kansas City, Mo.
abstract: Port Fonda attracts a dedicated following, even though the chef warns it’s “not a place that everybody should even like.”
lead_paragraph: Walk into Port Fonda and your chest will likely rattle from the ear-popping rap music. You may be tempted to dance. But instead of D.J.’s and writhing partyers, you’ll find a mix of soccer moms, yuppies and beanie-and-flannel-wearing hipsters at minimalist wooden tables, straining their voices between bites of lengua tacos and tomato-braised octopus and sips of margaritas flavored with blood orange liqueur and hibiscus syrup.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Austerity
abstract: A bottle of “Austerity”-brand wine.
lead_paragraph: I just received an (unsolicited) package of “Austerity”-brand wine, marketed as an inexpensive booze for our age of austerity. Appropriately, the wines were packed in shredded $1 bills.

headline: Wages of Tamil Insurgency Paid by the Poor Left Behind
abstract: When the end of their revolution came, the Tamil expatriate middle class that supported the Tigers in the name of nationalism was fine. It was the poor with no means of escaping their geography who had become the body count.
lead_paragraph: It appears that the Sri Lankan government had somehow forgotten about the existence of the mobile phone.

headline: In Dubrovnik’s Medieval Walled City, a Renovated Four-Story House
abstract: Two stone town houses have been converted into a home with five bedrooms, listed for $1.74 million.
lead_paragraph: Two stone town houses have been converted into a home with five bedrooms, listed for $1.74 million.

headline: Van Cliburn 50th Anniversary Tribute
abstract: A video about his life and career.
lead_paragraph: A video about his life and career.

headline: House Hunting in ... Croatia
abstract: Average home prices fell by about 30 percent in Croatia as a result of the global financial crisis, though prices receded only slightly in Dubrovnik.

headline: Scientists Uncover Invisible Motion in Video
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Science and Technology', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A group of scientists have developed a system that amplifies tiny movements in videos, a technique that could have practical applications in fields as diverse as health care, manufacturing and law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: A 30-second video of a newborn baby shows the infant silently snoozing in its crib, his breathing barely perceptible. But when the video is run through an algorithm that can amplify both movement and color, the baby’s face blinks crimson with each tiny heartbeat.

headline: National Parks to Get Grants
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: National parks, forests and wildlife refuges are to receive $12.5 million in grants to improve access to them while supporting greener travel.
lead_paragraph: National parks, forests and wildlife refuges are to receive $12.5 million in grants to improve access to them while supporting greener travel, according to Ray LaHood, the transportation secretary. One example is a $1,735,000 grant to expand the Rocky Mountain Greenway, a pedestrian and bicycle trail system that will connect the Denver metropolitan area’s trail systems, three national wildlife refuges in the region and Rocky Mountain National Park, above. Another grant will finance new fuel-efficient buses for visitors in Glacier National Park. The grants, announced amid fears of widespread budget cuts to services in national parks due to sequestration, are part of $80 million in funds for transit improvements over the last three years.

headline: Witness in Oil Spill Trial Accuses BP of Negligence
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: An expert witness said the oil company’s actions before the explosion aboard a drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 were “beyond imprudent.”
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The practices of the oil giant BP came under sharp attack on Wednesday in a courtroom here by an expert witness who said its negligence caused the 2010 explosion aboard a Gulf of Mexico drilling rig that killed 11 workers and spewed millions of barrels of oil.

headline: Will Journalism Go the Way of Whaling?
abstract: Brooks and Collins ask how much new media mangle the message.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks:  A couple of times a week I walk by the Yale Drama School. It’s a strange experience because my dream through college was to go there and become a playwright, a cross between Clifford Odets and George S. Kaufman. When the socialist revolution came I wanted to be the one writing snappy one-liners to support it. Then I gave up that dream and decided to become Herbert Croly, the early New Republic editor, or John Reed, the radical who went to Harvard and then had a love affair with Diane Keaton (at least in “Reds”).

headline: Bernanke of Hippo
abstract: Not the time for chastity.
lead_paragraph: In discussing fiscal policy, I’ve been fond of quoting St. Augustine: “Grant me chastity and continence, but not yet”. Trying to slash the deficit while the economy is still up against the zero lower bound is a really bad idea, because it will depress the economy further and hurt both growth and revenue.

headline: Van Cliburn, Cold War Musical Envoy, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Cliburn won the first-place award at the 1958 Tchaikovsky International Competition, a victory viewed as an American triumph over the Soviet Union at the height of the cold war.
lead_paragraph: Van Cliburn, the American pianist whose first-place award at the 1958 International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow made him an overnight sensation and propelled him to a phenomenally successful and lucrative career, though a short-lived one, died on Wednesday at his home in Fort Worth. He was 78.

headline: Why Borrowers Use Payday Loans
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Payday Loans']
abstract: Borrowers often use payday loans out of desperation, a new report finds.
lead_paragraph: People use payday loans to avoid borrowing from family and friends, and to avoid cutting back further on expenses. But they often end up doing those things anyway to pay back the loan, a new report finds.

headline: Clip: ‘War Witch’
abstract: A scene from "War Witch," directed by Kim Nguyen.
lead_paragraph: A scene from "War Witch," directed by Kim Nguyen.

headline: Remembering Van Cliburn
abstract: Images of the celebrated classical pianist.
lead_paragraph: Images of the celebrated classical pianist.

headline: Hagel, in First Day on Job, Warns of Challenges Cuts Pose for the Military
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel started his first day at the Pentagon on Wednesday morning by warning that looming cuts in military spending were one of the biggest challenges facing the Defense Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After surviving a long and bruising Senate confirmation battle, Defense SecretaryChuck Hagel started his first day at the Pentagon on Wednesday morning by warning that looming cuts in military spending were one of the biggest challenges facing the Defense Department, but that the United States must continue to “engage with the world.”

headline: Union Leaders Call for Repeal of Automatic Spending Cuts
abstract: With President Obama and Congressional Republicans making little progress toward reaching a budget deal, the nation’s union leaders on Wednesday began pushing a new proposal to prevent the looming cuts: immediately repeal the sequestration law.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — With President Obama and Congressional Republicans making little progress toward reaching a budget deal, the nation’s union leaders on Wednesday began pushing a new proposal to prevent the automatic spending cuts, known as sequestration: immediately repeal the law that put them in place.

headline: Tomorrow Has Arrived
abstract: A prize for Dan Perkins.
lead_paragraph: Tom Tomorrow, that is; he’s received the Herblock prize. Congratulations to Dan Perkins for a well-deserved honor, even if it required some violence to my cartoon alter ego:

headline: Media Companies, on Defensive About Violence, Plan Campaign on Parental Control
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Movies', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Television', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)']
abstract: Entertainment companies are responding to criticism that violence in film and on television has contributed to a culture of violence in the country.
lead_paragraph: Major media companies, facing criticism about the level of violence in their content, are initiating a campaign intended to make parents more aware about ways to limit exposure to violent entertainment.

headline: Clashes Over Land Seizures Batter the Police in Myanmar
abstract: The police tried to disperse villagers in a township in the Irrawaddy River delta who were protesting the taking of land by a private company.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — When angry villagers clashed with security forces on Tuesday over land seizures in Myanmar, the police apparently got the worst of it.

headline: History Shadows an Upbeat Music Sales Forecast
keywords: ['Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Music', 'Shopping and Retail', 'United States Economy']
abstract: For those who have seen the industry’s optimism dashed before, an upbeat report on Tuesday by its global trade body, the International Federation for the Phonographic Industry, brought hope and skepticism.
lead_paragraph: In early 2004, Billboard magazine ran a cover story with a hopeful headline: “Have Sales Finally Hit Bottom?”

headline: Blaming the Victim
abstract: The G.O.P. thinks it’s always up to the other side to make nice.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Republicans who manufactured a crisis over the nomination of Chuck Hagel as Secretary of Defense are now saying that it is up to the newly confirmed Mr. Hagel to mend fences with Congress.

headline: A 1960 Cadillac Takes Center Stage at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: The Cadillac is the real thing, bought on eBay, then painted indigo blue with metallic flecks by the Met staff and illuminated by the lighting designer, Kevin Adams, to reach the high C of automotive fantasy.
lead_paragraph: In classical opera, characters tend to get around in swan boats or chariots, but a production of “Rigoletto” at New York’s Metropolitan Opera puts a 1960 Cadillac Coupe de Ville in the spotlight. A soprano who has been fatally stabbed is briefly stuffed in its trunk, and the final duet, with the soprano dying in her father’s arms, takes place at the car’s rear, framed by fins and tail lights.

headline: The Economics of Visual Effects
abstract: With visual effects firms under great financial strain, their artists are protesting their working conditions and the loss of jobs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – There’s a high-stakes fight brewing here, between the digital artists who create the movie-magic effects that many blockbusters depend on and the studios that employ them. Audiences got a taste of it on Sunday, when Bill Westenhofer, a visual effects winner for “Life of Pi,” was played off the Oscar stage with the “Jaws” music, just as he was talking about the bankruptcy of the film’s effects house, Rhythm & Hues.

headline: A Tide of Local Influences
abstract: As the expedition prepares to leave Chile, an early look at the data reveals conditions both familiar and distinctly local.
lead_paragraph: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes and wrote about his expedition to the North Pacific in the fall. This is his last post from Chile.

headline: Raised in Louisville and Peru, Farrell Takes His Game to New England
abstract: Raised in Louisville, with a side trip to Peru, the No. 1 overall pick Brian Farrell is hoping to hit the ground running with the New England Revolution.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Farrell was hardly a surprise as the top pick in Major League Soccer’s Superdraft in January: he was one of the most dominant players in the country during the 2012 N.C.A.A season with the University of Louisville. A versatile player, Farrell excelled in central defense, right back and defensive midfield, and he is expected to be in the starting lineup for the New England Revolution when they open at Chicago next weekend.

headline: New Partnership Brings New Design for Sol Republic
abstract: Sol Republic, known for making headphones with interchangeable components, released two new designs Tuesday that are infused with Tokidoki’s distinctive style.
lead_paragraph: Sol Republic knows a good partnership when it sees it. After Michael Phelps wore a pair of Sol Republic headphones during the Summer Olympics last year, the company quickly signed an endorsement deal with the swimmer.

headline: Season-Ending Surgery for the Knicks’ Wallace
abstract: The veteran Rasheed Wallace helped push the Knicks to a 17-5 start before his injury.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When Rasheed Wallace came out of retirement, he was everything the Knicks expected: a 6-foot-11 savvy defender who provided veteran leadership and helped spread the floor with long 3-pointers. As the season progressed, though, Wallace showed why it was risky to sign a 38-year-old player who had been out of the league for two years.

headline: Dick Tracy, Your Watch Is Ready, Almost
abstract: Here come the smartwatches, and a motley bunch they are. Some require daily charging, others use watch batteries. When it comes to design, well ...
lead_paragraph: Every time you look, our computers have moved closer to us.

headline: Florida Atlantic Students Protest GEO Deal
abstract: Florida Atlantic students have been protesting the school’s decision to sell the naming rights to the football stadium to a private prison company.
lead_paragraph: When Florida Atlantic announced that it had sold the naming rights to its football stadium to a commercial prison company, it prompted a round of sighs across the college landscape, seemingly the latest example that money trumps all other concerns in modern athletics. And, it turned out, many Florida Atlantic students weren’t crazy about the idea either.

headline: Smithsonian Says Looming Cuts ‘Won’t Affect the Public,’ for Now
abstract: Rather than close museums or the National Zoo, the Smithsonian says that if cuts take place they will initially affect maintenance, new construction, hiring and other areas.
lead_paragraph: Despite automatic federal spending cuts scheduled to take effect on Friday, the Smithsonian Institution has promised to keep its 19 museums and the National Zoo in Washington open for their regular hours, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Guide to Paris Fashion Week
abstract: From juicers to perfumers to street photographers, we suggest noteworthy boutiques, exhibits, and eateries to check out during downtime in the City of Light.
lead_paragraph: From juicers to perfumers to street photographers, we suggest noteworthy boutiques, exhibits, and eateries to check out during downtime in the City of Light. See the interactive slide show

headline: Incarceration Rates for Blacks Have Fallen Sharply, Report Shows
abstract: The decline from 2000 to 2009 marks a significant shift in the racial makeup of America’s prisons, according to a report released Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Incarceration rates for black Americans dropped sharply from 2000 to 2009, especially for women, while the rate of imprisonment for whites and Hispanics rose over the same decade, according to a report released Wednesday by a prison research and advocacy group in Washington.

headline: Branching Out From the Altar
abstract: Having specialized in wedding dresses, Monique Lhuillier’s boutique includes red-carpet ready clothing as well.
lead_paragraph: I DON’T KNOW who’s mixing the soundtrack at the sleek new Monique Lhuillier boutique just off Madison Avenue, but I was amused to hear that old standard “Everything She Wants” (Wham!, 1984) bleating from the loudspeakers.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: New fiction by Holly Goddard Jones, Jim Gavin, Lucy Ellmann, Lars Iyer, Gene Kerrigan and Chloe Hooper.
lead_paragraph: This month’s new books involve their share of chills and thrills: a girl discovers a body in the woods; crooks in Dublin plan a heist; a woman finds herself stranded with an unhinged paramour; and intellectual life teeters on the edge of collapse.

headline: Telling the American Story

lead_paragraph: The journalist Lisa Ling discusses the third season of her documentary series, “Our America.” | Computer programs that amplify video. | The future of mobile advertising. | Apps for stargazing.

headline: AMC Confirms New Show Runner for ‘The Walking Dead’
abstract: Scott M. Gimple, who joined “The Walking Dead” in its second season as a writer and producer, is the third person to serve its show runner in the short but successful run of this AMC horror series.
lead_paragraph: “The Walking Dead,” the hit AMC horror series, will live on for its fourth season under the stewardship of a new show runner, Scott M. Gimple, the cable channel has confirmed. Mr. Gimple, a writer and producer who joined “The Walking Dead” in its second season (and whose previous credits include the television series “FlashForward” and the film “Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance”), was first reported to have been promoted to the position of show runner by the Hollywood trade publications in January. At that time, AMC had about as much to say about the news as a zombified corpse might. But on Wednesday, the cable channel finally confirmed his appointment in a release that also said production on Season 4 of “The Walking Dead” would begin in Atlanta on May 6.

headline: Scouting Report
abstract: Following the adventures of a fictional, fashionable child, and sales at Patrik Ervell and DKNY.

headline: Her Crowning Glory in a Box
abstract: Not just celebrities, but socialites, models and everyday women wear wigs on the sly, not to disguise thinning or sparse hair, but for fashion and convenience.
lead_paragraph: It was the best hair day of my life, and I was working it, tossing my head like a supermodel, twirling strands around my fingers, admiring myself in store windows. At home, my doorman said, “Looking good!” My husband greeted me with, “Jennifer!” as in Aniston. My teenager muttered, “That’s a little sexy, isn’t it?”

headline: Rand Paul, Realism and Republican Reform
abstract: How the Kentucky senator has widened the foreign policy debate within the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, during Chuck Hagel’s confirmation hearings, the American Conservative’s Daniel McCarthy wrote a post arguing that Hagel’s treatment at the hands of various Republican senators demonstrates that the space for a less bellicose foreign policy in the Republican Party has essentially vanished, and that the advice often given to the party’s realists and non-interventionists no longer obtains:

headline: Internet Sleuths Add Evidence to Chinese Military Hacking Accusations
abstract: In the last week, Chinese-speaking Internet users and amateur hackers have added further proof to a security report that tied a prolific Chinese hacking group to China’s People’s Liberation Army.
lead_paragraph: Regular users of the Internet have been busy in the week since The New York Times reported that Mandiant, a computer security firm, had tied a prolific Chinese hacking group to a specific People’s Liberation Army unit in Shanghai.

headline: The Daily Do | Dries Van Noten
abstract: At Dries, a perfectly polished do looked slightly unraveled after a supposed night on the town.
lead_paragraph: Dries Van Noten’s finger wave evoked the unraveling of a perfectly polished do after, say, one of Zelda Fitzgerald’s nights on the town. Elegant, loose waves swept across the forehead, side-parted and neatly tucked behind one ear but messily half-tucked out of the other.

headline: Six Ways to Spot an Eating Disorder Early
keywords: ['ANOREXIA NERVOSA', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Eating Disorders', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Weight']
abstract: Cooking? Breakfast on the run? Some of the early warning signs of teenage eating disorders aren’t what you might expect.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t just want to be thin,” said Madi O’Dell, whose battle with an eating disorder began in her freshman year of high school. “People think you choose to have an eating disorder because you want to lose weight. But that’s not how it was for me. I wanted to be in control.”

headline: Holding Hands Across the Years
abstract: A new exhibition in Paris uses fashion as part of the conversational to-and-fro with the past.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Olivier Saillard, who moves with dragonfly quickness and always seems to be smiling, has done as much as any costume curator nowadays to make the trifling seem profound and the old appear modern.

headline: Corvex and Related Dangle Promise of Higher Bid for REIT
abstract: An activist hedge fund and The Related Companies offered to raise their takeover bid for CommonWealth REIT on Wednesday to about $2.26 billion, aiming to put additional pressure on the real estate company.
lead_paragraph: An activist hedge fund and The Related Companies offered to raise their takeover bid for CommonWealth REIT on Wednesday to about $2.26 billion, aiming to put additional pressure on the real estate company.

headline: Statue of Rosa Parks Is Unveiled at the Capitol
keywords: ['Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Dozens of Rosa Parks’s relatives attended a dedication ceremony on Wednesday as she became the first black woman to be honored with a life-size statue in the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than half a century after Rosa Parks helped kindle the civil rights movement by refusing to give up her seat on a segregated bus in Alabama, she has become the first black woman to be honored with a life-size statue in the Capitol.

headline: A Pep Talk on Energy Innovation
abstract: Steven Chu, who will soon step down as energy secretary, champions alternative technologies at a conference on cutting-edge energy research.
lead_paragraph: In what might prove to be his last public appearance as energy secretary, Steven Chu delivered a pep talk of sorts on Wednesday to hundreds of entrepreneurs, researchers and others at the ARPA-E conference on energy innovation in suburban Maryland.

headline: Exiting Fifth Avenue Station, Subway Riders Find a Trap
abstract: With one gate open but another one locked, some unwary subway passengers at the Fifth Avenue-53rd Street station stumble into trouble.
lead_paragraph: The travelers stewed, caught between the trip they were sure they had completed and the sidewalk they could not reach, compelled to confront a question of ethics at, of all places, a subway turnstile.

headline: Private Equity’s Tax-Advantaged Rivals
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Private Equity', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Master limited partnerships received a tax break decades ago when United States oil production was declining. Now, with oil output booming, is this a wasteful subsidy?
lead_paragraph: American buyout barons have new tax-dodge rivals: master limited partnerships.

headline: Talking Talent | Sarah Paulson
abstract: The actress, praised for her role in “Game Change” on HBO, opens up about her more recent parts.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off an Emmy and Golden Globe nomination for her supporting role in 2012’s “Game Change,” Sarah Paulson is starring as Sally Talley in Lanford Wilson’s 1979 Pulitzer Prize-winning play Talley’s Folly, playing Off Broadway at the Roundabout Theater Company’s Laura Pels Theater through May 5. In 97 minutes, Paulson gives a moving performance opposite Danny Burstein, as two complicated souls who are destined to fall in love, no matter the cost. After the production, Paulson will return to Los Angeles this summer to shoot the third season of Ryan Murphy’s “American Horror Story.” To the dismay of her Lana Winters fans, she will not be reprising the Emmy-worthy character, but will be recast in a new, top secret role. But it’s not all stage and small screen for Paulson, the 38 year old actress is slated to star in a slew of films, including playing Michael Fassbender’s wife in Steve McQueen’s “Twelve Year’s a Slave.”

lead_paragraph: … And now for a bit of counterprogramming …

abstract: Ms. Zarin discusses her new book of personal essays.
lead_paragraph: In the personal essays that make up her new book, “An Enlarged Heart,” Cynthia Zarin writes about the changing face of New York City, the pleasures of a good coat and her life as a poet and journalist, including her time at The New Yorker magazine. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Zarin discussed these subjects and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: More Retailers at Risk of Amazon ‘Showrooming’
abstract: Target and Best Buy have made it clear they are fighting the phenomenon of showrooming, in which customers browse for television sets and other products in stores and then buy them online for less. A new study of Amazon customers who research products in stores offers some insight into who else could be at the greatest risk of losing business to showrooming.
lead_paragraph: Target and Best Buy have made it pretty clear they are fighting back against the phenomenon of showrooming, in which customers browse for television sets and other products in stores and then buy them online from Amazon and other etailers for less. Both companies recently made their seasonal practices of matching prices at online retailers a year-round policy.

headline: Test Run: Sleepytime, a Bedtime Calculator
abstract: Early bird wannabes, rejoice! There is a nerdy hack for helping you become more of a morning person.
lead_paragraph: I’m not a morning person, not even close. Over the years, I’ve devised several systems to get myself out of bed at a reasonable hour in the morning and curb the bouts of chronic oversleeping that have plagued me since high school. But setting multiple alarms proved futile, as did programming automatic wake-up calls. I’ve tried bribing my mom and close friends to call me when they wake up and hidden alarm clocks under the bed to force myself out of it. Nothing has worked for more than a day or two.

headline: Mapping a Plague of Frogs
abstract: An interactive Web site, periodically updated, visualizes the occurrence of cases of amphibian chytrid fungus around the world.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things that epidemiologists do when studying a new outbreak of disease is to map its occurrence. From there, they try to tease out patterns related to the malady’s cause and prevalence, and begin working on solutions to quell it.

headline: Prince Harry Dons an Apron
abstract: The Prince of Wales makes mokoenya, a type of doughnut, on a trip to Lesotho.
lead_paragraph: Prince Harry helped to make traditional cakes on Wednesday when he visited the Kananelo Centre for the deaf in Lesotho, a project supported by a charity he founded along with Prince Seeiso of Lesotho. Wearing a Paddington Bear apron, Prince Harry helped roll out dough to make mokoenya, a doughnut-like treat cooked in boiling oil, according to The Telegraph.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Multilingual Smartphones and the Kindle-Killer App
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Low-Risk Offenders on the Loose
abstract: ICE has released several hundred people from its detention centers.
lead_paragraph: Immigration and Customs Enforcement has released several hundred people from its detention centers across the country, saying it needs to save money ahead of the automatic budget cuts due to begin Friday.  The detainees were not simply let loose, but placed under other forms of supervision, and their deportation cases will proceed.

headline: Old Acquaintances Remember Cliburn
abstract: Van Cliburn, who died Wednesday, was recalled as a 20-something who moved his own furniture and was seemingly deaf to wake-up calls.
lead_paragraph: To the world, he was the famous concert pianist who gave an uncertain nation a shot of confidence in those tense months after Sputnik. “The Texan who conquered Russia,” Time magazine called him. But to the people who saw him carrying furniture on West 57th Street, he was just another 20-something, moving to a new apartment. And mostly doing it himself.

lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Manager Terry Collins informed catcher Travis d’Arnaud on Wednesday that the team did not want him to block home plate when applying a tag on a runner trying to score.

headline: Be Careful of the Locals: They’re Tough
abstract: The short story collection “Nothing Gold Can Stay,” by Ron Rash, offers 14 stories that range in mood from wryly comic to brutal.
lead_paragraph: Ron Rash’s new short story collection, “Nothing Gold Can Stay,” is this Appalachian author’s best book since his 2008 “Serena.” If “Serena” becomes famous as the basis for a coming Jennifer Lawrence-Bradley Cooper movie, never forget that it began as a fierce, breathtaking book, one of the greatest American novels in recent memory.

headline: Iowa Congressman Says He Won’t Run for Senate
abstract: The decision on Wednesday by Representative Tom Latham not to make a bid to fill the seat of Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who is retiring, disappointed many Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Did the Republican Party’s quest to win control of the Senate just become more difficult?

headline: A Hush-Hush Topic No More
abstract: Devotees of sex play involving bondage and domination want to make their voices heard.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday night, a small group of people lined up in a cinder-block hallway inside an unmarked entrance to Paddles, a club on West 26th Street. Two men in their 60s were discussing real estate and a few women in their 20s were sending last-minute texts before going down two flights to the subterranean space.

headline: Intel to Invest in Research and Development in Brazil
abstract: Intel plans to invest $152 million in Brazil over the next five years in research and development, joining forces with the Brazilian government, which has made increasing the country’s software output a top priority.
lead_paragraph: SAO PAULO – Intel plans to invest $152 million in Brazil over the next five years in research and development, the chip manufacturer said on Wednesday. In doing so, the company will partner with the Brazilian government, which has made increasing the country’s software output a top priority.

lead_paragraph: TORONTO – Michael Ryder was in a familiar place Wednesday morning with the Canadiens’ backdrop behind him as he met the media for the first time since Tuesday’s trade which sent him from Dallas to Montreal in exchange for Erik Cole.

headline: The Rough Beauty of Everyday Speech
abstract: In inspired hands the most unbeautiful, sometimes maddeningly hazy and imprecise language can take on a distinct and surprising appeal.
lead_paragraph: We don’t go to the theater to listen to conversations that we might just as easily hear while waiting in line at the grocery store or commuting on the subway. Among the essential gifts that most great playwrights possess is an ability to take the dross of humble human speech and give it a silvering polish.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Rochas
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a deep-blood crocodile Mary Jane.

headline: A Maverick Unleashed
abstract: Jun Takahashi’s modest and brilliant show on Wednesday night at the Sorbonne probably confirmed for many in the audience why they will cross an ocean just to be tickled for 15 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Jun Takahashi’s modest and brilliant show Wednesday night at the Sorbonne probably confirmed for many in the audience why they will cross an ocean just to be tickled for 15 minutes. Mr. Takahashi, the creator of Undercover, hasn’t done a Paris show in awhile, though he has been busy at home base in Tokyo. You may remember he designed a line for Uniqlo.

headline: One on One: Sugata Mitra, 2013 TED Prize Winner
abstract: Sugata Mitra, best known for an experiment in which he provided a computer to children in an Indian slum and watched as they taught themselves how to use it with no supervision, is the winner of the 2013 TED Prize, which grants him $1 million to build an educational facility based on what he has learned.
lead_paragraph: Are teachers keeping students from learning in the digital age? Sugata Mitra, a professor of educational technology at Newcastle University, believes so. Dr. Mitra is best known for an experiment in which he carved a hole from his research center in Delhi into an adjacent slum, placing a freely accessible computer there for children to use.

headline: Smith, Now No. 2 in San Francisco, Is Expected to Be Sent to the Chiefs
abstract: Quarterback Alex Smith, the No. 1 overall draft pick in 2005, would join a franchise that won two games last season but seems poised for a turnaround.
lead_paragraph: Quarterback Alex Smith, the No. 1 overall draft pick in 2005, whose career was revived by San Francisco Coach Jim Harbaugh before he was benched last season in favor of Colin Kaepernick, is expected to be traded to the Kansas City Chiefs when the new N.F.L. year begins in two weeks.

headline: Houston Hall
abstract: A cavernous spot for unusual brews.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new beer hall in town and, surprise, it’s actually in Manhattan. You’d think it would be tough to fit one into the bourgeois West Village, but the owners of Heartland Brewery have done just that, repurposing a parking garage across from Film Forum into a fin de siècle themed drinking parlor for up to 500 people.

headline: Court Approves Dewey Bankruptcy Plan, Officially Dissolving Firm
abstract: At the heart of the proposal is a deal under which about 450 former partners agreed to return a portion of their pay, raising about $72 million for creditors.
lead_paragraph: Nine months ago, when it filed the largest law firm bankruptcy case in United States history, Dewey & LeBoeuf effectively ceased to exist. But its carcass has languished in court, as restructuring experts handled the messy task of unwinding the firm and negotiating a plan to pay back its creditors.

headline: As a Veteran Violist Takes His Leave, a Quartet Briefly Becomes a Quintet
abstract: Samuel Rhodes, the Juilliard String Quartet’s longtime violist, played works by Beethoven, Mozart and himself alongside Roger Tapping, who is to replace him in July.
lead_paragraph: In a relay race some of the most dramatic moments occur during the handoff, when the anchor begins to accelerate as the incoming runner approaches, until the two run side by side, charging forward while trying to pass the baton as seamlessly as possible. Tuesday evening’s concert by the Juilliard String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall offered the chamber ensemble equivalent of the handoff zone with Samuel Rhodes, the quartet’s violist of 44 years, playing alongside Roger Tapping, who is to replace him in July. While the program of works by Beethoven, Mozart and Mr. Rhodes himself did not quite reach track-and-field levels of adrenaline, there were moments of breathless intensity as well as long stretches in which to revel in the glowing warm sound created by an additional viola.

headline: Angry Viewers Are Writing the Academy (and Here’s What They’re Saying)
abstract: Viewers upset with the Oscars telecast share the letters they’ve written to the Academy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The producers of Sunday’s widely criticized Academy Awards, Neil Meron and Craig Zadan, have paradoxically been on a victory lap.

headline: Corporate Call for Change in Gay Marriage Case
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: More than 200 companies have signed on to a supporting brief calling for the Supreme Court to overturn part of the Defense of Marriage Act.
lead_paragraph: Arguing that the federal Defense of Marriage Act imposes serious administrative and financial costs on their operations, some of the nation’s largest companies filed a supporting brief with the Supreme Court on Wednesday, urging it to overturn a section of the act that denies federal benefits and recognition to same-sex couples.

headline: Drawing on Hip-Hop, Indie and Pop to Frame a New Jazz Ensemble
abstract: Next Collective, which played at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday, has a new album, “Cover Art,” which draws inspiration from pop.
lead_paragraph: Christian aTunde Adjuah pointed the upturned bell of his trumpet directly forward at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night, head cocked as if he were staring down a rifle sight. Over an arpeggiated line spun fast by the guitarist Matthew Stevens and the bassist Ben Williams he floated a mournful melody, recognizable as “No Church in the Wild.”

headline: Still Raging Loudly, Headbanging Included
abstract: Conor Oberst and his band Desaparecidos brought their songs of sarcasm, pessimism and rage to Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: Conor Oberst half-apologized for the “very pessimistic” and “very sarcastic” songs of his band Desaparecidos when they performed at Webster Hall on Tuesday night. But he knew that sarcasm, pessimism and rage are the essence of Desaparecidos’ songs, which proudly and knowingly join the tradition of punky protest music.

abstract: At the Slava Cup in Moscow last weekend the main event was the Top 8 Teams.

headline: Oscar-Winning Lessons in History and Hard Sell
abstract: In the days after “Argo” won best picture at the Oscar ceremony on Sunday, it’s been a parlor game in Hollywood to figure out why “Lincoln” lost.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A few months into awards season, at a party celebrating another movie, a veteran actor-writer-director-producer, who takes his Academy Awards duties very seriously, whispered to me that he was sure “Lincoln” would win big on Oscar night. “Because it’s Lincoln,” he said. “It’s like not voting for George Washington. And you really feel like you get to know Lincoln. We can’t not vote for our favorite president.”

headline: ‘Jay DeFeo: A Retrospective’
abstract: A look at the exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: A look at the exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Amateur Stargazing With a GPS Tour Guide
abstract: Several apps for iOS and Android will recreate the sky, calculated from your GPS coordinates, to help you understand the heavenly bodies you see.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite things to do on a clear winter night is to take a trip to a beach near where I live and do some amateur stargazing, far from the glare of streetlights. After years of simply using my eyes, I recently bought a portable telescope. Now I can just about see the stripes of clouds on Jupiter, which is a truly awesome sight.

headline: Rue du Mail: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Syrians Describe Apparent Missile Strikes on Aleppo
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: In the aftermath of deadly explosions in Syria’s largest city, apparently caused by government missile strikes on neighborhoods in rebel hands, survivors described the devastation.
lead_paragraph: Human Rights Watch investigators who visited Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, have concluded that the Syrian government fired at least four ballistic missiles into civilian neighborhoods there last week, killing more than 141 people, including 71 children. As my colleague Anne Barnard explained, the rights group released details of the four documented strikes, and a video report, on Tuesday.

headline: Extra Help for Selling Used Furnishings
abstract: An online furniture consignment business offers an alternative to Craigslist and eBay.
lead_paragraph: Viyet, an online furniture consignment business, was created for people who want to sell their goods but are wary of Craigslist and eBay. Founded by Rachel Rodin, a fashion stylist, and Louise Youngson-Klasfeld, a former physical therapist, the site is scheduled to officially begin in early April with two tiers of service. In the White Glove program, Viyet will remove all consigned items from the home and sell them online, starting at a cost of $250 for the first piece, and $1 per cubic foot of storage. For those who choose the Premiere service, Viyet will price and photograph pieces that remain in the client’s home until sold, at a cost of $150 for the first piece and $50 for each additional item. Consigned items stay on the Web site for 60 days, and Viyet takes 50 percent of the sale price. Items that aren’t sold are either returned to the owners or donated to the Salvation Army. Information: (212) 712-1513 or viyet.com.

headline: A Desk That Aims for Progress
abstract: The compact plywood work station includes a storage cabinet and a swiveling rocking chair.
lead_paragraph: For Jurgen Bey, a partner in the Dutch design firm Makkink & Bey, too much attention is paid to home furnishings and not nearly enough to design for public spaces. Seeking to bring domestic comfort and elegance to work environments, Mr. Bey, a first-generation member of the avant-garde Dutch design collaborative Droog, and his wife, Rianne Makkink, have produced furniture over the years for the Dutch company Prooff (short for progressive office furniture). Their latest, the SideSeat, is a compact plywood work station that incorporates a linoleum-topped desk, a storage cabinet and a swiveling rocking chair. Mr. Bey favors small work surfaces. “With a big table,” he said, “you always see too many things to distract you.” The price is around $3,000 plus shipping and duty from Prooff, 011-31-10-211-00-80 or prooff.com.

headline: When a Gardening Manual and a Cookbook Collide
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Patti Moreno’s book “Gardening by Cuisine” provides basics on growing food as well as recipes.
lead_paragraph: “I want to bring my garden to you, to let you twist juicy tomatoes off the vine and serve them at your dinner table,” Patti Moreno writes in “Gardening by Cuisine” (Sterling Publishing; $19), a guide for yard-to-table foodies. Ms. Moreno, a creator of the Web site gardengirltv.com who lives in urban Roxbury, Mass., gives the basics for gardening in raised beds, containers and window boxes. She first lays out essential bits about water, compost and pestilence, then offers plans for an herb pesto garden, an Asian stir-fry garden, a vegan raw garden and more. Confident that her instructions will yield bounty, she also provides recipes, like baba ghanouj from a Mediterranean vegetable garden and sunflower-seed cake from a Native American garden. A frisky yet sensible tone pervades the book, from the author’s dedication (to her family, “for eating all their veggies”) to the Mouth-watering Cilantro Lime Martini recipe at the end.

headline: In Dumbo, Showing an Industrial Aesthetic the Door
abstract: A colorful renovation to soften the rough edges.
lead_paragraph: A colorful renovation to soften the rough edges.

headline: Colors to Make Dumbo Blush
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: When Ryan Foster and Anne Maxwell Foster expressed interest in buying an industrial-style loft in Dumbo, even their real estate agent was surprised. “She was, like: ‘Are you sure you like this place? It’s very Brooklyn,’ ” Ms. Maxwell Foster recalled.

headline: Dale Robertson, a Horse-Savvy Actor in Westerns, Is Dead at 89
abstract: Mr. Robertson appeared in more than 60 movies but was very likely known more for his television work in shows like “Tales of Wells Fargo” and “Iron Horse” and as a host of “Death Valley Days.”
lead_paragraph: Dale Robertson, who parlayed his Oklahoma drawl and a way with horses into a long career as a popular, strong-minded star of westerns on television and in the movies, died on Wednesday in San Diego. He was 89.

headline: The Heartbreak of a $40 Million Yacht
abstract: G. Bruce Knecht on his new book, “Grand Ambition,” about an effort to build the best yacht in America.
lead_paragraph: G. Bruce Knecht considers his new book, “Grand Ambition” (Simon & Schuster, $27), to be a water-based companion to Tracy Kidder’s “House.” Like that classic work of nonfiction, “Grand Ambition” focuses on all the aspects of building, and all the people involved, only instead of a house the subject is a $40 million yacht called Lady Linda.

headline: Senate, in a More Affable Mode, Backs Treasury Nominee
abstract: The Senate easily approved President Obama’s choice for Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, just a day after a highly politicized vote for Chuck Hagel, the new defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday easily and, for the most part, affably confirmed President Obama’s pick for Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, a day after the president’s nominee for defense secretary narrowly survived a highly politicized confirmation vote.

headline: A Big Swig of Extra Battery Power
abstract: Digital Treasurers has gussied up the basic auxiliary battery, putting 13,000 mAh of lithium-ion power into what appears to be a flask.
lead_paragraph: There is not a lot that sets auxiliary batteries apart. A few more amps here, a few more USB plugs there, and that’s about it.

headline: Dining Tables
abstract: Today, the dining table has unlimited uses, and its size is bound to make an impact on a room.
lead_paragraph: DINING TABLES USED TO be reserved for special occasions, but not anymore. “People work on them, kids do art projects on them, and it’s where you hang out,” said Andrew Kotchen, who founded the New York design firm Workshop/apd with Matthew Berman in 1999. “It’s often the single biggest surface in the house.”

headline: Sales at Modani Furniture, Garnet Hill, DDC and Others
abstract: Discounts on rugs, floor samples, lighting and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected pieces are up to 70 percent off at Modani Furniture, through Monday (the white Callisto dining table, originally $940, is $240); 40 East 19th Street (Broadway), (212) 780-1800, modani.com.

headline: A Dream of a (Designed) Couch
abstract: Sofas do more work than any other piece of furniture. Don’t they deserve to be more than humdrum?
lead_paragraph: The sofa of my dreams is low and blocky, with cushions covered in different fabrics. It has big, cheerful buttons tacked on the back and a casual asymmetry that invites sprawling. Designed by Hella Jongerius for Vitra, the sofa, called Polder, costs at least $9,500. Which is why it furnishes only my fantasy life. But if a pile of extra cash were to drop in my lap, I would consider the indulgence.

headline: If You Can’t Bear to Buy a Couch, Try a Makeover
abstract: Quick fixes for stained upholstery, when a new sofa isn’t an option.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I remember peeling myself off friends’ vinyl-covered couches and feeling lucky my house didn’t turn people into Colorforms characters. Now, with my furniture yielding to assaults from children, dogs and a cat, the big question is, where I can lay my hands on some vinyl?

lead_paragraph: Three days after crashing the Oscars red carpet by dressing Helen Hunt in a strapless gown, H&M, the Swedish fast fashion retailer, crashed Paris Fashion Week.

lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Samsung Electronics, which continues to vex Apple, now has another target: the BlackBerry.

headline: Pandora to Limit Free Listening, Citing Royalty Costs

lead_paragraph: Faced with rising royalty costs, Pandora will limit the amount of free music that its users will have access to on mobile devices.

headline: Germany: Gay Rights, Including for Marriage, Are Campaign Issue
keywords: ['Elections', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative Christian Democrats are struggling to catch up to changing attitudes among voters on issues like gay marriage and adoption.
lead_paragraph: Gay rights have quickly emerged in Germany as a campaign issue in this parliamentary election year, with Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative Christian Democrats struggling to catch up to changing attitudes among voters on issues like gay marriage and adoption. The debate here was given new impetus by a decision this month by the Federal Constitutional Court, which ruled that gays and lesbians should be allowed to adopt children already adopted by their partners. The next battle, over tax benefits for civil unions, has already begun. The issue is particularly contentious for Ms. Merkel’s party, which has tried to balance a conservative, traditional family-values approach favored by the party’s older voters with a desire to appeal to younger voters who support gay rights in greater numbers.

headline: Analyzing the Couch
abstract: A high-end sofa can look remarkably similar to a low-end one, so why is it more than 10 times as expensive?
lead_paragraph: Does anyone get excited about buying a couch? I can’t say the prospect awakens the impassioned consumer in me.

lead_paragraph: ORLANDO — The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nation’s largest federation of unions, has issued an apparent endorsement of the Keystone XL oil pipeline — apparent because it enthusiastically called for expanding the nation’s pipeline system, without specifically mentioning Keystone.

headline: Switzerland: Shooting in Factory
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Gun Control']
abstract: At least three people were killed and seven people were injured in a shooting at a Swiss factory on Wednesday, the police said, adding that the gunman was among the dead.
lead_paragraph: At least three people were killed and seven people were injured in a shooting at a Swiss factory on Wednesday, the police said, adding that the gunman was among the dead. The shooting occurred at a wood-processing factory in Menznau, about 14 miles west of Lucerne, the police said. A police spokesman said that the gunman was a 42-year-old employee of the factory and that he had not been shot by the police. Although shootings involving multiple casualties are uncommon in Switzerland, the shooting was the second such episode in two months, and it could revive debate on gun control in Switzerland. An estimated two million to three million guns are in circulation among a population of eight million people.

headline: Council Votes to Add Curbs on Aiding Deportations
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to sign two bills passed by the City Council that expand restrictions on New York’s cooperation in federal efforts to deport immigrants.
lead_paragraph: The City Council overwhelmingly passed two bills on Wednesday that would further restrict New York’s cooperation with federal authorities seeking to deport immigrants.

abstract: North Korea’s representative to the United Nations in Geneva made vitriolic statements at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, capping a week of fiery rhetoric.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Brushing off widespread condemnation of its nuclear test earlier month, North Korea rebuked the United States on Wednesday for destabilizing the Korean Peninsula and fueling an “explosive situation” by its persistent hostility toward Pyongyang.

lead_paragraph: In the past month, the N.C.A.A. and its president, Mark Emmert, have been sued, criticized and ridiculed — and more than usual. They were embarrassed by admitted mistakes in a high-profile investigation. Their critics, growing louder and in number, included a governor, state senators, lawyers, academics and university presidents.

headline: Vulnerability of the Vote
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'States (US)', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The fundamental question is whether states that have a history of voter suppression should forever have to live with the legacy of that past.
lead_paragraph: An odd scene unfolded in Washington on Wednesday: as the president and leaders of Congress were dedicating a statue to Rosa Parks, the lifelong activist whose defiance on a Montgomery, Alabama, bus helped spark the Civil Rights Movement, across the street the Supreme Court heard oral arguments on one of the signature piece of civil rights legislation, the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Critics Say City Should Pay the Wrongly Convicted

lead_paragraph: A lawsuit filed against New York City by the five men who were convicted, and later exonerated, in the racially charged 1989 Central Park jogger rape case is a decade old, and the city’s reluctance to settle the case has attracted widespread criticism, even from other city officials.

headline: Advocates Concerned by Shipment of Horse Meat Through U.S. Ports

lead_paragraph: As concerns over horse meat infiltrating products labeled ground beef grows among American consumers, an advocacy group released shipping documents showing that horse meat does pass through at least one United States port on its way from slaughterhouses in Mexico to destinations in Europe.

headline: Dog’s Death After Westminster Leaves Handler Suspicious

lead_paragraph: Cruz was a fluffy marshmallow of a dog, a prizewinning Samoyed who flew commercial, not in the cargo hold; scarcely touched the sidewalk; and competed at this month’s Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: U.S. Offers Training and Other Aid to Syrian Rebels

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court considered on Wednesday whether to expand on its recent rulings allowing companies to avoid class-action lawsuits by insisting that customers resolve complaints through arbitration.

keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The court said that a class-action lawsuit against Amgen could stand, and it imposed a strict time limit on some suits filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of securities fraud decisions issued Wednesday, the Supreme Court ruled for investors seeking to band together in a class-action lawsuit and imposed a strict time limit on some suits filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: New Attention to First Lady as She Presses Ahead With Healthy Eating Drive
keywords: ['Obesity', 'First Ladies (US)', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs']
abstract: Michelle Obama draws criticism and praise not only for her advocacy for nutrition but also for TV push-ups, the “mom dance” and the Oscars.
lead_paragraph: CLINTON, Miss. — To her admirers, Michelle Obama is the patron saint of quinoa, charged with reducing the nation’s dangerous obesity rate and helping children eat better. To her detractors, she is the fun-killer, possessed with crushing America’s cookies.

headline: Ethiopia Tries to Capitalize on Its Running Fame
abstract: Organizers hope a marathon event set for October will attract top international runners to Ethiopia for competition, not just training.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — On a warm Sunday morning in late November, about 36,000 people set off on the Great Ethiopian Run, a 10-kilometer race across the center of Addis Ababa. Diplomats, students, merchants, Orthodox priests, homeless children and professional runners were among the participants. It is one of Africa’s largest road races, hosted in the capital of a passionate running nation that has dominated long-distance competitions for the past two decades.

headline: Chief of F-35 Jet Program Rebukes Main Contractors
abstract: The comments, by Lt. Gen. Christopher Bogdan, echoed his critique last September, suggesting a poor relationship between Lockheed and the government.
lead_paragraph: The general in charge of building the new F-35 fighter jet sharply criticized the main contractors on Wednesday, saying that Lockheed Martin and the engine maker, Pratt & Whitney, were trying to “squeeze every nickel” out of the program.

headline: Still Big but No Longer East, League May Sell Its Name

headline: As Castro Era Drifts to Close, a New Face Steps In at No. 2
abstract: Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez, the top contender to succeed the Castros, will need to display authority while acting as if he does not want the presidency.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — He may have just taken on the toughest job in Cuba. Rivals at home will try to take him down. Enemies abroad will discredit him. Almost anyone with an interest in Cuba — including American spies and Cuban intelligence officers — will dig through his public and private lives, rummaging for secrets or clues about his plans.

headline: It’s the Sugar, Folks
abstract: A new study shows solid links between added sugar and the onset of diabetes.
lead_paragraph: Sugar is indeed toxic. It may not be the only problem with the Standard American Diet, but it’s fast becoming clear that it’s the major one.

headline: Stéphane Hessel, Author and Activist, Dies at 95
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A hero of the French Resistance, Mr. Hessel marshaled the same defiant spirit more than 60 years later in a manifesto that inspired social protesters in Europe and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Stéphane Hessel, a hero of the French Resistance who, more than 60 years later as a nonagenarian, marshaled the same defiant spirit in a manifesto that inspired social protesters in Europe and the United States and became an international publishing phenomenon, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 95.

headline: Parties Focus on the Positive as Budget Cuts Draw Near
