lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Stress-Free Service Ranks High
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A recent survey finds that although cost is No. 1 in importance among the respondents, it is followed by trust and customer service.
lead_paragraph: Ease and convenience matter as much as cost to some people shopping for mortgages in the wake of the foreclosure crisis.

headline: Dish Network Takes to Twitter in Battle With Broadcasters Over Ad-Skipping DVR
abstract: Dish accused CBS of pressuring one of its stars, Kaley Cuoco of “The Big Bang Theory,” to take down a Twitter message that praised Dish’s device, called the Hopper.
lead_paragraph: The Dish Network’s battle with broadcasters over a tricked-out digital video recorder called the Hopper has come to Twitter.

headline: Inner Child Comes Out to Rage
abstract: The main characters in “Molly’s Theory of Relativity” — a father, his son and his daughter-in-law — are volatile, complicated people in touch with their inner children.
lead_paragraph: “Molly’s Theory of Relativity” is an intentionally uncomfortable movie to watch. The fifth feature from Jeff Lipsky, this eccentric, often high-pitched family comedy might be described as a surreal, post-Freudian gabfest. The main characters — a father, his son and his daughter-in-law — are volatile, complicated people alarmingly in touch with the part of the human psyche that therapists call the inner child.

headline: The Colors and Joys of the Quotidian
abstract: A retrospective at the Portland Museum of Art showcases Lois Dodd, who has reveled for decades in making images of her immediate surroundings.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — Lois Dodd paints with an insistent, sometimes daring economy. She has spent some 60 years making images of her immediate surroundings, and each painting seems to go emphatically as far as she thinks it should and no further. No frills attached.

headline: Trevor Paglen: ‘The Last Pictures’
abstract: Trevor Paglen, at Metro Pictures, shows what went into his photographic project that was recently launched into space on a communications satellite.
lead_paragraph: Metro Pictures

headline: Yishai Jusidman: ‘Prussian Blue — Memory After Representation’
abstract: Yishai Jusidman’s show at Americas Society, which features paintings of Nazi gas chambers, is more editorial than art.
lead_paragraph: Americas Society

headline: Lucy Dodd: ‘The Studio Before 54’
abstract: In Lucy Dodd’s show at No5A, “The Studio Before 54,” enormous canvases colored with dog urine and rust create infinite space.
lead_paragraph: No5A

headline: Miroslaw Balka: ‘The Order of Things’
abstract: Miroslaw Balka’s sculpture at Gladstone resembles a giant industrial device and makes an allusion to Michel Foucault.
lead_paragraph: Gladstone

headline: Cut. Print It. That’s a Wrap.
abstract: The Carpetbagger signs off for the season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – It’s been a record-breaking Oscar season; have we parsed it all?

headline: Walt Kuhn: ‘American Modern’
abstract: DC Moore takes a look at Walt Kuhn, a painter who helped organize the 1913 Armory Show, which helped many careers take off — though not his own.
lead_paragraph: DC Moore

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, South Korea, North Korea and Vatican City.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, South Korea, North Korea and Vatican City.

headline: Orchestra to Disclose Its Nazi Past
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Classical Music', 'Music', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: Historians will soon release a report on the Vienna Philharmonic’s links to Nazi activity in the 1930s and ’40s.
lead_paragraph: THE Vienna Philharmonic, which is often berated for its slowness to act, has reacted quickly to charges that it shields access to its archives to conceal the darker aspects of its Nazi past.

headline: Out of the Debris, a Stone Goddess
abstract: Scholars are analyzing a three-foot-tall stone carving of an armless nude that surfaced during archaeological digs last summer below a Brooklyn overpass.
lead_paragraph: A stone goddess slumbered unseen for decades below a Brooklyn overpass. Last summer, it surfaced during archaeological digs, and now scholars are puzzling over it.

headline: Before There Was a ‘Grand’ in Central
keywords: ['Railroads', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Grand Central Terminal (NYC)']
abstract: Grand Central Terminal is a descendant of an earlier, much smaller station.
lead_paragraph: Everybody’s wishing Grand Central Terminal a happy 100th birthday. But nobody ever wears a party hat for its predecessor, a cute little Gothic depot created at least 150 years ago.

headline: Matthew Barney Heads to the Morgan Library
abstract: A coming exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum focuses on drawings by Matthew Barney; public art exhibitions resume at Rockefeller Center with a series of figures by Ugo Rondinone.
lead_paragraph: Try as it might, the Morgan Library & Museum has never been a magnet for the art world’s young and trendy set. That may change, at least temporarily, when its big show “Subliming Vessel: The Drawings of Matthew Barney” opens on May 10. Mr. Barney, an artist with a cultlike following, produces films and videos, most of which he performs in. He also makes sculptures and objects, as well as photographs, books and installations derived from the films. He fashions his sculptures out of unusual materials like tapioca (dumbbells) and petroleum jelly (a weight bench). His drawings are the least known of his works. But to a place like the Morgan they are also the most intriguing.

headline: Facebook Buys Service to Show Targeted Ads Across the Web
abstract: Facebook buys an advertising technology that could allow it to better use its personal data to sell ads.
lead_paragraph: Facebook fired another salvo at its archrival Google on Thursday with its acquisition of an advertising technology that can help Facebook put its piles of personal data to greater use for behaviorally targeted advertising.

headline: No Escaping the Shadow of a Legend
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company sandwiches four works by contemporary choreographers between two classics by its founder and reason for being.
lead_paragraph: In the third of its three programs at the Joyce Theater, the Martha Graham Dance Company sandwiches four works by contemporary choreographers between two classics by its founder and reason for being. The combination proves that the current Graham dancers can tend their heritage while performing equally well in pieces that might suit almost any other repertory troupe. It’s an ambiguous achievement.

headline: Gene Sperling Doesn’t Respect Me
abstract: Hey dude, where’s my threatening email?
lead_paragraph: So, after reading the Bob Woodward saga of the alleged “threat” from Gene Sperling, the White House supereconwonk, I went through my own correspondence with Gene, and couldn’t find anything threatening — although I guess you could read his injunction, at one point, to “take care” in an ominous tone of voice.

headline: Magazine Cover Draws Claims of Racism
abstract: A Bloomberg Businessweek magazine cover published this week about the housing rebound in the United States — featuring cartoonish minorities holding fistfuls of money — has drawn intense criticism from readers and critics of the news media.
lead_paragraph: A Bloomberg Businessweek magazine cover published Feb. 25 about the housing rebound in the United States — featuring cartoonish minorities holding fistfuls of money — has drawn intense criticism from readers and media critics, some of whom have described the cover as racist.

headline: Sotheby’s Raises Commissions, Following Lead of Christie’s
abstract: Over the last few years both auction houses have begun giving some of its biggest sellers a percentage of the buyer’s premium as an incentive to get their business, a practice which has cut into their profits.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after Christie’s announced that it was increasing the fees it charges buyers, Sotheby’s followed suit. On Thursday afternoon, when the auction house reported its 2012 financial results, it announced that it would increase what is known as its buyer’s premium – or the fees it charges buyers — for the first time since 2008.

headline: Brazil: The Big Pictures
abstract: Massimo Vitali’s photographs in our Voyages issue.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly a decade ago that the photographer Massimo Vitali first heard about a “fake lake” in Brazil. “Since nine years ago, I had this thing in my mind, the Piscinão de Ramos,” he says. The pools, which are composed of filtered seawater, were built for favela dwellers in Rio de Janeiro who lack access to the city’s well-heeled beaches like Ipanema and Copacabana.

headline: A Mighty Beanstalk Grows a New Twist
abstract: “Jack the Giant Slayer” sticks with the familiar bedtime story, embellishing it with 3-D and other effects, noisy battles and an occasional wink at the material.
lead_paragraph: Recently filmmakers have been dusting off fairy tales and giving them a revisionist feminist spin. As movies like “Red Riding Hood” and “Mirror Mirror” suggest, striking a balance between the old (and often sexist) and the new (and vaguely progressive) is trickier than it might seem. The makers of “Snow White and the Huntsman” tried to reconcile two potentially irreconcilable ideas — a thoroughly modern miss and an old-fashioned happily ever after — by putting a sword in Snow White’s hands so she could ride alongside her heroic hunk. The results weren’t half bad, even if this butched-up Snow White didn’t magically transform into a genuinely liberated princess.

headline: Or Would You Rather Be a Fish?
abstract: Lucien Castaing-Taylor and Véréna Paravel’s “Leviathan,” set on a groundfish trawler out of New Bedford, Mass., emphasizes the brutality of fishing.
lead_paragraph: To describe “Leviathan” as a documentary about fishing is both accurate and deceptive. The misleading word would be “about.” The film, by Lucien Castaing-Taylor and Véréna Paravel, is a work of nonfiction set entirely on a groundfish trawler out of New Bedford, Mass., but it avoids the standard equipment of interviews, analysis and explanation. If you want to understand the ecological consequences and economic challenges of the modern commercial fishing industry, or to learn about the place of the ocean in the global food chain, you will have to go elsewhere.

headline: San Francisco Symphony Oboist Who Collapsed Onstage Dies
abstract: William Bennett, the principal oboist of the San Francisco Symphony, died on Thursday, the orchestra announced.
lead_paragraph: William Bennett, the principal oboist of the San Francisco Symphony, who suffered a brain hemorrhage and collapsed in midperformance on Saturday night, died on Thursday the orchestra announced. He was 56. “I am heartbroken by the tragic death of Bill Bennett, which has left a terrible, sad emptiness in the hearts of the whole San Francisco Symphony family,” Michael Tilson Thomas, the orchestra’s music director, said. “Bill was a great artist, an original thinker and a wonderful man.”

headline: Atrocities, Through a Child’s Eyes
abstract: “War Witch” tells the story of orphaned African children who have been conscripted into a rebel army after their village has been attacked and their parents slain.
lead_paragraph: “Respect your guns. They are your mother and your father.” In “War Witch,” those orders are barked at orphaned African children who have been kidnapped and conscripted into a rebel army after their village has been decimated and their parents slain.

headline: Easing U.S., Slowly, Out of Home Financing
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The government now backs about 90 percent of new home mortgages. A new report outlines a plan for getting the private sector more involved.
lead_paragraph: Can the American mortgage market ever function again without Uncle Sam guaranteeing that lenders will be repaid?

headline: Remembering the Long, Strange Trip of Groupon’s Now-Fired Chief
abstract: From “Monkey for a Week” to “Battletoads” — yes, we can only be talking about Andrew Mason. DealBook takes a look back at the life and times of one of corporate America’s most unusual top executives.
lead_paragraph: With Andrew Mason’s forced resignation from Groupon on Thursday, the career of one of the most unusual corporate chieftains has ended.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Carven
abstract: The makeup artist Nina Haverkamp explained the concept behind the lipstick she applied on models for the show.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Carven, the makeup artist Nina Haverkamp explained the concept behind the lipstick she applied on the models: “This girl applied it yesterday evening — and was out kissing all night. This is the leftover.” Clinique’s Caribbean Coral lipstick was the only “incriminating” trace of frisky business. Barring a little Laura Mercier foundation brushed on in Secret Camouflage, all other features were left nude. Even undereye circles remained relatively unmasked. The hairstylist Romina Manenti’s teased-out tresses added to the story line.

headline: A Streak of Brooklyn in Beijing
abstract: In a cluster of traditional alleys in the Chinese capital, old-timers have been joined by a new breed of residents clad in skinny jeans and riding fixed-gear bikes.
lead_paragraph: Many of Beijing’s ancient hutongs — alleys formed by the outer wall of courtyard homes — have been erased from the cityscape to make way for new roads and high rises in recent years, much to preservationists’ dismay. The hutongs that have been spared are celebrated as retaining the charm of residential life, with alleys filled with vegetable stalls, kebab stands and tiny shops, and the hidden courtyards occupied by families who have called them home for generations.

headline: DiPietro Discusses Depression During Struggles With Islanders
abstract: Goaltender Rick DiPietro, waived last week by the Islanders, said in a television interview that he had battled depression over his inability to live up to expectations.
lead_paragraph: Goaltender Rick DiPietro, waived last week by the Islanders and sent to the American Hockey League, said in a television interview Thursday that he had battled depression and even had suicidal thoughts over his inability to live up to the 15-year $67.5 million contract he signed in 2006.

headline: From Mill to Mall in Mumbai
abstract: Once the site of a textile mill, the High Street Phoenix mall now attracts the city’s rich and famous.
lead_paragraph: Once the site of a textile mill, the High Street Phoenix mall now attracts the city’s rich and famous.

headline: Darkness Descends on a Family
abstract: The territory staked out in “Stoker” — a landscape of family secrets, sexual subtext and aristocratic entitlement — is at times reminiscent of a Henry James tale.
lead_paragraph: The first half of “Stoker” passes in a rapture of dread, as the viewer anticipates terrible things to come. This is partly because the director, Park Chan-wook, here making his English-language debut, is an internationally renowned master of bloodshed. His “vengeance” trilogy — in particular the middle chapter, “Oldboy,” currently being remade by Spike Lee — is cherished by many cinephiles, in South Korea and beyond, for its blend of visual elegance, melodrama and extreme violence.

headline: Paulson Opposes MetroPCS Merger With T-Mobile
abstract: The investment firm Paulson & Company, the largest shareholder in MetroPCS Communications, said the deal would saddle the new company with too much debt.
lead_paragraph: 7:59 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Harlem Shake’ Protests in Tunisia and Egypt
abstract: The rapid evolution of the “Harlem Shake,” from a dance to a song to a viral video craze to a new form of Middle East protest, continued apace on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The rapid evolution of the “Harlem Shake,” from a dance to a song to a viral video craze to a new form of Middle East protest, continued apace on Thursday. Hundreds of protesters danced outside the headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood in Cairo, and students and ultraconservative Islamists known as Salafists clashed in Sidi Bouzid, the Tunisian town where the wave of uprisings in the Arab world began with a very different gesture of defiance.

headline: A Just-So Apartment in a Just-So Building
abstract: Alex Disbrow wanted to live in a certain building on Pelham Parkway North.
lead_paragraph: Alex Disbrow always loved Art Deco.

headline: Table Talk | Ma Cave Fleury
abstract: The Parisian store and bar celebrates biodynamic wine making and is beloved by a bohemian coterie of actors and musicians who revel in its unpretentious joie de vivre.
lead_paragraph: It has been four years since the ex-stage comedian Morgane Fleury opened her “cave-écologique” on Paris’ seedy Rue Saint-Denis to showcase the biodynamic bubbles that bear her family name. In the intervening years, the wonderfully chaotic Ma Cave Fleury has become a tightly held secret for a bohemian coterie of Parisian actors and musicians who revel in its unpretentious joie de vivre and affordable bottles (costing as little as €25). Its unassuming appearance and unlikely location amid X-rated stores in a gentrifying area belies the fact that it is the cellar door of the small respected Champagne house Fleury Père Et Fils.

headline: Living Small Is the Best Revenge
abstract: The architects Mimi Hoang and Eric Bunge won a design contest for micro apartments.
lead_paragraph: Despite less-than-rhapsodic memories of miniaturized apartment living, the married architects Mimi Hoang and Eric Bunge designed the winner of the adAPT micro-unit competition sponsored by the New York City Housing and Preservation Department and endorsed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: A Dreamy Drift From Teenage Idylls to Adult Complexities
abstract: In Tim Sutton’s dreamy “Pavilion” a teenage boy leaves his mother’s upstate New York home to live with his father in Arizona, where youth starts to feel even more ephemeral than summer.
lead_paragraph: Washed in soft color and tremulous mood, the modest, lovely American independent movie “Pavilion” opens with a group of teenagers setting off fireworks at dusk. They’re boys, mostly, dressed in oversize shirts and baseball caps and standing a few feet from one another, as young men tend to do in groups. It’s a spatial arrangement that announces their independence even as everything else — clothes, gestures and camera movements — unites them. Given the sizzle and fiery sparks, the bright green smudged across the image and the thick summery feeling enveloping it all, this could be the Fourth of July, or just another day in that paradise, soon lost, called youth.

headline: Justice Department’s Amicus Brief in Gay Marriage Case
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The White House is filing a legal brief to the Supreme Court, urging the justices to overturn California’s ban on gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: The White House is filing a legal brief to the Supreme Court, urging the justices to overturn California’s ban on gay marriage.

headline: W.H.O. Sees Low Health Risks From Fukushima Accident
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Radiation']
abstract: The World Health Organization, cautioning that its report is based on early information, says that continued monitoring is necessary.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A study published on Thursday by the World Health Organization on the health risks associated with the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant suggested that the risk for certain types of cancers had increased slightly among children exposed to the highest doses of radioactivity, but that there would most likely be no observable increase in cancer rates in the wider Japanese population.
